reviews.review: Breathtaking. Galleria Borghese is one of the best museums in Rome and a must see for art lovers. Do not forget to reserve in advance or you may not be allowed entrance.

plenty to be see and be awed with the art works. Not a big museum, but with strict limited capacity the place doesn't feel crowded. There are so much to see in 2 hr limit. Definitely buy the tickets ahead of time.

An absolute must-see. This is by far one my most favorite museums in the world. Right up there with the Rodin sculpture gardens and museum in Paris. The inside is spectacular in and of itself as it was once home to the Borghese family. The sculptures by Rafael Bernini are what set this museum apart from others. Such unbelievable artistry. Be sure to see the sculture of Daphne and Apollo. We were staying near the Piazza di Popolo so it was an easy walk through the Borghese Gardens to get there. The gardens are quite beautiful and a wonderful respite from the frenetic energy of Rome.

Highlight of Our Trip. You must go to the Borghese Gallery! If you only have time for one art gallery while in Rome, make it this one. They have one of the finest private art collections in the world. Before entering, check out the gardens and park. Time is rigidly restricted to 90 minutes per reservation. Yes, reservations are required and can be make on line. The process keeps the crowds down allowing more enjoyment of the exhibits. Hint: you can reserve telephonically and receive special consideration if you have purchased the "Rome pass".

Outstanding. Take the tour. The Galleria Borghese is outstanding, fascinating, and well worth the effort to make reservations in advance. Visits are limited to two hours. Audio Guides are available and are probably pretty essential. But better yet are the museum sponsored guides available in English at fixed times in the morning. Having a tour guide enhances the visit immeasurably, and is surprisingly inexpensive. Be sure to include this feature when making your reservation. Felix, our tour guide was an art expert yet very down to earth and accessible. Without a guide (or perhaps the audio guide) I can't imagine how one would get a sense of the entire museum.

Make advance reservations . It was a good thing we had made advance reservations before our trip, because when we arrived there was a sign saying there were no tickets available for the next 11 days. I can't imagine our trip to Rome without our visit to the Borghese Gallery. The audio rentals are worth the money, but get in line no later than 20-15 minutes before your reserved Gallery time. They do not start renting them until 10 minutes before but the line gets very long quickly. You only have two hours to look at everything but we were able to enjoy it all by going to the least crowded rooms first. Make sure to tell the taxi driver that you are going to the Gallery and not the Villa because they are on opposite sides of the park/gardens. Also, with so many tourist, if you stop by the cafe it can get confusing. Pay for your items first then get in the next line where all items will be retrieved for you.

Mind Boggling Art, Magnificent Setting . Quite simply said, one gets a two-fer here, the art of the pictures and sculptures then the art of the fabulous villa and gardens. From one gigantic room filled with some of the greatest art created by the greatest artists to the next one very nearly goes culture blind from overload. One recent visit I photographed only the art on ceilings in the glorious rooms and quickly had an album of sublime photos. The collector was a patron of Bernini and some of him greatest works are here. A room of Caravaggio's! There is more eye candy here than one can manage in one visit. You must make a timed reservation, and exchange for an admittance upon arrival. No admittance without a reserved ticket and the ticket is limited to a 2 hour visit. It was jam packed every day I visited. Rather unfortunate that large groups with guides pack the rooms and all the guides are talking at the same time. Very disconcerting.

The best place to view priceless art in Rome without the awful crowds!. We visited the Borghese Gallery 4 years ago and recently had the opportunity to take our friends with us on a return visit.We toured Borghese in the morning and the Vatican in afternoon. The wonderful thing about Borghese is the lack of a crowd. They only admit 200 at a time for 2 hours. Reservations are a must. Opt for the audio tour, it is extremely well done!The art is fantastic and a wonderful variety is in place which provides a nice overview without overwhelming the visitor.In contrast, our visit in the afternoon to the Vatican was disappointing. The crowds were horrific and the amount of art was simply overwhelming. The Sistine Chapel was literally elbow to elbow which prevented visitors from having the opportunity to absorb the magnificent works. It was truly sad that the crowds have grown to such a degree since our last visit 4 years ago. And our visit this time was off season for tourists. I can't imagine what it is like in the summer.Of course, visitors to Rome must do the Vatican and Sistine Chapel. It is simply a must. However, I would strongly urge visitors go to Borghese to take in magnificent art and focus the Vatican visit to St. Peter's and the Sistine Chapel.

Not to be missed wonderful gallery. BOOK IN ADVANCE!! We saw many people turned away. We went on a Saturday afternoon and the next available tickets were for the following Thursday. If you have booked online you get a reservation voucher by e-mail You need to exchange tis for your tickets well before your timed entry. You can choose a 2 hour slot which is just about enough time to see the treasures here. We had rucksacks with us and it was free and simple to store them in the cloakroom. The gallery is beautiful with so many things to see it would take ages to list them all, Caraveggio paintings, Bernini statues, amazing frescos on the walls, mosaics of the floor. It is glorious, and not too tiring - long enough to look without being overwhelmed. The gardens are beautiful too, with people on bicycle "vehicles" - parents pedalling and a row of little children sat up front laughing with excitement. Lovely area for families

Beautiful Gardens. We missed the gallery but thoroughly enjoyed walking around the gardens watching Roman families cycling, eating icecreams, picnicking and enjoying the sunshine. There is also a nice cafe where you can sip on an Aperol Spritz afterwards!

Stunning gallery with amazing pieces of art. Lovely gallery in the Villa Borghese gardens. The guided tour is well worth it. So many beautiful paintings and sculptures that you just can't see anywhere else. The ceilings are stunning.
Stunning collection. Must see whilst in Rome. Stunning collection of paintings and sculptures. Villa is in a lovely park and the walk through is nice.

Wonderful Gallery. We did another City Wonders tour of the Borghese Gallery. Our tour guide was Alexsandra. She knew her stuff and spoke very well. Beautifully displayed artwork and sculptures of many of the Italian artists, Bernini,Caravaggio and many more. You will be glad you took this tour because the beauty is magnificent. We unfortunately did not go on the tour of the gardens because of time constraints.

Absolute must-do in Rome!. To me the Borghese is the best museum in Rome, and maybe in Italy. While it obviously doesn't have the scale and scope of the Vatican museums or the Uffizi in Florence, it's just the right size for a good dose of beauty before you start to feel museum-ed out, and the collection of Bernini sculptures is truly spectacular. His pieces come to life in such an amazing way, and in this setting you can really see and feel them up close. The rest of the collection is also just extremely well curated, and the building itself is beautiful as well. Be sure to make a reservation in advance, especially if you're not there in the off season, because you don't want to miss this one!

Book your tickets ahead of time so that you won't miss out!. We booked tickets a week ahead of time, in October - and didn't get our first choice time slot. However, we did get a slot on the day we wanted, and we were grateful. It's not easy to get to the Borghese Gallery by Metro - it's about a 20 minute walk from the Barbarini Metro stop. Once at the Borghese, turn in your confirmation number for a ticket. You have to check ALL bags - including purses, no matter how small. You have to wear your jackets. Go figure. People began lining up for our 2 hour time slot about 10 minutes early. We spent a very enjoyable hour here with our two children (aged 10 and 12). They particularly enjoyed the statues, especially those related to Greek and Roman mythology (I prepped them before hand on what we'd be seeing). The paintings weren't as big a hit with the kids, but that's okay. Overall it was a very successful outing and gave the kids something to think about!

fantastic sculptures. This is a beautiful gallery and well worth a visit. Tickets have to be purchased in advance. Just don't book through Viator.com, who let us down less than 24hours before the trip. Fortunately we managed to book a replacement tour with "together in Rome" who were absolutely excellent.
Excellent Gallery. My wife and I did a tour to this wonderful gallery. It's a small but great collection which makes things a lot more manageable. The surrounding park is nice to walk through too.

Favorite museum I need Rome.. If you enjoy sculpture and beautiful architecture, this is one of those small finds. We did not have reservations, but went in an hour before closing to see when the next opening was. They let us go right in with our Roma Pass. Without the pass, I believe we would have been out of luck. The best is a reservation.The audio tour is excellent and very helpful. So pleased we had the chance to see this very special gallery.

A surprising sight!. Having toured much of Italy and its arts and antiquities, I was surprised at how much I was awed by the Borghese villa that houses an immense collection of important paintings and sculptures. Walking from room to room on three floors, I felt closer to the pieces than in a museum. I thanked my wife for her wisdom in planning this reservation.

Stunning inside and out. This beautiful palace is a work of art of itself. However, it holds some of the world's most amazing sculptures by Bernini and others. You usually need advance reservations to get in. It's worth it for art lovers. This trip I could not get there, but went in 2006 and 2003.

Breathtaking Berninis!. Our guide's passion for the artwork was contagious. We left so impressed with the Bernini sculptures, in part because of the way she had us view them. This is the first time we've done a group tour in a museum and I wasn't sure I'd like it. I figured we'd just go off on our own if we felt like a herd of cattle. That wasn't the case at all and we were so glad we had a guide. The extra cost was minimal and the personal touch made all the difference. Definitely order your tickets in advance. We neglected to do that before our previous visit to Rome and did not get in. It sells out quickly for good reason. It's a wonderful collection and a must see, especially the Bernini sculptures!

A Magnificent Treasure. This extremely well-run museum cum art gallery will not disappoint. Beautiful intricate sculptures, breathtaking paintings and other objects d'art are presented in luxurious settings. Take the guided tour to reap the full value.

Very pretty.. The villa, located in a big park in the heart of Rome, is very pretty and if you love sculptures, you'll love the art gallerie. The ceilling paintings are stunning and you can spend a lot of time looking at all the details.

Unmissable Rome highlight!. The Borghese Gallery has a priceless collection of art treasures from Titian, Carravagio and other Italian masters but the Bernini sculptures were simply breathtaking. If you appreciate art, this is simply unmissable. Make sure you book in advance, it sells out weeks in advance!

A must see. We did this tour on a very hot day in Rome. We did buy our tickets ahead of time from the museums website in order to skip the line and were very glad we did. The day we want it was sold out to the general public and did not have any openings for 5 more days. Well worth the time and effort to book ahead. They do have a lobby area and cafe open to the public, however this means that anyone can come in and sit down beside you. My husband witness a young lady with her mom take down a pickpockerter. They pinned him to the ground while they made sure he had not taken any of their belongings. No one helped these ladies or arrested this criminal once they let him go. The ladies were stunned and left the museum. So be ware.

Jaw droppingly beautiful. Don't worry about the skipping the line punters...just book your date and time and show up! You have a code that means your booking is secure...they limit the numbers of folk in the gallery so there is not really.much "line" to skip...better to buy a shot.of the excellent audioguide..then you can go at your own pace and spend ages looking if something grips you...or skip over if not your thing!They insist on you using their free cloaKroom to dump your.bag (you can take pictures). So good to walk around free and uncumbered!!Weirdly...went looking.forward to he paintings! Left with a new love for sculpture!! The audioguide is sooo good at explaining certain pieces (not everything is covered...othwrwise they'd never get you out in 2 hours!!).Each room is superbly opulent! Floor to ceiling masterpieces (literally). Beautiful mosaics...stunning ceiling decor. It's an overwhelming assault for the eyes at first. Staff are welcoming and friendly as they protect the art from the public.Go see...worth it for the weird inteplay between biblical stories (Jesus++, St Paul, St Peter etc), with the Greek/Roman mythology. Despite being a cardinal...think Mr Borgese was more into art than scripture etc. Worth it too for the sheer beauty.of many priceless pieces.
1000% MUST SEE. This must be a part of your trip.Marble sculpture pieces are amaizing. The park around is great for a fresh air walk at any season of the year.

HUGE regret!. I wanted to visit here so badly, but didn't do my homework. Because it's hugely popular, you have to book ahead for tickets. I did not, and couldn't get in as a result. Ahhhh. Next time!

One of the best museum in Rome. Here you can find the world best collection of Caravaggio (Michelangelo Merisi) paintings, Raffaelo and Tiziano, great sculptures as Paolina Bonaparte of Canova and Ratto di Proserpina and Apollo and Dafne of Gian Lorenzo Bernini.Keep in mind to book your visit, only few groups per hour!.Museum is situated in Villa Borghese, u can take 360 bus from Termini and S. Giovanni Underground Station line "A" (the red one).

Truly wonderful. As with many sites in Rome, the time to go is when the cruise-ship hordes have left, and mid-week after lunch is a good choice.We were fortunate in that the day we chose was a little overcast, and the circuitous walk to the gallery meant we didn't arrive hot and bothered; it was worth the long walk.Not too many people in the gallery which gave us plenty of time to view this truly stunning gallery at our leisure - no queues, very few handbag vendors and absolutely no selfie-stick salesmen; quite unique, in fact.After several hours in the gallery, we took the easy route (downhill, via the Spanish Steps, a truly wonderful cafe and deli, the Via del Corso and back to the hotel) a wash and brush up and off to eat, replete, happy and full of really good memories.

Worth the money and time to see this. Book tickets in advance.
Enjoy the art and the Borghese house. A terrific place to visit to escape crowds and heat of Rome.

Gorgeous. Galleria Borghese is stunning on its own. If you add the masterpieces inside it... The most eye-catching are the Berninis there. You will see :) Painted walls and ceilings, marble and gold, amazing feeling. Make sure you buy tickets ahead online (myticket.it). You will pay an extra 2 eur for the online service, but you don't really have an alternative (I mean there is an alternative, but that is to give your credit card details over the phone to a robot...). They let about 50 people get inside every two hours so that the villa doesn't get too crowded. This is why there is a limited number of tickets. If you book a 9'00 o'clock, for instance, you should get there a bit earlier. They say 30 minutes, but even less is enough. Even if you are late, if you still pick up our 9 o'clock entry ticket, you can get inside. The villa will take from 1 hour to 2 hours to visit. But once in, nobody will kick you out. Important: Though you buy your ticket online, you have to go the ticket office downstairs in the villa to get the actual ticket with your booking number. You won't pay anything extra, they just print your ticket. If you stay more than 5 days in Rome, you could go buy the tickets in person for the following week. Otherwise you need to buy it online.

Worth the effort. Plan ahead and get your tickets online. Spots fill up fast and we met people who just showed up who could not tour the day they were their. Enjoy classic Italian sculpture and painting in a setting that transports you back to Baroque Italy.

Lovely Gallery in an immense garden setting. We spent a couple of hours in the gallery looking at all of the Baroque sculpture. The Bernini pieces are amazing in how delicate they appear - I was impressed that something carved in stone could look so light and airy. All of the pieces are displayed to allow you close examination. The Gallery has a reservation system that allows only a limited number of visitors in a time, so you never feel crowded.

Don't miss it!. I saw this the day before the Vatican, and looking back, I would do it the other way. This is a very subjective view and I am not an expert in art, but the Borghese was magnificent, making me think that the Vatican art was fabulous, but not as impressive. There is no other way than to reserve tickets - often well in advance. This was a bit of a pain, as I like flexibility in planning during my trip. However, it was well worth the restriction. Nice walk through the park too.

Concise and to the point!. I have visited the gallery with 17 yr old twin boys who are not much into art; We concentrated on the central piece in each room and did some reading on it and the story behind it. The layout of having 1 central piece per room is quite useful and allows you to sample the cherry on top of the cream

Top site for art; get tickets in advance. The Borghese Gallery is a gem. The collection of six Caravaggios in one room alone is worth the effort of visiting. It is fascinating to compare the self-portraits in the head of Goliath (a magnificent work) and the so-called Sick Bacchus. The Madonna of Loreto has great psychological and spiritual depth, especially if you are (like me) skeptical of the Loreto miracle but moved by the faith of simple people whose faith is rewarded by glimpses of the holy.

A collection of treasures.. Galleria Borghese is simply one of the most spectacular collections of sculpture and ancient art I have ever seen.The wealth of Baroque here makes it, to my mind, one of the most important collections of its kind in the world. The fact everything is housed in such a beautiful building just adds to the wonder of it all.I won't bore with what is here but would recommend this to anyone.
Well worth a trip!. It is important to book online (before your trip is recommended!) as places are limited and the gallery is a must.

Beautiful Gallery. We had a lovely personal tour of the gallery and could have stayed a whole day hearing more stories about all the fantastic artwork inside. The grounds around the gallery are also lovely.

Absolutely essential to visit.. I could rhapsodise forever about this museum but just go. Bernini's sculptures must be seen not to mention the Caravaggios, the mosaics, Everything. book in advance and read the requirements on the web site.

Art and architecture. Beautiful paintings and art work in the renown villa - worth having a guide to discuss the particular details. You should book tickets ahead - it is also really worth it for the city view and the marvelous landscape.

Excellent. We booked a tour online for the Gallery. We enjoyed every minute of this beautiful Gallery. We learned so much for our tour guide as he did a great job explaining the details behind all of the art. Booked online before you go to Rome. This Gallery only allows appx. 200 guests every two hours.

Absolute stunning sculptures, must see . This is an absolute must for a visit to Rome. Skip the cathedral and Vatican Museum if you must, do not miss the Borghese Gallery. There are sculptures here that will take your breath away and imprint forever.

Very high demand - plan in advance. It's not a very large museum and they only sell a limited number of tickets each day (and for each time period) so it's best to buy your tickets well in advance. Your ticket allows you to visit the museum during the 2-hour period you've purchased and then they usher you out. Even before you arrive it can be confusing as the entrance is not clearly marked (enter through the bookshop). We wanted to purchase the normal tickets but the only tickets available for that morning were for the guided tour in Italian so we had to pay 19.50€ each plus the 2€ "hidden" pre-sale fee so 21.50€ total. A long line of people (in a crowded hall) queuing for coat check made it a bit more confusing but eventually we discovered that we needed to show proof of our online ticket purchase to get our tickets. Then we had to go to another line to get the audiobox and earphone for the guided tour. The unenthusiastic tour guide explained to another young man that the tour was only in Italian and if he wanted another language that was his problem. When we got to the point where a woman ripped the ticket (to validate it) she explained that no bags were allowed - so we had to go back to the coat check. Fortunately by that time there was almost line. We went back to the line and rejoined our tour. By that time the tour guide was already explaining the third room; she didn't wait for us. It was a bit hard to hear with the earpiece and so many people so we decided to ditch the tour and explore the museum on our own. There were sheets of laminated paper explaining most of the rooms (in Italian and English) so I don't think we missed too much.While they could do a better job organizing the whole process, the museum is a real gem. Take time to explore the lovely grounds outside as the palace is set in a beautiful park.

Wonderful Museum. My husband and I came here in early September when we were visiting Rome. It is a beautiful Museum with so much to see! We went on a guided tour (highly recommended, or at least get the audio box so you can walk around independently) and our guide was very knowledgeable. This was our second time visiting the Museum, the first time 13 years ago, but we liked it so much we wanted to go back this year. I would recommend buying tickets ahead of time, maybe a couple weeks in advance, because they seem to sell out daily. I think it is nearly impossible to walk up and buy same day tickets. Also, I think you only get to be able to go for about 90 minutes at a time, you can't spend all day there. But there is so much to see while there, you just can't see it all in one visit! It is one of the highlights of visiting Rome, in my opinion.

A MUST SEE museum in Rome. This was the highlight of our tour of Rome and a MUST SEE visit for everyone. It is extremely well organised and run and you must pre book to gain entry. This limits numbers to a manageable degree and allows sufficient time to appreciate the wonderful interior. If possible take a guided tour (pre book as only 30 permitted at a time). Our guide was superb and helped bring the sculptures and paintings alive. The 4 Bernini sculptures are breathtaking and works of pure genius. You could look at them all day. Don't miss this!

Borghese is a must see . This is a great collection of works and worth experiencing. It is in a wonderful setting and the works are extraordinary. To top it off, the park surrounding the Museum is a great place to hang out and experience a "slice" of Roman life.

Smaller museum, Great Art. If you have been overwhelmed by the endless corridors at the Vatican give the Borghese a try. Very reasonably sized but every piece is worth your time. So many masterworks in one place and the surrounding grounds are a great place to have a quick pick-nick before or after your visit. Plenty on food carts and strolling musicians make a great place for an afternoon in the city that feels a million miles away.

Great collection of art work . Did the 9 am English guided tour .. absolutely fantastic collection of sculptures by Bernini especially, paintings of cartavaggio, and one of titian, Raphael amongst many others, Roman sculptures frescoes mosaics .. the guide was friendly and very informative and covered explaining so many works and helped me understand and appreciate some more art.. a must visit but advance booking telephonically is a must

My favorite gallery in Italy. Bernini. Caravaggio. Titian. Rubens. And I mentioned Bernini, right? The sculptures and paintings I had admired as images on screens for years finally came to life at the Borghese Gallery. What a glorious place to experience the great artists.
Buy your ticket in advance online for a small additional fee. It's worth it.

What a great little gem!. The Borghese Villa feels like a mini Versailles... gorgeous decoration on every surface, fantastic works of art (especially Bernini's sculptures). We did their group tour (you can sign up when you buy tickets online) and it was fantastic. BE SURE you prebook at least a week in advance, as they only allow 360 visitors per day and they are usually booked out several days in advance.

The best museum in Rome. To me, this is the best museum in Rome. Both collections, sculptures on the first floor and paintings on the second floor, are superb. The rooms are great by themselves. They sell a limited number of tickets for every two-hour interval, so it is not overcrowded. We bough our tickets in advance. When we came on a Sunday in mid September to pick them up, they were sold out through Thursday.

Excellent Borghese Gallery Tpur. With Claudia, a passionate guide who brought the museum to life! The gallery is well worth the visit, with walls and ceilings completely covered with beauty beyond compare.

Carravaggio and Bernini treasures at the Borghese Gallery. The tour is two hours which came with excellent commentary and background information from our guide Anna. Her explanations of the Carravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures made viewing these treasures such a wonderful experience.

Beautiful art, beautifully presented!. One of the attractions here is that the gallery is crowd controlled. About 300 visitors are let in at a time. I recommend reservations at least a week in advance. Your reservation is for a date and a specific time of day. You are allowed 2 hours and the ushered out to the cafe or bookshop or gardens.The galleries are spacious and lend themselves especially well to appreciation of the large sculptures. The cardinal who collected most of this art had a good eye! There are wonderful sculptural examples of Roman art and mosaics as well as sculpture by Bernini. Many painting masterpieces are here also by Caravaggio, Rubens, and many other Italian masters. The whole is set in beautiful gardens! Do not miss it!!

A half day in the gardens. Pre-purchase your gallery tickets (no need for a tour) and enjoy the beauty of the building and its artwork. Afterwards, stroll the gardens and descend down the Spanish Steps to return to the bustle of Rome.

My favorite museum in Rome. The art in this museum is breathtaking. The sculptures divine.The size of the museum is perfect, it is not overwhelming and the two hour limit inside is enough time to see and enjoy all its masterpieces. The audio guide is most helpful and very well done. Reservations are a must and should be made well in advance.

Don't miss this in Rome. The Borghese Gallery was one of the best venues for anyone who appreciates art. We decided on a small group guided tour. Our tour guide Tiberius was the best tour guide for this gallery. Passionate about art and clearly an expert in every aspect of the Borghese, he made this tour exceptional. Without his guidance, I would have missed most of the history and a full appreciation of what was there. The gallery has magnificent works of art. The displays are open and you can get closer than most museum allow. HINT* We were delayed waiting for a missing group member and instructed to start the tour on the second floor. All the other groups were jammed in on the first floor and we had second floor to ourselves. We completed the second floor and then had an almost empty first floor there too. If you can, start upstairs then head down!
Nice Collection of Art, Huge Garden. Enjoyed visiting the gallery with great works of art, huge garden. Good that they have limits on the time and number of people to get in.

An Outstanding Surprise. We went to the Borghese Gallery as a "this might be good" side trip. We made reservations weeks ahead of time which you must do. We were so amazed by the beauty of the art in the Borghese - paintings and such wonderful statues. Highly recommend this outstanding gallery
Historical place with garden. we stay there for 5 hours , visit the palace and then a long walk at surrounding area. nice place to relax but this area is little far away if you wanna to go by foot

Stunning sculptures by Bernini; not to be missed!. The Gallery is in the North end of a HUGE park. Unfortunately our reservations were for 9am and we did not have enough time to explore the park. City buses drop you off near the entrance. The gallery allows 200 people in for a 2 hour visit. There are frequent announcements that you must not linger too long in one room because you only have a limited time there. The day we visited, there were many small tour groups and some of the more popular exhibits were quite crowded. But we just moved on and returned 10 minutes later. In all, it was one of the most pleasurable experiences we had in Rome because the crowds were controlled. Other sites, which I had loved in the past, were so overrun with tourists, and not possible to appreciate or enjoy.

Well Run. It's great the way they make you get a reservation. Unlike many tourist sites in Rome you can take a little time and not be too overwhelmed by other tourists and enjoy the great art. Loved some of the sculptures on the first floor.

Well worth the visit. You need to pre-book, and getting in can be a bit tortuous. You get two hours to see it all, which is enough. We did the guided tour, which was very good in explaining the important stuff while still allowing time to see the rest afterwards. Great art in a great setting.Be sure to walk around the gardens as well.

book ahead. a walk through the park here is lovely and well worth it. but if you want to go in make sure you book ahead. we arrived, went upstairs to the main entrance only to have a lady grumpily point downstairs where apparently you buy the tickets (no signs anywhere). It was a Thursday and it was sold out until the following Tuesday!
I enjoyed this sightseeing. Its location is adorable..The park with the trees and that silence...You should book an appointment before you go there but don't lose it!!

Beautiful Museum!. To visit the Borghese Gallery you must pre-book your tickets. Easiest to do online. You can choose a time and are given a 2 hour slot. We chose the first interval, 9am to 11am. Overall we ended up spending one and a half hours there. There is more to see on the first floor, therefore we spent half an hour enjoying the Picture gallery on the second floor and then an hour on the first floor enjoying all the sculptures and paintings. If you do your research beforehand you don't need an audio guide. The gallery is attractive and well organised. Don't miss Bernini's sculpture 'Rape of Persephone'. There are also works by Caravaggio and Raphael among many others. You must also check all bags. Gift shop available too.The gardens and park are also a very attractive area. We walked back through the park and it was so relaxing.

Top notch Gallery. The paintings and the sculptures were of the masters. One could have spent much longer that the two hours allowed. I would recommend having a guide. Trying to figure out the best way to see even the most important works was very hard.

Lifestyles of the Rich & Famous. Get a peek at the opulent lifestyle experienced by the Borghese family! Stunning interiors, with beautiful terrazzo floors and finishes. An amazing collection of paintings and sculptures. A tiny elevator can spare you a strenuous climb to the upper level.May be hard to find - signage is poor from the subway stop for the Villa Borghese. We had to hunt for the museum, and met others on the same quest. There are some who may not feel the effort worth it. You must reserve a space in advance - available online.

Missed it last time. ...but made up this time. I knew now I had to make the online booking a lot of time in advance. The gallery is splendid, and everyone know that, but walking along the gardens is not less is also great. Surpreised to see how cars park not just in the sides, but in the center of the street, leaving space for circulation

Superb ... but a walk. Outstanding gallery of paintings, murals and sculptures. Got to buy tickets in advance, can't just roll up on the day. Cafe is a bit naff - the 2 old boys working there did not seem to have much joy in their lives - and it's quite a walk from the centre, though an enjoyable one of you have the time.

Splendid!!. We were told we had to book in advance, and asked our Hotel to call for us. They said it was fully booked, but we went anyway and got tickets with a 3/4 hour wait. Well worth it. This collaction is one of the best I have ever seen, and I've seen a few! Sculpture and paintings on a par wit the Vatican. Recommended.
Newly found treasure. Do not miss the tour of the galleries and gardens. A must see especially if Felix is your guide. Book the tour in advance this is essential!

Amazing collection. Worth going for the Bernini statue of Apollo and Daphne. Looking at how her limbs are turning into a tree is just other worldly.Just make sure you make your reservations or you will not get in.

Amazing interiors . The Villa Borghese is set in a very nice park which we strolled through to get to the gallery. The setting is beautiful on a warm day. We were not expecting the stunning interiors of the villa not the amount of exceptional paintings, especially the Caravaggios which were amazing to see in reality. Well worth a visit

Do not miss this gem. Wonderful collection of Bernini sculptures, and paintings by Titian, Rafael and Caravaggio, among others. Beautiful setting in the Borghese gardens. Note- reservations are required and may need to be made 2 weeks in advance.

Worth the visit but only for Caravaggio. See Caravaggio paintings but nothing else compares to the art of Caravaggio. Also , you must check all bags including my wife' s purse , Does my wife' s purse offend the museum ? Caravaggio painting would not fit into her purse.
Just big enough. More Caravaggio's than anywhere else. Don't miss thegallery and gardens if you visit Rome. It is truly a lovely time.

Our vote for best destination in Rome. I have been to Rome several times but missed this gem. We fell in love with the Bernini's here, especially Apollo and Daphne. Entrances are scheduled without the hordes of the Vatican and Sistine Chapel. We were so glad that we had planned ahead with a guide as they we still selling tickets for several days away at the end of September! We walked to the Gallery which was also pleasant going out one way and returning another to the central zone of Rome. Not to be missed and don't know how I could have before!

Borghese Gallery, the Bernini Experience. Borghese is not huge gallery that once was home to a Pope. It has three floors, and is probably less than 8000 square feet. You MUST reserve well in advance to gain entry. It has many famous painting from the Renaissance, but the highlight are the sculptures of Bernini, who must be seen to be appreciated.

Do NOT miss this magnificent gallery. We booked a tour through Viator and were so pleased with everything at Borghese Gallery. It has an amazing history and some of the most beautiful art and sculptures you will ever see. Plan on several hours including getting there. (I would recommend a taxi).

Second Visit to My Favorite Museum in Rome. This is truly a treasure in a city of so much beauty and history! The gallery is very manageable and not overwhelming; exhibits are well presented, can view close-up and each room is a marvel in art. Reservations are required and try to make those in advance. Enter gallery through the brown ground floor doors in the middle of the building. Queue to pick-up your tickets. There is security check-in of personal belongings such as bags, umbrellas, etc. The gallery is handicap accessible. Photography without flash is permitted.We took the English guided tour which included headsets for each guest, so there were no issues with hearing the guide's excellent presentation. Would recommend this tour for an overview of the gallery and exhibits. After a visit to the gallery, take a walk around the gardens and park - shaded and so peaceful in comparison to the hectic city it is situated in. The water from the fountains in Rome are drinkable, so fill up your water bottle by the fountains at the entrance to the Gallery.

Get the individual audioguide. This is one of the must see places in Rome, but…. the place doesn’t hold crowds well and the flow to get in is chaotic. You'll have to check all bags, which was (of course) not well marked and across the crowded reception area. We used Viator for their Skip the Line: Borghese Gallery Tickets at $34.60 each for what was really an 11 Euro museum cost. The audioguide was 5 euro each, and it took some experimentation to figure out how to sink the track number to the display. All in all though, well worth the hassle and cost.You will see some of the best art in Europe. Bernini's sculptures are unparalleled.

Beautiful Bernini!. The sculptures by Bernini are worth the entrance fee alone. Be aware though that you need your passport or ID with you to obtain the audio. Fabulous collection to view along with the park. We sat and listened to a guy playing the Four Seasons on a piano/organ/ accordion he was amazing and set the mood for what we were about see.

Best art gallery in Rome. Beautiful villa with amazing art inside. We loved this gallery with beautiful sculptures and art in an uncrowded atmosphere where you could really look at them and enjoy. Must book ahead.
Away from the crowds, highly recommend!. They have some of the best work of Bernini. Highly recommend for art fans! The park surrounding the gallery is beautiful!

Oh my, those beautiful statues by Bernini!. A palace full of art, statues and paintings (also by Carravagio). Our guide Paolo was so kind, new so much and adjusted his story to the interests of the group. The one with Pluto and Persephone is absolutely astonishing. I really had tears in my eyes, it is so beautiful! A must see.
Great Collection!. It is a fantastic Art Gallery Collection. It is preferably to book your visit on line. Monday is closed. Enjoy the park as well.

One of the most beautiful galleries imaginable. We were enchanted by the Borghese Gallery. The ceilings alone are jaw dropping and the sculpture and painting collection feature Bernini, whose Apollo and Daphne is exquisite, while other paitings by Titian, Carravagio, Raphael and DaVinci also delight. The self walking tour is very informative and the quality of the recorded material is excellent. Give yourself 2 hours to listen and see everything. The grounds surrounding the Gallery are picturesque and there are several lovely ponds. The Gallery is renovating the gardens attached to the home which should be lovely once finished. Hope to see it again then.

Do you like amazing art?. My wife and I really enjoyed the Borghese. Situated just outside the north wall of ancient Rome in a villa set in a gorgeous park setting and still walking distance from many of the main attractions, this small to medium size gallery has just enough amazing art on display to wow you without overwhelming you. We took a guided tour through City Wonders and Mike was our tour guide. He was fantastic, giving us a lot of perspective on the art and stories that really made the paintings and sculptures come alive. I will say this was one of the few attractions that did not have long lines at this time of year, however it does require reservations. If you plan ahead you can purchase tickets on line very inexpensively to see this gallery on your own. Personally we preferred the tour with Mike. Whether you choose to visit or not may depend on the length of your stay in Rome. There are other amazing attractions that most tourists will want to see first, (check out the Trip Advisor website or Rick Steves website)but if you are spending more than a couple of days in Rome and you love art (in which case you already know about this place) I would definitely put this museum on your list. If you don't think of yourself as an art lover then find Mike and take the tour.

Not to be missed . We visited late in the afternoon with a very small tour ( 3 of us) and a terrific tour guide named Teresa , this was by far the best tour we've done in Rome .The borghese gallery is small but beautiful.we learnt so much about the artworks and historical facts that we wouldn't have if we didn't do the tour with such an informative guide.Unfortunately though, we found the gardens to be run down and very unattended which is such a shame. Come on Rome clean these beautiful gardens up and bring them back to their former glory

Small, but Excellent Gallery. If you like art and history, this is a must stop on your visit to Rome. Get the audio guide to better understand the history of what you are seeing. Canova's sculpture of Pauline Bonaparte and the Bernini sculptures are worth the price of admission. Admission is limited and requires a reservation (make at least a week in advance). Takes 1 to 2 hours to see.

Wonderful art and sculptures in great setting. A must see to get a look at some special paintings and sculptures. Book a timed ticket ahead of time and spend some time in the wonderful park that surrounds the museum.

Mind Blowing. Entering the first gallery is breath taking.The opulence and splendour is mind blowing, I just stood and stared, Forget how this collection was put together and at what cost justabsorb its greatness. The sculptures and paintings were to die for particularly the Bernini and the Caravaggio which was the purpose of my visit but there was so much more.Any visit to Rome should include a visit to this gallery.Photography was allowed using small cameras or 'phones but none would do justice to what is on view.

Better than the Vatican. This place is awesome. I liked Borghese much better than the Vatican. The small amount of people make the Gallery user friendly. They also do a great job of giving you info in each room so you don't really need the audio tour or a private guide.

Stunning. Borghese Gallery has been on the list for a while, it is absolutely magnificent with great well displayed art . Booking in advance was important and regulating the flow of visitors with times tickets made the whole experience much better. It is really the most beautiful gallery in Rome.

One of the best musea in the world. Ticket must be reserved on there site. You can choose day and time. Print your reservation and go to the counter at least half an hour before your visit starts. The museum tickets are always sold out. So a reservation is a must.It is the third time that we visited this museum. This year there was a much bigger crowd than before. It is obvious that the museum increased the number of people allowed. This is really a pity. Now you also get in this museum people who are not ‘really’ interested in what there is to see. They only look on there smartphone, standing in the way and obstructing other visitors the see the exhibition; very annoying. Fortunately the smartphone adepts are gone after 45 minutes. So you still have an hour left to enjoy this fabulous museum. A note for the luggage > you have to leave everything in the luggage storage, you get a small plastic bag for you wallet and your phone. It not longer allowed to take some water in the museum, not even a very small bottle. But the museum is air-conditioned now. Two years ago it was still steaming hot. If there is only one museum you can visit in Rome, take this one. You will find the best pieces of Bernini and Caravaggio.

Spectacular, must-see, art collection viewable in a few comfortable hours!. After spending the good part of a day in the immense and crowed Vatican galleries, it was a joy to visit the comfortable and nicely displayed and very fine collection of the Borghese - Baroque, renascence, mannerist paintings and sculptures. Entrance seems to be by reservation, we made advance ticket purchases by internet before our travel to Italy. While not an outdoor activity, it is in parkland, so there is a little walk to the gallery itself.

Ahhhhhhhh sooo beautiful. What a great experience, we went there on our last day in Rome, the entrance is very disappointing, I walked in and thought 'I'm going to spend the whole day here?' but we walked in a little further and it was just perfect. You can rent bikes or segways and cycle around the Garden, its very big and has great scenic views. The atmosphere is just perfect, a real Italian experience

Caraveggio and Bernini. If you are interested in art and sculpture from 16th and 17th centuries, then put this museum on your list. There are probably more paintings by Caraveggio and sculptures by Bernini in this gallery than in any other museum. You have to have reservations to get in (they are timed tickets), so make sure you plan accordingly. We ordered our tickets several months in advance as on our two previous trips to Rome we had not been able to get tickets.

Interesting for Art lovers . If you enjoy Art & Sculpture, then you probably would really enjoy a visit. We visited as part of an organised tour, but it wasn't our favourite place & isn't somewhere which we would make a return visit to.

Should be on everyone's check list for Rome, IMHO. This was my 2nd visit to he gallery, my first visit was 8 years ago. All I can say is that when you walked into the first room from the entrance and look up at the ceiling, you know you are in a special place. It would be hard not to be in awe of the magnificent beauty all around you. Each room is magnificent in its own way. The sculptures by Bernini are exceptional. We took a couple who had never been there before, and they were just thoroughly amazed with the gallery.If you have the time, I feel this is a sight in Rome that should not be missed.Several point that might be helpful:* Buy/reserve tickets in advance, on-line.* Prior to entering the gallery, all visitors must check-in all bags, backpacks, purses, etc. * You are now allowed to take pictures inside the gallery. During my earlier visit, no photos were allowed.

Simply the best of Rome. Book your tickets well in advance as the touring is limited. I am happy they do this as the crowds are manageable that way. This museum has plenty to see but it is not overwhelming like the Pradoor the Louvre. It is bite sized. But, oh what a delicious bite of art candy!There are two floors and one has two hours so plan your time accordingly. I tried to help someone get upstairs with ten min left in the time period and it was already too late. They had closed the doors to the second floor.I really enjoyed the second floor with many paintings in a beautiful space. The first floor is mostly sculpture with Bernini's works being the most famous. Carraviaggio is featured on floor one and his works are a must see. Probably the best collection of his work in the world. The grounds are also beautiful and the park is very well kept. A thoroughly enjoyable experience.This museum is a must see in Roma!

Wonderful sculptures and paintings. This was recommended by a relative for its Bernini sculptures. While his David is amazing for its muscle tone and look of determination, Pluto and Persephone had a softness in the sculpture with Pluto's squeeze of Persephone's skin. Other sculptures throughout had power. The paintings on the ceiling and walls were also impressive This is quite a collection of sculpture, portraits, and other paintings from the 16th to 17th century.Tickets should be purchased in advance as it does sell out. The gallery also only allots 2 hours. Audio tour is available for a fee, however each room has a large pamphlet (English,Spanish and other languages) explaining the artwork on ceilings and walls.Well worth the visit.

Ridiculously good - dont miss. Super great collection of art. Get your tickets in advance (days in advance!!!). The guided tour was informative and nice. The guide Felix was both personable, knowledgeable and quite funny as well. I could spend a lot more time here.

Best of Bernini (and remember to buy tickets online). The two advantages of Gallery Borghese make it my absolute favorite in Rome. First of all, apart from being a museum it allows to understand how an oligarch lived in the middle ages - well pretty much the same as now. :) Secondly, it houses some of the best of Bernini, who is my favorite among sculptors, and importantly it houses Bernini's David, who is my favorite among Davids. It also has many other famous pieces of art. Finally before and/or after visiting the Gallery you can walk for hours in the beautiful Villa Borghese gardens, which is very relaxing. Make sure you buy tickets online or reserve them on phone, no other way to get into the gallery. Visiting Rome and not visiting Borghese is unimaginable.

So Lucky to Visit!. We were so fortunate to secure tickets to this gallery for the same day! It must have been a cancellation! Lucky for us, because we so enjoyed this spectacular gallery. I don't believe I've ever seen a finer collection of sculpture, especially private. Bernini's sculpture of Apollo and Daphne is exquisite and it alone is worth the ticket price. The paintings are gorgeous, too. Manage your time while there since you are only allowed a two hour block of time in the gallery. I feel honored to have enjoyed this remarkable, one of a kind collection.

Best part of Rome. The best part of our visit to Rome was the Borghese Gallery. All the other attractions were too crowded to fully enjoy. The Borghese wasn't as crowded and had incredible art. Our tour guide, Pia was wonderful. She was knowledgeable, funny and was able to tell the stories behind the artwork which added to their beauty and purpose. The collection is incredible and wonderfully displayed.

Spectacular, if lesser known museum. This relatively small museum is a masterpiece of Baroque architecture, sculpture and painting. You must make a reservation as access is limited. It provides an extraordinary look at how the other half lived a few hundred years ago. This should be the first sight to see after the Forum, Coliseum and Vatican Museums.

Fantastic place well worth the money. I have been here twice now and it's worth every penny. If you love Bernini you simply cannot miss this place.You do need to book tickets in advance as they only allow so many people in on each 2 hour slot.There is a small cafe there and you will have to put luggage in cloakroom however bum bags are allowed.If the weather allows you can walk back through the gardens to the Spanish steps however it is along walk for elderly people.There is a electric train that runs from the gallery down to the view point over Rome and near to the Spanish steps but I've never managed to find any info on it ,it has just appeared and it's a lovely ride.

Outstanding. We booked in advance for this as you must and it was worth the wait. The extent and quality of art work, particularly Bernini's sculptures was outstanding. This gallery is smaller than some of the headline galleries around the world but holds quality the equal of any in an accessible format. Unfortunately it also has the rudest staff we have ever encountered in a gallery. They are unnecessarily aggressive and generally unpleasant - multiple instances we observed supported this view. We even saw one young man attempt to prevent a mother from feeding her hungry baby in one of the rooms. Impossible to imagine why this would cause any threat to the exhibition - it could not be on the basis of modesty as there were more bare breasts on display on the walls than anywhere else you are likely to visit.

Well Worth a Visit. We had a wonderful two hour tour of the Borghese Gallery with a guide from Context travel. The tour was in the early evening when the gallery is much less crowded. The gallery has a marvelous collection of sculpture by Bernini and a number of paintings by Caravaggio as well as paintings by Titian, Raphael and Rubens. The Gallery is in a beautifully decorated villa previously owned at various times by religious figures and royalty. The gallery is small enough to see in a few hours . Be sure to look at the large and beautiful mosaic dating from early Rome on the first floor.
MUST VISIT HERE. Thoroughly recommend a visit to the Borghese Gallery. Beautiful sculptures ! The museum is set in parkland and within walking distance of the Spanish Steps. Well worth a visit.

Favorite Gallery. Every time I visit Rome I come to this gallery. You have to book ahead of time because they only sell a certain amount of tickets, which is amazing because it's not horribly crowded. The sculptures and paintings are amazing Love it.

Impressive. A ticket to the Colloseum for 18 euro gets you into the Palantine hill which is adjacent to the Colloseum It's about a half a mile square and has some of the most impressive ruins in RomeGo before 11am to avoid the flag waving legions of touristsAlso best as it can get pretty warm later on. We went in late September and it was 29c!With the the Colloseum this is at least half a dayAvoid the guided tours at both sites as they try and rush you aroundGet the guided audio which is much better and much cheaper which you can dpi at your own paceReward yourself with a cold beet or wine afterwards and then revisit all those documentaries on u tube that fill in the gaps

Wonderful experience . We had a group of 20 visiting Rome and was told Borghese Gallery is a must if we only have time for one art museum. I was kind of worried when making reservation for a private English guided tour since none of us really know too mush about arts. Am I glad I did! What a pleasant experience for all of us. Our guide Maria was wonderful. Walking through the gallery watching her and listening to her, we felt the connection to the artists. A great art lessen! We were very lucky to have Maria as our guide. This gallery will be just another art museum without her.

Borghese Gallery is not to be missed. An incredible 2 hours! Get there 30 minutes early to pick up your tickets (must order them online first...only so many people are allowed in at a time and they were sold out on our day) and drop off your bags. The audio guide is a must! An incredible collection!

Outstanding. This is one gallery worth booking advance tickets online. You are given a two hour time slot and they only allow around 350 people at a time. We were able to go through the 2 floors in one hour with the group but then go around again in the second hour when most of the people had exited. The second time around you see all the things you missed the first time when groups were blocking your view. Admission in your time slot is precise as is clearing out.

One of best things to see in Rome. Borghese Gallery is a must see and well worth the effort of pre-purchasing tickets and going out to the gardens. The atmosphere and artwork in the palace setting is far better than many of the museums and more enjoyable than the vatican museums.
Good, especially with a guide.. We used a Viator guide for both inside and gardens. Great inside tour, saving time and dodging lines. Outside just fair, not guide's fault, just poor maintenance.

Stunning villa and impressive collection!. Book in advance on line. Tickets are generally not available last minute. The audio guide is quite helpful if you don't read Italian. Tours are two hours. Leave time to enjoy the beautiful gardens as well. Also, consider taking a cab unless you are pretty familiar with the area as arriving 15 min. prior to your scheduled entry in mandatory.

A must see. Tour this gallery with a private knowledgable guide. We used Evan from Rome Illuminated Tours. You get so much information and is fluent in English and Italian, very easy to understand and communicate with.
Master pieces of the renaissance . The Grounds are vast and wonderful. You can always rent transport to go around. Make sure to reserve tickets to the museum at least two days before your visit.
Breath Taking. Be sure to rent the audio guide! Very helpful to understand the history and stories behind the sculptures

Good but not great. The Villa Borghese is a small art gallery with some magnificent rooms and an impressive collection of paintings. However, I think it’s a bit overrated here on trip advisor. Don’t take me wrong, it was a great visit but I don’t think I’d recommend it if your time in Rome is limited.Keep in mind that you have to buy tickets in advance. If you don’t want to miss your time slot, you’ll have to arrive a bit early. You have to leave your bags before entering the gallery which can take some time if there are a lot of people. Also, it can get pretty crowded when you actually enter the gallery because everyone can enter at the same time.Maybe you should consider the Palazzo Doria Pamphilij instead. You don’t have to buy tickets in advance, it’s least crowded, it’s just as beautiful (if not more) and you have a free audio guide that actually explains the story of the Palazzo.

Outstanding museum. Marvelous museum with ancient sculpture and baroque sculptures by Bernini besides wonderful paintings -6 alone by Caravaggio. Remember to book tickets online before your visit - otherwise you Will not get in!

Wonderful. Take your time to admire all this beautiful artwork. Highlights are Caravaggio and Bernini. You must book a time slot in advance, even if you have a Roma pass. Time slots last 2 hours, starting from 9am and last one at 5pm. Recommend audio guide. The restricted entry makes viewing very peasant and civilised, not like some other sites.

Villa Borghese. I booked tickets on-line to visit the Borghese Gallery through Dark Rome (City Wonders). I thought I had booked a guided tour however was advised when receiving the tickets that it was not guided. Slightly disappointed as I'm not sure why I was charged 30 Euro as the entry fee into the gallery is only 11 euro. However the gallery was excellent and is a must see when in Rome.

Ok gardens. Prefered the campari family more. Big park worth visiting. Metro is a walk away from the park which you should consider if you are not a good walker. It's very nice during a summer day. Clean, water,...

The Perfect Museum. When everything in Rome becomes either too big or too overwhelming, The Borghese Gallery serves as the perfect cultural experience. The Daphne & Apollo sculpture will take your breath away, as well as the other Bernini treasures. . Reservations for the gallery must be made in advance. It's small and easy to move around. Plus it's located in the beautiful Borghese park atop of a very historical street, the Via Veneto.

Somewhat disappointing. The Borghese is set in a wonderful park. As others have said it is very important to purchase tickets in advance. That being said, we were somewhat disappointed in the Borghese. The sculpture collection is magnificent but the paintings, with a few exceptions, are rather ordinary. Also the tour seems somewhat confused and the staff are not as helpful or courteous as one would like.
"the" juwel museum box of Rome!. The museum of the Vatican is great, but this museum is the top!!!Enjoy the beauty of the sculptures of Bernini in the most beautiful setting.

Viewing Perfection at Borghese. If you ever considered sculpture by other great artists, ensure you don't miss what this museum offers - GL Bernini, a true master where numerous works are displayed. This museum may be small but its contents are rich in history & beauty! Do not miss this museum, but ensure to reserve your space /time for entry. Highly recommend this to all who come to Rome as a "must see"!

Perfect for the casual art lover. I am not a huge art fan, and for that reason did not want to spend an entire day at the Vatican museum. This museum was perfect though - takes about two hours to complete, and the audio guide gave very thorough and interesting commentary. Must buy tickets in advance (either online or in person), you will not be able to just walk in and buy tickets.
Not to be missed. Make a reservation if you dont want to be disappointed.Be ready to enjoy from room to room the history and splendour of statues and paintings .

Museum is a must - Garden is a a park not a garden. The museum is wonderful. We took the audio tour and it provided a lot of insights about the history of the things we were looking at. We really enjoyed seeing the treasures housed here. The gardens were disappointing, it is really just a park. We did rent one of the "bikes" but after a 1/2 hour we were pretty well done, however, we did see that there was quite a bit for children to enjoy.

Need Tickets In Advance. The purpose of this review is to warn travelers that you cannot simply show up and expect to get in. We were there on a Tuesday and the next available tickets were for Friday - the day of our departure.

Go for the sculpture. We made our reservations to visit the Borghese Gallery. I highly recommend a visit to the gallery. We made our reservations ahead of our visit. It is easy to do by calling them (they have English speaking operators). We went to the 9 am opening, great time of day to get there. The sculptures by Bernini are incredible, each one took my breath away. There are many painting to be seen, also. We did not have a tour guide, but used the audio guide available at the gallery. I found this enough for me. You get 2 hours to tour the gallery, it was just the right amount of time for us. This is a "don't miss" art gallery. Be sure to make your reservations ahead of time so you are not disappointed!
Spectacular. A great museum with so much colorful art work. You need reservations as it is busy there. The museum is in a beautiful park, which is an attraction in its own right.

Good art collection. It is situated near metro station and has good connectivity ,though there is a walk to villa Borghese from station exit or bus stop. It boasts of good collection of paintings and sculptors by renowned artists ,some made famous after their work was displayed here. It is advisable to take a audio guide to know more about important art pieces . Must go if you appreciate art. You may find its tickets online in advance for particular day and slots to avoid big lines. Upon entrance ,you will have to deposit your bags at the counter. Slot is for 2 hours and you will be able to cover whole gallery in that time frame if you arrive on time. There is small cafe at the entrance ,where you can rest a bit after roaming about.

Wonderful art in an amazing palace. This gallery is a "must see" for lovers of art. It is inconvenient to get here since they have discontinued the little electric bus but taxis are readily available. The gardens are also wonderful for a stroll or a picnic.

Well worth a look.... The borghese gallery is a magnificent place to visit and the art is wonderful. However, make sure you book those tickets well in advance. It is surrounded by a huge park with lots of other places to see, which does involve alot of walking. So it might be worth hiring a bike! Go and see for yourself.

Nightmare!. There is so much to do in Rome. We suggest you give this one a pass. When you arrive (early, of course, and with your previously purchased tickets) you will be stripped of your purse. Yes, that's right. You cannot have your purse with you in the museum. For some reason, not explained, your purse offends the museum!(I am not talking about a backpack or suitcase. Just an ordinary lady's purse, not large.)Now, I have no pockets on my clothes. So the 'guard' rudely thrust a plastic bag at me. I put everything that was in my purse, in the plastic bag. And then checked my purse. So stupid. And, of course, the line up to check my purse was 15 minutes. Remember that your ticket only buys you 2 hours. And they do not care that following their useless and weird rules eats up 15 minutes of the time for which you paid. Annoying and ridiculous. Now you are on the clock. Race through the museum. There is no time for contemplation or reflection. This is a meat-grinder venue: get their money, get 'em in, get 'em out. There are papers in each room, explaining the items in that room. However, you do not have enough time to read the papers, review the items and comprehend. There simply isn't enough time. Run through, snap a few photos and get the hell out. Out of the galleries...so you can wait in line, again, the get your purse back!Really?!?!There are better things to do and see. Don't bother with this. Or if you must, be prepared for the nightmare.

Beautiful Art, Less Beautiful Visitors . The art work was absolutely beautiful and the rooms were stunning. However, a lot of school trips would stop in front of specific paintings for long periods of time and take all of the seating in the room. Could be a problem. Other school trips were perfectly fine, but one school had a noisy teacher who told other people to shush while she would talk to her group which was rude. The toilets were not brilliant (a bit messy and not very clean when I went in) and were located between floors.The gardens were beautiful and you could not fault the interior and exterior art works. The interior gift shop is reasonably well stocked, slightly expensive and often busy, but worth a visit Nearby there are a lot of ice cream trucks for sunny days. Beautiful place to visit. But I would advise booking in advance.

Must See Sculptures. When planning our trip to Rome I read somewhere that if you only visit one museum in Rome, it should be the Galleria Borghese. Well, I couldn't agree more. You need to book a 2-hour time slot so I booked 11.00 am to 1.00 pm. We booked our tickets through ticketone.it before travelling. There was a booking fee of 4 euros but we felt the convenience was worth it. We received an email confirmation which we had to print and take to the ticket office on arrival which was exchanged for an entry ticket. We were staying near the Piazza Navona but taking a taxi seemed the easiest way to get there. Once there, you can buy a book in the shop which tells you about the main exhibits, or you can hire an audio guide. We preferred to just walk around and found that in some rooms there were laminated descriptions of the exhibits which were in several languages which you could walk around with and then return. Unfortunately I had left my reading glasses in my bag which had to be handed in on entry so wasn't able to read anything. The museum comprises two floors with several rooms. On the ground floor there are several Bernini sculptures which I can only describe as absolutely stunning and amazing. The upper floor rooms contain paintings only but for us the sculptures were one of the highlights of our visit to Rome.

Stunning!. My wife and I aren't art people, but can appreciate the classics. This place just blew us away! The park is wonderful, the house itself is amazing, and the art is one of a kind! I'm going to ruffle some feathers here: Bernini's David is much more dynamic, exciting and emotional than Michelangelo's It was by far my favorite, and we went the next day to Florence, waited in a brutal line, waded through huge crowds to lay eyes on Michelangelo's David, which was really a marvel itself. However, not as emotionally charged, not full of power and kinetic energy as Bernini's If you only see one museum in Italy, make it this one. In fact, go out of your way to get here, as what we saw here will stick with us forever.

Fabulous Gallery. We booked a session for 5pm - you need to book beforehand. This was a great time to go as it was quiet and only a few people. We hired the audio guide and this was well worth the money - €5. Some amazing works of art in this gallery, not to be missed.

Must Visit While In Rome!. In a city that has the Vatican Museum, it's hard to compete, but the Borghese Gallery is a must-do in Rome. It's much smaller in scale but has breathtaking pieces from Bernini that you really have to see in person to appreciate fully. I personally prefer Bernini's David to Michelangelo's--the level of detail, action and emotion in his pieces really move you--and the Gallery is set up nicely so that the major pieces each have their own room so you can view and contemplate and give them the time they deserve. The crowd control and advance reservation process is a bit annoying, but in the end it really helps enhance your experience. Leave some time afterwards to explore the park. We rented one of those 4-person bikes afterwards and rode around the grounds and it was lovely and the kids really enjoyed it.

Citywonders.com Tour Not so Wonderful. We had booked a tour of the Borghese Museum for 3 people through citywonders.com. We got there early and took a tram ride through the grounds which were beautiful. We were supposed to meet our tour guide on the steps of the museum at 2:40 with the tour to begin at 3. We got off the tram and went to the museum steps at 2:45 but couldn't find our guide. Walked downstairs into the museum, asked the worker at the door, etc. and to no avail. Although we prepaid for the tour, we were stood up! Book directly through the museum as we couldn't even get into the museum as it was sold out. Very disappointing!

Stunning! . We absolutely loved it, it was our first and best thing in Rome, huge collection of statues & paintings. A must-go but you have to book a week or so in advance even if you have the roma-pass, also try to book the guided tour or if you couldn't, you can get an audio guide, if you go all by yourself and no audio guide you won't understand and absorb the place. Absolutely stunning.

Must-see museum with Bernini and Caravaggio masterpieces. This is a relatively small museum that fully lives up to the hype. Highly recommend the guided tour---costs a bit more, but our guide provided details and answered questions that enhanced the experience for us. The building itself---with elaborate and varied decorations on walls, floors and ceilings---is very impressive. There are several Roman mosaics on the floor in a great state of preservation. The high points for us were the amazing Bernini sculptures---ranging over much of his career---and the 6 Caravaggio paintings. But there is a lot more too. Visitors enter in two-hour "shifts", and this was about the right amount of time for the two floors. It's not a large museum---just about right for our taste. Planning ahead is essential for most of the year.
A must visit!. Do not miss visiting the Borghese Gallery if traveling to Rome. Allow several hours to tour the museum and the beautiful grounds.
Stunning!. Impressive collection of Italian classic art in one of the most beautiful buildings I have visited during my sstay in town.

You will drool!. This is a must see museum in Rome. I must warn you, bring a bib, because you will drool!. Be sure to make reservations quite sometime before you want to go. The Bernini statues alone are worth the visit.

Disappointed. We didn't realise that this needed to be booked in advance with no leeway for spontaneous visitors. On the Saturday we walked up from the Spanish Steps so it was a bit of a hike only to be told we couldn't go in as it was fully booked until Thursday - really disappointed.

Amazing collection and a wonderful villa. As other reviewers have mentioned, you have to do an advanced reservation as the number of visitors per a two hour visit is limited. We did a guided tour booked through the gallery itself and our knowledgeable guide Isabella Botti did an amazing job. She really did an art history crash course for those without knowledge and for those with some knowledge, her descriptions and dialogue were amazing. I loved seeing Bernini's sculptures (David in particular) and loved the beautiful ceilings of the villa. The Borghese Gallery is much less crowded than other attractions due to the reservation requirement and it was amazing to be able to see some amazing paintings (like Raphael's Portrait of a Lady with a Unicorn and The Deposition) so close without crowds. I highly recommend a stop at Borghese Gallery and a stroll through the gardens after.

It would probably have been nice IF IT WAS OPEN!!. I made the reservations well in advance, was there at 8AM for the 9AM appointment, and there was a strange sign on the door. Finally someone translated for me. Union strike. Museum closed. Lovely. No officials outside to help. No nothing. Flight leaves tomorrow. I was very much looking forward to this.
Close to Hotel Bernini Bristol. Within easy walking distance of hotel. Lovely walk through park. You need to reserve ticket & visit time.

A true gem of a museum. You must book an online advance reservation, as the number of visitors per 2 hour visit is limited. This is a "must see" museum as not only is the building itself quite beautiful, but it's collection is a true gem. Be certain to get the audio tour as it will give you in depth information about many of the pieces as some history of the villa itself

Such Bernini, so wow. The sculptures by Bernini are simply amazing. Such detail, such craftsmanship, very wow. Even as a layman, you can appreciate his art and skill (this sometimes bothers me about paintings, where I'm too dumb to understand why it is a masterpiece). You can see the veins stand out under the flesh, the expressions on their faces, the wind in their hair, the motion and emotion, I've never seen sculptures like this before.The gallery is situated in a great park. Just keep in mind to book well in advance. We went for the last time slot of the day which was very nice because there is not that much pressure to leave. Unfortunately, if you do not book a guided tour or an audioguide, you won't get much information about all the paintings and sculptures. Be prepared and take your travel book!

So worth visiting!!! Art lovers will be thrilled.. I was reading about Galleria Borgese art collection and for many of the master pieces that includes, since I was a student. Being there and seeing all these incredible paintings and sculptures is beyond description. Make sure that you book ahead the day and time of visit and have the booking number with you. It takes a full two hours, for me it was not even close, but you can see almost everything within this time frames. The building itself is marvelous, the ceilings and walls are masterpieces and what you can say about Bernini's sculptures,Caravaggio's paintings, Canova's Paolina sculpture, Tiziano's Sacred and profane love painting??? If you have time to visit only one museum while in Rome, Galleria Borghese must be the one. Personally I'll go back again and this time I'll book a guided tour since although I've read so many books over the years about the masterpieces, there are always so many stories, facts and fascinated details to know about them.

Best part of the trip. We saw many museums while in Rome, Florence, Venice and this was the best of all. The Bernini Statues are breathtaking. Incredible treasures and beautifully laid out. Very rich in history. Crowds are not bad because they limit how many can get in. You will need reservations a few days ahead of time.

No line..All tickets are timed. Some firms promise if you buy tickets from them you can by-pass the line. There is no line...all tickets sold for the 250 individuals permitted in each of the two hour time slots is timed. Although English cards are available in each room describing some of the items, the audio guide is a good investment.(If you have seen the David in Florence, the version here is an intriguing contrast. Restaurant about two blocks away is a wonderful economical treat, Fiore Di Zucca.

Do Not Miss The Borghese Gallery. The Borghese Gallery was on of our favorite stops in Rome. The mansion and its artwork were spectacular. The sculpture collection was particularly impressive. Reservations provide a two hour visit and guarantee that the visitors are not overcrowded. Visit the park afterwards and drive around in a golf cart while eating a gelato.

Take your time. First you must make reservations by internet. If you go there thinking to buy your ticket and visit in the same day, not happening. The place was booked fot the next 4 days when we arrived with our internet tickets. I've gone by bus, but you can go by subway and walk a little more. The art is fantastic. There is a good café inside and take your time to see the gardens outdoor - they are huge!

A Place To Visit at Sunset. What a wonderful park! This is a large park on the edge of the city at the beginning of Del Corso. When it is a hot day it is great to just sit and cool off in the shade. There is a merry-go-round for children so is good for families. If one finds the walking too much or there walking difficulties there are mini trains that takes people about the park. Also self pedalled gold buggies if one is fun loving. There are mini lakes and small eateries where one can get a panino, drink or coffee. The peace de resistance is as one enters the park is the vista looking over all Rome and at sunset it is magical.

Favourite Museum in Rome. The Borghese Gallery is by far our favorite museum in Rome. The collection of statues and artwork is outstanding. I recommend getting the audio guide (5 Euros) as it is informative and lets you explore the museum at your own pace. When we got to the museum, it had been completely booked for the day and the next 5 days. Thankfully, we had ordered tickets beforehand.We visited the picture gallery on the second floor first and then work your way down do the statues on the first floor. By working backwards, I think we avoided the main crowds that were touring the museum along a more conventional path. We were able to spend a few moments alone in the room with Bernini's statue of David.Because of its ticketing system and the fact that it allows only so many people in the museum of time made the visit so much more enjoyable.
