Magnificant sculpture experience. Book your tickets timely online. Mind that the chosen time slot is binding. Enjoy the sculptures of the old masters in a very relaxing exhibition house. Also spend some time in the guarden and visit the nearby Piazza del Popolo.
Should be on your bucket list!. Fantastic art museum with the best of Italian baroque. And it is perfect size. Too popular, so tickets should be prebooked, and you only get 1 hour

Astonishing gallery. Do not miss this gallery when visiting Rome. Extraordinary collection of exhibits. Shame the museum only allows one in for 2 hours at a time. Remember to book online - museum often sold out so cannot get admission on the door.

Blissful Bernini. Visited to view the Bernini statuary and highly recommend here for the statues alone !We'd booked several months in advance for a timed ticket of 2 hours at face value and hired the audio guides to have a better understanding of the viewable collection. They do sell out in advance and thie tickets are easily bought online prior to visit.Personally I have a limit to how much I can see before I get overwhelmed and can't take any more so the Berninis alone were more than enough for me.Did not get a chance to explore the gardens and will make sure we get a picnic to spend more time here.
Great. Defonately valid to be placed in top ten of sites to do in rome paintings sculpture frescos on ceilings
A must!. Third time visit, but still as impressive as the first. A treasure chest of collected art and statues for the ages.
beautiful grounds. We walked the gardens and grounds and rented double bikes to see all. We couldnt get into the gallery itself as you need to get tickets in advance They sell out early and are timed

Vacation 2016 in Rome. The gardens are amazing, we took my daughter for 2 pony rides, took the 4 seater bike around the gardens, stopped i for the cafe for lunch. Enjoyed a gelato filled with flavour. The zoo is also interesting however it was 38 degrees and we moved fast through it

Borghese Gallery. Our guide Mikaela, did a fabulous job on this tour. We learned all the details to this gallery and it was very informative and entertaining!! Would definitely request her on other tours

What an absolutely beautiful place,brought to life by our private tour guide. Even though we have been to Rome several times,we've never visited Villa Borghese.I contacted Tuscanyall.com,a Rome museum excursion company and arranged for a private tour.The Borghese Gallery is quite unique in that they monitor how many people are admitted to view the works of art .Tickets are a must and there are designated times in 2&1/2 intervals.We met our tour guide,Mr Alvise Tarantello in front and waited till our designated time slot.Mr Tarantello was wonderful! His knowledge of the Borghese and the works of Bernini,Caravaggio,Canova and Titian was wonderful and insightful.We all enjoyed it,and that was because of Mr Tarantello.

Often overlooked but GORGEOUS. I visited the Vatican as well, but I have to stay I was very pleasantly surprised with this gallery. It's a lot smaller and situated in the park, but the art and especially the rooms are beautiful and ornate! There's so much detail and the top of the ceilings are incredible to look at. Would certainly recommend to anyone visiting Rome.

Sculpture highlight of the trip in a country where stunning sculpture abounds!. This is an expertly-curated museum, and the beauty of it is that a limited number of people are allowed inside at each timed entry, so you get to really savor and appreciate every piece of art without having to fight crowds. It has treasures, but not an overwhelming amount of things like the Vatican museums which are truly tiring because you can only take in so much.
Great gallery :). Lots of exhibits, while the gallery is set in the midst of the gardens. Combines a great walk in nature with a worth-seeing cultural exhibition (statues, paintings, etc.)

Totally Satisfying. Our guide, Anna, was simply amazing. She loved the sculptures and paintings, knew them in satisfying detail, and took the time to show the five of us the skills of the sculptors and painters. It was a long tour for two 79 year olds, two hours, but, limited, seating was available in many galleries. The magnificence of the rooms, their themes and contents were simply placed before each of us by Anna, for us to wonder at. We could question Anna at any time and receive pertinent answers. Her love of the art and her job were central to our totally satisfying experience. We were favoured indeed.anna, if you read this A BIG THANK YOU!

Marble is alive. This is Italy, this is Rome, and nowhere, even in Rome itself, there is something so exquisite as the scuptures you will enjoy in Villa Borghese, where the marble becomes tender and you feel it so alive that your hand becomes the hand touching the flesh of Persephone, as if you were the god, and your eyes rest on the languid figure that Canova created. A rich collection of paintings will give you an even deeper aprehension of sublime art. Villa Borghese puts you steps above your previous self.
Very nice. We went for the sculptures and they did not diassapoint. The berninis were beautiful! You need to prebook a timeslot.

Heart of Art. If you like the art , paintings , sculptures yhis is your heaven. Roma pass can use. Booking is necessary. We arrived 10am and made a booking to 1:00 pm. Online reservation also possible as I know. I not show many picture ... Visit time is 2 h for each group and bag is not allowed! Downstairs has a place to leave bags...

Incredible gallery and garden, rent a multi person bike to enjoy the gardens!. The official ticketing website is 'ticketone [dot] it' and you want to search for 'Galleria Borghese - Biglietti'. It is also here that you will find all the information you need about opening hours, rules of ticketing, days the gallery will be closed and where you can choose your day and time to enter the gallery. Do not even entertain the idea that you might be able to buy on the spot same day tickets here. You MUST book to see the wonders that this gallery holds, and know what time you plan to go in because your entry time is strictly adhered to (everyone lines up into this huge snake around the foyer). While you will still be allowed in after your allocated time within the two hour block (e.g. you enter the gallery at 11:30am instead of 11:00am) you will be promptly told to vacate the gallery as soon as the 2 hour time limit is over to make way for the next group, regardless of when you decided to enter.I was scared that 2 hours wasn't going to be enough time for me to see everything in the gallery, but rest assured that 2 hours is plenty of time to take as many photos as your camera can store and to cry over the absolute ART!!! that you will have the privilege to see with your own eyes. YES, all the rumours are true!- It is absolutely exquisite work that you get to see in there.Make sure you leave yourself plenty of time to collect your tickets, as you MUST leave all bags and clunky objects with staff and the lines for both services can get quite long. There is an audio guide available for those who would like one as well. After you finish enjoying the gallery, make sure you take time to explore the gardens as well if the weather allows. My family decided to hire a big 4 person bike (we were permitted to fit 5 people on it, with responsibility of safety on us) and it was so much fun pedaling this huge bike around the garden! It is partially motorised and fitted with a big brake to help you get up and down the slopes of the garden. We hired the bikes by turning right after we exited the gallery from the gift shop and walked down the path leading towards the zoo within the gardens. The bikes are available for hourly hires, where you will have to leave some form of ID with staff before collecting it back when you return the bike.

Bernini's Finest. Most of the sculptures in the Gallery are from Bernini (designer of St peters square). The 'other' David is here, the rape of Persephone, all set in a beautiful Villa decorated with frescoes all over the ceiling. Book early though because all tickets must be booked at least a week in advance and only in 2 hour time slots.

Beautiful Borghese. The Borghese Gallery was full of beautiful works of art from sculptures to painting to unbelievable mosaics. Tiffany was knowledgeable and made a learning experience quite enjoyable. Loved the small group environment.

Beautiful art collections!. We enjoyed this visit very much, seeing the beautiful grounds surrounding the gallery in addition to viewing all of the amazing art collections. We did an audio tour, and booked it ahead of time which I recommend.

So much treasure in one place. First of all this is a wonderful building in an impressive setting and the contents are just breath taking, from Bernini to Caravaggio and plenty more of wonderful artists work including Titian and Raphael, a feast not to be missed.

Galleria Borghese. Art lovers paradise- these are some of the important works of Bernini, Raphael, Caravaggio and Canova. YOU NEED ADVANCE RESERVATIONS! We bought ticketsfrom tour groups that overbought and were able to get in. The numbers are limited so it becomes an uncrowded and up close, personal experience. We wandered about at a leisurely pace. It's more interesting if YOU are familiar with mythology. Many of the works are related to myths, which was interesting since Borghese was a cardinal for the Catholic church and related to the Pope! There is a more realistic DAVID sculptue by Bernini. (More masculine and realistic version than Michaelangelos David.)Bernini has become one of my favorite artists due to this museum. Notice- one visit take all the pictures you want at these museums whereas the next visit- NO PHOTOS!

A Garden of dreamy time. Villa Borghese is a landscape garden in the naturalistic English manner in Rome, containing a number of buildings, museums and attractions. It is the third largest public park in Rome after the ones of the Villa Doria Pamphili and Villa Ada. The gardens were developed for the Villa Borghese Pinciana built by the architect Flaminio Ponzio, developing sketches by Scipione Borghese, who used it as a villa suburbana, a party villa, at the edge of Rome, and to house his art collection. The gardens as they are now were remade in the early nineteenth century. You enjoy a fully day in the gardens of the Villa with the walking promenade, fountains and there is restaurants, attractions for children and families too. I had a wonderful time there before continuing my way to the City Florence.

The best Gallery I have visited. This was my third visit to the gallery (from Australia) This wonderous gallery is more lovely than Versailles. It is a work of art filled with some of my favorite works of art set in the refreshing Borghese gardens. The marble sculptures by Bernini appear soft as flesh. Sacred and Profane Love by Titian is in the top corner room. The statue of the naughty Paulina is also a highlight. Make sure you book ahead on their website or you will be disappointed.

Stunning. Blew my socks off.. Small museum packed with iconic pieces one learns about in art history class. The foyer certainly has it's desired effect on the visitor; power, wealth, and a small taste of what is come.

Some Great Works but Many Are Just So-So. Maybe we were overwhelmed by the art in Rome and we visited the Borghese Gallery after several other galleries and museums. However, I would not put this on my "must do list" for a first visit to Rome.
Plan to visit. Make sure you book in advance. They only let in certain number of people and you have 2 hours for the visit. There are days when they are sold out.

Must be on visit list. We took guided tour through viator. It was exellent. Our guide Angela was super knowledgeable. We pick up a lot of info, without guide we would just aimlessly walking and looking at stunning pieces of art.
Great things!!. Bernini's sculptures are amazing!!!They are all over the building and you can see also caravaggio's paintings.

A small gallery with impressive art . The Borghese does not have the fame of the Vatican but it is a place to visit in Rome. You must book in advance for a two hour slot to visit. This limits the number of people in the museum so it is never crowded. There are only two floors of art work, so two hours are enough. We were impressed by the variety of everything there, also be sure to look up, the ceilings are covered also.
Amazing art, pretty good cafe, lovely gardens. Nice gift shop.. This was my second visit to the Borghese Gallery. Every bit as beautiful as I remembered. Alot to take in, so I plan to return again.
Joanna. Hard to know whether to look at the decoration of the rooms or the sculptures and paintings in the walls! Well Worth a journey but book in advance!

Stairs and stairs and no English. For hearty souls that love art history, this is the perfect tour! "Oh, my God, the actual XXX in real life!" With no background in art history the significance of so much was lost on me. All titles and labels were in Italian only. I would have appreciated a TED talk with slides more. If you do not know Italian, try to get an English tour. An audio tour device for 5 euro was better than nothing for us. Too many steep steps for this old gal.

Better than the Vatican. This gallery was my favourite place to visit for statues and paintings. Everywhere is beautiful and as long as you book in advance, there's no problem at all walking in. Really really great place to walk around. Make sure you go and see the fountain behind the building too, beautiful!

nice museum. staff needs some organization.. Make sure you pre-book your tickets. They sell out fast and you may miss a chance to see a rare collection of art work if you do not pre-order your tickets on line. We went through a tour guide service. We arrive 1.5 hours early and went to the front desk to get our tickets. They indicated to wait outside for our tour guide to arrive. My wife received a text on her phone with a confirmation number so I used that number to actually get our tickets. 20 minutes to 3pm we stood in a line to check in. Wrong line for our tour group. Nobody indicates where each tour group is suppose to meet and both the counter staff and other tour groups could care less to give you and directions. Another couple had booked through the same tour group and totally missed out on getting in at all, because they did not receive the text which contained the ID the counter agent needed to print your tickets. Our tour guide never showed up. Make sure you check all your hats, selfie sticks, bags, purses and umbrellas at the coat check as they will send you out of line to put it away. What happened to me is they tore my ticket sent me away to check my selfie stick. When I tried to re-enter after checking my selfie stick, they looked at me confused like they had never seen me before.... You just yelled at me to check my selfie stick and throw away my water bottle. What ever, We got in anyways and walked around and looked at the sculptures and paintings by ourselves without a tour guide. They only give you 2 hours per 'group' in the museum. We did eavesdrop on other tour groups in the museum so we could get a little background on each room and some of the paintings. Lots of famous pantings and sculptures done by famous artists. Worth seeing if you can getting inside.

The must see museum in Rome. This museum, reached through a huge park (gardens would be a huge understatement), is worth the walk. It’s relatively small, but the art it houses – amazing. It has the largest collection of Bernini’s in the world and they alone are worth the trip. To see these sculptures with their amazing movement embodied in marble something to behold. Rent the audio guides (5 euros each) to get the backstory of the piece, museum, how the acquired the pieces (much of it somewhat unscrupulously). You’ll need reservations as they only let in a limited number every two hours. Start with the paintings (as the Rick Steve’s guide book suggested) rather than the sculptures and you’ll have the sculptures almost to yourself. You can bring in your camera and take photos, but no flash. Everything else needs to be checked. But beware, the Borghese park is huge so it’s a fair walk to get to the Gallery itself. You can rent rickshaw type bikes to get there though. There are a few food and drink stalls throughout the park as well as a cafeteria and gift store in the Gallery. Drawbacks: Reservations only. Long walk to get to the Gallery

Walk in the park. We had a very nice walk in the park wich was out of this world, a big, nice, quite and very cousy park with a lot of statues, you could rent a segway or a bike for up to 4 people i think, to use in the park :) we were never in the galleria itself but outside :)

Masterpieces from Bernini!. Make sure you book in advance for an allocated 2 hour time slot and get an audio guide! I truly enjoyed viewing the sculptures from Bernini and my particular favourite was Apollo and Daphne. Not to be missed if you are in Rome!
Awsome. What I loved best was the surrounding gardens. Glorious. One has to book or else even with cash in hand they would not let you in

A treasure trove. This gallery hosts a superb collection of the masters, the highlights for me being the series of Caravaggio and Bernini masterpieces. The building itself is beautiful, inside and out. The gallery is set over two floors and easy to take in all of it in 2-3 hours. Practicalities:There is a small cafe in the entrance hall.No bags -- not even small handbags -- are allowed in the gallery and all have to be checked in. A small clear plastic bag is given out if you wish to keep your valuables with you.Tickets have to be bought in advance -- either for the gallery box office or online. It is a very popular gallery and tickets limited so booking online a few days in advance is essential.

Privileged to have visited this treasure. My wife is the best at spotting the greatest places when we travel.Organization, clean, perfectly maintained, great lighting.Now our tour guide, don't forget to book in advance limited spaces available, was a doctor in art, so knowledgeable, easy, fun.What a treat.

Must See. If time permits go see this Galleria, you need a good couple of hours to walk through this galleria. Extraordinary paintings hanging on the walls & on ceilings. Magnificent sculptures throughout the 3 floors. A tour is a very informative way to help you understand the family, the paintings & sculptures. The galleria has headphones for rent to walk you through the exhibition. Gift shop, small cafe, bathrooms near cafe.

excellent -a must see for art lovers. Id booked a tour through Viator, our guide was outside, we were running a bit late as we'd walked and the estate is quite big, lots of paths, roundabouts and greenery to walk through until you reach the gallery. (looks like a huge house). give yourself plenty of time. You have to book in a time slot, there was only the two of us and one other man which made the tour better as it much more intimate. we had to leave our bags at the desk and just take your camera with you. it was quite busy but easy to get around, our guide explained this is a very special art collection as it is the only place in the world to have 6 Caravaggio paintings and 5 Bernini sculptures (or something like that) very impressive! It includes Caravggios paintings Saint Jerome Writing, St john the Baptist, Madonna child and Serpent, Boy with a basket of Fruit, and Young Sick Bacchus. All beautiful paintings, along with other works of art, egyptian hieroglyphs, chairs, sphinx statues, and of course sculptures by Bernini. These were impressive, stunningly beautiful and a real highight for me, his earliest work was Goat Amalthea with Infant Jupiter and Faun, Aeneas, Anchises & Ascanius. Rape of Proserpine is absolutely beautiful, revolutionary at the same time, to turn a chunk of marble into a masterpiece showing fluidity, movement, flowing hair, tears and features including grief and pain. absolutely groundbreaking and beautiful! also sculptures 'David' and 'Apollo and Daphne' is a triumph. Stunning works of art by an artist who was very young. Definitely worth a visit, definitely get a tour guide as you'll miss out on alot if you have no idea of the context of the artwork. Absolutely beautiful museum and felt very privileged to be let in, never mind get shown around. it feels priceless and a very special experience. Fantastic.

joy to the eye & mind. If you want to see this museum you truly need to make reservations online ahead of the time. Even now as the tourist season is waning, the tickets sell out. We took the last slot 5-7pm. Just to be able to see Bernini's masterpieces was magical. But there's more : Canova (his famous scultpure of Paolina Bonaparte-Borghese) , Caravaggio, Titan, Peter Paul Rubens, Raphael....

Overwhelmingly Beautiful. The artwork and the building is gorgeous. Make sure you make a reservation before hand since they book up. The audio guide was helpful - we brought a headphone jack splitter so we could share the audio guide - not only for cost but also so we could discuss what they were saying.

Worth getting inside - lovingly restored interiors and unmissable masterpieces!. The Villa, built as a fun palace for Cardinal Scipio Borghese, was the first attraction that I saw on visiting Italy as a student in 1975. I was astounded by the sculptures and pictures but surprised by the decay of the building. Returning with Maggie ten years after that, it was closed for restoration - and still closed ten years later! Third time lucky, and the loving restoration has worked marvels. The ornate walls, ceilings and floors are dazzling - the floors of the central ground floor room contain the best Roman mosaics of gladiators to be found anywhere in the world. Scipio Borghese was a patron of the young Bernini and Caravaggio: Bernini's 'David' (the deliberate opposite of Michelanglo's) and 'Apollo & Daphne' are stupendous and the Caravaggios are beguiling; two Bernini busts of the fun-loving Cardinal are on show, because the first had a flaw in the marble. The Borghese family were forced to sell 200 pictures & sculptures to Napoleon, but what remains includes Titian's 'Sacred & Profane Love' and Canova's 'Pauline Bonaparte as Venus', which are both exquisite.The Villa was built as an intimate space to show treasures to a select few, and capacity is limited. The two-hour ticket slots give ample time, but they are often sold out weeks in advance. We were lucky: it was sold out but, as it was September, we could go back at five. You can buy the tickets online in advance - and buy well in advance: the museum's own site sent me to an inaccessible website, but the Italy musems site allows you to select dates and time slots. It is a bit of a hassle, but well worth the effort!

Poorly organised . Despite works by Caravaggio, Titan, Paul Rubens and Federico Barocci we decided not to go inside due to the high costs, the inability and inflexible booking system. The facade of the building is grand enough to give you an insight of the numerous marble offerings inside. The gardens were also nicely presented.

Borghese Gallery. We chose to see several spots in Rome and not do the Vatican. At this time it's hot and very crowded. So we chose the Borghese, we were delighted with our choice. The art and the buildings are spectacular. Very well organized with a limited number of visitors allowed in. You need to select your time slot in advance for your visit.

Afternoon in Rome. I was worried when we ordered our ticket about the two hour time limit. No need to worry, 2 hours is plenty. The cap on the number of guests allows this sight to not be overly crowded in any area. This was a very welcome as other Rome sights were packed.The grounds are very lovely and well appointed and maintained. We enjoyed our audio tour. Much history given for each entry.

A "Mecca" for sculpture enthusiasts. This beautiful building houses one of the world's greatest sculpture collections, perfectly displayed in an easily visited space. It is full of incomparable masterpieces from the Italian baroque and neo-classical periods. Just go, and be blown away.

A must when in Rome. The Borghese was by far my favourite part of our trip to Rome (surpassing even the Vatican museums/St Peter's Basilica and the Colosseum). It showcases incredible works by Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael, and many more. The beautifully decorated villa itself would be worth the entry fee even with all the sculptures and paintings removed. The audio guide was very good (a bit more focused on history than technique) and each room had laminated leaflets identifying all the works and describing the most important ones (including the ceilings). The fact that only 360 people can enter the gallery in each 2-hr time slot makes the experience so much more enjoyable. Don't forget you must pre-reserve your tickets by phone or online before visiting. Also, if you make a bee-line to the second floor and do the painting gallery before the sculptures on the first floor you will have even fewer spectators to contend with. My only complaint? 2 hours isn't nearly long enough to view this collection! Make sure you arrive 30 min before your reservation time to pick up tickets and grab your audio guide (available 20 min before your reservation time) before checking your bag (all must be checked) for the shortest lines.
Bernini. My wife loves Bernini's sculptures, and so this was a must for us. Be sure to purchase tickets in advance.
Incredeble Bernini sculptures. After passing through some very strict security, this museum has the most incredible examples of Bernini's work. The lifelike figures from marble are amazing.

Highlight of visit. First visit here despite third trip to Rome. Worth the pre booking as numbers are lower and the atmosphere more calm than other "attractions". Took a taxi there from Piazza del Popolo @ €9 for 3 persons. Stress free so worth it. A great guided tour by "Felix" who gave us enough info to keep us up beat and keen to be there. His style was relaxed but knowledgeable and witty. Excellent ambassador. Had brunch in the cafe which was very good and not expensive for Rome. As we exited we were all agreed that it was well worth the visit. It was very hot so we caught the tourist train from the front of the gallery around the park for €3. It duly delivered us through the beautiful grounds back to the majestic view of the Popolo Piazza. Great photo opportunity, we descended the steps to the side and were again stress free returned to the bustle of the city. We too had worried how to get there and back - no need to. Taxi and "Disney " style train, sorted. Felix, you were great. We agree that Berninis work is remarkable. A stunning Gallery.

Super Lovely Gallery: Spend as much time there as you can.. First, you need to make reservations for an entry time. I think they are 09:00;11:00; 13:00 and 15:00. You can do it on line at the official website and it is worthwhile doing so. You can usually get in five or ten minutes before your time, but not much more.Second, understand you will have to check anything larger than a camera or a wallet at the baggage check before they will let you enter. I don't think anything has ever gone missing on them. Quite an accomplishment.Third, the bookshop/souvenir shop is a little dear, but it has stuff that you won't find anywhere else.Fourth, the coffee shop is good for arriving early, sitting with your coffee while awaiting your entry time. I like the staff there: They treat me with respect, but don't suffer fools or dumb tourists gladly.Finally, the Galleria itself is a gem. There was not a room that did not entrance and engage my teenaged granddaughter (16) or grandson (12) in one way or another. And that is a major accomplishment after weeks of concentrated exposure to history, art, culture, architecture, etc. etc.One last bit of advice: Take the time to read up ahead of time about all of the exquisite statuary, paintings , etc. that you will see as you pass thorough. The Berninis, Caravaggios, Titians all deserve more than just a passing glance. If you do take the time to do a bit of studying in advance, you will be rewarded many, many times over in terms of appreciation and understanding.So, Go and Enjoy. Two to Three unhurried hours is just right for a visit. And you will want to go back again for more another time.
A must visit place if you like art. Great classical works of art in this place. The building itself has a lot of history. You must book as there is a 2-hour time slot and it gets booked up quickly.

A Must if You Are in Rome. Get Tickets ASAP. One of the best small galleries in the world. The Berninis are just wonderful, The David, which I think is better than Michangleo's. The Apollo and Devante is the best sculpture I have ever seen.  If you can't get tickets then you'll need to hire a guide, check with your hotel. I suggest getting the audio (assuming you do not have a guide), it is 5E. Purses and back packs need to be checked. The Borghese only allows a certain number of people into the gallery - your viewing is just two hours. Start on the second floor since most people when entering start on the first floor.On Sunday's it is free, but you still need to reserve a ticket which cost about 2E. Without the reservation, you will not be allowed on the "free" day.

Borghese highlight. City Wonders (through Viator) 3 hour tour of the Borghese Gallery and garden/park was made outstanding thanks to the passion, enthusiasm and knowledge of our guide Rebecca. 2 of the 3 of our party were ambivalent going in but Rebecca made it a thoroughly enjoyable experience. We learned a ton and got far more value than we would've had we toured the gallery on our own. Fantastic.

Guided tour. You must purchase tickets ahead of time to see this Gallery and you only have 2 hours total for your visit. We ordered a private group tour which was well worth the cost. Our guide was an Art Historian so really knew her history. We were 6 so that helps to share the cost and ability to see the gallery efficiently.

Wonderful. I added this as a last minute stop on our trip based on a friend saying I must visit. I was so glad I did. You have to purchase tickets in advance so we actually visited the same day we arrived and it was so worth it. We spent our entire time slot there. My son is 12 and he loved it. If you are not sure about visiting, make time you will love it. I would suggest and audio guide we didn't, we just read the information that was upon entering each section but I believe the audio guide would be much better so much to see.
No tickets, only pre booked. As usual in Italy many things are unclear. You must prebook tickets online. We have to wait 3 days, although we are here in person. Just a tip. Pre order tickets.

Excellent even if you don't have tickets to get inside!. Note to self. Buy Borghese Gallery tickets well ahead of time! Otherwise, silly traveler, you arrive there and find no tickets to be had for 2 weeks and can't get into the gallery. So, if you're a fan of Bernini, you may want to line up your tickets before you land in Rome. Once said, the Borghese is more than the famed gallery. The gift shop is fun, and serves good coffee. The grounds surrounding the Gallery is beautiful and a great walkabout. We were there on Earth Day and Rome's celebration was happening in the park in front of the Borghese Gallery. Live music, vendors, and everybody trying to make Rome a more sustainable and clean city were there. It was great fun and we didn't even get into see the great Bernini works. Next time...
Amazing galleri. Amazing gallery wonderful state of art work in particular Canova & Bernini. Wonderful architecture of the building also. Long queue for entry but is worth . Beautiful Rome...

Bernini Rules. If you love Michelangelo's sculptures, you have to witness the best of Bernini in this museum. It's hard to say who was a greater master of the medium. You can get closer to the work here than you can to Michelangelo, and be amazed at how marble can be transformed into flowing cloth and hair. The building looks small and the exterior doesn't hint at the amazing interiors. I didn't see this museum my previous Rome visit because I couldn't get a ticket. It's worth buying in advance. Several Caravaggio masterpieces are here as well. I recommend a tour to get the back story behind these great artists and works.

Amazing Exhibits. Booked on-line tickets for this gallery. It is time specific for your entrance so very little wait time to enter. Audio guide is a must but was difficult to co-ordinate with exhibits, probably due to my inexperience with these type of guides. They are hand held (no earphones) so clumsy to operate while taking pictures. Amazing collection of exhibits, almost as good as St. Peters Basillica and not as crowded. A guided tour could be helpful for personal touches, but information overload usually limitss my memory of what I saw and was told. The park is huge and you could spend hours walking through it but I didn't find it too exciting.

Outstanding Art Collection. No bags or water bottles of any size are allowed in the gallery so drop them off first. We found the audio guides very useful but they wanted our passports as security for them. All our ID of course was in the bags we'd dropped off. It was a frustrating start. It was a stunning museum with extraordinary Bellini sculptures. Two hours was not long enough to see everything in our time but we weren't kicked out after our two hour slot was finished.

Book a small personally guided tour to truly appreciate this gallery. This is a fantastic gallery whether you are an art buff or not. Our tour was a small personally guided 2 hour tour and this helped to connect with the paintings and sculptures a lot easier rather than just with a headset. You definitely need to book this tour a week or so in advance as the gallery can be booked out in advance and then possibly be closed on the day you were looking at going.

Fantastic Art Gallery. First, get tickets in advance and the times on the tickets are serious--if you aren't on time, you basically wasted your money. They do this for crowd control. It's a really great art collection, with sculpture, paintings, contemporary exhibits as well. The Renaissance comes alive here. And the building itself is worth the trip.

A "must visit" in Rome. A wonderful museum in the Villa Borghese Gardens. One needs to book in advance especially if you want a guided tour in English, which is worth every penny. Book online. The marble statues are breathtaking.

Be sure to book ahead to see ALL the Bernini and Caravaggio's. This gallery has many of my all-time works of art, so it's one of my favourite places on the planet.If you want to go you absolutely 100% must book your ticket in advance. You can't get in otherwise, and they won't have same-day tickets available on the door, especially during high season.If you're desperate to go and all that's left are Italian tours, book anyway. You won't get the tour, but you will get in and can skip the tour and go on your own. You could probably hire an audio guide if need be.If you're there to see works by Caravaggio, as soon as you enter turn left and you're there. We went as soon as we got in the door and had the room to ourselves. I've rarely been happier.On an side note, the Sleeping Hermaphroditus is been turned against a wall so you can't see the front of it, which is a massive shame. Not only is it (a copy of) a beautiful and important work of art that many people would love to see, the way they've positioned sends a rather unfortunate message.

Must see on your trip. The priority and museum are spectacular. We didn't need a tour just skip the line tickets. The sculpture, paintings and frescos are indescribable. If you come to robe you have to go to this historical site.

Fabulous sculptures. Have heard great things about this gallery and was not disappointed. Definitely worth the pre booked tickets. The sculptures in particular were amazing - the rape of Prosepina was well worth the ticket price alone.
Rome visit.. If you are interested in art works this is worth a visit. The surrounding gardens are also worth alook although not in summer.

Excellent. The villa and the artworks are on par with the best exhibits I've seen anywhere. The rooms are so crammed with treasures and over the top decor you hardly know where to look first. A guided tour is highly recommended as you'll get far more out of the visit by knowing the stories behind the art. Just arrive in advance, as it takes a while to check ALL your things and sort your advance vouchers - and you MUST book in advance during tourist season. The only thing I found annoying was the rigid insistence that one couldn't even take a small water bottle in. When you have a dry throat condition, it's very hard to go for 2 hours in the heat with no water at all. The museum should make allowances.
One of our favorite musuems in Rome. Beautiful Bernini Sculptures on beautiful grounds. You can get a light lunch on premise and sit outside.

Just exquisite . I loved this gallery and the gardens around it. Pre book as it gets very busy. When we went the were sold out for the next 4 days. You get a timed ticket and an alloted amount of time in the gallery itself but there is more than enough time. The sculptures are some of the best around. Every room was amazing. A must see.

Amazing Gallery. If you are into sculptures, go and see this gallery. It has 4 of the 5 Bernini masterpieces and they are truly magnificent. I had a tear in my eye! The room decorations are masterpieces in their own right! You have to book in advance and get a 2 hour time slot. Be there early to avoid the queues but you can easily do the gallery in 90 minutes. The paintings are magnificent, but you get a bit tired as the rooms are packed. Concentrate on the Berninis and the rooms and you will not be disappointed. The Gallery is situated in a park, which offers a lovely walk from the Piazza Di Popolo to clam down from the city heat.

Wonderful Museum. It's a wonderful museum - Bernini at his best!! Remember you have to make reservations to get in! We used our Roma pass on this - just make sure they have you for correct time and date. Save some time for the park too! Make sure you pay for the audio guide - it is well worth it - if there is 2 of you - you can easily share.
well worth the visit. very interesting place. you have to pre book a time slot as you are only allowed 2 hours. there is a cafe inside & plenty of other things do do around the vicinity
Worth the visit. . Not sure why anyone would come to Rome and not visit this Gallery. The sculptures by Bernina were amazing.

Chaotic, disorganised, but great art. Came here with family. Bernini's David is stunning. But the organisation of the place is a real mess. We collected our pre-booked tickets and wandered around the building on the outside looking with other ticket-holders for a door to get in, there was no door. Poor instructions. Disinterested staff.
Bernini,Bernini,Bernini. And Caravaggio. What a collection. Some of the most famous Bernini sculptures anywhere. And some equally wonderful Caravaggio paintings. Take a tour, well worth it.

Just great!. Amazing place. Had read about it before visiting, but was still amazed with this place. They allow a limited number of people at a time which is great as it is not overcrowded. A must visit when in Rome!
Book in advance. With only a 2 hour window, we took an English tour. It was good; however if you are v cultured and knowledgeable then buy the guide and go back after you read it!

Use the laminated sheets in each room if the Borghese. Each room has two laminated sheets on a stand in a corner that tell you about the art - one for the ceiling, one for the pictures. Use them! They make the museum much more interesting, otherwise you don't really know what you're seeing, as each picture is not marked. Also, make sure you go upstairs. My husband walked the downstairs rooms and thought that was it. Go up the spiral staircase for all the art on the second floor.

Beautiful art museum for the whole family . We ordered the tickets online, because it's not possible to buy tickets at the museum. This has the big advantage that the museum is not crowded! We spent 1 hour with our 3 teenagers which enjoyed it also because the museum is not too big: one floor with statues and one floor with paintings. It's a good idea to start first on the second floor with the paintings. If you like art, don't miss this beautiful museum!

Meh.... In my personal opinion, the tour of the villa itself was way overrated. The history of the Borghese family and specific art in every room was very lengthy, sometimes up to what felt like a 15 minute history lesson of one piece. Entirely too long for me. It felt like they were more interested in justifying the ridiculous amount of money we spent on the event than giving us the time to look and inquire about other pieces totally ignored in the room. If you've every been lucky enough to visit the Louvre or the D'Orsay, it's not that interesting...Sorry.
Really interesting. Only so many visitors allowed in on time slots. Well worth a visit, it's a beautiful building. Maybe worth preordering tickets as when we arrived we couldn't get in

Don't Miss this Museum - Book ahead!. There are a lot of amazing museums in Rome to visit. However, I loved my experience at the Borghese Gallery. Since they don’t want to get overwhelmed by people, you have a timed entrance and exit. This aspect only makes the experience much more enjoyable, as you are not being jostled on every side by other people. The art collection is truly extraordinary and provide excellent examples of the art for the periods. The sculptures are the thing to see – breathtaking.Advice: Make sure to book your tickets ahead of schedule. We had the first time slot at 9am and the museum had already sold out for the day.

Must See When in Rome. It will require some planning in advance, but the Galleria Borghese should be on everyone's Rome itinerary. As noted in other reviews it is a little off of the normal tourist track, and you do need to make a reservation in advance for a two hour visiting block, but it is worth it to see an amazing collection of sculpture and paintings in a relaxed, non -rushed setting. Indeed, this is a collection that compares against any other in the world. It is housed in a beautiful villa in a large park in Rome.We had no difficulty making our reservation online two days before, but I understand that since we went mid-August when many locals were on vacation it may have been a little easier. Make sure you make your reservation through the Rome museums website instead of the commercial websites that will pop up if you do a google search for the museum. After making your reservation, you need to go to the ticket counter in the lower level to pick up your tickets, check your bags, and go to the bathroom of you need to. There is also a small bookshop and cafe on the lower level. Your ticket allows entry during a two hour block of time, and most people arrive a little early and line up at the main doors.We found two hours to be plenty to view the collection at a leisurely pace in the two story villa. In fact, we were done after about 1 1/2 hours of leisurely viewing. We found the first few rooms to be a little crowded when we entered, but after that the crowds thinned out which allowed for a very pleasant viewing experience. Having come from the Vatican Museum that morning which was wall-to-wall people, this was an extremely pleasurable experience. Others have mentioned the contents of the collection, let me just say it is world-class and spectacular. The first floor rooms are magnificent and contain most of the sculpture along with some of the artwork. The second floor is mostly artwork. There is a winding staircase from the first to second floors which may be difficult for some, but there is a small elevator operated by staff for those who are mobility impaired. The gallery is located in the Villa Borghese, the second largest park in Rome. When you are finished with the Galleria, the park contains lots of other things to do. You can ride a mini train around the park to other museums, rent 4 wheel bikes, or walk the grounds. A pleasant way to spend half a day in Rome away from the crowds.

A few highlights for a smaller gallery.. This museum houses the Rape of Proserpine, Apollo and Daphne by Bernini as well as a famous sculpture of Napoleon's exhibitionist sister, Pauline. The rest is standard museum art fare unless you are an avid art student. You must buy tickets in advance (we bought ours on their internet site a month prior) for an assigned two hour period. You must be present at your appointed hour to get in. Pick up your tickets at the ticket office with your voucher about 15 minutes prior. If you didn't buy tickets in advance you probably won't get in. I saw people being turned away. They are strict on even taking in small bags but make a bag check available for free. The facility has a decent cafeteria for snacks. The herds all line up pushing and shoving to get in first but there's no rush. Two hours is plenty of time to see everything and do a little studying as well. And if you hang back, they all clear out so you can see everything without the crowds. Unless you are going there to see something specific as we did and have an extra two hours to spend, the Vatican and Capitoline museums will give you plenty more to absorb for about the same expense.
superb collection. A visual delight , ours was a very short tour , would advise more planning in advance . The gardens within which located is a great treat by itself

Rome Summer 2016. Another MUST if in Rome. Reservations are mandatory and if you know you are going, book in advance. We got a guide, and he was incredible! I cannot say enough good things about this gallery!

Loved it. Worth coming but be sure to book and print your tickets before you arrive. You must queue to pick the tickets up underneath the building (near the shop) then head up to the galleries. Bags must be put in the cloak room for storage. This was a very interesting gallery, loved the Carravagio paintings and the marble sculptures.We got on the small train around the park afterwards which was fun

DO NOT MISS THIS-MUST BOOK FIRST!. This was one of those days where you really didn't want to go but dare I say was almost life changing!I have never been so mesmerised walking into a gallery , an emotional experience.The beauty , stunning -to hard to comprehend on one visit .Will lock it in for next time as well.You will not regret a visit. We did have to book a week in advance at the time .

Borghese gallery. We loved this gallery. You will need a timed ticket but we were not rushed through. The sculptures are magnificent. It was also easy to get to. I think this was my favorite site on the trip

beautiful home- imagine the parties!. Buy tickets in advance from their website, not from " skip the line' websites, and be there 20-30 minutes early to check your purse, your backpack, your selfie stick, etc. Take a guided tour which is only a few euros more and well worth it. The collection is lovely, in a city of museums, this is a jewel. The Bernini sculptures are my favorite part of it. The gardens are a cool breezy walk for a few quiet moments in hectic Rome.

Beautiful Art Poorly Displayed. Yes, the Borghese Gallery has an amazing art collection, including Bernini's haunting "Rape of Prosperpina" and David, as well as works by Caravaggio. Unfortunately, it is also crowded, hot, poorly lit and the artwork poorly marked. You must book a tour in advance, and even though access is by timed entry, it's crowded. We went in the late afternooon, and I would highly recommend visiting in the morning. Be advised that the tour begins with a very steep climb up a 2-story circular staircase with little ventilation. You will have to check all bags before entry.
PLACE TO ENJOY. The gardens are really beautiful. The sculptures at the back of the Palace unfortunately have been replaced with cement figures in resemblance of the original sculptures.

Fascinating collection. The building and gardens themselves are beautiful, as are the paintings and sculptures. This is definitely worth a visit for those into Renaissance art, perhaps not so much for those who prefer modern or impressionist styles. However, some of the artwork is quite amusing if you look closer at the faces or details.. Definitely worth a visit to fit in some culture, or some low key laughs!

Great museum but bad customer service!. Borghese Gallery is an amazing place. However, if you need help, employees are more interested to talk to each other than service to customer. I think the organisation would need a serious training for their employees. However, our guide was wonderful and I really enjoyed the 2 hours visit. Our guide had a degree in history of art and was passionate about it. I really recommend a guided visit.
Best art gallery in Rome. A must see in Rome! The art collection is extensive and the villa is jaw dropping. Audio guide recommended.

Magnificent Borghese. My favorite part of the Borghese Gallery or the Borghese Gardens next door. Obviously, gardens are best viewed in spring, summer and partially into fall. Summer would be optimum, but the crowds of tourists can detract from the beauty of the setting. My favorite thing to do is to pack a picnic lunch and bottle of wine, fine a cozy shaded spot, and enjoy the view.

Best gallery in Rome. The Vatican Museum may win in terms of overall size, but the layout and visitor limits make this place a must hit. I'd even say go here instead of the Vatican Museum if you're short on time. But! You need a reservation here (easy to do online, or over the phone).There are some absolutely amazing classical masterpieces here to view, and because of the visitor limits you wont be run over by tour groups or other mobs of visitors.Arrive on time though, because you only get two hours for your scheduled time, and you'll need every minute to truly appreciate the collection.Also, the audio guide is only 5 Euro, and adds some very useful information about many of the rooms or art pieces. Unfortunately it's phone shaped, so you can't share headphones with a friend.https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g187791-d190133-r409464636-Villa_Borghese-Rome_Lazio.html#

Beautiful . Spent afternoon in gardens chilling out of heat. Lovely building husband wanted to see Caravaggio we enjoyed. Walked to Pincio for views over piazza del Popolo. Roller skaters put on show 1 aged about 70 doing splits very impressed
Must see attraction in Rome.. The villa borghese in impressively beautiful and the gallery which is located inside is spectacular because you can find impressive sculptures and paintings.
Amazing Villa and splendid space, worth to be visited. The most beautiful frescos, splendid space, amazing garden, it is beautiful visist. Must be pre-booked It's very close to the Piazza Del Popolo.

Bad Lighting . While I enjoyed getting to see all the fabulous art the lighting was awful. Some of the paintings were nearly impossible to make out because the lighting was so bad. The paintings that you could make out in the bad lighting were wonderful. The sculptures were my favorite part and I enjoyed getting to see them. We did buy tickets through a company ahead of time and I am glad we did because they were sold out for the day we went.

I had no idea how beautiful it was and WHO was in this gallery!. I am so glad that someone told me not to miss the Borghese on one of my first trips to Rome. It was small enough to really see things, not overwhelming but had way more than I expected!

A must see in Rome. The art collections here are fantastic. Amazing sculptures and paintings. We purchased our tickets online which I highly recommend (no lines and no threat of being sold out). The number of people let in at a time is limited and therefore so much easier to enjoy the collection without the hoards of people. We all did the Audio Tour and it was very informative and helped us navigate through and pace ourselves for our allotted 2 hour tour time. A must not miss when you are in Rome.

One of the best places to visit in Rome. Absolutely breathtaking. What makes the experience so special is that tickets are limited to a specific number of visitors each day which makes for a very pleasant relaxed visit where you can really appreciate hhe art and surroundings, unlike the jam packed elbows out frustration of, say, the Vatican. Tip: buy your tickets well in advance as they are hard / impossible to get on the day at peak times. I got the audio guide as i was solo and it was cheap and v useful. Note, ALL bags must be checked in, even handbags.

A must-see museum!. Everybody traveling to Rome should stop at the Museo di Villa Borghese. Please note you should book ahead of time. And the museum sits in one of the most beautiful parks of the city, with lots to do, including the Globe Theatre for Shakespeare plays, a puppet theatre for kids, or simply strolling or renting a bicycle in the park.

Very nice place!. Nice museum, with some excellent paintings and sculptures. Very long way to the Villa Borgese so be prepared to walk at least half an hour in the park. You should book the tickets from before or else you may not be able to enter!!
A must see. Make your reservations and GO! The art collection here paired with the way it is displayed is a wonder

Wednesday evening discounted price. We loved the Borghese Gallery. It was pleasant to walk around without the hoards of people that were in the Vatican museums. I saw my best piece of sculpture of the trip here too. It was Pluto and Persephone by Bernini. I am no expert, but the way the sculptor was able to recreate a hand pressing onto bare flesh and make it look real from a chunk of marble is quite incredible.You have to book in advance to come here, and at the moment you can get discounted tickets on a Wednesday evening at 5pm which is a good time to come. No bags are allowed in at all. You have to check them in after you have collected your tickets. No water allowed either, which is a bit silly considering the heat at the moment in Rome.

Only for the art enthusiasts. Was first ripped off by getting a "skip the line" ticket. Then the person working the line had no idea what I was talking about with such tickets, and we had to wait in line anyway. After being in France and Italy for 2 weeks, it was just another art museum, and also not impressive. The Borghese Villa where the gardens are were not well kept. No flowers and lots of weeds and dead grass. You also cannot being any sort of bag with you into the museum.

Good place to visit.. Whilst we was in this park we hired some bikes where you sit side by side which was great fun and they had a battery so it wasn't so hard to pedal. The views where fantastic from this park.

Book Guided Tour if Possible. In spite of some initial confusion over where to meet our guide (bottom floor, check in where you purchase audio guide) we thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Our guide was knowledgeable and very engaging. We got so much more from the visit thanks to this service. Be sure to check your bags before entering or you will be sent back. DO bring your camera. Do not enter through the main entrance of you book a tour.

One of the best. Went here on holiday. Simply amazing amount of high quality art. Well organized and the taped tour guide did a nice job covering the art and the History behind the art. I preferred this over the Vatican Museums. I have to say the humorous part was the Cardinal looks a lot like Chef Boyarde.

A must-see in Rome. This museum features spectacular art in a beautiful, opulent palace, and it was among the highlights of our trip to Rome. Reservations need to be made online, in advance, for a particular time. I'd recommend making your reservations several days ahead, at least. The number of visitors allowed into the museum at any one time is limited, so it never feels too crowded (this will be a relief to those of you who struggled through a packed house at the Vatican museums!). Please keep in mind that this is a relatively small museum, so there's no need to rush, even with the two-hour limit! Relax and enjoy the many masterpieces here.

Very ugly experience for disabled visitors. During my last visit to Rome with my family, I had an unexpectedly bad experience at the Borghese museum. Since my daughter uses a manual wheelchair, we always check the accessibility of the sites we are about to visit. In the "Gallery Borghese" official site I couldn't find any information. I searched in other sites and found out that a wheelchair user can visit only the ground floor so we decided to give it a try.Upon arriving at the site we were told to go to the back door and press the doorbell. An employee opened the door and, when I showed him my daughter and explained the situation, he seemed perplexed. Finally, he allowed only me to get inside and then closed the door firmly on the others' faces. I was told to go to a reception desk where I was informed that we could get a "pass" for my daughter by providing documentation about her disability. I hadn't brought along any medical documents because : a) I was not so informed by the museum's official site b) all her medical certificates are written in Greek c) my daughter and I have visited other European museums and we were never asked for any medical documents and d) my daughter's disability is more than obvious.I offered to sign any official statement they wanted but it wouldn't do.I offered to pay for our visit (my daughter and one escort) but there were no tickets available. I admit that the girls at the reception desk were sympathetic but a certain lady, who apparently was the chief, was adamant.It was either the certificate or nothing! Furius, I was driven to the back door which was, once more, practically slammed on my face. Our day was so marred by the incident that we left the site immediatelly without taking a stroll in the gardens as we had planned.By writing this down I want to poin out at the museums' lack of consideration to people with special needs. Disability is not a choice. Nobody asks for special favours. Politeness, delicacy and flexibility is all that is required!

great but.... entrance with a wheelchair is restricted to the first floor. so some people will miss bernini's self-portrait and the boy removing a splinter from his foot. I could have scored 5 stars, but missing out on the top-floor reduced it to 3.
This is a MUST !. Quiet , nature and a really treasure of art , this can be a description in a few words of Villa Borghese . I'm sure you'll be delighted by this experience .

Important Gallery to see. I would highly recommend visiting this gallery if you are into art however if you are not (like me) I think it is still worth visiting because it has some landmark artwork, a bit like seeing the Colossuem.Do's and don'ts1.Book ahead of time - well ahead of time- if have a Roma pass, you can call and book over the phone2. Don't take children or teenagers 3. No bags or hats to gallery as you will have to queue separately to put them in a safe.4.turn up 10- 15 minutes earlier5. Rent and audio guide (5 euro) from the front disk upon entering

Incredible sculptures and artwork...a must see!. Borghese Gallery is an amazing treasure of numerous masterpieces, especially exquisitely carved Bernini sculptures. Reservation needs to be made in advance via phone to gain entrance to Borghese Gallery, even for those who have Roma Pass. Make sure to call in few weeks in advance to secure reservation, especially if visiting during the peak summer season. The Gallery is air conditioned and the audio guide is quite helpful as well. The gallery layout/ directions can be a bit confusing so make sure you get the map before entering in order to follow the audio guide clearly.

Beautiful. You'll have to book a session here and a time slot to visit, but don't be put off - it's absolutely worth it. The sculptures by Bernini on the ground floor are incredibly special. The gallery also has helpful guides in English in each room. The gardens are stunning and it's worth spending time here - I'd recommend taking a picnic as there aren't many good cafes or places for lunch.

Wonderful. A wonderful museum not to be missed on your visit to Rome. The artwork is amazing with three floors of incredible masterpieces. The Bernini sculptures are incredible works of art which I will remember forever!

Excellent museum experience. Be sure you make reservations in advance, we did it on- line without difficulty a few days before. You are allowed 2 hours inside which is enough time but get there early to pick up tickets, check backpack, etc. Cameras are allowed inside. Be sure you get the earphones which makes the museum an excellent experience even for neophytes. We rented bikes and rode around the park- not worth it as it not very big and the park is mediocre at best.

Incredible. . We couldn't actually get in to the Gallery but we spent hours walking in the Gardens of Borghese which offer you some incredible sights. Beautiful statues, a gorgeous lake where you can hire row boats and an open air cinema. Stunning.

Impressive!. Visiting this gallery was one of our highlights in Rome. The collection is amazing with numerous masterpieces, especially those of Bernini. I do suggest purchasing your tickets in advance as they have timed visitation which is very strict and I recommend that you are not late. The museum is on a smaller scale than many of the other attractions, so is not overwhelming. We found the walk through the park and the visit relaxing as well.

Air conditioned sculptures and artwork. What a nice treat that this is air conditioned in July. The English guided tour was worth the minimal fee and you still had time to poke around before the 2 hour ticket expired. Be sure to purchase tickets before you go as they sell out and this is artwork worth seeing.

City wonders tour with Becky. Took the borghese gallery tour run by city wonders but booked through Viator. Was lucky enough to get Becky for guide. She's from the UK and is super knowledgeable and passionate about art. It was a wonderful tour. Don't know if you request a particular guide, but if you can, get Becky.

A wonderful experience!. Book tickets in advance to avoid disappointment, they limit how many go in at a time, but you have a very good experience when you do. Arrive early for prepaid tickets! The gallery was beautiful, and was made accessible to novices (like myself) by the in depth information provided, would definitely go again, one of my highlights on the trip to Rome!

Great Museum Experience. First off, you get a 2-hour time slot to visit the Borghese. This sounds strange, but it is a terrific system. The museum essentially empties and you get to move about w/ a limited number of people. The building/collection is small enough that the 2-hours is more than enough time (we spent about 70 minutes). And you don't have to buy tickets through the tourist trap agencies that charge you way more than you need to pay. We got tickets through our hotel the day before.The collection is in general pretty interesting, but the multiple Bernini sculptures are fabulous and alone worth the visit. It is also set in a great park setting, so plan on spending time roaming about on the old palazzo grounds. This really is a must-see in Rome.

Book early-well worth the visit.. After seeing this place in our guide book and reading about pre-booking I found myself booking the tickets on the plane to ensure we got to see during our trip. Definitely worth a visit for classic sculptures and paintings. You get a 2 hour window, we were there for about 1.5 hours. Lovely little café in the basement. Will have to check in all your belongings in the cloakroom before heading up so be sure to arrive 20-25 minutes early to pick up tickets and deposit. Gorgeous building and well worth the visit.

A Blast from the past. interested in amazing works by Bernini and the like? The Borghese gallery has a terrific collection . Bernini's sculptures mesmerize even the most jaded museum goer. Reservations are a necessity in summer months.

Phenomenal Rooms. Thoroughly enjoyed this beautiful collection of paintings and well appointed rooms. The sculpture collection is impressive. Bring almost nothing with you because everything has to be checked. All visits are timed. Wonderful experience.

A nice museum away from the crowd. The Borghese Gallery is off the "beaten trail" and a nice reprieve from other tourist crowed venues. The surrounding garden and pathways through vegetated areas were a welcome change of pace. Reservations are required so get them online.

Renaissance Masterpieces- what a beauty . Borghese Gallery it seemed to me initially difficult to reach,because you need online reservation and they ask you to choose a specific hour for coming and,honestly,I don't like to have a strict schedule in my holiday.But ,after I see the gallery,I realised that is good to be scheduled,for seeing all the masterpieces relaxed and without being in a crowd at every step.Be careful about the way to the gallery,we choose to go by crossing the park.It's a beautiful park,but in these hot days of august it's not the best way to reach the gallery.It's an entry from the street near to the gallery,but it is not so well flagged-I recommend Google maps-.You can admire a lot of Renaissance masterpieces from paintings of Rafael Sanzio to sculptures of Bernini.For Renaissance lovers,it's a must.
Dull. Dull. Lots of statues and paintings. Not at all memorable and the gardens are very poor. Not worth a visit unless its of special interest to you

Among my fave places in Rome. It is a small nice gallery in a huge park.. Both worth visiting.. The gallery has nice sculptures and paintings specifically in the first floor... But do book ahead...The park is nice for a stroll, has nice lake with boats and ducks and geese. Park is very close to Plaza Spagna with the famous Spanish Steps..
Not to miss. What a wonder among many other in Rome and the world! Magnificent venue, magnificent works of art, amazing, touching. Do nit forget to prebook, impossible to buy tickets locally.

Absolutely amazing. My wife bought tickets for the guided tour in advance. We arrived thirty minutes early as recommend by previous reviewers. We checked are bags and picked up our tickets and audio devices. The tour began approximately ten minutes after the hour we were scheduled to go in. The guide was awesome and my wife and I are so thankful for taking the guided tour. We learned a lot and after the tour we had about forty five minutes to roam on our own. This is an absolute must see.
Amazing museum. Take the time and schedule a visit to this museum. You will not regret it! We went in April and it was not too crowded. You should purchase your tickets ahead of time.

Need to buy tickets in advance!. We walked to the museum only to find out that they were sold out for the day (no crowds though) and could only preorder tickets for the next day. Wish we had known beforehand as we wouldn't have bothered as we couldn't go any other day. Disappointing. Tickets must be bought online as well!

Brilliant sculpture collection but beware the stairs!. Wasn't sure what to expect from the Borghese gallery but the sculptures blew me away. The rather pricey audio guide was a bit of a waste because most of us struggled to find the audio numbers.Also, there is no warning about the stairs! There are a lot of winding stairs and no place to stop for a breath. Terrifying. The rooms are beautiful and worth looking at for the stunning architecture and ceilings.We didn't get to visit the gardens but they are supposed to be outstanding.
needs reservation. you need to buy your tickets in advance. This museum worths the visit. Impresive Berninis sculpture collection.

Beautiful Building housing beautiful art.. We arrived in Rome that morning and could not check into our hotel until the afternoon. We were staying 5 minutes from the Borghese Gallery. I had read about it before we went and knew to book and buy our tickets before we left the US. That process was very easy. We walked around the Villa Borghese(park) for a while before we were scheduled to go in. It is important to note that you must check all bags before you go in which is free, but before you go I would make sure that anything of importance is not left in your bags. I am sure the staff were trustworthy, but I think that is wise to not leave money etc in your bag. The Gallery is housed in the once home of Cardinal Borghese who became Pope. The building alone is gorgeous and the art work inside just stunning. There are some works by Bernini and Raphael in there. I am not up on art so much, but I enjoyed seeing all of it. It isn't that big of a museum and you have a limited time to see it, but the time is plentiful. The kids seem to like it too. We rented a few headphones to tell us about what we were seeing. The only negative I had was the restroom was not very clean. I am speaking of the one inside the museum. There is one downstairs in the basement where you check your bag that is very clean. It is attended and you have to show your ticket to use it. This is to keep the people who are just in the park from using it I would guess. There are upper levels which aren't clearly marked, but don't miss going up.

liked it better than the Vatican. the frescoes are not so impressive as in the Vatican but the statues (marble and mixed minerals) and the roman mosaic are so fine that one can have the impression that the person/s from the statues would move or if you do not pay close attention you can miss that the 'painting on the wall' is not actually a painting but a roman mosaic (see attached photos VB Statue & VB RMosaic). do not miss to see the garden behind the villa - barely there is a visitor and the place is so nice that one wants to stay just to admire the plants and the fountain.piece of advice: make the reservation online for your visit because you can easily fall in the situation where you go to the villa but it is 'sold out'. the reason is simple - though the park is large and nice to have a walk, the villa itself can accept only a limited number of visitors so everybody can enjoy the many pieces of artwork and to avoid overcrowding.also, be at least 30 min in advance before your scheduled time, because there is still a queue just to reach the ticket booth and show your reservation to get your tickets.from the villa you have easy access to the Spanish Steps (via the metro's underground tunnels) and if you continue Piazza di Popolo.with an open heart I would strongly recommend this visit to anyone who enjoys art

Excellent collection of renaissance art!. Second visit and was impressed just as much as the first time. Don't forget to book in advance as you are required to have a reservation in advance. Great collection of Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini sculptures, the most breath taking of which is his version of Apollo and Daphne. There are paintings as well by Raffaelllo and Corravagio. 2 hours or a bit less covers the museum and my whole family enjoyed the visit. None of us are particularly "art lovers" but still really appreciated the place!

I am now a Bernini Groupie :). After researching my trip to Rome the Borghese Gallery popped up as a Must See. I bought tickets through their website a few months in advance and had no problems when I arrived. YOU NEED TO BUY TICKETS IN ADVANCE. I wouldn't miss this. The Bernini statues were breathtaking and one of the highlights of my trip to Rome. My daughter and I bought the audio tour and really enjoyed it. You may take pictures, but no flash.

Nice museum but too much art for beginners. Nice museum with some beautifull pieces of Art. However I am a Art noob and because of that there are a bit too many pieces of Art to see the real good ones between them (part from the obvious works from Bernini etc.

Wonderful Gallery. The Borghese Gallery has the best Bernini's sculptures. The Apollo and Daphne sculpture is a masterpiece. It also have many other wonderful sculptures and paintings. It is a must see during your stay in Rome.

A gem of a museum. This gets busy, but we were lucky to get some ticvkets immediately. Some real historical gems that take your breath away. Lovely gardens around the gallery. We spent most of the day in the museum and the gardens.

Place to see top view of Roma and relax walk. Big green nice garden in heart of Roma. Also place to see top view of Roma. Pizza di Popolo. We walk down to it and turn to Via di Corso where is the famous shopping street.
Very perfect in spring and autum as garden turn to blossom or in yellow.

Civilised Viewing!. The number of visitors is controlled so it means that it's possible to view without a crush which in Rome during the summer is a real bonus. There are some very fine examples in all the rooms and the painted walls are stunning. Definitely worth a visit - the park itself is very attractive plus the gardens behind the villa are well tended. Even the cafe was quite a find as it was relatively quiet - we found somewhere to sit, and quite reasonable. We booked on line and as it was all in Italian, Google translate came in handy. A pleasant few hours in the cool with some visually stunning sights.

A MUST SEE GALLERY. Traveling with a group of art historians. We were totally in awe of the famous and beautiful statues,paintings, frescos well, just everything. The fee is well worth it. Give yourself ample time to savor your surroundings. FEE IS WELL WORTH THEEXPERIENCE. YOURSELF TIME TIME TO SAVOR YOUR

Great gallery, but limited time to visit!. Wonderful place to visit. We purchased our ticket in advance as it is mandatory. We chose the reserved the time slot from 13h00 to 15h00. The problem is that even if we got there in advance, there was a huge waiting line to validate our ticket and only one person to do the work. The result is that our allowed time was greatly reduced. At the set time the guard bluntly told us to leave immediately.

Phenomenal gallery - BOOK IN ADVANCE!. Bernini is one of my favourite artists so I have wanted to visit this gallery for a very long time as it holds some of his best works. I was in Rome several years ago but was unaware that you had to buy tickets for the gallery in advance so I was unable to visit it. Last month I finally made it in and it is incredibly impressive. A visit to this gallery is a must for any art lover. The collection is breathtaking and the audioguide is very informative and interesting. When you buy a ticket you must choose a two hour time slot on the day you wish to visit. It is worth factoring in some time to visit the expansive gardens in which the gallery is situated.
An Unexpected delight - huge variety or gaes and exhibits. The variety in the museum is what marks it out for me. The statues are a particular feature - making hard marble look like ptastcine
Was not disappointed. It is kind of hard to get in, but that is a good thing because it avoids the large crowds like some of the other museums. They only give you 2 hours but that was plenty of time.
Impressive sculptures . Worth the visit. Sculptures are truly magnificent. You can do a quick visit or linger as long as you'd like. You will not be disappointed.
Lovely Exhibition. Worth seeing, beautiful collection of Caravaggio paintings and marble sculptures. Gardens were a bit disappointing as not kept very well.

AMAZING!. Make sure to buy your tickets in advance because times sell out fast. I got ours through CityDiscovery online. It was easy and prices were good. Worth spend the time to see, it is beautiful and the gardens are a wonderful place for an afternoon picnic.

Borghese Gallery. One of the most beautiful displays of art anywhere. Lots of amazing statues. Requires a reservation well in advance but that is because they limit the number of people that come in at once, which makes it much more enjoyable. The two hours you are allotted is an ample amount of time to enjoy the incredible display of art.

Book Borghese Ahead!. The Borghese is filled with treasures, and you will love it if you plan accordingly. 1. YOU MUST get your tickets ahead of time. MUST. GET. IN ADVANCE. The museum only allows a certain number of people in at a time. And, for only a limited amount of time. And, at a certain time. 2. Once you have your reservation and tickets, be sure to be on time as they let in the group. 3. If you want to have more time in the Borghese, I think signing up for a guided tour is the way to go. 4. Because of the limited time, move through the rooms at a purposeful clip. If you can, go to the second floor first and then on to the first floor - to avoid the crowds. 5. There is a nice little cafe and gift shop. Also, there is a little train (not working the day we were there) that will take you around the garden. 6. You have to check in your belongings, but if you ask for a clear plastic bag, you can keep your smaller items with you. Also, there is no flash photography. However, you may take pictures. We checked our cameras and learned this lesson the hard way. 7. There is a very small elevator for wheelchairs and those unable to navigate stairs. But, only two people in the elevator at a time, and one of those people is a museum staff person. 8. I don't know why, but there is NO A/C in the Borghese. Just a few small fans to blow around the hot air. So, plan accordingly. Wearing your new fabulous Italian leather ensemble not recommended. 9. Clean restrooms. Non-smoking.

Beautiful, but my goodness so many statues!. Be forewarned - you must have made advance reservations/tickets to get in here. So many people approached without them and were sent away. We were lucky, we knew this and just went through the beautiful park to look at the outside of the building, when a nice lady gave us three free tickets since her party didn't appear. So, we went in. Beautiful building and many beautiful examples of Italian art -- Caravaggio paintings, for example. Beautiful statue of David with his slingshot. Egypt room which shows the Italian Egypt craze (think Cleopatra and Antony). The park surrounding it is very nice as well - rent a little electric pedal cart and you can cover a lot of ground. Great views of Piazza de Popolo for photographers!
Must see. The gallery was awesome, could be the best of ones I have ever seen. Only one tip is that you should get the ticket before your visit in the basement of the building. €15.5/person

Go early . Go early and reserve tickets ahead of time. They were booked through until September. Caravaggio was amazing, the tours were a little aggravating but to see the art was worth it. We nixed the metro, it was a nice walk from Roma Termini.

Wonderful!. Really recommendable art collection of Bernini, Carrevaggio. Art at its best, especially the ceilings. It's truely amazing. Admire the statue of David and Apollo and Daphne and more.
