You have to make a reservation for the tickets as they only allow app. 200 people inside at the same time. This is a good thing, otherwise it's too crowded.The Galeria is situated in a nice park. You can spend an entire day here. Really worthwhile!
Spectacular art..tour guide is ideal. Wonderful collection of art which was made more so by having a tour guide from Walks Of Italy to point out and explain the best pieces.

Quite a collection of art!. It was an incredible experience to not only see the artwork, but how a room was designed around all of it!! After the artwork, the grounds are amazing - rent a bike and make it even more romantic!!

Beautiful yet tiring. When I arrived the gallery the queue was long and unfortunately they were out of tickets so it's better to buy yours in advance.
To get to the toilet you should pay or show your ticket.
Cabs stop next to exit entrance so you will not have difficulty getting to Spanish steps or Trevi Fountain.

Fabulous but book in advance.. This was one of the wonders of Rome in particular the Bernnini statues do not miss this gallery. Be warned however you cannot just turn up and get in..... tickets need to be booked in advance and you will not get in without a pre booking. (We saw numerous people being turned away disappointed). You also will not be allowed to take any bags inside...even handbags!! but there is a free cloakroom where these cab be left. Photography is allowed however but no flash, so enjoy this treasure.
Bellissima. The Borghese Gallery is an unique example of Villa and Museum. A great collection and a beautiful Villa. You can't missit while you're in Rome.

Tickets from the basement and book ahead.. Second visit here and hope for a third one day. Beautiful rooms with some stupendous artworks. Book ahead tho, as we made one wasted visit and had to come back another day. They will gibe you a two-hour slot. Ticket office is in the basement. They unhelpfully waited for us to go in the entrance before sending us back outside and down to biglietteria, so signage could be better and staff not the friendliest.

A Must See in Rome. We return to this gallery every time that we come to Rome. It is amazing! You must make a reservation so have your hotel person do it. Take an audio guide with you unless you are lucky enough to book a tour. The paintings and the Bernini sculptures are amazing: notably Paulina, Daivid with his sling shot, Neptune chasing Prospina, and my favourite Daphne being pursued by Appollo.This is really worth a visit. GO!
GREAT AFTERNOON. This was one of my favorite afternoon excursions in Rome. Great guide and wonderful art work to see.

Bernini!. Get your tickets in before you travel; tickets sell out weeks in advance. This is one of the finest galleries in Rome. While the Vatican is crowded and too large to enjoy in a single visit, the staff at the Borghese limit entrance to a certain, small number of tourists at a time. You can enjoy the masterworks of Bernini without getting elbowed or having a selfie stick shoved in your face. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and consider it a must do if you're in Rome.

Context travel tour of Borghese Gallery. The Borghese Gallery is a small once private museum next to the gardens with a great number and variety of paintings and sculptures from the collection of Cardinal Scipione Borghese. There are works by Caravaggio and Titian, and Raphael's Entombment of Christ along with many others. We used Context Travel, and guide, Teresa, was wonderful. We learned many things about the work in the gallery, and many others in and around Rome. This tour took about 2.5 hours and cost 200$ plus tip. We felt it was worth every penny and was one of the best attractions/tours we had in Rome. Of course, one will want to bring a bottle of water and wear comfortable walking shoes. No flash is allowed in the museum, and some rooms do not allow photography at all. but of course, you should just enjoy the museum, and if you want photos, they offer several lovely books which include photography of their collection

Great park, beautiful art. Galleria Borghese is situated inside of Villa Borghese, which is a beautiful park in the heart of Rome. The art collection that the gallery owns is quite impressive.If you're having a rainy day in Rome, this might just be your silver lining.

Amazing collection. This private collection is amazing! It was worth the effort of making advance reservations. The 2 hr allocation was just right to be able to see all items. The bernini masterpieces were the best!

Phenomenal place for art enthusiasts. What a collection Cardinal Borghese and his family amassed!First, the Bernini masterpieces are worth the visit alone. There are plenty of reviewers who have said more so no need to repeat.The picture gallery is also fantastic, with Raphaels, Caravaggio, Titian, and more masters.Beware of the heat if you're using public transit. Also be sure to call and set up a time to visit. The general public cannot just show up since the museum is not large and they want visitors to enjoy walking around without too much of a crowd.

Amazing. Just like the Vatican this museum is massive for a villa with many artworks religious and otherwise. A long walk from the main gate. Must pre book tickets otherwise you won't get in. No bags allowed so you can store these while you are there. Many steps to the upper Levels there is a lift for the disabled. There are carts that can be rented at the main gates. There is also a small shop inside for coffee, sandwiches Etc. Hiring earphones is extra at 5 euros. Well worth a visit make sure you take water and hats in extreme hot days.

Awesome. The art here is stupendous, and you're viewing it in the house it was designed for. You do need a reservation ahead of time. Don't wait until the last minute, or you won't get one. The grounds are lovely as well. Come early and enjoy them. Don't use the Spange subway stop.

For the first time. I've been to Rome many times and have not been able to visit this museum. It was always booked in advance. This time I book several months in advance with Viator and was able to get in and have a guide in extra. It worth every penny. You can see masterpieces that are in art books in a set up that is quite unique.Another check on the bucket list!

Cannot miss this site. Gorgeous museum, manageable size, and peaceful location. Don't miss this site when you are in Rome! The Bernini sculptures are ravishing...but be sure to look at them as you will probably be so mesmerized by the intricately designed ceilings!

Plan your visit and be amazed. You'll need reservations and I recommend the tour guide option for the extra few euros. Arrive early and make sure you check your bag at the bag check. They won't allow even a purse through the metal detector at the main door. Bernini and others await within and their masterpieces are fantastic to see.

Packed full of beautiful art, but not many master pieces. Wonderful how they control the crowds, perfect group size that they release per time slot. Book ahead, it is sold out often times weeks in advance. Make sure you enjoy the surrounding park, rent a golf cart too enjoy that.
A must for art lovers!. Nowhere else you can enjoy Bernini's famous sculptures or some important Caravaggio's paintings, and above all the authentic atmosphere of Rome's glorious moments!

Great tour. We opted for the guided group tour. Our guide was amazing and bought the incredible pieces we saw to life with stories about the artists and the influence of the politics of the time on the art.Definitely get the group tour if you want to visit.

Excellent place. A must see, the building itself is impressive with the borghese villa surrounding it. Before going to the borgheze gallery you should check that it is open since they have one day per week and one additionally per month during which they are close

Amazing collection, disappointing staff. We booked the guided tour and arrived early. Because our child was in a wheelchair due to a sprained ankle, we were told to ring the side door connected by a ramp. No one there answered and we had to assist our child down to the gathering area in the basement and carry the wheelchair down the stairs. Before the tour started, an employee asked us to leave our wheelchair in the basement due to the narrowness of the elevator and brought us upstairs to get into a the museum's own wheelchair. This was a nice accommodation, but the problem was he brought us to the SECOND floor, whereas the tour starts on the FIRST floor. We showed him our tour group tickets and where wearing the radio headsets, which should have told him where to drop us off. As the starting time of the tour drew near we didn't see the rest of the tour group and became a bit worried. I asked a staff member and she said the tour will eventually come up here so just wait. Those of you who've visited know that the most interesting parts of the collection are on the first floor, which we weren't aware of at the time. When we started to hear the voice of the tour guide on the radio through the floor, I went down to check it out, and he told me to bring my family down right away so as not to miss out on the most important parts. By the time that I went upstairs, had someone bring us down in the elevator, put my child into another wheelchair, and found the tour group, we've missed almost 30 minutes of the 90 minute tour. At the end of tour, there was about 10 minutes left for us to wonder around before everyone was asked to leave to make way for the next wave of visitors (apparently the visits there are time-blocked for 2 hours), which didn't give us time to catch up on the things missed (not to mention the missed explanations). After spending 50 Euros on tickets for the three of us, plus the taxi fare, and in general planning half our day in Rome around the visit, we feel a bit robbed.When we're about to leave we found that our wheelchair was missing (!), and after searching for it they discovered that it was put into general circulation among the other wheelchairs at the museum, and someone was just about to use it for a patron, which would make it much more difficult to find. Better training or perhaps just more care by the staff would've made our visit less of a debacle. I've been somewhat forewarned by one of the other reviewers who've brought someone in a wheelchair and tried to avoid some of the pitfalls, and still encountered these problems. I won't comment much on the attitudes of the staff, except to say that they appear to be less empathetic than encountered elsewhere in Rome. ------The collection, particularly the Bernini sculptures are unforgettable. Our young tour guide was knowledgeable, humorous, and good at relating historical events and concepts to what we know today to make things instantly understandable. The tour itself (English version) is highly recommended.
Fantastico!. Traveled in 2012 . Caravaggio paintings amongst others. Not too large like other galleries. The outside gardens are very nice. Very picturesque.

One of the most beautiful art galleries in the world . My fiance and I are so glad we decided to see this Gallery. It is absolutely breath taking and fine art that just makes you in awe of talent and history captured in so many rooms! We had arrived late on the bus for the minimum 45 mins before our reservation time but got in without issues. You can't bring in any bags or small purse or water so you will need to check in (free). Coat check and reservations persons were very direct and not friendly to us though. Due to 3 long lineups to get your reserved tickets and bag check and audioguide you should try to get there before your reserved time. You get exactly 2 hrs and then security kicks you out to let the next group in. Audioguide was 5€ each and it's worth it to understand the paintings and sculpture. It was wonderful to see all the great pieces of artwork including the famous Sacred and Profane Love by Titian (in the very last room). Some suggest you to go upstairs first in your alloted time so it's not as busy. We took photos of everything (without flash) without problems. A definite must see!!!

Go there when in Rome. There has been so many good reviews of this place, and TV programs, but I do not believe anything prepares you for the actual impression. There are so many good museums in Rome that one visit cannot cover all if shorter than a month - but this one you should not miss in your first visit. It is not overwhelming, the reservation system actually benefits all, as it is not overcrowded or policed like the Vatican museums and the Sistine Chapel where the pre booking system does not decrease the crowds. The Western art since the renaissance is here, save the moderns of course - the very best of everything to the extent that a Leonardo is stuck In a corner of the upper floor. That work would probably be the main attraction in any other museum.The internet reservation system is simple and reliable, and there were several options for admission for just the next day when I tried - not like the last supper of Leonardo in Milan that that you have to book months ahead. (Clutch- you need to allow all cookies for the Visa/MC verification)And while it is true that you need to check in all backs you can have your phone and camera and take pictures freely, in contrary that my ticket info was. And going to Villa Borghese anyway is a delightful experience, so I recommend that you reserve ample time to enjoy the park while there.

Large grounds, good for a half day. Large grounds set around the villa and a lake. We took a buggy to get around which was fun. You could also spend about a half day exploring the whole place if you have the time.

Amazing art. Amazing art without the crowds, but you must book well in advance. We took a tour with City Wonders with Rebecca as our guide. She was brilliant and her love of the art and her stories kept my two teenage children interested for the whole two hours (quite a feat). You cannot bring bags into the museum, but they have a place to lock them at entrance. There is a fountain outside the entrance where you can get fresh water. The air conditioning was working when we were there. They have an elevator (small) if needed.

Beautiful --you need advance tickets...!. These galleries are filled with exceptional paintings and marble statues. Study your guidebook to be prepared for this visit. Visits are timed and you have less that an hour.  Be sure to book in advance, which you can do online.

Skip the Line Tour. This was a great art gallery to do with a guide. It's not so massive that you can see most of it in a reasonable time and learn about the paintings and statues. We really enjoyed it.

Make this a must!. Get your tickets 3 days in advance or go to Viator online and pay for skip the line pass. Otherwise you won't get a two hour pass. 1/2 hour on the top floor for the art and 1 1/2 hour on the next floor for the sculptures. In not an art major but still could appreciate the Bernini sculptures and fine art. It is wonderful. The park and gardens all around the area on the hill was a great walk. We arrived by going left up the hill from the Spanish steps and walking thru the park.
Good fun for all. The gallery is lovely and has amazing artwork, the garden itself had loads of families riding bikes etc., the grounds are lovely and are nice for a picnic!

Beautiful Artwork, Ugly Treatment from the Staff. First, you need to know that you cannot just go to the gallery and buy a ticket. You have to book at least a day (if not more) in advance, because they strictly limit the number of people allowed inside at any one time. This makes it very pleasant when you eventually get to see the artwork, because it's not wall-to-wall people and you can actually move freely and see things up close.Once you book an entrance time, you are told sternly to arrive at least 20 minutes before your reserved time, so that you can be herded around for those 20 minutes and - of course - directed to the café and gift shop to spend money while you wait. Also you cannot bring any sort of bag into the gallery, even a tiny clutch purse, so you have to check all your items. For such an elegant and cultured place, they have THE ABSOLUTE RUDEST BRAT working at the bag check. She is a surly young woman with long black hair whose life goal obviously is not to be working at a bag check desk, so she acts as bratty and rude to people as possible. Seriously, the gallery should fire her. (She was working there at 3:00 pm on Friday, July 29th.) I hope the management reads this and does something about her asap.
Glorious!. We stayed at the Clarion Princepessa just so we could be near this fabulous museum. The work of sculptor Bernini is not to be missed........!

Borghese Gallery: Be careful booking tickets on line. The Borghese Gallery is an incredible museum, worth visiting on every trip to Rome. Advance reservations are necessary and printed vouchers for the reservations made on line will be exchanged at the museum for tickets. It's recommended that visitors be at the museum at least 15 minutes before the beginning of the two-hour time slot in order to exchange vouchers for tickets. BUT: If booking on line, make sure to book through the museum's official web site and read all instructions very carefully. We mistakenly booked through a tour operator whose web site appeared at the top of our Internet search for Borghese Gallery. This web site charged a fee considerably more than the cost of the ticket on the museum's own web site. Further, this tour-operator web site required that we state a desired time of visit and an alternate time. The voucher that we printed out as proof of purchase stated a different time, 11 am, than the 9 am time for which the museum's computers showed our purchase time. Although we arrived at least a 30 minutes before our 11 am voucher time, we underwent considerable and time-consuming hassle to have our admission time changed so that we could enter at 11. The first two people that we encountered at the voucher desk (legitimately) wanted to turn us away without admitting us to the museum. But when we explained our situation, one, nicer, sent us to the person who actually collected tickets. She seemed to undergo somersaults behind the scenes and then engaged in a lengthy, heated discussion in Italian with the initial two voucher people. Eventually, we were told to wait in the ticket-holders line but without tickets. At 11 am, the nice ticket lady allowed us into the museum. We also sadly observed a young woman turned away from the voucher desk because she only had proof of purchase on her cell phone and did not have a printed voucher!

A beautiful place!. A wonderful place! You should definitely book your tickets in advance! And easiest way to get there is take a metro to Barberini station and then catch a bus (i think it was bus 63 or 83) to the gallery. On the website it also says bus 116, but that line is cancelled and no longer runs. Gallery is at the stop 'Po' NOT Villa Borghese. Villa Borghese is a 200acre park. Gallery is just one small part of it! If you're walking from Spanish steps, note that it's up a hill... There's a cafe so if you're walking you can have a nice ice coffee and rest your legs :)

Pretty Impressive. You have to book this attraction a couple of days in advance, so if you realize it during your short stay then it might be frustrating, but on the other hand you wish you would not face long lines before all the other attractions in Rome. That is deal, and I like it. The collection is pretty impressive, even compared to other collections in Rome. There are bigger ones for sure, but the average quality is extremely high. What I did not like is that you have to leave all your belongings in the cloakroom, but its communication is a bit confusing. Also they returned somebody else's things to me first. The toilets are pretty limited in bandwidth, so make sure you use them when you have the chance.

Book ahead if you don't want to be disappointed. As we were travelling in high season I thought it would be worthwhile pre-booking our tour. When we turned up for our morning your, people were already being turned away as tours were fully booked for the whole day. Well worth a visit,

Bernini sculptures. The Borghese Gallery is absolutely beautiful with lots of art and sculptures to see including pieces from Michelangelo. Luckily, we managed to get tickets even though we hadn't booked ahead. Please note, bags need to be checked but there is no extra charge for this. The gallery is surrounding by a beautiful park area so allocate time to explore this too.
Unfriendly. I enjoy much this great museum, but cannot understand why all (literally all) staff is unfriendly, ad if visitors are disturbing them. Coffee was not good. Otherwise fun, with great arts.

Borghese Gallery. Borghese Gallery is beautiful. Definitely plan ahead and book tickets for this gallery as it requires reservations. You will also have to check your bags. They do have a cafe with good coffee/breakfast foods as well. An audioguide may be helpful at this location.

Wonderful art museum. The Borghese is full of outstanding paintings, sculpture and decorative arts. Be sure to arrive on time for your reserved time slot, do use the audio guide, and allow extra time to browse the beautiful surrounding park.

not an art lover but ????. i am by no means an art expert and the gallery wasnt the highlight of my visit,,,,its well organized,,,you must prebook,which keeps the crowds down and youre time is restricted to 2 hours
the best part of this place for me was the gardens,,,,stunning,,,,take a picnic and enjoy

Book ahead. Beautiful sculptures and paintings - doesn't take long to see everything and they are strict in that you can only go in at the time it says on your ticket - at busy times can be a bit crowded but if art is your thing, do not miss it...

Phenomenal art and nice park to walk in. I am glad that we went with a tour group with our own guide and bus. I was very busy with school prior to going to Italy with the high school tour group that I did not have much time to research the city and the sights before getting there. Our guide placed this on our itinerary and I was very glad that we did visit this gallery. How many amazing pieces of art in paint and sculpture. As I am only able to make stick figures, it is amazing to see the works that these artists made. Bernini's sculptures appear to be living through the "softness" and malleability of the marble. The linens on the couch are impressed by the subject reclining on it and the indentations made by someone gripping or holding on to another is astounding. After leaving the gallery, we wandered through the park for a short time before our group left. It is worth the effort and time to visit Borghese Gallery.

Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. How does one describe a miracle in marble? In a gallery filled with treasures, one takes my breath away: Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. "Destroy the beauty that has injured me, or change the body that destroys my life," Daphne begged her father. "Before her prayer was ended, torpor seized on all her body, and a thin bark closed around her gentle bosom, and her hair became as moving leaves; her arms were changed to waving branches, and her active feet as clinging roots were fastened to the ground—her face was hidden with encircling leaves." Wikipedia notes that "much of the early work was done in 1622–1623, but a pause, quite possibly to work on the sculpture of David, interrupted its completion, and Bernini did not finish the work until 1625. Bernini did not execute the sculpture by himself; he had significant help from a member of his workshop, Giuliano Finelli, who undertook the sculpture of the details that show Daphne's conversion from human to tree such as the bark and branches, as well as her windswept hair."

Bernini's Scultpures. Apollo and Daphne by Bernini is stunning but only one of serveral outstanding sculptures by Bernini. The building itself is a treat and it has many other great pieces of art. We did find the guide to be hard to follow and it seemed only a few of the pieces had audio descriptions. Still this is highly recommended.

my favorite place in Rome. The most exciting of Giancarlo Bernini"s Baroque sculptures are housed here in a magnificent palace. And when you are finished you can tour the beautiful park (called Gardens) Don't miss the sculptures of Pluto and Persephone, David, Apollo and Daphne and the Caravaggio Room. I will attach pictures. Also, they provide two wide, flat couches in the room with the most beautiful ceiling paintings so you can lie on your back to view and photograph it! All you want to know about Baroque Italy is right here. By the way, you are required to buy tickets ahead online directly from the gallery. Very worthwhile because it's not as crowded as the Vatican Museum; Borghese restricts the numbers entering .
What a beautiful place. Went very early in the morning and spent over 3 hrs here. Only negative is that all the toilets were shut. No entrance fee to just wonder round.

One genuine jewel stone of art at the end of the Vila Borghese Park !. That was the museum - gallery we pined rather long time to see.The building itself is very nice, white painted with the central portico, containing the four columns and arches between them.The access to the main entrance is done by the two staircases from the left and right side.The Galleria Borghese is an art gallery housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana, called like that, due to the patron, art lover and collector the Cardinal Scipione Borghese and name Pinciana comes from the notion of the Pincio Hill between Piazza del Popolo and Vila Borghese Park.There are a lot of paintings, sculptures and antiquities here in Museum Borghese, gathered in twenty rooms across two floors.The first floor is represented by the classical antiquities, including famous mosaic of gladiators, then the large number of statues of the great Italian sculptor Bernini. Those are just amazing stone- marble deeds of the great artist, which covered so much topics from the old history, the Bible but also depicted to visitors how looked the Romans Emperors, given in the busts.On the second floor we enjoyed mostly in the paintings of such art masters as Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio, Peter Paul Rubens, Bellini and many more.Outstanding, that's for sure !!

Book your tickets early!. We missed the Galleria on our last trip because we had not purchased advance tickets. So five years later it was our first stop in Rome. What a terrific kickoff to a holiday! The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the trip.

Breathtaking Bernini!. Book in advance. No words can match the wonder of Bernini's sculpture. Just go and see for yourself.
The added bonus of a walk through the gardens will enhance your visit.
for Art lovers. Located in The Villa Borghese parc, the gallery is full of sculptures and Art. The museum itself is so beautiful it is worth spending an hour or two. Book in advance!

Amazing Borghese. We booked tickets by internet. Not so close to the centre of Rome. We took taxi. Villa Borghese became one of my favorite place in Rome. Gallery is amazing! Unbelievable to see so many masterpieces in a little place. The unforgettable are Canova's Paolina Bonapart and Bernini's The Rape of Proserpine. Visit continues 1.5-2 hours. After this we went with children to Bioparco di Roma.

Worth advanced booking. It is 2 floors of art and jam packed with original master pieces. We did an English guided tour. It was very interesting and informative. You have a strict 2 hour time limit. The last 20 mins of the tour was to explore on your own. I would not pass this up and will definitely be returning on another trip. Since you have to get advance tickets(which are limited) the museum is not packed with people even in the summer.
Buy tickets ahead of time!. We didn't get to see the actual gallery because the tickets were booked for days out, but we did walk the grounds and Borghese park and it was awesome!!

A most see !!. I visited Vatican city in my previous tour in Italy and I wanted to go somewhere else, I read some reviews about Borghese Galley and it was worth it. I think I enjoyed it better than Vatican. You have to buy the tickets in advance at least one week (the earlier the better). The control of the amount of people that gets in make the big difference. After your visit to the gallery a walk to the Villa Borghese Park will complete the whole experience.

Beautiful Museo - Borghese Gallery. There are so many museums to see in Rome. This museum offers you the opportunity to view some incredible art after walking in the spectacular gardens. There are many unusual paintings and sculptures to see. You can spend hours in the Borghese Gardens, the museum and leisurely boat ride in the pond in the gardens. I highly recommend this.

interesting frescoes, sculptures and artworks. the reservation process ensures that it will not be too crowded, and we didn't need the entire 2 hours. you must check all bags (including purses) so be prepared for that. the art was amazing, the park is great, and it was a great value.

Amazing Display . Be sure to book online before you go. The gallery sits in a beautiful park. The art inside was simply breathtaking. I found some of the frescoes more impressive than even the Sistine Chapel, and that doesn't include the countless paintings and sculptures. There is a 2 hour time limit that I would have exceeded had I gone alone. It's very much a must visit if you will be in Rome for a day. They also have audio guides for rent at 5 euro each, which I'm sure would have improved the experience even more. Once you're done with the gallery, you can enjoy the wonderful park surrounding it. This is a treat in its own right.

So many things to see, yet so little time. We booked a one-hour ticket to the gallery, but it still seemed like a rush to see all the rooms in the building. All these amazing statues and paintings worth one hour each.

Lived up to all expectations!. First, get a timed ticket online before you go. Get tickets online for everything in Italy: the Vatican, Uffizi Gallery, Academia, Duomo, etc. Don't wait in three-hour lines in the scorching heat when you could be doing more productive things with your time. Furthermore, the Borghese limits its number of daily visitors, which means that tickets can sell out, and if you just show up, you may not be able to even procure a ticket for the next three days. Onto the review. The Borghese Gallery is home to Bernini's most famous statues: David, Apollo and Daphne, Rape of Prosperina, etc. I learned about these works in school, so I was especially excited to see them in real life - they did not disappoint. The statues were magnificent, awe-inspiring, and elegantly displayed. The gallery was well-maintained and rich, and even the rooms themselves were worthy of a museum display. I would highly recommend visiting this gallery - it hardly takes the two hours that one is allotted, and the experience of beholding Bernini's masterpieces is not one I will soon forget.
A Hidden Gem!. What a treat! Only smaller numbers of visitors, which allows for greater time of enjoyment. The art is outstanding, especially the works of Bernini.

WOW Incredible exibit. This exibit is incredible, the sculptures are incredible and well worth the hassle of reservations for entry. Be aware that you are not allowed to carry any size bag into the exibit and will have to leave everything but a small plastic bag that they provide for your wallet. You need some sort of guide to fully appreciate the exibit, its a small exibit and you can view it at leasure in the 2 hour window that you get.
Good place to visit if time permits. The location is away from the crowds and it have a nice surrounding. If you have time, visit it. If not, you won't miss much

Fascinating collection of sculptures. Once the palace of the borghese family, this gallery has the most extraordinary collection of sculptures, particularly the portrait of Pauline Borghese reclining on a chaise-longe all in marble. Another extraordinary piece of marble carving is Bernini's Apollo and Daphnis, she is turning into the shrub as he tries to grasp her, with the tips of her fingers sprouting leaves. The traditional decorative painting of the walls is remarkable and there are two wonderful paintings by Caravaggio. The gallery is in a beautiful settling of the grand alleys of the Borghese Gardens. Not to be missed.

My favorite !!!. Our visit to the Borghese gallery was our favorite in Rome ! We booked our tickets and a time slot online . .Which I highly recommend especially in the busy tourist periods. Get there at least half an hour earlier to exchange vouchers for tickets and to hand in handbags etc at the cloakroom Visits are timed for two hour slots and a limited number of tickets are sold . This ensures that there is no overcrowding in the gallery and one may view and enjoy the artworks at leisure ! So much to see . The Bernini sculptures were just awesome to view up close . Certainly use an audio guide . There's little cafeteria in the foyer as well as the usual bookstore and souvenir shop. Once done, stroll in the beautiful park and gardens of the Borghese Villa . We spent a most memorable time here .
Rooms and rooms of masterpieces. My head was spinning from looking at the painted ceilings, wall sculptures and mosaic floors. The Bernini sculptures were breathtaking.

Stunning gallery! . This is a must do in Rome! The entire building - from the roof to the floor - is filled with exquisite art. I thoroughly enjoyed wandering around here for hours! The surrounding gardens are lovely as well.

Borghese gallery and gardens. We were lucky to get a really excellent guide who knew her material and presented it well. We were the only people from the tour that stuck around for the garden part of the tour and it was beautiful. Our guide lead us to some fantastic views and told us a lot of the local history. Wear good walking shoes

A must for art in Rome. One of the highlights of our Rome trip included seeing Bernini's sculpture in the beautiful palace. Advanced tickets a must. I went with an older relative so taking a taxi let us get closer to entrance (5 min flat walk). The gallery is at the top of an enormous park/garden (a bit rundown park), sitting high on a hill. You must go downstairs to check all bags (give yourself time to do this when you arrive and when you leave), so have your wallet and camera pulled out to carry. Limited to 2 hours tour time and they are serious about getting you out, so I recommend reading up on art that is there to be sure you don't miss highlights in all these rooms. There is a small lift if you need it, ask security. Small cafeteria with lots of seating, in basement, and tempting gift shop. We got lunch to go and sat outside. There is a Roman water fountain in the park to refill water bottles. Walking down the park on a hot day to Spanish steps required breaks from the sun, lots of water, but a great views of Rome just before winding down the final path. Maybe 30-45 min walk. You can rent bikes in the park if you wish.

Very nice!. Be sure to book reservations in advance and have your confirmation printed out! Wonderful setting inside the park- the stroll to and from was such a nice walk. I was very glad I purchased the audio guide (it was just a few euro), as it really added a lot of context for the works, as well as the Cardinal himself.

One of the best places I have seen. I absolutely fell in love with Bernini, and my friend, with Caravaggio.
The gallery has an excellent collection of art, and a few hours isn't enough to see and study everything in it.
I would definitely recommend to make reservations for a visit, and buy tickets online.

Great sculpture collection. The Borghese Gallery is actually an old villa turned into a museum. The building itself is amazingly ornate and ostentatious. It's difficult to believe that people actually lived in the rooms. The art and sculpture collection is relatively small (for a museum), but is outstanding. I normally skip sculpture rooms in art museums because they normally do not interest me as much as the paintings; however, the sculpture collection at this museum was so good that I liked it better than the paintings. The museum requires timed reservations. I bought mine over the Internet and found the site somewhat difficult to navigate (not terribly use- friendly). There are limited tickets available for each time-slot, and they do sell out, so get your reservations in advance. Transportation to the museum was a bit difficult for me. There are no nearby metro lines, so I had to take a bus. Unfortunately, I could not find a return bus stop, so I had to walk to the nearest metro station. Despite these difficulties, I really enjoyed the museum and would recommend it to art lovers.

A must see in Rome. This is a museum that must be visited with very important paintings and sculptures. The rooms have a printed guide with a brief description for the exhibits. This was useful because we did not have the audio guide.

Lovely Museum. A nice change from the insane crowds everywhere else. Entry is regulated to specific times, and it does sell out, which makes being in the museum a pleasant experience. The rooms are gorgeous, with terrific sculptors and paintings to admire. Two hours was more than enough time for us, we tend to be on the faster side in museums and finished in about an hour, then took a nice stroll through the park. If you come in high season during the summer, definitely purchase ahead, and also arrive 15-20 minutes before your scheduled time since lines do form. You also have to check all bags, including pocketbooks.

Oh My. To Die For!. For some reason a lot of people don't visit the gallery, and even few people visit the gorgeous gardens. Where closed toe shoes in the gardens or you'll spend a lot of time getting pebbles out of your sandals! Advance tickets are a must. Plan on spending a full day if you're doing the gardens and the gallery together.

Make reservations in advance in summer!. Unfortunately, we were unable to visite this beautiful gallery, as no tickets were available for the next 3 days! Don't forget to book tickets in advance if you want to visit it!
Amazing. This is an amazing museum to visit but make sure you book in advance. Stunning sculptures and paintings in a wonderful building.
Loved the Borghese. We used the audio which was perfect. We had a wonderful visit there. Gorgeous place with amazing art. Book tickets in advance. Sells out quickly

Caravaggio and Bernini sampled by contemporaries. We loved this gallery. It is very popular so be warned, last year when we showed up without pre-purchased tickets, it was already too late to purchase tickets for that week at all. This time we came prepared and even had a tour organised. The gallery is no so big that it is overwhelming (hello Uffizi, Louvre) and you get time to enjoy the works. It feels more intimate also because many of the works inhabit spaces intended for the work by the artist and the Borghese family and the gallery was also a home, although a very grand one, and the space and the works reflect the eclectic tastes of the Borghese. My preferences were for the Caravaggios and the Berninis, famous works most people have seen in print, I just never knew they were housed in this rather small gallery.

Beautiful Sculpture Highlight of Tour. Get your tickets online in advance of your trip and not through a ticket agency, go to the museum website. Beautiful baroque sculpture by Bernini. I had a wonderful Rick Steves tour guide, Francesca, who had the magic metaphor for understanding the difference between baroque and renaissance. I won't give her secret away, but it will stay with me forever and I feel so much more knowlegdable. Incredible gallery - worth your time.

Borghese Gallery. The best museum in Rome! Two hour time limit which is perfect. Short, sweet, and incredible 3-dimensional art. Loved the David in this gallery. The villa or part surrounding it is also worth strolling through

Wonderful gallery. What a delight it was to revisit this beautiful museum with its classic collection of sculptures and paintings from the Middle Ages-some of whom are the best known in the world.Definitely worth a visit of around 2 hours.Be advised one has to book in advance for a specific time.It is also easy now to go down to the Spanish Steps by walking through a covered walkway at the end of the park.
Unmissable. You have to buy a ticket in advance. It's a good thing, though, because it doesn't get too crowded. Take some time afterwards and enjoy the rest of the villa.
Beautiful collection. Lovely collection of Bernini sculptures and iconic paintings. Perfect for a place for a quiet afternoon of culture and art. Also take a stroll through the gardens.

A marvel. Outstanding gallery (and gardens) that is a must on your visit to Rome. We took a tour with City Wonders and our guide Gianluca was absolutely fantastic with a nice easy pace and great depth of knowledge.Site is full of treasures and not to be missed if you like to immerse yourself in some fine art and outstanding sculpture.Be aware that no bags are allowed into the gallery (although can be stored for free in the basement) and booking in advance during peak months is essential.
Don't miss to book the visit in advance!!. One of the most important museums in Rome. It's small so better book the visit in advance if you don't want to find with the fully booked day you are there.

Amazing Gallery and gardens. We did a full day tour with City Wonders and the tour guide was amazing. You have to pre book your day and time if you don't plan on doing a tour. The tour was well worth it as we wanted to know what we were looking at plus you get to bypass the line.

Rude and unreasonable ticketing sales. We walked an hour to get to the villa because of very bad signage - almost none. We had to keep on buying waters and asking the vendors to point is to the direction. Finally when we got there, we realized that we booked the wrong date for the reservation...we nicely asked the ticket sales if we could change the tickets, this man behind the counter said yes he could change to tomorrow but we have to pay full price again? We said we'd like to exchange given they can see that we didn't use the tickets and they were booked the wrong date by mistake...he didn't care. We went to their office inside and asked for the manager...the office lady was very willing to help us and just asked for identification so that they can make sure we are the people who booked the tickets. After that, the ticket booth person came over and started speaking in Italian about how he wouldn't allow it. He said to us "you are not allowed to come into my museum." - we were shocked with his arrogance, attitude and his inconsiderate way to treat tourist. We said we were here to enjoy art but given their horrible attitude, it is better that we don't. We told them that we came from New York and if you ever stop by the Met museum, not only ticket is optional, the staff is friendly and will always treat everyone with respect. However, that is not the case in Villa Borghese. It is sad to see this side of Italy, probably just this one person's arrogant self ruining many tourists happy time. He is truly horrible and should not work in a service role.

My favourite place in Rome. I nearly passed this museum up as I couldn't book tickets with my Roma Pass (next availability was 3 months ahead). I am glad I changed my mind. This museum is full of treasures, Titians, Caravaggios and my favourite sculpture by Bernini, Apollo and Daphne.I booked my tickets online from tosc.it. I was emailed a code and I presented this at the ticket office at the galleria. Please make sure you arrive at least 30 minutes before your allotted time as you will have check in your bags.I also booked an audio guide €7. Well worth it. You are only allowed to stay in the museum for two hours, which in my opinion is enough time to see all the works.A must see.
For All Ages. There are so many nice things to see even my young daughter got excited with it. I suggest that after this you should visit the Biopark.

Bernini is the real tresor in Borghese Gallery. What a beautiful place to visit starting from the garden. The Gallery is really fantastic with lot of great artists; but I was really shocked but the huge talent of Bernini and the beautiful sculptures he done especially "Pluto and Persephone" and how He gave life to this Fantastic piece of work.

Absolutely exquisite! Well worth the money!. Just BEAUTIFUL! I'm so glad we toured the Gallery...probably one of my favorite places we visited in Rome. We are not art aficionados, but truly enjoyed the park and the museum. We rented tge audio giides to help navigate through the two floors. The two hiur alloted time was plenty for us to marvel at Berini's statues (David readying to slay Goliath was my favorite! ), and the paintings throughout the upstairs masterpieces too.
A must if Caravaggio is on your list. This small gallery has some of the most famous Caravaggio paintings in Romeplus fantastic statues of Bernini. Unmissable !

So thankful for this beauty. The visit to the Borghese Gallery, for four of us (two moms and two teenage girls), was booked on line three weeks earlier. I am so glad we did it as the tickets for the following few days ahead, on the day of our visit were sold out. This place is heavenly. Getting there on the bus 53 from the Largo del' Argentina took about 20 min. Bus stop is about 100 meters from the villa. Everything about this place was efficient and easy; from exchange of the vouchers, bags deposit, audioguides collection and safety check. The Bernini statues are absolutely amazing-Apollo and Daphne statue is simply breath taking. As they are on the first level near the entrance people quickly gather around them. My advice would be to see the paintings on the second floor first and when most of the group is done with the statues and selfies to return to the first floor for some very special and intimate moments.

Amazing art in an exquisite setting. it s my favorite art museum !!!the reason being is that it contains the famous paintings by Caravaggio, Titian and Rafael and amazing sculptures by jean Lorenzo Bernini which you can view in an uncrowded environment and enjoy all the fine points in solitudeno elbow to elbow fights in this museum- because they restrict the entrance to 300 people at a timeit is not like Versailles or Vatican - where all you can remember is the glitter of gold and the crowds, crowds, crowdsHere you can actually enjoy the art at your leisureI believe that with a guided tour the 2 hour slot is just perfect timing to appreciate all the fine art and not get tired or bored even with the teen audience !!It is my favorite gallery!I return to it every time I visit Rome and every time i discover something new and exciting!!!

Beautiful gallery and gardens. This gallery was not on our original list of places to visit as we have younger kids (ages 7 and 10) but we wanted to see the gardens and decided to do the museum tour as well. We are so glad we spent the time in this amazing museum - we all enjoyed the experience and especially the spectacular Bernini sculptures. The gardens are also beautiful - get there in the morning to stroll around or rent bicycles, as we did. You need to book ahead to get tickets as well.
The Galleria Borghese is NOT to be missed!. Be sure to reserve your tickets in advance, online. The audioguide we rented for 5 euros was excellent. Our two hour visit was far too short.

Excellent Crowd Control. For the sheer number of high-quality paintings and sculptures in an art collection, this has to be one of the best in the world. And they're all displayed on two floors in a series of small rooms splendid with furniture, mosaics, ceiling paintings, etc.This gallery visit needs planning: you just can't show up and walk in. You book tickets in advance (I bought mine on-line) and are given a 2-hour time slot on a day you choose. If you arrive late, you may not be admitted that day. I saw some late-comers arguing with staff about this. Deal with ticket business first, and then check out the small formal gardens behind the gallery if you get there early. About 10 minutes before your allotted time, walk around to the front of the building and get in the line.The staff has got this system worked out smoothly. The 2 hours you have inside means the rooms aren't packed, so works of art can be admired better. (For example, I could look at Bernini's "David" for a good 10-15 minutes with only about 10 other people in the room.) A few minutes before the 2 hours are up, guards begin to direct you out.Most paintings are on the upper floor, and there are some significant ones such as Raphael's tragic "Deposition" and Titian's "Sacred and Profane Love." Other highlights on the lower floor are the room of Caravaggio's paintings, Canova's icy sculpture of Pauline Borghese, and several dramatic Bernini sculptures.This is a world-class gallery. 3 hours, not 2, would do it better justice.

Didn't get in - but I know how good it is!. Ok. This one is a "warning" review. The Borghese Gallery is simply a must see if you have any love of art, especially the baroque masterpieces of Bernini and Caravaggio. But be warned. They have changed the booking system. You used to book on the day at the ticket office and they would give you a time slot later in the day. This has worked brilliantly on our previous two visits. Now you have to book on-line in advance - so when we arrived, there was no availability until the day after we would leave Rome. Perhaps this is just a high season blip, but last time it was the same time of year and booking was easy. So. Although I was disappointed, and will be forearmed in the future, I know the delights inside this gallery, especially "Apollo e Dafne", one of my favourite objects in the whole world, so I still have to give it five stars.
Welcome respite from the busy attractions. Beautiful, calm park with wide walkways. Tranquil atmosphere we spent several hours there. Locals having lunch on the shady benches, would recommend.

stunning sculptures, paintings and dresses. This was one of my favourite places in Rome. Your entry fee (19 euros) gets you a strict 2 hour window to visit the whole gallery. This gave us just about enough time to see everything. It is advisable to pre-book your tickets online well in advance to avoid disappointment, (especially for Sundays when entry is free) apparently tickets regularly sell out a month in advance and if you just turn up, the next available tickets might only be for the next day. Only small numbers of people are admitted at once to avoid overcrowding inside. I found their admission policy to be quite fair and effective as it made sure everyone had enough time to visit without there being too many people around.We were VERY fortunate to purchase tickets from a seller outside who was selling them at the low price of 10 euros as a tour was just about to start and he had some spare tickets, so you might get lucky like us. Inside is absolutely beautiful, much like the Vatican, the walls and ceilings are covered with beautiful detailed artworks. There are sculptures by Bernini, paintings by Titian and Caravaggio and while we were there in August there was an exhibition of couture dresses that looked like works of art and although they were modern, they blended in well with the rest of the gallery exhibits. An audio guide in English is available and there is a café located on the ground floor which does a great Irish coffee.I took hundreds of photos but they will never do it justice - this place really has to be seen.

An amazing museum. There is so much to see at this museum two hours is barely enough time depending on how much you want to absorb. Plenty of amazing statues, sculptures and paintings throughout the building.

Must see for art lovers. Rome has many attractions but this one is special. So much beauty inside you don't know where to look. Works of Bernini are especially abundant and mesmerizing. Be aware you need to reserve in advance as there is a limited number of visitors that can enter the gallery at once and visits are set two hours apart from each other. The good thing is there is never too many people inside (as is the case at the Vatican museums) and you can truly appreciate the art pieces. The bad thing is you only have 2 hours to complete your visit. The museum is set in a magnificent park. You can make it a day visit and stroll in the park afterwards.

Must visit, For the Art Lovers- Amazing Collections, with Limited 2 hours viewing time is Not Enough.. Villa Borghese Gallery is now added to One of my amazing & favorite museums.For the Art Lovers, should make time to visit Villa Borghese Gallery. Definitely your Limited 2 hours viewing time is Well Worth, and I wished I had more time allowed inside. (Met with many returned visitors, and mentioned that every time of their visitsgave them different impression.) Each rooms with Full of surprise with "WOW" & Speechless -as other described.Planning to visit Villa Borghese Gallery ?? Must reserve ticket in advance-Limited No. of people allowed & with every 2 hours.After the visit of Villa Borghese Gallery, if time allows, should walk around or riding rented bike inside Villa Borghese gardens with enjoying Long and Tall Stone Pine trees.

Fabulous. The gem of Rome with the beautiful Bernini statues and so many treasures! It is one of the best museums I have ever visited. It is stunning. Crowds are controlled with the limited access, make sure you book a ticket it is fantastic!

A must see when you visit Rome. I very much enjoyed the time I spent visiting the Borghese Gallery and the grounds.They only give you a two hour window but if you move quickly you will be able to see most of the collection .So many beautiful things to see.The views from the rooms is spectacular.

no crowds, but book in advance. I didn't appreciate how great it was to avoid the crowds until I went to the Vatican Museum the next day. Here, they control crowds, and it is just a wonderful museum. Don't miss the Apollo statue.

A nice way to spend a Sunday. We went to the Borghese Gallery on a Sunday morning and just strolled through the gardens before touring the art gallery. There were families enjoying themselves and it is a lovely way to spend the day. We took the tour and the museum docent was excellent. The museum itself is beautiful, as are the grounds and if you love Bernini, this is a must
Wonderful setting and exhibit. We thoroughly enjoyed the Borghese Gallery exhibit. The 2-hour tour, with audio guide, was well laid out and interesting. The limit to entrants helped - no crowding.

90 minute guided tour with www.Italy-museum.com. On a Saturday morning we spent 90 minutes looking at Bernini's statues and a lot of other stuff in the Borghese. We are not Renaissance or Statuary experts and found the guide interesting and informative. It made going there worthwhile - we would use the same people for any other visit in the future

Favorite Gallery. This was my favorite gallery in Italy, I loved the sculptures, the most beautiful I saw during my 3 week trip. They said to arive 15 minutes early, we arrived half hour early and picked up our tickets (prebooked) got audio equipment and checked our bags. You can then take a walk until your tour, or have a bite at the cafe. 15 minutes before our tour it was very crowded and we were glad that we didn't have to stress about that. After the tour we rented bikes and rode around the park, easy way to see the whole thing, it was a great day!

The genius of Bernini.. The Borghese gallery is suffused with wonderful classical sculpture and paintings, but the baroque sculptures of Bernini are of a different order. The Rape of Proserpine, with the incredible impression of fingers into flesh, is hugely memorable; the sensuality of Bernini's work makes him, for this humble viewer, the most vital of sculptors and his works at the Borghese Gallery make the visit a requirement of any stay in Rome.
Great art. I was there with tourist group. It was amazing visit. With all those rooms with arts. You become speechless. I will come back and recommend it :)

The Borghese Gallery - superb collection of art and sculptures. A lovely 2hour visit to The Borghese Gallery was well worth it. Fabulous sculptures and works of Art. A few tips - if you book online, they suggest you get there 15mins beforehand to collect your tickets. I would suggest that at busy times you get there 30mins before so that you can line up to get rid of your bags which HAVE to be handed into the cloakroom (free). Then the line to pick up your tickets - it is not clear if you can pick up your pre-booked tickets there or if the line is for anyone buying for that day. It is BOTH. You have to stand in with people who are queuing up to see if there are any tickets for that day so be patient. After all that, it is worth it all. One of the Must Do things in Rome.

Must !. This Gallery is amazing. It contains the most beautiful sculptures and paintings. It is really fascinating and rare and located in a beautiful and peaceful park . Be sure to book your tickets in advance on their web site , otherwise you will only see the gallery from the outside. Enjoy !
Borghese. Pre book and go on Sunday if you can -- it's free then !! The park is really lovely if you go early and the cafe there is great !

Roman treasure. This is by far a most beautiful, sumptuous gallery of sculpture.Must have advanced tickets and for a little extra book the tour with a docent. Website will lead you to ticket purchase. Easy to do. It indicates that you have reserved seating, but ignore this detail. You have 2 hours to tour the galleries and don't miss the fact that as you exit there is a tram that will give you a tour of the grounds. Tickets are less expensive if you telephone while in Italy, but still reasonable on-line. This a a must visit!

Must See. Some tips!. 1. Take the first available time so the place is more calm. I bought my ticket personally two days ahead. The person at first said they didnt have more tickets for 2 days ahead, just for the next day. I insisted and they actually had it.2. There is no information about the pieces of art so I recommend to take the AudioGuide - 5 extra euros. 3. Be careful about time. You have just 2 hours and you can't stay after your time is done.
Very impressive. One of the most impressive galleries in Rome. Very well organized and the self guiding tour is very informative. My favorite statue was David.

If you love art this is the place for you. The Villa Borghese is a must for anyone who loves art. The Bernini sculpture is so subtly beautiful it is hard to stop looking at it.On the practical front, you have to book your visit in advance, they allow 2 hour timed slots to keep the numbers inside manageable. This is an excellent idea and allows everyone to see the artworks comfortably.You can book online or if you will be using a Romapass, ring and book your slot. You need to arrive at least 20 minutes before your allotted time to pick up your tickets and put your bags into the cloakroom area, you are allowed to take a few valuable items in with you in a small transparent bag which they supply. The Borghese Gallery was the most pleasant gallery/museum visit of the trip.Far better than the heaving, uncontrolled mass visitor experience of the Vatican Museum, where you are carried along by the crush of guided tours all rushing through the galleries en route to a passing glimpse of the Cysteine Chapel.

Love this museum!. Six Caravaggio paintings! Titian, Raphael, and many Bernini statues are among the amazing works at this museum. Wow! No need to get a ticket from any outside agencies, just go online and purchase from the Gallery itself. But getting tickets ahead is a must! You will need to take a taxi up to the top of the hill unless you really like long, strenuous walks! Another tip: start on the top floor. You only have a 2 hour time slot for your visit,

Amazing art work. We did this with a tour guide and were glad we did. There is so much to see and it is very impressive. Get your tickets in advance. I was not allowed to take my purse in there even though it was small. - I had to check it.

You'll be missing out if you don't see this Galleria!. When you purchase your ticket you receive 2 hours in the actual gallery. What I did was split the time in half for the paintings floor and the sculptures floor. This also means the gallery is less crowded and more quiet than let's say the Vatican because only a set amount of people are allowed per 2 hours. Really everywhere you look is art! Including the floors and ceilings. Absolutely loved it and discovered an artist named Bernini who's sculptures really caught my eye.

The museum itself is art!. Amazing sculpture collection. Beautiful frescoes and architecture. Be sure to reserve tickets in advance. Plan to stay and walk the public part (or rent a bike) after visiting the gallery.

Amazing collections. A reservation is absolutely necessary here. Baggage must be checked, which is actually helpful if you want to enjoy your time here. This collection is not to be missed, even if it is a little difficult to find. Smaller than the vatican museums, but a better collection for the smaller area.
The best ART. A collection of the most amazing art collections - sculptures and paintings by the most famous Italian artists. Beautiful gardens around the Villa

Excellent contents!. This museum is really one of the interesting one other than uffizi in my opinion. Be wary, while roma pass is valid, you need to make a reservation. Won't become a problem on off season, but on July, well, you better have a long time or call them way ahead of time.Quite far from the nearest bus stop, so prepare to walk. The view at the top is amazing. Provides the view of the whole city.Recommended visit.

Bernini masterpieces everywhere!. Some friends recommended that we visit Borghese Gallery so we scheduled our visit about a week ahead of time. Please be aware that you must reserve a time online before you go, and you only have a 2-hour window. If you show up too late you WILL be turned away - we saw this happen with several people while we were in line to pick up our tickets.That being said, be prepared for overwhelming amounts of beauty and talent on display inside. It's worth the trip to see the Bernini works alone. Absolutely breathtaking.

Amazing!. We had a 2 hour guided visit.It was just enough to discover all the magnificent art works / sculptures on the ground floor. We had to rush through the galleries on the first floor. No chance to enjoy all those magnificent paintings.We will be back.

Outstanding -- whether you are an art lover or not!. This gallery, set in a beautiful building in its own right, lets you experience sculptures and paintings you have heard of all your life. The audio guide was a great tool for non-art history majors to get to know what you were seeing and appreciate it even more. . In reminiscing about our 16 days in Italy -- this site comes in at # 1 or 2. Also set in a garden park, for a relaxing walk. Early in the morning is a great time -- few lines, not crowded yet.

Bernini sculptures are the best. Having seen sculptures at the louvre and many other sculptures, Bernini's sculptures are Breathtakingly beautiful! Most of his masterpieces are at this gallery and even though it is small, just his sculptures are worth it!
Escape from madness of the city. Great gardens as well, Great escape from crowds. Afterwards you could walk to Via Vittorio Veneto, fll of nice hotels, restaurants and bars

Astoundingly Stunning. The art collection is only a part of the overall experience. The gallery itself - the rooms, walls and atmosphere are all absolutely marvelous with millions of little details. A visit takes two hours, but honestly you would have to spend two weeks there to examine it all.

Unmissable Rome highlight!. The Borghese Gallery has a priceless collection of art treasures from Titian, Carravagio and other Italian masters but the Bernini sculptures were simply breathtaking. If you appreciate art, this is simply unmissable. Make sure you book in advance, it sells out weeks in advance!

Borghese Park. Walked from our hotel to the Borghese for a booked morning 11:00 guided tour. Book ahead, there's little chance of getting tickets on the same day as the number of people touring are limited. A must.
fascinating. because of the reservations, it was not as crowded as other attractions. the sculptures inside were wonderful and well worth it.

Beautiful Gardens and Art!. An amazing collection of sculpture and art, set in a beautiful garden. Be sure to pre-book an entry time on-line. You will have a two hour time limit. You will also need to check any bags before you go in. A don't miss attraction in Rome!

Social experiment in waiting; the Berninis were worth it!. As suggested by all travel sites, I bought my ticket online to reserve my two-hour time slot. The email I received suggested patrons should "usually" arrive one hour beforehand to pick up their actual tickets. I arrived 30 minutes beforehand to see a crowd gathered at the barred entrance. A guard gruffly said to walk below and wait at a small wooden door for the tickets. The crowd then waited at that door for over 30 minutes in the blistering heat with no explanation (there was a rumor in the crowd of a power outage, but no staff member confirmed this). We were eventually allowed in, but it was chaotic and stressful to be hearded in like that. Fortunately the artwork made up for the rocky start, and it was an interesting social experience to see how different people reacted to the wait.

Beautiful gallery but very busy.. We bought a romapass for three days and went to the Gallery to visit it as our first attraction point. Unfortunately the Romapass holders can't go in with the pass and the only way is to call a number and book a slot. It was very inconvenient as our mobile didn't work in Italy and going to the gallery didn't help either. So be aware if you are on a short visit that you will need a reservation by only calling them and they might not have a slot on the same day. It was very busy in July. I wouldn't recommend the romapass to visit this gallery.

One of my new favorites in Rome. The Borghese Gallery has become one of my favorite places to visit in Rome. It houses artwork by Bernini, Caravaggio, Titian, Rafael, and more. I would spend all day just admiring the statues by Bernini, but alas there is a 2 hour time limit. Despite that limitation, I had a great time and was able to slowly wander through the entire museum in under 2 hours. The major upside to the time restriction, however, are the crowds, or lack of them to be more accurate. I never had to squeeze through mobs of people or wait to see any of the art.Buy your tickets in advance (we ordered them online) print out the voucher they send you, and then when you arrive, go downstairs to the ticket office and show them your voucher. They'll give you the real tickets then you go upstairs at your specified entrance time, pass through security, and you're in. It sounds difficult and lengthy, but the process was actually quite easy and it really didn't take that long before we were in and admiring the wonderful collection of art.
One of the must-see attractions in Rome. A stunning collection of sculpture and art in a beautiful setting. Prebooking of entry times is essential and is easy on-line. There is also a pleasant cafe.

Magnificent and Decadent!. I could not believe our luck in getting last minute tickets to see this treasure. Rome is filled with so many "must sees" that while this was on our list, it had not hit the top. We wandered up the Villa grounds, purchased tickets (which trust me was considered a miracle by all around us), entered and were immediately overwhelmed with the splendor. Next trip: top of my list.

Do It!. One of the best collections of art and sculpture I saw on my trip and we toured most of the Paris, Rome and Florence museums. Worth the hassle of making a reservation. Definitely get the audio guide as well. Splendid museum!
Views of rome. This was an interesting place to visit, but the most breathtaking thing is the view of the city from atop the steps.

Amazing! Do not miss this while in Rome!. We visited in July and could not pre buy tickets. This museum sells out in advance. We purchased tickets and a guided tour with Citywonders. We paid a premium but worth every bit! Our guide was terrific. Very knowledgable and helped make our visit worthwhile. The museum only allots a certain number of people through during different time backers. Having the guide was time efficient and helped us to make the best out of our time. Highly recommended! Our favorite museum in Rome!

Crazy bycicle ride. the location is far from the historic center and very few buses go there.We went there on subday and on our return we waited for the bus about an hour.The gardens are beautiful specially for hot days.We went on a bycicle ride with a bike for 4 .We did had a lot of fun but not on the way up hill....

Audio Tour is a plus. A showplace of amazing paintings and skilled sculptors. Purchase the audio tour and take your time. Buy a pannini or loaf of bread, fruit and cheese at a local alimentaria and picnic in the park after you visit.

Best small museum/art gallery anywhere. Borghese Gallery is an absolute must in Rome.From Bernini, Caravaggio and Titian the collection is amazing set in a Renaissance Mansion.You have to book it in advance and it you can get a guided tour for about 90 minutes.At the end, enjoy walking or renting segways at the Villa Borghese gardens

Wow!. So much wealth and art, so little time! You need tickets in advance and are supposedly limited to a 2 hour tour (self guided with audio). Can be crowded, but hang back and people move on. They only let a limited amount of people in for the 2 hour session. If you have a print out of your ticket, you still need to get into line to get a "real" ticket before entering. Get there early, lines start forming about 20 minutes before your time slot. Need to check large purses, backpacks, satchels.

The Artistic Beauty will take your Breath Away!. It is definitely recommended to make your reservations on line and pay for your tickets; we saw many disappointed tourists whom did not do this and missed an experience of a lifetime. To walk amongst the masters next to their paintings and sculptures was truly humbling.

Must See for any art lover. Book well in advance. You'll need time to pick up your tickets and check your bags. You want to be on time because after 2 hours, everyone is cleared out for the next group. The ground floor has a snack bar, checking, and ticketing. The first floor has mainly stunning marble sculptures, mostly by Bernini. The second floor is mainly paintings, many of them quite famous. This museum is suitable for people who say they are tired of paintings on the wall, because the Bernini sculptures are so magically beautiful. This is worth the effort to see.

Very difficult acessibility. There are great sculptures here. But if you are handcaped , the acess is difficult . The elevators are small and you have To change The whellchair every floor . You cannot enter The museum even with your own little bag ! The staff are rude . The gardens are worthwhile .

Borghese is my favorite. Our art historian guide started on the second floor and we worked our way down to the 0 level. This was a great way to do it as entries are timed and visits are limited to an hour. We had an excellent tour which highlighted the major works at the villa Borghese and also pointed out some lesser know facts about the family and the collection.

Must see in Rome!. Reserve your visit in advance. This gallery sells out fast and has limited capacity per two hour blocks. Great Villa and amazing details throughout. Would not recommend young kids though.

A "Must" see in Rome!. I didn't realize just how wonderful it would be at this museum. They do a good job of limiting the number of people, so if you find a particular room you like, just wait a few minutes for people to move on and it's possible to have it to yourself for a bit. I really love Bernini, so it was hard for me to finally leave! What I accidentally discovered is that the entry time on your ticket is when everyone is in the rooms, but by the last half-hour of your time, most people are down in the very good cafe, so you can spend more quiet time in your favorite room.
Beautiful and peaceful. The day after being crushed in the Vatican museums this was a welcome experience. There are a lot of significant works at this museum worth the visit.

Beyond words. I just spent a week in Italy visiting Rome, Florence and Verona. The Borghese Gallery was my favorite place. My wife has been here several times and this was my first visit. I used the audio tour and when I return (this is a place you have to revisit), I would love to hire a private guide since there is more than one can comprehend. Definitely visit the gallery with the paintings.

Lovely sculptures. We went here because the reviews and guide books encouraged us to. It was also close to our hotel. The sculptures are amazing. It was nice have timed tickets that we bought via the internet before we left on our trip. It took us under 2 hours, but we also had an 8 year old with us. She actually enjoyed it. Nice bookshop. You can take non-flash photography. You have to check bags, etc in the basement before your visit, but that is free.
One of the best museums in Rome. Went there to see Bernini`s famous sculptors.Was not disappointed.Proserperina,Apollo&Daphne and David,all amazing works of art.Among ewerything else...

Wonderful Gallery in Villa Borghese. If you only have time for one gallery visit, I recommend Borghese Gallery. We saw the entire gallery in under 2 hours and were amazed at the quality art. You must make a reservation to see this gallery, which is actually a plus because it keeps the crowd to a minimum. They are more interested in the overall experience and not packing the gallery with visitors to maximize profits. Try making the reservation at least 48 hours in advance.

Beautiful villa and gallery. The best Caravaggio collection in the world in magnificent rooms arranged by Cardinal Scipione. This villa was on tourist lists of the finest houses in Rome by 1650. Do not miss this in Rome, but you must book at least several days in advance as it sells out every day. Luckily we returned to Rome after a week in Sorrento and were able to book tickets for a two hour entrance slot a week in advance. You must take your reservation downstairs and exchange it for tickets and you must check all backpacks and handbags – supposedly a kid with a backpack stole a small statue. Their online reservation system has a problem with US credit cards, but if you call they will authorize properly. I don’t think you need a tour or an audioguide since there are large pictorial guides in English available to borrow in each of the villa’s magnificent rooms.

Some of the most amazing work of art. It's an amazing museum, a must in Rome. It is not very large, it is done in less than two hours, but it has a major concentration of masterpieces. The sculptures from Bernini and the paintings by Caravaggio are my favorites, obviously. It is amazing how marble can come alive and transmit softness, warmth, and vividness.The audio guide was great.Well worth it. Don't forget to make the reservation or else you'll not make it in summer.

My favorite gallery in Roma. It was my 3-d visit, each time i discover new agile, new perspective, Bernini masterpieces breathtaking again and again.Recommend to order online, not to come and be disappointed, you may try to order the even same day, this time for me was surprising lucky.Maintenance -

Top of the line. We took a taxi to the Gallery and walked back through the park; we recommend that others do the same. The Gallery itself more than lives up to its reputation as one of the finest attractions in Rome as it is chock full of magnificent art including some of the most beautiful Bernini statues. Of course, in addition, there a collection of 6 Caravaggio's on display, plus, plus, plus. You must book in advance to have any chance of visiting this magnificent gallery.

Best view of Rome. We rented a golf cart, my Mother us unable to walk very far, and rode all over the Borghese park. This has the best view of Rome I've found. There are two or three lookout points where you can see much of Rome. We didn't make it inside as the park itself is very entertaining and beautiful.

Worth the trip. It is a little out of the way from some of the other attractions in Rome, but it is definitely worth the trip. The tickets are free, but you do have to call ahead and reserve them for the hour blocks that you want. The grounds around the Museum are also gorgeous. So, if the weather is nice, you can plan for a picnic outside before going into the museum at your scheduled time. Along with the Louve, I feel like this is one of those museums you just have to stop in for if you are visiting the city.

Amazing Art and Mediocre Service. The great thing about the Borghese Gallery (beside the art!) is that they strictly limit the number of people allowed into the gallery, and limit the amount of time you can spend (2 hours.) So the crowd is manageable and you can actually see the art... and what amazing art it is! We got the audio-guides, which were helpful and added to our appreciation (note: you have to leave an ID as security when you rent your audio-guide.).The Borghese is all about the art... and not so much about the visitors. Almost every staff person we encountered treated us as regrettable inconveniences (or necessary evils.) You cannot take even medium size purses into the gallery, so you have to check all bags ahead of time. Our scheduled ticket time was the last one of the day (5-7pm) and by the time we were done with our audio-tour, the gift shop and the bathrooms had closed for the day (they close at 6:30) and the staff working at the audio-guide stand, the bag check and the ticket window were all visibly chomping at the bit to leave, which contributed to the feeling that they couldn't wait to get rid of us. Seems a bad business model, since we probably would have spent money in the gift shop if given the chance.It is definitely worth the visit, just be forewarned that you may not be greeted with a warm welcome.

Great gallery, grumpy staff.. Booked our visit for 9am over the phone, however when we showed up the lady at the desk was grumpy about us not having the conformation number, lesson learned. Other than that, an excellent visit. The Borghese Gallery is stunning and a must see for art and history lovers. Beautiful park surrounding, great for a walk before or after with lots of shade which is extremely nice in Rome in high season.
You have to visit this gallery. If you didn´t know Bernini, go there!! eery sculpture is master piece. There you can see Caravaggio and others.. splendid antiques
