Wonderful museum!. If you like sculpture, this is the museum for you. The Berninis are incredible. You must make reservations and they only allow a certain number of visitors at a time, so it is nice to be in a museum which, for Rome, is relatively U crowded.

Utterly mesmerising. Booked in advance to do a tour on the first Sunday of The month when entry is free. Absolutely fantastic to see the beautiful Bernini sculptures and other art works. This has to be one of the top handful of galleries in the world and is worth the trouble booking ahead. The Villa Borghese gardens are also great to explore.

Divine sculpture. Bernini was perhaps the finest sculptor of his time, surpassing even the great Michelangelo. The Borghese is a timed visit and require advance reservations even in the slow tourist season. It has two floors of art, with the lower floor devoted almost entirely to Bernini's sculpture. Rick Steves has a valuable viewing tip: upon entry, go to the second floor first because the crowds want to see Bernini's masterpieces. You will be alone both on the second floor and then on the first floor if you see the Bernini's in the second half of your visit.

GetYourGuide.com #fail. We arrived timely at the gallery, having acquired tickets from GetYourGuide.com. We were told by the gallery official that the ticket numbers issued by the ticketing service were invalid. Both the ticketing service and the gallery were utterly unhelpful. The gallery official responded to us by screaming at us, without offering any help whatsoever, and GetYourGuide.com could only offer us a refund, without any capacity to resolve the problem on the ground and in real time. We left heartbroken and deeply disappointed.
Paintings and statues. It´s compulsory to book a ticket in advance for certain time. They take in only a limited number of guests which is very good. Then you can go around the rooms for two hours.

Fabulous Museum. Our first day in Rome, and am I glad I had ordered tickets in advance online because when we arrived at our appointed time, they were turning away lots of people saying the gallery was sold out for the day! We had reserved for 2 hours and it was so worth it! I am glad they monitor how many people enter because it keeps an intimate feel to the collection and you really are up close to all that history!

Don't miss!. This is an excellent museum. Everyone including children thought it was the one cannot miss museum in Rome. An advance ticket is required but can be purchased online. Leave some time to wander the grounds after visiting - especially if you have kids.

Amazing Sculptures. Plan on visiting this gallery when in Rome. You do need to plan ahead for reservations. Sculptures are breathtaking. The visit is very efficient. Time slots very helpful. Please note that they don't allow strollers or any bags. The benefit of that is you get an unencumbered view of the art. I love Rome but it is crowded in the Summer. This gallery does a nice job in controlling the traffic. The artwork speaks for itself. My review could not do it justice.

Wow! Must see in rome. Wow!! Was the first word out of our mouths on entering the Borghese. As you need to book online for an allocated day and time to view it means only a limited number of people are allowed in at a time giving you time to admire all of the art. This is a rarity in Rome!

Must see! Book in Advance!!!. We booked our tickets months ahead of our trip. If you plan your trips and read a little Rick Steves, you'll know this. We saw numerous people turned away because the time slots are sold out for weeks to come. (What Rick was wrong about is that you CAN take your camera in and take pictures.)Your advance tickets give you an entry time and 2 hours to visit the gallery. Both the architecture and art are amazing. Unless you are really, really slow, you probably only need 60 - 75 minutes.Keep n mind that all bags must be checked, even purses.

Amazing art in an amazing Villa (Book in advance). Book in advance to see one of the best museums in Rome. Definitely a highlight of Rome in a city of highlights. We booked in advance and were glad since the next slot was out a week. The Villa is a treasure and the art is just simply stunning.Some of the finest sculptures in the world that you can get right up close and study.Not crowded (glad they limit access), well maintained. Go!

Tour with City Wonders. Enjoyed our guide - Ricardo - very much. Insightful descriptions of the art - including historical aspect of artists and patrons. He was excellent with the history and mythology behind the works of art. Meet the guides in for one of the galleries and receive the audio headset. All went very smoothly.

Breathtaking. My main reason for going to the Borghese Gallery was the see the Bernini sculptures. These proved to be as breathtaking as I expected. There are so many paintings and scultures to enjoy plus the actual building itself. Each room is covered from floor to ceiling with the most beautiful paintings. The gardens were lovely and enjoyable to walk around. I booked in advance and I'm so pleased I did because people were being turned away. The cost for a two hour slot was only13 Euros and it was certainly well worth it.

Love this gallery. You have to call for a reservation to be able to enter. We're lucky, I guess, to get slots the day after we called. You have to leave your bags and the guy from the bag checkin was very polite. Audio guide of 5 € was helpful in navigating through the picture and sculpture galleries since you can only stay for 2 hours. Works of Bernini and Caravaggio put an awe to our faces. I love everything about this gallery and the Villa Borghese outside.
Go here! It's worth it!. Actually went in July 2014 - Booked in advanced for tickets. A must see for art lovers! Beautiful statues by Bernini, and paintings, frescoes - a must.

Please book in advance. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Rome. You absolutely must book in advance. We saw so many disappointed people be turned away and I felt so guilty for being one of a few that understood that we needed to book in advance. I booked 4 months in advance and it was absolutely amazing. It's not crowded, has unbelievable works of art and it's intimate enough to to enjoy with small children without being overwhelmed.

Very informative . We are 8 travelers, 4 adults and 4 teenagers. This tour was very educational for us and our teens. Our tour company was City Wonders. Our guide Andy, was extremely knowledgeable about the gallery, sculptures and other works of art that he show us. You must remember that the Gallery only allots 2 hours per tour. So it is no possible to see all of the Gallery. I felt that Andy did an excellent job of showing us the most important works. After we toured the Gallery we then toured the Gardens. This tour is not to be missed!

OH NO!. Rude staff, limited collection, and many galleries closed due to renovation. Plus the Palace is nothing to see. The grounds and exterior are the best part of a visit...walk past and keep going.

"THE" museum in Rome. If you have little time to visit Rome and want to see a museum without spending the entire day as for the Vatican museum, then the Borghese gallery is THE place to go. In 90 minutes you'll enjoy the most beatiful Roman museum witth Bernini, Caravaggio, Tiziano, Reubens, Canova, etc. etc.. Must make a reservation thru the the internet.

Stunning. The Borghese Gallery is magnificent. I'm only just starting to learn about art so I'm no expert but the sculptures of Bernini et al and the painted ceilings and whole rooms effects are amazing and I don't say that lightly.Well worth a visit, you only get two hours which is enough. They close at 5 so getting there at 3 gives you a short time at the end to take pictures when it's virtually empty. This place attracts tourists! A must see when in Rome!

Amazing. The status of bernini are amazing. Look also at the ceilings. Come at least 15 minutes before. I took the audio guide (5 euro), didn't listen to all of it but was efficient because there are no writen explenation.

Make reservations. Run by the usual indifferent civil servants. Do you have an elevator (I ask, women in 60s with a cane) they aren't sure! Still, there are a few pieces here -- Bernini's Apollo & Daphne, Caravaggio's David & Goliath, that you should see in your lifetime.

Grounds were beautiful, but tickets were sold out and we couldn't get into the gallery!. If you want to see this beautiful spot, make sure you have a reservation. You can walk the grounds, but going in the gallery would make the trip there perfect.

Incredible concentration of Art. If you like Bernini, Caravaggio, Titian, Reuben's , and Rapheal,this may be the best and most concentrated collection in the world....You must buy your tickets 2 months in advance.They will Email you a receipt which you can exchange for tickets on site. Do your home work... You will have two hoursto focus on selected masters but will not have time too see everything... Be sure and rent the electronic tour guide.

Excellent visit!. One of the best visits ever with our beautiful, well informed and friendly guide, Mikaela from City Tours. The treasures this gallery holds is breathtaking...4 of Carravaggio's masterpieces are here...each one amazing and awe inspiring. Our guide wove legends and stories into her narration, making every moment interesting. The tour takes about three hours- two inside the gallery and one a walk through the gardens. It ends at a point where you get a fantastic panoramic view of Rome. So glad we did this.

Sad state of Affairs - in decay. Visited here after 15 years. Other than the museum, which takes 45 minutes there is nothing else to see.The beautiful gardens from 15 years ago look terrible see pictures. Service at the museum was terrible with a lot of attitudes. Don't spend more then a couple of hours here. Also parking situation is impossible. Prosbabaly best not to come in the summer.

Great start to any tour of Rome. I would fully recommend a visit to this beautiful gallery, but be sure to book well in advance. There are timed slots of a couple of hours long. This is a great system that allow visitors to enjoy the rooms without the obligatory overcrowding that is common in other popular tourist venues. The scale of the rooms, the paintings, the statues and object d'arts are simply stunning. You will not be disappointed!
Fantastic. You must reserve in advance. You should go. This intersection of the ancient displayed as the moderns of the day is unique. I would revisit next time.
Stunning collection and so tranquil, but you need to book in advance. The collection is incredible- the Bernini sculptures, the Caravaggio paintings, in particular. Do take the audioguide.

Don't Miss This Gallery. Amazing works of art throughout this gallery. The gallery is located on the Villa Borghese grounds. Your ticket to the gallery limits access to a 2 hour block of time. One could easily spend a lot more time in this gallery admiring the amazing works of art.

Exquisite Art in Situ. This is on top of my list for enjoying art in Rome. The gallery houses art of exquisite quality and the fact that it is in Situ makes it very rare and precious.It's accessible to both old and young as they have restricted entrance which makes sure it doesn't get too crowded. This enhances the experience even further. Make sure you buy tickets in advance directly from the gallery which will give you a time slot of two hours. That is plenty time to enjoy the collection.Avoid buying tickets from private guiding companies (like Get your Guide) who overbook tickets to make lots of profit, which means you might not get in despite having paid in advance.

A wonderful gallery. A tremendous place to visit and to marvel at the stunning collection of the artwork this particular family was able to gather together. Much of it is priceless and a good system of entry means it does not feel over-crowded.

Lovely park but unable to get into the gallery. I had a lovely walk in the park to get to the Borghese Gallery but sadly when I got there, I cannot get in. I was only told that I must get tickets online for entries before 2nd June. The lady at the ticket counter is not that friendly.

Fantastic 2nd visit!. Went here first time back in 2012 where I did a memorable English guided tour. Second time around was just as fantastic. The crowd management is the key - they only allow a few hundred people in at a time over staggered intervals. Also the English guides are amazing and some of the best quality out of all the tours I've done across various museums in Europe. Our guide this time perfectly balanced the academic analysis of the art with pop culture references to things such as The Simpsons, "selfies", and photoshop! The quality of the art itself makes it one of the most outstanding collections in Europe - while the smaller size of the gallery makes it a manageable dose for those overwhelmed by bigger museums like the Louvre. If you see anything in Rome, make it this.

A must visit outstanding gallery of paintings and statues. Please book entry tickets on line prior to your visit since you will be disappointed otherwise .Located within a parkland setting in a fashionable part of Rome-allow 2 hours for your tour and obtain audio equipment to enhance your visit

Must see for palace, statues and less so for paintings. Make reservation on line and pickup tickets at will call. All bags must be checked including small purses. Photo without flash allowed. Contrary to to Internet the Borghese only has Italina AC- open windows only. Audio guide a must.
Exquisite. Start from the top and work your way down. There is so much details in this gallery. Get the audio guide.

Don't Miss it. Overly impressed with this collection, spending time admiring the work of Bernini, is in my top 3 of the things I've done in Rome, Don't forget the audio guide or you could miss important piece of art, oh and don't hang around too much in the rooms otherwise you won't see the all collection, you are only allowed two hours,

Always Worth the Extra Effort. Do not plan on going to this museum and just buying an entry ticket. It doesn't work that way. You must first reserve a place. Quite rightly, they control the number of people in the museumat any one time. This allows for a much more pleasurable experience and undoubtedly helps to protect the works of art.But it is worth the effort!! I suggest showing up at your allotted time 15 minutes late---ask in advance if that is OK. This will allow you to miss the initial mad rush. Also do NOT forget tocheck your bags, backpacks, etc. below the entry staircase.They are very efficient---but keep your valuables just in case.The staff is very accommodating. You might want to hire a private guide (the group tours seem a little bulky in the restricted space). It's just a shame that a lot of the original part of the ancient collection was sold off to Napoleon and is now in the Louvre. Nevertheless, if you enjoy sculpture, painting and a very beautiful building, do not hesitate to plan ahead, put in the little extra effort and GO.

please buy tickets online. one of the few places which donot keep tickets for walk ins, I was very disappointed to find there were no tickets available, luckily there was some cancellation and I was able to secure 2 tickets for a later day. I took the audio guide, which requires an ID proof, so donot keep those in lockers, anyway made the mistake of going in through the spiral staircase which led us to the second floor and could not understand the audio guide then. best works would be titian's painting and Bernini`s statues. was extremely disappointed to find out that the boy with fruit basket, Caravaggio, was not currently there. A fact which was very conveniently left out when selling the tickets. when you don`t have Caravaggio`s most famous painting LET PEOPLE KNOW BEFORE HAND.

Incredible collection of high renaissance art. This beautiful and enormous private collection of high renaissance art is a Rome must-see! The number of visitors is limited, so book online and arrive early to guarantee your admission.

Stunning artwork - book in advance!. In reference to the negative reviews, I must preface my review by saying that we booked tickets several months in advance with a private tour group and went through the museum with a private tour guide. We had tickets for 11:00 and we got lost in the gardens so we ended up going in at 11:15 but I think that was only because of our tour guide's connection with the museum. The timed tickets makes the museum less crowded and allows you to really enjoy the spectacular art that is in the museum. In comparison, the Vatican museum was so hot and crowded that you felt like cattle being herded along the path. The Bernini statues are the most amazing pieces of art I have seen and for them alone the visit was worth it. There are also gorgeous mosaics and a nice selection of Caravaggio paintings as well. The building itself was quite a stunner. I think the museum is definitely worth a trip- just plan to be there very early and make sure to book well in advance. You cannot take any large bags into the museum- there is a free check area and you are given a plastic bag to put your wallet, phone, and water in.

Interesting but dated. I love art galleries and history, but no interps boards in English, no gallery guide available in English for less than 15 euros, very little seating (but plenty of 'decorative' seating with ropes across taking up visitor space). Old-fashioned gallery that needs to lift its game, comms-wise. Ditch the top floor and go straight to the Caravaggios and mosaics next floor down.

Deserves more than one visit. There is so much to take in at this gallery. It is worthy of two or three visits over time. It is helpful to have a guide or at least a guide book to help get a better understanding of what you are seeing and where it fits in the history of art and of Italy. Beware...no backpacks and only very small handbags/purses were allowed on the day we visited. There is a checkroom for your bags and your water bottles.

Now that's a collection of Art!. The visuals are magnificent here and I fell in love with Sculpture for the first time amongst this World Class collection. The information I got from citywonders tour guide was invaluable in understanding the collection!

Brilliant - book online in advance . A fantastic collection. Just make sure you buy tickets well in advance and arrive at a little bit before your 2 hour slot as you have to check in bags and you need full two hours to see everything. I'd also recommend getting audio guide or reading up in advance as some of the exhibits have really interesting back story and signage inside is minimal.

Visit to the Borghese Gallery. What a beautiful gallery! The art work is absolutely beautiful. You do Ned to have a reservation and you can only stay two hours. I made the reservation about a month before we visited Rome. I made them on line and then presented the confirmation to obtain the tickets

Borghese Gallery and Gardens. The Gallery has a small but lovely collection, which for me is all about the sculptures on the first floor, AND leave an hour to walk through the surrounding park to THE BEST OVERLOOK OF THE CITY OF ROME.
Masterpieces. a must-see museum in Rome. just make sure you buy tickets in advance (better via internet).the surrounding part is very nice too, and you can rent a bike
Not worth your time. You will need a reservation although holding a roman pass. Isolated place with no great interest. Don't waste your time
Beautiful!. So many amazing statues and paintings that you're feeling almost dizzy! The ceilings are particularly "grandioses"...
What a collection of art!. We toured the Borghese Gallery yesterday, and it was a great time. Our guide was very interesting and engaging. The tour was the perfect length so we did lose interest.

Best Bernini collection. This smaller museum outside the city walls of Rome is a good shorter trip and has the best Bernini's in the world. Only 180/hour are allowed in the museum so you can get up close and spend time with the smaller, but exquisite collection. To keep crowds from building time is limited to 2 hours per visit. Ticket Italy said no photos or phones, but people were taking lots of pics (no flash). You do have to check ALL bags so we left everything including our smartphones/cameras at the hotel. Taxi is easiest way and will be about €20 for a trip outside the city walls. There is a taxi stand, so we didn't have to wait when we left either. The taxi driver was so happy to be going back into the old city he only charged us 50% or about €4 for the ride back.

Beautiful collection of art. The Borghese is a smaller museum with wonderful sculpture and paintings. You have to have a reservation and you are only given two hours to go through the museum so you don't want to dilly dally! We opted for the audio tour which I highly recommend. Many of the museums do not provide much info next to the art. Sometimes they have a little card or sign with some vague details and sometimes not much at all. I thought the audio tour really gave nice background of not only the pieces but how this collection came to be. Don't miss the sculpture here- it's truly beautiful!

Amazing. if you only have time to see one museum in Rome this should be the one. You must have a booked ticket and the numbers are limited. This is great as it allows you to fully enjoy the beauty of the artwork. You are given 2 hours and there is so much to see.

Might get a sore neck . There's endless amounts of art and history here if you're into the history side of things. You get given a two hour slot in the gallery but personally we only took 30 minutes but with a guided tour or more attention to detail you could take longer. like the title says, you might get a sore neck cause I was personally always looking at the ceilings. Incredible!
Amazing museum. You can't visit Rome and not visit Villa BorgeseAmazing airy and dynamic Bernini' s sculptures , mysterious Titian's " sacred and profane love"; intense Carravaggio....

Your brain will explode after you 2 hour stinti.. In peak season must ticket at least a week in advance. Small snack bar and gift shop. Has a teeny antique elevator to take the handicapped upstairs. Paintings upstairs, statuary downstairs. Magnificent building, friendly guards. I found the statuary at the Campo Santo in Pisa to be far more admirable. Glad I came tho. Easy to buy ticket on line. Steps to enter and to go down to basement. Can be hard to find in larger park if you don't go by cab.

Lovely gallery. This one I prebooked tickets with GetTourGuide as queues inside can be large.Once inside it takes a few hours to see everything so good value for money.Be warned part of the gallery is up old stone spiral staircase of 100+ steps. I think there is an elevator if you're disabled or elderly.Beautiful artwork to see and all set in a lovely park to walk around after.Worth seeing.
Borghese Gallery. A must see in Rome. Remember they only allow 360 people in every 2 hours. Get the recorded guide while there so you can really appreciate the art collected there.

Lovely visit on our arrival to Rome. We came to the Borghese after we had come to room and dropped our stuff off at hotel. The gardens are beautiful and relaxing, with many places to bask in the sunshine. The gallery itself is beautiful inside and holds some amazing pieces, It is also refreshing to have gone somewhere which though certainly not quiet was considerably less busy than the Vatican museums. Definitely worth a visit especially for the price. And you must explore the gardens they are wonderful!
With kids. Took our 8 and 9 year olds with audio tour. They stayed interested for 1.5 hrs which was great and allowed us to enjoy the art.

Caravaggio and Bernini Overload!. If you're really interested in fine art, then make sure to reserve your tickets beforehand. The museum boasts many Caravaggio paintings and awe-inspiring Bernini sculptures. Keep in mind that your ticket is only valid for two hours.
Amazing art and villa. Could be the best small museum in Europe!Beautiful villa housing Bernini sculptures that amaze you!

Loved it!. Seeing Bernini's sculptures - particularly The Rape of Proserpine and Apollo and Daphne - was one of the highlights of our trip to Rome. It literally took my breath away. A visit to this gallery would be a nice and romantic way to spend an afternoon, especially followed by a bike through the adjacent gardens. I think it's not just a visit for serious art lovers, as I'm not an art expert at all but still thoroughly enjoyed my time here.

Very Interesting tour. Wonderful artwork and sculptures cover this entire Gallery. We had a art history teacher giving us the tour and she was able to describe the pieces in detail. Tour is only two hours and it goes rather quickly.

Out of the way place but pretty.. I would see this after seeing places in Florence and the Vatican museum. It is smaller, has a few famous statues/paintings. Took only an hour to get through. You need a reservation.
Great collection, hostile staff. The Borghese Gallery is magnificent, especially the Bernini statusry. But the staff is rude to the point of hostility to patrons. Who needs that?

OMG!. We arranged for our tickets in advance through WekaTravel in Rome...so glad we did! We also too advantage of Rick Steves Europe 101 book before our trip so we knew what we wanted to see. It was amazing...and we are not museum geeks!
Wow!. This is not to be missed. Stuffed with treasures, take your time and take an expert to guide you too. Arrive early and walk the gardens.
Two hours of absolute art!. You are advised to book your tickets in advance. You get two hours to see the exhibition. That gives you time to see everything. It is just marvelous!

Amazing art collection, we just didn't know what we were seeing!. You have to book this. We booked 4 days before we visited and space/timings were limited. The Gallery is a good 20min walk from the centre so the 5-7pm time slot is a good one. When you arrive, you have to go down stairs to collect your tickets and check your bag - no signs tell you this! They are strict about not letting you in until your time slot. Once inside, it can be overwhelming as everyone goes to the same rooms at the same time, just take your time. We felt there was a lack of information about what we were looking at and probably walked past some of the most amazing art in the world without having a clue! The upstairs picture gallery is limited to 30mins only so make sure you have time for that. The only negative i would say is that the lighting is angled in such a way, you end up with reflections of the spot lights on your photos - odd when you can't use a flash but they can use bright lights!Worth a visit when in Rome.

So many marble sculptures in one building.. The Borghese museum is a masterpiece of collected works and taking the guided tour really helped me appreciate the stories behind Caravaggio, Bernini, and the cardinal who owned the building in the 16th century.

Amazing museum. A must see, would definitely recommend the audio guide as the signs are not in English and you get to know so much more anyway. Make sure you are well hydrated before the visit as you are not allowed your bags/drinks with you, they stay in the cloakroom

Most Amazing and family Family-Friendly Art Gallery . Exceptional artwork is showcased throughout this gallery, with artists like Bernini and Fontana featured multiple times. The audio tour was absolutely amazing, with explanations that kept our teenagers engaged and intrigued. We will definitely visit again soon!

Great visit, need audio giude. Fantastic art, very beautiful works. It would be useful to get an audio guide as most of the works do not have much explanation. The two hours would be best spent by trying to go upstairs first to avoid the crowds.

A sumptuous art experience!. One of the best art museums in all of Italy! Don't miss out on this experience. Reservations are mandatory, so make sure to go to their website several days (or several weeks in July and August) before you want to visit.

Great gallery. We bought skip the line tickets but really did not need them this week. The gallery is quite impressive and worth the trip. Spent sometime outside afterwards and it was very nice. Probably not the very most impressive thing to do but I would go if you have time.
An amazing collection. I've got to admit that this site has an amazing collection of paintings & sculptures but also the building its self is impressive. Everything comes together in extravagance.

Amazing - buy tickets in advance. Limited number of people are allowed in at set times in the day - we booked our tickets online in advance and did it late afternoon following a morning in the Vatican! The park it's in is also lovely

Art history comes to life. It is an outstanding collection. Both in it's conception and its presentation. It is a must see for anyone interested in Renaissance art . Both the paintings and the statuary are incredible. Reservations are necessary.

Remember to schedule your appt. We saw this attraction using the Rome card and made an appointment via telephone (#2 for English). It was great, but would have been better with the guided tour. We were there the same time as a guided tour and I liked how they focused on a few things and shared a story about some of the pieces, but not all. If I did this again, I would not use the Rome pass, I would schedule it with the guided tour. You can book this online and it costs an extra 5 Euros.

So beautiful!. Make sure you make your reservation in advance for this museum. Guests have a two hour time window to visit the museum. We used the 5 euro audio guide available to rent. It was excellent and we were able to visit all the beautiful statues and artwork before our time ran out.

This museum was a major highlight during our time in Rome. This is an amazing museum and I highly recommend the audio tour. You will not be disappointed. The collection is great and the way it is set up makes it one of my favorite museums in all of Europe. The audio guide is is truly one of the best I've ever listen too so go the extra length to get it.

I'm not a huge museum lover, but I really enjoyed the Borghese Gallery. Most museums are huge and can be overwhelming. I love that the Borghese Gallery is a smaller gallery of artwork. You can really take your time appreciating some of the beautiful sculptures and paintings.Make sure you book your tickets in advance - better early than late. Once the doors open, you go down the stairs and exchange your voucher for the actual tickets. You then need to check your bags in. They give you a clear baggy for your valuables.Our tickets included an English tour guide. They hand out little radio receivers so you can hear the guide without being right next to him. Don't drift too far away as the connection breaks up.The Bernini sculptures were stunning! You can get really close up and examine the incredible craftsmanship.We took the metro to the Spagna station. The route to walk to the Borghese park from the station was a little awkward, but we eventually found it. Make sure you give yourself enough time to get here.

Wonderful.. Unlike the conveyor belt Vatican Museum, here you can really savour the art. The park is wonderful too. Take a picnic then walk down to The Spanish Steps. Savour the views. Villa Borghese was wonderful.You have to pre-book at they have times tickets.Disappointed that the villa gardens themselves were closed but the surrounding park is beautiful-a welcome reprieve from hot, Rome streets.
How the rich once lived.. Travel back in time, beautiful building and grounds.Make sure you read up on the history of the building so it makes the trip worth it.

Not to be missed when in Rome!. Loved every second of our 2 hour tour of the Borghese Gallery and Gardens. Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael sculptures and paintings galore! A beautiful museum in an enchanting setting!

Bernini is a genious!!. Bernini's sculptures are breathtaking, even today, several centuries later!! Unbelievable artistry! David (against Goliath), Neptune, and Apollo are astonishing sculptures. Get an audioguide - will nicely take you through the exposition. You'll want to go back and review these three amazing Bernini sculptures on marble - leave the last 5-10 minutes for that!

Missed mass for this?. I'm sure it's touted as an amazing museum, but for me I was underwhelmed. I wish I would have proceeded on plan to attend St Peter Basilica Mass. It was a bit boring but beautiful.

requires detailed planning and timekeeping. Essential to pre book and arrive on time as you get kicked out after 2 hours and that is barely enough to follow the very good audioguide.Getting there on public transport will take a lot longer than you think - the 63 bus is highly unreliable, 910 not much better, road works at the Porta hold up everyone, some of the nearest bus stops are not in use and alternatives are not given. On leaving we found it easier to walk across the grounds to the Metro Piazza Spagna than find the stop for yet another diverted the bus.The building & its frescoes are as much the star as the pictures and the sculptures - but would have meant little to me without the audioguide.If you encounter a group blocking your view of its feature pieces, move on & back track - the one way system i not enforced.

Stunning bernini. This is my favorite museum in the city. I love Bernini and sculptures. Its a magic place. I like as well that you have to book in advance and the museum is never that busy. My english guide was a professional expert of art and was great. Strongly recommended

Bernini's statutes might come to life at any moment!. This was the highlight of our trip to Rome -- the building is beautiful, the setting is bucolic, the paintings are very nice, but the Bernini statues are to die for!
Best Art Museum in Rome. Great collection of art and not too crowded. Be sure to check out the porch. It is nice and cool on a hot day.

Beautiful Berninis. Be sure to reserve your tickets ahead, because you cannot visit the Borghese Gallery without advance tickets and you don't want to miss this incredible gallery. The statues are breath-taking. Bernini was a genius. We did a guided tour which was very informative and interesting, but not necessary. I would definitely return here on a second visit to Rome. The gardens surrounding the gallery are wonderful as well.

Best place for Bernini, Caravaggio. You can find Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings throughout Rome, but the Borghese offers a jackpot for each in a single location. Five Caravaggio paintings and Bernini's most delicate works, all in one place, make this a memorable stop under any circumstances. Mosaic floors, painted ceilings and phenomenal decorative arts add to the experience. The two-hour visit limit proves workable; you can catch the basics without suffering from museum overload.
Great Family Fun. Great place to have a fun family adventure. They have wonderful bike carts that you can rent and have fun touring the gardens. Just what our family needed to break up the touring.
Amazing. Simply amazing. Wonderful sculptures and art. Not terribly helpful signage, had to kind of guess how to get to the entrance.

Don't feel bad if you miss out on this. The Canova and Bernini statues are fabulous, and the palazzo itself is superb, but of the art museums I've seen in Rome I consider this by far the most overrated. The reservation system limits the number of people in the museum, but you'll still be with a crowd of people. The display of art in the Galleria could use work. Either keep the art as it was originally displayed (the surprise effect of Apollo and Daphne is lost) or at least display it in accordance with modern standards. The Hellenistic hermaphrodite statue is displayed half hidden, thus obscuring the whole point. Raphael's Lady with a Unicorn is displayed where both glare and shadow make it hard to see the colors. The staff, moreover, at the Borghese are less than professional. The man at the ticket counter kept asking young women by themselves or with other women if they had boyfriends. The bar serves drinks in glasses with bits of pastry stuck to the inside. Guards made little effort to correct guests touching the less famous statues. Apparently only Berninis need protecting. This museum is resting on its laurels. If you want old masters, go to the Palazzo Barberini or Palazzo Doria Pamphilj. Both will give you similarly fantastic frescoed galleries and more varied collections with 10% of the crowds as at the Borghese. The Palazzo Venezia near the Forum is friendlier and has a sweet little collection. The paintings at the top floor of the Capitoline museum are just as interesting. If you want a nice museum in the Borghese gardens, see the Etruscan art at the serene villa Giulia or the early 20th century sculpture at the free Museo Pietro Canonica. There are plenty of museums just as beautiful and without the hassle and actual harassment of the Borghese. Don't feel bad if the Borghese is sold out.

IMPRESSIVE COLLECTION OF ART IN A BEAUTIFUL BUILDING. iN A CITY WITH LOTS OF ARE, THIS IS EVEN IMPRESSIVEBuy timed tickets online before your trip or you'll miss out.the building is cleared every two hours for the next group.Don't spend too much time at one exhibit or in one room

Best gallery in Rome. The Borghese Gallery keeps the private collection of one of the wealthiest Roman families- The Borghese. They had few popes and many cardinals and their collection of unique statues and paintings is just amazing! I enjoyed this visit more than the one at the Vatican museums, because it's more intimate and the only mostrate masterpieces

Skip the line. Booked a guided tour (6 of us) the day before, online with AboutRome. Paid 34Euro. All superb - met Tatiana our guide, outside, who provided earpiece. The gallery have timed entry, 2 hours, so restricted numbers, which makes viewing pleasurable. Tatiana was extremely knowledgeable and made the tour most enjoyable.

The statues are amazing!!!. It is necessary to arrange online for a time to visit this galleria. After a 6hour tour of the Vatican - I thought I had made a mistake to go to this gallery to see more statues. I was wrong. The Bernini statues are phenomenal. The David with the Slingshot and Daphne and Apollo are breathtaking.
One our favorite sites. Wonderful artwork and history comes alive as it has for hundreds of years. A great place to walk around and close to other attractions as well.

Amazing art, beautiful architecture and gardens. We ordered our tickets about a month in advance, if visiting in the summer months it is advised to book several months in advance.. The Gallery is located in a large park towards the north of the city. Beautiful for a walk and gardens close to the gallery to lie down on and enjoy the sun... The Gallery is home to many amazing paintings and frescos - most notable several by Caravaggio. With artwork over two levels you can easily spend 2 hours walking round and admiring it all...We had an excellent time at the Gallery and highly recommend others visiting while in Rome!

One of the best galleries that I have ever seen. The Borghese is magnificent. It is crowded and very popular, but worth it.Get tickets in advance, particularly if you go on Sunday. Plan to spend 3 hours to see it all.

One of the highlights of our trip. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.The work that went into the different pieces of art is incredible and is something you just have to see for yourself.Tips:- make sure you leave in PLENTY of time... It's so easy to get lost in the garden like we did! We struggled to find the place for a while and had a bit of a panic.- Get the audio guide and try not to stay in one place for too long. We didn't realise that there was an upstairs until it was too late and we had to rush the last few minutes then. You will be rushed for time walking around.

the best of Rome. If you love art go, even if you don't like art, go as well. There is nothing like this in the whole world. You will be transported to a world of dreams where Bernini's sculpture well leave you thunder stroked. Go, go, go. When I left I sneakily joint the following group to see it all again, that is the beauty of this place. Book in advance because it is very popular. Visit not included in Roma pass.

The art collection is surperb. We visited recently. The tickets are on a two hour time limit. We did not find this to be a problem. The only major problem is that the Gallery is inside a large park and no vehicles( buses, taxi) can enter. It was a 1/2 hr walk from the Metro and maybe a taxi could have gotten us a little closer but some walking was still required. We enjoyed the museum. Non flash camera's are allowed.

So beautiful!. It is a wonderful gallery, you should go there. Most of the people, while in rome, don't go there but it totally worths a visit. If you can choose, go on a sunny day because it is situatted in Villa Borghese, which is a very beautiful and huge green park in the city.

Borghese visit. A bit out of the way from the centre (but a nice break from the hustle in the open park) but worth it if you enjoy Renaissance art and sculpture and Roman inspired art. It is a 'must visit' attraction because these artworks are rare and found nowhere else, but you will need to preferably book in advance or come in early because the limited tickets are booked quickly. Also, a lot of walking up steep steps and standing (few seats), but this is an excellent rainy day activity.

Beuatifull and worthy collection. Real gems are Bernini sculptures.. Firstly and the most importantly - book online in advance!!!! It will save you a lot of time and even a visit. As sometimes it is available only for online booked visitors.

Superb Collection, Beautiful Gardens, Lovely Walks. You feel a bit like you've escaped the bustle of Rome in the gardens, so beautiful and peaceful. They are huge, but there are maps periodically so you can find your way around (and out!). Do not miss the Gallery and the collections of the Borghese family--some of the most incredible sculptures and paintings in Rome. There are ONLY timed entries and they severely limit the number of people who can be in the gallery at any one time--a good thing, so you can actually get close to and see the pieces in the collection. You reserve a day and time on line--my best advice is to do this planning early and base your Rome stay around this, as most places don't require the advance tickets. The website is a bit clunky--I couldn't figure out why I couldn't reserve the day and time I wanted, but realized later that it was because they were sold out for those times--it doesn't really tell you that, but just won't let you reserve them. DO NOT pay for the ticket guarantee, unless you just forget to take your confirmation with you. It's an unnecessary €4 if you carry the confirmation to the booking. The ticket office is below the Gallery structure--you enter down the stairs below the center Gallery opening. Leave your shopping purchases and backpacks in the hotel as they are strict about not taking those things into the Gallery and the lines at the bag check can be quite long.There is a coffee shop/restaurant in the lower level where you buy tickets, but every time we were there it was very crowded with no place to sit.The building itself complements the collection--an incredible structure. This is a MUST for Rome visitors. It's a nice walk from the center of the city--a bit uphill, but not terribly strenuous, if you are an active walker.

Beautiful Gardens and Gallery. The gallery has a great collection of Roman art. You must book your visit before arriving or there is a huge lineup. With Roma Pass this could be a free entrance, yet you must reserve your timed spot. The surrounding gardens are beautiful and peaceful for a picnic or a quite relaxation.

Great artworks in a beautiful setting . Initially my mother wasn't interested in visiting this gallery, she said after Uffizi in Florence, she didn't think she'll be impressed. Probably because this gallery is much smaller and not as well known in Taiwan. But when in went in , she was suitably impressed, the Bernini sculptures were wonderful, the roman gladiator mosaics were awesome, the palazzo itself is beautifully maintained, every wall, ceiling is an artwork. 物超所值， 精品中的精品。連牆壁天花板都是藝術的精華。雕刻品真的很棒，不去看太可惜了。一定要提早訂票喔。

Visitors beware, you are not welcome here. It could have been a nice visit, instead we were shown the exit because we had no reservation. It was late in the day and there was no one in the museum so they could have made an exception. The person at the counter said there were 360 people inside, yet we saw no one get out. This is by far the worst we have been treated at a museum where we already had tickets (we had the Roma pass). The person at the counter should be fired immediately based on how she treats customers. Same story at the cafe, very rude staff. Get your reservations in advance and ignore the staff, maybe you'll enjoy your visit.

amazing attraction. This is a wonderful attraction , beautiful art and sculptures , large park for walking, having a picnic, little train takes u around. If u r feeling energetic, bikes and go carts , zoo in grounds. May need to get taxi bit far out

Caravaggio and Bernini. We had the pleasure to visit the Borghese Gallery and Park with our private guide and it was for us even better than the Vatican.Caravaggio and Bernini...two artists who are really something!!!GO there!!!!

Visit for amazing art. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Make sure you order tickets ahead of time, as they sell out the time slots very quickly. Loved the Caravaggios as well as the mosaics which were incredible.
Too much hype. Was led to believe this place was nonpareil. Some great Caravaggios. And, well-positioned in the Borghese compound. But not all that titillating otherwise.

Beautiful; Get a Guide or Do Advanced Research. The Borghese Gallery is filled with so much magnificent artwork. If I could do the tour again, I would have spent the extra money to get a tour guide. There is just so much to see and it would have been great to get the highlights and the stories/context a guide can give you. It's not the same reading the summaries they provide to you on the tour. That said, if you are an art buff or do some advanced research, you may not feel the need for a guide. Definitely plan to do a stroll (for free) through the Borghese Gardens before or after as well.

Amazing art, beautiful interior and serene grounds, calming!. The Gallery was amazing. You must check your things, but keep some identification and some cash out so that you can rent an audio guide! The audio guide was helpful, especially since many call great artists by a part of their name and their full name is listed, of course! The works were truly magnificent! Bernini and so many others! The setting, palace, was beautiful! You have two hours maximum. You will need every second. The gift shop is small, but nice. Nice books. Be sure to check out the grounds. You can ride a train, bicycle for four or two, Segway, or walk. There is a park, zoo and merry go round. Outdoor food venders. Great, safe place to let the kids run outside. The grounds are free, not the rides. Nice place to have a picnic.
Bernini. Must see for Bernini fans! Buy your tickets way before you get to Rome, entrance is timed and booked out a little!!

Carvaggio, Bernini, Titian, Rubens all under one roof.. If I was to compare this to a food experience it would be the equivalent of a medieval feast. There is so much to take in that by the end your senses are overloaded. However, you don't want to be the person who missed on it. An absolute must see.

A truly memorable gallery. We followed the good advice from others on this website and hired a guide. It was well worth the money because Felix (a history of art graduate) was outstanding - with in-depth knowledge and the ability to answer all manner of questions that occurred as we were looking at the paintings and sculptures. A wonderful collection - the Caravaggio paintings were superb and I was entranced by the Bernini sculptures as Felix pointed out the key details such as texture of the marble on the statue of Apollo and Daphne. A genuine must, if you are visiting Rome.

Amazing!. We booked the tickets weeks in advance. They sell out so plan in advance. This was our favorite thing besides the Sistine Chapel that we did in Rome. We started upstairs first to see Caravaggio,s paintings which were intriguing. The majority of the people started downstairs on the main level. The upstairs took us about half an hour, then we headed down for the last hour and a half of our allotted time. The nice thing about doing it that way is by the time you get to the downstairs rooms you have many of them all to your self. What an amazing experience to be alone with the Bernini masterpieces. Truly a surreal moment. We loved the David, Apollo and Daphne and the Pluto and Persephone sculptures. Simply indescribable. We were able to savour the works without much distraction. The gallery is beautifully decorated. We also used the audio guide which I would recommend. We found a few of the employees not too friendly but others were over the top helpful. The park was beautiful and we enjoyed the green space after walking Rome city streets for 4 days. Please do the route we did you will enjoy this much more without the crowds.

A long walk but worth it. The galleria is a long walk from the entrance to the Borghese Park but the paintings and sculptures are marvellous. Each group has a 2hour block to visit and they are very strict on time. The staff were friendly and helpful to my disabled friend. Disabled badge owner is free as is the accompanying adult. This is true for most galleries. Well worth a visit.

Go and see the sculptures. Firstly, do remember to get your tickets in advance. If you wait until you get to Rome you will be disappointed as the gallery gets fully booked, sometimes weeks in advance. The highlights for me were two sculptures. One by Canova of Paolina Bonaparte and Apollo and Daphne by Bernini. I know there are many other works of art in this lovely Villa, but these are the ones I wanted to take home with me. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It is a fair walk from the tube or bus stop to the villa, so wear walking shoes. Also allow enough time to see the lovely park and gardens.

Wonderful museum. Much less crowd and more enjoyable than visiting Vatican Museum. The collections of artworks here is impressive. They impose a strict rule of limited number of visitors for each 2 hours period. Once 2 hours is up, they will vacate the whole museum and then will admit another group of limited number of visitors. It is much less crowded then the Vatican Museum and it is much more enjoyable.

Well worth the visit. Great place ancient artworks & sculptures it's in the corner of a park. You have to pre-book tickets as only groups are let in recommend a guide or audio guide to fully appreciate it. There's not much around this in terms of restaurants or bars. The bio parc zoo is about half a mile to the left of the main entrance. So both can be visited in one day.

Borghese Gallery and Gardens. In the Gallery we had headsets and were able to understand and absorb what our guide Angela was saying.However, before the second half of the tour, when we went outside to explore and view the gardens, Angela collected our headsets. This was not right as those in the group who couldn't keep up with her fast pace were not able to hear what was being described. Eventually she ran ahead, disappeared and we lost sight of her and missed the second half of the tour. We did not even know when the tour ended and had to find our own way out to leave. We were not alone as there were others in our group who had the same problem.This was completely unacceptable as we paid for a complete tour and wound up getting only a half tour.
Villa . Didn't go to the gallery but the gardens are wonderful. Be aware of the golf caddis everywhere as Americans struggle to drive them as we found out on several occasions. Great walks.

Rude staff- great art. Al the rude people in Rome must work here.... on audio guide desk and upon entry to picture gallery.Not knowing we must be out by a certain time, we stopped for a cup of tea in the handy cafe.... only to be denied entry to second floor because "FINISH, madam, FINISH!"Check the exit time on your ticket or you too will be disappointed!Stink. Lovely visit ruined by unhelpful staff.
Amazing Art, and Tour. Our guide (Angela) was very well informed and excellent in taking care to not lose the group. Highly recommend this tour with 'City Wonders'.

Art lovers paradise.. If you love art and sculpture, then you will love this gallery. Just make sure you book your 2 hour visit a few weeks in advance and get there 30 minutes before your scheduled visiting time. There are a lot of stairs to climb to reach the upper gallery, which is opened first, but a lift is available if needed.

Fantastic Art Gallery. Visited the Borghese on my second visit to Rome. Wow. The Borghese collection includes some of the world's most important paintings and sculptures, including masterpieces by Antonello da Messina, Giovanni Bellini, Raphael, Titian, Correggio, Caravaggio and sculptures of Gian Lorenzo Bernini and Canova. I'll be back.

A special place. The Borghese Gallery is wonderful visit. The tickets are timed and you only have 2 hours. This is about right. It is not crowded because of the size limitation. In addition to the museum, you have the whole park to visit. I have visited Rome 3 times and I always go the this museum. Do not miss this.

Museum fabulous. Viator tour a bust.. Since I have been to this museum in 1987 and 1996 I know it is fabulous. We had booked a tour with Viator for a date at the end of May 2016. We showed up at the appointed time. The museum was closed because the staff was on strike that day. No one from Viator was there. We came the next morning at 9 AM. We were told that if we had a ticket from Viator from the afternoon before they would have let us use the ticket that morning and enter the Borghese Gallery. We had come to Rome for 3 days, from the USA for only two reasons, of which visiting the Borghese Gallery was one. We were extremely disappointed. We called Viator. They are refunding our money. Small consolation for all the travel.

Book in advance!!!. I didn't actually get to visit this place because it was booked well before we even arrived. Therefore, make sure you book in advance!! I've heard incredible things about the place though which is why I rated it still highly.
Great variety of works of art. Caravaggio, Bernini, Raphael. Plenty of art to see, and the villa is beautiful. As is the park. Highly recommend. The cafe was nice and had good wifi.

Amazing museum/private collection. When you are the nephew of the pope, you can certainly amass an amazing collection of work. The main floor-what to look at first in each room? The statues--yes, of course. The paintings--yes, absolutely. The floors, often with interesting mosaics-can't miss those. But then, look up. the ceilings are beautiful and stories in and of themselves. The second floor has amazing paintings (some statuary, mostly paintings) that tend to get lost in the masterpieces on the ground (first) floor. It's a tragedy that one only has 2 hours, but given the size of the gallery, and how long many people could stay, I understand it. I want to go back and spend more time in each room to really see each piece. On the ceilings, don't overlook the non-focal paintings. I forget which room, but one of them has two winged lion women 'supporting' each 'main' mural. They all have different facial expressions, but one of each looks calm, informed, sometimes smug; and one looks like she's saying 'whaaaaa?'. even though the exact expression varies The gallery is also in a very large park (the grounds of the villa, originally) which is beautiful to walk around in. Have fun!

Great gallery with great art. We visited the gallery a month ago and this is absolutely the number one spot to see the most fantastic art there is of the great artist Bernini. You have to make a reservation, especially when its getting more crowded in the summer. Absolutely a must see.

Best kept secret in Rome. This is an excellent museum. You must reserve ahead and you must have a guide to get the background on each item. I am a Carravagio fan and David and Goliath is a treasure to see and hear the story. Please add this museum to your Rome visit.

Completely worth the up front planning. Maybe it's the lesser known nature of the gallery, or maybe it's the fact you have to reserve a time ahead, but I cannot believe how underappreciated the gallery is. How is this place not on every visitor's lips as a top destination? The gallery had some of the most viceral art I have ever experienced. It is singlehandedly turning me into an individual with almost no appreciation for art to someone who will actively read up on art styling and history. The fact that only a certain number is allowed in each 2 hours controls the crowd quite effectively and allowed you the space to fully experience each of the pieces. The only comment I have is we didn't feel the 2 hours was enough time. I would happily spend an hour in there if allowed. Oh, also the audio tour is worth every cent. Get it before your entry time so you maximize your 2 hours.
So beautiful. Wonderful museum. Aboslutely best were the statues by Bernini and the Carvaggio paintings. Well worth to prebook the ticket and spend some time in the gardens while waiting.

The best of Baroque. The gallery was definitely one of the highlights of my trip to Rome. Thoroughly enjoyed seeing many of the best Renaissance artists and sculptures' work up close. I would recommend doing the audio tour as this gives a succinct and interesting background on each piece in the gallery. You will need to book this in advance of your visit as the gallery only allows a certain number of people in at a time (which is great for avoiding overcrowding and noise). The gallery is situated in the Borghese gardens so weather permitting, it is nice to spend some time in the gardens before/after your gallery visit - maybe rent a bicycle or a segway...

Amazing Bernini. Usually not a big fan of paintings and sculptures, i got stunned by the Borghese museum: ceiling frescos and Bernini's sculptures are amazing. The movement given to marble statues is extraterrestrial. A must see.
A must.... It is a must if you are in Rome for a couple of days. Book in advance. Cheaper if you book on the website but you can get last minute tickets on tripadvisor, roomtoolkit etc.

Brilliant!. Make sure you take a guided tour with Rebecca B of City Wonders who is an outstanding tour guide. I think this was probably the highlight of my visit to Rome and cannot recommend the gallery and Rebecca enough.

Unbelievable Bernini Sculptures. I went to this museum primarily to see the Caravaggio paintings, but was instead blown away by the sculptures of Gian Lorenzo Bernini. The tour guide did an excellent job of pointing out the subtle details in these works. Note that one needs to buy tickets ahead of time via the museum web site. I believe the same is true of the guided tour; I somehow got lucky.
A good but not a great museum.. It is a good (but not great) museum. The overall collection and elegance of this place do not match many of the hyped up description I heard and read.

we arrived here at 12.45pm to be told there are no tickets left.... What a bit let down this was, no tickets left at 12.45pm!! it definately was not busy BUT we were told that the tickets had to be reserved online!!! NOT happy about that.
So we spent a long time in the beautiful park it is set in which is shaped as a heart. Gorgeous park to spend the day in.

Elegant Mansion and Gardens. I truly enjoyed my first visit at the Gallery Borghese. The mansion is so huge and elegant. The rooms displayed elegant works of art, mostly sculptures done by Bernini. The sculptures by Bernini are so expressive and well done especially his version of David. I also discovered some Caravaggios displayed in the gallery. The staff were also so kind and gracious to let me go out again to get my mobile phone so that I can take photos. For security reasons, they require our bags to be stored down near the ticket office. It's definitely worth to visit the Gallery then go out to see the gardens.
Art lives there. Yeah, me and my girlfriend went there last december, and it's amazing, sculptures, paintings, the place breathes art!

Lovely tour. The sculptures were absolutely amazing. I'm so glad that we went this time. They only allow a limited amount of people every 2 hours, so it almost feels like you have the place to yourselves.

Beautiful ceilings. Paintings on ceilings and statues were amazing gallery is set in large gardens where you could spend all day but if walking from centre of Rome you need to be reasonably fit otherwise get a taxi there

A great collection of art in one place. We had a guided tour of the Borghese Gallery. If you love Bernini and Caravaggio you must visit this spot. You will be mesmerised by the sculptures. A beautiful peaceful park surrounds this gallery and was a fitting end to the tour when we casually walked back to our hotel through the park.

Excellent sculptures, the painting collection less so. The quality and easy placement of the sculptures at the Borghese reminds you of the reason the Rodin Museum in Paris is so pleasurable. Sculptures are not crowded together, there is opportunity to view from different angles, and the range of works as well the quality of work are quite superb. We could have easily missed the painting gallery both for the selection of what was on view as well as the display. The limited number of people admitted at any one time was a real plus. If you have a good amount of time to spend in Rome, the sculptures are worth the visit. If your stay is short and you're trying to figure out a priority, I'd question squeezing this in.

Best of Bernini. Set within the emense gardens is the Galleria Borghese. The entire building is a museum, not just the paintings and sculptures but the walls and ceilings. This museum can only be visited by pre assigned time slots lasting for 2 hours. Get your tickets in advance on line or you will not be allowed to visit. Highly recommended is to take the very interesting group tours that you must also pre arrange on line. Beautiful works of art and Bernini masterpieces that come alive with or without being on a tour.Small cafe downstairs and lots of food also in the outside park.

Best of Bernini!. This place was built by Borghese to impress ... And, IT DOES! The finest Bernini statues are here along with great paintings. The building itself is beautiful. 2 hours is just the right amount of time to enjoy this place. NOT crowded thanks to the ticket/time slot system. If you like art - GO HERE.

Absolutely Amazing Sculptures and Art--Highlight of My Trip to Rome--Book Early. Two amazing hours touring this small museum (former residency of the Borghese Family. They collected some of the most amazing art in the world to include paintings and especially the sculptures. So well integrated in to their residency. They take reservations for small numbers of people which makes this place one of my favorite museums in the world to include the Louvre

Not to be missed. If you are interested in sculpture, particularly by Bernini, this is the place to go. His statue of David is magnificent showing every muscle, tendon and vein as well as the most life like facial expression. That along with the other art works and sculptures are well worth the admission price.

A Definite! Do not miss this gallery!. You must make reservations in advance. The Gallery does an excellent job of controlling crowds by allowing groups in the facility for only 2 hours before clearing out for the next group. Amazing works of art!

Poor customer service. I have no issue with the gallery itself which clearly displays some magnificent works of art in a wonderful setting. My issue is with the poor customer service that greeted me that it totally spoilt my experience to the point that I left within 20 minutes of entering. My advice to visitors is to get there early to sort out tickets and audio guides well before entry time as staff seemed to struggle with this task on the morning that I was there. My advice to the management is to provide customer service education to some of their staff.

Masterpieces galore!. Obviously, a must-see for art lovers... but in thinking about those who are not, the question then becomes whether to skip the world's great art museums altogeher when this near to them ... or to open one's mind up to possibility of falling in love. With 2 hours and a set of headphones, the stunning works here -- Bernini, Raphael, Caravaggio, Rubens, Titian and Canova -- just might light a spark that will change you "love life" forever... Advanced reservations; 2-hour time limits; bag check; photos w/o flash OK; beautiful park-like setting.

Excellent learning experience. My wife and I had a 2 hour private tour with Silvio (from Tuscanyall Tour Operator). It was special in depth experience to see the main works in this gallery. Silvio provided so much knowledge and input to enrich our experience. We particularly enjoyed learning about the sculptures by Bernini. We are most grateful for that.

A Treasure House of Treasures but book way in advance. The Borghese Gallery is a must see. Stunning rooms filled with stunning antiquities and art. But, so you can see what it holds, the Gallery limits your visit in terms of time (two hour timed tickets with the earliest ticket for 9 AM, the next 11 AM, etc) and the number of visitors per 2 hour time period. Be thinking in terms of booking your visit a week or more in advance especially with summer tourism. When you are admitted you may want to go immediately to the second floor (you will have it to yourself) and, later, go to the first floor when most of the visitors are coming up the stairs to the second floor and have the first floor rooms to yourself (We had 3 PM tickets - see the accompanying pic taken of one of the main first floor room at 4:15 PM)

Tons of art. The amount of art packed into this villa is impressive. The ticket procedures are inconvenient, however. You must book in advance and you can only enter during your prearranged two-hour time period. If you are running late, it cuts into the time you have. You probably only need an hour to see everything. The location is also far from most other sites so you really have to plan your visit. I recommend Costa Paradiso nearby for lunch before/after your visit.

Absolute must see, sculptures that rival "The David". By coincidence our tour guide was David. But David was such a critical part of the tour, with the history, myths, and legends. Obviously you need a good tour guide but if you're lucky enough to get David, you have a tour that's an 11!!!

Well worth it, get a guide.. We did the 2 hour guided tour in English. We had an excellent guide. Then we had a picnic lunch on the grounds at the pond. Roamed around these lovely grounds for an additional couple of hours

Incredible museum, incredibly careless staff. First of all, definitely put this on your to do list in Rome...the works of art are incredible.On the other hand, the staff is horrendous....be forewarned!We were there in early May, having purchased advance tickets, in plenty of time for our appointed time to visit. When we got our tickets at will call (front desk), I was informed that my backpack needed to be checked. My wife asked if her purse needed to be checked, and was told that it was not necessary. So we went and checked my backpack in, and went to their very small cafe. I ordered a very dry sandwich and drink, and my wife ordered a salad that came out completely different than what she ordered. We ate it anyway, taking our time until our admittance time, when we joined a now growing line to get in. That line went thru quickly, but when we got to the ticket taker, he said my wife's purse needed to be checked. We told him the front desk said it was OK, but he wouldn't budge. By now, the line to check a bag was very long, so we had to put up with that and then gained entry.We put on the audio tour devices. Mine was working, but my wife told the guy at the desk that hers was not working well. They made an adjustment and got it working. It died during the second exhibit room, after we had climbed a long set of stairs and hallways to start the tour. I told her to use mine and we'd get a refund from the desk when we leave, instead of negotiating the long set of stairs.When we returned I told the manager there that the unit had died shortly after we started. He said it is not normal and that we should have brought it back. I told him getting into the exhibits is difficult, and we did not want to go thru that to trade it in. He very reluctantly gave me my 5 euros back, was definitely upset, and said "next time we don't do this". I told him don't worry, this is likely the only visit in our lives.We then decided to make use of the rest rooms before leaving. These were in marginal shape, to put it kindly. When my wife left the rest room and approached the cafe, there was a German tourist in front of her who proceeded to vomit...fortunately not on her. She pointed out the Men's rest room to him, and then went to the ticket counter to report that the man just vomited in the hall between the cafe and the rest room. The lady there said it was not her area and to go tell someone by the cafe. My wife said "I am just informing you...YOU tell your staff over there.I am a guest here" and we left. It is a shame that such a wonderful gallery is run by a careless staff...the three stars are strictly for the art.

Quite a collection. Found the entire collection of masterpieces, its statuary, antiquities, and paintings very impressive; it was overwhelming. Unfortunately they allotted only a couple of hours to visit the gallery. If you do not come with a tour guide I recommend the inexpensive hand held guided tour radios. What took away from my visit was having to deal with its rude employees; most apparently didn't want to be there and have deal with visitors to the gallery. Didn't understand their attitude since we were part of first group that morning after they had been closed the previous day.

Must see. Tickets must be purchased in advance, but are inexpensive. This collection of art in a historic building is amazing, and must be seen. An area in the lower level sells fruit, sandwiches and pastries, as well as drinks, so you can picnic on the grounds after seeing the beautiful art.
Make a reservation a week in advance. I made a mistake in assuming that I could make my reservation a couple of days in advance. I was wrong and could not get in (even with stand by). Maybe next time

Breathtaking!!!. I recommend either taking a tour or come with a very good book.You make a reservation online for a time slot or you can try your luck to see if it has open slots for you to go in. You go in for 2 hours and then they clear the museum for the next group. I was trying to reserve 11 AM but there was no space. I checked the tour at 11:10 and it was available. 11 AM happened to be very popular as I found out at the bus stop as well. Rick Steves recommended Bus 910 from Termini to the museum. When I got to Termini, the bus just pull in. There were three times the number of people waiting than the bus can hold. I immediately took the metro from there to the museum. We had to walk through the length of the park in order to get to the museum. Signage was very poor after about 10 minutes into the walk. I presented the reservation number to claim my ticket but the woman said I had the financial transaction number instead of the reservation number. She rudely told me again in slow English and asked me to retrieve my email using their public wifi. I frantically pull out my pad device and tried to retrieve the Borghese email. Unfortunately, the public wifi was so slow and I was never able to even get into my email site. I approached the other receptionist and asked him if he can search me by my name. He asked for an ID and in less than 10 seconds, I had my tickets.The docent was very knowledgeable. She explained what intricacies to look for in a painting or in a sculpture and what might be in the minds of the artists. She guided us around a sculpture to point out what we can expect from a certain angle. She really made this one and a half hour extremely enjoyable.After our tour, I wanted to stay longer to look at items that she did not use for her tour. However, time was up.

Bernini no one like him. I enjoyed the Borghese Gallery , especially works by Bernini. He made marble look soft , a glow about it that I have never seen before. The statue of David with slingshot is just amazing , the expression on David's face. I enjoyed the paintings , sculptor's even more then I imagined. Beautiful grounds , lovely areas to walk in. If you need to go to the Colosseum just walk down to the Porta "Gate " in Roman wall , shops and buses. Very easy !
Not To Be Missed!. One of the great galleries in the world. The Bernini sculptures alone would be worth it, but they are only the beginning of a fabulous collection.

Must do this gallery. We had a guided tour with a very passionate lady who enriched the visit . The Bernini sculptures are amazing especially Pluto and Persephone where the marble looks like it is real flesh being grabbed.

Lots of cool pieces and easy museum to get around. We spent the morning with our guide and had a great time. The guide knew a lot about the history of the place, painters and works of art. The museum is on 2 floors and is very manageable to walk around it - with some places to sit of you are tired! The place was quite full, even though they do have crowd controls. Books tickets early and online to not be disappointed.

Borghese Gallery tour with guide. The Borghese Gallery is a wonderful gallery! A pleasure to visit with crowd control. You had time to really enjoy the sculpture and paintings within the gallery because the crowd was smaller. And the Villa Borghese was a wonderful place to stroll through after our visit to the gallery

Best small museum of art in the world. absolutely stunning Bernini sculptures. The Apollo and Daphe sculpture with Daphne becoming an olive tree and Apollo loosing the love he sought is beyond description. You just have to see it. Extremely old mosaics and a selection of Caravagio's works including the boy with fruit and the version of Madonna with baby Jesus that was rejected by the Vatican. Renaissance work fills the second floor. Your 2 hours goes by in a flash. To get in for 11 E you must pre book your 2 hour time slot at least 2 weeks before you plan to go or buy a tour which will cost much more. Get the interpretive headphones as it gives lots of interesting details. Not a place for young children.

Great nap in the park!. We set out to explore the park at the end of the day but due to our jet-lag we ended up falling asleep in the grass! It is a huge park with a lot to see and do, great place to relax, take children, ride a bike or just have ice cream.
A Treasure. This is a fantastic small villa turned into an intimate museum with fantastic and important art. Reservation and timed entry are a MUST

A must do but book well ahead. By the time we got to Rome there were no bookings available for solo entry so we booked an organised tour which turned out to be a real bonus. Without a guide you will no doubt enjoy the Gallery but with a knowledgeable guide (we used GetYourGuide and rate them 10 out of 10) you will get a great perspective of how the gallery came into being and the background to the art on display.A must do when in Rome.

Worthwhile & Interesting. As instructed, made our reservations for the Borghese in advance. Got there early and was standing at the wrong entrance for when it opened. Note, entry is at a small door at the lower - sidewalk level, not up the stairs to the larger doors. Followed Rick Steves's book advice and started in the upstairs portrait gallery. The 1st level sculpture gallery and the doorways, floors, and ceiling decorated art is the most interesting. Wonder why a beautiful palace/art gallery that charges quite a bit for admission cannot supply toilet seats in the restrooms (like many other public places in Italy).
A Must!. I have toured the Borghese 4 times over the years and it is the pinnacle of all museums in Italy. Get a knowledgeable guide tour and bask in its excellence.

One of the top art galleries in the world.. First and foremost - do not go the gallery without pre buying your tickets. When we were there on 26.5.16 the signs at the desk clearly showed no tickets available until 31.5.16. They were turning people away.On arriving at the Gallery (a splendid looking building in itself), make your way to the small door at ground floor front and down the steps. This is the location of the ticket desk, the bag store, the restaurant, the toilets and audio tour desk.You will not get in with rucksacks, camera bags, etc. but there is a free ticketed cloakroom where you can leave your bags in safety. You can take cameras in with you despite what it says on the internet pre bought tickets. I will repeat this because I didn't believe that you could even up to arriving there. Photography is permitted. Flash photography is forbidden.The gallery is divided into two floors. The first floor contains fabulous sculptures by a multitude of sculptors including the world renowned Bernini. There are also the better paintings by the likes of Caravaggio and Raphael. I would stress at this point the advantage of paying about 5 euros per person for the audio guide. The descriptions of the pieces including how and where they had first been displayed certainly breathed more life into the tour. The quality of the paintings and the sculptures from over 400 years ago is beyond belief.The upper floor which houses more paintings is accessed by going down a floor and then back up again via a different door.Only about 360 people are allowed into the gallery at any time and you will have a 2 hour time slot to view the exhibitions before you are asked to leave and the next 360 will enter. So use your time fully and revisit the sculptures to stand and gaze in complete admiration of the men who made them.

The Top Attraction in Rome. Which is a city of many attractions. This is our second visit in as many years and it did not disappoint. Secondo me, as we say in Italy, this is the best art collection in the world, and the Bernini sculptures are the best thing in it. Hot tip: Start off upstairs in the picture galleries, when when the hordes move upstairs you'll have the downstairs rooms and the Berninis to yourself.
Best museum in Italy. A stunning gallery of various sculpture is mind blowing. The place is well kept and you have enough time to spend at each gallery. Tends to be a bit crowded though.
