Best ever, loved it!. I have not been known to love museums but this place was stunning. I also loved how only so many could go in at one time and had to leave before a certain time to keep the number of visitors down. I was amazed at everything in this place, everything. Afterward we rented e-bikes and enjoyed seeing the park. Also a great time.

Impressive collection . Interesting collection impressively displayed. Warning - you have to check in every bag so be prepared or just don't take one. The gardens are lovely to stroll through after visiting the gallery.

Glorious . Booked a time abc tickets fromAustralia and had printout with us.Caught the 910 bus from termini to about 200m away. Dropped off bags and entered at appointed time. We went first to the top floor.Loved it all, especially the sculptures. Give yourself an hour or so. We took picnic and had a lovely walk though gardens to Etruscan Museum.....another not to be missed sight if you are interested in history. Enjoy. It's pretty great.

Great Museum with an awesome lush garden. Entry to garden is free.Getting there is little confusing because Metro and street sign will say Villa Borghese this way and you expect it to be there but you have to walk several blocks.Keep in mind Borghese property is huge with so many entereances and you want Borghese Museum and surrounding garden. You can walk the garden or rent a bicycle there and explore the property.

YES, you MUST go there.. Skipping this one is a crime, period. Book well ahead, minimum 6 weeks. Not a square inch is undecorated. Mosaic, fresco's, everything is covered. One pair of eyes will not do. The stutues by Bernini are the most amazing. Some paintings could use some professional attention but a 6Star place nevertheless on a 5Star scale. Combine it with a walk through the park to e.g. pza Spagna.

Could never get in. IF you don't buy your ticket before hand then you won't get to see anything but the gift shop. Even if you got in it's really crowded in the enclosed spaces. Art lovers definitely plan accordingly, but regular tourists can see much more elsewhere.

Well worth the entrance fee. Our visit to the gallery was a stunning experience. The sculptures, in particular, are breathtaking. It's incredible how such detail, movement and expression can be communicated with a piece of marble. A real treat. The ceiling of the entrance hall is incredible too. We reserved our tickets online as I'd read reviews that said tickets are always sold out and it's true! We visited on a Saturday and they were sold out until the following Tuesday. We reserved the 9-11 am slot as you only get 2 hours and it worked well as we were the first group of the day, so checking in our bags, getting audio guides and exchanging our voucher for tickets was relatively easy as only one group was there. When we came out at 11am it was very busy as the outgoing and incoming group was there. As the time you have there is limited, I'd advise going for the first slot of the day and getting there 20 mins early to get everything you need ready to start at 9am. You won't want to waste a second! We also found that by the time we got to the third room it was packed, so we went to the second floor and skipped ahead in the audio guide - easy to do as it's just typing in numbers - so that by the time we returned to the first floor it was much less crowded. This meant we could enjoy the most impressive sculptures in relative peace. I'd advise managing your time well as there is too much to see in 2 hours so if there's something you especially want to see then make sure you leave time. We found that the audio guide - which is well worth the money so you know what you are looking at - lasted about 1 hour and 40 minutes, with walking between rooms, so then we used the remaining 20 to just soak it all in and revisit our favourite works. I'm not an art buff but I have to say I was blown away by the incredible works of art.

Most favorite museum and gallery in all of Rome. This is my most favorite place in Rome - Bernini's sculptures of the Rape of Prosperpine and Apollo and Daphne are exquisite! You MUST book your 2-hour time window tickets well in advance. They sell out every day (only 250 people per time slot). In fact, when we visited, people were turned away and told the earliest available date with any openings was 4 days later.

Borghese Beauty!. Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the man behind the collection, aggressively collected both ancient and modern art, stealing it when he couldn't strong-arm the owners into giving him what he wanted. The result is OVERWHELMING BEAUTY! I agree with Rick Steves who calls it "one of Europe's most sumptuous art experiences." Book online at least a week ahead and arrive at least 30 minutes early! You get two hours in this gallery of art and sculpture. It was hard to see it all because the sculpture alone was so riveting. Bernini's sculptures “Eneas and Anchises”, “Proserpine’s rape”, the David, “Apollo and Daphne”, plus Canova's statue of “Venus Victorious” all held me spellbound. Be sure to get the self-guided audio tour which allows you to set your own pace.

One of the best musuems in the world. I have been to museums all over Europe and this was definitely in my top 5. The setting is beautiful, but the Bernini sculptures are what make the visit worth it. However, don't miss the Roman mosaics on the floor of the grad entrance hall as well. Even if you are not a huge art enthusiast, you will be impressed. Best of all, the strict limits on admission mean that you can enjoy the ambiance without lots of noise and pushing (even on the weekend!). And, if for some reason you still don't enjoy it, you have to leave after 2 hours so it will be over quickly. Do rent the audio guide! Sometimes it is hard to find out what commentary goes with which room, but it is worth it. The explanations focus on content and historical context which is good if you are not so interested in technique. Also, I found the guide helped me pace the visit well. By only spending time on one or two pieces per room I was able to make it through in the time allotted, otherwise I would have missed a lot of interesting things at the end. Logistics: You need to call and reserve at least a week in advance, even 4-5 days before is too late. The telephone reservation process is easy, the line to pick up the tickets wasn't too bad, but the lines to rent the audio guide and check bags (they are very strict about this) were extremely long. The line for the bathroom was also very long- wait until you are inside and use the one between the 2 floors of the exhibit. The park outside is very nice for a picnic, and there are lots of bicycle car things you can rent that would be fun with kids.

Lovely Selection of Painting and Sculptures. Despite other reviews we had read, staff was quite friendly and we did not feel rushed at all. Only snafu was leaving -- no cabs at the ready and no place to buy bus or transit tickets. We ended up taking a lovely walk through adjoining grounds and back to the city center.

Must see. Beautiful architecture, beautiful interior decor and amazing Renaissance and other paintings. This was a villa for a Cardinal from the Borghese family. Every inch of it is decorated in exquisite classical, neoclassical, and a few other styles with different colors of marble, paintings, and ceiling frescos. There are some very famous artists works including among the paintings including Botticelli, Titiani, Caravaggio. There are many statues and busts from the Roman period. They only let 250 people in at a time, and they kick everybody out 2 hours later before they let the next group in, so pace yourself accordingly. There are two floors and many rooms on each floor. YOU MUST HAVE A RESERVATION TO GET IN.I can't recommend this museum strongly enough!

A must do! . We missed this museum last time as we did not get tickets ahead which is a must! It is easy to do online from the states. I would suggest getting the audio guide which really makes the place even that much more special. The sculptures were so beautiful that they take your breathe away. The building, art, grounds, all are so special! Book and go! You will not regret it!

Depends on your taste. The place is really exclusive. Though, if you don't like baroque as much as I don't, you might want reconsider visiting. Or, at least, you might adjust your expectations. The Caravaggio was still perfect - nevertheless there are even more striking pieces by him at Basilica Parrocchiale Santa Maria del Popolo and Church of St. Louis of the French, with easy access and free of charge.

Purpose-built gallery.. Being a Bernini fan, I can't get enough of Galleria Borghese. I visit it almost every time I'm in Rome. One must reserve in advance, however. Besides the marvellous marble sculptures by Bernini, there is probably the largest collection of Caravaggio paintings in one place.

We spend a day, and fortunately in the park nearby was a horse jumping competition.. It´s a splendid place to chill out with family members as romans do on Sunday, have a pick-nick with friends etc. It´s a large area so every one will find a place :)

Best museum of art in Rome. Without a doubt this is the best classical art museum in Rome. A reservation to enter is a must and should be made a few months or longer before you want to go there.... Your visit is limited to about 2 1/2 hours ... It is not overly crowded. Take time to walk the grounds and park surrounding the mansion. What a fabulous gem!!
Seriously the tour is limited to 2 hours. Thank god we reserved beforehand. It is very important to reserve. Gallery has plenty beautiful sculptures!
Must see!. We enjoyed this museum with Walk of Italy. The park is pretty (could stand some TLC). Glad we booked with guide - she brought it alive! Great guide - must see while in Rome!

Spectacular!!. We visit the galleria Borghese and it was an amazing visit!! What a gorgeous villa with spectacular sculptures from Bernini etc... A must on any visit to Italy!! You need to make reservations online prior to trip since they get filled quickly and they only have a certain number of groups they admit every two hours! I booked our tickets on line and they mailed them to me in the us. The garden also is so beautiful with gorgeous fountains!! So you can spend half a day there and enjoy!!! Very highly recommend!!
gallery visit. if you are into Bernini and his work....awesome. a personal guide will make the experience 100 times better

Very interesting. Official tour recommended. The Gallery is excellent. A reservation is required and I would advise booking in advance maybe a few weeks before you travel. When I arrived people were being turned away and the next available slot was a week after! The official tour was excellent and the guide was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about all the works described in the gallery. Definitely worth a visit. The gallery is accessible by bus and a short walk or from the Spagna metro stop and a 20 minute walk.

World class. The museum is worth the visit just for the Bernini sculptures. They are superb, among his most important masterpieces. Be sure to get advance tickets because you will most likely be closed out if you don't have reservations.

Caravaggio lovers must see!. But you must get tickets in advance. We only got in due to the kindness of a tour leader who had two extra tickets. To be able to see this glorious museum, with the Caravaggio paintings I taught about all of my life, was thrilling and memorable. And the surrounding gorgeous gardens were captured in watercolors while my husband rode his rented bike.

Do not miss !. So most tourists will slug their way through the massive crowds at the Vatican, but this gallery is a splendid treat on a much more manageable scale. The attraction office is very good about spacing the groups and managing the number of folks going into the Borghese Palace Museum. The artwork here is amazing and the rooms are far more comfortable to enjoy. Please go with a group tour, as you will need the guide for proper details of such fine works of art. It can be appreciated much more if you know what you are looking at. Many companies offer walking tours here, so plan ahead and book the ticket. The surrounding gardens and park area are quite lovely to stroll before or after the visit. The gallery is well located and within walking distance of central Rome area. My visit was done through Walks of Italy and the guide was excellent with her knowledge of the works of art here. I highly recommend.

Still a magical place.... Just about! Worth it for the Berninis alone but the art gallery on the 2nd floor doesn't have a lot of good stuff. And be aware that you MUST book in advance to get in. And don't get a taxi there - walk from Piazza di Spagna via underground travelator to Via Veneto at Spagna Metro.

A Beautiful Borghese Gallery. When you are deciding to visit a specific site, be sure to buy tickets ahead of time. If you don't, you won't get in! We bought ours through Viator. When we arrived, an agent was outside who handed us our tickets. The lines were long & the villa itself was very hot. So hot, in fact, we felt faint!!! Needs better ventilation! The artwork is beautiful, full of Berninis, Caravaggios, Titians! Wow! Very worthwhile! They have a headset tour in many languages to enhance your tour.The tours are approximately 2 hours so book ahead & figure in your travel time by bus or taxi. Remember, you can't do everything in one day in Rome, so pick & choose carefully. Borghese Gallery & Gardens are high up on our list

The most beautiful marble sculptures in the world. Surely these are the four most beautiful classical sculptures in the world. The first time I saw them I thought "I didn't know you could do that with marble" and they instantly became the highlight of my Rome trip. Re-viewing them years later I cannot repeat the shock, but the sculptures still amaze, as you remember when they were done - when sculptures were just dull busts, or people sitting or statically standing. Bernini was so young and his sculptures are so dynamic; the contrast between an image we all know, Michelangelo's David (just standing there, naked, with his small willy), and Bernini's David, a cunning absolutely determined, coiled-up spring about to kill the giant with his shepherd's home-made rope sling, couldn't be greater. Such a simple, strong image, while, if you approach it right, his Apollo and Daphne stuns you: as you walk round it the image completely changes from one person to two people, to two people in a very different relationship, one of whom is transforming in front of your eyes. You must have a guide - either the standard audio or, better still, a live guide who will physically place you in the right spots to appreciate the story and the artistry. The leaves in her hair and the bark on her skin take your breath away, as you remember they are made of marble and were carved with a hand-held chisel.It's absolutely ESSENTIAL TO BOOK ONLINE BEFORE YOU COME, and you get plenty of space and time to appreciate these masterpieces - unlike the Vatican museum where they let in far too many people.WARNING: Despite the most welcome restricted number of visitors THE LAVATORIES ARE PLAINLY INADEQUATE FOR THE NUMBERS OF VISITORS. There are only two lavatories before entering and one in the galleries, for the hundreds of each gender in the Gallery, and you're there for a two-hour time slot. Two of the three weren't working on the day we visited, so women were having to queue up to visit the men's! The authorities might say this was an exceptional day, but, looking at those lavatories, I don't believe that. Go before you enter the grounds, view just a few of the many quite interesting paintings on the top floor, and then go downstairs and give yourself an hour with four of the most beautiful marble sculptures in the world.

It's All Here. Be sure to make a reservation otherwise you are not likely to get a ticket ... only 200 people every 2 hours. Also, take a guided tour ... otherwise you will miss so much unless you are already an art historian.

Not to be missed!. This is one of the best museums in the world. Your timed ticket (best to purchase in advance) allows you a 2 hour visit. The Bernini statues are fantastic; Apollo and Daphne, David, The Rape of Persephone are the highlights, but there are smaller works as well. This is the kind of art that inspires and amazes.The overall collection is marvelous, and the space is lovely. A great alternative to the sometimes overwhelming Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel. Very special. The little shop in the basement and the cafe are also very pleasant.

Beautiful works of art!. Unfortunately we missed our guided tour and had to do the museum ourselves. The works of art are masterful, but without an explanation, it was difficult to truly enjoy the museum.

Must see art - but book ahead!. I feel this is one of the most beautiful museums in the world. It is not overly large and can be viewed in a about an hour. Every room is absolutely amazing. I love how you can walk around many of the main statue. I have been here several times and always am saying WOW! I highly recommend booking tickets in advance for the opening time. Be aware on my last visit they forced you to start on the top floor and it could be quite a climb for some people. It is easy to get lost in the beautiful park.

Book before you go. We saw quite a few people turned away - there were no slots free for 5 more days! We took the 63 bus up from the river and walked through the park, to the Museo Bilotti, until it was time for our two hour slot. Get there on time as they throw you out at the end of your slot time. We didn't bother with an audio guide and loved the collection, spending around 90 minutes there. The Bernini sculptures are pretty amazing and there are also some fascinating paintings.
Take the guided tour!. Our English speaking guide was extremely knowledgeable & our 2 hour tour was perfect. The sculpture was incredible!

Galleria Borghese. Roman culture is nothing if not layered and to unearth its foundations is to uncover the roots of western civilisation. There is no better guide to human history than that provided by art and no better guide to the art of Rome than Alwaysrome's Anna who took us through the Museum and Gallery of the famous Borghese collection, housed in the spectacular rooms of he Vila Borghese situated in Rome's most beautiful parkland.Where other guides on other tours are always keen to rush you to the best spot to take a quick glance and a snapshot of a famous piece before moving to the next room, Anna was intent on imparting a sense of what's important about the work, the context in which it was made and to draw our attention to the artistry at the heart of each piece that she'd selected for us to focus on.Anna's technical and historical knowledge was impecable to the point where we felt we'd achieved a minor qualification in art history by the end, but what was really most valuable was the sense of being there in the incredible prescence of the magnificent works of art that told the story of not only the history of Rome but he history of human society. This is the kind of tour that makes coming to Rome not only an unforgettable experience but one that makes us a better person.Sent from my iPad

Insight into how early Cardinals lived. The museum was very nice, especially the sculptures. The woman providing the audio guides was rude and abrupt - definitely not interested in providing a great experience for tourists.
Great find. Although I had been to Rome several times over the years, I had never been to this gallery. Only complaint is that it can be very hard to get into. well worth the effort.

Small but great. Get reservations early and if possible before you land in Rome. This is a very popular tour site. A park surrounds this museum which is very nice. We traveled by taxi to the Catacobs of Priscilla from here. Take a taxi or city bus.

Wow - Benini is a god. In my opinion Benini's work trumps Michaelangelo's David. When you go and see the detail in these sculptures you will be blown away. Make sure you book though. You will not get in otherwise. A must in Rome.

Great building! . Located in the Borghese Gardens, near to the metro station. You need to book ahead and then wait in line for the Tickets (the ticket bought online ia just a voucher); you should come at least 15 minutes Earlier before the scheduled time, in order to Take your printed ticket and your audioguide (only 5 euros, But it really helps you to understand something about the paintings/frescoes)!! You can Also go inside the gallery with a guidedtour-it costs 6,5 euros! The interior is wonderfull and you should go while you are in Rome, But a "minus" is that the tour lasts for only 2 hours (it wasn't enough for us); ten minutes before the end of the tour, we were announced that we should leave the gallery...oh, well-the Next group (who started at 11.00 am ) was patientely Waiting for us to finish ....another thing: you Can not Take inside your bag/a bottle of Water; you should leave them at the cloakroom. You can Take pictures, But without blitz! You should definitely not miss this Spot!!

Treasure Trove. This wonderful museum is worth the special effort. The Bernini sculptures are breathtaking, but there are so many exquisite paintings and furnishings, that a visitor just wants to absorb everything. This was my first visit, but it won't be my last!

Careful with Ticketing Agents. The art in this villa is worth the pre-booking and time limits imposed by the museum. The Bernini sculptures alone are an experience of a lifetime. But a cautionary tale - we booked our tickets through GetYourGuide and were sent a voucher on our smart phones. Trouble is, the museum does not recognize the voucher, a representative of the ticket company must collect the tickets they have ordered and give them to you outside. Apparently the representatives of this company don't bother doing that (this is just entrance tickets, not a tour) and the museum has had enough with dealing with individuals with vouchers sold by GetYourGuide.

Art at it's best. If you plan on visiting make sure you make a reservation and note there is a time-limit however I had plenty of time to wander about the gallery. Definitely worth a visit if you only sculptures.
gorgeous. great for a sunny warm day, we were four people and got a golf cart for an hour - awesome time and we saw so much - have fun.

Amazing Collection. The only reason this stunning gallery gets a 4 star review is that it really should be easier to get tickets and not have to deal with reservations, and once one goes through all of that to get in, I don't think the time limit really allows one to see all this amazing place has to offer; at least not as calmly as I would've liked. That being said, it's definitely worth a visit and a good thing to do if you have a Roma Pass. It's been a favorite of mine for quite some time.

Art overload.. A private guide would be a good investment especially since visits are time-limited. We will admit to eavesdropping on one or two and they were adding very important context to the works as they provided a pathway through what is an astonishing amount of art. Bernini statues and Caravaggio paintings are gorgeous. Book ahead. You will still have to wait in line to pick up tickets and check your bag but you'll be assured of entrance.

Fantastic experience wouldn't miss it!. Tremendous variety of art. This is a well run museum. Some of the statuary is the finest in the world and amazing to view. Allow plenty of time. I went through twice. Entrance was a bit confusing to find, so ask around. During busy time check their website and buy a ticket early, saves lines. Not a great snack area and few places to sit, so grab a water before you go. plan on checking any bags except the tiniest wallet.
Bernini will blow your socks off. If you love sculptures, stop by here to see some of the best Bernini sculptures ever created. The tension he can add to stone is simply spectacular!

Well worth a visit. Six of us pre booked our tickets before leaving home (advised) went for the 11am visit, took the full 2 hours and thoroughly enjoyed our experience followed by a walk through the grounds on a lovely cool May afternoon. It would take too long to highlight the various things to see, go do it for yourself and read up on it before you go if you can. You will enjoy it.

A must see when vacationing in Rome. Absolutely I must see while visiting Rome to imagine that hundreds and thousands of years ago someone wood carving a statue out of one piece of marble the detail of the tree out of Daphne's fingers and legs was Exquisite the teardrops you can't even imagine the Artistry was so magnificent it brought Goosebumps please take the time and visit this beautiful gallery

Stunning art, helpful staff, peaceful walking around. The Borghese is unique in that it only allows you to attend if you have a reservation. This keeps queues at a minimum and unlike the Vatican, you can freely move around during your 2 hour slot without bumping into other people. The sculptures by Bernini are the best!

Bernini sculptures and paintings of different artists. The Borghese gallery is located in the nice park close to the Spanish steps.We were lucky to book the tickets early in the morning on the day of our visit. It is good that you don't need to print the tickets, just show the email on your smartphone.The visit is 2 hours long so you need to plan your time during the visit.The sculptures are really beautiful, but it may get too crowded so you can't enjoy the art at 100%. Anyways, this place should be visited if you love art and have enough time in Rome (3-4 days at least).
For fans of Bernini. Book a tour to get the most out of your trip and also to get a "time slot" as entry is limited (and even then felt a bit cramped). The statues by Bernini were stunning

Beautiful art, got to book early (limited number of visitors), so-so guided tour in English. Lots of wonderful pieces of art on the ground and TOP floor.We booked for an English guided tour with our tickets from 9.15am to 11. The guide took us through the first level but then finished at 10.35am and just told us to climb to the top floor and check it out.I'd have appreciated a couple more minutes (like, until the end of the slot allotted) to be taken to the top floor's most notable pieces.The ticket is kind of expensive compared to other museums and you've got to book early or you won't get in.If you go for the guided tour, well, your mileage may vary.

The Rape of Proserpina is not to be missed. Magnifient!. A really enjoyable museum. The sculptures were even better than I had imagined they would be. I particularly enjoyed 'The Rape of Proserpina' and the Palazzo was an amazing backdrop to all the fine art.
Ultimate in Bernini Sculpture. This is a must see for sculpture enthusiasts who travel to Rome. The museum operates by reservation only so make sure to get tickets ahead of time.

Don't miss this gallery . Carefully curated collection of extraordinary paintings and sculptures housed in a beautiful building in the Borghese gardens. We weren't able to get tickets online as we didn't book in advance so we took a private tour - expensive but worth it. If you only go to one gallery in Rome visit this. Online booking is much more affordable but they only allow a limited number of people (which means it's not overly crowded) so if you want to go make sure you book online well in advance before the tickets sell out.

Great artworks!. If you're in Rome, don't miss to visit this museum: it offers so much if you're an art lover...for exampe great sculptures of Lorenzo Bernini, simply irresistible, good audio guides, nice park as well, to enjoy afterwards...

Beautiful art in a wonderful setting. The Borghese Gallery, which is not that easy to get to, is a jewel in a park in the middle of Rome. I took a tour with a docent from the Gallery. You are only allowed two hours in the building, and it is a timed entrance. You need to buy the ticket ahead of time because they are usually sold out. The Bernini sculptures are fabulous. I am not a big sculpture fan, but what he could do with a piece of marble is unbelievable. The paintings, the room decorations, everything was beautiful.
We love Bernini. Small museum, we love the larger than life sculptures by Bernini. We have been 3 times and advise a guide If unfamiliar. Some nice Caravaggios but this time many were out on loan.
Beautiful. The park around it is great for kids. Large space with a small lake that you could rent a boat to paddle for 4 euro per 20 minutes. Romantic and peaceful. You must see it.

Outstanding. Outside of the Louvre in Paris, I don't think I have ever seen such a great collection, this place is a real treasure, be sure to book online well in advance or you will not get in, I wish I had sprung for a guide as the historical significance of this place is worth having someone really explain it to you. Audio guide is a must at a minimum.

Spectacular experience. We chose to have a private guided tour and it was a good decision. The building oozes history and culture - floors, ceilings, walls are more than a setting. They are part of the "picture" and our Always Rome guide, Valentina, was so good at pointing out their significance. Bernini, Caravaggio, Titian and others are well represented in this intimate and important collection.

The best Bernini collection in the world--truly magnificent.. This is a must see if you appreciate Bernini. I preferred this museum to any other we visited because it limits the number of visitors at any given time (reservations are a must--make 'em on the Internet), so it isn't the usual jostling and standing in line to catch a glimpse. The galleries are magnificent, the art is unparalleled. Absolutely incredible.

Must do with a guide. We were a little apprehensive since the tour is expensive, and the exterior is not as pristine as some other museums we've been too. But the museum is spectacular! You ONLY get 2 hours, then they kick you out. They limit the number of visitors so don't wait until the last minute to book this, even if you don't use a guide. All the historical details about the collection, the artists, the families, politics etc. can be appreciated through the guided tour.... We used Viator, but it's more about the guide.Most importantly, you can't do the museum in 2 hours, so a guide will take you to see the best of the best.... Like Bernini's room.

Must see ... but with a tour guide.... Take a tour guide! Take a tour guide! You miss out on so many details of this fantastic art collection without a guide. The Bernini marble sculptures are out of this world!

Beautiful gallery and gardens . Went to the Borghese Gallery on 17 May 2016. Took the metro to Spagna and walked thru the gardens to reach the gallery. The garden is beautiful and very charming. The galleria is worth a visit to see Bernini's works and the villa itself is beatific too. A ticket reservation is a must! They have a lovely cafe as well.

One very rich family's art collection.. The Borghese family built one of the world's greatest collections of classical art. Here, you'll find most of what they accumulated. Paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael, Bassano, Titian and Rubens, and sculptures by Bernini. In addition to the art gallery, you'll also find the famous Villa Borghese Gardens.
do english language tour. only cost 4 dollars more than price of visit to do tour with commentary. felix was the guide and made it very interesting. great pieces of art

Hidden Jewel. Buy tickets in advance! Do not just show up because you will not get in. The upside of this is that it is not completely overrun by tourist and you can actually see the Caravaggio's, Rubens and Titian's

Fantastic. Loved this museum and the surrounding park. Reserve your spot ahead as they limit visitors and keep very strict time slots (they literally kick everyone out after two hours). Go early and have a picnic in the surrounding park.

a must see (make your reservation before you leave home ). We arrived in Rome 5/3/16 & on 5/5 we went to the Borghese to make a reservation. We had to wait until 5/19 to get a reservation. Fortunately we had the time in Rome to make the reservation. Once you arrive for your reservation time, you can pick up for 5.00e a hand held that explains what you are seeing room by room( well worth it). The sculptures on the 1st floor by Bernini nust be seen to be believed. He makes finger indentures in flesh where the hand is resting on a leg or body. There is a man on horse falling off in 3D above a doorway. The paintings are great but the sculptures are amazing. David has a sling in his hand & his body is being torqued as he is twisting to fling it. DON'T MISS

Great place to visit in Rome. Besides the gallery that is very difficult to get in (you need to reserve a ticket in advanced) there are some other attractions in the beautiful park. So, it is a nice place to visit.

Unbelivable. The Borghese Gallery is one of the finest galleries in the world. Inside are kept some of the most spectacular masterpieces of the last 500 years. One above all the famous "Rape of Proserpina" by Gian Lorenzo Bernini. Even the art gallery is wonderful. Admission by reservation only. The Borghese park all around the Museum is gorgeous and totally free. Getting lost among its streets is a mystical experience. Do not forget to get in the most beautiful place in the park, the small lake of water lilies where you can hire a rowing boat and feel a character of an ancient fairy tale.
no dice if not reserved. cannot get inside without reservations.was very disappointed.but,walked outside with lovely park views.
A must see before leaving Rome. Our guide was superbly informed and made the wonderful woks of art housed in the Villa all the more absorbing

Poorly Managed. Listen, we all know that Rome isn't the greatest place when it comes to picture galleries. We also know that visiting the Borghese is a must, even though it isn't anything like the Louvre or the Met. Okay. We showed up in the afternoon and were told that the next "tour" was in one hour and there were only two tickets left. This is ridiculous. I mean, since the place is THAT popular, wouldn't it make good business sense to keep it open around the clock or something? Just to ease the congestion? I daresay I've visited every MAJOR gallery in the world, and I don't remember a single instance where they'd make a paying customer wait an hour to get in. I don't need a "tour," either: most people who are truly interested in art already know what's inside this little museum. This was a disappointing experience. The gardens are great, but that's a whole different story.

Beautiful park and gardens. First, let me start by saying we did not go in the gallery/muesum. We went to the gardens and park surrounding the Gallery. We HAD to escape the madness of Rome for a bit, and walked up to this green, lush, quiet area, with fountains, ponds, benches and paths. This place helped us to regain sanity, and we were able to continue our visit to Rome, fortified by the quiet space of trees and shade.

Art in a Palace. My favorite parts of this museum are the Bernini sculptures and the wonderful mosaic floor of gladiators and beasts on the main floor. Because timed visitations are limited, it's never overcrowded, but you must reserve ahead. Starting upstairs and working down makes for an even less crowded visit. Next time I'd like to catch the tram that stops in front of the museum and see more of the gardens.

Stunning. I booked this online via Rome-museum for 11 euros per person. More than worth the money! ticket allowed us straight in at the specified time, you MUST book before you go. Tickets on the day are not available. Inside was filled with beautiful art, sculptures and painted ceilings. Didn't have a guide but art is not my bag, might've been a good idea though.

do not miss this. The highlight for me were the Bernini statues. The Apollo and Dafne was amazing. The paintings were also well known. This is easy to move around in since they limit the number of people at any one time. So, it is necessary to make a reservation there.

Lovely uncrowded Gallery with spectacular sculptures. We bought our tickets on lone for the first slot of the day so the Gallery was still closed when we got there. It is hard to know what door to line up at, so a word to anyone going for the first reserved viewing of the day: The line for ticket holders forms at the centre entrance to the Gallery, but NOT the one at the top of the stairs as you might expect, but at the doors beneath those that lead into the basement. Aside from the initial confusion, we were enchanted by the Gallery and can't imagine another visit to Rome without revisiting. The audio guide is excellent and well worth the money. And if you want to make the best use of your 2 hours, head first to the paintings on the second floor before turning your attention to the sculptures. two hours didn't seem like enough time to appreciate everything that was there, but because of the timed tickets, the gallery never felt overcrowded. A stroll through the grounds afterwards is also lovely. Highly recommend.

My third visit to wonderful museum. Just love this house, beautiful rooms, just full of magnificent paintings and sculptures. The best thing about this museum is that they only allow 150 visitors each two hour slot during the day, so there is no crowding or shuffling shoulder to shoulder with other visitors, you can take your time to admire the artists works in peaceful sorroundings- personally I just love the wonderful Giovanni Bellini sculptures, that are so life-like, they look like they are formed in soft clay instead of marble,really a special place to visit in Rome, and the extensive grounds are beautiful, just right for a picnic.One problem is that you can only book up to 7 days before you visit, so many people turn up hoping to book on the day and are turned away. Just book on-line on the Borghese website at least a month before you visit, as should you book the Colosseum tour and the Vatican, no need to queue if you book before you travel.

Two For One. We saved the Borghese Gallery for our final day in Rome. Fortunately, we went in November so we were able to get tickets about three days before we went. We were lucky. This attraction only takes a certain number of visitors per day and the length of all visits are limited to two hours. It sells out fast so if you want to go plan ahead. What an amazing two hours we had. Each room in the gallery is filled with beautiful paintings and statutes. We spent a long time looking at the Bernini statutes. The rooms themselves are a work of art. Although there a many visitors, you have plenty of time and room to enjoy the art. We spent the entire two hours there. After our time in the gallery, we rented a tandem bike for a very reasonable rate and biked around the grounds. If you have an opportunity, I highly recommend spending most of a day there.

Nice change of pace away from the crowds. This is an amazing gallery filled with statues and paintings. You must book at least a week in advance for a two hour window time to visit. Make sure you allow plenty of time to find it. We took the metro and still had difficulty finding the gallery. Enter at the main gate and walk through the large park to find the entrance of the gallery. It is a long walk from the metro. You have to check all large bags however you can take pictures. This is a new policy. We paid for the English guided tour which left at 11:10 (our entrance time was 11:00). It was well worth the price. However we also read the Rick Steves' guided tour before going which gave us some insight as to what to see.

Bernini and Caravaggio. Speaks for itself. This is a small museum that gets an awful lot of hype. But it really is first rate. I recommend going in with a tour that contextualizes the building as well as the individual pieces of art. The official ones, best I can tell, are all in Italian. That wasn't an issue for me since I know the language. The building itself is in a lovely park. The art inside is exceedingly famous, and it speaks for itself. If you want to see Bernini and Caravaggio masterpieces, it's a must see at some point in your travels to Rome. If you are organized, buy your tickets well in advance, and you won't pay three to five times the regular price from an "authorized vendor."
Bernini!. Lovely gallery in nice surroundings. Must be pre-booked. Its large enough to be interesting and small enough to do in detail. The Bernini sculptures were the highlight of my trip.
Closed on a Monday. Beware this gallery is closed on a Monday. Visited before and it is a lovely spot - the gallery is just the right size.
A beautiful museum. A small museum with some impressive artwork and incredible ceiling paintings. By having a tour guide we learned a great deal about the home, the family and the artwork.

Borghese Gardens Superb. We ended up not going to the Gallery but instead spending our time in the gardens. The weather was superb and our 16 year old grandson hired a Segway for an hour. The atmosphere was magical. A busking Trumpeter,( accompanied by recorded background instruments) played all our favorite songs which we listened to as we waited on the park bench. The crowd of people passing by were all in good humour with exchange of 'high fives' as Segways and pedal bikes passed by, some pedaling in time to the music. My grandson remarked it was like something out of a movie. Definitely our best day in Rome.

fabulous...must buy tickets in advance. wonderful, and worth the extra euros for the tour. you are limited to 2 hours in the gallery, so a guide is essential. we were left with about 1/2 hour at the end of the tour to explore on our own. most important thing is to book in advance online. when we visited in early may, next ticket availability was more than a week away. sad how many people came to buy tickets when none were available. however, limiting the number of visitors makes for a very nice experience for those who purchase tickets in advance..

A beautiful little surprise in the park.. The Borghese estate in the park in the center of Rome is a great place to wander about and relax for hours. The Gallery is in the former Borghese Villa and is beautiful and includes some rotating exhibits as well. Come to the museum and and wander the park for a couple of hours to relax on an afternoon.

Amazing art and building. I was there with an organized tour group. The leaders were smart and got us tickets for the first entry time of the day. This meant with had fewer other visitors to contend with in the galleries. The highlights for me were the Caravaggio paintings and the Bernini sculptures, but the building itself (and its wall paintings) was also extraordinary. Note that one only has 2 hours to tour this attraction. Then you must leave and the new groups are admitted.

A guided tour is highly recommended. The guided tour was great! Expensive, but worth it. I especially loved Bernini's beautiful sculptures. It was not too crowded, and the guide was very good at selecting what to show us and explaining about each painting and sculpture. The tour also included a nice guided tour in the lovely park - with a view of the city.
Inspiring. It's important to book your tickets in advance. I suggest early morning. There is so much to see both inside and out in the gardens

Borghese gallery - absolute highlight . This was one of the best things I saw in Rome and it was an unexpected highlight. I was disorganised and didn't have a pre purchased ticket. They have very strict numbers which means it doesn't get too crowded. What a relief in Rome. As I turned up when it opened I managed to get one ticket even though they were pre selling for 5 days later. I was lucky enough to get on the guided tour as well. It was fantastic, Bernini sculptures, Raphael paintings and more all in beautiful rooms. Such a highlight. I recommend you buy tickets in advance though as I wouldn't dare risk missing out.

Beautiful Gallery but prebuy tickets!. Highly recommend the Borghese Gallery to anyone traveling to Rome less small children. I had been to the gallery before with my adult children several years ago (we lucked in to getting in when we happened upon the Gallery as we did not know about it), but my husband had never been to it. I always prebuy tickets to any of the major sites we plan on seeing, and luckily I did for the Borghese for this trip. The families in front of us were turned away, even using the excuse, "but I've traveled so far". The answer from the ticket clerk was so have the people from China, Australia, and Africa, and the next available tickets are May 11th. This was May 6th. In other words, buy your tickets on line well in advance when planning on seeing this absolutely amazing gallery.
Next to St. Peter's this was our favorite stop. Next to St. Peter's this was our favorite stop! Daphne and Apollo are the most beautiful sculptures anywhere, yes including the David in Florence.

Excellent!. Visited here for the 2nd time, but this time used viator for a fully guided tour (Pia was tremendous!)The guide really gave it another dimension and the offering of great masters on display was a real pleasure.

Unbelievably ornate, and the statues are wonderful!. In a city full of incredible art, I think this was my favorite spot. Our tour guide explained the art well, and the stories about Bernini and the wonderful statues - the Apollo and Daphne is fabulous. On a nice day, the grounds are a pleasant respite from crowds elsewhere. We were lucky to sit on a bench and listen to a street musician playing accordion - it was such a Roman Holiday type of old-time music experience.

FANTASTIC ART. Must gHave a tour guide to better appreciate the beauty of the arts. The family collections of Frescoes and Bernina Sculptures especially the Statue of David is amazing. I also enjoyed walking the vast gardens. A great tour!

Galleria Borgheses - The rudest staff in Rome!. Against some pretty stiff competition the staff at this gallery must surely win the title for the rudest in Rome. We hadn't planned to tour the gallery, we had just accompanied others in our party who were going on a Segway trip round the park that started outside. It was before 10am, teeming with rain and early in the season so we thought we could spend a pleasant hour or so at this famous attraction, however we were informed that there were no tickets available for that day. Fair enough, guide books do say booking in advance is advisable. Nevertheless we decided to have breakfast in the cafe and to buy some souvenirs from the gift shop in the hope that the rain would have eased off in the meantime. In the cafe I was astonished at the way the cashier was dealing with an English couple in the queue in front of me. The lady had ordered and paid for a coke (it was one of those systems where you have to order and pay before taking your receipt to another area where they fill your order) but then decided she also wanted an ice tea. The cashier, chatting to another member of staff, then tried to charge her for two drinks. She tried every way she could think of to explain that she had already paid for the coke and should only have to pay for the additional iced tea but was met with cold indifference and repeated demands for "5€". She was flustered, upset and embarrassed for holding up the queue but when she suddenly remembered the receipt (proof that she had, indeed, paid for the coke) she received no apology whatsoever from the cashier who acted as if the whole incident were due to her stupidity! After eating, I decided to go to the toilet before browsing the gift shop but was met by an attendant who refused me entry on the grounds that I had no ticket for the gallery. I explained I had no ticket because there weren't any available but I had spent money in the cafe and was about to spend more in the shop but she, literally, screamed at me, saying if I had been in the cafe where was my receipt. Of course I didn't have it since I had handed it in at the counter. If I had known that it was also my entry to the toilet I would have treated it with the reverence it deserved! I complained at the ticket desk but the girl there refused to let me speak, she just kept shouting that these were the rules again and again. Rome is great; it is filled with amazing sights and experiences don't waste a moment of your time at the Galleria Borghese.
Very nice villa. I was.more interested in the building itself and not the artworks. Very luxurius and posh, represents the level of Rome's noble families

The Mecca of Bernini admirers. Rome is like a candy store for those who like and admire art. Every corner has fabulous architectural treasures. There are dozens of fabulous museums and modern art galleries abound. However, my favorite spot of all is the Galleria Borghese. Located in the Northern part of central Rome, in the Villa Borghese gardens, this small and self-contained museum hosts some of the most beautiful works of Bernini and Caravaggio. The Rape of Lucretia and Apollo and Daphne are pairless sculptures that capture your imagination and make you wonder how such perfection can exist! Make sure you buy tickets on line in advance of your visit; if not, you will likely miss this fabulous gallery.

Must See, but be Quick. the gallery was so gorgeous and we were very glad to take a tour! Our tour guide truly loved art and art history, he was fantastic. The time constraint is a little tough, but makes it worth it since it isn't ridiculously crowded like other attractions

One of my favorite places in the world.. Extraordinary collection by great, great artists. But for me, it's all about their Bernini collection. Amazing works . I have brought first-time visitors here about 10 times, and they are always stunned by the beauty of these works.Don't miss it- BUT be sure to make reservations well in advance. if you wait, you most likely won't get in. I do it 2 weeks prior.
Very good art gallery!. This museum was the most impressing I've been too. It houses much renaissance and barock sculptures. Don't forget to book tickets in advance!

Welcome to the world of art and beauty. There is a very easy review to be made about Borghese: if you have little time and want to see Rome, come to Borghese. It has everything you need so that to feel the magnificent and mighty world of the Italian art. Art which makes the magic of Italy.

Outstanding gallery, but under time-pressure. There are two floors: the lower floor is mostly sculpture plus Caravaggio paintings; the upper floor is mostly paintings. Both are outstanding - the lower one especially so. But timed tickets (a which you must book in advance) limit you to a 1h:55m visit, which isn't quite enough to see and absorb everything. The audio guide is so-so: it tends to have long descriptions about an entire room, so although it's interesting, it's not terribly helpful while you are there. (It also lasts ~90 minutes, which doesn't give you much time for looking around). But the collection is stunning, and so is the environment.
vacation 2016. A must see hire a private tour guide it's worth the price that you pay they point out things that you would never read about

Another wonderful legacy. Having read reviews suggesting it was imperative to book ahead but you may be lucky if you just pop in, we called in around 2pm and got tickets for the 3pm session. Entry is every 2 hours from 9am to 5pm and apparently limited to 200 people per session. Tickets €11/adult and €5 for the audio guide. It is fair to say that organised chaos reigns in the 20 minutes leading up to the entry times with people milling about not sure which queue to join to check in bags and buy audio guides. This, coupled with the last of the previous visitors returning audio guides and collecting bags, makes for a very confusing time. Some staff were quite off hand which was disappointing. The collection itself is brilliant. Cardinal Borghese started something quite unique and his legacy continued through subsequent generations. Bernini's sculptures are exquisite and the gallery itself is beautiful to see.It was disappointing that the secret gardens are currently in a state of disrepair and the parterre garden looked very unloved. The Villa and its gardens are meant to be viewed as a whole so hopefully the gardens will get some attention soon.Highly recommend this gallery if you are prepared for the chaos at the beginning. Assistance for the disabled can be organised. The cafe serves excellent coffee and light meals at good prices but can be understaffed at the busy times.

Breathtaking. What can one say about this extraordinary place? The Bernini sculptures are totally devastating in every way.The statue of David is worth the admission price alone.You must book in advance but if you visit Rome and miss this you will regret it for ever.Utterly sensational and quite literally breathtaking.
Frescoes everywhere. Filled with frescoes, the museum is interesting. But it's only 2 floors and you will soon run out of stuff to see.

Fantastic!. A somewhat overlooked museum in Rome, but very conveniently located and well worth visiting. We joined a City Wonders tour and had a great guide. The surrounding park is very nice to stroll around and affords fantastic views of Rome.

Beautiful sculptures. We had been pointed to this gallery by our friend who know Italian renesance really good. The sculptures by Bernini are really masterpieces! Our 8-year old enjoyed for over an hour crawling with an audio guide through the exhibition!

Beautiful museum and park. Definitely a must see. Also a must-buying your tickets online ahead of time, or at least reserving them. Plan on spending at least three hours here, and that is if you are moving along and not pausing for reflection. It is well worth it.

Lovely interesting gallery. Four of us took a guided tour which was worth it. We normally just take headsets but opted for a guide this time. The knowledgable guide explained the history behind the Bellini statues and the paintings. The two hours passes very quickly. Helpful hints. There is a lift up to the second floor for elderly visitors but you need to ask. The toilets are perfectly OK , ignore previous reviews. However you need to have your ticket before going in or the guardian of the toilet will not let you thru. The cafe is good; you just need to pay before you get your food in the usual Italian way.
Beautiful building in a fab park. Would have loved to visit the gallery. Did not pre-book. So if you are thinking of going book in advance

If you want to visit a museum in Rome then make it this one. A friend thankfully told me to visit this gallery whilst in Rome & warned that you have to book your tickets well in advance. We pre booked/purchased tickets for the 10th May & when we went there was a sign on the day saying the earliest available tickets for purchase was the 17th May. A lady in the queue had a Roma Pass, but she was advised that she still had to reserve her tickets to gain free entry. So glad we booked, the paintings & sculptures are amazing. Bernini, Caravaggio, Rubens & much more. Even if you don't book for the Gallery the park is lovely & free to Walk around. They have segways & cycles for hire. Tip to get there - from Spanish Steps take the Spagna Metro & follow the signs for Borghese Villa, you don't actually get on a train, you just take the escalators & moving walkways to get to the Borghese exit - about 10 minute walk. Also even though you have to check you bag in you can take your camera in to take photos.

Good to see B4 Vatican. 1st day we went to the Gallery,. We orderd tickets on the internet so we only had to wait to our sharp time. otherwise you had to come a day later! very nice pictures and sculptures. Better to see before the Vatican museums because after that nothing is impressing.

Borghese borishness. We had a reservation. Paid, but had an emergency that meant we spent an hour at the police station. We were an hour past our start time when we arrived and the staff was completely inflexible and very rude. Do not expect that the Roman staff will have compassion or be willing to assist in any way if you need help. If we had been bleeding to death they probably would of asked us to not bleed on their fine marble floors and asked us to leave. Not only that, they say you have 2 hours in the museum but ask you to leave 15 minutes before your time is up and lock the bathrooms so you can't even relieve yourself. Mussolini would be proud. Also expect to check you bag, as they are inflexible about this as well. It was truly disappointing and and a very unfortunate experience.

Beautiful museum, stunning gardens. Whether you choose to go around the museum and gallery or just walk around the gardens this is a terrific place to visit especially on a hot sunny day. We only did part of the gallery the ground floor which has the most amazing statutes and works of art and the ceilings are unbelievably beautiful. We then spent a couple of hours walking the gardens and grounds. This is called the 'Lungs of Rome' and it's vast. There is a little train that goes around for those who don't want to walk and also little double bicycles which you pedal around. A lovely way to spend an afternoon in the heat of summer lots of fountains and shady woodlands. Highly recommended.
The "must see" museum in Rome. One of the best, small scale, museums that we have ever visited. Book tickets early, before arriving in Rome, or you will miss out.

A feast of Italian art. Incredible collection of masterpieces. Famous but breathtaking sculptures by Bernini, can't believe that it was made of stone!The upper floor is mostly dedicated to paintings. Raffael, Bronzino, Cranah old, etc. actually words fail.The pilaf one and the frescos on the walls are also fantastic. Two tips:Book well in advance, especially in high season,Second, take your time. Usually you are given two hour visit but none would check and you can enjoy the exhibits unhurriedly
Pretty. This is a pretty place to walk around and spend some time. Not too thrilling but I would suggest going if you have time to kill.

Highlight to Rome visit. Managed to book on the phone after several visits to Rome. What a thrilling day & so many treasures to view. Be prepared for half an hour's walk through the park from Metro station.
Not to be missed. Even with a Roma pass you need to book in advance. We failed to do this and ended up having to pay for tickets. The Bernini sculptures are stunning.

Book in Advance!. A must see gallery in Rome! One of the highlights of our trip! At a Minimum get an audio guide. It does not cover everything but you can also get a personal guide upon entering. Take a walk through the park or just rest on a bench afterwards and enjoy people watching.

Don't use the toijets. This gallery is a cornucopia of wonders .. Caravaggio, Bellini. Titian. Raffael... But! The toilets are possibly the worst ever encountered in a public place save for the Great Wall of China in 1985 . There is one block at the entry- not many & 1 didn't flush & 1 had no paper. As I was with a group I didn't have time to wait so had to use upstairs. Nothing on first level & only 1 on 2nd which was smelly & had no seat. I fail to comprehend how the toilets can be in such a deplorably disgusting state in such a magnificent gallery. Note to visitors don't go unless you are truly desperate..

Disappointing. Judging by the fact that you had to get reservations weeks in advance, I expected this to be an incredible place. If you had a 2:00 reservation, you could not enter until 2:00. The best part were the first 3 rooms, which had great artwork. The rest was average at best. It looks like they tried to fill the rest of the rooms with whatever they could find. The other issue was everything was in Italian. Other museums had Italian with English below. If you wanted to understand, you had to grab a card for each room. These cards were disorganized, as quite often the wrong cards were in the wrong rooms.I was expecting a lot more from this gallery.

worth while. Best art and sculpture collection I have ever seen You wont be disappointed ,howeveryou must buy tickets in advance as they are sold out at least a week in advance anice walk in the park either before or after
greaqt place. we visit Biorghese villa museum. Great collection of art especially sculptures. Can get quite crowded so book early in the day and it is a good idea to visit during midweek

Breath-taking. Do order your tickets online. We watched many people get turned away. There may be times when you can just walk up and purchase a ticket but it would be a shame to come a long distance and not be able to get in. The number of people who may enter at one time is limited so you never feel that it is crowded. If there were nothing in the gallery other than the Bernini sculptures, it would worth the price of your ticket but there is so much more! This is an absolute must when you visit Rome. There is a cafeteria on the lower floor if you would like coffee and a sandwich. And try to allow time to enjoy the park surrounding the villa.

Must See!. I loved this museum. (Must make reservations in advance!) Be sure to give yourself plenty of time before your scheduled entry time to get there, check your bags, and get your audio guide if you choose. I don't always get audio guides in museums but I'm happy I did here. This is a beautiful museum with some really amazing works. The two hour window of time that you have is plenty. I found that I was able to go through in an hour and a half and didn't feel like I was rushing. I highly recommend walking around the beautiful park either before or afterwards.

Renovation a success. The high price tag is worth it as having timed entrance to the museum makes for less crowded viewings. The most comprehensive Bernini sculptures, Raphael's and Caravaggio paintings in every room, what's not to like? You must leave purses and bags at check in, but are allowed to keep cell phones to take photos of all the fantastic artwork. Worth walking down hill to Popolo Piazza. About a 15-20 minute walk

One of Rome's most beautiful sights.. The Borghese Gallery is a wonderful place for lovers of Renaissance art. For others, it might not be worth the expense and time. First, it is essential to book a reservation ahead of time. You cannot merely show up and expect to get in. You are limited to a visit of two hours and this is vigorously enforced by the staff, I felt rushed with that time limit. I would suggest that you research the collection ahead of time and decide what works are most important to you. Another suggestion is to go upstairs first to see the painting collection while most of the other visitors are downstairs looking at the sculpture. Then you can go downstairs while they have come upstairs, And after visiting the Gallery spend some time in the large park surrounding it. It is one of Rome's most beautiful green spaces.
Amazing collection. Feel the Bernini and make it to this museum gallery. The villa of the Borghese family turned into a magnificent art gallery experience. Each room is breath taking and amazing.
Wow! Amazing!. Incredible treasures in this magnificent museum. Sculptures are unbelievable! You must not miss this! We took audio tour which was great!
Amazing park. What a great park. Elite ally worth a visit and you can relax for a few hours. Also rent a Segway and have some fun!!! We really enjoyed our time

Go and visit it, is really excellent. You don't really need to be an art expert to appreciate the beauty and the taste of the collection. That being said, if you know a thing or two about art, this is a truly rewarding place.

Party Villa turned into an amazing Art Gallery!. A former Pope amassed this unbelievable collection of mostly Baroque Art in this Roman Estate built as a party villa, surrounded by gardens which unfortunately were in disrepair when we visited in early May. We chose the self-guided headset tour which did a fine job of describing what we were viewing & you can do this at your own pace which I like. If you didn't know better you might think you were in the museums at the Vatican with this overwhelming collection...a must-see for the art lover! Do make a reservation & show up on time or you'll be turned away.
Stunning collection. A very manageable museum in a wonderful park. Usually need tickets in advance. Reserve well in advance for your 2 hour visit.

A must see! . We took a guided tour with City Wonders and it was well worth it. Our guide, Georgia, was excellent. Her enthusiasm was contagious. Its a remarkable collection. The sculptures by Bernini are incredible. I suggest that you do book in advance. After the gallery we took a walk through the gardens to the overlook of the Piazza del Popolo. A great view.

Stunning art and building, crowds a big problem. We visited the Borghese some years ago and couldn't wait to get back. We did this May. Stunning building and art. But, we think they are letting in many more people than before, and more than they can effectively handle. Dirty toilets, no paper, one person to change your voucher to admission tickets - so a long line, and a long line to check bags (mandatory). You must book tickets minimally one week in advance - you can't just walk up and expect to get in. We booked a month in advance and still had to be flexible with date and entry time. Having seen it twice (and loved the art), don't think we'll go back anytime soon. Too much of a hassle.

MUST SEE! !!!!!!. You MUST MAKE RESERVATIONS Before you go, and then show up for your time that you have selected, (there was a guy in front of me that missed his time and he was our of luck) they only allow a small amount of people in at a time, Unbelievable art marble statues just beautiful!

Worth The Quirks. A beautiful collection of works in and amazing setting, and absolutely worth the navigating you will need to do to get into the place.First, tickets are usually bought on line. The first oddity is that when you choose an available date and time slot, you will be prompted to "choose your seats", like you are in a theatre. There are no seats, as you are merely lining up to access the exhibit.You will get a confirmation of the booking by email...make sure you print this and bring it with you.It is recommended that you show up 1 hour before your time, which is good advice, as the steps to gain entry are poorly designed and time consuming1. Line up to get your actual tickets2. Line up to rent the audio guides3. Line up to check your backpacks and purses (very strict)4. Line up to enter the museum/gallery...which is outside the portico. Not sure what the plan is if it is raining.Once inside, you have two hours to tour. And they aren't kidding. At 10 minutes to the two hour mark, you are asked to leave the premises. You will then join the throng to collect your checked backpacks.It is suggested you pace your touring. They indicate the tour of the upper painting gallery should be limited to 30 minutes, which leaves 90 minutes for the more art rich first floor. I would suggest you move along through the galleries on the lower floor with some briskness, and then return to dwell on favourites if time allows.You really need about 2.5-3 hours to do this gallery justice, but as it stands, you need to keep an eye on your time.

Fantastic gallery. This was a great museum in a beautiful and peaceful green setting. You definitely have to reserve it in advance online. The size of the museum was just right for us, as it wasn't so large that it was overwhelming but there was still enough to see. The selection of the pieces is fantastic and found the art quite stunning and unique. The space itself is also beautiful.
Must See OUTSTANDING. Caravaggio's and those great Bernini Sculptures. Honestly my favourite gallery anywhere. It was busy and the staff could have been more friendly but the art is to die for.

Visually stunning. We came here and followed Rick Steves' direction from his guidebook for a great visit here. This helped with our tour and highlighted many magnificent works of art. Statues by Bernini. Painting by Caravaggio. In their original setting. Magnificent. One of our highlights in Rome.
Order before . You need to order visit gallery Borghese before your visit! We arrived 4 of may and the museum was selling tickets only for 11 of may. But the place is great like everything in Rome

a "must do". Make sure you pre-purchase your tickets. They usually sell out a few days in advance and it would be a shame to miss it. They only allow 200 people inside at a time, and your ticket is strictly timed. We did the guided tour, which allowed some time at the end to continue our exploration of this incredible site.

Lovely Gardens. The Gallery was so nice to see. Some things lost on us as we don't speak the language but with an Audio or tour guide definitely worth it. The gardens were lovely to walk around. Nice day out!
Amazing Art Collection. A must-see gallery for art lovers. Includes marvelous works by Italian artists. Check out amazing masterpieces by Bernini.

Great Art; Inconvenient. We visited this small museum and found it to be inconvenient. The building and the art (including works by Bernini, Caravaggio and Rubens) are wonderful. But one can only visit with a set time reservation at certain intervals, for a set amount of time, which artificially created a more crowded environment. This is also the only museum in Rome that required that I check my handbag, which is on the smaller size to avoid this very issue, so I had to carry a number of plastic bags to hold my valuables and eyeglasses through the museum.
Fine arts museum of first tier quality. I found the Baroque sculptures worth the cost and trip. Be sure to book ahead as they require reservations for admission.

Splendid collection. The Borghese popes collected well, but the sculpture and the building itself make it well worth the almost obligatory advance booking. The surcharges are exorbitant, but if you chance stopping by for a ticket a day or two later, you'll miss out on a small Roman treasure. Take something to read and sit in the garden on a bench afterward.

Best of Bernini. best collection of Bernini's sculptures anywhere. Many good Caravaggio's too. Room after room of priceless artworks. And the rooms themselves are worth the price of admission. You have to book online in advance. No exceptions.

Story, history, all beautiful creations of mankind. I had a vip experience since the entrance, guide support and a wonderful houers d'ouvre. But to think that there are criations older than my country really made me crazy about. I recommend, since it is story and history in a nutshell.

Must see. This is by far one of the most astounding gallery's to visit! See some of the greatestArt in the world, allow lots of time to truly absorb the perfection and beauty of theGreat works! The grounds are also spectacular!

Beautiful oasis but beware closed on Mondays. We climbed the hill to see the gallery in the lovely Borghese gardens but it was closed - though the guidebook and website did not say so. Lovely setting and the park is very pleasant to walk through. Interesting to see the traditional garden design and fabulous fruit tree collection.Cleary needs a lot of upkeep.The children enjoyed the zoo, which was a good fun size.

Wow-excessive consumption from old world Italy.. Buy tickets in advance! We were lucky and bought two tickets and walked in, but that was only after being told the odds were low we could purchase tickets as they were sold out. However, 15 minutes after the tour begins they release some unclaimed tickets.The tours are two hours, buy the audio device for a more meaningful tour. The explanations are invaluable and yet, the tour is completely overwhelming. "Sensory overload" is all I can say. Murals, statues, paintings beyond the imagination. A good idea would be to review online available resources to acquaint yourself with the gallery.Be prepared to climb stairs unless you can squeeze into a tiny, circular elevator.The art is really something you have to see to believe; quite over-the-top for my tastes. This is not a young child gallery.The restrooms are not pristine evidence of the huge crowds that gong on the gallery. The grounds are wonderful and are conducive to strolling around for hours.

Please do not miss this!. This was truly a highlight of our visit to Rome. It was recommended to buy our tickets well in advance (we did) and to choose the first time period in the morning (we did). They are very strict about when you may enter the museum, the tickets do sell out quickly, and while we enjoyed a wonderful visit, we were astonished to see just how crowded it became as we were leaving at 11 am! Wonderful gift shop, and fantastic grounds to walk around after you exit. Do not bring valuables, as everything that does not fit into your pockets will be required to be checked in. Also, spring for the audio set, it has an enormous amount of info that you will enjoy as you stroll from room to room.

Underwhelmed. We were looking forward to going here since we planned our trip. However on getting here, it was not as great as we expected. The location of the gallery is very far from the main city center, no restaurants close by, and for the time we traveled to visit it, it really was not worth it.
Greatday. Large area parkland park outside cafesLarge boating pond with rented boatsMuseum Locals taking a strole through parkPark free to walk throughNot advised to risk entering when going dark

Nice art but not worth the hype. Let me start off by saying that there are some nice pieces in this gallery; however, in my opinion it does not live up to the hype. Tickets sell out sometimes weeks in advance, so it makes it seem that this is a must see while in Rome. The gallery itself is quite small, with two floors (statues on the first floor and paintings on the second). When you book you get a 2 hour window and depending on how much time you spend looking at each piece, this should be more than enough to see everything. If you happen to get tickets then it is a nice gallery to see in Rome, but if they are not available do not feel like you are missing something major! Definitely check out the Vatican museum if you only have limited time available.
MUST. Superb museum in a superb villa. Paintings but above all the Bernini sculptures. Lovely park outside.

Go to the park/garden for an off the beaten path experience (very affordable too!). I highly highly recommend walking at the park and boating on the lake in the Borghese gallery park/garden grounds. It was a romantic way to end a day full of sightseeing. Me and my fiancé enjoyed boating on the lake for 20 minutes, which sounds short but it was enough to enjoy the small, gorgeous lake. It was relaxing especially when some musician at the park was playing violin or harmonica. The park was not crowded and not filled with tourist. We paid about €5.00 (or less, if I'm not mistaken. all I know was that it was cheap) for two people for 20 minutes. You will definitely enjoy and I highly recommend. You will not regret.

Borghese Gallery. Had a 2 hour tour with Susanna from Driver Guide Service. The art work is incredible! Original works still in the place it was designed for, not just a bunch of stuff gathered and shoved into a museum. Our second time there and we'd do it again next time!

One of the world's greatest galleries.. You have to pre-book for a specified two hour slot - I booked online a few days before travelling. Exquisite rooms filled with works by Caravaggio, Raphael, Titian, etc and statuary of Bernini and the famous (perhaps infamous) Canova sculpture of Pauline Borghese. Two hours is about enough time for you to enjoy this without getting artistic indigestion! Be selective.I'm in my 70s, yet walked there and back from the Flaminio metro (near the Piazza del Popolo) through the Villa Borghese park to reach the gallery. A very pleasant walk away from the crowds - on a dry day!Something of a bind to have to pre-book, but well worth the effort.

Getting to Borghese Gallery by bus.. Here is a suggestion which should be useful. From the bus stop at the Barberini metro stop (RED LINE AND THE SAME STOP WHICH IS FOR THE TREVI FOUNTAIN) take the Bus number 61 towards Villa Borghese. However do not make the mistake (which I had made) to travel to Villa Borghese. You need to get off the bus much earlier at S.PALO DEL BRASILE. This is two stops from Barberini amd takes less than 5 minutes to reach there.As you get off the bus, you will see a gate to a massive garden on the same side. Look for the sign to Borghese gallery.From here it is a straight path which is about 300-400 meters long that leads to the Gallery.Very close to the gate there is a Cine Borghese and this is NOT THE GALLERY although you see the pic of that on the website.The number 61 bus runs at about one per 20 minutes.
Looked great but couldn't get in. Everything was massively booked in advance, so make sure you do the same or else you're SOL for a weekend visit to Rome.
Nice but not a hit with the kids. Younger travelers did not appreciate the splendour of the palace nor the works of art. An adult only visit is recommended.

don't forget to book tickets!!. if you decided to visit only one gallery in Rome it should be it. amazing and famous pictures and sculptures. you must book the tickes in their website in advanced. the visit is limited for only 2 hours. it is best to take guided tour or to be prepared in advanced so you can understand more what you see

The best art in Rome. Tickets sell fast for the gallery and it's easy to see why. The collection is superb and the grounds are stunning. We loved it. Well worth booking in advance to ensure you don't miss out!

Beautiful Renaissance and Manerist Art. Gorgeous sculpture, some vary nice paintings derived almost completely from the Borgese family collection.. The setting is incomparable and historically accurate. Make revervations well in advance, or you will be shut out.

Closed!. Booked this through Viator and was very excited to be going, but they shut the gallery without notice.
Gutted! Had to leave Rone the next day so no chance of a revisit.

Borghese Gallery. The most outstanding non-royal collection of art. Set in a park just outside the Roman Wall. Here you sill see a private collection of art by Raphael, Caravaggio, and statues by Bernini, to name a few.
You should see this. Not as publicized as other Rome sights, this is a must-see for art and architecture lovers. The grounds are peaceful and there is a lot of hidden nooks and crannies

Inspirational, but be wary of tourists. The staff is nice enough, but given that the Borghese Gallery limits the number of persons and only takes reservations, you would think they would have some experience with crowds. In our reservation was a group of at least 50 teenagers who had no respect for anyone or anything around them. They completely dominated the bag check-in, and almost made my husband and I late for our reservation. When you are only given 2 hours, every minute counts.
