If you have time for just1 gallery in Rome -this is the place. Not too big,but very rich with sculptures and paintings- mainly Baroque style. I loved the "David" and the Bernini sculptures.Don't forget to order tickets in advance.

must see. make sure you book before you go this place gets very busy only so many people allowed in at certain times get there early park is worth a look round the statues are the best part of visit pictures not to my taste a bit to religious also you will be kicked out when your time slot has finished so watch the time

One of the best art collections in Rome. Galleria Borghese is a gorgeous example of Roman art collections. It errs towards the classical side, with incredible marble statues, as well as Caravaggio paintings. The interiors are lovely as well, and the visiting exhibits that contrast with the traditional art are usually some of the best in Rome.

Expansive Park and Beautiful Setting!. Bring your comfortable shoes because you'll do lots of walking unless you rent a bicycle. The signage isn't the best here as it drops off so it's not that easy to navigate yourself to the actual museum for which you need to get your tickets in advance. The grounds are beautiful and serve as a wonderful retreat from the city. No entrance fee required for the park and there are activities here for small kids like a carousel and pony rides.

Closed to non-bookers. When we arrived about 10am, there was just a school party waiting to go in. We walked up to the entrance hall which was empty apart from two custodians who told us to go downstairs for tickets. Having done this, we were staggered to be told none were available till 1pm. Our pleas that we'd seen no advice about pre-booking, had a plane to catch soon after and that the place was empty fell on deaf ears.Call them to book.

A must see in Rome. Fabulous museum. It is best to book online. It's important to come on time as they do send you out after your two hours are completed. If coming by public transportation make sure you get off close to the gallery as it is a long walk from the entrance to the garden.

Worth the visit. A very lovely, manageable museum. Not huge so you are not there or skipping parts just to get through. The grounds are wonderful by themselves so feel free to just stroll the park. Lots of trees, so even in July it's barabel in the heat.

Absolutely Brilliant. Booked for the 11.00 entry and arrived early at approx 10.20 and were allowed in as not too many people in. Absolutely amazing place, don't forget to look up at the ceilings as the frescos were also breathtaking - I found that the sculptures and paintings were so wonderful and the setting in the villa made you forget you are in a museum. My husband who doesnt normally appreciate museums also really loved this visit - so much to see and only 2 hours - could have spent all day here. Enjoy the park afterwards. We took the 910 bus from outside the Termini (train Station) which dropped us off at the park gates. We bought Roma passes and used this as one of our 'free museums' together with the Colloseum - just remember to book your timed entry.

Beautiful setting. We walked to the Borghese Gallery and enjoyed the peace and greenery after the rush of the central city attractions. The sculptures by Bernini are breathtaking. The cafe is slightly disappoinnting, take a picnic and eat it in a beautiful setting.

A beautiful gem. It's a tiny Vatican museum. It's just simply beautiful. The collection is breathtaking. My favorite is Bernini's Apollo and Daphne, which is just a masterpiece. Make sure you make a reservation online (required) and you may want to spend some time walking the grounds. There is also a museum of modern art nearby (Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna), with a nice cafe, perfect for lunch or coffee.

Honor to be near such paintings. All details for planning a visit are described in details on the webpage: booking your tickets, collecting them and to be prepared for a meeting with one of the most incredible paintings collection on this planet. The most overwhelming thing is that each of works in the building is a masterpiece and is alone worth a visit, but together they provide unforgettable feeling of being in a place you will never forget.After new group is let to the museum it is quite crowded in first hall, but if you use this time to proceed further, you can enjoy it on your way back.

Amazing collection of masterpieces. Been to Rome many times, but this was the first time at the Borghese.This estate that belonged to the famous Borghese family was sold to the Italian government over a hundred years ago. What a great collection of paintings, especially the Carvaggios. Amazing 3-dimentional appering ceiling fresco in the first room.Get tickets in advance, be prepared to walk up stairs, and get everything seen in the 2 hour slot time allowed.

Worth doing, but make a reservation!. We visited on the first time slot of the morning. They recommend that you arrive early but for this time slot it's pointless, it's shut so you can't go in anyway. You are given 3 hours which for us was more than enough, we were approx 2 hours and felt like we spent a lot of time taking everything in.
A magical collection of art. There is everything here from Caravaggio to Bernini.With Daphne and Apollo just mind blowing. Each room is just amazing and the two hour allotted time slot just perfect .
Most amazing art museum you will ever visit!. You need to make reservations, but so worth it. I have never seen such a wonderful display of artwork. Just breathtaking. Words will not do it justice.

All I hoped for and more. As a student of art history I was looking forward to our visit. I'm a fan of Caravaggio so seeing so many of his works, albeit earlier ones, was indeed a treat. But the sculpture was what blew me away. To see, in person, Apollo's garment floating in space, parallel to the ground, was a thing of beauty. Add to this, the beautiful designs by Azzedine Alaia which took the experience over the top. Only problem I had, time went by too quickly to savor it all.

Unexpected Treasure!!. If you like Culture, Art and Museums you have to add this to your schedule. There are Gardens and a Museum (rent the Audio Guides) and plan on a minimum of 3 hours. If you only see one Museum, make it The Borghese. (Buy your Tickets online prior to your Visit)

A great museum worth to visit. If you love Bernini then you will love the Borghese museum. We spent two hours in this museum and love the incredible sculpture of Bernini. Unfortunately it was not possible to spend a longer time. Worth to see it once in Rome

Fantastic sculptures and painting.. I am not going to make an art review :)
Visiting hours are pre-defined, so it is best to plan your visit and book online in advance.

impressive. hard to find.. The art and building were fabulous. Probably the only thing in Rome I would take a cab to see. I like subways. But it is in a large park and kind of hard to find --- the cab lets you out 100 yards from the door.

Sensory overload!. The building was hard to find on foot and we swear that the sign posts were wrong; however, the grounds were very pleasant to add unexpected kilometres! The tea room was small and someone was stopping people using the toilets if their tour time was not close! Anyway, the top level (where you have to begin) impressed us... then the lower level really was an incredible feast of art and design in sumptuous splendour.

Difficult to view. Made the trip here but didn´t know you had to pre book (not everyone has 24 hour access to internet!) so didn´t get to go in and next availability was 3 days later when we were flying home. Also not easy to find. Sign posts in the park are lacking in some areas. However, we did have a coffee in the café which was very nice but weren´t allowed to use the toilets as we hadn´t been in to the museum! Maybe next time we go to Rome we´ll pre book this attraction.

Excellent museum. The Borghese gallery one of the best museum in the world and is surely a nice place to visit because it is a very special place, all about the work of art in the gallery together with the surrounding including the beautiful gardens the building and also they limit the amount of people in the museum so there is no a lot of crowd in reservations, but the best thing to do is to buy your ticket online earlier before date, you don`t have to miss this

Park or Palace / it's all good. The "Central Park" of Roma is the Villa Borghese. Great place to stroll, picnic or relax. BUT the Galleria Borghese is a must as well. Book your tickets in advance. The limited access makes for a wonderful experience without the Vatican Herd mentality.

Must see. To enter the gallery you have to reserve in advance. The ticket grants you entrance for two hours in specific time-slots. We reserved our tickets online. In addition, you will have to deposit an ID if you want to get an audio-guide, which costs an additional 5-euro per person (and it's worth it in our opinion).Remember to deposit your bag before entering, as it is forbidden inside. There is a line for this as well, so it's a good idea to come early (even though usually you won't use up the whole 2 hours of your visit anway).The gallery itself is marvelous. Especially notable to us were the statues by Bernini – Pauline Bonaparte and Daphne and Apollo, as well as the paintings by Carravagio. Don't miss this Gallery, and make sure to walk around the beautiful gardens surrounding it (the Villa Borghese) after or before your visit to the gallery. The service at the ticket office is quite rude as is typical of Italian service in tourist attractions, but don't let that stop you.

A Gem. The Borghese Gallery and the Gardens are very special. The works of art in the gallery are priceless and the building itself is a work of art. Be sure to get tickets well ahead of time, they limit the number of visitors which is good, never the crowd like in many other museums.

Excellent Must See Museum, But Book Ahead Anytime of Year. The Villa Borghese houses one of the best single collections of masters in the world. Bernini's Apollo Chasing Daphne and the Rape of Proserpina are incredible. The gallery is not enormous, but there is a lot of incredible art to see. Reservations are REQUIRED even in low season. You can make reservations on-line and pick your tickets up at the gallery before your reserved time. You do not need to purchase through a ticket broker. Groups are let in according to the reservation time, so get there before your time. The Villa Borghese is a mansion surrounded by the Borghese Gardens which are located above the Spanish Steps. The gardens (public park) is worth a visit to chill out if you need to escape the crowds.

Buy your tickets online before you leave home. Plan ahead to visit this gallery. Tickets sell out days (weeks, in the summer) in advance! If you can, book your tickets online as soon as you know when you can visit. You'll need to print your confirmation and bring it with you. Their rules are a bit archaic, but if you don't follow them, you'll be denied admittance. It is so worth it to visit this museum. Collection is beautiful, but very small compared to the Vatican Museums. Quality, however, is 5 stars.Coat check for your bags, jackets, umbrellas, etc. Photography IS ALLOWED (this is new) inside and cameras are not accepted in coat check. Small cafe below and nice gift shop.

This is the 'must see' gallery in Rome. Take the time to approach this gallery via the gardens and stroll among the many carved stone portrait heads and marvel at the diversity of artistic talent. This is a wonderful FREE exhibition. The Borghese is one of the best galleries in Rome, I think, and houses many 'must see' works of art, in particular the amazing sculptures. There is so much to see that it is perhaps worth a second visit, if you have the time.
Simply the best. The best gallery in Rome and the one of the nacest places I have ever visited. The excellent art collection will satisfy every person interested in or passionnate with Italian art.

Put It on Your Rome To Do List Early & Use your Time Strategically. As many others have said, the quality of the sculptures, paintings and mosaics are without equal in the city. Whereas others have Roman copies of Greek statues or repaired ones, pristine ORIGINALS are here. Authentic gladiatorial mosaics laid out like promotional posters too. One of Bernini's sculptures as a 12-year-old! Masterpieces by Raphael, Titian and Caravaggio. Gotta see this place.This is off peak, so we were able to reserve weekend spots online with just 2 days advance notice. On peak, think about booking 1-2 weeks beforehand. Go with a touring plan. Speed up your tour by doing the second floor FIRST. Less crowded that way. We took Rick Steves' book along on our tablet to winnow the field down and used the audio guides for the rest that interested us. We finished the whole museum with 20 minutes to spare, so no lines to pick up our bags. Avoid the crush to check bags/backpacks by arriving at least 30 minutes before your scheduled time.It's worth noting that they have an exceptional cafeteria. Really good snacks, sandwiches and wonderful espresso drinks for reasonable prices. Terrible sit down area though. Tiny and jam packed. If the weather is good, think about taking your snack outside to eat in the surrounding villa gardens.Highly Recommended.
Disappointing that we needed to book . Difficult to find if using the tourist maps and guide books.We never found it and would not bother in future visits
Weekend away. Majestic Collection of the finest works in marble to be seen. accompanied with works of art by some of Europe's renowned masters.

Get your tickets online. Went here to get away from the busy streets of rome didn't get in the gallery as no entrance unless you have had tickets reserved.never the less the park was a great day out with pedlos for hire boat hire at the lake with turtles.so visit here just to relax .

A must see!. This place was absolutely amazing. Exquisite works of art by the masters. Must book ticket well in advance and reserve a time slot. We did the guided tour and that was worth the price (about 6.50 euro). The great thing is that only a certain amount of tickets are sold for each time slot (2 hour blocks), so you are not crammed in with a thousand people to see each piece. The guided tour lasts about and hour and a half, which gives you about 30 minutes to backtrack to your favorite pieces before he next group is let in.

Stunning!. Spectacular art in a spectacular building set in a lovely park. Book online and arrive early; it takes time to get your bags and stuff which is not allowed in in the cloakroom.The park itself is worth a visit on it's own right.

Do not ask directions from the guy at the reception area!. We visited the gallery on a day that was overcast and wet. My friend was not feeling well and so we chose to leave after a short while. Nothing to do with the gallery. The little that I saw was awe inspiring and I plan to return. We asked the guy at the reception desk for directions to Piazza Venezia. He told us to get on 71 and it would take us directly there. Needless to say we ended up in a very unsafe area so be careful. Most of the people are friendly and very helpful.

Overwhelming enjoyment!. This was a surprise tour as it delivered so much more than expected with an exceptional art collection combined with the family Borghese history. We were fortunate to have booked a tour, and Rebecca the guide was so passionate about Bernini, the whole tour was such a deep emotional experience.Set in quiet surrounding grounds with a cafe for food and drinks to relax prior or after the tour also added to the convenience.
2nd Only to the Vatican Museum. A must see collection of fine art and sculpture. You must reserve ahead as the visit is limited to small groups.

A must see... in my second trip to rome i planned to visit villa borghese with my friends: the gallery is a must see place, the painting, bernini sculptures, the ceiling everything was fantastic...we were astonished. we didn't have plenty of time as the duration of the visit is for 2 hours only :(

Spectacular art, spectacularly badly organised. Booked online, low season, for a specific time slot. Still, queued for 45 mins to a) collect ticket, b) leave bag in cloakroom (mandatory) and c) to actually get in. It's like buying a train ticket in India 20 years ago, but less efficient. The audio guides can only be hired with cash ( no cards, splendid, welcome to the 21st century).Once you're in, however - great art - lots of Bernini sculptures, and plenty of paintings of course. When you leave the Borghese gallery you also need to queue again - only 5 mins in our case - to retrieve your bag ( almost funny).Advice - don't take a bag ( avoid 2 queues) and do take cash ( for audio guide). In my opinion, if you had to choose, you get a lot more bangs for your buck ( in terms of time, effort & cash spent) at the well-organised and obscenely well-stocked Vatican museums.

Don't leave this out of your trip!!!. The audio tour made this gallery a great way to see art and sculptures that anyone can appreciate! I learnt a lot and got to see a good range of work!! You need to pre-book tickets but this can easily be done on the website. The only downside is that in one part of the gallery you are only allowed 30minutes - some may want more time!!
Ticket in advanced!. We are in Rome only for 3 nights and they already running out of tickets. You should reserve ticket in advance. Their bookstore have good collections.
A must see!. You must visit one of the most prominent art collections in Southern Europe. Bernini's sculptures are hosted in one beautiful palazzo, amidst one of the coolest gardens of Italy.

Lives Up To The Hype. Visited Rome out of season so had little bother booking a suitable time slot to visit. Easy to get to by local bus, although heavy rain made the walk from stop to gallery a little damp. A pleasant coffee bar in the Gallery to while away a few minutes waiting for the visit slot to begin. So much to see and perhaps a little overwhelming at first. Might be an idea to pre plan and focus on a few items you really wish to see as otherwise you want to see everything and not sure whether you can in the 2 hour visit slot. What it would have been like had not Napoleon "plundered" the Gallery is beyond imagination. Definitely worth the effort and could visit numerous times as so many interesting objects. A must do.

Gorgeous Setting and a Great Collection. Make reservations in advance and be prepared to leave all bags (including purses) at the coat check. This place is amazing and you could spend hours looking at the incredible collection! One room after another, your jaw will drop. Loved it.

A magnificent museum!. We had never got around to visiting the Borghese Gallery, and more fool us! It's truly a magnificent museum!We booked our date and time online, as one will find it difficult to just turn up and get in! We'd booked for 11am and all that day's tickets had gone!From the outside its a very grand baroque palace, but once one is inside it certainly has the "wow" factor - it's outstanding!Each room is absolutely beautiful with incredible statues by the likes of Bernini, centrally positioned, with others dotted around the room which is also festooned with the most amazing of paintings by Caravaggio amongst many!Bernini's David is there, but of course one can only think of Michelangelo's David in comparison.The Caravaggio's are incredible and a must see in themselves!There were too many paintings of religious content for our taste, but if that's your thing then you won't be disappointed.I wouldn't waste your time going to the cafeteria- it's overpriced for what they offer; the staff are rude and unfriendly - more interested in chewing coffee beans, talking to one another, or looking at their paperwork- rather than serve their queuing customers! Totally letting the Gallery down!

Sculptures - just wow. Had been told that if we only visited one museum in Rome, this should be it and that was so true. From the ancient fresco ceiling art to the stunning berlini and other artists' statues - we were just blown away.

Nice gallery but not so great for Rome as the reviews generally say. This gallery has wonderful pieces of art from renaissance, however, I believe it's overrated and not worth the hassle you have to go through for it. Italy is full of amazing galleries. If you still go, definitely book in advance because there's almost no chance that you will get tickets on the spot, normally it's booked for the next several days, if you just arrive to get a ticket there.

Fantastic Museum. Even in the winter it is best to book in advance. When we arrived to pick up our prebooked tickets they only had tickets for late in the day still available.A great selection of Bernini Statues and large number of Caravaggio's paintings are the highlights but there is so much more besides all displayed in breathtaking rooms.

Book ahead if this is on your must see list. We wondered onto this gallery while walking around the Borghese gardens & would have loved to look around the gallery but they only take specific numbers each day. So we missed out. Make sure you book online to go here.
Must visit!. The Bernini Statues are the best in the world. If you have seen them, you die knowing that you have seen the true beauty that marble can be transformed into.

A Rome must. As good as everyone advised. Audio Guide E5.00 good value easy to use and informative.Expensive shop but v reasonable coffee bar.Essential to book.Bike hire in park look good fun and E12.00 per hour for a tandum unfortunately too late & too tired after our tour 2-3 hours.

Wonderful museum.Buy tickets before you come.. They really aren't as strict as they say they will be. People were taking photos and no one was stopping them. It didn't seem that anyone was checking the time stay limit.Amazing artwork. Amazing sculptures and paintings and rooms. savor it. Go back and see it all again.The sandwich in the café was inedible-the worst piece of food I had in all of Rome. But the café workers were very professional and kept it running smoothly.

Time -limited opulence and grandeur. Amazing architecture,Bernini sculpture and pictorial art well worth a visit.Be warned that you are allowed in at your pre-booked time and ushered out 2 hrs later whether you have seen all you want to see or not.....so time yourself accordingly. We only got to see half of the art gallery upstairs which was a great pity.So I suppose we will just have to go back another time !

Impressive collection. Entrance cost 17 Euros, the visit was limited to 2 hours, contrary to earlier reports, we did not pre-book and were herded out at the end of the 2 hours. There are various art forms on display, paintings, frescoes, mosaics, sculptures etc… My favourite sculpture was the Apollo and Daphne, the detail was incredible.Once you have completed your tour of the gallery do not miss the opportunity to stroll through the impressive gardens, there is a very nice pond with various water fowl and a Byron statue.

Must see on Rome Itinerary. Must see for statues of David, Rape of Proserpina, Apollo and Daphne and the Caravaggio paintings. Get your advance tickets online (no need to pay extra to have them shipped to you, you can easily pick them up at the entrance. The entrance is in the basement, so enter through a portico at the front of the building and at the bottom. If you go upstairs you won't get in) You MUST relinquish your backpacks and purses and there is no coat check. We tried the suggestion of going upstairs to see the paintings first, then downstairs to the sculptures to avoid the crowds, but that doesn't work anymore. Everyone has to see the paintings first. What is really remarkable is the gallery itself. The rooms are fantastically ornamental and you can imagine being a Borghese princess.
Great art. Located in beautiful gardens. Bit of a walk from city center but sculpture collection is amazing. Worth the entrance fee.

Essential to book ahead to guarantee entry. We arrived here in late February and there was a notice up that only pre booked could enter as they were fully booked. We asked and were told we could be admitted if we waited two hours. We were very disappointed not to be able to go in and wished we had been aware that pre BOOKING was necessary, even in winter months.Maybe will try again next visit to Rome.

My favourite museum up to now.. The house where the Galleria is located is amazing itself. Floor, walls, ceiling... it would be enough to worth the visit. But there´s much more. Amazing sculptures and paintings all at the same place. You have to reserve a day and time do visit and it´s perfect because it´s never too crowded and the time they give you to see it all is just the correct. You won´t be bored and even won´t leave without things to be seen. It´s not a big "museum" but it´s the most captivating one. If you go to Rome, you can miss Vaticano, but you can´t miss Galleria Borghese.

Best sculpture we saw in rome or Paris. This museum was the last of many we visited in Paris and Rome including the Louvre and Vatican. We took a taxi as it is a bit out of the way for walking. We saw the Bernini scupture of Apollo and Daphne and it was the highlight of our trip.
Do not miss!. Possibly my favorite museum in Italy. There are so many Bernini sculptures here. The rooms are filled and beautiful. The grounds are beautiful.

Very nice place but had higher expectations, staff at the coffee bar is terrible!. We booked our visit months before we went to Rome, we where so excited! Every time we went to Rome we forgot to book tickets but not this time.. But it didn't really meet up the expectations for us. Yes it is a beautiful place, yes there are some great great works in the museum but there where a few things that made it less. The staff at the coffee bar was just rude, the girl at the cash desk was making a phone call in stead of helping us, it took way too long and so we got irritated.. next was the man who made the coffee, he just ignored us! Other people wo didn't get in line got helped before us.. Took us 15 minutes to get a coffee and there was only one person before us.. The place gets very crowded, which is a logical thing but still it's very unpleasant. The museum itself just didn't blow us away, we are big art lovers but the combination of crowded rooms and having to wait before you can enter didn't get compensated. There are some great pieces there, but not worth the time (wait).

Beautiful collection. Worth making the effort to book ahead and secure a ticket for a two hour vist, as well as make the journey to the far end of the park where it's located. Wonderful collection of art and sculptures, particularly the Bernini statues which are breathtaking, Good value and two hours is plenty of time to see it all.
Villa Borghese. What a great place to explore. The grounds are beautiful, it is a place you must take the time to walk through.

Must-see. Book ahead even in low season. Get there 30 min early because all bags must be checked, including small purses. You get exactly 2 hours and you'll want every second of it and you'll regret having spent any of it on the bag check line.
Astonishing paintings and monuments. One of the best museums ever, everything inside is gorgeous. You should definitely consider it as a part of your trip.

One of my favourites. I didn't really have a great interest in sculpture until my partner insisted we visit here as a priority when we first visited Rome.And I am very grateful!The Borghese Gallery is a highlight of any visit to Rome for me. It contains some of the most exquisite art and sculpture you could imagine in one relatively small gallery.Bookings are essential, but also make sure you allow time to explore and enjoy the surrounding gardens. Wonderful experience.

Masterpiece collection . We considered this as one of our favorites in Rome. Several masterpieces to enjoy! I really enjoyed the story behind several of the pieces offered by the audioguide. Only downside is the limited time you have to enjoy this collection is 2 hrs and less than 30 minutes in the pinoteca picture gallery. Makes you relish the time you are able to spend there. Must have reservations.

A Quick but Impressive visit!. We arrived late afternoon to look around here.It was a bit of a rush but very impressive! The statues (lots of Berninie,s) were amazing. Loads of impresive renaisance paintings and the internal decor' was as good as anything else we have seen here only on a slightly smaller scale.

Wonderful Gallery. Dont miss this gem in the heart of a wonderful park. Small group entry times,book in advance as numbers are limited save on time. Small gift shop ,cafe and toilets inside for ticket holders. You can now take pictures without flash.

Fantasic place, paintings and sculptures galore. We went around the gardens one day and noticed a very large queue, alarm bells rang that this must be another great Roman place to visit. We visited another day, no queue. This place was magnificence the paintings and the sculptures were breath taking. However there is a very high and quite a lot of steps to the 1st floor where the paintings are; but there is a lift for the disabled which if I can remember can only take 1 or 2 people up at a time.This is a must to visit, we must have spent approx. 2hrs looking around inside then there are the gardens; please set aside at least half a day for this visit. Cost is 11€ well worth it and the gardens are free.. enjoy

Fantastic collection, could be better curated. The collection here is unimpeachable - the greatest Berninis and some excellent Caravaggios on display. The paintings are all clearly marked, but supporting information (ideally in English) would improve the experience.

Well worth a visit. Best to book online in advance as only 300 people allowed in at any one time, with a 2 hour window for each group. The Bernini statues are particularly good and the interior design/architecture is superb.
Family trip. Great place to visit, such a surprise in a busy city - a real hidden gem. Had a lovely time exploring the place, boating and lovely walks.

Wonderful gallery, horrible security staff. The gallery itself is wonderful, full of incredible art work and is laid out well. The audio guide is worth the extra €5. However, my experience was tainted due to the security guard lady who was absolutely horrible and condescending. I put away all my belonging bar a camera and small side bag and confirmed with the luggage staff that I could keep it with me. I walked up to go to the entrance and the security guard actually yelled, wagged her finger and tsk-tsk'd me for bringing my items up even though I had said calmly that the staff downstairs said I was able to. She yelled at me so forcefully and loudly that I actually cried. She said and i quote "I'm security and I say no". If thats the case then the luggae room staff shpuld also be made aware of what the security guard wishes. I went back downstairs to put my items away and tell the luggage staff. They were confused as to why the security guard would say that and offered come back up with me. They then just told me to go via the picture gallery entrance which was helpful. I noticed a lot of other people with cameras and small side bags so I couldn't understand why she'd pick on me. This really affected my experience of this lovely gallery.

Wonderful exhibits but organisation needs sorting. We'd been here before twice when there were fewer visitors. It is obviously so part of the tourist trail now that some control of entry is needed and they have done this by 2 hour slots; BOOK IN ADVANCE TO BE SURE OF GETTING THE TIME YOU WANT. But bags have to be checked in and they are also collected from the same place so every 2 hours there's a log jam. Additionally the small and inadequate cafe provides a tiny area in which to sit/consume. Such a pity as it could so easily be streamlined and improve the "visitor experience". The audio-guide is very worth the money. The top floor is only allowed for 30 minutes but doing it first would allow the crowds to clear in the lower rooms. The "Daphne" is as lovely as ever as is "Pauline".

Place, where Statues are Alive. If you are in Rome for a longer period of Time, you should definitely go to the Borghese Gallery. And particularly if you are in Rome in Spring, when the weather is nice and the sun is shining. Note that the Borghese Gallery is not easy to access. If you are on foot there are two possibilities: Either you go to Piazza del Popolo and than turn left and walk up the whole way (but that is rather far - it will take you up to half an hour) or you can go to Piazza Spagna Underground Station and down there are the directions and you will follow them and walk and when you come out you will be just in front of the Villa Borghese.But do not worry about the difficulties of getting there, because once you are there believe me you will never forget it. Please Note: During High Season they only sell tickets online and you won't be able to purchase it at the ticket office. Also be aware that they are closed on Monday ! When you book a ticket online you can choose the time slot that will be good for you. Note that wandering inside the museum takes up to 2 hours :) and they have an excellent collection of Bernini Statues as well as paintings by Caravaggio. But this place is awesome not only because the Museum. It has a huge green, garden with Statues around and by the way there is a chance of hiring different types of bicycles (which are at a quite reasonable price) and one should do it and afterwards cycle on different routes, which are also marked.There is a cafe inside the museum, but I highly recommend to take your own food and have a picnic outside in the green. The Museum has also it's shop and there you can by art magazines for only 2.50 EUROS - which is excellent because it is good quality magazine about several Italian painters that has a great English text along.

An amazing collection. Take a walk up to the Borghese Gallery and wander through the grounds to get to this art treasure house. You must book in advance and you are given a 2 hour slot (nobody polices this time I don't think ). Once you have left all your belongings at reception , I recommend you hire an audio guide for the full experience. You learn so much about Caravaggio , the times and the philosophy that informed the art and the commentary is humorous and insightful. Everything is amazing - the ceilings, the floors , the sculptures and you can imagine the ghosts of important people plotting and planning .

Amazing sculpture. Book in advance and see this place. Some of the best sculptures I have ever seen. We try and go to this museum every time we are in Rome. Small groups are allowed so you need to book your time in advance.

Breathtaking. I can't recommend a visit to this amazing gallery. It is imperative you book in advance otherwise you will undoubtedly be disappointed. Visits are done on 2 hourly time slots. Bags must be checked in before the visit. On entering the palace you are immediately taken aback by the magnificence of the place. Room after room is amazing. The art, sculptures and the decoration of the rooms themselves. There is so much to take in and I would love to go again.

Sculpture is.... ...my favorite form of art, which explains why Florence is my favorite small city in the world, and this is my favorite gallery in Rome. Sure, see all of the Michelangelo's you possibly can, and then come here to fill up on Bernini and Canova. Also a good selection of Caravaggio's...not one of my favorite painters, but what a great life story.

Enjoyable few hours - advanced booking required . I really enjoyed the Borghese gallery. We booked our tickets online a couple of days in advance and were a bit annoyed to be charged some additional booking fees especially given its not possible to book at the gallery.We had booked the 9-11am slot for our visit and were very glad to have booked for the first session of the day as it seemed very busy when we left.Prior to entering the gallery it is necessary to put all bags into the cloakroom. My travel companion wasn't happy at having to leave her small handbag especially given there were plenty of people with large camera cases walking around the gallery.The exhibition itself is very enjoyable although some of the exhibits would benefit from a little more written information.

Beautiful Museum. Reserved my tickets online about six weeks ahead of visit. Picking up tickets right before scheduled time was easy and efficiently handled. The bag checking area is also well run. Stairs up to second floor ( first floor in Europe) went on forever and were problematic for some visitors. Only option was to climb all the way up as it was not an option to begin the tour on the ground floor. Since visitors are limited in number and to two hours, the rooms never were overcrowed and we could see and appreciate the works at our own pace. Renting the audio tour was worth the five euros.Beautiful grounds and even a few gladiators were present for a photo opportunity.

Beautiful gallery. Everything great. Wonderful gallery if you can ignore how all the fantastic art was acquired. A bad point was the ridiculous queues before entering despite having booked ages ago. A queue to collect tickets, a queue for the cloakroom where they won't take coats, a queue for the audio guide, a queue to get in, where I was sent back to the cloakroom queue again to deposit an umbrella.

A Rome Must. We absolutely loved our visit here and glad we made time for it. First, walking through the park really sets the tone and when you arrive, it is a beautiful villa. From the outside, you would think the exhibit would be smaller but no, it is a remarkable collection of art, statues, and unforgettable masterpieces. We would definitely return and recommend this museum to family and friends. The lighting was perfect, architecture stunning, collection wonderful. Book your tickets online in advance!

Sublime. Booking is essential as only a small number of people at any one time can go into the galleries as you are given a time slot. The villa is a pleasant walk from the centre of Rome and its tranquil gardens make a pleasant change from the hustle and bustle of the city centre. There are very few bars or food places within the gardens and villa so take your own water. The villa interior is crammed with the most amazing sculptures of the Rennaissance period, Canova and Bernini being most prominent. They are displayed in order for people to be able to walk around them which is why the numbers of public are limited at any one time. A good idea, but not if you haven't got a ticket!!!!!Even my husband who is not usualy keen on museums was impressed by the villa and its contents. The visit to the Borghese gallery should take about 3 hours, and strolling through the gardens is up to the individual.

Beautiful paintings. The paintings and sculptures in the Borghese gallery are absolutely stunning. We were on the last tour at 5 p.m. which was nice as it wasn't too crowded and going in February meant it wasn't too hot. During the summer it can be very crowded with the large number of tourists

Lots of Religious Art. An amazing building - to my mind the star of the show. The upper floor is crammed full of (mainly) religious art which is not really my cup of tea. The ceilings are truely amazing, almost rivalling the Sistine Chapel. The ground floor has many Roman sculptures and some mosaics as well as a few paintings, to my way of thinking far more interesting. You are limited to a 2 hour slot which is plenty and booking is essential. Note the photos I took were all of the decor, none of the paintings

The Museum in the Heart of Rome. The Borghese Gallery is a masterpiece of fine arts and the remenant of wonderful architectural beauties that Rome could offer. Located in Villa Borghese, there's always a great exibition ad well as the possibility to learn more about the Gallery itself.

Every room is more astounding. This was the highlight for my trip. The artwork was amazing, the statues were unreal. To see The Rape of Proserpina in person was something else. You can easily spend 2-3 hours here.

Excellent museum. Have to book in advance. We showed up one day without tickets and it was sold out for the day. We made reservations online and went one afternoon and it was fairly open / not crowed. And it's a bit out of the way and not near to too many other attractions. We put it together with the Bernadini museum which worked out well.

Stunning ceilings and artwork. Amazing collection of artwork housed in an incredible building. The ceilings and walls are absolutely stunning before you even get to looking at the paintings and statues. You get a 2 hour block to visit - I'd suggest starting 15 minutes after your start time as it is a bit crazy at the beginning. Even in February we had to book our slot and there were no places left for people just arriving. Definitely worth a visit.
Nice Gallery. This is the first view we visit in Roma. It's a very beautiful and luxury gallery. You won't regret to go there.
Best Gallery in Rome.. Although is not in the center and walking distance, it does worth to pay a visit. After Vatican museums this is the best place to visit.
Celebrating the art. Galleria Borghese is a treasure. An incredible collection of art. Only 2 hours to visit. Be carefull with your time , because 2 hours is not too much for this splendid gallery.

touring tips. In a City where there are so many excellent things to see and do it is hard to see everything in one visit unless one has a lot of time. Take the time to see this Gallery and you will not be disappointed. We loved it.Part of the Roma Pass.You MUST make reservations ahead of time. We asked the Concierge in our hotel to make reservations for us several weeks ahead of time.No need to arrive at opening time- they only let 200 people in for each arrival time. Take whatever time slot is opened. Best would be the afternoon so you can see other things in the am.Arrive early as you will need to check your bags.You can take pictures inside. All the tour books said you cannot but this is not true! No flash allowed however. We had checked our cameras thinking we could not take them inside. (Hint: have locks to safe guard anything you are going to check) However, luckily we had our cell phones with us so could take pictures.We are not “into” art but do appreciate great art when we see it- this is great art.Check out the sculpture of Napoleon’s sister. Or the Bernini’s sculptures. Truly outstanding.In room IV for Bernini note how the man’s marble fingers dig into the female’s skin- and this is made of marble!It did not take us 2 hours to see the whole thing but we went back to see our favorite parts at the end- they were less crowded than.If you like my review, I hope you'll click the 'helpful' button; those of us who write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more.

Amazing sculptures. This Villa is on the tourist trail in Rome, but I know that because it is away from the centre, it is often missed.However it should be your list, the Villa is totally crammed withwonderful paintings and sculptures, some of which just take your breath away.Shame that the audio tour does not match their quality, if possible get a personal tour guide

Amazing works of art. The sculptures and paintings rival the Vatican museum and the Louvre. This family did it right when collecting a wide ranging representation of Roman and Renaissance art and sculptures. TIPS: it's a hike up the hill and thought the park, give yourself some time to get there. Make reservations from your hotel if they can help. The online redaction system is longer than need be. Get the audio guide so you know what you are looking at. At the end of the tour, follow the path a block out to the street and grab a cab or Uber. It's a hike back if you aren't part of a tour group.
Capodilavoro.Masterworks..!. We were lucky to find tickets by phone. In 2 hours, we were overwhelmed by the art of Caravaggio, Bernini, etc. Hidden treasures of Rome are here.

Excellent small museum, visit requires planning. This small museum is a true gem with an exceptional sculpture collection (which includes many Bernini's masterpieces) displaced in sumptuously decorated rooms. The collection of paintings is not as impressive, however. Visiting this museum took quite a bit of effort and planning. Firstly, there are only 360 tickets for each fixed 2-hour visit time window, hence on-line advanced booking is essential. Booking confirmation email with a ticket pick-up code as well as Photo ID are required for picking up the ticket at the museum. Secondly, even though the museum's web site listed 20 lines of buses for accessing the museum, there are only 2 buses stop near the museum entrance (stop: Pinciana /Museo Borghese) -- Bus 910 (direction: Mancini) from Republica metro station, and Bus 53 (direction: Mancini) from Barberini metro station. I was at Piazza Barberini at 4:10pm to take Bus 53 and barely made it to the museum on time for my 5pm entry because the bus ran every 18 minutes, but it was a more than 20 minute wait for this 10 minute ride. I'd advise others to start heading for the museum one hour before the entry time if you plan to take these 2 buses. Coming on other buses and metro listed on museum's web site would require quite a bit of walking in the vast park hence would be a good idea to have plenty of time to walk there.

Art and more art . A very impressive selection of Renaissance art in a beautiful palazzo. You are allowed 2hrs do the self guided tour but around 1hr is sufficient. It might be worth getting the the audio device as the exhibits don't have much information next to them. Recommended.

Napoleon's sister by Canova is worth the visit by itself. Firstly: get there early in the morning - we arrived at 8:30 with advance tickets. Even in February it can get crowded.Second: our well-known guide book says that no camera are allowed - this is rubbish! All kinds of cameras are fine, but no flash. Third: bags have to be checked in - so you can't carry your camera bag with alternative lenses with you - have a jacket with large pockets and use these!The Canova carving of the Cardinal's wife - who was the sister of Napoleon, holding the golden apple that meant the artist was comparing her to the goddess Venus is absolutely stunning. It is in the centre of a room and can be viewed from all angles. The story of Venus and the apple is shown in a fantastic ceiling painting. The Galleria is crammed with wonderful paintings and stunning sculpture - and would have had a lot more if Napoleon hadn't "bought" a lot of them for himself!The book / souvenir shop is pretty good with some non-tacky things to buy. The refreshment area food looked good, but we didn't try it ourselves.When you've finished, walk up to the outdoor cinema area and hire a bike or a peddle-powered vehicle and enjoy the whole park in which the Galleria is situated.

Beautiful. Very well known place in Rome because it is a house in the middle of the green heart of Rome: Villa Borghese. The Gallery is the house (villa) which never served as a house for that family but a gallery. The owners enjoyed art so much they kept in that very place for exhibits only. Today it belongs to the community of Rome. I suggest a guided visit because the main purpose of your visit it will be to admire the works of Bernini made by his very hands since his 14's. Not doing so you will be fascinated withso many master pieces and it will end up confused. Take your time to enjoy the sculptures of Bernini and that is already quite a work! After the visit go for a stroll over the gardens up to the top of Piazza del Popolo.

Amazing sculptures and art. Well worth a visit but do book in advance. The Bernini sculptures are stunning. There is a good cafe in the basement. You have to leave all bags in a lock up so give yourselves time before collecting your tickets also in the basement.
Rodin who?. If you like sculpture, this museum will make you forget you ever saw Rodin. Some of the finest Renaissance pieces to be found anywhere. Takes your breath away.
Fantastic sculptures. Worth buying your ticket in advance to get into this wonderful museum. So nice to get up close to the famous sculptures!
Closes on Monday... boo hoo. Unfortunately we got Metro to here on the Monday and it was closed... devastated wasn't the word.. always next time as my friend had told me to go see as its a must.
Great Gallery. Must see in the park. Not free but tickets can be bought online for a 2 hour viewing window. Lots of nice pieces to view. Mainly statues.

Wonderful art - unfriendly staff. This private collection set in a lovely house in parkland is well worth a visit. In particular the Bernini paintings and sculpture are stunning. You have to book in advance and are given a two hour slot. At the end of 2 hour slot they empty the gallery and let next group in. There is a good cafe. The downside is there is not good signage from metro and very little explanation by each piece of art. Also you have to check in all bags including handbags but cannot check coats. I dont understand rationale as we just put everything out of bag into coat pockets! Staff were officious when checking this and very unfriendly. However please visit you will not be disappointed.
Beautiful. Excellent museum in a big and beautiful park. The museum has many thinks to see. It's far few minutes from piazza del Popolo
One of the great sights in Rome. The mansion is full of amazing paintings and sculptures. The audio guide is both interesting and helpful. The grounds are sumptuously beautiful even in January.

Gorgeous gallery/museum - it's a must see!. Luckily, for the first 2 days in Rome, I was within walking distance to the Borghese Gardens and Gallery. The grounds and the incredible Bernini statues were all so beautiful. One of my favorite experiences in Rome!

A Must See. If you only want to visit one museum in Rome - this is the one. Stepping into the first room is breath taking. Bernini's sculpture's are exquisite and gave me a new appreciation for sculpture. You can't believe that you can make marble look so real. Absolutely spectacular.Remember to pre book tickets online. Entrance is for 2 hours only. So make sure you're there with enough time to pick up your tickets. Bags have to go into the coat check and they will give you a small plastic bag if you want to carry anything with you.Held hand Audio language guides are available for 5 euro and well worth it. The climb to the picture gallery is a long winding staircase and seemed a little tough for some senior ladies who'd taken a break. There is also a lift.Also a cafe, gift shops and toilets inside.

Amazing place, be sure to make reservations before you travel.. The Borghese Gallery does not make it easy to obtain reservations for tickets via internet, that need to be collected one hour prior to the slot you've bought them for. It is a true steeple chase. But it is worth it. The museum is a treasure trove of some of the finest artworks in Rome.

The sculptures are amazing, the place needs refurbishment. Ok, I might be a little harsh on the Villa Borghese, but I was expecting a little more. After visiting Villa d'Este gardens in Tivoly and Versailles in France, I thought that the grounds would have been better looking than this. But I'll attribute it to the fact that it was January, therefore, the winter had an effect on the land. Right.The gallery itself was nice and busy. Book your tickets in advance because you wont get in otherwise. If you have a few days planned to be in Rome, you can always drop by and purchase your tickets for another day, but to visit on the same day is impossible.The Bernini sculptures are simply breathtaking! I stood in awe looking at all the details of the hair, facial expressions, bodies and forms. Take the time to admire the pieces. I don't know anything about art, but I know beauty when I see it.The rooms are well decorated and there are many paintings to see. Of course, the best, in my openion, is to check out the sculptures. But there is something for everyone from paintings to frescoes. I only felt that the place was a little old and dusty. Perhaps showing it's age a little. But it wouldn't stop me from going again and my expectations were perhaps a little high going in. But you have 2 full floors of amazing artwork to check, and paintings you only get to see in books normally, that are hanging right in front of your eyes.This places is packed and very busy, but towards the end of your 2 hour window, most of the people have left to give way to the next set of people, so take the time to go back to the 1st floor and give a final goodbye to the sculptures, by then, you'll have them all to yourself.

Ok, but after the Vatican meuseum, this was old painting overload.. This was highly recommended to us, so we went. It is a nice building set in nice grounds. There are some interesting old paintings and statues, and i would have been awestruck, had we not been to the Vatican museum the day before. In short, nice but nothing on the Vatican museum and could have been left out on a tight schedule.
Best Art in Rome. This museum was formerly a residence. The decor - walls, ceiling and paintings and sculptures are stunning.

An art treasure. The Borghese Gallery is definitely worth a visit. The Palazzo and the art collection are quite astonishing. The admittance time is assigned and only allows a 2-hour visit which we found to be sufficient. The Cafe and gift shop are both not as inviting and well-stocked as other museums. But then, in Rome there are more places for a meal, drink or snack than one would ever be able to visit. The Bernini collection, the Caravaggio paintings and many other featured artists, the mosaics, and the lovely design of the walls and ceilings is breathtaking. Enjoy!
Best museum in Rome. Do not miss this museum, it is the best museum i have seen in the my life. DO NOT miss it. Best baroque art in the world.

Amazing sculptures. This is actually very small for a museum and it’s at the end of a big park with contradicting indications but it has some amazing sculptures. You have to make reservation and be there at the time you are scheduled or you will lose from your 2 hours visit time.Unfortunately, all written explanation inside the museum are in Italian. The only thing they will say in other languages (broken English and French) is that your time is ‘open’ and you have to get out.
Fantastic.. Amazing. Beautiful. I loved it.We booked on line, so did not have to wait to get in. There is an extra fee, but it is worth it.
A place one must see. Enjoyed the gallery and it is best to visit the place with someone who understands art in order to appreciate it.

Great art and tour. We visited on a Saturday in January. We did the 9:00 entry. Be aware that you have two hours in the museum. For example, we entered at 9:00 and had to leave by 11:00. At 11:00 another group of visitors was admitted. We took the guided tour (audio guide was 5 Euro while the guided tour was only 6.50 Euro). There were only four of us so it was pretty much a private tour with a great English-speaking guide. When we left at 11:00 it was obvious that many more people were there for the later tour. So I recommend going early to avoid the crowds. If you're not a Bernini fan before you go, you will be when you leave.

Finest art museum in Rome. Our second visit to the Borghese was even better than the first. The most amazing works to us are Bernini's "Apollo & Daphne" (the exquisite work on the leaves, fingers and toes is amazing) and "Rape of Proserpina" (the emotion captured in the eyes is remarkable). With an amazing collection of Caravaggio, Titian, Raphael and Rubens to name just a few even non art lovers should be impressed (our 15 and 17 year old sons found it interesting). The one failing is the two hour time limit on your visit guarantees you will need to return to fully appreciate all this museum has to offer. On your visit we suggest you go ahead of the crowd to the second floor and then come back to the first floor to avoid the crowds or enter ten minutes after your ticketed time to avoid the crush. There is a small refreshment area for drinks in the basement and you will need to check your bags while you are in the museum (this is free and provided by the museum). After your visit it is nice to walk through the park and work your way down through Piazza del Popolo to Via del Corso. The Borghese is definitely on our "don't miss" list in Rome!

A step back in time to be here. I agree with the other positive comments here and would like to add the following. I would suggest late morning through early afternoon as a good time to visit to enjoy the light in and around the gallery. It enhanced our visit.

Beautiful Museum and Park. We liked very much this attraction. It's good for strolling through a beautiful park before enter the museum. We got there by metro. The Gallery has Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures like 'Il ratto di Proserpina' among others.

Stunning rooms filled with interesting sculptures. First thing I noticed about Borghese Gallery was how much it stood out, as it is this bright white building on the edge of a park. The steps up to the gallery levels are quite long and spiral, so some people might find these a bit difficult. There is a lift but it is one of the old fashioned metal ones with the shutter, and it is very small. They also have a sign saying that some wheelchair users might struggle with the small dimensions of the lift. The rooms are beautifully decorated and ornate, and themselves are works of art. There is a great variety of sculptures throughout, including a few which are truly magnificent. The paintings floor was good too, again, with a few stand out pieces but I enjoyed the sculptures a lot more personally. I think it is worth visiting, whether you're into sculptures or paintings or not quite sure. I think even people not very into art could appreciate how beautiful the rooms and some of the pieces are.

Not a must visit, but a great museum on beautiful grounds. The Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures alone are worth the trip.Try and make it here if you are in Rome for more than a couple days. I really like how their tickets are in two hour windows to avoid overcrowding. I highly recommend booking in advance online on the museum website as the time slots fill up quick; I was there in non-peak season and tickets were all but sold out for the day.Tickets are €11 each.

Superb. A magnificent collection in an equally fantastic setting. All the works are great but one comes here for the Caravaggio collection. That alone is worth the price admission. Entry is timed and you have two hours. That should be more than enough time. they actually us to enter early as it was a quiet time.

A magnificent gallery. This is a very popular site. Worth pre-booking with a guide and skipping the queue. We were taken around by an American gentleman who was very knowledgeable and was completely understandable.This site is likely to be extremely popular at peak times of the year and hence very crowded.
Gift to Italy.... The Borghese family contributed so much to the city of Rome. Come visit the art and beautiful buildings attached to this infamous family.

Worth it for the Caravaggios. A lovely long walk through the park and you're greeted by locals dressed up as gladiators offering you the photo opportunity of a lifetime. The gallery is extraordinary and not always in a good way. Incredibly surly ticket seller didn't deter us though he gave it his best shot. Look up. the ceilings are fabulous. Look down, the gladiator mosaics are stunning. And finally there are Caravaggios.

Unbelievable! This place must be visited (with a guide). Our hotel recommended this place and Joy of Rome tours as guides. Both the things were perfect! Perfect commentary, perfect museums (not crowded, only 200 people at the time allowed). Just make sure you reserve it in time since it's not possible to buy the tickets on site. A guide is necessary to optimize time.. This place is full of masterpieces litterally everywhere!!! Enchanting!
Almost indescribable!. The villa is astounding on it's own. Then you add all the wonderful art and it is almost too much to take in. One of our top three experiences viewing art.

Great art. Beautiful works of art that overwhelms your mind. Definite must see. Ensure you get the audio tour from downstairs. Note: this gallery is not easily accessible by public transportation, so be prepared for a long walk through the park, or consider hiring a cab for this one.
A lovely gallery. Favorites were Bernini's David, Apollo and Daphne, and the Caravaggio room. The gallery itself is lovely.

Wow....!. Such richness!!!My daughter and I just got lost in the gallery. Each on her own, occasionally meeting up to exchange what we had seen. Loved every second of it - and we did not use the guide - which I think is a must to use. This was an oversight of mine, but will rectify next time!
Spend a day!. We went to the Gallery, but wished I'd set aside a whole day to explore the park - the Contemporary Art Museum, stroll the gardens, rent a bike or golf cart!
hidden gem. This has to be booked in advance so make sure you go online a day or so in advance and book a time. Must do for art lovers!
Great!. Well worth it... easy to buy your own tickets and go yourself, but a small group tour would have been nice too. Don't forget to walk around the park afterwards.. lots of great fountains.

Fake gladiators . On our way to the museum we walked through the beautiful park and enjoyed the sunshine.Once we arrived on the drive of Borghese, two Italians dressed as Roman Gladiators approached us about taking pictures. We rebuffed advances, until the Gladiators ensured us no charge. They then took 3 terrible photos with our camera, and then asked for a €20 tip. REALLY €20 TIP.Borghese gallery you have a duty tostop this harassment.

Absolutely amazing. Fantastic, breathtaking sculptures set in amazing, ornate rooms. Totally worth it - you have to make a reservation and only have access for two hours. Primarily paintings upstairs, they were okay, but the sculptures on the first level were outstanding and worth the price of admission alone. So glad I went and great for photography.

Astonishing collection of sculptures and paintings. We loved the Borghese Gallery and the astonishing Bernini sculptures. The Apollo and Daphne sculpture by Bernini is worth the trip all by itself. We had an expert (PhD Art History) guide from Walks-Inside-Rome. The gallery and the grounds contain an amazing collection of artwork. There were also Roman soldier actors just outside the gallery willing to playfully pose for a photo with you (for a small fee).

So. Much. Art.. Make this place the only cultural thing you do that day. It is so rich with painting, sculpture, ferscos, friezes, archetecture, tapestry, mosaics, you name it, it's here in abundance. Each room is exhaustingly dense I had to admit early on that there's no way to fully appreciste it all in one visit. Honestly my eyes and neck were sore from gazing at the famous pieces and craning at the gorgeous ceilings. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful Building Still Sitting in its Park. We only visited the park and gardens before moving on to other places of interest. We were there on a Sunday morning and saw the park full of locals walking, talking and sitting, beautiful places to stop for coffee and mingle.

In LOVE. Located in a beautiful park, Galleria Borghese is one of the most impressive sites in Roma. In my personal opinion, it stands out from other so famous monuments in the city centre.Totally worth the time searching the way to reach it and totally worth to see the gallery in detailI was amazed by its beauty! Galleria Borghese is one of my favourite places in Rome!

History and art combined. Pay the extra and get a guided tour. We were in a group of about 10, with an art historian, and it was well worth it (there are also audio guides). Our guide really added to the experience, with lots of details about the buildings and historical anecdotes, as well as plenty of knowledge about the art on display. Great sculptures and paintings. This is set in a beautiful park, which is worth wandering around. The tickets are timed, with a 2 hour limit, which is great because there are only so many people let in at a time, so you avoid the congestion you can experience at other galleries.

Treasure not to miss. This collection is unique and if you are in Rome, you have to see it, but you have to be aware that you must book your tickets in advance. You do not need a guide. Book tickets directly on their site and read about the collection prior your visit - save your money! You have plenty of other places in Rome to spend them!
Spectacular. This museum is a must for anyone going to Rome. You have to have a reservation to get in so get that in advance.

Unbelievable Borghese. If you love art, this is not to be missed. We enjoyed it as much as, and in some ways even more than, the art in the Vatican. We were not rushed, even though time was limited. The sculptures are just magnificent. We are so glad we did this. However, when we booked the tickets we didn't realize they were going to ship us the actual paper tickets rather than send them online. That mistake cost us an extra 30.00 for shipping - so be careful when you book it. You do have to book in advance, though.

Bernini and Canova impress. Apollo and Daphne by Bernini and Pauline Bonaparte as Venus Victrix by Canova are world class sculptures worth travelling for. In my view it surpasses everything else in the museum, including the Caravaggio paintings, which are probably more famous.

A must see!. I have been to Rome several times and never visited the Borghese. Until this trip! I was not disappointed, only sorry I waited so long to go. It is well worth viewing on your first trip to Rome. A Must see!

an Aladdin's cave of wonders!. Undoubtedly my favourite museum in the WORLD! Incredible collection of Caravaggio and Bernini's mesmerising early statues. Floor to ceiling frescoes; crammed full with ancient statues, mosaics, renaissance and baroque paintings… truly I could have spent the entire day here! I love the way they limit the numbers of people…. such an amazing private experience to savour!

A must see!. This gallery lives up to all that is written about it. One of our highlights in Rome. Art and sculpture is magnificent. Bus transportation right to door on arrival but a bit of a walk to get the bus back to Termini. We ended up getting a cab. You will definitely use up the two hours you are allotted. Start at the top and make your way down to the first floor.

Loved the interior. A friend suggested I go here. I am glad I did. The interior is beautiful and it is just far enough out of the way that most tourists would not head in this direction. Their loss. If you have kids, there is a Zoo on the grounds (separate ticketing) that was compact enough to do on the same day while having enough to see to make it enjoyable.

Beautiful. Stunning. GO!. My girlfriend and I visted the Gallery on a whim and fell in love. We aren't artsy people at all but loved everything inside. It was pretty empty when we went, so that was nice. TIP! Remember to take water with you everywhere. Italy has awesome public water spots in their piazzas but you'll hardly ever find a fountain in a building!

Everytime an emotion . I have been in this museum many times. The ticket is good for two hours, and the entrance is at fines Hours. so plan the visit and don't waste time as it is needed. Probably best to book via internet.The museum is in the middle of Villa Borghese, one of the best parks of Rome.The museum contains marble sculptures of Bernini, David, Apollo and Dafne, Neptune and Proserpina.Sculptures of Canova (Paolina) and many Roman and Greek sculptures. Piantings include Caravaggio and many more.The whole museum is simply magnificient, ad it was the collection of Scipione Borghese.The audioguides are very helpful.The bookstore could be better.The visit is well worth it and you feel richer at the end of the visit. I love it.

Our favorite museum in Rome. We recently revisited the Borghese and enjoyed it as much, or more, as we did on our prior three visits. The museum is in a palazzo set in lovely, park like grounds, and is small enough to enjoy without feeling overwhelmed, but large enough to hold many masterpieces well worth your attention. It is important to book your tickets online in advance as this is a popular attraction and they are very strict about entry times. You will be given a specific entry time and must show up within that 15 minute period. Bring your codice (reservation number) to the window to get your admission ticket. Do not forget the codice, you will not be given your ticket without it. Once inside, enjoy the great masters that are found at every turn, such as Bernini's Appollo and Daphne, as well as works by Caravaggio, Titian, and others. Maximum visit length is two hours, but the upside of this is that the museum is not overcrowded as the maximum number allowed is 300. There is an optional audio guide for 5 euro, useful if you are interested in the stories behind the sculptures and paintings. Admission is 11 euro

This is not to be missed. This gallery was full of beautiful art . You need to call for a reservation since they limit the number of persons in the gallery at one time. You will be able to enjoy the art work with the lack of crowds. Not to be missed and well worth the time

Best museum in Rome and I am roman.. This is without doubts the best museum in Rome and I am roman. It is not so big but it contains an incredible density of arts that I even see in the whole world. If you are a tourist in Rome I will suggest to see this as a first choice instead of some more famous like Musei Vaticani.
Worth the Advance Ticket Purchase. I bought my ticket online prior to my visit - you have a 2 hour window - I honestly thought it was not enough time - but it was perfect.

A two-hour tour onto beauty. Tired of fake Berninis and imitators of Caravaggio? Jump into this two-hour rush of beauty, lust and power that represents best the power of imperial Vatican Rome. Created by a criminal maverick, cousin of the Pope and dangerous collector that used to blackmail rival collectors to get what he wanted. But, let´s say he wanted the best. Bernini makes you cry, roman materials are astonishing, the Caravaggios have no rivals in Rome (maybe St Louis...) and a thousand more trophys are all there. Be ready fo a real art-shot.

High quality but manageable size. Great small museum that can be done in a manageable amount of time (in fact you are supposed to be done in 2 hours)So if you have time after the Vatican museum (which should be your first priority make sure you hit this one. Picture is is Apollo and Athena. Look at the detail in the leaves.

one of the best collections of art peices. beautifully designed palace..now converted into a gallery. Very well maintained. Has one of the best collections of artifacts ...esp. the paintings. If you are an art lover, must visit the place.

Gorgeous jewel of Roma. This museum and garden should be your number one attraction on your list for Roma! Do reserve tickets in advance at the museum – your hotel could arrange it for you.The gardens are beautiful and host this beautiful historic villa that houses the museum. Entrance is restricted with a certain number of people allowed every two hours. Arrive a bit earlier not to lose out on this marvellous attraction. Photos are allowed and audio guides as well as printed descriptions are available. The art collections is breathtaking, the interiors magnificent and most impressive. Take your time and savour every corner of every room on every floor. Often exhibitions are staged within the villa museo, offering further beauty for the eyes.This history is fascinating, intertwined with that of Napeleon Bonaparte. Ideal for those who love art, architecture, history and beauty

Stunning Gallery. The Borghese Gallery was exceptional, particularly if you like the works of Bernini. This is perhaps the most underrated gallery in Italy, if not the world. Stunning works of art throughout, including both sculptures and paintings.The admission fee was nominal, and the crowd was very manageable when we visited.The gardens seemed worn and less than vibrant, but we visited in December. Nevertheless, the gardens are just the appetizer. The gallery is the main course.

Very impressive. Fabulous display of statues, paintings and frescoes. Be aware that there is a long walk from Spagna station, including the longest escalator we have ever seen. Signage could be improved once you exit the station. You must book in advance but when you book online you are charged an extra fee for picking up the tickets when you get there.
Great location. set in the gardens of Villa Borghese the Gallery commands a great elevated position and is certainly worth a visit
5 Stars in Any Other City. Only in Rome would this not be a 5 star attraction. If you only have a limited amount of time to spend in Rome (ie 3 days or less) I would not make this a priority stop.
good. Really good, however you have to book before when you want to go. and only via phone who has a Roma pass.

Linger longer. Take your time here. There is an adequate amount of art to see, but it's not too overwhelming. You'll want to saunter through the halls and enjoy yourself. You'll be talking about this museum for years to come.

Call first to get in; then see the most beautiful sculptures ever. We were warned to call the Gallery first, and set an appointment to view the Gallery. We did so and when we arrived we were told that we must adhere to the schedule. We had some difficulty finding a way to return to our hotel. All this was minor compared to our stupefaction and joy when we saw Bernini's sculptures.
A Jewel In The Crown. A must to visit in Rome. Plus a lovely walk around the park is well worth the leg work. You will certainly not be disappointed.
Best museum after Vatican. Do not miss this incredible museum with Bernini statues and Caravaggio paintings. Do not forget to book well ahead of time

The world's most extraordinary private art collective. The villa and its vast collection of sculpture, art is without equal. The audio guide enhances the experience. Make sure you make your reservations in advance. It is a true highlight to any visit to Rome.

A great, great museum. And just the right size for two hours of amazement.. The former Borghese Family villa sits in a magnificent park and houses a sizable portion of the family's collection of paintings, sculpture, and decorative items. And what a collection it is. Prime place for me are the extraordinary Bernini sculptures. He brings marble to life with unparalleled technique and beauty. The works at the Borghese, including the Rape of Persephone, Apollo and Daphne and David seem to be the work of a magician rather than an artist. But an artist he was. Close behind is the Caravaggio collection; covering all stages of his career and capturing the many moods of this peerless painter. Add to this marvelous offerings by Perugino, Canova, Bassano and more and you have one of the world's great museums providing you with a most memorable experience. We had the benefit of a great guide and skip the line admission, but a guidebook or the audio guide and advance purchased tickets will work as well. The Borghese Park in which the Gallery sits is also quite lovely for a leisurely stroll and a bite to eat in the very good, if slightly overpriced restaurant.

Many Paintings Ahead!. Ever so slightly off the beaten path, but if you like art this is definitely not to be missed! It's helpful to have a tour guide, but a great time could be had without one. The of the most famous artists showcased throughout the gallery is Bernini. His work is quite unbelievable.The gift shop is nice and small, and has a cafe adjacent, should you need a snack. And, since you're right there, walk around the Gardens and take in the splendor or a city park.

Art overdose!. What a grand time to explore and view some of the most facinating artwork. From paintings to culture to murals and woodwork, the gardens lend for a niece stroll or just select one of the inviting benches to relax and digest theExperience of the gallery. With fantastic food and all the romance the city offers; Borghese Gallery is another must see for the senses while visiting. There is a time limit for your visit and be sure to purchase your tickets in advance! Do have small change for the locker rental available. They are, rightfully, strict on what can be carried and allowed into the gallery. Art overdose at its best!

Do it for Bernini. You have to make a reservation to get in, and then you get 2 hours--that's it. If it's your first time, absolutely rent the audioguide, which will help you to focus on key pieces and offers helpful information and context. The Bernini sculpture of Daphne and Apollo alone was worth the visit.
Amazing collection. Great collection of artwork. The architecture of the building as well as the interior of the building is incredible.

Absolute Favorite. Its a medium sized art collection from the '700-'800, in my opinion the pinacle of artists' achievements. Everything is worth seeing and if you have more than 3 days in rome, ABSOLUTELY go see this.Warning: you have to book tickets well in advance, maybe 2-3 weeks. At the most basic level, it's at least a break away from all the religious themed art, but really, it houses the most undeniably beuatiful sculptures outside of the Louvre and the Vatican.Do NOT forget the Pinacoteca upstairs, even if the really awesome works are on the main floor.

Great density of art masterpieces.. Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings are my choice, but there are a lot of art works in a relatively small palace. Outside there is Villa Borghese where you can walk up to Piazza Spagna or Piazza del Popolo.

Beautiful Estate. A hidden gem in Roma besides seeing the other main tourist sites. Visited during the winter, so visit was inside the gallery of beautiful art. Highly advised to book the tickets online in advance as only have 2 hours to tour the inside of the estate.
The opulence of the Vatican on a smaller scale. A superb collection of old and new. Wonderful interior decor similar to that seen in the Vatican buildings. Superb frescos and ceiling designs

Art gallery. Can't really claim to know my art so this did not really help. Rooms full of art,statues and marbel. Once you have seen one room I thought it was all the same however art lovers may call me ignorant so like most places "horses for courses".Don't get your photo taken outside with the "Romans" a ripe off they wanted €40 off me,gave them 20 and as I waked away I thought "you mug" should have told them where to go

Amazingly beautiful. Whether you are an art lover or not this place is a must see. No one can avoid standing in awe at the sheer beauty of the exhibits and the villa itself.
