It a must!!Precioso museo, tanto las piecas como el palacete, que decir de las obras de Bernini. Si vas a Roma y te da pereza el museo Vaticano, este es tu lugar, solo puedes estar 2 horas y 200 personas, por lo que ni agobios ni estrés.
Art Art Art. Art Art Art, so much to take in. Lovely blend of periods and type of art offered here at the Borghese Gallery

Bernini took my breath away. Some of the masterpieces of Italian art are here. The villa is gorgeous but their Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings make this place a must see. What really impressed me were the formers as I saw them in photographs in books when I was studying art back at school. They are so big and show every single detail that they are almost alive. I loved Apollo and Daphne, so much feeling, so much movement, so perfect.Don't miss it!
Incredable Art and sculptures. We used Tours of Italy for a tour and the guide was exceptional. His knowledge of art and history made the gallery come to life.

Fabulous. You are only allowed two hours to see all. But do not rush. See BOTH floors...the 2nd floor first, as most viewers start on 1st just The Bernini statues unbelievable. And if you are not familiar with the art get a guide.

Wonderful museum without the crowds. It is easy to make a reservation online. They control the number who can enter so it doesn't feel crowded. We rented the audio guide for 5 Euros and it was well worth the money. We got much more out of the gallery than those who walked around and didn't appreciate what they were seeing. Spend the extra money and you'll enjoy the gallery more!

Best museum in Rome. What made this museum so special was that they limit admission in 2 hour timed limited admission groups so that you get to have a more intimate experience with the art. Everywhere else in Rome and Florence, we felt like we were pushing through throngs of tourists who were taking selfies with everything. At the Borghese Gallery, we actually got to enjoy and appreciate the art (especially the sculptures!) in the way they were meant to be observed. They have some fantastic pieces, recommend spending the bulk of your time on the first floor as the second was not as impressive. This is a do not miss, make reservations in advance!

Highlight of our cultural trip to Rome. Aside from dining out....this place was a pleasant surprise. On TA advice we pre booked (essential as limited to 360 people per 2 hour slot). The gallery sits over two floors and is quite small. Every inch of every room is amazingly decorated. The highlights are undoubtedly the Bernini sculptures of David and Daphne/Apollo. It takes around one hour to make a good visit. We circulated around the best rooms two or three times. Not too busy either!

A Must See. Advance reservations required (can get on-line). The interior is magnificent. The 2 hours allotted is sufficient. Arrive at least 30 minutes before ticket pickup (downstairs) as line gets long. Bags must be checked and checkout room not available until within 30 minutes of start time. Gardens are poorly maintained.

My favourite museum in Rome! A MUST SEE!. This Museum was recommended to me by a work colleague. It was my favourite museum in Rome. The art collection is incredible and the audio guide is really informative. It tells you how to look at the art to get the most of it and points out details you could easily miss on your own. Book your ticket in advance - especially in peek season as there are limited numbers of tickets in 2 hour slots.

Outstanding collection in beautiful building. If you are at all interested in art, this is a must see in Rome. The former palazzo of Cardinal Borghese is wonderfully decorated, and full of outstanding artworks chosen by him for his own collection. A welcome surprise was the dominance of secular art, a relief from the might overdose of religious art you can easily experience in Rome, and the religious works in the collection are of high quality artistically.The great gardens surrounding the central building are superb to wander through too. We spent several hours doing just that. Highly recommended that you book in advance, which we didn't, and had to wait to go to the 1pm session the following day. Check session times. You have a maximum of two hours to go through the whole gallery, and we didn't get to see all the works on display even though we didn't linger.

Fantastic Art Collection in Wonderful Setting. This is one of the great collections of classic art - highlights for me are some of the greatest Bernini statues (how did he ever carve such delicate & life-like details!!), as well as some of his lesser known paintings; Caravaggio; Raphael; many other Italian and Dutch Renaissance masterpieces; and the fabulous decor of each of the rooms - incorporating ancient Roman artworks. 2 hours well spent - just remember to pre-book!!!

Number one place . It is the first place u have to visit .The most beautiful park I have ever visit .
Also a very nice place to have breakfast.

Stunning!. Stunning statues and art within. The gallery has a cap on how many visitors are actually in the building at one time, a pleasant break from other crowded museums like the Vatican - try to book over the lunch hour and you'll have even less crowds.
Great old home converted to an art gallery. The Gallery limits the numbers per tour so that you are not over crowded and has fantastic displays of paintings and sculptures.

Watch out for concealed paintings. If you go here to see the Caravaggios, bear in mind that they are tucked away deep inside the sculpture collection (which has some magnificent Berninis). There are a lot of fairly awful mannerist religious paintings in this collection. Entry times are staged at two-hour intervals! so you need to apportion your time carefully.

My fifth visit and still fantastic. no matter how many times I go to this gallery, I love it only more and more. This time, they also have an exhibition of amazing dresses. They do take your attention away from the major art pieces from time to time, but they by themselves are art and simply incredible. But my favorites are, of course, Bernini's sculptures. Nothing can compare.

Loved this Gallery. We weren't sure what to expect when we booked this tour but we really enjoyed our tour of the Gallery.We had a great guide who spoke good English and had a wicked sense of humour!The sculptures here are spectacular. Definitely worth spending a couple of hours here.

An unforgettable experience. First off- you need to book./ reserve your tickets to visit the Villa Borghese gallery in advance. The dates and times have restricted admission in 2 hour intervals. Now that may seem a little extreme but it makes for a worthwhile and unique experience. No crowds and you are able to savour the incredible artwork in relative solitude. Bernini's sculptures are incredible and awe- striking. We visited in such a way that we saw both floors and had an extra 15 min to go back down to the 1st floor and further admire the sculptures in a more serene environment. Please note that even if you have the ROMA pass you need to book the date and time of the visit in advance.
Best museum in Rome. Do not forget your reservation.Do not mind the "two hour " limit. Stay as long as you wish, there is no control of how long you remain in the museum.

Lovely. Every room is covered in works of art; floors, walls, ceilings, furniture. What a treasure. Even though the gardens aren't well maintained they are still nice to see. The connecting park is a great place to enjoy a sandwich you can purchase next to the gift shop.

No words describe this place (Borghese Gallery). We rented one of the audio tour guides and hooked our earphones to it so that we could both easily hear the descriptions. This Gallery is so massive that if you are an art lover you will not be able to take it all in. They have a set time limit of two hours per visit to get as many people in and out as they can. It is a great system because once you are inside you can go any place you want on your own and not be over whelmed with crowds. We followed the audio tour guide and were on the last painting that the audio tour guide was disgusting when they came over the loud speakers that our two hours was up. Yes, the time goes by that fast!!!! You will want to spend some time in the park around the gallery since there are statues all around and if its a nice day it is great. We had a wonderful day at the gallery and the park and then walked to other sites around Rome.

A 'must see' when in Rome. Absolutely amazing - not quite The Hermitage in St Petersburg, but the quality and quantity of art exhibited in a relatively small space means that it runs it close. We booked a ticket through the gallery website (cheaper than a tour) and were thrown by the fact that we were allocated a seat number! Don't worry about this, it just means you have an allocated place at your given time. It's strictly a two hour visit and if you buy the audio tour @ 5euro per person then you will see most of the main pieces of art within your allocated time. Be aware in advance that you must check your bags into the cloakroom below (free) as these are not allowed into the gallery. This can involve quite a queue, so allow plenty of time for this prior to your admission time. Go and enjoy
Borghese Gallery. An incredible gallery. Get tickets in advance. Some of the most beautiful marble sculpture I have ever seen is in this gallery. A must see while in Rome.

Must See Private Collection of 15th-18th century artworks. Extraordinary experience to be among the original sculptures and paintings ( Bernini, Correggio, Rubens, Caravaggio to name a few)in the private collection of Cardinal Scipione. Not only were the works of art spectacular, what made the visit memorable was our guide( extremely dynamic,knowledgeable and amusing story teller). Very clever in the way she organized the tour. The exhibits less crowded with people dictated the order of the floors and rooms visited. Tickets purchased in advance is a must. The visits are scheduled in 2 hour blocks thus limiting the number of people in the gallery at a time allowing for a much more intimate experience. Time in the gardens is highly recommended.Flora A
Must Do in Rome. I lived in Rome and have always gone back. This is a must. Get the headphones and enjoy! You can taxi there. Get your hotel to book the tickets which are required.

The gardens are great!. So I can't say much for the gallery since it was completely sold out when we got there, so book in advance!Instead we decided to wonder around the gardens and in the end decided to get one of the strange peddling cart things. Don't know how to describe it other than a little car with power assisted peddling involved. It was 12 euros for an hour which was plenty for us as once you get started, you realise the gardens are not that big. But we had so much fun and it was a lovely place! worth a visit!It's quite a walk but doable. We didn't get any public transport while in rome and walked everywhere.

Enjoy it more by reading in advance about the history. The building, the art works and the gardens at the back are a must when visiting Rome for more than 3 days. We booked the last two hours of the day to visit (5-7PM) which is good because there is always fewer people. However, there are no,guides on offer except the audio guides which are a bit off the entrance so we missed them... Since the collection was a private one put together by one man while he was alive, the works are very 'similar' and without a more detailed knowledge of the history one misses much because the explanations next to the works are insufficient. The park around the villa is fun to visit hiring one of those bike-carts, absolutely worth your while!

Fantastic. This is one of the attractions in Rome that a number of people miss because it takes some planning. You can not walk up to it and get a ticket to see it. You need to buy a ticket in advance on line months before to get to see this mavelous place. I am not a museum lover, but the pieces inside are worth the planning to see.
Wow!. Rome is a museum under Italian sun! many great places to visit, many history books to read, many movies to watch :)

First here then the rest. Galleria borgese it's "the place "where to go.Inside of a beautiful park in the center of Rome, it's for me the place where I come back every year. Just to see the magnificent the marvelous, to get astonished looking the sculptures of Bernini. Just to see how Dafne become a "plant" with the touch of Apollo. For me it's indescribable, pure emotion.

take your time and go see it!. The most beautiful Bernini statues and the most amazing Caravaggio paintings, but the others like Perugino, Tiziano will blow your mind! The palace is a wonderful place to spend an afternoon looking at the most important peaces of art, and the park surrounding the museum is great to walk.

Breathtaking Collection, Equal Atmosphere. If you like sculpture, this is your museum. I am a tour guide for other locations in Rome, and this place is my favorite (don't tell my boss!). The collection is truly astounding. They have a ton of Bernini, including Apollo Chasing Daphne, and they are all brilliantly lighted and displayed. Don't even get me going on the Caravaggios. The marble-work in the first floor galleries is unparalleled. Those Borgheses had impeccable taste, and it shows through in this museum. It is also one of the museum in Rome that control the number of people inside, so you are guaranteed an intimate experience (and you need to book your tickets well in advance).

Great Collection. The Borghese Gallery is set in a beautiful garden. You need to order your tickets online, then come and pick them up earlier than the appointed time. We arrived very early and after picking up our tickets we wandered around in the gorgeous gardens. The signage is not ideal and it takes a while to find the actual gallery, so give yourself extra time. The collection is very beautiful: statues, paintings, frescoes, and a full room of Carravagio paintings. When we were there, the fashion stylist Azzedine Alaia had some of his dresses displayed among the art. It was terrific. His lines are very classic so it went very well with the renaissance pieces of work of the permanent collection.

Best Bernini Sculptures and key Italian Art Pieces. The gallery is a place that you must go in Rome for timeless pieces of art, but book in advance for your two hour time slot. Book well in advance of your trip. One of my favorite art experiences in Rome and after there is the garden to see for free.

Even off-season, book well ahead on weekends. After spending two weeks in Sicily, my husband and I took 2 days in Rome on our way back to the States. I had spent so much time planning Sicily, I was just winging it in off-season Rome, Nov. 7 and 8, Saturday and Sunday. What I learned: For the Borghese Gallery, you can't wing it on the weekends even in the off-season! No tickets available til Tuesday, when we'd be home. Tickets were available during the week this late in the season, tho some two-hour slots were sold out. Our hotel concierge said it seemed unlikely that walk-up tix would be available because people pay for them in advance. Don't know if other travelers have tried that? Also, it's easy to check for and buy tix on the gallery's web site, which has a little button where you can change Italian to English.
Not worth visiting. Location is not easy to get to. Reservation is needed for Roma pass but the phone is never picked up. Staff are unfriendly.

Loved it!. I arrived fifteen minutes before the designated time and got in line. Visitors climb 2-3 stories of a spiral staircase to see the first gallery. The marble floors are quite beautiful and the painted ceilings take your breath away. They have Bernini sculptures and paintings across each walls.This is one of those "must see" sights. The galleries are very well organized and are huge. Two issues stood out to be about the museum requirements: a) they are strict about guests arriving on time prior to the designated start; b) visitors are allowed only two hours to view. If you are still looking after two hours have passed, they escort you out.I recommend buying tickets in advance and arriving in time to view the galleries fully. This is a beautiful museum and I had a fabulous visit. Highly recommended.

Art everywhere . Such a fantastic collection of paintings and statues. A fantastic building in the villa Borghese park. Audio guide is necessary in order to understand the meaning of every room because each room has a theme.

It would not be possible to build this today. It is hard to imagine what this would cost todayWe made our reservations on line prior to leaving home and paid with PayPal. Go in the door under the stairs leading into the building and get your tickets. The receipt was accepted without problem and we then went over to the Audio Guide table and got very good Audio Guide equipment for 5 euro each. You are not allowed to carry bags or large purses into the museum and they have a good cloakroom to leave you belongings but since you know better now bring a small purse and ditch your big bags elsewhere. A small purse or camera is fine but we saw them require what I would consider a standard purse to be checked. You get in the Gallery right at the assigned time. Do not get in a big rush – let the anxious folks go first because it is better to be behind the crowd and take your time. The two-hour window will get most of us through without a problem and by the end of the two hours your feet will hurt anyway. The Bernini sculptures are fantastic and the entire building is a huge piece of art. If we were here for a few more days I would make another reservation and go again just to look at the items that I may have missed. For those of you that do not like stairs ask to use the elevator to go up to the upper floor where the paintings are located. There are 105 stairs to get to the floor and lots of folks were having problems.I have attached a snapshot of Pauline Bonaparte and David but these are only two of hundreds of sculptures.

Borghese Gallery visit. We visited the Borghese having pre-purchased tickets online directly through the Borghese site. Like many Roman sites there are numerous companies selling tickets, all making an extra Euro or two profit from the tourist unless you make sure to purchase directly from actual site. You are only allowed a two hour window with your ticket. Gallery guards will not let you in ahead of time. Gallery was spectacular and a must see in Rome. Allowing only limited people in makes your time there pleasant as you can actually view the various works without being jostled and pushed by others, as does the museum policy of making people check their large sized bags. The Borghese is a well run operation making the museum experience there a pleasure and very worthwhile.

A Must See. 2 suggestions before you go: 1st, make your reservations well in advance. 2nd, make your reservations on the Borghese Gallery website. There is no reason to pay the extra fees from tour organizers who provide no benefit for this attractionThe gallery is a marvel and the history of the acquisition of the works is almost as interesting. A prime example of the benefits of power and intimidation. The downside: visitors are restricted to a 2 hour visit. Not nearly enough time.
A Private Tour. We used City Wonders for a private tour. What a treat. 3 hours of intellectual delight whilst every painting, sculpture was explained. Fantastc not to be missed.
Amassing. Amassing. Bernini is fantastic. The sculptures , pantings and the Willa's so beautiful . Can't wait to see it again !
beautiful small museum. this small museum had many wonderful pieces of art tastefully displayed over several rooms. we took a tour, but i think using the headphones would have been better.

Amazing art collection. Pre-booking is essential - tickets are rationed and sell quickly. Do not book over the internet - charges seemed outlandish. We booked via our hotel front desk - had a 2 day wait and paid the correct ticket price.

Most wonderful art work,especially Bernini at his most brilliant.. I loved every exhibit at the gallery,and visited three times on my recent stay in Rome.
The gallery is so beautiful,and surrounding gardens are a delight.

Wonderful visit!. We had a great visit here. You have to have pre-booked tickets to get inside, as they only allow small tour guided groups to enter. We were really lucky and had a small group and a wonderful guide, which gave us the opportunity to ask any questions we had in mind. Also great for a very warm day, as there is wonderful aircon throughout the museum.

A great art museum.. My wife and I saw many great museums during our visit to Italy. The paintings and sculptures in the museum are wonderful. You must make a reservation to get into the museum. If you think you will buy a Roma Pass, call and make a reservation and then pay for the tickets using the Roma Pass on the day of your visit. You are only allowed to stay in the museum for 2 hours so obviously you will only get to see a portion of all of the artwork.

One of the BEST art expeditions you can experience. HIdden away in the midst of the lush Borghese Gardens, the Gallery holds one of the most impressive collections of art in the world. It is 100% necessary to book your visit in advance, as they do not allow walk ins. They have a trustworthy bag & coat check, so take all you need! The museum itself is gorgeous, but I cannot even begin to describe the art collection. Bernini's famous "Rape of Persephone" as well as "Daphne and Apollo", Raphael's "Disposition", works by Caravaggio, and countless others. If you have an opportunity to visit DO NOT miss it!

Spectactacular Art in a spectacular setting. Absolutely must reserve, a month or more in advance, since each entrance is limited to two hours (9,11,1,and 3) and limited to a specific number of persons.(250-300, I think) Fantastic collection of both sculpture and paintings, not to be missed .First Sundays of the month are free, but reservations are still required and free if made directly with the museum.

One of the best museums in Rome apart from Vatican. This Museum, erstwhile residence of Scipione Borghese has one of the finest collection of art and sculptures. Not crowded since they allow only limited person in two hours time slots. Prior reservation is required since tickets sell out fast. Has one of the best audio guides. The gardens surrounding ie Villa Borghese is also great for strolls and spending time with nature. Every room has a breathtaking center piece worthy of spending time. Arrive early and checkin bags which takes some time. One of the most well managed museums.

One of the greatest private collections of the past. Located in a beautiful park, the Villa Borguese is a magnificent palace that hoses one of today most spectacular collections of baroque art, home to some of Bernini's best known sculptures, and Caravaggios paintings,. I think it is best to visit privet lay, The audio guide is good, the visitor is allowed two hours, it is a good idea to purchase tickets in advance and arrive 15 min before the time of the visit

a bit of a disappointment. Expected a bit more from this venue-they mixing some fashion cloth show with ancient art works-the rooms are spectacular and the Bernini sculptores are beutiful-book online the tickets otherwise end up with no entry as it's books out fast

I spent the day at the Borghese Gallery and was completely overwhelmed by the beautiful works of art. It is a MUST see when you are in Rome. Prepare to be blown away by the beauty in one of the most beautiful cities on the planet!

Outstanding visit. The quality and density of the exhibits are really impressive. The entire gallery is filled with first rate exhibits, and they are presented in an outstanding fashion. More to see than in many other venues that are twice the size and everything was first rate.

Short, sweet and informative. The gallery houses some of the best art in Italy. It is recommended to take the audio guide as it gives some very informative and quirky backgrounds of the artists, patrons and artworks. Some of the best sculptures of Bernini are found in the gallery. These are well worth seeing because they are so amazing and beautiful, you would easily be a fan of Bernini. The audio guide is perfectly timed for a leisurely pace coinciding with the allowed time of stay inside the gallery. Another great thing of the whole experience, is that the gallery limits the people inside. It gives you enough time and space to go around without bumping into other spectators.
Outstanding art and sculpture. Definitely recommend and suggest you get a good guide since the amount of info on the art really makes the visit worthwhile. Awesome and will do again!

Booking a long way ahead ESSENTIAL. We turned up on spec, only to be told that a) there were no tickets available for the day, and b) the soonest available would be in 6 days' time. So we didn't go around the exhibition. It might be fantastic if you've planned ahead (like we didn't) but I wouldn't know!
Amazing Gallery with real masterpieces). I opened for myself the world of sculpture as statues never were so alive, so sensitive and emotional)

Amazing gallery & grounds. First, let me say that I would have given this 5 stars if it wasn't for some of the gallery staff. We booked this tour through City Wonders/Dark Rome and we're glad we did. They have great tour guides and you're never let down by their enthusiasm. As for the gallery, the works of art are breathtaking. To see these famous works of art up close leaves you in awe. Now for the disappointing portion that left us sour for the first 20 minutes. The older heavy set lady with dark hair who takes your ticket at the entrance is nasty. I would rethink who welcomes customers into the building. She snaps at you if you didn't check your bag even if you apologize and say you thought it was after you entered the gallery. She raises her voice and says "there are signs everywhere". That's not the point lady. I intended to check my bag thinking it was just beyond the entrance. Thank goodness for the tour guide. He wisked us downstairs where there are signs to check your bag and helped me cut the line to check my bag. I guess this type of thing isn't their priority since people flock to the site for the art & not the employees.

Be certain to plan for a visit to the Borghese Gallery!. An extraordinary small selection of works; unmissable! The sculptures are exquisite and the paintings beyond one's dreams; both the number 52 and 53 busses will take you right to the side gates...

I would go back!. This was the last place we went after spending 5 amazingly full days in Rome. We were tired and did not feel like another tour. We just went on our own--mistake. We LOVED the fabulous couture dresses displayed alongside these amazing pieces of art (of which we knew little about because we did not get a tour guide!) We knew we were looking at some amazing Bernini's. But it wasn't until we got home and listened/watched some videos on the sculptures that we realized we short changed this beautiful museum. Now that I am "educated", I would love to go back!

Stunning collection, much more pleasant than Vatican Museums!. You have to make an appointment and are only allowed to stay inside for two hours, which limits the number of people there at any one time - much more pleasant than the crowded rush through the Vatican Museums. The surrounding grounds are beautiful for strolling, biking, picnicking. A really pleasant experience, and the art is very impressive.

Amazing and able to see the art up close. A great experience but do need to book in advance very enjoyable beautiful location with other galleries and a park to visit. Place to cool off when it is hot

Original Art Gallery. Very modern art ehibitions, and very original. The permanent gallery is fantastic! There are great paintings and amazing sculptures: the very famous Apollo e Dafne, David of Bernini.. just to mention some of the most beautiful

Amazing art collection in a beautiful setting. This family estate is now a public park. The art, both paintings and sculptures, was collected during the 16th century and is displayed in the villa among the frescoes on the ceilings and mosaics on the floors.
Great paintings. Carravaggio, Titian, Bernini are all stored here. You need to purchase your tickets online, and you only get two hours to enjoy the art. But it is well worth it.

Stunning. This was easy to book I telephoned two weeks before our visit and said we would be using a Roma pass I was given a booking number and a time slot and when we arrived quoted the number and showed our pass, no problems. All bags must be checked, but cameras are allowed. There were never too many crowds and the art was stunning, in the most magnificent setting. I would say a better experience than the Vatican museum because the gallery is smaller and more intimate and the art is labelled. It was an experience I will never forget, especially the sublime Bellini sculptures and the Caravaggio paintings.

Sculptures, paintings, architecture, and furniture, oh my!!!!!. Recommend booking tickets well in advance of your visit. The ticket is for a specific date/time window (only 2 hours). At the end of your time window, the gallery is cleared of visitors to make the whole gallery available for the people with tickets for the next time window. While waiting for our tour to start, we had the opportunity to enjoy the beauty of the exterior of the building, which is breathtaking by itself and is situated in a grand public park where there were many people enjoying the beautiful spring day. There are so many masters' works in the gallery to see, we had opted for the guided tour. Our learned art historian/guide encouraged us to view each of the many sculptures from several perspectives to maximize our appreciation of the artists work. I was overwhelmed by the quality and the quantity of their collection of statues. There were also incredible collections of antique furniture and paintings from the old masters. I was especially taken with the room of paintings which displayed the effect of sunlight shining into a room as if it were coming from an unseen window. Any visit to Rome would be lacking without a tour of the Borghese Gallery.
Breathtaking Art !. Worth every cent! Reservations are required and you most likely will need to take a cab. Allow PLENTY of time to enjoy the Gallery and surrounding gardens.

90 minutes of Masterpieces. The Borghese Museum aka galerie borghese has one of the best Italian collections of late Renaissance and Baroque Italian art in the world and it is all crammed in several rooms on two stories. It has a few Raphael's and two by Titian but it contains several of Bernini and Caravaggio. You must reserve ahead of time for a two hour slot. After two hours, they kick you out but we finished in less than 90 minutes. It is definitely a day one attraction for art lovers and day two or three for everyone else.

None of the most beautiful galleries in Rome, if not the world. It's stunning, the building itself and the contents. So sad that you are only allowed two hours to enjoy it as it always feels like such a rush. So, make sure you make the most of your time. First, don't even think about appearing without a reservation. It seems to sell out every day, at least at the busy times of year. If you get the audioguide, it will direct you to start at a certain place in the gallery, which most people will do. As everyone comes it at the same time, this means you will be with a crush of people. I would recommend that you do one of two things instead. One option is starting at the Pinocateca Gallery which is on the second floor. Spend your half hour there, then go downstairs. The other option is to start st the end of the first floor tour, which is the Caravaggio room which tends to get very crowded. We most enjoyed our last 45 minutes in the gallery because we managed to escape the crowd. It's worth a little strategy to do this as we got to see all our favourites in silence. Also, we read in some source that photos are not allowed and that you would have to check your cameras but this is not true, everyone was snapping away.

Omygosh you must see these sculptures! . Very peaceful gardens, and the artwork in the villa is breathtaking. Remember, you need a reservation to go to this gallery. You can get tickets online and should do it before you arrive, often there is a 4-7 day waiting period. It's definitely worth it!

Stunning even though I'm not an art fan!. I think it was about 5 euros for an audioguide and I'd definitely recommend it. It's a fairly small museum with only 2 floors but there are lots of great pieces to see.I'm not even an art fan and I found it interesting.

Must visit! Book reservations online 30 days out.. My sister and mom recommended that my boyfriend and I visit the Gallery. I can't believe I had never been before. It is absolutely amazing -- the building is nearly as beautiful as Bernini's sculpture. Breathtaking. Make sure to make reservations online prior to your trip.

Everything I thought it would be and more. The gallery was awesome. Appointments are necessary to get in and that made the experience much more personable, it wasn't crowded and was able to really explore the artwork and sculptures, if you get a chance explore the surrounding park, great place for families.
An essential part of a visit to Rome. The Borghese houses an excellent collection of paintings and -- especially -- sculpture. Do not skip it. Reservations required.

Best gallery experience!. My group of four agreed this was the best! Why? You can only go at a reserved time, which is because they restrict the number of visitors to a reasonable amount. Also, the audio guide was STELLAR. We used many audioguides in many museums and galleries, and this one was best: perfect balance of amount of info and type (combination of historical and/or artistic relevance, acquisition info, etc.) for those of us interested in important art but not terribly educated about it. Also the audioguide is timed for 90 minutes and your reserved stay is 120 minutes, allowing you to focus on what mattered and have a little extra time for things that caught your eye, and to move around. We recommend you listen to the intro piece then move up to the second floor, away from the crowd. We ended up having many rooms to ourselves! Travel note: we struggled with our public transit route for this destination plus were in crammed rush hour Metro cars. We ended up grabbing a cab outside of a fancy hotel and being taken right to the gallery gate for just a few Euro, which was great.

You can leave me grounded there. One of the coolest places in Rome. We spent our morning enjoying a bike at Villa Borghese and then , in the afternoon, we visit the Galleria Borghese in the reserved time. The visit was special for us and for all delicate works that are there and especially because of Bernini's works such as Pluto and Proserpina Bernini. Whenever in Rome, do this visit.

A must see in Rome. This museum is worth going to just to see Bernini's most famous sculptures alone. Get the audio tour so you can appreciate what you are seeing. It's easy to skip exhibits if you want to. Make sure to book tickets in advance and allow yourself a couple of hours to walk the surrounding gardens if it's a nice day. Remarkable!

Art. We booked a tour and had a great experience. Becky was our tour guide and she was very knowledgeable and enjoyable to listen to. I believe the only way to truly get the information that you need at this gallery is to go with a guide. We were then able to walk through the gardens which were beautiful.

A jewelbox of a Gallery. I had the pleasure of visiting this Gallery last year so it was high on my list to see again during my week long trip this year. Bernini and Caravaggio are stars here but there a treasures everywhere! It requires reservations and you get a strick two hour limit. So much to see here and the wonderful thing is that you see the art in situ.

Galerie Borghese. It was a Cardinal called Borghese, he organize to construct this superb palazzo for his fun and pleasure for social gathering. The sensuous cardinal likes valuate art and sculptures and ordered most by Bernini. He let visit the public his palast; today you must pay entrance and wait about a week for ticket better to order by internet.I was impressioned by Pauolina, the sister of Napoléon, sculptue in white marmor and also the face of David in marmor by Bernini. Paolina was the nicest sculpture which I remember.
so much to take in. My tour was spoiled slightly by the flimsy dresses dotted around as part of an additional exhibition, but my wife loved them, so horses for courses !
A must see In Rome. we spent the full allotted time in the building. What a collection of statues, paintings and fabulous rooms. I think the statues were as astounding as the Louvre

Simply Stunning..Rude Staff. To access they require you to hand over purses, bags, umbrella, etc. My wife will never give up her purse with money, credit cards, passports, etc. So we split up. I toured for one hour, came back to the entry and took my wife's purse while she toured for an hour. I have an artificial hip and stairs are extremely difficult. The staff grudgly allowed me to use the amazingly small lift( 3' dia.) to the top floor so I could walk down. I saw NO handicap access, so ask ahead if you need a wheelchair. The staff denied my wife the use of the elevator. I have words that describe the staff, but they are inappropriate for Trip Advisor.

Stunning presentations. Buy your tickets on line and show up at your appointed time and you will be treated to a up close presentation of some of the finest Italian paintings and sculpture outside the vatican museums. it is a stunner. Bring your "non flash" camera and enjoy.

Sublime art spoiled a bit by the overall experience. I hardly need to go on about the sublime nature of what is on show here, so I won't. However what needs to be mentioned is the overall quality of the experience which is not great owing to the surly and unhelpful staff. You have to allow a lot of time just to get in - first to exchange your ticket, then to check in your bag (however small) and to queue up for an audio guide (where you need to give them your passport as security). Don't pay too much attention to the time restriction as 2 hours is plenty. The audio guide is good and worth getting. Overall a must visit place when in Rome, it is just a pity about the pointless restrictions and unhelpful staff.

"Intense!". Beautiful art! It immerses the viewer in a total experience of wonder and joy. So much to see and appreciate. I would advise anyone who is going to take a guided tour. Keep in mind that you can only stay for two hours.

Fantastic Gallery. You've got to book in advance and only get a 2 hour time slot to visit but well worth it. Bernini's statues are incredible as are many of the other great works of art (one of my favorites was Girolamo da Carpi's Corteo Magico).

Best Museum in Rome. This museum was beautiful and had some of the best statues in Rome. You need to purchase tickets in advance to avoid delays. They advertise that all bags and cameras will be checked at the door. They also said absolutely no photography. To avoid checking bags and camera, we left ours at the hotel. The biggest disappointment was watching everybody have a camera taking pictures. No enforcement of the rules they publish.
My Roman Experience.. Beautiful gardens and you get lost in it's past. close your eyes and drift into the moment. you will love it.

wonderful museum, horrific staff. While the museum has beautiful Bernini sculptures and the Azzedine Alaia exhibition is wonderful, I have never been in a museum before where just about everybody who works there was grumpy or downright rude to the visitors. Quite an experience...

So Much Art in one place!. Only the Vatican can come close to the artwork at the Borghese Gallery. The palace itself has artwork floor to ceiling from all the masters. I would advise anyone who is going to take a guided tour. There are thousands of paintings and the history behind them is fascinating. The crowds were thick even in late October. Without the tour guide you would probably not be able to get close to the artwork.

Don't Miss! Don't Follow the Crowd. As most reviewers have said, this place is amazing and you need to book tickets in advance. Allow plenty of time to get to the museum, check your bag and get an audio guide. You will be let in the museum with all the others who have tickets for the same time period. The crowd will start in the entrance hall and move from room to room in a counter-clockwise manner. I suggest quickly moving to room number 3 while everyone else is still in the first room. This will give you the chance to view the absolutely stunning Apollo and Daphne Bernini sculpture all by yourself. By the time you loop back around to the first room, the crowd will have dispersed and you will enjoy the first three rooms more.

Stunning art works!. After 40 years of visiting Rome I had never gone to the Borghese until this year. Should have started 40 years ago with repeat visits. We had a guide and the tour was wonderful. Tours are limited to two hours so repeat visits are a must to see it all. The art work is absolutely breathtaking...Raphael, Carravaggio and Bernini shine! Don't miss it!

You need to book. This is an extremely impressive gallery and one not to be missed. The audio guide is better than average. We booked at the last minute and managed to find a slot that suited us, otherwise is was fully booked for several days. Only thing that stopped me giving this a 5 star was the impolite staff.
Astounding. Wouldn't have missed it for the world. But book your tickets a month in advance! The beauty of it is that they only let people in 200 at a time.
Amazing place!. Loved walking through here! The statues and paintings were inspirational! Make sure to book ahead as it gets sold out pretty quickly!
One of a kind museum. Just go.. Breathtaking on every level. Floor to ceiling artwork. And yes, I do mean the entire ceiling. A must see.I will go every time I'm in Rome.

Fabulous collection. The gallery is superbly laid out with immaculate sculptures and paintings.You need to prebook tickets which is easy online. I enjoyed the fact the tickets are timed allowing you sufficient opportunity to enjoy the exhibits without the gallery getting overcrowded. There are audio guides available also each room has large cards describing the main exhibits. I would also allow time to walk around the park that has many interesting architectural finds.

First Sunday of the month is free entry - but make a booking!. We had the fortune of happening upon the Borghese Gallery on the first Sunday of the month - happily, this is free entrance day (also the case for multiple other museums and galleries). We were quite put out, however, upon discovering that the gallery was booked out for three days in advance. I tried my luck with the ticket office (downstairs) and, amazingly, I had three tickets placed in my hand and was warned that you could only spend two hours in the gallery. My thanks to the individual for getting us in, since I've heard that the bookings are sometimes enforced quite strictly. Absolutely gorgeous collection inside and make sure you look up to the ceilings!

Stop here first to understand the Roman look. If you want to understand Rome and its current look, you must stop here first to see Bernini's great influence on Rome in the baroque period. And check out his statue of David. It has Michelangelo's David beat, in my opinion.

If you have extra time. We visited the Borghese Gallery after our cruise. We had seen so much art work and sculptures by then that it did not excite us we thought it would. It's a lovely setting in a huge park. You only get 2 hours in the museum but that is plenty of time. We bought our tickets online.

Amazing sculpture collection. We enjoyed the visit and glad that reservations limit the crowds. Wonderful art collection in amazing building and park setting. Was closed first time we visited Rome so very happy to see this time!

This museum lived up to my expectations - stunning collection. The art in the museum is well known and some of the best sculptures I have ever seen. It is displayed well, however there was a fashion show which covered some of the Roman Mosaics on the floors. Personally I would rather see the mosaics. Make sure you get in early to check in your bags. cameras are allowed and you will want to take photos. Also, it is important to book ahead to get into this museum. I missed out eight years ago because it was fully booked. It has been a long wait but very much worth it to see this stunning collection.

Do not miss this!. We enjoyed the Borghese Gallery so much on our first trip to Rome that we went again on this trip - and we would go again. You must buy tickets ahead of time. The tickets are timed and you only have 2 hours to complete your stay. Get a headset.

Beautiful building with amazing art!. The building itself is beautiful as the former home of the Borghese family. Many works of Bernini are featured here including Apollo and Daphne. The museum is small and advance ticket purchase is required. The audio guide is very helpful in understanding the collection.

Cultural morning. We visited the Galleria Borghese while in Rome recently and were wowed by its treasures.A visit had been recommended by a friend so we thought we'd give it a go. The Borghese is to the north of the city at the top of the Via Veneto and is accessible by metro or bus. We walked from our hotel on the Via XX Settembre and it only took about 20 minutes.The Galleria is situated in parkland that is pleasant to walk around but, realistically, needs some better up keeping in my view.To access the Galleria you do need to pre book a time slot as only 360 people are allowed in per slot and for 2 hours maximum. You can book on-line and collect your tickets at the reception desk.To do justice to the treasures on view would take more words than are available in a review. All I can really say is, simply stunning.I would buy a guide book, available in the shop for 16 euros although you can hire an audio tour.There is a cafe in the basement tha serves great coffee and snacks.A top tip is to get to the place at least 45 minutes before your time slot. The queues can get lengthy to collect tickets and for the cloakroom. You are not allowed to take coats or bags into the collection rooms.A must see really.
should state you have to prebook. got a taxy there found it was fully booked to end of month, so take my advise and book or check by phone

A beautiful gallery full of wonderful things. The Borghese family was one of Rome's wealthiest and produced the odd Pope or two. That wealth was partially used to build an enormous collection of art over the centuries. The Borghese Gardens once belonged to this suburban villa.The collection includes paintings by Raphael and Caravaggio inter alia and sculpture by Bernini and Canova's famous nude statue of Pauline Bonaparte.
The sculptures - just wow!. Make sure and book your tickets to the Borghese Gallery at least a week in advance or you risk being shut out! The Bernini sculptures are well worth the advance planning.

Masterpieces in an Opulent setting. We visited the Gallery in the morning and were charmed by the villa as well as impressed with the incredible art inside. There was also a temporary modern art installation. Don't forget to look up at the ceilings and down at the mosaic floors. Make sure to secure tickets ahead of time online.
Bernini!. Remarkable villa filled with awe inspiring sculptures and other art. Don't miss this. No trip to Rome is complete without visiting here.

Best Sculpture. We visited the Borghese Gallery on a Friday in October. The gallery admits people in two hour intervals so it is less crowded than the other major attractions in Rome thus a much better experience. We had the last reservation of the day and thoroughly enjoyed it. The sculpture in the Borghese is incredible..the detail..the condition...the variety...must see it to appreciate it.

Would have loved to go in but shut! Gardens pleasant. Attempts to book something on our long weekend proved fruitless. Would visit if we went again. Went to the gardens via the metro as it is off the tourist beat. Finding a metro means looking for an M just like McDonalds. It can be difficult. Gardens pleasant after being in the busy city for three days and quiet - but then it seems the museum is only for a few. Nice restaurant in the gardens.

Fabulous. Hard not to like what is inside the Galleria. It is so fantastic. Sculptures, paintings, salons that are so breathtaking one after the other. Very impressive. Do get advance reservations or you'll miss this art jewel. They only take so many people at a time and limit you to 2 hours. However, it is ufficient to see it.

Bernini Rocks. I loved the Bernini statues and the opulence of the palace. The surrounding park is pretty spectacular too - especially the umbrella pines. We took the audio tour, which made it much more enjoyable. I was a bit disappointed that the paintings were not on par with the outstanding sculptures. Seeing the Bernini Apollo and Daphne was worth every euro to get in. The palace itself is also a work of art - it would have been awesome if it could have had a few furnished rooms.

Booking in advance means better viewing. The collection is awesome. I never really "got" Bernini until I had a guided tour of the galleries which are not at all crowded due to the restricted entry - only c300 people in each 2 hour slot. The Caravaggio collection was another highlight as was the unexpected haute couture collection mirroring the folds and colours in the sculpture and paintings surrounding the pieces. The English speaking guide was originally from Argentina and our small group enjoyed her interpretations of the historic collection.Come early and stroll around the gardens - I walked from via Veneto but you can also approach from Piazza del Populo or Spagna.

A Highlight of My Recent Visit to Rome. I have been to Rome at least six or seven times now (I love that I'm losing count - means I'm finally getting familiar with the eternal city!), but before the last trip (just three weeks ago) I had only been to the glorious Borghese Gallery once, and that in the late 90s, when it was undergoing such extensive renovation that only the ground floor was open. Fortunately on that ground floor stood some of the treasures of the Borghese - at least three Berninis in a row (Apollo and Dafne and the David among them), and I was bewitched.Since then the Borghese has been restored magnificently, but the difficulty factor in getting into the museum has increased. Timed tickets only, booked in advance. THIS time I finally got back to it, and got a good look at the entire Borghese. There are great paintings and especially sculptures enough to make this museum absolutely world class, but the building itself and its gorgeous interiors are almost as wonderful as the art.So as soon as I knew when my train would arrive in Rome I booked a timed ticket for three hours later. Once there (and boy, did I get lost in the Villa Borghese - those gardens are very difficult to navigate!) there was still a short wait. A line outside the entrance was divided by a sharp and friendly young member of the museum stance. Those without timed-tickets were ushered into another long line outside - where, if there was room after the ticket holders who had booked in advance were let in, a few of those in that line MIGHT have the chance to get in themselves. I was ushered right in, to another wait - of about ten minutes, until the stroke of three pm, when my "time" had come. This is probably somewhat tedious to at least some visitors, but it seems the only way the museum can cope with the crowds - even with the carefully allotted number of people I still found it a bit of tour group hell, groups herded around guides speaking English, French, German and of course Italian (there may have been more languages represented, but those I recognized), but especially after the first few minutes where everyone is stuffed into the entry and still confused about which way to turn, there was room to breathe and more importantly to gaze on not just the Caravaggios and Berninis etc, but also the breathtaking walls and ceilings (even if you don't like the art in front of you, just look up).I had an absolutely wonderful visit, though I confess that my first time, back in the late 1990s, remained with me. At that time I was only vaguely aware of who Bernini, for instance, was. Now I am much better versed in his sculpture, which I think is THE reason to visit the Borghese, crowded as it is not just with tourists but with other great artists and sculptures, and in art history as a whole, but the air of entering a place mostly closed off and discovering a new artistic hero was not lost, but considerably lessened. This is one of my very top recommendations in Rome!
Something else to see in Rome. Buy ticket in advance otherwise you might not be able to enter. Nice change during visit to Rome. Otherwise, gallery like many others in Europe.
Great Collections but check times and book in advance. Good to use on the Rome pass and centrally located so its easy to include in a days Itinary of central Rome.

One of the Best Museums in Rome. The Borghese Gallery was one of the best sites we visited in Rome. The site of the museum (in a very large park) and the building itself are beautiful - gorgeous ceilings and mosaic floors.I was so excited to see all of the Bernini sculptures there and they did not disappoint - just stunning. There was also a temporary exhibit of Azzedine Alaia's gorgeous couture clothing.Based on Rick Steves' recommendation we booked tickets one week in advance, although I have no idea how frequently they actually sell out of particular time slots. I appreciate that they limit the number of people who can visit at any given time so it doesn't feel crowded.The only negative was that the entrance was unclear. You have to go into the basement to check in and then go outside and up a flight of stairs to enter the exhibition space. (This was not explained to us.) Also, be aware that all bags and purses need to be checked.The museum also includes a cafe a gift shop.It was getting dark by the time we left the museum so we didn't get to explore the gardens much, but what we saw was lovely.

Don't Leave Rome without a Trip to the Borghese!. You need advance reservations, but it is well worth adding this museum to your Rome itinerary. We got an early morning reservation and took one of the regular tours. If I remember correctly, the tour was very reasonable and it made all the difference having an enthusiastic Italian tour guide who loved the art.

One of My Favorites. This is a beautuiful museum in a beautiful park. You must book in advance and are only allowed two hours to see the collection. But, for me, that was the perfect amount of time. I've been twice. The first time, I went with a small group and a guide; the second time, I used the audio guide. Both work. The advantage of the former is that you can ask questions, of the latter, that you can go at your own pace. I loved the Caravaggios, but it's the Berninis that really make the pre-booking and entrance fee worthwhile.

Great Art Superbly Displayed. We booked ahead for the Borghese Gallery (do it--we saw people told to come back in four days) and were rewarded with a 2-hour visit to this magnificent gallery. The Bernini sculptures were amazing, especially since he was in his early 20s when he did them. Given you have a limited amount of time, we went upstairs first while others were downstairs, then retraced our steps. An amazing collection.

Book in advance. We like many other people we saw turned up without pre booking. It is booked up weeks in advance.When we checked our guide it did clearly say to book in advance, but like a lot of other people we didn't read this before walking out to the museum. Our fault just trying to stop others from making the same mistake as it is a bit of a hike.

Lots of Busts. A country bumpkin might grin and say that this small but widely acclaimed (and rightly so) gallery is "full of busts, both kinds, and more 'junk' hanging out than a redneck front yard." A lot of nudes, in other words, but if that was your outlook on the arts you would not be coming here.You will need to buy tickets months in advance, of course, and they will be for a specific time slot of two hours long. That requires more planning than many people are comfortable with, but they limit attendance within each group so that visiting here is much more pleasant than places like the Vatican Museum (see my review) or the Uffizi Gallery in Florence (see my review). You can actually stand close to the art and admire it at length without being jostled or elbowed out of place. Anyway, to visit, you will need to arrive early and go downstairs to exchange your online voucher for real tickets and to check your camera bags, purses, backpacks, but NOT coats, in the coat room. Helpful hint: carry a small nylon duffel bag (with a shoulder strap, to carry your coats in as the day heats up, and you can then check THAT here. Then go outside and take the steps up to the "0 floor" and start your tour there (they will let you in at exactly your appointed time). Just inside the door pick up a little pamphlet in your language; it may help a bit. For serious art lovers, you will need a guidebook, but if you're like me and don't much care who did it or even what it is called but just want to appreciate each piece you like on its own merits you can probably be done here in an hour. They're going to kick you out after two, so make good use of your time. The "zero floor" is mostly sculpture in some spectacularly elegant room settings, with four rooms dedicated to masterworks by Bernini, who may be the best ever, at least in my poorly educated opinion. Amazing. The "1 floor" above is mostly paintings. Because the crowd has been managed I suggest seeing the lower floor first, and then as time permits going to the upper floor.
Fantastic!!. Breathtaking beauty of sculptures and wonderful paintings! Loved it as timed ticket so only 300 people in at a time for 2 hour visit.Buy ticket in advance.

Favorite Museum in Italy. The sculptures are great. My favorite piece of art was here. I don't recall the name but the model was Napoleon's sister in a state of undress. It was amazing how the artist made the marble sofa she was on appear to be soft. One of those things you would never get from a photo. The gardens are also beautiful here. Order your tickets in advance. Unlike the Vatican, they limit the number of people in the museum so you can enjoy the artwork.

Odd man out. After hearing exhalted praise from so many people about this museum I decided to see for myself. I was able to snare a ticket for the first time slot on my last full day in Rome. After standing in line to get into the building and then standing in line to get my ticket and then standing in line to check my backpack (mandatory) I then stood in line waiting for the interior doors to open. So when the interior doors finally opened I was less than enthused. I guess I am the odd man out as I did not find this museum to be that interesting. It is very small (two floors only each of about 3000 sq. ft?) and the rooms are way to small to appreciate the huge art pieces. Although you are given two hours (never heard of that) I was done in less than one. Sorry I wasted my time on this attraction.And yes the staff are rude and unhelpful. The only place I encountered this in Rome.

Best Museum We Saw. My wife and I visited Borghese, the Vatica, Academia and Uffizi museums along with a few others during our recent trip to Italy. Borghese was at the top of the list. The museum was pretty uncrowded, had tour cards in every room (which I really like as compared to the electronic devices) and had a number of great pieces of artwork - both paintings and sculptures. The amount of time allotted is appropriate for the size of the museum and the ticket cost is appropriate for the collection.Our favorite part of the tour was probably the Carravagio collection. We have a new appreciation for this artist.The location was accessible with a moderate walk from our hotel at Piazza Navona. It is in a very nice park with bicycles and other attractions. Nice park to spend the day in.Highly recommend this as a gotta go site.

Borghese Gallery Private Tour with The Roman Guy. This tour was such a surprise. It's such a beautiful place and our tour guide Bajon really cared about the subject matter. The Gallery is a manageable size with little crowds as they are good at making sure no one goes over their two hour time limit. I would recommend going with a tour guide so they can help to point out the important / special pieces in the collection that you might other wise miss.

One of the highlights of Rome.. Visiting the Borghese was definitely the highlight of my stay. In addition to all the fantastic Bernini sculptures they were hosting a magnificent fashion retrospective of Azzedine Alaia. Afterwards we walked leisurely through the gardens. Definitely a must see in Rome!

A breathtaking little museum in a beautiful park. I had friends tell me this was a not-to-be-missed museum, and they were right. So I booked our places online a few days before we left, and even then it was not soon enough because most of the places were taken the day we had available. They only give you 2 hours, but it should be enough. We walked from the Metro Barbarini up to Via Veneto and through the park. In another visit if I am so lucky, I will take a taxi as close as allowable. It was a longish walk, but to be honest, it was worth it. The Borghese is breath-taking. I discovered what a genius Bernini is and saw the opulence of the aristocrats. You don't see this at home, I'm guessing. Be amazed at the grandeur. That is what Cardinale Borghese wanted to do almost 300 years ago, and it still impresses.

Must see, if you have time. This is a world-class museum with many paintings and sculptures you see when looking at the best of the best. It's a little out of the way for those who want to take buses or the metro, but the Villa Borghese is a wonderful wooded area and a delightful respite from the business of the city. It is sometimes sold out. Go online for tickets.
Must book in advance.... A fantastic collection, housed in a magnificent building. I enjoyed that they limited admission, as even then the building was a bit busy.

Staff just rude. I don't care how great this gallery is, the staff here has to be the rudest in all of Italy. Very mightier than thou attitude, almost like they don't want you here. If you're going to spend your time and money, do it elsewhere.

Green space in Rome. Beautiful gardens surround the Borghese Villa for all to enjoy. Visit the museum and stroll around the grounds to get that great green space feeling. We walked from the villa all the way to the beginning of the Spanish Steps. What views of Rome!

A gem. Beautiful building in a garden (really a park) not far from downtown Rome. The collection is highlighted by sculpture by Bernini and paintings by Caravaggio. Because timed tickets are required, the museum is relatively uncrowded.

Bernini sculpture exudes life... Must witness it personally!. We toured multiple museums for two weeks in Italy. This was by far a favorite for several reasons. The Bernini sculptures were like nothing I'd witnessed prior. I usually prefer painting over sculpture; however this gallery changed my thoughts. To see marble generate energy was beautiful. We had an exceptional guide! Becky relayed story after story about the paintings and sculptures, which gave us a rich and in depth glimpse into a world inhabited centuries ago. The museum also requires a reservation, which greatly limits the number of guests present. This feature greatly improved our experience!

Pleasantly surprised - worth the visit . The most amazing ceilings & statues!!!
Organised Staff, clean and a good little cafe. Great security and and in a lovely location with g argent to walk through.

Well worth the advance reservations!. The Borghese Gallery offers an extremely unique collection of art and it well worth the mild inconvenience of advance reservations (use their online system). The collection housed here is awe inspiring! You only get 2 hours, so use it well, because they're serious about moving you out at the end of your reserved time.

Beautiful art, magnificent surroundings. Know what you are looking for, and at, before you visit. You have to move smartly through this fantastic museum to get finished in the alloted two hours. Not too crowded.

One of the most beautuful museums in Rome. You need to book in advance to experience the Borghese Gallery, but make sure you do. This is one of the best art museums in Rome, and this saying something with the number of museums in Rome! The sculpture is sublime.

beautiful. everything aabout it is great if you don't go with a tour group you have to get your ticket ahead of time and the ticket lets you in for a specified two hour period we took through eternity tour ... 4 total people on tour with an art historian as our guide excellent

Everything You'd Expect...and LESS!. My wife is an art lover and dabbled in painting as a young woman, so we naturally made reservations at Galleria Borghese before leaving on our vacation in Rome. The gallery, the gardens, and the opulent palace itself did not disappoint. We enjoyed the Bernini sculptures, especially the Rape of Proserpina. There was a special exhibit of modern fashions interspersed with the art and presented as art itself.We expected the gardens to be a simple park, and we were surprised to find that they were full of attractions in their own right: fountains, monumental works of art, refreshment kiosks, and a dramatic overlook on Piazza del Popolo. Swallow your pride and ride the trenino. It was fun!Don't allow the arrogant, condescending staff ruin your day. Beware of the middle aged female at the ticket counter, who is trying too hard to make a fashion statement. She shaved her head and wears blue "cat's eye" eyeglasses. She really hassled us because she said our registration number was invalid, and we didn't have a smart phone to show her the receipt. We asked her if the museum had wi-fi, and she denied it. (They do!) Finally, she threw a pair of tickets on the counter and said, "Thank you. Bye-bye. Next!" In a loud, sarcastic voice.Look out for the older male barista in the coffee shop, too. He's not exactly Signore Personality, either!

Must get ticket before visit but absolutely worth it.. You get 2 hours to do the two floors but we found that we didn't have to hurry. The building is lovely and the way the art is arranged is very accessible. Lots of statues: David with his slingshot is looking so intense you can feel the impotance of the task.But the ceilings are the best: look out for the group sitting on a ledge peering down at the visitors!If you like art then this is a must.

Definitely one on the "must see" list. You have to purchase tickets in advance for this gallery - I booked in the UK online and the admissions are for timed entry as you have 2 hours in all. When we pitched up on the Tuesday, there was a sign saying there were no tickets available until Saturday - as this is Oct and towards end of season, I would say don't bother showing up if you have not already got tickets.I really enjoyed seeing the sculptures - more so that I was expecting and the decoration in each room, including the ceilings, was amazing. I would highly recommend an audio-guide as it was much more rewarding to hear about the background to each piece. Some great paintings too. For me, the most refreshing thing - after a visit to the Vatican and the Sistene Chapel the day before - was that their control of the numbers entering makes it a much more enjoyable experience. For sure it is busy, but you can walk around in the order you choose rather than being herded, so you can go back to bits that were crowded.
Great art, shame about the grumpy staff. Fabulous Berninis, superb Caravaggio, beautiful setting.Grumpy staff - they were so rude, it made us laugh.
Book AHEAD. I'm sure the gallery is great once you're inside, but you should book ahead if you want to enjoy it. I didn't do that and it was such a disappointment.

Much More Than a Magnificent Art Collection. The Borghese is much more than a magnificent art collection -- though, of course, all the art is breathtaking. Visiting also provides an enlightening experience.

Brilliant art wrapped in shoddy customer service. Why, oh why, do these places shoot themselves in the foot by doing such a poor job of customer service that they nearly ruin a great art collection? The cynic in me says that the answer is in the question - when you have something great, you don't really need good customer service to get the money coming in (especially when you have limited capacity).I'll start with the good - the content. The art collection is both interesting and excellent in equal measure. The headliners are the real highlight - the paintings by Caravaggio and the sculptures by Bernini. There are several 'masterpieces' which captivate and come with an interesting back-story. Furthermore, the interiors of the gallery itself are works of art - they could sell tickets to empty rooms given the quality of the wall and ceiling decorations. They very helpfully provide information explaining the history of the room itself and how the content has changed over the years.So, why was I so negative at the start? Well, they really don't make you feel welcome. The gallery has a relatively small capacity and so booking tickets in advance is a must - you need to be there an hour or so before a pre-allocated time slot to collect from the ticket office. After doing so, and having a wait before we could enter, me and my wife went to the cafe where the service was at best functional. There were no niceties and no friendly tones, it was very down to business. The cafe has very little space / seating given how many people are waiting around - and the rules seem overly constricting. There are several 'no food past this point' signs and, despite there being more space they could make available for people to wait in comfort with what they have ordered, you are cramped into a smallish area with a handful of tables and one or two benches.Another aspect of the service which seems unnecessarily rule-based is making it compulsory to put your bag in the cloakroom (where they ironically refuse to take any coats from people). Naturally, given the pre-allocated slots and compulsory nature this gets very crowded and there will be a big queue just before the time window starts. It all just feels a bit like rules for rules sake.I understand that there is a need to limit throughput, to protect and conserve. However, I compare this to galleries with similarly high profile pieces such as those in London - where you can walk in, no charge, no security check, no unnecessary rules and limitations, no unnecessary discomfort - that seem to do a perfectly good job of looking after the art they are responsible for.I'm afraid I just find it a little frustrating that such a great collection of pieces are wrapped in quite a poor service.

The summit of art history within two hours.. If you don't have time for the Vatican Museums or don't want to support the Roman Catholic Church, you can go to the Villa Borghese in stead. Book your tickets online in advance and get a two hours' time block. Don't walk in during the first ten minutes of your time block, because the crowd will already do. Most of that crowd will be out again within three quarters and then you have the whole building for yourself and the other real art lovers. Enjoy Bernini's statues of Apollo and Daphne or David or Pluto and Persephone, Canova's Pauline Borghese as she is laying on pillows and a matrass, all marble of course. Enjoy Caravaggio's, Rubens' and Honthorst's paintings, the gorgeous wall, ceiling and floor decorations and all these smaller artifacts. Don't forget the second floor, a bit hidden away. After this museum one needs a proper recovery. A walk through the beautiful park will help.
A Must DO!. A MUST DO! Amazing Bernini sculptures that will take your breath away. You only get 2 hours for your tour and you need every minute of it!

Borghese Gallery. This was an amazing gallery. I loved the statues, and the hand guide that you rented was well worth the money. Around 5€'s. You will need to leave some form of identification like your driving licence behind. One tip is to book on line in advance for your tickets otherwise when you arrive you will not be able to get in. It's booked up at least a week in advance!!! Well worth the visit.

So much to see and absorb. We went to the Borghese on a Sunday. If one has a reservation then one enters downstairs and one exchanges the voucher for a ticket around 30 minutes before the alloted time. All of the signage said no cameras. One has to go to the cloakroom area and check coats, backpacks, purses, cameras, and more. Once the items are checked, then one can get an audio tour using the cloakroom ticket as the reminder to return the audio. With the audio in hand, then one goes outside and up the stairs to wait in line ( Italian style- in a crowd) for the time to enter. The previous groups has to go out before the next group can go in. As soon as we entered we saw that most people did not store their cameras and everyone was taking photos including photos of the no cameras signs. The collection is massive. Even with the audio one can only take on so much information. I think one could go there and spend the entire time allotment in one room. There is so much to see. I felt badly that we passed by items without a glance because there was so much. It is a great experience for any art lover.

Beautiful setting to see art. Caravaggio pieces were the highlight of our outing there for me but Belinini, also. They looked even better in the setting. Beautiful building and interior. Because they limit numbers of visitors, we could see all these in more normal setting, unlike Vatican Museum.
Make reservations. Best small museum in Rome. And they even allow non-flash photography. Bernini, Bernini, with some Rafealo and Boticelli thrown in.

Well worth the advance tickets, a gorgeous museum without the maddening crowds. This wonder tucked away in the Borghese gardens is not to be missed. If you can't get tickets, you can hire guides for tours and sometimes last minute tickets are available. The limited amount of patrons let in makes this a much more personable experience and does not feel as overwhelming as the Vatican Museum can be at times.

Bernini statues and much more in a Baroque palazzo. The Borghese Gallery has adopted a system of timed entry to keep the crowds from becoming too impossible. You have to buy a ticket in advance from the website. I didn’t find this process quite as easy as all the guidebooks said it would be, but I was able to negotiate it successfully in the end. When you arrive before your tour time, you enter at the ground floor level and pick up your tickets. There may be long lines for the audioguides, so make sure you’re in the correct line! Big bags have to be checked, but cameras are allowed (no flash). The routing of the tour was different than what’s given in the guidebooks I had looked at. We were sent up a spiral staircase to the second floor and then down to the main floor, where most of the Berninis are.During our visit, there was a special exhibit of couture designs by Azzedine Alaïa mixed in with the Classical and Renaissance art. This produced surreal juxtapositions at times--gold chainmail minidresses next to classical statues, extremely elongated black evening gowns spotlighted as if they were Baroque statues.The Berninis are just amazing, and with the lack of crowds, you can get fairly close and examine details--Daphne’s toes as they turn to tree roots, the softness of Persephone’s flesh as Hades’ fingers press in. They deserve the time and space you’ll have to contemplate them. Don’t miss the horse and rider tumbling through the wall in one of the larger rooms. The Borghese Gallery was a highlight of our visit to Rome.Take time to walk through the Borghese Gardens before or after your visit to the gallery. They are a pleasant respite from Rome’s traffic and bustle.

Ahh! The Borghese!. What a fabulous place to visit! The sculpture here, particularly the large collection of Bernini pieces, is breathtaking. Do not miss this when you visit Rome. Make sure to make reservations at least several days in advance as tickets can be hard to come by in peak season. You get 2 hours to do the tour so there is no wasting time. It was quite crowded with large tour groups. If I were to do it over, I might have gone to the upper floor and done that are first and then come back to the ground floor. The ground floor was almost empty after the first hour of the tour.

Book in advance online!. We turned up here not having known about booking in advance until we got to Rome and having been unable to get a ticket once we were there. However, this place has a lovely park to stroll in - a bit of a refuge from the noise and bustle of the city. You can hire four-seater bikes or take a little tourist train around the park if you prefer not to walk.

Lovely Gallery and grounds. Visited for the brilliant Azzedine Alaia exhibition which incredible. However it was clear that a visit to this gallery would be worth it even if there was nothing specific showing. Opulent rooms, beautiful art and fascinating Roman history. The surrounding gardens are lovely and you could easily spend a day here. The walk back into Rome from the gallery is worth it too, if you have the time.

Grand Feast for Art-lovers. Visitors have to book in advance, and each entry is limited to a 2-hour stay. We had a reservation at 1 pm, attempted to persuade the staff to let us in at 12:50, but with no luck. In fact, 2 hours prove to be enough time for most visitors. To avoid long queues at ticket office and deposite, you can arrive a bit earlier, and take a walk in the Borgese Garden before you are allowed entry. There's a cafe on the basement floor.

A Museum for all levels of art appreciation. This gallery requires reservations. It is located in the heart of the Villa Borghese, Rome's Central Park. The tour is limited to approximately two hours. The museum has great sculpture and great paintings. It entrances the most sophisticated of art lovers, and it delights the most casual viewer of world class art at the same time.

Perfectly sized gallery with wonderful art. This gallery requires reservations and as a result is never crowded. The art is interesting and beautiful and well documented with the audio tour. The setting in the Borghese gardens is lovely. Take a picnic to enjoy in the park before or after your visit.
