For art lovers. It is a very nice gallery located in the north park of Rome, full of precious paintings and other artworks.The number of visitors is limited to 350 per day so be sure to book your ticket at least few days before your visit!
spectaacular. Audio tour was well done, beautiful paintings on the walls and fabulous sculptures. Glad we reserved in advance otherwise we wouldn't have gotten in

Truly a special experience. When Rome tires you, look no further than the Borghese, the beauty of the venue is that they limit entrants so one can spend as much or as little time as you wish walking through endless marvellous works of art and especially the architecture.Book in advance to gain entry, turn up and attempt entrance leads to refusal
A MUST SEE. The art, the grounds, the villa - all extraordinary and breathtaking. Art includes works by masters like Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael and a wonderful sculpture by Canova.

A wonderful surprise!. The Borghese Gallery was one of the splendid, unexpected surprises of our trip through Italy. It is one of the lesser-known attractions, but well worth the visit. My husband and I enjoyed our audio-guide tour through the museum and we highly recommend it. The Bernini sculptures were amazing, and my personal favorite was the Apollo and Daphne. Be sure to book your tickets in advance. You won't be able to buy them the day of. Time slots are two hours and they enforce that. So you'll want to arrive early, pick up your official tickets from the basement level of the museum, and check your belongings. Purses/bags are not permitted. Cameras are allowed. You should be ready and waiting at the museum entrance prior to your entry time. That way you can enjoy every minute of your visit.

Nice gallery. Advance booking of the slot was required for the museum. Bought the Roma Pass but was unable to book through the phone hence we went to the museum in the morning to book for the slot and was thankful that we were able to get a slot of the same day. It was a nice 15-20mins walk from the train station through a garden to the museum. There are many nice paintings and sculptures, would recommend if you have interest in arts.

A feast for your eyes. Villa Borghese has an amazing collection of art including works by Caravaggio and Bernini. The exhibits are well organized and given the necessary space. Of particular beauty is the statue of Apollo and Daphne by Bernini.... simply breathtaking!

The walk is long, but the beauty is endless.. I captured a number of great photos while walking through Borghese, and even through the park, you can see a beautiful view of the center of Rome...but you will walk. If you take the tour...the walking tour...you will walk 3 plus hours. Wear your best walking shoes.

Best collection of Bernini and Caravaggio!. I highly recommend the Borghese Museum - it is a superb collection of art and sculpture - book your tickets online before you go to Rome so you will have a guaranteed entry time.

Be sure to spend time in the park. The Berninis are astounding. You don't really need to worry about a time strategy, because the two hours you're allotted is ample to see everything you'll want to see in the palazzo. This was the second place in Rome where we saw green parrots -- about fifteen of them wheeling around in plain sight. If you're tired of sculpture and art, you'll love the grounds.

Fantastic museum. Truly a gem that should not be missed! If you like Caravaggio and Canova this is the place to go. Be aware you have to reserve your tickets there is no walk in. Though this way the museum in never overcrowded...

Amazing experience. We took / book one of those curious bikes (four wheels) and went around all the park, stoping in the different and nice places o see the town.Although we did not visit the museums, it was really funny to drive that bike.We enjoyed very much.

How is it that people in Rome don't know where this museum is?. Wild goose chase. That's what we want on trying to find this place. No one seems to know where it is. We asked no less than 6 people for directions and not once could get us to this site. Not one. We missed out on it and were extremely disappointed. All of our maps of Rome had some stupid "auto bike" rental and sales symbol where the park and gallery were and we couldn't get navigated through the park well enough to find it once we got off the metro. Lesson. One is ticket in advance.Two. Take a cab or you will never find it. The park is a maze of trails and streets and we literally spent 2 hours looking for this place.Three. Don't trust the natives when they give you directions. They have no idea where this place is because they don't appreciate having it in their city.
Exquisite!. A must see but you need to get reservations before you go. No other way to get in. You can do it on-line before you travel to Rome.
The building and art here are not to be missed. The Bernini sculptures here are among the finest to be found in any museum in Italy. The building and grounds were beautiful.

Worth the price of admission. If you can get in, the Borghese Gallery is well worth the price of admission. The sculptures of Bernini and Borromini are incredible to see. The paintings of Carravaggio, Titian, Rubens and Raffaello are masterpieces that one must not miss. The setting is intimate and so one has the ability to view these works up close.Booking ahead is a must because the Gallery has limits to the numbers entering per day.
One of the world's best museums. The building is magnificent with every room a work of art. The art collection is excellent and the statuary is beyond description

An art lover's dream. We took a tour with a small group that enabled us to avoid the lines. The art was magnificent. The only drawback was a silly exhibition of costumes through out the galleries that was' clearly explained. The sculptures were wonderful.
A joke. Went on a Sunday morning, only to find out that it's sold out until Thursday! Which museum does that?!Seriously, if the current location can't take it, move the collection somewhere else!

Not worth the admission.. Had 5 - 7 pm tickets today. Go downstairs/basement with you internet voucher to exchange for ticket - very easy. This is also where the bathrooms are. Once inside it's basically one floor of the house that has art. Don't get me wrong it is amazing. I can't stop thinking about the one piece the had a guy holding up a naked woman by her thigh and his hand/thigh situation looks so realistic - and this is marble. Amazing. I personally wouldn't go back and wouldn't recommend since you have to plan your day around your ticket time.Also I don't understand what all the dresses were there for. Also beautiful but fairly modern compared to the art.

Exquisite. I thought I would enjoy the paintings more the the sculptures, but the reverse turned out to be true. The building itself is worth a visit.Limited number of visitors every two hours and by reservation only. Be sure to book ahead.
WOW. One of the best things we did in Rome. So pleased we prebooked this fabulous gallery. The artwork and statues just blew me away.

Amazing. Absolutely the best museum I went to in Rome. The grounds and building are beautiful and the interior is spectacular as well. The Bernini sculptures are wonderful and there are many great painters featured here as well. The best part is its crowd controlled to 2 hr windows with pre booked tickets so you can look in peace! Do remember to book at least a few days in advance though! Day of tickets are very hard to get.

The highlight of our trip. A must see.. One needs to book a two-hour slot for the timed entry to this palace. Please, do not fail to book this ticket. (One doesn't need a tour, just google it online, find the English language version and pay on-line for your tickets.) There's a line to pick up your tickets, then promptly, at your appointed hour, they let you in, so you have two hours with many fewer people than at other top attractions in Rome. We went directly to the back on the palace on the right to climb the stairs to the second floor and avoid the group. The strategy worked so well, we were practically alone when after viewing the INCREDIBLE paintings by Caravaggio and Raphael upstairs, we made our way down to spend a full hour ogling with utter amazement the gorgeous Bernini sculptures there--and many other incredible works of art. The palace is a lush environment--like a jewel box of color. We've seen a lot of gorgeous museums in France and Italy, but this place was just awe-inspiring. Apollo and Daphne by Bernini was worth the price on its own. A perfect experience in a wonderful park. Enjoy walking the park and eat at ai Fienaroli, a great restaurant nearby. Ciao.

Tour Guide Needed. We had a great guided tour by a local university professor. You will be lost by yourself.
Museum is great exhibit of classic paintings and sculptures.

AMAZING. I can't recommend a trip to the Borghese Gallery strongly enough. Buy tickets online well in advance -- entry is regulated by time, so you can't just wander in off the street. The advance planning is worth it just to see the Bernini sculptures in a sumptuous setting. Afterwards, spend time strolling through the park and enjoy Rome like a native. Loved this place.

Beautiful grounds!. This was fun. We'd seen all the big sites in Rome and decided to see the Villa Borghese. It's really just a sprawling park. You can rent a crazy bicycle-ish thing for two, which can be dangerous if you are reckless, which we were and had a lot of fun. Great place for kids to run around and have a good time.

Great museum!. The works of art in this collection are amazing, but during my visit they had an exhibit of high "fashion" dresses throughout the building. Some of these "dresses" were covering some ancient roman mosaics which were one the main reasons I was interested in visiting the museum. Overall it is a great museum, but I could do without the dresses which seemed very out of place and unnecessary. Make sure you reserve your tickets at least a few days before you plan to visit.

Appointments prevent overcrowding. I enjoyed this more than the Vatican museum because of the art, but also because of the scheduling system. We were able to see everything at our pace in 1.5 hours during the 2 hour appointment. It's a system that seems rigid and restrictive, but it pays off.

Best Gallery of Our Trip. We would have loved this gallery even if it had been empty. The interior is magnificent, over the top ... and then there are the paintings and sculptures. Gallery didactics are primarily in Italian but look for oversized laminated sheets near the doors for some info in English. We also enjoyed the Couture / Sculpture exhibition displayed throughout the permanent collection (until October 25, 2015): flowing contemporary gowns juxtaposed against the draped fabrics in many of the paintings. The BG is a relatively compact space in which to see an almost overwhelming volume of art. BOOK YOUR TICKETS!! If you try to walk in, you will likely be disappointed.

Amazing place for art lovers in the midst of a beautiful park for nature lovers!. Don't miss Borghese Gallery - some of the world masterpieces of sculpture and paintings inside such an amazing and exceptional decorated museum! Don't forget to order tickets on-line in advance.
Compact treasure. Excellent small museum especially rich in sculpture. Crowd control excellent with their 2 hour timed tickets.

A must see. Find out for yourself why you should see this place but here's a tip. You will need to book ahead online and you are only allowed two hours inside the gallery. Get there first thing in the morning and roll up at least half an hour before your scheduled starting time so that you can present your voucher and get your entry ticket. They are strict about only allowing people two hours inside the gallery and you will need all of the two hours. Turn up five minutes before your scheduled time and you could find it takes you 20 minutes to actually get inside but by that time the clock will have been ticking on your visit for 15 minutes.

So Many Wonderful Things. While you need to book in advance, it is worth it. Set in the idyllic park surrounding the Gallery, it is a peaceful oasis from the noise and chaos that is Rome. The collection of sculptures is so amazing that the paintings often do not get the recognition they deserve. The sculptures of Bernini are divine but so are the paintings of Raphael and Titan. If you are a lover of art, this is not to be missed.

Must see for Art lovers. The Borghese Gallery houses some of the best art pieces by Bernini & Caravaggio you'll find anywhere. The building is stunning in its beauty. The museum itself is situated in a beautiful park, great for strolling and biking. Reservations are required and getting them in advance is preferable. Go to the website for the gallery to purchase.

Book in advance - and fall in love with Rome. Loved this wonderful museum. Do book in advance - by the time we arrived the tickets were sold out a week in advance! Its a treasure, wonderful pieces. Well worth a look. 2 hour slots are enough to enjoy the pieces. Note : you can't take your bag in with you - they don't charge to mind your bags but prepare in advance - you can bring in your purse/camera/phone - but in your hand. Enjoy!!!

Truly amazing!!!. Words cannot describe, but I'll try.... the Bernini statues were one of the best highlights of my trip to Rome. The photos I took do not do them justice, they are breathtaking!!! The museum is definitely worth the visit to see these master pieces up close. Seeing all those famous paintings in person was hard to believe. In reference to some comments I read before my trip about rude staff, personally everyone was very polite to us, however I witnessed one of the staff members being a little rude with one group that missed their booking. Our booking was for 5:00pm and no one was allowed in not even 1 minute before! They are very organised and get upset if anyone tries to break the rules. Unfortunately we didn't get to enjoy the lovely park the museum is situated in, as it was raining :(

Hands down, the best. This museum is not to be missed. It is the best collection of Bernini statuary that I know of. If you are not familiar with him, go to the museum and you will be a fan. The rest of the collection is lovely as well. The size, setting and quality are unrivaled. It is not overwhelming like some places (Vatican Museums) can be.You have to make a reservation for a time to go. ... then go.

Great place to start your trip. We visited this awesome museum on day one of our trip and were amazed by the art. Then took a stroll in the beautiful park in front of the Borghese. Highly recommended!

The best museum I have watched so far!. I have been to Louvre, Uffizi and Academia but this is the best museum so far. Just loved each and every masterpieces especially Bernini's Pluto and Persephone. The grip of Pluto on Persephone's left thigh is so realistic and each of the muscle flexing is so authentic as if the drama is enacting right in front of our eyes.
Interesting. Amazing sculpture and superb artwork. There was also a fashion display which was very artful and interesting. Definitely worth the visit

The best art gallery in Rome. The museum has 2parts- the ground floor gallery with amazing sculptures of Bernini and upstairs picture gallery with paintings by Caravaggio ,Raphael and many others genius. The gallery is absolutely beautiful !! If you want to see the gallery you need to book the voucher online 10-15 days before you arrive. It's better to rent the audio guide.

A Jewel Box of a Gallery. This would have to be the best gallery in Rome. A must see for anyone visiting this beautiful city, but make sure you take a guided tour as you will get so much more out of your visit.

Disappointment is an understatement. Went there today as tried to call two numbers from Australia to book as I had a roma pass and wanted the museum included in the price . They hung up on me twice. I asked the lady this morning if I could wait and see if people didn't show up if we could take there place. She literally screamed at me saying no tickets all sold out till Wednesday .hence putting a damper on my day. But the grounds and outside of the building was amazing. Your customer service is a disgrace

Inside and Out A Treasure. Our group of artists and friends made this our first outing on our Roman holiday. But before I left home I had booked ahead to ensure our entry. That was not an easy thing to do. I tried to book online but my credit card was repeatedly refused. (the same card was used with no problem on the Vatican web site and for the transfers) My daughter booked for me using her credit card and when the confirmation was printed out the instructions for picking up the tickets at the gallery were precise stating one needed photo id and the credit card used to purchase the tickets. I called the gallery and the man who answered impatiently hung up on me. I called another day and a woman who answered, likely because she had a better command of English, listened and told me to bring a signed authorization from my daughter. My daughter prepared that and gave me her card to take on the trip and I had a handful of documents to present at the ticket office. When I handed the wad of papers to the man he barely glanced at them and printed my tickets. I did not know whether I was disappointed or relieved but it went well nonetheless. ( A man ahead of me in line at the ticket office was stunned when he was told he could book tickets for a week from then. He lingered trying to overcome what he could not understand and the ticket agent explained again and again that the gallery was booked until then.) Our group walked in the gardens until our entrance time and enjoyed them immensely. It is a lovely spot for picture taking but every step in Rome is that too.Our time in the gallery was joyful. There are so many priceless treasures and all so well positioned for viewing that it would be impossible not to love the experience. I was surprised that many of the people around me are so poorly informed about what they are looking at but seemed to be enthralled at any rate. Baffling to me that they would pay so much and go to the trouble to be there and not have a basic clue as to what the collection was about. But to each their own.

A don't miss in Rome. You must make reservations before you leave the US. The Gallery is a highlight of a Rome trip. The limited access by required reservations make a visit a delight. No crowds, no pushing, good audio guide and FANTASTIC masterpieces especially the Bernini sculptures.

Need lots of time.. Spent about 4 hours at the Borghese Gallery....not nearly enough time ! I am trying to find enough discriptive noun's to let you know what I thought, these are a few that come to mind. Awesome, lovely, elegant, balanced,beautiful, awe inspiring. Well worth the trip !!! I HAVE to go again.

Buy tickets a week or two in advance of your trip!. We really wanted to see the gallery while in Rome, for 7 days, but couldn't get tickets when we arrived! Very disappointing and their staff was not very helpful.

six stars at the least if i could give them ! absolute must see. go and you see why.honestly : it is a gorgeous house, with top jewels of art, a few Caravaggios, Paulina Borghese sculpture, go there and see. lovely pics and sculptures. Look at their web and dont think much and go if you can.it is necessary to book in advance. and book well in advance or else it will be sold out.you can spend inside only two hours (or have more bookings which is quite expensive :) ). so you should be very careful about the time. Its even allowed to take photos inside!! without flash. and they insist that it must be without flash (staff is polite though).there is also a nice and large park around Galleria Borghese and some other galleries near Galleria Borghese (such as Villa Giulia with Etruscan art and other stuff, which is also quite recommended, especially if you have the opportunity to visit first Sunday of each month when its free entrance to Villa Giulia- for Villa Giulia you should have a few hours surely, its biiiiig). there is some bus going to the Galleria Borghese, which you can get on on Termini station.

Breath taking. . If you love art do not miss the Borghese Gallery ! Be sure and buy your voucher/s online before you arrive. Also your voucher must be exchanged for a ticket in the basement of the gallery before being admitted. It is absolutely beautiful.

This museum should be among the top four sights of everyone's "must see" list.. After the Fori Romani, the Palatine Hill, and the Colosseum, the Museo / Galleria Borghese should be at the top of the "must see" list in Rome. The beauty of the art and decorations in this museum is stunning, enough to bring tears to the eyes. Virtually every ceiling, wall, and floor is covered with beautiful works of art. One is powerfully moved by the imagination, creativity, and genius of the artists and designers who created this masterpiece. The museum contains multiple masterpiece paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael, and Titian, as well as beautiful sculptures by Bernini and Canova. The marble mosaic floors one wants to reproduce in one's own home! Take a tour if you wish, but also walk through the museum at your own pace so you can absorb as much as possible. When we were there, the museum was cleared periodically, so check on times. Also check on how to get there. It's near a main road to the south, so don't walk endlessly through the park to get there! In the bookstore, pick up a book on the collections. And absolutely,...don't leave Rome without going.
Wow. Wow! A must see in Italy. The audio guide was excellent. Don't miss. It's easy to get overwhelmed so take it slow! Easy to navigate and not over crowded. Enjoy!

Nice tour. I had been to Rome several times in the past, but hadn't been to the Borghese Gallery on my other trips. I enjoyed my visit to the Gallery, but I wouldn't put it as a "must do" if your time in Rome is limited. Purchasing tickets in advance is a must...when we were there they were only selling ticket for 5 days from then. The surrounding gardens are similar to Central Park.

Well worth the effort.. Tours are scheduled for 2 hours so you need to plan accordingly. We visited via Viatour so that saved a lot of hassles and gave us a very informative guide. Incredible works of art on display. Take in the grounds too.

Amazing collection - Borghese gallery. A wonderful collection of Renaissance art in this beautiful palazzo. There are many stunning works of art, my favorites were the marble sculptures by Bernini.
Book your tickets over the internet, reservations must be made in advance.
I suggest rent the audio guide.
If you love art this gallery is a must when you are in Rome.

Amazing rooms full of paintings and Sculptures. Took the Borghese Gallery tour through viator which included the walking tour of the gardens. Very good gallery to see and would definitely recommend it to others as something to do if you have time.

Couture and art. We were lucky enough to go during the couture show by Azzedine Alaia that was imbedded in the art exhibit (see photos). That and the audio tour meant that we learned a lot and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. One thing to note, you can take pictures in the Borghese AND you don't have to check small purses/bags. The one pictured here was allowed in.

Excellent Tour Guide. We took an afternoon tour of the Gallery and surrounding area just recently. Our tour guide, Rebecca, was an American expat, and was knowledgeable and very enthusiastic. We had a wonderful experience and saw the highlights in about 2 hours. If you are looking for a more in depth experience, you should go yourself, but if you want to see all the highlights, and learn more about Caravaggio and Bernini, take this tour.

A must see in Rome. My favorite museum in Rome! Enough there to be interesting and not so much that it's overwhelming like the vatican museum. Make sure you reserve your tickets ahead of time or you'll never get in.

Great Baroque Art all in One Place in Rome. This is really the only place in Rome that has great works of art in one place - no walking from one obscure church to another. Even my husband, who is not an art lover, thought the tour was the best part of our entire trip. The guide was enthusiastic and generous with her time and very knowledgeable. I would highly recommend going with a tour group through this museum -unless you're an art history teacher. There's so much to see and learn, and I thought I knew a lot before I went. It was wonderful. I'd go back tomorrow if I could.

Respite from the madding crowds!. A lovely big park to walk around, especially on hot days, and to escape from the intensity of Rome and its' traffic! The lawns are a bit scruffy looking. More like a natural park than manicured gardens. There are bikes to hire (somewhat expensive in my view). Very enjoyable if you have the time.

Don't miss this! Stunning art, inexpensive but must be booked in advance. We aren't art experts, but the statues and paintings in the villa were beautiful even to our untrained eyes. The ceilings alone were worth the trip. They also had a very interesting dress exhibit when we were there. Very accessible for people with disabilities and the staff was fantastic. Visit the artificial lake on the grounds while you are there. Quaint and peaceful.

A must for art enthusiasts. This gallery houses some of the most sublime works of art in the world. The Bernini sculptures are incredibly moving in their beauty. Because of the advance ticketing system, the gallery is not too crowded, allowing for a very satisfying experience. When we visited there was an integrated temporary exhibition of couturier clothing - quite sculptural in themselves, and an interesting complement to the permanent collection.

A must see treasure.. I did not know about this museum until someone suggested to go before I left states. Make reservations befor you leave as they only let in 40 visitors per two hr shifts. It is very small in very large park but so worth the visit. Bernini statues abound on the first fl. I am not an art aficionado but was struck by the anatomical detail and beauty of his works. Please go. You will not be disappointed. Note: you will have to check your purse or bag and are given a small plastic bag to carry your valuables.

The Painting and Statues are Magnificant a Must for Art Lovers. The art (statues and painting commissioned and appropriated by the Cardinal Borghese) are beautiful and priceless. This is the home of the Borghese family where a he commissioned Bernini to create the beautiful statues and paintings. Of course, there are many other artists works on displace as well as ancient Egyptican art. A must see.

Go For The Bernini's. A wonderful collection of Renaissance art. You could spend several years studying just the Bernini's and the Carrvagio's. Another attraction where a knowledgable guide enriches the experience. Again, try Livitaly.

For the art lover. This is a mid sized gallery compared to the Vatican. The place is beautiful and management takes care to ensure that its not over crowded by regulating the number of tickets. There are many stunning works of art. My favorites were the marble sculptures by Bernini. You cannot take your bags inside the gallery. There is a small cafe and you must set aside about 60-90 minutes for this tour. Book in advance.

Returned to Rome just to visit the Borghese Gallery...worth the trip.. We were in Rome four years ago and saw all the standard sights (Colosseum, Forum, Vatican museum, etc) but we missed the Borghese Museum. Mistake! I am so glad to have made it back for this beautiful, intimate and impressive art experience. The movement that Bernini creates from marble is unbelievable. The audio guide (5 euros) enhanced our experience. Plan for extra time to check and retrieve any backpacks or large purses. Enjoy!

Worth the planning. MAKE APPOINTMENT IN ADVANCE! We watched them turn away numerous tourists who had (very logically) assumed you simply walk up and buy your tickets, but as entry is limited by time and number they allow in, an advance reservation is essential. AND be aware they allow NO bags -- not even small purses. But once you run that whole gauntlet, the collection is fabulous and beautifully presented, and the fact that they limit the numbers viewing at any one time means you don't encounter the crush and crowding that you do in many other galleries.

Mixed feelings. The collection of paintings and scupturues in this gallery is wonderful, I believe that. Everybody recommend this place higly and I understand why BUT if you're not interested in 15th or 16th century religious paintings or scuptures generally, don't waste your time here. It's really boring and crowded. But if you are interested in this kind of art don't forget to buy tickets ahead or you won't get in. When you buy the tickets you have to deside when you're are going to go there and buy the tickets for that particular day and time. It's actually a very good systems since then you don't have queue that much. Just buy the tickets and be there on time. And remember that you can't bring any bags inside the gallery.
Borghese, you need Reservations. Didn't make a reservation and without it you don't go in. Very limited groups allowed in each viewing. Did hear it was beautiful. We walked the grounds. Nice

A gemstone.. If you are an art history buff you will "knock yourself out" in Rome. But this Museum, small in actuality, but I rate it as one of the most important in the country. (A must). Not only for the treasures there but also for the manner of presentation which is unobtrusive and therefore appreciable in a more detached way. Good food for thought there.

Nice but if you have limited time spend it someplace else. The grounds are not well kept as you would expect from a place visited by thousands. Grasses are not mowed regularly and can be a foot high in some places.a people do not pick up after their dogs. If you plan on going to the museum buy tickets on line a week before or more they sell out and you will not get them a day or two in advance. Tickets are 11. Euro so don't spend money and do the tour guide route. Too expensive and how much can a tour guide tell you about a park and the art in the museum. Not worth the price. There is a nice place for capucino on the end of the park over looking piazza popolo. From there you can walk down to the piazza. Very nice. Park grounds are free.

Incredible rooms. This is the most incredible collection of art and sculptures and the moving 3-D zoetrope is worth waiting a few minutes to view in one of the final galleries. Do book online beforehand as you may well not gain admission if you just turn up!

Very special. I arrived early so had to wait outside in the pouring rain for an hour. However I walked around the back of the building and found an alcove facing the gardens where I could shelter in peace and quiet. It was very special. Once inside the gallery, it was very crowded but I'm afraid that this is how it is in Italy in season. The artwork is simply breath taking. Two hours was long enough. I was staying in a hotel close to the station and chose to walk to the gallery. It took less than an hour and was a lovely walk, the last 20 minutes being through the VIlla gardens.
Not easy to find, but worth it. This was a great surprise! Beautiful collection of art -- painting and sculpture. Easy to get lost in the expansive rooms.

Eye-popping. Amazing collection of sculpture and paintings in this beautiful palazzo surrounded by park. Among other things, the famous Bernini "Daphne" sculpture is here and worth the visit by itself. This is a don't-miss Roman venue BUT reservations/tickets must be made in advance. Walk-in viewing isn't possible. Your hotel can take of this for you or you can go on line yourself for the reservations.

Know your art history. Beautiful gallery if you know a lot about art history and read Italian. Very poor labeling of artwork, no staff to help. Audio tour is a must. Otherwise just a nice place to look at old stuff. Very disappointing, plus the gallery was cluttered with Couture clothing that was extremely distracting. Bernini "David" was the highlight.

Extrodionary. I real must even if you are not a art fan. you will be amazed at the Extrodionary examples on display. There are no words just keep looking at the ceilings Wow oh Wow. I would have stayed all day if they had allowed me to. Be sure to buy ticket in advance other wise you many not get in.

Reserve Your Ticket. The Borghese Gallery is a wonderful museum that has famous sculptures and paintings. Unless you are an art historian, I suggest going on a guided tour or rent the audio headset (English, Italian, French, German, and Spanish). If you take a purse, backpack, stroller, etc, be prepared to check it at the cloakroom prior to your visit. Cameras are allowed.I booked our tickets 2 months prior to our arrival in Rome on the Borghese Gallery website. The cost was 11 Euros per ticket. Make sure you contact you credit card company and alert them to the charge so that the foreign transaction is not rejected. The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday 9 AM - 7 PM. Closed on Mondays, December 25, January 1, and May 1. Entry to the museum is scheduled in 2 hour blocks of time. Make sure you are at the museum at least 20 minutes prior to you appointed time. Check in is in the lower level.We visited the gallery on our first day in Rome. The museum is 2 floors be prepared to climb stairs to the second level. Although it is not large we spent the entire 2 hours in the gallery using the audio set. We were glad that entry was limited because we were able to enjoy ourselves and not feel hurried or crowdedWe stayed near the Piazza Navona. The Concierge suggested taking a taxi (12 Euro) and save our legs for the museum tour. This was a great suggestion. There is also public transport by subway, bus and tram. After our tour we walked downhill to the Spanish Steps, Trevi Fountain (under construction) and back to our hotel. Since we weren't in a hurry we stopped along the way and enjoyed a glass of wine in an outdoor café. Great way to start our Roman Holiday.

Best gallery to visit in Rome (possibly the entire Italy)!. The collection is amazing and because they limit the number of people at any given time, you get to spend a lot of time up close with some of the best art in the entire world. The place is setup well and you can tell that the place was designed to showcase the art in the best way possible. Remember this was curated by a huge patron of the arts in this very place and it makes everyone who goes there appreciate it in the best way possible. You must have an advance reservation not only because of the lines but because of availability of the place. It is a MUST SEE and I think to appreciate art and the link of art and history this should definitely be part of your itinerary. See Ancient Rome + Borghese + Vatican in that order if you want to see how history meshes together and is puncutated by the Renaissance.

Book in advance . I'd say this has been a disappointment as I wasn't aware that I had to book a week in advance to get to access the gallery. Nevertheless, I had the chance to spend some good time in the surrounding park, and the experience is extremely enjoyable!

Crowded but worth it. A very crowded museum for which you need a reservation to enter at a specific time. Despite the mobs the art work was stunning- many very famous and exceptional works of art in this collection.

Private Tour: Borghese Gallery and Baroque Rome Art History Walking Tour. This was a pricey tour for us but worth every penny. Isabel is a superb guide. I would sign up for any tour that she leads. She is incredibly knowledgeable about her subject. She focused on certain pieces so we didn't get overwhelmed by the surfeit of treasures in front of us. This tour was one of the highlights of our trip to Italy. In the future, I will never look at a Bernini work without thinking about what she taught us.
RESERVE A TICKET EARLY. Beautiful grounds. Unfortunately, we attempted to get a ticket too late. Turns out you need to book at least a week in advance.

Lesser known Rome treasure.. A bit out of the way, but lovely grounds, great collection. Must sees are Bernini's Pluto and Persephone and David sculptures and the absolutely sublime sculpture Apollo and Daphne. Many other great pieces in this remarkable collection that was mostly obtained by pilfering by the Borghese family...

A visit worth making.... I visited the Borghese Gallery for the first time; it was definitely worth the visit. However, the signage to get to the gallery itself is lacking. We walked around in circles in the Borghese Gardens before we found it. If you do go, might make it worth your while to book a private tour with a guide. We hired Giuseppe Perrino who is very knowledgeable. His historical accounts of the art work opened my eyes and especially gave me a new appreciation for sculptures. My family and I enjoyed a local's perspective of the tour! If interested, please send him an email at giuseppeperrino@hotmail.com. If time allows, explore the surrounding garden (free to the public). I will definitely pencil in some time to enjoy the garden when I return.

Important!cannot visit without a reservation. We had trouble in finding it...we walked through the park in all directions,it was also raining...and we finally found it we were informed that all is booked until the next few days...we didn't have an online rezervation so we could not visit it...Staff seemed friendly though...

A must for sculpture lover's. You will need to book your tickets in advance but it is definitely well worth it, I would also recommend taking the audio guide for 5 euro's to tell you information on the most important sculptures and paintings. Bernin's Apollo and Daphne is jaw dropping and you can see many of his best works including Pluto and Persephone and David.

Not worth the time. We went to borghese gallery since it was a place to see in all the guide books. However, pale in comparison to everything g else we saw. We would suggest going only if you have extra time in rome.

The Borghese is a very worthwhile visit. Not being an art critic I struggle to articulate the beauty of the artwork offered at the Borghese. I've been to several London galleries including the National Gallery/Portrait Gallery, the V&A and the Courtauld Institute of Art as well as the National Gallery of Edinburgh and this is almost as impressive. I am guessing that the entry fee was around EUR 15 ( I can't quite remember) - well worth it if you love renaissance paintings and sculptures. In fact, I preferred it to the Colosseum because I prefer old paintings and murals to Roman history.

Out of the Way, But Well Worth It. After the Vatican Museum, the Borghese Gallery feels positively luxurious in its smaller crowds. The strict reservation system and the inconvenient location limit the numbers who visit, and that makes the whole process far more pleasant (and far less cattle car-ish).As for the gallery itself--the Caravaggio and Bernini works are the obvious stars, but there is a wealth of material here. You can breeze through in an hour or so if you just give each item a cursory look, or you can spend your entire two hour block in just one room studying the amazing works on display...As much as the art, however, the palace itself is part of the attraction. This is one heck of a look at the opulence and luxury of another age (the word "excess" comes to mind). I enjoy studying the rooms as much as I do the art itself!

Fabulous palace and amazing designs. The Borghese Gallery is a must see when in Rome. It is a stunningly beautiful palace with an impressive collection of art and sculptures. This visit was enhanced with a fantastic collection of Azzedine Alaia's couture fashions. The beautiful gowns were strategically and creatively displayed among the priceless permanent collection. A double wow!

WOW. Absolutely no reason not to book tickets and visit this gallery. A shame they only allow you to stay for 2 hours.We visited several galleries/museums and this was by far the best....even better than the Vatican Museum.

Just go!. Excellent museum. Book in advance as they limit the number of people allowed in at a time (you hear that Vatican Museum? That's the way to do it). As a result the museum never feels crowded and you can really take in the art. You are limited to two hours but that was enough time as the museum isn't huge. We went mostly for the Bernini sculptures and as expected they were amazing. Pictures just don't do them justice. There were a lot of other great pieces as well. Definitely a must see.

Really Enjoyed This!. The museum only lets in a certain number of people, and only allows you to stay for two hours. Therefore, it wasn't too crowded and you were able to see everything. Make sure you call ahead to reserve your time. And come early in order to get through the line to confirm your reservation and pick up an audio guide - included. They had an exhibit of formal evening wear mixed in with the classical art and sculpture, and I really enjoyed the whimsy of that juxtaposition. The park surrounding the Gallery is beautiful. Places to picnic, musicians playing.... it was a beautiful day.

Superb. but requires planning. The Borghese is a wonderful museum, full of treasures. After the Vatican and the Roman ruins, the museum ought to be at the top a visitor's list. The park in which the museum sits is also lovely, kind of a small Central Park--well worth the wander before or after. To fully enjoy the museum, however. takes some planning. 1. You need to reserve your tickets on line well in advance of the date of your visit. You pick up the tickets there before you enter. 2. Arrive at least 15 minutes early. You have to check your bags, and because visitors enter the museum at set hours, there is a long line to drop off bags just before an entry time.3. Get the audio guide. Without the guide, you won't know enough to appreciate all there is to see. 4. After you get the audio guide, take time to orient yourself with the map. Time spent in orientation will save wandering confused later ("Is this #2?"). 5. Keep track of time. Visits are limited to two hours. If you dawdle in the beginning, you'll have to rush at the end.

Finest Broque sculpures. Please don't miss the incredible Bernini sculptures. They are masterpieces that you have to see to believe... perfection in marble. Be sure to book online in advance to get a timed ticket for entrance to this marvelous gallery. There are other great things to see such as the Canova masterpiece of Pauline Borghese as Venus and the wonderful Caravaggio Room.

So amazing!. I booked this through a small tour online that I found by chance...and it was the highlight of my short stay in Rome! Amazing art and my tour guide was knowledgeable and entertaining. But they limit the number of visitors per 2-hour visit and they make you leave when time is up! But I found it much more enjoyable than the vatican museums since I wasn't being jostled every second...

Rude ticket staff colors visit. We booked in advance but we were 10 minutes late of our ticket time due to the traffic on a rainy day. The staff at the ticket desk would not let us in because we were late! They said we had to buy new tickets. We stepped outside for a few minutes, disappointed by their behavior, but came back in to buy new tickets anyway. When we came back, they said they were sold out and that next time we should arrive on time. While standing in line, we also noticed they were extremely rude to some elderly travelers who asked to come a few minutes before their ticket time. The Gallery is probably wonderful, but we left with such a bad feeling.

Loved it!. We booked the tickets a month in advance. Thank goodness we did, as the tickets were sold out for the next three days when we arrived.The gallery is located in a beautiful park, easily accessible via the station called Flaminio and we collected our tickets downstairs of the museum and sat in the park until it was our alloted visit time.This museum allows know a certain number of viewers every two hour session and therefore we were able to see all the beautiful art in a relatively quiet and peaceful manner.I highly recommend this museum, especially if you like viewing art without the crowds - eg the Vatican museum is super crowded.

A Must See. Well worth the time and effort to visit. Don't forget to make reservations in advance. It is very easy to call ahead and get reservation number. The door to the ticket office is actually below the main entrance to the galleria. You also need to check your bags/backpacks in advance on this lower level. Renting the audio tour was well worth it. We greatly enjoyed spending the afternoon in the park and garden.

Borghese Gallery, not to be missed. We arrived early and had a chance to stroll through the park.Later we went into the Gallery and admired the MANY magnificent sculptures and paintings. Pity that you are limited to 3 hours, you need more to really enjoy it.Would love to go back and explore the beautiful park in its entirety.

Even in September, book in advance. Gardens and surrounding architecture still worth a look. Not sure why, but showed up at the Borghese gallery in late September and found that it was sold out for the next 3 days. So, you might want to consider ignoring those who tell you they "walked up and walked in". Advance tickets are easily purchased on line. The surrounding park and building are still a nice place to walk and relax. Plus, there are many other things to do in that area.

So very wonderful. Starting with a couple of helpful hintsGet your tickets on line well in advance of your visit to the gallery. Go to the Borghese website and you can get them. With your on line receipt in hand you redeem it underneath the museum. With on line booking available there really isn't any reason for anyone to ever miss out on getting tickets unless of course they wait until the last minute to order them. Also check out a few online sites to get an idea as what you will be seeing on exhibit in the gallery.Get there at least 30 minutes before your admission time to avoid the ticket redemption line, and to get your bag stored. Remember when you go to get your bag back to use the line on the right otherwise you will be in the long line for storing bags.If you are there for the 11 am tour I strongly recommend signing up for the English tour of the museum. It is very inexpensive and well worth it. You can't sign up on line so once you redeem your on line voucher go in and stand in line for the headsets and tours. The day we went we had a marvelous person conduct our tour (I think she might have been the art director for the museum).The day we were here we could bring in our cameras even though everything I had read said you couldn't. I am glad I brought it along that day.There is a small gift shop and snack bar on the lower level along with toilets. Be sure to have your admission ticket with you if you plan to use the toilet otherwise the attendant won't let you in.There is ample bench seating underneath the gallery while you wait for your tour to start.Once the tour starts you immediately climb a high stairwell to the top floor of the museum. There is a small elevator that could be used if you have a problem with the 90 plus stairs.While we were there a special exhibit was on display that incorporated fashion into the items on display. I have included some pictures of that fashion.Once you climb the stairs be prepared to see some of the most beautiful pieces of art in the world today.The artists, sculptures and paintings are what you probably read about in school and here they all are under one roof for you to see first hand, up close and personal.A David is here, the rape of Proserpina is here, the Apollo and Daphne is here, Bernini, Canova, Ralphael and Corregggio are all here on display for you to enjoy.When done with the top floor you descend to the main floor and see even more wonderful art. As admissions are limited, the museum will not feel crowded. If a particular item is blocked just have a seat and wait for the people to move along.Note that the gallery tours last two hours and they are very strict about your leaving the area as soon as the two hours is over. If you arrive late for your admission time you still need to leave at the end of the time slot even if you were only there for 45 minutes.Once done with your visit, you can rest up in the snack bar area. Remember to order and pay at the counter before getting your items. Just put your receipt down on the bar top and someone will get you what you ordered.Once you leave the gallery you can stroll the grounds, get a bite to eat in a garden restaurant (if open) rent a bicycle carriage to pedal around, or just sit on a bench and enjoy the gardens.
The august results of having a pope in your (Borghese) family.. A magnificent collection of statues and paintings in a lavish palazzo, at the entrance to a splendid park.

Don't Miss This Art Gallery. Some of the best artwork in Rome is housed in this spectacular villa. The gardens are beautiful and very inviting. I recommend taking a guided tour to learn about the most important pieces in the gallery.

Early booking essential. Unfortunately, we were unable to visit. Despite trying to book as soon as we arrived in Rome, there were no tickets available for another 9 days and we were only there for 6 days. Make your booking before arrival in Rome.

Extraordinary. The Borghese Gallery is one of the finest museums in the world. It holds a truly extraordinary collection, highlighted by the numerous Bernini and Caravaggio works. But there is so much more to delight the eye and the imagination. Just make sure to reserve on line ahead of time, be there a bit early, be ready to have your purses and backpacks checked at the door....etc. But what a museum!

Didn't book. Sold out for all next week.. Very disappointed that we didn't do our research well and the Museum was sold out for the whole of all next week. Couldn't see it easily on their website but reservations are definitely needed. Checked out the bookstore and around the gardens. Don't forget to book by phone or online in advance.

A Gotta See!. If you love art this gallery is a must when you are in Rome. You will need to reserve and pay for your ticket ahead so book as early as you are able to assure your entry! The managable size of this gallery is wonderful. The Bernini sculptures are what we love the best. Having a good guidebook is a real help here so that your 2 hours can be filled with looking, seeing, understanding and appreciating!
Great baroque collection . The villa hosts one of the biggest baroque collection in Italy. A nice point is that reservation is mandatory, so the museum never feels overcrowded.

A wonderful art museum. This impressive art museum has many fantastic paintings and sculptures. The Borghese family has collected many great treasures and the tour was very informative and educational.

Definitely worth an art enthusiasts time. I am not an art enthusiast but being in villa borghese and holding Roma pass, I decided to chance making an on the spot reservation. And guess what...there had been a cancellation so I got the time slot for 5 mins later - that was rather lucky! ( Coz I read a notice saying that the museum reservations were fully booked for until a week later). I enjoyed the museum fir it's sheer uniqueness (considering I am not an art enthusiast). But it could be a paradise for those interested in art!

It is a must when you visit Rome. You have to book online to get to the museum. And the entrance is at specific time but you have to arrive earlier to exchange your booking confirmation to tickets.It is a stunning place, beautiful sculptures and paintings. We really loved this place.You can spend there 1,5h and then we had a nice walk in the surrounding park.Make sure that you book your tickets when planning your Rome trip.

A must see when in Rome.. I visit Rome a few times a year. When there, I never miss a chance to visit the Borghese Gallery. Per square foot, the best art collection on all of Italy. Situated in the park with the same name, it houses a magnificent collection of Renaissance and Baroque sculptures and paintings.... Bernini, Rafael, Caravaggio, Bassono...just to mention a few. The building itself is a beautiful piece of history and the timed tickets (every two hours) keeps the crowds under control and it is enough time to view the many works. Also, a fun gift shop.

Rivaled Only by its Gardens. If for no other reason, make this stop to see Bernini's extraordinary works. His sculptures are unparalleled. The two hour time limit accorded every visitor is ample to view and appreciate all the Gallery has to share.

Spectacular, if expensive, but worth it! Reservations required!. The entry is at specific times so reserve a few days in advance online (2 Euro fee extra). There are spectacular sculptures and paintings by all of the Master Artists and Sculptors as commissioned by the Bishop. Each room in the mansion is unique and we spent over 2 hours mesmerized. This gallery was superior to the Uffizi Museum in Florence.= - we toured that place the following day.

Best Museum in Italy. We were in Italy for two weeks and toured many museums, but I think the Borghese Gallery was our favorite. The Gallery itself is a beautiful building, and it houses many amazing works of art, including some very impressive statues. Admission is limited, so be sure to buy your tickets in advance. During busy times (we were there in July) they do sell out. We appreciated the limited admission because it allowed us to tour the Gallery without the crowds we encountered every where else we went on our trip. You are limited to two hours in the Gallery, which I am sure is not enough for true art aficionados, but for our family (including a 9 and a 14 year old) it was plenty of time. Finally, we really enjoyed the air conditioning. Sounds silly, but in July in Rome it was HOT! Our family agreed that our favorite statue that we saw on our trip was in the Borghese Gallery, Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. It is amazing how something so large and made in stone can seem to float in the room. It's in a room at the end of the self-guided tour, saving the best for last.

This is a MUST DO when in Rome. To be within inches of many of Bernini's most famous sculptures is breathtaking. They limit the number of people who can enter at any given time so you never feel rushed or crowded.You must make reservations in advance so be sure to schedule your time and buy tickets before you leave for Rome. I highly recommend that you buy the guided audio tour, it is very well done and really adds to the experience as you view Bernini, Caravaggio, Rafael, and many other important works of art. Gallery and surrounding grounds make for a wonderful afternoon and break from the hustle and bustle of Rome.

WOW!. We booked the tickets, as advised by other Trip Advisor reviews, and it was well worth it. The Gallery is a former residence of the Medici family. It looks every inch what you would expect from that family!At the same time we were there, there was a fashion exhibition of haute couture dresses and coats. So beautiful to see the modern fashions displayed with ancient marble sculpture and paintings. I could not take enough pictures!
Outstanding-The Best. You will need to make a reservation, but it is worth it. The galleries are wonderful, full of art and sculptures..

Must see Gallery. I caught a taxi to the Borghese Gallery as it's up a steep incline .I opted for the 2 pm tour which incorporated the Garden , wonderful grounds .As it was a Sunday I went to the Blessing by the Pope at the Vatican at noon then had a quick lunch & headed for the Gallery in plenty of time .I had been to Rome on many previous occasions & have never been inside this amazing Gallery . The Park is absolutely enormous & being a Sunday was alive with activity with families . Quite a lovely experience to see how the Romans spend their weekends . The tour finished close to the top of the Spanish Steps & above Piazza Popolo which is a must to be seen . I highly recommend this tour . Try to organise prior to leaving as they are limited numbers [ about 8 to 10 only ] & are very popular.
For art lovers, a must see!. Stunning palazzo turned gallery with exceptional works of art (and loved the temporary Fashion as Sculpture exhibit)

Loved the Borghese Gallery!. After a great walk through Rome and the Borghese Gardens, we arrived at our allotted time for the Gallery. It was fascinating, and the pacing was just right for savouring all the sculptures and paintings - the extent of the Carravagios was a great surprise. Also, there was a current show of haute couture fashions from the last 25 years interspersed with the ancient art - very arresting and wonderful!

Don't miss this palace full of Bernini sculptures--get tickets in advance. Even after a week of sculptures, churches, paintings, fountains, ruins, etc., my family of four (kids 7 and 10) loved the Bernini sculptures in this gallery. Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Persephone are not to be missed. We tried to go earlier in the week, but the tickets were sold out for the day, so we bought tickets for later in the week while we were there. Worth planning ahead.

stunning collection, beautiful gallery. This museum never gets too crowded because they limit the tickets sold for each time slot. We bought our tickets online before leaving home. The collection is stunning and the building and gardens equally beautiful, well worth the two or three hours it takes to tour.

Great way to spend a day away from the crowds. My son and I got our tickets ahead of time (which you need to do online) for the gallery and both of us really enjoyed it. The gallery is just bursting with amazing art on every floor and because they control the crowds with specific entrance and exit times, it was really pleasant. In addition, we just loved spending the rest of the afternoon in the gardens surrounding the gallery. So much to do! It kind of reminded me of central park in new York as a quiet oasis away from the crowds just a short walk from the hustle and bustle of the city. The highlight for my teenage son was of course the segways! Would definitely recommend as there is something for everyone, overall just a great day!

Amazing art, average staff. An amazing art collection in a fabulous palace. A long walk but great park to arrive through. This is a control-freak's gallery with only a 2-hour period allowed to view the amazing collection (including 6 Caravaggio paintings) and you need to show your ticket to use the toilets. None of the staff seem to speak any English, including those who answer the phone, and make no effort to try to help with your small amount of Italian. I've not had this response from any other art gallery in Europe, and given the cost to get in and hire an audio guide, a very unusual approach given the number of tourists to Rome who can't speak Italian but have English as their first or second language. Took the gloss off an amazing art collection.
Very interesting building and contents.. Statues and pictures is not normally something that hold our attention but not so at this house and gardens. FULL of interest and not to be missed

Sumptuous Palace and Sumptuous Art. This is a gorgeously decorated palace with art to match. The Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings are a must-see. Because the museum smartly and strictly limits the number of visitors per hour, guests can enjoy a personal and intimate experience with the art. It’s lovely to approach the palace after a walk in the surrounding park. Don’t expect a last minute admission. Tickets must be purchased far in advance, particularly during tourist season.

Amazing collection of Art. I booked a guided tour of the Gallery and gardens. The tour guide was awesome - her knowledge of art/history was outstanding and her enthusiasm was contagious. Thorough explanation was given about the acquisition of the art along with the artists ie Bernini, Raphael,Caravaggio etc. Only allowed 2 hrs inside the Gallery and our tour guide made sure we got the most out of this visit. Highly recommend doing with a guide.The Gardens are also worth visiting - there is even a zoo on site!

Jaw dropping display of ostentatious wealth and amazing art. He was a prince of the church with the determination to build an art collection which showed that his contemporaries were at least the equal of the ancients and employed every form of blackmail, treachery and chicanery to build this astounding collection - he was, presumably, not in a holy order which embraced poverty. The resulting treasures, brilliantly displayed in this magnificent building, are not to be missed and they have cleverly organised it so that only a limited number are permitted entry in allocated time slots. Get your hotel to buy these in advance. If you only see one of the many treasures of Rome, make sure it is this one.

Must see!. This has to be one of the must-see's in Rome. The travel guides which suggest this is one museum you should see in Rome are absolutely correct. The Bernini sculptures are superlative - marble really does melt like flesh in his hands. Do have a wander in the gardens too. It does require planning ahead however - don't expect to be able to just turn up.
Buy tickets online before arriving. The Gallery is all it is said to be by the tour books, and more. If you see only one museum in Rome, this should be the one.

For all lovers of art!. A beautiful property that houses some of the most famous works of art by Bernini, Caravaggio, and even Leonardo da Vinci! Easy to get to, not far from the Metro (Spagna stop). The surrounding grounds a very nice, and from the overlook at the Pincio, you have great views of the domes and other wonderful building in Rome.

Great history. This museum has done a brilliant job maintaining its art and sculptures. The paintings and sculptures are brilliant. But do bring water, the walk to the Borghese Gallery can be Tiring and exhausting especially on hot and humid days (basically most days in Rome) But the art and sculptures are definitely worth the walk!!

Sumptuous small art paradise!. I was glad that I was able to get last-minute reservations for the gallery - make sure to buy your tickets well in advance, since this is not a walk-in museum. Once I got there, I was glad I rented an audio guide: with those precious history bits, I was able to make the most of the visit to this absolutely gorgeous place, filled with precious sculptures, paintings and decorations. It's really stunning, even for those used to nice museums. A visit takes on average merely 1.5h, since the gallery, despite sumptuous, is not that big. Bernini's statues and many nice paintings and the tales behind them are precious. Well worth visiting!

Borghese Gallery: food for your soul. It's quite difficult to get tickets there to the same day, therefore you shall book them online.The building of Borghese Gallery is small, 20 rooms only, but the concentration of famous pieces of art to one square metre is so high, that you feel the great beauty with whole heart and soul.

Small but lovely gallery. You have to generally book if you want a ticket to get into this place and they give you 2 hours, which is plenty. The marble statues are the highlight here. A very beautifully put together museum. Don't forget to go upstairs (we almost missed it!). The museum is a lot smaller than I expected but you really do have to go to appreciate its beauty.

Amazing Italian sculptures!. A feast for the eyes! We bought our tickets online prior to our trip and brought the printed receipts. You have to plan your tour since only 2 hours are allowed per admission. The Bernini sculptures are amazing!

Renaissance comes alive. This awesome museum of some of the finest art is only available to 360 people every two hours. Recommend going with a professional tour company (Walks of Italy) is a great choice. With only two hours, they will highlight and thoroughly explain the standout pieces. Dress comfortably because it can get very warm. Something to definitely see!

Bellismo Bernini. Caveat: One must reserve your time ahead as we did on line.You pick a 2 hour slot and exchange your voucher for a ticket.Once in you should rent a audio guide for your language,5 Euros with ID.Actually if you wait for the mass of people to move on it could be much easier to navigate the 1st floor.We were awed by the skill of these artists, how they did those masterpieces at such a young age,mystifying.Obviously Bernini was a brilliant piece,The rape of...,as the picture shows on line bellismo!!!

Start with Borghese Gallery and you will enjoy the Sistine Chapel even more. Before taking the tour with Jean Luc from CityTours, I had no appreciation of sculpture. But, Jean Luc (Lucca) so effectively communicated the brilliance of Bernini and Carvaggio that I was mesmerized and, at times, overwhelmed by the collection. Also, the Borghese Gallery only allows so many people at a time. This allows for a much more pleasant experience.

Amazing Bernini statues. The paintings upstairs are worth seeing , as well as the 3 or 4 famous Caravaggio's downstairs in Room 8. However, the reason to come here are the 3 Bernini statues: David, the Rape of Persephone, and Apollo & Daphne. They display Bernini's range and talent. Interesting to compare thi sBernin's David statue with Michelangelo's David at the Accademia in Florence. And the hand on Persephone's hip is a testament to perfection in stone!!! A must if visiting Rome....and walking the Borghese Gardens is relaxing as well, a respite from the ever hectic Rome.

Beautiful museum. Although I went to this museum on a school field trip I really enjoyed this museum. I have not been able to see the whole museum but from what I have seen they have a very beautiful collection. Together with what my teacher knew and told us about all the paintings and statues I learned a lot in this museum.

CULTURE AND FUN. Traveled with our grandson aged 13years. Saw the Borghese gallery first. If they are not academic or into art it is best to get this amazing building out of the way. In between you can have a snack in their great cafe. But for him the real fun took place when we took out the motorized bikes. They go pretty fast up and down the hills of this beautiful park but provide a great hours entertainment in what is a long day for a child in Rome!!

If you're in the least interested in fine are, do not miss this gallery. My wife and I did not anticipate the time necessary to reserve on line to book this venue. Basically the only day we had to see the gallery was the very next day and the on-line indicated they were completely sold out. Rick Steeve's book mentioned that you may be lucky and get in IF some people did not show up for their allotted time. We arrived at 8:45 for the 9:00 am showing and asked if there were any no-shows. So far no, comeback at 9:00. At 9:00 we were told we could get in as there were some no shows. Great. They only let in so many people for a 2-1/2 hour time period so this is why you need a reservation. Its usually full. The reason its usually full is because it is a fantastic place to see some beautiful art like Bernini, Canova, Caravaggio etc. The sculptures are incredible. We only got to 2 of the 3 floors in our time limit. We purchased the guide recordings and highly recommend it. With the small amount of visitors for the 3 floors, you can always find an exhibit for a private viewing. There is not only art throughout he gallery, but the entire place, on the floor (tiles) on ceiling etc. Do not miss this.
Magnificent. Awe inspiring art and sculpture; please don't hesitate to get the pre-recorded tour so you can explore and learn at your own pace. I am now a true lover of Bernini and Caravaggio.

Visit to the Borghese Gallery -- Wonderful Experience of Fine Art!. This is a very unique museum. You must reserve your tour in advance. I really enjoyed walking throughout the gallery looking at all the masterpieces. Visits are timed.
Love this gallery. great size. not too big and not too small. You can finish within two hours and a lot of unforgettable pieces there

book in advance!!. mega message is book in advance - easy on the internet site. if i had no done this there was no spaces available. get there in enough time to leave your bags in one of their lockers - compulsory but it is worthwhile - totally amazimg statues in a historic setting. worth the effort and planing - nice Borghese gardens outside for a stroll.

Artful Villa. This old villa is a museum filled w/wonderful paintings,tapestries,statues and furniture. The tour I took got a bit boring as the guide went into alot of detail on the various paintings and sculptures. The gardens were disappointing, they don't appear to be maintained very well.

Overwhelming history of Italian Art. The museum requires a bit of patience. There is a bit of confusion regarding where to buy tickets and advance reservations for tickets which we found out were for tours, not individuals. Once inside the amount of art is overwhelming. There are great examples of Bernini sculpture (David from David and Goliath, Apollo and Daphne) and paintings: Botticelli's Virgin and Child with St John and Angels, Raphael, Bellini's Madonna and child and a room full of Caravaggio!). There laminated cards that tell about a fraction of what is in each room. Each room from ceiling to floor is covered with paintings and sculpture. Some of ceiling are painted in 3D perspective and you get sore neck from looking up!. Our only criticism would be the lack of more detailed descriptions of the artwork in each room. Reading in advance would enhance the tour. The museum is located in the slightly scruffy Borghese park, great for a walk before or after the museum tour.

Great, Even If You Don't Know Much About Art. You MUST get tickets in advance. They hold you to specific times. The sculptures and ceiling art is very cool. The park in which it is located is one of the nicest we have ever seen, anywhere. A must see in Rome.

Compulsory for anyone with eyes!. I first visited the Borghese Gallery on a school art trip to Rome at 17. Since then I have been eagerly awaiting the opportunity to return, to see what is in my opinion the most accomplished sculptures in existence. Finally, 23 years later, I revisited this amazing gallery. The whole Gallery is filled with masterpieces, but without a doubt, Bernini's sculptures are the most outstanding. His 'David' is my favourite piece of art (as an artist that says a lot), and his 'Apollo and Daphne' is a close second. There are a number of his other astounding sculptures on display, and you don't have to have an academic background to be totally blown away by these masterpieces. He sculpted them from single pieces of marble with a virtuosity that is rarely encountered. If you're more interested in painting, there are some excellent Caravaggios on display.I would advise to book tickets on-line, with a guide if possible.Also, the gallery is not so easy to find within the Borghese park. If you're arriving by metro ( spagna is the closest stop) leave at least 20 minutes to find it. Alternatively, take a cab to the Gallery.

Wonderful tour. Mike is fabulous. He has a broad and deep knowledge base, and his enthusiasm is contagious. He greatly enhanced the experience with his expertise and humor. Would definitely highly recommend him."

Very rude and bad mannered staff/ Anti-climax after the Vatican Museum. From the very first contact the person on the door just started shouting at us, and told us to check our (small) bags. But he didn't tell us where (in Italian), just waved us away like a pestilent fly, with rude hand gestures. Down in the bag and ticket area, they were also infected with this grumpiness and rudeness. The Vatican, the day before, was so spectacular, even though it was very busy, that this museum was a bit of a disappointment, except for the few Bernini pieces, and 2 Raphael paintings that were worth seeing. IF YOU DON'T MIND BEING ABUSED, you could go there. Book ahead.

Spectacular. The Borghese was my favorite museum ever! (Even better than the Vatican Museum) The art and sculpture were absolutely magnificent and we appreciated the fact that each piece was given the space needed to be displayed and appreciated. We also applaud the fact that admission was limited to allow for better viewing.DO purchase your tickets on-line and well in advance. Also, the audio tour is a must.

An art lovers paradise. I took this tour with about 25 other people near the end of our week in Rome. I have an appreciation for statutes and paintings. The works by Bernini were so detailed and exquisite that you could actually feel the emotions depicted. The guide was an art history scholar who provided insight to each piece that we saw. His knowledge added so much to the tour and made each of us more informed than we first started. There were a number of tours being conducted while we were there and at times it was hard to hear what he was saying.The history of the Borghese family and their place in roman history and how they obtained each piece was nearly unbelievable. The best part was that you get get so close to the sculptures and paintings and almost reach out and touch them. The detail of the sculptures were incredible and almost lifelike.Would recommend this tour to any history or art major or any one who enjoys looking at the great works of art.

Best Private Collection. It's hard to imagine this much famous sculpture and artwork in one private collection. The Bernini works alone are worth the visit. I believe that it ranks only after the Vatican and Capitoline museums as the top art museum in Rome Don't miss it.P.S. - reservations should be made in advance to assure access on the day you want !

Good variety of artist paintings.. Had a variety of Artists so made it more interesting. Booking to the gallery was straight forward and easy to pay. There was a bonus couture fashion display when we went.

Bernini sculptures. Apart from the usual tourist haunts, I highly recommend visiting the Borghese Gallery. You're only allowed in for two hours then they close the rooms and let another lot in. The Bernini sculptures at Borghese are amazing to see in real life. I chose to see the sculptures first and the painting gallery second as the sculptures were what I most wanted to see. The detail and the emotion they exude have to be seen first hand. After the gallery you can also wander around the grounds. The signs to find the gallery aren't all that clear. For me, it was the highlight of a week in Rome.

Worth Making Reservations to Visit. This was the last site we visited on our trip to Rome. You'll need to reserve your two-hour slot a week in advance if you want a prime visiting time. The building's rooms alone are worth the price of admission. The works of art are icing on the cake. Take time to walk the park. Especially when it's warm, the grounds are a green and quiet oasis. Although the Spagna Metro stop purports to be the stop for the Gallery, be prepared for a very long underground hike before you reach the appropriate exit. Several city bus routes will drop you off much closer to the Gallery.

Absolutely stunning.. I came to see four artists work: Statue of Bonaparte(Canova), and the work of Raphael, Rubens, and Bernini. I was not disappointed and saw so much more. Room after room great art. We did not feel rushed or crowded. It is definitely a place one must visit.

Simply fantastic but is a must to have a guide. Doing this on your own defeats the purpose. The information provided is absolutely critical to get the best out of this amazing experience. Totally awesome!

Simply stunning paintings!!. The Borghese Gallery houses a large and amazing collection of paintings by several of Rome's most noted artists. It also contains some of Bernini's best work in marble. If you are into Fine art, this is a "must see" place!

19th century art and the art of fashion in the 21st century. We had a lovely walk to this museum on a bright sunny Monday. The museum and grouunds reflect the 18th-19th century. The art itself was inspiring and mesmerizing. Unique artistic talent by the director was reflected in the current fashion on display and intermixed with the art. An uncrowded museum that day but you do need reservations. We did not have reservations but fortunately they had a few tickets available! Take a walk around the area, unique in its own way

Caution. Beautiful Gallery; however, I didn't enjoy seeing couture gowns mixed in with the likes of a sculpture of Paulina Bonaparte. It spoils it. Ladies be careful you have to leave your purse upon entering the gallery and then your purse is thrown in a bin along with everyone else's in the gallery. It creates mayhem upon closing of the gallery when everyone is grabbing for their purse.

First Rate Sculpture Gallery. We very much enjoyed our two hours in the gallery. I highly recommend renting an audioguide. Take a driver's license to leave as collateral to be returned when the audioguide is returned. You enter in a number for each room to receive commentary. Many individual items have their own numbers, so you can decide which items you want to learn about. The cafeteria in the gallery building offers a quick meal with limited seating. Backpacks and purses must be checked and then recovered after the tour. There was a long line for this, so try to avoid bringing those items in.

Stunning - must see for any Caravaggio/Bernini fanatic!. A must see while in Rome for art lovers. Doesn't take more than a couple of hours and it's in the area of the American Embassy, which we walked too while waiting for our timed entry. There's a nice cafe and clean restrooms on the bottom floor. Super easy access via the 910 bus from where we were staying near the Colosseo.

Alaia exhibition a must see. Right now you have the designer Alaia show going on, it is superb, Alaia dresses in the middle of all the beautiful and historical statues, under the amazing heavy painted ceiling and marble floor, ceramic works...so overwhelming. Great exhibition. But the ticket on line, it is every 2 hours.

A visit worth. I really liked the Villa Borghese, it is worth going to, but I strongly advise to take your tickets beforehand so you won't be waiting a lot. I thought the security check was a bit exaggerated but the cards and souvernirs' shop is good to see. The gardens are beautiful and one can rest there a bit befor or after the visit. This you visit once and not twice but it need to be visited.

Breathtaking. I've wanted to visit the Galleria Borghese ever since we watched a BBC programme on Italy 5 years ago, but, being a disabled lady I thought it would just remain a dream.
