Well, Hubby and I were talking about things we'd like to see and I said oh the Galleria Borghese to see Bernini's Marbles would be a dream come true, Hubby immediately said why don't we go, so off we went.We went to Rome just to do this one thing so I booked a private tour through our tour operator well in advance. We took a taxi to the Gallery and were dropped off right at the entrance, we entered the gallery and as we were there a little while before we decided to have some lunch in their lovely café.We met our guide who was really good and she gave us earphones and a receiver to wear around our necks after we were all ready she took us in to the gallery to secure our bags in lockers. We proceeded on our tour which started on the lower floor so I got to see my marbles. Oh, I've never seen anything like them in my life breathtakingly beautiful and I was in awe. We then went upstairs to see the famous Caravaggio's, well I was n't sure I was going to interested in these but, they are amazing and Hubby loved the St Jerome so I was pleased he enjoyed something as much as I did.They looked after me very well and took me upstairs in their lift so disabled people we can do these lovely places.We upgraded our tour to a private tour and it was well worth it, we learnt so much from her and she showed us how to get the most out of the exhibit's. City Tours were the company we were booked with, we can't agree on the guides name one of us thinks it's Hayley and the other thinks it's Kylie so if one of us is right THANK-YOU once again you were amazing.

Very nice. In the heart of Borghese Park we enter Borghese Gallery. The teenager kids went through it pretty fast. Our young one just kept running around. And me and my wife enjoyed the beautiful work of art.
Very nice and very recommended for grownup. Would not take the kids there.

Great Collection of Art. The Borghese Gallery contains some of Bernini's finest works in marble. Along with an extensive collection of marbles, the gallery houses a large collection of paintings by several of Rome's most noted artists.
Great art. Great place to visit wonderful art! Worth the trip! We left the group tour only because we were exhausted!

Caravaggio!!!. Galleria Borghese is out of this world. It sums up the great Italian spirit to the core. Culturally and more. The collection of paintings and sculptures show the great influence Borghese family had in the Italian society.

A Must See. The Galleria Borghese houses beautiful paintings and sculptures. The Galleria was crowded but there was plenty of room to move around without difficulty. Our tour guide, Jonathan, was from Maryland but moved to Rome several years ago. He has such a passion for the arts and has an excellent knowledge base. Book online on Viator for Jonathan of City Wonders Tours. He made the experience. The gardens were so magnificent.

A sensory oasis in the heart of Rome. The Villa Borghese is an experience that should not be missed! From the moment you set foot in this beautiful building you will be mesmerised by the incredible paintings by Caravaggio , the sculptures of Bernini,the sumptuous painted ceilings juxtaposed with other pieces of Art. On the occasion that we visited there was an exhibition of dresses by Azzadene Alaia, which was so striking as the form and colour of the dresses were masterpieces in their own right.

Best Gallery in Rome!. A must see in Rome. The collection of sculptures and paintings are amazing as well as the back drop -- the Villa is beautiful with the most amazing painted ceiling throughout. Don't miss a walk through the gardens, they are spectacular in the evening. Book in advance because tickets sell out and are timed.
Beautiful. A must see. Have to prebook as you cant buy a ticket at the door. Dont worry about crowds as they dont let too many in at any one time.

A hidden treasure in Rome!. In the middle of chaotic Rome, there is an enchanted forest called the Villa Borghese Gardens, the home of the Galleria Borghese. It houses a beautiful sculptures, paintings and antiquities collection that fill your senses! You will find treasures from Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael, to name a few. You will see the magnificent sculptures of Apollo and Daphne, Truth Unveiled by Time, the Rape of Proserpine and David by Bernini and paintings of St. John the Baptist,
Worth the visit. A must see in Rome. It is equally painting and sculpture, with several Carvaggios and Berninis. The gardens make the trip complete.

Two Fantastic Hours of Immersion in Art. Year after year, the Borghese Gallery always stands out as a fantastic place, worth going back to, when visiting Rome. Just make sure to book tickets way in advance; otherwise, it is very unlikely that there will be admission tickets at the door or even a few days before the desired date. Visitors are only allowed to meander through its galleries for two hours, per visit. For a first-time visit, a knowledgeable, tour guide is recommended. For subsequent visits, anyone with a good guide book or other reference materials can do it alone. Prepare to be awed. Seriously.

Beautiful and most of all quiet. Due to limited access to the Borghese Gallery we ensured we booked a tour with walks of Italy.The gallery is of medium size and furnished with some beautiful art and sculptures.We were very fortunate to visit at the one of the Azzedine Alaia exhibition, the stunning structural clothing complimented beautifully by its surroundings

Do not think of going without a prebooking. Hundreds of people. No one could get in. Fully booked for the following four days with no chance to get in. Plan in advance. This is the same with most of the attractions in Rome these days. Couldn't even use the bathroom facilities.

A jewel of a museum. This is one of the finest museums in Rome. The collection is superb and manageable - one of the few you could visit in one session and not feel overwhelmed. The two hour time slot is ample. The suggestion to do the second floor picture gallery first is a good one. I went up and was one of maybe 10 people while the other were downstairs looking at the sculpture. When I did get to the main attraction I was nothing less than stunned by the major works. The sculpture is breathtaking and I do not exaggerate when I say I was almost moved to tears by the beauty of Bernini and Canova's work. Just astounding. Frankly if you have to choose one art museum to see in Rome this is it. The gallery is located in the fabulous park Villa Borghese - pick a morning slot - we did 11AM-1PM - pick up your tickets early at the register and then take a nice stroll around the park while you wait for your entry time. Yes - buy those tickets early - the online process is easy - there are many comments about surly staff but I found them to be professional and serious about their work at such an important institution. A smile and friendly approach will work every time.

Relaxing afternoon. I am glad we bought tickets in advance, because the gallery is sold out today and Tuesday. Very nice collection of paintings and sculpture. I am no expert, but I liked the organized, but relaxed viewing experience of the gallery.We also walked the grounds of the park and enjoyed watching the Roman children and families at play. All in all a very relaxing Sunday afternoon.

The most beautiful museum in Rome. On two floors, it is just enough to make you drool but not too much to make you tired. You have to buy tickets on line, at least during the busy season, and you have exactly two hours to see both floors so don't dawdle or you may not get to the mouth-watering sculptures on the first floor. They escort you out just before the end of your two hours.

If you love sculpture, you must go here.. In my opinion, this small museum contains some of the finest sculpture in the world. I always visit when in Rome to marvel at the works. The reclining women is incredible. I remember seeing this as a child, touching the couch, and being amazed it was actually made of Marble.

One of the Best Museums in the World, not just Rome.. This is an outstanding museum and should not be missed when going to Rome, it is one of the best in the world.A reservation is required to enter, and should be made a few of days in advance.

What a wonderful collection!. Note: during tourist season, it is MANDATORY and ESSENTIAL to buy your tickets well in advance, preferably online. The ticket office is downstairs; upon arrival, bring your receipt and it's back outside and up the stairs to the entrance.Also note: rent the audio guide - excellent explanations.The entrance ceiling sets the tone of elegance, with fabulous statues and artwork of unequaled beauty.

Cardinal Borghese was one lucky man. The villa is surrounded by a very nice park and after a short walk you will reach the villa.The Collection that was constituted by the Borghese is simply a treat for the eyes. Major paintings from the Carravagio and sculptures from bernini in addition to painted walls and ceilings.We were lucky enough to benefit as well from the Azzedine Alaia exhibition taking place at the villa Borghese

A Gallery of Great Art. A superb collection of paintings, viewable in a pre-booked two hour slot, which allows plenty of time to absorb the detail of the many paintings, without having to compete with vast crowds of people taking selfies.

A Don't Miss in My Book. Smallish museum filled with beautiful paintings and statues. Advance reservation required. We were lucky in that we bought our tickets online just two days before we went. Tickets are sold in two-hour blocks and you enter exactly at the appointed time and are asked to leave when those two hours are up so that the next group can take their turn. Everything to be seen is on two floors of the former villa. We entered from the basement level and walked up a circular staircase to the top floor -- if the door to the second floor was open at the time, we did not notice it. A modern couture sculpture exhibit was interspersed amongst the classical works, adding an interesting dimension. Cameras are allowed, but no flash photography. You must leave your personal belongings at the bag check, including purses no matter how small, and are not allowed to take anything into the galleries. Read the rules online so there are no surprises. Restrooms on the basement floor ... must show your ticket to gain access. Also restrooms on the second floor.Inside each room of the gallery, look for the laminated information pamphlets that provide details about the room, what's hanging on the walls, and the paintings on the ceilings. Not really enough time to read it all, so I took photos of them to refer to later. Yes, as others have noted, the staff can be abrupt. Don't let them ruin the experience; you are there for the art not for them.Several bus lines take you there, we took #160 even though we knew it would mean a longer walk through the park to get to the gallery. The stroll through the park is pleasant.

Borghese Gallery. Select only 10 Masterpieces. It is a must when you are in Rome. You are not rushed as in the Vatican museum because you have to reserve a booking and a limited number allowed in. My favorite sculpture was Rape of Proserpine with god's hand sinking into her flesh. You could see the flesh indented by the hand amazing sculpture.Read about the masterpieces before you visit the gallery so that you can enjoy what you see. I suggest a booklet called Galleria Borghese 10 Masterpieces published by Gebart Spa. Do not dwell on all the material exhibited because you cannot digest all. Photography allowed but no flashAlso Caravaggio's Madonna of the Palafrenieri . This painting was refused entry in St Peter's Basilica Cause ? Probably Madonna was not properly dressed The painting was bought by Cardinal Borghese

Amazing experience. This is my favorite museum. Its a reasonable size but filled to bursting with fantastic art. You need a reservation, and I suggest getting one early and then spending the rest of your morning exploring the grounds the museum is on.

One of my top three attractions in Rome. This Gallery is stunning, especially, for me, the middle floor with several Bernini sculptures that are unbelievable. We had trouble with their website, so went to the Gallery to buy our tickets a few days before we wanted to go. That worked well as we were able to figure out the bus route, etc. The cafe is a good place to sit and wait with a coffee if you are a little early. The audio costs 5 Euros and is well worth taking. I thought the two hour time slot allowed was just about right. The audio tour starts on the middle floor and moves up to the top floor - took us a while to figure this out!

make sure you book in advance. Admittance strictly restricted to bookings only & full for days in advance, so make your booking as soon as you possibly can.For art lovers, I'm sure this would have been impressive, but we did not think it was particularly well organised, nor informative. All 'labels' were in Italian only & set out in a row below a group of pictures, so you were unsure which related to which. Some pictures appeared to require considerable cleaning.Sculptures were dotted among rooms & there was an abundance of people, tho in most areas, not overcrowded.

One of my Faves. Only later did I find out that you can now bring your camera as long as you don't use flash. I've never seen sculptures look so light, airy full of movement. This is one of my favorite museums in the world. The first time I visited you were not allowed to bring purses or cameras so I checked my whole bag when I entered the second time. Be sure to buy your tickets before you arrive since you cannot purchase them at the site and they sell out. I made my reservations the first time for when everything closes down at lunch. They only let a certain number of people in per hour so it's never ridiculously crowded. The gardens surrounding the Borghese are filled with happy people riding bikes or playing with their children. It's a beautiful, shaded walk lined with benches.

Attention Art Lovers!. Borghese Gallery is a must see if you're an art lover -- or even if you're not. Room after room of classic art and sculpture housed in a truly old- world ornate Villa-- the kind they sure don't make anymore. Plus: the gallery isn't so big as to take up your whole day -- you can linger and still be out in a couple hours -- no museum fatigue here!

Bella Villa Borghese - reservation needed. You are given two hours to explore a time capsule of magnificence compiled by the familia Borghese including the nude of Pauline Borghese, the sister of Napoleon Bonaparte. History lives in this stately home.

Beautiful gallery and grounds.. Very beautiful grounds and gallery. Each room is gorgeous and houses exquisite art. You MUST purchase tickets ahead of time and, if you are walking, be sure to leave plenty of time to walk around the grounds. The signage to find the gallery is not great - you have to walk all the way through the park, so be sure to leave time for that.

Breathtakingly rude staff. our visit to this attraction was ruined by the rude staff. At the ticket desk they could not change 20 euro note for 17 euro entry fee and insisted we pay by card. You then have to check your bags in. This takes longer than getting the tickets and no information is given about what you can take into the gallery. On the door the security person was rude beyond belief and ranted in Italian because I had water on me which is not allowed in the building. This is despite information at the bag drop which was at least unclear. The museum is good but the hassle of getting tickets and getting in is rubbish from our experience.

a very full and interesting gallery Art students get in for €2. all the web sites say to book online to make sure you get a ticket, well we didn't and it did say it was full, but we just asked and they had had loads of cancellations and no shows so we got a ticket no problem. Also Art students get in for only €2 !there is lots to see and if you like renaissance art then this is a must see
Great art - make a reservation. Great art museum on two levels. A lot to look at. You need to make a reservation for a time to go in. Check your bags early because a line forms fast

Well worth visiting.. We thought this location was superb, and really enjoyed the fabulous paintings, sculptures and grounds. However, two members of staff, namely in the baggage store, and the cafe, were unfriendly to the point of rudeness - not the kind of reception we expected, at all.

Nice gallery but rather pricey. Situated in the gorgeous Villa Borghese, we pre-booked tickets to see this gallery. The art and sculptures were nice enough, however, the items were rarely labelled and half of the time you had no clue what you were looking at. During our time there, there was a haute couture dress exhibition which covered up amazing floor mosaics.... really disappointing. Unless you are a hard core Italian art and sculpture fan, save your euros and rent a bike to tour the park.

Idyllic Rome. I had no problem making our reservation by phone before our visit, since we were using Roma Passes. We made to sure to arrive 30 minutes before our time slot. This gave us time to stroll through the lovely gift shop and check our bags before our visit. You can only take wallets into the museum, not a purse, so be prepared to consider what you will take with you during your visit. I brought my guide book and my cell phone. You can take pictures during the visit, but no flash photography.My daughters enjoyed the dresses on the temporary display at the museum, but we also really enjoyed the amazing sculptures by Bernini. We all especially admired Apollo and Daphne. The paintings are also enchanting. We easily filled our two hours taking in all this museum had to offer.After our visit to the museum, we really enjoyed strolling through the Borghese Gardens to the Laghetto and renting (very inexpensive) a row boat to enjoy the Lake in the gardens.

Must See!. We loved visiting the Borghese Gallery. It's a bit off the beaten path but we are so glad we made the effort. First off is the park and or gardens. We spent 45 minutes walking through the park before we got to the gallery which was wonderful. It is a beautiful green space in Rome to stroll and or people watch. The gallery or villa itself was spectacular. We were lucky enough to catch their designer gown display at the same time which was going on throughout the gallery. The dresses were an amazing backdrop to the art that is showcased in the gallery. I highly recommend getting the audio guide for the extra 5 euro as it gives a simple yet informative background on what you are looking at. The villa, art, sculpture, and park are all amazing and worth the visit. We used our Roma Pass which made this an even better deal.

Alaia in Rome. Beautiful place, worth its price. Many pieces of art placed in magnificent surroundings. When I was visiting, there was an exhibition of Alaia's houte couture dresses - it suited perfectly!

Guided tour . A tour with City Wonders was a great way to avoid the queues - Marco was an excellent guide and showed his passion and knowledge particularly for Bernini.I warn you though that you will need to go again as there is so much to see! A real delight.There is also a short tour around the gardens ending at Popolo.

Beautiful gallery but beware of their reservations staff. This is a must in any Rome itinerary. However note that it is essential to book in advance. I booked over the phone and for some reason the reservation did not appear in the system when I was at the gallery. So make sure you write down the name of the person you talk to as well as the confirmation number. I would even call a day after to make sure everything is OK with the reservation. This will avoid a lot of arguments and probably the possibility of not entering the gallery. Also, be warned that there is a very rude woman working at the ticket office who treats visitors terribly bad. Management at the museum should try to do something about it as this is a great small museum and that type of behavior is just unacceptable.

An attraction in the middle of a park. Fantastic park, but be prepared for walking, lots of little areas to sit and enjoy the views, you can find a nice shaded area and if you want hire a tricycle, the museum is great and well worth a visit just to see the statues. Suggest book through the hotel as there are normally time slots and if you just turn up, you may be disappointed and in for a long wait. The only downside is the noise of the birds in the park, they don't give up and put on plenty of insect repellent you can get bitten a lot, overall though a fantastic place.

Superb Caravaggios, alas no photos !. Pre booked 2 tickets online €25, as almost impossible to turn up on the day and expect to get in. Printed out voucher which specifically explained that prior to admission to the gallery all bags must be left in the cloakrooms and photography was NOT permitted. Did as I was instructed only to find on entry that EVERYBODY was taking photographs with either a camera or an iPhone !!! As you can imagine I was extremely disappointed not to have any mementos of our visit. On asking a member of staff why? was told '' okay for camera, no flash''. That aside the gallery has a beautiful collection of Renaissance art and sculpture, and as an added bonus we were able to view 'Azzedine Alaia' exhibition of 1990's haute couture juxtoposed amongst the historical artefacts.

Amateur's view. I'm not a big lover of art but this Gallery was in my "must see" list. You need to buy tickets online in advance if you want to garantee your visit. We took 2 tickets but my wife couldn't go and I was alone. You have 2 hours to observe gallery and it was enough. Some rooms were closed but after a time have been opened. It was great to see Bernini's David after you've seen Mickelangelo's one. I don't know majority of creators but all their works deserve attention.

Excellent but be prepared to queue. The most irritating part of the visit is the queues. We queue 15 minutes for tickets. Then queue 15 minute to place our bags in the cloak room Note even a small handbag cannot be taken into the gallery irritatingly they did not state this when we got the tickets only after we got to the front of a 5 minute queue to go in so we had to then join the cloak room queue. So we spent the best part of an hour in queues for a 2 hour visit Note your ticket only allows you 2 hours in the gallery. However having said all that it is a wonderful gallery and well worth the pain. So if you going leave you bags behind and book tickets online

Very impressive place. Highly recommend .. So many great and impressive items. 2 hours is enough. We ordered the ticket online and before start, we went to the museum to get the ticket and audio guide is helpful.

The Borghese Gallery is a highlight in Rome. Don't miss it.. It was a wonderful experience to visit the outstanding,great Borghese Gallery. It is very important to book in advance to ensure that there are available space for you to visit the gallery. Bernini's sculptors are mindboggeling. He captured the human soul in marble. His facial expressions are excellent and the human body very realistic. Bernini was an outstanding artist and a leading sculptor. It is very important to experience the gallery if you are in Rome.

Bernini overload from this amazing little Museum . Only takes an hour or so to enjoy the whole museum but is packed with some amazing Bernini work. Also has a interesting high fashion dress display that the ladies will love. Just check in advance if tickets are available. The museum sells out. The day I went everything said it was sold out, but i walked right up and they sold me tickets for that day with no waiting. A must see.

great gallery and gardens. We did this with a City Wonders Tour group - what an amazing site. our guide explained the history of the art works, took us around the entire gallery and explained who painted/sculpted when etc. just great. we took a walk of the gardens after the gallery - what a lovely walk. Would highly recommend you take the tour with City Wonders for this site, as you will miss so much otherwise.

Inspiring!. Borghese Gallery was a spectacular collection of ancient artwork housed in an elegant old mansion. We hired a private tour guide which made all the difference so the place came alive for us. I would go back.
Absolutely fantastic!. It's a stunning collection of art, including sculptures by Bernini, paintings by Caravagio, Raphael and Titian in a beautiful setting!!!An absolute must see when in Rome!
Visit to Villa Borghese. Really enjoyed our visit here - very interesting but be sure to pre-book. Gardens are also very good.

Excellent villa and art gallery. The Borghese Gallery is a beautiful villa with fantastic art collection. Apollo and Daphne by Bernini is breathtaking statue! There was an exibition with Adzedin Alaia clothes. Take a walk around the park, on foot (if you have a lot of time). Is very relaxing.

Alright. Nice art but to be honest it was very poorly air conditioned which meant there was an uncomfortable journey throughout the building with barely any space to walk around it. Particular highlight was the carvaggio paintings. And that one where the woman is lying down.

Amazing Bernini. The Gallery is located in a beautiful park which itself is a gift when you visit Rome in summer. The art collection is large and diverce but the most amaizing in my opinion are Bernini works. It's hard to imagine how someone could turn a cold piece of marble into something so beautiful and full of life.Booking in advance is recommmended.

worth a visit, even your first time in Rome. Maybe if we had gone to Florence or Paris or other art hot-spots, this would have been less amazing. We did this our last day in town, after the Vatican museums and many gorgeous churches, and it was the best art experience we had. The art was lovely, but the fact that much of it was commissioned to fit THIS space, or the space design specifically for that particular piece, it's an amazing full experience of walls, ceiling, and numerous art works in each room.Get the audio guide. It's definitely worth it. Then ignore the "instructions" and start by going straight upstairs. All guests have to enter at a set entry time (every two hours during the day). You have a timed 2 hour allotment, and most everyone starts in room #1. If you start upstairs you'll have many of the rooms and artworks to yourself to appreciate and enjoy. And you should still be able to take in the downstairs in the last 45-50 minutes of your visit.

Time slots!!!. The gallery is beyond amazing. Apollo and Daphne by Bernini leaves you moved for hours. But their reservation system is terrible, for roma pass you have to call (!) even from abroad (!!!) and to be there at least half an hour before. If you do so it's a breeze, I highly advise arriving 45 min in advance, getting your ticket, leaving your bags and enjoying the best iced cappuccino in town (seriously) at its cafe. Pictures and water bottles allowed, not many explanations under each work of art but a big explanatory card in each room. Allow yourself time to wander afterwards to the magnificent park after you leave, will make a perfect half day trip.

Fantastic Collection of Classical Art. A little off of the beaten tourist track, but still accessible, the Borghese is testament to the religious opulence of the 17th Century.Fantastic sculptures by Bernini are alongside artwork by Titian, Caravaggio, Raphael and Rubens and more...All Exceptional value, if you're an art buff.Make sure you pre-book, people turning up 'on the day' will be disappointed. The 2 hour time slot given for viewing is actually more than enough, although we didn't see anyone being urged to move out after their viewing time. Make sure you visit the bag check area before your entry time, no bags allowed, but cameras without flash OK.Absolutely a 'must visit' if you love classical art.
Worth the trip. The Gallery is outstanding and is located in a beautiful park setting. After attending the other must sights this is worth the trip.

A Highlight of Rome. If you are in Rome more than 2 days, or if you are an art afficionado, you can not skip the Borghese Gallery. Set in the beautiful park it makes for a lovely half day outing admiring the building and its contents along with the grounds. As you know by now, get your tickets before you leave home. It is a relatively small museum but houses such treasures so that you may spend more time than you realize. No fear--there is a nice cafeteria and clean bathroom facilities. You will have to check your bag and sometimes there is a line. It is also a bit of a trek from the metro or bus stop through the park.
What a treat!. Just two hours, not more not less (this make it a perfect museum to visit with kids!). We called the day before and got a place easily. The collection is magnificent. Not to be missed.

Love this spot in Rome11. This is one of my favorite museums in the world. There are so many incredible works of art, including the building itself. Not to be missed in Rome. And the times tickets make the experience even better, since the crowds are limited!!

The best little museum in Rome. The perfect museum for people who don't like museums. The ground floor houses sculpture by Bernini and some Caravaggio paintings as well as the Egyptian room. The second floor holds the pinacoteca - art gallery - full of priceless works of art. It's best to book in advance so as to avoid being disappointed on the day. And after an hour admiring art you can walk out into the splendour of the surrounding park - if you're there with kids there's always the promise of a trip to the Biopark just metres away to bribe them.

Not much to see and not much variety, but what they do have is excellent. I'm a big fan of Bernini, so I enjoyed this small museum which houses some of his most famous works. However, there is not much variety in the type of works of art. We saw everything at a leisurely pace in one hour.

Beautiful Bernini statue. Great, compact museum. 2 floors stacked with paintings (mainly top floor), statues (main floor) and decorations. During the tourist season, you must buy tickets in advance! Admittance in 2-hour blocks only. I was impressed by a Bernini statue, best I ever saw.
Apollo and Daphne most beautiful sculpture I have ever seen!. Incredibly beautiful! Must get reservations in advance. Do not hesitate. The ticket system was easy.

Feast for the Eyes!!. An absolute must if you are a Bernini or Caravaggio lover. The art in this gallery is breath taking. In order that you are not disappointed make sure you pre order your tickets to enter the gallery or take a tour to ensure you get in,

A wonderful place to visit. The Borghese Gallery is full of fabulous works of art which will take your breath away. Currently there is also a fashion exhibition on too which was an added bonus! You need to book in advance and you get a ticket for a two hour time slot. The surrounding park is wonderful to wander around especially as you can escape the beating midday sun in the shade!

My favourite place to visit of all. The Villa Borghese was the biggest treat of all our stay but you have to book online beforehand to get a slot. This rule applies for most sites to avoid the queues and disappointment if there for a short time only. The marble statues stood out for me the most.So hard to believe they are made of marble!!!!!!!! There is also a lovely park where you can hire bicycles and rickshaw type vehicles which are great fun to ride around the park. Battery and pedal powered.For children there is a zoo and a fairground carousel. A globe theatre. A dressage ring and a boating lake. Loads of places selling cold drinks and ice cream, sandwiches etc.

Piece de Resistance of The Villa Borghese!. The piece de resistance or crowning glory of the villa Borghese is the museum called THE GALLERIA BORGHESE. This is a spectacle to behold as it has possibly some of the finest of art in the form of sculptures and paintings in Rome. The tickets sell fast and nedd TO BE BOOKED WELL IN ADVANCE. There are limited numbers let through the doors in 2 hourly slots comprising of 350 people at any given time. Entrance for children below 18 is free with the exception of an online transaction fee of Euro 2 per child. For adullts it costs Euro 16 including the transaction fee. It would be worthwhile renting a audio guide to the place - something that we repented not investing in - as there are important works by the great renaissance artists and the anecdotes that are attached to the paintings are worth their weight in gold.

A "must see". Get your tickets early before you travel to Rome and avoid the lines. Skip the line tickets. We also recommend having a tour guide. so much to see and it is impossible to absorb all of it in a day! We spend a few hours here and that is all we could handle because it is overwhelming!

Wonderful Gallery of Fine Art. What a beautiful park setting with sculptures, fountains, and an amazing Gallery. Small museum but worth the visit. Wonderful little train and/or bikes for rent to travel all through the area. Direct drop off and pick up at Gallery entrance.

Museum is great, but a bit unorganized. well, yes, museum is amazing, work of art is breathtaking. Like everything else in Rome.Just getting there is a bit complicated. First, reservations and paying over the phone. Strange. That, not many buses (as far as I know) pass by. They tell you you need to be there even half an hour before, but than there's no real order in getting in. You still wait in line to get your real tickets. Not clear policy about what needs to be stored in locker room. Not clear where the exhibition starts. Very overcrowded to really enjoy the museum.Maybe better to visit it some other time of the year.

Fantastic Museum in a Gorgeous Setting. The Galleria Borghese has so much going for it - an amazing park setting overlooking Rome, an incredible collection of Bernini's greatest works including Apollo and Daphne, The Rape of Persephone, and his amazing David, Canova's Pauline as Venus, and several Caravaggios, Raphaels and a Titian. And, you can get so close to them you can practically feel the life in them - but don't touch. Truly a remarkable collection.Equal to these masterpieces is the fact that the Borghese carefully controls the crowd. Only 200 people are allowed entry for each 2 hour period, making the experience intimate and quiet, giving you plenty of time to take in the amazing art.After your visit, be sure to take a stroll through the Villa Borghese, the amazing Roman version of Central Park that the family bequeathed to the City.

Don't Miss!. Such a beautiful gallery with paintings and sculptures. It is a small museum with intimate rooms of collections. Even the walls are a work of art! We were so amazed with the beauty here, we started over in the beginning again and walked thru twice! We are not museum people, but surely enjoyed this one!!

Breathtaking!!!. Unbelievable works of art! Wow!!! Art lovers could easily spend days here. You are limited to two hours. I was worried we would feel rushed with the two hour limit - but, we actually had ample time to wander through all of the rooms and then go back to spend more time at our favorites - we finished well before the two hour limit. You ARE allowed to take pictures (just no flash). Expect to stand online for quite awhile to pick up your reserved tickets. By limiting the number of visitors present at any one time, the museum never feels too crowded. The day we were there, they were sold out - I imagine that probably happens quite a bit, so make sure you reserve tickets in advance. After visiting the museum, you can then spend time wandering through the gardens and surrounding area - absolutely beautiful. It is well worth the price of admission - the Bernini sculptures alone are too beautiful to describe with words - and there is so much more there than Bernini. Nice gift shop. Bathrooms on site. Cafeteria there also but not much in way of selection (and plenty of places relatively near by you can eat before or afterwards)

Stupendous!. A must see for anyone visiting Rome. A beautiful Gallery 'stuffed' with an amazing collection of art and sculpture. Our guide Kylie brought her sheer enthusiasm with her and you couldn't fail but to enjoy every minute in her company. Absolutely excellent in every way.

Just go. One of the great small museums I saw in Italy. Too big for the 2 hour time slot they make available, but intimate, great collection, beautiful setting. If you enjoy Renaissance sculpture and art, consider booking two visits. The audio tour worth renting. If I go again, and I will if back in Rome, I would seriously consider a guided tour.

Outstanding collection of Bernini sculpture. The art in this building is overwhelming. Everything within its walls, including the walls, are works of art. The walls, the ceilings, the floors. the furniture, the paintings, and the sculpture all demand attention. The life-size pieces by a 23 year-old Bernini are worth the trip. With a two hour time limit, the pace throughout the building is brisk. A wonderful place to spend a warm dan in Rome.

Absolutely amazing. Did not expect that amount of nice stuff in a single house. I am by no means an expert in statues but i can say for sure the ones in galleria borghese are some of the best in the world. Dont forget to look at the gladiator mosaics in the entrance hall which is for some reason covered up by 25 year old dresses for anorexia patients. One of the best experiences ive had in rome.
not big, but good museum. 2 floors museum with good collection of Renaissance + antique sculptures from roman empire periodsmall, but good and recommending to visit

Art's lovers mecca. Possibly the best museum in Rome. After the Vatican Museums this is my favourite place where to go and refresh my love for art. Canova's statues, Caravaggio's paintings, the beautiful setting and architecture of the villa create a unique athmosphere for the observer who falls inveitably in love with the place. Tip: the earliest hours are the best. Don't forget to book well in advance.

Art history paradise. A must see in Rome as you move up Via Veneto or take the escalators from the Spanish Steps and walk into and through the park. The collection and its historical ties to the Popes of old is a story until to itself, and the pieces are displayed with stunning light and care in this magnificent mansion. Do enjoy the audio tour (a must) and allow 1-2 hours to wander and enjoy. A true highlight of any trip to Italy.

Impressive collection. You must make a reservation to visit this gallery, but can often do so only a day or two in advance. A tour is not necessary as each room has several laminated informational guides explaining the artwork presented. The rooms on the first floor feature statues; including famous works such as Bernini's "The Rape of Proserpina". The second floor features many beautiful paintings. The gallery is located in a park-like setting that is refreshing in a busy city. Purses and bags must be checked downstairs prior to entering, but cameras are allowed. Reservations are for a two-hour visit, which was exactly what we needed.
A welcome surprise. A must see for anyone travelling to Rome...thoroughly enjoyed the surroundings and most importantly the art.

Up close and personal with Bernini. small museum that gives the visitor an opportunity to get up close and personal to several of Bernini's sculptures. Many other beautiful pieces of work to see. Good layout to the museum. Can get crowded in this small space but a must if in Rome!
For the Art and history Lover. One of the rich museums and historically and archetecturally interesting sites to visit in Rome. We enjoyed the art collection and glimpse back in time.

Didn't get in. We made the mistake of not booking to enter the gallery therefore did not manage to look around inside, however had such a lovely time in the grounds, riding on the 4 seater bikes and visiting the zoo that we were not disappointed at all. What a lovely place to relax and take a break from the hustle and bustle of the centre of Rome. The banana split is worth a try in the cafe near the lake too.
Beautiful park . The park is beautiful ,,, I wanted to visit the museusm and see the Bernini sculpters but I didnt book in advance so I couldnt see them ,,,

Wonderful Gallery to visit.. The gallery was great, as usual. This was my fourth visit, but the first with family. Our visit was slightly spoiled due to a morning strike by the workers. I had bought advance tickets months ago, but upon showing up at the designated time, a sign was posted notifying of the strike, and advising to return at one. When we returned, the line was 200 meters long, but upon opening, moved pretty quickly. The small group ahead of us in line proved the need for advance tickets, they had none, and after standing in the line, were turned away. The gallery is noted for its diversity and did not disapoint on this vist. The wall murals, the beautiful art, the graceful statures, all made this a great visit. One sad note, perhaps due the drought, the gardens were in a state of disrepair, I remember them as beautiful on my previous visits.Get your reserved tickets and make this a must stop whilst in Rome.

Collection of beautiful sculptures - worth a visit. If you have little extra time in Rome, this Gallery is worth a visit. The best attraction in this Gallery is "David" by Bernini. It is considered one of the best sculptures of Rome. There are several other beautiful works. Many paintings. Advance booking is a must. They give 2 hours time to visit the Gallery and it is sufficient. Just book your ticket online and be there on time. You can also have some relaxed time after the visit, in the serene green park outside the Gallery.

At the top of my Rome list!. Make your booking, rent the audio guide, and experience these beautiful pieces of art in a beautiful environment. Such a welcome relief to see these ancient and Renaissance pieces in a calm gallery, after the horrible experience of the Vatican Museum. The Bernini sculptures are amazing!

Another Florentine gem. Reservations are a must here, since you get a specific two-hour visit. Unlike many of the other wonders of Firenze these galleries are manageable in that time frame. And the adjacent park and gardens are restful.

Nice, small, art packed gallery. If your time in Rome is limited, it's better to see the Colosseum and Vatican. But if you have an extra 3-4 hours, this may be worth your while. Lots of sculpture here, some nice paintings as well. Not real easy to get to and you need to book way in advance to secure a time slot. They allow you inside for 2 hours, which is more than enough. But it might take an hour each way to get here from your hotel. I don't think it's the 'knock your socks off' museum that most people rate it as, but it's good. And it's compact, which I like. Nothing bores me more than huge galleries with endless corridors of meaningless art, along with the few gems. Have good stuff, keep it small and simple.
Enjoy the gallery and park. Great visit and lots to do in the local Borghese gardens..mini globe theatre..zoo..cinema..and great panoramic view of Rome.

If in to art, worth the visit.. To start I am not an art aficionado. But I will compelled to see the super famous sculptures. The building itself is an impressive work of art. The frescoes ceilings and inlaid floors are worth the admission alone. The gallery is organized well to highlight the most important work. Bernini's David, Apollo and Daphne and Rape of Persephone. All were impressive. What I liked was the Ancient Greek and Roman works interspersed. The whole second floor were paintings and not any masterpieces. I did like the Bottecili Madonna. Book advance as it sells out.

Impressive art collection and gallery. We made a great decision to book a tour of the Borghese Gallery and Gardens with Viator. Our tour guide was exceptional. He had a great knowledge of the gallery and its works and art history during the period. His insights and commentary really enhanced our experience.

Must see in Rome. Amazing art collection! a must see in Rome!! you must book ahead of time. We booked a tour with a guide a day ahead through darkroom.com. During our visit there was a fashion exhibition for the fashion designer Azzedine Alia, magical dresses!

Reserve Your Tickets In Advance On Line. I almost missed my chance and if I save just one person with this advice it will be worth it. I traveled in June and booked my tickets in early May. Even then I had to go on a Saturday night from 5-7pm. Odd time but worth it. Very small which explains the timed tickets. I had no idea about the statuary inside. Best I have ever seen. Both my 11 and 16 year old children enjoyed and seemed to be suitably impressed with what they saw. A must see in Rome. Quieter and more quaint vs. insanity of the Vatican.

Book before you go!. This Gallery is set in lovely grounds. You could plan an entire day here. They have cafe's, lovely areas to walk or picnic. The grounds also rents out bikes, sedways so you can tour the area quite quickly if you would prefer.We booked our tickets for the Galleria before we left for Rome. As we had also booked the Roma Pass - we could enter the museum for free (as one of the attractions) as long as we reserved our tickets and showed our Roma Pass on visiting.For the Roma Pass holders and tour guides, tickets must be booked by phone at +39 06 32810 and picked up at the ticket office of the museum 30 minutes before the opening hour, otherwise the cancellation.It was quite easy to phone Italy and they have an automated service - for an English speaker.When we visited there were quite a few people that had simply turned up to the Galleria on the day and found that it was fully booked and would be for the next 2 - 3 weeks.The Galleria only lets a certain amount of people through their doors - this is great!! as you have the space and time to enjoys the arts.You have to check any bags in, but you are allowed to take your camera in with you. There is a small cafe within the galleria, toilets and gift shop.

Reserve ticket online advance . Cause of crowd limitation, advice online reserve advance, otherwise you need to wait for available space. Each ticket Duarte 2 hours, print your confirmation for exchange ticket at reception at -1 floor of museum which is the entrance also.It's like the little 'Vatican museum' but much less people, truly worth!
Amazing villa. We had a great time watching the gallery ,going through the history ,we reserved the ticket online in advance and we got there in time ,really it was an amazing 2 hour in my life,

Private Guided Tour is worth the money. I spent 2 hours here this morning. The art is superb and I arranged a private guide in advance - which was well worth it. Because of this I got to see all of the key pieces of the collection within the limited timeframe allowed in the gallery.

Must see. A beautiful gallery in a beautiful and always memorable garden.
Go early to spend enough time for garden visiting and the gallery exploring.

Unexpected gem. The scope and splendor of the Borghese Gallery was special. You must reserve tickets well ahead, six to eight weeks is not too early. We took the subway and walked through the lovely park to the gallery. The gallery is very efficiently run and the tour started right on time. I was not expecting the splendor or quantity of great art in the gallery. What a great surprise. The architecture of the building was on par with the art. A small restaraunt is located on the first floor with snacks and drinks. My wife insisted we go, I am glad we were able to see this gallery. A must see when in Rome.

One of the many nice museums in Rome. This is a nice gallery, but very overrated. It has wonderful Bernini statues, but so do so other museums and even piazzas in Rome. So I don't think it is in the top ten must see places, as people indicate. Book in advance, otherwise, you won't get tickets for the nearest days you are going.

BERNINI!!!!!! wow, it's a must see place. you can't miss Bernini's statues, they look like they are coming to life.so much movement and passion in an object.also a person that doesn't connect to art can appreciate the great Bernini.

Get the audio tour!!!. Trust me, get the audio tour. It really gives all the paintings and statues a voice, you notice things (expressions, materials, colors) that you wouldn't have on your own, and it gives you a history of the artists as well. You MUST reserve your ticket beforehand. We couldn't get any openings online so we called and they made a reservation for us! If the timing is right, don't forget to stroll in the lovely gardens outside the museum. We walked a couple of minutes to the fountain and dipped our feet in, it was absolutely beautiful. One of the few, really green spots inside the city!

Caravaggio and Bernini. We reserved tickets the day before, which is great because sometimes it sells out. We also arrived well in advance, and hung out in the cafe until it was our reservation time at 1:30pm. We also are happy we checked out the audio tours, because they gave more in depth descriptions of specific works. My favorite may have been an early in-process Bernini work which still had charcoal marks on it from sketching out the sculpture. There was also a nicely curated modern couture exhibition woven into the more permanent Baroque and other art works. It was a great experience, and two hours felt like enough time to see everything.

absolutely fabulous. This is a smaller museum in the mannor home of the bishop Borghese. Not a very religious fellow but he had a lot of money and wanted the power of being bishop. The man had a fabulous sense of art and the statues alone are worth the entrance fee. I'm going again to Rome with my sister and told her we ARE seeing the Borghese.

Worth it if you have the time. The Borghese Gallery is small but has some very interesting art, not necessarily what you would expect. This was my 4th or 5th time to Rome, but my first time to visit this gallery. If it's your first visit or you're short on time, I would suggest the Vatican Musuems, unless you prefer a more intimate viewing experience.

Third visit here- still gorgeous!. Every time I come back to this gallery, I'm so blown away by the Bernini sculptures. Each one is more breathtaking than the next! I am also fascinated by the frescoes on the walls and ceiling which appear to be 3-dimensional while we were there, the gallery was exhibiting fashion pieces in addition to their typical art collection. At first I felt it was a bit distracting, but after visiting a couple of rooms, I got used to them. The dresses were gorgeous.
Must see. Don't miss this. You will be in awe. Only downer was the staff while waiting to get in. They were rude and wouldn't answer questions. Just ignore them.

My Favorite Spot in Rome. I have been to Rome a number of times and had the pleasure of seeing many of the first class attractions the city has to offer. The Borghese Gallery, however, is my favorite and what I recommend most to other tourists. They require appointments for entry, but visitors should not be deterred. The appointments mean there is CROWD CONTROL. When I was there during the shoulder season our hotel concierge was able to book us tickets with no problem. And once inside the architecture and art are stunning. Where else do you get to be alone in a room that is part of a cardinal's villa with a Bernini statue?
Nice villa , worth of visitng!. Must see, beatifull building inside , wall paintings, fire places,....If you are there in the neigbourhud in Trevestere, you should not miss it.

Worth a Visit. I enjoyed the experience and liked the sculpture on the first level. It's worth seeing but you do have to have a 2-hour reservation time slot that is strictly enforced. The building itself is beautiful and I would have checked out the rest of the gardens if it hadn't been so hot. But, it's within walking distance of the Spanish Steps and the shopping in that area, so worth a combined visit.

Lovely!! Do not miss out!! . I typically do not enjoy art galleries and museums. Looking at paintings on a wall becomes very monotonous for me very quickly. The Borghese however is fantastic. It's small so it's not overwhelming. But the quality of art there is spectacular!! Be sure to book your tickets well in advance! Afterwards stroll through the park.

Impressive. It was a memorable visit. To visit the Galleria Borghese, you have to make a reservation in advance. I strongly recommend to hire the acoustic tour to completely understand how the museum came about and it points you toward the best works of art and explains them.
A spectacular museum. The Borghese Gallery houses some truly incredible works of art, including several incredible Bernini sculptures. This should be a must-see on any visit to Rome.

Great experience. Definetely worths visit. The gallery is very impressive and must see for art lovers. Do note that you must make reservation in advance in order to buy tickets. The park offers many attractions - sagway, rikshas, bycicles etc. Nice cafe with great cold capuccino, good service.

Overwhelming artwork. Visited the Galleria Borghese during our 3 week trip through Italy. Had purchased our tickets online before we left; a good thing as when we arrived they were taking reservations 5 days ahead. You have a set appointment time but are asked to arrive 30 minutes before hand. We purchased the audio guide for 5 euro each as we wanted to know the history behind the works that we were viewing. Amazing to see the opulence of the artwork which included paintings and sculptures from many of the masters. One thing that amazed us was that the windows were open & there was no AC; wondered how that effected the art? Overall a must see when in Rome; just remember to reserve ahead during the peak tourist season.

Proserpina Sculpture. We made a reservation two weeks before and we did not regret it. You must make a reservation because the tickets will be sold out if you want to buy tickets when you get there. There is a 2 hours limitation for the visit. You must give your bag before entrance, they lock them and give you your phone, camera in a plastic bag and you can use them during your visit. Bernini's sculptures were amazing but the incredible one was Proserpina's. You should definitely see it and also Daphne and Apollon. Besides the sculptures and paintings, the villa is also worth-seeing. After visiting the museum, take a walk in the gardens of Villa Borghese, too.
Great place to visit. Great place to visit spend some time in the park also, water outside in the fountains was good to drink and fill up bottles.
Unexpected and grandiose! . Don't miss it. What a jewel. It is not your average museum and if you take a tour you will learn all the fascinating story behind it.
Bernini fans- a must do.. This museum is a MUST SEE if you are fan of Bernini. While the other rooms are interesting, The Bernini's are the stars.

Nice building, good exhibits, nice restaurant. I booked our tickets well in advance as you have to book specific entry time slots and it sells out very quickly. The gallery is located in a fabulous building in the middle of a wonderful park in Rome. The exhibits (sculptures and paintings) are wonderful and while we were there they also had a showcase of couture gowns which was wonderful. We eat sandwiches from the very reasonably priced cafe after our visit. Very enjoyable, recommended.

Borghese simply the Best. This museum is not large but jam packed with the most amazing art. My wife and I have been to all the major museums of art thru out most of Europe and we both agree that The Borghese is one of the best. If you like marble sculpture or 13-15 century paintings this is the place to go!
Nice Gallery. Great walk though the park to gallery. Very interesting pieces worth seeing. The palace itself is worth visitimg.
What a delighted experience it was.. Was moved by the presentation of art in every part of rome and this was no exception either , but trust me you must visit it to believe me.
I love Bernini. Great Bernini collection...my favorite sculptor. I love the sculpture of Daphe & Apollo...I stood there for an hout just looking at it.,

Fantastic Tour on a Sweltering Hot Day. This was first of three tours with City Wonders. Marco was our guide for the tour of the Borghese Gallery and the Gardens. Marco was very professional, knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the art he was showing us. It was not easy keeping everyone entertained as we had a late afternoon tour on a very hot day and the Gallery has very few rooms that are air conditioned. We would recommend tours in the morning on the hot days during the summer. Eight of our group dropped off after the gallery tour, leaving just two couples and Marco for the tour of the Park area. Like I mentioned earlier, this was the first of three tours (Breakfast @ the Vatican and Tour of Coliseum at Night) with City Wonders over the next two days; all of the tours were fantastic. There was so much to see and take in and only a limited time to visit. We plan on bringing my folks back next year and sharing the same tour with them.If you want a great experience while you are visiting in Rome, book some tours with City Wonders.

Stunningly beautiful!. The Borghese gallery is one of the most compelling museums in Europe. The Bernini statues are so beautiful they can bring tears to your eyes. Each room is a feast for your senses and since the number of visitors is limited you are not crowded and can stand in awe of the artist's creations. Not as overwhelming as the Louvre or the Uffizi,you can enjoy all of the galleries and also enjoy the wonderful gardens. Reservations are required. Once you see this musuem, you will want to return again and again.

Set Aside a Half Day to See the Borghese Gallery and Enjoy the Gardens. The Borghese Gallery in Rome is one place where you MUST plan ahead especially if visiting in the busy tourist season. Advanced reservations are required. Time slots are two hours with the first at 9 am. The good news is that the number of people allowed in during a time slot is somewhat limited - about 350 people - so the Gallery never feels really crowded. We had an 11 am time and got there early to enjoy the gardens a bit before going in. The gardens are huge and one could spend an entire day there although, despite the shade, it can get hot. Plan to arrive at the Gallery at least a half hour before allowed time and bring your passport for identification. I almost didn't get in even though I had a confirmation number. The interior itself is stunning - a mini Versailles. The Borgheses were an affluent and very wealthy family. Pope Julius II of Sistine Chapel fame was a Borghese. The art depicts mostly religious themes and some pieces - particularly the Rafaels - are impressive. The BIG draw are the sculptures. Some of Bernini's masterpieces are housed here including his version of the David, Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Proserpina. Unbelievable!The outdoor garden behind the house is somewhat charming but ill kept. Check out the transportation situation carefully. We found it easy to get there by bus nut not so easy returning. This is one of Rome's highlights but you have to really want to go since it is a bit off the beaten track.

Bernini and Caravaggio. Bernini statues in the settings they were made for,caravaggio's galore and limited crowds a perfect experience. You have to book beforehand as visits are in 2hr slots and numbers are limited but that's what makes it so nice to view,go the opposite way from most of the crowds and you can have rooms almost to yourself. The gardens and building are also very attractive

Excellent event with couture exhibition. We enjoyed our visit to the gallery, there is also a couture exhibition alongside the normal historical pieces and the effect is really interesting. The gallery is very popular and we booked online, you can stay for 2 hours inside the gallery and entrance time is strictly controlled. You are advised to book as we noticed many people arriving with tickets and being turned away as the gallery was full booked for many days ahead.We spent a little time in the garden before entering the gallery but wished that we had allocated more time for the genera visit. The gardens really are very spacious a relaxing escape from the busy centre of Rome.

An absolute must see!!!. If you love art you must see this place!! The Bernini pieces alone are worth the visit!! This incredible art carved from marble. The realism of these pieces took my breath away. I walked each floor 3 times. Looking at painting, sculptures, and ceilings. Just incredible. Book early!!! At least a week. Although I booked 3 days ahead but they were almost completely sold out.
nice. Nice gallery, well organized ticket service, you can easily overlook the sign for the gallery with the paintings on the second floor.

Interesting museum guided by City Wonders. We booked a City Wonders/Dark Rome tour of the Borghese Gallery. I can recommend them; we've used them several times. The gallery has some wonderful sculptures by Bernini and others, which is what we focused on with the help of our guide.The gallery, I think, limits numbers, so it's not crowded. There is a lot more to see than can be squeezed into a two-hour visit.

A bit of a waste of time and money..... If you genuinely appreciate art then this is the place for you- no question. However if not, then don't waste time booking it, paying for it and travelling to get there. There is so much more in Rome to see that is free and just as interesting. Much of the art, albeit fascinating is very similar to what you can see elsewhere in the city and just as awe inspiring (how this is #10 I do not know!). Sorry art fans!

Sculpture Masterpieces. Borghese highlights the work of Gian Bernini, a master sculptor. The statues of David and Apollo and Daphne are truly great works of art. The David has a fierce look of determination on his face, quite different from the calm and poised David of Michelangelo. The Apollo and Daphne sculpture is sheer beauty.

Book your tickets ahead of time! . The Borghese Gallery is 100% worth the visit! They limit the number of people allowed in the gallery, so you should definitely book your tickets ahead of time, or try to get there right when they open. The sculptures are breathtaking. This was one of my favorite places in Rome!

Most amazing museum in Italy. We travelled to italy this summer and visited several musea, but this one stood out by far. The statues in this museum are absolutely wonderfull. The amazing rooms in which they are placed contribute to the atmosphere. On top of that they have a room with some beautiful Caravaggio paintings.You do have to reserve tickets in advance and pick them up in time but when you visit the galleria it's nice that it's so exclusive because the rooms aren't crowded like Uffuzi or Vatican museum. Villa borghese is located somewhat outside of the city center, but travelling by subway to Spagna and walking the rest is no problem. If you have to wait some time before your time slot, the caffetaria has really good prices! Oh and if you wait till the end of your time slot, almost everyone else has left and you can take your time appreciating the art better.So just visit this! Or you will have really missed one of the best places in Rome...

City Wonders Borghese Gallery Tour: Great!. Earlier this month my wife and I took the City Wonders Borghese Gallery Tour. Two years ago we were in Rome and just could not fit the Borghese Gallery into our schedule….So we were really looking forward to the visit. The whole direct booking thing with the Borghese Gallery seemed a hassle so we opted to book through City Wonders and get a guide to boot. We were not disappointed! Kylie, our guide, was fantastic! The Gallery had gone on strike in the morning of our visit (welcome to Italy) and that afternoon there were almost twice the amount of people as usual in the building. Kyle moved us through avoiding most of the overcrowding. Her knowledge of the works of art and the history of them, the people involved and the building was amazing. She was also amusing and interesting. I teach History and she taught me a thing or two that I can pass on to my students. We loved it!

Amazing Display of Art & Fashion. I was surprised at what I found at this gallery. It's such a unique experience I truly enjoyed it. I found it fascinating the way items were displayed. Pure beauty in my eyes. Do know that you must purchase a ticket ahead of time online. I think it's well worth a visit.

skip it. Unless you are an art aficionado, skip it. Outside of a couple of highlights, I was a bit bored in the museum. If you are looking for a pleasant stroll through a park, the grounds are beautiful.

just the Bernini sculptures are worth the trip. "Opulence" does not even begin to describe the Borghese Gallery and adjacent gardens.In the allowed two hour time blocks (do preorder reservations online), you will have just enough time to see an amazing array of artistry. The most interesting thing, however, is the almost 3D appearance of figures within the ceiling paintings. Of course, the multiple Bernini works add to the pleasure that is this art museum. It also balances out the somewhat repetitive (though still engaging) nature of ruins and churches that stretch out across Rome.The location is not far from Piazza di Spagna and, if you decide to dine in that area, do consider Ciampini Ristorante (look for my review here on Trip Advisor).Sadly, with the temp on our visit day topping 100 F, we did not take time to stroll through the gardens.

Bernini extravaganza!!!. Beautiful intricate Bernini statues. My advice take an audio guide and start on the first floor. Not where the guide says to start. The best stuff is on the first floor. That way if you run out of time, you've seen the best! You have to pre book online. My slot was for 1 - 3pm. They started herding us out at 2:45pm, which was infuriating. Entering at 1:15pm was great because there is a huge line to enter at 1pm and by the time we started the crowd had dispersed throughout the gallery. If you have extra time, this is a great place to visit for art.

Rome July 2015. I prebooked this museum and it was just as well as it was sold out on the day. It is a very small museum, so only a certain number of people are allowed in and you must check in your bag if it is sizeable.I went here the day after the Vatican museums and was more impressed here. I prefer pictures to sculpture and although there is a fair amount of sculpture there are also many paintings shown off in rooms will intricate ceilings and floors.If you only see one museum in Rome you must see this one.

Wonderful!!!. Villa Borghese is home to many wonderful works of art and statues. Some sculptures of Bernini, well known for creating Baroque style sculptures date back to 1618. Some of my favorite pieces were the mosaics on the floor. At a distance they look like fine crafted rugs, but the detail work up close is wonderful. If you enjoy these, make sure you find your way to the National Roman Museum near Termini Station for more beautiful mosaic works of art. But before leaving Villa Borghese, don't forget to look up and enjoy the amazing works of art on the ceiling.Important --- You have to make a reservation in advance for a specific time slot which allows 2 hours in the Villa. Time wise for us, it worked out really well. You are free to spend all day in the gardens, it is just the museum that is time-restricted.

In a city of impressive sights, it still manages to thrill. Aside from the Vatican Museum, i think its the single best art experience in Rome. The building itself is amazing, the picture gallery is jammed full of beautiful surprises, and the statues (esp Bernini) are heart-stopping. The gardens are also lovely. Dont miss it.
Must see. This art collection is amazing. It includes beautiful sculptures and paintings.You need to reserve and buy tickets in advance. The visit is limited to 2 hours only.Highly recommended.

Must-see!. You need to book in advance for this, but you should definitely do so if at all possible. Absolutely beautiful artwork in a beautiful building, and the crowds are much smaller than at the Vatican museum. A bonus is the cafe in the lobby, which was very good, especially for a museum cafe. This is a big win as there is pretty much nowhere else to eat right nearby and you can't be late for your entrance time.Make sure you get the audio guide, it adds a lot to the experience.

Phenomenal collection. Amazing art gallery! We got a bit lost and went to picture gallery first and had little time for sculptures in the 1st floor - which was a mistake. But this gallery is a definite must-do if you are in Rome. Just go to Apollo-Daphne, Bernini's David first. Breathtaking sculptures and it takes time. Since you have only 2 hrs, ensure you see the must-sees as identified in the audio guide. 2 hrs is too short a time to enjoy the collection! Before going,if you are a layman like me, please go through Rick Steve's Art for Travellers to appreciate what you are seeing (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uF4zhg9lkxk). On booking, I have heard you have to book months in advance. Not sure if I was lucky, I was able to book 2 days in advance and able to secure a place.

Sensory Overload!. The Borghese is two floors. Order the audio tour and start on the top floor. Both floors offer not only great art but great ceilings, walls and floors. I have never visited a building where every square inch was art. Tickets are preordered and you get 2 hours. Not to be missed!

beyond words!. this museum was the most amazing place in all of Rome for us and it is most unfortunate that the time is restricted to only 2 hours per visit since it was barely enough to really experience it fully but be sure to take some extra time before or after for a walk through the park, it is worth it!

another must do. This is noted as a "must do" when in Rome. The gallery is loaded with precious works of art (paintings and sculpture) created by Canova and Caravaggio and Bernini. Take an audio guide. Too much to see at once, it is an overload. The rooms are gorgeous even without the works of art. Of course you will appreciate the all star team of David, Apollo and Daphne. Do some research before you go. Purchase tickets on-line before you go. PLAN AHEAD. This 1612 villa was never used as a residence but made for the exhibition of the accumulated art. Go first thing in the morning before the heat of the day seeps in. Have fun.
Beautiful but small. Very beautiful gardens and gallery. Though very small and repetitive. I guess im comparing with the louvre which is on a much larger scale and with a lot of variety.
Beautifull place. Great museum,wonderful work.A lovely collection in a beautiful villa and big enough to be satisfied.Purchase tickets in advance!.

Amazingly beautiful statues- Bernini, Canova- beautiful paintings by great artists.. The statues are amazing both in their beauty and in the number of such great art works in one gallery. The gallery also has many lovely paintings by great and well-known artists. This is a truly great gallery and well worth visiting. It is a gallery where you need to book in advance and you can book and get tickets sent to your home address if you want, though there is a charge for this. I thought it worth the charge to have the tickets in hand and be able to go in. You can book tickets through here:http://www.tosc.it/tickets.htm?affiliate=T2C&sort_by=event_datum&sort_direction=asc&fun=erdetail&doc=erdetaila&erid=912678&language=enThis is not a cheap gallery but it is easily worth the money you pay for your two hours of entry time. Two hours is also enough to get through the gallery, although I would like to go back to have more time to appreciate better what is there. Photos were allowed. The reason for pre-booking is to limit the numbers in the gallery and they do this enough so that you can get photos without people of most major items if you wait just a little. The rooms themselves are also fabulous, with ornate beautiful painted ceilings and lovely marble floors and walls.

villa borghese. in a beautiful park there is near the zoo .the borghese villa with its astonishing statues and its worth a visit inside the gallery.the park its huge and you have a fine view of the city of rome.one of the best spot in top ten visit spots in rome
Get your tickets in advance.. I did not get to visit here. We visited on a Monday and the next available ticket was Saturday. Very disappointed. So please learn from my mistake.
Outstanding!. One of the best art galleries / museums I have ever been in my life! Amazing art pieces! Totally recommend, but if you really plan to visit, make sure you reserve your time slot online.

Lovely Gallery--bonus the Couture Collection is now showing. We have been to Roma a few times. This is the first time we went to Borghese Gallery. The Gallery is just lovely. There are quite a few stairs so be aware of that. There is a lift if needed. This time of year they had the Couture Collection- Italian designer prototype gowns matched with each of the rooms and themes. Just stunning. Please book early-the admissions are limited to a certain number of people at certain times of the day. In the summer please book the earliest timeslot available. Don't forget the Borghese Gardens that surround the Gallery. It is a mini version of Central Park in N.Y. A must for your visit to Roma.

Magnificent. The Borghese Museum was one of the highlights of our 5 day trip to Rome. We hired the audio tour for €5. It was well worth every cent. Gave us quite a detailed history of most of the major pieces and of the family 'Borghese'.When comparing it to the Vatican Museum..... It is far more impressive, except that the Vatican has more pieces.I would visit it again and again and still find it fascinating. The flow through the different rooms, appears to work very well.The only downside for me was, I wanted to stay longer than my allotted time but had leave, in order to allow others to visit.

Wonderful collection and condition. This gallery, set in beautiful grounds, houses two floors of fantastic works in immaculate condition. In addition to the amazing collection of paintings and sculptures, the gallery itself is a treat, each ceiling a work of art in it's own right.Be sure to book in advance. The one warning I do have is that viewing times are strictly enforced, and at the end of each block, visitors are hurried out so the next can begin. You will have enough time to view the entire museum, just not to linger too long. The upside of this is that even in peak season, this was one of the few attractions that wasn't completely overcrowded.

Breathtaking museum!. This was our favorite museum by far in our recent trip to Rome. The fact that they limit the number of guests who can visit at a time is part of the pleasure of the place. We reserved online ahead of time and it was easy to pick up tickets at the start of the visit. We also used the audio guide and would recommend it. Be careful not to spend all your time on the first floor, as your 2 hours will pass quickly and they begin to ask people to leave after 1 hour and 45 minutes. We hardly had time to see the paintings in the last few rooms. The sculptures are very accessible in the middle of the rooms, so you can see them from all sides. The surrounding park is a bonus!

My favorite!. The Borghese gallery was my favorite of all the art related attractions I saw in Rome. You absolutely MUST book your tickets in advance and I highly recommend heading upstairs to see the paintings first, then go back down and really see the first floor sculptures in a leisurely way. The works in this place are incredible but the estate itself rivals those works. We had seen the Donatello and Michaelangelo David's in Florence but Bernini's masterpiece was our favorite! Capturing motion and concentration in marble...it was stupendous! The Borghese is well-organized and fascinating. Highly recommended!

Astonishing interior and collection. Definitely worth visiting even if you are not an expert in visual arts and sculpture. You will be walking from hall to hall with your mouth open.Bernini's statues impressed us the most of all!You must buy your tickets online as the entry is strictly at specified hours. Only 200 people can visit the gallery at a time during 2 hours.

July 2015. This gallery was truly spectacular and stands as one of the most underrated attractions in all of Italy. One caveat, do not buy the audio tour. It is incredibly difficult to follow. Either go without it or go with a group tour.

This is a ten star attraction!. The Gallery Borghese is by far one of the most beautiful specialized galleries in the world. We love the work of Bernini and the gallery probably has the vastest collection of the artist's work. It is worth buying the entry tickets well in advance because it might be difficult to visit otherwise. There are long lines, even when you have a ticket and the security in the building is intense.

Nice and amazing park surrounding. Had a nice visit.Enjoyed the fashion exhibit mixed in with the museum items.Really enjoyed the surrounding park and walk into the area.Give yourself plenty of time to walk around before and after.Nice gift shop too!

Stunning collection, but make sure you book your tickets in advance.. Tickets are almost impossible to get once in Rome. Luckily I reserved ours a couple of weeks in advance. There was a sign outside the day we visited advised no tickets till May 7th, (this was April 27th). The reason for this is they restrict the number of people in the galleries in 2 hourly slots. That way it is never crowded and you can stand and admire the art, statues and furnishings without being caught in a steady flow of tourists. The contents of the Villa are outstanding! And the painted ceilings are simply stunning. Use the audio guide to fully appreciate it. Outside the parkland is a quiet oasis in a bustling city. Families were hiring bicycles and touring the wide avenues,others picnicking, there is a special area for roller blades showing off their skills and a couple of Mini-trains traversing the huge park if you get too tired. A wonderful place to visit.

Amazing sculptures but the staff were rather snotty. If you are a Bernini fan, do not miss this gallery! Love the intimate experience with all its various artwork but the overall atmosphere (treatment) by the staff was rather disappointing. How can I put it.... the museum felt rather snotty and unwelcoming. Nevertheless, they have a great collection especially Bernini's sculptures.

A Great Collection of Art. The artwork in this Galleria are amazing. Some are actually in better shape than those in the Vatican. Make sure you book your tickets ahead. You are expected to arrive 40 minutes before your ticket times. We did that, and it paid off. When we got there, they were booking tickets for 3 days after already.
