Keep your reservation number ready when you arrive. The signage for the Galleria itself from the Spagna metro station is not the easiest to decipher. The Galleria is far into the Villa Borghese park, so give yourselves plenty of time to get to the actual gallery to pick up your tickets. You can use your Roma pass for this gallery as the first visit for free or to get a reduced price.

Beautiful sculpture collection. The Borghese Gallery is a lovely museum when you want to get away from the crowds. You'll need to preorder tickets online since there's a timed entry, for 2 hour time slots. Because entry is timed, it's not so crowded and you'll be better able to see the exhibits. Upon entry, you'll need to check your bags at the desk. This service is free and you'll be given a key. We paid for the audio guide and thought it was very helpful. The museums is filled with beautiful Bernini sculptures and other masterpieces and worth visiting.

Absolutely astonishing!. It shows art at its best; recommendable for all baroque and classical artfans. Try to read something about the sculptures myths and bernini, it will make your visit much more interesting.

My favourite museum in Rome. A little jewel of enchanting beauty inside one of the green heart of Rome. An amazing Villa surrounded by Italian gardens, an orangerie and a public park is the site of my favourite museum in the city. Inside the elegant location you could be captured by the beauty of each single piece of the collection, from Caravaggio to Tiziano paintings to the amazing statues of Bernini and Canova.There is just an issue: you have to book your visit in advance, but it is totally recommended. Do not miss it!

I love this place!. Galleria Borghese is an Unique place, you must go! You need to book but you don't need to pay in advance, you go there half hour before and you pay. There is a huge collection of Bernini's sculptures and also some Caravaggio's paintings. Go there and then you will send amazing feedback!

Beatiful art muesum in Rome. Beautiful art museum in Rome. We walked around the muesum on our own- I think we would have appreciated it more had we gone on a tour or rented an audio guide. Reservations are necessary. We had a hard time finding the museum once we were in the park. You may want to have clear directions before you go.

Great Building and contents!! Staff is unhappy, bring your own toilet seats.. Only place in Rome where we found rude people during 2 weeks. The Building itself and its contents are really great. We really enjoyed them.There were some intangibles however- in no particular order:- we had a 1:00 entry time and we got there at 12:40 and asked if we could go in. Firm no . Maybe they close for lunch? Off topic: a VW dealer in my town used to close for lunch- they went bankrupt. Picasso Museum in Barcelona said no problem in a similar situation. So we went back outside. At 1245 a crowd formed at the top level steps where earlier people had been going in and out but now there was an iron bar gate closed. people in the crowd started yelling loudly to someone inside who would only yell back, not come into view at the gate (why not come to the gate and explain?), After about 10 minutes of this and continued yelling back and forth they stuck out an old looking sign that said enter on the first level so the crowd moved there and waited til 1:00. Why no sign earlier?- Just before this we went in the cafe which seemed staffed with rushed abrupt almost unfriendly staff.(My opinion)- when we went in at 1:00 we went in a second or 3rd floor room, and got confused using the audio guide. A nice attendant came over and asked if she could help- I said yes we cant find the numbers in this room (numbers for the audio guide keys) She looked around the room and said yes some are missing, she told us what the numbers were, I thought why not get an index card and tape on some numbers until the permanent ones are replaced?- air conditioning- A very hot day and I though the AC was doing fine, they had many portable dehumidifiers in use and two mecahnics working on one wall AC unit. one of the floors either 2nd or 3rd when you entered seemed very humid. when we went over to the far side the attendant had two 7 ft high windows fronting on the garden fully open, with a 10 mile per hour breeze blowing in, 15 minutes of that and the Air cond will take hours to catch up.- they have toilets off the main stair well and I went in to use them, mans side. Clean and neat but no toilet seat, just the china rim of the bow, They had a toilet paper roll so I guess they wanted you to sit on the bowl. I did not need to do anything serious , just thought it odd, maybe broken seat on the mens side- I asked my wife who said the womens side was the same - no toilet seat. All the Rome restaurants seemed to have toilet seats. Maybe it was a turkish influence aka pit toilets. A guide at the coloseum I asked thought it might be to save money on cleaning it. ??!! Learn to squat or bring your own seat.- near the end my audio guide locked up and I went downstairs to exchange it, going out the entrance I said "my audio guide is broken I want to exchange it", the woman said you only have 30 more minutes, I took that to mean why bother just stay out, but I went over and exchanged it, the attendant tossed it in a pile of 15 other ones to be reissued.- about 15 minutes before the 2 hours end time shown on the ticket (you are only allowed in for 2 hours, they started making announcement to leave. At that time they were only a few people left. I asked an attendant on the way out why they run all the people out when only a few are left, she said for security reasons, I asked what security reasons then she says because of insurance rules. ??

Amazing History In A time Capsule. NEVER have I had an experience like visiting the Borghese Gallery. Better than a great art museum, in my opinion, The Borghese is the story of a family of collectors and fascinating characters.Entrance is by ticket on a timed tour and well worth the effort to secure them. I can't imagine touring this gallery amid a crush of tourists. With limited access, it is possible to view the individual works in a close and very personal way. The mosaics, the Greek and Roman sculptures and the paintings speak of a highly personal taste.The highlight of the Borghese collection has to be the amazing statues created by Bernini. These statues are so fragile that they do not travel. I had difficulty understanding why until I stood before his sculpture of Apollo and Daphne, looking at light filtering through delicately carved leaves, or looking up at Pluto's hand pressing against the soft flesh of Proserpina's thigh. His interpretation of David, readying his sling to use against Goliath. Not the standard David, the perfection of manhood, Bernini's statue is of a small young man with an expression on his face that displays the variety of emotions that would obviously transform him, rather than the passive gaze of Michelangelo's more famous sculpture.And then there is Canova's noted sculpture of Pauline Bonaparte Borghese, another famous occupant of this beautiful villa in Rome. Stunning.

Can't miss experience !. Borghese Gallery tour is truly a cannot miss experience. Our guide (Rebecca) is a art educated guru and an expert on the pieces in this gallery.There are 4 Bernini's to see; totally awesome.My wife was not real sure about this tour but I wanted to go. Her opinion changed to "it was the best tour other than the Vatican".

Outstanding collection of sculpture and art. This gallery is the ultimate experience for an art lover. The museum itself is a glorious palace which enhances the viewing of amazing marble sculptures. You must get advance tickets, which will give you exactly 2 hrs of time in the gallery. Be sure you know how to get there so you don't miss your entrance time! It is a LONG walk through the park to the gallery and signage is not great for directions. You get a close up view of these incredible pieces of art which you will remember forever. I read that no photos were allowed, but indeed they allow photos (no flash) all over the gallery.

Really is a must see. I was so blown away by this lovely museum and its collection of stunning works. There are so many masterpieces that leave you speechless. Bernini truly was a genius. Do yourself a favour, book early and make this a must see on your trip to Rome.

A gallery in Rome you should not miss. If you have time to go to one gallery in Rome, make it the Borghese Gallery. It's a small, manageable museum with the most amazing artwork situated in a lovely, sprawling park. I suggest arriving 30-45 minutes before your booked slot so you have enough time to pick-up your tickets, explore the garden and take pictures, deposit your things in their locker and pick-up an audioguide. Their audioguide is excellent, you don't need to book a guide for this visit. You only have two hours but for us this was enough. Once inside, proceed to the second floor first while the rest of your party crowds the first floor so there will be less crowds when it's your turn to visit the first floor. I like that there is an effort to control the number of people so you can appreciate the art more. It's always pleasing to see artwork in its natural habitat in contrast to the curated work in other museums. There are a number of exquisite art work here but my favorites were the sculptures of Bernini. I marveled at the details, tension and movement in his work. As you go around the sculpture of Apollo and Daphne, you can see the story unfold as Daphne turns into a tree. In Pluto and Proserpina, you can see the indentation created by Pluto's fingers in Proserpina's marble thighs and the tears and anguish on her face. All in marble. Unbelievable. Go!

Spectacular. Unlike some other sites in Rome, it was very easy to order tickets online. The gallery collection is fantastic and the chance to explore the magnificent gardens make for a great day! Take your time at Villa Borghese!

Beautiful despite rude staff. My favorite art museum in Rome. The paintings and sculptures inside are really tremendous, very similar to what you might find in the Louvre or Guggeinheim. Despite booking ahead, the museum was still somewhat inconvenient. We had 11am tickets, but apparently the staff was on strike until 3pm (typical Italians). When we returned at 3pm, we attempted to enter before being told we had to check our water bottle and my wife's small purse. There was another ridiculous line to check these small items. Overall, it was worth the inconvenience though.

Great art musem. The Borghese Gallery has some of the best pieces of art in the world. We enjoyed the picture gallery as well as all the Bernini sculptures. If you are looking for one art museum in Rome to see this would be my choice. In a city of amazing museums this is one of the best. Walk through the park to get here if you want an even more enjoyable time.
Worth the visit!. Borghese Gallery Museum is worth a visit! Great history, stunning statues, and impressive paintings. Go! (ENJOY the air conditioning in summer! Might be the COOLEST place in Rome!)

Favorite Site in Rome. First, buy your tickets online and book a time. Tickets are picked up in the basement but you enter up the stairs, outside directly above where you got your tickets. Having said that, this was our favorite stop in Rome. It's small which means it's up close and intimate and since you only get two hours you don't burn out like the Vatican Museum. The collection is outstanding and we spent barely 90 minutes. We never felt rushed nor was it crowded. We went early and it felt like we had the whole place to ourselves. This was truly a highlight and our favorite outing in Rome.

Wonderful Museums. Had a private guide for the museum and it was well worth it. Beautiful art in a fabulous area! They have an amazing collection at the Gallery. The gardens surrounding the Borghese Gallery are beautiful. I highly recommend you visit the Borghese Gallery!

Worth the visit!. As this was my second visit to Rome I cannot believe that I didn't visit before. It is essential to book in advance but this can be done at the museum with 1/2 days notice if you find the on-line booking system daunting. We were lucky enough to be able to walk to the museum through the park which was an enjoyable experience in itself and the sight of parakeets flying around was slightly surreal! The Bernini sculptures were amazing and it was incredible to think that they started life as chunks of marble. Some of the paintings on the upper floor were interesting but I'm afraid I found the views out of the windows and the highly decorative fireplaces in the rooms more worthy of my photographic talents!

The Museum is great, but. . . .. It's a bit of a hassle all-around. First, you must book in advance. When we were there on July 8th, there was a sign that the next tickets were for July 11th. So don't turn up in high season without a reservation. Second, as others have said, you cannot bring ANY bag, no matter how small, into the museum, so you must check it all (no fee). They have small plastic bags for your valuables, which you need not check. That being said, the museum is a small gem. The art, of course, is amazing, but I found the building itself to be even more amazing. The ceilings alone are mesmerizing. My kids (13 and 10) didn't mind the museum at all, and in fact enjoyed the fact that there were plenty of places to sit down in each room and gaze around. If you're going with kids, you may not even need the full two hours allotted by your tickets.
Borghese Gallery. ...a totally amazing experience!...a must for anyone visiting Rome if you only have three or or four days in this enchanting city...do book ahead...I'm glad we did...

Brace yourself for the Appallingly Unhelpful Staff!!!. The Bernini sculptures are truly sublime. It's so awe-inspiring that over 400 years ago, this talented genius produced works that we can still gaze upon today.BIG TIP: when you enter the gallery, immediately turn left and start your visit in the opposite direction to 99% of the other visitors. You see everything, but get to have a significant portion of the ground floor without crowds. As noted by others, you must book, you can't take bags etc into the gallery (I was given a plastic bag for my wallet and camera) and nobody is willing to help you. The cafe is pretty average and the toilets were too.BUT if you're a lover of art and sculpture, book before you leave home, print out your confirmation, arrive half an hour before your visit to collect your ticket and smile sweetly at the rude staff... It's worth it! And then have lunch at the cafe in the Gallerie of Modern Art 10 minutes walk down the road... their service is top-notch.

Don't miss this beautiful museum!. Such a beautiful museum & grounds. I agree with other reviewers about doing a bit of planning ahead of time to book your tickets. Also read up a bit on the museum so you have time to visit the artists on your must see list. The first time I went years ago was on my own, second time was with a tour group which was easier. Tickets were purchased ahead of time by the company and we did not have to wait in lines and it was a guided tour. Also the fall is a wonderful time to travel to Italy or Europe. The weather is still beautiful and not nearly as crowded.

Bella Borghese!. This is one of the greatest art collections I've ever seen. The gallery itself is a wonderful piece of art and architecture. Fantastic sculptures from ancient times and from the Renaissance, and perhaps the single best and most diverse collection of Renaissance artists anywhere. I especially like the Caravaggios. You need to reserve your tickets in advance on line, although we got lucky and were able to walk up and purchase tickets that had been cancelled. Get there 45 minutes early to check your bags. Better yet, arrive at Villa Borghese 2 hours ahead of your gallery tour and enjoy a walk in the park. The audio guide is definitely worth the 5 euros. Tall winding staircase to get to second level - not sure if there is an elevator. Thank you, Scipione Borghese (and the Italian government), for collecting and preserving these great works of art!

MUST SEE IN ROMA. If you don't have time to do anything else in Roma, take 2 hours to see Borghese Gallery. It houses amazing masterpieces by Renaissance masters. The house/gallery itself is a work of art and will not disappoint. You are only allowed into this place in 2 hour slots. You cannot enter without prior reservations and you can choose your view time slot. But beware, this place sells out quickly. I booked mine about 6 weeks before our visit and could barely find slots that would work for us. This will be on our list for future Roma visits!

A spectacular museum. This is one of our favorite places in Rome. The limited number of people in at any time give you some unusual space compared to the rest of Rome. The statures are simply astounding, and you get to walk up right to them. Most definitely worth the trip.

Excellent museum to visit while in Rome yet avoid the mobs of tourists. Must book your tickets online, no same day sales on site. Get there 15 mins early. You will have only 1 hour to see the 3 floor place so plan your time accordingly. Obviously Bernini's passionate sculptures are the focus here but there are other valuable artworks to enjoy. Better to go in the morning and stroll in the park while you wait or afterwards. Can buy snacks & even wine at some vendors within the park to have a small picnic while there. Other very good museums are in the area, consider the House of Pietro Canonica nearby which is free and quite interesting especially if you like historical sculptures.

Amazing if You Appreciate Art. Our travel agent arranged for an English-speaking guide with an art-history background to meet us at our hotel and take us on a two-hour tour of the Borghese. You have to pre-purchase your tickets, and I suggest that you purchase them well in advance of your trip to Rome.The gallery is housed in this gorgeous villa in a beautiful park, similar to Central Park in NY (although on a slightly smaller scale). The villa itself is worthy of a visit, even without the artwork.And, the art is AMAZING. Filled with some of the most important pieces of the early period, we were particularly amazed by Bernini sculptures and the Caravaggio paintings. I would note that you would likely be lost in this museum without a guide. Our guide was able to point us to the highlights (and details) that we would have surely missed had we gone without her.

An absolute must visit. We took the bus there from the centre which ended right outside. Luckily we bought tickets in advance. Those who hadn't found they could purchase for the next day. Terrific exhibition and a lovely house to visit.
incredible museum. incredible museum in a nice environment, specially see the Paulina Borghese statue and the paintings

Worth the visit. Recommend getting the tour instead of the audio tour. It is only a small difference in price and worth being able to ask questions to an actual guide. Definitely need to make reservations for your visit and arrive early. You are only allowed in the museum during your designated time period.

Amazing, when in Rome, don't miss it!!. We have been to Rome twice, and gone to Borghese both times. The Bernini's are stunning! I find myself mesmerized by the beautiful pieces! Book in advance, show up on time, you usually have a time range to enter. They have lockers to store your things, and a snack shop as well. You can see it in a few hours, depending on your admiration of the pieces. The first time we went photography was not allowed, but this last time it was! The grounds are lovely as well. Enjoy Enjoy Enjoy!!!

Well worth the advance booking!!. We loved this!!! We had to book 4 days in advance as there are only limited people allowed through at a time for a 2 hour gap - when we arrived for our time slot we noted it had sold out for 5 days after, you MUST pre book! But totally worth it!! Beautiful architecture as well as the sculptures and paintings themselves, we found the audio guide although a little too in depth for us but still worth it! They were setting up for the Alaïa sculpture/fashion exhibition running until October which would be lovely too!

Relaxing retreat from the heat. The gallery is wonderful, even for an art layman like me. I found the sculptures of Bernini to be my favorite, however, there is a little bit of everything in there. I highly recommend joining a tour as they will furnish you with earbuds where you can hear the tour guide even if you get distracted and wander a little :) Most people, myself included, do not know the details associated with each piece; this is where your tour guide will shine, creating an experience that you would not have had otherwise.Although it says August, this review is actually from June 2014.

gem away from the crowds. We loved this beautiful collection of Bernini sculptures, great audiophone tour (much better than most), and well-run museum. the staggered entries are a good solution, making it possible to plan your day and keeping the crowds from getting to the point where nothing can be viewed or contemplated. nice little cafe, great walk through the park, one of the best things to do in Rome!
Stunning Bernini's work. A must see in Rome. Should never be missed. Get the guided tour. After one sees Bernini's works in Borghese Gallery, he/she will never be interested in it's replicas.

Charming and Elegant Inside - A Must See!. We visited on a Sunday at 1pm with reserved tickets. We arrived early so we took a stroll of the gardens and even grabbed a bite to eat at small coffee shop near by. When we entered the Borghese Gallery it was very confusing where to go to collect our reserved ticket and they do not allow you to take your purse in, you are required to leave it at a storage for bags/purses/personal items in exchange for a ticket with a number to retrieve your bag at the end of your visit. Although you are allowed to take your phone and take pictures inside. The staff here is nt very friendly, not willing to help and not eager to please guests! After a very confusing entrance and getting a little bit aggravated we finally entered the museum and it was charming and elegant with lots of beautiful art work from the ceiling to the floor. It was definitely worth seeing and I would recommend. The gardens outside were just ok....

Good, but also grates.. The Borghese Gallery is, we're led to believe, something special. So special that there is a limit to the number of people that can go there, and a limit to the time they can spend there. Given horrific experiences in places like the Palace of Versailles, this sounds like a terrific idea. Too bad it feels like you're being treated like a nuisance - and too bad the crowds to get in and around the gallery's rooms, which are sometimes quite cramped, don't seem to reflect the limits. That said, the collection is in places excellent. As my diary of the event says, "the gallery includes a goodly number of artists, including our old friends Bronzino, Raffaello, Botticelli, Del Sarto, Bartolomeo, Carreggio, Parmigianino, Carracci and Veronese. But as usual it's the sculptures, especially Bernini and Canova, that steal the show. Canova's 'Paolina Borghese Bonaparte' reclining on an amazingly life-like mattress is sublime, and Berninini's 'David' is also spectacular.'So where's the grate from the title? The fact that there is, on a balcony tucked out of the way, a piece of marble carved at the behest of the original owner, that says, in part: 'Go wherever you want to, ask for whatever you desire, leave whenever you wish...the owner forbids the imposition of rigid rules.'Try trotting that one out when you're being unceremoniously booted out because your allotted two hours are up.

Borghese Gallery and Park. A beautiful gallery in the heart of Rome with a fabulous park to wander through. The interior of this once private family art gallery is spectacular with gorgeous ceilings and amazing painting and sculptures.
Take a guided tour to fully appreciate its marvels.

Great museum. It was a very busy and a bit confusing at the entrance. We bought tickets in advance thank goodness because they were sold out for several more days! The walk through the park to the museum was lovely and the museum itself was very interesting with lots of great sculptures. The cafe inside is minimal. The audio guide was good and a must for the descriptions

Beautiful not to miss gallery in Rome. The Borghese Gallery is one of the best galleries we visited. It is located in a nice park, and a number of fountains, perfect to relax. The gallery is splendid. We took the audio guide and this really upgraded our visit. For two hours (the time limit of 2h is enforced), which go by pretty fast, we viewed and learned about the amazing collection displayed at this gallery, from sculptures, to paintings and ceiling fresco. I think it is a must when visiting Rome. Book in advance.

An excellent way to wile away your day.. If I had to do this over again, I would have packed a picnic beforehand for the park surrounding this place. Then I would have gone in to see the gallery. I would do it the other way around if the place held my picnic basket for us. They do take your bags and hold them for you. Definitely get the audio recording. Makes it a whole lot more interesting. My favorite was hearing the story surrounding some of the statues like Pauline Bonaparte and of Prosperina being abducted by Pluto. The Bonaparte marble looks like a real bed or wrinkled cloth that she's reclining on. We couldn't stop looking at it. I do wish, however, that there was more audio for more of the paintings, which were fascinating. I wanted to know the stories behind those, too. I am planning on going through the internet and reading up on some of them. There's nothing like seeing these figures in person though. Do book in advance and don't show up too early because they won't let you in. You may go downstairs to check in your bags and lounge around for awhile, but trying to enter the galleria itself won't be permitted. After the galleria (about an hour at the most), walk throughout the park. We discovered a large pond with a Greek-like statue setting in the center and people rowing about. We also wish we would have rented one of the those multi-person's bike to traipse around in the park. They had four people sitting in this buggy-like thing, pedaling, relaxing and enjoying themselves.

Worth Our Time!. We just visited yesterday, which was Sunday, while on a walk from our hotel (Victoria). After a pleasant walk through the park, we went into the basement entry, saw a sign saying that tickets were sold out, and approached the person at the desk for tickets for the next day. He said we could buy the tickets OR we could just go in as it was a free entry day! Fabulous collection. Be sure to stop at the desk across from the food and get headphones for 5€, and give yourself a proper tour.

Well worth the visit - get organised with your tickets in advance.. It was very confusing when we arrived. Signage is not clear. We had tickets booked but we found ourselves on a couple of lines we didn't need to have been on but nothing clearly telling you where to go to meet tour guides. If you book a tour be sure to get very clear directions where to meet the guide.

Beautiful inside, shabby outside. We had an initial let down before we got inside, the gardens and the exterior of the building were not well kept. and it wasn't even clear which door was the entrance.The Lady at the baggage check was very rude with everybody and it was the beginning of the day.They don't allow you to take even a small purse so take out your wallet or important documents before you get there . The art and audio tour were nice , but not enough to be treated like that.

Nice setting in a busy city. We toured the Borghese based on recommendations from a travel agent. It is definitely a beautiful villa with an outstanding art collection. However, signage to find the gallery in the large park was nowhere to be found, so we ended up walking around the entire park before we found it - frustrating on such a hot day with 3 teenagers. While the art collection is beautiful, but unlike the Uffizi and Accademia in Florence, there are no descriptions that you can read while viewing the items. After touring the gallery, we sat for a while in the beautiful garden setting which was very nice. All in all a beautiful place, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you buy the audio tour.
beautiful!. A beautiful museum with a gorgeous collection of paintings and sculptures. You must order tickets in advance a few days before your visit!

A beautiful museum that even a non-art lover will appreciate.. This is a very busy museum. Reservations must be made in advance. I highly recommend you get the audio tour so that you can appreciate the history behind the pieces. Once you arrive on time and put your earphones on, you will experience a very very interesting tour of both artistic and historical value. Everything is intricately designed from the floors to the murals on the ceiling. There are incredible sculptures and paintings, and the audio tour colors in the story of each painting and makes it extremely interesting even for non-art lovers.

"My third visit and counting". You cannot possibly see everything in this place in one visit - it is truly a treasure trove! The floor is art , the walls are covered with art ,the ceiling is art- everything is art. Built to show off the art belonging to the Borghese family , this place has still got IT ! You feel like you are in the country and its a nice walk through the park back to the hustle and bustle of Rome. Tip book ahead and choose the time that suits you.

Art History 101. Beautiful palace with fantastic art that you studied if you took art history. The Palace was awesome, and the ceilings were beautiful. The site has an excellent cafeteria that is very reasonable. The park around it is relaxing, and it was fun to walk around it.
Stunning Sculptures A Must See. We spent a few hours at this gallery which is set in a lovely park area.Worth paying to see the wonderful sculptures within

Fabiulious. Amazing villa that is a must to see. Apart that it is in a very nice garden. To visit this place, you have to book online several weeks before. Without pre booking it's impossible to get inside, as it is always fully booked.

Beautiful Art. After many visits to Rome, we finally visited Borghese Gallery and Gardens, and we were not disappointed at all. We hired a guide who expertly taught us about the statues and Art in the Gallery, bringing each alive with stories and historical references, What a beautiful gallery this is, its close to the Spanish steps and easy to walk to from anywhere in Rome. I was totally impressed with the quality of work at the gallery, the Rape of the Sabine Woman is an amazing piece that should be viewed and photographed from every angle, its amazing to behold. There are several incredible statues in the Gallery, each a masterpiece in and of itself! The Gardens are not quite up to par, apparently they do not spend much money keeping the gardens up and it shows. Save you energy for the Gallery and enjoy the gardens as you come and go, not a destination in and of itself!

Worth visiting. Situated in the Borghese Gardens this gallery was worth visiting. You must prebook on the Internet. At least in June 2015 this was required. Not sure if this applies all year round. You get a 2 hour window to peruse the gallery eg 9-11, 11-1 etc. This helps them control crowds. There are some fantastic sculptures to see as well as other art. It wasn't too crowded and a pleasant thing to do. The surrounding gardens provide shade to rest from June heat and to watch the world go by! Highly recommend as a break from June Rome crowds and heat!

A place for art. This beautiful palace hosts some very interesting paintings and sculptures of Italian and other famous artists of the Renaissance. You should visit it to have taste of Italy's rich artistic heritage.

Worth visiting but need booking. don't book your ticket for the 3 to 5 pm timesheduling, you won't have time to see allget a good map or you will wander quite a bit in the big park before to find the museum

Just an average attraction. Enjoyed the visit..but quite a walk to get there from either the train or the bus. This home was Cardinal Borghese's 'party' house. He never really put any great treasures here and what;s on exhibit pretty well confirms that. Lots of mediocre paintings and sculptures on exhibit. A couple hours or less is all you'll need,

One of the best art collections in Rome, which is saying something. Summary: The Borghese family collection of paintings and sculpture rivals that of the best museums, all in the setting of their gorgeous garden villa.The great:- An entire wall of Raphael, wall of Tizian, room of Caravaggio, and room of Garofalo- Many of the downstairs rooms were finished specifically to house the Bernini sculptures at their centers, which allows them to be seen from all angles- Nearly every piece in this gallery is a masterpiece - The layout is inviting with large rooms, mostly well-lit- Take a chance to explore the frescoes on ceilings if you have time. Some by Lanfranco are as good as exceptional as the paintings hanging on the walls.- Best spent 11 euros ever; Relatively inexpensive for museums in RomeGood to know:- It's worth knowing what you're looking at here: The Borghese Gallery guide is phenomenal with beautiful color photos and explanations for each item in the collection. As an alternative, read Rick Steves' summary or Wikipedia it!- You MUST reserve ahead unless you get super lucky and are there when a tour begins and somebody with a reservation did not show. Book online or by phone.- Entrance to pick up tickets is at the center/front of the building underneath the staircase.- You must pick up your reserved tickets ahead of time. Come 15-30 mins early.- You will be asked to check in large items, including most purses.- Photography is permitted, so do not check your camera/ phone with your bag- Viewing time is strictly limited to 2h. You will be kicked out when that time ends.- You will not have time to see everything, so be wise with your time (or reserve a 2nd...or 3rd...or nth visit)-Downstairs is mostly sculpture, both Baroque and ancient-Upstairs is mostly paintings and frescoes; This is also the best place to start because the crowd generally flows in the opposite direction- There is a huge staircase to 2nd floor and no lift in sight.- There is a cafe at the entrance, but you will not be allowed to bring any liquids into the gallery with you.

Great visit. I love all the art. Statues and paintings were extensive. My teenage son enjoyed the visit. Wear your sneakers a lot of walking and to get to the top floor you have to climb stairs. Very nice garden in the back.

Beautiful!. This villa houses some amazingly beautiful art, both paintings and statues. Although it says in the guide books that you are not allowed to take pictures, everybody brings in their cameras and takes pictures (which I had!). You are required to check your bags before entering, even small bags. Definitely book your entrance tickets in advance. We spent a few hours wandering through the park before it was our time slot to enter the Villa, as the park is also beautiful and well worth visiting.

Simply wonderful. Imagine visiting that rich aunt with a private art collection you can't imagine getting to see. Well, if your aunt has the last name of Borghese and you buy your tickets on-line prior to arriving, you too, can see an impressive array of artwork in an intimate environment with about 40 total strangers. Hey, it beats the Vatican Museum where it's thousands of strangers!

Must see in Rome. This museum has a very nice collection of sculptures! My family was impressed and we enjoyed this much more than the Sistine chapel which was extremely crowded and not enjoyable at all.

Must see museum. The three life-sized Baroque marble sculptures by Italian artist Gian Lorenzo Bernini alone are worth the trip. Not to mention the Caravaggio, Titian, Raphael, etc... They have to be seen in person to fully appreciate the artistry and workmanship.

Galleria Borghese - a stunning collection but you must prebook!. After reading on TA the necessity to prebook for the Galleria Borghese, I followed that advice and am so glad that I did. There is no way that you can just arrive on the day, they are booked up days ahead. You book for a timed entry slot and they are strict in limiting the numbers and keeping to the alloted times.The gallery itself is stunning, I so enjoyed the allocated two hours there. The collection of artworks, paintings and sculpture is quite mind blowing and the rooms where the art is displayed are works of art in themselves. You really do need an audio guide to get the maximum out of the visit. Even in a place like Rome where every corner has a feast for the eyes, this gallery stands out.The Gallery is set inside the Villa Borghese which is a nice park with various things to do. We had a picnic before our timed entry and it was very pleasant. There is a cafe inside the gallery and a small shop. The cafe staff seemed less than helpful but that was a minor thing overall.Highly recommended.

Mind blowing and head turning!. A definite "must see" when in Rome. One of the highlights of our trip...unlike other museums and galleries that tend to be crowded and claustrophobic, G Borghese is a true jewel of an experience that one can savour. Filled with delights yet not "never ending" so the collections on display are a delectible sight in a superb location.

the main objective for me is to allow other people coming to the Abruzzo region of Italy to sample some of the wonderful. A hidden gem is to be found in a small village called OFENA, in the Abruzzo... the region of L'Aquila offers many places yet to be found but this particular albergo, restaurant is called VILLA VERONICA.I first found the place after it was renovated and much improved, by Signora ANTOINETTA and her husband Sig. SPARTACO.The bedrooms are furnished suitably and each has an ensuite bathroom.. the daily rate per person is 30 euros and one can be well satisfied with the breakfast.While I have not stayed in the albergo, the restaurant is my favorite.. .the food is great, cooked by Signora Antoinetta and her team of family members.Sig. Spartaco is a superb host and it is rewarding to see that through the years those young men who went to the United States, Canada and other countries so many years ago after the war, that their grandchildren are returning to °find their roots° and so one hear U.S. speaking guests continually at VILLA VERONICA.. My favorite.The menu runs from euros 15 to 25 per person.The telephone number is : 0039 271212285 and the email address is:s.pierannunzio@gmail.com

Don’t miss!. I would NOT recommend going to Borghese Gallery without purchasing tickets in advance. We arrived by taxi and that helped us to have enough strength to walk in the park (Villa Borghese) after spending 2 hr in the Gallery. Caravaggio was one of the main reasons for our visit, but unfortunately, some of his paintings were away, on the tour. So if you are planning to see something particular – call in advance and verify that the art is displayed. Bellini, Berlini, Rubens, Titia, Raphael and many others...what a great collection! Don’t miss!

OTT. Okay, I'm not enamoured of High Renaissance art. It was nice seeing the famous and not so famous and the explanations were not all they could be. I embarressingly confess to you, I enjoyed ambling about in the Roman twilight thru the gardens more... each to his own. I would definately take an entire 1/2 day to appreciate the Pinico Park that leads into the Borghese gardens and Gallery. The fountains there are time capsules of 18thc art and need as much attention as the Borghese itself

My fave in Italy. This is a family collection though can give any public museum a run for their money! As few people are allowed to enter at one time slot, you need to book in advance even if you have the Roma pass.
I was awestruck by their collection and ceiling paintings were beautiful!
A must visit

Best museum we visited - take your time!. If you have read any articles/reviews of this museum, you already know it is spectacular. It is manageably small, filled with treasures, and the museum/rooms themselves are spectacular. Here are some tips:1) Yes, you need to purchase your tickets online in advance. The museum only lets so many people in at a time, in two hour visits. It DOES sell out at times.2) Because of the two hour time limit, you will be tempted to push to the front of the line and rush through so you don't miss anything. DON'T DO THIS. When we went, after about 60-70 minutes, most of the people had left, having checked off their list of items to see. For the rest of the two hours, there were only about 20 visitors scattered around the museum's 22 rooms. So I sometimes had a priceless work of art, and its room, to myself. 2a) In other words, plan on staying the entire two hours, and take your time at first. In fact, why not sit down and enjoy a capuccino in the cafe for the first 10 minutes? This is a small museum, and you can easily see all the highlights in under two hours. Only a serious, scholarly devoted art afficianado will need more than 90-110 minutes or so here, and the first several minutes are crowded, as noted above.3) Do a little homework. Although most of the works are simply visually stunning, the back stories add so much more to your enjoyment. What's with that weird dog at the foot of the Rape statue? Why is that girl growing out of a tree? How did the young lady lying topless on the chaise lounge feel about posing, and who was her brother anyway? 3a) So before you go in, I would recommend either: buy the Museum Guide at the book store; at least read the Rick Steves description/guide; or get the excellent and affordable audio guide available just before you go in.4) Decide: are you more of a sculpture or a painting person? Then allot most of your time to the appropriate floor.5) If you are someone who likes to buy souvenirs in the gift shop, be aware the shop closes at or right around the closing time of the last tour of the day. So either hit the gift shop first (difficult because you haven't seen the museum yet and may not know what you want to buy), or don't book the last visit of the day.Final thought: I am not an art buff. We visited the Vatican Museums, the Uffizi/Bargello/Accademia in Florence, and more. This was my favorite museum of the trip. Worth the time and entry fee.

Superb. Make sure you book your tickets in advance. I have to say I lack some patience when it comes to art but this galley was truly excellent. So many great pieces in one place. Make sure you get the audio guide.
If you only do one museum .... Wonderful museum, great work, nice cafe and the walk through the park is a bonus. Book tickets in advance!

Simply Perfect in Every Way. This museum was perfect for me - a lovely collection in a beautiful villa, timed entry (so it wasn't too crowded) and big enough to be satisfied but doesn't require more than 2 hours (if that).

Very nice gallery. Very nice gallery. If you buy the Roma pass, it is especially worthwhile as your first/second attraction for free, because otherwise the entrance costs 11-13 euros - so start with this gallery :)

Only an art lover can truly judge this.. Not being totally knowledgable about Italian art make this difficult to review. You will appreciate the talent of the artists that have created the large number of sculptures and paintings. The audio phones for 5 euros are well worth the cost and are very informative. It is an interesting visit for the 2 hours that you will be there for.

A superb collection of Bernini statues, not to be missed. We reserved tickets in advance -- a must -- and could have spent all day in the rooms with the Bernini sculptures, especially the Rape of Proserpina. The galleria is not easy to reach, but well worth the effort to get there. Although it was not far from our hotel, we took a taxi because the walk was circuitous and uphill, though the walk back was very nice. The ticket allows a visit of two hours, which was enough to see all the rooms, because the gallery is not large.

Don't Miss This In Rome. This was an amazing gallery of paintings and sculptures in an amazing setting (within a large park) in a amazing structure. There will be no pictures attached because they just can't do it justice. You have to see it!It is important that you purchase your tickets BEFORE leaving for your trip. When we visited in June you could not obtain tickets for another week. If you don't plan you will miss this.Select the pick up your tickets at the will call window. This will save you having to ship them to you. The place is small and not many people are there at one time so picking them up is not a problem.You are allocated two hours to view the museum. This is plenty of time. You are asked to check any bags, umbrellas, etc. before entering. This caught some people off guard and they did lose a little time. You are allowed to take non-flash photos in the museum.

Italian art and beautiful surroundings. This gallery is worth of seeing. First of all the garden where is situated is wonderful and the paintings and sculptures exposed there are part of very important period of Italian art.

Great collection of art - camera were allowed!. We did a bunch of research before going to the Gallery and everything we saw said no cameras. We followed the rules and didn't take the nice camera, but then everyone was taking video and pictures (without flash). We had to use our cell phone camera. The two hours of the timed ticket goes very fast. We started on the second floor picture gallery and listened to most of the audio commentary (extra charge). It was well worth it, but hard to find at times. The pictures were amazing - some of the best we've seen. Had about 50 minutes on the first floor sculpture gallery, which was not enough time, we missed some stuff. But, at 11 am we were kicked out. Sad we didn't have our camera, but a great gallery anyway! Don't forget to look up - a lot!The gardens looked nice and there were 2 and 4 person electric bike/carts to rent, whcih looked fun.

It is too bad.... We booked tickets thru Viator with guide...air conditioning has not worked in over a year! Paintings are being neglected with humidity and some are copies. The Bernini sculptures are exquisite! Grounds needs much work.

The Most Beautiful Gallery in All of Rome. Located in the Borghese Gardens, this museum is a must see for anyone visiting Rome. The building and gardens are lovely and the art inside is exquisite and very approachable. Some of the sculpture/art is permanent but there are also changing seasonal exhibits. If you love art and parks and Rome, you really should add this museum near the top of the list next to the Vatican Museums. It is good to buy your tickets in advance.

Beautiful gallery and park. Borghese provides a sampling of sculptures and artwork across many years. In each gallery there a explanations sheets in multiple languages to go die you through the room. If you don't see them, just ask a guard and they will point you to the bin that holds the plastic coAted sheets.

Awesome Beauty. The gallery is a treasure trove of beautiful, jaw-dropping works of art. We did a guided tour which highlighted sculptures by Bernini, paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. I feel it was worthwhile to do a guided tour the first time to see the major pieces as visitors are given a window of 2 hours to spend in the gallery. The guide helped us to appreciate the finer details about each piece and gave the back stories about the work or the artist. It kept my teens engaged too. I will be back someday to wander through on my own.

Only the Sistine Chapel compares. This place is SO chock full of MASTERPIECES you will be blown away. It sits in a beautiful park (the Borghese' of course) and will require reservation which can be bought on line. There is limited admittance for a 2 hour period so you never feel crowded like at many other Roman attractions. The Bernni's are incredible (Apollo & Daphne, David....) the ceiling paintings,) I can't go on, but you will not be disappointed, unless you miss it.

Art in every square inch. An amazing display of sculpture in incredibly artistic setting. Truly breathtaking. Bernini sculptures are wondrous, and Caravaggio paintings pulsing with life. Most amazing setting I've visited

5 stars for sculptures. The sculptures here deserve 5 stars, they are beautiful. The gallery lets each group in for a 2 hour visit and you must have a ticket and to get a ticket you must make reservations days ahead. If you just show up you may not get in, reservations are a must. The oil paintings in the gallery range from ok to great. Its hard to believe they let the museum get so hot and humid, I heard the a/c broke years ago.

The best crowd control we encountered in Rome. LOVED the Borghese. We booked on line and breezed right in at exactly the time on our ticket. The paintings, ceilings, and gardens were magnificent. Don't bring any bags -- everything must be checked (Unlike the Vatican, where crushing crowds of people had on backpacks).

Art treat. We went with DarkRome their tour guides are excellent they know their history and the mystery gossip that attaches itself to all great art works. The collection is stunning and one could spend a few days seeing something different each time. cameras can be used.The gardens are a tray and there are all manner of hire vehicles to move ones body around the extensive park if your feet cannot. There were a lot of happy people laughing as they manoeuvred their transporters around. Lots of good humour places to stop and have a meal or light refreshment. Amusing views of the Roman wall and city

Art treat. We went with DarkRome their tour guides are excellent they know their history and the mystery gossip that attaches itself to all great art works. The collection is stunning and one could spend a few days seeing something different each time. cameras can be used.The gardens are a tray and there are all manner of hire vehicles to move ones body around the extensive park if your feet cannot. There were a lot of happy people laughing as they manoeuvred their transporters around. Lots of good humour places to stop and have a meal or light refreshment. Amusing views of the Roman wall and city

One of the best sites to view!. We tried to get tickets online, but were told it was sold out. We thought we would just go walk around the beautiful gardens, and my husband thought he would at least ask if tickets were available. About 2 pm, we were able to go right in! Ahhhhh. It was breathtaking. There was one room alone dedicated to Caravaggio paintings. Then it went on and on from there!

Excellent Art!. They allow 300 people in at a time so it is not over crowded. The art work is amazing. Many sculptures as well. The ceilings are breathtaking. Have to check all bags, they do allow you to carry water. The gardens are lovely as well. Highly recommend.
Everything is a masterpiece. This small private collection is stunning. It's not crowded like the Vatican Museum and the guide we had was well informed and personable.

Best Gallery!. For me this is the best gallery because it is not overcrowded like the vatican and other museums in Rome. When you first enter there is a bit of rush (I'm not sure why, everyone has a timed ticket) but as the 2 hours pass the museum really thins out and you can fully enjoy all the amazing rooms and unbelievable sculptures. I highly recommend the audio guide, probably the best one of all the museums we went to in Italy.

Must See Museum. If you are in Rome and haven't been there, the Borghese Gallery is a must see. The Bernini sculptures are amazing. The art is excellent. Even our kids, ages 16 to 22 loved this gallery.

Silly policies.. This is a privately owned gallery, however thrill "policies" are completely ridiculous! I did not mind reserving an entrance time in advance, however I found that their expectation that you arrive 45 minutes in advance of your reserved time ridiculous. Then, we were told that we were allowed only stay 2 hours in the gallery. (It was quite likely that we would not have been longer than 2 hours however it is annoying to be told you had to leave ). Then I was told that I could not bring my purse (a medium size cross body) inside the gallery. Well, at that point I was fed up with their "policies" and left. I am sure it is a nice gallery, however they seem to be more interested in being pretentious than welcoming visitors to their gallery..

Beautiful and interesting. I'm not an artist and I don't know much about art, but I was fascinated by the amazing collection of art and statues this family had collected to impress their visitors. The gallery was a great place and the grounds were huge. Be sure to reserve a ticket and time to enter before leaving home as it sells out days in advance often.

A must see. The Borghese gallery is a must to see when visiting Rome. Some of the finest pieces of art you can see. Bernini statues of Appollo and Daphne and his David. The artwork is incredible and the setting is in a beautiful park you can walk around or rent a bicycle.Make a reservation in advance to avoid arriving to find sold out. We bought tickets in advance and it was excennent.

Priceless Collection. A fantastic collection of art all assembled into a former Papal villa. This has to be one of the very finest small Art collections in the world (think along the lines of The Wallace or Frick Collections). With all the fantastic art to see in Rome, this is one that should not be missed.You can easily book on line and can only gain access with a pre booked time slot. Some beautiful pieces of sculpture and paintings - get a guide so you don't miss the highlights such as the Caravaggios. The two hour slot you get is sufficient to see everything at a leisurely pace.Afterwards take some time to wander through the Borghese Gardens and drop down to the Piazza del Popolo to visit the Church of Santa Maria del Popolo to see the iconic Caravaggios.

Fabulous!. Went with my husband to this Gallery and we both thought it was really wonderful. So many amazing pieces of art; paintings, sculptures, and absolutely mind-boggling ceilings. The 2 hour time slot allowed was enough time to wander around the gallery looking at everything properly. We started on the top floor as the ground floor was full of organised guided tours, and so avoided any congestion, though it never felt particularly crowded, as they limit the number of tickets for each time slot.I bought our tickets online from the Gallery website 2 weeks in advance of our trip - they were delivered to my home in the UK by UPS a few days later. No problem getting the time slot we wanted (11am) and having the tickets delivered meant we knew we would be OK to get in without any problems. The price was pretty good I thought, though they do add on a few extras such as a 'pre-sale fee' of €2.00 per ticket, a service fee of €4.00, and I paid €1.30 for ticket insurance. I also paid €19.99 delivery charge, but since the tickets arrived so quickly that was worth it. So the tickets and the gallery were both great - however the staff at the gallery were quite unhelpful and answered very brusquely when asked any questions. And the toilets in the gallery, off the stairway, were absolutely dire, so avoid them if you can.
Well worth a visit.. Superb sculpture and paintings (including Caravaggios).Essential to book in advance online or by telephone.

A must-see while in Rome. The quality of art in this Gallery is of course an indication of the buying power of wealthy families such as the Borghese: you won't be disappointed! Entrance is limited to small groups every 2 hours, which keeps crowds manageable and the art visible. So reserve your tickets online ahead of time - there aren't always tickets available at the door during busy tourist months.The "train" around the grounds and the 2- or 4-post bicycles offer a nice way to relax before or after your visit, especially for families with children.

Amazing Art, combined with a lovely day in the park. We were blown away by the art at display at the Borghese Gallery. We ordered tickets well in advance and got the audio tour upon arrival. Make sure you arrive at least 30 minutes or more before your ticket time, as there can be long lines to get the audio tour and to check in your bag. You don't want to lose out on time spent at the gallery.Our children (6 and 11) enjoyed the audio tour and the artwork as well. Two hours was just enough to see and hear it all. Afterward we had a picnic lunch in the lovely park in front of the gallery which offers shady spots everywhere. After lunch we rented bikes, walked around, and enjoyed the view from the lookout point at the other end of the park.A day well-spent for a family of four, combining art with rest/relaxation, family fun, and city views.

Best art we saw in Italy. I wish we had taken a guided tour but even without the art is impressive. More impressive than the Vatican. It is not crowed since they restrict the number of people in at one time. Don't take a purse unless you don't mind checking it. Like wise with backpacks! You are given 2 hours to tour and the time was right. Make sure that you get tickets in advance or you might be disappointed.

Visit not recommended on a hot day. The villa and the gardens are wonderful, but for some reason there was no air-condition and it was so hot inside that we had to leave early (the visit is two hours)and we weren't the only ones. I strongly recommend not making this visit on a hot day.

Simply beautiful...for the adults. There is no doubt this gallery is gorgeous with both a beautiful sculpture and picture gallery. Kids, however, won't really appreciate it. My kids had the most fun counting how many sculptures were naked, until they realised every sculpture was naked and they got tired of counting. My daughter loves art galleries, but this one doesn't really help them understand what they are looking at like some of the other galleries she has been to do. Having said that we did not get the audio tour and this would have likely helped. The shop at the end had some gorgeous books though and she bought one on Raphael, which she loved.

Beautiful!!. we did not book a guide but happened by luck into a small (6 of us) one, definitely worth the guide,they sell tickets to control the crowds so the experience was so much nicer.. do get your tickets before you go, they were sold out on the day we went. Did not feel rushed and were able to enjoy the paintings and sculptures. It is a must to see..
Most impressive!. Only wish we'd had more than the allowed time to enjoy this impressive collection! The grounds surrounding the gallery are exceptionally well maintained.

A SPECTACULAR ART GALLERY IN A BEAUTIFUL MANSION NEAR VIA VENETO. The Borghese Gallery is in everyone's top ten things to do in Rome! It was built for Cardinal Scipione Borghese in the 17th century. The Cardinal originally owned most of the land that comprises the mega destination Villa Borghese or park Borghese. The Borghese is an art gallery that features renaissance painters such as Raphael, Titian and religious painters, including Peter Paul Reubens. There are also Barocci's and Bernini's in the collection. The star of the gallery is Caravaggio, who is well represented in the collection by his Boy with a Basket of Fruit.BIG TIP!! You must have a reservation to come here! Because of the complexity of the collection it is smart to come by a reputable tour group. They will get a ticket and advance you to the front of the line. I have some photos to share.

Directions via Metro to Borghese Gallery. Gallery - excellent. Accepted my "voucher" for tickets from my iPhone. Audio Guide was worth getting. Museum is hot - even though it was a nice cool temperature outside.Directions: Barbieri Metro stop. Allow 20 mins to walk from Metro stop to Gallery. If you arrive at Gallery at 8:45am you'll be fine. Follow metro exit signs to Via Veneto. Above ground, walk along the street with all the trees (follow the trees) - which is Via Veneto. You'll be going slightly up hill. When you get to the round about - walk as though you'd be driving and staying on the same road. The green park should now be on your right. Then turn right into the park and take the wide, paved path into the park. It runs parallel to the sidewalk, but is within the gate of the park. The path dips down, then goes up and is shaded. About a 10 minute walk and dead ends at the Borghese Gallery. The doors opened this AM at 8:30, at which point we queued for tickets (everyone had a reservation - no "walk up" tickets available. Then we waited in the entrance hall to be let into the gallery at 9am all together. Save your ticket stub if you want to use toilets after your gallery visit - must show it to use facilities. It's possible to use toilets and get something to drink while waiting in the hall for the 9am opening. We took our own water bottle but had to check it at the coat check. Where comfy shoes - floors are all marble. At 11am, the guards will say, "Please exit now." Enjoy!

Must visit. Must go.Amazing sculptures .take no. 910 bus from termini station. It takes about 20 minutes. Take same bus back. Bus stop is on the opposite side down the road , turn right on the second street you came across. (The bus stop opposite the stop you get off the bus isn't the right one .) remember to check in your bag/purse. Camera is allowed as long as no flash.

Best Museum on Globe. Will keep going back. My favorite museum on the globe. The setting is a replica of how the upper class lived. The collection on Bernini sculptures are breath taking. All located in a cute park where you can rent power assisted carriages. Book in advance to avoid being disappointed!

Book Tickets in Advance. We visited the Borghese Gallery on our last day in Rome, and I was pleasantly surprised at the amount of INCREDIBLE sculptures (by the master, Bernini) and other impressive artwork.Book your tickets in advance (online) or you will NOT get in. The tickets are good for a 2 hour window, and 2 hours is plenty of time to explore to galleries.After, grab inexpensive sandwiches from the cafeteria in the basement of the building and have a picnic in the expansive park surrounding the Gallery. The park is not well kempt (and I would even say ugly in some places), but it is a nice shady retreat on a hot Roman day. You can even rent segways to explore the park after your lunch!

Hopeless getting a voucher for 1pm and not being open. Whilst the contents of this gallery might be spectacular, having only 20 minutes to view everything was hopeless. Why send out vouchers stating an entry time of 1pm and then kick everyone out because of a staff meeting? Not good enough and we weren't the only unhappy people. We were told to come back at 3pm but in my experience people plan their time carefully in Rome so this wasn't possible for us.If you do go the leave plenty of time to collect tickets, hand in handbags etc. Go and see the Doria Pamphili palace instead. Their audio commentary is fabulous and so is the artwork and the building

Well organized gallery, but arrive early. Online reservations were easy to make ahead of time (2 months prior). We opted for the 11am visit, but I'd recommend the 9am visit, due to the heat in the summer months and increasing number of guests. Be prepared to form a line -- 4 steps are required to gain access on time so arrive early. 1. To pick up tickets at the front desk, only 2 staff members available to assist (bring online voucher). 2. To pick up your audio guide (need a form of ID such as drivers license to rent). 3. To check a purse or camera bag. It doesn't matter how small, you must check these items. Personal items such as passports, wallets and cell phone must be placed in a clear 1 qt sized bag with handles that may be carried inside. 4. Line up at the entrance to the 1st floor of the gallery to gain access at the exact time of tour. Look for brochures in different languages near the entrance. The 2 hour time limit is strictly enforced. To avoid crowds, we went straight to the painting floor (2nd floor) and toured, by the time we finished, the crowds had thinned out on the 1st floor and we were able to get close enough to the sculptures to appreciate the fine details of Bernini's work.It is very hot inside, no A/C to speak of. A hand held fan will help. No flash photography permitted. Bring a bottle of water to drink inside.

Fantastic collection . Really excellent museum, the collection is brilliant particularly the Berninis!my favourite was the Bernini piece Apollo and Daphne. The audio guide is very good and gives just a good amount of detail without being overwhelming. You do need to book in advance so make sure you phone and book so you are not disappointed!! The villa borghese gardens are a must see also, had a fantastic hour spinning around on segways!!

Incredible Sculptures, must book in advance.. Whatever you do, make sure to reserve your ticket online well in advance. I visited the gallery last Friday and it was completely booked for the next four days. I also read that I should arrive at least an hour in advance to pick up my ticket (when you book online, you have to print out the email and the receipt to collect your ticket at the gallery), however there was no line to pick up my ticket at all, and I ended up waiting around for about 45 minutes until everyone began gathering to enter the gallery at the allotted time. Also, no bags are allowed, so the gallery provides a small plastic bag for your cellphone, camera, wallet, keys, and then you check you bag for free and pick up when you finish. I did see several people bringing in bags, so not quite sure how much this rule is actually enforced. Each ticket is good for 2 hours. Once everyone entered (exactly at the time on the ticket and not earlier), we were ushered upstairs to the second floor where all of the paintings are. While I enjoyed the paintings, the sculptures on the first floor are incredible, so make sure to give yourself plenty of time for the first floor if you enjoy sculptures. Lastly, I booked my ticket myself directly through the museum and did not rent an audio guide (available at the gallery). I assumed that I could simply read descriptions in front of each painting/sculpture - however there aren't any! There are laminated cards available in each room that provide some detail, but I wish I had either purchased a guide book for myself or rented an audio guide.

One of the Very, Very Best!. If you are in Rome for the first time, you really need to see the Vatican, the Colosseum and... the Borghese Gallery. The Borghese is as good as the best museums in Paris and Vienna. Incredible work by Caravaggio, Bernini and Titian, and the building itself is breathtaking! Be sure to make reservations, and do it several weeks ahead. The tickets are for a particular time slot, which means that the floors won't be overcrowded while you are there. The audio guide was great, and the tour guides seemed to be competent as we eavesdropped occasionally. Be sure to give yourself time to wander through the park while you are there. I just can't recommend this museum any more highly!

Beautiful scuptures. The scuptures are not to be missed. Get tickets ahead of time. Its very crowded. You have to stand on line to check your bags. I mean even your pocketbooks. Then stand on line to get in. First floor is amazing.

reservations are required. Reservations are required - this may seem harsh but the result is strict crowd control and a wonder environment to view the art. There are excellent paintings but the real gems are the statues - they are just amazing. (Look it up and check out the pictures.) The gallery is easy to reach by bus.

Not to be missed. An exquisite museum featuring the work of Caravaggio & sculpture by Bernini, that will take your breath away.
The museum is set in a beautiful garden and is never crowded, because it is a timed entry. The interiors are highly decorative and the museum itself is wonderful.
Recommended to prebook your tickets in advance on the museum website.

Everything Under On Roof-This place has it all!. If you don't have a lot of time in Rome, but want to get the very best artwork, architecture and wow for your time, look no further than the fantastic Borghese Gallery. The artwork; paintings, sculpture, mosaics, frescos and decorative arts are stunning. You can't just drop in;**** YOU MUST RESERVE IN ADVANCE***** trust me when I say you have to plan this visit, especially during high season. But it's totally worth it.
Lovely Gallery. The villa itself is amazing as are the works within. Reserve ahead of your visit to ensure you get in. Wander around the beautiful park too.

One of the Best Galleries in Europe. If you are a fan of Bernini or Caravaggio or simply Baroque arts, this is the gallery that you cannot miss when visiting Rome. It houses a good number of Bernini's masterpieces in his early ages, including The Rape of Proserpina, Apollo and Daphne, David, and etc. Collections of Caravaggio are also outstanding, including Young Sick Bacchus, Boy with a Basket of Fruits, David with the Head of Goliath. Apart from Baroque arts, the gallery also has a variety of collections covering Renaissance to Neo-Classical Arts, e.g. Raphael's Lady with a Unicorn, Titian's Sacred and Profaned Love, and Canova's Pauline Bonaparte. You must make a reservation for the visit, which can be done either online or via phone. The gallery is open every two hours to a fixed number of visitor. If your reservation is for 9am, then you can enter the gallery at anytime from 9-11, but you have to leave exactly at 11am. Roma Pass can be used for the gallery with no extra booking fees. Historically cameras were not allowed, but now you can take pictures as you wish, as long as there is no flash. Recommended route would be to start from the second floor to avoid the crowd, but it would be better to leave enough time (slightly more than an hour), so that you can enjoy the stunning sculptures downstairs.

Must see in Rome - but book ahead. The sculptures housed at the Borghese by Bernini are arguable some of the best sculptures in the world - worth going for these alone. The interiors of the rooms are stunning as are the many other painting and sculptures. Make sure you go when in Rome but you need to book, sometimes a few months in advance - do it - it is worth it!

Borghese Gallery. We got tickets way in advance. Also you have to reserve a time to be there, as they only allow a few into the museum at a time. That's the good thing about the museum. No huge crowds.By the time we got to the Borghese, I was about arted out, and that's saying a lot for an art professor. But, this museum has some amazing Bernini sculptures. It's worth the visit if you are a Bernini fan. Bernini's "David" is the emotional of all the David sculptures and well worth the visit.

Beautiful inside and out!. The guided gallery tour we took from "CityWonders" was great, but you can also do a solo tour of the gallery. Every two hours they let a goup in, five minutes before the 2 hrs is over they clear everyone out, so a guide to point out the great stuff an manage the time was very helpful. You'll have to check your bags, no food or drink, but cameras are OK (no flash!) The art was beautiful, but I especially enjoyed it because of the stories and insight added by our guide. Many artists are represented there, but especially If you like Bernini you have to go! (Much of the art and architecture of 17th century Rome is intertwined with Bernini.) The AC inside has been broken for a couple years now, and some of the artwork is deteriorating because of it, but for the most part it well maintained inside. (Note: Inside the gallery there are a lot of spiral stairs. There is supposedly an elevator but it is tiny.) The grounds outside a also a treasure, there is a map outside and you are free to roam the grounds. You could spend a whole day there if you wanted to!

Borghese Gallery -Rome. Wonderful gallery with stunning works of art. Make sure to make reservations in advance. We made them a month ahead of time and we're glad we did. We went on June 2nd and a sign there said next available reservations were June 9th.

Don't Leave Rome Without a Visit to the Borghese!. I made our reservations for the Gallery online. Don't attempt to go there without a reservation. The villa containing the paintings and sculptures is almost as spectacular as the art it contains. As others have said the sculptures are among the best in the world. We avoided the crowds by heading up to the second floor as soon as we received our audio guides. The second floor has paintings by Raphael, Caravaggio, Rubens and Botticelli and other famous artists. We had to time ourselves so we had plenty of time to head down to the first floor to see the sculptures by Bernini. Daphne and Apollo is the most beautiful sculpture I have ever seen. An unbelievable work! When our time was up, we headed outside. It was hot when we were there and it was very pleasant to wander through the park in the shade.

Borghese Gardens. . The gallery it's self is wonderful. Full of spectacular are. The grounds and gardens are another issue. Sorely neglected, run down dusty and sad would be my assessment. For a country with so many famous landmarks to maintain I understand. Regardless I was saddened and disappointed though.

Borghese Gallery, Rome. We did a guided tour as there is a wealth of art, sculptures in this Gallery. The tour guide was an artist and art historian so we were well informed. This Gallery is in a park on a hill along from the Spanish Steps so you get to enjoy a peaceful part of Rome, enjoy street musicians and see amazing art works.

Try Segway. There is Segway on rent, and make it quicker to stroll around the vast areas of villa. The staff that rent Segway at villa teach well on how to grasp the Segway, if you are trying it out for the first time, it's a perfect place to learn. Remember to bargain on the price too, as discount are possible, especially when you are there at evening.

Lift your spirits - and buy tickets in advance. Simply stunning. This priceless collection is an easy visit. They regulate numbers so it is never overwhelming with too many tourists. The Bernini sculptures are simply breathtaking. How pure stone can be converted into flesh is a mystery. Well worth the visit and an easy one for families with children as the two floors are easily visited.

Too hot in there for people or the paintings. Yes. The art is incredible. But, the AC broke 5 years ago. It is time to replace it already.Also, not only does the lift only hold two people, the staff complain at you for using it if you are not in a wheelchair.

A tranquil setting with beautiful art. On my first day in Rome, ever, I visited this gallery as it was very close to my hotel, and the timing was perfect. having booked in at 12.30 i spent an afternoon touring the exhibits. The quality of the sculpture and some of the art set a very high standard for this first trip, and persuaded me that this was the first of many trips to Rome, which it has proved to be.
Gardens, art and architecture. Not to be missed while you're in Rome. We spent a really pleasant two hours walking through the house looking at the sculpture paintings and architecture .

PERFETTO / PERFECT. Second time we visit this museum . One of the worlds finest at a low price. One has to reserve online , limited amount of visitors are allowed in at the same time. One has got two hours to visit , that is enough to appreciate and enjoy. Very fine paintings , sculpture , objects and furniture. A must !!!

A beautiful building and grounds housing a wonderful art collection. One goes for the art collection, of course, which is at least as fantastic as that in the Uffizzi and Academia d'Art in Florence, but the gallery building itself and the surrounding gardens are well worth the visits in and of themselves.We visited with the "Skip the line: Gallery Borghese and Gardens Walking Tour", booked on viator.com. Our guide, Maximo, was excellent, providing an extensive and entertaining history of the gallery, a number of the most noted artists and the symbology of a number of the more significant pieces, adding significantly to the experience.
Gorgeous villa/museum. Be sure to get your tickets in advance, as they will likely be sold out at least a week prior to your visit. Stunning artwork - well worth the walk to get there.

Magnificient!. Incedible museam with a few paintings of Caravagio. Lots of sculptures and pay attention to the cealings. It also hosts one of the most luxurios rooms in the world for the 18th century.
Super nice. It is a must go in Rome. They have some great pieces. It is no as crowded as the other museums in Rome.

Well worth your time. There are a few practical things to keep in mind about visiting the Borghese Gallery. You must reserve tickets ahead, online or by phone. If using the Roma pass, I believe you can only reserve by phone. Book at least a week ahead. It's best to go at 9 am before the place starts heating up. It takes at least 20 minutes to walk from the Spagna metro stop and you can get lost if you don't pay attention and/or stop passersby for directions. You may read that you must be there 30 minutes ahead or risk losing your reservation, but when we went it took them nearly 30 minutes to process everyone that was on line at 8:30. So shoot to be there at 8:30, but don't panic if you are running a few minutes late. Consider taking a taxi, as well, to avoid the angst of potentially getting lost.You will only be allowed 2 hours in the gallery, but that is plenty for the average person. The audio guide is interesting but not really necessary. I found the sculpture and room decoration as compelling as the paintings. Allow time in your schedule to wander in the park after you exit the gallery.

Book a ticket!. The Borghese has some very important and renowned art work which is really worth seeing when in Rome BUT the gallery does not have the capacity for a lot of people so during summer months it is a MUST to book tickets online at least a week in advance to make sure you don't miss out.  My parents went at Easter time a few years ago and they did not book and were able to go in so I assume it is more the summer that it is an issue. However I would recommend checking out the booking system to see if there are available spaces in advance to have an idea. The main website for the Borghese does not warn you about this and so it is very easy to remain in the dark about this and then be disappointed! FYI - the park and gardens are also very nice and include cafes, refreshment stands and playground areas for kids as well as plenty of seating and grass for picnics etc.
