Amazing Baroque Art. this was one of my favorite museums in all of Italy. You must have a reservation to get in. There are some amazing sculptures. We went early and bought the booklet of the top 10 attractions. We read it while we waited. This really enhanced our visit and made it easy to complete our visit in less than 2 hours.

Sumptuous. It was back in the 1980s that I first heard of Galleria Borghese and Canova's famous sculpture of Pauline Bonaparte as Venus. Two months ago I finally got to see it. It doesn't disappoint. Neither does anything else about this museum. It is a beautifully furnished building with many distinguished works of art.Bernini, who invented the baroque style, is the star. His famous works here include David, Pluto and Persephone, and Apollo and Daphne. They are remarkable for sculptures in that in spite of being static, they tell a story. I think Bernini version of David is the best. There is much else to like.Be sure to order your tickets early; at least a week in advance for weekends. Be on time. Some guide books say that photos aren't allowed; actually, flash free photography is permitted. After departing, enjoy the walk across the villa. Plaza del Popolo at the other end is worth visiting. The Church of Santa Maria del Popolo has some beautiful paintings. People watching at the plaza is fun. There is a Metro station nearby.If you haven't seen Galleria Borghese you're in for a treat. Enjoy.

Wow!. So glad I was told a couple months prior to traveling to Rome that advance reservations/tickets are required to visit the Borghese. A specific time is reserved and you receive 2 hours to visit the rooms. It costs 5 euros to use an audio device which discusses the rooms and sculptures and paintings. Definitely worth the 5 euros.Can't miss this - but do remember to purchase tickets online well in advance.

Second-best museum in Rome. This museum has 6 Caravaggio paintings, including the spectacular Madonna of the Palafrenieri, and works by Raphael, Rubens, and other masters. It also has early statues by Bernini including a lifelike David who is definitely committed to killing Goliath, the lifelike Rape of Proserpina, and the stunning Apollo and Daphne - where Bernini is really showing off what can be done with marble. Admission to the museum is in 2 hour slots; counting security checkin and them starting you out 15 minutes before the end of your 2 hours, you won't be able to take even a quick look at everything on display. Buy your tickets in advance; the earliest entry at 9 AM is recommended, and avoid bringing a bag or large purse as you will be required to wait in a second line first to check it and then to retrieve it.

Overwhelmed & Intrigued. A wonderful collection of paintings, sculptures, frescos, & mosaics. My go-to pieces here are always the pieces by Bernini. Incredibly intricate work! Look for the Egyptian room as there are fascinating items there that hold magical meaning.

Worth the long wait and crowded museum.. Excellent Roman tourist destination. Totally and overly crowded. The tickets have a timeframe for the visit, however the administration of the villa had to have a meeting that day and , after waiting a couple of hours in a very long line in a hot sunny day we were pushed in with another group, that made this a body-to- body experience. Worth visiting, but pick up a different month. Summer in Rome is not fun, and the city is quite dirty.

Fabulous Renaissance Villa and Bernini sculptures. We recently visited Galleria Borghese for the 4th time. It is the most enjoyable presentation of Renaissance art and sculpture that I have experienced in all of Italy. My strategy to ensure maximum enjoyment of the main Bernini works is to linger in the main hall and study the room and works there, then proceed to the next few rooms after the initial crowd has moved on. A better strategy, if you have the patience, is to first go upstairs to the paintings gallery, then come down to the main level for the sculptures. Toward the end of your two hour visit window, you will have most of the rooms almost to yourself.The first room after the main hall has a wonderful Canova sculpture of Pauline, sister of Napoleon. Note the detail of the mattress. In the next few rooms the works of Gian Lorenzo Bernini are just wonderful. Note the intensity of the subjects, the facial expressions, the flowing robes, and texture of skin and hair. See if you can see light through some of the leaves of the Apollo and Daphne. One of the pleasures of Galleria Borghese is that one can stand and study all the details and intricacies of a sculpture without crowds interfering with the enjoyment. The number of visitors is limited for each two hour visit window. I highly recommend the audio guide. It will greatly add to your understanding and appreciation of the Borghese collection. I also recommend a little pre-trip research on the history and content of the gallery.Non-flash photos are now allowed which is a big plus.
If you can only visit one art museum in Rome......... ....this is the one. The pieces are stunning and varied. The audio guide could be improved, but you nonetheless finish the visit awed.
Borghese Gallery . One should not Miss visiting this. The Time allowed to see this Place is too Short .Is Time ,Money & Booking if available it is the Place re -visiting.

Do the Audio Guide!. I am not an art buff, but I had seen a lot of great things about the Borghese Gallery and figured I should visit it while in Rome. It was very enjoyable overall. You definitely want to buy tickets ahead of time. I went from 5 pm-7 pm on a Tuesday and it wasn't insanely crowded which was nice. They do not allow any bags in the gallery (which the staff member veeery rudely informed me of) but they have a bag check for free near the ticket desk. Do it before you get in line to enter so that you don't have to get out of line, check your bag, then back in the entrance line.The audio guide was well worth the money. The pieces are clearly labelled with corresponding numbers, and the map that you get is helpful in determining where you are in the gallery.The rooms are numbered with little hanging pendants as you walk through the doorway- look up at them and you'll have an idea of where you are on your map, otherwise the museum is confusing! The cafe and bookstore close before the gallery closes, so if you have the last time slot like I did, 5-7, you need to go to the bookstore before you go into the museum, otherwise it'll be closed when you're leaving. I wouldn't recommend the gallery for young children, but it was a great use of a few hours of my time in Rome!

Wow! What a museum!!. There are so many things you need to know before going to this world famous museum. First of all, you need to book days ahead of time. When we went on June 3, 2015, the next available day was June 9. Having said that, the Italian way is to see if you can still go in, even though the sign says all sold out for today. (If you're a small group of 1-2, you could try) anyway, arrive 1/2 hour earlier coz there are so many things you need to do before you go into the museum for your 2-hour visit (they will usher you out to let the next group in!). Below the main entrance, there is a door with a couple of steps going down to it. Here is where you need to go first to exchange the voucher or confirmation # for the actual tickets. Then you need to check in all your baggage (back packs, large purses etc) The sign seems to say that you're not allowed to bring a camera but you can. You just can't use the flash. Their audio guide was decent. I learned a lot from it. Then once you do that and perhaps use their WC, you then go back outside to now climb up the stairs to go to the main entrance. You really only have 2 hours to finish your tour-there will be an announcement and then people will actually usher you out. The museum is completely emptied before the next group is let in. Have fun!! (Don't forget all the garden/park surrounding the museum) There are Segways, bikes, golf carts and electric cart for 2 or 4 with pedals for rent.

Definitely Worth Seeing. This museum is definitely worth seeing. Very impressive, especially if you have a tour guide or other source of info. We had purchased a timed entry pass in advance, and then signed up for an English-speaking guide when we got there. Isabella was a good guide, and the tour was well organized with the little radio transmitters and earplugs to keep the noise level down. One small quibble, though, was her tendency to walk off to another room and leave her flock behind!Save some time to walk the Villa Borghese Gardens as well.

Overwhelming art oppulence. Almost too much too absorb. Tip: when entering on your time slot, proceed directly up the steps to the second floor and avoid a lot of the crowd as you circulate and then go down. The audio guide and floor map were confusing to us and if not too expensive you might consider a real guide to get the most out of your visit.

A Beautiful Roman Gem. This is a smaller property/museum but certainly worth the time to investigate. A good time to visit is when the Roman sun is HOT as you'll find a true respite from the heat here on the lovely grounds. The fact that you are also treated to some fabulous art is just a plus!

One of the best museums in Italy. A must.. Amazing sculptures by Bernini. Seven Caravaggios. A beautiful gallery that offers the most beautiful work you can image, all collected by Cardinal Borghese. You must get reservations or you will be disappointed… the cost is quite inexpensive but if you don't book in advance it's quite likely that you will not be admitted. Admittance is limited in number (which is wonderful -- no crowds) for two hour increments. Choose your time and enjoy! The grounds are huge and a great way to spend a long part of a day. Everyone who visits Rome should visit this marvelous museum. An international jewel.

Mesmerising!. Read from several guide books that Galleria Borghese is a gem and if there is only one art museum that one has to visit in Rome, it has to be this. So enticing are the recommendations that I eventually booked this tour online in their website about a month before my visit in early May 2015. I liked their system in having limited no. of visitors for per 2 hour session after been to Vatican museum. One will have the peace and space, and sufficient time to admire each piece of excellent work by the masters. Although cameras are allowed inside the gallery, it is difficult to take pictures of the paintings due to the lighting system creating a lot of reflections. Good thing they have a book store in the basement should you fancy the art pieces in posters, book, magnet forms etc. for purchases. All bags have to be checked in before entry and there is a café with limited seats for chow. Outside the gallery lies the massive but beautiful garden and water fountains with portable water. Taking bus 116 is recommended compared to taking metro to Spagna to this gallery due to it's extreme end location inside the Villa Borghese.

Small but beautiful. Borghese Gallery is a small museum, located in the Villa Borghese Park above the Spanish Steps and Piazza del Popolo, near the Zoo. The museum draws such a crowd that you must have reservations and visits are limited to two hours. There are a number of Bernini sculptures and other art works. There are several differences from other museums. Pictures (without flash) were permitted. The windows were open, even with air conditioning, resulting in exposure to humidity and temperatures. This has caused some impact on some of the paintings (e.g. pulling away from the frame). Note that all bags larger than small purse must be checked. This museum provides an opportunity to get up close and personal with masterpieces from the Middle Ages. After the museum, take some time and tour the gardens and park for a relaxing experience with nature.

Great Gallery. Reseve online ahead of your trip to Rome. No crowds because of their reservation system. Amazing building - walls, floors, ceilings are all amazing. Great art throughout, but the sculptures are amazing.

Galleria Borghese. Fantastic collection of paintings and sculptures in a beautiful location, in Villa Borghese, close to Via Veneto. Important to book the visit and better to have a guide. You must leave bags at the entrance. Every floor has a fixed time to visit, so better to see all the floor first then if you have extra time you can look again.....

What a great experience!!!. I booked the tickets for the there of us well in advance due to the restricted entry system they have. But it was really amazing, and in some rooms there were no more then us and maybe three other people. For me a completely new experience viewing art, and I suppose I don't need to mention how breathtaking the pieces are that are here to see.If you ever come to Rome, make sure you get some tickets - and the audio guides are well worth the extra fiver

Outstanding Art Museum. We were amazed by the art on display at the Borghese Gallery, especially the sculptures by Bernini. The gallery's inlaid marble floors and ceiling frescos complement the fabulous artwork. Visiting this museum is a much more intimate experience than at the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, with lesser crowds. Reserve a time slot online.
Plan your visit. The gardens were lovely, but if you intend visiting this museum, book well in advance. Unfortunately, we didn't book,so we could not visit this museum.

Make it a "must do"!. I had heard that the Borghese Gallery was among the most impressive art collections in the world and, now that I've seen it, I would have to agree. The only downside is that it is overwhelming on your first trip. If possible, book a knowledgeable tour guide so that you have help sorting through the amazing array of art presented. We would have enjoyed having more context for what we were seeing. However, I plan to return at some point. It's a little off the beaten path, but very accessible by bus or taxi.

Great place. We booked online, printed the voucher and went to the location about an hour early. We got there by bus, left us right near the park entrance. It's much more difficult with the subway from Spagna - long walk through a tunnel. Just take the 223 bus from Termini, it's way more convenient (there are several buses that take you there, not just 223). We exchanged the voucher for tickets, then took a walk in the beautiful park. Got back 15 minutes before our scheduled time, checked our backpack (it was a small one, wasn't expecting to have to leave it, but we had no problem with that). We visited for about 90 minutes and loved the artwork.

If you must see one Museum in Rome, then it has to be this one!. Personally, I rate this better and more impressive than the Capitoline Museum. From the moment you enter the Gallery, you are mesmerized by the sculptures and paintings all around you. From Bernini to Botticelli to Tiziano to Domenichino to Caravaggio to Raffaello..........this villa is a treasure trove !Most important is to make a reservation prior to your visiting the Gallery and take your time slot for the trip and stick to it. If you change your mind after taking a 1300hrs slot and want to do it at 1100hrs, its not likely to happen and a couple infront of us got turned down for the same reason. Their website says one needs to call and book, however we sent them a mail from our country,and got a revert with a reservation number too. So that was convenient......Secondly, I recommend all to take the guided tour instead of the audio guide (its just Euro 1.5 more expensive, per person) since one really cannot spend the whole day at one's leisure out here, everyone gets a 2 hour slot for the tour. We decided to do the guided tour, instead of the audio tour, and were so glad that we did so. Our guide, Isabella was wonderful. Knowledgeable, she spoke with such passion about the sculptures and paintings and the creators of the same. It was as if each sculpture came to life with her explanation and each painting told us the story behind. She was fantastic ........And I would recommend if one has only time enough to do one Museum, choose Villa Borghese and you will have no regrets!
Auseric. In Rome for only 6 days, found Museo unfortunately booked out until after we leave Rome....so book well ahead. The gardens of Villa Borghese were a pleasure.

Amazing!. The Galleria Borghese is full ow wonderful works of art. It is unique in that this is the original building, with the original works of art. The 3D effect on the ceilings is worth the trip alone. This is a by appointment only tour, so make your reservation well in advance.

A Privilege. As someone who has been studying renaissance and baroque art, visiting this gallery and collection was a bit of a dream. Seeing a number of Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings was a highlight of my Rome trip. For sure, our tour was booked well in advance, and that would be my advice to anyone reading this. It would be a shame to travel to see this collection only to be told there is no availability for the duration of your trip. The architecture/interior complemented and added to the understanding, not only of the art, but of the lives/wealth of the Borghese. There are headsets. We had our own historian with us explaining all the details. Certainly there are other important artists represented by this collection, FYI. I am just keep on Bernini/Caravaggio. A giftshop and snack bar in the basement was well stocked with the typical books, postcards etc. The grounds were lovely though we didn't see that much of them since we were on a jam-packed schedule while in Rome.

Beautiful gardens. We visited in April 2015, and unfortunately we were unable to enter the gallery, however the gardens and park surrounding the gallery is beautiful. It was a lovely, peaceful afternoon walk around the park, and looking at the architecture of the building. I would recommend a visit here, however I would suggest confirming beforehand that you are able to enter the gallery.

A must see!. This is a must on any visit to Rome. It is important to purchase your tickets prior to your trip to ensure you can get in. The sculptures are amazing - to be able to get so close to such wonderful pieces is an experience to not miss.
Great exposition, poor staff. the exposition is absolutely fantastic. Belini in all forms, wonderful. the whole building is beautiful and the garden is very nice.

One of our favorites. Spectacular gallery in the heart of the gardens so both sites can be combined. Tickets in advance are a must, as entrance is timed and the gallery is very popular. Ladies be prepared that your purses will need to be checked.
Small tours allowed. Must make a reservation. Worth seeing, make a res. buy advance tickets. Saw this on a cool rainy day & was worth seeing. Head sets are used.

A stand out for art lovers. Excellent! What a little jewel, housing an abundance of magnificent pieces. MUST get advanced tickets! Accidentally started on the top floor(I think it's referred to as floor 2 but actually the 3rd level). Floor 1 took our breath away so we were happy to end our tour there. Bernini's Daphne n Apollo stopped us in our tracks. Audio tour adds life to the experience, but you must leave a form of ID with them to do so. Also be prepared to check in your bag, no matter the size. A clear plastic bag is given to you to transfer and carry with you your wallet, passport, etc.
Check availability!. Unfortunately we were not able to get in because the museum was sold out, we were there on May 19th and it was sold out untill May 26th! So best to check availability beforehand!

Wonderful art, beautiful villa. We toured the Borghese Gallery while in Rome. I had made an appointment for the 1pm tour and we arrived just in time to tour this beautiful villa with such amazing art and sculptures. We went to the upstairs gallery first as recommended by Rick Steves books then went down to the first floor. We must have walked through every room at least twice! Very very beautiful. Don't forget you must have an appointment since they only allow 360 people inside for a 2 hour window. Well worth it.

Great Museum. We visited Rome for three days and this museum was a major highlight. The artwork was fantastic. Reservations strongly recommended and they control the number of visitors in two,hour periods. Also suggest use of audio guides.

Do not miss this. Buy your tickets online early. Very easy process. The art and statues will leave you gasping. Nothing else like it. Only smaller groups are let in at your time so you are not crushed by the big tour groups at the other Rome sights.

Borghese. This gallery has an amazing collection of art. Don't miss this gallery, take your time walking through it because everywhere you look you will see spectacular pantings and statues. Pay particular attention to the ceilings in each room they are awesome. You will need to purchase tickets and enter at a specific time.

For the love of art!. While I have visited Rome often and the Borghese Villa a few times, this was my first time that I entered the Galleria. It is one of Italy's many treats for art lovers! In this case to see one of my favorite artists, Bernini, and one of my favorite sculptures, Daphne and Apollo. It is an exquisite piece and given a great space to be viewed from all angles. But it is one of many art treasures to be viewed in this grandiose villa from an era of untold wealth! Certainly a stop in Rome to be treasured.

An intimate luxurious gallery. This is an incredible gallery. They are incredibly strict about the time slots, a tour group is let in every 2 hours. If you are late, they don't accommodate. So be on time! The best time slot I found was the 5 to 7 pm. Everyone rushes in but by 6 pm, most of the visitors have left and you find yourself only with a few other patrons wandering around this most gorgeous building and viewing such incredibly art. If you do pick this time, go to the gift shop before the tour as it closed by 7 pm. There is a mandatory, but free, bag check. No bags or coats allowed. But you can bring in your camera!!! Just no flash. Such a treat when viewing these amazing rooms of treasures! The bag check and gift shop are on the first floor or basement level. We took the subway and walked through the beautiful park. Visiting the Borghese Gallery was just lovely.

Must go for people who appreciate fine art. In my opinion Borghese Gallery is one of the best/most important collection of fine art in the world. Visit to Rome without visiting this gallery won't be complete. Unlike Louvre, Metropolitan or Hermitage it's compact enough to see complete exposition in a few hours before you get really tired.Everything displayed there is the first class fine art, especially collection or sculpture.It is not overfilled by tourists and you are not rushed by the crowd like in Sistine Chapel.Big plus is beautiful park where Gallery is located.Warning: you need to order tickets at least few weeks before visiting to get convenient time/date.

A gem in Rome. The Gallery collection is outstanding, especially the Bernini sculptures. The way that the gallery limits numbers (for 2 hours) gives you plenty of room to view each object. Make sure that you book well in advance. The Vatican should take a lesson from Borghese and limit numbers. That tour was much too crowded.

Lucky to get tix on our last day in Rome.. Make sure you reserve or prebuy your tix! We almost blew it. Our group was waffling on dates and times when we realized that the next 5 days at BG were all sold out with only 4 days left to visit in Rome! I telephoned the BG and they said no way. I asked if i could just go down and buy if there is a cancellation. The BG said we could try but it was unlikely. My wife and I took a chance and went first thing in the morning on our last day and luckily got tix for 3PM later that day. Well worth it. The Bernini sculptures and the building are beautiful. I like Bernini's David better than MA's David in Florence. Because of the limited admissions, the crowds are actually minimal compared to the other big Rome attractions. We had moments where we had a room to ourselves to enjoy the art. You can also get up close to the sculptures. I hope this does not change in the future.

Paintings were a big "meh". Overall the grounds are huge but the actual museum is tiny: just two floors of sculptures and then paintings. The rooms themselves are impressive (almost Versailles-like) with ornate frescos in every room. But the main attraction (the actual "galleries") were a very limited baroque/Christian paintings- most of them portraits on the smaller side. If that's your thing, great, but we breezed thru the floor in 15minutes flat be completely unsatisfied. The sculpture floor features some more interesting and famous work. Somewhat worth going to but not considering the complications of reservations in advance (which is NOT clearly stated online) and the proximity to other great European museums. You can do better!

Amazing collection showcased in a Grand Palazzo, don't miss this Roman jewel. Colosseum, Capitoline Hill, Pantheon, Piazza Navona, Gallery Borghese, this is the usual roster of Rome main attractions. Well, let's say that Borghese shall (arguably) top the list. Not only it offers one of the most amazing art collections in the world, very carefully and tastefully selected, but the collection is housed exactly where it was originally intended to be housed. The degree of preservation, and the upkeep is par excellence. We won't bore our fellow travellers with extensive/excessive details pertaining to the museum. Any guide book or reliable online source would suffice. We simply have to mention an uncomparable line-up of Bernini's sculptures, including several undisputable chef d'oeuvres. The works of Caravaggio, and specifically 'The Sick Bacchus' are first class, even for Caravaggio. Bellini, Leonardo, Rafael, Rubens, Titian, Veronese, Canova, you just got to see it all, Renaissance and Baroque alike.A few practical advices. First is how to get there. We got a bit concerned when Google Maps gave us 43 minutes' walk from our Piazza Navona hotel, so we used Uber (very unreliable in Rome). This was unnecessary, for a leisurely walk to or from Piazza del Popolo, made pleasant by the arbory shade, was a twenty minutes' breeze. Secondly, your visit is limited to two hours only. You can either book your tickets online (several sites offer Borghese tickets for sale, some do overcharge; we would recommend www.tosc.it, that we equally used for Castel sant'Angelo and other Roman attractions). We, however, opted for a small group tour; it is inexpensive and provides you with a thoughtful selection of a knowledgeable yet lively guide (at least such was our great guide Massimo). Venturing on your own, being limited to two hours only, may present a certain challenge.Can't recommend the attraction high enough.

Breathtaking sculptures. Book in advance- we booked one month before our arrival in Rome- since limited numbers allowed at one time. The building is beautiful but for me the sculptures are exquisite. Bernini was an unequaled Master- so worth the visit.

Superlative Museum. We visited this lovely gallery in early May, having made our reservations while still in the US. The collection is overwhelming. What pleased me is my son, who is not a great fan of art museums, totally fell in love with the Bernini Persephone and Daphne. He explored every floor and was the last to leave. It is set in beautiful gardens, there is access to food in the surrounding town, and it was a nice place to sit outside in the park and talk afterwards. Allow plenty of time. There is an elevator for handicapped access, but you need a guide to get you on it. Stairs and steep and winding at times.

Breathtaking but book tickets in advance!. This gallery is tastefully placed in one of the largest public parks in Rome. I was advise walking to the gallery, there are fabulous views of Rome along the way and plenty of benches within the park itself to stop if feeling tired. The park itself is dotted with sculptures and fountains. I was with one of my parents so we also rented a small golf buggy-type car cheaply an drove part of the way to the museum on the small paths within the park.The collection is beautiful with painting by all the famous italian painters and other European works. The collection is housed in a beautiful old villa. You are not allowed bring your handbags or other things along with you, this all must be placed into the free locker system which is busy and you will have to stand in line for this. This museum stands out as one of the most beautiful galleries I have ever been in. Book your tickets in advance- there will be a certain amount of tickets available at the gallery for later that day but you will need to come early.

Stunning Art Collection. A lovely gallery, set in beautiful gardens. This gallery quite simply holds the most beautiful sculptures I've ever seen. The Bernini statues really look like people that have just been turned to marble. A must for anyone who loves sculpture & beautiful art.

Spectacular. Get your tickets ahead of time (weeks ahead by internet) the number of visitors per blocks of two hours is very limited. It's great, because it allows you to enjoy the many works of art without ever feeling crowded. Do not get concerned by the long queue, as soon as it starts moving (time that your visit is scheduled at) it goes quite fast. Look at every ceiling in each room, each is more spectacular than the other. The Caravaggio room alone is worth the visit. A must when visiting Rome.
Good. We enjoyed the gallery but made the mistake of booking our tickets online. Paid over 25 euros each when the face value is 11 euros. The website looked as though it was direct. Watch out!,

Awesome. Bernini sculptures were incredibly beautiful. Advance tickets are a MUST. Number of guests regulated and spaced so there is plenty of time to enjoy the Villa and the art. Surrounding park is beautiful.

An Italian Job. Galleria Borghese contains some of the best marble sculptures I have ever seen. Bernini's "Rape of Proserpine" and "Apollo and Daphne" alone are reasons to go. However be very conscious of the time allocation.First of all, don't even think of getting in without prior booking of a time slot and tickets. They will not entertain anyone without ticket reservations.I took the first slot of 9am-11am, was advised to arrive half hour earlier but the door only opened 5 minutes to 9. Then there's the line to get the physical ticket. After that we have to get in line to check the bag, no bags allowed no matter how small. And then back in line for the audio guide. By the time I am ready for the museum, 20 minutes are gone, and none of that was my fault.My suggestion is to be picky (really picky) on what you want to listen on the audio guide because if you are interested in most everything available on the guide, you will not get through the museum. The announcement that the 2 hour time slot is up came 15 minutes before 11. Mueseum staff started herding people out. When I tried to get a quick run through of what's left of the galleries, the staff started closing doors in my face. So effectively you get 1.5hours or less.A great museum, but not a friendly one. The surrounding park is very pleasant so I ended up spending the rest off my morning there.

The masters in an intimate museum. This museum is small and they limit the visitors so it is never too crowded. The sculpture is unbelievable. I have never been inside and have visited Rome many times and I will never miss it again! What a treat!

Not to miss. Such a wonderful gallery and grounds. You have to make a reservation (easy to do online) as they keep the amount of people in the gallery to a certain size limit. This is worth so much because it is not crowded. Just beautiful works from Bernini - a true treat. Easy to get to.

An Amazing Collection!. Make reservations as far in advance as possible. Walk-ups are difficult if not impossible. Admission times are set with only so many allowed in during each session. Unless you have a private tour guide, an audio guide rented from the gallery is absolutely necessary. You would be able to look at the beautiful artwork but unless you're are an art major you would get lost in a hurry. And audio guide is just a five euros and two people can listen to the same device.Among the memorable exhibits are Bernini's Apollo and Daphne where Daphne begins to turn into a tree at Apollo's touch. It is a remarkable masterpiece. The other is Bernini's David - the twisted torso, the determination on his face and the slingshot about to be released. Bernini was an extraordinary sculptor.You cannot linger too long because at the end of the one hour and 30 minutes they clear the gallery. This is a smart move because it never becomes too crowded and requires that you be efficient in your viewing of the exhibits.We will visit this gallery again when we come back to Rome. This time I would have a private tour given by a guide from Miles and Miles.

One of the Most Beautiful Art Museums in the World. Pope Paul V Nephew's Collection.. Who but that genius Gian Lorenzo Bernini could carve an attractive young girl turning into a tree? Let alone finishing off building Saint Peter's and the Fountain in Piazza Novona.He and Canova could make marble talk. Meet Napoleon's restless, little sister Pauline as she reclines on her chaise lounge.This fantastic collection of Pope Paul the Fifth Borghese's nephew, Cardinal Scipione Borghese includes the top artists of his times,- Titian and Raphael. I guess that these two gentlemen were in the right position to pick the best, let alone to build a nice little Villa in the local park. However, as Wiki. states, this is only part of his collection.As many Tripadvisors relate, even on 'Skip the Line' you are lucky to be able to buy a ticket these days with the Chinese and all of Asia now in a position to be able to appreciate Western Art. Brian, from Perth. W. Australia.

Some great artwork in a crowded and stuffy area. First of all, get your tickets a few weeks in advance. If you plan to go day-of, you will not get in.  The room with the Caravaggios was extremely crowded. The lighting is also not great, so there's a glare on most of the artwork that you have to move around to get a good view. The Caravaggios, however, are some of his best (though all of his work is pretty much his very best). It is not air-conditioned, it is very crowded, and extremely stuffy.  The artwork incorporated into the building itself is all outstanding. All in all, the house itself is a masterpiece, and houses some great artwork. It is worth the ticket price.

little pricey. there is a very good collection of sculpture and paintings here but the display needs to improve the lighting to highlight the art and not shine down into your eyes as you view the pieces. it was not a singular problem as i then watched many patrons shielding their eyes at various times. i have been to art exibits around the world and found that by comparison this one is overpriced for admittance. so, improve the lighting and lower the price and i'll then raise my rating.
Roma. Wonderful location in huge garden park with other museums. Rent a quadricycle. Schedule at least 4 hours. Easy access by bus, taxi or metro.

Fabulous!!!. We had a private tour with a docent. It just happened to be available so we did not do the self directed as we had planned. She was very informative and loved her art. Borghese is nice because they control the number of people who go in at a given time. Pre-order your tickets. Buy before you leave home!

Don't miss. This is my favorite place in Rome. I recommend to book tickets online in order to avoid long lines and to ensure your visit. The gallery is situated in a beautiful park. The price is 17 euro. You can see Raphael, Caravaggio and Canova. It takes between 1 and 2 hours to see.

Don't Miss, better than the Vatican Museum. First of all, you must get your tickets online, because they limit (thankfully) the number of people in the museum which makes it very enjoyable. When we went there on April 26, they were sold out until May 6. Also keep in mind that the museum is closed on Mondays, amd make sure you get the audio tour.Close to the Metro, the gallery has sculptures and paintings that are probably the most beautiful I've ever seen. You get a 2 hour window to view all the artwork, and it is a reasonable amount of time to see everything.
Skip the line. The art here is truly amazing. It most definitely a must see while in Rome. I did a tour with City Wonders and would recommend it to any one.

You really have to prebook - rating not relevant as we couldn't get in. We prebooked lots of attractions before we travelled but unfortunately not the gallery. It was booked up for days when we got there so we never got to see inside. You can visit the gardens though.

A must for art lovers. For lovers of Caravaggio, Raphael and Bernini, this is a must. David, Apollo & Daphne and the Rape of Proserpine by Bernini are all here. Then you can trace the development of Caravaggio through five paintings starting with his self portrait to the Boy with a Basket of Fruit and the Madonna of the Palafrenieri. Raphael's The Deposition of Christ and Woman with a Unicorn are both there in splendid condition. Although you can visit on your own, taking a guided tour with someone who knows the works so well brings a better insight into what you are looking at.

You don't have to be an art lover to appreciate Villa Borghese. This was a gem we were not expecting, not only were the exhibits stunning but the building itself was stunningly beautiful. Every room has the most magnificent painted ceilings, so before you take in the art and sculptures you are captivated by the beautiful ceilings. There is so much to see, the beautiful sculptures that are so old you can't quite take it in, and the paintings of the best of Italian artists make it a superb couple of hours. We were on a guided tour but I believe you need to book in advance otherwise you will not be allowed in. It's best to check on all the attractions as there are so many tourists here most places will need to be prebooked to avoid disappointment. The Villa Borghese is a must see, don't go to Rome and miss this.

Spectacular! Absolutely see this!. The interior of the Borghese Gallery is quite ornate and enough reason for a visit, but the real attractions are the Bernini sculptures. They are so impressive, it is hard to take your eyes away from them. The lifelike details are breathtakingly beautiful. Each room is a masterpiece in itself with frescoes on the ceilings, ornate marble floors, lovely paintings, and sculptures, but when you see those Bernini pieces, all else fades into the background. You must make a reservation in advance. Don't miss this, it is an unforgettable collection.

Breathtaking. We were so luck to get same day tickets to the Borghese Gallery. The artwork and sculptures are incredible, and the mansion itself has amazing decor. The two hours allotted is more than plenty to view all the art. The garden and the grounds are just as stunning so definitely add that to your itinerary. Also, the Roma Pass helps save a lot of money to this place, and it is possible to get same day passes (just go first thing in the morning to give yourself plenty of time) though be on the safe side and make reservations.

Dissapointing......... To be fair to the Galleria, it's not their fault. I tried to visit 10 years ago but was unable to get tickets. In the mean time I have built it up to be something it is not. Don't get me wrong, this is a great stately home with a vast art collection. The art is mainly of a period older than I personally like. However, I do not wish to put you off. The grounds themselves of Villa Borghese are worth a visit alone. If you wish to see the Galleria you will need to book online. So if it is your thing, do it. Public transport is not straight forward. On a hot day, get a taxi from Termini. If you intend to walk, I find going from Flamini Metro the most straightforward. As you exit the Metro station walk up the hill and keep going, keeping your eyes on Villa Borghese Perimeter on your left. You will then find the entrance reasonably easily.

Borghese Gallery--Wonderful Gallery!. Fabulous private collection! Read the former reviews and tips, particularly Rockjoe's--the audio guide and paper guide take a few minutes to figure out--know in advance what you want to concentrate on and go directly to that area--they do make you exit in two hours, and time can get away easily. And don't even think about going without reservations. You enter at the ground level at the center of the building. Arrive 45 minutes in advance of your reservation time--it stated on line to arrive 30 minutes in advance; a telephone confirmation gave a time of 45 minutes, so we arrived 40 minutes early and were told we were 5 minutes late, but "we could go in." As soon as you can, get the audio guide and get in line to be admitted. Afterwards, visit the cafe near the zoo and get a Caffe de Parc---wonderful!

Great Gallery, Research Bus Stops, Take Waist Pack, Take Photos. Famous paintings and sculpture. You must have a reservation, and you will probably need to arrange weeks in advance. Call them using Google for free or nearly free. They will want you to check all large bags, but I was able to carry a medium fanny pack with my coat draped over the strap. They called it a "pouch." There is one sign saying No Flash, other photos are OK. As the gallery is distant from other attractions, you will probably want to take a bus. The return bus stop for Termini is not near the arrival stop, it may be wise to inquire where to go before leaving the gallery! We didn't, and it took a while to find the stop, requiring us to ask non-English speakers. As the gallery is cleared every two hours (actually less), when a group is admitted, some start up, and some down stairs. If you use the audio guide, you should be able to get through in time. They want a photo ID left as security for the audio guide, as with all museums we went to. I used an International Driver's License. You may want to bring some ID that wouldn't be a disaster to lose, just for museums. The audio guide has a recessed 3.5 mm receptacle. If you use a splitter and your own headsets, (so you only need one audio guide), make sure your splitter will go deep. There is a cafe at the gallery with reasonable prices. If you arrive early, you can eat or stroll around the huge grounds.

Stunning - but you must pre book. The Galleria Borghese is situated in the Pincio Gardens, which provides a peaceful haven from the hustle and bustle of Rome. Walking up through Rome from the Termini you pass through one of the city's 'smart' areas where there are embassies, posh hotels, cafes and restaurants. Once into the Gardens you walk along tree line boulevards. There weren't many flowers out when we visited (May) but the trees afforded a welcome shade from the unusually hot sun. The Galleria - like a few others of the must see sites, currently has scaffolding round it, but it is inside where the spectacular starts. Entrance is only by pre-booked ticket which means numbers are controlled and you get 2 hours to view masses of art and sculpture by some of the most famous artists ever, such as Canova, Bernini, Caravaggio, Rapahel and Titian. You can get up close and have a good look. Photography was allowed but not flash. Take a look out of the windows as you pass through the galleries as you get good views of the formal gardens. After our visit we took the little road train, which for 3 euros takes you for quite a long ride through the Picio Gardens and sets down high above the Piazza del Popolo, where you get magnificent views over the city. You are not allowed to take bags, rucsacs etc round the gallery, but there is a free left luggage facility where your gear is locked up.

One of the World's Greatest Museums. Carefully curated and displayed masterpieces in rooms which are themselves works of art in this splendid Villa. You must reserve your visit. You will be permitted 2 hours time to visit the collection. Then all museum-goers are cleared from the galleries to make room for the next two-hour group. I thought I wouldn't like being told when to leave, but the plan avoids the crunch of over-crowding which makes the Vatican Museums ever more unenjoyable to visit. Most people don't stay over an hour and so your second hour in the galleries will seem strangely uncrowded. The Italians are to be congratulated for this fine experience. Bravo!

Awesome art. Unbelievable sculptures by Bernini that are inspiring. Love the fact that tey control the traffic by limiting tickets. That said, if you plan on going book well in advance. It is a bit of a distance from the center of Rome so plan accordingly

Amazing pieces of art, bad signs to access.... If you like sculpture you can´t miss this gallery. There are several Bernini works that are beautiful and inspiring, and other interesting sculptures and paintings, like Caravaggio´s. The good thing about this place is that, as if you don´t reserve you probably don´t enter, the visitors are well distributed. The ticket is valid for 2 hours and you have an specific time to check in. It is enough for the size of the gallery, and allows you to admire a piece of art with less people around it. Mi favourite piece: "El rapto de Proserpina". Please be advised that the gallery is not part of the Palace named like it that is more or less near Piazza Navona. It is near Villa Medici and very far away from that private property. The signs to access are terrible.

Book well in advance!. We were recommended to visit the villa, but were unable to buy tickets because they were sold out for a full week from our arrival (we tried to buy tickets at the door). Make sure you book your tickets well ahead of time if you want to visit this museum so you don't have the same issues we had. :(

Breathtaking, yet so hot one can hardly breathe. Enjoyed a privately guided tour of the former home of one of the wealthiest families in Italy's history. The villa is large and beautiful; the decoration and use of antiquities in the interior was foreshadowed by the collection of artifacts, works of masters in paint and sculpture, and some remarkable baroque period heirloom furnishings. We had incredibly hot weather while in Rome, it was 35 degrees Celsius or 95 degrees Fahrenheit the day we visited. Arrived at 9am and cut short our visit at 10:30 because there was no air conditioning and no amount of complaining would stir an employee to open more windows for a cross breeze - it was sweltering and every guest was complaining. We exited after a granita at the coffee bar, quite exquisite and appreciated, and the coffee bar staff were a delight. Roaming the gardens and vast property was the needed respite for the still hot air in the Borghese Villa. I gave 4 of 5 because any one of their priceless artifacts would more than cover the best air conditioning system in the world a hundred times over, yet it's not to be!

The highlight of my trip. The Borghese Gallery was the highlight of my trip to Rome. I teach a World Thought and Culture class, so several of the works there are ones that I talk about in the class. It was awesome seeing them first hand. I marvel at Bernini's sculptures and Caravaggio's works. The gallery is not as massive as some, so it's very manageable, but allow yourself plenty of time.

Art Gallery. Probably the greatest private art collection ever assembled. Some truly stunning pieces that you are likely to recognise from copies in any number of other galleries and museums around the world. Located in a pleasant Park tickets can be difficult to get in season and I would advise purchasing in advance of your visit. Tickets are for time slots so only valid between a particular 2/3 hour slot. May appear expensive until you get in then you realise this is a viewing you will never forget.
Awe inspiring. The Bernini sculptures housed here will take your breath away. Order tickets in advance for your 2 hour timed admission. It is well worth the visit.

Make sure you Reserve your Tickets!. A wonderful, crowd-free visit to see some of the most amazing sculptures I've seen! Bernini's sculpture of Apollo and Daphne executed in 1622-1625 when he was 24 years old is wonderful. Daphne is changed into a tree to escape and her fingers have turned inti delicate leaves. Loved Pauline Bonaparte lazing on her chaise- she looks so comfortable.Leave plenty of time to reach the entrance to the Museum and the 2 hour timeframe is strictly observed. A great spot to start your descent down the Spanish Steps about a 15 minute walk away. Hardly any crowd at the top of the steps but then you descend into chaos.
Not enough words. An exhilarating experience - yes, it would be better with a guide but only had a short time and was still amazed at the exhibits and sculptures.

Amazing. The Borghese Gallery is an art gallery located in the Villa Borghese in Rome, Italy. This huge park is located just north of central Rome and can be found by taking the metro to the Spagna station and then following the signs. After you leave the long metro tunnel it is a little confusing but just keep walking north about a block and you will run into the park. There are signs in the park that lead you to the only large white mansion inside the Park (the Borghese Gallery is inside this mansion). The Galleria Borghese houses a large part of the Borghese Collection of sculptures and paintings begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese (nephew of Pope Paul V). Cardinal Borghese was a huge art collector and built this mansion to house his collection. Part of the collection (about 500 pieces) was sold by his heirs to Napoleon in 1807 and that art became an important part of the Louvre in Paris. I visited this amazing art museum at 9 AM on a Tuesday morning in mid-March with my wife and daughter and really enjoyed looking at the old mansion and the great art collection inside it. To enter you need a timed reservation and then only have 2 hours to see the entire museum until the next group of ticket holders enter and you are required to leave. I purchased our tickets on the gallery web site a few weeks before arriving in Rome. Since we had a 9 AM reservation it was not very crowded. The lines seemed much longer for the 11 AM reservations. The building is not very big so it is relatively easy to see the entire collection. We were done visiting this gallery in about 1:45 minutes.I rented an audio guide but my wife and daughter did not. I liked the audio guide tour but thought it gave way to much information. It was a little confusing as the paper building map they give you with your ticket uses a different room numbering system than the audio guide. After walking through a couple of rooms a woman saw that I was having trouble and showed me how the audio guide number system worked (she was also confused but eventually figured it out). I am not sure why the audio guide did not just use the numbering system used in the paper map. Overall I really enjoyed this amazing art gallery and also liked touring the mansion (as it was also a work of art). The many Bernini sculptures were the highlight of the gallery. I really enjoyed looking at the two Busts of Scipione Borghese by Bernini. He sculpted the first one and then found a flaw in the marble so easily made an identical second copy. We passed small groups of people taking guided tours with professional tour guides and they seemed to be getting lots of information. Afterwards we walked around the entire building and walked through the small garden in the back. You can also look at the old birdhouse (a small building on the side with two large wire roofs). After touring the garden we spent some time walking through the Villa Borghese.

Amazing collection, captivating at every turn. Originally, we were going to book with our Roma Pass, which you can only do over the phone. I found the rep on the phone blunt and less than friendly.We ended up going on a Sunday, which made the visit free and did not require booking ahead of time. We arrived extra early to avoid the tour groups and huge crowds.The museum is breathtaking. We had audioguides, which made the visit more meaningful. What stands out about this attraction is not only the beautiful pieces, but the walls, doors, floors, and ceilings that house these pieces. There are magnificent mosaics and carvings to look at at every turn.

Amazing. The Borghese Gallery has some amazing artwork. The Bernini sculptures and the Caravaggio painting are truly worth seeing up close. Unless you are an art historian, I recommend going with a tour guide to fully appreciate.

Wonderful. This is a wonderful gallery. Be sure to buy tickets and reserve time ahead. After visiting the gallery walk around the gardens and park. Lovely. We used the auto guide and there was some paintings that were a little mixed up but otherwise was great.
Great collection. Wonderful exhibits with the most important of Bernini and Caravaggio.. Not too crowded as the most sights in Rome.. It could be combined with a walk or a relax to the park.

An amazing collection in one location. We visited the Borghese Gallery as part of a tour. The walls are adorned with magnificent artworks and the sculptures throughout the gallery are stunning. The historical background of the gallery is so interesting it is easy to spend a few hours.Make sure to visit as part of a tour as visits are strictly limited and you cannot just turn up and visit.

Great of course, but.... Overcrowding,despite timed visits, makes the experience less wonderful than the art.Well the Bernini are perfect no matter what the conditions. But too many large and loud tours disturb and the lack of clarity about entry rules -- you must check your bag, but then see so many who have not -- you must line up here -- or there, makes entry annoying.

Not to be missed!. First things first: to visit the Borghese Gallery it's essential to get a reservation. I say this although we managed to get in without one because I left it too late to book, but that route is not to be recommended! Basically we waited and eventually managed to get a couple of 'no show' tickets. Entrance numbers are strictly controlled, and only by having a reservation can you be sure of getting in. On the first Sunday of the month entrance is free, but a reservation is still necessary, and these free days book even further ahead. The exhibits are stunning, in particular we loved the Bernini sculptures - the Apollo and Dafne, and the Rape of Proserpina were breathtaking. The gallery is set in a large park, perfect for relaxing and with beautiful views of the City from the Pincian Hill. Definitely one of our favourite places in Rome.

Must see when in Rome. I spent about 4 hours going through the Galleria, Bring a good camera and cell phone for pictures of all the artworks and statues. Since this was my first trip I wanted to see it all. Was not over crowded, and was not rushed by the staff. Truly enjoyed this visit

Very nice museum. Ok I liked it..i am not big on the galleries but i did enjoy..Now very important is to get your tickets online few weeks in advance.. Firstly they let only certain amount of people onside and you can stay only 2 hours.And second they run out of available spaces very fast so if you are planing to visit the gallery book your ticket online in advance.

One one sights of Rome. Don't miss this treasure. Beautiful villa filled with the best art in Rome. The grounds are Romes backyard, filled with families enjoying the park. We hired a private guide and it was worth it for the depth of knowledge gained. Your time in the villa is restricted, too short to see it all. Reservations are mandatory.

Wonderful!. One of my favorite things in Rome. The Bernini sculptures were breathtaking. Worth the price of admission just to see them. As audio guides go, theirs was a good one. Book ahead--Borghese fills up early. First thing in the morning is best. We had reservations at 9 and it was not crowded at all. When we left at 11, it was mobbed with long lines

Must book in advance!. It was the first time I did serious research befor we traveled and found out this Museum was an absolute must. I also read that you have to make a reservation prior to getting there if you want to get in (even better if you do it before you reach Rome). It doesn't matter if you got the RomaPass, you still need to call and reserve your spot in order to enter.I wasn't very thrilled about the calling ahead part so I searched for tickets online. If you want to be sure you'll be able to get in, I advise you to buy tickets online for the Borghese Gallery the second you book your Rome vacation.3 days before leaving for Rome I started browsing for tickets and it was sold out. Luckily i was able to book via Viator for 30€/person. We payed by card, no printed voucher needed, got there, met with the guide (you must be there 15 minutes prior to the admission hour) and got the tickets.Before we entered i saw the price printed on the ticket (11€/person) and felt i had been scamed having payed 30€/person, but the second we got in I saw a large sign saying they were fully booked until 19.05 (we visited on 12.05) and I felt instant relief and joy for being inspierd enough to buy the tickets online.As for the Gallery itself: OUT OF THIS WORLD AMAZING!~We fell in love with this ceiling

Great Decision!. This was something we decided to do on the spur of the moment but we didn't realize you needed reservations to go. We decided to try our luck on possible cancellations but no such luck. A very nice employee talked with us and we explained we would not be able to come back, as we were leaving the next day. She allowed us a 3:00 ticket - not before - and we were thrilled. The gallery is something to see! Fabulous works of art! Make your reservations and go. What did we do until 3:00? The whole area is a beautiful park. We rented a bike and toured around, relaxed in the grass, enjoyed the fountains....We thought about the zoo that is on the property but it was school "field trip" day so we opted not to fight the crowds of little kids.

One of the great art museums of the world. If all art museums were like this one and the Louvre, people would actually like going to art museums. Borghese was a rapacious patron and collector of visual art during one of the great periods of the production of visual art. Go to the website and see the nuber of historically great artists who have one or more items on display in this place. Hire a professional guide from a good company so you get the history behind each work you view. Whatever else you see, be sure to see Bernini's David. Such human expression is nowhere else captured in marble.

breath taking. This is by far one of THE highlights of our trip to Rome !!!!this museum is mind blowing !!!!! be sure to order tickets in advance thru their website !!!!! they only let in a certain amount of people at a time for a two hour tour and they are sold out way in advance !!!!an hour was enough for us but we didn't use a tour guide device .... u can't take your bag with u and only a camera with no flash is allowed .there are stairs and much walking but they can accomadate people with special needs which was nice to see.... the galleria is in an amazing park we walked from one end to the other but there r other fun ways to enjoy the park with bikes and electric open cars for rent ... we started from the southern point where you can enjoy an amazing view of the city and walked up north to the galleria

A wonderful visit and excellent guide. We booked ahead for the visit and joined a guided tour of the gsllery which was both informative and enjoyable. The 2 hour slot is not enough for this wonderful museum but the guide made sure thay our time eas maximally efficient.

Museum Superb, Staff Not So Much. The Bernini sculptures, the Caraaggio and Raphael paintings are over the top wonderful to spend time admiring. The staff range from simply not caring to being obnoxiously unhelpful. All in all, the people running the place are worth suffering through because the Art takes you higher. Other museums, like Kunsthistorische Museum, Metropolitan, Art Institute in Chicago, MOMA - all more fun and fulfilling to visit in part because their staff are more professional and you feel good about being there, rather than, as people started doing in the line waiting to get in this place, mooing like cows.
Must see when in rome. The bernini statues are worth the fact that you have to make reservations to visit this museum. You can make reservations easely in advance

Fabulous collection, but book ahead. This little gem is not very well known, yet it has some breathtaking pieces of art. My favorite is the very famous "Apollo and Daphne." Be advised that you do have to get a reservation ahead, but it is worth it. The reservation says you only have 2 hours for the tour, but I didn't find that to be a problem. Give it a try!

Loved the gallery. The staff here are very unfriendly! No matter what size of purse you bring in, you have to check it no matter what. I had a very tiny purse, not even big enough for my regular wallet. I still had to check it regardless, even though their website said, only backpacks and large purses have to be checked. But the gallery itself is wonderful! It's well worth the advance purchase price. Be sure you BOOK in advance! No tickets sold at the door. Only ADVANCE PURCHASE only.

book early. Great gallery but hard to get a ticket for. Book online, it was booked out a week in advance April '15 so cannot use Roma pass. Worth the organization of your plans to see this one. You have to specify a time, only allowed to view for 2 1/2 hours.
sculpture fantastic!. went specifically to see the bernini's and it does not disappoint, yes it can be crowded but fantastic

Must see in Rome. One of those musea where you are still surprised if you love art. Of course I had been here before but there is so much to see of such a high quality that you have to skip somethings. Bernini and Caravaggio are the high lights but the re is so much more. Problem is that you have to book in advance to get tickets to stay only for a few hours. We booked ours for the 9th. We saw that if we had just entered the museum we could have only booked tickets for the 14th earliest! 5 days later! So beware! Book your tickets on the site in advance. The waiting time is not hours as with the Vatican Museum but days! I like the system though because it makes the museum less crowded and we enjoyed that very much.

Book before you leave home!!. This is an unusually short review for me because we couldn't get in to see the gallery! We arrived in Rome on Tuesday so went to the Gallery on Wednesday to see when we could visit - we were staying until Sunday so had flexibility. The first tickets that were available however were for a week after we were due to go home. This is because the numbers of visitors are restricted to avoid huge crowds - unlike the Vatican [q.v]Top tip - you need to book on line in advance and unless you are in Rome for a while do so before leaving home. That way you will be able to see the wonderful exhibits we will have to return to view - hey ho.....

Stephanie delivers excellent background to Borghese Gallery tour. Our tour of the Borghese Gallery and grounds was great. Our guide Stephanie was a great story-teller and delivered excellent background information to each piece of art that we viewed as well as the Borghese grounds. Despite the crowds she held our attention and put each work in context. We learned a lot. It was an excellent tour and we highly recommend it.

Number one art experience in Rome. Capitoline -National -Etruscan-Montemartini-Plazzo Barberini and of course the Vatican-all full of "wonderful things". Nothing can top the collections in the Vatican-It must have been very good indeed to be Pope-but it is the quality of the experience that makes the Borghese my number one recommendation for art lovers. The Vatican sells tickets in unlimited numbers and puts 40,000 through in a day. Going there and trying to see through the tour groups is like riding the New York subway at rush hour. Seeing the Sistine Chapel crowded like sardines in a huge can with constant amplified voices calling for silence and no pictures was not fun. If you can afford it by all means go with an early entry tour. Besides one of the world's greatest art collections, what makes the Borghese stand out for me is the careful, limited and controlled entry.300 people max with a strict two hour limit. Every two hour shift people are ushered out so the next block of people with tickets can have a quality experience. We booked a tour with Walks of Rome-highly recommended. The experienced and knowledgeable guide had the visit timed Down to the minuet , knew how to dodge the other tour groups to be sure of good looks and made sure you got a chance to see all the really important pieces. Otherwise I would have run out of time just walking around and marveling at David or Apollo and Daphne or The Rape of Proserpine or Truth Unveiled By Time, caught in awe, of the genius of Bernini .We were so glad we made the required reservation in March by booking the tour before leaving the US for our early-April visit. The box office had a sigh up-"No tickets until May 5th." when we were there.The Vatican makes sure late comers can get in-and maximizes their biggest single source of revenue-while the Borghese resists the financial incentive to insure a quality experience -but you do need to plan ahead during tourist season.

Impressive. A little off of the regular tourist route in Rome but so worth the effort. A 2 hour time limit is enforced and booking ahead essential. Audio guide was helpful but I found it did not co- ordinate with the brochure.It did match the tag attached to the guide but the rooms were not clearly identified. A little confusing and stressful with the time limit given. The tour is doable in the 2 hours but not if you want to study more items. Impressive building and collection. Washrooms, food, luggage storage and gift shop available. The gardens are impressive As well but a map of them only available with a 5 euro purchase.

Total Sensory Overload. There are not enough superlative adjectives to describe this gallery and this comes from someone who does not necessarily get all excited about art galleries or museums, but this really is a feast for the eyes. Floors, ceiling and walls are all works of art and then there is the actual ART. Tickets are available to book on line and entry times are strictly enforced, which means that the galleries are not too crowded, affording really good views of the paintings and sculptures. I would recommend that you give yourself at least two hours. We had initially thought an hour would suffice, but it took all five of us an hour just to appreciate the ground floor, which is given over primarily to sculpture, we rushed through the first floor in thirty minutes, but could easily have done with more time.The Borghese requires everyone to leave handbags, backpacks and such in a checked area, but cameras are permitted.

Not to be missed. Easy to miss this out if you are on a tight schedule but if you're an art lover, find the time. Tickets easy to get on-line, nice walk to the gallery through the park, excellent organisation. The crowd all turned to the right as they got to the top of the stairs, my friend and I turned left and we had the magnificent Bernini statues to ourselves for awhile.The rooms are stunning and there are information cards in English. Absolutely fabulous works of art and well presented. It didn't take us the full 2 hours as we skipped some of the works we were less interested in.There is a small cafe with not much sitting down space but the prices are good. We caught the little train to save our feet, I think it is 3 Euros.

Beautiful. You must order ticket in advance!!!For example, at May 5th all ticket were sold until May 10th!Come in half an hour in advance for ticketing and procedure. they open in exact time as in the ticket. English group guide is only in the morning, audio guide any time.For kids it is close to the zoo and nice park around.Do your homework and read about the painters in advance there is much to see.Prepare your camera (battery and memory)....

Wonderful museum!. If you are an Art/History lover this is a must visit while in Rome.We were there on a beautiful, sunny Sunday in April and the whole experience was great.Apart from the major works of sculptors like Bernini and art work from the likes of Reuben, the architecture is well worth a visit.I think I enjoyed it more than the Vatican as it is smaller, there are less crowds and it is maybe a more pleasant experience.A couple of recommendations:- you MUST buy your ticket in advance and book a time. There were several disappointed people who showed up thinking they could get in and were told the next available space was the following week!- The gallery is deep in the park so allow at least half and hour to walk in from a metro stop. I think there may be a closer place for a taxi to the east of the park. While in the park enjoy a ride around on one of the many "vehicles" that you can enjoy.

OK, but Better Sights in Rome. Gallery is a pain to reserve and get to. Timed entries every 2 hrs. Must buy tix in advance. Would by tix in advance to Vatican Museum and Scavi tour under the Vatican and see 10 times as much for the price. Some spectacular work here, but would have gone somepace else if I knew.

Do not miss this! Bernini's work can't be missed!. I am not really into art but this place blew me away... Please give a chance even if you are normally not into this stuff! Bernini's Rape of Proserpina is amazing! Pictures DO NOT do it justice, you have to see it for yourself. Even if that is the only thing that "wows" you (which it wont be as there are many other great works), it would still be worth it!! I recommend getting an audio guide as it gives more context to the art and helps you understand/admire it more.

Astonishing!. The Borghese is two floors of displays. One is paintings, the other sculpture. Rooms are 270 degree art (the floor is not used). Bernini's sculptures in particular are inspiringly beautiful. Go. It is the ultimate of Rome.

Fantastic, but book in advance. Book in advance! Its the only way to get in. Well worth the money. You wonder if you will fill 2 hours allotted to you, but (if you are into art) you will find yourself being shoved out the door. The sculptures are wonderfulFree (compulsory) bag drop, we were allowed to take cameras in. No large bags allowedCould maybe do with more seats, but I just sat on the floor to gaze at the ceilings.

Borghese Gallery is just amazing. What an experience! We had a timed ticket with a two hour bracket, which was the only way we could be admitted. Once we got inside the rooms, it was very comfortable. We did not feel rushed. Next time I'll take a different route than the crowds. We spent the entire afternoon, but I could have stayed all day just because of the Bernini sculptures alone.

Magnificent collection in a beautiful park / advanced reservation required. The building is very beautiful, and the collections are extraordinary, even when you are not amateur of that style of paintings. There are Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio to name a few. It takes about 2 hours to visit everything.The only negative point is the attitude of the waitresses of the cafeteria in the basement who don't care about their customers and prefer to chat between themselves.

Collection of a lifetime. While this museum is a bit of trouble to get into to, it is worth it. Visitors must book tickets as much as a month out. There will rarely if ever be tickets available on a walk in basis. And, visitors only have 2 hours to explore. That's it. I could have stayed twice that long. Having studied some of these works 20+ years ago, and having loved them all my life, it was a dream come true to be standing right in front of them. Absolutely overwhelming.The Roman mosaics on the floor were super cool. Very impressive to see such ancient art, preserved for hundreds of years this way.However, I was very disappointed in the lighting of the oil paintings. I am from a mid sized midwestern city in the US, and even us hicks know how to properly light a painting like a Caravaggio or a Titian. In the Gallerie Borghese, the paintings are often lit with a single flood lamp, which creates a big glare spot, making it impossible to enjoy the whole painting at once. I had to walk around and get a bunch of different vantage points, and then try to reconstruct the whole thing in my mind. It was a bummer for me.And why are visitors allowed to take flash photographs of these priceless treasures? This does not sound right.But even with that, I don't think there is anything man made that is more beautiful than some of these Italian masters' works. The sculptures were literally breath taking. Bernini was the real deal, ya'll. Apollo & Daphne will just boggle your mind. It doesn't even look like marble, because the textures are so super realistic. Look at their fingers. And their mouths. The figures look like they are about to turn their heads and look at you and say, "Aren't we gorgeous????"Really dug the Paolina Borghese Venus Victrix by Canova, too. The picture gallery upstairs was pretty impressive, too, but could have also benefitted from some better lighting and better organization... some works were jammed up very close to each other, others were so spread out or high up on a wall it was hard to see them.Audio tour was pretty good. That really helps visitors get the most out of what they are looking at. I highly recommend buying tickets for this museum if you are going to be in Rome for a few days or more.The park around the museum looks great for picnicking, or walking, or people watching.

Stunning collection. Bernini's sculptures are definitely the star here, but there are so many beautiful paintings to see as well! Most of the paintings are upstairs, and frankly it can be an overwhelming amount of art. I do wish I had used one of the audio guides as the pamphlets out front just give a bit of map of the rooms without much additional information, but even without the guide any art lover should be able to appreciate the gallery. There are books in the gift shop that delve into more detail about each piece (also books for children, prints, jewelry, and a handful of Bernini figurines). The work on the ceilings is absolutely breathtaking, and the second floor is much less crowded than the first, so we started there and worked our way back down. Photography is prohibited, though everyone around me seemed to be flashing pictures (even though cameras were supposed to be checked?) and none of the staff moved to stop them. Bag check is also compulsory, so I didn't bring one--from what I saw it looked as though they were all locked in a single bin so I'm not sure how that really worked. There's also a small cafeteria next to the bookshop.Beyond the gallery, enjoy the rest of the huge park! Our tickets were for 5:00 PM so we walked from our hotel to the park after lunch and spent the afternoon just wandering around and people watching. The zoo is in the same area of the grounds as well.

A great way to spend an afternoon. The gardens and park of the Borghese are beautiful. People riding bikes, pushing baby strollers and playing ball enjoying the day. Be sure you have made reservations beforehand to visit the Borghese Gallery. It is stunning. They do not, however, seem to have some of the artwork placed at a level where it can be truly enjoyed. Some of the painting are hung so high that you have to stand in the middle of the room to view them. This is not always a good vantage point. The collection is amazing and should not be missed.

Make time to lounge in the gardens. The museum was really great (as noted by most of the reviews)! My cappuccino from the cafe was one of the best I had while I was there. Make sure to leave yourself some time to lounge in the grass in front of the gallery. I only spent a few minutes there, but I think I could have spent the whole day!

fabulous art collection. one of the best art collections in Rome featuring Canova, Bernini and 5-7 Caravaggio paintings besides many others. The rooms are outstanding with marble floors and frescoes in the ceilings.
be sure to book online -otherwise you can't get in.

Beautiful grounds, amazing art and sculpture pieces!. Once owned by Scipione Borghese, it was aquired by Rome in 1903 and opened to the public. A patron of Bernini, you'll see his sculptures in the gallery as well as paintings by Raphael, Titian, Reubens...all breathtaking and beautiful. A stroll through the gardens is also a high-point on a beautiful day. You do have to purchase your tickets ahead because visitors are restricted to a certain number every couple of hours, and there are sites on line which provide that service. On the other hand, if you stay at the B&B , Al Colonnato di San Pietro Bed and Breakfast, Anna might just offer to purchase your tickets even before you arrive in Rome and have them waiting for you in your room! Quite frankly, there is no other place to stay in Rome! Breakfast in your room every morning, a quick walk to St Peter's Square? Yes! But I digress...this is a must-see in Rome! We visited in 2010, but the option wasn't in the drop-down menu...:)

Miles Anspd Miles Of Marble. The beautiful building is a fitting setting to the magnificent collection of art. Cardinal Scipione collected many paintings and Renaissance sculpture that contributed to the start of the collection which took over 300 years to get to where it looks today. The Cardinal also commissioned marble recreations of ancient sculpture that are nearly impossible to distinguish from the originals attesting to the skills of the artists he selected.

Excellent gardens not far from the middle of Rome. We never actually found the gallery itself, although we tried to follow the signs to it, but ended up walking all round the gardens and the lake and found them a very attractive retreat from the hustle and bustle of Rome!Beware (as in much of Rome) of expensive refreshments on offer! The gardens are free to visit and well worth it, but bring your own refreshments if you don't want to spend too much.

A must see when visiting Rome. Can't recommend highly enough. Amazing sculptures, beautiful paintings and the gallery itself is stunning. You do have to book beforehand and it is booked months in advance. Lovely walk through the park afterwards takes you to a stunning view of Rome then not very far to the Spanish Steps.

A must see gallery!. This villa is filled with incredible art. Get a ticket in advance on the internet as they are usually sold out. It is set in a beautiful park for a lovely walk or picnic afterwards. The audioguide was well worth it. They made us leave after 2 hours as the next shift came in so time your visit carefully. Go to the 2nd floor first, as the amazing Bernini sculptures are there. They make you check all of your bags!

Disapointing staff.
