Admissions to Borghese gallery are restricted to a fixed number of visitors every 2 hours so we have made online ticket reservation for the last entrance at 5 pm on Saturday in advance. The gallery closes at 7:30 pm, but gallery personell asked us to leave the last hall 10 minutes to 7 pm. They were very eager to close gallery as soon as possible and our explanations that we need last few minutes more to finish our discussion in the last hall were declined strictly. We went downstairs, took our bags from the cloackroom and were outside the gallery 3 minutes before 7 pm wondering why staff is so unfriendly to visitors. The art collection of the gallery is very nice and worth visiting just have in mind that you need to plan your time and be prepared to be kicked out without discussions earlier than it is written on their official site.

We loved this Gallery, Palace & Gardens. You MUST reserve tickets months in advance to get into this incredible Palace and Gallery. Cardinal Borghese was a powerful and wealthy man who acquired (by commission and terrorism) one of the most incredible collections of sculptures and paintings ! Bernini and Ralpheal's works are here, along with Caravaggio !The Borghese Gardens are enormous and free to walk...you'll want to plan extra time to stroll the grounds ! Awesome ! We will come here again for sure !

I want to be a cardinal. It is well worth setting a time and date and online reservations before you get to Rome. You can plan lots of other things around this not to be missed collection. Being a cardinal was a great way to gather so much. I appreciate that he did it for generations to see. It is hard to really absorb everything in two hours, but plan a second visit if you are an art historian. We appreciated the audio, but if you are not so interested in knowing more about the selected items discussed you should not be bored by simply looking and being amazed.We were told that we could not take cameras,but that is not true. Must not flash. They require that you check bags, umbrellas, etc.,Getting there. We took the metro from Ottaviano to Spagna. Once off the train we exited the turnstiles and walked until sign over side tunnel said Villa Borghese and Via Veneto. Follow the Via Veneto signs!!!! You will travel along moving sidewalks and a few escalators. Hope they are working because sometimes they don't. When you have finally reached the top (Via Veneto) pass through the ancient wall, cross the street, follow the signs to GALLERY Borghese. On our way back, we retraced but instead of the tunnel of escalators, walked straight down the Via Veneto to metro Barberini.

See Beautiful Art, Up Close and Personal. For lovers of Italian Renaissance art and sculpture, the Galleria Borghese is not to be missed. Although visitors are allowed only two hours to see some of the world's most magnificent pieces--including dozens of Bernini sculptures and paintings by Caravaggio, Titian and Rubens (to name but a few)--the experience is beyond words. Be sure to bring a guidebook so you can spend time at the art works you most want to see. Start at the third floor and work your way down.

Tip for best viewing at the Borghese. This is not a huge museum. You must have an appointment, and the appointments are 2 hours. Book for the first thing in the am. Once you purchase tickets, you go into a long line. Don't do it! Go out of the lower level ticket area and go up the outside stairs. They open the same time (9) as the lower level. This way you get to see the Bernini sculptures practically on your own. You will want a lot of time for these, esp. Apollo and Daphne. Other big treat is a room full of Caravaggio's.

Breathtaking museum but plan ahead.. One of the finest museum experiences of my life. One blockbuster work after another. But as others have noted, it is absolutely essential that you get tickets ahead of time. They are sold out days and weeks in advance. It is certainly worth the effort, though.

You need to reserve a time window. This is one of the best collections I have seen. Although the access is limited to some hundred visitors per 2h, it's still worthwhile to go early. Take the audio guide and take your time to see the artifacts at a relaxed pace. Make a reservation well ahead, the tickets seel out very quickly.

Make your plans early for Borghese Gallery. We bought tickets a month in advice of our trip and almost did not get in. It's worth getting the tickets. The museum is incredible and since they limit access you won't be crushed by crowds. In the last 20 minutes of our 2 hour time frame the galleries were almost empty. We went through to look at our favorite sculptures and paintings one more time. Note, if the website only offers only one ticket in the timeframe you are considering, that means that is the last ticket. Go to the next timeframe if you need more than one ticket. Whatever it takes, go see the wonderful art work at the Borghese Gallery!

Fantastic collection a gem and a must see in your lifetime. Pre-sale!!!! that's the magic word. If you plan to visit borghese gallery booked on line at least 2-3 months ahead! As they are always sold out!!! Small but collections are amazing!!! I like the sculpture of David! There is maximum of 2 hours time limit I suggest pick either 9am or 1pm entrance! The place is near piazza de populous but you need a long walk and the gallery is at the last end of the road! Many people mistake this for villa Medici.
Burghese gallery. I did not go inside bit the external was amazing - as always the history was amazing to know - Ancient Rome is so full of history

Fascinating museum! Make sure to book your tickets upfront!. We visited this fabulous museum on Sunday afternoon. Small, unique, and includes amazing works of art. Do not forget to check the website of the museum at least one week before your planned visit in order to book your tickets upfront. Otherwise you will not be able to enter the museum.

Limited access. It would have been nice to see the Borghese Gallery, but when we tried to buy tickets on April 23, 2015, they said the first access available would be May 5, 2015. The building itself is striking the park surrounding is beautiful.

Must see in Rome. Stunning villa filled with even more stunning works of art. their collection of sculptures from Bernini is astounding. Definitely get the audio tour. You must book online at least 2 weeks ahead of time if not more. Plus it is a very nice walk through the park to get to the villa.
Excellent. Took a wonderful tour of Borghese gallery . Rebecca,our tour guide dramatically brought the art alive with great stories and a few tears.Don't miss this. Booked through Viator.
Incredible!. The gallery is a work of art in its own right but the collection is fantastic, too. All in a beautiful park. Wow.

Always amazing!. This is my second visit to the Borghese Gallery and was equally impressed as I was the first time. Such a fabulous collection of art in a beautiful setting. The gardens were in bloom.
This is a very busy time of year but the crowds move through fairly well.

Absolutely Amazing. Everything that could be said has probably been said.But I could not believe the details that were shared by our tour guide. He spoke as though he was there when each item was being drawn or sculptured. I am sure the information he shared was accurate even though many centuries have passed since treasures were made.If you get a chance go to this Gallery. Especially look at the detail of the brush strokes and the tool marks left by the sculptors.There are messages in those details that you might miss if you only look from a distance. You can have fun imagining what they mean till a tour guide tells you what "really" makes the story.The immense scope of the artwork on display is mind boggling. Especially to know that at one time it was all owned by one family.How some of this art was accumulated is also amazing. To think that more than 500 pieces were taken away from the family.
Must see. Outstanding collection in a lovely space -- not to be missed on a visit to Rome. The Bernini sculptures are especially compelling.

Italian Vacation. This is a beautiful gallery. Be advices you only have 2 hours to explore and it is best to make reservations. When we were there on a Friday, the next reservation was for Tuesday the following week.Most of your time should be spent on floor one if sculptures are your thing.Definitely a don't miss when visiting Rome
Book early. Sold out for over a week in advance. Book before you go or you won't get in. The parkland around is worth a visit and pedestrian friendly.

This place is great, just make resverations. My wife and I loved the gallery. We are not art people, but the lovely walk up the Spanish steps and through the park made this and the museum a wonderful day. We rented the audio guides which really helped us understand the art. The limited crowds, due to the reservation system, and intimacy with the art, makes this a special venue for all to enjoy.

Wonderful place to spend several hours. Really enjoyable place. See the beautiful gallerie (but order the tickets and the time for visit in advance, via Internet), walk ijn the park, take the electric car and drive on the park roads. Finally, visit the location watching at Rome and specifically at Piacca Popola. This visit was planned by us in advance, and I really regret only that we did not add another 2 hours to

The Canova sculpture was incredible. I am a seasoned art gallery visitor and even I found myself absent minded oh reaching for the sculpture to touch it..... And I abhor anyone who does not preserve cultural pieces- to the extent that I have told someone else to behave. The Canova was so...so...SO beautiful!

Amazing Museum. We are glad we pre-purchased tickets so we were able to enjoy the amazing artwork and sculptures in this wonderful gallery. The grounds surrounding it are also quite impressive and very expansive. I believe it is widely used for walkers and runners alike, although we were there on a rainy day so seemed lightly used. One is allowed a strict two hour time-frame inside the gallery so plan accordingly. We paid extra to get the audio tour, but please be aware it actually starts as though you were entering from the outside original main entrance on the first level - fact is, you enter from the back side and are directed to the second level through the winding staircase. This left us a little "lost and confused" until we figured this out ourselves and got on track with the audio tour!Please also be aware they expect you to check your handbag and all personal items, although non-flash photography is permitted. You'll exit through the cafe and gift shop area, but prices are not shown on the books and other items which wasn't too helpful. All in all, it was a very memorable and worthwhile two hours spent.

A little out of the way, make sure you have tickets, and hard to do on your own. We toured Borghese on our own. We eventually bought a tour book to better understand what we were looking at. We had ore ought our tickets- but watched as others were turned away without theirs or because it was sold out. They are very strict. Photos were permitted without flash- and the artwork was amazing. This includes the architecture, the statutes and paintings. We didn't get to see much of the gardens as they were closed- and probably could have lived without seeing this gallery given how hard it was to get there (wromg directions by the hotel and taxi) and how little there was (comparatively) to see.

Fantastic. Brilliant museum. An extremely impressive former home. Stunning ceilings and amazing artworks. Great Bernini sculptures. You must book in advance. Cafe inside is fine and decent value. Set in a lovely park which is worth exploring too. Take your time looking round. 2 hours is plenty (and all that you are allowed) and if you are patient the crowds will disperse and you will have rooms to yourself.
Rough exterior hides exceptional art. Savor the Borghese gallery, it is exceptional and the reservations mean smaller crowds. The sculptures are truly inspiring.

Stunning, don't schedule visiting another museum at the same day. Everything about this gallery is absolutely mesmerizing. The fact that the number of visitors are limited really allows you to gasp in and admire the beauty of the artworks. The setting is very fine. You can also enjoy a very nice cafe at the same place while waiting for your visit time, they had the best white chocolate muffins that I have ever tasted. After you are done, you can enjoy the rest of the day walking in the park. (Trust me you will not be disappointed). You can walk to flaminio area too which is a very vibrant part of the city.

Impressive. The Borghese is an incredible gallery of art and sculptures and should be on everyone's list when visiting Rome. You must book your ticket ahead of time and you will be able to print off a voucher. When you get to the Gallery - arriving 20 minutes prior to your scheduled time - go down the stairs at the front entrance to redeem your voucher for your ticket. Punctuality is essential - you have exactly two hours to enjoy the gallery. There is a waiting area and a counter at which to check your bags and cameras. You will be told that cameras are not allowed, however, after we checked our cameras we saw almost everyone on the tour with their cameras in tow and they weren't told to put them away. As Rick Steeve advises, do the upstairs (Art Gallery) first where you are limited to 30 minutes. Most people do the sculptures first ( main floor) so by going upstairs first it is less crowded. The Villa itself is a work of art so make sure you look at the building itself. We just love walking through the beautiful Borghese parks and to the lake; you won't believe you're in the middle of Rome it's so quiet.

Borghese Gallery is a do not miss.. The audio tour is very interesting. I'm not a big fan of art museums, but I'm so glad my wife scheduled this on our trip. The back stories on the art work makes this enthrawling.

Unforgettable!. Pay attention to booking advice and punctuality warnings. The staff was trained by state motor vehicle employees and if you don't have reservation and are EARLY you will be disappointed. Be sure you understand where you are going and how to get there. The audio guide is important but difficult to use.........sounds silly I know but very few pictures or rooms have clearly displayed numbers. Once acclimated you are in for an impressive 2 hours. Price was no object and they spent like funds were unlimited. It is opulence like I have never seen before.

a must !. the most beautiful gallery ever seen ! must go again next time in rome ! you should remember to reserve tickets before , otherwise is impossible to enter . the art pieces are divine . Remember to come exactly on time , because after two hours you must leave the gallery .

Outstanding. This is definitely one place you don't want to miss seeing if you are into art! The paintings and sculptures by artists such as Bernini, Caravaggio,and Raphael are overwhelming!The collection, I believe, was organized by one of the Popes who was a Borghese. Each room is adorned with floor to ceiling treasures. The frescoes are amazing. You do require a reservation in order to view the collection as only a certain number of people are allowed in at a time and your visit is limited to a 2 hour time frame. There is a fee to get into the museum but if you have a Roma Pass, the cost is free. If you are travelling by bus, the #92 bus from Termini Station will take you to and drop you off at a stop near the museum; however, it does not stop near the Borghese for the return trip to Termini. The museum attendants will be able to give you directions how to get to the main road where numerous buses run and if you are staying at a hotel near Termini Station, just hop on any one that indicates it will stop at Termini. A great experience.

Some tips to share. The Borghese gallery is an exciting art collection and could be considered as the best in Rome. We visit it on Saturday; the tickets were sold out until Thursday. Reserve your tickets online prior your visit; we did it a month ahead. Take bus 910 (platform L) in front of Termini (train station). Request a bus to stop when you see the park on the left. It is wise to arrive on time. If you are late, you are wasting your time because the announcement will ask you to leave the gallery exactly at the time stated on your ticket.

Amazing collection. The sculpture and paintings are exquisite. The timed ticket is a great idea as you can enjoy the art work at your leisure.I would recommend the audio guides and do make sure you book in advance, when we visited the next free time was in 2 days time.The park is also a great way to relax,we did this on our last day and relaxed after the bustle of Rome's streets.

High point of a 3-city trip. After 6 days in Venice & Florence, you think you have reached the saturation point with art. But to miss the Borghese Gallery in Rome would be to miss a peak experience if you are an art lover. Admission is limited for every 2 hour period, so you can get up close to all the pieces of Bernini sculpture and so much more. Each room is a work of art In itself. Advance reservations needed (we got ours through select italy.com) and I highly recommend the audio self-guided tour because this is the chance of a lifetime to appreciate a superb collection of art in its intended setting.

Rude, unhelpful, reservations and ticket staff. This attraction was at the top of our list to visit. Perhaps foolishly, my wife and I purchased Roma passes in advance over the internet, and the first attraction we hoped to use them on for free (already paid for) was the Borghese Gallery. Upon arrival at our hotel in Rome on Tuesday, Mar 31st, I asked our concierge to call the gallery and make reservations for us. After a lengthy exchange, the person assisting us at our hotel informed us that the earlist reservations would be available would be the following week, Apr 6th or later...but if we wished, my wife and I could go to the gallery, arriving 10 to 15 minutes prior to entry times, and standby for entry. We arrived at 12:45am for the 1:00 entry, and after standing in line for several minutes, we were told that we could purchase tickets for the 3:00 entry at 22euros, but no guarantee we would be allowed to enter. The fact that I had already paid 22euros with my Roma passes was of absolutely no consequence. A simple "I'm sorry, I just can't help you" would have gone a LONG way. I still would like to see the contents of the gallery on a future visit to Rome, but I will forever have a very bad taste in my mounth due to the personnel working there. Maybe they were just having a very bad day!

A Grand Palace. Each room was a palace unto itself. The art work was grand. You can see enough in the two hours, mainly because more time would be too much stimuli - as each room was a sensory overload. The surrounding gardens and buildings made this a highlight spot to visit. Be prepared to walk, as its 3 floors of grandeur.

Beautiful sculptures!. Borghese Gallery is a relatively small museum, situated in a lovely park. Inside you can see some works by Caravaggio, such as Boy With a Basket of Fruit. However, what I found really inspiring were Bernini's exquisite scultpures. If you plan a visit, you must book it in advance via the official website of the gallery. The price of the ticket was 11 euros + 2 euros booking fee. You are expected to show up some time earlier to validate your reservation and get your tickets, the visit starts exactly at the time booked, not a minute earlier.

Great sculptures and painting collected by borghese family. Its a must visit in rome. The art is organised by era. So , some works dates back to early roman period, then there are few pieces which has greek influence that show violent themes. Then there are neoclassical pieces from renaissance and 17th century. Its better If you take the audio guide to enjoy the tour. Because without it, you would not be able to fully appreciate the gallery

Favorite gallery in Italy. We visited Rome, Florence and Venice on a recent trip. My family loved this gallery. First of all, the collection is not too large so it is not overwhelming. Secondly, it is displayed in a home ( too grand to call it an intimate setting) which makes the art seem more approachable somehow. It reminded me somewhat of the feeling of the Frick Collection in New York. The art is also not exclusively religious so it makes for a very interesting collection. The Bernini sculptures here are the most spectacular sculptures I have ever seen and they are so easy to see. His Apollo and Danae(Daphne) is breathtaking and his David is so beautiful. Helpful hints: You must reserve tickets for a specific time well in advance of your trip as this place sells out fast. They allow only a limited number of people in at a time for only two hours at a time which is more than enough time). Also you must get there at least a half hour before your scheduled time or they will give away your ticket and it is VERY HARD to find in the park. Make sure you ask for the Galleria, not the Villa if you are asking for directions. Allow yourself 15 minutes once you get to the park to find the Galleria as it is in the north east corner of the park and if you walk from the Spanish steps you will arrive at the southwest corner.

STUNNING. The Galleria Borghese is located near The Spanish Steps in central Rome. The Villa Borghese was built by Scipione Borghese to house his art collections. He was a patron of Bernini so many of his pieces are housed here.The Borghese family rose to prominence and wealth after a member of the family became Pope Paul V in 1552, and gave power and titles to members of his family.The villa houses a vast and diverse collection of masterpieces including works by Bernini, Titian, Rubens and Raphael. We enjoyed exploring on our own, but tour tickets can be purchased.Afterwards, we enjoyed a very peaceful stroll through the beautiful Borghese Gardens; a tranquil spot away from the business of central Rome.Highly recommend.Read up before you go.
perfect for families. The best places for families when kids are tired of looking at churches, museums etc.Rent a bike. The restaurant had unpleasant waiters. Toilets are 2€ and the line is long.
Must see!. If you only have a little bit of time in Rome, out this on you to do list anyway! An amazing collection of artworks housed in rooms which are artworks themselves. Awe inspiring!

One of the best museums in Rome!. After seeing this on Rick Steves, we knew we had to add it to the list of places to visit in Rome! We booked tickets online (which is a must!!) and we got there a little early, so we sat outside and enjoyed the day. There were a lot of people trying to get in, only to be told that reservations were booked a solid 2 weeks out. I highly recommend booking this as soon as you know you want to go! The sculptures by Bernini can't even be described, you have to see them for yourself! Just go!!

Borghese Gallery. If you visit Rome, villa Borghesse and Borghesse Gallery should be in your visit list. The sculptures of Bernini are really impressive. Reservation in advance are necessary. Take your time after visiting the Gallery and have a walk in the park. The Rome Zoo is also in the area.

Must be part of any trip to Rome. Galleria Borghese must be part of any trip to Rome. There a various paintings of Caravaggio, Raphael, and other masters, as well as arguably the most impressive sculptures of Bernini. Reservations are necessary and the first Sundays of the month are free (those reservations must be made even further in advance). There are two floors of rooms which can all be seen calmly in 1.5-2 hours. The time investment is not heavy but you will see incredible masterpieces. Plus it is in a beautiful zone, the Villa Borghese, and near a beautiful part of Rome containing many other visitor hot spots.

Borghese Gallery is a "can't be missed" in Rome. If you're going to Rome you must see the Borghese Gallery. Book your tickets in advance and prepare to be amazed! The walk to the gallery is a fitting lead up to some of the finest works of art in the world. Make sure that you spend some time exploring the grounds.

WOW. My wife booked the tickets for the 9am-11am slot. To be honest this was the part of our Rome trip I wasn't looking forward to, I dont do art gallery.So after all that I did enjoy it, only took us an hour as it was busy you dont feel like standing aboutIt says to leave baggage and no cameras, so we left everything at hotel, yes there is a left luggage place but my camera is my baby so didn't want to take it there to be left with a stranger.There was a Q to leave bags and luggage! But everyone kept their cameras and took pictures, very annoyed

Worth the effort. I was a bit wary of the idea of going to Borghese gallery because it requires reserving a time in advance and we had a full itinerary which made nailing down a specific time difficult. I am so glad we made the effort- this was actually one of my favorite sites in Rome and one of the best small collections of art I have experienced. Enjoy the walk through the park to get to the museum- it's a nice break from the crowds, as is the museum experience itself which was significantly less crowded than most other sites and allows guests to linger (within their specified two hour time slot, that is) in front of paintings and sculptures. We were able to see all that we wished well within our two hours and saw many paintings that we immensely enjoyed. I wish there had been more written information posted, but there were handouts in each room.

Even my children loved this art museum!. Everyone loved this museum, even our 9 year old twins. The Bernini sculptures alone are well worth it. Definitely purchase your tickets in advance and arrive 30 minutes prior to your reservation time to pick them up from the ticket office. We bought ours before we even left for our trip and so glad we did because they were sold out for days in advance. Getting the audio guides really helped our children to grasp the significance of the art pieces they were looking at, and they enjoyed it so much more.

Amazing statutes and art. Get here early and try to check your bags as soon as possible. You only get two hours here, and they push you out early. However, the art is amazing. Bernini's works are astounding, and the Caravaggios are also excellent. We couldn't see a lot of the second floor because we were being pushed out, so time your trip wisely.

As good as its reputation: a very special museum of Ancient and Renaissance Art. We bought our tickets at a web-site ahead of time from City Wonders; we may have paid too much but they did everything they promised and we had our tickets in hand 15 minutes before our start time. You will only have two hours and it is necessary to be ready at the appointed time.We spent quite a long time around the grounds, which are huge and lovely, and full of people, including many runners and hundreds of small conveyances for individuals and families, including lots of "segways".The whole museum is on two floors of a 17th/18th Century Villa, and is packed with extraordinary sculpture and paintings. I do not see how anyone can take it all in in two hours but that is what you have; either you can be selective and pick out what you want to look at beforehand or you can wander around and spend as much time as you like in any given room, knowing that the crowd that came in with you may all also be there. We were jammed into a couple of rooms with everyone at first but an hour later, we found ourselves in a room with an Andrea del Sarto Madonna with Christ and John the Baptist by ourselves. The Caravaggio's are the featured highlight of the collection, but there are Raphaello's and Perugino's and Bernini's and so forth. You could spend all two hours looking at the statues, the bas reliefs or the ceilings and not even take in the exceptional paintings; it is that rich a collection. Two or three notes: you cannot carry in any sacks, backpacks, big bags, etc; you can take photos without flash and there is a small cafe downstairs for before and/or after.We were exhausted after just two hours but this is a place to remember.
One of the best Museums. This was one of the best museums we visited. They only allow a limited amount of people in at a time so it isn't over crowded. The art is outstanding, so worth it!

The Bernini statues? Wow.. Get your tickets ahead because the two-hour time slots fill up quickly. Get there at least 30 minutes early to obtain your pre-ordered tickets. Then brwose the gift shop until your time slot comes up, Go to the top floor first to avoid the crowd.

Great art museum. A beautiful gallery. Better than the Vatican Museum. Intimate experience, priceless artwork, smaller crowd. We loved it. You must purchase tickets ahead of time. Reservations only at this museum. Be sure to visit the park around the museum. Walk to the Piazza Del Popolo from there, it the best views of Rome.

One of the World's great art collections in a fine setting.. Unmissable collection of fine art in a stupendous building with decorated ceilings. The gardens in which it is situated are just as good a reason to visit.
BUT PRE-BOOKING IS ESSENTIAL. In March people were being turned away who had not pre-paid.

You had better pre-book tickets. We turned up to be told that all tickets for that day had been sold. This was annoying. It was also suprising in that the gallery did not appear to be busy (there were only a handful of people to be seen). It was also unexpected as no other place in Rome operates in this way. Also, it was not well publicised that tickets should be bought in advance. It was even more annoying that the gallery is not easy to get to: We had travelled by a combination of metro and bus and long walk to get there only to be told there were no tickets.

When stone is alive. The borghese gallery is hosting main pieces of Le Bernino and many pictures from Rafaele. Visits must be booked by phone for a time slot in the day. It's a marvellous place in a beautiful parc. The exhibitions of painting and sculptures are really great with all representants of the Italian renewall. To see absolutely are the sculptures from Le Bernin with the "Rapt of Proserpine" where stone become flesh, Daphnee transformation is as well a masterpiece. Really a must in Roma.

You need to plan in advance - no last minutes tckets. We wanted to visit the gallery so much - but the next available tickets were 2 days after the end of our stay. I don't know if "walk in" is acceptable - we didn't try, but I suspect you cannot

Magnificent. Visted Tuesday March 24/15. Went a little early strolled in the gardens, perfect sunny morning, hardly any people, a lovely place. Of course the gallery does take ones breath away, Bernini and Caravaggio are masters of their craft.

A MUST SEE. Amazing sculptures and artwork, probably only surpassed by the Vatican museums, but unlike the Vatican you can view these works properly due to the restriction on number of visitors at any one time.This was my second visit to this gallery and I will visit again should I return to Rome.
terrific. This is a beautiful gallery in a loving setting. Reservations required. The initial great room ceiling is mesmerizing. Statutes were well displayed. Highly recommend.

Wow!. On what we thought was aa very well--planned trip to Rome, the Borghese Gallery was an absolute delight. Getting there takes you through an exquisite park. We walked for hours with a smile on our faces.

Not to be missed!. Wonderful art and sculptures. You need to book online as only a certain number of people are allowed each day. You are not allowed to take ANY bags in, so make sure you hand them in on your arrival as the signage is not clear!

Some tips. - Let me start with saying that the very best museum in Rome is the Galleria Doria Pamphilj, so if you have to choose...- The Borghese collection IS stunning too, however, so it is a HIGHLY RECOMMENDED visit.- You ARE REQUIRED to book in advance and SHOULD take the audio guide. You can only visit in 2 hour time slots and as we listened to the last explanation of an artwork in the last room of the Pinacoteca, visitors were asked to leave. We took our time getting around, so the audio guide timing was just PERFECT.- The limitation of visitors works perfectly. Never scenes like the ones you get in the Vatican museums, where you are herded along like a flock of sheep.- The Borghese park (always open to the public) is absolutely charming, and worth a good long stroll. Adds to your experience of this museum! From the park, head either direction Villa Medici for great views of Rome, or to the charming Piazza del Popolo (with magnificent art in the church).

Wow. The sculptures were amazing. The art was fabulous. They could have used more seating so that you can sit and look up at the amazing ceilings. The time is limited to 2 hours and when you start seeing the amazing works of art, you know why, no one would leave. They want everyone to have the opportunity to see the art. Understandable. I look forward to visiting again.
Perfect.. One of the very best in the world. Not to be missed. Period. The museum requires nothing from you other than your full emotion and senses. Come to be awed.

Wow Factor Here. This is an amazing place to see if you love art and especially sculpture. You need to book well in advance as they only allow a certain number of people in at a time and there is a time limit on your visit. A tour guide is a great idea, if not then buy a recorded guide. Absolutely amazing.

unbelievable collection. It is really astounding that this place has survived for so long with so many treasures in it. You get a sore neck from tipping it back to see the wonderful ceilings in every room. Floor lying space would be great!! The first floor is full of sculptures that require time to walk round and admire from every angle. The second floor has a rich collection of paintings. I was keen to see the Caravaggio collection. I did think though that the lighting did not always enhance the paints and it was difficult to get a good spot to view some.

Totally worth it !. First the park that you have to walk throught to reach the gallery is just amazing the most beautiful and peaceful place i have ever been! There is also a lake that you can rent a little boat and boating around ! The Gallery was really nice, all the paintnig and statues , and I was amazed by the statue of Apollo and Daphne! Totally worth going !

Underwhelming. After living inEurope for so many years, I just might be burnt out on museums with murals, sculptures, and old, dark paintings. But, I think the Galaria Borghese was not worth the money. The grounds surrounding it are very nice, though.

Lovely Caravaggios and Berninis. Great small museum. It is manageable in an hour. Two floors of ancient to Renaissance art--with some major pieces by Caravaggio and Bernini. Most of the major pieces are located on the first floor, with the second having a few more pieces of interest. At 11 euros a person, a great museum experience.

An amazing little gem in Rome. Was quite surprised and impressed with the little gallery that could! Looking at it from the outside, it was hard to imagine the impressive collection on the inside. We booked out tickets ahead of schedule (0900, 1100, 1300, 1500...) and took advantage of a nice self guided tour.Take the time to visit all rooms, all floors and appreciate.

the best gallery in Rome. Go Go Go. do not forget to buy tickets in advance - no "on the spot" tickets available. great pictures and unbellivable scuptures - great bernini (the son) - Appolo and Dafni, David and others. it is a must in rome.

Stunning. So glad we took the time to visit this amazing gallery; the building is a work of art in itself!Set in beautiful grounds in a lovely park, just walking there is a pleasure (although we did struggle a little finding it, some more signs would have been very helpful!).For me, the Caravaggio's and the Bernini sculptures were the highlight; being in a room with Bernini's Apollo and Daphne was simply breathtaking, but the place is just jam-packed with fabulous masterpieces.The audio guide was really helpful and gave you a good overview of many of the key pieces without the need to shuffle round as part of a guided tour!A must-see for art lovers.

Exceeded all of my Expectations. Reservations are essential, especially in the summer. but totally worthwhile! It is an easy walk from the Spanish Steps, you just need to get specific directions from a guide book or from other posts on Trip advisor.The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the price of admission. My favourites were David, Apollo and Daphne and the haunting realism of the Rape of Proserpina.

Fabulous private collection of art . This gallery has a tremendous wealth of art collection and worth the time of about two hours which has to be pre-booked. It is spread over three floors and a fair number of steps have to be negotiated. However there is a lift available for persons who need it. Paintings and sculptures by Bernini, Raphael, Titian, Michelangelo and others not to be missed.

truely amazing. I am so glad we fitted in a visit to this amazing gallery. You MUST book ahead-easy on-line.you can pick your tickets up an hour beforehand. I don't think you are able to turn up and buy tickets on the door. You get a 2 hour slot to see some incredible works of art "collected" by the Borghese family. The Bernini statues were a highlight for me especially Apollo and Daphne. I also loved the Caravaggio's.We used the audioguides- they helped us to appreciate selected works in more detailI loved the Roman mosaics(many of which which you just walk over!)The cafe was reasonable value The staff were all friendly and helpful and smiled(a rarity in Rome during our visit) which enhanced the visitALL bags need to be checked in so be prepared for that.

My Favorite Gallery/museum in Rome. After 7 trips to Rome, I continue to visit every time I come. It is small intimate collection of Baroque painting and sculpture with what is, so far as I know, the largest collection of Bernini everywhere. Despite the need for a reservation and a two hour visit limit, it is the very consumable nature of the collection which makes it most enjoyable. Unlike the Louvre ofr the Vatican one can actually do a superficial overview of the collection without being overwhelmed to the point of confusion and exhaustion. At the same time, if you find a Canova or a Carrivaggio that you love, there are no huge crowds to stop you from enjoying it for the duration of your visit. I will cintinue to return here as long as I am able

Small but filled with great works of art. I booked my tickets on line which I would recommend. You can pick them up before the hour that you've booked. I was under the impression that a smaller number of people would be let in and that there would be more information provided about the art. There were several school groups in the same time that we booked that made it a moderately annoying experience. The museum does provide laminated cards for each room but they don't contain a lot of information about the work in the rooms. I would recommend an audio guide as you could get more out of it.Lovely location, come early to walk through the park. There is a small book shop and café in the bottom. The café is good and very reasonable. We had 2 sandwiches and 2 coffee's and 2 small chocolates for 11 euros. You do need to store you bags and purses so keep that in mind when your filling your bag in the morning.
Impressive. It's a very little museum, compared to many others in Rome, but it has so many beautiful artwork that you are affected.

Fabulous Gallery. This is one of the most incredible galleries in Rome. You need to book online to secure a 2 hour timeslot. You must check in all bags (including larger handbags). I took notice of the sign showing a line through a camera & left my Smartphone in my handbag - bad move, it only meant no flash photography so I missed all the very special digitised memories. One of the first things you see when you enter is a brilliant carousel which begins to move and as it speeds up it works on the principle of cartoons being flicked through in a booklet. You have the impression of gladiators & others fighting. I think it's the most memorable thing I've seen in a very long time. Read up on the Gallery before you go so you know a bit about the exhibits. We made the mistake of having lunch in their café - it was the most confused service I have ever encountered & the meal was dreadful. Enjoy a walk in the gardens & perhaps a picnic brought from somewhere else.

Lovely works of art in a fantastic palace. You have to book in advance and you get only 2 hours for the visit, but if you want to see only one of these art-packed palaces in Rome, let it be this one. The Bernini statues, the Canova statue of Paulina Borghese, the paintings, the superb ceiling frescoes and the Roman mosaics are unsurpassed. And the villa is set in a beautiful, large, quiet park. Unbelievable that this is possible in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Rome !
A must. Filled with beautiful art in a lovely park setting. Several famous artworks. Take a walk around them park after.

Wonderful!. It's just wonderful! Bernini's statues are awesome and the gallery itself is a work of art. You can get there by foot,walking through the Borghese gardens taking advantage of the lovely walk.

Do not leave Rome without seeing this. Simply put - if you leave Rome without seeing this you have missed one of the best - if not the best art collections in the western world. The Bernini marble sculptures alone are worth the visit. Add in great Roman floor ,mosaics, Caravaggio's , etc, etc and you need to go here. Make sure you get your tickets in advance online - very easy to do - or you will not get in. You have 2 hours max inside - it is enough Really treat yourself and hire a local guide to help you appreciate the art. Afterwards stroll around the gardens.

Unloosable Art Gallery in Rome. This is one of the unloosable beauty of Rome.The noble Palace of Borghese family itself could deserves a visit.It shows better than a lot of talks how the life of noble families was, and how they usued to live in and out in the Popes' society of those times.There are collected there a lot of wonderful pictures, I remember a stunning Tiziano, but it's only a sample: the walls are completely full of pictures from differents ages. The people of those times infact usued to collect beauties, but with the second intent to fill the empty walls of those, how says: we don't use a common paint or arazzi, but Tiziano, Caravaggio, etc.The arts collected by Prince Borghese include the world's famous Canova's statue: Paolina Borghese Bonaparte, the Napoleon's sister.But not only : there two amazing, incredible stautes by Bernini: the King of italian Barocco.Everything in that house screams ART!From the furnitures, to the marbles, the lamps, and some lovely mosaics from late Roman Empire: simply amazing, really incredible!For the mosaics' lovers I suggest a visit in another unloosable museum: Villa Massimo, in which there is only Art from Roman Empire, in front of Termini central railway Station .There are not only mosaics, from huge to atomic size, but original frescos from those times 2.000 years ago more or less. A collection of statues (Romans was lovers of statues) and finally a very very rare bronze statue: the boxeur. How this statue is made, what it rapresents, the ability of executions are something that you never have seen before, trust me! It is so real how the boxeur see you when you see him (after 2000 years), giving you a shock that is impossible to forget .Have a good visit.Aldo Martellip.s.next time Galleria Colonna

Probably my favorite museum ever!. We visited the Borghese because my art-loving friends said we had to and I am so glad we did! Bernini's statues are the highlight of the museum and are truly amazing. We preordered tickets for the last two hours of the day which was wonderful because by then the crowds had thinned and, at times, we had some rooms to ourselves. A previous TripAdvisor review said to rent the audio guide for 5 Euro, and that was critical to getting the most out of the experience. We would not have learned or appreciated the art nearly as much without it. We talked about what we saw there for days afterwards! Note: they don't allow bulky bags or umbrellas, so there is a coat check room. We didn't need to do this but the line to pick up looked pretty long. Avoid bringing items that need to be checked if you can.

Wow.. We loved Gallery Borghese, especially the exquisite collection of statues and the painted ceiling which looked so 3-dimensional.Don't forget to make a reservation.One more thing, on GoogleMaps it says that it takes 3 minutes from the metro station to the gallery, but we needed more time to get there.

Do not miss this. What an extraordinary collection of art . There are few galleries like it anywhere in the world. The management limit visitors to two hours . If I could I would visit it several times

Amazing Borghese Gallery !. When you are in Rome you must visit this museum. I recommend you to buy your tickets in advance online www.galleriaborghese.it, and it costs euro 11 per person for adults. The Borghese Gallery collections of paintings and sculptures begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese. Such as famous sculptures of Bernini, including David, the Ratto di Proserpina, Apollo e Daphne; Paolina Borghese; Tiziano's Amor Sacro e Amor Profano, Caravaggio's David con la testa di Golia and stunning collections.There is so much so see inspiring works in this museum we will go back again.I highly recommend it...

Make your reservation and go see this amazing and beautiful gallery!. Small but beautiful! Don't take a chance - reserve a head to get the time you want- it is worth the fee. They let 360 people in every 2 hours, and 2 hours is all you get. It is easy to make reservation online, print your confirmation and pick up your tickets at least half hour prior to your reserved time. We signed up for a guided tour which is available 20 minutes before our 11 am reservation, and got an art historian to bring it all to life for us. She was exceptional. We still had about 30 minutes left of the 2 hours after the guided tour, and spent that time admiring the sculptures again and it was wonderful because by then the most of the crowd is gone. It is simply amazing. Enjoy the park and cafe after your visit.GO!

A must see! Plan to go! Don't miss!. This gallery is stunning and well worth the extra planning and no phones nor purses rule. Belongings are safely held behind the desk, and YES. EVERY Euro and credit card was still there.Statues are stunning and paintings are incredible. Gallery is rich with art history and is worth any extra scrutiny the museum defines.

Must see. We adore the Borghese. The sculpture is breathtaking and the atmosphere was phenomenal. This is the one place that we like to return time and again on vacations to Rome. This is our must see. We scheduled a middle of the afternoon visit to the museum, then took a leisurely walk through the park and ended with drinks at the open air bar at Hotel Russie. With so much to see and do in Rome, this was one of our favorite experiences, if not the best experience. HIGHLY recommended--must see.

Two hours of heaven. Yes you have to see the amazing Michelangelo at the Vatican museum when in Rome, but the Borghese museum with the Bernini sculptures is the Piece de resistance, the unforgettable dazzling gem. We tried to reserve tickets online but there was a huge fee so we walked to the museum at 11am and paid and reserved tickets for 5pm that evening without a fee for 3 people for 11 Euro each. (Depending on the time of year tickets are usually not available for the same day so go in the museum your first day to deserve them and reserve and an English speaking guide.). I have taken the guided tour twice and taken family there a couple times and these highlights are not to be missed: Bernini's David and Apollo and Daphne, and Persephone sculptures are fluid and show motion and are so lifelike. The details to look for are fingerprints digging into the lifelike flesh, toes hanging off the pedestal base and fingers turning into leaves. Upstairs find Carravaggios and Corregio and pay special attention to Sacred and Profane Love....modesty and marriage vs. an immoral life. It's breathtaking. It takes a minimum of an hour but spend two with a guide or on your own pausing to look up at the frescoes on the ceilings. After you leave stroll through the Borghese park and have snacks and sandwhices at the Bibite trucks, row in a boat on the lake and sit and admire the roof tops and belltowers and domes. This museum and park will be your favorite memory of Rome.
A jewel not to be missed. I visited this little museum several times and never get tired! The masterpieces kept there are outstanding.

A jewel box. This is the most beautifully scaled and interesting museums I've been in. It is small, but each room is fascinating both in its decor as well as the important art works. Where else can you see such important works in such a gorgeous setting? There were no crowds in February, a perfect time of year to go.

Villa Borghese a place to never forget. This art gallery has got to be one of the most interesting and enjoyable museum of its kind. It is hard to imagine how the place (beautiful grounds and gardens, the museum building architecture, the selection of art, etc) could be better. It has the right amount of art pieces so that one does not feel the urge to have to rush to see ´eveything´, hence inducing a quite and serene perfect atmosphere to exchange the diverse feelings that the art pieces call for. The Bernini´s David is, by far, the best David in my opinion. The Michelangelo one (Galleria della Academia, Firenze) is no match for this piece of live marble that moves with such intensity under ones eyes. There is so much awe inspiring works of the human intelect there but just this one would make me go back time and again.

Beautiful Art Gallery. This is one of the most beautiful Art Galleries that I have seen and I highly recommend it. This museum only allows a limited number of visitors with a time frame of only 2 hours. Reservations are required and I purchased the tickets on line using Paypal. The museum has Bernini Sculptures and paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael, and Titian. The building and grounds are also very lovely.We used the audio guides to improve our understanding of the scupltures and the paintings, which I would recommend doing. You also need to check your purse (handbags and parcels) but not your coat in this museum which threw me. This museum can be difficult to find so we ended up using a taxi to ensure that we got there for our time slot.This is a very lovely art galley that is well worth the effort to get the tickets for it when you are visiting Rome.

An absolutely beautiful museum--a must-see!. Our tour guide encouraged us to go here and we are so thankful. Everything about this museum was fabulous from the art, the beauty of the displays, the grounds, the shop. I sure hope that I have the opportunity to return.

For the refined palate. This meseum holds some of the greatest Renaissance works. If you truly appreciate art history, make sure you reserve a visit. The grounds are very impressive as well and a refuge from the hot, Roman sidewalks.

Prior booking required. As title suggests, we did not actually get into this exhibit! That said, the park it is situated in was very pretty with fountains you could actually dip your feet into! So not a completely wasted visit.

Not to be missed. Our theme for this visit to Rome was based around sculptures. This museum should not be missed. Even in th peak tourist time, crowds were managed to ensure you were able to get close enough to see the details desired. Works included Bernini, Michelangio amongst others. Grounds were wonderful, with various options to get around. The building itself had an interesting history. Probably only downside was the friendliness of the staff.....but I expect I would be similar at the end of the summer tourist season.....

After the ruins, this is a must!. An absolute gem of a museum. I highly, highly recommend for art lovers. Houses many masterpieces by Bernini, as well as Caravaggio on two floors.(no lift) and works from Imperial Rome. Plus, the palace is magnificent - each room more beautiful than the last. Most paintings are not covered by glass which allows visitors to take clear photos and the sculptures are exquisitely placed throughout the museum. Nice little coffee shop and gift shop too. The museum limits the number of visitors and limits the time you can spend inside the museum to 2 hours... depending on if they are busy. Try to pace yourself so you don't miss anything! You must make advanced reservations online at gebart.it or call +39 06 32810 . If possible, don't carry bags with you, because you'll have to check them before entering the museum. Ticket prices are 11 Euro, visitors with disabilities and their caregiver can enter for free. If you're planning a trip to Rome and happen to be there during the 1st Sunday of the month, the museum is free BUT you must make reservations well in advance. After you finish admiring the art in the museum, be sure to take time and stroll the magnificent Borghese Gardens. I just can't say enough about this museum, it's my personal favorite in Rome.

Bernini Central. If you want to see some of Bernini's most lifelike and dramatic sculpture outside of a church, this is the place. Also, unless you are an art buff, I would highly recommend a talented guide. There's no greater waste of money than coming to an attraction because you are "supposed to" on a visit to Rome, and then having no idea what phenomenal item you are looking at and why it is important!

Just go.. I love small galleries. And this was simply stunning. Probably the greatest per-square-foot concentration on Bernini sculpture anywhere in Rome. With some other great names thrown in for fun. And obviously ancient Rome has been pillaged to line the walls of the rooms so don't forget to tear your eyes away from the main attraction in each room. Book ahead because the gallery limits the number of people given entry, but don't worry - the two hour window is perfect. Start upstairs in the painting gallery because everyone starts their two hours downstairs.
very nice to visit not just the gallery but also the park.. I think that was walking there more than couple hours, it is so beautifull park and Borghese place. Can't compare it with anything else.

One of the best galleries we ever visited. We have been to Rome many times, but this was the first visit to the Borghese Gallery and were absolutely not disappointed. The building itself with its frescoes and mosaics is already worth the visit, not to mention the statues with real life details, paintings (including several Caravaggios) and many other amazing works of art. A limited amount of visitors are allowed in every two hours and allowed to stay for two hours and ushered out at the end of the visit. Two hours can be enough to get a good idea of the exhibitions of the gallery, but for someone more interested in art will find the two hours a little short. We did have to rush through the paintings gallery on the upper floor and an extra hour would have been adequate. Well, I guess we will have to return and will not mind doing so. We were however somewhat lucky that for the visit we chose the group entering the gallery was not so big. The queue entering after us was long and I guess there must have been quite a crowd in the first rooms. Do purchase the tickets in advance not to be disappointed. You might be lucky going there and be able to purchase a ticket, but I would not bet on it. The Borghese Gallery is very popular. It is easy to purchase the ticket online and then pick up at the ticket office just before the visit.

Great collection, worth visiting. We were lucky to visit the gallery on the first Sunday of the month when the entrance is free. You have to make a reservation beforehand calling them but it's worth saving 12 or something euro. The gallery is not too big and so doesn't wear you out so much and allows you to enjoy the collection. The visit is limited to 2 hours, which is roughly enough to see everything there, stopping ocassionaly to learn more about certain works. I loved Il Ratto de Proserpina sculpture, the way every detail is shown is just incredible. It's my personal favourite of the whole collection. You can find it in the first hall upstairs, if I'm not mistaken. I'd totally recommend this place, well worth visiting.
wow. don't miss this in Rome. We did Grayline On Off double decker bus and Borghese is one of the stops. Formerly cardinal's residence. Beautiful gardens. Do the audio tour for all the place.
Delightful palace. On the way to the gallery you begin to admire the park. Inside the famous paintings ( one of them - Botticelli Sacred and Profane Love) and stunning sculptures by Bernini

Book well in advance to visit this gallery. We waited until we were in Rome and found that all of the tour times were already booked. Very disappointed. We have heard it is a fabulous experience. Next time.....!

The architecture rivals the art. Some of Italy's most beautiful sculptures are housed here. If you bore of the art, check out the architecture! Be prepared to be rushed though the museum, as the tour is timed. The museum grounds are gorgeous, and a walk through the surrounding park is both peaceful and vitalizing.

beautiful. You purchase a ticket for a 2 hour time slot. You can take photos without a flash, so don't leave your camera at the mandatory bag check. Breathtaking art and sculptures! Nice café for tea and treats afterwards, beautiful grounds, even in January.

Borghese Gallery. It is a stunning display of medieval art; put together by generations of a wealthy family. I especially enjoyed the statues by Bernini.
They also had a nice museum store, and overpriced restaurant. The grounds around the gallery are also beautiful, even in January.

Interesting. This gallery is well worth the visit because of (amongst other things) the nicely decorated rooms, the paintings by Caravaggio and the Bernini statues. We didn't like the way our visit started though, we had to stand in line to collect our tickets (after online booking), we had to stand in line to leave a (small) bag in the cloakroom and then we had to wait some more to enter the museum.

Worth the effort. Reaching Galleria Borghese is a bit of a challenge - uninspiring approaches, and lamentably bad signposting. However the effort is well worth - what a wonderful collection of artworks - one's senses are fully sated!

Go for Bernini's masterpieces. We saw a documentary about Bernini's life, his competitors and the statues that he created. We were impressed and intrigued by his masterpieces. So when we visited Rome last May, we bought tickets to the Borghese Gallery online a few days in advance. Seeing Bernini's masterpieces up close is even more awesome. He's managed to make something as hard as marble look like flesh. The facial expressions are accurate too. He has captured a moment in time in these characters' lives but really they're all just from his imagination and his hands.

Amazing, no other way to put it. For those that have an appreciation for sculptures and paintings, go there. For those that don't, go there. Just go there and experience it, I can assure you that you will enjoy it

A great gallery with fixed and changing exhibitions. Fabulous villa stands in gardens and offer to the public entrance to this beautiful art palace.Do not miss the statue of Daphne an Appolo, turning Daphne into a tree. Done in white marble and fixed in your memory for ever...The sculpture of Napoleon niece reclines is an outstanding piece of white Carrara.This villa once belonged to the noble family of Burghese. I have seen here excellent exhibitions from other parts of the world. You will spend here a few very very pleasant hours.

Absolutely Beautiful. My sisters and I visited Villa Borghese summer of 2014. Walked the grounds and visited Galleria Borghese. Well worth visiting. We were staying within walking distance. Will visit again. Great way to spend a day.

Carravagio and Bernini!. A feast for the eye's in every room. Everywhere you look, the floors, walls and ceilings and the art on display amaze and delight. Well worth a visit, but you must book in advance.

Very nice place to go after a walk in the park. We took te metro to Piazza Spagna, Villa Borghese and walked in the park for around half an hour until we reached Galleria Borghese. It was a great way to experience a calm, relaxing time in the middle of a busy visit to Rome. The museum and the park are great, and so close to the center of ROme.

Beautiful and very rich contents. The accumulation of excellent paintings and sculptures is amazing. You need a lifetime to go through the museum. Especially the combination of a palace bursting with incredible treasures of art and the beautiful Borghese Gardens is unique !

rude staff at the cloackroom. very rude staff arrogant and xenophobe , they wont let you take your own purse! and they were quite rude and patronising but
beautiful places and statues though

Well worth A visit. If you have an our or two to spare visit the borghese gallery. It's a masterpiece collection of sculpture and paintings. It's well covered in history and design, tours are regular and ear pieces will navigate u thru the rooms. The art is marvellous, ancient, inspiring and unbelievably you can get around the exhibit in 1-2 hours! The only drawn back is they will take your hand bag before you enter the gallery, which is beyond ridiculous as many other wonderful museums do a security check and allow u carry ur purse around the halls!

This is not just another museum. This place is amazing!. I almost skipped this place thinking I've seen enough art around Rome. But once I entered I was literally out of breath. I've seen many museums all over the world, but this one may be the one to top them all. The decor of the museum, including walls, ceilings, doors, is truly amazing. And then there are all those Bernini masterpieces! Don't go there... Run!!!!
Spectacular. This museum is quiet and beautiful. You are able to view the paintings and sculptures up close (with a guard in the room!) if you want to vie pew Bernini sculptures, thus is the place!

A must see. Even if in Rome for only a day, put this on your list. Many had told us not to miss it and we certainly saw why. Located in a large and beautiful park this mansion from days past is now home to a fabulous art collection that shouldn't be missed.

Some masterpieces, glorious setting. It's true that you can see Berninis and Caravaggios in other places. But not these specific ones, and not in this kind of setting. Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is a wonder, and the overall design of the rooms--with a mix of sculpture from the classical, baroque, and neoclassical, Renaissance and Baroque paintings and ceilings, marble and mosaic floors, and countless other decorative elements organized in a harmonious whole--is a joy to the senses.
Best sculpture collection. Make sure you get tickets in advance for the Borghese Gallery. They will be times so make sure you are not late!

You can see better things for free. Staff was very noisy for a museum, they had a long conversation very loudly in the museum rooms and also very rude when you ask them to be silent.If you want to listen the entire audio guide is longer than 2 hours and you are rushed out after 1 hour and 45 minutes.You can see Bernini and Caravaggio for free in other places in Rome.

Disappointing. I expected more from that place. The collection is less impressive than a lot of other places in Italy and you can only stay 2 hours in the expositions (tickets are timed). The staff was cold and unhelpful and I was disappointed overall. Unless there is something you really want to see, I suggest taking a longer walk in the gardens (that are beautiful and FREE) and skip the museum.

Beautiful and no reservation needed!. This was a very special place. It happened that it was the last cultural thing we did in Rome as we did not have a reservation and were having difficulty with the phone call. However, we gained immediate admittance. I paid €2 with the Roma Pass. My 18 yr old daughter was free! (Pass a waste!). The Galleria was so beautiful. The audio guide could have been better.

Must see!. The Gallery at the Villa Borghese contains the finest rendition of David facing Goliath that I have ever seen. Sculpted by Bernini in 1624. Not as well known or as large as Michelangelo's in Florence, but the intense look of determination on David's face as he is hurtling the sling is next to miraculous!

Breathtaking works of art!. Here are some tips for a great visit - DO NOT settle for a booking time that is the last booking time of the day. You will lose precious minutes as they will start to usher you out even before your time is up as they want to shut up the place and go home. Also, spend money and get the recorded guided tour. You will need it to appreciate the art. Enjoy!

For the cognascenti. Amazing gallery and an oasis after the hoards of tourists at the collarseeum. Fantastic works in an amazing setting, loved the Rafael of his lover and the Hans Holbein of Henry viii, who knew it was there? Highly recommended for those looking for some high art.

Totally baroque and over the top but well worth a visit. Great Bernini statue and Caravaggio... Worth the complicated booking procedure. We went with Rome pass . But you have top rebook by phone . Plan before you get to Rome. Much easier than Vatican or capitoline and nice setting in park

Borghese - Splendid Find. On our second trip to Rome, we wanted another museum experience besides the Vatican which we visited on our first trip. Borghese was a great choice. Be sure to procure museum tickets BEFOREHAND as we talked with several visitors who arrived assuming they could purchase on-site for immediate entry - not so (we purchased ours on-line well in advance of the trip). Since museum access is crowd limit controlled, your ticket is good only for a specific entry time. Unlike most major world museums, cameras are allowed inside. Magnificent works of art acquired over the years by Cardinal Borghese and housed in his former palatial estate.Galleria is in a massive public park (including zoo, flower gardens, numerous walking trails, etc.) with panoramic vistas of Rome. We took an enjoyable ride on motorized tram which was a great way to get the lay of the land. Many more areas to explore beyond what we could enjoy in a half day.

A truly fascinating visit.. Lovely and interesting building housing a magnificent collection of sculptures and paintings.Made the mistake of going in part way through a timed session and ended up rushing round. Don't make that mistake!The paintings are well exhibited though for us a few more English captions would have been helpful (should have had the audio tour) Particularly wanted to see the Carravagio exhibits but strangely these are not in the gallery, but with the sculptures etc. They are worth the visit on their own!The Villa is set in lovely surroundings of parkland and a stroll round completes great visit.If you like art and history, its not to be missed.
must see. Liked small group entry, but viewing time too short. Enter and explore multiple floors and rooms of intense talent.
SUPER!. Everything is so beautiful and exciting.... I will never forget that place... No dought, to come here again...

Paradise for Renaissance Art Lovers. The "Galleria Borghese" is situated on top of a hill in the park of Villa Borghese. The outside of the building, although beautiful, cannot prepare you for the absolutely gorgeous interiors with its Renaissance masterworks. Each room is more stunning than the one before. If you are going to visit only one museum in Rome you should go and see this one. It will give you an idea of the wealth and richness of the Renaissance art and the creativity of its artists whose work was commissioned by the then reigning popes. We had taken a bus from the Piazza di Popolo that took us through the park and left us at a 10 minute walk from the museum. The park is very well maintained with all kind of different trees. Green parrots were happily chattering on that sunny winter day in January. The gardens of the museum were lined with orange and lemon trees and daffodils were already appearing all over. After our visit (2 hours max.) we walked through the park to Colline di Pincio from where one has a beautiful view over Rome, a city with endless beauty.

If there are only 6 things to see in Rome, this is one. Many people miss this gem. It has sculptures and apparently people are not into that, what a mistake. A must see, Flesh made out of stone. It will take your breath away.

One of the best museums i've ever visited!!. It was absolutely miraculous. This is one of the few places i coundn't get enough of!!it was amazing!so much history,so beautiful! We stayed almost the hole day there and then we rented bikes and explored the amazing gartens! You will not regret visiting Borghese Gallery, don't skip it it is absolutely worth the trouble!

has to be visited. Huge collection of paintings and sculptures. Even the building itself has a great interest ! Notice you need to do a reservation (calling them will avoid you paying some fees). and for Roma pass holders, you have to call to reserve : no other choices

Excellent. Fantastic, the mueseum has so many works that are fabulous. I recommend hiring the audio guide so you hear all the background information on the history of the Borghese Family, the Cardinal and the works.

Breathtaking!. We are fairly frequent visitors to Rome but we had never before visited the Borghese gallery. As it was raining, we were looking for indoor attractions and were so glad we were able to spend two hours going around this amazing place.The sculptures br Bernini and many others were awesome, as were paintings by Caravaggio, Titian, Canaletto, Botticelli, Rubens and others. This gallery is a must if you are at all interested in art. You will surely be amazed!Just a side note, you are not allowed to carry bags, umbrellas etc around with you at the gallery. These must be checked into the baggage drop-off point beforehand. Also, tickets are issued with a time limit of two hours.

fully booked till april....... Apparently fully booked until April but certainly didn't look busy. The cafe just inside you could use but not the toilet unless you had a ticket (which we didn't due to being fully booked. :-(

Complete diastor. Though I had booked a visit to the Gallery on the phone beforehand we had a problem wiyh admission. When we arrived at the gallery there was a huge line and so we were a couple of minutes behind the set time. The lady at the counter woud not listen to any reasonable arguments, just refused to give the tickets poit blank. What struck most was not the fact that they did not live up to their obligations to the visitors but the style and the rude manner they resorted to. We tried to speak to another member of stuff who was not nice even derisively offensive either. The visitors willy-nilly feel unwelcomed at this particular place. We came across other toutists who shared our opinion having been similarly turned down.

A sublime experience. Galleria Borghese was the last stop on our week-long vacation in Rome, and what a perfect ending to a wonderful trip. The classical statuary is gorgeous and in immaculate condition, considering much of it is approaching 2,000 years old. And words can't begin to describe the Bernini sculptures. They are gorgeous and fascinating. The upstairs is focused on paintings, and contains masterpieces by Raphael, Caravaggio, Rubens, Titian and many others. Most of the works are religious in nature. Raphael's Deposition is awe inspiring.Most web sites say that photography is not allowed. This is no longer the case, as of last July. Visitors may take photos, but flash photography is strictly prohibited. There are audioguides available for €5. I was taking photos, so I found my audioguide distracting. They might be useful for some, however. Rome is full of museums and churches with exquisite art. That said, Galleria Borghese's vast collection of immaculate art makes it a must see.

Majestic hallery. The paintings and statues are amazing. The ceiling is beautiful. Everything is majestic.You need to visit the gallery and see what it hides inside. It is really big so it's not too crowded.

Wow! those Bernini statues!. We had a 5-7pm reservation and it was perfect. Very few people were in the museum making it a great time to really appreciate the Bernini statues! A highlight was the Zootropio exhibit by Mat Collishaw. Wow! It was mesmerizing.
Do not miss!. It is a must if you like art! The whole building is amazing with paintings, statues and mosaic that will mesmerize you.
Don't miss. This was our fourth trip to Rome, but our first to Borghese. I am so glad we finally saw it! Spectacular pieces and beautiful grounds. Audio tour is only 5 euros; highly recommended.

Get a guide. If you can't afford a guide take the audio guide. There is so much to see & you will need to allow sufficient time or you will not benefit from the visit.We felt we needed to go around again to truly appreciate everything.
Among the Best. This is one of the best collections of art I have ever seen. The presentation is superb and the variety unparalleled. This is a must when in Rome.

finest collections. the best thing you could do when arriving Rome is to reserve yourself the tickets to the gallery prior to your visit and you will have a smooth visit at the place. Unlike other museums around, the place does not allow too much crowd and has limited tickets which gives you easy access to the exhibits without getting stomped. The collection is brilliant and a good insight into a whole lot of renaissance masters

Special Place. The Borghese Gallery is a really special museum in Rome and definitely worth some of your time. I loved that they only sold a certain number of tickets per reservation time and gave you two hours to leisurely view the treasures. It was the best museum experience we had while in Italy because once we were inside we were not crowded by a million other people. It was so relaxing to stroll around, spend as much time as you wanted in front of the art or the statues and really enjoy them. Make sure you purchase your tickets well in advance because the reservations routinely sell out and a reservation may not be available for days.

So very much to see. The Borghese is an intimate museum with a stellar collection of works from Renaissance masters. You will have to make reservations to enter, but this means you do not have to contend with the swells of people that you do at, say, the Vatican Museum. As you only have two hours to see everything, plan ahead and budget your time. My girlfriend and I started on the second floor and worked our ways backwards to avoid the crowd. This worked out quite well because we are then able to enjoy the highlights of the museum (such as Bernini's Apollo and Daphne) all by ourselves. I would also highly recommend the audio guide, which provides not only helpful input to better appreciate the works but also gives historical details surrounding the creation and acquisition of the museum most notable pieces. If you are in Rome, this is more than worth a visit.
Super place. My favorite especially villa Julia and the museum with Bernini statues! Out of this world! Cafes great too!

Very small and intimate gallery.. To be honest, I was torn on whether or not I should give the Borghese Gallery a 3* or 4* rating. Although the layout and time limit really bugged me, I settled on a 4* because it's not the fault of the works inside that the gallery is somewhat of a jumbled mess in parts. For example, you'll see five artworks on the wall. Below them, you'll see five cards stating what each work is. Unless you have a greatly in-depth knowledge of art (and I do, or at least thought I did before I got here) you'll have no clue which is which. From everything I've been told, the audio guide is extremely helpful. Would've loved to have known that before we attended, but what can you do. There are some works in the Gallery, many, actually, that you don't need an audioguide for. You know Caravaggio's "Boy with a Basket of Fruit," "David with the Head of Goliath," and "St. Jerome" when you see them. You can pick out a Bernini on sight. The works in this small but intimate gallery are all beautiful, masterpieces, and absolutely gems of their era. The grounds surrounding the gallery are also beautiful and are worth a walk around beforehand.Book in advance or you won't get inside!

Two hours isn't enough time; visit more than once. Although I'd heard quite a lot about the stunning works of art inside the quaint "villa", nothing prepared me for what lay inside. It's a shame that you only get to be inside for two hours at a time, but that's actually a good thing, because otherwise, you'd never get to enjoy what you're seeing. It would be too crowded, and some pieces you'd likely miss.If you care anything at all about art, this really is a must-see while in Rome. Book your tour early, and again, if you can, make more than one visit. I don't say that about many galleries, but once you see something like a Bernini statue or a Caravaggio painting in person, in such a close setting, you'll understand.

Small but sweet. It's hard to get into this gallery as it is small, thus it only allows a limited number of visitors in per session (two hour slots). So go to the website and book a date in advance. Twice in the past when I went to Rome, I attempted to just walk in, but it was always fully booked. The gallery spaces within are small and intimate, but it means you get much more up close with the statues (such as some by Bernini) than you normally might at other bigger museums, and you can truly appreciate the astounding work and skill that goes into creating each of these masterpieces. There are also paintings by a range of artists such as Caravaggio.

Gorgeous little villa. Definitely pay for the earphones to hear a history of the paintings or you will just walk through the villa in 30 minutes and not know any of the back story. Never heard of Cavaggio till I came here.

Absolutely stunning. Art, galleries, beauty....The works of Bernini, Rafaello, Michelangelo - amazing contribution to art world. Entering gallery you feel the special atmosphere that surround you. Enjoy this beauty and you will never regret

Absolutely splendid collection. Situating in the beautiful park, Villa Borghese is a place where you can see fantastic collection of the sculptures by Bernini, pictures by Rafael and a lot more. You will see the masterpieces of the renaissance and baroque art. Undoubtedly a place that must be seen.However remember to make a booking via internet!
