Plan, book tickets ahead, spend some time with gorgeous art. Don't expect to walk up and enter, plan your visit ahead, review which paintings or artwork are most important, book tickets ahead and enjoy. Visit the gardens, too!

An incredible collection of Bernini, Raffaello, Canova and more!. The Borghese Gallery is not to be missed. Although don't just walk up to the gallery and expect to wait in line and enter directly. There are specific entries during the day so check out the website and book your tickets in advance. The Gallery is an exceptional collection of masterpieces that are not to be missed. The audio guide was ok although a little confusing therefore I highly recommend a private tour with an expert guide to bring the history to life. There are many stairs to climb to arrive at the two floors available to be viewed. There is a lift for wheel chair access. You can not take in any of your belongings like your hand bag must be left at the locker room before entering in to the gallery. Photographs and filming is allowed

Excellent Paintings - book tickets before going!. Took the metro, and alighted at Spagna. In the underground, you will see various signs leading to Borghese Gallery. It was a long walk underground uphill (probably took like 5 mins brisk walk). After you exit the underground, you will have to walk straight, cut pass a plain field and walk through a garden to get to the Gallery.Read online that taking bus 910 from Termini Station can help avoid the long uphill walk from metro.After the visit, you can walk to Spanish Steps and down to Spagna.When I arrived at the Gallery, it was about 5:30pm, and the wasn't much crowd. You need to place your belongings at the cloak counter. The entrance to collect the tickets is at the basement.Buy the audioguide for a better understanding of the paintings. Personally I left that the audioguide should have more in elaboration about the paintings as on many occasions I thought.. that's all you've to say? Nevertheless, having the audioguide helps to some extent.The paintings are vibrant and well maintained. And I enjoyed my visit.

Make the time to see this. You have to reserve a ticket -- either on line or by stopping by the museum in advance. You only have a two hour slot to visit, but you can see a lot in that time and it is wonderful not to have the overwhelming crowds that seem to populate so many other tourist spots in Italy. The building itself is unbelievably sumptuous and I would have gone to have seen it on that basis alone. The art just adds another layer of beauty onto an already incredible experience. One added benefit is that it is on the edge of a really lovely park -- so I'd leave some time in your schedule to walk through it and enjoy a little nature downtime after the hyper visual stimulation of the museum. (FYI: You cannot drive directly up to the building so people who have issues with mobility should be aware that there will necessarily be some walking involved in this visit.)

Bernini's must see marbles. We were lucky and I guess it was also because it was a rainy day, but we walked in without booking, and bought 2 tickets for the 3-5 pm timed visit session, at 2:40 pm. Went to the cafe on the same floor and had our 1:50 espresso to wait for 3 pm. There are 2 floors - top floor for the paintings and the middle floor for the sculptures. The rooms had beautifully painted ceilings. We started at the top floor and worked our way to the lower sculpture floor that had the more interesting exhibits.Photos are allowed, no flash. But some sneaky people do try their luck when the room is emptier and the museum staff is not there ... The Cravaggios and Berninis are fabulous. There were having an additional exhibition called Black Mirror, and featured a fantastic zoetrope; every 8 minutes the room lights are turned off, and the zoetrope spins to create an animated scene of an attack - violent scene involving throwing babies over and fighting. Fascinating piece of heart. Caught it twice.I come from Singapore, and we get charged a lot for "art", so the entrance fee was fair, although that having said, we all wished things were cheaper. The euro just dropped further so, there, ok! No bags allowed - free deposit service.

Best of Bernini's private sculpture. Must book well ahead. Tickets are not generally available while traveling. Even so, rooms will be crowded. Most rooms have Bernini sculptures in the middle of the space. Bernini's David and Apollo and Daphnae have exceptional fluidity and emotional power. Raphael's and Caravaggio's paintings alone are worth the visit. Canova's statute of Pauline Bonaparte reclining is a masterpiece.

Popular site for tourists but wasn't impressed. The caveat to my review is that I didn't recognize many of the pieces that were on display coupled with the fact that I'm not familiar with the artistic culture in Rome. This wasn't one of my favorite spots we visited in Rome and would be okay not going back.

Amazing Sculpture. There are plenty of gorgeous paintings, but I am always awed by the sculptures.
Check the schedule. They open for 2 hours at a time, and you may have to wait, or may have your visit cut short if you are not aware.

First choice. Get that reservation sorted out in advance. Totally brilliant and it`ll take up your entire 2hr time slot, for sure. The treasures within are unbelievable. The touted description as being one of the best small museums in the world, is fully deserved. Breath-taking collection that will blow your sock off. Make sure you stay for the spinning carrousel (7 minute cycle, in a dimmed room). It’s much further away than it looks on a map, to try and walk it. So get there in plenty of time. Good to then amble down the park to the Modern Art Gallery, which is equally great but for other reasons.
Good collection. Good collection but a rip-off as you have to book online and they charge service fee. Not cool. There are also time restrictions.

Worth visiting if you are interested in art. The first thing that catches your eye is the ceiling with colourful and legendary paintings. The lights go off..go further and you will enjoy a small "spectacle" of Gladiator's fights.The whole gallery is very impressing, but do remember that you have to reserve in advance to enter there and don't forget to come at least 30 minutes earlier to get the entering ticket.You can't take bags with you to the gallery.

Two levels of interesting art. This small art gallery covered two floors of the Borghese Villa in a park that included a considerable amount of outside statuary, including Byron's tomb. The art covered multiple centuries, and literally included the floor and ceiling. Every room had a theme; the top floor was focused on Christian pieces, the bottom floor went as far back as ancient Greece up to Victorian times, including a very intricate, mechanical diorama carousal. The accessible entrance was at the back, close to the small elevator to the second floor. It was a little challenging to get to due to the gravel driveway and a low step into the building. The elevator would not fit my large wheelchair with my leg extenders, but my husband was able to use it with his cane.

An excellent display of the lavishness of Rome!. An amazing display of utter pomp and wealth put together by the nephew of the pope. The gallery is so lavish it made me contemplate the self-centered nature of this family. At first we were not going to go because we had had our fill of museums. But, we changed our minds and decided to go. The Borghese Gallery turned out to be an unforgetful sight in Rome and one I would visit again. Highly recommended.

Small but Impressive. The highlights are definitely Bernini's sculptures. Nice collection of Caravaggio paintings and a collection of works by some other renowned Italian artists like Bassano and Raphael. Some other works by artists like Rubens and van Dyck. Small gallery but impressive.

Nice art with opening stories how the cardinals got their collections. Prepare to wait before get to enter the gallery. Only sertain amount of people are let in at one time. Timeslots to get in. Guided tours. Interesting. Liked stories behind the art works. Not much else to do but the exhibition. On a hot day take something to drink with you. Make sure to find your transportation back to city figured out before you go to Borghese.

Super museum. This place is great, a not-so-big collection (with 2H is more than fine) but nearly all they have is masterpieces. My favourites were the sculptures of Bernini, in particular the Apollo and Dafne one that is the most beautiful sculpture I have ever seen!Remember to book online!

Wonderful gardens and museum. We were fortunate to do a quick golf cart tour around the beautiful arboretum and grounds before going into the Gallery. The Bernini sculptures are so beautiful and masterful, particularly Bernini's David.

A MUST See~. What was once a palace is now a gallery of the finest paintings, statuary, and frescoes. Everywhere one looks, there is art. On the floor, the ceilings, hanging, displayed in every possible way; it is simply stunning. And mixed with the old there is also new pieces by newer artists. What is possible with marble is unbelievable. Overload of the senses, to be sure; but a must see.

Perfect if you dislike huge museums. The Borghese Gallery is a must see in Rome. Their collection is historic, beautiful, and small enough to get through quickly even at a slower pace. They are strict about timed tickets so get there early. Make sure you also build in time after to walk through the park/gardens.

Amazing. The condition of these artifacts relative to their age is amazing. There was plenty of time to see everything. Take time to walk the grounds as well. Don't use flash photography or you will be publicly scolded by a little Italian lady. There are plenty of warnings to save you the scolding.

Beautiful - worth the visit. Was in Rome in March, but actually visited this gallery on a previous trip a few years ago, which was my second time to Rome. The gallery has so many beautiful pieces - and I do remember no photography was allowed. Was nice to walk around the grounds as well.
Gorgeous. Loved, loved the Brunelli sculptures and the gallery's ceilings and light are just gorgeous too. Not a huge gallery so you don't need more than 1-2 hours.

Sculpture "Apollo & Daphne". A very beautiful gallery/museum, with wonderful sculptures from famous people, like Bernini. For me the most beautiful sculpture was the "Apollo & Daphne". Certainly worth while visiting, pre-booking through there website is a must, duration is 2 hours, but that should be enough. The Villa Borghese (the park) itself does not look very well maintained and could use some better maintenance.
Fabulous art!. This is a beautiful gallery which is under appreciated. It's not a normal touristy stop. The villa and the art are well worth the visit.

I love the two-hour scheduled viewing system. The art is noteworthy, of course, and the Galleria displays it well. I thought it was a bit of a pain to have to book tickets ahead of time for a two-hour viewing window, and then to have an appointment that we had to get to. But it worked out great, and I now wish that more museums did the same. It permits you to enjoy an uncrowded experience. We did arrive a bit early, and they let us right in. We did not stay the full two hours. But this was a joy, to really see the artwork at your own pace, in peace. At some other major museums, you are carried along in a surge of humanity, and the thing you see best is the back of the person in front of you. Borghese has solved that problem.
Stunning. The collection is spellbinding. The sculptures are some of the best you'll see in all of Italy. The stroll through the park to get to the gallery is what makes the whole experience special.

DO NOT MISS THIS SPECIAL GEM!. We stumbled upon this gallery and it was the best museum we saw in Rome. It is smaller than the more known ones but this is really a special gem. There are masterpieces here you see in books. I think you need reservations ahead of time because they are smaller and allow a certain amount of people at one time. We had a handicap pass which in Italy allows you entry any time ahead of lines.We were so happy to have seen the Borghese Gallery/Museum.

One of Rome’s Best Galleries. This is one of my favorite Rome galleries. I particularly love sculptures and this gallery is full of some of the most famous and spectacular sculptures in the world. Just being able to see Bernini’s Rape of Proserpine, Apollo and Daphne and Truth Unveiled by Time all in one place is simply a blessing. However, the gallery is also full of some truly spectacular paintings including, the Deposition and my favorite, Bassano’s The Last Supper. Even though the Gallery would be a highlight of anyone’s trip to Rome the grounds surrounding the Gallery are worth a visit as well. The large expansive lawns and flower gardens provide a beautiful tranquil spot to relax right in the middle of the busy and hectic city.Now, in order to view the Borghese you must arrange for tickets in advance of your visit. This can be frustrating for folks who are unaware of the procedure and expect just to go to the Gallery and purchase a ticket. However, the booking process is not an onerous one as you can simply phone or book your spot online. Well worth the little extra effort you may have to make to visit. Highly recommended.

Poor exhibition and restrooms. Very confusing g museum. Some great sculptures. Paintings are Poorly exhibited...lighting stinks...hard to see.The restrooms are a scandal -- no toilet seats or soap...and they literally stank.If I hadn't seen dapne/Apollo, I would consider it a waste of time. Spend more time at capitoline Ignore Rick Steve's transportation advice and use Google maps...since this will save you lots of walking.

The most beautiful art gallery in the world!. Of all the art galleries we have visited in Italy and the world -- this is the one that is the most amazing! Any of the works would be a real treasure in any other of the world's art galleries. If you only see one art treasure in your life... make it this one. The Uffizi in Florence is the only other one that comes close. You will need to make reservations in advance online -- we were able to make ours with a 2-day notice. I am guessing in the summer or tourist-heavy periods, you will need to purchase tickets at least a week in advance.

A must visit . It is out of question that one must visit Borghese Gallery while in Rome. With a Bernini a centerpiece in each room - it is hard to put it in words. The intimacy to behold the masterpieces within a few inches... which is shared only with a few other ones (due to limited attendance per every 2 hour) - it is an experience by itself! Unlike visiting large and crowded museums. I wish I had time for a second visit during my short time in Rome...

Superb. went to Galleria Borghese as it was suggested by the manager of the guest house we where staying at. Simply a wonderful experience as the museum is not very big and you can enjoy wondeful masterpieces of the Italian Reinessance. Stongly recommended.

Do Not Skip Villa Borghese While Visiting Rome!. I have never been so awe-struck by sculptures! This is an absolute MUST when visiting Rome. It will not disappoint! Get an audioguide, they are great to explain the meaning behind each piece. The sculptures and paintings have wonderful stories and are true treasures!The Bernini sculptures are incredible. Villa Borghese has a wonderful collection of sculptures and paintings by the Masters: Bernini, Canova, Caravaggio, Raphael, Titian, and Rubens. The Villa sits on beautiful grounds with ample gardens to enjoy a lovely afternoon. YOU NEED TO MAKE RESERVATIONS IN ADVANCE! You cannot enter without a reservation!
Beautiful Gallery. I did the morning tour as you are only allowed two hours in the gallery, It is beautiful and worth every moment.
Special visit. The gallery itself is worth visiting (take at least 3 hours if you like art), also the park and surroundings.

The most important sight in Rome. First of all make a reservation of your visit or you won t go inside.Try to get a guide It only Costs 2 EUR per person.We did that twice and it was great.Berninies sculptures were amazing.Don't miss villa borgese if it is the only thing you will do in Rome.

What a Day - the gallery is the masterpiece collection you don't want to miss. On one floor - the upper (with which yuu should begin) there are the paintings. On the other the Statues of Canova and the great Masters. Highly reccomended to order online tickets if possible, and to devote 3 hours at least fot the place. Good coffee and cacao at the caffe below - you must leave bags at entrance and photos are allowed . Yeah! Regards, The Desert Dragon.

if you get serprised you probably are in the wrong place. well art treasures are inestimable probably the most wonderful sculptures you can see all over the world not to talk about paintings and villa decorations..unfortunately such a huge amazing capital could be kept in a better way, the surrounding and the outside walls and garden would need a small redecoration..was really amazing the zootropio (temporary installation) by Collishaw.I guess you should know what you gonna see and not get surprised to appreciate more the masterpieces that are inside..Galleria Borghese is not Disneyland!!
Exquisite. There are so many gems in this gallery. Bernini's The Rape of Persephone is beyond awesome. A ticket entitles you to only two hours among the treasures.

Familiar Artworks. The artworks were really impressive and familiar. However, with many people, art appreciation becomes less. In addition, having gone through the art works in the massive Vatican Museum, I must have reached my quota for art works.
Beautiful setting. The Villa and the park are breathtaking.. Its is nice that there is crowd control so it is not so crowded but not my kind of art,
Loved it.. One of my favorite things to do in Rome. Be sure to make reservation and do the audio guide. Bring your earphones so you can walk around hands free.
Spectacular... for a price. It's not very cheap to go inside and you are not allowed to have more than two hours to see the whole place. Not that you would need more, but still worth seeing.

Bernini sculptures are incredible. I can stay in the room with Bernini's Apollo and Daphne for hours. It is a masterpiece, as are the Rape of Proserpina and his David. This museum is my favorite in Rome and one of my favorites in the world.

More than meets the eye!. When you walk up (through a very nice park) you see a simply stone building (nice, but still simple) and you think it can't be that much to see.Wrong, wrong, wrong. This place keeps on going with busts, statues, paintings, and rooms. The one big room has a carousel that spins with the lights out....very eery but amazing in it's gruesomeness. Definitely a must see in Rome!
A nice surprise in Rome. We just stumbled into the Borghese and were so happy to discover it. A lovely place and so much to see. It was a lot of fun for my group.

WOW. This museum is just beautiful! There is amazing history inside this rather small gallery. The art is breathtaking and the statue of Apollo and Daphne is worth the trip in and of itself! You can spend hours here and walk the grounds or you can just see the gallery in about 2 hours. They don't have information at each piece but rather a laminated card in each room. I suggest you read the card as it gives you the information you'll need to fully appreciate each gallery. We were there on a rainy day so we didn't walk the grounds but I can only imagine how lovely it would have been to see the gallery and the grounds! If you're there on a sunny day, be sure to build in enough time.

Wonderful experience. The art is fantastic. The building is a work of art. Ceilings and floors are beautiful. This should be a must see museum. Art collection is outstanding. The gardens are beautiful even in winter.

Beautiful gallery with great sculptures. Essentially it’s one person’s collection from one period with a few later additions. But don’t worry about that - it’s a fantastic collection displayed in an enchanting building. It’s well worth a couple of hours of anyone’s time. The sculpture alone is worth the price of admission. Pre-booking is essential.

Mind blowing art collection. Any body that loves art or architecture will appreciate the awe that this gallery creates. Two floor white villa in a beautiful garden that is a beautiful walk in! First floor is dedicated to statutes mostly which alone blows the mind. The second floor is art and the collection is haut amazing paintings and sculptures done by Raphael to Botticelli. Book your tickets before hand either online or through your hotel it cost about 11€ per person.

Well worth your time.. We went on Sunday our last day in Rome which was the first Sunday of the month. They open it up to the public free. We tried to buy tickets but were told sold out. However go anyway if you are lucky like us they will have extra tickets. We received our tickets at 9:02 am. We had a private guide for just 16 Euros for the two of us the only way to see the Gallery... My only complaint not long enough to see everything. Fire Dept. rules only so many people at a time our tickets were for 9:00 am to 11:00 am 2 Hours. Grounds worth the trip also they have a Zoo on grounds.

Absolutely stunning. The paintings, the sculptures, the tapestries, the frescoes--it's almost too much. "Oh, look. Another Caravaggio". It's all beautiful. Borghese Galleria requires advance reservations and you are limited to a 2-hour window, though they did not seem to be enforcing that in off-season. You have to check bags but not jackets. Gift shop is very nice, and there is a cafe/snack bar.

A fantastic art gallery!. In Rome you should spend months to visit all the monuments and museums the town can offer. However, every visitor interested in art should find the time to go for at least one hour quick visit at the Galleria Borghese. Not only the beautiful sculpture of Paolina Borghese made by Canova, but also the nice pictures exhibited there. Also the way the Gallery is organized is worthwhile for a visit. The only problem is that, although are now many years that the Gallery is open again to the public (at least 20 years) the access is limited to a certain number of visitors inside. Therefore, it is advisable to book the ticket in advance on line, to be sure to have the possibility to enter the Gallery when you are in Rome.
Magnificent!. Very nice works of art and unique sculptures! They made the place very delicate that the art stands up!

A dream come true. When I was a senior in high school (back in 2000-2001) I took a year long Humanities course, which was a mix of an English, art history and history of western civilization course. Through that course, I became kind of obsessed with Bernini, and ever since then, have vowed to see his statues in person. When I started planning our trip to Rome, imagine my joy to find that many of my favorites are housed in this gallery.Getting tickets can be a little bit tricky. They limit the number of people at a time (makes for a much more peaceful experience than the Vatican museums) and so they must be booked weeks in advance. However, the only way to do this online is if you are purchasing a ticket, and we had already planned on using the Roma Pass. They do allow you to call and reserve the ticket, but thankfully the people we were renting our apartment from made this arrangement for us.It is also a little tricky to find, as it isn't directly on any Metro line, and you'll want to give yourself some time so that you arrive early. The Rick Steves guide had good directions from the Spagna stop that involved going through a bit of an underground maze and then walking through the parks in the Villa Borghese complex - it was 10-15 minutes of walking.IT WAS COMPLETELY WORTH IT. There are many amazing things here but to be honest, I only had eyes for Bernini and I spent most of my time (that I wasn't calming my child) gazing raptly at the Rape of Perspehone, Apollo and Daphne, David, Truth Unveiled by Time or Aeneas, Anchises and Ascanius. He is able to make marble seem soft, supple and weightless.The upper level had paintings as well as some other smaller sculptures and busts (including some Bernini did of his patron, and a Bernini sculpture that didn't seem as high quality as the others - I later found out he did when he was 11). There were also some Bernini self portraits.I also enjoyed seeing the Titian and Carravagio they had there. The gallery itself is also sumptuous and beautiful - a fitting surrounding for these works of art.After our trip, we got a little something to eat at the café in the basement, and enjoyed a more leisurely walk back amongst the greenery of the villa (a refreshing break from the city) and there was a nice playground there for my two kids to burn off some energy.

Worth the visit. The park surrounding the gallery is beautiful and green. A lovely place to relax. The gallery is overwhelming and the art spectacular. The audio guides are easy to use but there are laminated reading guides as well in each room. Very enjoyable

Great for those who love sculpture. Nice to see the palace of the Borghese family. The walls and ceilings are painted beautifully. Though I think the main focus was the sculptures. I wanted to come here to see Pauline Bonaparte as Venus, and that alone was worth the admission. Space is limited and you have to make reservations. There are many steps you have to climb in the beginning and it didn't look handicap accessible (in my opinion) and it was very warm in building in November...can't imagine what it would be like during the summer.

Exquisite. Do not miss. I only regret not going twice. The most approachable collections. The best gallery experience in Rome. A lovely "scale" for a gallery/museum experience. Advance reservations are a must, and really work. The reserved ticket system guarantees that you will not be overcrowded, jostled, herded, like in the Vatican, or other major attractions. In October we booked four days ahead, and observed some would-be visitors being very upset to be unable to get tickets the same day.

Borgesse gallery great place to vist. This is our second time to Rome and missed this the first time. The part that is a little trouble you have to purchase the one hour ticket to get in. If you buy in advance be sure to get there in time . About the gallery it's terrific a must see in Rome. Can't see how any one could not rate this place excellent this has some incredible works of art. A note that will help you. I should have read up on the works before going at least the major pieces. An example a sculpture of Borgesses's wife is Napoleans sister and he locks it up when it was finished so no one could see it.

Stunning collection of sculpture and paintings. You need to reserve ahead to visit the Gallery, but it is definitely worth the effort. The rooms are superbly decorated and the collection is stunning. Reservations are generally for 2 hour periods and you can easily spend that much time looking at the artwork.
Bernini +++. The treasures here are overwhelming and the two hours time-slot that you get is hardly but two large Bernini statues (Proserpina's abduction and Apollo & Daphne) were my favourites.

Wonderful. Absolutely intresting with a lot of pictures of some of the famous artist in the world, take a look also to the borghese garden is very romantic and you are just 10 minutes from the Spanish Steps-

Amazing collection! Buy tickets in advance. This amazing collection of art is absolutely worth seeing. Not only does every room have some stunning object, but the rooms are small and intimate-feeling, not institutional.The down side of all that is that the museum has had to put in place crowd control measures -- entrance by timed ticket, and only a certain amount of time in the museum. Keep that in mind, and enjoy your visit to an extraordinary collection.
Spectacular if only for Bernini sculptures. Nothing in Rome can top the half dozen magnificent Bernini sculptures--especially the one of Apollo and Daphne.

BOOK IN ADVANCE!!!. I give this three stars because while it has a stunning collection, one of my favourites in the world, you need to book in advance. Do not make the mistake of just walking up there, you'll likely not get in. Book a few days in advance or prepare to be disappointed!
Awesome. I did not expect to see so many astonishing works of art in a small and cozy space. I was impressed very much.

Go to the second floor first. This is our third time here--still breaktaking! If you want to have more space, go to the second floor first to see the paintings, while evereybody else are on the first floor to see the sculptures. Just watch your time. Since everyone is allowed to have 2 hours--and you do need the full two hours, make sure you spend about 45 minutes for the paintings, then go downstairs and spend a little more than an hour--with fewer people--to see the outstanding sculptures.

Amazing Art. Galleria Borghese is a must see for everyone who loves art. The sculptures by Bernini absolutely take your breath away, and the whole gallery is stunning all the way around. Definitely worth a visit!
Amazing !!!. Great collection of paint and sculptures. Definitely a place not to be missed.Don't forget to make reservation in advance...

The One Must-See Museum for Art Lovers. The first statue I saw, by Bernini, brought tears to my eyes and transfixed me for half an hour. And that was just one piece among dozens of unforgettable works. This villa is jaw-dropping amazing. Do rent the audio guide. Do book in advance; otherwise it is pretty hopeless to try and get in.

The legendary private art gallery!. This legendary private art gallery is located in the eastern corner of the Villa Borghese in a summer house built for pleasure-loving Cardinal Scipione Borghese who was a great patron of the arts and laid the basis for the remarkable collections of paintings and sculptures on view today. The gallery includes such masterpieces as Bernini's "Apollo and Daphne", Titian's "Sacred and Profane Love", Raphael's "Deposition", Caravaggio's "Jerome". Buy tickets in advance since there is limited number of people allowed to enter each hour. You have 2 hours to see all that beauty and trust me if you love arts you won't be disappointed! After that if you have some time to spare have a stroll through beautiful villa Borghese, one of the most elegant parks in Europe.
Scuplture Galore. I visited with my family. The collection of sculptures was amazing. one of the most fascinating items was the spinning display. It made the sculpture come alive.

Fantabulosa. Aboluetely fantabulosa, great works everywhere, all the greats. Well worth the entry charge, but book via internet a long time ahead my son or you won't get in. Their hot-dog stand isn't worth much, however.

Most beautiful place to visit. Just a little out of main Rome but easily reached by metro. The most wonderful sculptures by Bernini and absolute opulence in the decor by Cardinel Borghese. Really highly recommended.

A mini-vatican!. This is an amazing little museum - almost a mini Vatican full of classical and renaissance treasures. The only down side is that the labelling on the exhibits is very sparse and only in Italian, so if you want the details it's worth getting the audio guide or bringing a guidebook.

Beautiful artwork and building. We were lucky to get tickets when we got there. As I have heard you usually have to book online and preferable days ahead. But in late November it was possible to get tickets on sight. The building itself was very pretty as well as the artwork in there. It's worth a visit even if you not an art-fan.

So much to see! You CAN bring camera. We had conflicting instructions (online) that we could not bring a camera. Well you can. Be sure to make reservations ahead. Take the two hours and plan to spend all of it. We booked the first time of the day, and then toured the gardens after. There is so much amazing art to see here. By the end I was glad to spend time outdoors in the huge park and gardens.
Best museum of Rome. I loved everything about the Galeria Borghese, but make sure to book your tickets 2/3 days before online!

Borghese Gallery. Borghese Gallery Tour & Tickets: Bernini, Caravaggio & RaphaelThe tour was exceptional! Cecilia was upbeat, knowledgeable, informative, humorous & professional. My name wasn't on her tour roster and she had to call your office for confirmation. She quickly learned that our 2 tickets were in our travel agents name, which was then easily dealt with. We would highly recommend this tour as we learned so much and we felt that Cecilia definitely could have taught us 'hours' more of important details. Thank you so much for providing us with such an outstanding tour guide.

By far my favorite place to see artwork. . I am a huge Bernini fan. I've always wanted to see his works in front of me. His detail is exquisite. From his facial expressions of David in the act of giving the last blow to Goliath, to the pressure of the hands in which the god is taking Proserpina away from her home is simply breathtaking. This is a must see for any one who loves and appreciates art. So so so worth it.

Great Gallery. Wonderful gallery. Get the audio aid - it's very beneficial. You have to have a reservation. During the high season, you need to get a reservation before you leave the states. During the low season you only need to get a reservation a few days before.

Amazing museum - do not miss! But make a reservation!. This was one of my favorite things in Rome - such a beautiful setting and such amazing artwork! The Villa Borghese is a large, pretty park on the northern edge of downtown Rome (up the hill from Spanish Steps and Via Veneto). It's nice to walk through, check out the fountains and then visit the Gallery. But you MUST have a reservation or pre-bought tickets…I watched many people get turned away at the door! (keep in mind this was a private home, so while enormous, never meant to be a public museum)! Some of the world's masterpieces are here - Caravaggios, Titians, etc. But the best are the Bernini sculptures! Just beautiful…I noticed some people had hired a private tour guide, but you really don't need one. Maybe bring a list or book of what you want to see. But it's worth just going to see the actual building - unreal! Great cafe and gift shop on the way out!

Art and Beautiful Architecture. Outstanding collection of art (many recognizable pieces) housed in a spectacular villa.The art is almost overshadowed by the exquisite architectural details, paint finishes and ceiling murals. Even the marble floor patterns are outstanding. Each room is designed to stand on its own with its particular style and detail.We did order tickets in advance, but in late November many were able to purchase tickets on the same day.The steps to the top floor seem relentlessly long and not recommended for anyone infirm. And you do have to check bags--but, oddly, not coats.The Borghese grounds house other museums and the zoological gardens so one can spend an entire day here.

Fantastic Bernini sculpture collection and much much more. The Borghese Gallery requires a scheduled entrance time and limited number of spaces. This really cuts down on the crowds and vastly improves the experience compared to most of the high-traffic museums in Italy. You are allowed a peaceful opportunity to learn about and have up close views of this massive collection, particularly Bernini sculptures. My average review is only due to the archaic upstairs-downstairs handling of ticket entry/security/lockers and the clerk who crabbed at us for not having a printed version of our tickets. We were traveling in early June before the crowds and had been able to book as we go on-line, bringing the confirmation number and details on our phone. We had done the same at the Vatican Gallery, but apparently not allowed at the Borghese. Instead we received a lecture on where to find a computer printer since there wasn't one in the apartment we had rented. Oh well. At least it didn't spoil the entry or visit.

Lovely museum- lots of steps. This museum is fond inside a beautiful park which is a nice walk outside of the city hustle and bustle. The museum has a fantastic collection and handle the crowds very smartly by requiring an appointment. We saw this first hand when the people in front of us got huffy with the staffer as he was told that they could not get in that day as they were sold out. But it allows you a 2 hour window to see everything with elbow room, which even in the "off season" is a welcome change. Be warned - there are about 80 steps to go to the upper floor. The do have an elevator, but it seems to be for the disabled only, which I get. But, be warned - it will make you huff and puff!! But they have a nice collection - the sculptures were my favorite!
Make a reservation a few weeks before. This was great! If you want to see some really nice art with a small crowd this place is for you! By tickets weeks before going, sells out quick!

Must See for anyone that likes art!. This was definitely worth the time and money spent for the visit. You only have a couple of hours to see the whole collection but as you walk from room to room you will be amazed by both the famous and well known art works as well as those you may not have heard about prior to your visit.

Well worth the trials of booking in advance. Beautiful sculptures by some of the masters of the art in a wonderful setting , as well as having a huge park to relax in afterwards which is well worth seeing on it's own account. Just look closely at the execution of the fingers sinking into the flesh of the lush lady in Bernini's sculpture and tell me that that one square foot of art isn't worth the entrance price alone. I have no intention of looking to see what the people who rated this gallery with one or two stars said to justify their claims. Philistines, one presumes.

Fantastic - do not miss. This is one of the do not miss attractions of Rome and really fantastic. Note that you have only 2 hours inside, and make sure to pre-book your ticket. We had a guided tour which was a good decision as we would have spent too much time on one floor without seeing all important works, as there are just too many to see in 2 hours. will have to come back next time on our own to enjoy the rest...

Stunning Collection. Book in advance and do visit. Booking over the phone is easy. However, you get only 2 hours to see everything. The gallery has an amazing collection of art and sculptures- all by renowned artists. We followed Rick Steve's 'Guide to Rome' and it helped us see the important things within the 2-hour time frame

Must book online!. One can't just arrive at this excellent galleria, you have to book online. Fantastic collection of roman art. Tips: you can take pictures, just not with a flash. I left mine in my bag due to the "no photo" sign - a misleading sign! If your are like me, someone who enjoys art but cant handle "information overload", do not opt for an audioguide(xtra €5), there are nice information cards available in each room. And trust me, 2 hours is enough time inside. Loved the trope l'œil art& Bernini!

Good for art-oriented visitors. I highly recommend early purchase of entrance tickets, all places were fully booked for weeks ahead. It is possible to deposit your personal belongings before entering the exhibition.

Must see for art lovers. This is a great gallery to visit while in Rome. I especially wanted to see the works by Bernini the sculptor and Caravaggio the painter. With sculpture you need to be able to walk around the work and view it from many angles which you are able to do in this gallery. They have an audio guide which you can rent for 5 euros which we did and I recommend this. There is an english speaking guided tour offered as well. The downside to this gallery is that you are only allowed 2 hours to view the works which for me was not enough time.

Amazing art works, must see. It's a quality classical art collection museum, so booking essential, I went there in May, it's not high season yet, the booking was needed a week in advance. There were 5 sessions daily(9am,11am,13pm,15pm,17pm), and 2 hrs per session, only allowed 320 visitors in each time.
Beautiful. Incredible art collection, magnificent park in a thriving city. A breath of fresh air and a welcome break from the bustling city centre.

Look at the ceiling. No. Sit down, look at it.. To me this is a unique museum in its opulence. Where a museum usually is a place with blank walls, and space around the thing that needs your attention, borghese is crowded with eye catchers. Sort of overwhelming, but in a good way.
1,000 Places to See Before You Die. Bernini Sculptures!!!! Best Bernini Sculptures outside of the Navonna Fountain. Picture Gallery average.

Great collection of art and sculpture. This was an amazing gallery with some classic sculptures and paintings. The collection was very diverse and the history behind it was also very interesting. I only say very good though because I am comparing to other galleries I've visited and while this one is good I have seen more impressive collections on my travels in Europe.

Stunning!!. My husband is not a museum fan but since this was one of the museums included in our Roma pass we decided to go. My husband LOVED IT!!! We both we're mesmerize by Bernini's scultures, especially Appolo and Daphene.......Incredible!! If you don't go for any other reason, you must go to see his work, it truly should not be missed. The garden you walk through to get to the museum is beautiful as well. Set aside extra time to see everything. I encourage you to get a map of the gardens to find all the hidden "gems" that there are to see. If not you" ll be going in circles. There is play areas for the kids as well as places to seat and take in all the beauty. I think of it as the "Central Park" of Rome........It's a must see!

Must see in spring, summer, or fall. I wasn't going to visit this place until I realized that in the last 3 days I had visited 22 of Romes "Must See Places" and was missing this one. During my visit, it rained so I was unable to take in the gardens but still made the attempt. I can tell that in the summer it would be beautiful. Inside it was amazing! The rooms did not look real at all. Amazing works of art throughout both levels of the building.
Amazing art. Fantastic collection, but too little time based on timed admission. VITAL to book ahead, sold out weeks in advance!

Yes!. Beautiful and inspiring. Great place to visit especially on a Sunday afternoon. Loved the gallery, gardens and the park. After visiting the gallery having a snack in the park and people watching is a great time out.
Another Italian gem. After a stroll through the magnificent Villa Borghese a wonderful museum with some of the most beautiful sculptures. Absolutely beautiful!

Middle Ages Arts. The original sculptures and paintings in the Borghese Gallery date back to Cardinal Scipione's collection, the son of Ortensia Borghese - Paolo V's sister - and of Francesco Caffarelli, though subsequent events over the next three centuries entailing both losses and acquisition have left their mark. Cardinal Scipion was drawn to any works of ancient, Renaissance and contemporary art which might re-evoke a new golden age. He was not particularly interested in medieval art, but passionately sought to acquire antique sculpture. But Cardinal Scipione was so ambitious that he promoted the creation of new sculptures and especially marble groups to rival antique works. Also the Park around is great to walk around.

A must see if you love art or even just the sensuous lure of marb. If I could only pick one place to go in Rome, it would be the Borghese. And if I could pick only one piece of art to see, it would be Bernini's David. What a man! What determination! What power! And then there's Bernini's unearthly mastery in carving marble . . . can hardly believe a human created the marble rope of David's sling. And finally there's the marble itself . . . it just calls out to be stroked. Oh well. Seeing will have to do.

Brilliant !!!. Had called and reserved the time and date for the Borghese gallery before our trip to Italy. Used the Roma Pass for my husband and myself and had to pay Euro 2 for my daughter's entrance(She is 13). The gallery is undoubtedly one of the best that I have seen.A must see !!! Please call and reserve in advance even if using the Roma Pass as they were turning a lot of people away as they had not reserved
Wow!. Our last day was spent here and I am so happy that we made the time to go. It had some of the best paintings and sculptors. So much Bernini makes me happy!
Not to miss. Completely enjoyed our time spent in the gallery. The sculpture of Apollo and Daphne is alone worth the visit. The palace is amazing as are the grounds.
One of the best museums in Rome. As a tour leader I visit the gallery very often every year. It is one of the best museums in the eternal city, worth a visit at least once in your life!
Don't waste your time. Disappointing considering you have to make reservations before hand. If you have heaps of time to waste I'd say go but make sure you have a reservation.

Average food. After a long tiring walk , we needed to rest our weary legs , the floor space was limited and the food was average,mother drinks were too expensive , they don't cater for daytime tourists, only fine dining

A quiet oasis. Worth the hassle of getting a reservation. It's worthwhile to do some homework in advance so you can maximize the value of your two hours.
Don't forget to appreciate the setting,the fireplaces, the chandeliers, flooring and window treatments.
The Ultimate museum experience. Exquisite collection of fine art. The 4 Bernini masterpieces of sculpture are alone worth the price of admission.

Better the first time. I visited the Borghese Gallery many years ago and have very fond memories but it was my husband's first visit. I found the written descriptions very confusing even though we had relied upon similar information in other galleries. Although I did not pay for the audio guide, I believe one would enjoy the visit more with good information about some of the art.
A famous museum. A famous museum, with famous paintings and sculptures. It is a must see. Do not forget to buy your tickets from internet some days before.
Arrive early :-). We went here first thing on Saturday, after reading about mandatory reservations, but we could walk right in! Excellent collection, very spectacular statues too.

A Must-See. Make sure to make an appointment to reserve a time slot to visit the gallery BEFORE you plan to go. A beautiful, intimate setting for sculpture masterpieces by Bernini and Michaelangelo; frescos and oils by Carravagio, Raphael, Michaelangelo; mosaics. Too beautiful for words.

Excellence, of course ... But spend time in the park for a wonderful Italian experience.. There's little anyone can add about the Borghese collections ... stunning and humbling. But do yourself this favor, too ... budget an hour before and after your visit to simply wander the large park. You can wander into amazing experiences. We did just this and witnessed, at 8:30 a.m., a full brigade of the Italian Guard on 30 massive black stallions canter without words up a tree-canopied brick pathway to their stations ... chills up our spines. Later, we wandered to spraying Baroque fountain where four golden dogs were splashing about, to the utter delight of a gathered crowd of adults and children. Treat yourself to something not in the tour guides.

reservations are REQUIRED. MUST RESERVE AHEAD OF TIME!Reservations are not even recommended. They're REQUIRED!If you're planning to use your Roma pass for this attraction, just make sure you mention you'll have a pass when you're reserving it. Time slots begin every two hours, starting at 9 a.m., so this means you get a max of two hours to explore the museum. But I didn't really need the full two hours.Tip - Bus 53 goes there, straight from the Colosseum, if you're planning to visit there first. Just pay attention to which stop you need to get off at.

Bernini's Masterpieces are here. Bernini's Masterpieces are on display, they alone justify a visit. Wonderful collection of statues constitutes the heart of the collection, some very good paintings add to it. Devote most of your time to 1st floor (paintings are on second floor).

Flesh or Stone?. The Borghese is an amazing experience. Every floor, wall, and ceiling is almost as spectacular as the paintings and statues. The greatest highlights are Bernini's incredible sculptures. They seem to come to life right before your eyes. You'll marvel at Daphne's transformation into a tree as Apollo helplessly tries to catch her. Bernini used plaster to support the delicate parts of this statue as he carefully chiseled away. As the fragile leaves and stems emerged he removed the plaster leaving behind marble that defies the imagination.

Go if you like sculpture. It's in a beautiful mansion set in a park. The first floor is devoted to sculpture. Bellini's pieces alone are worth the admission price. 2nd floor is for the painting, which I don't think are first rate.
Dark.. Seeing the scuptures was the best. Being in the Villa Borghese was the best. But, the inside of the gallery was way too dark and hot.

For all real art lovers. make a reservation of your ticket in advance via internet - it worth of it and the reservation system works very well. Inside let your artistic spirit fly over the centuries, styles and authors ... nothing more it could not be recommend ... perhaps, check your visit time because the time inside villa flies very fast and there are many master pieces to see... so .....

Exceptional. To visit this extraordinary building and its collection of priceless treasures, it is strongly advised to book in advance online (www.rome-museum-tickets.com). The gallery has the sensible practice of having 2-hour slots for visitors - for example, from 0900 to 1100. If you're an hour late, you have only 1 hour. The building itself is a magnificent nineteenth-century villa containing 20 rooms on two floors. In much of the main area, there are classical antiquities and incredible sculptures, including many by Gian Lorenzo Bernini as well as Canova's life-size, semi-nude portrayal of Pauline Bonaparte as 'Venus Victrix'. But there is much more than sculptures. The breath-taking collection of paintings includes masterpieces by Caravaggio ('St. John the Baptist', 'Madonna, Child and Serpent' and 'Boy with a Basket of Flowers'), Raphael ( the beautiful 'Lady with a Unicorn' and 'The Deposition') and 'The Scouring of Christ' by Titian.Still set as it was created in a vast and most pleasant park, the Borghese Gallery is Rome's must-see collection of art treasures.
Living Marble!. I have seen marble work in France, Italy, Spain, Germany, India, and many other places in the world. I was dumbstruck by some of the Bernini pieces here. Worth seeing, do not miss it.

Stunning.. This was one of my favourite points on my visit to Rome. So much so that I visited twice. You need to book tickets before hand and you are given a specific time slot but that really is not an issue. Once inside the beauty and sheer size of the building is totally overwhelming. I would recommend the audio guide as it is great to earn about the history of the building and its treasures. The grounds of the gallery are equally as stunning. I would recommend renting a bicycle and exploring if the weather permits.

Unbelievable - A Must See. Prior to our 17 day Italy trip, including six days in Rome, I purchased online tickets for my wife and I to attend the Borghese Gallery. It worked out well. I was asked to bring an email they send me that confirmed our reservation. I believe I paid an extra euro or two per ticket.We walked to the Gallery from our hotel that was near Termini Station. It was a pleasant 20 minute walk. Our route took us through a good portion of the park. It was a pleasant and quiet walk. When you arrive at the gallery, you'll need to go downstairs through the small door at the center of the staircase. There we traded in our confirmation email printout for tickets. We were told to return near to the hour to await entry. One suggestion: since you cannot take bags or backpacks into the Gallery, you must have them stored in this same area. Women can keep their purses or smaller bags. It's quick but I suggest you do it immediately after getting your tickets. We came back just before entry time to deposit my backpack and there was a long line waiting to those type things in. However, as you exit, they are very quick to get your belongings back to you. In this same downstairs area are bathrooms, a large bookstore, and an area for snacks and drinks.You are allowed to take your cameras in to take photos. There initially was some confusion about that. We also rented the audioguides. Get those. This Gallery has so much wonderful art and there are back stories to much of them. The audioguides provided that info. We noticed couples and small groups who hired guides. If we were to return, we'd do the same. We overheard one of these guides talking and her narrative was informative as well as very interesting.There is so much to see in one visit and you are limited to 2 hours in the Gallery. At our own pace and listening to a little bit more than half of the audioguide presentations we easily used up the two hours.Since the Gallery houses almost all of the best of Bernini, I suggest you take time to fully appreciate Apollo and Daphne, the Rape of Proserpina, and David. I took lots of photos from all angles to remember these works.This is an unbelievable collection of art. It is amazing that so much is housed in this one building. Our visit here was one of the many high-lights of our trip.After our visit, we walked through the park and arrived at Piazza del Popolo.

A wonderful way to spend the day. buy a ticket to enter the Gallery which was the home of the famous Borghese Family. We rented double bikes to ride through the beautiful park then entered the gallery to view stunning artwork collected over the centuries. A great way to spend the day.

Some special atmosphere to be there in winter. Wonderful!. Worth to visit not only the museum but the park - if you have time and allow yourself just relax. The park is very big, a lot of benches if you are tired. Just to walk and enjoy the life within beauty

Handicap entrance in back. I had read the gallery was assessable. Went to the front of the building to find stairs going down and stairs going up. No information on a handicap entrance. My wife went down and found that the handicap entry was at the back of the building. There is also a very small elevator. There are wheelchairs on each floor but they could not fit into the elevator

At the risk of bucking the trend, the exhibits were ok. Brought kids up to this estate way hell and gone and the grounds were amazing but the Bernini statues- magnificent- got a bit overwhelming and sad to say....overkill.
Overwhelming. Recommend going EARLY in the day, to be able to appreciate the artwork, rather than later, when you are exhausted from walking all day

Just perfect. The museum is filled with masterpieces, particularly the Bernini sculptures. No visit to Rome is complete without it.Timed ticket gives you 2 hours to see the galleries. I suggest circulating through the entire museum quickly in the first hour. By the time you're in your second hour many of the other visitors begin to leave. I have had two visits where I was alone in the room with Bernini's Apollo and Daphne for ten minutes or more. It's incredible.

Wonderful. The setting of this wonderful collection is beautiful. We walked through the park to the summer house and then entered to view a very special group of sculptures and paintings in magnificent surroundings. It is well worth a visit but you must prebook. Save time to spend in the park !

Very nice museum with a few spectacular pieces. There are a number of spectacular pieces of art in the museum, but for some reason they make it a pain to visit.It really is a beautiful museum. Very nice painting and fresoes. The sculptures are incredible. The Rape of Persephony, the Reclining Venus (Napoleon's sister was the model) and a number of others. There are a limited number of tickets sold, and they are scheduled every 2 hours. You can't schedule there, you have to call in. So you start off in a crowd after waiting around for your scheduled time. Presumably this is done to ensure it's not overcrowded. And it's not overcrowded.

Had to go twice. And we could have gone twice more. The tender texture of Bernini's sculptures cannot be imagined in the pictures in books. The Caravaggio's and Raphael's are just stunning. The gardens were dead, at least in late October. Stay inside and take your time..
must!!. Lovely palace and gardens. Make sure to have your tickets before. e walked over to the Modern Museum and enjoyed lunch on their covered patio.

A great way to see how the Romans lived with their art. a former Cardinals home set in a beautiful park.
Not huge but worth making a reservation to enjoy the art displayed as it was when the Cardinal lived there. The mix of important sculptures and paintings is mind blowing. If you like Bernini and Caravaggio you will be happy

Experience the genius of Bernini & the intensity of Caravaggio. Exquisite sculptures by Bernini, the master of baroque & powerfully dark paintings by Caravaggio are the highlights of this museum.Do book your ticket in advance & take the guided tour at 11.00, given by an art historian. Their in-depth knowledge helps you to look at the works in a new light & with a greater understanding. Note that they also have audio guides but the guided tour at 6 Euros is well worth it & lasts for about an hour & a half, focussing on the works of Bernini, Caravaggio & Raphael.

Tickets. The Gallery is very often sold out far in advance. We purchased our ticket, before we left, thru the Ticket 1 site. You must go thru their site to register before you can buy the ticket. I believe there was a 2.50 Euro ticket fee, well worth it. Many of the other ticket sellers will want you to buy there "reserved line ticket" It is not necessary as all the admissions are for a specific two time frame. A walk thru the large park, in which the Gallery is located, is a nice quite place to rest and relax. We walked over to the Modern Museum and enjoyed lunch on their covered patio.

Breathtaking art in a beautiful location. We purchased our reservations online before we got to Rome and had no trouble exchanging our vouchers for tickets. The priceless works of art displayed in the Borghese are unbelievable. We spent the entire two hours of our tour being enchanted by one phenomenal sculpture after another. For people like me who get overwhelmed in huge art museums like the Louvre, the smaller scale of the Borghese was perfect.

Absolute must!. The Gallery is also included in the Roma Pass, so we got a discount of nearly 50% as it was our third spot (the first two were free to enter). You must book reservations in advance, with the Roma Pass this means you need to call to book, but otherwise you can book online. Show up half an hour before your time and enjoy a walk around the park area and a gelato. Inside, the gallery is incredible, definitely one of my top three sights in Rome. Two hours should be plenty to enjoy the gallery, but in retrospect I wish I'd have gotten the audio guide as well. Lovely spot, and no matter when you visit it won't be TOO crowded since they limit the number of available tickets.
beautiful Borghesi. Lovely palace and gardens. Transports you back in time.Difficult to access by public transport. Take a taxi and avoid stressfrom the metro.
One of the best sights in Rome. Unbelievable sight, curely one of the best in Rome. If you are a man of the arts, you simply can't afford to miss it.
Amazing. Make sure to have your tickets BEFORE you go--you will still have to wait in line for your specified time, well worth seeing
Wow!. The Bernini sculptures were amazing. The roundabout just inside the entrance was totally unexpected and marvellous. Make sure you stay and watch the spectacle!

if you see nothing else in Rome or in your life..... This is the most stunning musem ever...tickets are sold for particular times so only a certain amount of people are allowed in at once. The museum gives you 2 full hours so you can take your time and circle back and perhaps catch a moment alone to gasp in wonder at the most beautiful marble Bernini statues you will ever see in the world! It is truly a one of a kind experience and one you will never forget. Every room is a jewel box of exquisite art from the marble floors to walls to ceilings never mind the art work in the room. Set in the beautiful Borghese Gardens, you can stroll under trees, perhaps sit on a bench and listen to an old man play classical music on an accordian and relish in what you have just experienced. Security is tight so only bring what you need and you'll have to check your bags but they do allow photos (no flash). We go back every time we are in Rome and are always amazed!
Best gallery I've ever visited!. Don't be put off by the walk to find this and the bland, albeit grand exterior, this is a hidden gem, was absolutely blown away by it's contents!

Very good. We took from tram number 19 to reach the park from the zoo. The Gallery was fantastic perfectly located inside a beatifull huge park.Since November wekdays are probably not a peak period for turists, perhaps there was noneed for skip the line extra costs

Art Paradise. The gallery requires a reservation and visits are limited to two hours. The Bernini sculptures alone justify a visit, but there is much more. We went with the audioguides, which add a lot of information and help guide the visitor through an amazing collection within the time limit.

Beautiful museum, rude staff. I went back to this museum to see the best Bernini sculptures in Rome. The place is beautiful and the gardens sourranding the place are amazing. Just beware the staff is very strict about reservations. Be sure to do it in advanced and then get there in time. You won't be allowed to enter or even get your audio guide before the hour. And they are rude about it! Worst customer service ever! Great place.

Breathtaking. This is a fantastic place, the museum is a work of art itself and the sculptures by Bernini are not to be missed. They make you not pay attention to the other great art and sculptures but take the time to see it all.
A Treasure for Art Lovers. A must see for anyone who enjoys art. Remember to look at the ceilings and walls for excellent decorative pieces.

WOW!!! As good as the Vatican Museum without the crowds. The beauty of the Borghese, notwithstanding the fabulous Bernini collections, art masterpieces, painted ceilings in a beautiful palazzo is the lack of a crowded feeling. Entrance is strictly controlled by reservation or a wait in line until the current group exits. Tickets are available online and you have two hours to view the museum. Follow it up with a walk through the beautiful shady gardens.

Don't forget the park. Visited here whilst on holiday and on advice hired segways to explore the park and admire the many views of Rome. You can also hire bikes go carts and battery powered bikes.Not only are they great fun they allow you to silently glide round this lovely space which is adjacent to one of the super viaducts that are still evident.A place not to miss.Free to enter but hire is chargeable
For discerning viewers. And what a setting - you could spend hours in the park too just Roman watching as well as the antics of fellow holidaymakers

Quite the collection of art. A good place for seasoned travelers to visit. Its located in the park and the park is up hill from most of the central sites in historical old Rome so its a tough walk to get there- recommend taking a taxi

Awesome - A Must For Art Lovers!. If you see nothing else besides the Sistine Chapel - see the Borghese Gallery! I can't say enough about this amazing art housed in a beautiful building and grounds. You MUST book ahead online. Print it out and take it with you. You are allowed 2 hours in the gallery. Arrive a minimum of 1/2 hour (off season) before your scheduled time. Go in through the ground floor archway at the center of the building. The ticket desk is immediately to your right. Stand on line and trade your computer printout for a paper ticket. There is bag check room desk to your left with another line. Ahead and in between the two is a desk (also with a line) to get your audiophone. Some people then went to the rear of this floor to stand on line to get into the picture gallery - don't do it. What I did and I think it preferable is to go back outside and walk up the lovely outside staircase into the first floor and start your audio tour there. There are less people entering at the same lime and you walk into pure beauty. It is amazing! THe first floor has wonderful works - frescoes, sculptures,etc. My favorite was Apollo and Daphne in white gleeming marble. Bernini of course. In room number IV at the right side corner is a spiral stair case that will take you up to the Picture Gallery. In between on the left side of the staircase is a toilette (WC) if you need one. The second floor Picture Gallery has so many paintings it is overwheming. My favorite there was Caravaggio's painting of David holding the head of Goliath (actually the head of Caravaggio himself). Two hours ( all you are allowed) is certainly not enough time for this place and it is worth a future repeat visit. Bernini and Caravaggio art works shine in this beautiful setting.

Splendid. This was my second visit to Galerie Borghese, after my first visit a few years ago, and it remains one of my absolute favourite galleries. The rooms themselves are splendid, but the paintings and sculptures - most notably those by Caravaggio and Bernini - are just beautiful.It's not such a huge gallery, so it's great that a limited number of people are alloted to each 2-hour session to avoid overcrowding.Would recommend pre-purchasing tickets online (both to arrive on time for each timeslot, as well as to avoid missing out as we noticed some sessions for a later date were booked out early). I would also highly recommend renting the audioguide as there are no translations or descriptions of the artworks in the rooms, and the audioguide (much better than most galleries IMO) provides very good contexts and explanations for the various rooms as well as artworks. However, the guidebook which I also purchased in the bookshop prior to entering the gallery (there are two guidebooks for Galerie Borghese and the one I purchased was the comprehensive one at €25) was not very useful at all as it primarily focused on acquisition / transfer / restoration of the artworks.

If you love art, a must see.. Reservations absolutely required. Rome's version of the Uffizi but I liked it better. Maybe it was the smaller, more intimate scale. I was blown away by the Caraveggios and the sculptures and that is not usually my favorite. Better audio than the Uffizzi. You can also have a personal guide as well. Go early. Remember, you are sent out at the end of your 2 hour visit so try to see everything without dwelling but hard to do. Loved it.

Beautiful Borghese. We visited several art galleries in Italy recently and this was our favourite by far! Bernini and Caravaggio lovers will appreciate the Borghese, and especially the ability to get up close to the sculptures and view the fine details first hand. Other galleries did not seem to have that feature, which I found disappointing. The grounds surrounding the gallery are also beautiful, and offer a welcome retreat from the busy city areas.

Wonderful Museum. Make reservations and be early to stand in line. The paintings and sculpture were fabulous and the setting was lovely. The villa is surrounded by a lovely garden. There's a cafe to eat (and rest) either before or after viewing the collection.

For me the best. Loved this original 'museum' in its own parkland with wonderful masterpieces still in the house they were designed for. The statue of David here was my favourite. Well worth a visit but you must book.

If you go to only one place in Rome, let this be the one. A magnificent collection of paintings and statuary in a wonderful palace, laid out and curated for enjoyment of the visitor. It doesn't get any better than this.

Wonderful. You must book on-line before your visit to be certain you get to see this art gallery. Bus 910 is the closest public transportation for this gallery. Be sure you check in and get your tickets downstairs before your reservation time and check your backpacks and purses. What bags have to be checked is not consistent. My wife did not check her small purse worn across her chest, but others in line ahead of us at entry were told they had to check hand held purses that were smaller than hers; also umbrellas must be checked. Photos are allowed, so don't check your camera. Audioguides available and guided tours are also available. We listened in on a couple of the tour guides and they go into great detail about the art, artist and the gallery. Also a nice gift shop and snack bar at the gallery; visit before or after your 2-hour reservation.

Amazing, do not miss!!. Absolutely beautiful!! Make sure you make your reservation on line as they limit attendance and sell out early. Ignore Rick Steve's book saying you can't use your camera. You do have to check your bags but not your camera. The subway stop is very close by and convenient. We didn't see any interesting places to eat nearby so we ate there and it was ok.

Arguably the finest art gallery in the world. Nothing can prepare you for the exquisite excellence of this magical place. Two hours is all you are allowed so why not book two slots and go twice? You won't regret it!

Lovely small museum in a beautiful settong. Make a reservation online for the two hour window. Be careful to check any bags in the basement area prior to presenting yourself with your ticket at the entrance. The collection is wonderful and the building is an attraction on its own. The gallery is in a beautiful park. Very large with many sitting areas. It's worth the time and price.

The best art in the world. I book this online and I advice everyone to do this, the place was booked two weeks in advance. The gallery has the best sculptures found anywhere in the world, I have been to Florence and seen some fine examples of art but nothing compares to the collection in this gallery. If your in Rome and you appreciate fine art visit this place. When you finish admiring the art take a stroll through the gardens and stop for coffee, it is so relaxing and the views are amazing.

Our favourite gallery in Italy. The most unbelievably life-like sculptures and exquisite paintings can be found here. You MUST have a reservation, and I'd recommend an early start to the day, I'd have stayed longer. Because we had the first tour of the day we viewed the villa a bit back to front, and i think the revelation of the grandeur suffered for it. We thoroughly enjoyed the audio tour, and i strongly recommend a picnic lunch in the surrounding park, well worth a stroll.

Oasis in Central Rome. Beautiful artwork and sculptures by Bernini in this beautiful home of a Cardinal in central Rome. First Sundays of the month are free if you call ahead and reserve tickets. Two hour timed tickets are enough time to enjoy the museum. Then walk or rent bikes through the park.Enjoyable quiet morning.

Caravaggio e Bernini. the place to be and see if you enjoy Italian art. Don't forget to make reservations online, in advance, as you can't buy tickets there directly. The Caravaggio's gallery is impressive. So as Bernini's. You can spend hours inside.. Have fun!

Art Lover's Paradise. If you can visit only one place in Rome, then this is the one to go to. Unless of course you belong to the 'Cultural Ingrate' category. Seriously! the art on display here is to die for! The scultures of Bernini will rival anything the Vatican or Florence city can throw at you. We took a museum guide rather than use the audio-guide as there was not much of a price difference. The guide was a very knowledgeable art historian who gave us a good insight into some of the works on display. The best part is that unlike the Vatican, you can explore the rest of the museum once the tour was over.DO NOT MISS

Rome's best art. Sure, there's a lot of competition, but this museum is exquisite. Almost everything here is A list, which is not the case with most of the other museums in Rome. Set in a beautiful park, even getting here is pleasant. The strict two hour visit is barely enough time to devour the best works, but you are left wanting more. And isn't that the way a visit should be? Best bet is to book your tickets on line so that you won't be kept waiting. The Bernini statues here are among his best. Just incredible stuff. If you go to only one art museum in Rome, this is the one to vsiti.

I Really Liked The Cafe Downstairs. Probably not my cup of tea. I did not get the same enjoyment as I did from the nearby Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna and Musei Capotilini. But went along because I thought it was the thing to do.We were lucky in that I had not booked, but rolled up in the November afternoon and was able to join the next admission.Best thing about my visit, bearing in mind I perfer modern art, was the view of the gardens and the cafe below. Of course there were one or two pieces worthwhile, but I could have easily skipped this galleria and not felt I missed anything.BTW the cafe downstairs is fabulous for afternoon tea and very affordable. The fruit granite was worth the visit just in itself.

the BEST!. loved touring the Gallery using the audio guides... just the right amount of information. Your eally do have to make a reservation or you will not get in. I was gobsmacked but the sculptures! The surrounding park was beautiful. We didn;t rent the bikes, but definitely wouldupon our return to Rome. The park is like a quiet oasis, families relaxing, a little restaurant, lovely....

An ABSOLUTE must for art lovers. A short bus ride north from Termini, you can find one of the greatest galleries in the world. (It rivals the Frick in NYC, and Vatican, but lacks the sheer scale of the Metropolitan Museum, d'Orsay, or Louvre). The first floor is filled with sculptures by Bernini that are truly "awe" some. One wonders how he was trumped by Michelangelo. The second floor is filled with Italian paintings. The entire museum is an amazing "home" filled with treasures and priceless works. The frescoes on the ceilings alone were a sight to behold in each room. Truly not to be missed by anyone visiting Rome that has an appreciation for art. You get a 2 hour pass with a set entry time, so plan ahead. I'd recommend getting an art historian guide to accompany you. There were several there guiding others... And I feel I missed out by not having one.

Spectacular. If you are a lover of Art history then you will be amazed by this collection. It begins at the very large gates the encase the wonderful building that showcases the artworks. Not to be missed when visiting Rome.
Gorgeous!!!. It's areally gorgeous place to visit, especially if you have already visited the majority of famouse monuments in Rome. It's better to buy tickets via internet in advanced.

Great small museum. The Borghese Gallery is a wonderful small museum for those who love Italian art or who are interested in learning a little about it. The Villa Borghese is worth a visit just to see the lovely home of an aristocrat. They have some lovely sculptures by Bernini including Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Persephone as well as art by Caravaggio and Titian. They only allow a two hour visit which is adequate as the museum is small but a reservation is recommended. We were there in the summer when a reservation is a must as the museum was sold out for the whole week that we were there.

Villa Borghese Gallery. Villa Borghese Gallery is set in a nice garden setting. Pre-booking tours is required to keep numbers limited. We had an 0900 tour which allows access for 2 hours. Great place to see lots of paintings, sculptures etc. Although the visitor numbers are limited it is still fairly busy, so it would be mayhem if access was unlimited. If you only have a short time in Rome this museum gives you a lot of culture in the one hit.
Amazing. We went from room to room, and never knew what to expect in the next. The sculpture collection is incredible as are the ceiling paintings.
Well worth a visit. Some stunning works of art but it was hard to find even with a reasonable map and signage from the metro was poor. Not to be missed though if you are a fan of art.

The best gallery in Rome. After reading the reviews i desided to book and buy ticket 7 day ealier. It is not too big. The sculptures by Bernini are wonderful. I would recommend this museum to all art lover.

Not to be missed!. This was our favorite…even my husband (who has zero interest in art) agree that it topped even the Vatican museums and the Coliseum/Roman Forum (we don’t like crowds have no any special affinity with these sites so that may have something to do with it). We went in early October and it was sunny with sudden downpours. If you’re in the property and are thirsty, you can grab bottled water at the gift shop/canteen or have a drink from one of the water fountains in front of the Gallery (we were skeptical to try this at first, but it was great tasting and refreshing!) We met our guide outside and were ushered in to deposit our things in a locker. We were given 1 small clear plastic bag per person and we were allowed to bring in anything we could fit in that bag- including wallets, passports, phones and cameras.We had the most enthusiastic and charming guide (Viator/City Wonders- ask for the wonderful storyteller/art expert/overall angel of a guide Rebecca) that gave us a great narration on the exquisite art pieces including the jaw-dropping Bernini sculptures which IMHO is scores more intricate and dynamic than those seen in the Vatican museums and even the Uffizi Gallery. Bernini’s marble sculptures capture pivotal moments in Greek mythology- they seem to come alive vs. stationary statues like the popular David. The gallery is like a high-end restaurant; it doesn’t drown you with art and instead showcases choice pieces of really great looking and interesting art (no renaissance pieces either) and gives you enough time and space to actually appreciate what you’re seeing.It rained the afternoon we were at the Gallery so we weren’t able to tour the gardens, which is a shame because it looked gorgeous in photos.
