Instead, our tour guide walked with us all the way to the nearest subway station and saw us off to our next destination (can’t say enough nice things about Rebecca, she would offer help to anyone who looked lost!)If you’re a walker and are wearing comfortable shoes, you can walk all the way to the Pincio Terrace overlooking the Piazza del Popolo so you can end with a gorgeous photo of the sun set over the piazza.Try to schedule this at the end of your trip so it doesn't spoil the other museums/sites for you :)

Amazing Art Collection. We were extremely lucky to get admission tickets because they were fully booked until the next week. Normally, reservations are a must. The art was collected by a cardinal who was the nephew of the Pope. The many rooms themselves were works of art.

Best of Bernini and more. While a great museum, not a great flow of getting in the galleries. We had a wait over 15 minutes past our ticket entrance time. The holding/staging area was insufficient for the number of people in our group. Once in, tour groups were overlapping and crowding in certain areas. But what a beautiful building the museum was in. The rooms/galleries were lush and over the top.We loved the busts of the Roman emperors; seeing them in one room brought faces to these historic names we have read about. Towards the end of the tour, the Bernini sculpture of the woman turning into a tree was amazing!If you have time to roam the gardens, do it! Carousels, local spontaneous musicians, seg-ways, bicycles, ponds and fountains--it's a lovely place to spend the day. Paths, trees, shade, gardens, vendors, musicians--what's not to like!
Over rated. It has a few pieces worth seeing but the rest of the collection is over rated and over priced. Better to spend the time in the park.

Astounding pieces of art!!!. I didnt have thic place in my schedule originally, but after reading the reviews here i decide to book it and im more than happy that i did it. Simple astounding. Every room more impressive than the other. A must for every art lover.
The best. This is my favorite place whenever in Rome. It's small but i bet one of the most valuable in the world. Many Bernini works and most of the best Italian sculptors and painters

Stunning Sculptures. Immerse yourself in the sculptures of Bernini and Correggio. Admire a Raphael painting. Make this your only art museum of the day. Otherwise you will be on cultural overload and will not appreciate the greatness of the Borghese.It is imperative to buy tickets on-line before you go.
Beautiful!. My favorite museum ever! Not very large, but there are fabulous pieces at every turn. You'll need to make a reservation.
Third favorite place in Rome. The Borgese Gallery has two sculptures by Bernilli. They are the best anywhere except for Michelanglo'sDavid in Florence and the piata in St. Peters.

Surrounded by Beauty. I recommend getting a guided tour. The history of the museum, the family and the art is so rich in history that an explanation helps and you can also get in before the museum opens for the day. The collection is impressive and the rooms they are places in are stunning.

A gem of a museum not to be missed. A gem of a museum, filled with Bernini sculptures and incredible works of art. We always visit when returning to Rome, and now they allow pictures to be taken! Be sure to reserve your space before coming - they are nearly always full. And take your time. The 2 hours they reserve isn't crowded, and provides ample opportunity to view these statues from every angle.

Small but impressive gallery. There are two floors of rooms to see in the gallery and while some are small they hold an impressive amount of paintings, scultures, furniture and special exhibits. Make sure you look up in every room not to miss the art on the ceiling and takenthe full 2 hours youbare allottednto see everything the gallery has to offer. Make sure you visit the entire park after or before you visit the gallery, either on foot or by renting a bike, golf cart or segway.

Queues and Officious Staff. The Borghese Gallery is for art and sculpture enthusiasts. Even if you pre book you have to queue - to get your ticket, to deposit your bags, to retrieve your bags, to wait for your entry time. And heaven help you if you approach the entrance to the gallery before your allotted time! the security dragons will chase you off. We found that we overdosed on pictures and sculpture and left early. I have no doubt that for art students and real enthusiasts it is a great experience but for the casual tourist it is boring.
Beautiful. Don't miss this one! The sculptures are the most amazing I've ever seen. So much art kept so well preserved.

Remarkable sculpture and artwork. Make sure to get ear pads for the art explanations; it is best experienced this way. You can take plenty of time to enjoy the art that way as you walk. Not enough guards around; people were taking flash pics and this was not allowed. Could have used better reinforcement in this area; this art is priceless.

Possibly My Favorite Exhibit!. We have been here before but this time we had a private tour with City Wonders. Our guide, Rebecca was absolutely the most amazing art guide ever. She is so passionate about art and involved everyone in our group. She was so knowledgeable about each piece, she made each of us love it as a much as she did! Bernini is so amazing, how he could create such masterpieces out of marble with the tools that they had, with such expression & grace. Rebecca crafted us around the museum in such a way that we had each room to ourselves when no one else was there. If someone else was in a room, we went to another and then came back. It was seamless. I'm amazed that the museum doesn't take better care of the paintings though. They are open to the elements of the weather and such.
A must for any visit to Rome.. It is worth just seeing the Canova Pauline and the Bernini David! Go! Reservations are required and this was our second visit.
Borghese Gallery. Absolutely worthwhile to do a tour and have major works explained. The stories behind each painting and sculpture add to ones appreciation and memories.

Awesome tour. Arranged a tour thru City Wonders For the Borghese Gallery on Sept 21, 2014. Absolutely great tour. The place is a marvel. The statues and paintings are stunning.Our tour guide Rebecca was very knowledgeable and passionate about the art and helped arrange a tour for the next day. She was the 2nd person I fell in love with in Rome.George K

Berninis by the kilo!. Breathtaking sculpture collection in gorgeous palazzo. One of the finest art collections in Rome. Tickets must be purchased in advance (on line.) Bernini's Apollo and Daphne alone is worth the price of admission.

Fabulous Collection of Art. Lovely gallery in a beautiful park setting hosts an incredible collection of statues/paintings/tapestries. Book in advance on line, this places sells out 2-3 days in advance.Any descriptive signs in the gallery are in Italian only, so opt for the audio piece in your language if this is important to you. They only let in so many people for a finite length of time so don't be late. Usually I skip the pencils and magnets in the gift shop, but if you enjoyed the place as much as we did there is a book that comes in several languages with pictures & text covering every piece in the gallery, and the story behind it. Enjoy !

Overstuffed. Gave no impression of being a lived in space. To my mind it does not compare well with Museo Correr in Venice.
I confess I do not enjoy The Baroque Style

Beautiful private gallery, paintings and sculptures.. The Borghese Gallery sits to the north of the main city centre and is surrounded by parklands and gardens - a stunning setting for the large, white gallery building itself.As the gallery only admits 360 people per two hour timeslot, you need to book your tickets online and then arrive at the gallery at least 30 minutes in advnace of your timeslot to collect the tickets. Make sure you also join the cloakroom queue, as ALL bags, umbrellas etc must be checked. This includes womens' handbags unless they are small purse size. (Don't try and bypass the cloakroom as you will be stopped before entering and asked to check your bag.)You then join the queue to enter the gallery at your allotted time. Note that you have two hours, and at the end of your timeslot must leave to admit the next group.The gallery was stiflingly hot and humid on a 19 degree day, which made queuing downstairs unbearable, and unfortunately it was just as bad on the 1st floor where the bulk of the paintings are showcased. Fortunately the lower floor with the sculptures was much more comfortable.We enjoyed the art, including Caravaggio and Rubens amongst others, and the rooms were an artwork in themselves with lovely frescoes and paintings.So in a nutshll, the gallery is highly recommended, but prepare yourself for a stuffy environment inside and dress in layers accordingly. (Note that the cloakroom won't take jackets so you'll have to carry them.)Other points of note:- The website says all cameras must be checked in the cloakroom, but this was not the case. Cameras without flash were fine, but definitely no bags or purses, or water.- At 9 Euros for a fridge magnet (admission is 11 Euros), don't bother with the souvenir shop.- Reserve/pay for your tickets online in advance. No walk ins allowed on the day we were there, and 7 November is hardly peak season.

Family Borghese. This was a nice place to visit .Inside the house was amazing and outside was a lovely place to walk round there is a zoo and a train to take people round the grounds.We only had a couple of hours here but I would have happily stayed all day.there is lots to do and great for children also.

A Pleasant Suprise In A Quite Neighborhood. A pleasant walk from our apartment , through the Borghes Garden to the Villa. Lovely art, great rooms and outstanding statuary.A must see with out all the crowds. You must have a reservation, but that is easy to do.

Small, but powerful. The Bernini sculptures are breathtaking. The collection is well displayed and very accessible. The 2 hour time limit was just right. We were sorry we hadn't left time for the Villa.
Set in a park, full of treasures. Away from classical Rome, in a park full of greenery. The paintings are superb, especially the Cranach and Rafael which you know from photos.

Beauty in a Fabulous Setting. We hired a private guide for the museum (like many others there) and felt it added to our enjoyment since we could stand and talk about the pieces that interested us and move on as needed (you have a 2 hour time limit inside). It is a lovely palazzo and I am sorry we did not have time to see some of the park. If you have more time, take a walk before or after. We would definitely like to return. Highly recommend as a 'do not miss this' location.

Borghese Gallery. Spectacular gallery of the masters. Despite reviews to the contrary, they do permit photographs without flash. If you start on the top level, you avoid the initial crowds (groups of individuals are admitted for a two hour period and then have to leave). The gallery is well laid out and you can visit all areas in the permitted time.

Very good but-. Know the rules. Buy ticket in advance. Know you are only able to access museum during that time slot. Two hours only. Have a plan to use your time as best as you can. Whether this means spending your time frugally or leisurely, depends on your museum style. To access toilet before your time slot, just go beyond cafe and flash ticket. There will be a line. Be hydrated and ready to go. The paintings are on both floors.

The pearl of Rome. The Borghese grounds are similar in size and impact to Central Park in New York City. Advanced tickets are recommended. The Gallery is a great museum with works of the masters. However, it is of a scale where you are overwhelmed by the beauty of the furnishings and art work, not the size and crowds.It was our favorite museum in Rome
You must book. This gallery always seems such a struggle to get into. I would like to see it eventually but it always seems like a heap of problems after a long walk.
Great Gallery. We wanted to get away from the hoards of travelers, so we visited the Borghese Gallery. Here you will see works of art that you have only read about! Buy your tickets online and early!

Favorite. This was actually my favorite museum in Rome! Unlike the vatican the numbers are limited. We took an English speaking tour at 9:00a.m. No one else thought this was a good idea, so we were 2 people on a private tour. Yes 13euro for a tour worth 250 euro. It was fabulous!

Incredible. An astounding collection of painting and sculpture. The Bernini sculptures are absolutely amazing up close. Buy tickets in advance, they are often not available at the door. The first availability we had was 3 days after we arrived.

Wonderful Gallery. This is a great museum with a combination of paintings and sculpture. It's in a beautiful setting. You need reservations to get in and you need to reserve early in the high season as it is very popular. You only get a set amount of time to amble around and there's a lot to see. The audio guide is very helpful to see the most important works.

Great masterpieces, specially sculptures. Its a great place and not too crowded. "Sacred and profane love" Titian is already reason enough to go there. But in addition there are great sculptures by Bernini and others. So I definitely recommend going.
Book to see it. You must book in advance to see this. It is absolutely worthwhile as it houses a truly incredible collection of renaissance art, including thee Caravaggios.

Great art in luxurious setting. This gallery has a collection of sculpture and paintings that would please anyone. The rooms themselves are works of art with painted ceilings, beautiful fireplaces etc. Tickets are available on line and limited to a certain number every 2 hours. A bag check, cafe, and gift shop are located on the lower level. If you arrive early, the adjacent gardens are pleasant for a walk through.

Stunning.. The most amazing collection of sculptures and art outside of the Louvre! A must see in Rome! We were lucky to have been blessed to see this museum on our last day in Italy. Thank you, Alex....you made our trip exquisite!
A Must See. You need to make a reservation but it is well worth the effort and entrance fee- we were glad we did.

Incredible. Words cannot describe the beautiful works in this world class museum!
Well worth the effort of buying tickets weeks in advance and getting up early to collect your tickets before your appointed time.

Beautiful art and grounds. Small enough to not get overwhelmed with art. Beautiful large grounds to wander around aimlessly. Must make a reservation. Only 2 hours allowed for each group. Start at the top floor to avoid crowds.

Audio Tour was Frustrating. We purchased the audio tour, but found it difficult to use. The maps of the gallery were not particularly specific and so it was unclear where we were located. Most of the displays were not identified to match the map notations so it was hard to find the display that was being described. As a result we feel that the frustration of the confusing audio package was a big distraction and disappointment from a potentially otherwise great experience.

Worth Multiple Visits. If for no other reason, this gallery is worth visiting to see the great Caravaggios hung in an intimate setting and to marvel at Bernini's ability to bring marble to life as he practically invented the Baroque style.Make sure to buy tickets in advance (you will be given a set hour to arrive, and should get there 30 minutes in advance and go to the ticket office to get the ticket before entering the galleries) and DO NOT fail to also explore the entire Borghese gardens and park, one of the great urban oases in the world.

Spectacular art. Plan ahead to reserve your tickets! There is a high demand and you may be left out during the busier times of the year. Tightly controlled entrance and expect to be ushered out 15 minutes before your 2 hour time limit is up. Not nearly enough time to see anything but the several featured pieces. The audio tour was informative but gave poor directions on which gallery in which you need to start. We lost valuable time getting reoriented.
Berninis Galore. This is where you go to admire Bernini's skills as a sculptor. Not to be missed. Classic pieces, and not as overwhemlming as the Vatican's collections.

What a Collection1. If you only have time for one art museum, consider Galleria Borghese. Its collection of Bernini statues is amazing, the paintings by Caravaggio well worth the trip. It is a beautiful home to some of the world's finest pieces of art.

Best gallery in the whole world!. This is probably my favorite art gallery in the whole world. The art is magnificent, the building is a gem, the location in the park is stunning, and the experience is sublime (timed tickets keep visitors to a minimum and allow for a great museum experience). This is my favorite museum in the world (I've visited 5 time during various trips to Rome). It is a must-see in Italy.

The Highlight Of Our 3rd Trip To Rome. We had been to Rome before, and had wanted to visit the Borghese Gallery then, but hadn't been able to get tickets. This time, I booked well in advance. It turned out to be the highlight of our time in Rome. The art collection is very good, and would be worth seeing on its own. But, seeing it in the mansion, with rooms and outdoor views which seem designed to enhance the art, is an amazing experience. In a way that wasn't true in any other museum we visited in Europe on this trip, in the Borghese we felt almost as we had stepped into a different, calmer and more beautiful, time and place. If you go to the Borghese Gallery, try to arrange your time so that you can walk back to central Rome through the vast Borghese Gardens. It takes less time than you might guess to walk to the Spanish steps from there. For most of the way, you'll be walking through a leafy park. Then, near the end, you'll be on a promenade overlooking all of Rome. You'll pass a nice Gelateria, which is worth a stop. A bit past that, you'll find yourself at the top of the Spanish Steps. All-in-all, a trip to the Borghese Gallery and Gardens is a wonderful way to spend your time in Rome

Too little time - frustrating experience - fantatic museum. The strictly enforced 2-hour limit at the Borghese Gallery is not nearly enough time to appreciate its holdings. Yeah, you can cherry pick and join the mobs ogling the Bernini statues, but the gallery has a wealth of other art. For example, 4 (5?) Caravaggios; Titian; Rafael; Canova; Rubens and on and on. In addition, the rooms are beautiful and full of interesting details - moldings, ceilings, floors. If you visit, I suggest finding a printed or online guide beforehand and deciding what you want to see. Then, depending on how long your list is, book more than one two-hour slot. You might have to use a travel agency to accomplish this, I don't know how smart the booking site is.

Awful unhelpful staff. gallery was nice.. The staff should be better managed as they were rude and extremely unhelpful, do not answer the phone and really are not bothered about service in the gallery. When I mentioned that the phone was difficult to get through to we were told 'I don't care' and 'please dont come back'.

The sculptures make the visit. Fortunately we were well prepared and booked our tickets in advance. We were expecting huge queues for the ticket and then for the baggage drop, but they weren't too bad. Unlike other reviewers we had no hassle from staff and the baggage area was manned by 2 people throughout. We didn't bother with the audio guide.We much preferred the sculpture here to the paintings. The highlights being David and Goliath, the rape of Proserpine and Canova's sculpture of Pauline Borghese. The restriction on numbers meant that you could get a good view of everything in the allotted time.The paintings could have been displayed better I feel, and parts of the upstairs gallery were extremely hot and humid, not sure it will do the exhibits much good, but they have been here a while I suppose. Others have commented about the difficulty getting here. The number 116 bus delivered us almost to the door (well 100 metres away at the most) direct from Via Veneto. It was a gentle stroll back to the Spanish Steps through the park. Seemed quite easy to me.

Book in advance, now crowds. The only place I found in Rome that actually thought of tourists - you have to book in a advance and there is limited amount of people allowed at a time. This made it possible to walk freely around the gallery and enjoy the art without crowding like in any other place in Rome. I was a bit dissappointed that the gallery was rather small, some of the works were copies. The garden around the gallery is perfect for relaxing after long day walking.

A slice of great art and history. Worth the extra effort... a bit of a walk from the rest of Rome, the beauty of the art and the grounds are wonderful. Admire the great works of Bernini, paintings, sculptures. Make sure you make reservations well in advance, it is your only way in.

Good way to end the day. This is a good place to end a long day of sightseeing. It is a good place to rent Segways or bicycles and just have fun. Good family outing. Also a lovely view over Rome at the top of the steps from the Piazza del Popolo.

overrated impressive collection of paintings. great park but the museum itself is small and thus we found it overrated compared to other great things to see in Rome. Also it is far out of the city center. Prefer to go there by taxi and walk back through the park and down the Spanish steps. Better to go down than up ;-)

A must. The grounds are magnificent, the view over Rome from the top is a MUST - quite breathtaking especially with the music in the background. Quite romantic. Take as many strolls as you can while there and grab a bite at their cafe. Quite a lovely and relaxing experience.
A MUST SEE. The garden was a relief after all the narrow streets.The sculpures & art in the gallery we rate better than the vatican - without the slow shuffle !!

Only saw exterior. set in Borghese park which was great contrast from busy Via Veneto (which leads up to the park) excellent way to spend sunny afternoon but beware the café at the crossroads where the tariff was dearer than some of the expensive restaurants in town.
Nice little gallery. Nice exhibits with lots of culture. Smaller place compared to other nearby attractions though. Good that it was free with the traveller pass.

Good place to escape the crowds and see first class art. This is where I really got to know Bernini's art -- it's really worth it! Every room has much to see, the building itself is also interesting, and the amount of people does not impede your experience.

Truly worth a visit. We tried for 3 years in a row to visit. Finally this year we got in. 1st year we didn't know you needed tix in advance as they are usually sold out. 2nd year there were demonstrations (possible riots?) set to occur right between our hotel and the gallery. Our tickets where for 9am - we arrived a bit before 8:30 and took pictures outside as they weren't open yet. at 8:30'ish they open the doors and you enter and go thru the process - very organized. FYI: no bags/purses allowed so they make you ck them in a locker - they have staff take your bags and place them in lockers and give you the key. They won't let you into the exhibits till 9am but you can visit the cafe and gift shops. We saw a line forming at 8:45 so we joined in and right at 9am we were allowed through the roped off areas. They direct everyone up to the top level - so you either walk up a couple of flights of stairs or take elevator. At first I thought you couldn't take photos, but then realized you could :-)The art on display is truly amazing. The crowds when we went weren't large. We went on a Sunday so no school groups.The tix give you a 2 hour window to enjoy the gallery - it was plenty of time. When you're done, you go back to the staff counter to return the key and retrieve your personal bags.At 9am they allow you full access.

Worth the visit!. The Borghese Gallery is really worth the visit as the place houses some great art treasures and the villa itself is quite magnificent. Book ahead. Also really worth taking a stroll in the park after your visit to the Gallery (you can rent bikes, segways, you can rollerskate or just walk aroung) and its practically in the center of the city.
AMAZING. Get an art historian guide! This is rare to find the works of art still in the home location! Three of the most famous statues are HERE!

Great collection, bad display. I expected much more from this gallery. The collection on display is extraordinary .. beautiful works and the best Bernini collection available. Problem is the display of the paintings. The light (or absence of it) obscures the majority of works.

Borghese Gallery with Private Tour of Rome. I went to Italy a month ago for three weeks. Most of the time I was with a tour group, but I spent 3 days in Rome on my own. There were three sites I definitely wanted to see: Vatican, Colosseum, and Borghese Gallery. I decided the best way to do this would be with a private guide. I found a company online called "Private Tour of Rome." The company offered private tours for all three sites so I booked with them. I cannot tell you how pleased I was. Everything was handled via email. I was contacted immediately and guided through the process. I purchased my own tickets to the Vatican and Colosseum online (was sent the link to the website) and then forwarded the vouchers to Private Tour of Rome. That was the only thing I paid for in advance. Payment for the tour itself was not required until the end of the tour (although payment was requested in cash). The price for the private guide was very reasonable, and I could not have asked for a better guide. Elisa was a young Italian woman, very professional, very educated, very enthusiastic, spoke perfect English, and provided me with lots of information. We spent one whole day together, including a delightful lunch at a restaurant she selected (she introduced me to some typical Roman fried appetizers). The tour of the Borghese Gallery was delightful and it is now my favorite museum in the world. The Bernini sculptures were simply dazzling. I highly recommend this company if you are seeking a private guide in Rome. I liked everything about the way the tours were arranged and handled. A+++

Really enjoyed this museum!. It was great that we had to make a reservation and that they limited the number of people in at one time. We followed Rick Steve's advice and started on the top floor first and it was empty! We worked our way downstairs next as everyone else was making their way upstairs. LOVED the main floor sculptures!!!

Exceeded our expectations. The Borghese Gallery is fabulous. The Bernini sculptures, in particular, are absolutely breathtaking. The painting collection is also excellent, but the sculptures are phenomenal.Rent an audioguide. Also, make advance reservations (we went on a Friday and they were sold out until the following week) and get there early in order to check any bags (mandatory, but free) and be ready to roll when your entry time comes up. The timed/limited admissions make the museum more accessible, though we did start our tour on the 2nd floor in order to run into fewer people.

Worth it for the Berninis. Interesting to see this villa/ museum as an example of Roman wealth and excess. They admit 300 people every two hours, so reservations are definitely needed, but it is not overly crowded once you are in. Oddly enough they make you check even small bags but will not take coatsThe sculptures are the high point but also many worthwhile paintings
breathtaking visit. Bernini's sculptures are worth seeing!!! It's a must!!! And though it took us a loooooong time to get to the gallery, we were rewarded!
Art. The shear quantity of stunning Art is fantastic and needs far longer than we had. The park around is a further bonus.

Must do your homework to avoid frustration at this superlative museum. This is a relatively small museum which house some of the finest works of art in the western world. Therefore the demand to visit this museum is very high. The Gallery's solution to this demand is to sell timed tickets for a specific two hour period (actually they start ushering you out 10 minutes before the end of the 2 hours) allowing only 360 people to enter the museum at any one time. Tickets need to be pre-booked in advance, perferably online or by telephone, as the time slots are usually booked out a week in advance. Do not expect to be able to walk up to the gallery and get tickets for the next session or for one of the time slots that day. That would be a receipe for disappointment and frustration. A few reviewers on tripadvisor obviously did not do their homework, were not aware of the booking system and made their way to the gallery only to be disappointed. A few people have claimed on tripadvisor they have been able to get walk up tickets but this is EXTREMELY rare and is a tactic which will usually end in tears if tried.I have wanted to visit Galleria Borghese for the Bernini statue of Apollo and Daphne alone ever since Kenneth Clark introduced me to the work in his wonderful TV series "Civilisation". I had been put off attending the gallery on previous visits to Rome thinking it was too far away, not wanting to be tied down to a specific time, and being worried I would not be able to book by telephone as a non Italian speaker. I was almost put off on this last visit by the sprinkling of bad reviews on tripadvisor about the ticketing rigmarole and, the queueing, the restrictions, and the brusque staff. These are not unwarranted criticisms but if you do your homework it is well worth the trouble to be able to view the sublime works on show.In these days of free wifi and iPads it is now easier to book online but it is still advisable to have access to a printer (I used the one in our hotel) to have a copy of your booking as a back up to face the famously unhelpful gallery staff. I booked a convenient session a week ahead (also note the gallery is closed on Mondays) and allocated a whole morning for the visit. Sessions are for two hours starting from 9AM and we chose the 11AM session to allow time to get to the gallery, being mindful of the gallery's warning to arrive one hour before the session, and also being forewarned that there will be queues to a) collect your pre-booked tickets, then b) put in the cloakroom everything and anything you may be carrying (no coats, bags -even purses, handbags or gift bags- cameras etc are allowed in), then c) queue to obtain an audio guide, and finally d) queue at the main entrance to access the gallery when your time arrives.The online booking system was a little involved but not too difficult, although you do have to log on and create an account for the TicketOne system to book and then provide an email address, home address etc (a little involved for purchasing a 11 Euro - AUS $ 15.85 per person ticket). I only used TicketOne once for booking the Galleria Borghese and have never needed this system again but I still get advertising emails from them one year later. There is also a 1,50 Euro booking fee per person so the total cost for two people was 25 Euros. The booking code provided is needed to pick up your actual tickets on the day, so make sure you print off a copy of your booking as proof when you confront the unsmiling ticket staff at the gallery. Some tripadvisor reviewers have already mentioned that this can sometimes be a problem if one does not have a copy of the code.The gallery advised on their website to be there an hour before the session time. We dutifully followed this but it was probably not neccesary to be that far ahead when we visited during November. 30 minutes before might be more reasonable, but this may change in the busy summer period or if one needs to check bags or pick up an audio guide. We rarely use audio guides and were suitably forewarned so did not have any bags, not even a camera or a purse, to avoid the need to use the cloakroom. At least getting there early allows one to explore the extensive park which surrounds the gallery.Some reviewers have commented that the gallery is some distance from the centre of Rome but that is probably a little overstated. It seems this may be because people catch the Metro to the Spagna station and find that they have to walk a fair way thorough the Villa Borgese gardens (which has an uphill gradient) to reach the Galleria at the eastern end of the park. We walked from our hotel on the via Nazionale finding it an easy 20 minute walk (about 1.7 kms) by way of the via Torino to the Piazza di San Bernardo (and not too far away is the church of Santa Maria Vittoria which holds another Bernini masterpiece, The Ecstasy of Saint Teresa) , then further north to reach the via Piedmonte, crossing the Corso d'Italia, the road becoming the via Giacomo Puccini to reach the park on the via Pinciana. It is a short walk along the path in the park, Viale dell' Uccelliera, to the Galleria Borghese.To get an idea of the attitude of the staff of the gallery, think of the purveyor of soup in a well known Seinfeld episode. Of course they deal with thousands of tourists a day, many unprepared and asking the same inane question, but they should make it less obvious that they would rather chew their own legs off than talk to you politely or even, God forbid, give you a smile. They seem to forget they are in the hospitality business. Be prepared for their brusqueness but if you have planned ahead you should be OK. First you must go to the ticket counter in the basement area below the two storey building. We were about 90 minutes ahead of our session time and there was no queue but of course the two people behind the counter failed to acknowledge us or even look up until they were ready to deign to attend to us. I provided my name and booking code (with a copy of my booking handy) and was handed my tickets by the unsmiling attendant. Forewarned, we did not need to check bags or get the audio guide. There were no queues at this time but we did notice later that people who arrived only 15 minutes before the session had to negotiate lines for each of these requirements.Before our session we did see a little of the park (although it was quite a cold and overcast day so we did not linger long outside). We did sit inside to watch the antics of the cafe. As we already had our tickets we could avail ourselves of the toilets (the ticket being scrupuously scanned by the attendant with greater vigilence than a US Immigrations Officer - fortunately we did not have to suppy our finger prints!) and noted museum patrons, who had pre-paid the gallery entrance but had the temerity to buy something from the cafe and decided to defy Roman officialdom by using the bathrooms before collecting their tickets, were ruthlessly turned away from the needed ablutions. The cafe bar counter was well patronised by other staff of the gallery crowding out any gallery visitors and making it difficult for these actual customers to use this cafe (for whom it was presumably designed). One unfortunate Japanese tourist ordered a coffee from the disdainful cafe staff and sadly knocked it over spilling the contents over the counter, much to the undisguised disgust of the "friendly" hospitality worker. The spillage was inexpertly wiped up by this aforemnetioned "paragon of friendliness" but some had seeped into a few of the cakes and sandwiches etc in the counter space below. It entertained us seeing how the mess continued to drip for some time, or that some puddles still remained, effecting the items below which were still for sale for the next unsuspecting walking wallet (I mean, gallery visitor) to come along.One leaves the undercroft area where the ticket counter, cafe, cloakroom, toilets etc are to go outside and then up the stairs to enter the gallery when one's session is due. People assemble a little before time so there is a little queue here too. We noted too that those who had not done their research had arrived in the vain hope that the staff would expalin the rules, were unsure as to where to go to find the entrance, or that others had foolishly decided to get a last minute purchase from the cafe or bookshop (or use the toilet) and lined up at the entrance clutching small bags or their gift shop bags only to be triumphantly turned away by the entrance guards when entry was allowed.I don't want anyone to be put off by all this, it is just the entertaining theatre that one encounters in many Roman attractions. Don't be put off, be prepared, hopefully laugh at the stupidity of it all before enjoying the sublime beauty in store for you inside which makes all this nonsense worth it.Despite this being a timed session, with 360 people in the mainly small rooms of this relatively small gallery, it is usually fairly crowded in each room. It might be advisable to try and avoid the initial rush to the Bernini sculptures in Rooms I, II, III and IV. The natural inclination of American and Contentinal tourists is to turn right and make for Room I. Being Australian we were more inclined to keep left, made for Room VIII first, and had the marvellous Caravaggios almost to ourselves. Other more canny visitors make for the Picture Gallery on the First Floor and then return to the Ground Floor to view the Berninis when most of the session group (often dutifully following their audio guides) have moved upstairs. Note too that there is also a toilet halfway up the stairs to the first floor should one require it and so one does not waste time leaving the gallery to go back to the main facilities in the basement.It amazes me that there are the odd reviews on tripadvisor who say that the collection is "nothing special" or that they had had enough well before the two hour (actually 110 minutes) session had expired. To paraphase the science historian and broadcaster James Burke, I can only imagine these people as some modern version of a Philistines picking their noses uncomprehendingly in front of a Raphael and wondering what the toilets in the building are for!Room VIII, the Sala of Silenus is positively dripping with some of Caravaggio's most wonderful works including "Boy with a Basket of Fruit", "Saint Jerome", "David with the Head of Goliath" (the head being Caravaggio's own portrait) and "Saint John the Baptist"(1610). Room VII and VIII sport some fine Roman sculptures of the second and third centuries AD providing a prelude to the breathtaking sumptiousness of the Sala degli Imperatori. The room itself is spectacular enough, the Borgheses shamelessly flaunting their immense wealth - the marble flooring, the pilasters, the hexagonal cameos, the friezes and the ceiling frescoes. I could have delighted in the many marvellous porphyry busts of Roman Emperors here alone (which excel anything one can see in the Capitoline Museum), yet the centre piece of Room IV is Bernini's "Rape of Proserpina" and one is amazed at the delicate detail, rendering in marble the curls of Pluto's beard or that solid stone could portray the softness of human flesh as the God of the Underworld's fingers cause subtle indents in Proserpina's skin. More of Bernini's genius is on show in Room III which holds surely the highlight of this museum, "Apollo and Daphne". I spent the most time in this room wondering and at the artistry and beauty of this work from every angle. Words can not describe adequately this triumph of an artist's skill. To say this gallery contains nothing special!? What are you doing in a museum or even in Rome if you could think this! Finally seeing this work was the highlight of my visit to Rome and one of those rare moments when seeing the work "in the flesh" is a far greater experience than seeing it in a book or on TV (the Mona Lisa is a scribble in comparison! - I am joking, well just a little).Room II contains Bernini's David which, on some days, I think gives Michelangelo a run for his money. I like the realism and action of the work and Bernini made a face in a mirror to copy for David's visage, so it is a self portrait of sorts. When we visited in November 2013 it was partly obscured by scafolding so one could not get the full 360 experience, but hopefully renovations of this Room have now been completed.Being something of a Bonapartist I was equally excited to see Canova's famous reclining nude of Paolina Bonaparte Borghese. This work is in no way shamed by being in close proximity to the genius of Bernini. Again something not to be missed and demands a leisurely viewing. Although it may be a little crass, I was keen to obtain a souvenir of this work. I found the examples in the Galleria Borghese gift shop expensive and very poor quality. I would recommend visiting the shop of a Florentine seller on the Corso Vittorio Emanuele II called La Fiortentina which has some beautiful souvenirs of Roman artefacts, including a minature of Paolina.Upstairs on the First Floor is the Picture Gallery with some 12 small rooms of paintings from mainly the 16th to the 18th century. One has to tear oneself away from the Berninis to not run out of time to see this floor, but I might not have done them justice as I had to return to the Ground Floor before the session expired for one last look at the Berninis. Highlights of the Picture Gallery would have to be Raphael's "Portrait of a Lady with a Unicorn" and the brilliant colours of his "Deposition" (both in Room IX). Lorenzo Lotto's "Portrait of a Man" in Room XII appealed to me as well as the senuous beauty of many of the figures in Domenichino's "Diana the Huntress" (Room XIX). Not forgetting the rich blues in Bellini's "Madonna with Child" (1510) in Room XX which shares space with a couple of wonderful works by Titian.We could have easily stayed three hours or more in this wonderful museum but from 10 minutes before the session ends the staff begin to rapidly and methodically closing off rooms to quickly usher visitors out the door to clear the venue for the next session. In conclusion, be prepared, BOOK IN ADVANCE, be bemused by the outrageous staff and revel in the superb masterpieces. A MUST for any visit to Rome.

Very good. We enjoyed the paintings, sculptures and the experience - so much better than the awful Vatican and Sistine Chapel. We were lucky to get tickets on the day - normally they are selling them for about four days ahead. The place has three levels: the underground level has the ticket office, cloakroom, cafe and shop. You have to leave your bags in the cloakroom. The next floor is the main entrance - there was no indication of whether you should go left or right, so we went right. We circled around looking at the magnificent statues and paintings until we arrived back where we had started. We had to ask how to get to the next level and had to go half way around the rooms again to find the place where you go up to the next floor - it wasn't indicated which is a bit odd. The top floor is mainly paintings and not quite as good as the first floor. All of the paintings and sculptures have a description just in Italian, not in English, which is a pity. There was not a single employee of the villa borghese in any of the exhibition rooms, which is a bit strange, so there was no possibility of asking any questions about the exhibits.

A must to see!. This has to be one of the most beautiful museums in the world. Loved all the Bernini works of art especially Apollo and Daphne! Truly a 'don't miss' experience! Be sure to get tickets in advanced. The audio guide was worthwhile! Be sure to allow time to wander around the gardens....beautiful and a nice retreat from the crowds of the Vatican!!

Amazing art, excellently presented. We rented the audio guides, and they were really excellent. I wouldn't have understood or appreciated Bernini without them. We went quite early and spent a lovely couple of hours in the park. Limiting attendance made it a very good experience, without too many people to appreciate the art.

Well worth it!. A perfect place to see art. The Borghese Gallery is two floors, not a big as a regular museum & easy to cover in under two hours. In fact, you must get tickets in advance, which are date and time specific , and allow you only two hours in the gallery. There are information cards in each room which explain all the pieces, which adds to the experience of looking at the sculptures & paintings. A don't miss, in my opinion !

A must see while in Rome. This is a must see while in Rome. We decided to get a guided tour while there, and it was worth the extra euros. Having someone who is well educated in art made this a unique experience. Just beware, we took the metro and it was a good 15 minute walk from the stop. Give yourself plenty of time. Reservations a must!

Must see . . .. but be sure to get reservations beforehand as total number of visitors is restricted. Walking around the grounds is a real treat. Especially lovely are the indescribably beautiful statues in the main gallery.
Nice paintings. Liked it, the paintings, the sculptures, the garden.A beautiful place.If you like art, go there.It's a bit far from the city center. Worth the visit if you have time.
Too much, wonderful. Book your ticket in advance, you migth risk that all are sold out. The Borghese is full of artworks, don't forget to go upstairs!

Borghese is a Must. This gallery was one of the best small art galleries I have seen. I recently spent 6 days on a Docent Art Tour and nothing compared to this. The Bernini sculptors were exquisite. Book in advance. I almost missed it. As a sole traveler, I took a chance and walked to the gallery just to see if I could get a last minute ticket. Tickets are now paid in advance and they are limited which makes your 2 hour viewing very enjoyable. The ticket sales person must of guessed I was alone. When I confirmed it, she miraculously offered one ticket. That is an anomaly, so book early (months/weeks not days) especially for peak seasons.

Beautiful!. I was so looking forward to this museum because of the Bernini sculptures. I was not disappointed. To see the detail, the emotion, and the exactness to which Bernini carved these is just amazing. The paintings, the ceilings, and everything will just blow you away. Definitely worth the trip up to the park, and it's super easy to find and get to. When you get off the metro, it's a short walk through the park and to the Gallery. You'll have to call ahead for a reservation. We spent about 2 hours in the gallery and it was perfect. Even gave us time to walk around the grounds.
A welcome get away from the hub. Beautiful gardens to chill and listen to buskers. We did not visit the galleries but chose our time here to relax and wander around at leisure.

Bernini's sculptures.... Amazing... Can't say more than that... Pity that in 700yrs time people may look back at us and see iPhones, tablets and paintings that can by no stretch of the imagination be called "art"!!
Book early. There are limited tickets to the gallery. Book early. You do not want to miss the fantastic artwork here.
I love this gallery. Can stay hours watching Bernini sculptures and in the end look back that nobody is watching and touch the mat.. if it really made from stone? ..
i loved it. I bought a viator ticket that was cheaper than buying it there, no lines and fantastic. The gallery is beautiful and worth it. Beautiful paintings.

Beautiful gallery - Stunning art. In a city full of beauty and wonder, it is easy to get a bit weary of sculpture and art.However - don't miss the Borghese Gallery. The collection is amazing, my favourite is the Apollo & Daphne (the leaves are beyond belief)The villa itself is also very pretty.We enjoyed the gardens, and even returned for a second visit to the gardens to take time to enjoy the peace and quiet from the busy city.Definitely recommend visiting the Gallery.

Relaxing tour. When you purchase a ticket, you are given a set time for entry. We arrived early and walked around the gardens and sat on a bench and observed all the people walking by. We found the gallery very interesting and informative. A definite must see when in Rome.

Fabulous small museum. This great museum in the heart of the Borghese gardens has an amazing collection of paintings and sculptures, especially from the young Bernini. There are several of his sculptures that you want to just sit and look at for a long time. Reservations are easy using the online system. You have to have a reservation and you get a two hour time block to walk through the museum. We did it in an hour and a half and didn't feel rushed. The reservation system is actually quite nice since it keeps the crowds down which results in a pleasant visit.Don't miss the rotating art at the end of the museum...it is fun to watch. you won't be able to take in any bags or a camera so you'll have to check it in at the basement. Highly recommend you get an audio guide.

Go for the Bernini, Stay for the Caravaggio. Breath taking experience. You'll see Bernini sculpture that will you leave you wondering how in the world could someone sculpt stone like this with the available tools of the day. You'll also see the mid blowing dark paintings of the murderer Caravaggio, only slightly less evil than the pope and his henchmen of the time.

Amazing. You should have a reservation; however, three of us got in at 3:00 p.m. on a Sat. without. We did not have a guide; just wanted to stroll and look. We did do the audio guide. They were just we wanted. The priceless art and sculpture in this place is unbelievable. Every famous Italian artist known. Very enjoyable for a 2 - 3 hour adventure. Lovely part of town also. Surrounded by a huge park.

This gallery is a must.. I loved this gallery. We chose to take the docent lead tour and it proved to be excellent. The docent selected the most famous pieces to discuss and explained them in detail. The gallery itself is beautifully painted and contains many world famous works of art. In order to visit the gallery you must make a reservation and are only allowed in the gallery for 2 hours at a time. This keeps the crowds manageable and makes for a lovely experience.

Make reservations. We arrived October 3rd and they were sold out of tickets until October 8th. We didn't get to see the museum. We bought the Rome City Pass and it didn't get us into the museum. They were sold out!!

Fabulous collection of Bernini sculptures. Must have tickets in advance -- they sell out weeks in advance. Read up on it first. You have a two hour window to go through. The Bernini sculptures are the best; there is also an incredible amount of artwork. Very hard to find the stairway in the back to the second floor, but it is there!! Recommend the audio tour.

Magnificent. This is one of Rome's best galleries. Well organized tours without cramming people in like sardines (Sistine Chapel!!!) and the works on display are magnificent. Would highly recommend but book before you arrive in Rome. In October was booked out two weeks ahead!

On Line Reservation - Warning. We are not positive but we only use one credit card for travel and found the on line reservation for the Borghese Gallery quite a mystery, we had to set up an account for a European version of PayPal to pay for the tickets. When we come home on that same day we found out that our credit card number had been stolen, since this was the only transaction that day and very few before you might take this as a possible warning. Maybe have somebody make your reservation by phone, out hotel offered and we should have accepted their offer.

Very interesting museum. If you decide to go to Borghese Gallery be prepared to deal with a lot of restrictions, rudeness, lack of signage on your way to this museum not very well organized tours. It is expensive and the tour itself with the head phones is annoying as it is jumping from room to room, from one piece of art to the other.

Beautiful art in a wonderful villa. The art is displayed in a beautiful villa in the park. Definitely worth the trip. They only let in 250 people at a time with only certain times available. You must have a reservation. I called -- it was very easy.

Small enough gallery to connect with the art. Very much enjoyed our visit to the Borghese. It was not as overwhelming as larger galleries, and we were able to actually learn a great deal while soaking in the paintings and amazing sculptures. The park in which it is located was a relaxing respite from the hectic pace of Rome. Highly recommend, even if art is not your primary interest.

Beautiful gallery!. You need to purchase your ticket online ahead of time!no guide in English was available,only head Phones!gallery is full of the Most famous sculptures in history..it is a True oasis in a busy city like Rome!this was our second time and it has made several improvements!
Magnificent house and gardens. This space is so filled with beautiful art and sculpture, it is hard to believe that anyone could collect so many phenominal pieces. The rooms are magnificent to see.

Great Facility and Art, But Miserably Managed. We arrived on Friday afternoon and went to the ticket desk where a young man at a computer managed to ignore our presence for more than a minute. In a snarly manner, he said we'd have to make a reservation and handed us a slip with a website and phone number. The website, being in Italian was hard to navigate, so I made a reservation by phone for the next Tuesday at 1800, the earliest opening available. We were told that our confirmation would be sent by email, but we never received it. When we returned on Tuesday, a different young fellow, probably playing games on the same computer, ignored us for a while before asking what we wanted. We said we had a reservation and he asked for our confirmation number. Of course we had none, so he said that was too bad. After arguing a while, he agreed to check under my name and indeed found our reservation and gave us our tickets, chichi were prepaid. We had arrived early, so we sat to wait for our entry time. Lo and behold, hundreds of people were coming in for that same entry time and we were all let loose into the Gallery at the same time. I've never witnessed anything like it. There's got to be a better way get people in and out of the museum. We enjoyed the paintings and sculptures and the building itself is fabulous. It's too bad that our experience was so marred by the way they run the place.
Buy tickets ahead of time as they're normally sold out for days. Spend time strolling and hanging out in the surrounding park. Walking distance from popolo, similar to Central Park.

Beautiful. We made an online purchase of tickets for the set entrance time. As others have mentioned, visitors have specific entry times and it is strictly enforced. You can not take your backpacks or purses, and they have a fairly effective bag check department downstairs. If you are a Bernini fan you will be in heaven. Such beautiful work. The Borghese Gardens are wide and open. There were many families having little picnic's in the Gardens. The main gallery was closed for restoration, but we were able to point our cameras over the barriers and get some good shots of what was behind them. It is a small gallery, but well worth a visit.
Breathtaking. An amazing collection of sculpture and paintings in an exquisite setting. The museum sets in a lush garden setting.

Whirling barroque statues and paintings!. I was told this was a must-see, so we reserved tickets well in advance. The place was packed with tourists, and we never did find the statues of David and Pauline Borghese. Bernini's Rape of Persephone was beautiful despit the subject - the sculptor made marble into flesh! Beautiful quiet grounds in the Villa Borghese park.

Wonderful Museum.. This is a lovely, small gallery located in the Villa Borghese. It has several beautiful Bernini sculptures but it is the Caravaggio paintings that are truly amazing. Definitely worth the visit. You need to book advance tickets to visit (usually 2 to 3 days in advance) and time of your entrance is scheduled on your ticket. We had no problem booking online and simply took a cab to the front door at the appointed time and walked right in. Not overly crowded and a very respectful group. A must see for any art lover!

Superb. I have wanted to visit this gallery for years and finally made it. On account of being a small gallery, visitor numbers are restricted and visits strictly timed - the process of getting in is a bit laborious but worth it in the end because you are not fighting crowds to get a good view of the precious paintings and sculptures within. The building itself and the history of the collection are of course also worthy of note.

So Beautiful. What can you say about this exquisite collection of paintings, sculpture and Gardens? You could spend all day there! Be sure to buy tickets like a month in advance. They sell out for weeks. You can now take pictures with no flash! Gift shop is great!

Reserve in advance. Worth a visit, even if just for the Bernini sculptures and the
Caravaggio paintings. And it's in a park, always a perk in densely built up Rome.
A don't miss for the art and sculpture lover. Canova's Pauline is the Best!! But loved Bernini's work too. The upper floor is a treasure trove of art also with lovely Madonna among the collection.

Book in advance and well worth a visit. Nice cafe, excellent art, worth the entrance fee as numbers are limited so there is no crush as you walk around and enjoy the wonderful paintings and sculptures. A walk through the park afterwards is highly recommended. BOOK IN ADVANCE or you may not get in.

Borghese Gallery. Excellent collection of art, magnificent sculptures and paintings in the Villa Borghese Gallery wonderfully displayed with the opportunity for close up viewing makes this an awesome experience. My tour guide, Viera, was exceptionally knowledgeable about the artists and pieces displayed making the tour a great learning experience too. She was very pleasant to be with. I highly recommend this tour as a way to see the Borghese Gallery and park. Private Tour of Rome did a fantastic job and I highly recommend them for your trip.
Daphne and Apollo. My favorite museum in Rome; seeing Bernini's Daphne and Apollo is worth the trip alone but then, oh my, what other wonders there are for us!

Quite Small - Sculpture Rooms are impressive.. It consists of only several rooms. Paintings are not that impressive, but some sculptures are nice. I actually like the park itself. Definitely over priced venue.

Excellent. The layout of the rooms, the content, lighting, etc, are excellent and definitely worth the two hours they allow you here. We had the 9 to 11 slot, got there at 8:30 and there was already a line. But that is not a problem. They let you in exactly at 9am and they shoo you out at 11. But in those two hours you are more than amazed and educated, especially if you get the audioguide, which is excellent. Highly recommended and reservations are a must, must, must.

If you don't care about sculpture - this will make you. I could've wept at the beauty of the art in this gallery. Granted, I do appreciate art, especially Italian art. I have a new and special appreciation for Bernini now. Be sure to book at least a week in advance. I booked the first 'window' of the day - 0900. It says to get there an hour prior, but this probably is not necessary. You get 2 hours. And, that is really all. They will holler at you until you go, and usher you out. I definitely recommend the first tour of the day - it was very peaceful. I also highly recommend the audio guide. My husband and I each got one for 5 Euro each. It really brings to life what was going on during the acquisition and situation for each work covered. You really do have to push quickly though, the guide is about 1.5 hours worth of talking, and it's mostly about specific pieces. Look quickly at the others. I also recommend strolling through the park if you have time. It really made me feel like saying "when in Rome" - as the local seemed to be strolling about too. Wonderful highlight of my 2.5 day trip!!

Borghese Gallery. My husband and I visited the Villa Borghese Gallery in early October, 2014 with my brother, sister-in law and two young nephews. We had a lovely afternoon walking through the gardens and then onto the Gallery which is filled with spectacular sculptures and paintings. The Bernini sculptures are beautiful. The first Sunday in the month is free entry - but you need to call in advance and reserve a time. We were there on the free entry Sunday with a reserved time registered and had no problems being admitted. Well worth the visit when in Rome!!
Bernini heaven. Best collection of gorgeous Bernini sculptures I have ever seen! So realistic. Michelangelo still my favorite but Bernini close second.

Best museum in Rome with a lovely garden. This was the best art we found in Rome. It is different to other museums in that only a certain number of people are allowed within a time slot - which is a dream compared to other overcrowded tourist attractions. You must make your booking beforehand, you can pay there on the day. When you enter the gallery you need to leave all cameras, handbags and extra jackets with reception (you get a ticket nr for this) so know this beforehand if you do not like doing this, leave all extras at home. The art is less easy to understand, they do have big pages with a description of the room and it's art which is not always necessarily easy to follow. Every room has a center piece sculpture (amazing) - the rest of the rooms are then filled with either paintings or smaller sculptures. You get 2 hours inside which is enough. My husband is not even into art and he found it captivating. The gallery has nice gardens to stroll through especially after a long day of walking around. There is a lot to take in, but take your time and just view the beauty.

Breathtaking gallery. Our tour guide had recommended the Borghese Gallery. You need to order tickets online before you go. It is limited, we order the tickets about a week ahead. You pay them when you get there so no obligation if you don't show up. You just get a confirmation number and don't have to leave any information.The entrance fee was €11 per person. For an additional fee you can rent audio guides...but there are maps in English in each room of the gallery describing the art and the layout of the room. We went around 11 in the morning and it was not crowded in the gallery. The rooms have a famous and breathtaking art collection from different artists and different centuries.

Small, Beautiful, Manageable Gallery!. The Museo Borghese is a small, beautiful gallery located within Villa Borghese. You will need to go online to purchase tickets ahead of time. We visited Rome before and after a cruise in September and decided to visit the gallery when we returned from the cruise. Our entrance time was from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. and the allotted time was spot on! We were able to see the entire gallery in that time. The only negative is that the gallery does not provide a guide in English unless you pay additional for head phones. All captions in the gallery are in Italian.The gallery is beautiful and well worth the small cost. I would definitely recommend this gallery. It is much easier to navigate than the Capitoline Museum at Campidoglio,

Villa Borghese Not For Art Lovers. Just to warn you that if you really like to look at art works don't expect to do this here. I paid extra to book online to be sure I would secure entry. However when I got in there was no opportunity to really look at anything. I used the audio guide to give me more information but after rushing through the bottom floor when I got to the top floor with numerous paintings I wanted to see I was told I only had 30 minutes to see everything.A Complete rip off in terms of money spent and a thoroughly frustrating experience. They were closing the doors to rooms to make sure you couldn't see the art works. You even had to show your entrance ticket to use the toilet!!!!

Museum in the Garden. This area is a green heart of Rome. Plenty of greenery. In the park, you can hire cycles, toy train ride... Musical , lot of folks running. The museum has great collection of scuptures , some of them amazing. You have to remind yourselves that its marble/ stone and not flesh ! Bernini has his creations throughout the city , decorating many piazzas. The ones in museum were fantastic. Like one of the guide outside told us how Michel Angelo used to say - sculpture is already inside the marble and he had to work to release it! Ther is a small caeftaria and the place is very close from piazza barberini/ metro stop or from spanish steps side.

Beautiful Museum. I'm not much of a artsy person and don't care for museums but the artwork in this museum has changed my opinion. I now look forward to visiting other museums. A must see when in Rome.

UNBELIEVABLE!!. I have visited many museums around the world, but impressed me more than the Borghese. Even without the numerous masterpieces it would be a major attraction for the opulence of the room decorations. Factor in the many Bernini sculptures and the largest collection of paintings by Caravaggio in one location and you have an absolutely must see attraction. Be sure you book in advance as walk ups are most always disappointed and turned away. Your ticket allows you two hours in the museum so manage your time efficiently. To avoid the crowd, reverse your touring by starting in the picture galleries on the second floor and ending up viewing the impressive array of sculptures and the Caravaggio collection on the ground floor last.

been a while since we were there but worth it. spent a delightful afternoon there a few years ago loved the secret gardens, booking tickets in advance is super no cueing. got the headset instead of tour guide so we could go at our own pace. Put this on your list hwen in Rome

Peerless collection, but poor for photographers.. The collection is 5 star. The sculpture pieces, mostly by Bernini and also Canova, are as good as you will see anywhere. The paintings amount to the pick of all the great renaissance artists, although Caravaggio seemed particularly noticeable perhapsbecause of his distinctive and innovative technique. However there were downsides to the tour. Photography is allowed without flash, but the routeing of visitors is such that people can walk round all sides of some of the best sculptures so it is almost impossible not to get some person in your shot. Then there is the spotlighting deployed which reflects excessively off the surfaces of the paintings, even worse for those works protected by glass. I can't recall another major gallery where these problems were so infuriating and other photographers whom I spoke to readily agreed. Too much to hope that the VB will read this post I suppose?

great art, terribly managed. Our first stop while we were in Rome. The art work speaks for itself, but what a disaster in regards to operation. These people didn’t even know where the entrance to the museum itself was! My girlfriend and I went here in September. I called a month in advance and gave them my name and they told me my reservation time (you have to call and reserve a time before you go). When we went inside, the girl asked for my confirmation number, but I was never given one on the phone?! I eventually talked her into letting us in at our reserved time of 3pm. I then waited in line for a device for the audio tour and they told us to go outside and upstairs to the entrance. It turns out this entrance doesn’t exist, but we stood there with other people for 20 minutes before I went back in and figured this out. Then my girlfriend had to check her purse…the entire purse so be prepared to hand that over. Then when the tour started, the audio device I had stopped working. Now, once we started with the tour, it quickly became apparent that the audio tour and the direction we were told to go didn’t match, so you would be listening to info for one room when in fact you were in another room. Also, it appears that this museum doesn’t like to use air conditioning and it was very hot inside. Nobody smiles or is polite so unless you REALLY enjoy classic art, I would skip this museum and save your money.

More than worth the time. The first thing to know is that reservations are almost mandator. Also, the English speaking guide is a must; the cost was about 7 euros per person, the guide is an art historian, and there were only six of us on the tour. Time in the museum is limited to two hours from the start of your reservation time and it is strictly enforced. Next time I will plan additional time for the surrounding park.

Bernini!. It is beautiful and I can't really add anymore to the existing reviews, other than this is a GREAT collection of Bernini's sculptures!! I studied them in school, so couldn't wait to see them in person. Don't know if it's the largest collection, but certainly has some of the more well known.

Definitely worth a visit!. We visited the gallery after walking around in the surrounding park (which is also a very nice thing to do). Beautiful house, great collection of art - even a little eclectic at times, which was refreshing.I feel like we should have taken a guided tour because the information next to the art was, as you would expect, quite short. There is a 2 hour time limit and booking in advance is a must, if i remember correctly, but without a doubt this gallery was worth the visit!
My favorite. Been here three times, and for each time I see new things I haven't seen before. This is my favorite museum - can walk here many hours

Short But Sweet. We took the guided tour, so we went to all the "popular" spots. Pretty cool art and the Borghese's had a great collection. You could spend a lot more time in there to admire everything, they only allow you 2 hours max.

Beautiful Art. This stunning palace now turned museum, is full of some of the most famous sculptures in history. Purchase the audio guide, or download one prior to visiting so you know the history behind what you are viewing. Either before or after your tour, spend some time walking the grounds. There are a lot of things you can do from riding a train with kids, visiting the zoo, or renting a 4-wheel bicycle to further explore the grounds. You must have a reservation in order to enter the museum, so be sure to make that in advance.
Wonderful gallery. There were some great Bernini sculptures on view. Very worth the visit. Beautiful place in a wonderful setting.

Fabulous Gallery. This gallery requires reservations (on-line, unless you are using a Roma pass, and then you must call), and limits your visit to two hours, which means that you are not crammed in rooms, shoulder-to-shoulder, but have plenty of time and space to enjoy this wonderful collection. The highlights for us were the Bernini sculptures - just amazing. Then take a relaxing stroll in the extensive park. It is a true oasis in a busy city!

Beautiful. Reservations mandatory. The ground floor has ıncredibly detailed sculptures. What İ found most impressive however was the detailed ceiling paintıngs. The colors are so vivid. The details so extraordinary. On the second level are additional paintıngs. The second level is reached by a long winding staircase [although İ did see an elevator, İ did not notice anyone utilize it] İ missed the crowded entrance by arriving approximately 10 minutes late. No bags are permitted inside the museum, but you are given a plastic bag to store any belongings you do not wish to leave at the storage drop off.It is a beautiful museum and very much worth a visit.

Amazing gallery. Wish I had stayed longer as the gardens were amazing. The tickets are timed, so you won't be able to spend more than 2 hours in the gallery. There are several paintings by Caravaggio that we enjoyed seeing.

A favorite site to visit. This is a beautiful, unpretentious Villa (originally the Borghese's hunting lodge) with lovely gardens and some of the most fantastic art in all of Rome. We found the rooms easy to negotiate and see all the wonderful works of art. Would definitely visit again and again.

Excellent. Be sure to make a reservation. This is an excellent way to spend a couple of hours and a walk through the park surrounding the Gallery will give you a nice break from the hustle and bustle of Rome.

Excellent, manageable museum. We visited the Borghese as our one museum stop while in Rome. You need to book and then line up for tickets and bag checks. The place is not air conditioned so it can be oppressive. Get and audio guide. Garden areas very beautiful

sculptures superb - staff uninformed. After reserving months in advance, and getting our tickets we were in the line-up waiting for our 3Pm entry when we were advised "No handbags and no CAMERAS". One couple refused to check their bags so I left my Camera with them. As the whole group marched up a circular flight of stairs to the art floor I told an attendant that I just wanted to see the sculptures. He then opened a false door ad let me in to the sculptures floor. For 20 minutes I was all alone with some of the worlds most famous sculptures WITHOUT my camera. NOW FOR THE RUB!! When the rest of the 3pm group arrived there must have been 20 CAMERAS. Needless to say I WAS LIVID. When I went to complain I was told that the camera rule had changed. Even their brochures said NO CAMERAS. Sculptures, FANTASTIC...Borghese staff, UNINFORMED.ADVICE...TAKE YOUR CAMERA IN!!
Very nice gallery in a green park. The most important sugestion is: reserve tickets in advance !The visit is limited for only 2 hours which is enough.We enjoyed very much the sculptures of Berenini

Stunning!. There is nothing to dislike about this extraordinary and visually compelling gallery. The rooms, without the art or sculpulture, are a treasure onto themselves; and, with them, the experience is memorable.
Lovely gallery. Highly recommended. Just don't go when it's super hot - like I did - as the ancient building doesn't have a/c.
galleria. ıt deserves 5star. ı visit lots of galleria. but thıs one ıs dıfferent. ıts amazıng. you cannot take any picture ın there. they'll take your phone too :)
Plan Your Visit. Some spectacular pieces to see, particularly David. Take the Audio guide and check out the key pieces beforehand.

Skip the Vatican museums this is better. The Borghese Gallery from my experience is a far better choice if you have limited time in Rome than the Vatican museums. The Villa and gardens are lovely the artwork spectacular but you must have a reserved ticket. When we were there they were sold out a week in advance. You can buy on line. You are only allowed two hours and if we were able to I would have booked another two hour slot right afterwards. The Bernini sculptures are unsurpassed. This is an absolute must when visiting Rome.

closed! you had to make a reservation. when we walked thru the beautiful park/garden (so nice and quiet) we could not visit the Borghese Villa. Sold out for 3 days. And yet we did not see a lot of tourists around the villa (??). A bit disappointing and that's why a LOW rating.

The Best Attraction in Rome!. If you like non-touristy activities like we do, you will LOVE the Borghese Gallery. Rome was the last stop on our Italy vacation and admittedly, by the time we arrived our feet hurt and we didn't enjoy being herded through mobs of tourists through polluted air on the hot city streets. That said, the Borghese Gallery was a MOST PLEASANT surprise!The air was fresh; there were no mobs of tourists. We scheduled an afternoon tour at 3PM and wished we could have stayed longer. We could adequately view the art pieces (unlike the crowds at Uffizi and Accademia in Florence), and the artwork and sculptures in the Gallery were fascinating (our tour guide added to this delight). The Park outside was delightful. Unfortunately, the gardens are unattended and falling into disrepair but all in all the Borghese was the most enjoyable. activity for us in Rome. The view over the city at the end of the Park is comparable to the view from the Piazelle Michelangelo in Florence. Don't miss this attraction if you want a pleasant and more relaxing experience while in Rome. (My only regret is not taking the train ride around the entire park.)

Awesome. Great collection of cultural works dating back to 300 BC. The audio guide works great in this location as you have only two hours to tour and then you are out! The guide helps you to use your time wisely.. Be sure to call and book a time, the reservation system is easy and will ensure you get in.

Well worth the visit. This was our second visit and it has had many improvements in the last several years. Be aware you cannot take large bags in, you can check them at the entrance, however. You can take pictures so hang on to your camera or phone. While you can book in advance (visits are limited to 2 hours), we've done it, paying full price for tickets, only to find both our visits could have been made for a Euro...coincidence, perhaps, but next time, we're not booking in advance and will take our chances on getting in.

Borghese Gallery - Bravissimo. Even after seeing the Vatican, Capitoline, and other museums - this is still a stand out for me. The setting in the villa gardens, the glorious decoration of the building and the art is holds within - it's as if you stepped into a renaissance painting. The Bernini statues ... well, words fail.

OK, but time consuming... is it worth the trouble?. If you know the collection and there is something you definitely want to see here, then of course it is worth a visit.If you are generally interested in art, but not knowledgable, then bear in mind the effort it takes to go here.You will have to book in advance - we went on 1st October, it was sold out to 7th - booking in advance is ok on internet, but involved booking fees. You have to select your two hour slot on booking. This means you have to work your day around the visit. We found ourselves wanting to go somewhere else and not doing this because we had our slot booked, so recommend either early in the morning or late in day to give more flexibilityYou have to get there! - it is off the beaten track and on top of a hill. Nice walk through the park, but be prepared for the slope, especially on a warm day.... alternatively use the 116 route electric bus.You have to go through the ticket collection and bag check in process. We arrived a bit late so the queue was not too bad.After all this, the collection seemed good, but not "wow". And not better than that elsewhere.

Beautiful Gallery. Amazing collection of paintings and sculptures. We had never heard of the gallery until we were researching things to see in Rome. We would definitely recommend the Borghese Gallery as a must see site while in Rome!

Gorgeous art in a gorgeous villa. The art was amazing, and the locations made it even more special. We picked up a tour guide after we arrived at the Villa, and she was great.
