There is no need to hire the much more expensive 'Viator' type guides. Wandering around the gardens afterwards was also a treat. Iti s one of the few 'green-spaces' in Rome, and was a lovely antidote to the other attractions.

Worth a quick trip if you have time. This is a museum with sculptures and art, worth a quick trip. The art was nice but no on par with Vatican or other sites. FYI, don't go walking around looking for a Villa on the property because the Gallery is what used to be a Villa. There is a big park here, way too much to walk in a busy city with lots of sites. there is a little train you can ride for a few Euro if you want to see the parks.

Bernini is the best. Reserve tickets online. Go at your allotted time. You have to check all bags. Beware of the grumpy older lady with the silver sparkly eye shadow at the entrance! She isn't happy. We went late in the day and it wasn't very busy outside. Rooms can get crowded inside, which is why they limit the visitors. The Bernini's are the most marvelous sculptures. Worth the price of admission and the hassle and the old Las Vegas dancer taking tickets at the entrance.

Money and good taste. These two don't always go together. The ticketing and baggage drop arrangements are a bit of a ruck. Among the old masters there are some truly regrettable paintings that are well worth avoiding but the sculptures are really worth seeing. Bernini's David and his Apollo and Daphne are worth the admission fee alone

crowded and confusing. We had a reservation. Still pretty crowded. The audio guide wasn't cheap. The art and interpretation were both great. But it was impossible to match the room and art with the verbiage.
One of Romes top three places to visit. Set in a beautiful park, it shows the elegance of a time long past. Wonderful displays. Be there on time, you only get two hours and then are escorted out.

Masterpiece. So many masterpiece and a lovely organizations: 25 people a time every two hours. We had a private guide here and she took us first to the top and so we were always alone in the rooms. Need reservation in advance !

Culture's home. The arhitecture is wonderfull
The park around it is beautifull and big
The restaurants here are very expensive
Set in a beautiful park. Amazing paintings and sculptures that never seem to end. They alot 2 hours to tour and it's a good idea to reserve times to visit ahead.

Best Gallery in Rome. This was the best art gallery tour in Rome for a couple reasons; our tour guide was excellent and the art is amazing! Pay for the guided tour with headphones - its worth it. Pay to skip the lines too - also worth it. Our guide not only brought the art to life with her passion and descriptions, she also gave us personal insight into the artists, with specific and personal insight into Bernini. We were traveling with a small group and everyone agreed it was the best tour in Rome! Everyone left with a greater appreciation for Borghese, Bernini and the role the Pope played in Rome and art history.You must arrive early. The walk to the gallery from the front entrance is quite distance, although the walk through the grounds is very impressive.Don't forget your camera or video (no flash allowed). Many great photo ops! A good quality camera with low light capabilities is a must. This was an amazing and memorable experience and definitely a "must see" on a trip to Rome.

Beautiful area and museum. This is a fairly small museum compared to some others but it has a very beautiful and unique inventory of paintings and sculptures.Only bad side is when they let you in (2 hr schedule by reservation only) they escort you up a horrible amount of steps to the top floor (no lift for non handicaps) and so you are totally worn out by the time you get up there.

highly recommended. amazing gallery especially for those who appreciate sculpture.located in a nice park online reservation requested especially during peak season. take into account one only has 2 hours to spend inside the gallery (enough time to admire the exhibits)

Not to be Missed. Really breathtaking stuff. Book your tickets online, arrive early for your allotted two-hour visit, and rent one of the audio devices. Plan your day around your visit, and be sure to leave time for a long stroll through the villa grounds.

Wonderful museum; marvellous experience. Prior booking is essential, but easily done on the internet. Arrive early so you can dump coats etc. in the left luggage as they are strict about what you can take in. In the gallery itself you can go which ever way round you like - we tried to avoid the crowds by starting upstairs but it wasn't really necessary as they restrict the numbers to a manageable quantity.The gallery is really like a mini Vatican Museum with ancient exhibits of superb quality and antiquity. We loved it and will certainly go back.
worth a visit. It is a great place to see some real art up close. Book a private tour before you go. Our guide was very good and told us lots about the works that we were looking at.

awesome sculpture. This museum is a pain to get to. We took the bus which was confusing and we were late. Take a cab. Also, must purchase tickets in advance. Then you must stand in lines(three to finally go into the museum). One to exchange ticket, one to leave bag, and one to purchase audio tour guide. Give yourself lots of time to get there as you are only allowed two hours in the museum and we ran out of time as we were late for our two hour apt.

Fabulous, intimate museum. Having done the research ahead of our trip, we had tickets in hand and were able to visit at our scheduled time. I would recommend arriving about 30 minutes before your ticket entrance, as visitors must leave after their two hour timed tour. We arrived about 10 minutes ahead, but, by the time we made it through the pick up ticket line, checked our bags, and got the audio tour (which I highly recommend if you don't have a guide), we "lost" about 15 minutes of our allotted two hours. This made us move more quickly than we would have liked at the end. It's a great museum, and it is easy to see, appreciate and enjoy all of the art it contains.

Mini Vecchio Palace. knowing how all these art works came to be here one thinks of jealousy with the Vecchios of Florence… This little mansion has too many Bernini's per square foot. Like someone with 6 gold chains around their neck.Over indulgence, can be seen in the bust of the Cardinal Borghese…. ever notice the name of the main door of St. Peters Basilica … Borghese too!Really? I'd like to do something to show my faith and also have my name on it … like in the most prominent place?
Beautiful building. Not enough info provided - many things not labelled. Highlights were the exceptional Bernini sculptures. Good size to visit - began to glaze over just at very end.

absolutely wonderful-- but!!. we booked our visit as you must. The crowd control was dreadful. We queued in pretty hot weather for about 20 minutes to get in. We had the audio guides - there was not much included in this. I thought there should have been more 'pieces' included in the audio guide.
Very beautiful place. Very beautiful place. You need reservation to visit the gallery. You can do it by phone or by internet.Huge park and also very beautiful.

Best Art Museum outside of the Vatican. This small museum houses the most incredible original statuary in the entire world! Do not miss this opportunity if you visit Rome. Buy tickets well in advance as you likely will not be able to get them after you get to Rome.

Wow - the gallery of all galleries!. Amazing, seeing art you have only seen in pictures! Absolutely superb. You must book your ticket/time slot before you go. This can be done by phone, or on the net. Best done before you travel to get the slot you want. Worth a walk through the park from the Spanish steps, but it is a way. Buses stop not far from the gallery.
best gallery. Borgese gallery is the most famous gallery in Rome after Vatikan museum.There are many paintings of Rafaello,Caravaggio and Bernini statues .ATTENTION: Check before you go!!!!!!!!!!

A lot of repetition. Booking essential and visited on basis of Tripadvisor reviews. Worth noting the Gallery/Museum is some distance away from Villa Borghese so check the map and do not simply follow the signs from Spagna Metro. Also handbags not allowed in to the gallery so be prepared to queue to check bags in. I would have preferred a bit more variation in the paintings and sculptures but there are plenty of quality exhibits on show.

Nice museum - Worth an afternoon visit. Lots of masterworks and intelligently assembled collections. Caravaggio is featured in several rooms. Many sculptures and busts of famous Romans, along with the stellar collection of works from a broad spectrum of painters, mostly Italian, make this a museo worth wandering through for an afternoon. Take a look at the house and architecture while you are looking at the art, as the architecture is also very interesting.

I'm sure it's amazing, but you need a reservation!. CHECK BEFORE YOU GO!!!We couldn't visit b/c we didn't know about the reservation policy. Please look into it before your trip to Rome. We heard the gallery impressive, but were disappointed to learn, since we only had 2 days, we couldn't get in.
Beautiful!. Seeing the sculptures and paintings were amazing. Be sure to book a tour ahead of time. They are closed on Mondays.
Small, intimate and amazing. One of the world's greatest painting and sculpture collections, in Rome's largest park. Make reservations before you go as it is frequently sold out.

A must-see in Rome. A superb collection, well worth the effort to set it up ahead of time. Advance reservations are mandatory. The audio tour is a must if you want to understand what you are seeing. I did have trouble making a reservation through the TicketOne site - I tried multiple times and was able to complete it only by trying during business hours in Italy. But it was worth the effort as the "skip the line" tours were several times the standard ticket price (11 euros). Be sure to show up 20-30 minutes ahead of your appointed time or you'll eat into the two-hour window.

Wonderful . Galleria Borghese is, of course, in the to do list of Rome and...is at the top of it! Great museum with reservation only policy and time visit. This make life really easy. The building itself is a wonder: every room has majestic decorations on walls and ceilings and the floors are amazing too. For me just Canova (Paulina Buonaparte) is worth the ticket: I went back 3 times to the room in the 2 hours slot just to trying to sink every single detail. Breath taking!
reservations?. We took the time to get to the Villa Borghese gallery on a Friday, only to find you had to make reservations ON LINE and the next available access was the following Tuesday. Bummer

You don't need to be an art expert, anyone with eyes can appreciate this gallery!. The Bernini statutes are brilliant, unlike anything I have seen before, especially Daphne and Apollo. There are also a huge number of famous paintings, I particularly noted the Caravaggios but there is quite a range of periods and countries represented here. The gallery is the perfect size - not overwhelmingly big but not too small either. The mosaics are also incredible and because of the entrance policy it is never too busy to enjoy. Make sure you book in advance or arrive in good time for tickets. You don't need to be an art expert, anyone with eyes can appreciate this gallery!

Don't bother.... The instructions from the Gallery on how to get there and exit from metro send you on a long meandering through the park without rhyme or reason. The Gallery itself is staffed by overworked, bored people who treat visitors as hordes of lemmings. The art itself is mostly 2nd and 3rd rate late Renaissance pieces that you can see in any small metropolitan art museum all over the world. There are a few nice pieces and some interesting marbles but certainly nothing justifying the hoopla around this place, the convoluted reservations (you can't use your Roma pass if you book online, etc. etc. - basically a rip-off) and the long trek to get their to be treated like cattle.

Apollo and Daphne will make you cry. This carefully controlled art museum (you must buy advance tickets and can only stay two hours) has the most beautiful sculptures per square foot of any museum. The Berninis are spectacular, as is the Canova "Pauline." The ceilings and wall paintings are also fantastic.

sold out -. on our scheduled date was turned away on arrival, visited outside grounds only. Nice gardens statues - but I did not go there for that . It seems the gallery is fantastic but that is hearsay on my part.

one of Rome's great galleries. Read up on this in advance so you know what you're looking at. You have only 2 hrs to visit the 2 floors, and there is a superabundance of things to look at. One friend got the audio guide but I am not sure I would have been able to listen to everything on the guide's itinerary and see everything else too.

Wonderful tour. I visited the gallery with a small tour group and the guide was fabulous. He knew so much art history and history in general, it made the visit far more interesting. The gallery is gorgeous and the artwork eye candy.

A long awaited visit. Restricted visit time of a two hour guided visit and lead to visit being cut off without completion.Excellent tour guide supplied by City Wonders.easy to book tickets on-line through wwwViator.com

The most beautiful Italian artwork. This place was amazing, the park was beautiful. You'd never know you were surrounded by an ancient city. Peaceful and quiet. The gallery was spectacular!!! Definitely worth a visit.
Great museum. Our favorite museum. The sculptures are amazing. Not to be missed. But be sure to make reservations in advance.

Calm oasis. Loved the limited visitors especially after the sheer numbers of people crowded onto the Vatican. Some of the most beautiful art, pairings and sculpture. I was captivated by Bernini's Apollo and Daphne

Very hot and crowded!. Book in advance online or you will not get in. It contains some interesting works and it has a broad grouping in one place. that being said, it was very crowded and very hard to appreciate the art. There are one or two spectacular statues you need to come here to see but the rest of is comparable work to many other museums. The park-lands surrounding are beautiful and with having a picnic lunch in. You can also hire bikes to tour the park. Do not overlook the gladiator mosaics, these are worth the price of admission alone. If I had my choice i would come in off-peak to have a peek! See what the nouveau riche were like in times past!

Art History comes alive. The Borghese gallery, with its sculptures by Bernini and paintings by Caravaggio and others, is breathtaking. Do see it with the live guide that forms groups for tours in various languages before entering.

Best art musuem we've ever been. Bernini's artworks are absolutely breathtaking. The gallery has a great collection of his masterpieces. Booking is essential. We also thought that it's good they restrict the numbers of visitors per sessions so everyone will have a chance to have a good look at the artwork, unlike other places such as the Louvre and the Vatican museum where it's so crowded that you can't see anything.
Great. Great, lovely building, lovely gardens, huge expanse of Villa Borghese, thoroughly enjoyable, easy to find and easy to get to..

Sculpture hot spot. Hard to say something new about this deservedly famous villa/gallery, but preparatory reading online & in guidebooks in no way lessens the awe of being in the presence of such a high density of amazing masterpieces. The lovely grounds (filled with families on a Sunday), building, mosaics & paintings (several of which mirror the subjects of the sculptures) are all quite worthwhile, but are overshadowed by the sculptures, which repay careful study from all sides. Do allow ample time to get to the gallery from the park borders, & to pick up tickets, check bags & queue up for the timed entries. Afterwards, a pleasant 12-15 minute stroll to the south takes you to some excellent restaurants on Via Flavia (la Locanda, la Pentolaccia, il Pinsere).
Sculptures and paintings are breathtaking. There is so much to see! But our favorites were Bernini's sculpture of Daphne and Apollo, and Caravaggio painting of David & Goliath are stunning!

Breath taking experience - book your visit in advance. Unbelievable, gorgeous gallery and gardens. A must see when in Rome but book in advance to make sue you get in. I will return, the next time I'm in Rome. Note: Closed Mondays
go!. Italy keeps 30% of the masterpieces of art of the world! This place has probably one of the best collections of Italy

Book ahead. We were in Rome for Easter week. We had booked and paid for our tickets before we left the U.S. and it's a good thing we did or we would not have been able to get in. Many great works of art to see and the park surrounding the Villa was a very nice place to walk and picnic in.

Cardinal Borghese's Art Collection. He would purchase portraits that had been rejected by the subjects. He also has many important pieces. It's located in the most beautiful area/garden. Pack a picnic lunch for this area, then tour after lunch.

Wonderful gallery but pity about the staff. This art gallery is rightly world famous but the staff were not as user-friendly as they might be. On a wet day with people trying to find somewhere to sit with their lunches, the small cafe was overflowing but anyone trying to eat just outside the cafe area were brusquely told to move, though there were no signs indicating that you could not sit in the entrance area.

Two hours goes really fast! Be prompt and mind the time if you want to see it all.. Everyone knows the art is fantastic at the Borghese Gallery, so I will just talk about logistics.You absolutely do have to book your tickets in advance for the Borghese Gallery. We got there very close to the admission time for our tickets and it ate into our time a wee bit because I wanted to get the audio guide. I felt the audio guide was really worthwhile. Very informative about the artists as well as the pieces of art. If there are two of you, have one person stand in the queue to go into the museum and the other person go to pick up the audio guide(s). Also, I'm pretty sure that the Borghese does not allow large backpacks and camera cases, so leave these items at the hotel, or you'll also have to go to a line to check them.The museum is set up with sculpture on the first floor and paintings on the second floor. I'm more of a sculpture person and dawdled too much on the first floor. I had made it through maybe 30% of the second floor when they announced it was time for my time slot of guests to vacate the premises. And they do NOT give you much time to high tail it out of there!If I were to do it again, I would trot right up to the second floor and work my way backwards, going into the most empty rooms, paying attention to the time. Most people work their way through the museum in the order that the rooms appear on the maps. But the audio guides are the kind with numbers for each piece, so you can view/listen in any order you want. Starting on the second floor and working down, I think the crowds would be less in each room. A lot of people don't spend the entire two hours in the museum. By the end of my slot, I'm guessing about 65% of the people had already left. So, rather than starting off in rooms so crowded that you can hardly see anything, you'd have a good view of all the art this way.

Magnificent small art palace. Visits to the Borghese Gallery are timed, and you must leave within 2 hours after your entry time. Tickets sell out quickly, so reserving in advance by internet is recommended. Be prepared to check all bags, including small handbags, as they're not permitted in the galleries. The artwork is simply astounding, as is the architecture of the villa itself. The lower galleries are dedicated to classical art, while the upper galleries display art of the 15th through 18th centuries. There is a small cafe on the premises for the famished, as the museum is inside a large park, and the immediate surrounding neighborhood has few places to eat. A 10-minute walk takes you to the Via Veneto and a wealth of restaurants.

The best of the best. This was a repeat visit for us. The gallery is fabulous with one art icon after another. The two hour limitation is not a problem - be sure to get reservations as they were turning lots of people away.
Pure art. Very well organized visit, prebooked, the crowd wasn't so tough, and the view of the exposed pieces was quiet good.

Be forewarned- book ahead of your visit. We actually called from the states(using Skye) before we left to buy our tickets. You will need a Roma Card too to gain entry, buy the three day card if you plan to also see the Colosseum,etc. We thought the two day would be enough but it only allowed one museum and discounts on the others The guides are very worthwhile , far better than the audio. As others have mentioned it is quite crowded even with the time entry . The gardens of the villa were disappointing as very little was in bloom. In fact the main Borghese park was disappointing too as very little was in bloom , which was surprising as we were there in early Sept. The park could use a good seeding too.
wow. The bernini's are exquisite and the gardens a serene respite from the hectic pace of Rome. We remember this as one of our highlights to our Roman adventure.

Great. Must admit, visited this place because it was raining. Really fun , modern art, broken glass floor. My son was in shock, look the floor has cracked ! Great modern Art, weird stuff, porcelain, very Italian let s go crazy. Worth a visit if you stay in a Hotel nearby and have some time to kill. Otherwise go for a walk somewhere else

A must see attraction, but could be better managed. If you are interested in art this is a must see attraction. However, the timed visits mean that as you go from room to room you always seem to be in a crowd as others make their way round at the same time. Also if you really want to spend time looking at the pictures etc, you will be disappointed. The whole place seems geared to tour groups rather than anybody who really wants to study the art.Facilities are actually quite limited. The queue for the cloakroom, cafe etc made the whole place too crowded. Also the cafe used the old Soviet system of buying a ticket for your food first and then exchanging the ticket for the food-so two lines. Quite ludicrous.

So much beauty in 1 place. We had choosen to hire a professional guide which is pricey at 200 euro for 3 hours, but we felt it was worth it as when you are confronted with such an abundance of incredible paintings and sculptures you really want to know more about them. and most of it done 400-600 years ago, it´s truly mindnumbing that such artistry existed. your guide will book tickets, which will ensure you get 2 hours there with only 200 people, so you are not forced to frogmarch or hurry, but can take your time and just let your mind and senses that this wonderfull pallazzo has to offer
A Masterpiece of Masterpieces. Make sure to take the time to wander the incredible Borghese Gardens surrounding the gallery as well - it is the "central Park" of Rome.

Definitely a must!. Amazing exhibit. Stunning statues and art work. Definitely worth the time. Cal ahead or get tickets ahead of time because it does book up. There are time slots and each group gets two hours in the gallery. We were of the last out of the crowd. So much to see. Definitely get the guided audio tour.

Make a reservation. There are set entrance times and if you don't have a reservation ahead of time you wont get in. The cost is the same and you are limited to a two hour visit. The first floors has beautiful sculptures and statutes by Bernini and other masters. The upstairs is a picture gallery. The downstairs alone is worth going.

Surprised by how much we both enjoyed it. I'm an art lover, but my husband is not. I was hoping the trip to Italy would convert him and it sort of did. He loved this gallery and the audio guide helped him to appreciate the art. This museum was close to our hotel, but still worth a trip from across town. But there is never enough time in Rome, is there?

Awesome gallery. The most impressive gathering of sculptures and paintings. It is remarkable the sculpture of Paulina Bonaparte by Canova and Apollo and Daphne by Bernini, within others. The latter not only impressed by the perfection achieved, but the genius of the artist who achieves the effect of transforming Daphne in a tree to preserve its purity from Apollo´s harassment. It's amazing to check the sensitivity to art that it is felt at each corner of this place.

tickets sold out way in advance. Well, we couldn't get in as the tickets were sold out for 4 days in advance. Ridiculous..They only allow a certain amount of people into the gallery. We were really looking forward to visiting as its said to be pretty incredible...but couldn't get in..

interesting collection. but the exhibition is not organized at all unless you are an art expert you dont have the faintest idea what you are looking atbeter book in advanceentrance is allowed every two hours obligatory to leave all your stuff at the wardrobe

One of the highlights of our trip!. Fabulous place to visit. We stayed nearby and got 9 am tickets - so the lovely early morning walk through the gardens was very special and the gallery is just amazing. Literally jaw dropping beauty. Should not be missed (and get the audio tour!).
Art, history, beauty in abundance. Paintings and sculptures of the finest artists in a beautiful setting. It shouldn't be missed. The Bernini sculptures are beyond description.
after Vatican Museums is the best. Vatican museums are the best but also Borghese is very beautiufl musem. I suggest to visit this amazing palce and enjoy also the park around.

Great art and a great tour. Make your reservations for 11am and then sign up for the English language tour once you are there. Our guide, Felix was very knowledgeable, thorough and quick, 1:15 and done giving us time to go back hit our favorite Bernini's. Never get tired seeing them again and again.Do yourself a favor and go online and read about the art before hand.

A must see. One of the best museums in town. You get to wander around the villa checking out all the beautiful paintings and sculptures. The audio guide is very good. Nice little café inside. Make sure you make a reservation in advance.

A Littel Gem. We stumbled upon this gallery as we walked through the large Borghese Gardens. It's a small museum but just a gem, with one of my favorite sculptures, Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. It's so impressive to see in person, even if it's smaller than I thought it would be! It's just amazing to think this gallery was once a palace home.

Incredible. As former History/History of Art student this was one place that was on my must see list whilst in Rome, I pre-booked tickets, which were for a specific time slot before my trip which as it turned out was a great idea, on the day we visited, the museum was fully booked up for a further week after that day. Some people may complain about not being able to book on the day but the fact that you have to book a time slot made for a much more pleasant experience as the place wasn't jammed to the rafters. I was able to take in the beauty of the Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures I love so much without feeling I was being rushed. Amazing place and the surrounding park with additional museums and it's own full size replica of Shakespeare's Globe theater is a delight in itself.

do not miss. Spend the money on the audio guide as it will explain the paintings and sculptures in a lot of detail. Also, make sure you take pictures, but remember to turn the flash off on the camera. You will most certainly need reservations as there is only a limited number of people allowed to enter for each tour. Do Not miss this one...

Really … you can't miss this. A world class gallery with some of the world's most famous paintings and sculptures. Take some time to view the surrounding gardens as well. Booking ahead is a must. We arrived on Sunday morning and noticed that the next available times were Tuesday. To rent the audio guides is five Euros per person. Take identification, as they want to hold it as a deposit for your device. The 116 minibus takes you right to the grounds, and takes an interesting, if circuitous route to get there. You are allowed in the museum for two hours. The audio guide does not cover all the paintings, but one or two per room. If you listen to each commentary, and move to the next room when the commentary for the room is finished, you will finish comfortably within the tours. Return of listening device was quick. Pick up of checked items was a short wait. You can take your camera into the museum, but flash photos are not allowed. We went for the 11:00 a.m. tour on a Sunday. Appeared crowded when we left. There was a long line for the cafeteria at that time. Noticed a restaurant on the grounds, that may have been less crowded.

Absolutely stunning - book in advance - check for 2hour entry slots.. As numbers are limited and booked in advance, you have lots of room and time to see the wonderful statues and painting in this collection.One word of warning - I had booked tickets online for midday. We got there early (fortunately) and found out that viewings are in 2 hourly slots. For example 11am to 1pm. Had we waited till midday to enter, we would not have had enough time to see everything. Please check this when you book your tickets online.
They do it right!. The museum only let's 90 people in at a time, so there are no crowds or rushing... Book tickets ahead of time and early!
Gotta preorder. Beautiful place- we heard it was a must but no one mentioned getting tickets in advance… which is apparently a must. We walked the grounds, hit up the gift shop and had a nice time.

A must-see. This small museum beautifully located in the park of Villa Borghese is an absolute must-see for the art lovers. The Bernini statues are exceptional, filled with emotion. A reservation is necessary in order to visit the Galleria and entrance is every two hours, and max 2 hours long. I had to rush through the last rooms when we were ordered to immediately exit the museum just ten minutes before our two hours' visit ended! Even with these schedules it can get crowded in the museum's rooms!The audioguide that you can hire is good and informative. A fun thing to do after your visit is to rent a 2-person bike and explore the Villa Borghese park!

Lovely!. The gardens are also great, as is the tram ride, which takes you all the way over to the Santa Maria del Popollo, where you can get off the tram, climb down the stairs & go into the church to see the 2 Carvaggio paintings. The tram ride was 2 euros-much cheaper than a cab ride would have been.

Wow -- ART!. This was an incredibly beautiful place -- even without the incredible art housed inside. I especially loved all the sculptures. The audiio guide was very informative and just the right length. The fact that they restrict the number of guests at any given time is THOROUGHLY appreciated once you see how packed the Vatican Museum becomes! I actually had to miss the date and time that I had reserved, but when I presented my voucher (which was for the previous day), I was given a ticket without hesitation. I am not sure if this is their standard procedure or if I just got lucky that no one paid attention.
Best Museum. This museum is a must but do it with one of the tour guide groups. They do a fabulous job of sharing info one would never find out on their own.

Amazing!. The Villa Borghese is a huge "closed" space in the midst of Rome, made out of natural trails, paths and roads... Many art galleries inside this space and many sculptures and beautiful fountains to discover while you are taking a stroll. It's a huge space/park where you can walk, run, bike...even rent a canoe!p.s: While in Rome, check twice your bills: in restaurants, cab drivers...everywhere.
A feast of Bernini!. Stuning Bernini works in a beautiful setting. The villa is set in beautiful gardens, and the exhibits are stunning.

Very hot and crowded.. Book in advance online or you will not get in. It contains some interesting works and it has a broad grouping in one place. that being said, it was very crowded and very hard to appreciate the art. There are one or two spectacular statues you need to come here to see but the rest of is comparable work to many other museums. The parklands surrounding are beautiful and with having a picnic lunch in. You can also hire bikes to tour the park. Do not overlook the gladiator mosaics, these are worth the price of admission alone. If I had my choice i would come in off-peak to have a peek! See what the nouveau riche were like in times past!

Gorgeous! My favorite gallery in Rome. I cannot express how much I enjoyed this gallery. It was breathtaking. While I enjoy paintings, I was awed by the sculpture found within. I highly suggest arranging a guided tour (Rebecca with City Wonders was AMAZING!). We spent two hours at this gallery and it felt like no time at all had passed. The Bernini sculptures were absolutely stunning. The paintings by Raphael, Ruebens, Titan, and Caravaggio were spectacular. The tour of the gardens was very nice. There is much to see and lots of open space.

See the museum AND the park! Both are terrific.. Obviously you must book a reservation in advance as there are only so many people let into the museum at a time. We chose the earliest time due to our kids being fresh at that point and it worked out beautifully. The museum is lovely. The line is not. Granted, you're guaranteed to get in with your ticket but there's such a difference in politeness and manners amongst Americans (get in line, don't cut) and Europeans (specifically the older French & Dutch ladies at our visit! Even a French man behind me was annoyed with their pushiness & line cutting). But once inside you're free to roam about. I suggest having a guidebook in order to know what you want to see, especially if you're with children and know your time is limited. The volunteers/staff were helpful & kind despite the language barrier (they didn't speak English; I didn't speak Italian) in explaining how one work we wanted to see was on loan to Boston. We only spent an hour here max...that was enough to catch all the major works we wanted to see. Afterwards we spent another hour exploring the park. It is a sight to see in and of itself! We rented a surrey bike for 4 and the kids had a ball riding all over, stopping to take pictures. Afterwards, there were pony rides, an amusement ride and a playground to let the kids have fun. Plus many balloon & food vendors. There's a nice cafe by this play area that we bought paninis & drinks from and then ate on a park bench. FYI: It's a nice, downhill stroll back to the heart of Rome from here; even our kids didn't complain!
stunning. This is a fabulous museum and should not be missed. Make sure your visit includes the gardens. Have your camera ready.

Very good..but expensive. The statuary on the ground floor is superb especially Bernini's "Rape of Proserpina". The picture gallery, except for the Room of Caravaggio, was good though not brilliant. Worth a visit for Bernini statues alone. Must pre-book your visit as visitor numbers are limited.

One of the finest private collections in the world. This 17th century villa was built to house the art collection of Cardinal Scipione Borghese(1579-1633) who became Pope in 1605. Make sure to reserve tickets several days in advance. Your ticket allows you only two hours in the museum so arrive on time because the museum is completely emptied before the next timed visit is begun. An audio tour will enhance your appreciation of the villa and it's remarkable collection. On the ground floor are amazing sculptures by Canova and Bernini and six masterpieces painted by Caravaggio set among the lavish rooms with highly decorated floors and ceilings. We spent too much time on this floor and had to rush through the next floor dedicated to the painting collecting. Masterpieces by Rafael, Bellini, Titian and Veronese round out this unique collection. The gardens surrounding the villa invite you to tarry.
BEAUTIFUL! My favorite Museum in Rome. This gallery contains so many beautiful structures. I wish to go back. I was only able to visit once and it's not enough.

Very nice, not too crowded. This galleria has some impressive sculptures, even compared to what you see in Florence at the galleria del'acca, you do have to make reservations and please plan to ride on a bike through the park after you finish.
A veritable feast...!. There's a lot to take in, so pace yourself - using the audio-guides available downstairs is advised.

Make reservations early!. The Galleria Borghese is worth the time and money. Not only is the collection of Bernini sculptures impressive, the house itself is a work of art. Make reservations early as the number of people admitted at one time is limited. Go to the gallery website for the phone number to call.

Gorgeous. You're supposed to book a day ahead but my wife asked at the desk ever so nicely and since there were only the two of us they let us have a ticket to go in straightaway. Sumptuously gorgeous rooms full of amazing art and sculpture - Bernini's here, Caravaggio's and Canova's there, famous originals just all over the place. Very cool.

Roman art, Bernini, Caravaggio. As the gallery is very popular book tickets in advance so that you can choose the 2-hour interval for your visit (which is obligatory).And apart from the marvellous exhibition enjoy the park round the gallery.
Amazing. The collection of works in one place is very impressive. Well organized. We walked in the villa before going into the gallery. A delightful experience.

Impressive Artwork. Diverse Artworks from a mostly private collection of the Borghese family. Impressive sculptures, beautiful marble walls and floors among other artworks. You need to make a reservation ahead of time. Give yourself a half a day to also enjoy the surrounding gardens. Several acres big. Quiet & relaxing. You'll feel like your Not in a big city. Check out the fountain with Horse sculptures as the base as well.

Excellent-amazing Bernini statues. You MUST reserve tickets in advance- only admit people with tix every two hours. Reserve your time slot online. And they only give you two hours. Then go and enjoy the beautiful gardens

Crowded. This attraction is very much on the tourist map so in late August was exceptionally crowded. A few start pieces of art but other pieces of similar quality can be viewed elsewhere. The over decorated nature of the Galleria itself echoes the Vatican museum.

simply perfect. Book in advance and take a guided tour with an art historian to make the most of the thousands of artworks and sculptures on show. You will be taken to the most important pieces and gain a greater insight into the renaissance period. An audio guide is ok but with a human guide you gain a much greater understanding into the symbolism, the history and the passion of the masterpieces and also the Borghese family. After a 2 hr tour you are free to wander around for another hour on your own. Bags have to be checked in but you can use a camera or mobile phone without the flash. To actually see with my own eyes the sculptures of Bernini and the art of Caravaggio was an extremely emotional experience, I wept throughout the tour as the professor )who spoke perfect english explained in detail how the works were created and the stories that went with them. The cafe is not particularly expensive and there are plenty of toilets. It is accessible for those with mobility problems and - or wheelchairs if you book in advance and explain your needs. All staff were very helpful, patient and informative even on a sunday in August ... When in Rome this is an essential attraction, possibly even more so than my beloved Colleseum. I will go back whenever Im in rome.

A must see.. This has got to be the most beautiful Gallery in Rome. You MUST have reservations. You get two hours for your reservation and that is really not quite enough because you just want to stand there and be in awe. Also, don't fail to walk the surrounding park because there are gems to discover at every turn. This was my most memorable experience in Rome.

The must visit in Rome. That is one of the places to be visited in Rome, especially for those who are interested in art. Me, being a simple tourist, I had a "pre-visit study" online just to avoid the ignorant face not recognizing at least the top 10 masterpieces.It is really advisable to buy the ticket online beforehand herehttp://www.galleriaborghese.it/borghese/en/einfo.htm. Doing so you will not have a big surprise seeing on Tuesday visit the information that the tickets have been sold until the next Sunday.

Magnificent Treasure.. The Galleria Borghese is a magnificent art gallery in Rome, Italy, housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana. There are very treasures of art, such as paintings and sculptures from the famouse Italian artist Gian Lorenzo Bernini. Complimenting the property there a the Borghese Gardens, where one can take a beautiful walk or rent a bike to go around. Highly recommend to book in advance to avoid disappointments.

Beautiful villa to display beautiful art!. The Borghese Villa is beautiful in itself and the art collection is houses makes it one of the top must-see art museums in the world. It is wonderful to experience art of this caliber as it was intended to be seen - in a stunning palazzo. The Bernini sculptures are magnificent and well-displayed.We used our Roma Pass to cover our entrance fee, but you must call ahead to reserve your time to enter. You are given two hours to tour the museum, which is sufficient. Take a leisurely walk around the gardens and through the large park (Rome's "Central Park"). This is a treasure.

A must-see when in Rome. The Galleria is in beautiful grounds and a beautiful palazzo so there's much to see here apart from the art. The art is magnificent; this is one of the major collections in the world though it's not the largest - there are a very large number of Bernini's here including the Rape of Persephone, one of the most fabulous sculptures you'll ever see (his hands pinching into her flesh - and it's marble!!), and Napoleon's sister posing too. Caravaggio is here plus many other greats - plus the fine arts. You should book ahead - and you will be slightly rushed on your way through as it's such a popular place for tourists but don't miss it. The cafe here is very good too if you need refreshments.

Wow!. We managed to get timed tickets for the last tour of the day.We were very impressed with this villa and the treasures it contains.We only got a little time to explore.Amazing that so much can be in one private home"It is now open to the public and it has much to offer yet our visit was timed.There was to be no photography allowed but we did see the rules openly violated,no flash no problem.We will go back when we return to Roma!

Not possible to visit. Without an on-line reservation you cannot visit it. 16hrs: museum empty , no queues, closes at 19hrs. Tried to get a ticket at the ticket counter... No way without internet booking! By the way staff is gross and rude, not proper for a place like this.

Classical art lovers dream!. The Borghese Gallery is a must--every inch of this astoundingly beautiful palace is covered in art, whether paintings on walls or ceilings, or sculptures in various, gorgeous colors of marble or bronze, or columns--it's all breathtaking and not to be missed.

Beautiful place!. Took the guided tour of the museum and the gardens, and both are exceptionally pretty. The tour guide spoke extremely fast, and even as a native English speaker, I had a hard time keeping up with him. Due to the "cultural crisis" in Italy, the A/C was not on, which was ok...but it was strange to be in a museum with all of the windows open to keep people from passing out. The lights were also not on, so in some rooms the tour guide had to borrow a guest's cell phone to use the light on it to illuminate the pictures. We also did Segways in the gardens, which was lots of fun!

Superlative. We conveniently got Bus 495 from our apartment near Valle Aurelia to the San Paolo Del Brasile stop in Villa Borghese. It was a pleasant walk to the Galleria and we arrived in good time for our reserved tickets. It was grand to approach the fine Villa, looking very impressive. The audio guide is beneficial providing much interesting detail. The interior decorative detail is astonishing. The marble, paintings, frescoes, carvings and more are wonderful. There is a treasure trove of art works. Canova’s sculpture of Pauline Bonaparte is sublime, down to the detail of the cushion creases being perfectly captured in marble. For us the highlights were the Bernini masterpieces. The sculpture of the myth of Daphne, pursued by Apollo, changing into a laurel tree is imaginative and lovely. That of the abduction of Proserpina by Pluto is wonderful. The realism of pressed flesh portrayed in carved stone is admirable.

The most beautiful museum of the world.. We visited this museum 2 years ago so we already knew that it was one of the best in the world. Seeing the wonderful art, magnificent paintings, stunningly beautiful Berninistatues again, was the highlight of our trip to Rome. Especially if you admire Bernini you absolutely have to visit this museum. The reservationsystem works perfectly. You have to book online and during the day you can pick up your tickets at the counter. You cannot take anything inside, not even a small handbag. They give a little plastic bag for your walled. You may take a camera inside but without a bag. The visit is exactly 2 hours. Try to drink enough water before you enter because it is extremely hot inside, especially on the first floor in the painting galery. But this is just a small inconvenience for all the beauty that you can see. This museum should be on your priority list.

Top notch. A wonderful gallery! Set in the heart of the beautiful Villa Borghese park, the building is a delight in its own right! Once inside you will be overwhelmed by the splendid works of absolute masters of the Renaissance, such as Raphael, Caravaggio, Sebastiano del Piombo, Sassoferrato and many others. Not to mention the breathtaking sculptures by Bernini! Each single piece is literally Stendhal Syndrome material!!! So be warned! Remember to book your visit in advance. All it takes is a simple phone call....and, yes, they do speak English!

Disappointed. To get here is an adventure. From the Spanish Steps, enter the train station, a series of tunnels will lead you to the Borghese Park. Walk thru the poorly maintained park, locate the gallery, your advance ticket or long wait in line to purchase a ticket is good for a two hour admission. The gallery opens on the hour at 9,11,1, and 3 PM. They advertise more than they offer and you see it all in less than one hour. You see more and greater works of art in all of the church's of Rome.....FOR FREE AND NO WAITING

A Definite Must-Do!. Artwork is incredible, but it all was made better by the best audio guide we have ever used. Audio Guide is succinct yet detailed, allowing us to experience the entire gallery without receiving mundane information. It takes a few hours to get through the gallery, but it definitely is worth it.

Bernini Sculptures not to be Missed!. Do not go to Rome and miss an opportunity to visit the Borghese Gallery. The Caravaggio's and Bernini sculptures are outstanding. Advance tickets are a must as the entrance to the museum is limited and timed in two hour time slots. Splurge and pay for the guided tour (not expensive at all). We had a phenomenally well educated and well spoken docent that explained in detail the museums highlights. A MUST SEE while in Rome!
Exceptional art. Located in a very large park, astonishing sculptures and paintings displayed in a villa. Walls and ceilings are also adorned with exquisite paintings.

A Must-See. Buy your tickets in advance and be prepared for crowds nevertheless. The collection is worth a visit and the stories surrounding the acquisition of the works makes each even more fascinating.

Not to be missed. My husband and I enjoyed this gallery. After visiting the Colosseum, on a very hot busy day, with hundreds of other people, we really appreciated the smaller, limited groups with set times at this gallery. It gives you the space to fully appreciate the amazing works of art, especially the Bernini sculptures. We were allowed to take a camera and take photos, we had conflicting information beforehand, but cameras are allowed.With lots of churches and galleries to choose from in Rome, this one should be at the top of the list to see, just make sure you book ahead to secure a place - at least a week before you want to visit is recommended.
Beautiful art. This gallery is filled with beautiful art and sculpture. Apollo and Daphne were the highlight. I would suggest you get the audio. We didn't and I think we missed a lot.
Not to be missed. You need to book and pick up tickets about an hour ahead. Get an audio guide as it is well worth while. The paintings and the Bernini statues are fabulous. So ornate. Loved it

Dysfunctional booking/staff. Booking tickets for the gallery are a bureaucratic hassle beyond belief. Pages to be filled out, complex questions (tax # ID? Other "codes' that are unidentified?). Clumsy software, intrusive (wanting date of birth, home country address, age, on and on) for what is really, just a ticket to a gallery! After 30 minutes spent attempting to get a ticket online, and braving the vague language that mentions the fact that you get to know the location to pickup your ticket before you get to go to the gallery (suburbs? naples? where?) you make your purchase and hope for the best. There is a confirmation code, a "pickup" code, etc. and you must run off pdf's of your email, and have ID along with these codes. All for a 13 Euro ticket, and tons of legal language. Let alone translation issues like "seating". Seating? At a gallery? And then coming one hour early. One hour early? Is this a joke? No, they mean it. Look there is other art in Rome. Easier to get to. And when you come down to it, other countries to visit besides Italy where there is less sulkiness, arrogance, dysfunction, corruption and vice.

Incredible art gallery. Villa Borghese is a site not to be missed while visiting Rome. Is set in an idyllic Roman park on top of Piazza di Popolo and the building of gallery is itself a work of architecture and art. Inside you can enjoy sculptures by Bernini and paintings by Titian, Raphael and Caravaggio. You need to pre-book and you are only allowed 2 hours inside the gallery, but it will make you visit worth-while.

Art was fantastic and don't miss the ceilings. We visited the Borghese gallery on a Sunday morning. We planned to use the Roma pass so we attempted to make reservations over the phone but could never get anyone to answer the English line. While we didn't have reservations, we took Rick Steves advice and arrived 30 minutes before it opened. We were second in line and were able to secure tickets for the first admission at 9 am even though there was a sign at the desk that indicated no tickets available. The residence and the collection were everything we expected and more. First, I appreciated seeing the art displayed in the home of the owner. Second, the detailed painting on the ceilings were an unexpected surprise and showcased the 3-D effects of the day. In every room there was a different theme and one was more fantastical than the next. Third, the grounds and Borghese garden are worth a visit. In addition to the obvious greenery, the park is a great to place to take a break from the rest of Rome.
Book in advance. Small and easy to walk around. Do not miss it. Just breathtaking.Allow sometime to visit the surrounding area as well.
Art. this is an amazing place to see and enjoy the paintings. as I said there are paintings that are going to take you back to the history and you would be amazed to see this paintings.
pre purchase rickets ahead online. Wonderful museum full of amazing pieces. English maps in each room offer descriptions. Timed entry, buy beforehand.nice cafe and gift shop too.

Must see Bernini. While not knowledgable about art I love this place and the Bernini sculptures. Out of all the art work we saw this really stands out. If you get Roma pass then you just need to call and reserve and you can use it as one of your 2 passes to locations. Colesseum and Roman Forum count as one. You still need to go downstairs and get your tickets with Roma pass and reservation.Even though it was sold out it was not super crowded. Make sure you get the recorded tour as you will not have any idea what you're looking at.

Beautiful. The Borghese Gardens are beautiful and the gallery is a must-see for those who enjoy art. There are several Bernini sculptures inside that are so beautiful and realistic. Everyone should make time to visit!

Simply superb. Set in a lovely park high up in Rome, above the Spanish Steps. Sculpture of true excellence, Berdini's talent is amazing to the eye. The rest of the place is fascinating for its oplulence and the plethora of art in every room.The staff at check-in are rushed and so a little rude, we didn't let them get us down, though:-)So worth a visit if you can spare 2 or 3 hours.You must pre-book - using their Ticket-One secure website.

A Profusion of colors and perfection in art. Do NOT miss this site in Rome. Sure, reserve ahead if you can, but get there! The collection of art masters is certainly of the finest in Europe, but don't let that distract you from the majesty of the building, and the extraordinary decor within. Each room visited should be first viewed as a room, then for the art held within, Fabulous!Crowds are a bit difficult, but can be navigated by avoiding the flow.
A must see in Rome. I've been to Rome many times but never quite made it to the Borghese Gallery. This time I went & was thrilled with the museum & the beautiful grounds surrounding the area.
galleria botghese. well organized good art a liitle too longbut very intersting knolegeble guide in 3 different languages mad tour interesting

Start on the second level to avoid the crowd. You must reserve your time in order to gain entrance to this beautiful art gallery. Wow, and I must say wow at the collection of paintings and sculptures here. They house a great collection of Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio and many others. My favorite were numerous Bernini sculptures placed throughout the different rooms.Reservations are based on 2 hour visit times at the gallery. You receive your tickets at the basement and the entrance is the main doors on the first level. I was suggested to avoid the mass of people crowding around the first floor once you enter by going upstairs to the second level. Everybody starts on the first level to admire the sculptures and then eventually make their way up to the second level for the paintings. If you do the opposite, the place won't be empty, but you'll get a smaller number of people enjoying the gallery in the same room as you. during the second hour of the appointed time, the first level was fairly empty. We were able to admire the sculptures in peace, not having to wait for all the other tourists to take their turns snapping photos. The Borghese Gallery is a must see when visiting Rome. I am glad I took the advice given to me and started my way up, and then down to the first floor. It gave us plenty of time to admire these masterpieces without feeling rushed.
worth a visit. You are only allowed a two hour visit, but worthwhile. We took the audio tour, which is good but following the floor plan was confusing.

Ticket sellers lie about admission times and prices. There was a placard saying no tickets available for the day. At the counter I was told tickets are available after 3 hours. I asked my wife to queue up. She was given ticket admission after 1 hour. I went for a walk and was stopped by conmen in a car showing a police badge. They wanted to run away with my wallet in the pretext of drug search. When I asked him to step out of the car they drove away. Rome is full of cheats.

A MUST Visit When In Rome. As mentioned, book you tickets in advance. We did our two days beforehand and got the exact day/time we wanted.If you are using a Romapass, you need to make your reservation via telephone.Audioguide is very good and worth the €5.

Extremely rude. Amazing works of art but you will be asked to leave after 2 hours. The stuff was apparently asking us to leave in Italian and we told them we didn't understand but they kept talking in Italian for several minutes. When we told them to speak in enlish all they could say was "exit", pointig us to the exit. VERY rude and unhelpful. Also, more than once the artificial lights were shining upon the paintings and you couldn't see the details.

Stunning. One of the best museums we have ever visited ; anywhere !Yes,obviously,book in advance.Its how the spectator numbers are managed to make it a more enjoyable experience.The audio guide is excellent. Note that you can stay there beyond your ticket time.Definitely worth going there later in the day,it really clears out in the last hour.

Beautiful villa and museum. Amazing Borghese collection. This place is a must-see. We reserved our places over the phone the day before. The day I visited, there was an annoying and insolent visitor who would refuse to turn off his camera flash. He got caught a couple of times by the staff but he'd just go to another room and continue at it. The Borghese Gallery is located inside a large park (reminds me of Golden Gate Park) and was walking distance (25-mins) from our hotel. The Bernini sculptures were breath-taking.
Sculptures that give you goose bumps!. Magical marble sculptures that look like they could come to life if you blinked the right way. Too bad that photos were not allowed when we visited.

Simply Beautiful!. The Borghese Gallery is a beautiful collection of statues and paintings. You have to make a reservation or get a "no show" slot. I was so impressed with the wonderful artwork! Even if you're not an art lover, you will at LEAST be in awe. It is amazing! I HIGHLY recommend!
Simply Beautiful!. The Galleria Borghese is a beautiful collection of paintings and statues that is worth seeing. I highly recommend it for those who appreciate this type of art.

Bernini statues alone are worth the visit. Make sure you book your entry time online beforehand, it books up during busy periods - tip: you are given a 2-hour window, you can enter any time during that two hour window, but you have to exit at the end of the 2 hours. We went in 15 minutes after the window started just to avoid the lineup. When you go to pick up your ticket with your reservation you go in the doors UNDER the steps, get your tickets, and then enter the gallery at the top of the steps. The Bernini statues are breathtaking, and some of the other art pieces are just fabulous as well. A big plus is the lower crowd level as well, since the entry numbers are limited. Really, make sure you go!

A must do museum in Rome. This museum, which I suggest you book in advance, as they fill up spots, is simply magnificent. They only allow a certain number of people in the gallery for 2 hours at a time, so you can really get a good look at the collection. I was amazed at the sculptures and art work from artists like Bernini, Caravaggio and Canova, including the Bernini David, and Apollo and Daphne. It is the most manificent collection I've seen outside the Vatican and Louvre. Head upstairs to the portraits first to avoid the bulk of the crowd, and then after you've been through that floor (you have 30 minutes), then head down and most of the crowd will have moved through. We got the audio tour and it was nicely done, one of the better ones, and very informative. They were a bit disorganised when we first arrived with no directions about where to pick up the tickets, but we soon sorted it out. Highly recommend! The grounds of the Villa are also quite beautiful and worth taking the time to walk through.

Worth the time and effort. Book your tickets to the Borghese Gallery in advance of your visit to Rome. Print them and bring them with you. You will then be shuffled around by the staff into the hands of an outside tour guide who will help you understand the vast collection of art inside. Your guide should be able to give you an understanding of the immense power and wealth of the Borghese Family and if you are visiting without a guide, read everything you can get your hands on about what you are seeing. We walked the Gardens after touring the Gallery and it is an expansive piece of real estate in Rome. There aren't the same large crowds as The Spanish Steps or The Vatican, so it's a nice break from the traditional tourist attractions of Rome. It is also not a Church nor is affiliated with the Church so the art you are seeing lacks religious restriction. It's amazingly beautiful and inspirational. Plan to leave your back packs and purses in the main lobby. They are strict about these items in the Gallery.
Magnificent in every way. The Borghese Gallery is a jewel of a collection. In scale it is perfection for an afternoon of rapturous gazing at some of the most remarkable works by Bernini and Raphael.

Belle arti in Rome!. Rome is not just city of Hepburn-Peck style romance, or purely religious pilgrimage; it has numerous treasurable works of art worth your precious time too and Galleria Borghese is the place. if you are stunned by the master pieces of Bernini in the Basilica di San Pietro, you could find some more of the great artist's exquisite masterwork here! and of Caravaggio, and of Titian...Oh by the way, please book the tickets online or call in advance with the Roman Pass.

Book, book, book!. No tickets left to buy on the day so I was glad we booked. The gardens were amazing to walk through, the building itself is like a stately home with the family's art collection. Caravaggios were amongst some of the pieces on display. The gallery was one of the less busy tourist spots, maybe because it's a little way out of the city centre. It's shut on Mondays and one Sunday a month has free entry but you'll need to book tickets which I would recommend whenever you decide to visit as time slots are limited to a certain amount of visitors.

Horrible staff. Please do not waste your money here! We read so many positive reviews and bought our tickets in advance because they so sell out, but what regrets! The staff was rude and unhelpful. After much hassle form her concerning our "will call" tickets were difficult to locate and we were given grief for not preprinting it. after several minutes she accepted it in its electronic form and issued our tickets. There is a counter to check in your bags but we had simple shoulder packs and asked the lady at the ticket counter if we should check our bags or if we could carry them in. We were a party of nine. She said we would be fine. we stood in line for twenty minutes to enter and at the entrance the guide turned us around and told us we must check our bags. So then the two hours we were allotted to spend in the museum was used up to stand in lines. Furthermore, inside the museum I overheard a docent question a patron with his Audio guide about showing his ticket. I was also accosted about my travel pack that had my paperback and sunglasses. They docent was not happy until took my book and tucked it under my arm and placed my sunglasses into my pocket. My conclusion is that there are so many beautiful museums to visit in Rome- skip this one and go where the staff is more friendly and appreciate your patronage.

Loved it, to the maximum.. Only reservations are accepted, so make sure to do that in advanced, and also book a guide of good quality. It makes a huge difference. The art pieces in there are fascinating and have huge history. Personally I am not big on art, but I loved this! There are some mysteries, and many stories. This was definitely worth my time, and would not hesitate to come back here again. If you are unable to get a guide, rent the audio books, so you know the history, and what you are looking at. Also make sure to note hidden messages the artist puts in. Like proportions; to show whether a lady is beautiful or not.

wonderful museum. Great small museum. You arrange in advance for a two hour window for your visit, which limits the number of people in the museum at any one time. The Bernini sculptures are extraordinary. I am no art historian but LOVED this collection. Strongly recommended.

Amazing Museum. One of the highlights of our stay in Rome - what an incredible museum! In our opinion, the art here highly rivals that that you will see anywhere else in Italy and should be high on your priority list when visiting Rome. You do need to book your tickets ahead of time online, often a week in advance (especially during the summer season).

We didn't go to the galley but the gardens are beautiful. We hired bikes and cycled round, it's lovely with a really nice atmosphere, lots of places to eat/drink and importantly there's plenty of shade. It's about 30 mins walk or 5 mins in a taxi from the Vattican.

A Must-See in Rome. I took the advice of my tour book, and made reservations in advance. We arrived about 10 minutes before our scheduled time and had no problem getting in on time. Make sure you pick up your tickets downstairs before you try to enter. Get the audio tour--it's well worth it. Read up on Bernini before you go-- it will add to the experience. Check your bags. Photos are allowed.

Gallery and Park. We booked the Gallery for an early entry. We spent about two hours in the gallery - it isn't that large which makes it nice - not too much museum overload. After the gallery we found the Borghese Park to be so much fun that we ended up spending the entire day there. First we rented a row boat in the pond. Then we rented one of those bikes for four. They look silly, but they are so much fun to drive and they actually go very fast and you don't have to do much pedaling. We did the last couple of hours at the zoo. There's so much to do in this park if you want a day away from the city.

Outstanding Gallery in Rome. Do your homework and book your tickets in advance. We had booked for the 11:00 time frame, got to the gallery at 10:15 and the gallery seemed to get much busier for the 1:00 time frame. Rent the audio guide - so you understand what you are looking at and don't miss the paintings upstairs. It is a wonderful gallery with outstanding sculptures and a not to miss when visiting Rome and is located in the lovely Villa Borghese park - a much needed green area in city filled with stone.

A treasure. Although somewhat out of the way and difficult to fine, it is an excellent Gallery. The reservation system and orderly entry is excellent and permits you the opportunity to view the exhibits without the crush and noise of a crowd

The Best Little Museum in the World. The musuem sits in the Borghese Gardens, and was the home of Cardinal Scipione Borgese, who amassed an incredible art collection (and had a pretty nice house, too). The musuem has timed admissions which you must book in advance. It is easy to do on-line. They limit the number of entrants, and limit your time there to 2 hours (which is not really enough, but allows you to enjoy the whole collection. )Get there 20 minutes early to cue up. Be sure to get the audio tour. They don't allow you to bring ANYTHING in, and the line to check a bag gets long as the time to enter approaches.Want to see Roman artwork close up? Or sit in a room by yourself with a signed Rafaelo? Or see more Caravggios in one place that exist anywhere else in the world? Or come right up close to the most magnificent Bernini sculptures, taking a leisurely 360-degree view while not being pushed by other tourists?Then go to the Borghese Gallery, and enjoy. I wouldn't say you can skip the Vatican,...but don't skip this musuem

Great gallery that gives an insight into one of the major Roman families.. We walked from the river up to the Spanish Steps and then to the Borghese Gardens. I must say signage is poor and we spent an extra half hour wandering the wrong way through the gardens before we found the Gallery. We didn't have tickets but asked if any had come available (this was the Sunday of the Agostoferro weekend. It was right on 1pm and two miraculously appeared. Really liked this gallery. It was not overly busy and I really appreciated how the commentary on each artwork linked in how the Borghese family acquired it. Make sure you stop and have a peak in at the Spanish Embassy which is housed in the Palazzo Borghese on Largo Fontanella di Borghese just below the Spanish Steps. This was one powerful family.

IF you enjoy Art, this is the place to go!. This is a private museum. You can buy your ticket via Internet ( http://www.galleriaborghese.it/borghese/en/edefault.htm) and the visit is 2 hours ( not more) so you must organize your visit to match those 2 hours of maximum stay. Whe4n you have booked your tickets with the time schedule, I recommend to be there 1 hour before, to take your tickets enjoy the Coffee place inside. You can rent some audio phone to have explanations during your visit, it is 5 € per audio phone ( you must leave an ID as a caution) no big bags admitted, so you can leave it before entering, they will give you a key or a number, this is free and secure. some time the visit starts from level 1 some times from level 2 ( you will start than from the -1 level and goes through stairs till the up level). The room 2 is really exceptional so if you are starting by the top, do not spend extra time there and enjoy the room 2. You will have time to visit everything in 2 hours, however if you are a slow moving just before the 2 hours ends you will be invited to get out of the museum, so the next groups of visitors can start their visit. The all Area is nice to visit, there is a big park, and a lot of fountains. a good place to spend an entire afternoon, enjoying also the shadows when the sun is hot !

A small gallery treasure! Not to be missed!. One of the best collections in a small gallery! The Bernini statues and the Caravaggio paintings are absolutely breathtaking. It was wonderful to compare Bernini's "David" to that of Michelangelo's in Florence. We had a guide that made the gallery come alive. We made the reservation as an afterthought, and very glad that we did. One of the highlights of our two week trip to Italy! Must make reservations, as the number of visitors in the museum, at any one time is tightly controlled.

Bernini and lots more. Fabulous trip with City Wonders and our guide Rebecca just was so enthusiastic and knew so much that she made the whole experience a joy. The art work and sheer beauty of the location, made this gallery a highlight of our trip
Worth being organised. Have to book this one beforehand, but worth doing. As Lonely Planet says, a taste of all the galleries without culture overdose. Would go back.
Stunning. While this attraction needs to be prebooked, it meant no crowds and the opportunity to see such wonderful sculptures and paintings without a crowd. Beautiful gardens as well!

A must see. Our hotel was a few blocks away and we enjoyed walking through the park grounds to get to the Gallery. We enjoyed the statuary mostly, especially that of Napoleon Bonaparte's sister. Do the second floor first when you get in, there's a special entrance for this, that way you're not fighting the crowds so much. Advanced reservations were easily obtained on line. The surrounding park grounds were a welcome break from the heat and the crowds.

Be sure to visit is gallery and park when in Rome. I am so thankful that I did my research and reserved tickets ahead of time for this museum. First. The park surrounding the Borghese is beautiful and a nice change of pace from the streets of Rome. If you have time, you can rent bikes. Just take your time to enjoy his park. Second. You will love the Borghese Museum. Art work and statues are housed in this old palace. Your time slot is exactly 2 hours. I suggest you get there a tad bit early and pay for their audio guide. You will understand so much more if you do this. Also, you must check in your backpack and purse. So get there a little early. You do not need to wait in the long line to then pick it up upon completion of tour. This was definitely one of my highlights while visiting Rome.

Book in advance but really unmissable!. This is really one of the top museums in the world. Some of the the Bernini sculptures are jaw-droppingly amazing. It is a relatively small museum, and your ticket is for a two hour slot. This is just enough time to see everything if you don't hang around too long at any one thing. There is sculpture on the ground floor and paintings on the floor above. However, part of the magic is seeing amazing art in such a beautifully decorated villa. A real must-see if you are in Rome. Book ahead online. You don't need a printer, but can just show your iPad with the receipt.

A must-see collection in a park setting. First thing: YOU MUST MAKE RESERVATIONS to go here because demand is so high for admission. No wonder----because there is a picture gallery with paintings by some of the most famous old master artists, such as Raphael, Titian, and Caravaggio. But there are also sculptures by the great Gian Lorenzo Bernini and his less gifted father, Pietro. In fact, I think that Gian Lorenzo Bernini's "Apollo and Daphne" is the most beautiful sculpture in the world. Wait till you see the nymph Daphne fleeing from handsome Apollo. As she prays for help from her father, also a divinity, she is turned into a laurel, and you see her toes and fingers sprouting roots and leaves. This isn't the only amazing work of art here, either. The interior decoration, from around 1800, is also exceptionally beautiful. But you must show up on time and you need an advance reservation.

Amazing Collection and Beautiful Scenery. This museum has an incredible collection of sculpture and art, and only allows a certain number of people in at a time, which reduces crowding. I'd recommend buying your tickets online ahead of time and arriving about 30 minutes early. Though we visited in December, the gardens and outdoor space is beautiful and well maintained. This museum is located a bit out of the way - but was only about a $10 cab ride from near the National Museum of Rome.

Wonderful gallery marred by rude and surly staff. Undeniably, the content of the gallery is stunning. I would have expected the staff that work there to have been more enthusiastic about their surroundings. Unfortunately, they all appeared surly, disinterested and totally put out by visitors. For example, you have to hand bags in prior to going into the gallery - the woman that I handed mine to practically spat at me when I handed mine over. The queuing system is also a nightmare - queue after queue after queue.

Highlight of Rome visit. The entire villa is spectacular. We hired a private guide and highly recommend that option! The quality of the exhibits is unbelievable. Not to be missed. But eating in the café was a mistake - poor food & expensive.

Very beautiful. This is a beautiful gallery that we liked a lot. You've got to book tickets ahead of time, and finding the gallery is a bit of a hike through Borghese Park, but it's worth the time to get there. Even my 12, 15, and 17 year old kids liked it.

Book Well In Advance & Allow Adequate Travel Time. This is one of the greatest museums in the world. It is chock-a-block room after room with fantastic art. You need to book well in advance (at least 3-7 days) for your appointed time and your time in the museum is limited (but adequate). It is not particularly easy to get to the Borghese, so plan for that and allow adequate travel time. The audio guide which you may rent is excellent.This was our second time in Rome and first time to the Borghese. This is #2 on my all-time list for Rome attractions behind only the Vatican Museum and its Sistine Chapel.Note with the Roma Pass the entry fee is heavily discounted (less than half price as I recall) but you will still need to reserve your spot well in advance and then be there at the appointed time.Your effort will be richly rewarded!

Must See!. Although the Borghese Gallery was small, the contents were magnificent! The Daphne and Apollo sculpture was amazing! Lots of statues, sculptures and paintings. The entry to the Borghese Gallery' ceiling and walls were just beautiful. Also, the cafe in the basement was very delicious.

My favorite museum in the world. If I hear of any of my friends are going to Rome, I tell them that this place is a must. You need to make reservations as they are strict about letting a certain number of people in during a 2-hour window. If you care anything about sculptor, this place will change your life. Bernini's work is prominently featured here, showing off some of his most famous pieces. The city of rome displays even more throughout the city in public spaces. I could return here many times and this place will always be on the list of must-sees.

Worth it for art lovers. It was a long walk from the center of Rome to get to the Villa Borghese, but it was worth it! I've read that you need reservations to get in, but we managed to get in without them, although this may be because we just happened to come at a time when reservations weren't necessary. The museum does require bag check-in though - no purses or anything like that, but you can keep your camera. :)I love Renaissance art, and art by Bernini is particularly awesome, so this museum was amazing. Seeing Apollo and Daphne in person was absolutely breathtaking, but every single room was full of masterful paintings and sculptures - even the ceilings were covered with them! I could see how those uninterested in art would be bored, as this museum requires an appreciation for the beauty of Renaissance art. But perhaps even those who aren't originally interested in art will soon find themselves mesmerized after visiting this museum.

Amazing. If you go in the busy times like July and August, you will need to book. Do this with the Gallery itself, and do it before you leave the UK. The original sculptures and paintings in the Borghese Gallery date back to Cardinal Scipione's collection and they are truly amazing. Educational for teenagers. My two granddaughters were enthralled and intrigued by it all. Afterward stroll in the lovely gardens, have a ride on the train that goes around the complete park. You can then visit the zoo, small but nice. Allow a whole day for the entire experience.

Nice Park!!!. You must see this area!!! It is inside city but when you enter from gate... Nature take you away.
