There are sculptures, pools, garden decorations, rental cycle & segway & boat, minitrain... and galleria!!! There is also policeman with big horses. It is very beautiful place.The galleria is amazing.You must buy ticket for galleria entrance.

I loved it!!. If you have more than three days in rome, do not miss a day in villa borghese... The park is nice with many activities and a zoo... The gallery is amazing.. Remmember to make a reservation in advance.

Fantastic sculptures and art. Visit was a highlight of holiday in Rome. Make sure you get there at least half an hour before your entrance time. It gets very busy but is well organised. Didn't feel rushed during 2 hr visit time and surprisingly you are allowed to take photos. Completely blown away by the sculpture of David and the rape of proserpina. You can almost believe stone is flesh. Unbelievable and very moving.

A must when in Rome. A visit to the Borghese Gallery is a must.The sculptures and artwork are outstanding. Bernini's statues of David, Pluto & Proserpina and Apollo & Daphne are breathtaking.Access is limited so make a reservation in advance.

Long walk - only to find it was fully booked!. We had a Roma pass so decided to take a long walk to see the Villa. Unfortunately unless you book in advance, you can't get in - with or without a pass. Consequently I can't comment on the interior or the contents which might be wonderful. It's the first museum I've ever been to where you HAVE to book in advance to get in [ however this important fact is not obvious in the tourist blurb on the Villa]. The staff are a little brusque staff too.The large gardens offer plenty of shade and make a pleasant walk but they are nothing special compared to many parks and gardens I have visited with few flowers or specimen shrubs and poor quality lawns. Sissinghurst or Hidcote it is not

Good day visit. the Borghese Gallery is a wealth of beautiful art works. Everywhere you look you will see beautiful art. If you are not into art or museums this is not for you. The visit was nice and we bought the audio tour which explains what every room is about and also explains some of the works.You need to buy your tickets online ahead of time and they give everyone a 2 hour window to visit. It was well worth it and the fact that is inside beautiful Villa Borghese park was a huge plus as you can walk in the park and enjoy being outside on a nice day.
Reserve in advance. Two hours is plenty to see this lovely collection of art. Now they even let you take pictures inside. For a summer visit, book online in advance, or you won't be admitted.

Stunning statues, beautiful building. Book on line to avoid disappointment. Beautiful statues and interesting art work. Took about an hour to go around. You need to hand in bags but can keep cameras as long as you don't use flash. Small basic cafe with limited seating.

Beautiful Museum. It seems like a hassle to go to the Borghese Gallery and I had avoided it on previous trips. Yes, you must make a reservation and most likely take a cab there as it is out of town. But, it is a quick trip from Piazzo Popolo, you can reserve online and then once you are there-- absolutely beautiful masterpieces. Even my children were speechless and enjoyed every minute.

"Excellent". Don't forget to reserve your tickets in advance, otherwise you won't be able to visit the Borghese Gallery. It is a good system and they stick to it from the first till the last minute. Highlights are of course Pauline Borghese, The Sleeping Hermaphrodite, the various Caravaggios and of course Bernini's magnificent marble statues. He really understood how to handle marble and to make the best of it.
Terrific. The gardens, not far from the Spanish steps was a spectacular example of local faune and the residence was a wonderful experience

Very rude staff who know nothing abt respecting tourists. My visit to the Borghese gallery was by far my worst visit ever to any touristic attraction all over the world, we booked our tickets 1 day in advance and at the door they wouldn't let us in as they had an important guest for whom they closed the gallery; it was our last day in Rome and we had other plans so we couldn't come back later so we wanted to refund the tickets; the ticket office as well as all those who kicked us out were very rude and refused to give us a guarantee that the tickets will be refunded or let us talk to the manager to write an official complain and when we insisted to meet the manager they threatened us to call the police as if we were thieves. I wouldn't think of going again even if it was for free. Tourists should be treated respectfully and they know nothing about curtsy.

Take your own earphones for audio tour. Borghese is GREAT! Book a tour in advance online. If it is summer, I recommend the 1-3pm time slot because it is cool inside. Arrive half an hour early to get your ticket (downstairs) Also, I suggest paying the 5 Euros for an English Audio guide. Take your own ear phones so you don't have to hold the device up to your ear all the time. You will want your hands free to take photos. (NO flash of course) Also, you will have to "check" any bag that you may have with you...ie purse, backpack, etc.Enjoy!Ciao!

Even better than expected.... I wanted to visit only one more Museum (besides the Vatican) in Rome and choose the Borghese Gallery. And I am glad I did. The Gallery is housed in an impressive Villa that was set up to show off the collected works of Art displayed its individual rooms. Each room is also itself a work of art with suitable surroundings for each collection of statues and paintings set by period. Including masters Bernini, Caravaggio and Titian.Some rooms are sparse, some are busily ornate and some have three dimensional looking painting on the ceilings (Trompe l'oeil). It makes for an interesting additive to the displayed works of art which can be seen up close throughout the room. Some of the interesting items includes two identical marble statues of an Emperor. The second was produced in a week after the first showed a marble flaw. And the Abduction of Poserpina by Pluto statue in which the legend of her being turned into a Linden Tree to protect her is shown by moving around the statue from front to back to observe " the transformation" in minute details.. The Gallery is very worthwhile but may be a bit taxing for youngsters.Tip: There is a Gift shop and a small food bar (reasonable) in the basement (on the floor where one enters). Be sure to get your tickets over the internet for a timed slot before going. They are strict about time, and rules. Pick up an audio guide in your native language (for 5 Euros each) and use the numbers around each art piece to get details about them. It's also well worthwhile to save time before or after the tour to experience the surrounding Villa Borghese gardens.
Really a pleasant mornings tour.. Loved the tour, paintings were beautifull and explained well. Building is light and airy , and the grounds. lovely. one can ride bycycles there afterwards

Stunning for art lovers. This is a lovely gallery, full of Italian (and not only) renaissance artists and sculptors like Bernini, Titian, Raffaello and Caravaggio. Other pluses are that it is a manageable size so you can do it all in an hour or so, and it is in a lovely villa in the middle of one of Rome's nicest parks. You have to book tickets on line. Come out for a stroll in Villa Borghese and then walk down Via Veneto (but don't stop to eat there as it's it's very overpriced) to the centre, maybe stopping off at the bottom at the amazing Cripta dei Frati Cappuccini
Beautiful!. Borghese Gallery is just amazing. A must see and you should purchase the audio tour. The audio tour gave such interesting facts about certain pieces.

Very refreshing. Refreshing to get away from the heat and crowds of Rome and particularly the tourist attractions. The pre booked tickets system is a chore but the result is a quiet viewing of some great works (Titian, Caravaggio). Also the gallery is set in a lovely park, boating on the lake is 3euro per person for 20 minutes. Perhaps not great for kids, but the park is (there is a zoo at extra cost).

Loved it!. The fact that they meter the entrances greatly enhances the experience. We went through at our own pace and enjoyed the freedom to take our time. We were in Europe for three weeks and spent number of afternoons in museums and galleries. As we look back on our trip this was probably the most enjoyable. Besides the museum the entire surrounding park area is a secret to most Rome visitors. Besides a couple of hours in the museum budget time to enjoy the park. There is little lake and great places to enjoy a picnic, views of Rome or a shady nap.

Our favourite gallery!. We had no hesitation in visiting this gallery for a second time - absolutely packed with fantastic art - Caravaggio and Bernini at the top of the list!Note that you need to get a timed ticket. Worth checking in your bags in advance so that you can get in for the maximum time. (There is a fair queue)Rather than going to the second floor and working down (which is what is expected), consider stopping at the first floor first to avoid the effect of a 'crowd' or at least move quickly through the first rooms to reach a later room which will be quieter. (We definitely wanted to visit the Caravaggio works without crowds - they are on the first floor)Lovely park to visit before or afterwards and a pleasant 'little train' ride' which includes a short break at the spot from which you get a stunning view over Rome, above the Piazza del PopoloNice bookshop - the set of 10 cards at 5 Euros is worth getting - most of the main works of art and only 2 naff cards!

Beautiful Borghese. The greatest art of our entire trip was viewed in this museum, and we just listened to the audio tour! The outside looked unkept, but the inside held some of the best, most interesting art and history (surrounding the art) we saw or heard.

Great park-not sure the art justifies the journey. It's very hard to offer any criticism of an art gallery, without appearing a total philistine. I have enjoyed art galleries all over Europe, but I was disappointed by the Borghese. There were two Caravaggios (on my visit) and a fantastic rendition of David v Goliath, but also a lot of slightly underwhelming paintings and monumental but uninspiring statues. Maybe the Baroque isn't my period, but I didn't think it was worth the trip out of the city centre.

Beauty and Serenity. This was a wonderful escape from the hustle and bustle of Rome. It is a bit off the beaten path so make sure you give yourself plenty of time to get there. Also, you MUST buy tickets ahead of time which you can do on-line. I can't imagine how disappointed some of the people were who had shown up without reservations. Something about the space and light of this home make it a wonderful art viewing experience. We did the audio guide and found it really educational. It also gave us a greater understanding for many of the sculptures we saw when we visited Florence.

Definitely Worth It. This is an outstanding palace filled with sculpture and paintings from the Borghese family. The palace is surrounded by beautiful gardens that were filled with walkers and cyclists. It must be on your to do list while in Rome.
Worth a visit. The galleries are small yet fantastic. Excellent bronze sculpture. The gardens are free. Worth renting a four sweater or two sweater bike to explore gardens
gorgeous. I like that they dont let a lot of people in at the same time: you can enjoy the beaty of the gallery without crowd.

unmannered ticket seller. We tried to visit on the 31st July 2014 - Cannot rate it since we didn't have the possibility to visit the gardens, since only people with pre-booked tickets were admissible . However when trying to ask a simple question to the lady who sold tickets inside, she was very rude by ignoring me completely after clearly noticing that I wanted to ask her something. There was a man as well selling tickets and he answered me even if not in a polite manner, however I received an answer. I really wanted to visit the gardens but after the way they treated visitors I lost all interest. These people working with tourists should really learn some manners.

A jewel of a musem. Classic paintings, Caravaggio especially, lots of Bernini sculptures, Apollo and Daphne very beautiful, get the audio guide, it is worth the money. The surrounding area is nice too, water available at a fountain outside, nice to take a walk. Downsize: must make a reservation beforehand, otherwise they don't get you in, pay extra for reservation, but avoid the lines. Once inside, they take your bag at cloakroom, you are allowed only 2 h to visit. They announce thru speaker to exit. It is not enough, I did not finish the audio guide explanations in that time. It is a kind of fast gallery.

Unbelievable~. How a man could amass all that art? We went there 3 times. We loved the gallery, (get the audio), the park was nice to walk around in , and we rented a bicycle and rode around for the morning, before going for lunch.

So many masterpieces on such a marvellous background. Bernini, Caravaggio, Canova and a number of astonishing less known pieces from Imperial Rome. Surrounded by an oasis of green where cicadas sing the whole day. Worth the visit, especially if approaching from via Del Babuino.

Amazing art, limited space. The Borghese museum has a great collection of art, especially the sculptures by Bernini. The Borghese gardens seem pretty rundown in comparison with the Parisian gardens, but inside it is magnificent and well curated.

Not customer-friendly. There is a complex 'arrival procedure' you have to work out for yourself (the staff seem happier telling you what you can't do rather than explaining what you do need to do) that involves queuing to buy tickets, showing the ticket the the cloakroom staff (no being naughty and having one person check all the prohibited items such as phones, cameras, water etc. while the other is queuing for the tickets) then, and ONLY THEN, being allowed to use the toilets before finally being allowed in. And if you don't do things in the right order you may find yourself treated quite rudely by staff.I've been in plenty of great museums around the world where people are not treated as cattle. This is not one of them.

Stunning Work. The work is stunning and learning about the history of the family is both frightening and wonderful all at once. A combination of incredible greed and brilliant artwork all in one venue.

A very big and nice park.. We didn´t visit the gallery inside, but we spent a couple of hours in the beautiful Villa Borghese garden. A great lake, lots of flowers, small cafes and a lovely atmosphere in the midst of a busy city. We were there a sunday afternoon...together with a lot of locals and tourists who enjoyed the peace in lovely surroundings.

Beautiful art in relaxed atmosphere . We had a nice time visiting this gallery. It had great art and isn't too crowded due to their restrictions on tickets and visit time (2 hours). We finished after about an hour but of course that's with kids. Be ready - they are very strict about not taking bags into the museum, even my wife had to check her purse in before we visited. They have a cafe in the basement with reasonably priced (and average tasting) food.
Pure bliss!. Each year we're in Rome, we go to Borghese Gallery just to see Bernini's Daphne and Apollo. It's the most beautiful sculpture in Italy. Always brings tears to my eyes.
Bernini Lovers. After visiting Italy, we have become big Bernini fans and this gallery has 5 incredible pieces and a self portrait. Apollo and Daphne alone are worth the price of admission.

Must See. This may be the best art museum in the world. Be sure to reserve ahead of time (and don't worry, the amount of time allowed is just right). Arrive by taxi and, afterwards, stroll (down hill all the way) through the park, down Via Veneto, to Trevi, the Pantheon, Navona, Campo di Fiori, ending at Piazza Farnesse. That will make for a very nice day.
Don't miss this!. This museum is on the Borgia property. It's not well marked on the maps but so worth the effort if you like museums. Buy your tickets in advance. The shows are timed.

A nice palace set in a huge park right in the middle of Rome. This is Cental Park in Rome ! The Palace is wonderfull. Rent the audio guide to optimize your visit. You need to make reservations in advance as you cannot buy your tickets on the premises. A phone call we make it and you just have to be there 30 minutes before your tour. ( tours are scheduled and you have 2 hours to complete your visit)
so ornate. this museum is one of the best so full of fantastic sculptures & paintings,& what is more there is no restrictions on photos .not like other museums

Wow. What a wonderful experience. This museum set in the Borghese Gardens contains room after room of master artworks including important paintings by Caravaggio and sculpture by Bernini. Tickets must be purchased in advance, often a day ahead, for the two hour entry session. A must for anyone going to Rome.

Bernini was worth it!. Loved the Bernini sculptures in this museum. There is a limit on the amount of time that you can spend, which seemed to be enough for the size of the museum. We took a tour because the tickets got sold out, and it was worth the visit! (Took City Wonders tour)

You will be amazed. As soon as you enter the gallery, you will be astounded at the number of statues and paintings on display. Truly unbelievable. Don't miss it. We showed up at 9:30 (after the 2-hour, 9 to 11 session had started) and used our Roma pass. Actually, I would recommend turning up after the start of the session to avoid queuing.

Probably the best museum in the world. It is not exagerated to say that this is probably the best museum in the all world: not only the building is beautiful by itself, but it also contains some of the most beautiful statues in the world (from Bernini and Canova) together with amazing paintings from Caravaggio and others.Last but not least, it is not that big so that you can spend a couple of hours visiting it all and enjoying with some of the best masterpieces in the world.Absolutely a must see in Roma!

A very special place. Although I live in NYC and go to museums often, I would not describe myself as a "museum person" [have been known to spend a week in Florence without stepping foot into a museum...]. The Borghese, however, is one of my exceptions. I never tire of it. The Bernini sculpture is breathtaking, literally. If you only see Pluto and Persephone, and Apollo and Daphne, it's worth the visit - not to mention the other art and the building itself.My only suggestion is to make sure you have some cash with you after you check all of your items (including purses) at the door - because you will need to pay for the audio tour, if you choose to take it.

More Than a Great Museum. Beautiful Villa surrounded by beautiful gardens /park with masterpieces in every room.The best is Bernini's Apollo and Daphene Baroque sculptures as well as paintings by Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio, and Rubens.Need to book weeks in advance. Easiest to call and reserve time and day and pay when arrive.

Wonderful. This was one of our favourite museums in Rome. The statues by Canova and Bernini were magnificent. Also we were surprised to discover quite a few paintings by Carravagio: six of his most well-known works, to be precise. Loved it!
Rent an audio phone.. The statues are amazing. To get the most out if the visit, rent an audio phone. You have to pre book the tickets and do the visit at a certain time.

Totally Worth the Effort!. I have visited Rome several times previously and never made the effort to visit the Borghese Gallery before. Wow...what a mistake! This is a gallery that is completely worth the little extra effort of getting tickets beforehand. I like to plan my sightseeing trips w/ a bit of flexibility built in...so I had avoided nailing down tickets for an exact date and entrance time. One quick hint when you visit...given that the gallery only allows 300 people in during every two hour window...the gallery entrance is a bit crowded as everyone starts their audioguide. Skip the ground floor and head upstairs to the paintings. I know it will be difficult to walk past all the gorgeous Bernini sculptures, but I promise it's worth it to enjoy them the second hour after the crowds have passed by! You'll practically have Bernini to yourself!We lived in Rome for six months and this was our favorite place to visit. It is truly extraordinary and a stop you will never forget!

Great little gallery. This is a great little gallery located in a very nice park (Villa Borghese) which you should also spend some time exploring. You need reservations for a 2-hour time slot to visit the gallery. They will ask you nicely to leave so that the next group can enter. You can try to get unclaimed time slots by waiting at the ticketing area at half past the hour. If you have reservations, you must claim them by half past the hour. If you are late, they give them away to those waiting for unclaimed tickets. I called from America to get my reservations - they gave me a confirmation # which I gave them at ticketing and paid for my tickets. You can also buy them on-line and exchange the confirmation e-mail for actual tickets. If you go at 9AM or 11AM, you can get a guided tour by a museum guide. This is highly recommended. We met the guide at 10 past the hour, she talked for a few minutes and then she let us to several rooms and showed us the highlights of the museum. The guided tour took about 75 minutes and then we had about a half hour to wander around. This worked perfectly as it allowed the people who weren't on the guided tour to get through the turnstiles and upstairs to the gallery. They only accept cash for the guided tour - 6 euros/person. Our guide was very knowledgeable and she gave you a better understanding of what you are looking at than if you just wandered around. Perhaps the audio guide would do just an adequate job as well - can't comment on that as we didn't get an audio guide.It's not a very big museum and 2 hours is adequate. It never felt crowded, not like at the Vatican Museum. There's a small café (kind of pricey) and a small gift shop. All bags must be checked, even handbags. You can take pictures - no flash.

Perfect collection and nicest are in Rome. Love the area, the palace and Borghese park also.Collection was amazing.Building and its garden was perfect.Such a great roman experience that I love most about Rome.

Absolutely wonderful. It is essential to book in advance, but it is well worth a visit. There are two floors, one containing pictures and the other with sculptures. The detail on some of the sculptures is incredible. The ceilings are a delight with many displaying pictures which appear 3D.
While you are there, make sure you also visit the surrounding park.

GOOD PLACE FOR PHOTO'S. I took many photo's of the place. Enjoyed the many things about the place. I enjoyed the garden, but felt I might have been there at the end of the growing season. FOUNTAINS for drinking water thru out the park (outside). Take a water bottle you pay dearly for water in ITALY.

Art History Eye Candy. It was truly wonderful to see the masterpieces of art that we had studied and read about for decades. The sculpture is magnificently displayed and the whole gallery is breathtaking. We rented the audio tour and it was very informative.

Fantastic Collection. Bernini, Bernini, Bernini, Caravaggio, Caravaggio, Caravaggio. Great examples of their and many others' work, all crammed down your throat in 120 minutes, despite a large plaque which says you should ignore the rules because the museum is their for the viewer.

A "Must See" in Rome. Impressive collection of masterpieces and sculptures. Due to the limited number of timed tickets, it didn't feel crowded.
BUY TICKETS ON THE INTERNET IN ADVANCE. NO SAME DAY SALES.
Must See. We booked private tour through Roman Odyssey Tours, slightly more but worth it. Never rushed and took time to give full history on paintings ,artwork
Wonderful Bernini. Just amazing sculptures, plenty of space and its not overcrowded. The little café inside is needed, as there are not many cafes in the park.

Great Museum!. I really wanted to like this museum, and I mainly did, when I visited it while in Rome. Maybe it was the 1.5 mile walk to the museum from the Piazza del Popolo that made me tired or the somewhat confusing walk through the Borghese Gardens(which are beautiful) that dampened my enthusiasm for the venue. However, I think the real culprit was the audio guide that I purchased to accompany my visit. Maybe it was just me, but I had difficulty matching the guide with the actual room I was in. Some were labeled one thing, but didn't match with the corresponding number on the audio guide. You also don't start in room 1, which they don't tell you unless you ask or notice that what the guide is talking about isn't what you're seeing. IMO, without the guide it is difficult to get much info on the pieces in each room(all placards are in Italian). They do have "placemats" in each room that has info on the pieces, but who wants to read all that?

Great Artwork!. The gallery holds several beautiful Bernini sculptures, Caravaggio paintings and many, many more amazing artworks. I was pleasantly surprised that they held my carry-on luggage in their baggage room (the staff in baggage was great!) while I visited the gallery. A must see if in Rome! IMPORTANT!!! Get tickets in advance, best using an online booking because their daily reservations can be a weeks wait.Overall a wonderful visit and beautiful grounds. However, one woman who collected tickets for our appointed time was very rude and made me take my tablet all the way back to the front of the gallery to store it, after I was told to keep it on me by the front staff.

My favorite Rome museum. I visited the Borghese Gallery on a Sunday morning with my husband. We had 9 am entrance with the Roma Pass. Our hotel made the reservation for us. Make sure you print out your reservation details and bring them with you and book ahead. The next open tickets they had were for Tuesday afternoon. I thought no cameras were allowed, however, after checking my camera bag with the camera inside I found out otherwise. I was able to go back downstairs and get my camera. Found the sculptures to be amazing along with the ceiling artwork. Each room was a treat and I really liked the English guides provided in each room giving you a little peak in to what each room was about. We did not get the audio guide, but found that the sheets in each room were just enough for us. We took about 1.5 hours to see the whole gallery. The line for the bag check got long so we broke up and one got tickets while the other stood in the baggage check line. Being at the end of the line of people going in at 9 turned out to be good as the rooms weren't as crowded. There were some groups of teens being led by their own guides, which were kind of loud, but we were able to pick a different room at most times and it felt like having the gallery all to ourselves. A definite must see if you like painted ceilings and sculpture.We took the bus from the Plaza Repubblica and found it easy to find the gallery. Getting back out of the park to was a bit of an adventure, however, it is a beautiful park that is worth taking a little bit of time to explore after or before the gallery!

Wonderful Museum in Rome. We were so impressed by the collection of this lovely museum! Berinini, Carvaggio paintings and statues were overwhelming in numbers and beauty. You will need a reserved ticket to have access to the works of art. A beautiful setting with a lovely garden and greenhouse to display such a terrific selection of works of art. I highly recommend a visit if you are in Rome.

Not to be missed!. The fact that we got to escape the city and spend time in the park was a major plus. The collection is stunning and learning about Bernini through the pieces here helped us when we saw Bernini's work in the basilicas. YOU MUST RESERVE A TICKET IN ADVANCE. Calling is easiest.

beautiful. We so enjoyed the expansive art collection at the Borghese. You do not need a guide here, they have earphones you can use. We didn't get them, as there were laminated flyers in each gallery to explain what you were seeing. Very informative. Bernini's "David" was absolutely breathtaking!
Wonderful art collection. A bit of a trek from the metro but easy to find and well worth it. the statues are amazing as is the painting collection
excellent. a magnificent collection of art by bernini,caravaggio etc. the statues are absolutely breathtaking!the drawings on ceilings and paintings were amazing!those artists were actually gods!

A world class museum. This museum is not as well known as the Louvre or Uffizi, but it is a must-see. Several Bernini sculptures, including his David, and several Carravaggios, all contained in a magnificent palace. You need a reservation ahead of time, and are limited to only two hours inside. It's now one of my favorite museums, and I will go there again the next time I'm in Rome.

Visit the Borghese!. We so enjoyed the expansive art collection at the Borghese. You do not need a guide here, they have earphones you can use. We didn't get them, as there were laminated flyers in each gallery to explain what you were seeing. Very informative. Bernini's "David" was absolutely breathtaking!

Extremely interesting visit . Very very long queues in a small room. You have to book before your visit unless you are lucky and there are tickets left the time you go. We had the audio guide and spent the full two hours we were given.

Extraordinary. If you like fine art sculptures and when you think about them you think about Micahel Angelo, please come here and enjoy Gian Lorenzo Bernini's masterpieces. They are as perfect as a man made work of ark can be full of emotion and with magnificent skill and they are surrounded by the grandiose building with its outstanding Roman art collection and the paintings o some of the best European artists.

Great Museum!. A must see museum. The gallery itself is a work of art. And there are so many great works to see. Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is worth the price of admission alone! The procedure for visiting the museum is curious, though. A group enters together and has two hours for the museum as a whole and, supposedly, only a half hour for the Pinacoteca (though I could see no way this time limit of a half hour could actually be enforced). We used the hour and a half audio guide and had to skip a few works discussed because of time. So, my only regret is that we didn't have another, let's say, half hour to spend in the museum..

Just loved it.... We booked ahead (a must in high season). Went for the 11am time slot. Took a little time to find the galleria in the villa Borghese Gardens from the metro (spanga) give yourself time. It was a great art gallery, for not crazy art lovers we were really surprised! Love Bernini's sculptures! And the themed rooms (because this gallery was built to house this art) were wonderful, matching frescos to the sculptures. The first floor is a mix of art mediums but the second floor is all paintings. We paid the five euros for an audio guide and was surprised with lots of information and stories befitting the art. Remember to bring a Y jack to plug in two headphones into one guide (the plug in is in the bottom where the lanyard hangs from). Overall we enjoyed this gallery and would suggest it to everyone. But please remember it's still an art gallery, children will not love this (I only say this because I saw many bored children, who then start to touch and cause problems)

Bernini heaven!. On my last tour of Rome I wasn't aware of this gem of a museum. This time around I am staying near the Villa Borghese (largest park in the north of Rome) and was told about this place by the hostess of my B&B. You will want to call and make a reservation or have your hotel do this for you. You will be given a confirmation number which you supply upon arrival to pick up your ticket. No need to stand in line. Your visit has a specific time of arrival and a limit of 2 hours. Plenty of time to peruse this beautiful place. In the sculpture of The Rape of Proserpina, Bernini makes stone look like flesh. It is the first sculpture you will see upon entry. Definitely worth the price of 11 euro for admission. Bernini has a new fan!

Skip the Vatican Museum Crowds and Feast Your Eyes!. Call ahead and reserve a time for an enchanting walk through this colorful museum. Its treasures include breathtaking, polished marble sculptures by Bernini. David is gearing up to cast his stone at Goliath using a tremendous amount of force and strength. Apollo chases Daphne as she pleads with Zeus to save her. As Apollo's marble hand touches Daphne's waist, she begins her metamorphosis into a tree. Set in jeweled-toned rooms, you will be glad you skipped the crowds at the Vatican Museum and feasted your eyes on sculptures and frescoes galore! Get a taxi to take you directly to the door, as the museum is hidden inside a beautiful park and can be difficult to find. Reservations are necessary, as entries are timed. Enter below the stairs to the desk for your ticket opposite the bookstore and cafe. Cameras and backpacks checked in below to be collected after your visit. It was our favorite museum.

Beautiful. If you like art, this needs to be on your bucket list.. Some of the most beautiful artwork in the world is here. My visit was inspired by my desire to gaze at the Caravaggio paintings (which I did for a long time), but the statues, paintings, and mosaics are also wonderful. If art museums bore you, don't go, but if you like art, and you have the time, this should be on your to-see list. A lot has been written and said about this gallery, as I discovered when I planned my visit. Yes, you have to reserve a ticket ahead of time (that's very easy to do on-line), yes, you have to check ALL bags and purses. To make your visit pleasant, I suggest you plan. Get reservations, and, if you have items you can't check, wear something (not a bag/purse) that you can carry them in. Getting there by metro was about a 20 minute walk, the gallery visit is limitted to 2 hours, and you should arrive before your reserved time to pick up your ticket. Allow at least 3-3 1/2 hours.

Art Museum. This tour of the gallery had numerous painting, sculptures, and other art work. We took the guided tour as we felt there was so much that we could miss important items. We felt it was a good value.

Works of art truly amazing. Over the top Baroque pieces, a collection of the uber rich! The best sculpture (and there were many) was the Apollo and Daphne sculpture by Bernini. Worth the visit. The marble looked like butter. He carved leaves and bark from marble making it look so easy. Truly a masterpiece. Roma Pass allows you entry for free or at a discount if you have visited two others on the pass,
Must see. Beautiful. A pleasure to visit. Lovely grounds, not crowded. A peek at how royalty lived. It takes about two hours to see everything so it is a nice morning visit
A confusing garden to tour,. Wonderful gardens with lake, fountains and wonderful villas and art galleries,unfortunately the signage could be better to help you walk around these huge gardens.

Best of Bernini.... We knew about the Bernini statues watching travel shows and knew what to expect - but were still blown away by their beauty in person. We found the painting gallery (upstairs) to be OK. The audio guide was confusing to use with the painting gallery since it wasn't clear which number to punch in (since they were not clearly displayed in all the rooms). But the statues downstairs are the main draw and the a/g works fine there. The grounds surrounding the museum are also nice to walk in. Advance reservations are highly recommended for peak season. We found the cafeteria food to be good - esp. for a museum cafe. And as it is everywhere in Italy, the espresso was excellent.

A Top Rome attraction if you like the arts or culture. 1. Book in Advance online 2. If you wish to eat there pick a slot earlier than 11.00am. Ours visit finished at 1.00pm and the whole place closes then until 15.00. We had an audio which was good but even with that and not wasting time we missed the last top gallery and ran out of time. The building inside is tremendous as is some of the sculpture. Good selection if paintings but many lost in history via Napoleon to the Louvre. Definitely a top attraction in Rome. The outside area could do with some tender loving care for such an important property.
Superb Gallery. If you love Renaissance Art you - probably in a daze - will walk about recognising numerous famous and fabulous works. That overworked word "awesome" is really appropriate.

B G. Some say you need to buy tickets in advance and it is not true. Depends when you go. If you go an hour or two before closing, you can buy ticket on place. And do not worry, one hour is enough, even for biggest art lovers to enjoy it! Plus, before closing, less people and more peace to enjoy. you can even take some photos secretly, as it is forbidden to photo.

Very unfriendly staff!. The gallery itself is impressive, although there is minimal information inside to guide the trip if you don't pay for the additional 5 euro guide. Most upsetting, though, was the poor quality of the staff personnel. When we arrived, we saw a long queue to check bags; as we were carrying our passports and iPhones, we were nervous about this prospect and asked the ticket agent what the rules were. He gruffly brushed us off and gave no additional information. Only after waiting in the long queue did we realize that small bags were provided to visitors and that we could therefore still carry our passports and electronics we us through the museum.Also, we had tickets for the 5-7 block. For anyone buying tickets for that block: The museum store and cafe close at 6:30, leaving no time to shop or pick up a bite to eat for the way home. When we were leaving, we were hoping to catch the 95 bus back to the city center. We asked the previously-unhelpful ticket agent for advice regarding where to catch it. Without looking up from his computer, he said, "We are closed." We tried again, stating that we just wanted to know where to catch the bus. He again replied, "We are closed, madam." It was 6:30 -- our tickets went for another thirty minutes at that point!Incredibly poor service.

A must but book in advance. This gallery is amazing and contains the artwork that I always wanted to see. No words does it justice... A great thing is that they limit the number of visitors and give each group a 2 hour slot, which allows for really admiring the works, and not doing a bull run with crowds like in Vatican. Book a few days on their website and come 15 min early (or earlier if you want to see the garden too).

Must book ahead of time!. This has great pieces of art. It's free on the first Sunday of the month which ended up a bonus for us! We saved 13 euros!! You must book a time to tour ahead of time as they let in only a select number of people at a time! It's well worth it!

Overrated. The Grounds are beautiful and breathtaking. The Gallery was a bit of a diappointment. While there are beautiful pieces of Art, based on the word on the street, I just expected more. Okay to go to if you have time to kill. However, if you are tight for time, there are many other places you could visit.
Biggest surprise in our trip. The best Bernini's collection ever seen. The guy was a real genious and it is worth seeing.Museum employees lack politeness. They should dramatically improve!

Beautiful gallery with stunning masterpieces. This place is absolutely gorgeous! The building of the Gallery is wonderful, placed in the middle of lovely huge gardens and the masterpieces inside are just amazing! My biggest favorite was the painting from Caravaggio - San Gerolamo, which was absolutely brilliant!I highly recommend to visit this place to all art lovers!

Worth a visit to Rome. Got tickets in advance, and were completely impressed. This is clearly deserving of its top rank in the guide books as "must see" places in Rome. They handle the admission pretty well, and you must check purses or backpacks, so consider leaving them at home. Read up on the attractions inside in any guide book, and then marvel -- we especially found the Bernini sculptures everything and more as reviewed. The audio guide was good, worked well, and really helped. But don't dawdle, they do expect you to move on through so the next visitors will have room, and we found this fair - keeps the crowds down and evenly spaced so YOU can enjoy the experience, so reciprocate and take your turn moving along.We recommend to everyone we know. We have been to the Academy, the Uffizi, the Hermitage, the National Gallery, the Williams, Guggenheim in Bilbao, the Louvre, the Fitzwilliam, (well, you get the point) and this is right in that company. Small enough that you CAN get a good experience in your alloted time. GO!

If you love Bernini . . .. This palatial home of the Borghese family contains magnificent art just as it existed when the family resided there. The collection will blow you away if you enjoy Caravaggio, Raphael, even Leonardo, but the piece de resistance is the Bernini collection! David! The Rape of Persephone! Daphne and Apollo! His exquisite modeling of flesh takes one's breath away. And the museum allows only a certain number of visitors at a time so that it is truly possible to study the art.The grounds and gardens are beautiful as well. A splendid morning in Rome!

If in Rome make sure you go and visit. First day I was in Rome I went to buy a ticket for gallery Borghese and had to wait for two days and it was worth it. You get a specific time slot that lasts two hours and I warmly recommend to invest 5€ in audio guide, unless you are on a guided tour. I found the audio guide good enough to keep my interest and to draw my intention to details that would otherwise go unnoticed. I personally preferred the ground floor exhibition which are mainly sculptures in contrast to the first floor where are mainly paintings.

Great museum with wonderfully peaceful gardens surrounding it. I really like this museum because it is so doable. By that, I mean that the museum is small enough to see most of the works comfortably in the time allowed (approximately two hours). I also like that groups are limited to 360 people at a time, making the viewing of the rooms much more pleasant. In other museums, including the Vatican museums and the Louvre in Paris, an unlimited number of people are allowed to enter the museum at once, so that it is difficult to maneuver and to actually see the works of art. Here at the Borghese, you can move around quite easily and actually see the works you have paid to see. And the works themselves are well worth seeing--my particular favorites were Bernini's Apollo and Daphne and his version of David (which is quite different from either Michelangelo's or Raphael's). There are also beautiful works by Raphael, Titian, and Caravaggio, just to name a few. It is difficult to believe that one man, Cardinal Borghese, was able to accumulate this vast amount of artwork. You must, of course, buy tickets in advance, and you will be assigned a two-hour block of time. You can easily do this online. Please note that the place where you pick up your tickets is below the circular stairway at the front of the museum. Also be aware that the climb to the second floor of the museum is quite strenuous. I was not prepared for the number and steepness of the stairway leading to the upper floor of the gallery. But the museum is well worth the time and money. (Cost is about 13 euros per person.)
the marble that you can't imagine. never the marble has been so soft, the statues have been so living and moving as these ones by the great Gian Lorenzo Bernini.

Superb. One of the great galleries in the world. What a fabulous art collection. I would recommend a private tour unless you are an art historian. A really good guide can make the experience so much better.

Gorgeous art. Many rooms packed with a variety of artists' paintings and sculptures. Even without specializing in art history, there was a lot to admire. Also, some rooms have small sofas where you can sit, which is much appreciated when you have a packed itinerary.
Fantastic. Whatever you do in Rome you must see the Bernini sculptors in the Borghese. One of the best days of our visit.

Most beautiful museum in the world. In my opinion, if you are an art lover and enjoy Bernini, this is a must. Tucked away in the Borghese Gardens, this museum allows very few people in at one time. during high tourist season, it is impossible to get a ticket. Get it before you go. Prepare to spend a couple of hours. They will store EVERYTHING, purses, wallets, keys, cameras....they are protecting their art. Afterwards, if the time of day is right, walk on down to the Pomodorini (Little Tomato) for a salad or pizza. Delicioso! If you don't buy ahead, you will not get in! Sometimes the concierge of a hotel will be able to help you. But don't count on it.

bernini. the place was very hard to find. signs in the area were not really helpful. we walked more than an hour to find the museum. When we arrived, the museum was about to be closed. fortunately we didn't give up and entered in. in hundreds of sculptures I saw in Italy, bernini's sculpture that ı saw here, were the most impressive ones..

Don't Miss This. If you love art, this is the place to see it up close. Book before you come to Rome. We took the early morning tour at 9:00 to avoid waiting out in the sun, but really, it is air-conditioned in the gallery, so any time would be good. Give yourself lots of time to arrive and find your way through the gardens to this location. Your ticket only allows you 2 hours in the gallery and you don't want to waste a minute. You will need a map to find your way here, unless you arrive by cab. The gardens are a lot bigger than you think. I can't say enough about the sculptures. After having seen Bernini's Apollo and Daphne so close that you could have touched it, and then to have to stand in a giant crowd at the Vatican to see his Piata behind glass, it makes you realize what a treat it is to be in this gallery. There is more fabulous art in this gallery than you could possibly appreciate with several visits. I recommend the audio guide to direct you to the major pieces in the gallery and then you can book back in again to view the other pieces on subsequent visits.

Beautiful. Not usually huge on spending hours in museums, however the Villa was the exception. Spent a couple of hours following the audio tour and being amazed by so many masterpieces. Was a beautiful Sunday morning, followed by a relaxing walk in the surrounding park. Make sure you pre-book your tickets.

Excellent visit. This visit was spectacular! I was so impressed with the quantity and quality of the art exposed in the museums on each floor. If I would have to pic a favorite it would be the floor that has all the sculptures .must visit if you are in Rome!

Family vacay. Hired a private guide through our hotel, who was an art history major. This enabled us to skip the long lines and gr eatly added to our knowledge of the beautiful artwork. Wish we had allowed more time to explore the extensive gardens.

Borghese Gallery. We booked several months ahead to see this collection. As we were going to us the Roma Pass, you must call the Gallery directly to book your tour. A guided tour in English is offered twice a day, guided by Gallery staff and is well worth the effort. A spectacular collection of art and sculpture, not to be missed.

Art, Art and Art. I really like this stop on our trip. Reserve your tickets ahead, they only allow a certain number of visitors for each 2 hour session and you will be asked to leave when your time is up. There are guided tours each morning you can sign up when you pickup your tickets. The 9-11 session we had was sold out when we arrived, so had we not prereserved our tickets, we would have not gotten in. They did not take credit cards, so bring Euros. This is and incredible collection of art from the Borghese family, one member who became pope. The art was purchased and stolen by the family and is well worth the trip.

A truly lovely gallery and park. The good things about The Borgehse Gallery was the wealth is exceptionally beautiful. As a fan of Bernini, I was so excited to see his work in all its magnificence. I absolutely adore his work so seeing it was a real thrill for me. The downside is not being able to take your own pictures while in the gallery and the time you have is limited.Also, the gift store closes before the Gallery, so if you want to pick up any souvenirs, make sure you go in before the last time allotment. Other than those two things, it is definitely worth it.Loved that Gallery.Tip: If you are going to go, for sure book your tickets online at least two weeks before your trip because they sell out very fast and I saw people turned away because the time slot was full.

Amazing building and artwork!. What a magnificent collection - the artwork, ceilings and statues are an art lovers dream. We bought our tickets online to avoid long lines (glad we did since they were sold out for that day and the next few days!). Tickets are sold at 2 hour increments to avoid overcrowding. The park is also worth a visit.

An Art Must Destination. This Galleria Villa Borghese is an art lovers must destination. In fact even if you are only remotely interested in art it is a must. Set within the grounds of the Borghese Gardens, a must in itself to escape the hustle and bustle heat of Rome lies the Villa. As soon as you walk throughout the entrance into the large reception hall your senses are sent into art heaven. The sumptuousness of the Villa is amazing. From the floor, the walls to the ceilings your eyes are given a feast. That is before you even take in the paintings and sculptures. Roman Gladiatorial mosaics line the floor, frescoes adorn the walls and ceilings. Sculptures from some of the most important artists of their periods are here. Upon walking into the second room I was in heaven. Not one but six Caravaggio's all in the same place. Two more are located in the other rooms. Incredible. This Galleria cannot be fully described or appreciated by words. It has to be seen. I would rate this as one of the most important and beautiful collections I have seen. It is worth its five stars based on the building and its art content. It is essential to book your ticket on line though since they only allow a limited number of visitors inside during two hour time slots. Both a blessing and a curse. Two hours is not quite long enough but it does prevent the terrible crowds that plague The Vatican Museum. The other downside was that some of the staff were extremely rude and brusque in their manner. Just wonderful.

Fabulous - visit this if you only do one art museum in Rome. This is a modest sized villa with two floors packed with impressive sculptures, paintings, and painted ceilings. There are many Bernini works here because of his connection to the Borghese family and other historical links such as with Napoleon make this much more than a museum gallery. It is a nice primer before seeing his contributions to Saint Peter's, the large central sculpture (Four rivers fountain) in the Piazza Navona, etc. Reservations ensure that you will get in and help to regulate the number of people so that you can actually see and enjoy the works. Our hotel concierge made the reservation for us and we were able to get one for the next day with no trouble. The gallery is located in the middle of a beautiful park and it is a short walk from the main portico at the end of the Via Veneto. Very memorable gallery!

Incredible!. We reserved tickets for 10:30 am, about two weeks in advance, by phone, and used our Roma pass when we arrived. The collection was absolutely incredible. Spent about two hours there, then strolled through the park all the way to the Spanish Steps where we had lunch. The Bernini sculptures were absolutely amazing. If you are planning a trip to Rome, this collection is a must see.

Rome Highlight. Absolutely Worth Doing.. What an incredible showcase of magnificent art! Tours limited to 2 hours, which keeps crowds small and makes the museum visit attractive, but not overwhelming, for almost everyone. The Bernini sculptures and Caravaccio are showcased in such a manner that they are up close and personal. A definite must, if you have the time to visit -- with an added bonus of strolling the beautiful Borghese Gardens.

Loved It. We did a tour, our guide was amazing. she had such a love for the art....she made me want to hear more. The gallery is beautiful with so many precious items. The Bernini sculptures and out of this world, the beauty that can be created out of a piece of marble.

A must see collection! Not for kids though.. Everyone should witness the grandeur of this collection. It is truly remarkable. The Bernini statues are just incredible, some of the most beautiful in the whole world. Both the Apollo and Daphne AND the Rape of Persephone, on the same floor. And the Canova Violet Bonapardte as Venus. So much fun to experience her, she is so clearly loving the attention and her godliness. Note to families - Try try try to avoid bringing any children up to an age where they can appreciate what they are seeing. There were tons of crying babies, and it was very distracting, especially having paid. I couldnt give five stars however because I spent so much time walking around in the crazy Roman heat, trying to find the museum. Once I finally found the building, it took another 10 minutes or so to figure out where to buy tickets. Maybe to some it was obvious, but there are zero signs. And the service is way understaffed- of course there are going to be lines if there is only one cashier at one of the most famous museums in Rome. But whatever- just the walls and cielings of the building itself are enough reason to go. Spectacular.
Great gallery. Book in advance. Neat place to explore. Gorgeous surroundings. Painting are beautiful. The building is also neat to see.

The Originals!. The Borghese Gallery is a collection of some of the finest, original art pieces in the world. The most striking parts of the collection for me were the Caravaggio paintings and all the works by Bernini. His sculptures are sublime in comparison to Michelangelo. BUY YOUR TICKETS PRIOR TO YOUR VISIT USING THE ONLINE SITE - otherwise you risk being shut out for the day. We had tickets for the first morning tour and by the time we arrived at 8:45 a.m., they had already sold out for the day. One must expect navigating through crowds in the gallery. Best to hire the guided tour - guides know how to navigate through the crowds.

I thought I could not stand another Museum. After a week in Rome, I thought that I could not stand another Museum…However the Borghese Gallery surprised me with its collection of art. Even though I have not studied art, there were significant art works that i recognized from memory. Just seeing the Bemini sculptures would be worth the visit.I booked tickets for a timeslot online ahead of the visit. You reserve a timeslot, and need to enter the museum and can only stay to the end of your timeslot.Because everyone enters at the same time, people tend to clump together through the first few rooms. If it did it again, I might skip past the first few rooms to get past the tour groups, and come back later to do those rooms.The park around the Gallery is good for a stroll.

Finest Gallery In Rome. This may be the finest art experience in Rome, and that is saying an awful lot! You must book your reserved time in advance, and you get only two well-enforced hours to visit, but that is plenty of time to enjoy the outstanding painting gallery and remarkable artifacts and sculptures, especially Bernini's "David" and "Apollo and Daphne". Afterwards, stroll through Borghese Park to the Pincio overlooking Piazza del Popolo, which has a fantastic view of the entire city, especially at dusk.

Take a taxi. We walked and were spent by the time we got there. I'd take a cab next time, and don't bother bringing little kids. Lots of beautiful art but my son was bored. Art history buff? Don't miss it.

Amazing. Set in the Villa Borghese (essentially a big park). Entry is timed and limited so call ahead to book a time slot. No bags allowed, free cloak room. The gallery housed some very beautiful paintings, all which could be appreciated in the alloted time frame. Toilet facilities are only for those with tickets.

The one that got away. Please, have an open day at least once a week. This was one of the places you had to pre-book and when we tried to book it was full until the next week.Lesson learned, I suppose. So if you are reading this - book yourself in before you travel.

Best example of Bernini!!!. Beautiful "private " museum in Villa Borghese.. Need to make a reservation as only so many people can be in the museum at a time. I recommend a guided tour. Beautiful Bernini sculptures and historical paintings

Magnificent art and sculpture. A must see in Rome if you are a fan of Carrivagio art. Some wonderful examples of his work and others of the same era. Wonderful sculptures make the gallery the best in Rom

Reservation system lets you focus on art, not crowds. We booked our reservation for the first entry of the day on a Saturday morning. We had a delightfully uncrowded two hours to enjoy the magnificent art in lavish surroundings. Unlike other galleries we visited, the Borghese allows a fixed number of people inside, gives them two hours to browse, and then dismisses them and lets the next group in. It turned out to be a very effective system. Two hours was just about right for a leisurely viewing of the entire collection. We followed our guidebook's advice to tour the upstairs painting galleries first and then head downstairs to see the sculptures. Since this is the opposite of what most visitors do, we found ourselves virtrually alone with some of the paintings (such as Bassano's Last Supper, with the cat under the table) at the beginning of our visit and with some of the sculptures (such as Lorenzo's Apollo and Daphne) at the end.
Well Organized. They keep the crowd to a minimum, with limited ticket sales, so it was an enjoyable experience. I highly recommend. I'm not an art expert, but the works are worth seeing.
Quiet, high quality museum. Book your tickets before you go - they limit the number of visitors. Your entry will be 2 hours long, and that's plenty of time to see everything in this small gem.

Stunning Borghese Gallery. Other than the HUGE walk to get there, it was a stunning collection of artworks spanning centuries that you could get closer to than any gallery I have visited at home. Just wonderful but another visit is required!

Beautiful Museum. You have to make a reservation, so the gallery is not crowded. We signed up for a tour and were fortunate to be the only people in our group! I definitely recommend taking a guided tour.Our guide was terrific. She succinctly described each important artwork and its historical significance. Each room is amazing. There are many fabulous sculptures and paintings. You can only stay for two hours. At the end of our tour, we walked around the adjoining garden, which is a large, grassy park. It did not cost us anything to make our reservation and the hotel made it for us when we arrived. It was called in on Tuesday for Friday, during the busy summer season.

Don't Pass Up this Museum - AMAZING!. We had already done the Coliseum, Capitoline Museum, Conservatori, Vatican Museum and the Pantheon & my husband was already beginning to go into "museum overload" (with Florence & Venice still on the horizon). And then on a misty Sunday morning we went to the Borghese Gallery & it just took our breath away. The Bernini statues are so magnificent you think they will come to life in front of your eyes. Not only is he still talking about them, but the only 'souvenir' we brought home (leather doesn't count), was a small (18") copy of Apollo & Daphne. Make sure to make a reservation (can be done on-line before you leave)

Make time for this gallery!. Getting the advance tickets for the Gallery seemed like a bit of a chore, but it was well worth it. The art collection is fantastic but the building itself is what impressed the most with ceilings that took our breath away- we took two kids (ages 7 and 9) and they loved it.

Don't leave Rome without seeing. This is a small museum so you need to book in advance to see. it is worth it. As an art historian, I've been on many a museum tour but "Skip The Line Tours" at the Borghese Museum and Garden Tour with REBECCA, is a good as it gets!
A must go in Rome. The most incredible place to see the most beautiful sculptures. You must schedule your visit in advance, and I swear it is worthy every effort.

Check out the Borghese but leave time to stroll the park too. Stunning sculpture collection. Room after room of Renaissance paintings. Little museum cafe allows free seating even if you are not buying. Loved the walk through the park. There's a cute children's zoo just down the road that runs in front of the Borghese and past that you will encounter a pond where you can rent paddle boats. Makes for a fun day. .

Excellent gallery. Fabulous Bernini sculptures! They alone are worth going for, but the artwork is excellent too. It is a long walk once you get into the gardens, so plan plenty of time. Buy tickets or make reservations in advance. I suspect a guide would be nice for this gallery as there is quite a bit to digest.

A Must See Gallery. Being the spouse of an artist, I sometimes get dragged to galleries in which I have no interest. While in Rome, we visited Galleria Borghese and it was spectacular. You will need to reserve before your arrival (you can sometimes pick up 'no show' tickets) because they only allow 350 guests in every two hours (and make you leave at the end of your time). This eliminates the crush found in most European galleries. Before your entry time, we recommend joining a tour with an art historian or renting one of the audio players to give you a better understanding of what you're looking at. On entry, go straight to the second floor which is all paintings and very interesting. Almost everyone goes to the first floor first so you'll be relatively alone when you get down there. The reason I found this museum so great was the first floor is almost entirely statues, mostly be Bernini. Michelangelo will always be first but Bernini does things with marble that are unbelievable. We'll go there every time we're in Rome.

Villa Borghese is amazing!. Don't miss this on your trip to Rome. This has some of the best sculptures I've ever seen. Bernini's galore. Make reservations in advance or you won't get in. You can spend as little as 45 min and see everything or take your time. Rome is a city full of art and this definitely takes the cake.

A perfect art experience. I have a degree in art and my husband kindly tolerates visiting one or two galleries on our three week trips. Once in a while we hit a place where he truly gets into it...the Borghese gallery was such a place ! The place is amazing ! Not too large, beautifully laid out, and knock your socks off sculptures displayed in the places for which they were created...it's like being invited to the cardinal's palace to view his collection. You must book ahead...visits are absolutely limited to two hours each and a very specific number of people are allowed to enter at a time...I felt it was all worth it !

breathtaking. amazing very elegance very beautiful gallery and amazing room you can enter without a reservation but you have to wait about 10 minutes and you will enter it worth every euro and they have a cafeteria cheap but the bookshop is very expensive

Breathtaking. Renata, front desk agent at our hotel in Rome, the Aurelius, called the Galleria and got us a reservation in short notice. She told us it was heavenly, and certainly is. It's masterpieces, paintings, the limited amount of people allowed to visit the Galleria is certainly what makes this attraction so unforgettable. The surroundings are also great. Don't miss it.
Bernini!. The Bernini sculptures are amazing - we were blown away! A must see for Rome - be sure to make reservations in advance as they let groups in every 2 hours.

Borghese Gallery - Breathtaking. We were fortunate enough to have a private tour of the Borghese Gallery as arranged with Miles & Miles tours. Our guide, Lucia, brought us in and out of each and every room giving us the history of all the most amazing masterpieces your eyes can consume. It's hard to remember too that YOU MUST LOOK UP as well because every ceiling takes your breath away. Oh and let's not forget this was someone's private home. Don't miss out on this if you visit Rome.

A gem!. The museum is excellent. It is very well controlled so one doesn't feel rushed or overwhelmed with loads of people. While I had never seen this in any previous museum, the strict adherence to time slots allowed for a more enjoyable meander through the museum.

best museum in Rome. This was my favorite museum. While it's smaller than many of the others it has the best overall collection that I saw. The setting is perfect and the way the art is displayed allows it to be fully enjoyed. A definite must see.

Classic. Beautiful displays, well-lit sculptures, good audioguides and books, a must-go for any art-lover. We went in November and it was not too crowded, really pleasant. Very enjoyable walk through the villa on the way.

Very scenic place!. You have to allow a lot of time to enjoy every corner of this huge park. Drinking fountains are there to quench your thirst. Local people jog or walk here even at night. From here, you can walk to the crowded and famous Spanish Steps area (only if you can read the map!). There's a spot near a luxurious restaurant when you can see the city from above on the way to Spanish Steps.

For lovers of classical art. The Borghese Gallery is a must see when in Rome. Pre-booking is advised and may even be mandatory. Although we were advised to arrive at least 1/2 hour before our scheduled visit we arrived 1/2 hour past the appointed time and found no queue and were able to see the entire collection without worrying about time constraints. After the visiting the Gallery leave yourself time to wander in the beautiful grounds.

Ehh, nothing special. The Michelangelo exhibit had nothing really famous of his and the staff/guards were very rude. I understand they have to be protective, but they can do so without an attitude. It was pretty boring and, although not crowded, it was humid in there with minimal places to sit for a little.

Unforgettable Bernini sculptures. "Apollo and Daphne" by Bernini-- awesome and unforgettable! Weeks after our visit, I read Rick Steve's write up in SF Chronicle where he opined that this is the best sculpture in all of Europe. This and the other Bernini sculpture - the rape of Proserpina-- made it all worth a trip to Borghese gallery. Perfect way to end our last day in Rome!
Magnificent Museum. A magnificent museum en the gardens of Villa Borgese.This museum should not be missed on a visit to Rome.Both the buildings and the exhibits are a joy to see.

Absolutely worth doing!. Before we left for Rome, I dithered about booking tickets for the Borghese. I thought the whole thing would be a hassle - being tied to a specific time, having to hand over ID for an audio guide, put off by reports of surly staff! Well, don't dither as I did and get on with booking your tickets! I'm so glad that I did as the Borghese turned out to be one of the highlights of our holiday. It was a little far from our hotel but we took a taxi there so as to be sure not to miss our slot. We arrived about 45 minutes before our 11am visit. Collecting the tickets was completely hassle free - we took all our internet documents with us. We then had time for a coffee before getting our audio guides. I was prepared and handed over my driving licence as collateral so that was hassle free too. Then we got into the queue and were quite near the front when we were let in at 11am.My partner had a small bag with him and he did not have to check it but it is always good advice to ask at the cloakroom beforehand. Photographs without flash are allowed. We started in the pinoteca and there is so much good stuff there. Perhaps the biggest problem is that because your time is restricted in this section, I don't think there's time to listen to all the audio guide entries here so you have to be selective. My favourite things though were on the ground floor. I never expected to be so swept away by statues but the Bernini sculptures in particular as just fascinating and beautiful. His 'Apollo & Daphne' is almost worth the ticket price alone! In addition to all this, every room in the villa as sumptuously decorated - most rooms have painted ceilings. Two hours is plenty of time to see everything and the audio guide is very good. I would say that if you are even slightly interested in art, the Borghese Gallery is a must visit when in Rome...but do book in advance!

Borghese Gallery. Enjoyed the sculptures on the 1st floor, several Bernini's; much more than the paintings on the 2nd floor. The timed visits makes sense to control the flow of visitors. But they need to be far more organized and service oriented at the entrance area; staff were unfriendly almost to the point of rude; you need to turn in all bags, including handbags, to a check area, which is not totally secure. Though it's watched by an employee, the bags are either placed on tables or in lockers which they don't bother to lock. The café only takes cash, which is inconvenient if you've already checked your purse at the check-in and are only carrying a credit card.
pre order ticket. Even with a Roma pass you still had to orders tickets on line or you wont get in. Closed on Mondays. This was a fair amount of walking since it wad far from the metro exit.

Art galore. If you like antique art be prepared for an overwhelming session.
Incredible to think that that building and his content has been someone house. Statues , paintings , mosaics one item steals the attention from the other. Take your time and enjoy.
Must have reservation!

A must to see in Rome. Located in the beautiful Villa Borghese Park, the gallery offers a huge collection of art, we especially admired the sculptures of Bernini and the pintings of Caravaggio. But it is almost impossible to find tickets for the same day, we bought the tickets for the next day, but as the park itself worths seeing, you can go to the park rent a golf buggie or a multi-rider bicycle, have a tour in the park, buy your tickets and the second day visit only the gallery.

Wow... Not to be missed. If you only go to one art museum your whole trip, make it this one!Excellent setting, amazing pictures and sculpture. You will remember many from any art history you may have encountered. Get a reservation/prepaid entry way ahead of time. Folks who don't will be disappointed. Saw many unhappy folks turned away.

Plan a few hours here. The gallery is located within the many rooms of a beautiful villa and well worth a visit while in Rome. Reservations are required. However, we walked in without any and were able to be admitted. Roma Pass gives you entry but it is best to go online and make a reservation as only so many people are allowed in at any given time. And don't miss the magnificent garden and statues at the rear of the villa. Metro line A to the Barberini exit, followed by a moderately short walk(we walked through the park) brings you to the villa and historic gallery.

Do not miss this. This was more beautiful than words can describe. Make sure to make your reservations so that you don't miss out. Easy to get to on Metro system but lots of walking -- but well worth the time and effort. You will not regret seeing this one.

Great for a day!. You have to get the tickets in advance, but really, this is a good thing - not so crowded! I was actually happy to drop my bag at the bag drop and not lug it around (they give you a plastic bag for your valuables). A really amazing museum and great escape from the crowds of other tourist destinations. The park surrounding was nice and cool and very relaxing.

Excellent small museum. You must have a reservation to visit and it`s well worth it. We took the audio guide and it was very good and will guide you through your 2 hours visit. Yes with your reservation you have a time to go in and must leave at a specific time.

Breathtaking gallery!. We almost missed out on seeing this exceptionally beautiful gallery, because we weren't sure what it is all about. There are pieces of art in there, you'll never see in your life again! It sure is worth a visit.
Awesome.. Not just another art museum, this is a special experience, sort of like a mini Versaille Palace. On the lower floor, every square inch from floor to ceiling is amazing.

Simply amazing statues. This is an amazing museum. Even if you are not an art lover, the statues and paintings are simply amazing. You need to book in advance or show up to grab a "no-show" slot. We did the latter. We left the kids in the lobby since they are not terribly interested in museums.

Hidden gem. Off the beaten path, this little gem of a gallery is a ‘must-visit’ for art lovers. Housed in a lovely villa in the expansive Borghese gardens, the Galleria Borghese displays stunning works of art by masters like Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. But the stars of the collection are Bernini’s breath-taking masterpieces - Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Proserpina. Tickets to this gallery must be booked weeks in advance for two hour slots. But like us, if you wait around for a little while, you could find tickets for the next time-slot due to cancellations or no-shows. You could spend your wait time exploring the gorgeous gardens or relaxing on a bench by the lake, taking a breather from the bustle of Rome.

Photography allowed!. I visited this year the Hermitage in St Petersburg, and it is chilling to see how much of the Borghese Gallery is repeated in the Hermitage, even the little paintings on the wall are similar. Stick around for two hours, most people are gone around 1 or 1.5 hour so you will basically have the rooms to yourself the last quarter of your slot. It is stated on the website and on the flyer that it is not allowed to take pictures. I wonder whether they have recently changed their guidelines, because it was now possible to take pictures. This made for a different viewing experience, because now everybody was quite absorbed with their smartphones.

Audio guide was difficult to follow. As other reviewers have stated you do need to book ahead. Our booking was fine but the couple before us were dismissed by reception as their booking had gone 'missing' on the internet. Staff were quite unhelpful to the couple.You need to check-in all bags & you are given a clear plastic bag to carry.The art was great but it was difficult to follow with the lack of signage and audio guide issues.Very busy and crowded.

Great Gallery, beware of rude staff. This gallery is incredible, great art, beautiful rooms, great settings, etc. We didn't have reservations but we decided to take a chance getting there early in the morning,probably 8:30 a.m. 9:00 a.m. on a Tuesday, even do it was a sign "No tickets until next saturday" When it was our turn we show our Roma Pass and they let us in. We noticed that the staff in charge inside the gallery are very rude, we know that you can not take pictures with flash but they were hysterical if someone forgot ,you can hear the screams from far away, and this in a sense make everyone uncomfortable., at one point I wanted to finish my visit so I can stop hearing all this people scraming. So be aware if you visit "Flash off"

Stunning artwork. I stumbled upon the Borghese Galley when looking for things to do in Rome and I'm so glad I found it. The artwork was amazing and I thoroughly recommend getting the audio guide for 5 euros. As a student the price was already reduced and I think highly worth it. You are only allowed in for 2 hours and it is reservation only - but this means that it isn't crowded when you are in. 2 hours was a perfect amount of time for me to walk round the whole building and listen to the full audioguide. The grounds are also very relaxing, you must do this when you visit Rome!

Bernini's masterpieces. Probably the most accomplished sculptures in the world. Baroque masterpieces of movement and energy. Just look at the fingers pressing into the skin. David's concentration as he is about to release his slingshot. A truly wonderful experience although the original over-indulgent Baroque decoration of the galleries doesn't set the key pieces to their best advantage.Book ahead or you won't get in. Places are limited to make it a joy. The Vatican Museums could learn something from these people.

Amazing Bernini!. Absolutely beautiful. Not overwhelming or crowded like the lovely Vatican museums. Highly recommended of you are a fan of art. A great collection. Make sure you pay the small fee for a guided tour (the guide was extremely informational) and explains many of the main pieces and the family history. Amazing Bernini collection.

A don't miss.. I was last here in 1963, and there is huge improvement in the big remodeling. Everything is in beautiful condition, clean and well lighted. I wanted to see Daphne and Apollo again, I was so taken with the piece at 21. I didn't need a guide then. You will need one today. I guess Bernini has been "discovered". The gallery wasn't badly crowded and we weren't rushed at all. I thought it wonderful, and afterward, we roamed the grounds a bit.

Borghese & Gelato. Make sure you have your climbing shoes on, as they are needed. As stated only so many visitors per seating. Basically tickets reflect the number of people versus an actual seat. There are not many of those. Gallery itself varied and in some rooms unbelievably inspiring. Paintings, frescoes and sculpture all completed by masters throughout the centuries. We enjoyed are time and the two hours is appropriate.Side gate walking down along the street toward Rome proper a Gelato store offering two scoops for the price of one. A great day for the arts and the treat.

A Beautiful Museum Experience. Our visit to the Borghese Gallery was definitely a highlight of our trip to Rome. The breathtaking Bernini sculptures and the haunting Caravaggio paintings are just a few of the outstanding pieces of art in this museum. Try to save some time at the end of your two hours of allotted tour time to go back and enjoy your favorite works. Be sure to get reservations ahead of time. Our hotel owners made reservations for us before we came, but you could do it yourself before your visit.
