Beautiful Museum. This is an excellent museum- the Bernini's and Caravaggio's are incredible. Make sure to reserve well in advance. The park surrounding the house is a wonderful place to picnic and relax.
Parc+museum. Good combination of villa borghese parc + museum , with kids , on a hot day. Both stunning, and worth visiting ( close to city center), for a break from the noisy city.

A perfect afternoon activity. The gallery only permits so many persons to visit at a time so advanced ticket purchase is required. Avoiding large tours is recommended. They tend to be oblivious to the space they occupy. The main floor is filled with sculptures, several remarkable pieces by Bernini and beautiful collection of pieces on the second floor but in order to see them all you do have to keep moving or come back a second day.The gardens surrounding the Palazzo are unremarkable and the historic fountains have long been forgotten.

See the Caravaggio, the Raphael, the Statues. Have your hotel make reservations as there are groups allowed to enter by reservation only in 2 hour slots. Take a rainy morning to wander and enjoy the wonderful paintings. Don't forget the statue gallery both in and on the porch.

Incredible Art. If you only go for the Bernini sculptors you will not be disappointed. The man was a certifiable genius and must been seen in person to truly appreciate the depth of his once in a millenium talent. The rest of the collection is also awe inspiring and the beautiful park makes the perfect setting for a pre or post tour picinic. Fantastic

Breathtaking Museum. We were staying in the Via Veneto area for the first time after a few previous visits to the city. We had already seen "the must do's" of Rome or so we thought until we came to the Borghese Gallery. The Borghese Park that we walked through in order to get to the Gallery was gorgeous in and of itself. After getting your tickets down the stairs in the center of the palazzo you proceed up the staircase to enter the museum. The minute you step into the palazzo that was built just to house this amazing collection you are lost in the beauty of not only the art, but also the architecture and decorative arts used to frame the pieces inside. The Bernini sculptures took my breath away. Truly. This is a "must do" in Rome.

Beautiful museum but make sure you have reservations!. Make sure you have reservations before you go!! You must check your purse and backpack before you enter the museum so make sure you grab some money first before you give it to them! I walked in thru the gift shop and they had a little place to buy snacks. I really wanted to knock down a water before I went in but I didn't have any cash with me. :( Next time I am going to make sure I get an audio guide too. I feel like I would have gained so much with that but my art major daughter loved it without. When you are allowed entrance, they usher you up the stairs, and up the spiral staircase, and around the spiral staircase, and around the spiral staircase, until you finally get to the top floor! Whew! What a great museum and the grounds around it are amazing!
WOW!!. Breathtaking sculptures and art. So incredibly beautiful! One of my favorite sights in Italy. Well worth an afternoon.
The icing on the cake. For me, this was the best part of our trip to Rome. Such a huge collection of truly awe-inspiring sculptures and masterpieces! I would go again and again.

Beautiful gallery. Visited Borghese Gallery as part of a conference trip. There were about 100 or so of us booked in for a guided tour. The gallery staff really weren't prepared and there was much confusion over whether to hand your bags in (they absolutely insist you hand your bags in before going in to gallery), how to be assigned to a guide etc. However, once in, all was quite stunning. Our guide was absolutely lovely and clearly passionate about the paintings and sculptures. A lovely gallery built purely to house beautiful artworks. Well worth a visit.

Magnificent Art and Property!. This to me is better than the Uffizzi as it has a wonderful variation of art and has the most beautiful architecture and grounds! Well worth a visit and very easily located in the heart of Roma!
Amazing!. There is nothing to add that others have not said in previous reviews. This is a must see during any trip to Rome.
Wonders of the renaissance. A truly spectacular collection of masterpieces, well worth the need to pre book. The sculptures alone justify the planning needed to visit this gorgeous museum.
Borghese. We made a reservation online before leaving the USA. We loved the museum and the grounds. One of the best art museums we went to.

Wonderful gallery. This was one of the highlights of our visit to Rome. We opted for the Guided Tour in English and the Guide was so knowledgeable and enthusiastic. If I were to do this over again, I would book back to back reservations and take 2 different tour guides-just to spend more time in the gallery. And, while it is officially discouraged, non-flash photos may now be taken-so bring along your camera or smartphone. The paintings and sculptures and the Borghese building were all just so beautiful.

Hidden Treasure. We spent on afternoon at the Borghese Gallery and was very pleased. It is a real hidden treasure. Once we walked thru the entrance, it was breathtaking. Hard to believe that the Borghese's used that building to only entertain. The art work is outstanding. I would recommend taking a guided tour in the gallery to understand the total background and history. We used Angel tours and it was well worth the cost.
The Highlight of our Trip. Going to Rome? Best advice I can give is to reserve tickets to this incredible gallery ahead of time. This was the highlight of our trip.

Walk in the park. Took the Metro to Via Veneto and wandered up to the park. Great walk. Park was beautiful with the museo at the end of a long pedestrian boulevard. Museo was excellent structure, but works were displayed in a confusing manner. Special exhibit of Giacometti was intermixed with the Bernini work. Cafe was great. Good lunch stop. Must have reservations for the Museo as attendance is limited.

Best gallery in Rome. When I was in Rome in 2012 I tried to get tickets for the Borghese Gallery. In my naivety I thought I could get them 5 days in advance, but I was to be disappointed. This trip in 2014 meant that I stayed one day longer than my tour group just to visit it.It is well worth it, particularly for the works of sculpture by Bernini. Get your tickets online before you go. You are limited to 2 hours so make sure you redeem your ticket voucher a good 1/2 to 1 hour in advance so you can make the most of your time once your time to enter arrives. Don't bother getting the ticket express post to you, printing off the voucher works just fine. My ticket was 11 Euro which I got on line 3 or 4 months in advance... you just need to know the day and time you want to visit. When I redeemed my ticket they were selling tickets 'at the door' for a week later, nothing was available sooner. I went on a Sunday and so Also enjoyed the Borghese Gardens... about a 3/4 hour stroll to Piazza Popolo where you can catch the metro back into the heart of Rome. (Two great Carrivaggio in one of the churches in Piazza Popolo... but I saw those last visit, this visit was on a Sunday so only open to those attending mass.

WOW, just WOW!. My wife and I went to several gallerys while in Rome, but this one just blew me away. Bernini is easly one of the greatest artists I've ever seen. His carvings really come alive, the detail that he put into his work is just unbelievable. To carve veins and wrinkles into the marble with this level of detail is really wonderful. If you go to only one gallery when in Rome, make it this one.

A must-see in Rome. A beautifully contained museum - the Bernini sculptures are stunning. the ceilings of each room are gorgeous. Reserve your booking well in advance. The grounds also make for a great walk and house some good cafes and smaller museums.

don't miss. Don't miss this attraction. You can book tours directly through their website. You can access the gallery using the bus system. Just be sure to get directions before you go regarding which stop for your exit and where to catch the bus to return, as they are not in the same location

Selective Admissions. The Borghese Gallery is a privately owned museum, so pre-booking is required to get tickets. Try to do it online before arriving in Rome. Getting there is also a hassle unless you're a familiar with the local bus routes. Please do arrive early as your visiting hours are limited to two-hour brackets and the time of your ticket is the exact starting and ending time. Don't worry, two hours is more than enough to enjoy the collection. Especially so when there is also limited availability of the tickets. I suggest that you either get the earliest 2-hour slot or the ending 2-hour slot. So that you don't have to rush to get to the museum.

Book in advance. This is a very busy gallery and rightly so, the works of art are exceptional. The building itself is worth visiting, particularly if you have ticked off the big ticket attractions in Rome. If you want to visit book before you leave home, you nominate a 2 hour slot for the day you wish to visit and you must arrive early as they will resell your tickets if you are not in time, such is the popularity of this gallery.

Excellent museum, caution about your bags, bring your camera. This museum was a huge surprise during our visit. I visited three of the four Rome National museums -- this better all of them. More in intact sculptures and everything is set in absolultely beautiful rooms. Some important notes:(1) GET TICKETS IN ADVANCE. There was no walk-up when we were there -- there was a sign that tickets were sold out for the next four days.(2) They are serious about not letting you in with a bag or large purse. They will turn you away at the entrance to check your bag and then you get back into the line -- at the back of the line. And, you only have two hours in the museum.(3) We took pictures inside! Guidebooks say that you cannot take pictures, but my wife was told to keep her purse when she was checking her purse. No staff stopped me from taking lots of pictures throughout the place.(4) People move through the museum as a big group because everyone enters at the same time. You don't need to stay with everyone else. We went back to the "first" room about an hour and half into our visit and it was completely empty. (Nice for pictures.)(5) There is food in the basement, but few seats.(6) As part of your visit to the museum, you can spend time in the Borghese park, too. We went on a Sunday afternoon and did a bicycle ride around the park as part of our visit. (Then, we went over the TechnoTown, but that's another story.)

Great Art; not so great staff. The Borghese Museum is a must see for every lover of art and sculpture. The have spectacular exhibits and, unlike many museums, you can walk around the wonderful sculptures 360 degrees...really getting to see the magnificent pieces from every angle.TIP: the museum only allows "timed" entrances during high season and the tickets sell quickly. You should purchase your tickets online ahead of time. There is a 2 euro surcharge, but it is well worth it so you aren't disappointed. When I was collecting my tickets at the desk (purchased online), many visitors whow showed up to buy tickets were turned away because they were already sold out.The tickets have a 2-hour block assigned. Our tickets were 13 euro each and gave us entrance at 3 PM and stated we must exit by 5 PM (a 2-hour) window...which is more than enough time to see all of the major pieces in the gallery/museum.You will also have to check any bags/backpacks you have; they will not allow you to carry them in the museum.I visited every major tourist attraction and museum while in Rome. I can tell you that the staff at this particular museum was the least friendly and least helpful of any place I visited; some of them were just outright rude and offensive. However, you simply tolerate their poor customer service and attitudes at the ticket counter, bag check, and museum entrance and then you are in a wonderful gallery with spectacular art that will make you forget all of their poor service.I rated the Museum a 4...the staff (on this particular day) would get a 0.

Great art but they rush you and the website doesn't prepare you. First, know you should arrive 30 minutes before your scheduled time. Second, the line to pick up the tickets is long. Third, the line to turn in your bags for the duration of your stay is also long. These are the reasons you need to arrive early. Then you line up with the others scheduled at your time and like a herd of cattle you are let into the building. The first floor is large and if you listen to the audio recordings where you are supposed to, it will take an hour. DO NOT stop at the cafe or the bathroom on the way to the second floor or you won't have enough time to explore all of the rooms up there. We did and were sorry. Though the Gallery says you are allotted two hours to see everything, the security and attendants start chasing you out more than 10 minutes before you time is us. Because we needed a quick snack and were chased from the gallery early, we missed about 4-6 rooms upstairs, as did many of the people in our time frame. If you listen to everything you are supposed to on the audio the tour definitely takes more than the two hours max you are given and before of that, I am giving this an average rating. Also, the place is severely lacking in toilets in both the gallery and in the gardens--especially for the volume of summer visitors.

Nice and not crowded because they limit the number of visitors. Great artwork in a beautiful setting. Leave time for the nice park. However, getting there and back by bus was a challenge. The bus stops were changed or cancelled, and it was very hard to figure out how to get back to our hotel. We ran into several other tourists with the same issues, some of whom ended up taking expensive taxis because the bus stops were mysteriously moved or cancelled.

Come for Bernini and Caravaggio. The former villa of Cardinal Scipione Borghese is the place to see three of Bernini's best privately-commissioned sculptures as well as six non-altarpiece Caravaggios (some of his most interesting and personal works). The rest of the collection, however, is average, with a focus on sixteenth-and seventeenth-century Italian painting (outside of Caravaggio, not the best period for Italian art). Raphael's Deposition is a standout, although do not look too closely if you have a weak stomach as the paint surface is exhibiting tenting in areas painted with green pigments. Overall, though, all good fun.

Marbellous!. A wonderful museum, full of over the top galleries with richly decorated walls, marble sculptures by Bernini, and that was just the ground floor. A good audio guide was available which provided a way of navigating thought the various rooms. The limited numbers (session times) allows you to comfortably explore the museum (unlike the Vatican museums) without feeling hemmed in. Fantastic and one of the highlights of our stay in Rome. The whole Villa Borghese was a delightful park and allowed us to take some time out whilst still being in the middle of the city.

Make reservations days in advance. Make reservations days in advance or you might not get in.
Wonderful place to visit. It's a must. Go early and explore the garden.

There are better galleries..... It was highly recommended by Rick Steve and so I made reservations. However, after having been to a lot of other museums and galleries, I think I would have skipped it.

Truly an underrated gem. We love the museums on our travels and the Galleria Borghese was an underrated gem. Fantastic collection in a gorgeous building. Take lots of pictures. Lovely grounds too. Make sure you get reservations for the two-hour period they allow you in. The system works very well and cuts down on overcrowding.

Wonderful collection of sculptures!. Not being an arty couple, and Borghese being away from the tourist center, we didn't visit until our third trip to Rome. We shouldn't have waited. The sculptures are the ultimate all in one place. Not to be missed -- Bernini's Apollo and Diana. The villa itself is worth the effort to visit. Get tickets on line ahead. Confirm directions before entering the park -- not as easy to find as we had hoped. Take a minute to study the map inside also. No need for special guide as each room has very detailed write up for all pieces allowing you to move at own pace. However, two hour limited ticket time is just barely enough even for us non artists.

Wonderful. Visiting the Borghese Gallery was one of the highlights of our trip to Rome. Unlike the Vatican, entry is limited. The gallery was not overrun with people and we were able to enjoy the art. Our two daughters (ages 6 and 8) also enjoyed the gallery. The Bernini sculptures are breathtaking. We booked our tickets in advance - necessary during the summer months.

Best Gallery I have been!. A Gallery that's really well laid out in terms of the painting in each room and succession from one level to another. The staff also limits the number of visitors to enter each time period, hence giving the space to admire and walk around to catch close glimpses of the art and scultpure pieces.Beware, to get booked tickets first else you'll be in for a long queue!

Poor show. Waited in the queue to book tickets. We noticed a sign saying:no tickets until Saturday. However, when it was finally our turnwe were told: no tickets until following Tuesday and, as we were travelling back home on Monday, it was just a big waste of time waiting in the queue. We went to their bookshop/cafe and had lunch. When we needed to use toilets in cafe we were told that toilets could only be used if you had museum tickets. What a joke! Surely if customers use your cafe, they should also be allowed to use your loos. Instead we were told to walk to zoologicalgarden's public toilets, half a mile away. Shame on you!!

Beautiful place to visit. Splendid collection of sculpture and artwork. Crowds are limited by a ticketing system. We booked in advance (an extra fee) and visited on Friday. If you had turned up to book, the next available was the following Tuesday. It's worth the extra so book online.

The most beautiful Bernini are here. The renovated Gallery is today one of the best places to see art in Rome.They are very much organized so it is not so crowded since they have a 2 hours time visit allowance.It is important to order the tickets by internet because otherwise it is not possible to get in.The Bernini family sculptures are fantastic as well as the paintings of the time.After the visit it is nice to walk around the park.
Incredible Bernini Sculptures. Stunning collection! Must have reservations & you only have 2 hours to tour museum. Get there a little bit earlier as you must check your bags.

Peace and Quiet. Location: About a 20-30 minute walk from the center of Rome, depending on which route you take. The place: First, the building (and surrounding buildings) is beautiful. Secondly, the massive park that spreads out before it (Villa Borghese) is absolutely phenomenal. If I lived in Rome, I would be running through that park every single day. The general emplacement of the park and museum offers you a much needed break from the hustle and bustle of Rome. It's quiet, peaceful and secluded. The art: Definitely one of my favorite museums, for it's fabulous sculptors by some of Rome's best artists. I mean, you can't go wrong with this museum. You must look up when you visit the museum because the ceilings offer you beautiful paintings. You just want to lie down on the floor and stare up at them. One of the definite perks of this place is that they only allow 300 people in every 2 hours, so there is no pushing or shoving, no one getting into your personal space and pressing up against you to gaze into the eyes of a sculpture. I saved this for the end of my stay in Rome and I'm glad I did. Price point: 11 Euro, and remember to book online before you leave so you can skip the lines.

Great experience. This is a beautiful gallery and the fact that it is not crowed really lets you see things close up. You must book online or go the day of and hope for openings. The one thing that I had a problem with are the employees seem so unhappy to work there. It has strict rules on line that say you cannot have cameras but everyone had a camera and people were taking a ton of pictures. If you asked a question you just a blank stare. The gardens around the gallery are beautiful plan for a nice walk around them.

One word, Excellent. This was the last of our City Wonders tours, and by far the best. The four masterpieces by Bernini are worth the entry fee alone, especially on my part The David. My wife loved the Apollo and Daphne. The Canova "Pauline Bonaparte" is very interesting too. Since paintings are my forte, it was great to see works by Caravaggio, Raphael, Titian, a hidden Vasari (blink and you'll miss it), a Botticelli (not in guide), the list goes on...And don't forget one of the few female artists of the time Lavinia Fontana...Our tour lasted 2 hours, but you could do with more. Having an excellent guide was a bonus, there are audio guides too of course. Photography is allowed, but I got told off for using a video camera. Mind you this was in the last room, so I'd got away with using it throughout the rest of the gallery!
Great experience. The fact that the villa is not over crowded adds to the experience. Beautiful marbles and fabulous art followed by a lovely walk in the gardens, which ends in great views over Rome

The light made the statues glow.... The museum was what I expected from Rome: gorgeous sculpture and frescoes, with beautiful paintings. I used the full battery on my camera trying to capture the folds in the marble of the statues (without flash, of course)! Breathtaking. Online reservations in advance are a must. We arrived on Sunday with reservations and all entry times were sold out until Wednesday. Take time to rent a riscio bike mobile and take in the Borghese park.

A wonderful experience. This is an amazing gallery full of old master paintings, roman sculpture and three of Bernini's best marble sculptures, in one of the most beautiful buildings in Rome. Once a private collection the gallery is now owned and run by the City of Rome. Advance booking is necessary via the museum's own website which allows you a 2 hour slot to get round. Small cafeteria on ground floor, toilets etc., situated in the Villa Borghese Gardens with cafes and pleasant walks nearby.

Only if you're really into art........ Incredible collection of paintings and sculpture no doubt, one of the finest in Rome. But you'll waste 20-30 minutes of you allotted 2 hour time in line waiting to pick up your tickets. The galleries themselves are nice and the art is incredible. Disappointing to see layers of dust on the sculptures though. Park surrounding the Gallery is very nice and a great place to spend a few hours away from the big crowds.

Don't miss it, or the gardens. After many trips to Rome, we took a private tour of the Borghese Gallery and were amazed at the important artwork contained there. If you are a huge Bernini fan, as I am, do not miss it. The park and gardens surrounding the Gallery are a great place to spend the afternoons just like a Roman!

beautiful collection. This gallery was themed by room - gorgeous collection. The check in of bags was inconsistent - although ours were secure, we noticed other women carrying their purses... You have a two hour limit to tour the Gallery... more than enough time. After touring the Gallery, we rented a two person bicycle to tour the grounds. We pedalled more in one hour than we would have walked - well worth the price.

Our Favorite Museum in all of Europe!. A little-known, relatively little-visited hidden gem in Rome! Advance reservations are a must but so well worth is as this enables crowd control. You can only be in here 2 hrs, which is enough since after that it's pretty much sensory overload in a museum anyway. We are totally enamored with the amazing sculptures, which, in our opinion, steal the show from the other art work. Have been there 3 times and never tire of the gorgeous sculptures. Small enough to really enjoyed and not overcrowded or ostentatious like the Vatican.

Absolutely exquisite and rich in history. Exquisite villa established by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, nephew of Pope Paul V, located just outside the old walls of Rome which houses a number of beautiful paintings, sculptures and antiquities by such masters as Raphael, Bernini, Canova and Caravaggio. We especially appreciated the gallery’s policy of limiting the number of guests at one time within the museum ( 2 hr time frame allowed by “appointment” ) which makes for a much more enjoyable visit. The gallery has a small cafe for a light meal and/or snacks and beverages located below the museum as well as bag check service.

A Rome must visit. The Borghese Gallery was my favorite museum in Rome and in the top 3 of over 50 Italian museums I visited over an 18 day trip. The sculptures, the paintings, the villa, and the grounds were all extraordinary. I would like to share a few tips for the best possible experience:- Make a reservation by phone - no fee - they give you a confirmation number.- Buy the Roma Pass - admission to the Borghese and Colosseum alone cover the pass and you get 3 days of unlimited buses, metro, and other bonuses.- Arrive half an hour early. You have to check in to get your tickets and all bags and cameras must be left at bag check.- When they let you into the museum go straight to the 2nd floor. 75% of the crowd will start on the first floor. Art in nicer with fewer people between you and the masterpiece.- We were at the museum in late April. It was warm and humid inside. There is an outdoor patio with sculptures and benches where you can cool off.

Not impossible to visit without reservations.. A stunning collection, of course, and a top "must see" in Rome. Don't be discouraged if you have not reserved...my son and I were able to get in on a late May afternoon. Another friend was admitted on a June morning at opening time. If there are just one or two in your party it is worth a try. Check out the location prior, or use your map app because the gardens are enormous.
An astonishing collection of artwork. The treasures in the Borghese Gallery are to be seen to be believed. This would have to be one of the most recommended places to visit after the Vatican Museum.

Evening visit. We had reservations for the last entrance of the day and found some of the rooms quite dark, which wouldn't be a problem in the summer months. Bernini is the king here and is not to be missed.
Must visit. Incredible Bernini sculptures. The palace is lavish and first rate. You must book tickets ahead of time online. Be punctual on reservation time because you have two hours only.

Fabulous. This is quite a small and manageable gallery. You have a two hour time period to spend in the gallery and tickets should be bought far in advance of your visit. We visited as part of a 'Rome Walks' walking tour and even in 2 hours we merely scratched the surface. We have put it in in our list of things to do again! The Bernini sculptures are just wonderful and being able to see them up close and in an uncrowded room was very special indeed.The gardens around are also wonderful - walk there and enjoy the peace.

Must see, but book in advance!. This is a must see attraction in Rome. First of all you need to book up in advance as the numbers are limited to 360 people in 2 hour time slots. I booked a few days in advance and there was only one session available from 5pm - 7pm. Print out the email receipt and hand in at the desk to collect your tickets. All bags must be checked into the cloak room. Make sure you allow time to collect the tickets and to drop off your bags. 2 hours is easily enough time to see the whole gallery. It is a very pleasant experience strolling around with a limited number of people.As we were the last session of the day the shop was closed when we were finished. Bear this in mind and visit the shop before the gallery, if you are there for the last session.If you walk through the park and are going to catch the metro from Spagna station, please note it is a long walk from the metro sign to the actual station!

Amazing Museum. I am so glad that we visited this museum. As someone with a degree in Art History whose senior seminar was on Bernini, this museum was a treasure trove (as was Rome in general). Even though you buy tickets in advance there seems to still be a pretty long line. I believe we had to wait for around an hour to get in. I would definitely recommend this to anyone in Rome. And if you have a couple hours to kill after the museum the grounds are beautiful. I wish we had had more time to walk around.

We enjoyed our visit. We enjoyed our visit, do not forget to book your ticket in advance as we did, there is no chance to get the ticket on spot due to the demand. you may combine you plan to visit the spanish steps as it is very close to the gallery.

One of the most beautiful places in Rome.. The Borghese Gallery is a beautiful palace where every wall and ceiling is painted. There are statues everywhere and many by famous artists. Just walking into the main room left me breathless. There are two floors, and many rooms also contain paintings by famous artists. You have to buy tickets online in advance as they sell out quickly and only let a certain number of people in. There are two hour time slots. Ticket pickup is downstairs. There is also a cafe downstairs which is really good for afterwards. Nice museum gift shop too. The outdoor grounds are also beautiful. This was a highlight of my trip to Rome & I will return here.

Book this before you go!. We managed to get a slot a couple of days in advance - our B+B booked for us. You can't just turn up - all visits are at two hourly intervals, and you can't stay any longer than that. Having said that, that's about my maximum in a gallery! Two floors - one for paintings, where you can only stay for 30 minutes. We had gone to hunt for Caravaggio, but actually found paintings of his we preferred in St Maria del Populo. Didn't expect to enjoy the sculpture floor so much - lots to see, and some wonderful work by Bernini.

The best museum tour (yet) in Rome. This is a MUST SEE museum. The art is more impressive from one room to the next, despite the fact that the entrance facade is itself amazing. We booked a private tour with "Through Eternity Tours" and our guide Marco did not disappoint - he was amazing! I would urge you to have a guide as the museum allows you in for three hours and then you are ushered out for the next group. We attended L'Accademia and the Uffizi in Florence. In my opinion, they paled in comparison to the Borghese.

Amazing building and exhibition. What a wonderful museum this is. There is one amazing piece of art next to the other and the interior of the building is equally nice. So no matter if you like paintings, sculptures or nice interior you will truly enjoy this museum. We felt so full after this experience. Note: you have to book in advance using a Roma Card (we sort of overlooked that part, but got in anyway since it was beginning of the morning we think).Also: enjoy the beautiful park around. It is really a nice fit.

Still give it a try if you don't have reservations. The Gallerie was sold out for a week. We decided to show up for the 1 pm opening to see if we could get in. We did get in for free with the Roma pass. Well worth it on a scorching hot afternoon. Great art. The English audio tour was worth the 5 euros. They will ask you to check your bag.
Great collection of art. An amazing museum and excellent collection. If you decided to go make sure to book your ticket in advance. A guid tour would be helpful, there so much to learn.
Roma pass users beware !. 3 days advanced booking required with the roma pass and only found that out on arrival .... very disappointing, especially when a roma pass is only valid for 3 days !!!!!!!

Great museum!. We found the Borghese Gallery to be the best museum in Rome for several reasons. The collection is wide ranging and the setting just beautiful. If you are a fan of Caravaggio they probably have the largest collection anywhere. The other reason is crowd control. You must book ahead of time and you only have two hours for viewing. This gives you enough time to "leisurely" view this masterful collection and not be warn out. (Unlike the Vatican museum which feels like cattle being herded). Without question, if you are a museum lover, the Borghese is a must see in Rome.

Loved it! Don't miss it!. This gallery is job-dropping...so nice and easy to get around. Manageable without giving gallery fatigue! You have to reserve in advance but easy to do on-line and you are given a time-slot to arrive at. Get the audio-guide, well worth it as it brings the stories of the sculptures alive.
Spectacular collection. Loved the art quality shown in its original setting. Ignore the rude staff and enjoy the lack of crowds

Absolute Must-See Borghese Gallery. Even if you are not an art buff, you absolutely cannot leave Rome without visiting The Borghese Gallery. But do book tickets at least a few days before at www.galleriaborghese.it You cannot get tickets on the day - it is always booked out. Just take your booking code on the day and collect your tickets. Get the audio guide - EUR 5 (buy on the day) in addition to your EUR 11 admission price - absolutely worth it, very good audio to explain about the artworks. The Bernini sculptures are sublime. You are limited to 2 hours (I recommend go early and get in at 9AM like I did), but that is sufficient to get around the 15 or so rooms. This gallery has to be seen to be believed; it was the absolute highlight of my 3 week visit to Europe.
A must. Take a guided tour. There is so much to learn. A lot to see . Needs at least 2 hours. If you want to visit the garden, you need an extra hour as well.

Beautiful gardens!. One of the most beautiful places I have ever been. We were here in 2012 and this was one of the places we had to come back to. It is romantic beyond belief and the art is truly amazing.

Glorious!. An amazing, gorgeous building & collection of art! The Bernini statues, the ceilings, the floors, the walls, the art!! Try not to miss it. You must obtain reservations. Each visit can only be 2 hours long. Only 350 people @ each 2-hr. increment, which is nice -- not overly crowded. Good, clean W.C., bookstore is so-so, small, little cafe w/good espresso. We hired a private guide-Richard Bowen & he was worth the price. Wonderful tour & visit!

Exquisite art in an Exquisite Setting. The Borghese Gallery is the perfect art museum. Small enough not to overwhelm you, but filled with a breathtaking collection of some of the world's masterpieces. Although the gallery offers an impressive array of paintings, particularly by Caravaggio, the sculptures by Bernini were simply awe inspiring. They will remain imprinted on my memory for many years to come. The gallery itself is magnificent, with each window casement and doorway painted with exquisite scenes and decorations. The Borghese Gallery is also very intelligently managed so that there is a limit to the number of people allowed to enter within the set time periods. Be sure to reserve tickets ahead of time and be prepared to see art that will leave you breathless.

A small museum with incredible masterpieces!. The Borghese Gallery is easily one of my favorite museums in Rome. It has everything from ancient sculpture to Renaissance paintings, not to mention Bernini's famous sculptures of Apollo and Daphne, Pluto and Proserpina, and David. The Gallery is in the former Villa of the Borghese family, so the rooms of the building are filled with beautifully painted walls and ceilings. While it is necessary to book online in advance and you are only allowed two hours in the gallery, it is well worth the effort to go to this gallery!

Wonderfull, specially for Caravaggio's lovers. Even though we are not sculptures fans, we have to admit that the sculptures collection in the Borghese is magnificent and made us rethink about the sculpture as art.Caravaggio's paintings there can tell so much about his nature and biography.

A wonderful gem. I absolutely loved my time in the Galleria Borghese. Because of the relatively small amount of people allowed at a time, you really get a chance to admire some stunning artwork without feeling rushed or overcrowded. Because you do have a time limit, I recommend reading up on what there is to see before you enter so that you have a good idea of the things that interest you the most and don't end up feeling overwhelmed by how much you still haven't seen when you're halfway through your tour.

Not to be missed on a trip to Rome!. From the setting in the Villa Borghese to the building itself, to the incredible art inside, this was one of the high spots of our trip to Rome. The opportunity to see several of Bernini's masterpieces (done before he was in his mid-20s) up close and personal is worth the visit by itself. All of the other works, architectural, sculptural, painting, etc. make this a work of art itself.

Very pretty gardens, great museum. For someone who wants to take pretty pictures in Rome, close to Hotel Majestic, this is a good place to go to. One of the attractions via Roma Pass, it has beautiful gardens, art and great views.

Overwhelming!. Liked: the plastic cards explaining the ceiling treatments and other room decorations Liked: loved the various sculptures and frescoes and paintings.Liked: reservation limits the number of people in museum.Not like: no where at all to sit...Not like: the follow the lines approach Not like: large tour groups with translator headsets crowding rooms one pack after another..this would crowd out smaller or individuals.

Beautiful place. A glorious place to see Bernini statues and Caravaggio paintings. Beautifully decorated. Advanced booking direct with the website saves money and time on arrival as you have time sllots to visit.

One of the nicest museums. One of the nicest museums with a large variety of painters and artists and sculptors- definitely worth the visit. Some tips: prebook in advance as it was sold out for a week when we got there (luckily we had tickets). Also, take the train ride that stops just in front of the entrance to the museum. Only 3euro per person and you get to see a lot of Villa Borghese.

get confused using the audio aguide. we booked on line ahead of our visit which was really important - recommend that you do this - whilst the gallery was interesting we hired an audio guide which basically guided through the rooms but starting from the old entrance which was on a different floor - they basically need to update the audio guide to reflect the new route through the gallery

Sublime art guarded by thugs. Beautiful collection of spectacular pieces by re known masters as well as other lesser artist in a gem of a palace. Far more impressive, in my opinion, than Vatican because the number of visitors is restricted and traffic regulated which allows for leisure viewing. Apollo and Daphne is truly breathtaking. Now, be prepared to be abused, insulted, condescended by the staff at galleria Borghese. I presented my prepurchased tickets to the one and only person checking in all those in the 9 to 11 viewing and she was pissed because evidently one must bring copy of the invoice as well - almost dismissed me expecting I would walk away - good thing I'm from New York. The person where one checks in personal belongings mumbled something about what may be brought in and what may not before grabbing my bag and tossing the check my way. There were no brochures in English (needles to say many English speakers in the crowd), when someone asked, they just pointed at the stack where everyone had already looked. The people at the coffee shop, by far the nicest of the bunch, make very good coffee. Enjoy.
2 hour time limit is not enough. We enjoyed the gallery but needed more time. Advance reservation required. Get the audio tour need the min 50characters but don't have anything else to report.
excellent collection- amazing tour guide Daniela. the collection is incredible and our tour guide Daniela was excellent- she made the art come alive- her passion was infectious!

Stand out experience. A homage to Bernini, Caravaggio and other leading artists of the Renaissance, as well as a stunning building within the Borghese park. Book before you come on your trip or you will miss this extraordinary feast for the eyes. You get 2 hours to do your viewing, and the numbers of visitors are strictly controlled so you do get to wander at your own pace and to stop and see whatever you want to stop and see without a shuffling crowd getting in the way. Buy the audio guide if you don't know the pieces and paintings, it has been carefully made to fit the allotted time with enough space for you to admire each room (and its ceiling) happily.A true highlight in the city.

Excellent Collection. Loved the Bernini sculptures. This is a terrific collection, and relatively small so you can enjoy it in a manageable time. In fact, you need reservations and the reservations are for two hours, which is sufficient time. Since visitors are limited, you're not overrun by others (see Vatican museums). If you have any interest in art, you'll be glad you went.
A special treasure. Tickets are strictly limited and need to be ordered in advance. The beauty of the setting, building and collection is breath taking in a city filled with treasures.

Did not live up to the hype. I am not sure why Borghese Gallery is considered so special among the Rome museums that a reservation is required in advance in order to the visit the museum, the museum guide calls it the best in Rome (and even the world?) and the washrooms are only accessible if you present your ticket ( really?). I almost feel like there is some kind of hype generated here, because the art collection is not that big or great, certainly less than Palazzo Barberini that was virtually empty when I visited it. Don't get me wrong, there *is* some worthy art here, but I would say the Barberini has the more extensive and better art collection, virtually no crowds, and the mansion itself is stunning inside. And it does not require reservations. If you have limited time, that is the one to go to, not the Borghese Gallery.

excellent gallery. we had booked online and told them we'll pay with our Roma pass. arrived by 8.30 at the side musee entrance... many people try and negotiate their way through the gardens , but it might be a tiresome process to trace the right route. with the limited number they let in to the gallery, we had a great time admiring the collection in peace. only whinge--wish they allow photo without flash like other museums
Go there many times. I wll be back! 2 hours is too short. Absolutely i suggest everyone to go there. Maybe next time it will be enough time.

Buy ahead. Could not rate this as Rome was so full of tourists in May that we did not get tickets in time to see this, should have bought them before we left or very early in our trip. In fact we missed out on several places due to crowds and not getting skip the line tickets early. So heads up for others learn from our mistakes

Roman luxury. Borghese limits your stay to 2 hours. Further proof of its excellence. Since, seriously, you can't absorb its beauties in any multiple of the time you'll have, give yourself over to a quickie. You won't be sorry. The other side of their policy is -- no overcrowding! Our tour hosted by Felix was just right, you sensed his passion for the works but he avoided the Scylla and Charybdis of corny/stuffy.Extra points for the entrance floor cafe, where a perfect after-tour snack was a rare Roman bargain.
Beautiful Sculptures and Art. This gallery has a beautiful collection that even a novice viewer can appreciate. You only have a 2 hr window to go through the gallery but that was plenty of time.

Outstanding Art at the Galleria Borghese – But don’t forget to up look at the ceiling!. My partner booked tickets for us to the Galleria Borghese two and a half weeks before we went to Rome. First he had asked a mate in Milan if it was necessary to buy tickets in advance and this mate didn't really think so, but after reading advice on TripAdvisor I insisted that he call the gallery and ask. Then he was allowed tickets on the Friday we wanted but at 17:00 hrs (last entry of the day closing at 19:00 hrs.) instead of at 11:00 am as we had originally thought. This may prove that Italians themselves do not visit their own museums very often, as if we had listened to this friend’s advice we would not have got in. So, booking well ahead is essential! When we arrived a little early I was somewhat startled to find that all visitors had to leave their bags, cameras, telephones etc. with a security reception – it was difficult being parted from my bag with wallet, plastic cards, mobile etc. and my partner had to hand in his zoom lens camera – but we and everyone else received a numbered tag to guarantee safe keeping of belongings. There were two security guards in the reception who assured that all belongings would be safe, so we decided to relax and trust that. The Galleria’s book and gift shop is right beside the security reception, we bought the Galleria’s own book instead of the audio guide, anything bought in the shop was allowed in, this was nice to refer to when at the specific masterpiece. When we and all others were allowed in at 17:00 hrs it was a delight to be surrounded by the most wonderful paintings and sculptures  My partner had especially come to see Bernini’s Rape of Persephone, one of the main exhibits in the Galleria. This marvel we found almost at once just by walking straight ahead into the first room from the main entrance hall – it is a wonder of course, how someone managed to make such a statue out of marble – stone – and then to make it so full of life and beauty, in spite of the subject of Spring itself being seized and drawn down into the underworld. The genius Bernini was also responsible for the lovely Apollo and Daphne, the god and the wood nymph turning into a tree, so beautiful from whatever angle you look at it. There was much to see at the Galleria, each room seemed to be filled with more paintings and statues, we also went upstairs to the second floor, less crowded and more spacious but also here the walls were hung with paintings absolutely worth the climb up the stairs. We both love Caravaggio, and room 8 of the Galleria is filled with his paintings, fantastic! Caravaggio’s art was controversial in his own time, not very difficult to understand but he was surely an artistic genius. Something else very special about this room is the ceiling! People look up when you are in room 8, there are fantastic paintings of incredibly lifelike 3-dimensional Satyrs who almost seem to be coming down (!) from the ceiling at you! Don’t miss this! When you go out the door to the right and into the main hall again (where everyone comes in) Look up again at the ceiling in this room! Exquisitely painted – no satyrs here but beautiful pastoral scenes. It’s good to just stand still, look up while resting head on hands for support, and enjoy what you see. We thoroughly enjoyed our hour and a half (didn’t need 2 hours) at the Galleria Borghese and recommend to all Travellers who enjoy Italian masterpieces, worth every cent of the ticket price! And indeed our belongings were safely collected from security!

Truly worth the visit. Amazing collection of Bernini sculptures! Also loved the frescos on the ceilings. There is a lot to see in 2 hours but since only 200 people are allowed at a time, no crowds to worry about.
Art History lovers will be blown away.. A treat for the eyes and souls. The Bernini sculptures and the Caravaggio paintings are worth the trip to Rome in and of themselves.

Best museum I've seen. This was, hands down, the best part of our time in Rome. Every single part of the museum is covered in incredible artwork. The Bernini sculptures completely blew my mind. I have never really cared too much about sculptures, but I could have stared at them all day. Incredible.
Don't Miss It. Make sure that you book ahead to ensure entry on the day that you want. Absolutely wonderful to visit. Do some research to find out what works of art are there, they are all brilliant.

Excellent gallery and tour. Even at its most busy, the Borghese offers a quiet reprieve from some of the hectic-ness of Rome. Most people seem to use the audio guide, but we opted for the English language tour, which was only a little more, and was worth it to me. I don't know if we just got lucky, but our tour only had six people! Our tour guide was very knowledgeable about the collection, and provided information not just about the art, but about the space as well (what the rooms had been used for, changes in them, etc.) I enjoy art and have taken some art history classes, but having a tour guide helped me notice more subtle details that really make some of the pieces impressive. The tour probably isn't necessary to appreciate the museum, but I definitely recommend it.

Beautiful collection of famous statues and paintings. Book in advance. Galleria Borghese was one of the highlights for me. Not only stunning statues by Bernini, but also famous paintings by Caravaggio and Rafael. An other plus is that it's located in a park, so an escape of the busy city center.In high season make sure to make a reservation prior to your arrival. Luckily I had booked via internet because on arrival the tickets were sold out for the next 4 days.If you like background information, buy audio guide for 5 euro's because there are only a few signs with name of artist and work, but no further information.

Borghese Beauty. The Borghese Gallery is located adjacent ot the Borghese Gardens and contains paintings, sculpture and antiquities. There is so much to see...allow yourself two hours and make sure you reserve a entrance time for the museum or you won't be able to get in. The museum is closed on Mondays and unfortunately there is no picture taking. There are audio guides (in five languages) and guided tours (only in English and Italian). This impressive building was once the residence of Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the nephew of Pope Paul V, and now as an art gallery includes works by some of the most brilliant Italian and foreign artist including Titian, Caravaggio, Bernini, Raphael, Rubens, Canova and many others. The ground floor is mostly devoted to classical antiquities of the 1st–3rd centuries AD. My favorites include Bernini's sculptures "Apollo and Daphne" and "Rape of Proserprina" but his sculpture "Truth Unveiled" and his David are also magnificent. Canova's sculptue "Pauline Bonaparte" is the center focus of another room. The Borghese also houses The National Museum of Musical Instruments a collection of instruments from around the world. And of course there's a gift shop, as well as a small cafeteria on the below ground level.

Not to be missed. Book ahead online for the Borghese Gallery and arrive a little ahead of time. The excellent audio guide is a must. Visits are limited to two hours. Along with a spectacular art collection you get a history of this Pope and his family. If you only have a short time in Rome this is a mist.
Gardens........ The Borghese Gardens are FREE.....and lovely. A nice respite from the tourist heavy sites. A lovely large park ( not so much gardens).

Underappreciated but fantastic museum. We really enjoyed visiting this gallery. You must get timed tickets in advance (at least several weeks) then pick them up at the box office window. You must also check any cameras, backpacks or large bags, although I was allowed to hang onto my purse. Tickets are for specific times and you only get 2 hours to view the gallery, so you must really hurry if you want to see it all. Once inside the gallery, don't start in the first room, move into another room to avoid the crowds that start in that first room. Each room has a theme and unbelievable treasures. Many of the rooms have beautifully frescoes walls and ceilings, as well as paintings, sculptures and mosaic floors. As another poster mentioned, the statue of Apollo Chasing Daphne is probably the finest piece in the entire gallery, and the most beautiful sculpture I've seen except for the Pieta. In each room look for a small rack that holds laminated cards about 11x18, that describe all the items in the room. These cards are in different languages, some have English on one side and Italian on the other, and sometimes you will need more than one card per room (one describes the frescoes and another the paintings). You use it while in the room then return it to the rack for the next visitor. Very helpful. After visiting the gallery, be sure to spend a little time strolling through the grounds. It is lovely and peaceful and from the gardens, you can't even hear the hustle and bustle of Roman traffic around you. This gallery is not as well known as the other attractions (Vatican, Colosseum, Forum) but it is well worth the visit.
Beautiful. Love this place and the Borghese Park, get some bikes and go see the gallery, you must book a time slot, some incredible art to see.

quiet gallery in a serene park - must book in advance - do the tour. There's high demand for this gallery and they limit the places with rigid 2 hour time slots to control crowding. The tours in English (extra 6.50 euro) are in the morning and are well worth doing if you're not a renaissance art expert. The sculptures show a lot of the process of creation if you understand the process or get educated via the tour. It would have been nice to have an extra 15 minutes post tour to browse around. There's also an audio guide for 5 euros (cash only, of course.)It does have the usual Italian features as per Ctemple27's recent review. I was there on the Sunday and thought I'd book for later in the week when I was planning to use my Roma Pass. I was told that I had to call the phone line to book which, of course, was closed on a Sunday. When I questioned remaining availability for my last two days in Romes it was low and therefore likely that there would be no availability by the time I could reserve a place. In an unusual and refreshing move the member of staff realised this was a ridiculous predicament and gave me a reservation number.Closed on Mondays like majority of Rome's museums. After all, massive demand in tourist season, why not close on an arbitrary day? You expect this weirdness in France but the Italians have followed suit.The park is very nice too and a wonderful place to get away from the traffic and siren noise of Rome.

An absolute must see. We visited Galleria Borghese yesterday and were absolutely blown away. I am not generally a lover of sixteenth and seventeenth century art; but the Galleria is enough to change my mind. Everything about it is extremely well done: it is quiet, intimate, and extremely well arranged. I would rate it with l"Orangerie in Paris.I agree with Emgiesz: I would have paid just to see Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. But I also would have paid just to see Titian's Sacred and Profane Love and Caravaggio's St. Jerome. And speaking of Caravaggio, where else can you see six (!) of his paintings in one room?But Ctemple 27 makes one correct point: you need to book in advance. I would do it before you leave home as you are going to have to print out a copy of your receipt and that may be difficult to do once you get here.

Serene. The Galleria Borghese offers you a respite from the sometimes, chaotic, streets of Rome. You need reservations for a timed ticket. The reservation provides you with two hours of viewing the collection of magnificent sculptures . Please get an audio guide. If you are late for your reservation, they will still let you in, minus the time you missed. At the end of the two hours you reserved, your time will be up. The gardens are so pretty and you can visit them after the interior visit. It is all very breath taking and a most important part of your visit to Rome. It is truly beautiful!!

Remember to get tickets at least 2 weeks before you plan to visit. Limited tickets are sold and if you are in the gardens of the villa and need a toilet you won't find one. If you try the toilet in the gallery and don't have a ticket they don't let you in. Very Italian. The maps are hopeless and there are not enough signs, the place is huge and it's hard to find your way. As usual nobody will help you, they will give you a minimum of info with the vital bits missing.

Apollo Chasing Daphne: stunning. I would have paid to see the one Bernini. Apollo chasing Daphne is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen. In my life. Period. Everything else is nice and all, but dear god. That statue is breath-taking and absorbing to the the point where you just gape at it and walk around it in endless circles. You have to see it in person at least once in your life. Bernini gave magic a physical form in this piece.

Borghese Gallery. Do a tour with guide or at least the audio tour - there's so much to see here without the guide you will miss a lot of the back ground and history. Also located within a beautiful park to walk and relax in.

Fantastic Place. A great museum inside a beautiful villa set in the attractive surrounding gardens.This museum has a number of Bernini sculptures, and other world class Baroque sculptures. Plus, paintings by Raphael, Titian, Rubens, and Caravaggio. If you like Bernini then this is a place to see several of his works from as close as a couple of feet if you'd like. Awesome.You MUST have reservations which are easy to do online. Get these at least several days ahead of time to be sure you get the time slot you want. You are limited to two hours so planning how you want to go through the exhibits is important.There are some guided English speaking tours available. We wanted more flexibility than that and went with the well done audio tour which is a bargain at 5 euros each.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

Small but packed with art. Bought tickets online through galleries service, picked up at ticket desk when we arrived, was very easy. Staff makes you check everything. Had to check an umbrella but seems a chosen few people don't follow the rules regarding cameras and small purses and were not caught. Well laid out and saw everything in the 2 hours allotted. Somewhat hyped but worth the visit just the same.

realy interesting. Although we are not 'culture' types we enjoyed this visit.Special thanks to our guide, whom we got inside the gallery,and who explained in detail the exhibits, so we could appreciate more these pieces of art. Remember to book well in advance your tickets because it's always crowded.

Prior Reservations Must. We found the Borghese gallery and the villa and the gardens really nice. The gardens, while not the best, they are worth a stroll or a few hours if you have enough. The artwork inside is splendid and if your are a art lover then this place is a must for you. The biggest problem is tickets. Make sure to check for tickets preferably 2-3 weeks in advance or even more because they have a limited entrance and you wouldnt want to be left out for a silly reason like not having checked the website.

Caravaggio works. Had no expectations of this part of the tour and was totally ignorant about the place. Amazing works of art on display especially Caravaggio . The tour guide was excellent but could have warned us about how strict the policy is on no photos. One of our group had a camera confiscated as we were unaware and took pics in the portico before entering the palace proper. Loved the sculptures too. There is a reasonably priced cafe at the exit. Try and avoid the school groups though. They could make more money fro tourists with a more extensive gift shop as we couldn't find anything as a souvenir . Highly recommend a visit here.

Meh!!. This was a mediocre museum. There are enough paintings and statues to admire for 1 hour-1 hour and a half. Nothing too spectacular if I am honest, if you have seen one you have seen them all. They do delicious smoothies in the cafe.

Wonderful but a little crowded.. Wow mind-blowing - this is certainly worth visiting. You need to pre-book and I did it through Trip Advisor. I suggest you do it before you leave home. Fills up really quickly. Hightlight Bernini - Apollo and Daphne. Caravaggio and many other artists featured. With my limited knowledge of art history the guide was priceless.

Doesn't live up to the hype. We visited during a 5 day stop in Rome as this museum was on every "Must See" list we stumbled across while planning. And while the experience of visiting the museum was good, the art inside definitely did not live up to the hype for us. Pros: -While getting reservations seems like a hassle, we found it easy to do by phone and we had no problems with our reservation at check-in. I was a little worried at not having something in writing, but as we used this as part of our Roma Pass, I didn't want to advance pay for tickets and it turned out to be no issue by phone, for free. As far as the bad reviews from people who just turned up and didn't get in-it's not hard at all to discover that reservations are required and you usually only have to plan a couple weeks in advance. Unless you read absolutely nothing prior to arriving in Rome, the required reservations will not come as a shock.-It may seem stingy to limit the number of people allowed in and the time you're allowed to peruse, but we found 2 hours to be plenty of time to see everything and it was nice not to have to fight the crowds to see something. There were a few museums we visited during our time in Italy that we actually left after 20 minutes or so because you just couldn't see anything without having 20 others people right by you, in your line of vision, stepping on your toes, etc. Not so at the Borghese and that makes for a much more pleasant visit.-The park surrounding the museum is lovely and it was nice to see some locals walking dogs, walking or jogging. It was a nice break from the usual chaos of Rome and felt like a world apart by the time we reached museum.Cons:-This is not a museum you can get through without using the museum's audioguide, a detailed guidebook or hiring a guide/tour. While I realize this is the reason museum's offer audioguides and Italy especially seems to rely on these rather than give good explanations of the art near the displays, I don't like having my hand forced. The Borghese is already expensive. To then have to pay extra to understand what I'm looking at is disappointing. Were I an art scholar or paid the extra money for one of the above options, I wouldn't have had this problem. But I would prefer that the option to learn more be an option rather than the rule and at the Borghese, never mind learning more-you don't even get a simple explanation of what it is you're looking at. There's a portrait of a woman...and that's all you know. No mention of the artist, date, who the woman might be, etc. Maybe I'm a spoiled American who has gotten used to having these little signs at the art museums I visit, but we visited numerous museums in Italy where they explained what we were looking at. If we wanted to know more about the piece, we would have to pay for an audioguide, etc., but the information about the piece itself was evident. The Borghese didn't do this and as a result, you're either lost or giving up more of your money to learn the basic facts about the art around you.-Most of the art is unexceptional, in my opinion. Lovely, but nothing that really sticks out. I should add that I am more of a history fan and not into sculpture so maybe that's why this didn't thrill me. But for the most part the pieces look like a lot of other art you see in a lot of other museums in Rome. And I say this without the conflict of museum fatigue as we visited the Borghese on our 3rd day in Italy. Also, while I have no problem with their no pictures policy, this actually made our visit to the Borghese worse because I can remember almost nothing save for a few Caravaggios. So that tells you the lasting impression the art had on me.If you're an art scholar/fan and/or don't mind paying extra for an audioguide, your own guide or a book that walks you piece by piece through the museum, then the advance planning and cost the Borghese requires won't bother you in the least. If you're only moderately into art and would rather just see the "big stuff", there are plenty of other, better ways to spend your time in Rome. I read that advice in several places and ignored it because this museum kept being touted as a "Must See." Now I wish I would have listened and spent my time more wisely. For the average tourist, it doesn't live up to the hype.

Didn't get in. Cant really review this properly as we turned up to find that tickets were fully booked for that day and the next 4!It's nothing from the outside so if you want to see the art collection my advice is to pre-book tickets although we may just have hit on a busy period. Everyone was turning up with tickets bought and downloaded from the internet.Gardens nice for a stroll though I didn't think they were particularly well kept.

Absolutely amazing!. Rebecca was our guide for this amazing tour of the Borghese Gallery and gardens. Her enthusiasm and knowledge was outstanding. With her vivid descriptions she brought the statues and paintings to life. We could not have asked for a better guide and her passion has definitely left us wanting to learn more about the artists and their works. Thanks to Rebecca we are now big fans Bernini!

absolutely magnificent. Not to be missed. The combination of a truly sumptous villa, incredible sculptures by Canova and Bernini and paintings make this a true highlight of any Rome visit.Reservations are a must which means that the Galleryis never crazily crowded and the audioguide is excelllent.In our view, the most beautiful museum in Italy.

beautiful artwork inside. impressive art collection of the Borghesse family. Booked online a month before, for 2 hour visit in this Gallery...the audio guide (5 euro) was very informative and really help to understanding these magnificent artworks. No camera inside and all bags and carry on must be stored in locker near ticket office. take bus 116 to the garden and walk 10 minutes to the Gallery, on the way back we're take a nice walk down to Spanish steps via porta Pinciana

Outstanding Art and Scuptures. If you only go to one art museum in Rome, make sure its the Galleria Borghese. The Galleria houses outstanding sculpture and artworks. Cardinal Scipione Borghese was a true protector of the arts and commissioned a young Bernini. Here you will find Bernini's "Proserpine's Rape", "Apollo and Daphne" and "David throwing a sling". l could not stop staring at the astounding Proserpine and Pluto sculpture. Pluto is holding her and the pressure of his fingers is leaving imprints on her thigh and abdomen. It made me want to cry..this is stone! The Galleria is divided in two sections: the Museum is on the ground floor and displays the sculptures, while on the upper floor the Galleria houses its collection of amazing paintings. Several important paintings are here, among them outstanding works by Titian and Raphael. My favorites are the beautiful Caravaggio masterpieces: the "Madonna of the Grooms", "St. Jerome", "St. John Baptist", "David with Goliath's head", "Young man with a Fruit basket", and the "Little Bacchus" .A couple hints:- Book your tickets online, only x number of people are allowed in for 2 hours only. This means you will run out of time. Do your research first and determine which pieces are most important to you. Visit them first, then rest of collection. When they told me time was up I wanted to hide someplace so I could stay. - Get an audio guide. They are essential unless you are a knowledgeable art historian.- Do not bring a camera and knapsack. If you do you will need to check them. NO pictures.- Give yourself lots of time to get there. When you ask a Roman for directions and they say 'it's just over there'..over there can be 2 miles.

Beautiful place . This is simply fantastic. The art on display is beautiful. For us its the perfect setup in terms of size and time. Booking is a must but it is worth it. The lack of crowds due to the strict time code really helps. I found this more enjoyable than the Vatican museum which was way to packed.

Reservations only. A distant walk from our hotel. Pantheon, Piazza di Espana, Piazza Popolo are all on the way. But when we got there, only people with tickets bought in advance were admitted. None were available for 2 more days. Very disappointing.
A pleasant afternoon. We visited this and the Borghese Billa (which is a garden not a Villa) - well worth a visit and reasonably priced.

Beautiful. By far one of the most beautifully done museums in the world. Extensive but not exhausting and was a very pleasant walk to the gallery through the gardens surrounding it. We were so lucky as we bought tickets the same day (bought them at 1245pm for a 1pm slot) as a family returned 2 extra tickets at the same time we showed up. It is definitely possible to get in the same day but as we experienced the lines to get in, I would imagine you would not want to risk it like we did and I suggest to go for the online/advance reservations. You have a max of ~2 hours to see the entire gallery and it might be worth it to read up on the famous works inside prior to walking through to get some background. It was five euro for an audio guide which we thought was very helpful.

Amazing art in a managable gallery. The Borghese Gallery has so much wonderful baroque art, but the best thing about it is that, unlikely many galleries, it's small enough to enjoy in a morning or afternoon and it's overwhelming. It's also set in a large park, which makes a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city.
Bernini the master. Only for art and beauty lovers....audio guide is a must. Do not walk in otherwise. I do visit it at least once at year

Great Art Collections. This art gallery is located at the outskirts of Rome. This is a mini version of the enormous Chateau De Versailles in Paris. It houses great collections of painting and sculptures. Too bad it does not allow to take photos. There is mini train shuttle going around the Villa from the galleria. One of its stop is the nice view of Piazza del Popolo.

Lovely. Doesnt matter if you are an art expert or just someone curious, thats a place you shouldnt leave Roma without take a look, be aware that you need to make reservations before, i went there last april and many people that didnt book it were refused to access it.We did the appointment by phone, 3 days before, the art galery sounds amazing, you could stay an entirely day and even then, would need more time to feed your own eyes....the only thing i didint like was the sense of hot inside, my God, wasnt nice, had took off my scarff and coat, and even then....The green field that surround the Galery is something apart, just walk through it it pays off the walk.

One of the world's best. This museum is always "sold out." Except it isn't. Just arrive about 30 minutes before one of their official entry times and ask if tickets are available. If you are a small group - 2-3 people - it should work. Or make a reservation online before your trip. Be aware that after two hours they throw you out of the museum to make room for the next group!

great small museum. this museum is fantastic for its' settings in villa borghese park, and for the number of masterpieces it exposes. It is relatively small, therefor manageable to visit with children, and easy to combine with a walk in the park. It also has a very good layout, so that it isn't crammed with art that overwhelms you. It isn't a stressful experience like many museums in Rome, on the contrary it is quite a relaxing experience. among the different masterpieces, there is also my favourite statue by Canova. you should reserve in advance for tickets, it might be booked otherwise.

Magnificent art, poor quality staff. We had to book and the first time was a week after we arrived which worked for us. Prior to our allocated time we walked through the park in order to get our bearings and check out the location and procedure. Both the staff we spoke to were frankly awful. On the day of our booking we arrived 45 minutes early as we had to get our tickets, get a printed guide but none were available in English. Then we weren't allowed our audioguide until 20 mins before our entry time. The audioguide is the most illogical we have ever used and needs to be improved. Overall great paintings, wonderful sculpture, lousy lousy service.

Best Picture Gallery. One of my favourite museums in the world. First of all for the selections of paintings mainly centered on the Italian Reinassance, Marnnerist and Baroque periods; secondly because only here you may find the best baroque statues: masterpieces by Gianlorenzo Bernini commissioned to him by the Borghese cardinal-nephew; thirdly because of the "container", infact the building of the Galleria borghese displays astonishing marble, mosaics and fresco decorations in every room from the floor to the ceiling.As a Tour Guide I've been here many times!

Fabulous, well displayed art in a great setting. We visited in early May after making an online reservation a couple of weeks in advance. We went first thing in the morning and the gallery was not that busy. This is one of the better galleries to visit in Italy in terms of quality of art and a reasonable experience while enjoying it. Be sure to go for a walk or a bike ride in the park afterward if the weather is nice!

Missed the attraction due to a nasty fall on the way out of the Metro. We made our way over there but when we came out of the metro, having been up escalators and on two travellators we were met with waste ground and no signs at all. Looking out for signs I had a nasty fall, tripping up on all the debris that was lying around. I was quite seriously hurt and we had to turn back. I am annoyed a pathway was not laid and no signage at all. We therefore missed the attraction. A warning to others, be careful! A message to the organisers, get the route sorted!

A green jewel of a park and spectacular gallery. This could be the best, relatively unknown attraction in Rome! We liked the limit on people in the museul - we had an entry time (no waiting!), and the experience was uncrowded, unhurried. The quality of the art in this gallery may be second only to the Vatican. The pieces by Bernini and Caravaggio were truly amazing. Our guide was also the best of our many tours in Rome. Rebecca is an American guide living in Rome. Her knowledge of art history was incredible. Her energy and passion for the masterpieces at the Bourghese Gallery was contagious, and her charm made the tour very enjoyable. Of course, her ease of communicating in American English was also a huge plus. She even recommended other tours and local restaurants for us afterwards, so we can’t say enough good things about her. If only all of our tours were as nice! The Borghese Park, which surrounds the museum, is free and very beautiful too. A nice afternoon could be had picnicking in the park, enjoying the grounds, and then going on this tour with Rebecca. We stayed in the Vatican area, and bus 116 took us right where we needed to be. Secret tip - walk back to the edge of the city. The view of Hadrian's wall and the elevated view from the north over the old city are both wonderful.
If you have any appreciation for art, don't miss this.. Place reminds me of the Hermitage. Fantastic Bernini sculptures, beautifully adorned ceilings. This place is just terrific!!!
Art Lovers Do Not Miss. An un-missable experience in a beautiful park. Plan to make best use of two hour timed visit. Well organised visitor experience. Audio guide well worth paying for.

A Must See. If going to Rome, this should not be missed. Must make a reservation (~week in advance)...online or by phone. Small chance same day ticket could be available on-site, but not while we were there in mid to late May. The reservation system helps make it more enjoyable by strictly limiting the # of people/duration. This is unlike the Vatican Museum which gets overcrowded even on a slow day/time. No photos allowed, must check all bags/purses (free and secure). All of the art, and for me especially Bernini's sculptures, were awe-inspiring and I'm not extremely into art (but do appreciate it). Audioguide was good - had to leave ID (I used drivers license). Also had my guidebook out, reading about some of the pieces while my wife used our shared audioguide (Not something I could've done comfortably in the Vatican museum, for example). You are permitted 2 hours to view the museum. We spent the majority of the time on the 1st floor, but there are some highlights upstairs as well. Used nearly every minute of the 2 hours. There is a small gift shop, café, and restrooms in lower level. Went for a stroll through the park (Villa Borghese) afterwards.Saw a lot of Rome on a 9-night stay and the Borghese Gallery was a top highlight.
Amazing gallery. Caravaggio paintings and sculpturesNot so good for wheelchairs..they do have 2 on each floor but they are not so geared up in that respect

Don't miss it!. Last stop of our 4 nights in Rome. Had already seen the Vatican Museum, St. Peter's Basilica, Colloseum and Forum, but this was the highlight for me. Could not get enough of the Bernini sculptures. TIP: Make reservations before you go. Also make sure you wear something with pockets, since you are not allowed to even bring in purses. I felt perfectly safe with the free attended check room, but wanted to keep my wallet and passports on my person.

must for Bernini lovers. All the system of visit is clever and confortable.You need to have appointment [presales tickets] ,the duration is 2 hours,you are able to interrupt your visit,to go to the coffee bar or outside and return and of course ,no many visitors in the same time.You admire the Bernini's masterpieces and a lot of pictures.

Beautiful Gallery and Location. As the tribe tells it below, buy in advance. I was horrified to learn 5 days before I went that it books up 3-4 weeks in advance. A kind hotel manager phoned, in Italian, and reserved me a spot. Next to the ticket desk downstairs in the basement is a desk where you can obtain audio guides for a fee (I think it was 5 euro).Seeing the small collection of Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures, alone, was worth it. The experience and beauty of seeing the Apollo and Daphne sculpture up close is phenomenal. The audio, especially, gives you insight into the way the sculpture was meant to be experienced (the positioning of it in the room, how its aesthetic depends on movement around the piece and what unfolds).
