There is a small bookstore and cafe inside (near the baggage check counter). Unlike the Etruscan museum, there are no photos allowed (even without flash).
An extraordinary collection. We did a guided tour and loved it, Dark Rome are great and Daniel was excellent. We learnt so much and the time flew.

Glorious. I just love this place. I could stand for hours just looking at the statues by Bernini. A big plus about the Borghese is that numbers are limited - visitors are given a 2 hour time slot - so no fighting to get to the front. The visit can be rounded off with a walk or 'train' journey - or even a segway - around the beautiful grounds. Book early though.

Great Gallery-Poor Service. The artwork and sculptures in the Borghese Gallery are outstanding. We thoroughly enjoyed all of the exhibitions. However, our visit could have been so much better. First, to have an audio guide, you had to have made arrangements before you arrived. I did not know that! There are also no alternatives, like walking tours to help you see things better. The museum has pamphlet guides in every language but English. When asked if they had English guide books, we were told, "Sorry, we do not have any more!" No sympathy there! So, my advice, be prepared ahead of time, because you'll get little help at the gallery itself.
Small, but worth the visit. While it is small, it's collection is amazing. Always buy your ticket in advance as it sells out. They only sell so many tickets every two hours to keep the crowds down.

Nice art museum inside an impressive historical villa. You must appreciate the policy of this museum to limit only 360 people to enter every 2 hours (so buy on-line tickets is essential), if you have seen the some time mob-like crowd in the major attractions in Europe and not just in Rome. You must also appreciate their policy of strictly no bags (including purse) inside if you have been swiped/hit many times (like me) by the big backpacks some people carry around to sightseeing (what's in it any way, why burden with a big bag all day?). With these very sensible policies, you can really enjoy the great paintings, master works of Bernini's sculptures and the beautiful historical building itself in relative serenity and easy pace (2 hours are sufficient to see every piece of artwork). Although sadly, their policy still couldn't weed out all rude tourists, some of whom I saw 'smuggled' bags in and took pictures while the staff was distracted. Despite of that, the bonus of touring the gallery is that you can have a nice stroll through the beautiful park Villa Borghese afterward. We did just that, walked all the way down to Piazza Popolo, a vast and beautiful piazza which personally I like it better than Piazza Navona. Don't miss Borghese Gallery and the Piazza Popolo!

Great art poor information. A fantastic art collection in a beautiful building. A pity that the information about each masterpiece is only in Italian, all the museums we visited in Rome had excellent descriptions of displays in English - this gallery should learn from others in the city. Remember to book your time slot in advance (easy on-line). We visited on a Sunday and the place was fully booked until the following Thursday and there were a number of very disappointed people about.

One of my favs. I come here often with groups and it's a great place for students and adults to walk in silence and take in some of the greatest art in the city. Whats great about Borghese Gallery is that it's not on everyone's radar while in Rome, so the hoards of tourists that you'd find at the Colosseum wont be here. Ensure before you show up that you have a reservation - this is a very common mistake for most travellers here.

Bernini and the gallery. I've been to Rome many times. Last month, we took my wife's parents for their first time. I planned the trip with the Borghese Gallery as our first stop. The gallery can be quite manageable as the first floor with all of the Bernini sculptures is pretty small. I like to start a trip here so I can introduce Bernini to those who don't know of his importance. You will better appreciate the many Bernini sculptures you will see throughout Rome. You will also see other important works of art.Book as far in advance as possible. You will have two hours to visit which should be enough to see all of the floors.

We went to the Park not the gallery. We didnt make it to the gallery just to the park. Hired a little buggy to get about which was fun. 15 euros for 4 of us for 30 mins. You can also hire bikes and go karts cheaper. They were setting up some sort of show while we were there but it didn't matter its sucha huge place. Great vews. Welcome shade and welcome concrete after all those cobbled streets. Wortha viist for a stroll, chill out from city and picnic.

Outstanding Sculpture and Paintings. This small art museum boasts some of the best Bernini sculptures in the world, which is usually my main reason for visiting. I also enjoy looking at the wonderful paintings by famous artists, such as Caravaggio, Titian, Raphael, Peter Paul Rubens and Veronese. These works were collected by Cardinal Borghese, who was a patron of Bernini.The museum consists of 20 rooms on two floors with dozens of steps between the floors. An elevator at the rear of the building is available for those in wheelchairs. An audio guide is available and useful. There are brochures in various languages, but the museum was out of English pamphlets on my last visit.The museum has rules that visitors should be aware of before going. First, admission is for a limited number of visitors at a specified time for two hours only. So, if you have a ticket for 10 a.m., you are not admitted before precisely 10 a.m. Though you can enter within the 2-hour time period (10-12), you must leave at noon. I have found two hours to be sufficient time to see the works. Second, you must check bags, including purses, at a room next to the ticket office at the museum's lowest level. There are no lockers. Be sure that you keep anything of value with you. I have noted some visitors carrying Ziploc-type bags that hold money, a passport, etc. Third, photography is not allowed.I advise buying tickets in advance on-line. It is becoming increasingly difficult to get same-day tickets, because of the museum's popularity and the increased number of people traveling. As an example, I purchased on-line tickets for last Saturday. When I arrived, a notice announced that tickets were sold out until Thursday. A Giacometti exhibition brought me to the museum on Saturday (two days ago). This show features just 28 sculptures and six paintings, displayed throughout the permanent collection. I found this to be an awkward presentation, because it was not obvious where each work was exhibited. But these were good examples of what Giacometti has done and all were worthwhile seeing. The museum has a small, basic cafe near the ticket office. There are many nice restaurants nearby.We took the 910 bus from Rome's central station. This brought us to a stop that was a 1-minute walk to the gallery. There are other buses, of course, that go near the gallery but I doubt any would bring you as close as the 910.

Visited in 2002!. I'm very late for my review...I am not a lover of galleries, etc. but I really enjoyed this. It has some wonderful pieces and it is set in a beautiful location...just check the opening hours before you arrive!

My favorite gallery in Italy.. Having seen all the biggies in Rome, Florence, Venice, the Borghese is still the best. Mandatory booking process keeps the crowds in check. The art, architecture and experience is unforgettable. The two hour time slot is perfect for seeing the gallery without rushing, but not so long that you start getting saturated and overwhelmed.... It is my favorite art experience (so far).
Wonderful museum. Loved the fact that they restrict the amount of visitors so it's not too crowded - a good idea is to plan in advance and book online your time!

Favorite museum in Italy. I liked this small museum better than the Uffizi and the Accademia in FLorence (only Pitti Palace compares). The art is easier to view and it was a more enjoyable experience. The entrance is a 10-15 minute walk from either stopping point for vehicles so you need to arrive early for your appointment and allow for the walk (even tho you may be advised that the museum is "just a minute down that road"). Check your purse contents before and after the mandatory storage...The park is a lovely city park; think Central or Lincoln or Golden Gate. You need to wander around and discover it - enjoy.

"Amazing Borghese". Like other reviewers mentioned you need to prebook online. Tours run every 2 hrs starting at 9am. We booked the 9am slot and I was glad we did. It is necessary to arrive early to show your reservation, pick up your tickets, check your bag/purse and rent an audioguide if you want one. You are not allowed to check jackets. Around 8:30am or so it is relatively uncrowded to do this. We found it best in Rome to do everything early. When we were leaving at 11am and the next tour was coming in it was jammed. We were let into the gallery at 9 on the dot. It was not that crowded as we seemed to be ahead of the tours. We were able to view the amazing rooms of sculptures with very few people present. It got crowded later on and we tried to do different rooms than the tours. 350 people are allowed in every 2 hrs. Despite the ban on cameras, I saw a teenage boy snapping away but later on noticed he had put his camera away. There is a long flight of stairs to the second story. I did see a very small elevator but not sure if you need permission to use it. Just ask. When you have left try and zip down to baggage check for your bag as the line gets very long when everyone is retrieving theirs at the same time. They advertise a cafe but it is not the most pleasant and would recommend somewhere else unless you desperately need a cup of joe. We walked in the outside area afterwards. Will have great memories of the beautiful Borghese.

Go backwards!. The Bernini sculptures are amazing. Love the booking process which keeps crowds at bay only letting in a set number. Tip: Start the tour backwards since everyone else is going in the same direction and you'll have the works to yourself. Personally I find this much more enjoyable as I find people distracting. The audio tour is great! Spend the extra few dollars if your not an art expert and it makes it all much more interesting and fun. That's me - no expert but I like the stories behind the works.Enj
Overwhelming. We hit the Spanish Steps and then wandered over to the advanced-reservation-only Gallery. WOW. Just a beautiful experience all the way around

Don't miss it!. Amazing sculptures by Bernini, Canova, and others. Great paintings by Caravaggio and many others. Prebooking required, and numbers admitted are limited in two-hour intervals, so it's not as crowded as some museums. We used our Roma Pass and went here as one of our two free admissions. Beautiful grounds and gardens, too. Don't miss it!
Book in advance. Beautiful find in the Borghese gardens. Gallery is spectacular with some real gems. Definitely pre-book. I also wished I had bought an audioguide.

Great Tour of Borghese with Rebecca from Viator/Dark Rome/City Tour. We toured the Borghese Gallery today, booked through Viator/Dark Rome/City Tour. Rebecca was our tour guide. She was fantastic! Highly recommend this tour and request Rebecca!

Wonderful museum. You have to prebook. Don't just roll up and expect to get in.Also make sure you get the audio guide it's well worth the money as you get so much more information. The array of sculptures is simply mind blowing,some of the greatest in the world.unlike some attractions this is regulated with strict numbers allowed in 2 hr blocks. Get there early and try to get in front of the tour guides who can be distracting for other users .For me the highlights were undoubtedly the sculptures. Breathtaking. Like most attractions the crowds build up as day progresses so always try to get early tickets

Not a fan. Personally not a fan of this place whatsoever. While I appreciate the rarity of the collection, I think unless you are a true lover of the arts you can skip this. The staff is extremely pretentious also. Got in without a resveration and made it through the museum in about an hour. There are minimal descriptions of the artwork so you either need to rent the audio guide or bring a descriptive book with you.

A must! Just beautiful.. This beautiful Villa that has a great view of the city hides the most impressive collection of Bernini sculptures. You will be amazed at the selected collection in this beautifully kept small museum.

Best of the Best. Galleria Borghese literally has the best of the best of paintings and sculpture. If youravailable travel time is limited skip the Vatican museum or the other huge museums. Buyingthe tickets ahead of time is the only way to get into the museum. You can't just show upthey won't let you in. Its good that they do this since it would have way too many peoplegoing in. With the ticket and a scheduled time to see the exhibits - the experience isvery good. Bernini, Canova, and Caravaggio are the most prominent artist's.If you are coming from the Stazione Termini (the main train station) the #910 bus leavesfrom the bus lot at the train station and goes by the Galleria about 2 blocks after it turns north at the edge of the park. Another bus #16 coming from the Campo D' Fiore The #16is an electric powered minibus and is an interesting route right through the middle of the historic heart of Rome and has its turn around location at about 200 m south of the Galleria Borghese. Even my brother - who didn't want to go in, said afterwards that it wasa really wonderful co9lletion of art !!!

Wonderful gallery. One of my favourite attractions in Rome. Definitely book your tickets ahead of time, the Bernini sculptures are absolutely incredible and I also loved the Roman mosaics. I was there on my own and the audio guide was well worth it.Take some time to explore the gardens around as well.

basement cafe. I have two special memories of the Villa Borghese - the first - 1983 - driving into Rome in our old VW kombi van at night - not knowing where we were, looking for somewhere to camp, we stopped on one of the roadways inside a random park we found - anyhoo we slept and set up our breakfast table, worked on the van, and spent two lovely weeks using it as a base for strolling around bella Roma - not until we were about to leave we discovered that just back around the bend the big building was something called the Villa Borghese ... containing this amazing art gallery with wonderful ceiling frescoes, etc. - did I feel d'oh !next - 2005 - free time on a tour group - we revisited - and found the basement cafe where I asked for a 'latte' as is the standard order in my country - silence and confused looks - repeat - huh ? - finally she asked why I would ask for 'latte' in a cafe - and explained to me that I seemed to be asking for a glass of milk - do you want 'caffe latte ?' - ah - yes thank you !delicious - on a par with my best ever in Milan square - so recommended - see the Villa Borghese art gallery - and before or after - maybe both - enjoy 'un caffe' (espresso) or a 'caffe latte' (flat white) in the basement cafe - if it is still as good as I enjoyed, you'll remember if forever !

Great gallery, 2 hours just right.. We bought our tickets on line ahead of time which is an absolute must. This is a very popular site. The changeout every 2 hours is very tight. Loved the works in the gallery. In each room there is a plasticized sheet to help you if you don't have a guide. Washrooms are scarce; the only one we could locate is at the left on the lower floor.Do not miss the PIazza Borghese outside the back of the museum; you can visit while you are waiting for your time to come up.

Great Museum and Gardens. Borghese Gallery located in the lush garden setting should be definitely high on any list of attractions to visit in Rome. We liked the sculptures and art on display. The guide gave us detailed explanation of the art and its history. Walk the gardens surrounding the gallery. It is like being in Central Park in NYC, green space in the middle of a busy city.

I'm not much for museums BUT. This was well worth it. You need to make a reservation to get in, but it is so worth it. The statues were life like. We took the audio tour and it was very informative. The park is also amazing.. rent a bike or surrey and spend an afternoon enjoying the gardens.

Borghese Gallery & Park. A day spent walking around the tree lined Borghese Park is very pleasant and a welcome relief from the bustling central Rome sights. Large park where you either walk, cycle, segway or buggy your way around, includes a small lake, zoo, cafes, etc.To see the Villa Borghese you need to book a day and time. It is a collection of classical art and sculpture and a good tip is to enter at your time and go straight to the 2nd floor and start there leaving most people on the ground floor! If you don't do the Vatican Museums then I would suggest doing this instead coupled with a pleasant day in the park.
Loved it. Loved the gallery. The park is gorgeous too. There's a flee market just down hill and the food and beer are awesome

Make reservations!. Make reservations to see this place or you may not get in- you're alloted 2 hours with a reservation, but my husband and I did it in one. Be sure to check everything at the check-in desk before going in. Wasn't as big as we thought, but the artwork was beautiful.

Fantastic treasure-trove of Art and Statuary. How can one family acquire so much great art.Also, we can attest that you can get in without purchasing a ticket and making a reservation in advance. We tried a week or so ahead of time but were too late. So we just showed up on Monday just prior to 9:00 a.m. About ten minutes after those possessing reservations marched by 20 or so people were allowed to purchase tickets to make up for the no-shows. We loved it. If you get a chance you shouldn't miss it.
Another gem. Go to as many of the Basilicas as you can. Each is a gem it would be hard to pick the best. Don't be put off by the exterior step inside and be amazed

Well worth a visit. This is not an overly large gallery, but that's good, as you only have 2 hours to see it. Book your tickets in advance, as it gets very crowded. We took the English tour, which was well worth the small cost, as the guide's knowledge was incredible. There are many priceless artworks on display, but the marble sculptures of Bernini are particularly noteworthy.Take a taxi to the nearest park exit - it's the easiest way to get there. We got a bit lost in Villa Borghese on the way out. It's easy to take a wrong turn! We eventually got our bearings and found our way out.

Beautiful. The ticket reservation can be a bit of a hassle, but you don't want to miss this place. I recommend that you book tickets beforehand on phone(not sure if you can do it via email), so you can skip one queue entirely and save time. Audio tours are available for a small fee and I recommend that you get one to get more out of the beautiful sculptures and paintings, or even better get a private tour. You want to reserve at least 2 hours for your visit.

Bernini's masterpiece demands a 360-degree preamble around the statue. The incredible vitality in this work is astounding,considering it was commissioned in 1623 by a sculptor barely 25,capturing the energy of motion as if it was a snapshot in time. The look of Dephne's expression,immortalised in the act of changing into a Laural tree, is one of disbelief and despair. With her forward-leaning posture,Apollo,who has just caught up with her, places his hand on her hip,only to find it has turned to bark. With this virtuousity, Bernini succeeded in transforming the words of Ovid into physical reality. Its all here at the Villa Borghese,the cardinal "Villa of delights". The positioning of the sculpture to the side of the room from which we observe Apollo from behind,as the god was nearing the end of his race to reach the object of his desire,with the drapery on his body still evoking the impression of movement. Then, as you move around the statue their dramatic expressions take centre-stage.

Pauline's no shy wallflower in her waxy but not cheesy pose.. Napoleon's Younger sister wrote to her husband Prince Borghese to not show her "privacy" to public scrutiny, because the sculpture of her in the buff,was created for her husband's own pleasure. Today,2000 devotees line up at the gallery to admire her privacy which has been described "as it seems to be flesh and blood". Displayed semi-nude, lying luxuriantly on a chaise longue in the garb of Venus Victrix, it raised scandal and surprise among aristocrates of Rome in 1818. To really get the best out of this pinnacle of neoclassic design and form,you have to shuffle lemming-like,to the first floor,where "she" can be admired easily from every angle and the luminousity and softness of the work can be properly appreciated. The sculptor Antonio Canova applied a layer of wax to gain the effect which enhanced perfection,in marble.

Sculptures everywhere. I LOVE that they have sculptures everywhere! My favourite museum. I love the artworks displayed inside. Love love love.Downside was that we had to walk VERY far to this gallery because we didn't know how to get there from Piazza del Popolo.

Small but Impressive. Beautiful grounds. On a hot day, dangle your feet in the fountain out back. Timed tickets and timed duration for the museum which was a bit offputting as we would have liked to stay longer and linger - just pace your time. It did not keep me from visiting on a second trip. I had my innkeeper make our reservations which could be hard to get. Best to check availability before you go. Art was fantastic and due to its small size and limited ticket time, it is not an overwhelming visit. Would not recommend for small kids in tow. Rent a headset - well worth it!

A private tour!. We toured the Borghese Gallery in Rome with Mark on Sunday May 4. The building itself was just lovely & Mark was so knowledgable about the beautiful art especially the sculptures . I really liked the way he picked one thing in each room & helped us appreciate it.This tour was one of our highlights so Rome.!Thanks Mark.

One of the most beautiful galleries.... Had been here over 30 years ago, and visiting again brought back all those fond memories, I remember why I liked it so much.Just the right size for my teen kids to not get saturated either.Beautiful and sunny day too.We did not book ahead, but we lucky to get in at the end of the day. But the lady ast the reception was extremely rude and impatient with us. Unreal! If you land on her, just grid and bear it!I would suggest reserving ahead of time, to make sure you get and avoid the mean lady...

Beautiful Gallery and Park. First off, we had the most amazing guide for this visit (Lindy) who spoke beautiful english and was so enthusiastic about the Gallery it could not help but rub off on her clients! The art and statues are amazing. The history about the Borghese family is fascinating! Be sure to tour the adjacent park after seeing the gallery. They also rent surreys and segways at the park which can add to the fun.

Nice mix of art pieces. We enjoyed the museum. On our visit we rented audio sticks but we found them confusing as they did not match up to art work in a few locations. Order your tickets ahead of time.

wow. the paintings on the ceilings and walls exceeed the vatican in my estimation. One would swear the paintings that are so 3 dimensional are actual carvings and not flat paintings. I am not not an art devotee but I was visibly favorably impressed, and my wife who does appreciate art was blown away by the detail, scope and quality of the art

My wife's favorite. This was something I have never done and you need to plan for it, like the last supper in Milan. It is an amazing collection and so much it was almost overwhelming at times for me. Between the setting, the rooms and then the art it is a must see.

If you like weird art. This is not the "one museum to see if you can only see one in Rome". Period. The National Museum near St Maria Maggiore or the Vatican Museum, to name two, are infinitely more interesting and diverse. However, if you go to Borghese you will see about three fine world class marble sculptures

Yes. Yes, go see this. If you have only one day, go see the Vatican and the Colosseum. If you have any more time, this should be the next place you see. This is now my favorite art museum. Not only is the art great ( although there are many places that can make that claim ), but the setting the art is in is magnificent and enhances the experience beyond words. The only negative is that you are only allotted 2 hours there and you could easily spend a lot more time. My one suggestion is to not spend more than 45 minutes upstairs, the first floor that you get to see. The lower floor is far more impressive, far more and you will want to give it its due.Afterwards, take a walk in the park. The next time I go to Rome, I will spend 1-2 weeks there and spend a good deal of it relaxing in the park and seeing all of many attractions they have there.

Outstanding!. It is a two hour timed tour. Buy your ticket in advance and arrive at least 15 minutes before your entry. What can I say but outstanding! The English speaking tour guides that work for the Gallery are great. It costs something like 10 euros per person and you just purchase your ticket when you enter the museum. Beautiful paintings, statutes, furnishings and amazing history! Afterwards walk around the Borghese Gardens, which like Central Park in NYC have a Merry Go Round, fountains, gardens and horses driven carriages. We walked through the Gardens to the Spanish Steps. Great time and even our 15 year old enjoyed!
Love the Borghese!. If you love culture and art, the Borghese gallery is a must see attraction while in Rome. It is one of the best galleries in Italy!

Bernini and Caravaggio lovers' dream!. Absolutely wonderful museum but you must do your homework in advance or get a guided tour like we did. I say this since you are limited to two hours and that's it! Our tour guide was able to condense the visit and focus on the most significant pieces while working in the story and history of the Gallery and the Borghese family. Since Bernini and Caravaggio are two of our most favorite Italian artists, this gallery was the pinnacle for seeing their works. You can see Bernini's evolution as an artist as you stroll through the gallery. Highly recommend but plan in advance or miss out!

A condensed immersion in Italian art and history. Highly recommend a visit, especially for the opening first group. The park setting is lovely and in the quiet of the early morning we enjoyed a stroll from the bus stop through some of the park. We had read that we should start in the upstairs picture gallery. It turned out we didn't have a choice as everyone with electronic reservations had to enter through the lower entrance which led only to the upstairs rooms (lots of stairs). We felt we had ample time to stroll through both floors but we would recommend ending on the ground floor as you may be able to spend more time viewing the famous sculptures without large groups. The rooms themselves must be admired as well. Be sure to read about the history of the villa and collection. Each room has cards about the rooms and also the art, including English. They give a different (more positive) spin about the founder and his collecting. You really MUST make advance reservations. People without reservations found the next tickets were for 5-6 days later.
Very interesting visit. A pantheon of history , art , trandition in the middle of fabulous dream like park!!!!!Well organised visit but reserve your visit early at least 20 days before!!!
a must see in Rome. A must see museum in Rome!! They limit the amount of visitors so you never feel crowded or rushed and fantastic works of art.

Worth a second time visit!. In Rome, Borghese Gallery is the only place that impressed me. Definitely worth a second visit! The paintings and sculptures are breathtaking. Don't forget to make a reservation in advance.

Beautiful museum, but skip if your visit to Rome is short. We went to the Borghese Gallery in the morning of our first day in Rome (and the Vatican Museums in the afternoon). The park and gardens are gorgeous, and the villa itself is fantastic. I love art museums, but found the layout--walls covered in multiple pieces and the works not clearly labeled--to be overwhelming. There are some lovely paintings and sculptures here, but not worth going out of your way for if time is limited (The Vatican museums have a far more impressive and diverse collection).

If you like or love art, this is one of the best place in the world.. This museum is not big with the more spaces as any famous museum, but art pieces and things inside are so amazing. You need to call or make any reservations in advance, evenif you have the roma pass. No walk -in, they are offer you onlu 2 hours visitting, start from 9;00 am. ,11;00 am and so on, which is good and very conveniece to any visitors, because the spaces inside look very compactable to match anythings. Good place to visit with the beautiful and greenery park around the building. No doubt, go and consume the terrific art inside there.
Nice but quick visit. This place has some lovely Bernini sculptures especially Apollo and Daphne, and David. Worth the visit, especially the stroll through the park outside the villa.

Don't miss this Gem. The Borghese Gallery was one of the highlights of our trip. It was amazing to see this wonderful collection of artwork. Though it took some emailing back and forth with the hotel staff who kindly made the reservation it was well worth planning it in advance as the spaces filled up fast. Highly recommend if you are in Rome for enough of a stay to warrant planning this into a day.

Best for Sunday morning. If it is a sunny or warm day, it is a unique place to visit. Tranquility and interest.We took the "electric bicycle" for couples, it is nice to spend 45 minutes and explore the area with it.

Superb collection. Hard to get in as entry is timed for 300 visitors every two hours. YOU MUST BOOK A LONG TIME IN ADVANCE, as we did. There were no slots left for the week we were there.Magnificent collection with the great painters and of course the Bellini statues. Unmissable!!

Galleria Borghese. You should really visit this gallery, which is inside Villa Borghese(a huge park with much to see).
It contains works of art from many great artists of Renaissance and before, like Caravaggio and Bernini.
You should book your ticket online, before you go there though.
Gorgeous. Worth every second spent there. Purely magnificent. Bernini's statues are just as lovely as the whole arrangement of the halls and their ceilings

Bernini, Bernini..... If you are planning a trip to Rome, buy a ticket to this gallery online.
The Bernini sculptures are just unforgettable. The Apollo and Daphne work takes your breath away and that is just a small part of a wonderful collection.

Preplanning is a must!. Buy your tickets online! Incredible collection of art and the home itself is beautifully decorated. If you are walking there fr the Spanish Steps make sure you stay on the street on the right side of the park...the Spagna Metro Borghese exit will lead you the right way.

Make sure you pre-pay for tickets.. gorgeous grounds surround the gallery. The gift shop is totally overpriced but the gallery is a really neat place. Be prepared for lots of walking, like everywhere else in Italy.

A gallery not to miss. A must see gallery. I was last in this gallery in 1967 as a teenager and it has taken me this long to return but it was worth the wait. The only word to describe it is stunning. It was even better than I remembered and as a fifteen year old back then, I was so impressed that the memory of the amazing sculptures in particular never left me. My cousin who lives in Rome went along with me - he had never visited it and he rated it as the best visual art experience in Rome - on a par with the Sistine Chapel and St Peter's Basilica. I would not argue with that verdict.You have to book tickets in advance and this can be done on the internet. There are discounts for the elderly, children and teachers. You pay online and pick the tickets up in the gallery on the day of your visit. You choose a date and a time slot. The time slot is two hours and if you love sculpture, painting and architecture then you will need every minute of that time. The time slot is strictly adhered to and the gallery is cleared before the next viewing begins. I have tried several times to get in on the day and failed miserably so do book in advance.You cannot take your bags or a camera into the gallery but the system for depositing and retrieving these is very straight forward. There are toilets, a cafe and a gift shop that you can use before you enter the gallery and again after your visit.The sculptures are mainly on the first level and the paintings on the second and the rooms are numbered so you can visit in sequence and there is a reasonably priced guide book taking you through the rooms in several languages. It would have been worth a visit to see just one of the world famous sculptures or paintings let alone the whole collection.

Best museum of the trip. The Borghese does it right - staggering entry, reservations required, so you have the time and the space to truly enjoy the great works of art in this amazing villa. The Bernini sculptures are exquisite.
The sculpture of The Rape of Proserpina is worth the entire visit.. All the art here is top top top. The Roma pass will get you in free if you reserve COD. Loved it and have been here many times.

Well,..... Okay, here is the story. Yes, we visited the Borghese. My two friends did a tour (Walks of Italy) 44euro, I did not do the tour 16euro. While we all enjoyed it, I honestly do not recall anything especially fascinating about the Borghese....and neither did my friends. Now I'll grant you, we could have been tired, it might have been an off day, who knows. I did make a reservation, and they do reserve a specific time for your entrance. There was no line, however it was mid-March, and that should be taken into consideration. Right outside is this HUGE park/gardens. It was lovely. Filled with vegetation and people having a great time. This would be a wonderful way to spend a day. Take a picnic, see the museum, chill outside with a bottle of Chianti, cheese, bread, and fruit. Give yourself time to enjoy all that it offers instead of a 2 hour museum visit. PS, they will ask you to leave your purse or pack. Take your ID, cards, etc, with you. Bottom line: I would go back, if only because I cannot recall what the heck I saw the first time.....which may, or may not, be a statement in itself.
Fascinated. We are lucky that we immediately went to the site without reservation, otherwise must be reserved a few days earlier. You can book on their website on the internet.

Excellent Gallery and beautiful setting. While I have to give it five stars for the art and location and the beautiful building, the museum is so crowded and popular that it is hard to enjoy. We waited outside in the rain a half hour till we were allowed to come inside and stand in line to get tickets for our voucher. There were fairly long lines for every aspect of the visit.

Excellent art gallery located in a magnificent vila. The Borghese galleries are an exceptional collection of art (paintings, ancient sculptures) - bernini in particular has some excellent representations of the ancient people - as if they were alive in front of u. Located in a very nice parc (called villa borghese) - offering a quiet retreat from the hussle & bussle of Rome center. The price is well worth it - 16 EUR, the entrance is for a limited no of visitors per day (9.00 - 11.00; 11.00 - 13.00 and so on until 17.00), therefore booking in advance is mandatory.

The Best Baroque Gallery - a Real Jewel. Just as you can see all you need to know about French impressionists in the Musee d'Orsay, and all about Austrian modernism in the Vienna's Belvedere, the Borghese Gallery offers a great glimpse on the (mainly) Italian baroque. Here, you can easily follow the development of the baroque painting from the 15th to the 18 century.Yes, there are more paintings in the Louvre or in the Musei Vaticani, but then, their collections are not so intense and focused. The Borghese Gallery offers great paintings collection of Caravaggio, and pieces from Titian, Rubens, Bassano, etc. One of the high points of the collection are the sculptures from Bernini, which you have to see to believe that the marble can be carved so delicately and lively. Also, there are numerous (and very good) antique Roman sculptures, and the interior of the building is a jewel in itself, with all the frescos, stuccos, marbles, and impressive halls. This was my third time to visit, it is that good. Tickets must be purchased weeks in advance, the visit lasts max. 2 hours. Don't miss it.

A wonderful experience. This most exquisite of small galleries was the highlight of our visit. We were informed by the hotel that it was sold out and indeed when we went, there was a notice up to that effect, but we were lucky and got tickets straight away. The sculptures and paintings were a delight and it was joy to stroll around

Borghese Gallery. Recently in Rome. Amazing Gallery. Be prepared to leave your purse and backpacks, cell phones, camera, etc. with front desk. I was very concerned but got everything back in order. We booked a tour guide while we were there and I definitely recommend doing so. The information she provided was amazing and without her it would have been difficult to appreciate the art and sculptures in depth. Wonderful experience. Wonderful location. Great park grounds. Little train takes you afterwards right to the end of the park where you can visit the Piazza del Popolo. Great view of the city from there.
Beauty and splendor. Beautiful place, majestic interiors and espacially wonderful art collection?the place îs surprindere by beautiful grădina where it îs very plasat to walk

Gorgeus gallery packed with sculpture, amazing gardens. The Borghese Gallery is a delightful, small gallery packed with sculpture on the first floor and paintings on the second floor. The museum is so popular that they limit your time to a 2 hour visit. Spend this time wisely - we got so caught up with the sculptures that we had only 20 minutes left for the paintings upstairs. There are some remarkable Bernini pieces in the sculpture gallery, including the Rape or Persephone, which is just mind-blowing. Upstairs in the portrait gallery, there are several Bernini self-portraits and some lovely Caravaggios among other wonderful works. We loved the Borghese Garden as much as the gallery. I recommend renting a little golf cart to explore the gardens and see all of the views, even if it's just to narrow down where you want to walk or spend more time. The garden is so huge, it's really impossible to walk it all on foot. The area around the Medici Villa is absolutely gorgeous and some incredible views of the city are available by the villa. Spend the day at the Borgehese, then walk down the Spanish Steps and into the heart of Rome. Dinner at Il Falchetto would be a lovely way to finish the day!

Tours in English at the gallery. I took a guided tour offered by the gallery, and was very glad I did. You can only book the tour at the gallery, about a half hour before you're scheduled to go in, and when I was there it only ran in English in the mornings (check the website for times). It cost 6.50 Euros. You need to book your entrance ticket a few days/weeks in advance, depending on the season.The gallery is amazing. It's worth going just for the Bernini sculptures.

Not to be missed. The gallery is small and only allows you two hours. You must reserve in advance for a specific time slot. You are not allowed to bring any personal bags in, they must be checked and they are very strict about this. It has a very good painting collection upstairs - which you probably will see first. But the real treasure are the sculptures, especially the Bernini's. They are jaw-droppingly exquisite - each and every one. Words don't describe them, you must see these sculptures in person.It is an easy 45min walk to the gallery from the a hotel in the old city or near the train station and it takes you trough the park around it which is also lovely and can be explored.

Relatively Small but Packed Full of Renaisance and Baroque Art. Easy to see the entire gallery in a couple hours, the Bernini sculptures are alone worth the visit. Add in all the other art and beautiful rooms and it is definitely a good place to put on your itinerary. Take a guided tour, you will enjoy it and learn quite a bit!

Well worth a visit. Pre-booked (morning/afternoon) tickets are a must to save standing in queues. Although not the largest of buildings it coped well with the numbers entering at our session(afternoon). Leave plenty of time to get there as location in Park is not always well signposted. Very warm inside, so be aware, comfortable clothing important. Gallery itself was excellent, with wonderful paintings and sculptures. A great afternoon on our first day in Rome.

Disappointed !. We chose our hotel because it was near the Borghese Gardens and Gallery but after quite a walk through the gardens, found that you must pre-book. No tickets for sale on the day, or the next. Wish we had known. Very disappointed !

Borghese Gallery - AWESOME. Even though I had looked at length at the Gallery's web site, I was unprepared for how blown away I was in the presence of the gorgeous sculptures and artwork. Visitors are only allowed 2 hours so we took Rick Steves' advice and went to the second floor first (we did find Mr. Steves guide to Rome to be an invaluable tool). It boggles the mind how such intricate and gorgeous art works were produced hundreds of years ago without the modern tools we have today. This is a must do while in Rome.

Very rude. Visited the gallery borghese but alas was sold out for the next few weeks, asked to use the toilet (had been walking for 2 hrs before getting there) only to be shouted at, not just us but a disabled person in front of us who needed the toilet but was told to use the one in the park (about a 20 min walk away) certainly wouldn't be accepted anywhere in the uk anymore !

Must go!. The first floor of the Gallery - no words to describe. My 14 year old son (good student, intelligent, a normal computer and video games loving teenager) said that it was the best thing he saw during our Rome vacation. The first floor consists of the sculptures by Bernini and other sculptors. We bought an audio guide which offered really amazing explanation of the art - not just dry facts, but using very poetic and beautiful language. The second floor - is mainly paintings, which are very beautiful, but the audio guide has explanations just for a couple of them, which was disappointing. But regardless, the Borghese Gallery is a must see site. It is located in a beautiful villa - you can spend your day there, renting bikes, segways, going to the zoo (which we did and enjoyed) - just a nice break in you busy Rome vacation.

Fascinating. Book in advance as only 200 people allowed in with a 2 hour slot. Start on 1st level as most start on lower level so not so much of a crush. Didnt get the audio guide but those in our group who did said it wasn't much good for the paintings. There are informative cards in each room that I found useful. Sculptures impressive
Amazing. Find any way possible to make a stop here, so worth it. Breathtaking. There is a two hour limit in the museum and you need to reserve tickets online as it is quite popular.

Rome's wonderful art. We went with Viatour who consistently provide excellent guides from Dark Rome. Our trip was booked in advance (essential as there is usually a waiting list of days for an entry ticket to keep numbers down). The Bernini sculptures must be the finest in the world and the art work was an amazing collection of the finest Italian artists. Do get a guide to bring it all to life. It is one of the finest galleries we have seen in the world.

house of art. Do not miss Borghese Gallery in Rome; you can see an amazing collection of paintings and sculptures, works of Tizian, Raphael, Caravaggio etc. I especially admired " The rape of Proserpina" (Bernini). Don't forget your tickets reservations - booking online - two weeks before.

Missed exhibition. We had seen that threr was a Giacommetti exhibition which we were very keen to see. When we got there we were informed that it was severakldays before we could get tickets. We had to the a train ride through the park which was a small compensation even though it was very beautiful.

a wonderful collection of Roman art!. we was so lucky! we could not buy the tickets online before,just tried the beautiful park and went to museum.OH!there were 2 cancelled tickets for the time we arrived there! and we visited all that stunning painting and sculptures like a dream.the caravaggio,Bernini, and others...
Don't miss it at all!

Beautiful museum in a beautiful place. In this museum you can find statues of Canova, Bernini and also works of Raphael, and Rubens.
Is preferably reserve in advance, at least 2-3 days before if you don't want queue long time
After of before visit, is worth walking in the museum park for some minutes

A charming and special, very important little Museum. Galleria Borghese is a little, but great Museum situated in the famous Park of Villa Borghese. An amazing wiew on Rome, a lake with boats, a little train, a Theater, and many interesting Monuments and attractions (like Zoo). And there are some "Bistrots" to eat something...I usually suggest to my Guests of the Domus Ciancaleoni, to visit it, because it is an amazing experience. It id necessary to reserve by phone or email, because the visits (leght of each visit : 2 hours) are done only in little group of persons.Visits starts from 9 am. The last visit is at 17 h. I warmly recommend this place!

Amazing art gallery. Galleria Borghese is one of the most impressive art galleries in Rome. Personally I liked it more than the Vatican Museums, because it's doable in one visit and you don't feel like having lost 90 % of the museum. Keep in mind to book in advance and take the audio-guide as well, it helps you to understand the gallery a lot!

Perfect size, lovely art, must book in advance. Glad we booked ahead, on-line, as they were sold out for the next 7 days when we arrived. They really limit the number allowed (in two hour blocks) but it makes the experience inside the museum very enjoyable. Both the permanent exhibits (lovely sculptures and paintings) as well as the traveling additions are wonderful and not in such number that it is overwhelming. Beautiful Berninis, Boticellis, Raphels, and a small collection of Carrivagios delite the eye but almost like a nice antipasto, whet the pallet enough to leave you desiring more, as opposed to feeling visually overwhelmed. The sculptures are fantastic in both number and subject matter. Perfect when traveling with children to expose them to Renaissance art and some of the more famous artists without wearing out their attention. Absolutely worth the ticket and time to book ahead for any and all appreciators of Italian art.

Hidden Gem of Rome. This museum requires reservations-Be sure to make one! The Galleria Borghese houses Raphauels and Berninis that you dont want to miss. They are reservation only and only allow a certain number (I think 200) of guest in at one time (every 2 hours). Plently of time to see the beautiful pieces and beautiful building. One of my favorite spots in Rome! Mainly due to the crowd control and the amazing Bernini statues! Gardens are nice as well.

Always a treat. This is one museum not to miss if you like sculptures. We have visited twice -- be sure to pre reserve your time. We did this, and did find, even not during the busiest time of year, that when we arrived they were sold for for the next few days. Glad we had our tickets!
Worth the effort.. The Bernini statues are what make the Borghese an experience. Make sure you reserve tickets at least a few days in advance otherwise you will Not get in.

Giacometti - until May 25th. The gardens are great place for a family (we rented bikes) , the villa is beautiful and until May 25th there is an exhibition of Giacometti sculptures among the "classical" paintings and sculptures with an interesting cross-talk.

Fantastic Museum. Get the audio guide and see this museum! It is a gem! I loved that they limited the number of people who are in the museum at any given time. We went at noon, and it was a smaller crowd. Good time to go through, to see these masterpieces of art!

bergini. The most amazing part of our trip . Don't miss it ring before hand and book for this museum as it's on a booking service only. The works here are unbelievable and there are some good Caravaggio paintings and well as a reuben . If I was going again I would take a picnic with me because the park that the gallery is set in is fantastic and worth spending a few hours in

Breathtaking collection, magnificent atmosphere!. It is almost impossible to describe this incredible gallery without using almost every superlative in the English language. I found myself trying to imagine what it might possibly have been like to grow up in a palazzo displaying the grandeur exhibited here. It sparks the imagination as you stroll through each of the beautifully decorated, wonderfully preserved rooms! Truly one of my most favorite museums in the world! An absolute, not to be missed highlight if you are coming to Rome!

Purchase tickets ahead of time. We purchased our tickets ahead of time, also rented the self guided tour. I think this is a must. It goes into so much detail about every piece in each room. Make sure you have a couple of hours to dedicate to this magnifisent museum. My husband and I walked to the Galleria and then strolled back through the gardens and down to the original gate to enter Rome. Wonderful works of Art, they look like they could come to life at any moment. All bags, cameras, phones have to be checked in before entering the museum.

May reservations on line in advance. Glad we made reservations so we got in right on time. Wonderful collection which can be seen in the alotted 2 hours allowed for visit. Afterwards stroll through the gardens
The top of the Arts. An absolutely amazing Art gallery in a palace. Possibly the best gallery in Rome in a wonderful setting. This was our last stop in Rome and a very fitting one.

Get A Guided Tour. Easy to wonder why it is so difficult to get tickets (book well in advance), permitting 200 at a time, the 2.5 hour visiting restriction & most tourist maps don't detail Villa Borghese area well - all hassles you don't experience at the National Galleries (Bernini, Cordova & Caravaggio all well represented at Palazzo Barberini) - but with a guide you discover the importance of this very selective collection & with a high school art history education alone - one must appreciate the talent in the Bernini & Caravaggio works presented here. Spring is a great time for some relaxing on grass - so little in Rome to enjoy.

Raphael, Titian, Caravaggio, Bernini: Incomparable! But you need RESERVATIONS.. Incomparable, truly. A stroll through the rooms is like leafing through a text of the greatest hits from 1475 to 1780. The building has been renovated and the physical plant improved--although some areas are still muggy hot and the lights went out twice during our visit. The decorations and frescoes are pristine. Even the exterior of the building is fresh and clean. In 1975, on my first visit, I sat and gazed at Titian's "Sacred and Profane Love" for a bit over an hour; I don't think more than a couple of people came in the room all that time. I wrote in my journal and just looked at the painting. Today, of course one has a timed ticket: there is a two-hour period during which one must see everything, however long one wants to circle Bernini's "Daphne and Apollo" (my husband's favorite) or look back and forth between the self-portraits in Caravaggio's "David and the Head of Goliath" and "Self Portrait with Basket of Fruit" or get all dreamy over Raphael's "Deposition." It's a mob as the time slot starts; after about 75 minutes, the crowds thin out perceptibly. Hold on to those last 15 minutes--the building will be nearly empty, if you are lucky.Let's talk reservations, though. Understand this: the chances that you will be able to walk up to the Borghese Gallery and buy tickets for the next time of entry is slim and none. You may well not be able to get tickets that fit into your stay at all. You have to reserve tickets significantly in advance by computer when you are making your travel plans. At least a month in advance. Truly. Yes that ties you into a specific moment when you might want to be doing something else, and yes, it costs an extra 2 euros handling fee per ticket, but that's life. Yes, there are those mythical "cancellations" that open up space. I wouldn't count on it, though, and absolutely not if you are traveling any time except maybe November through February.Thinking you'll use this costly ticket to help defray the cost of your Roma Pass? Think again. Because of the way a Roma Pass works, you won't be able to get the Pass, go to the Borghese (and the Coliseum or whatever) before you do anything else. The Roma Pass may work for you (it didn't for us, but that's another post) but don't require the Borghese to be part of the story. Remember that they will make you check your backpacks, sacks, pocketbooks and cameras. All of it. Security at the garderoba is good, but I do get nervous leaving my all in the control of strangers. Afterwards stroll back down the Via Veneto, past Piazza Barberini and head to the via Panetteria for the BEST gelato at San Crispino. Or wind down the paths in the massive park that is the Villa Borghese. There's a zoo for the kids, the Museum of Modern Art and the Villa Julia (Etruscan art). End up at the Piazza del Popolo where you can people watch and enjoy an espresso. It will be a great day!

A lovely and well preserved respite just outside the Roman gate-. Order your tickets online ahead of time and arrive at lhe villa at least fifteen minutes before your scheduled entrance to the galllery. The villa museum is spectacular. It features paintings, sculpture, and furniture, including several major works by Bernini. A modern sculptural exhibit provided a fascinating counterpoint during our visit in March. Be sure to plan for extra time to enjoy the beautiful grounds and gardens of the Borghese estate.

Favourite day in Rome. Me partner and I found ourselves with a free morning as we had planned to go to the Vatican, however the Pope was doing a service and there was no hope of us getting in. We had read about Villa Borghese and decided we'd have a leisurely morning in the park before going to Castle Sant Angelo and it was brilliant! We decided due to time restraints that we should hire a bike or rickshaw to get around the beautiful and vast park quicker. We opted for a rickshaw and thought it was absolutely brilliant, only €6 for an hour and was so much fun. When in the park you feel like you are somewhere completely cut off, its quiet, calm, no one trying to sell you things. It was glorious. A definite go to for a relaxed time in Rome.

Kind of "too much" ..... It must be easier for a sinner to get into Heaven than it is for a turist to get into Galleria Borghese :-) Well, I had ordered my ticket in advance, so I did get in (this time), but even with a ticket they treat their guest more like "troublesome strangers" than friends. With that said I can't even add that it was worth it. As my headline says: It's kind of too much for the eye. Beautiful? Well yes ... the sealings are impressiv indeed! But if you ask me .... it was'nt worth "all the fuss"!

tickets to borghese. a last minute decision on our last rainy morning but no advanced tickets...what to do? Go just after they allow the timed ticket groups to enter and you can try to get cancellation tickets. It is worth it.

Amazing sculpture and art. First: Make sure that you get advance tickets to go to this gallery. It is well worth the effort and the cost. The tickets are available through the internet. Walk up tickets were not available when we went -- which was mid-week and off season. This museum is a treasure trove of art from the Renaissance and Baroque periods. Bellini's sculptures are unbelievably beautiful. A photograph simply does not do any of them justice. You can see all the sculptures from all sides. There is an amazing amount of art. Like any museum, you could be overwhelmed or be selective in your viewing. It is worth getting a guidebook in advance and figuring out what you want to see. (Rick Steve's has plenty of information on this museum and makes it very manageable.) We did get the audio guide. It certainly was not the best in the world but, does provide some guidance if you are not overly familiar with the art. This museum is not to be missed! The setting and the art itself are truly worth the visit.This was one of the highlights of our trip.

Same time for a walk around the park. Absolutely gorgeous place with amazing art. The adjacent park is a wonderful place for a stroll. My only complaint was that it was easy to get lost; I often found that I was in the wrong room and looking at a painting that didn't correspond to the description on the audio guide.

A living work of art. This gallery/home is the epitome of all that the Renaissance and Baroque epoch has to offer. A world class experience includes the art, the house and the gardens. Not to be missed. Part of the Roma Pass.

Overwhelming number of things to see. Very full of statues and paintings, overwhelmingly so. You have to pre-book to get in and it was not cheap. You have to hand over your passport or similar if you want to audio guide (nothing to tell you this when we booked). Its a fair walk to nearest underground station. You can not take your own photos the books or other products which you can buy to take home those memories have very limited images of what is on display, there is one ceiling in particular which is amazing but not eve a post card of it to buy.

Must book in advance. Luckily our hotel had booked at our request about ten days in advance. At the end of March there were no slots available during our four day visit. The setting of the Galleria had a particular character of its own: the fist spring sunshine and families and couples out to enjoy the weekend together. The museum was stunning, particularly the rooms themselves (beautiful ceilings and walls) and we really enjoyed the sculptures.

Fascinating!. The art on display, the house/mansion turned galleria, and history of the Borgheses and their influence on Rome and Italian history is well summed up in the Galleria Borghese. It is also in the huge park so you can enjoy a picnic before or after, or both.

Rude Staff!. The artwork is fantastic, but I have to rate the Galleria Borghese as average due to the rude behavior of staff. Primarily, I'm referring to the receptionist/ticket counter staff and the coat checkers who I openly saw snarl at customers. Unacceptable!

A jewel that cannot be missed!. You can - and should - buy your tickets in advance for this treasure well siutated above Rome. Take your time and enjoy the rooms with the paintings and scultures as well as the trompe l'oeil ceilings. Take your time and enjoy the park as well. Lastly, once here, walk over to the Museum of Modern Art (mainly early 20th century). That is the unknown secret of Rome.

A good place but overpriced. Be very aware when visiting Galleria Borghese not to mix it with Villa Borghese, as they are not that close, so you can miss you hour for visiting the gallery. I don't agree that you need a special guide, only ten minutes on the net, you can see what you need to pay attention at, and learn the basic things about the masterpieces in this gallery.. There is a perfect Caravaggio, Rafael, Bernini. It is actually a small gallery and no doubt worth visiting. But it is expensive, and you MUST buy your tickets in advance at least one week earlier. The gardens are simply gorgeous, quiet and if you have time and want some rest from the roman crowd , that's the right place.

Must see! And more importantly! Must book!!!. Please have your booking done in advance one week or more. I saw many people stranded as the gallery takes on only so many people at a time. I called them and booked seamlessly 10 days in advance. The gardens are unkept and you can skip them and save time unless you want to bike with your kids or family. They have bike rentals.

Not worth it. Perhaps I am used to American museums where an effort is made to teach visitors about each featured item. We walked around the museum not knowing anything about what we were looking at. It's also pricey for a very small venue with a limited private collection.

Over rated and a long way out. Had a tight scheduled but managed to make it here. On reflection we could have missed this one gallery ( perhaps we had seem so many amazing sights by then this was one too many). It is a long way from most of the other sights. Would have liked to have been able to walk around the garden immediately around the villa too.

Galleria Borghese - incredible sculpture and paintings. The Galleria Borghese was one of our favorite sights in Rome. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the price of admission. Plenty of Carvaggio paintings on the 2nd floor. Highly recommend the audio guide as it focuses you on the important work(s) in each room. Otherwise the gallery could be overwhelming if you try to take in everything - it's very cluttered and you only have 2 hours. You need to make reservation in advance.

A MUST SEE!. I only knew that there were lots of sculptures in the gallery, but had absolutely no knowledge of arts or artists before going there. Audio guide gave really good information on various sculptures, especially Bernini's works. His works are marvelous. I am totally in love with Bernini. It is also amazing to see how his skills contribute so much in making Rome such a beautiful city! A must see attraction!

Giacometti. During our visit there was a special show of Giacometti artworks at the place. For me as a fan of contemporary art the installation of the works and comparing the artist's thoughts with the old sculptures in Galleria Borghese was amazing. We spend hours there and the place was really inspirational.

Overwhelming. No doubt the art in this gallery is extraordinary (the Bernini sculptures!) but the way it is organized is horrific. There is too much crammed into the space, the eye doesn't know where to look. Perhaps this is how the organizers intended it to be. I don't recommend coming here on your first day in Rome, it gave me a migraine headache, frankly. I suggest you buy a Roma pass (if you're in town for a few days) and use it to skip the line or book online in advance. They allot two hours for you to browse, but I was in and out of there in 30 minutes.

a worthy stop. If you are not a art/history buff you may want to spring a few extra euro for a tour but they can last a couple of hours. The gardens outside are outstanding. The coffee shop inside is surprising good

Worst gallery in Italy. I visit the gallery because I red good comments in different sources, but when i was there, its not worth it! The paintures are very bad illuminated, and the visit is very short, and the personel is awfull, you cant go inside with your purse, camera, anything at all, and when I asked if they were responsible in case of lost, they told me: this is ITALY, not MEXICO!!!! Worts comment ever, im mexican!!!!! Now I understand the problems of Italy: ITALIANS!!!!! They are not making us any favor, but we are by visiting!!!!
Beautiful. Beautiful museum with paintings, arts etc. The building itself inside is a jewel to see. Do reserve tickets on forehand, you can't buy tickets there.

Beautiful art, poor organization.. The art was lovely. We loved the Caravaggios and the Bernini sculptures took my breath away. The organization of the museum is overwhelming and took away from the experience. The ticket line was insane, bag check for all bags, including purses,outright rude, and museum is crowded with tour groups. Enjoyed, but not as great as expected. Did like the park quite a bit.

Amazing. The Bernini sculptures alone make this place worthwhile. I believe it is also the largest collection of Caravaggio paintings.Be sure to book ahead of time. Our hotel was able to make reservations without any extra fees.

Best Roman Attraction. Absolutely stunning art gallery, filled with incredible sculptures and paintings. I would recommend an audio guided tour as you can wander around independently, but if you're a glutton for information try and book a tour guide (externally to the gallery's services). Remember to book in advance (get your hotel to do it or send them an email before you travel just to be safe), or you may not get a chance to view this incredible gallery. Better than The Louvre in my opinion, although considerably smaller (yet more personal as limited spaces for visitors per day). Also, situated in the most beautiful part of Rome, so after viewing the gallery you can wander off to see the rest of the park, the Villa, cinema, zoo, gellato, a bite to eat, you name it.

Awesome!!. We took the metro to get to the Galleria. The walk from the metro stop to the Galleria was long. However, it was worth the walk. I just finished that they allowed pictures. We used the Roma pass to pay for the attraction. Once you purchase your Roma pass you need to call to make an appointment. Good thing I made the appointment before leaving for our vacation. The day we had our tour people were being turned away since the Galleria was fully booked. The next available day was two days later.

Berninis & Caravaggios. Several Bernini sculptures, some spectacular (Apollo & Daphne; the Rape of Proserpina), and a whole room full of Caravaggios, including his self-portrait as decapitated Goliath head. You must make reservations in advance and will have only two hours to enjoy. (But that was enough for us).
Bernini. I love the work of Bernini - and his best work is in this gallery. Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Prosperpina. There are also smaller statuary such as a bronze Neptune that is wonderful.

Breathtaking... use Roma Pass!. The Borghese gallery houses some of the most beautiful art in Rome. There are many sculptors by Bernini and other great artist. We took a cab to location but walked back to Rosetta Inn (Great place to stay). Make a reservation far in advance and enjoy the people watching in the park surrounding the gallery.

Amazing Museum. This was our second visit to this beautiful museum and it's masterpieces. It is not crowned because only a certain number of people are admitted every two hours. The audio guide is good. Used it our first visit. The "live" guide is even better. Our best suggestion, Purchase your tickets early on the internet.

Take time for the view,too.. The park is big and lovely. Take time out to explore it. There is a fantastic view of the city not too far from the villa. We took the little train and it was worth it.The galleria is lovely as expected.Get reservations!

Allow Extra Time For The Walk. As other reviewers have stated, be sure to book tickets in advance and arrive early. If you are walking from the middle of the city, allow plenty of time as The Villa is located quite a distance inside the Gardens. Glad that we visited, it is one of the highlights of our trip to Rome. The Frescoes are amazing . Loved the Bernini sculptures !

Giacometti Exhibit is terrific!. Be certain to book admission tickets well in advance as they are very limited. Well worth going if there is a special exhibit. However, in my opinion it was over-restored a number of years ago and the frescoes are very garish. While there are some fabulous sculptures and paintings most of the others are not memorable.
art beauty. Beautiful Italian works of art, dating back to 1400's and beyond. Fills up quickly in shifts, go early.

Amazing Bernini statues. You must book tickets days in advance or you will not get in. The statues are magnificent and they have the most amazing collection of art. The Bernini statues are exquisite. It is worth going just for these. Get the audio guide. It is very good. The gallery is in the middle of the Villa Borghese gardens. Closest metro is Spagna. There are a couple of expensive restaurants in the gardens. You can also hire bicycles and Segways. The gardens are lovely and a welcome area of green and quiet after days in the busy city.

A must see in Rome - Book ahead!!!. SUMMARY: Book ahead, especially in peak tourism season! Otherwise you'll probably be disappointed. This is an absolute must while in Rome. We had a friend suggest to book a ticket in advance (as we were going in June, peak tourism time) and are SO thankful we did! Several people I talked to waiting in line were hoping to get tickets the day of. Unfortunately, they were sold out 2-3 days in advance. Once you have your ticket, you will have to wait in a short line (much shorter than those trying to purchase) in order to pick it up. You have a certain time-frame where you are allowed into the gallery, I believe it is 2 hours. I really liked this so that it wasn't so crowded (like some of the other places we visited). The picture shows the walk up to the gallery. It was a beautiful place to spend the afternoon.

Outstanding Museum. I have visited this museum several times will return every time I am in Rome. The gallery is relatively small and not overwhelming, as are so many other world-class collections. I am especially fond of the Bernini sculptures and the stunning villa which is the setting for the artwork. The number of visitors is limited to two-hour periods, requiring a reservation.Sadly, I must add a safety warning. I had a gold necklace ripped from my neck by a young thug on my approach to the museum in the Villa Borghese park. Visitors should guard their valuables closely in the park and in all public transport in Rome.
Great time. The Borghese was wonderful but I think that it is a bit over rated. It is a must when you are in Rome but I have been to other amazing art museums.

Overwhelming and not to be missed. What a gem of a place. The villa itself is gorgeous with wonderful frescoes, and it houses treasures by Bernini, Caravaggio and others. We happened to go while a exhibition of Giacometti was on. Book early or miss out on one the great galleries of Rome.

The best of Bernini. Beautiful museum, featuring a selection of top Renaissance paintings and, what I liked best, top sculptures of Bernini. You have to pre book and get 2 hours to visit, which was only just enough time for us. This system results in a fairly quiet museum where you can see all works from a really close distance. Special!

must visit place. it's fabuluos place and definetely must see. this time in Rome I fell in love with Bernini's works and enjoyed them in gallery. Tickets are expensive though and you can't just buy them, you hace to book them day or 2 before. So we had to come 2 times. But when you are inside you forget about everything.

Gorgeous Gallery and Priceless Bernini Marbles. This is a wonderful gallery with the most amazing works of art that include many renowned marble sculptures by Bernini. These were amazing to see, with lots of time to admire them. You must reserve tickets ahead of time. It is convenient to do so on-line. You must chose your date and also a time slot. They have strict 2 hour time slots. So reading a little about the artworks to be seen before going is helpful in planning your time while there. The gallery is in the enormous & beautiful Villa Borghese park with paths, trails, ponds, a zoo and is of interest for a day's outing. Stopping outside the entrance to the Galleria is a little train on wheels that will take you all about the park for about half an hour...very relaxing and scenic. It stops off at a scenic outlook over the city for passengers to take photos too. It was an inexpensive little ride, well worth the time and fun for everyone. This is a very nice outing and change from the bustle of the most touristic sights. You are not allowed to take any photos inside the Galleria.

MAGNIFICENT. This is where I fell in love with the art of sculpture. At the start of my tour, I walked into a room only to be disappointed in that it appeared they were working on one of the large pieces. When I got close, the covering was caved!! It was made to be a sheet-this was when I fell in love with Bernini. To be able to have taken a hard piece of stone and actually make it appear soft...well...it just "blew my mind".

Book ahead. I don't claim to be an art critic, but I know what I like and this collection was fantastic! The highlight for me was Bernini's 'Rape of Proserpina', the look in her eyes as Pluto grabs her thighs is haunting.The exhibits are not well labeled though, so I would recommend either a detailed guide book or hiring the audio guide. There are laminated 'mini-guides' in each room, but they are not very detailed.As other reviewers have mentioned, you do need to book your chosen 2 hour slot a few days ahead. If you are planning on using your Roma Pass (worth it as it's the 2nd most expensive attraction after the Colosseum) you need to reserve by phone. The number is on the website and they speak good English.

Great Museum for a Quick Stop. We didn't know about the Borghese Gallery until we got to Rome and realized how close we were to it. Because they limit the time and people to the museum, it was one of the more enjoyable experiences without feeling crowded or rushed. There is beautiful art and some of the best Bernini sculptures around ("David", "Apollo and Daphne", and "Pluto and Proserpina").
Bernini is my favourite artist. We loved the Bernini masterpieces, Daphne and Apollo is the most famous artwork of this small gallery.We booked the tickets in advance, reservation is mandatory!

next-level sculptures. after seeing a ton of sculptures, what could be so special about this place? You NEED to see the incredible details in this place. Rick Steves' free audioguide on itunes was fabulous, and made the place SO much more enjoyable!

Fantastico!!. amazing, stunning, wonderful, breathtaking. There aren't enough words to do this collection and its setting justice. JUST GO! make sure to pre-book as only 80 people allowed in per 2 hour visit and it is constantly sold out on the day. I can't wait to go back

Best thing we did in Rome. This was simply exquisite and surpassed all my expectations. An amazing villa/gallery stuffed with incredible art, sculptures, paintings, frescoes. If you have the slightest interest in art, don't miss this place. You have to pre book to get a slot as it's always sold out in advance, you can't turn up and expect to get in. But so worth doing. And lovely to wander through the park to reach it. Very pleasant half day.

Perfect!. This was our first time in Rome. Our friends had visited several times but had not yet been to the Galleria. We all felt it was the perfect size. It took us about 90 minute to see all of the rooms. Each room was laid out in a way that made sense. We enjoyed the beautiful paintings throughout. Definitely make time to fit it in.

Must do!. I'm no art freak, have no background in art whatsoever but I dare say that anyone with an open mind will find this visit a highlight of any Roman holiday. The Borghese art collection expands from antique sculptures to baroque paintings (Caravaggio...) or sculptures (Bernini's Apollo and Daphne!) and is simply mind-blowing.Make sure you book in advance as tickets (pre)sell fast. Visits are limited to 2 hours (a shame given the treasures in this collection but a good thing as it limits the number of people at any moment and ensure a -very- pleasant visit).
enlightning !!. very interesting if you like classical art in it's glory.Amazing what Bernini could do at such young age.Don't forget to book in advance. You can tour the museum for 2 hours.

Wow. Basically how many colourful spectacular treasures can you cram into one building. The ground floor was amazing, and by the time you get to the second floor you are a bit wow-ed out, just like a lot of places in Rome. Definitely worth the visit, especially if you have a Roma Pass. We got the metro to Spagna and had a pleasant walk through the Park to the gallery.

Each time I go to Rome, I go bacck to Galleria Borghese. The Borghese Galleria is a must everytimes I go to Rome.I can see its Berninis all the times and is never enough.Rome is fascinating, and I believe the Berninis in Galleria Borghese are the best sculpture after La Pieta di Michelangelo. in S. Pietro.The Pinccio park, is extraordinary too.Don´t miss it, I recomand it very very much !!!
Perfect walk in the park.. You have to walk through the park to get to the gallery and it's beautiful and serene. The art in this place is magnificent.

truly an incredible visit. This museum/gallery has given me my fondest memories of art in Rome. It is not that large, but the exhibits range from very good to beyond exquisite. My wife and I both were most impressed with the marble works, although there is much more to admire than that. Booking must be done by reservation and is best done day(s) in advance. IT IS ABSOLUTELY WORTH BUILDING YOUR SCHEDULE AROUND THIS VISIT!!!

One of the best galleries I've seen- fantastic sculptures, well-organised with info on each room.. This was one of the many highlights of my trip to Rome. As someone who can appreciate art without possessing a lot of knowledge of it, I had a fantastic time in this gallery. Each room has an A3 laminate detailing the highlights and you move from room-to-room admiring some incredible pieces.Absolute must-see for any art lovers. A bit of a trek to go to!

Bernini - Go to see these!. Some of Bernini's greatest sculptures are here - "Apollo and Daphne" (simply memorizing) the "Rape of Proserpine" (you can feel the emotions) and the power of "David". There are also many famous paintings, including works by Raphael, Rubins, Bellini and Caravaggio.You must pre-book the tickets as numbers each day are limited - with set entrance and exits times (a two hour slot). You cannot take large bags into the museum (they have to be checked into the cloak room) and no photographs or videos can be taken inside. There is a small cafe within the building (note you go to the cafe till to pay first, then take your receipt to the counter to get your food).

What a great collection.. Must make reservations ahead of time. Easy to travel on the bus. Walk to the gallery. Easy after the visit to walk to the area above the Spanish Steps. A great collection of Bernini.
