Not bad. Great collection of Bernini, take the guided tour or try to 'listen in' doing school groups. The park surrounding it is also beautiful. If you have time, get a sandwich and have a picnic right outside.

Good art, poor organisation!. I'm not a Renaissance fan but some of the sculptures were really impressive. Really loved Apollo and Daphne!l Lots to see, audio guide a good addition. 2 hours is all you get but for me that was just right. Some good paintings too and a lovely building set in a large park with other attractions justifying setting aside more time. You must book in advance.I didn't like the fact that you are fixed to a specified 2hr time slot. It's a crush to get in, there's a queue for audio guides, they're no room to stand in line to check in your camera as the previous crowd are collecting theirs. The flow in the entrance hall is a mess. You can't check a coat into the cloakroom but you have to check in your small bag. They need to rethink this reservation policy!

Must see a fantastic collection of the Bernini's sculptures.. This galleria is one of my favorite place in Rome. You can walk there from the Spanish Steps.Some of the finest art collection is here for example Caravaggio or Bernini.Some of the Bernini's masterpieces: Aeneas and Anchises, The Rape of Proserpina, David, Apollo and Daphne. And above all of it the sculpture of Paolina Bonaparte (Borghese) as Venus Victrix.You can hire an audio guide for 5 Euro. There is a restaurant, a toilet as well. You have to leave a bags in a safe deposit downstairs. No photo allowed in the gallery.Highly recommend.

So cool. Loved this museum. I had a guidebook from Rick Steve's it was so helpful to have info, so i knew what was the most import artwork. My aunt as rented a guidebook from the museum and liked that well.

Get Audio guide to have the full Experience.. An OMG experience in seeming the most magnificent sculptures in Rome. Truly breath taking in marble, beyond words in their beauty! Worth every euro and get the audio guide device, well worth the extra fee. Ticket reservations are cumbersome but possible to get day of if you go early.

Make a reservation! . My husband and I didn't know that they only let a certain number people in all day. We got there around 2pm and the tickets were already sold out for the whole day! They closed at 7pm on the day. We were really surprised and disappointed. However the park around the gallery was beautiful. A nice place to rest for a little while before heading back to see more sights!

slight disappointment here. although many caravaggios and berninis (stunning) were of course worth seeing, there was a jobsworth's attitude to taking any sort of bag into the exhibitions (difficult to smuggle a bernini out in your clutch handbag) and the curation was poor - inadequate english translations and often not even an italian explanation or detail - though the antique and very beautiful lift for the use of disabled was welcome as well as exciting to travel in! It was quite a walk from our bus stop to get to the villa, and it turns out there's a 'train' that goes round the park that we didn't know about. Nobody could tell us its schedule or times though. I'm glad we made the effort to go (we found it difficult to access by public transport) but wasn't particularly impressed given its international status - the Villa Doria Pamphili was better, and better value, though the decoration of the Borghese salons is gorgeous.. Be warned - the timed entry means you only have 2 hours there before you get thrown out. It's enough, unless, like us, it takes you so long to find your way you're late!
An important gallery in a quiet corner of a beautiful park. There are laminated cards in each room. Pick one up and use it for each and every room so you will be well informed.

Really worth the effort to get a reservation. Incredible works of art in magnificent setting. The paintings were memorable but the true stars of the show are the Bernini sculptures. Almost impossible to understand how they could have been executed, particularly Apollo and Daphne. Bernini David is magnificent, a young man in a determined, dynamic pose, attacking rather than at rest.
Good artistic experience. Amaizing art collection, confusing italself with Barroque and Rome history. The entrance system needs to be improved.
Pantheon. One of the most stunning buildings I have ever seen...I could have spent hours there - and i's FREE!!

beautiful Bernini's. With only two hours to visit, I left wanting more. The Bernini sculptures were fabulous and I gained a new appreciation for Baroque art through them. We had a guide, which was really helpful because she had us focus on a few pieces in depth rather than looking at every single thing and then not getting much out of it in the end.

Tint Treasure trove of Renaissance art. This is a great place to go if you don't want to spend hours walking around a big gallery or museum. It is compact yet full of great examples of paintings and sculptures from the Renaissance era and beyond. I wanted to see the three or so Caravaggio paintings here, but I was actually more entranced by the statues depicting scenes from (mainly) Roman mythology, which are incredibly detailed and beautiful. Entry is staggered so there aren't too many people viewing at one time but there is ample time to see all that is on offer and although it costs, it is worth the entrance fee. It gives visitors a quick taste of Italian art without having to queue or spend too long looking. In short, the perfect place for the curious but impatient or those who are interested but have limited attention spans.

lovely place. the artwork on the ceilings are amazing , its truly beautiful the only thing i didn't like was it went on for ages there is only so much you can take in before getting tired. there was things that were repetitive. A negative part was staff were rude as hell .
Good display of 17th Century art. It was very hot inside and made visiting the galleries difficult. Good selection of things, but the Vatican museum tops them by far

I love the Berninis!. The park is lovely and the Galleria is amazing, if only to see the Bernini's. I couldn't get over them. I could have stayed there longer but the maximum we were allowed is 2 hours. I'll have to go back again...
Beautiful villa. I loved the great art in a magnificent setting! It was a little hard for us to find, but very worthwhile once we got there.

Stunning Artwork Surrounded by Nature. Rome is so busy - it was nice to get away from the noise and go to the Villa Borghese park. In the park is the Galleria Borghese which was where the Borghese family also got away from it all and kept their sculptures and artwork. I am not normally a museum or art person, but the Bernini statues were breathtaking as were some of the Caravaggio paintings. The ceilings were magnificent with some of the paintings looking three dimensional. Unfortunately, no photos are allowed.In January, the gallery was not crowded at all, and there are places to sit in each room so you can enjoy the surroundings. I would definitely recommend a visit.

Absolutely fabulous. Pre booking online wasn't a problem and the system worked perfectly. After checking in our bags we went round the two floors (quite steep stairs, not a problem for us, but some folk may struggle), and saw a fabulous collection of statues and paintings. Bernini, Raphael, Caravaggio, Titian, what a collection, and set in a wonderful house in spectacular gardens. A great day out and fantastic art!!!

Just a bit overrated. It's pretty tough to get tickets to this galleria And it's one of the more stricter gallerias we toured - you can not bring any purses or backpack into it - you have to check them at baggage before entering. As other's noted, the park surrounding the Galleria is beautiful. We spent a couple of hours walking around and enjoying the park. There are some stunning paintings and sculptures in the Galleria and though I think it was overrated, I would still recommend that if time permits you go here.

Often overlooked but shouldn't be. You shouldn't miss this off your list during a city break. The Bernini's are spectacular. The location is a lovely quiet spot out of the city, but close enough to easily walk too.

impossible to describe. Because it was the off season, we walked straight in and could see everything in our own time. Wonderful. The audio guides are cash only and you must have picture i.d. to rent them. The café has a good cappuccino for a reasonable price.
Beautiful Architecture. Showed how the nouveau rich lived in Italy - we do not see this arhitecture in Canada. Liked the decorative touches to the architecture

If you like Bernini. Part of the attraction here is the location--walking through the park is so pleasant. The Bernini sculptures and the Caravaggios are worthy of study. Especially notice the eyes in the Bernini work. The museum states that advance tickets are essential, but in January, it is possible to walk right in without reservations.

Make your reservation asap!. The Borghese Gallery is one of the most impressive museums in Rome. The Bernini scultpures are unreal. I could have sat and stared at them all day. Even though we only had two hours to see everything, it was nice to go in with the limited number of people, so that we could enjoy the artwork and not fight crowds. Make your reservations early and purchase the audio-guide. It's one of the better audio guides available in Rome.
Not to miss!. The art is amazing! They regulate the numbers and the time spent so the crowds are not overwhelming. Get the recorded guide! It was very helpful and kept me from missing anything.

Worth the kaos. Wonderful! Had a guided tour - would highly recommend and ensure you reserve tickets ahead of time. They have a very disorganized system for picking up tickets and entering the museum, but once that is out of the way it was fabulous.

A must-see for art lovers. A must-see. Recommended by one of my Italian colleagues back home, this was one of the highlights of my trip. You must book in advance as the number of tickets per slot are limited, as is your allotted time. The audio guide really complements the visit.A visit to Rome is incomplete without the galleria Borghese. Despite being out of the way, it's the perfect way to start, or end, a day of touring.
very good museum. went as acouple, on asunday; without ordering tickets!had to wait only 45 min to go in. was not crouded.had an excelent time.will come again. p.s. had much better coffee in rome...

With out question.. With out question the most exquisite museum in the World. Cardinal Scipio Borghese didn't build this to live in. No one ever lived in it, as I am told. It was built to demonstrate to the World the sophistication of the Borghese. The Titian's and Caravagio's aside, the Bernini sculptures were specifically commissioned for their place. If you fail to go here while in Rome, well then you will just have to go back.Book in advance. They control crowds.
Delightful from the outside!. We didn't have time to go into the gallery but it looked stunning from the outside! Set in lovely park grounds, you can enjoy a walk from the station before going in.

Try it!. Everything are amazing. If u have a time u should go there check the paintings. For romapass card its free entrance if u did not use anywhere except colosseum. We came here end of january and we did not make a reservation for tickets. we try our chance and it was our last day in rome and we entered at 4 o clock without reservation. We came and we entered. But if u dont want to try your chance, book it. Negative thing is no information for paintings. Just who made it. really dissappointment in this way.

One of the most acclaimed museums in the world. I just can't possible phrase how awe-inspiring the works are. You have never seen this amount of decoration, and that's all of it - frescoes, sculptures, masterpieces (not a blank wall in sight, not a part of the museum that doesn't stimulate the senses). One must visit this museum.Highlights: Caravaggio's room (four pieces including my particular favourite 'David with the head of Goliath', only one is displayed elsewhere, fortunately for us (boy with a basket of fruit...yes that one is pretty but I'm talking about January here)Bernini's 'Rape of Persephone and 'Apollo and Daphne' - this will move youCanova's 'Pauline Bonaparte' - you've never seen anything like it, masterpiece of neo-classicismGetting there:I took the metro to Flaminio and enjoyed a twenty minute walk via Piazza del Popolo and Villa Borguese, then I took the metro back from Spagna, it's not hard at all, and the walk is so scenic!
Beautiful. Great time visiting the Borghese Gallery. Wish they would let you take pics inside...but oh well. Still very cool to see inside and all the beautiful marble and rooms.

NIice little museum in the park, residential neighborhood. Pretty museum, old art, need reservations ahead of time.
Nothing to eat or do nearby thought so we ended up eating in the snack bar in the museum.

Fun, but a little further out. My husband and I had mixed reviews on Galleria Borghese. I was not as impressed, though I was exhausted and had blisters from the day before and the long trek through Villa Borghese to get here. *I recommend getting a taxi vs. trying to walk to Galleria Borghese. It's a little further out from the other attractions, without many bus stops. We walked through Villa Borghese from the Church of Santa Maria del Popolo. So my lack of a pleasant experience may of been more self-inflicted vs what the museum offered. This was a highlight on the trip for my husband. He found it a great opportunity to see many pieces of art displayed the location they were designed for, especially the collection of Bernini statues. My husband rented the audio guide here and found it helpful. Photography not allowed inside.

All the best under a poor light. The museum inside Villa Borghese has a wonderful collection of pieces of art. Over all i'd like to remember the Apollo and Daphne sculpture. Only one thing gave a poor impression of the visit: all the illumination implant of the Villa has been made very bad. Apart the sculptures that were well lighted, all the paintings were poor or bad illuminated with reflections on the surface that didn't allow to admire them as they merit. Nevertheless the musuem must be visited, the "Apollo and Daphne" sculpture alone will be an enough payback.

One of three "don't miss" museums in Rome. The museum collection and decorations are simply breathtaking. Anyone whose review says otherwise is simply flat out wrong. I have been to a couple dozen museums in Rome, this is in my top 3. Best time to visit is when it opens first thing in the morning. Ignore the complaints about getting to the museum, and getting tickets. Be smart, take a taxi, and buy your "skip the line" tickets thru ViaTour. A taxi from the forum area was $15. Why waste your time trying to figure out buses? After the museum, stroll through Villa Borghese park, and work your way to the Spanish Steps. Lovely views, nice park (lots to see) and it sure is wonderful to get off the city streets for a bit. We then took a taxi from the Spanish steps to Trastavere for lunch, two more musuems, and a church or two. A great itinerary for a day in Rome.

Tour. You need to make reservations for this tour ahead of arrival. Make sure you ask for the english speaking tour guide. They automatically give you the head sets which is not as interesting of a tour as having a personal guide. The english speaking tour guide- Ludovica is wonderful! The rest of the staff is not friendly. Actually we were shocked at how rude the staff was. But the art is wonderful.

Awkward to get to. You have to book in advance and I was late arriving for the 0900 slot so I wondered if my ticket might have got reallocated but there was no problem as it's off season. Didn't float my boat and the pictures I'd most wanted to see just happened to be out on loan elsewhere! It is what it is. BTW I got a metro to Barberini and 52 bus from there stops just outside.
Could spend DAYS there. The art collection is unparalleled, the grounds are truly amazing as well. The history of the Borghese family combined with the sheer grandeur is almost overwhelming.

Try your luck with cancellations. Even though the website says you must make a reservation, you may still be able to get in without if there are cancellations, especially at unpopular times such as 5-7pm. That is exactly what the guy in line right in front of me did, when I picked up my ticket at 5:15pm. Wish I had known-- this would have helped me stay flexible and saved me 2 euros of online reservation service fee. I thought this museum was slightly overrated/overpriced-- sure, the centerpieces in each room (many by Bernini) were quite classic, and the gladiator mosaics in the center lobby was cool, but otherwise the collection were a bit repetitive... I tried to read the multilingual brochures in each room explaining the artwork, but perhaps I should have gotten an audio guide. Overall, I'd say it'd be worth it if you used Roma Pass to get the discounted price. Two hours should be more than enough.
Well worth visiting. The Borghese is a must see for its art and history. And be sure to leave time to stroll the grounds and park surrounding the Galleria, you won't be disappointed.
Beautiful Park and Gallery. A "must see" in Rome. Out of the historic center but worth the trip out to visit. Plenty of bus connections to get there.
A fantastic collection. Go for the house itself, go for the inside, and for the fantastic collection of art. An opportunity to meet a "Borghese" house

A MUST-SEE in Rome. GREAT crash course to Renaissance art. We LOVED it. The Bernini sculptures here were OUTSTANDING. There are also several Caravaggios which are pretty famous. It's an old mansion, and it was the private collection of the powerful Borghese family. We'd go back, but make sure you get reservations online!

If you only have time for one gallery in Rome, do this one!. We only had time for one gallery in Rome, and were so glad we chose this one. We booked online our appointment time one week beforehand. We took the audio guide and that was so interesting as we could take our time looking at everything and listen to more detail through the little earphones at our leisure. From talking with our guests on our trip, if you only have time for one gallery in Rome, do this one!

Go in the morning! Use audio guide or tours..... For the best experience, be among the first in the morning when it opens up - even if you have the mandatory reservations. Once you are in, it is easy to soak up this awesome place at ease than jostling for some quiet time. Unlike the biggies, Vatican or Capitoline - this place is relatively smaller. Guided tour or renting an audio guide will be worth the euros spent. This museum does a poor job of having labels or summary plates describing what the art work or sculpture is about. Compared to other museums in Rome, it is surprising that they overlook this. Each room do have a collection of 1-page summary sheets in different languages but they are only 1 copy and in that rush of crowds, you'll never get hold of that. As a result, if you want the biggest bang for your buck, consider reading up about this place before you arrive to understand and appreciate what you see.

Wow !. Wonderful exhibits...sculpture and paintings from the masters ! Set inside Villa Borghese park which is a wonderful walk-through in any season get 52 bus from Piazza Venezia or grand entry into the park from Piazza del Popolo (near Flaminio Metro) then a stroll to the Galleria...

FANTASTIC!. WoW! If you are going to Rome do not skip this great place.We took part in the guided tour offered at the Gallery and were so fortunate to have Maria as our Guide. The details she shared with us were interesting and varied. Maria made the sculptures and paintings come to life. When you combine her passion and enthusiasm with her excellent story telling (delivery of the subject) and knowledge.....well then it's magic!This gallery only allows a limited amount of visitors per day and you need to book ahead of time your two hour block you are allowed to be in the gallery. The benefit is that you are not all crowded in here like some other places you may visit in Rome (eg. Vatican). Contact the Borghese Gallery website to book and then you can arrive early to sign up to join the guided tour. You cannot pre-book this guided tour. I don't think our tour was full. Note: No cameras allowed in here. Allow time to enjoy the park area around this gallery.One of the highlights of our Trip!

Everything It Is Said To Be. A great experience. The displays are superb and you get a really good commentary on the audio guide. The pace for moving through the exhibit is not rushed and we were comfortably out within the two hours. It is a decent walk so plan ahead to ensure that you get there in time for your booked visit.

Unmissable treasures. Must be the greatest small art and sculpture collection ever assembled. You need to book a time slot in advance, and it is not the easiest place to reach, but the experience is unforgettable. The Bernini statues and Caravaggio and Titian paintings are breathtaking. The Borghese park is a lovely spot for a stroll afterwards.
Wow!. This is definitely worth going online and booking tickets. The art was amazing. The building itself was gorgeous. There was so much to marvel at in amazement.

Beautiful Villa and Art Work. We made advance reservations to visit this home turned into art museum. It is located in Borghese Park and is a very beautiful and imposing villa. We greatly enjoyed the experience except for the fact that there were too many visitors touring the various rooms in the villa. Also the audio tour is hard to follow at times and so we needed to consistently make sure we were in the right room for it to work. The audio tour is essential in order to understand the art work the visitor is viewing.

Amazing trip back to time thanks to an amazing tour guide!!!. Since it was very first time in Rome, we were planning and hoping that everything would be at least ok. Our tour in Galleria Borghese, along with our walk to the gardens was far beyond any expectation. We were mostly amazed by Bernini's sculptures, but above all, it was our tour guide's capacity and deep knowledge that made our visit worth to remember. Special thanks to Rebecca on our 12.01.14 tour, who managed to travel us back to time in such an unforgettable way...she is just born to do so...Many thanks from the Greek visitors!!!

Bernini sculptures you can't miss!. There were many sculptures there were exquisite . Bernini's Apollo and Daphne and another David are just 2 "must sees". We were there in Jan. and we still needed to pre buy tickets because this museum is so popular. The rooms themselves were spectacular and the paintings on the ceilings were giving me neck cramps. The gardens surrounding the museum were also beautiful. Totally worth while but you have to get tickets. It is less expensive to buy tickets on site but chances are, you cannot get in on the same day if you just show up to go.

A GREAT GALLERY TO SEE IN ROME. My wife and I visited Rome on our own after the completion of our Mediterranean cruise. We had read about this Gallery in the Rick Steves Rome Book so we had an idea of what we would see and we reserved tickets in advance as recommended. They only allow a certain number of visitors each day and your visit is limited to 2 hours so you have to plan your visit in order to make sure you see the artwork you really want to see. (There were dozens of visitors that came up while we were there that had no reservations/tickets and they were all sent away.) It can be a little chaotic when you check in as you have to check bags (at a different desk than the one you get your tickets at) and if you want headsets with the guided audio tour (requires an additional charge), you have to go to a third desk. The staff at the museum were polite but not overly friendly so you have to pay attention and be proactive in asking questions to ensure you follow all of their rules. The Gallery is in the Villa Borghese Park so I suggest getting to the area early so you can stroll through the park or just people watch as it is a very interesting park with lots of history. The actual art collection is wonderful and it contains many pieces that most only hear about from a book or on TV. The only negative was that the museum brochure and audio tour list works by identification numbers that have either been changed or no longer exist (or are so obscured you cannot see them) so if you are too anal, you will lose time trying to find works of art that are out being restored/cleaned or that are no longer on display. I found I had to limit my time trying to find certain items to just a few seconds and then I moved on to the next work so I had sufficient time to take in the whole museum. I recommend this Gallery if you like legendary works of art that are a big part of history.

A fabulous art collection in a splendid park. A Californian friend highly recommended to visit the Galleria Borghese in the Villa Borghese to see the fabulous Bernini sculptures. Already the way though the park was an amazing walk. It reminded me a bit of central park just more elegant - in a way. Luckily we got the last tickets to a just beginning 2 hr visit (each visit is limited to a certain amount of visitors and 2 hrs time, that makes it quite comfy to wander through the exhibition). With the audio guide my son and I were able to listen to all the background info on the gallery and the artwork!It was stunning to see what Cardinal Borghese has put together some 380 years ago. Especially the Bernini sculptures took my attention as I have never seen anything comparable carved out of stone.Of all attractions in Rome this one left the deepest impression. A very special place to go!

Splendid art collection in a spectacular palace. We visited villa Borghese, its gardens and its magnificent art collection recently. Our tour guide from Dark Rome through Viator travel, Rebecca was extraordinary. She made our experience unforgettable with her thorough knowledge and her genuine enthusiasm about her work. So do not go without a knowledgeable guide, unless you are an expert. You only are allowed a 2-hour stay in the villa as only a certain amount of people is allowed each time - and also pre-book the tickets. There are so many things to admire - and the walk through the gardens is a pleasure.

Fantastic Sculptures. I came here to see the sculptures by Gian Lorenzo Bernini and was absolutely blown away. They are some of the most realistic depictions of the human form I've ever seen. Everything from the wrinkles in a couch to the veins on a man's hands is perfectly carved in marble.The gallery is a very nice and quiet. You have to make reservations in advance, so they limit the number of people inside at any time, which I think is great.The surrounding park is also quite beautiful and great for an afternoon stroll. At the end of the park there is a great view overlooking Piazza Popolo.If there is only one museum you visit in Rome, make it this one. Just be sure to book in advance because walk-ups are not allowed.

One of the world's great art galleries. The Borghese Gallery is in what was originally called a "casino" or little house, built by Cardinal Scipione Borghese to house his ever growing collection of sculptures and paintings. It has some of the best sculptures by the great Gianlorenzo Bernini and paintings by Caravaggio, Titian, Cranach, and many others. The rooms alone are great art works themselves. Remember that you must book your tour beforehand, and it is easy to do online. Then you go an hour before your tour and collect your ticket. You are allowed 2 hours in the gallery, but it is enough time for most people. A definite MUST!

Worth The Walk. Although off the beaten path per se, this is a great museaum and your 2 hour time limit is a perfect way to view the whole collection---start at the top to avoid the crowds who mostly start at the bottom!

Amazing collection but average staff. A wonderful collection of art, definitely worth a visit. But 1) you have to book tickets and time in advance; 2) takes some time to get there on foot; 3) you have to leave ALL your personal belongings in the lockers; 4) unfriendly staff. Also do not miss a lovely park.

You can skip the museum, but don't miss the gardens!. Maybe I've seen too many wonderful collections during my time in Italy, but the art in the gallery was not the high point of my visit there. You have to have a reservation, which is easy to get on their website at this time of year. It is annoying that you have to check even small purses, which is not very common. There are some important pieces but they are fewer and farther between than other museums. The gardens, though, are lovely and a perfect stroll, weather permitting. Like Central Park in NYC, it is wonderful to have such a lovely garden setting in the middle of North Rome.

It's an OMG. Plan ahead. The extraordinary collection amassed by the nouveau riche Borghese clan, two of whom were a Pope and his nephew. The villa was intended as a museum and a party place surrounded by a vast park and gardens. Visiting is strictly limited to two hours, no more, and advance reservations must be made. The sheer size of the collection is mind-boggling (until you get to the Vatican), so know what you want to see and map it out. For me, the highlight was Bernini's David, a far more active and accessible figure than Michelangelo's austere perfection. David's face is that concentrated grimace you see in discus throwers and Bernini's own perfection is in the spiral of the action.If you need bathrooms, you have to show your admission ticket.

BERNINI!. No one could ever mistake me for a connoisseur of fine art. I mean, you know, I get it, but I've never really LOVED IT. Well, this place (and the Vatican) changed all that. Some of the pieces, particularly the Bernini sculptures, actually made me well up with tears. Absolutely stunning art.Highly highly recommend getting the little listening phone, it's a very inexpensive way to self-guide your way around the most important pieces. You can enjoy the whole place in about 2 hours, which is perfect bc that's all the time they give you. This is one place I will always recommend to people that visit Rome.
A beautiful place.. Wonderful paintings and sculptures. Don't forget to book by phone to get your code and time to visit ,before to go there.

Please make time for Borghese. In my visits to Rome, I have always thought I would eventually see Borghese, but have never made time. Finally took an afternoon to see the Galleria and feel like I have cheated myself of one of the most spectacular (and relatively intimate) spots in Rome. It can be part of a wonderful day of walks through the gardens down to the Spanish steps, but however you justify the detour, you will see sculpture that will move you in ways that perfectly complement what you have seen elsewhere in Rome from Michelangelo.
Lovers of art. It's gorgeus and just for lovers of art. You can find piece of art and a nice garden with beautiful flowers

Be there for sunset. The best sunset I've seen over a city. Beautiful views and a lovely park. Avoid the electric bikes as they are evil, but the normal bikes are a great way to view the park as it's pretty big.

Lovely and small.... This is an amazing "home" to unbelievable works of art....stretches the mind to believe it really was just someone's house. The surrounding gardens are a delightful location and opportunity for rest...I believe my feet would have thanked me for more cushioned shoes...the hard flat marble floors will quickly kill you, especially if you are already a bit worn from walking the city. Be sure to make a reservation for the museum...no impromptu admittance.

Do NOT miss!. A fabulous palace with equally fabulous art treasures. Worth the effort to make reservations. Gorgeous rooms and absolutely perfect Bernini sculptures top the list. Not to mention the terrific masterpiece paintings. A mini-Louvre in the heart of Rome. You have two hours to tour - every minute is worth it! Pretty to walk to through the Borghese gardens...

Not to be missed. First of all, you must book on line in advance or you won't get in! It is a must and an unforgettable visit, with every inch of the building a work of art, with some amazing pieces and the whole idea of the Villa mind boggling, when set in historical context. I think it should be on every first visit to Rome, along with the Sistine Chapel.

If you visit only one museum in Rome. ...it should be the Borghese. Or so I read. And since we one had a few days in Rome this trip, the Borghese it was and a delightful day it was to be. So many fantastic works and the building itself is also fantastic. As is the setting in a beautiful park. And still it is small enough to be able to see everything in a leisurely way in a couple of hours. Which you must, because your visits are timed. Be sure, if you plan to go, to go online or call and reserve your tickets. You will be given a time and told to get there 1/2 hour before. A bit if a pain, but it does control the crowds!
Fine art. This is a multi story art gallery with fantastic architecture. Be in shape or ask to use the elevator.

The gem in the tiara.... A must see while in the Boot. The Borghese Museum has superb art collection and antique sculpture masterpieces of Italian 17th and 18th century. It is a very manageable viewing as only the best is on display.

Book a time and go!. Make time when in Rome to visit this superb gallery. We were debating whether to get the audio guide but I'm happy to say we did as it really made our experience here first rate. The history and background to the paintings and sculptures is captivating and very interesting. The other great thing about this gallery is that it doesn't require a huge amount of walking inside (although the grounds outside do)! Very pleasant to sit on one of the lounges and soak up a time when art was life.

A perfect Art Gallery. Book your tickets well in advance. And get there on time. There is so very much to see that it is easy to run out of time and be expected to leave before you have seen everything.

Everyone falls in love with art in this place!. One can find anything here, from sculptures, to paintings, to the most gorgeous ceiling frescoes I have seen in my life. The collections are all gorgeous and wonderful to admire, and having the chance to see such artwork was an amazing experience. Also, Villa Borghese is an extremely nice area to walk around and admire the garden there!

Reservations required. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the price of admission. Plus, Cardinal Scorpine Borghese's art acquisition story and his relationship with his uncle the Pope is fascinating. Tours start every two hours and reservations are required. We used a tour guide for one hour (11 Euros) versus the audio guide (six Euros) and it was well worth it!

Make the Effort!. While this museum requires advanced timed entry tickets it is well worth the effort. It's one of the most beautiful museums in the world and I make sure to visit each and every time we're in Rome. The collections and displays are exquisite and the audio guide is very thorough. Walking the gardens and villa park before or after rounds out the experience in a lovely way. Others are correct when they mention the staff can be curt, but to me it's just become part of the experience and has no impact on your visit unless you let it. Enjoy!!!

Bernini and so much more. This museum had exceptional paintings and sculptures in a well organized and beautiful setting. My favorite sculpture of Italy was there- Bernini's "David", and to be able to walk leisurely around it, 5 feet away, was alone worth the price of admission.

A Visit to the Museo and Galleria Borghese. The impressive collections in both the Museo and Galleria Borghese include, Paolina Borghese sculpted by A. Canova; David with the Slingshot; Apollo and Daphne; The Rape of Proserpina; Aeneas and Anchises; the Sleeping Hermaphrodite and the Room of the Dancing Faun. In the Galleria Borghese which is at the upper floor of the Museo, are masterpieces by Titian, Raphael, Caravaggio and Domenichino. These are collections worth seeing!

Very unfriendly!. We admit we didn't get a tiket a priori, but they treated us like dirt! We were just asking if there are any chances to catch a last minute tour, we didn't ask anything for free! A very suerior attitude. Inappropriate.

Stunningly beautiful!!. It is important to make reservations to visit. The museum only allows a limited number of people through every two hours. On the day we arrived, the next possible day to visit was five days away.

Beautiful art, not so beautiful staff. Best art and sculpture in Rome! However, the gentleman at ticketing was rude and unprofessional. He did not represent the museum or himself in a polite, professional manner.

don't miss. If touring with kids there are plenty of bikes, segways, semi motirized family cycles, etc to rent, along with walking, and running to be done here to burn some energy. Beautiful green spaces. Via Belvedere, within the Villa's grounds has beautiful city views. Small carousel, ice cream etc are nearby. There is a seasonal pond with peaceful bot rides available (rentals). The museum itself is full of fantastic pieces; most notable are Bernini works; simply outstanding. Buy tix online before arriving....it all sells out repeatedly.This is not your typical, overwhelming museum visit ...very doable and a nice break away from trafficy city into peaceful space. Weekdays as opposed to weekends are better...much less crowded. Read up o. The Villa Botghese so you can appreciate it all when you visit. Can do it in 90 minutes or 3 hours st your leisure; time well spent in Rome.

Great Art, but hard to find. Enjoyed this but it was very hard to find. if using the Metro get off at Spagna and take the exit/tunnel to Via Veneto this will bring you out just a few blocks from the Galleria.

Ultimate Art lovers indulgence. This for me THE best sight we visited in Rome and I had done the Basillica of St Peter and the Vatican too. The detail and variation and descriptions, lighting and general ambience of the whole building just encompasses your imagination.At the time there were a few areas that had been cornered off for reconstruction but that has not tarnished my view on this visit at all, just disappointed me that I could not see what was behind it. Another jaw dropping beautiful piece of artwork no doubt.Again, I had booked my tickets in advance and was uncertain as to whether I had actually been booked onto this visit as the site who I booked it through declared it as the colosseum reservation but I has specifically chosen Galleria Borghese, but I was completely fine and had no problems at all.Prepared to be blown away although may not find it as spectacular if you have visited the Sistine Chapel First.Enjoy

Kind of Snobbish. Maybe we were overdosed on world-class art having already spent 4 days in Rome and Vatican City, but our visit to the Galleria Borghese wasn't the five-star experience we anticipated. It certainly is a beautiful setting in the park, and with the gardens all around it, but the "regulated" visit experience was a turn off. You have to buy tickets in advance... You have to get in a queue (in the basement) to pick up the tickets... Then you have to wait, with a bunch of other people, for the exact entry time on your ticket to actully enter the museum... Once inside, you are on the clock, and have to be out by a pre-set time... The staff was marginally friendly... Older people in our group had trouble with all the stairs and no one on the staff paid them any attention...Anyway, the art is certainly outstanding--though I can't draw up memories of any particular pieces approximately 60 days since we were there. Unless you do some manner of professional tour assist, consider taking the time to find the laminated collection description in each room to learn the basics of each piece. Be sure to find a version in a language you can read.Feeling like we were suppossed to keep moving, we (and many others who entered with us) were actually out of the museum in a little over an hour. We just took off walking through the park heading back to Center Rome and never looked back...
Best museum in Rome. The only reason this recieved 4 stars instead of 5 was due to the 2 hour limit. Get your tickets in advance.

Original sculptures and paintings in the Borghese Gallery. Original sculptures and paintings in the Borghese Gallery. Masterpieces from the ancient to the Renaissance period. The marble sculptures are magnificent.

Fantastic. This is by far one of the best museums in Rome. It's small and manageable, but packed with great masterpieces like Bernini's Apollo and Daphne or the Rape of Proserpina. You get an up close and personal view of the works. During our visit, there were no crowds and we had much of the art to ourselves. The grounds around the gallery are great for an afternoon stroll. A great visit.

Art at it's finest. Most beautiful marble sculptures I have ever seen, are at the Galleria Borghese. One word of caution, you must have a reservation to view the gallery. We wondered why a and discovered that even on a very slow day, the viewing rooms get crowded. This attraction is located in a beautiful park, be sure to allow time to wander around, maybe take a pedal car ride or stop for coffee at one of on the snack stands.
Amazing sculptures. I was amazed with the sculptures and the ceilings in this museum.The one from Bernini are amazing, worth same visit, can de seen in 1-1,5 hours

Almost too much. We were worried at first that the allotted time is only 2 hours to roam about the palace. But it turned out to be sensory overload! Every surface is a piece of art-floors, doors, hinges, windows, views, and then there is the art itself! Amazing pieces by Bernini,etc., that you can see very up close and personal.The grouds are also magnificient, and we enjoyed it all tremendously.
awesome Galleria. could not get enough of one masterpiece after another, but the problem was limited time to see it all.still deserves 5 stars

In my Top Two sites of Rome. After visiting the Vatican Museum, you must make your way to the Borghese Gallery. They are strict with checking-in your bag, sticking with a timed-reservation and a timed-visit (two hours maximum). This being said, you have enough time to go around twice if you don't linger too much. The Bernini sculptures are absolutely fascinating. Do not miss The Rape of Proserpina; you will be awestruck. The hands of Pluto are actually digging into Proserpina's flesh… I have never seen a sculpture look so real before. Ah, Bernini, you amaze me. Of course, there are also some Caravaggio, Titian and Raphael. You will not be disappointed.Please note that I followed Rick Steves' Tour and it was well documented.

Some of the greatest sculptural treasures of Rome. The Villa museum was created as a grand facility to house great works of art--mostly Baroque style. Grand works of Carravagio, Bernini, Titian and other masters are here. The grounds are beautiful and worth taking time to walk around it. You get a ticket that allows you entrance for two hours. This means that the rooms do not feel so crowded that you can't enjoy. We really enjoyed this place.

Wonderful Bernini's sculptures.. Vatican was so powerful to get whatever artwork they want. Cardinal Borghese from Florence was exposed to Renaissance art and commissioned to collect artworks for Vatican. I cannot imagine a single man can sleep with full body naked Madonna paintings. But it happened. You can see the beautiful Renaissance paintings. Both my husband and I loved the Bernini's sculptures. The audioguide is worthy to pay.

Worth the trip. This is such a fantastic collection, and such a stunning setting, that it is absolutely worth the trip. Reservations are needed in order to keep the museum from getting too crowded. Its location amidst a beautiful large park makes this a truly memorable museum visit, not to be missed.

Fabulous - put it on your list of things not to miss. Galleria Borghese has a wonderful collection of art and sculpture that really shouldn't be missed. We visited in September (so, during the peak tourist season) and were very pleased to have pre-booked our tickets from home through their website, as there's no way we would otherwise have been able to get tickets. You can go through the Galleria Borghese without a guide, or with an audioguide, but I highly recommend the art historian tour. We definitely considered the extra few euros worth the money, because we learnt so much from our knowledgeable guide and appreciated the opportunity to ask questions.

Magnificent!. In Rome now, went to 11am session this morning-this was absolutely wonderful, a feast for the eyes, rivals the Sistine Chapel for color and beauty. The statues by Bernini incredible, the Rafael called "The Deposition" of Christ coming off the Cross was absolutely gorgeous. Many, may other fine works, please go if you can. Booked a few weeks ago online, they take a limited amount of people for each 2 hour session, worth going for sure.

For Art Lovers. Very nice sculptures.... Nice climate when we visited in November 2013. Walked thru the garden and reached the gallery.. Had reserved the tickets. Nice sculptures with great details...

magnificent. Wonderful museum--went late in the afternoon which was great as not many others to contend with. Audioguide was a great help but all pieces did have English explantions. The sculptures by Bernini and others were magnificent, We were told to make a reservation as entrance is limited, but due to the later hour it was not needed. Spent 3 hours viewing every room and every piece on the numbered guide.

Wonderful Museum Not to Be Missed!. You get two hours for your ticket, but that gives you plenty of time because the number of people are limited for each two hour time slot. It is a fantastic place that you don't want to miss! Spend a little for the headphones as your guide; well worth it! Don't miss this one!

Stunning interior, superb sculpture. Not to be missed.... I saw this gallery on a BBC documentary & was stunned by the beauty of the interiors & of the great sculptor Bernini's work So I made sure to visit it on my trip to Rome.. It did not disappoint & I will definitely go again!The museum is situated in a beautiful park close to the centre of the city. There are antiquities in the surrounding gardens & a wonderful or orangry to one side with some very unusual varieties of citrus. Book online in advance, as they specify time-slots for entry.

Divine. Several hours at the stunning Borghese Gallery is a divine experience, a rare opportunity to be transported to a different time & place. The depth of the collection of Baroque & ancient art & sculpture in the glorious palazzo is dazzling & although it seems loosely enforced, the two-hour limit per visit, which sensibly prevents overcrowding, doesn't come close to being enough time to take it all in; so the next time we have the good fortune to be in Rome, we plan to visit at least twice..Reservations are required & accoustaguides are available, but since the narrative highlights only one painting per room on the third floor, you're on your own for the rest; so a more detailed guidebook available at the gift shop is recommended.

Just as wonderful the second time. I had been to the Borghese once before and one of my friends had been twice before, but we wanted to show it to another friend. It did not disappoint. The art and sculptures are impressive. The Bernini sculptures are quite amazing even for those of us with little art knowledge. Please note that reservations are required and a group is admitted only every two hours. Since we were there in November we were able to book on line the day before, but I would guess that this is not true during the summer. It is worth the effort to see such an eleborate place and to see priceless works of art.

stunning, and intimate. But wish you could tour it longer.. there were too many pieces that the audio-guide left out, and the written descriptions were terrible. There whsould be more opportunity to pick and choose what you want to explore. The art and building itself were incredible, though.

Art Paradise. This is one of the best museums in the world, great sculptures,wonderful paintings,spectacular collection of Roman marbles and marvellous environment...it is really a must! The visit has to be booked,you are allowed two hours in the gallery and can get an earphone which provides useful information.It is very nice to reach the gallery walking through the Villa Borghese,a lovely passeggiata where you can admire a lot of very pleasant buildings including the casina Valadier. When at the Galleria have a look at the gardens as well.Nice coffe shop where to sit waiting for your visit

Borghese Gallery in Rome - a must-see. This gallery contains the best sculptures you will find on earth such as Bernini's 'Aplllo and Daphne'. Reservations must be made in advance as the number of visitors is limited, which makes the experience all the more enjoyable.

One of the best gallery on earth. MUST SEE!. I’m into paintings and sculpture wasn’t really my thing, but it was changed when I visited Gallery Borghese. I encountered some of the greatest sculpture by Bernini and oh my god they are just soooo beautiful! My personal favorite is “Apollo and Daphne”, I think it’s the best sculpture ever created on earth!!!The story about the Villa Borghese is actually interesting. There was a wealthy, powerful man named Scipione Borghese who has a great taste for art. He was later made a Cardinal by his uncle, Pope Paul V. So then he was not only rich and powerful, he was also an important man. He collected art from the great artists on the era (1600′s) and decided to open the gallery for public to enjoy. I think this could be like the first art museum ever. The story of how he collected the art pieces is interesting. Some, he got it, um.. let’s just say in an incorrect way.Cardinal Borghese also built the gallery itself with heart and soul. Every room of the gallery has its own theme and personality. I must say, the gallery has its reason to be exclusive. The gallery doesn’t accept walk-in visitor. You must book a time slot and CAN’T enter the gallery even 5 minutes before your slot begin. You only have maximum 2 hours inside the gallery. Bandi was swearing silently, why is the gallery so arrogant?! But then, it has every reason to be.

Not to be missed. Breathtaking art. Two hours is not enough. I could spend hours in one room. Heard they run a tram around the grounds but it was raining on the day we went so we missed that. Definitely need earphones or a tour guide to get the most out of the Gallery

Breathtaking art and sculpture!. This is a must see in Rome. While there is much to do and see in this wonderful city, if you are an art lover, you must fit this in. It is a private museum and you have to reserve a time for a paid visit, but it is definitely worth it. Very nice gift shop at end of the tour.

Great Collection of Art. Sign up early for tickets.. Ticket has entry time with 2 hour limit; entered at 1PM to 3PM. Signed up early if you want certain time and date (may sell out weeks ahead). Cost was about 13 Euros, but use Rome Pass if you get the chance. Used the Audioguide for 5 Euros; it was very helpful and organized. Art collection in the galleria is impressive with Bernini sculptures and Carravagio paintings. The 2 hours was well spent. The park around the Galleria is a nice walk or jog, so add some time to walk the park.

#2 highlight in Rome: exquisite, small, accessible, inspiring. For Brits brought up on National Trust properties and for tourists used to mega-museums, the Borghese is a jewel of a treat!It's a small house (by the standards of stately homes, that is) which is filled to the gunn'ls with wonders. You can see lists easily enough of the contents but it was the sculptures that totally made my visit. Along with the Pantheon my abiding memory of Rome will always be the Bellini sculptures Rape of Persophone and that of Apollo and Daphne.If you leave aside the wonderful composition, visualisation and characterisation of both sculptures, the abiding shock comes from the simple question of how on earth it's possible to create this from STONE?? I have a very limited comprehension of working marble, but if you told me that it was a mix of butter and putty that later solidified, this would be a plausible explanation for the wonder in these two statues. I am now boring all my friends to death just repeating "they're wonderful" over and again.The house has other treats, don't get me wrong, but the Bellinis and the other sculptures really stole the show for me.Unlike many British stately homes there are no bedrooms, kitchens and other aspects of real life for the wealthy: the gallery was never in fact a home. Created solely for the purpose of housing this imperious art collection, it's as a result a compact, 100% art, visit.I reckon that you could "do" the gallery justice in 45 minutes, and the allotted 2 hour slot is plenty.Practical tip is to buy your tickets in advance, turn up 1 hour before to collect them and spend that time wandering the lovely grounds.

Exceptional. Amazing to be able to see original works from Carravagio and Bernini in a less formal atmosphere and relaxed surrounding than more famous Galleries. Was much quieter than in summer, and as such more enjoyable. Pays to book in advance as capacity is controlled.
Lovely !. This is my #3 pick for Rome. The park, the gardens, the quiet...the museum! Pack a picnic from the grocery store, and go here for an entire afternoon. I love this place!
Fantastic Collection. One families collection, but mostly one person's collection of art. Most impressive. Had to make a second trip to Rome to see, because tickets are sold out weeks beforehand.

Amazing!. The Galleria Borghese is an art gallery housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana. This gallery houses a substantial part of the Borghese collection of paintings, sculptures, and antiquities. The main floor is mostly devoted to classical antiquities of the 1st–3rd centuries AD and classical and neo-classical sculpture while the other spaces are devoted to Renaissance paintings.

Many many hidden gems. Loved the works by Caravaggio and the amazing works by Bernini. The night we went was fairly quiet, I think a Tuesday, so we were able to wander the galleries without feeling pushed. It was hard to see the gardens surrounding the gallery, but looked like they would be worth returning to in the light of day.

Perfect art museum. Outstanding collection in superb palace, beautifully presented masterpieces set in smaller rooms that give a feeling of really relating to the works. Unmissable when in Rome in my opinion. Not crowded because of the timed and ticketed entry. We had no queues and booked online the night before but it did appear as most sessions had booked out. We went for the first session and afterwards had a perfect stroll through the magnificent park and downhill through the via Venetto.
It is amazing!. The Gallery is worth visiting. Wonderful collection of sculptures and paintings of the 16-18th centuries. Paintings on ceilings that look like in 3D format are very impressive.

Don't Miss This. If you like art at all, do not miss this wonderful gallery. The Bernini statues are amazing, and if you've seen Michaelangelo's David in Florence, you HAVE to see Bernini's here. Then there are the Caravaggios--the largest collection anywhere in the world. "David with the Head of Goliath" features the artist in the role of Goliath. Worth a walk through the beautiful Borghese Gardens.

make a reservation!. This is one of my favorite galleries on the planet! Such high quality art and nice gardens to walk around in- a pleasant escape from Rome. I'd say one of the 5 top must see things in Rome.

A quick tour. We were lucky to get tickets to view the museum. It is mandatory that you get tickets ahead of time. Self-guided tours take about 2-2.5 hours covering two floors of the museum. The museum contains baroque art works. There is much to see that is wonderful and I am glad we went. However this style of art is not my choice of art and thus I was not inclined to tarry.
Bernini and many others. This is one of the best galleries I've been to. You can spend hours just looking at the Bernini's sculptures. Brilliant!

Wow. Could have spent all day in this gorgeous building and on the grounds, but had time constraints due to group we were with. Had a fabulous guide -passionate and knew the place inside out. Tons of stairs, but oh so worth it. You can't believe that you are within inches of the artwork you are experiencing. Staff not at all friendly or nice- actually, they seemed angry at us for showing up, even though we had an arranged tour(we were late due to an emergency that occurred- no matter, they were just annoyed) Had to wear headsets to hear our guide(rules) but they didn't work. Due to our being late, our tour was cut short, but we saw the highlights, again, due to a great guide. This place is a treasure, and makes you in awe of the brilliance and foresight of people who thought to assemble this amazing collection.

Disappointing, if you are short on time skip this one. I was expecting a lot more, while the statues are quite impressive the paintings, with only a few rare exceptions are quite mediocre. The people who work there are rude and don't explain things. If you decide to go after all check the times because you can only enter at specific hours and are only allowed to stay for two hours, not that you need much more time to see it.

Beautiful palace. Love the great park the palace was in. The Borghese, amazing with all of its artwork and statues. Must must see, need another glance. Repeat visit is a must. RESERVE tickets ahead of time. Only a limited amount of people can visit daily-well worth the visit! But keep in mind a lot of local school go to the gallery also. I used the subway to get to the park...and of course got alittle turned around so it too me about 45 minutes to find the Palace. My excuse was it is in a big park! Lol

borghese. Many times I ve been in Rome but still my dream was to visit Borghese museum. At first you shoud book a ticket, better on the web-site ant then when you come here the staff will print it and give to you. The gallery itself was even more than i expected. The works of briilliant masters were really amazing. I am crazy about painings, but this collection made me admire the sculptures also.

If you don't like sculpture, you will after visiting the Borghese. This collection is full of exquisite pieces set in exquisitely decorated rooms in the former home of the Borghese family. The audio guide provides plenty of good stories about how the art work was acquired through whatever means were necessary, including threats, extortion and outright robbery, by the nephew of the Pope at the time. He had great taste in art! The paintings are lovely, with some real gems, including some Titians and Caravaggios, but to me the real highlight is the floor of sculptures. Two of my favourites are both by Bernini: The Rape of Persepine, and Apollo and Daphne, where Daphne turns into a tree before your very eyes as Apollo is about to catch her and have his way with her. You literally can't believe that this sculpture can hold together, there is so much air in it. Pictures just can't compare with the experience of seeing it from 360 degrees.Too bad the staff is so unpleasant at this beautiful gallery. They act like the visitors are a nuisance, or worse, and are almost universally unhelpful. But go anyway; the beautiful art will take away all the sourness of the rules, regulations and surly workers.One word to the wise: book your tickets online ahead of time to avoid disappointment, but be really careful in choosing the date: the Italian calendar shows the week starting with Monday, not Sunday. I booked the wrong day at first and of course they would not let me change it or give a refund (in fairness this is clearly stated on the website numerous times); they also refused to just give my tickets to someone who could use them, which is a shame that they went to waste. So double-check your date carefully, and don't be late for your visit time, as you'll want to take advantage of every minute of your two hours!

Not to be missed if you love art. Awesome art, if you are a Bernini fan, this is where the Apollo and Daphne is located (she is turning into a tree as he catches her); Have seen pictures of this for years, very awesome in person, we circled and admired it for quite a while. Many other Bernini as well as Caravaggio. We had a 4pm reservation and missed the surrounding area, keep that in mind. Reservations suggested.

If you love sculpture as I do.... Get your tickets ahead of time or at least reserve them without paying extra through ticket sites. I fell in love with the passionate sculptures of a young Bernini who I thought did "just" columns!

Stunning! Especially the Bernini Sculptures. This gallery is a must. Bernini's sculptures are absolutely stunning, seemingly impossible to create by hand, even today. The gallery is beautifully laid out allowing close access to all the works of art. The cafe is a bit haphazard but the coffee is good. The bookshop is excellent. Afterwards take a stroll around the beautiful park and perhaps take a rowboat out onto the ornamental lake.

Very unique Gallery. It is located in Villa Borghese so you can get to walk around gardens before or after your visit to the Gallery but the Gallery!..It was a very nice experience for me, not only because gorgeous art especially Bernini's work was present, but I liked that rooms all have different concepts and arts presented accordingly.It was very well displayed, not like St Peter's Basilica (in Vatican) or Uffizi (in Florence), not overwhelming and gives you space to enjoy each piece.Of course you probably heard about Apollo and Daphne (which is stunning and it was so nice to see it in front of me, the statue I adored from books since I was a child) but also check out Bernini's David.(Ladies you will probably got struck with how handsome he is, but be sure to also check out how movement and the story represented).

fantastic, beautiful complete and small. in a beautiful spot, in the park of Villa Borghese, this (relatively) small museumis a jewel. Tiziano's "amor sacro ed amor profano" and Canova's sculptures Paolina Borgheseand Apollo and Dafne, are among the unique pieces here. well worth a visit. good for everyone.
The sculpture!!!!. make a reservation! Wish they allowed flash-less photos, but they are very strict. so we bought postcards...unbelievable sculpture, ceilings, paintings, and more.

A highlight of our visit to Rome. This was our first stop on a 6 day visit to Rome. We stayed nearby and it was an easy entry to our touring of this beautiful city. As other have said, you must book a reservation in advance. We found the audio tour useful but a bit confusing if you don't start at the right entry/starting point. It's actually NOT at the ticket office, it's upstairs. That said, the introduction to Bernini and Caravaggio here was fantastic and piqued our interest in learning more. Well worth including in your itinerary.

One of my favorite things. Art is not my thing, but I loved this place. Make sure to rent the audio guide because that brought a beautiful place to life. The sculptures are amazing - one cannot believe they were made from marble. Especially with the tools available during the time they were made. We only had two hours - they literally kicked us out! Make sure to buy tickets way in advance and get there earlier than your time slot. We wasted bout 1/2 hour checking our bags, getting our headsets. Don't miss this amazing place.

Don't miss it!. It's for many people one of the most beautiful museums in Italy. I'm a huge fan of Bernini so it was such a treat to be in front of his sculptures, especially Apollo and Daphne! And of course Canova's Pauline Bonaparte is breathtaking as well. Take a tour of the gardens, there are several means of transportation if you don't feel like walking. Get your tickets in advance because if you just show up without them, you wont be able to join the tours for a couple of days.

One of my favorites. We went to the Borghese Gallery and it was incredible. The Bernini works were wonderful and they have at least on Rafael there as well. The who building is wonderful and should not be missed by anyone who likes a less crowded museum. Be SURE to make RESERVATIONS ahead of time because they are REQUIRED.

Get tickets ahead on line.... or you'll be sorry you missed out on this collection. Get an audio guide to enhance your tour. The first impressive sculpture is of Pauline Bonaparte Borghese by Canova. My favorite was Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. You really have to listen to the audio guide to know how this collection came to be--through the greed of Cardinal Scipione Borghese who fortunately, for him, had Pope Paul V for his uncle. Raphael's Deposition highlight the underhandedness of such 'acquisitions'. I am thankful that these works of art have been preserved but the means by which they were acquired by Cardinal Borghese are reprehensible.

the original and best. This is the world's first true museum, meaning a building where Scilione Borghese thought it would be useful to attach labels to things in case his spell-bound visitors wanted to know what it was they were looking at.It is also the one 'not to miss' museum in Rome. Compact and stuffed with treasures from ancient Roman sculpture and gruesome pictures of gladiators in the entrance hall to a treasure trove of Caravaggio upstairs: and this is what's left after a large chuck of the collection was sold to Napoleon (and is now to be seen in Paris).But you go here above all to see the breath-taking Bernini sculptures. All the greatest ones are subjects in tension or in metamorphosis or some life-crisis. So there is David tensioning his sling as he eyes up Goliath, about to fire; there is the sublimely beautiful, ethereally delicate execution of the moment when Daphne, being chased by Apollo, turns into a tree; and there is the Rape of Proserpina - daughter of Gaia - being hauled off to the underworld. You won't get in without planning: tickets are timed and you need to book on-line a couple of weeks ahead. But do it: and then rent a side-by-side bike to ride around the surrounding park!

Gallerie Borghese. The art and sculptures are fantastic. As for the painted ceilings in 3D, they are amazing! So much to see on a 2 hour slot that you get an information overload. The cafe was very busy and reasonably priced for Rome but a bit confusing as you have to pay before ordering. There are extensive gardens to walk through to get back to the centre. Well worth a visit!

the most amazing surprise!. first of all, do not attempt to go with no prior tickets purchased. It has been the most amazing museum I have ever been to....I swear I could feel the statues almost talking to me, the art gathered in there is just breathtaking. The whole scenary, the park and the magnificent residence is one of the most beautiful parts of the moder Rome.

SHOWY AND A BIT OF FUN. The gallery itself has retained the original decorations in the interior especially on the main floor. Notice the trompe l’oeil ceiling. All a bit overwhelming at first glance. There are few Berninis remaiming inside but the key ones are well displayed. Not being allowed to photograph only means people use cell phones and Ipads and still interupt the flow so its a commercial decision. Buying tickets in advance is worthwhile but once in you only have 2 hours and are forced to climb 3 flights to start at the art collection which boasts some surprises like a great Cranack and a few other wonderful pieces but is generally pedestrian. Go for the decoration and the Berninis. Check out the back statue garden.

Overestimated. You have to pay 11 to see a 2 level bulding! You can visit the museum and have a walk in the Park a day with a nice wheather. From the Museum there is a nice view to the gardens of the villa.

Stunning!. The Borghese Galleria gave us the opportunity to see paintings and sculptures by artists we have only read about and viewed photos of. The Galleria in itself is beautiful and the the artwork is "not to be missed". You do need reservations because the number of people viewing is controlled and this is a very good thing. It was a nice walk from our hotel and a morning in Rome that was most enjoyable.

Bernini masterpieces and a walk in the park. The Borghese Gallery is a worthwhile addition to your schedule, but it certainly pays to do a little planning in advance. Ticket purchases are required in advance and are easy to do over the internet. Your visit will be a timed ticket, meaning you need to arrive on schedule and will have a limited period to visit, of 2 hours. As this is sold out almost every session, every day, there is not necessarily a best time to go to avoid the crowds. We chose to go on a Saturday afternoon between 5pm-7pm. We selected that time because it avoided the heat of the middle of the day, coincided with people heading off for dinner, so was a little less crowded, and was also towards the end of the day so the Borghese parklands were also less crowded. The gallery itself was very interesting. A couple of Bernini sculptures were my favourite items, Apollo & Daphne, and David. Both of these masterpieces are worth the admission alone, and I could have spent the whole time with just those two pieces.Unfortunately, there's no photography allowed in the gallery. However interestingly, when we hit the Louvre in Paris a month later, there was an amazing array of art from the Borghese on loan, with photos allowed!Also time your visit to take advantage of a stroll through the surrounding parklands as well. Allow a half day for the stroll and the visit for a leisurely trip.TIP: If you have a bag, it won't be allowed in. Make sure you get there a little early to collect your tickets and check your bag. As they are timed tickets, your session will all arrive together all with bags, all with tickets to collect. Getting there 10 minutes early worked very well for us. We were in while the pack was still queuing.

Bernini Sculptures are amazing.... A must see just for the Bernini sculptures. The are even more stunning in person. Get reservations early by calling directly or using their website. I found calling to be a lot easier. You get two hours in the museum which is plenty of time. Arrive early to check your bags. We started on the second floor (paintings mostly) and then worked our way back down to the main floor with the sculptures, this is reverse flow and let's the crowds thin out by the sculptures. Definitely worth the trip and the Roma pass works here.

No photos, no bags. Honestly, I think the Borghese is a bit over-touted. It is full of art and furnishings that are good, but not great, except for the room of the busts of the emperors, which was stunning. All bags must be checked and no photos are allowed. The stairs to the second floor are steep and the option of a lift/elevator requires special attention (though the staff were kind) to access for those unable to navigate them. I'm glad I went. I wouldn't make the effort again.

A must visit for anyone in Rome!. Even if you do not like museums and galleries, please DO book a ticket for Borghese (only possible online and at least a week in advance).Number of visitors is limited to 360 persons every two hours. So there is not a big crowd. And one can still enjoy the exhibits. And what exhibits there are! Excellent collection of art, featuring big names.You cannot bring any bags or cameras inside, but once you are done with your visit, make sure you drop by their bookshop. Wonderful books on art.
the most memoral part of my trip. this is one of the best museums in the world. to see this many caravaggios and berninis in one place is fantastic.

Go checkout the Villa Borghese. The Villa Borghese Park. It contains the Galleries, which you need a reservation for. So make one in advance. The park also contains the zoo. It's a wonderful park, just watch where you walk. A lot of people walk there dogs here and don't clean up!

Even better the second time!. We first visited Villa Borghese three years ago and it instantly became our favorite museum. We weren't disappointed the second time. I can't begin to describe the beauty of this gallery. All of the Bernini sculptures are breathtaking but don't miss Apollo and Daphne. The history of how Cardinal Borghese amassed such treasures is a fascinating story. Book online and don't miss this experience!

Resplendant... Where do you start?Now days one has to book online; having visited this gallery a number of years ago I just turned up and 'talked' my way in. If you are on a strict time schedule book !Yes, even in October it has the crowds.An expansive collection.The salons, mosaic floors, paintings, sculptures and even a harp make this one of the most enjoyable and visually exciting four-six hours in Rome. It is a treasure trove.This was my third visit and it just gets better.

Take the Guided Tour. In a little less than 2 hours, our guide showed us the sculptural and pictorial highlights of this relatively compact museum. She explained how the collection was assembled, how the design and decoration of the rooms relates to the displayed art, how the pieces represented the various styles and periods, and how the pieces displayed the genius of the respective artists.

No cameras - bliss!. The most depressing thing about modern travel is all the idiots who look at nothing with their actual eyes. If I see one more iPad waggled aloft, I'll scream.What I loved about the Galleria Borghese is that you can get very close to the artwork, see it from all angles, and spend as long as you like in each room. (You'll never need all of the allocated time). You are not allowed to bring your phone or camera in, so people actually * look* at everything, for once. I loved that. Sadly, one of my favourite, lesser known works, has been moved, and damaged slightly. There's a bust of Borghese showing him in sacred dress, and one of the buttons of his soutane doesn't quite close, because he's too fat. It's a tiny detail, but I always liked it.The button is now grubby and there is a crack in the statue, but you can see what I mean if you look up an old photo of it.The gallery is not suitable for anyone with bad vertigo, as the only way up was 3 flights of a spiral staircase. The lift didn't seem to be in operation.(I occasionally suffer from balance problems, and I did feel a bit sick after the third floor).Part of the reason the Italians are slim, by the way, is that it is considered shameful to use the lift if one doesn't have to. They walk up and down stairs all day long. Some of the Americans I saw were disgracefully unfit.I'm not young (44) and I'm a UK size 18, but I had no problems walking anywhere in Rome. (Some of the writers on this site seem to think it's an obsacle course!).If you can't walk up a few flights of stairs without being out of breath, get in training before you come.

Art History. Be sure to get there early for tickets, which give you a specific time for your visit. Backpacks must be checked, so leave that in the hotel if you can. We arrived at 10am and chose a 5pm entry. Beautiful setting in the park, which we rode through later and found much that we missed!

Bernini at His Best. This is an exquisite home. Thank goodness it has been preserved for generations to experience. It is easy to see all the wonderful works without getting worn out. It is the ultimate in up close and personal. I think Bernini's David is equal if not exceeding to Michelangelo's. The sculptures and paintings are in such a beautiful setting, you almost forget where you are. Be sure to put it on your list of must do's and remember you need to get tickets in advance.
Skip if no time. Nothing but posh style & statues! Too big, too tasteless. See it only to tick you tourist list.DO SEE VILLA GIULIA - the Etruscan Museum instead!

Marvels abound. Cardinal Borghese did the world an enormous favour when he had this gallery built for his collection, no matter what you think of the ethics of a churchman being this rich. The building itself is magnificent, covered from head to foot in multi coloured marble, and the ceilings are richly decorated with angelic scenes. One of the first such purpose built structures, it houses a priceless collection of paintings and statuary, most notably some of Bernini's masterpieces like The Rape of the Sabines, Apollo and Daphne, and his exquisite David. For a more comprehensive list, get a catalogue, because no photos are allowed here, like many other Roman attractions.

A Must for Art Lovers. Bernini's best statues are here--all in one place. There is also a room full of Caravaggios. Sprinkled throughout the ornate palace are other gems. Besides the content, the beauty of this museum is that they allow a limited number of people in at a time, so the problems you experience at places like the Vatican Museum are not an issue here. Be aware of the following:* Book in advance. Reservations are a must. Print your confirmation and take it with you.* You must leave backpacks, purses, etc. at the baggage check. You can only do this once you have your ticket in hand. * Arrive early. There is likely to be a line at the ticket desk and the baggage check desk.* There are separate lines for baggage check and baggage pick-up.* Restrooms are available in the basement (where you get your tickets), but you must present your museum ticket. There is a set of restrooms between the first and second floors of the villa.* There is a small bookstore and a bar (coffee and light refreshments)* Your museum visit is timed and will last openly 2 hours. I wish it were longer, but two hours is enough for most visitors.Enjoy!

Beautiful Gallery. I remembered this gallery as a highlight of a trip in 1960. It was still spectacular. Bernini's sculptures were the most beautiful things we saw in all of Italy. The limited admittance makes the experience so good with space to really see things.

The Berninis alone are worth the visit. We had to wait about 40 minutes to be admitted but that made the visit almost private as we moved against the tide of expert audio listeners and guides with groups.. sometimes we had entire rooms to ourselves and they are very special.

Make a reservation early!. This is an incredible museum full of wonderful paintings and marble statues. Really amazing! The only problem is that it can be very difficult to get reservations to visit. I would make them before you arrive or the moment you arrive with the help of the consierge at your hotel. It can often be a couple of days before they have an opening. We could not get reservations but instead decided to show up and take our chances.
