Luckily a couple was leaving early (your reservation is for a 2 hour visit - then you have to leave exactly after the time allotted) This couple only stayed for an hour and sold us their tickets for 1/2 price. Next time I would love to use the self-guided audio tour and stay for the full 2 hours. Highly recommended place to visit!

Well worth a visit. Wonderful museum, very impressive building and settings, great art very well presented,However, you should know the following1, must buy a ticket ahead of time2, visit is limited to 2 hour slots, You cannot enter before start of slot and you wre made to leave atvend of slot3. There are long queues at start of time slot. You should either come half an hour early or half an hour late (and spend only an hour and a half inside)

Wonderful gallery. This was my third trip to Rome and can not believe I had not visited before.. the setting is great - but be careful of the direction signs in the park.. they are mis-leading. Get tickets online ahead of time, regardless of season. You have two hours to view the galleries.. which is sufficient.

Must see. I believe that even if you don't care for sculpture and painting, you will still be impressed here. This purpose-built palace was built by Cardinal Scipione Borghese in the early 1600's. He wanted a place to showcase his art. This is such amazing collection that it's hard to believe an individual could have assembled it. Of course it helped that he was the nephew of the pope and had access to more money than god. Also he was not above having someone who didn't want to part with a particular piece, arrested until he decided maybe he would sell that sculpture after all. For me the "Apollo and Daphne" is the most amazing piece there. Even after looking at sculpture all over Rome, it still stands out. You absolutely need to make a reservation to come here. It's easy....just call them up and schedule a time. They give you a number. When you arrive - if you're not using the Roma pass - then just buy your ticket. If you want to get the audio guide (I recommend it), then you have to wait in another line. You only have 2 hours in the museum -- no more! So I recommend you get there about 30-45 minutes early in order to get your tickets and audio guide and be ready to go. It's enough time to see most everything, but you don't want to be rushed because you got there late.

Avoid the Crowds. The Galleria Borghese is located in a lovely park, and the advantage to a visit is that you can tour through the Galleria and really enjoy the art and Bernini's sculpture without the enormous crowds that you find in the Vatican Museum and other well known places in Rome. I recommend a visit here, with reservations, and do it on the same day you visit the Etruscan Museum which is a short, and very pleasant walk away.

Absolutely beautiful!. The Borghese Gallery is an art gallery in Rome. The Galleria Borghese houses a substantial part of the Borghese collection of paintings, sculpture and antiquities, begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the nephew of Pope Paul V (reign 1605–1621)We visited Villa Borghese: park, gardens and Borghese Gallery itself in the end of September. We bought tickets to Gallery on-line prior to our arrival to Rome, at least 3 weeks ahead. There are 2 hours sessions starting at 9 am: 9-11, 11-13, 13-15, 15-17 & 17-19. Our session was 3-5 pm. Size of groups are limited to 360 people that is great idea because the place is not huge and gets crowded very quickly. You can have guided tour, audio guide, or just go and read information in every room that is provided. The Gallery is absolutely beautiful: not just a collection of art that is displayed, but also the building itself. Every room is unique and beautiful from floor to ceiling! We loved it. We came to park of Villa Borghese from Piazza del Popolo and walked through the park for a few hours. The garden near villa Borghese is not as beautiful as gardens in France or England, not that many flowers, and not as groomed. There are a few places to eat and bathrooms in a park and also cafeteria and bathrooms in lower level of the gallery building.To summarize: we absolutely loved the Gallery and would highly recommend it. The park is just Ok.

Not to be Missed!. This was BY FAR the best art museum we visited in Italy. The variety kept our whole party engaged and we visited in the off season, so it wasn't very crowded. My favorite part of the entire Galleria was the large marble sculpture of Pluto and Proserpina by Gian Lorenzo Bernini. I could have studied it for hours with the countless amount of detail in the sculpt. Pluto has veins and muscle detail as I'd never seen, whereas the lack of muscle definition in Proserpina juxtaposed her feminine form with Pluto's masculinity. Where Pluto's hand holds tightly to her thigh, there are beautiful indications in the marble, just as there would be with skin. It is by far the most incredible statue I have ever seen and was the highlight of the entire gallery. I could go on and on about the genius in detailing. This museum is not to be missed. Be sure to reserve tickets ahead of time, as they sell out quickly. When leaving, be sure to take a walk through the adjacent park, which holds little treasures all of its own.

Rome's Best. This is without a doubt Rome's best museum/gallery. The sculpture is exquisite. I have visited many times, but every time I see "Apollo and Daphne" I can't believe the beauty of what I am seeing. Plus the lovely, quiet park setting is a wonderful refuge from the craziness of downtown Rome.Book ahead...on our last trip to Rome, naively thinking October would be quieter, we didn't book ahead, and tickets were sold out. Don't let that happen to you.

Best museum experience in Italy. I can't imagine a trip to Rome without going to the Borghese Gallery. I enjoyed this experience more than any other museum in Italy. I think it has a lot to do with the crowd control: limiting the number of people in the museum at any one time is a terrific idea! No mad crush of people like in the Vatican. And it's small and intimate, unlike the Vatican (not to knock the Vatican!) I was bowled over by the Bernini sculptures, and glad to find I could get close and walk around them to see them from all angles (the area around "David" was being worked on so we couldn't walk around it). The gallery itself is so beautiful -- with frescoes everywhere -- and that really added to my enjoyment of the artwork. I got the audio guide and thought it was wonderful. I am so glad I went! It is well worth the small effort you must make ahead of time for reservations. FYI, some people in line told us they had gotten their reservations that day; they called over and over and were told no each time, then suddenly there was an opening. So keep trying if you're desperate! A note of caution: don't start your visit on the lower level, where they check your bags, give out tickets, and sell the audio guides, unless you're prepared to climb at least 50-60 stairs! And get there plenty early.

Over-hyped - Rome has better galleries than this. Yes there are some treasures in here - Apollo & Daphne and the Caravaggios - but the place doesn't live up to its hype and is swamped with tour groups who hog the space.We had first entry tickets booked but they were late opening the ticket office so our two hours were cut short. Everything must be checked, including handbags/purses and no cameras allowed.The café in the basement serves good coffee and you need to show your ticket if you want to use the bathrooms.There are better galleries in Rome but this one seems to hog the limelight. Go to the Galleria Doria Pamphilj instead.
A must-see. Absolutely amazing museum and gardens. Just walking around the place you already feel inspired to do whatever you want... It's somthing you HAVE to see if you go to Rome!

Brilliant!. Set in the park, this gallery was only a short distance from our hotel. Set in a stunning building this gallery is full of outstanding antiquities, paintings and sculpture. Outside there is also a really nice restaurant where you can get a drink or snack of sit down for a really quality dinner. Away from the centre of Rome, you must not miss.

Amazing. It is unbelievable that just one family could have such a passion for art and beautiful pieces. We learned so much at this amazing place, from Napoleon to the last member of this incredibly powerful family. Not to be missed while in Rome

Don't forget to book.... If you're into arts, this is definitely a place to visit. My highlights go to the Caravaggio's and the sculptures in the first floor. Be aware that you have to book your visit or you will not have access to the museum (I saw it happen). The website (http://www.galleriaborghese.beniculturali.it/) has the reservation phone number and all the information you need.

personnel not very thorough. We had booked a visit to the Borghese Gallery and were given a booking number.when we got there, there was no record of our names and she left it at that. 4 days of Rome, and I was losing track of my own cell Phone number, my mind was so full. at another booked event, the attendant asked us our country of origin and telephone number- and hadn't we received a booking number? If the personnel at the Borghese Gallery had known her stuff and asked us the right question...we would have been able to enjoy this amazing gallery!

Book, book, book!. Our favourite place, the rooms were breath taking with the art work and sculptures! We went around twice, the given time of 2 hours was enough time, shame we couldn't take pictures! The park is huge and there are things to do there.
A Tree Grows from Her Fingers & Toes. All I have to say: if you see nothing else in this wonderful place come see Bernini's Apollo & Daphne. Oh my gosh!!!

Vatican museums offer much more. Although the art in the Borghese was impressive as a collection, it is a poor second compared with the Vatican museums, particularly the frescos.We regretted not using an audio guide, as the written text in the gallery is poor, although a few people with the audio guides appeared to be struggling to locate the correct route around the gallery.The beautiful Borghese gardens (free) are well worth a long stroll.

Galleria & Villa Borgese. An excellent art museum. Make reservations at least several days before hand and show up/check your all bags (& cameras) at least 30 minutes before your scheduled start time to avoid the line. Budget your time, as the 2 hour limit is strictly enforced. This is a physically small museum, but contains many interesting works. Consider heading upstairs to the paintings first, then back down to the sculptures, as this will mean less crowded spaces (the reservations/time limit already helps in this regard). We spent the rest of the day in the Villa Borghese (park) walking, riding the tram and having lunch near the cinema. We visited the park & gallery on All Saints Day (Nov 1 - a national holiday). The park was filled with people, but not crowded. A great experience.

for the art lovers. I felt that this place is very worth the visit with its well maintained building and stuffs that it preserved. There seems to be plenty of masterpiece for viewing. However no photography is allowed inside. Would have deserve more star if I know how to appreciate arts. I finished the two floor gallery in less than 15 mins.

BEYOND WORDS. The bench mark for the world's art galleries. Bernini abounds with magnificent sculptures. Raphael, Caravaggio and their contemporaries delight and move you. Just the floors, ceilings and wall decorations leave you gasping in awe! If you go to Rome this is an ABSOLUTE must. Intimate and manageable but you MUST book for a time and date well in advance. Walk ins, forget about it!
Stunning rooms and works of art - a MUST SEE!. Small but perfect museum of works of art owned by the Borghese family. Will definitely visit again if back in Rome.
Dream. i love this place.A stage of art and culture: Statues, paintings, fantasticexhibitionsBernini, my favorite.

Amazing Art. I am not an art aficianado, but after visting the Galleria Borghese I want to learn more. This treasure trove of Bernini Sculptures and paintings by Raphael,Lippi and Caravaggio is set in a historic mansion in the middle of the Borghese Gardens. The architecture of the mansion creates fitting background for these masterpieces. Be sure to book tickets in advance so you are not disappointed, even if you have a Roma Pass. The restricted entry enhances the experience by limiting the crowds.

My favorite gallery in all of Italy. Just made a second stop at Galleria Borghese with the hubby this time. We turned left after entering the main door and had a room full of Caravaggios to ourselves! By the time we made our way back to the Bernini sculptures the crowds around them had moved upstairs. And the Berninis are breathtaking - you literally find yourself holding your breath waiting for them to move. I love this museum - the building, it's setting and it's contents. Go!

Fantastic Exhibit. Don't miss this gallery if you are an art lover (especially Caravaggios and Berninis). You must book in advance, but easy to do on the Internet. We booked a visit time by phone without paying and then used our Roma pass for a free entry. Take some time to walk in the lovely gardens after viewing the exhibit.

"A treasure in the park". This gallery is absolutely one of my favorite places to see in Rome. The sculptures and paintings are beyond trying to put into words! Definitely book in advance and have a tour guide. The knowledge and information our guide shared, gave us such a wonderful insight to many of the incredible sculptures and paintings we saw in this magnificent Villa!

AHHHH, BERNINI!!!!. Incomparable: Apollo and Daphne ~ a sculpture of air!
Intense: Carravagio ~ self portraits within paintings
Incredible: Aeneas and Anchises ~ generations of skin
and then, the beautiful and self-absorbed: Pauline Bonaparte as Venus!
Loved every moment of our two, too-short hours!

Theft from cloakroom. The museum was wonderful, but when I returned to collect my bag, I found it had been rifled and multiple items stolen from it. I lost my Ipad, my wallet with $600.00, my passport, my drivers license and all my credit cards, plus my medicare and health insurance cards. I contacted the proper authorities immediately (police and security at the museum), went to the embassy to replace my passport and cancel my credit cards, and turned all the information over to the museum. The one person who bothered to contact me indicated the CEO (no name) would consider my claim and get back to me. It has now been 11 months and I have heard nothing. A reputable museum of the caliber of the Villa Borghese should have decent security and it doesn't. Since you can't take anything with you into the museum and there are no locked lockers, belongings are up for grabs apparently. I loved the art but will never go back. I suggest you think twice about going there unless your hands are empty!

Spectacular. We visited the Borghese Museum in October. We were blown away by the beauty of this amazing villa. The paintings and statues are beyond words they are so beautiful.The ceilings of every room are so beautifully painted. Bernini's statues are breathtaking. After our two hour time limit was over, we got on the little train shuttle for 3 euros each which took us into the park and over to the edge of the cliff overlooking the city of Rome. Amazing views. I wished I had purchased the automated guide to listen to the tour of all the treasures but I had forgotten to purchase it before we entered the museum. That would have been very informative. We did have Rick Steve's book though which was very informative.

A surprise treat.. The sculpture is the star of the show at the Villa Borghese. I used to skim past the sculpture in art museums, so I was surprised that I enjoyed the sculpture exhibits here as much as I did. Be sure to rent the audio guide, which provides a great explanation of the exhibits. Also be sure to reserve your tickets in advance. The day we visited, there were no tickets available for walk-up customers for the next three days.

Well done, but smaller than I thought. As a lover of art, the Borghese Gallery was a must see. I knew to make reservations in advance (which I did), but I was shocked to learn that it was sold out for the next week when we arrived for our appointment. After you check in, you get your tickets and you have to check ALL of your BAGS. This really bothered me, but you have no choice. The museum is housed in a small palace, and each room is very well put together. The frescos on the walls and ceilings of each room rival the sculptures and paintings decorating it. There is a mix of tour groups and individuals. While I enjoyed the museum, it is only two small floors of art work, and I was really surprised. I feel like for making reservations and paying for it (we used our Roma pass) that there should have been more.
Great pieces of art. Beautiful pieces of art--stunning statues. Make sure you make a reservation in advance--otherwise, you won't be able to get in!

Galleria Borghese. We got a ticket online the day before thus avoiding the fees from a tour company. Check all your bags,water bottles,everything. Gift shop very small,good cafe and a train ride around the garden. Not to miss this.

A walk in the park and a wonderful gallery. We so enjoyed our time here. The art is wonderful and we used the free Rick Steves Audio tour as our guide. It was such a peaceful gallery as the crowd is controlled which made it so much more relaxing than so many other places we visited in Rome.We arrived about 45 minutes early and they let the two of us in as the people from the prior group were already leaving. Sometimes it pays to arrive early, pick up your ticket and then ask at what looks to be the entrance if you are not sure exactly where to enter.We ordered our tickets on the internet and the pickup was seemless. When we arrived there was a sign stating no available reservations for the next four days. I think the tickets are a better way to go than trying to use the Rome Pass.Also the walk in the park, getting to the gallery, is fun and relaxing after the bustle of so many Rome locations. Don't miss this wonderful experience.

Amazing sculptures. Defnitely worth reserving in advance. The 2 hours alloted for a visit is more than enough because the gallery is not that big. Also, enjoy the attached deli and the beautiful park grounds. Pay 3 eruos for the little trolley that takes you to different parts of the park after you are finished at the Gallery.

THE BEST!. We had reservations to view the gallery - it is worth the investment!We felt, as far as the collection of art work the Borghese family amassed - it was one of the finest we have ever seen. They give you ample enough time in each room to view all items at a pleasant pace. MUST LEAVE ENOUGH ROOM TO CHECK IN!

Worth the trip. Taxi from our hotel near Pantheon took about 15 minutes. Beautiful old "palace" and grounds now converted to public park. Make a timed reservation to tour the palace which contains a wonderful collection of Italian Old Masters works. A nice afternoon away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Borghese Gardens...where have you gone?. I've been to the Borghese gardens many times. Last year in October, the grounds still looked amazing. This year, I took a friend who is an avid gardener, and was embarrassed by the state of the gardens. Weeds abounded and the grass was almost non-existent in the formal gardens. There were weeks growing up through the hedges in the statue garden in the back of the palazzo. I hope this is not a sign of things to come. I've loved bringing people to this majestic palace, but will skip it if this is a sign of things to come on the exterior.The picture gallery and palazzo interior, was as always, exquisite.
Beautiful setting. Top level paintings, lower level sculptures.....worth going to see, a little out of context as it is a collection, but nice environment
Visit just for the art. A fantastic collection of art, that should not be missed. Spend awhile wondering the gardens and park (free).

You Will Not Be Disappointed. My wife and I visited the Galleria. It certainly lived up to its top billing in the Lonely Planet Best of Italy Guide for places to see in Rome. Remember to book on line as tickets can be booked for a couple of days. Alternatively, you may get lucky by being able to purchase a ticket from one of the hop-on hop-off bus tours (blue line). Definitely a must see!

This is a gem of a museum, one of the best in Rome.. The Borghese Gallery was a big surprise at how awesome it was. Although we were aware that the gallery of sculpture & painting were very good, we were blown away by the Bernini sculptures of the David, Apollo & Daphne & the Pluto & Proserpina as well as the Caravaggio’s & other artists. Bernini’s detail in his sculpting is absolutely unbelievable. The museum is rather small being the former residence of a cardinal in the church who had a voracious appetite for fine art, but is packed is beautiful items. The building’s interior itself had been refreshed & the degree of detail & level of colors was almost as impressive as the art work itself.Reservations are a must & the museum personnel are diligent in maintaining the number of people allowed in the museum & the length of time. Thy give you a maximum of 2 hours, but with the use of the audio guides, you can see all of the art in about an hour & a half.The gallery is located in the Villa Borghese park so make sure you go to the Borghese Gallery & not just the park. The short visit to this gem is a must for art lovers.

The current renovation activity created a letdown. I never miss this treasure. Always,until this time, I have left thanking God for not taking me before my seeing it. It has always been a total visual assault from floor to ceiling. Alas, this time their in progress renovations just killed the experience. Just another nice museum now. Hope its' magic returns for my next trip.

Superb. Well worth taking the trouble to book ahead (which is necessary). This relatively small gallery has outstanding paintings and sculptures by Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael and others, perfectly presented in an uncrowded atmosphere.

Up close look at wonder art. We were on an early morning set of tickets to the Borghese adn were not disappointed. We spent 3 hours walking the halls and looking at the art displays. We used the Rick Steves podcast on our iphones which really made the visit outstanding. You are able to get up close to the art and the hall is not very crowded. An excellent visit.

Fantasic Caravaggio room. You have to book this several days in advance. Only available in two hour slots which is more than enough time to view everything.You have to check in your bag - no matter how small before you visit, which means lengthy queues. I booked a week before and on the day of our visit - Thursday in October it was booked up to the Saturday.

A must tour. Okay I'm a photographer and I teach art, so I'm a bit of an art nerd. That said you can't look at a Bernini and not be blown away, and they have more of his work than any place I know of. The 11e and two hour time limit are fair. The Gardens are a nice place to spend some time before our after your visit (but avoid the kid/ballon infested areas). The no camera rule is a bummer as was the fact the the David is currently unlit and all but covered/blocked off...because they are restoring the ceiling above.
Stunning. I am not a fan of art usually, but visited here and was stunned by the sculptures inside. Bernini's sculptures are out of this world!

Brilliant tour by Dark Rome with excellent guide. Our guide, Daniel of Dark Rome, was very knowledgeable and pleased to answer any questions we put to him. The Bernini sculpture 'Metamorphoses' particularly caught our admiration.

I have now seen the most beautiful sculpture!. Bernini's Apollo and Dafni at the Borghese Galleria is to sculpture is what Botticelli's La Primavera at the Uffizi in Florence to painting--breathtakingly beautiful. Try not to miss either. Italy never ceases to amaze no matter how many times you've been there. Remember that you must book ahead to get into the Borghese.

Great for lovers of art. The Galleria Borghese is set in a very nice part just outside the centre of Rome. It contains a large selection of sculptures and paintings that come from the renaissance. The ceilings of each room are covered in paintings and frescos. Overall a must for any art lover visiting Rome

On a visit to view the paintings of Caravaggio. 6 paintings by Caravaggio here. We booked before we went to Rome as it is a very busy Galleria - time limited to 2 hour visit. Security was strict - we had to leave our handbags in.' Saint Jerome Writing' and' The Madonna of the Palafrenieri' absolutely gorgeous.. 'Boy with a Basket of Fruit ' was on loan to another country. Remember to allow yourself 20 - 30 mins to walk from the Spanish Steps or Piazza del Popolo to the Galleria which is on the east side of the Villa Borghese. Mosquitos around this October as the weather was warm.
Galleria Borghese. A not-to-miss experience, with its statues by Bernini and paintings by Caravaggio, plus other treasures too numerous to mention. An advance reservation is required.
Outstanding attraction. Brilliant - did a 3-hour guided tour of gallery + the beautifuyl gardens. Guide was friendly, well informed and group was small (maybe 10 people) - definitely worth doing!

A walk in the park. When the streets and sounds overwhelm you, take a walk in the park. And, for a quiet cultural break, please go to the Galleria Borghese. It's well worth the trip. You will need tickets in advance because they only allow so many people in at one time...

GREAT ART & GREAT GUIDE. Recently toured this wonderful gallery with a terrific guide from Dark Rome tours. She is from Caracas, Venezuala and had a special gift of bringing each selected art item on this tour to life. Wonderful place to visit ---- ask for her.
glorious. just got back from Rome and had a chance to see tall the magnificence of the Borghese. Be sure to make advance reservations for your two hour tour of this place.
Go early and enjoy the grounds. The galleria is located in a very large Villa, the grounds are quiet and peaceful. Many fountains to check out while you wait for your tour to start.

Inspirational. DON'T FORGET YOU MUST HAVE A RESERVATION TO GET IN! have your hotel/B&B call to make you a reservation. The Galleria is one of the most beautiful areas and museums in Rome. The sculpture is almost too incredible to believe - we went back around three times to see everything by Bernini. Incredible. Make sure you take the audioguide, well worth the few euros.

Amazing sculptures. We booked tickets online before we travelled to Rome as they are limited. You are allocated a 2 hour slot which was plenty for us and as tickets are limited it is not crowded at all. Remember that if you are over 65 admission is free. Amazing sculptures and paintings housed in an excellent building.

couldn't get in. you don't discover till you arrive with a "Roma get in free for 60 quid" card hat you have to book a time slot some six or seven days in advance and you are only going to be in Rome for another three days. It was one of the things I'd promised the child bride we would do together

Over-priced and Average. This place is rather "up itself". You have to book and pay a few days in advance..ok, I can cope with that. I have a very bad back so stairs are difficult, we climbed the stairs to the entrance on out allotted day and time to be told, brusquely, that we had to leave our bags and cameras downstairs. My other half went and joined the queue to do just that only to return ten minutes later because he had to have the tickets (which I still had) to check in our bags! Back to the queue. It would have been helpful if there had been something to tell us when we booked, or when we tried to go in. So ewe finally get in, and yes, there are some wonderful sculptures and paintings, but quite frankly we'd been to the Vatican and several museums before we got here and the things here were no more interesting (to me, anyway) and we were allowed to take photos in all the other place (except the Sistine Chapel which is fair enough). So yes, a lovely building containing some lovely works of art but with unfriendly and unhelpful staff.
Wonderful experience!. Treasure of art, a lot of masterpiece under one roof, beautiful park, you easily spend a day at this place, if you have enough time in Rome

Worth it if just for the Bernini sculptures. But you get to see Titian, Raphael, Rubens and more. The admission process (buy or pick up your ticket thru the door under the entry stairway and enter up the stairway) and where to go next are a bit confusing but once you are inside the art is fantastic! The Bernini sculptures are simply amazing.Before or after your visit take a stroll through the park.
Not to be missed. An amazing afternoon of breath taking art!! This was one of the highlights of Rome. The sculptures are breathtaking and the park is huge and quiet.

Very impressive museum and grounds without the crowds.. This contains an impressive collection of Italian art with the bonus of being free of the crowds found at the more well-known sites in Rome. In addition, after enjoying a leisurely and up-close tour of the Galleria, a visitor can relax touring an impressive park.
Borghese Galley Visit. Excellent statuary and artwork (some unrestored and too dark). Very beautiful location. Just walk the gardens and enjoy time away from the Rome crowds.

A treasure in the park!!. After a stroll through the park you arrive at the gallery. It is small but is is filled with art and treasures. you must reserve a time in advance. A wonderful art experience. Do not miss it! A great escape from the big city!

How On Earth ... ?. This is one of two museums on our Italian Adventure that completely changed how much I appreciate the art of sculpture. Buy your tickets online, show up at the appropriate time and you'll have two hours to wallow in all this spectacular art and history. It's best to head to the top floor when you enter. You'll have a little more elbow room as you work your way through the galleries. That is also where you'll find the majority of the paintings. The sculptures are on the lower floors.We were fortunate to have the whole room to ourselves as we admired Titian's "Sacred and Profane Love" . There is so much more detail in the painting that just doesn't show up in reproductions.The real highlight of the Borghese is all the sculpture by Bernini. "Apollo and Daphne" is a virtuoso performance in marble. It depicts Apollo trying to hold on to Daphne while she is turning into a tree. (Research the story for details.) How on earth did he carve all these delicate leaves and slender branches out of one piece of marble?There are a lot of those "How On Earth" moments. Some of the most spectacular sculpture in the world is there at The Borghese.Don't miss this!BTW - There is a nice cafe downstairs where you check your bags. You can grab breakfast or lunch there if you like. And be sure to allow some time to stroll through the park. It is absolutely beautiful.

Excellent Gallery. The gallery is located in a park, an E10 cab ride from the Vatican. Our tour guide met us there and we did about a 2 hr tour. The gallery is magnificent with several great pieces from Bernini. The park setting is a nice respite from the crowds and bustle of Rome.

Superb collection. Visited in Sep 2009 and in Sep 2011Only now got to writing the reviewBest sculpture collection I have ever seenUnfortunately, you are not allowed to take picturesStrong advise - book your tickets in advance (~6 months)

Best visit in the morning. Took the audio guide and it was very good and did not feel as if you were pushed around by the Guided tour groups. The coffee area is very small for such a large gallery, so be prepared and grab a seat quickly, while one of you gets the goodies.

Bernini. He and I must have had a love affair in a previous life and it's still happening. Bernini is the sculptor who will make you forget all others. Make sure you make a reservation and use your Roma Pass to get in. It's the way to do it.

A Respite in Rome. Reservations are essential as the limit the number of visitors, but as a result there is a less congested more rewarding experience. The art, and the building, are amazing. The park itself is a treat that can be traveled by foot, bike or tram. Don't miss the west side as it has some great views of the city below.

One of the best art galleries in the world. Take the time to reserve your visit before you come to Rome. Use the Borghese site to save additional charges. The sculptors are some of the best you will see anywhere in the world. Enjoy!

Remember to book ahead. We were unaware that you had to book at least a week ahead if you were not in a group so we were unable to see the galleries. Consolation was strolling in the beautiful grounds

Beautiful home with an impressive collection of sculpture and paintings.. We are not great art buffs, but really enjoyed the smaller collection at the Villa Borghese. Well worth an afternoon, but be aware you do need reservations. This gallery is included in the Roma Pass, and you need to make a phone call for reservations instead of doing them online to get the free access.

AMAZING ART MUSEUM SET ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL PARKS IN THE WORLD!. If you even think you might enjoy the paintings & sculpture in this place, you should go. It's just lovely and very manageable (not too big, nor will you get lost). Plus, you can get up-close to the art. Full of amazing and usual art... much of which was/is considered controversial for it's time.The collection was all owned by one man, the nephew of a pope! The setting is the Palace/Villa of the Borghese family situated in the serene Borghese Gardens. This is one the world's great public parks. There are food carts/stands and restaurants nearby so plan to have a picnic in the gardens (many benches) or at one of the nearby cafes. The Galleria Borghese also has a cafe in the basement. I recommend you plan on travel time to get there as it's in the North end of the city, but if you're up for a walk, it is a lovely setting and beautiful part of Rome. Anyone w/mobility issues should probably take a taxi there.We downloaded Rick Steve's FREE smartphone APP and used that as our guide instead of renting the audio guides at the desk. You can also get into the Galleria Borghese if you buy the ROME CARD and use it during the time it's good for up to three of Rome's major attractions during a three-day period. You will need to call once you're in Rome (we had our hotel concierge do that for us) for reservations to get in as only a couple hundred people go through the Galleria Borghese every couple of hours. We got our ROME CARD at the Termini Train Station for 35 Euros and used it to get into the Colleseum and the Forum in addition to the Galleria Borghese (saves money for the gelato you'll want to enjoy later!).Tip: Enter from the basement (don't go up the stairs, as that is the exit). You need to go downstairs to enter. You check-in for your tickets to the right and the coat/bag ck is to your left.

Best hidden gem in Rome. I know folks who stayed in Trastevere and never made it to this side of Rome....they missed out big time. After all the Bascillas, Chapels, ruins, amazing architecture, etc etc etc, you need some time to just relax. The Borghese Gallery is exactly what you're looking for. The park is gorgeous- just grab a snack at the cinema cafe or a local vendor and stroll to your heart's content. Totally worth a visit if you're spending more than a day or two in Rome.

Don't miss it! Worth your trip to Rome.. Don't miss going to this galleria. Just the Bernini sculptures are worth the trip to Rome. You have to make reservations at least a week in advance but you can do those online very easily. When you go in to get your tickets you have to go to the basement. Don't go in the galleria from there. Come back outside and climb the side stairs that will take you to the main entrance. This gallery was meant to impress and it certainly does that when you come in the front entrance. Spend lots of time watching the Bernini sculptures. They all tell a story. It's a good idea to read about them beforehand or take a travel book with you. I had the Rick Steves one and it tells you the story behind each statue. I'm sure you can read about them online too. It makes a world of difference!! My favorite one is the Apollo and Daphne statue. This statue is meant to be seen from the back at first and slowly circle it to your right all the way around. It is amazing to me how Bernini told a whole story with one statue. The only sad part is that you can't take pictures inside. After your visit take a stroll in the park. We walked the length of it all the way to Piazza del Popolo.
wonderful relaxing walk. Plan at least 3 hours for this event. The park around the villa is amazing and really nice especially in the summer it is a bit cooler because of all the trees.

One of my favorite sites. I am not much for Renaissance art; I much prefer Impressionism. I came for the Bernini sculptures and was not disappointed. Stunning, lifelike, mesmerizing! I loved the sculptures. We quickly passed through the picture galleries and spent most of our time with the sculptures on the first floor.If you go - you must have a reservation. You can book them online, but you must pay full price. We opted to make the reservation via phone (my husband speaks Italian, which really helped), and purchased the entry tickets onsite using our Roma passes. The Roma Pass gives you free entry to two museums and unlimited use of public transportation in town. We used the pass for the Galleria and the Colosseum. Another important point - we got to skip the lines. The Colosseum has its own line for Roma Pass, and we thought it worth the price just to breeze past everyone waiting in that 2-hour line.

Incredible collection of art. this was our favorite stop of the week we spent in Rome! You can only stay two hrs but that should be enough to see it. The gardens are also lovely. Take the little train ride around.

Don't forget to pre-book. One of the great museums in the world, but still people show up (and I witnessed this myself) without either a pre-paid voucher or a reservation. Without it you simply can't get in and it will be days or weeks before you can. So book early.

Incredible, but book in advance or use Roma Passé. This is very very popular. Spoke to some people who have walked all the way through the park to get to it only to be told they have to book and come back 2 days later! Luckily, we had the Roma Passé so not only did we get in for free we only had to wait an hour and some minutes to get in. We spent this time walking around the area and park. The palace is incredible. The ceiling frescoes were my personal favourite, it was like 3D, look out for the room with the guys holding up the ceiling, absolutely fantastic. The cardinal who owned this was seriously rich - even had frescos in the room which was used as a kitchen! Loved the art work. Saw Benini, Raphael, Titan and loads more. I think it is a must to see.

Get a ticket first. We went on a Friday morning on the off chance that we might get a ticket to go in. No such luck...timed tickets were sold out until the following Tuesday. We spent a very pleasant two hours in the park in front of the museum at no cost and was able to buy take away food in the cafe.

Get Tickets Early, Tours are Limited and Sell Out Same Day. The Borghese is a dream of Bernini scuptures and Carrivagio paintings. Nestled in the "Central Park of Rome", the Borghese Villa was converted into a gallery of ancient and Renessaince sculpture with an upper floor filled with paintings. You can get right to the art without barriers and because admission is limited it's never too crowded. It is a must see when you are in Rome. Tickets are available on line a month in advance. Make a plan to see it. It is like a mini Ufizi in Florence, but much better cause you don't have the crowds.

Must reserve this "must see" museum. This is one of the true treasures of Roma. Bernini in all his glory. If you visit St. Peter's Basilica, remember, Bernini sculpted that! And its filled with the history lessons of when popes were "kings"! The gardens are a welcome treasure in a hot city, very relaxing as mentioned in prior reviews.

Beautiful marble figures. The marble statues in this museum are stunning. The 'skin' is smooth as can be but the folds of the fabric and the cushions on which some of them recline look soft and pleated. We were very impressed. We'd look at the individual fingers and wonder how in the world the sculptors didn't knock them off. Buy your tickets on-line ahead of time as the Gallery allows only a certain number of people in every 90 minutes. We were there on a Wednesday and all tickets were sold out through Friday. Purses are not allowed and must be placed in a locker. The adjacent gardens are well-done, shaded, and quiet.

Bernini heaven!. One of the top museums in the world. Go if only for Bernini's sculpture. After discovering Bernini here, I went on expeditions to churches all over Roma seeking out other of Bernini's work.

Beautifully worthwhile!. Really the one sight in Rome we felt was worth paying for, as so much you can get a taste of without paying - if budget issues are pertinent. Also, using the headset tour was a very wise idea, as the size of the Gallery would have proven overwhelming without assistance as to the most significant items worth understanding.

Excellent Art but A Little Long. Excellent example of Renaissance Art as collected by the Borgheses. Dark Rome Tour guide very knowledgeable and provided interesteing insights inthe art, the artists and the collection. Overall the tour got a little too long as all the touir guests, inclduding oursleves were getting very tired toward the end. We had to skip the gardens in order to make our dinner reservations. Try not to take any bags becasue none at all are pmeritted inside.

Beautiful and relaxing. The garden was a nice break from the crowds in Rome. There is shade from the sun, beautiful statues, ice cream trucks, bike, and golf art rentals. My sons had the best time riding the 3 wheel bike around and around in the garden. My brother had fun driving the golf cart around. I recommend grabbing a panino and having a nice picnic in the gardens and enjoy its slow pace.
I'm now hooked on sculpture!. This this should be near the top of anyone's list of things to see in Rome. The collection is spectacular. Advanced reservations are required.

More of the glories of Rome. This is a must for serious art lovers and travelers and well worth the time and effort. This is actually in a large park which attracts families. There are cycles built for two which can be rented and there are huge crowds of people. Purses, backpacks, etc., have to be checked in storage when you are in the gallery. I knew in advance so left my purse locked in my suitcase at the hotel.

A magnificent gallery!. Some of the most famous paintings that came out of the Renaissance are here. Surrounded by idyllic, beautiful gardens and housed in what was once a stunning villa, this was a high point in our trip. Be sure to reserve ahead of time on line, or you won't get in. They manage the numbers admitted at one time, so it's not over crowded, like so many other sites and museums.

Loved the Gardens. We didn't do the Museum as the was a two week booking time so must be good. We hired a Riscio, a two seater electric bike and it was so much fun, we sat in with my3 year old daughter sitting in the little chair at the front and went off to explore and had so much fun, I would recommend this to anybody wanting a fun morning at a very picturesque park
Borghese Gardens. Just getting to the Galleria is a treat in itself. Beautiful park and the entry way to the Galleria is breathtaking. This is well worth the trip!

Brilliant. Marvelous! Our favorite museum of all. The staff are not very friendly, but once you get passed them you'll love what you see. You must buy tickets in advance. A suggestion would be to allow yourself some time before or after to spend in the park surrounding the museum. It's really a large and very tranquil space. Nice refuge.
Not my favorite museum in Rome. The museum would be incredible in almost any other city in the world, but in Rome it is not my favorite.

A quite oasis in Rome. The Borghese Gardens are like a mini vacation from your vacation...you could spend the whole day...and if you don't you miss so much....that said..we only spend half a day.....you don't need to book a tour,except for the gallery...which is mandatory...it gives you two hours inside and you could tell that our guide really loved the art that he was showing us

Go though this with a guide. Well worth the visit. You can get the audio guide for 5 Euro but it is really worth the extra 1.50 Euro to have a personal guide. We had Isabella and it really made a difference.

Fabulous art in a Gorgeous Setting. Hard to know which is more jaw-dropping....some of the art, or the beautiful rooms the Borghese family lived in. You have to book ahead to get an assigned entry time, so plan accordingly. The park itself is worth investigating too. Roman citizens utilize it as their green-space/fun space and there is both energy and beauty. Walk through it and come out in Piazza del Popolo, and then take a cab home, if you have the time and energy.
Beautiful. Walked through the park and really enjoyed the steps leading up to the park from the Plaza de Popolo. Beautiful views of Rome. Will definitely return.
Breathtaking!. Tour guide was VERY knowledgeable and personable. Amazing artwork.... an absolute - must see!!! I would suggest taking at least half the day to see the grounds and Galleria tour.

Great place to visit. We loved the gallery but were VERY confused by the audio guides. The tour doesn't begin outside as the guide indicates so you can't tell which number to press as you don't know which room you have entered. Try to get the staff to show you the room you enter from the circular staircase before you go into the gallery. The map attached to the guide is not helpful if you don't know the room number to push. You must have your ticket to use the toilet or to put your purse in the checkroom and to get your audio guide. There aren't enough audio guides to get them much before your tour begins as the previous tour is still using them. You must leave a photo ID to get a guide and each audio guide cost 5 Euro.

Art in its Supreme. If you want to be stunned by those sculptures and the Renaissance paintings, this is the place. I was absolutely awe struck by Antonio Canova's Venus Victrix. I also loved those sculptures by Bernini. What a genius!. The ceiling paintings were awesome with 3-D effects. By reservations only and have to book at least a week or two in advance. You are allowed to stay only for 2 hours, but absolutely worth the visit. Cameras not allowed.

Stunning. This place is a must see for anyone interested in seeing a setting in which every inch has been given over to the presentation of an outstanding collection. The Berninis and Caravaggios alone are incredible and there is so much more. A feast for the eyes, the Galleria is an easy walk from the Piazza di Spagna. There is a cafe and a snack counter with a few seats. Don't miss this place but get your tickets in advance of your trip. It's easy to do online.

Incredible classical sculptures and paintings. You must book entry in advance as numbers restricted to 360 persons per 2hour visit. Get there in advance of time as you must get ticket then deposit bags & cameras then suggest that audio-guide is used - otherwise there is too much to see and be selective about. Fabulous Bernini sculptures are a must see.

Must see for art lovers. This is a worthwhile sight for art lovers. In particular, in particular, it features some of Bernini's best sculptures and some excellenct paintings by Caravaggio. In addition to art on display, the rooms are exquisitely decorated. It is on par with much of the Vatican Museums, however it is a smaller and more manageable visit and because visitor numbers are strictly limited, one is much freer to enjoy the art. Things to know: - You must book in advance. Be there 15-20 minutes in advance to pick up your tickets and check your bags.-You must check your bags. -The audioguide is very good.

Borghese Gardens. WE actually did not visit the Gallery as we were overwhelming our friends with museums but the gardens were spectacular and a welcome relief from the touristy hubbub of the Vatican, Spanish Steps and Trevi Fountain. A chance to relax, unwind, take photos far from the maddening crowd.

Incredible art treasures. So much to see in the allotted two hours! The advance reservation system works well, and we entered on time. Do your research in advance. Know what's most important to you. See those items first, then check out the rest of the works.. The only negative: Like so many galleries, no photos are allowed (to promote book sales).
Great Outing. Loved this museum! Be sure to book online in advance. We so enjoyed the tour guide and would highly recommend it over the audio guide.

Stunning - and gross in a way. This is a stunning gallery. All the effort to se it is worthwhile. Some of the sculptures are unbelievably beautiful. The setting is so grand that it seems gross in a way. But don't miss it!

Do not miss this!. This the best place to visit in rome! We were in rome for 12 days and went to every major museum, ruin and area of Rome. This gallery is by far the best place to see in rome! The sculpture s and art are superior and the whole tempo of this gallery is unique. You must purchase tickets in advance....we did it on the website from the states. You are only allowed two hours and they do not oversell. It is very easy to see everything, because there are no crowds. Be sure to get the audio tour and do it at your own pace.Just walking through the beautiful park to get there is a wonderful experience.... Plan a half day if you have time. It is close enough to the Spanish steps if you walk there ....about 20 minutes.....on the same day.Again... After visiting the cattle coral of the vatican museum.... This will certainly be a rewarding experience ...

Sculpture Fans Must Go!. BOOK YOUR TICKETS WELL BEFORE YOU VISIT...or you won't get in, as they limit the number of persons allowed to visit during any give time frame. If you are a fan of sculpture, or Bernini, this is a don't miss. There are five large, captivating Bernini sculptures, including his David. Those alone are worth the price of admission. The museum is in north Rome, and is a significant trek from other sites. There are several buses that drop off about a 10 minute walk away. You'll be given an entry time, which you won't want to miss, as you only have two hours and no more at the museum.

So worth going to. Although it is not in the other exciting areas to see we took a taxi to get there. You most pre-order your tickets on line , depending on the season weeks ahead of time. There are private guides that offer to take your around with extensive explainations of the art works. However you can rent headphones with recordings of most of the more important pieces that were very good and easily understood( which is what we did). Some of these private guides also offer to take you around the grounds but I don't think it is necessary the grounds are free to to walk around and they are beautiful but nothing or special that it would make it worth paying extra money for. Now that has all been explained I'd like to say that I live in Manhattan and have been to most of the museums here. I've also been to the the Vatican, Sistine Chapel, the Louve in Paris and many other museums throughout Europe. Now, the works of art especially the sculptures of Bernidini really took my breath away (not too many have done this through all my travels) there is just a wonderful collection there, more then I've seen anywhere. The fact that they are presented in this beautiful mansion, just adds to the ambiance. The history of the mansion is explained as well as the owners reason for his exstremely expensive purchases of all the art works. By all means make this a have to on your list of things to in while in Roma.

My favorite. I enjoy this gallery more than any. The Bernini sculptures on the first floor are worth your visit to Rome. The mosaic floors are breathtaking. This is a small gallery but the setting and the pieces are wonderful make your reservation ahead of time and enjoy.

Make the time to visit!. If you appreciate art, even in the slightest degree, do NOT miss this. Some of the most incredible pieces of art you'll see ... dare I say as impressive as the David. I can't believe this museum doesn't get more recognition.
Fantastic. This is a great museum with the most stunning exhibits. You need to book well in advance. Very highly recommended.

One of my all-time favorites!. Once you decide to visit Galleria Borghese, you'll have to do 2 things: one is book your visit in advance (either online or by phone). The second is figure what's the best way to get there, cause it can be a little tricky. I decided to take the subway to Piazza di Spagna and walk the rest of the way. It's a short walk, but it can be confusing and you may think you're on the wrong track. That's because the Galleria stands in a magnificent park that also hosts the zoo, a horse riding school, an outdoors movie theater, among other amazing things. The walk through the park is already a treat in itself, since it has amazing sculptures, fountains, and mock temples all over it. It's a place to explore and enjoy in a sunny morning.Once you get to the Galleria, you'll see that the building is also a jewel and its gardens are magnificent. But the best is yet to come.I love that they have the small groups booked. That allows you to find your own pace and not be where everyone else is at the same time. So you can enjoy your favorite works at leissure. At first, I thought 2 hours was appalling and that I would need much more to see the whole thing, but it's plenty. Be warned that it's strictly forbidden to enter the museum holding bags, umbrellas, cameras or mobiles. You must leave your things at a cloakroom, and it's a good thing it's free. I strongly recommend taking and audio guide for this. It's so worth it, with real interesting and relevant information. To me, the first floor or the statuary is the best part. Seeing Bernini's sculptures really brought me to tears. They are so amazing and larger than life. And the best thing is that you can walk all around them and see them at all angles and look at each tiny detail. The second floor holds only paintings and also has some amazing works, like some Caravaggio's, Raphael's,Titan's and other easily recognizable pictures. But I have to confess that I hurried here a bit, so I could go down again and take a longer look at Daphne and Apollo, Prosephine and David. On your way out, be sure to visit the bookshop. They have some great books (I got myself 5) and prints. It's hard to resist.Then, you can go explore the park some more. It's really something and one of my favorite places in Rome.

Worth a second look. This was our second visit to this lovely art museum, which boasts some amazing Bernini sculptures and beautiful Caravaggios. It is located in a Renaissance villa in Borghese Gardens. Be advised that you must make reservations for this gallery, usually several weeks in advance. And you will only be allowed inside for two hours. Pick up your tickets at the office in the basement, check your backpacks and purses (you must) and then line up on the big steps outside the gallery. And then marvel at the way Bernini could make stone look so fluid.

Worth the distance. It is not a central attraction in Rome, but if you have just more than a few days in the city it really worth the distance to get there. Inside the gallery you will find amazing art from Caravaggio, Bernini, Raphael and others. Best to book the entrance before you reach the place because it sold out easily. Just a phone call will solve this to you. Instructions can be found at their website or over blogs around the internet.
Incredible. An absolute jewel in a park setting. Reservation are a must, take time and explore this beauty.It is one small museum that should not be missed

Not enough time. You only get two hours to see the whole thing. Get the audio guides and don't linger too long at anyone area unless you plan on going back for a second stop in. Lots of great artwork to see. best plan to go early or late in the day.

Morning visit. The most fabulous collection of works of art I have seen. To be able to get close to the works of Berlinni, Carravagio, Michaelangelo, fantastic mosaics wonderlful sculptures make sure you visit.

too much dull religious art. It is certainly worth visiting the Galleria Borghese on account of Bernini's superb sculpture "The Rape of Proserpine" which is splendidly positioned in the middle of a large room enabling the visitor to view it from all angles. Be advised you are not allowed to take photos and all cameras and bags must be left at the designated area in the foyer before entering the museum. My recommendation would be to start at the top of the building and work your way down, as, due to visits being timed in 2-hour slots, there was a general scrum in the rooms immediately after the entrance as everyone for a particular time slot was let in at once. Upstairs you have the (in my opinion) aforementioned largely dull and repetitive religious-themed art - can't remember any one particular thing - but on the ground floor are the sculptures that make the visit worthwhile, including a representation of a reclining Pauline Bonaparte (Napoleon's sister). Personally I don't think you need the full two hours and of course it is expensive (about 11/12 euros) and tickets need to be booked in advance either online or by telephone.

Be still my heart!. This place was my all-time favorite, not just in Rome, but compared to museums in Venice & Florence. The villa is the perfect setting for a lot of stunning art. But get reservations ahead of time and take time to stroll around the beautiful gardens. Suggestion: go through once, then exit back the way you came. You will see twice as much and get a quick and much needed review of what you saw the first time through.

Best Gallery in Rome. I really enjoyed this stunning collection of art and sculpture, featuring some of Italy's most famous artists - Bernini, Caravaggio, Titian and Raphael, to name but a few. The audio provided a lot of detail and inside knowledge that was interesting and informative - it was well worth the extra five euros. We tried to buy tickets on the day we went and found they were booked up about 3 days in advance. Next time we will buy in advance online. Our trip wasn't wasted tho' as we bought our tickets for in a few days time and spent a lovely afternoon in the surrounding gardens, which have bikes or golf carts for hire.

Amazing museum. In a well kept structure there is such great pieces of art and scultures. We had the whispers which provided alot of good information, something I would recommend to anyone going to visit.

Beautiful and magnificent art collection fit for royalties.. Lovely, beautiful and magnificent art collection. I saw the boy David trying to sling a shot at the giant Goliath.A good place for art students to study art. Free admission for art students.So much to see within two hours.Will visit again in the future.

Best afternoon in Rome. I dragged my husband to this prepaid tour. we ended up with only 5 people on the tour and the guide was so enthusiastic and knowledgeable that my husband said it was the best thing he had seen in Rome.

Impressive!. I'm not that into art or museums (though my husband is, so I go along), but the Borghese Gallery was very impressive! You definitely need to make reservations at least several days in advance! We got the audio tour, which we both thought was very well done. I don't think you would need to do a guided tour, the audio tour should be sufficient. In my opinion, the Borghese Gallery is a must see on your trip to Rome!!

overwhelming. Each room contains its own masterpiece, weather it be a sculpture that leaves you breathless or a painting by a master artist. You are allowed 2hrs and since they only allow a limited number during each time period, you can easily see each and every room slowly taking it all in. Be sure to make reservations very early, long before you take your trip. It books quickly way in advance.

outstanding. you only get two hours allocated for this amazing collection of art which is only just enough, blows your mind away and is a must do when visiting rome. remember to book in advance as there is often no day tickets available.

Even if you hate art, you have to see this. I am not a big art fan. Spending hours wandering through galleries looking at paintings and sculpture is not my idea of a good time. But the Borghese Gallery was amazing, even for me. I could not believe how lifelike and intricate the sculptures were. I went back to some of the sculptures two or three times just because I couldn't believe they were made of stone. Really beautiful. If you are in Rome, I would put this on your top 5 list. Be sure and reserve tickets in advance. Even though we were there in September, the day we visited there was a sign up saying that they were sold out for the next 4 days.

Always impressive. Secnd time for a visit. Make sure you get the head set or take a tour to really get the most out of your visit. Yu must book a couple days ahead for a time, which is great as t is never to crowded.Your time is for 2 hours. Walk through the gardens before or after , wonderful park fr a hot Rome day

Book ahead.. I have had to rate this so low because although we made out way to Villa Borghese we could not get in. I can provide a tip for getting there though ... The electric bus 116 makes its way from the Vatican City through the back streets of old Rome and ends up at the end of the lane leading to the Gallery. THAT provides an opportunity to see several sights on your return journey.When planning a trip to Rome book on-line before you go ... the web-site is easy enough to use.

My Favorite Art in Rome. If vacationing in Rome, don't miss the chance to see the Bernini statuary up-close at the Borghese. Even in a city where amazing artwork is abundantly prevalent, the collection here stands alone.

Fabulous. We really liked the fact that they don't let the place get packed with hordes of visitors, therefore you can see all there is without battling for a space, and there's lots to see, so take every minute of the 2hours allotted time and enjoy art.

My favorite in Rome. I have been to the Villa Borghese on two different visits. My first was in 2010, the second in 2013. Both experiences were wonderful! The Bernini sculptures were exquisite, and I couldn't recommend more highly! I truly enjoyed my visit alone the first trip, but I was excited to share the museum with my parents and children on the second visit. It believe it is a must see. We stayed at an apartment by the Spanish steps and it took about 30 minutes to walk up the hill and get to the Villa. My girls enjoyed a buggy ride after a 2-hour visit, and we had a great time zipping around the pathways in the large park. Sometimes large public events are held at the park surrounding the Villa, and I did catch a World Cup soccer game on an enormous screen with a few thousand fans watching. That was definitely a immersion in culture! There is a wonderful overlook of the Piazza di Popolo where you can take a great photo of the whole city. Also a must-do.

Book in advance. I wanted to go but found out that the tickets are limited and you need a reservation to visit. It sounded like if I had just called a few days in advance it would not have been an issue but the day of was a no go.

Make sure you make reservations and don't drink anything!. We walked for almost one hour to go to the museum only to find a sold out sign for the next two days. We needed to use heir bathroom after arriving but they refused us without a ticket. We asked if we ate in their cafe could we use the facilities. Again NO! We asked could we pay to use their facilities...and we're met with a nasty No! Very nasty staff so we left with bursting bladders and walked another hour until we finally found a cafe that would accommodate our hunger, thirst and bathroom needs! Sorry not to get to see the exhibits but glad not tohave given them any Euros!

Pre book. To avoid disappointment you need to pre book your ticket for this Gallery. Galleria Borghese is often booked out for a week. It is an easy, gallery to go through. Get the audio guides for the explanations too.

Galleria Borghese has magnificient statues. It is worth your time to visit this gallery. The Bernini statues are breathtaking to see. We rented the audio guides. While they are very informative they do distract you from enjoying the statues. So some time I turned the audio off. This is easy to do.You have to book in advance. Yu can do so online. If you have the Roma Pass you can phone ahead and get a confirmation number if you tell them you will have the Pass. You need this number because you have to show your pass and the number to get your admittance ticket.You have to check your bags but this is quite safe.

Beautiful. We ordered tickets back in February for our trip in Rome in September. It's was worth every euro to see this magnificent museum. Our time to go into the museum was 9:00am you have to be there right on time.

Highlights: Bernini and Canova. This may be the place with the highest concentration of Bernini sculptures. Several of his most famous are there. I can tell you that there is nothing like seeing Apollo and Daphne in person. I could spent half an hour just looking at it. Canova's Venus Victrix is also breathtaking. For me, knowing something about the artists and their places in history add to the experience. So I would suggest reading a popular art history book if you really want the full experience. I read "Rome: A Cultural, Visual, and Personal History" by Robert Hughes. Some parts I found a little slow, but I was glad for the knowledge.Bags are not allowed, but there is a bag check. I think that it was free. Enter in the middle of the front of the building, going down the stairs for tickets and bag check. After that, you go up the stairs to enter the gallery. Audioguides available, and I personally can't do without them.After enjoying the gallery, the Piazza del Popolo is a pleasant 1.9 km walk through the gardens away. I found this more peaceful and enjoyable than walking down the streets.

Worth seeing. Need reservations. Recommended by friends and was certainly worth seeing. Elevator was not working when we got there. Walk up was not easy so be prepared. Got to the room where audio tour was to begin and headset did not work. Staff was not visible. Walked halfway down and met some official who did not seem to think he could do anything (like go get another headset). Friend and I deceided to share. Not too long after, official turned up with new headset. After that, all went well and we were dazzled by the art and history. We were there at Easter and could not find a restaurant open for lunch. Toilets were not the cleanest.

You need about 30 minutes in here - don't get a tour. This museum limits the number of guests per hour, so it is not as crowded and you can walk at a quick pace and stop only when you feel like stopping to see something. My cousin decided to book a tour guide for the museum. Little did he know, and little did the guide tell him, that if you are more than 5 people, a guide is not permitted to discuss out loud any of the art, so you are required to then spend more money to rent the headphone devices. I hate those things and can read what is written on the wall next to each and every painting (amazing how curators have thought of this), so I took my 2 children and niece and nephew with me so that we would be 5 and the others could get the tour. You definitely do not need more than 1 hour in here. 45 minutes tops and that should include a bathroom stop because it is clean. Nice to see, just plan on a quick visit. My cousin also made us meet the guide an hour before the museum even opened, so we were forced to wait there for 1 hour before gaining access. It was especially fun for the 4 kids, ages 9-5, to wait on the steps for an hour. It opens at 11 am. Each ticket gives you 2 hours access.
Best Museum in Rome. This museum limits the number of guests per hour. It means the galleries are not crowded and you can actually enjoy the experience of viewing the art inside.

Second Favorite Stop in Rome. A friend and I, both of us 30 (w/ rather diverse interests I might add) decided to add this to our itinerary for Rome. So glad we did! After Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini this was our favorite. The museum houses a large collection of Bernini statues and Caravaggio paintings and every room is more captivating than the last. A woman on the plane recommended the audio tour over the actual guide and we took her advice. I can't speak to how it would have been versus a real person, but I really enjoyed it. It was one of those go-at-your-own-pace, plug in the number of the statue when you get there type audio guides. As others have mentioned you have exactly 2 hours inside the museum and you need to get there 30 minutes before. TIP: the room you start in if you come up the staircase from behind the audio-rental desk is the back of the museum, NOT the front. The hardest part was figuring out what room on the map you're in to start plugging in numbers. It was a central rectangular room that had three separate audio tags...best of luck :-) We used the Roma Pass and had this earmarked as one of our free entrance fees. I emailed them to confirm our 2pm reservation and they replied w/ a confirmation number. When we arrived, I presented the ticket desk w/ both my initial email and the reply...they had no record of it. But seeing as I had the email and they were sold out for the next few days, they gave us tickets anyway (we were pretty nervous there for a minute). After your ticket, you have to check everything...remember to keep your ID on you and some $$ so you can rent your audio guide. Then you que up until they let you go in. It's a huge hassle, but worth it. Take some time to explore the gardens afterward, they're great.
A good time filler for at least one hour. If you are truly in to art and history, the Vatican Museum in Rome and the Eufitzzi in Florence are must sees. This one is a nice clean family time filler.

Superb. This is a must see when in Rome. You are only allotted 2 hours to see this whole thing and we didn't quite make it so we will definitely be going back next time in Rome. Absolutely beautiful and left us in awe. Highly recommend.

Our favorite gallery in Italy. We were able to squeeze in without a reservation one rainy Sunday at 5pm and we are so glad we did! This gallery is full of gems and the stories behind the acquisitions are very interesting. We highly recommend renting the audio guide - it was the best one of any we rented in Italy. If you don't have reservations, show up at 9am - there are always openings.

Breath-taking art & histroical content. We booked a week in advance (you have to book in advance, because that’s the policy) and secured the last slot of the day (5-7pm). We booked on the website: http://www.galleriaborghese.it/borghese/en/edefault.htm which takes you through to a secure booking site: http://www.tosc.it/tickets.htm?affiliate=T2C&sort_by=event_datum&sort_direction=asc&fun=erdetail&doc=erdetaila&erid=912678&language=enThe Gallery is spectacular and breath-taking, and the information on the audio guide interesting, educational and extremely helpful (and necessary in my opinion; I think your experience would be diminished without an audio guide). Whilst you pay for reservations online, you will buy the inexpensive audio guides separately on the day. I think even if you’re not an art lover, you’ll be impressed by the rich artwork and will appreciate the related historical value.Be careful as to which metro station you get off at to access the gallery! We got off at Flaminio and it was a 25mins walk (through a nice green parkland though) to get to the Borghese Gallery. I think it would have been faster/closer to go to Spagna (and that is where we went on our way back to the hotel). If you are comfortable with the buses then without doubt that is the option that takes you closest to the gallery itself.Another point to note is that you have to check in your bag so make sure you leave enough time for this. There wasn’t much of a queue for us, but maybe that’s because it was the last entry slot of the day so was less busy.

Stunning artwork and building. We had a reservation for 9 am Sunday morning thinking it wouldn't be so busy but is was sold out. (and sold out until Wed) We bought our tickets online about a month early.We took a guided tour because you are only allowed 2 hours in the Galleries so we wanted to make the most of our time and see the highlights.our guide was excellent, very knowledgable, tour was about 1 1/2 hours and then we wnadered for 1/2 hour on our own.

Beautiful!. Although my husband and I spent an hour finding the place, once we arrived for our scheduled tour, we were amazed by the vast collection of sculpture and painting. TIP: arrive early to leave time in case you get lost in the park! Get the audio guide! It is worth it!!
Beautiful. Beware, you have to check everything before entering. Make sure you allow enough time for the bag check line. Also purchase your ticket online or by phone well in advance.

Simply stunning. We booked our tickets in advance. We didn't want a guided tour but thought we would use an audio guide. We visited at 3pm and it must have been a busy day because the guides had to be recharged before we could use them. The queue was long and slow. In the end we decided against waiting.The pieces on display within the galleria are many and varied and all beautiful. The Bernini statues are breathtakingly exquisite. Worth the entry fee all on their own.If you only have time to visit one art collection in Rome, make it this one.

Not to be missed. If you like sculpture especially Bernini, you must arrange a visit to the Borghese Gallery. Among many treasures there are two Bernini sculptures: Daphne and Apollo, and the Rape of Persephone which are mesmerizing! Reserve online ahead of time
if you are not a fond of statues you will become here... among many others some of the best Bernini´s masterpieces you can admire at the gallery of the richest family in medieval Italy...

Beautiful!. This place was out of the way but worth the trip! I recommend buying tickets online prior to going there. It's a beautiful place- if you like architecture, painting, and sculpture, its a wonderful mixture of the different media! It wasn't something I had thought to go to (my husband had wanted to go), but I really enjoyed it.

I would go again, and again.... Of all the sites, museums, churches and monuments this was my favorite place that I would go back to again on my next visit to the eternal city. If you are a fan of Bernini I'm sure you will fill the same way! It contains probably the best masterpieces of the sculptor! Don't forget to reserve a ticket online before hand because you mind end up not getting in. Also the wardrobe would happily take your bag but not your jacket...strange right?! Well, be prepared. Oh, and no pictures.

gorgeous villa full of renaissance artwork. you need reservations in advance so do that as soon as you can or as soon as you land in Rome. we were lucky in that we were coming back to Rome at the end of our trip to fly out and so were able to make reservations a week in advance.situated in lovely park too.

Amazing gallery. After visiting the Capitoline Museum, National Museum of Rome, and the Vatican Museum, I wasn't sure I could handle another set of sculptures. I was wrong. The Borghese Gallery is amazing. I highly suggest it to anyone going to Rome. The sculptures are just breathtaking even if you aren't an art expert. So glad we went to the Borghese Gallery.

Great experience. We missed the point that we had to reserve a viewing slot online beforehand, but we were lucky to enter on a Saturday night for 2 euro only. The place itself is gorgeous. Except of all sculpture and pictures don't miss the ceiling - by the end of the visit your neck will ache, but it will well worth it =))

Beautiful sculptures in a pretty park. Exquisite collection of sculptures, along with paintings. Even if you don't know a lot about art or history (like us) it's breathtaking to walk through and admire. The visits are scheduled for a 2 hour time slot, which is probably adequate for experts. We leisurely finished in an hour.
Off the charts!. This is the one must thing that you have to do in Rome. Better than the Vatican tour by a long shot, and without all the people since the regulate how many people go in.

Good collection but time-limited viewing by pre-reservation only. Pretty good collection of works mostly by Bernini and Caravaggio as well as some Rubens and Raphael. The Galleria itself is majestic and located in the expansive Villa Borghese gardens. You have to reserve a 2 hour viewing slot online before hand and get there 15 mins ahead of time to pick up your tickets. They allow only a limited number of people in at a time so the slots get filled up pretty quickly so plan ahead. Moreover they are sticklers for adherence to the 2 hour slot so if you are not done with the gallery within the allotted time then tough luck, you will be politely told to exit out. They literally start closing off doors to the various sections one by one. We missed seeing about 20% of the top-most floor due to running out of time. Main reason was that we had gotten the audio guide and were spending a lot of time in front of exhibits listening to the audio. One recommendation is to skip the audio for the exhibits that you are really not interested in and move on to the next one in the room.Once you are done with the galleria make sure that you visit the gardens they are quite beautiful. My wife and I rented a two seater - 4 wheel bicycle and rode around the gardens (they are quite huge) which was a lot of fun. There are a couple of locations in the gardens to rent the bikes, the closest to the galleria is to walk straight down the road in front of the galleria (with your back to it) for about 200 feet and you will see the bike rental place on your right.Remember you will need at least 4 hours to do all this so plan accordingly. Overall highly recommended for art lovers.

not to be missed. This is one of the most memorable museums I have ever visited. The sculptures especially by Bernini are magnificent, breathtaking.
