We bought skip the line reserved tickets online, and rented an audioguide when we arrived. This gallery sells only 360 tickets per two hours , so you will have a limited 90 minute or two hour visit but you will have the pleasure of being in uncrowded rooms , truly uncrowded. Give yourself plenty of time to find the entrance to the Gallery which is far from most things and really accessible by taxi for most people, I imagine. You won't want to be late since your ticket has a firm time slot on it.

If you love sculpture, and would like to see art in a gorgeous, gorgeous setting, this is your museum. This is the private collection of Scipione Borghese, nephew of Pope Paul VI and an avid art collector. He amassed a dazzling collection of paintings (Caravaggio, Raphael, Titian, etc.) and sculptures (Bernini, Canova, etc.) which is housed in an exquisitely decorated villa. This museum is of perfect scale: lots to see and enjoy, but not as utterly overwhelming as some of the larger galleries and museums. You need to book your timed entrance in advance (when we were there those who did not do so were turned away, disappointed, with the first available entrance available four days later). purchasing the ticket is very easy to do on their website. You just pick them up upon arrival. You will have to check your bags (even your purse) before entering the Galleria.

Amazing art experience. The best way is to walk all the way through the Borhese park and finally arrive to this beautiful building in order to enjoy the art. You are most likely to enter if you bought the ticket ahead, so make sure you do that. Arrive earlier and bring only the necessary things with you, because all handbags and rucksacks are checked in the wardrobe. Two hours is just ideal period for a nice walk through the rooms. I personally prefer fine arts to sclupture, but I must say that after visiting Borghese and seeing Bernini’s pieces of art, my preferences are not so strict anymore. Bernini’s art exhibited here has left me speechles and utterly touched. Scene of Appolo and Daphne brought tears to my eyeswith its sheer beauty and purity. The collection of fine arts is also very reach and contains some true gems.

See some of the greatest masterpieces in Rome. Make reservations few weeks in advance and go early in the morning. We enjoyed a lovely, uncrowded,Saturday 9 AM morning tour. The works of many famous artist were truly awe inspiring. Afterward, we sat on a bench in the surrouding park watching joggers, bikers of all ages and families in electric peddal carts. The near miss collisions of the many wheeled modes of transportation while listening to a street musician playing Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D Minor on the accordian was truly entertaining-an almost magical morning.

A Gem. This is a wonderful gallery. You only get two hours inside, which is plenty, but be sure to enjoy the gardens a bit too. If you walk to the other side of the park, you can make it to the top of the Spanish steps and see the Medici palace - but it's a far walk so only try this if you're used to walking a few miles. Here's what you need to know about the gallery: reserve your tickets ahead of time, arrive early (like at least 20 min), and do spend the money to buy the audio tour - you'll get so much more out of it. Also, they are very strict with the bag policy, so just be prepared to check everything.

A must see while inRome. Rome has a lot of incredible sites to see and the Borghese is at the top of my list. I've been there twice and I'll go a third time. The artwork is very impressive and the Borghese was designed to accommodate the artwork. Order your tickets online for a predetermined entry time and you'll have a minimal wait. The Borghese is close to the Spanish Steps and not too far from the Vatican, so definitely put it on your list of must see sites.

The gardens alone are worth a visit. This review is for the Borghese Gardens, as we hadn't made reservations for the museum but it was a close walk from our hotel - and well worth it just for walking the grounds (if you can cover them all!)........admiring the outdoor sculptures and just relaxing outdoors. While we were there, there was a young man playing an accordion? near the path which was amazing - very skillful and it sounded like a pipe organ, playing classical and complicated pieces. There are apparently pedal cars which you can rent, it was a hoot to watch people using them; a 3-car 'train' which took people around the park, and probably other things we didn't see but the total experience was really lovely. So glad we found it!
Beautiful art work. The Bernini statues were exquisite, The best we have ever seen. Well worth the trip to the gallery. We can't stop talking about them!
Lovely museum. Beautiful artworks and statues. Some fantastic pieces. No crowds but you have to book in advance. Best gallery and museum in Rome.

Gorgeous, but small!. Gorgeous!But not very big...they limit you to 2 hours, but if you're not an art snob like us, you'll probably just need 60-90 minutes. You probably don't need a reservation during off season(September)...my wife and I just walked right in around 11am with our Roma Passes.
Stunning. The Bernini Sculptures in this museum are mind blowing and not to be missed. You need to book in advance because they only let in a limited number of people each hour,

Apollo and Daphne. Lovely villa and gardens. Amazing museum. Grab a picnic lunch at nearby open air market and sit by the fountain. Immense Umberto d'Italia statue, pony rides, music... Must have reservations for museum so not crowded at all. Bernini's Appollo and Daphne will take your breath away.

A compendium of some of civilization's finest artwork.. If you do not care for or if you do not understand art, you may wish to give this a miss. but if you do at least enjoy the massive gardens and surrounding area. It is up on a hill away from the masses, expect to share your day with students from Away. The reason to come here is to marvel at Gian Bernini's collection of sculptures. Move over Michaelangelo, this guy has you beat.

Stunning. This is a must for visitors to Rome. The location is beautiful and the artwork has to be seen to be believed. The statue of Apollo and Daphne is truly fantastic. Booking beforehand is recommended as it sells out quickly.

Don't Leave Rome without Visiting. The Villa is amazing with many famous paintings, and Bernini sculptures. Two hours is barely enough time to soak it all in. The gardens are also fabulous with many fountains, sculptures, lakes, etc.

Art work and gardens make it well worth the visit. The history of the Villa with all the fantastic art work and sculptures is fantastic. When you are tired of roman ruins this is a good break. There maybe long lines to purchase entry ticket so go early. If you can hire a guide it helps to understand the significance of some of the works of art.

The Villa Borghese. This villa is well worth a visit. If you intend to go, you may have to book it, as we did, two days in advance. The Bernini sculptures, particularly 'Apollo and Daphne' are stunning and there are some remarkable pictures also within; in particular Titian's 'Profane and Sacred Love'. Cardinal Borghese had an extraoadinary eye for major artworks. Not one to miss!

Amazing sensory overload!. Firstly the gallery is located in the gorgeous Borghese Gardens - a beautiful park to stroll through. Then.. the gallery is amazing - each room you walk through has so much to see - some amazing sculptures (my favorites) and then an astonishing amount of artwork - highly recommended.Remember to book ahead as it's often booked out.

Make pre-reservation!!!. I have no idea why but the day we arrived at the Villa Borghese, it wasn´t possible to visit the Galleria the same day. They told us that all tickets for the day have been sold out and that it´s necessary to make a reservation, either for the next day or another day to visit the Galleria. Pretty strange. So we needed to leave again and kept our visit with just taking a walk in the beautiful park.

Amazing!!. This gallery was filled with amazing art in a serene, relaxed but beautiful setting. The number of people allowed every 2 hours is limited - which is great as its not crazy inside like some of the other european galleries. But book before you go to avoid disappointment!

Another Roman favorite. This is a beautiful museum filled with beautiful artwork. The gardens are also beautiful and worth a stroll. It isn't always easy to get tickets without a long wait and once there were no tickets available but making a reservation is a good way to make sure it gets worked into the schedule. Very beautiful sculptures and paintings in a city full of incredible art!

Superb Art Museum. Large two story villa that is literally filled to the brim with amazing art treasures. The sculptures by Bernini alone are worth a visit. Advance reservations are a must, at least a few days in ahead. Location is not convenient to the Metro, it is a long walk up hill from either of the two closest stations, you may want to consider a taxi. On the Roma Pass list, don't miss it.

Missable. We of course researched Trip Advisor and other travel sites to learn that Galleria Borghese was a "must-see", so we booked tickets early, just as required. However, I'm sad to report that the hours spent in this museum were our least favorite hours in Rome! Perhaps it was due to our having a self-guided tour (we rented an audio tour at the museum) wedged between two professionally-guided tours of the Vatican and Colosseum. Yes, the grounds were beautiful and EVERYTHING in Rome is pure work of Art, but give yourself permission (if you feel so inclined) to spend your time where your heart leads.....reviews on the Internet won't always be correct for you.
Best sculpture museum - period. Wow, the Berninis will just bowl you over. Absolutely need to make advanced reservations. Stay to the end of the 2 hour visit to lose the crowds.

Fantastic Collection & Setting. Truly splendid way to spend two hours in Rome. My friends who are not big into art were blown away by this collection and the Villa itself. Getting to see Bernini's magnificent sculptures alone are worth the price of admission! Be sure to make reservations well in advance since it books up. I also thought the audio guide really added to the experience, unlike some of the other audio guides at the big Roman attractions. You won't regret making time for this gallery!
Superb. The sculptures within the galleria are among the best in the world. The grounds are lovely. You must see the sculpture of Paulina Borghese

It will make your day. Wonderful place, extraordinary art.. Some of the sculptures really make amazed, most of those are Berninies.
Make sure you buy a ticket in advance. And, you will have just 2 hours to see everything - clearly not enough, so hurry.

Awe Inspiring. The paintings and sculptures are awe inspiring! You will need to book this in advance as tickets sell out in the high season. You also need every minute of the two hours they allow. Be sure to get the audio tour. They make you check all bags so be sure to have a wallet or small fanny pack to keep passport and money. Walking from either of the two closest metro.stations is a long and very confusing process as you have to find the gallery within the huge gardens. Give yourself at least an hour unless you are very familiar with the gardens. It is worth the effort to get there.

Extraordinary!. It's truly amazing that the gallery was built by the Borghese's simply as a place to display their artwork. Now that's impressive! Much of the work was commissioned by the family, not just acquired. The Bernini sculptures are worth the visit on their own and it is amazing how accessible they are to visitors. This allows you stand right next to his works and really see up close the amazing detail. To see a hand gripping a thigh with indentations similar to someone grabbing a plump loaf of uncooked bread (sorry, best example I can give) and realize that it is marble takes your breath away. I'm not a big fan of renaissance painting, but the sculpture is stunning. Definitely take the audio tour or use a guide and read up on the gallery before visiting.

A must see while in Rome. Located in the Borghese Park you must have reservations to visit this gallery. The visit is limited to smaller groups of 2 hours per group. I made on line purchase of tickets which was well worth the additional cost.Picture taking isn't allowed inside but the artwork the Borghese family collected is incredible. Actually one family member was a Pope! Works of arts include paintings and sculptures from Bernini, Canova, Rapheal, Perugino, and Peter Paul Rubens. Bernini sculptures are mind blowing and the detail of the human body is a must see.

Divine.... This is a must go when in Rome. It is everything it presents itself to be and so much more. This takes you back to a time and place that is hugely rich & romantic. We always visit when in Rome, you should too.

incredible walk through history. I loved this Museum! I felt like I got to know some of the Artists personally. The audioguide was very helpful, although you can also choose to have a "human" guide. My favorite works were by Bernini and I can still picture them in my memory=absolutely amazing work.

Stunning - a definate must see !!!. In my opinion, the art on the ceilings in this building nocks spots off the Cisitine Chapel. You have to book in advance for your ticket sometimes by as much as three days or so and are only allocated 2 hours in which to walk around. Although this seems a long time, it will pass like seconds...I have been here three times now and I still am left in awe by the art, the sculptures...I cannot recommend this place enough. If you dont go anywhere else, visit this place - you will not be disappointed
Intimate small place. If u r art and history bluff!! Must see they have one of the mostBest art collection in Rome,the villa borghese have sculpture byGiovanni

Great Sculptures. Worth seeing this collection in the Villa Borghese park. There is so much to see in Rome but this is amazing, especially if you get a guided tour available at a very small fee. Not much more than he audio tour.The Bernini sculptures are inspiring!Walking through the surrounding grounds is reminiscent of Central Park with so many families enjoying this oasis in the city.

Excellent!. The construction is beautiful and the gardens surrounding the house are very, very nice. The museum has two floors, one for sculptures and the second one for paintings, but the sculptures from Bernini on the 1st floor are not to be missed. Pay attention to the fact you'll only have two hours to visit everything, as the visits are booked for a limited time. Even the ones who are not the biggest art fans will like it! No need for a guided visit or for audio guides: each room has cards explaining the main facts about the exhibitions. Need to book in advance!

Well worth booking. Booked this online in advance and then you need to pick them up downstairs. Usually all tour times are full each day so just log onto their website and book your tickets before hand. The audio tours are well worthwhile ( I was cheeky and shared one with my brother ) Because there are a limited number of spaces it is not crowded. I would advise hanging back at the beginning and then you can explore each room almost by yourself. The statues are incredible. Be wary bags are not allowed so you will need to check them in downstairs. Times are v. strict so there is no point getting there too long in advance ( but leave enough time to pick up your ticket )

Borghese gallery by dark rome tours. My husband and I toured the Bourghese museum and gallery with Rebecca from dark rome tours! She was so kind, funny, knowledgeable, and most of all so passionate about this Rome treasure. She makes you as the visitors just as excited to learn about all of what the borghese museum has to offer! She lit up with every story about Bernini or Corvaggio it made you just as excited to learn about it and to fall in love with the artwork! She was so generous in offering her experiences In rome with us. From metro tips to great restaurants and must go places it was great! She is the first tour guide who remembered every name of the members of our tour group.. That just shows this wasn't just a day job for her. She takes great interest in us the tourists and teaching us all she can! Book any tour with rebecca you wouldn't be disappointed!

It was good to be the Cardinal. Perfect 2 hours of quiet time in a museum. Must purchase tickets ahead of time (go online to the museum website). The museum provides a 2 hour segment for each visitor and limits the number of visitors per segment, so it's not overly crowded (Rome can be crowded). Get the audioguide and just relax and see some of the most impressive sculptures and paintings ever done. The Pope made his nephew the Cardinal and did he ever made the best of that! Loved it. Take the time to visit this museum and enjoy the quiet lovely park where the museum resides. It's a bit of a respite from the hawkers and crowds in the rest of Rome.

"Small is beautiful". If there is ever something which proves the old saying "Small is beautiful" this should be it. Located amidst the lush greenery of the Borghese gardens this small art gallery is a real gem. Among the paintings are some of the masterpieces by the likes of Titian and Caravaggio. The Bernini sculptures are some of the most stunning that I have ever seen (and I have seen a lot). Even the rooms themselves can be considered works of art in their own right. This in one attraction that should be a must visit for all art lovers. Remember that they only allow a limited number of visitors each day and the slots are filled out rather quickly. So bookings should be made well in advance.

Rome Attractions. This was my first visit to Galleria Borghese after several trips to Rome. It was the almost perfect gallery visit -- admission is for only 1 1/2 hours, which is just the right amount of time to see everything at a leisurely pace. The only drawback was the long wait in line - even with a "pre reservation" by our tour company. Very nice gift shop and beautiful grounds to walk and sit and terrific photo opps!!

A surprising must see !!. We didn't know much about this museum, but we were so happily surprised! The museum is small and intimate, but with so many works of masters. Two pieces of advice, make a pre-reservation in advance, and purchase the headphones for the tour.

Some of the finest art that was ever "stolen". While the paintings seem to get top billing, I found the Bernini sculptures to be the real treasures. The biggest thrill was probably the "Apollo and Daphne". If you do not know the sculpture, Google it, then be sure to see the original -- 100 times better than any photo.Remember admission is by reservation only and they can be sold out weeks in advance in the high season.

Beautiful!. So many outstanding works of art. Every room filled with so much to see and study. I recommend a guided tour or the audio tour. There is so much you could miss! The only down side, there was no picture taking!

Get the headset or a private tour for borghese gallery. After the Vatican, this was a very pleasant change. The rooms were well laid out and it is not overwhelming to see. I believe they allow only 200 people at a time so you never feel crowded. If you book online, the gray door below the entrance will open up and you can get your pass. You then proceed to a desk where your belongings are stored. Water bottles, cameras, etc. no pictures allowed. I only regret we didn't get the sound system and envied the people with private tours explaining each painting or sculpture. There isn't much signage at all for the exhibits. Just who painted it.
Children. If you have young children you will need to escape the city to here, hire a family bike, golf buggy, Segway, or walk plenty of playgrounds, sandwiches are pretty crap though bring a picnic

Don't forget to make reservations!. Our last trip to Rome, we thought we could just walk up to the Galleria and buy a ticket for entry. Not so. This time, we booked in advance (you can do it on the Internet) and breezed right in for our appointed time. It is a treasure trove and not to be missed -- just the right size for bringing a family too, because, while it is loaded with wonderful paintings and sculpture, it is not overwhelming in the least.

Definitely put this on your list to see. My husband and I had a private tour of this gallery with ANGEL Tours. We decided to see this gallery because Rick Steve's, the travel expert, highly recommended it. This gallery exhibits a large part of the collection of paintings and sculptures amassed by Cardinal Scipione Borghese (Nephew of Pope Paul V) between 1576 and 1633. The collection includes the extensive works by Caravaggio, Bernini, Raphael, and Rubens. No photos were allowed to be taken inside and you must check in your purse or any nap sacks before the tour begins. The Borghese Gardens also are quite extensive and beautiful to see so definitely put this gallery and gardens on your list of sights to see in Rome.

An easy 5. After the Vatican, this was the highlight of our trip. Book in advance. You are only allowed 2 hours in the museum because it is small and very popular. Arrive early--the grounds are lovely. You must check your belongings before you enter the museum. No cameras, purses, knapsacks, etc. The gift shop is small but quite nice.

Bucket List Worthy. We lucked into this one; a family of five Americans who didn't realize how special the Museum is...we booked a tour through Dark Room and our guide, Luca, was an art enthusiast whose passion rubbed off on us and the Australians who were also on the tour. Everything was amazing but the marble sculptures were my most outstanding feature. My adult son was impressed with the massive "bird cages" and my daughters seemed to enjoy the paintings. Oh, and there are only a limited amount of people allowed into the Gallery at any one time (which is great) so they do sell out but the tour guide takes care of that for you. The only downside was our own fault; we were there in August and it was so hot that I developed a rash on my ankles. Best to go in Spring or Fall.

Great art. This is quite a small gallery but with a great collection with Caravaggios and Berninis to the fore. You need to book in advance and if like me, you are not an art expert it is worth getting the audio guide to get any real appreciation of the work. The visit is limited to 2 hours but that will get you to view the main works at reasonable speed and for me 2 hours is as much as I can manage to take in of great art and still enjoy and wonder at it. Because they restrict the numbers it was not overcrowded.
Beautiful. I highly recommend going through with a guide. The grounds surrounding the museum are fantastic as well

Breathtaking art. Truly not to be missed. The most magnificent sculptures are on display in a beautiful setting. The park and gardens are tranquil.A great way to spend a day in Rome. Reservations a must!Guided tour a must!

Call AHEAD!!!. We got here just after 12 (noon) and was told that it was SOLD OUT for the day! There was hardly anyone there...I didn't get it. Soooo sad I didn't get to go in. So just a heads up, call ahead of time and RESERVE tickets! I had a Roma pass and they still turned me away. =(

You Must Book. the whole park which this sits on is fantastic and worth the walk alone, i have given an excellent rating for this and the surrounding area and the building alone, sadly we had not booked and so on turning up at 10:30am it was already sold out and we could not get in. You must book in order to get in so this is on our list to do as soon as we get back.

Art for the parents, gardens for the kids. A vast collection of beautiful paintings including some by some well known painters. We got there at the end of the day and only had about an hour before it closed. This was enough time with two young boys in tow. My favourite was the statue of Apollo and Daphne by Bernini. The gardens here are also a great place for kids to take a break away from all the all the art and sculptures. There are bicycles and quadracycles for hire. We hired a three seater and had one of the children sitting in the carrier in the front and we all had great fun roaming the gardens. We had to leave a drivers license as a security deposit. There are no road signs indicating you are approaching a main road so beware as you go hurtling down some of the roads! We also found that pedestrians seem to be reluctant to move aside even if you create some noise as you approach them.

Must see. That was one of those places what we think was must of see nad it was worth of it.
Better to go and see with your own eyes.
Remember to reserve tickets advance.

A gallery really worth seeing. Rome may be a museum itself but galleria borghese ,housing some distinctive specimens of Bernini's works of art as well as paintings by Caravaggio and other famous artists, is really worth visiting. Don't fail to spend some time at the wonderful gardens which are an oasis in Rome especially during the hot summer months. We spent half a day at the site and we would have definitely spent some more had we had more time at our disposal!

Such an amazing collection of artwork. Make sure you secure your entry time in advance of your visit. Tickets are rarely available same day.Please be sure to get the audio guide so you can fully enjoy this collection!

meh. Unlike most reviewers, we called in the morning and were given a 5:00 pm reservation that day. The check in is a little confusing, as you have to have a reservation then stand in line to get tickets, another line to check ALL bags then a third to get the audio. You start out by going back out the door you just came into to start the tour. See the first floor, then back out the "front" door to go back in side to see the painting section. Felt like a chinese fire drill. The audios are terribly outdated as there are repeated references to the Lira. In the paintings section, the audio become worthless. In most rooms there is only one narrative to listen to per room.The museum is in a nice building in a beautiful setting, but I've seen much better organization at county fairs. I dont consider this a must see. Not in the league of the Getty or Louvre or even the Denver museum of art.
Galleria Borghese. Book all reservations ahead of time, take the tour, take your time as it all is unreal. If you like history and stone and great wonders of the world you will love it.

Outstanding Museum. The museum is small but the Bernini sculptures are wonderful. It was a hassle getting tickets and checking our cameras, purses, etc at the front desk but the museum was worth it. The delicate features of the sculptures and the life-like ripples in the skin are amazing. We will definitely return every chance we get.
Roma Pass. Use your Roma Pass and pay 5 euros each for the audio tour and you will be blown away. So much interesting history.

Reserve Tickets Online. Do not make the mistake of showing up in Rome and thinking you can get in. You must reserve your tickets ahead of time or you will likely be disappointed and miss this small, jam packed treasure.

Art, art, art!!!. Beautifull and impressive collection of classic art ( Caravaggio, statues made by Bernini) Give special attention to statues of the rape of Prosperine and Apollo and Daphne. I usually aren't that interested in classic art, but thes statues were very impressive.Be sure to make a reservation the minute you arrive in Rome, because a limited number of people are allowed in each day and its often sold out fot days in advance!

Unforgettable!. Only 1 in our party of 5 had been to this museum before and it really knocked our socks off! I've never seen such beautiful, awesome sculptures other than in the Louvre. It is so popular that you have to purchase tickets ahead of time for a specific block of time - only 2 hours and you'll be hard pressed to get thru the entire museum in that short of time. As we got there a bit late, we spent our time in the sculpture wing and just had time to dash thru the painting wing.....too bad! Will definitely return and get there early so we don't miss out on anything. A real must see while in Rome!!

My favorite museum in Rome. Galleria Borghese is my favorite museum for several reasons. Sure, it doesn't have the (unmanageable) quantity of treasures that the Vatican Museums has, but the quality of its collection is no less impressive. Beyond the paintings and sculptures, the villa itself is a work of art. Combine that with the tranquil setting of the surrounding gardens and you have a much more relaxing day than standing in line at the Vatican. Don't get me wrong: the Vatican museums should not be missed. But as an overall experience, I have always preferred visiting Galleria Borghese.

This gallery must not be missed. The building housing this gallery itself is stunningly beautiful. The collection of art held within is sublime, it really does house some of the most amazing art in Rome. If going, don't catch the Metro, as the signage from the station is confusing and ends halfway to the Villa. There are several bus routes that serve the area, which are quick and easy to use. Taxis are an option, as are segways (we saw a family arrive on one while we leaving).The two hour limit on the visit is a perfect amount of time to see everything, so don't let that put you off. It is highly recommended that you pre-purchase your tickets as purchasing them on the day is fraught as they sell out quickly.

The gallery for real art lovers. If you are into art history and want to see the greatest collection of Caravaggios then this is the gallery. It's also a nice, peaceful experience. Unlike the vatican which has not limit to the amount of visitors, the Borghese limits the amount of tickets they sell each day. This gives you a civilized experience and you can enjoy the art without a million people in front of you taking pictures of paintings without really looking at them. I had to create an account on the italian ticket site to buy the tickets but it really wasn't that difficult. The one thing I would say is, the Borghese is not in central Rome really. We managed to take a taxi from our hotel in Vatican Prati and it was 10 euro. Make sure you get them to call you a taxi back if you do this. We wandered aimlessly around the park trying to figure out how to get back and there wasn't a taxi in sight.

fabulous even for the non art lover. Must reserve time in advance or you have virtually no shot of getting in during peak seasons. As the only let 200 people in every 2 hours. The 2 hour allotment is a little tight, but gives you enough time to see the vast majority of the Cardinals collection, and its quite a collection.Only down side is no cameras, you'll be asked to check it when you walk thru security.Definitely a must see while in Rome

DO THIS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. O.k., so, we went to our tour (which we booked in advance - a must - or you won't get in because space is so limited) after we had just come out of that swirling vortex of tourist Hell, also known as Vatican City, O.M.G., what a difference! Fist of all, my apologies to the Vatican, but they really need to take a page from Galleria Borghese. The Vatican seems to allow in an unlimited number of people at all times which leads to utter chaos & crowds. We felt like we were amidst an angry mob! Not easy to take in what we came there to experience in the first place. At Galleria Borghese they only allow in 200 people at a time, in very small groups, led by EXCELLENT, well educated guides. I think they could see that we had been put through the ringer that morning, so our most awesome guide ever, Rebecca, took our little group up to the top floor while the other groups were on the bottom floor. She managed to maneuver our group in such a way that we were never in the same room as another group at the same time, WONDERFUL! (Our guide at the Vatican told us to be aggressive if we wanted to be able to see anything!) One thing that initially bummed me out was that your not allowed to bring your camera in & take pictures. My baby, I mean camera, was safely locked away during the tour, which was like going through withdrawals for me! Very quickly though, I realized that I was more present & more able to really listen & take in what Awesome Rebecca (yes, that will be her name from now on) was saying. The gallery is so beautiful & to learn all about Correggio, Titian & in particular Bernini, from someone who is SO passionate about it was a real treat. We all felt so much better (& smarter!) after having been there & slowed our pace down enough to "stop & smell the roses", or in this case really see, listen & learn, rather than just trying to dodge mobs of tired, irritated & sometimes entitled tourists & their "be aggressive" guides. So, go and spend a few hours in the gardens, have a picnic & then visit the gallery. It's so beautiful & a wonderful way to spend part of a day. You'll be glad you did! And you'll be shockingly smarter too!

Borghese Gallery - Beautiful. This beautiful gallery has some much history about Rome and Italy. You will need to reserve in advance, otherwise you can't get in. If you don't have a private tour guide, spend the few Euros and get an audio guide as you walk through the galleries. Finally, walk through the park.

Amazing Collection, Worth the Wait. The first time I was in Rome we did not book an entrance and it was sold out. When booking our latest trip I made sure to organize an entry time! The gallery is spectacular and made even better because its not too crowded. The file statue that we saw by Bernini was my favorite hands down, its hard to imagine how someone can sculpt marble with that precision!

Great art gallery in a beautiful setting. This is a great art gallery. The building is beautiful (was home of one of the Borghese family) You must have a reservation. They only allow 360 people in at one time and you can only stay for 2 hours. That means it never gets too crowded. The gallery is located in a beautiful park. Would have liked to spend time in the park but it was way to hot in early August.

A must see!. One of the most popular museums/galleries in Rome housing works by Titian, Raphael, Rubens, Caravaggio and Bernini. The villa itself is a work of art in its own right. Prior booking is mandatory.

Amazing collection, the Bernini sculptures are incredible. I was not aware of this gallery until my husband told me about it - he learned about its collection in art history class. I'm an avid museum goer, and I have never in my life seen sculptures like the Bernini's in this place - particular the Apollo and Daphne, which I could not stop looking at. Make sure you purchase your tickets online ahead of time, as they sell out pretty early in the day! And don't bother to try and get in early - they are very strict.

Best Attraction in Rome. Ideally located in the stunning Borghese gardens, the Galleria Borghese has some of the most beautiful sculptures and arts you would ever see. Get the audio guide as the history makes it even better. I personally preferred it to the Vatican Museums.

No Detail Ignored. Crazy Borgheses went over the top, no detail ignored There are some VERY good paintings and sculpture (many Berninis, a few Caravaggios) but also lots of less than great stuff. It is crammed; good to walk in the gardens afterward to clear your visual palate.

Spectacular. This museum was truly amazing. The sculptures were unbelievable. I would highly recommend this museum as it has the best sculptures I've seen at any museum (and I've been to a LOT of museums!) You do have to have reservations, so just keep that in mind while planning.
Wow. Amazing Italian architecture and art and just so pretty... beautiful gardens to stroll in and overall a great break to the craziness of being a tourist and running around constantly...

Limited time. The Hotel made a booking for us as you can only visit for 2 hours a day, late afternoon suited us as it was a bit cooler. So much to see here and although my husband doesn't like museums he did enjoy seeing some of the sculptures and art on display. The time was long enough for us but if you want more you can always go for a second visit. There is a huge Park and it is quite restful to just stroll around before heading back to your hotel.

A must see. This is one of my favorite galleries. You must visit if you are a fan of Bernini. Even if you are not, the 3 big Bernini sculptures they have at the gallery are amazing. Very important: You have to make a reservation in order to visit this museum.If you have a Roma pass, the pass gives you 2 free entries to selected attractions. The Galleria Borghese is on the list so you can use the pass for a free entry.

A wonderful 2 hours!. This little gallery tucked into the Borghese Gardens is well worth a visit. You must make a reservation, as they only let in a limited number of guests every 2 hours. I chose to use the audio guide as well, which was helpful. Amazing displays of sculpture!

A Surprise Gem!. We weren't going to visit this museum, but at the last minute changed our minds to fill in a Saturday afternoon. We took a taxi there, as it is not easily accessible by metro, and we are glad we did. We bought tickets online as it was the summertime and you had to have a reservation time to enter the galleria. It was a very simple galleria full of Bernini sculptures! They were breathtaking and the highlight of the museum. After we toured the galleria we took the little train all around the gardens and grounds and found a lot more pleasant surprises...gardens,fountains, a zoo, walking paths, scenic views, sculptures and statues, etc. We wished we had more time to explore the areas and highly recommend visiting this gem of a gallery.

Called for an appointment and was told it wasn't necessary, just to be turned away on arrival because I didn't have an appointme. Arrived at the far side of the park, which is huge, and spent an hour trying to find the museum. I called in advance for an appointment but was told it wasn't required. After all the trouble of travelling to and through the park, I was turned away because the daily appointments had already been assigned.

Watch out for.... No photographs, so pointless.What must be checked: cameras, purses, phones.The check in process is flawed. You have to trust the people who check your stuff.Recommendation: leave camera, purses, phones in hotel safe before going. Make a special trip there and then return to hotel.Also, the required prepaid reservations are non-refundable.They are always booked.

Treasure trove. Perhaps my all time favourite gallery. It is jammed full of art treasures (Bernini and Caravaggio amongst them) and is an exquisite gem of a building in its own right. Situated in Rome's beautiful green public space and easily accessible by taxi - what's not to like? Pre-booking is essential but this can be done online. Remember to look up at the frescoed ceilings as you walk around - just beautiful. You could lose yourself in here for a day or longer - that would test their admission system!

One of the best sculpture museums with no crowds!. Galleria Borghese was a highlight on our tour of Rome. You need to make reservations in advance and you are only allowed two ours in the museum, but that is plenty of time because it is not crowded. The Bernini sculptures are breathtaking and the gallery also has a great collection of paintings. Don't forget to visit the gardens behind the villa. They are beautiful!

So close to the art at Borghese. It was like you could just touch these art pieces they were displayed so openly and like back when they were open to guests back in history!Wonderful place to go if you like scultures, etc.Brenda
statues like divinity. Go and take a big breath....THen see down...before to enter, that look up and see the splendor...Incredibles the clever of the hands of the scultures :)

Amazing experience. I was thinking if it is really worth a visit, but now I know it is a unique experience worth the money and effort :) I am not a huge fan of art, yet I can appreciate beauty of all kinds and I also have some knowledge of history and I admit I was really amazed at this gallery:) I enjoyed it even more than Vatican Museums :) It is good to have some audio guide here, but you can read some info in English or Italian as it is provided in every room (some laminated papers in corners) and for me it was enough... I loved the sculptures of Bernini and the ceilings :) Great! To avoid the queues arrange a meeting in advance and book the evening entrance (I was there at 5pm and there were little ppl there ) It was my second attraction with Roma Pass and I was absolutely satisfied with this choice :)
A must visit. This museum is a most visit for anyone who appreciates paintings from the Renaissance era. Purchase entrance tickets is advance or buy a guided tour (a bit more pricier)
Absolutely a must!.. Wonderful work from many masters. Be sure to make reservations in advance The gardens are beautiful. Take some time to walk around and enjoy the music and the outdoor sculptures.

Limited edition. Galleria Borghese is the lovely one. The capacity for the visit is limited, so it is necessary to book your place using internet. Also, the number of paintings is not enormous, but every one of them is phenomenal.
Beautiful gardens. We did not go inside the Galleria but the grounds outside are stunningly beautiful. Next time in Rome we will go inside.

Book your ticket in advance. As weird as it sounds, you should book your ticket in advance even is you have a Roma pass. Once it's sold out, they will not let you in although you might ask why, it's just a galleria not like a train with limited seats. You can easily walk from the galleria to the Spanish steps through the long underground walkway.
Pretty. Very pretty. Lots to look at and see. You must walk about 10 mins up some hills. Pretty items to look at though. Make sure to visit the gardens.

Beautiful Gardens. This house is full of history and art. It gives you an idea of how rich some people were in those days. The gardens are beautiful and we hired a four person bike to ride around as the park is quite large.

A gem of a museum. Absolutely loved the Borghese Galleria. The Bernini sculptures, alone, were worth the visit. Be sure to make reservations in advance, though. We made our reservations the day before our visit, and saw folks turned away who hadn't made prior reservations.

Fabulous Sculptures. I have to admit that I do not "do" many museums and prefer markets to galleries but this is a must for me everytime in Rome. For me it is worth it if only to see David and the Apollo statute. they do a big deal about how it will take you two hours, for me not that long but that's all your ticket is good for. Important be there on time, tickets issued in 2 hour segments, order on line. If you are not there they give your ticket away. Nice that there is some crowd control. In the park you can rent Segways, bikes and golf carts

Definitely Worth A Visit. While in Rome, we made the trip to this galleria as my daughter, who is a art history major in college, wanted so much to visit here while in Rome. It was simply amazing. The statues and paintings throughout are a step through history via a variety of art media consistent with the represented periods of time. The galleria sits in a large area that also has gardens/parks and historic adjacent buildings. I highly recommend that anyone visiting this location get advance tickets before visiting to avoid the lines which we did and were able to walk right in at our scheduled time. One item to not overlook while appreciating the artwork and statues is to view the incredible ceiling artwork. I was equally astounding by the painted ceiling as everything else in the galleria. Any bags/backpacks that you bring with you will need to be stored with security who place them in lockers during your visit. No photographs are allowed during your visit.

Caravaggio, Raphael, Bernini and more. The location of this gallery is unique in that it sits away from the hustle and bustle of the city in a vast park. In October the trees were still green and many locals and tourists wandered the park grounds outside. We had purchased tickets ahead of time and did not have to wait long to enter. The building is not very large and we made our way through the rooms in a few hours. The collection is very impressive and worth a visit alone to see the intricate carvings by Bernini. I wish I could have taken photos but understand why this was not allowed. Would love to go back some day.

Great Art and Villa. We went to this because my son wanted to see Bernini's David, which was great. I really enjoyed all the fresco's and art. The first floor holds all the statues, and there are many of them. The second floor has a lot of paintings. The whole villa has beautiful painted ceilings, walls with carvings as well and the mosaic floors are wonderful. We had a great time looking at all the art. A must see if you love art.

Bernini and more Bernini. If you are a artsy type of person this is a must see. After the Sistine Chapel, you must visit this place. The Gallery is within the huge Borghese gardens which you must take some time to walk around. You need to reserve your tickets and time online. This was free for me as I had the Roma Pass. You will be asked to leave all your belongings at the check in area, no cameras as the guards are always watching you. You have 2 hours to view everything because you will be ushered out pronto as the next reservation group is waiting. The art works and especially the sculptures by Bernini are amazing, a must see. After viewing the gallery and upon your exit, turn right and walk down the road where you will see bike and semi motorised carts. You can hire a 4 person battery powered bike for 25 euros and view the grounds.

Jet lagged and loved it. We did this on our first day in Italy and we were both wiped out. At one point we both dozed off while standing up. We rented headsets which I Highly recommend. Wonderful works of art by many masters. It would be at the top of my must sees in Rome.
You must book this in advance. There is not much I can say as we did not book well in advance and apparently this is very popular so beware to make sure you book if you want to see this.

Fabulous Villa and Artworks!. Don't miss The Galleria Borghese--it is stunning! Buy tickets online before your visit as it sells out ahead of time disappointing many late thinkers. The museum has figured out a most civilized way to display the fabulous works in the Villa--limiting fans within a two hour viewing time slot--as compared with the ungodly masses allowed through the Vatican Museum. We thoroughly enjoyed this attraction and highly recommend both the museum and the lovely grounds around it. Picnic or walk a short distance to the excellent Girarrosto Fiorentino restaurant for an upscale dining experience!

Wonderful, book ahead, take a picnic. we booked ahead and all left wishing the time slots were 3 hours not 2! the sculpture on the ground floor is so spectacular that we had only 40 minutes for the paintings upstairs, which is not nearly long enough. Excellent audio guide, lovely guide books in the shop. We picked up picnic stuff in a deli just by Spanish Steps and ate al-freco in the beautiful gardens. Overall a lovely, lovely day

It's how old?!?!. My wife and I are not museum people, but when in Rome... Other than the Vatican, this is the only museum we visited and Galleria Borghese is terrific. The large park that surrounds the Galleria is great for a walk, a picnic, or even a nap! Inside you see sculptures and statues that boggle the mind when you think of the history behind them. Be sure to take in the building itself. This used to be somebody's home! Reservations are a must, required I think. We had reservations for 17:00 and because of transportation issues not related to the Galleria, we were more than 30 minutes late and were afraid we'd be turned away. Nope. Not a word about it, walked right in and never thought about it again. Bring as little with you as you can. Purses, bags, phones, essentially everything must be checked in a locker before entering.

Stunning. Almost too much to take in. The building in itself is a work of art, make sure you look up and around at all the archtectural details. The artwork collection is considerable, and well worth seeing. Set in the huge and amazing grounds with sculptures, fountains, huge trees you will have a good day out by taking a picnic lunch to have first or a wander around after going to to the Galleria.Important: This place gets really busy during the high season so you may have to book tickets at least several days in advance online as we did for our session. The collection queue may be short, but allow ample time before your session to queue up on the day.

lavish museum with don't miss art. We reserved the first entrance of the morning by calling from the U.S. about 5 days before our visit. The operator spoke perfect English and was very pleasant. It was easy and worked perfectly. The museum is small but packed with some of the most impressive art anywhere. We lingered for about 2 hours.
Good vacation start. Begin your cultural experience in this museum. It is entry on scheduled times so plan accordingly. Once done, stroll along Villa Borghese, which I call the Central Park of Rome.

AC in August! Seriously, incredible art. If you are a fan of Caravaggio or Bernini, just go. Some of the most famous Bernini sculptures are here. And the rooms themselves are gorgeous. Take the Dark Rome tour, the guide is great.

Stunning Artwork. If you're looking for statues with amazing detail then go here. The statues done by Bernini are amazing here. The Apollo and Daphne is stunning in beauty. The detail of the Rape of Proserpina is incredible. Haddes fingers on Persphone leg shows such strength it is amazing to see. A must see.
Lovely galleria. Charming gardens peaceful area. The museum itself is very good especially the part where you can see the famous Daphne and Apollo statue. The surrounding paths are great for cycling.

could not get in. Went all the way there in the heat and up the hill and arrived to find that they had sold of ticket for that day - it was 4 pm and saturday and the next available tickets were not until Tuesday - not sure how you can book tickets in advance but clearly is a must the park itself though is worth a visit

The building IS art and sculpture and paintings not to be missed. Galleria Borghese was one of the highlights of our recent visit to Rome. We had an audio guide which added more depth and interest to the sights in the gallery. The sculpture is exquisite. The paintings were also of great interest but sometimes the light in the museum caused a bit of a glare and detail could not be seen. I would like to go back to this gallery again - it is a beautiful structure and houses fabulous art. We did not pre book during the August holidays. There were only two of us and we were able to enter as soon as we arrived. Your tickets are time limited so you cannot take forever as you view the magnificent pieces. Definitely worth the time.

Beautiful sculptures. I really enjoyed seeing all the beautiful sculptures in this gallery. The building is set in a large park which was quiet and a real respite from the crowds and general noise of Rome. I felt very relaxed before I even entered the gallery. No bags or cameras are permitted inside the gallery.

Fantastic collection, bad service. It's a must see, but be careful: I got the ticket which was valid from 5:00 to 7:00, left my bag and camera in the storage and nobody warned me that the gallery would be closed exactly at 7:00 without any warning. The booking website says it's open until 7:30 but I returned from the garden at 7:15 and it was locked like Fort Knox. It means if you get in at 5:00, you don't have 2 hours, you have to leave 10-15 minutes earlier to get your stuff back. As I already mentioned, no one cared to warn me about this and my stuff got locked there until next morning, which was supposed for visiting Vatican museums. I had to go there next morning( BTW their flyer said that bus 119 goes there but actually it doesn't), lost a lot of precious time and because of that I had to pay €27.5 to skip the line at Vatican museum.P.S. Bernini is so fantastic, I almost forgave them ))))
Expected more.. We waited in a long hot line for tickets and security check.So we were expecting a wow factor. We were sorely disappointed.

Overrated and pretentious. OK, yeah, the art is fantastic--gotta give it that! However, you can only stay for two hours, which is not nearly enough; the signage (getting there and once inside) is minimal. For me, the best thing was that the cafe had fresh-squeezed juice. I was SO disappointed, especially for the price.

Disappointment.. Be careful when you go, booked the tickets online, printed confirmation and everything was ready. Took it along, we took the Metro to the Borghese, (around 15 min walk from the Metro station), got there 15 minutes early. We went to collect our tickets, had the FULL CONFORMATION email, passports, and bank cards ready for it, yet they told us it wasn't the full conformation. They refused to search for our booking, and refused to let us in even if we paid there and then. We were unable to go in, and we were both incredibly upset about it. We had planned so that was at the end of the day luckily, but still, we had hours to spare which were dedicated to that gallery that we were excited to see. Really upset, especially because of having to change metro half way, took a while to get there, didn't realise how far out of Rome it was!

Thoroughly recommended. I booked online a few weeks before our holiday and found the process very straight forward. We were booked into the 11am - 1pm slot, so we meandered leisurely through Villa Borghese which is a fantastic and fascinating park. We checked in. I had a copy of my email confirmation, which was satisfactory. You must check in any bags, cameras etc and the door staff reinforce this rule to the letter. There were quite a few people turned away at the door of the gallery and told to check in their bags. I am an art history student so had a bit of background knowledge to the sculptures and paintings, and as my husband and I like to stop and discuss what we're looking at, decided not to hire the audio guides. However, if you do not know about the exhibits, I would recommend getting the guides as the description panels are few and far between. The two hours were enough and it was lovely to walk through the rooms, taking our time and not be jostled by other visitors.

If you are an art fan - then go - but, if not - don't bother. We are not big huge art fans - but, this is one of the top museums in Rome and in the world, etc etc - so, we went. But, the way they handle it is just horrible. If you could just go and pay to get in - no big deal - but, they do this horrible thing that you have to buy tickets ahead of time - and then go wait in line to get them. We had to wait over 45 minutes in a line - in the very hot August sun - just to get in - and they had ONE person giving out tickets!! It was a horrible experience and just not worth it. If you are an art fan - then of course you do not want to miss this - but, the only way to go is a private tour - because then you get to skip the lines!!! Another tip - get there at least an hour before your scheduled time. Our time frame was from 11 am to 1 pm. We got there at 10:30 - and so did everyone else it seemed. We did not get in until after 11:15 am. And the place was so crowded - that we were in and out in about 45 minutes. But, i noticed as I was leaving - that the line was down dramatically at Noon. So, get there at least an hour before your scheduled time - and get your tickets and walk around the park for an hour and then you can just walk right in.

A hidden piece of history in Rome that is truly underestimated!. The only con to the Galleria was that we got there an hour before our reserved time and we could not get in any earlier than the allotted time. With that said, that was not that big of a deal! It was truly amazing to walk throughout the Galleria and explore each floor! I love that they have each room divided into rooms. As I have no background in such art history but have a great appreciation for it, I enjoyed looking at the way each art piece differed in relation to their era. We were able to experience a great moment as well as a blind man was allowed to run his hands over the Pauline Bonaparte-Borghese sculpture. It was phenomenal to picture this and imagine what ties he had in order to allow him to be able to finally sense the details placed into this art piece.

Badly organized, unfriendly staff. Yes the galleria has some great pieces of art. Yes it is worth visiting if you like painting. Having said that, I was really disappointed. First, I had to retrieve my ticket and I came across two old and bitter ladies who were stupid and rude. Then the museum in itself is so badly presented. You can find sometimes comments in English but they are boring and pedantic. You're strongly advised to take the audioguide because the written comments are just useless. All in all, I would say that it's not a priority if you just have a couple of days in Roma.

Easy to Book Reservation!. My review is on the reservation process only, we don't travel here until Oct. 2013. This is incredibly easy. I recommend going to RONINROME.COM to get detailed instructions. Click on Museums & Churches then select Galleria Borghese. Reservations = FREE, Call to make reservation if you plan on using ROMAPASS to enter. Also, I made my reservations for almost 2 months in advance!!!Call #011-39-063-2810They speak English in the prompts! Press #2Follow the prompts from there. Someone comes on speaking Italian, didn't have to wait but less than 2 minutes. SAY PARA INGELSE? She says YES! So Easy!!!She will ask you which museum you want to make a reservation for. You need to give the date you want. The time you want, they do it in time slots of 2 hours each starting at 9AM and ending at 5PM for last tour. BE EARLY BY 30 MINS! EX: for a 3PM tour arrive at 2:30 minimum.Last name, you will need to bring ID with you. Phone numberThey you have your reservation code.Easy peasy lemon squeezy! Thank you RONINROME

What an enjoyed morning.. We loved this museum, including our 15 year old son. We took advantage of the audio tour and it really made the day. Afterwards we leisurely strolled the gardens. One of our best outings in Rome.

A hidden cultural gem. We spent a lovely time in the Borghese park on hired bikes before visiting this lovely gallery. Make sure you book your ticket a day or two before you plan to visit or you may be disappointed. Our hotel sorted the booking for us.You are rewarded with a feast for art lovers eyes.

Less stressful alternative to other tourist sites.. In retrospect, one thing I liked about this place (in addition to the excellent art) is that it was a much easier experience than visiting other popular tourist sites. Entry is organised into two hour slots and this ensures that the place is not overfilled with visitors. Also, you are not allowed to take pictures inside. You can go here and really appreciate and absorb the experience without having people falling over themselves to take millions of pictures. Compare this to my experience at the Vatican museum which was horrendous. Overcrowded with thousands of tourists, you can barely move one way or the other and it is basically unbearable when combined with the heat factor. To ensure at least one stress-free tourist experience where you can really enjoy ancient Roman art then this place is a must.

very nice. full of amazing sculptures and paintings, some are famous, and the rooms are decorated with more amazing decorations , besides the building is settled inside a very large area of very nice gardens filled with many beautiful fountains.

çould not get in. Once I finally found it it was closing for work for 2 hrs, and was sold out and just gave up. I tried to find out information on the gallerie but couldn't find anything. disappointed.

Book in Advance!. I strongly recommend that you make your reservation in advance of your visit in order not to be disappointed. The place is well worth it even if you are not into art - the fantastic Bernini sculptures are breathtaking! Reserve some time to stroll around the Villa Borghese (the gardens).

Disappointing and Chaotic. After looking forward very much to our visit, and buying our tickets on line in advance, we were hugely disappointed by our experience there. Each visit is scheduled for 2 hours. We had tickets from 13.00 to 15.00. So, imagine or surprise when we arrived to find a huge queue that took 30 minutes to clear and which meant we were left with only 1½ hours. The organisation was absolutely dreadful. It was by chance we discovered there was a second counter where tickets could be purchased (even though a notice told us this was not possible). Our disappointment continued because, once inside, there were no information panels identifying the various sculptures and busts of Emperors. In fact, there was a paucity of information for most of the exhibits, apart form the paintings, where a small panel identifying the artist and the work was set adjacent to each painting. Had we known this was the case, we would have rented an audio guide. But there was no sign saying that this was essential (which it clearly was).The result was that the youngest member of our group, aged 9, felt that the experience was boring, although she liked some of the sculptures. She found that not knowing who the busts represented was very frustrating, as she is learning about ancient Rome at School.If you are considering a visit to this museum, my advice is to (a) book online for tickets. Make sure you check one or two sites. The English speaking site we found wanted to charge more than double what we paid by booking through an Italian site (http://www.ticketone.it/)(b) get there about 30 minutes before the due time slot, as you should anticipate both queues and slow progress(c) take an audio guide.

A Highlight of our Trip to Rome!. My husband and I were traveling with our teenage grandson who was dubious about spending half a day in an art gallery. In the end, he raved about the Galleria Borghese - both the paintings and the sculpture. The audioguide was very helpful, especially considering that visitors are strictly restricted to two hours. We happened to enter the painting areas first, and that worked out well because we missed the crowds since most people headed for the sculptures first. The Benini sculptures are absolutely exquisite!! Reading about them first enhances appreciation. IMPORTANT: make reservations online ahead of time! The Borghese sells out. Only disadvantage - our grandson would have had a lower rate because of his age.
A bit of fun and a bit of culture. The sculptures, paintings and the building itself were amazing. The fun bit was hiring a four wheeler bike to see the grounds and some amazing views over the city.

Bernini at its best!. I have visited a few museums in Europe and, in particular in Rome, and I think galleria Borghese counts with some of the best sculptures I've ever seen in my life. The Bernini's pieces look as if they were made of flesh and were alive. And I thought that Apolo and Daphne was not my style when I saw the picture in my history book. If you come to Rome this is a must see, as much or even more than the Vatican museum.

The BEST gallery!!!. This was the best gallery we went to on our 4 week holiday in Paris and Italy. One of the reasons (other than the amazing sculptures and paintings) is they control the # of visitors so not crowded. For at least 5 minutes we were the only people looking at Bernini's David.The gallery can be easily done in less than 2 hours. Well worth it! Make sure to make a reservation.

Amazing sculpture. This is one of the best art experiences in Rome and takes you out of the hustle and bustle of the city for a couple of hours. The sculpture is some of the best you will see (Apollo and Daphne!!!). The audio tour is expensive but pretty good. Book ahead. 2 hours is plenty of time to get through it, don't feel stressed by the time constraint. Sumptuous experience - each room is filled with art treasure! Enjoy.

Be prepare to walk quite a bit if you take the metro.. Great art gallery. Lots to see. You might want to rent an audio guide for 5.00 Euro. Mediocre air conditioning.Things to be aware of:1. Book online or else you could be screwed as tickets sold out fast. Call on skype to book if you have Roma Pass.2. Even though you book online, you still have to line up on the main floor to pay and get tickets (11.00 Euro). Although typically you could still enter even if you got there after your booking time.3. You will need to check in all your backpacks and large purses.4. IF YOU TAKE THE METRO, BE PREPARE TO WALK AT LEAST 30 MINS ONE WAY.5. Alternatively, you could probably take bus 910 from Termini.6. Bring a big bottle of water, or else you will have to buy in the park at 2.50 Euro for 500ml (pricey!)7. The entrance to the gallery is on the second floor.

Amazing. Galleria Borghese is quite the walk away from the bus stop so you can rent bicycles if you don't want to walk the whole way, but they would also let you explore the gardens faster, which are enormous!The gallery is beautiful and has some amazing historical paintings and sculptures. You do have to call in advance to book a reservation though, otherwise it is unlikely you'll get to go in the same day you show up.

Meet the rudest person in Rome. If you want to go to the gallery then make sure you book on line or by phone. My experience initially with the ticket staff was undoubtedly the poorest I have ever experienced. I went to the gallery on a Tuesday to book for the Thursday. Upon arrival I noticed a sign that said Wednesday was full so I asked about any time slots available for Thursday. I was asked abruptly if I had rung, to which I replied 'no'. I was then told to 'get out' and go back to my hotel and ring for a reservation and then return. In attempting to explain that the hotel was someway away and that I did not have a cell phone on me all I was met with was a barrage of loud 'get out, get out' and not pleasant hand gesture waving. Without a doubt this woman is the rudest person in Rome that I met! I did book by phone and went on the Saturday. While lining up the young man on the ticket desk informed the people in front of me that despite having no tickets for 3pm if they waited around there was the possibility that they could still get in. I would love to know why I was treated so poorly compared to these other people.Although the gallery is well rated the paintings are not a patch on the quality of the sculptures which were of the highest standard. The audio guide at 5 euro only covers relatively few of the paintings but tends to describe the sculptures in great depth. If you are looking for paintings the Vatican Museum has a better array and quality along with many of the churches. What makes the value of the trip are the quality statues. You are not permitted to take photographs but the shop has some very good and comparatively inexpensive books including a guide book which compensate for the inability to take photos. The gallery is very good, without being exceptional, especially the paintings when compared with what was available in Paris. The opportunity to relax in the park area was great and the rickshaw bikes (12 euro for a three seater for an hour) were a great way to tour around and have family fun. The rickshaw bikes do not require as much energy as you might think and once moving are more difficult to slow down than anything. Also available were segway, golf carts and bikes. Given the size of the park and the lack of time that people generally have it is a great way to explore the area.

A Religious Experience. Do not miss this lovely collection of art. The Bernini statuary alone is worth the price of admission. Bernini's Apollo chasing Daphne is breathtaking. This villa was the home of Pauline Bonaparte, sister of Napoleon who commissioned Canova to create a statue of herself reclining nude on a couch and it is still the centerpiece of one of the rooms in the villa.This was our second trip to Rome and this was the only site we wanted to revisit. You must book a reservation well in advance since space is limited.

Full day of beauty. In all our visits to Rome, this was our first time and I am sorry that I had not taken the opportunity to do so before. Each room is more jaw-dropping than the other. Tickets are for a two hour viewing and lines can be long. Please allow at least four hours for this visit as you will want to walk the grounds, especially during the hot summer months where one can meander in the "central park" of Rome.
fab.. Lovely air conditioning. An interesting gallery which cannot be missed on your visit to Rome. Buy a Roma pass to avoid queues.

Book your tour in advance. We booked our tour in advance. Since we planned to use the Roma Pass, we had to have someone call the reservation line directly rather than book on the website. Since we didn't call for ourselves, we didn't think to specify we wanted a reservation for the English speaking tour. As it turned out our reservation was on an Italian tour day; however, it wasn't a big deal. We just rented a few audio guides for 5 or 6 euros. I was thankful for our advance reservations because the Borghese Gallery was fully booked for our day as well as several days thereafter. Also, the grounds themselves are as beautiful as the artwork inside. We took a little mini-train ride tour for about 3 or 4 euros each. Bikes, for 1-4 people, rent by the hour as well. If we had allowed more time at this wonderful site, we would have toured the grounds on bikes.
Hassle of a reservation worth it.. You have to reserve in advance but the statues are worth it and the reservations keep it from being crowded. A highlight of our trip to Rome.

Go for the Love of Art but be Prepared .... The Borghese Gallery holds some truly stunning masterworks of art and for that reason, it is well worth the visit. Visitors should order tickets well in advance or risk being disappointed on arriving at the gallery. On the plus side, the strict entry quota of visitors allows for an easy flow through the gallery and the lack of crowding permits greater contemplation and appreciation of the masterpieces. It’s a good idea to psyche yourself up too because waiting to get into the gallery can be frustrating. Show up early because signage is bad, line-ups for the audioguide and purse/bag deposit (there are strict rules for this) can be a problem – mostly due to the staff ignoring you … oh yes, suffice it to say that the staff are among the rudest museum staff you will likely ever encounter. I made the mistake of asking a female “guard” the number of the room we were in – she then grabbed my audioguide and shook the little map attached to it while yelling at me to “LOOK at the map”. I was so stunned, I laughed. But it really wasn’t funny...

Best of Rome but buy you tickets in advance.. This is art perfection. The setting the building and the art, not to mention how well it is laid out. This is absolutely some of the best art anywhere in the world and not to be missed. But as say if you don't get tickets ahead of time you may not be able to in. The Bernini sculptures here are just mind blowing.
Borghese is art lover's mecca. The paintings and sculptures (lots of them, so we had a guide tour us through so we would concentrate on the highlights).This is a must go museum when in Rome!!!

Perfect First Place to Visit. When arriving jetlagged from the US, it's hard to decide what to do with that first afternoon. We booked tickets at the Galleria, and then walked through the gardens to get there. The sculptures were a stunning and perfect introduction to Rome.

What a cool start to our visit. Extraordinary works of art, almost overwhelming, you could really spend a month touring this museum, but you only get two hours. This was our first museum in Rome, and the audio guide added quite a bit to helping us work our way through it. We prebooked, and then got there early. One of the more peaceful sites we visited during the busy season in Rome, which we appreciated.

Impressive museum. One great piece of art after another, and in the Palazzo of the Borghese so each room is also covered in artwork as well. I was particularly struck by Bernini's first sculpture that he did I think at the age of 12. Try not to feel to inadequate afterwards.

outrageous collection!!. I was in awe and overwhelmed. There's so much in every single room. It's packed from floor to ceiling. I wish there's a step ladder in the middle of the room so I could get a closer look at paintings on the ceiling and the paintings that were hung close to the top. They can be quite tough to see with the glare. Remember to book in advance (like at least 2 days in advance) and leave a bit of time to walk around the beautiful park.

wonderful museum. As opposed to the Vatican Museum which was overfilled with visitors, this museum limits how many people are admitted at the same time, which allows the visitor to see a wonderful collection of art, furnishings and an amazing mansion. Definitely, a do not miss site to see on your trip to Rome.

Stellar art collection and museum; no air conditioning :-). The Villa Boghese is simply one of the magical places in Rome. Reserve tickets online, but still be prepared for long lines. And if it's summer, be prepared to sweat while you are waiting in a massive crowd. The museum itself was for me a cross between the formality of a major museum like the New York MET and the more intimate collection of an astute collector like the Gardner Museum in Boston. The grandeur of the place is undeniable. Your feet feel it walking across all those amazing marble floors. But it also has the intimacy of personal preference. Borghese especially enjoyed Bernini and commissioned many fine sculptures—one set devoted to an entire room. Bernini's David is an absolutely incredible dramatic foil to Michelangelo's calm masterpiece in Florence. Borghese also collected works of Caravagio and a huge number of sculptures from antiquity. Rome's history is always overwhelming. It is so in this gallery, but you cover a lot in two floors! Also, the gardens surrounding the Villa make a very peaceful break from the traffic noise of Rome.

Amazing collection of sculptures.. You must order your tickets to this museum a few days in advance if you come during tourist season as they only allow so many in the museum at any one time. The museum hose may sculptures and paintings but for me it was the sculptures that really stood out.The museum is set in the large Borghese Park and if you need a relaxing break away from the heavy trafficked areas give yourself some time to enjoy the park as well.

check it out. this is a nice gallery in Villa Borghese with lots of sculptures and gallery of paintings. you must buy your tickets before and get a reservation and show up at the time of your reservation. our 6 year old liked it and it was pretty impressive. the building is a rococo style inside (I think, everything in Rome is bleeding together) it was cool to see the sculptures. it has the David by Bernini, the one that looks angry and he is about to sling a rock. I think that is better than the David in Florence. its cool to see it up close, the sculptures are pretty amazing. the paintings are cool too. been to rome a few times and this was my first to go here and glad I did. before I never really had the desire, but now that I have gone I would recommend going to this.

Go for the sculptures, stay for the sights.. The Galleria is a must on any art lover's list. The ground floor is full of some of the most spectacular sculptures. Take your time in these galleries as this is where you get you money's worth. It's a shame they don't have the comprehensive books in English nor that they have more prints to choose from in the bookshop. You must reserve your time slot, so make sure you do this in advance. You may find, as with those I saw that you will be turned away.Once you have seen the Gallaria, take your time through the grounds. There's plenty to see and do. You can even rent bikes and golf carts to get around.

The best kept secret in Rome - Villa Borghese. The first thing you must do after ordering your plane tickets is to purchase tickets for the Villa Borghese. There is at least a two day waiting period to get tickets, as many experienced travelersget their tickets early. The Villa is located in the park that bears it's name. There are wonderful gardens surrounding the Villa. The collection of art and furnishing is incredible. Each room is more beautiful then the previous one. The ceiling paintings and murals are captivating. there is so much to see and take in. The gift shop is outstanding as it has great gifts for all ages. Every time, I visit Rome I make it a point of visiting this extraordinary place.

Masterpiece. one the biggest chest full of masterpiece. Inside you can find opera of Gian Lorenzo Bernini like "Apollo e Dafne", " Il ratto di Proserpina"; Caravaggio, Raffaello Sanzio, Tiziano and probably the most famous opera of the museum : "Paolina Borghese" by Canova. Absolutely amazing......................

Bernini, Canova and more. Galleria Borghese is absolutely not to be missed while in Rome. I could spend hours just admiring the Bernini's marble masterpiece Apollo and Daphne and although I live in Rome, whenever I can I like to go and visit Galleria Borghese. One important suggestion: make a reservation before going (it can be done online) as Galleria is often very crowded.

It is one of the best places to be in Rome. It is a very special place where one can have a break from the rush of the city.. to enjoy a shadow from the trees in a park and then to see the marvellous collection of art in a Gallery. I chuffed that place to bits!

Bernini sculptures. I've lived here in Rome for years and only finally got to the Borghese Gallery recently. Can't wait to bring friends there this Fall. I always thought of Bernini for columns but I remained enchanted with his sculptures in the Gallery. The only thing is knowing that you have to reserve entrance tickets in advance.

Go for the Bernini sculptures. If you were suitably impressed by the magnificence of David in Florence but feel nothing else can live up to that then come to Villa Borghese in Rome and gaze open mouthed at two Bernini sculptures: the awesome Apollo and Daphne and the fascinating Pluto and Proserpina.

Prebook your tickets, take the taxi & hire a guided tour inside hte museum. We prebooked the tickets online for the Sunday 9 AM slot (28/Jul) and took a taxi from Ottavisno to avoid last minute direction issues.
