Collected tickets about 30 minutes before the slot - they open only at 8.30 AM and you need to carry a printout of the booking with id proof. No need for Roma pass here for the kids. We deposited bags at the counter after collecting the tickets and it was quite safe to leave even my new Nikon DSLR. We hired the guided tour insted of the audio tour and we had an excellent guide from the museum - Isabella (Euro 6.50 for adult). She took us though the museum giving us the best experience ever and even engaged the kids in some great conversation. OVerall we paid less than 50 euros and had a great time in the Villa Borghese after the museum trip for about 2-3 hours and let the kids run in the park. The cafeteria in the museum is good to get some nice simple food. Great experience overall !!

LOVED THIS. It takes 2 hours- buy your tickets with a fixed time ahead online. This means minimal line waiting when you get there. You can't take in cameras or large bags they'll make you check them. Every room is very ornate and filled to the brim with incredible art. The building itself is art. Also leave time to stroll the Borghese gardens while you're at it. This is like Rome's Central Park. Locals go running here and it is really beautiful.

Absolutely must visit!!. Unless you have not seen the standard "must see" sights of Rome and feel you will never return, this is an absolutely must see visit. It is stunning. The fact also that admission is by ticket only and numbers are strictly limited, means that it is relaxing and you can see everything in comfort. Do ensure that you have prebooked your tickets before visiting particularly in high season (not expensive - adult tickets are 9 euro plus 2 prebooking fee, children are free plus the 2 euro booking fee). We visited on a Sunday with our prebooked tickets and it was sold out until the following Tuesday. The sculptures are amazing but do pay the extra 5 euro for an audio guide as it gives so much more insight and information into what you are looking at and what you should look for. Afterwards, take some time out to stroll through the grounds including the boating lake where, if you like, you can rent a boat for 3 euro per person for 20 minutes
Grand and special. Superb art collection in a palazzo with magnificent gardens. Bellini's sculptures are not to be missed.
Fantastic!. Get online and snag your tickets early. This amazing museum sells out weeks ahead. It is worth whatever it takes to get there to see it.
Must see with a guide. Liked Julia with Walks of Italy. We would not have appreciated the art in the gallery without Julia's trained eye and enjoyable ability to tell the story.

A MUST!!! - Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is simply mesmerizing. I love art, but I've never been a huge fan of sculptures. Boy am I glad I stopped at the Borghese Gallery on this trip! Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is the most stunning piece of sculpture I have ever seen! The attention to form, intricate details, and the viewer's perception as they walk around the sculpture is simply astounding. Apparently, the leaves on this sculpture are so thin they chime like crystal!! I am actually sad just thinking that I most likely will never come across another piece of sculpture as beautiful and mesmerizing as this one ever again. Pictures do not do it justice.The rest of the collection is also magnificent! Book your tickets online as they will be sold out if you just show up at the ticket booth. You have 2 hours to walk around the museum. Arrive 20 minutes in advance to drop off your bags and rent an audioguide! The guide is 90 minutes long. I spent the remaining 30 minutes admiring Apollo and Daphne.

Fantastic!. This is a beautiful sculpture and art gallery with Bernini's David and 2 other famous Bernini sculptures - the Rape of Proserpina and Apollo and Daphne. Definitely worth the trek if you are a fan of Bernini or just want to see some amazing sculpture! The surrounding Villa Borghese around the Gallery is also a beautiful green space for picnics.

Stunning. I would highly recommend a visit to the Borghese. Planning is essential as it is by reservation only. This may be a nuisance however it does manage he crowd level. Rome is a busy tourism city no matter where (or it seems when) you visit.The Borghese is chock full of incredibly beautiful sculpture. The frescoes on the walls and ceilings are a sight to behold. My favorite was the Bacchus ceiling. The gallery has important paintings from distinguished artists. The villa was built to house these sumptuous treasures.Take the time to read the information cards in each room if not using the audio tour. These are a wealth of information.And the big treat is the Villa is located in the Borghese Gardens which is a wonderful park used by tourists and locals.
enjoyable. We loved this gallery, stunning statues, paintings. the line was about 45 min. with a ticket. I would go there again .

The best art experience in Rome. We had booked the Galleria for Saturday, after visiting the Vatican Museums on the Friday. the Vatican was slightly disappointing; not the art itself, but rather the crowds (pushing you towards the Sistine Chapel like you're on a conveyor belt). So this was a refreshing change. They only allow 300 people in at any one time, so it wasn't at all crowded, and there was plenty of space to really appreciate the art. No one review can highlight the masterpieces in this gallery, and I'm not going to try. There's just too many to list. Most reviewers will highlight the amazing sculptures, particularly Bernini's works: Apollo and Daphne (the most amazing sculpture I've ever seen), David, and Pluto & Prosperina to name but three out of hundreds of masterpieces. The paintings are just as amazing, however, and I enjoyed these just as much. Bassano's Last Supper, Carravagio's David with the Head of Goliath, and Raphael's Deposition particularly stayed in my head, although again there are hundreds of paintings that warrant as much of a mention. And, don't forget the artwork of the rooms themselves - they could sell tickets to see the empty rooms alone and I'd still pay. You absolutely need to book in advance, particularly in Summer. When we arrived on a Saturday, tickets were sold out until Tuesday. (And when we booked a month in advance, we had tickets 89-90 out of 300!). This may seem silly at first, but it's fantastic when you do get in, because it's never overcrowded and you have plenty of space and time to enjoy the art (we found 2 hours to be sufficient, although I'm sure some art fans could spend all day in this treasure trove). And, do be aware, you have to check pretty much everything (bags, cameras, phones...) at the door, so arrive in plenty of time. And afterwards, have a stroll in the Villa Borghese - the most beautiful park in Rome. Quiet, serene, and totally withdrawn from the bustle of the city, whilst still retaining a distinctive Roman feel.An absolute highlight of my trip, and a must for any serious art lover.
Masterpieces. I have never seen so many Carravagio paintings or Bernin sculptures in one location. If you are even slightly interested in such masterpieces, it is a must-see
Borghese Beauty. Another gem in Rome where one can admire the works of Caravaggio and Bernini amongst other great artists.

Oh, Carravaggio. The Borghese tour was truly the highlight of our time in Rome. Unfortunately, you only get to stay two hours which really isn't enough time. We had an excellent guide from Context Travel. I highly recommend a guide because there are so many wonderful stories associated with the art.

Amazing. Not only the museum is a lifetime experience with its fine art collection enriched by Bernini, Caravaggio, Leonardo da Vinci, Raffaello, Rubens, Tiziano and others but it is located in one of the most beautiful green areas in Rome: the Villa Borghese - a great place to stroll leisurely, gym, rent a bike or just connect to nature just a few steps from Via Veneto or an underground walk from Piazza di Spagna. The only glitch is that you may need to store large bags in a locker before entering the museum, which can be tricky if you plan other activities that require carry-on stuff

Unbelievable beauty gathered in one place. I heard about the Borghese Gallery on a blog and booked the tickets (dont forget) well in advance. It is an amazing experience with so much fine art in a compact space that entertains and enthralls even the least likely 'artiste'. The sculptures of Bernini in particular are so very beautiful and along wtih the art works on the first floor provide a layman's education to the arts. If your passion is the arts then you need no convincing! One of our highlights of Rome.

Excellent Bernini and other sculptures.. This was a scheduled stop on our Rome itinerary. You are only allowed two hours, which made us move a little faster than we normally might have. It was enough time to see it all, but the anxiety that we might miss some actually made us rush a little more than was actually needed.

Best Museum. Loved the variety and quality of various artwork displayed. Excellent audio guide. Lovely location, spent all day biking through the park, dining, enjoying the museum and the clean, very safe park. I dreamed I was a princess - and this was my castle!

Not To Be Missed. I always come back to the Galleria Borghese when I visit Rome. To me, the art is more exquisite even than that in the Vatican. I prefer Bernini's David to Michelangelo's -- the determined expression and pose that catches David in action are not to be missed. And of course Bernini's Daphne and Apollo is the most amazing sculpture. It must be seen 360 degrees. It's a sculpture in motion, from the wind in Daphne's hair to the form of each leaf. Our grandchildren surprised us by being fascinated by the quality of the ceiling frescoes as well as the sculpture and ancient Roman mosaics. Visitors may not notice that the art is arranged thematically. The David, for example, is in a room with many sculptures depicting the labors of Hercules.We did not feel like cattle in a stampede. A fixed number of visitors are allowed in every two hours (by reservation), nothing like the crowds at the Vatican. When we visited in June, the opening time was delayed because of a union meeting. People with reservations for 9:00 and 11:00 waited until noon to enter, but we still didn't feel crushed in a crowd. Yes, you must reserve in advance (easy online), and there is no mercy if you fail to show up for your reserved time or try to change your reservation. When the museum closed unexpectedly, however, there were no apologies for us. They did, however, let everyone in regardless of their reserved time. After visiting the museum, enjoy walking around the gardens, or make your way down Via Veneto to the "Bones Church," the Capuchin Crypt. It is very different and well worth a visit.

A great museum in a very nice park. We enjoyed the museum. You have to make reservations in advance and I would suggest going at 9:00 when it opens. Visitors get a two-hour window to wander. This may have been because it was summer and there are hordes of tourists.There was a bit of a back-up because of the numbers of people showing up at the same time.There are some great pieces of art by Bernini and Caravaggio, for instance. Unfortunately, the one Caravaggio I wanted to see was on loan to the Hermitage. Be aware that there is a long spiral staircase to climb. Anyone with a health issue may have to ask for the elevator to be unlocked. I have bad knees and could not summon the elevator to go down.The park is such a nice place to walk, picnic, buy a gelato or rent a two-person bicycle. There is also a zoo in the park area.

reserve tickets for the Galleria Borghese. The future sculptor Bernini sketched Michelangelo's work for years. One of the statues that resulted when he matured is in this Galleria: "Apollo and Daphne" has to be seen to be believed. It has twigs with leaves growing out of Daphne's fingers. This is there amid other amazing masterpieces. A short Taxi ride from the Vatican.Online booking -day and hour- needed, tickitaly, borghesitickets, or your agent..

A Must See. It took us several times to Rome to finally make it to the Borghese Gallery, and we're so glad we finally got there. We never went before because we were never organized enough to call ahead to make reservations, but this time, as soon as we got to Rome, we asked our concierge to make a reservation for us. He warned us that it is usually booked for a week but he would see what he could do. He was able to get us in in the next two days. When we got there, a sign said that it was sold out for several days and several people left disappointed. I would suggest you have your hotel call like we did; they seem to have an "in" with reservations. The art was fabulous. Afterwards we made the short walk to the Rome Zoo, which was also very enjoyable.

Great art in a great setting. You'll need to reserve a date and time in advance, but this gem of a museum is really worth it. Works by Bernini and Caravaggio by themselves justify going, and there's lots more in a beautiful building surrounded by a large, wonderful park.

Fabulous home with spectacular art. This mansion was built in 1615 and has been gloriously restored to house amazing art. My favorites were 1) Canova’s Venus Victrix (rumored to be Bonaparte’s sister) look at the sculpted cushion and pose, 2) Bernini’s David detailed angst in face and his twisted body, 3) Bernini’s famed Apollo and Daphne with lifelike facial features and a feeling of movement from the couple (as well as surprisingly thinly sculpted leaves), and 4) Bernini’s Rape of Prosperena with his hand realistically grasping her thigh. I loved having the audioguide for the sculptures. Be sure to keep moving to the upstairs picture galleries as well; art lovers WILL run out of time and be escorted the door after 2 hours.
Best Museum. This is a must see! Dynamite history and artifacts, and take some extra time to enjoy the wonderful gardens surrounding the museum.

Wow! Small art museum with big experience of quality. Well worth a visit. Great art very professionally displayed. The garden in back is worth a relaxing visit as well. This is a great visit for anyone having an interest in sculpture. Reservations are required and should be made at least a few weeks ahead of visit. A check of the website would provide additional information.

Not helpful staff, needs reservation over the phone. We had these Roma passes to visit Colosseum and Galleria Borghese. So we went to the Borghese gallery two times and couldn't visit the gallery because the staff didn't tell us that we had to make a reservation on the telephone at first.

Hidden gem for art lovers. Getting a reservation to visit Galleria Borghese was a nice way to begin our trip in Rome. Tucked away in the lovely Borghese Gardens, this museum features a great collection of paintings and sculptures for the art lover. If you are a fan of Bernini's work, you must visit, even if it's just to see his "Apollo and Diane." You get a two-hour block of time with your reservation, which is ample time to see all of the artwork. It's not overly crowded, which is a nice contrast to most of the popular galleries. There is a cafe near the entrance as well. I recommend that anyone who appreciates art enjoy this hidden gem.

Beautiful!. This is a very small museum but very beautiful. You have to make reservations to get in but I thought that was very wise, especially after going to places like the Vatican. You don't feel crowded going through. I think you book a three hour reservation which is plenty of time to leisurely see all you want to see.

Not to be missed!. Besides the Vatican, if there is only one other place to visit, I would choose the Borghese! The Bernini sculptures are exquisite! Rent the audio presentation to take you through the different floors. Buy your ticket in advance to avoid disappointment. Very best use of 2 hours!

Luxuriant Baroque. The Galleria Borghese is not a very large gallery but as it was the home of Scipione Borghese it represents an almost unique opportunity to see a Baroque collection in the house that is was originally kept in. The building itself is stunning. The reason I wanted to visit the Borghese was to see the paintings by Caravaggio. There are 5 works by Caravaggio in the gallery. St Jerome is stunning. I am not so impressed by how they are hung. The larger works are high up, I presume because they have so many works and so little space. But they are still magic.The Bernini collection is impressive. The Rape of Proserpina (1622) is stunning. The skill of Bernini is displayed in how the hands of Pluto press in on the marble flesh of the goddess. The dog Cerberus is incredible, with one head turned away, seemingly looking out the window on the modern Rome outside.I booked and paid for tickets online. It is the only way to get into the gallery. You line up in the underground chamber of the building to collect your tickets from a booking number. You then get two hours to see the entire collection. It is not too difficult, but the feeling of the gallery is a bit overwhelming as the art collected here is rich, intricate, luxuriant.I would totally recommend the Galleria Borghese if you are interested in European art, very rich (dead) cardinals or vast houses. The park around the house is also very good.

RESERVATIONS NEEDED.. Sold out, needed reservations. I checked their website the day before and no where did I see that reservations are mandatory. Shame...so many people were shocked and disappointed.

A- for the artworks, C- for the overall visitor experience, D- for accessibility. The artwork is fabulous. Roman sculpture on the ground floor, Renaissance and slightly later paintings one flight up. The guide who showed us around Rome yesterday said it's probably the 3rd most important collection in Rome, after the Vatican and the Capitoline, and I wouldn't disagree with him.But a museum isn't just the paintings. It's also getting in and out, getting around the building, and actually seeing the paintings. Especially for someone with limited mobility, this isn't a pleasant visitor experience.First, they sell tickets with an entry time and two hours to see the collection. This means you're always traveling with a bulge of people. Instead of people walking up at random times and entering as they arrive, you have this rush every two hours. You queue up to get your tickets, and you queue up to check your bags. While they limit admissions, it's a pretty small, cramped facility and there are always too many people crowding around, especially the artworks that are "numbered" items on the video tours.For a person with limited mobility, it's a little bit like they've never seen a disabled person before. There is an elevator for the disabled -- sort of. You're going to climb stairs no matter what, and it's not always easy to find someone to operate the elevator. If you have a person with limited mobility with you, count on spending at least 20 minutes of your two hours looking for a staff member to operate the elevator for you or watching elevators go up and down past your floor.Also, it's a tiny elevator. The people at the entrance said that the person could ride but the wheelchair wouldn't fit. REALLY? Are you kidding? What's the point of putting in an elevator if the wheelchair won't fit? The person who took us from the ground floor (sculpture) to the first floor (picture gallery) made the wheelchair fit, but then couldn't get it out when the elevator arrived, with the result that my wife had to climb out of the elevator over the wheelchair. On our exit, the person who brought us down on the elevator helpfully told us we could go out the rear exit and avoid the stairs but unhelpfully didn't tell us how to get around to the front of the building or warn us it was a gravel walk-way.The lack of staff in the galleries was weird. Like I said, it was an adventure every time we wanted to go to a different floor to find someone. They make the biggest deal of any museum I've ever been in of making you check EVERYTHING at the door, but then during the visit I saw at least a dozen people pulling out their point and shoots or smart phones to take a photograph -- and nobody to say cut it out. Museums that won't allow photographs bug me, but the ones where I'm obeying the rules and nobody else is are really infuriating.The artwork is great but it's really kind of a cattle car. And if you have the booking for the last entry (5 pm), do your shopping at the museum shop first. The place is closed up tight when you leave. I wasn't impressed.

Better late than never. Got lost walking here from Santa Maria della Valle for a 9am appointment and arrived 30 minutes late. Despite warnings to the contrary, we were graciously let into a relatively uncrowded museum. The Bernini sculptures lived up to reputation and 90 minutes was plenty of time to see everything.A highlight after leaving the museum into the park, the crickets were accompanied by an excellent accordion playing Vivaldi and Bach.

Great Galleria. Make reservations, they are required and limits overcrowding. The artwork and sculptures are wonderful. I loved the fact that we had time to enjoy the artwork without being pushed and shoved thru the gallery by crowds. The gallery sets in the park which I really enjoyed also. Very nice walk to Piazza Navona.

My new favourite museun in the world!. I heard a lot of compliment and did sone research before I go and I know this is a relatively small museum of art. At first sight when I arrived I thought the place is tiny and worried that I would finish everything within a short time but I went all the way to here! But I was wrong, the two hours time slot is just right and I can easily spend another hour inside it just to admire the collection. It was originally a private collection of the Borghese family. So imagine, some one with great taste and lot of money had already selected everything for you. I would really say that every single piece inside the museum is a treasure and a masterpiece. Great pieces from Bernini, Raphael, Caravaggio and many more. I really enjoyed the audio guide as well. It told us good details and histories of the great works and the Borghese family as well. Definitely worth every penny.With the limited number of tickets the gallery is not crowded at all and I could really enjoy the art with a good ambiance. It was like touring inside a private home of a noble.(well in some sense this is true!)The surrounding gardens are nice as well but I didn't have time to stay long.If I am a local I probably would want to come here every weekend!If you are choosing between a few smaller museum in Rome, I would definitely recommend this one on top of the list.Do remember to book tickets in advance as I saw people who didn't book ticket prior to coming to the museum and got back empty handed.

Oh, the Opulance!. We found the best thing to do when visiting Rome was to pre book all tours. However, even this does not guarantee a smooth experience. Nothing can take away from the marvel and grandeur of the Galleria and Villa Borghese, and its gardens. The entry, however, even with pre booked tickets, is a nightmare. The queue is haphazard and disorganized, all bags must be surrendered, and the lobby before the ticketed time entrance is pandemonium. The museum, though, makes up for this unpleasantry pre-tour. The art work, like many of Europe's museums, is an up close and personal experience.

Cannot miss it.. The art it contains and the whole Borghese story, are not to be missed. Get tickets as it is constantly sold out. Allow about an hour to see it. Late in the day it was not crazy busy.

Masterpieces abound, but only if you have a reservation.. The Galleria Borghese is situated in the Villa Borghese, north of the Spanish Steps. We visited here our first day in Rome. It's pretty far into the park, but just follow the signs and it's a straight shot. The Galleria Borghese houses some spectacular sculptures and paintings. If you want to feel less crowded, start with the pinacoteca (painting gallery) and then go back downstairs to the sculptures (thanks Rick Steves!). Don't miss Caravaggio's paintings! Plus, it's impossible to miss the famous Canova and Bernini sculptures, as they are the centerpieces of their rooms. Get a guidebook or audio tour because nothing is labeled. Keep in mind, there is a strict 2 hour time limit. We only needed a bit more than an hour, so this wasn't an issue for us. You must check all bags and cameras in the lobby. Bad bathrooms.Please note that a reservation in the high season is required! Having read guidebooks, we knew to make a reservation and asked our apartment proprietor to call for us (and he was kind enough to do so). It's free to call (+39 06 32810) and there is an English speaking option. Or, for an extra fee, you can book online (http://www.tosc.it). The base price of the ticket is 13 Euro. You must show up about 30 minutes in advance for your reservation, or they may release your tickets to people waiting on "stand by." For this very reason, we called in our reservation so we didn't have to pay in advance.

Probably the best museum in Rome. We were walking to the Borghese Gardens with little hope of actually getting a ticket to the Galleria Borghese. We asked directions of a distinguished Roman fellow (they are such nice people) and he told us we really MUST visit the Galleria Borghese. We didn't think we had a shot, but by chance we scored two tickets. We cancelled another afternoon tour to do this one. It's a museum folks, with great paintings, great décor (ceilings, tromp l'oeil, etc.), many sculptures from Roman times, and great renaissance sculpture and paintings, including more wonderful sculptures by Bernini that I have ever seen. If you don't know his work....please see it. He and Michelangelo were equals as sculptors in my book. His work here ranks with the pieta and the David. So, if you're into art museums, you have to see this one. If you aren't....well, you get it.

A must-see!. This gallery has a fantastic collection of Renaissance art - the remarkable Bernini statues were my favourite. The audio guide highlights selected pieces and is worth the cost. Be sure to book in advance, as the number of visitors is capped at 360 per time slot. You must be on time for your scheduled time slot. The cafe inside is also very good and reasonably priced.

Art overload. If there is one piece of advice I could give it is to use a guide, not the taped tour. A good guide will make your tour throughout this villa a great experience. You can not possibly absorb all the visual stimuli coming at you without the assistance of someone else. This villa though is well worth the visit for the lovers of the arts.

Scultures Worth the Visit. Reservations required for this museum, but it is worth the extra effort to be able to see the Bernini and Canova sculptures in the Villa for which they were commissioned. The Villa is situated in a beautiful park.
Must see in Rome!. Bernini's sculptures are incredible. They are a memory that will last a life time. You can't come to Rome and NOT see them!
Best villa we saw. Very quiet when we were there, which was a nice change from crowded churches etc. beautiful house and garden.

A bit boring and VERY out of the way!. This place had such a build up and it really was just average. VERY overrated, too many rules a high price for the admission at 11 Euros and then you have to buy the audio guide which was not great and the ENGLISH descriptions of the art is underwhelming at best. Only go here if there is nothing else to do!

Great Art!. This Gallery is an amazing place with enormous amount of masterpieces! I am a big fan of sculpture and architecture, so this place is like Mecca for me :) Caravaggio, Rafael, Titian, Bernini... Incredible names, breathtaking masterpieces, dizzy feeling of being close to the greatest art. You shouldn't hesitate to go there or not, you should see all this beauty. And undoubtedly you will like it!

Limited Collections. If you've seen the Brera Gallery in Milan (fabulous) and the Uffuzi Gallery in Florence, don't waste your time at the Borghese in Rome. The only plus side are the lovely gardens in which the gallery is situated.

Don't forget about this museum when in Rome.. Everyone knows to go to the Vatican. But not many appreciate the fine art at the Borghese Gallery. It is the former home of a cardinal surrounded by beautiful gardens you can walk through afterward. If you are a fan of Bernini (or you will be when you leave) this is a must. However, the museum only lets in a certain number of visitors per hour, per day. So book ahead on line.

Outstanding. We had an amazing guide on the audio tour who made this visit one of the highlights of our time in Rome. The Galleria was absolutely amazing and the artwork was breathtaking!!! I wish that I could remember her name (early 60's, blond hair, short in stature, gentle and thoughtful disposition) She was extremely knowledgeable on her subject and her tour held my children's interest throughout the entire time (ages 14, 16 and 18); not an easy feat. I would highly recommend this tour. I would not however, recommend renting the battery-operated bikes to tour the Villa Borghese because you are very limited as to where you can ride...much better to walk.

Outstanding. We booked a 3 hour tour that included a one hour tour of the gardens. The overall impression was meant to dazzle visitors and it did. The statues, paintings and frescoes were incredible. We could have easily stayed another 2 hours. This site is highly recommended.

Beautiful but overwhelming in a claustrophobic way.. Wife and I were excited but a bit let down. The entry and ticket process is crowded anf long. They group entry by time but it is far too many people inside at once to enjoy. We both felt overcrowded and claustrophobic, this was the only time in a week in Rome. The paintings and sculpture are pretty but the place is so over decorated its hard to enjoy. Try to go at an off time to avoid crowds so you can enjoy the art at your own pace.

Best museum in Rome. This is the must see museum in Rome in my opinion. The museum used to be the Borghese family estate and is located in the beautiful villa Borghese park. The museum features stunning works by Bernini and Caravaggio among others. The downside it its hard to get tickets, you must order them at least a week in advance.

Incredible art, Staff lacking. I'll start by saying that for me, this gallery was a true highlight of our trip. The masterpieces along with the audioguides, and smaller crowds, make this definitely worth the visit. You really must book in advance as when we were there, they had signs saying they were sold out for the next 4 days. Many people were just showing up and leaving disappointed. The grounds are pretty and do make for a nice walk as well. The not-so-great: Aside from the initial ticketing guy, every other staff member we encountered was either dismissive or outright rude. The two women issuing audioguides were so involved in their very loud personal conversation that they left me (and others) just standing right in front of them for several minutes - until they finally decided to acknowledge our presence. And even then, they were very abrupt. I wasn't hugely comfortable handing over all my family's passports to them to just sit on the counter in an open box while paid more attention to their conversation than their jobs. The worst was the older woman taking tickets. She didn't speak any English and after practically yanking our tickets from us, I tried asking her a question about where we needed to start. I'm not sure if she was having a bad day, but she literally gave us a dirty look, said something very loudly in Italian, and waved us away very angrily! She made it clear that she was NOT interested in answering any questions. We're not overly sensitive tourists, but we were taken aback by her.As I said, the artwork itself is world-class, and dealing with a few rude staff is still very much worth it to visit the Galleria Borghese.

Beautiful. Not being huge art lovers, we decided to check out the Galleria and are glad we did. We booked through Walks of Italy, and had a wonderful tour guide that really took the time to explain everything to us and helped keep us engaged. Not too sure if I would bother coming back again next time I'm in Rome, but I am certainly glad I did this time.

Borghese Museum vs. Gardens. With our family of 6 (kids from 9-16) we sent to Villa Borghese. The gardens - there aren't any - just open space but no real gardens with flowering plants. The museum however was very good - reserve in advance as the museum only has set number of vistors every 2 hours.

Tickets sold out. I am sorry that I have to review the galleria as terrible but since we arrived there on a week day (friday I think at about 10am) and the tickets were sold out, it was quite a disappointment)

not that impressed :(. not many tourists that visit rome decide to spend some time in villa borghese and the gallery.i was very impressed with the villa as an area.i loved it and would, without hesitation, go there again.in stark contrast to the villa i was not that happy with the gallery,just wasnt what i expected!!!!im not saying that it wasnt a one life time experience to see all that art in one place but for some reason,that i cannot still explain,it didnt live up to my expactations!!!!

Borghese gallery - bag free zone. Well worth visiting. But be aware that you have to leave everything - including handbag (wth passport and money) outside. Timed entry, very busy. Much easier to get into Doria Pamphilji and I enjoyed it every bit as much.

A Must!. You can't go to Rome and not find the time to go and see Galleria Borghese. It's in the Villa Borghese Park, that's also a nice place, and is one of the most high concentration of beauty and masterpieces of art I've ever seen. The Bernini works are worth a trip (to Italy! not only to Rome) and they are just a part of the gallery (actually a big part...). Remember you NEED a reservation to get in, so plan your trip and your visit here in advance, and be patient at the entrance because the entry system is not so clear and smart but don't worry the waiting will be rewarded by an astounding experience!

A Pleasant Surprise. We went mainly to see Bernini's sculptures, which were amazing. But it turned out that everything else in this Villa was incredible. All the artwork, including the ceilings, was awesome. It was nice to enjoy the parks surrounding the villa afterwards, which is about the only green space in Rome.

This is not just another museum with art..... We are not the most appreciative audience for art. I wish we were more so but alas, we enjoy seeing it but there is a point where too much is too much. This is NOT one of those places where you leave one room and hope that there aren't many more to have to view because "You've seen it all before somehow". The sculptures and the art are arranged so well and the audio guides do such a fantastic job making it all "fresh". It's well worth the $ to enjoy the audio tour throughout! We ordered our tickets online and be SURE to bring your voucher NUMBER. The grounds are as phenomenal as the museum so try to leave at least 30-45 minutes to enjoy the views, the space, the grounds and the refreshment trucks. They had bottled Jack Daniels and coke!!!?
Must See. The Galleria Borghese was my favorite site in Rome. My suggestion is to book ahead of time and get the audio guide.

A hard ticket to get, both worth the effort. Situated in the park (Villa Borghese), this separate structure and gallery are phenomenal. During our private tour we were able to get four tickets and schedule a visit during a private event being hosted at the gallery. The works include Bernini, Caravaggio, and Titian. If you get a chance to get a ticket, go!

Best Museum in Italy!!. Great museum. I love the fact that they controll crowds by requiring a reservation. Its awesome to think that most of the art here was actually created for this villa. The peices by Bernini were incredible. This was one of the true highlights to a trip to Rome.

"This is Italy". While the collection is impressive, the experience was not. We arrived early for our assigned time to discover that the gallery was closed due to a previously unannounced labor meeting. When they finally opened three hours late, all of the people with morning tickets or reservations rushed to enter, which made the gallery very crowded -- just what they generally try to avoid with their strict ticket policy.

Amazing Tour of the Galleria Borghese with Serena Cantagalli. We chose a late afternoon tour of the Galleria Borghese as the way to end our recent trip to Umbria and Rome, and our high expectations were exceeded because we were lucky enough to have Serena Cantagalli as our guide. We had been to the Borghese once before, and marveled at the Bernini and Canova statues and the Caravaggio and Titian paintings and many of the other amazing works there. Having Serena set the stage, provide the background not only of the works themselves but the purpose and use of the building in which they were displayed made the experience unforgettable.Serena doesn't read from a script. She asks questions about our interests and experiences, and then selects details, facts and points of interest to enhance and build upon what we bring to the works of art. The result is a tailor-made experience that leaves us with a richer and deeper understanding of the works of art, and in the process, gives us plenty to think about beyond the artworks and their times. We were lucky enough to visit the Vatican two years ago with Serena as our guide, and guessed correctly that she would be the perfect leader for a visit to the Borghese. Serena's company "Rome Is Easy" (www.romeiseasy.com; info@romeiseasy.com) made all the arrangements (access to the museum is in 2-hour timed blocks, so securing tickets in advance is a must -- Mariangela at Rome Is Easy saw to all of that). All we had to do is meet Serena in our hotel lobby and enjoy an ideal late afternoon at the museum, followed by a leisurely walk through the gardens and back to the heart of Rome. As if her knowledge of a wide variety of art styles and eras is not enough, Serena's gelato and restaurant recommendations have never failed us, and our last night in Rome was capped by an authentic casual Roman Saturday night dinner thanks to her. We could not ask for a better way to finish our trip, and look forward to the next time we can cross paths with Serena and great works of art (if only she would offer tours of New York's Metropolitan or MoMA!).

Totally unresponsive and rude to disabled travelers!. This museum claims to be wheelchair accessible, but is anything but. There are no signs outside pointing to accessible entry, (although there happens to be one, but it is not used - not making this up - read on). To get to the ticket booth, one has to climb down about ten steep steps without any guardrails or hand support. My wife who uses the wheelchair, is able to walk short distances, however I had to carry the chair down the steps. I don't know how this is done by disable people who are wheelchair bound and cannot walk at all. But this was just for starters. The entry to the first and second floor galleries is from the basement up a flight of a steep, spiral staircase. This is not a problem for able bodied individuals. My wife was asked to get out of her wheelchair and get into a small elevator up to the (second) floor. We had to leave our wheelchair in the basement and were given another one, belonging to the museum on the second floor. When we finished viewing the second floor, we had to give up their wheel chair, go back to the elevator down to the first floor, but now there were no wheel chairs on the first floor. So we slowly walked through the rooms, looking for the chairs normally used by the museum guards so my wife could rest before going on. No one approached us, asked us for assistance or help. Finally we made it back to the elevator, went down to the basement and collected our wheelchair. Now we had to leave the building and go back up to the street level from the basement ticket area. I noticed a perfectly new chair elevator in the so-called "scuola" room, and asked to be allowed to use it. They said no! They sent my wife again in the small elevator to the street level, and told me to carry our own wheelchair up the flight of steep spiral staircase myself. They did not offer to help. The guards and museum personnel who did speak English were brusque to the point of rudeness, others did not speak English (or pretended not to), and did not seem perturbed by a sight of a 61 year old man lugging his wheelchair up the stairs in their museum. Finally, we were let out through a side door, to the back of the villa. By now my wife could not walk anymore, and the gravel behind the villa was almost impossible to push through. A young official who unlocked (!) the back door to let us out appeared to speak English but did not care to offer any help, or make any comments. So, in a country and a city which do not offer almost any disability accommodations to begin with, Galleria Borghese reached a new low in adding additional rudeness, incompetence, and utter disregard for disabled travelers. We have been traveling with the wheelchair around the world for many years, with little problem. Almost everywhere else, when the process, or equipment breaks down, human concern and sympathy takes over and people help even to the point of manually carrying the wheelchair. The Italian officials at Villa Borghese managed to exhibit an almost unbelievable disregard for the most basic humane concerns for fellow human beings, let alone their paying customers. For shame Rome, Italy and Villa Borghese!!
Beautiful. Staff a little cold but still helpful. Definitely get the self guided tour which really helps to understand the sculpture and art. Gorgeous park. Breathtaking overlook.

Make your reservations and GO!. The Villa Borghese is a must see attraction in Rome, but you must have reservations in advance. Don't be disappointed when you get there. Reservations are easy to make online even from the States. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the visit, but there's so much else to see and the location in the park is also a wonderful respite from hectic Rome.

It was all about the Berninis for me. The Galleria Borghese is on the northern edge of the city. You might not be up in that neck of the woods for any other reason, but after the Vatican, the collection here is reputed to be the finest in Rome. I confess to having been in it for the Berninis. The Bernini sculptures The Rape of Prosperine, David, and Apollo and Daphne made the museum a must-see for me. I'm pretty sure we must have gone through a lot of rooms and seen many other priceless treasures, but to tell you the truth, I was so consumed by the Berninis that I've forgotten everything else. All I can say is wow. Wow, wow, wow.

For Museum Lover. The building is a museum itself. Lot of great art works. Situated in a beautiful park where Romans
relax on week-end, this is the place to discover the history and life of Roman people. Be ready to walk and don't forget to book in advance(for most of the major museum of Roma)

Wonderful change from the hectic Vatican Museum. Yes, we made reservations ahead of time. It really was necessary as they were sold out when we arrived for those without reservations. It is a wonderful small collection, beautiful home is the setting for the gallery. It was a pleasure to stroll through the collection without bumping into a million other tourists! We love museums and always take our time, but we easily made it through in less than the 2 hours allotted. It is in the Borghese Gardens, but a long walk unless you are in the right part of the grounds. We took a cab to the gallery because we were tired and running late for our reservation time. After, we walked back to dinner near Piazza Popolo...a LONG walk which I would not do after dark, but it was light until almost 9pm. Know that you cannot take pictures so be ready to check your camera. We left ours in the hotel. The grounds are pretty so it would have been nice to have a picture or two. They are pretty strict about checking bags, but amazingly we were allowed to bring bottled water in. Very glad we went in spite of some of the other comments. If this is your first trip to Rome, I would only do this if you have done all of the other big sites. For those of us who have been before it is well worth making time to go.

Make reservations then enjoy. Borghese Gallery has got to be among the top five small galleries in the world...maybe number one, mostly because the works are fabulous and the crowds are small. Reservations in advance are a MUST so plan ahead. Bernini works alone are worth the visit, but there is so much more. It's probably best to read up before your visit so you are ready for what's in store.

Must-reserve, must-see museum. Walk-ins are not accepted in the only museum you can't miss in Rome, but you can reserve date and hour via phone or web and pay upon arrival. Visits are timed so you should get there some 20 minutes before your alloted hour to go through a cryptic routine of checking-in, purchasing the audio tour (highly recommended) and leaving all bags in deposit. Ground level has some of the finest sculptures mankind has produced; upper level houses less-impressive paintings.The park beside the museum very beautiful; if you have time you can croos it to/from the Spanish Steps to the left.
Fascinating galerry. Please note that tickets should be purchased is advanced.Everything is fascinating in this galley: the building, the paintings collection and most of all the sculptures.

Remember to book in advance!. Well this was certainly the hottest spot in Rome for tourists or visitors. We purchased Roma pass and based on recommendation, we thought it would be nice to visit this famous Galleria. We arrived there on Tuesday morning, waited in line to get tickets and like most other people in front of us, were declined entry because all tickets till the coming Saturday were all fully booked out already! What a pity. Althought Villa Borghese was also very nice to look around, we still felt a bit disappointed. After all, we wouldn't have the chance to visit Rome that often and who knows when the next time would be! So a piece of advice for everybody who wants to go in the Galleria: book in advance!

Excellent!. My favourite place in Rome!! Plain beautiful, with priceless works of art. Audioguide is a must! Reservation is a must! The building is great on the inside and it contains demo's about roman talent at the range of... heavenly gift!

So happy to go. We knew this was a mandatory book in advance museum and we were happy to comply. I do suggest though that if you are in Rome, go in to the Galleria Borghese and buy tickets from there instead of online, I didnt know we had to pay a service fee until I booked our time slot which meant I paid around 4 Euros more. A lot of people didn't know you had to book ahead and if you have a Roma pass you need to call or go there as your first trip if you want to go in for free.They were very well organised and things went smoothly, everything has to be checked in, no phones and you need to get there early to pick up your tickets, which was not a problem because the Villa Borghese is absolutely beautiful. We brought fruit and ate it as we waited til we got in at EXACTLY the time the time slot began. There IS a second floor, picture gallery, so dont miss it.We were floored when we saw the Caravaggios, sad the boy with a basket of fruit wasn't there at the time, or St, Jeromes if I remember correctly but all the Berninis were which was fantastic. Everyone gasps in awe when they come across them for the first time and with only 200 people there, at most, everyone could get a good view. I loved the contrast of Caravaggio and Bernini's "self portraits, {sich Baccus and David)... All in all, it was fantastic to see and I am so happy I didnt miss it.Coffee right after was a big plus. :D

Great museum!. Make sure you call for reservations before you go-- you can't just walk in. Also, you have 2 hours in the museum. Go upstairs and see the paintings first, then downstairs to see the sculptures (this is the reverse of all of the crowds and will give you a much less crowded viewing experience.)

A must see. It doesn't matter that you need reservations two months (or more) in advance. Everyone must see the Borghese for the Bernini sculpture if nothing else. the palazzo is beautiful itself as well as the very calming grounds, but the sculpture is the star of the show. I'd not recommend buying tickets through a service - I did this time out of necessity and paid almost double the price as if you reserve through the Galleria itself (long story). You must get there early to turn in your voucher for tickets. Very nice gift shop, decent staff are a bit overwhelmed by the mob so be patient. Took Metra to Spagna (spanish steps) and then cab - $10euro via a detour - be careful of that. Regardless this is an experience that should be on everyone's bucket list.

Wife liked, husband didn't. Audio guide was difficult to follow, and when you did, it was laboriously detailed. Poor signage and tattered laminated handout were hard to follow as well. We paid online in advance for an English-speaking guide, but when we got there, it was going to cost another 8 euro a piece, so we just rented a single audio guide device to share. The best word I can use to describe this place is "stuffy". Not the "poor ventilation" stuffy, but the "we have the coolest museum on the planet, and you are probably not worthy to be here" stuffy. I was bored most of the time, and couldn't wait to get to some place to sit down. You only get two hours to browse the museum, and they don't have chairs for you to browse from. The park is nice in the surrounding area, and next time, I would spend my money renting a bike and having a picnic, rather than being in a stuffy museum.

We just relaxed at the park. This was my 4th or 5th time in Rome but this was my first time in the park. We loved it! We rented one of the motorized 4 wheeled bicycles for one hour to get to see the park with little efforts (just 15 euros per hour). We then chose a place to sit on the grass and relax. Our son found some friends to play ball, we relaxed on the grass listening to some street musician. We just ate some ice cream and spent free time doing nothing, excellent plan for a vacation! The gardens are well kept, huge and perfect to unwind.

"Apollo & Daphne". Bernini's "Apollo & Daphne" was the highlight of the Borghese for me. I just couldn't get enough of the detail and imaging the story behind it. It is really easy to feel like a Borghese as you walk through the museum. Fortunately the tickets are booked in 2 hour allocations - this made us move on to the next room or we could have been in there all day. Timed visits are a wonderful thing. It also felt like the number of guests were limited so it was not too crowded - if you wanted to get fixated on one sculpture you had room to do so without feeling rushed.The cafe downstairs was a nice place to get an expresso and gear up on the way out for the walk through the beautifully designed and manicured gardens.Tip: Book tickets ahead of time online so you do not have to wait in line.

What every museum wants to be. If we have one place to recommend in Rome (other than the Vatican), this is it. The gardens and park just add to the splendor. Frankly, I do not have the words to describe how brilliant the Galleria is. Each room is a color-coordinated masterpiece of paintings, sculptures, architectures, murals, and visual magnificence. We have been three time, each time seeing new things and experiencing an awe evoked by few other human constructions. Read all you can before coming. The more you know, the more levels of comprehension you will enjoy. It is a subtle and nuanced architectural and artistic creation unlike any other we have experienced. Make reservations. Be on time. Savor.
Nice park. Hire a 4 wheeler bike! Easy and a lot of fun!! Lol. It says not to cross the road, but advise isn't clear until later.....go through the roundabout for the views!
wonderful. great museum in terrific setting of beautiful park. the bernini sculptures are breathtaking and the villa itself is impressive. worth prebooking.

Come for the Bernini, Stay For the Peace. First, the caveat: the ticket sellers at Borghese are clipped at best, on a par with the famous moralising lecturers at the Louvre ("your scarf goes to a different garderobe, monsieur"). They know you desperately want to get in, and you do: tickets are sold in two hour intervals and in high season you have to book days ahead, so don't mess with them. Book on-line.Once you're in, run ahead of the pack and start several rooms on, then double back. The Borghese is quite easy to see in two hours, and the non-discriminating part of the crowd heads for the big ticket Caravaggio and Berninis. You'll soon find yourself alone. And the Berninis in particular are more than worth the price of admission: great examples of his ability to find compositional brilliance in twisting, dynamic torsos full of drama. Not every piece in the gallery is worth a look; as with the Louvre's obligatory but decidedly mediocre 18th century French collection, the post-Renaissance Italian work at the Borghese leaves a lot to be desired. No matter. Once you're done ogling the Bernini sculptures, head outside into the small garden and check out whether there's an exhibition at the far end. t's included in your ticket and it often takes the form of a marked contrast with all the classicism in the gallery proper.Once you walk out of the gallery, remind yourself that in you're in one of the most peaceful parts of busy Roma--a huge park that is never over-crowded. Buy yourself a gelato from one of the mobile vendors and relax before descending back into Dante's Inferno.

Almost an overload of renaissance art. We booked on the Internet the day before and were able to get in. Presenting the confirmation on an iPad screen was no problem; taking any bags in (including small ladies bags) was.It is great that they have timed entries and limit the numbers of visitors in the gallery at any one time~ although there were some clusters inevitably, and a small tour group or two, one could easily observe the works; in situ, on the walls and overhead, something often difficult with crush of crowds.At the risk of a sensory overload, the 2 hours allocated was enough without a chance to break midway for a coffee. The bar downstairs does a good espresso for a pre-viewing hit.The star of the exhibition for me was undoubtedly Benini's "Apollo & Daphne", a sculpture which was full of life and movement.A walk through the gardens afterwards is a good way to return to the reality of the 21st century.

The best museum/palazzo in Rome. We visited Italy for two weeks (Venice, Florence, Tuscany, Rome), but the Galleria Borghese was my absolute favorite. I enjoyed the architecture, Bernini sculptures and paintings so much that I made my family walk around the building twice. It was incredible!!

Borghese Must see. This is one of the best museums I have ever visited and I wasn't ready to leave after our two hour allotment had expired. ( I usually experience museum fatigue after a couple of hours.) I liked its small size which makes it more approachable. If nothing else, go for the Bernini sculptures, but there is much, much more -Caravaggio, Canova, Titian, and the list goes on.

Breath-taking Art. The Galleria Borghese has one of the finest art collections in the world, and is not to be missed. Get your tickets on-line before you leave home to be assured of entrance on the date you want, then pick them up at the gallery. You can also use your Roma Pass to get the tickets, but then you will have to wait until you arrive in Rome, buy the passes, and then you need to phone the Galleria for the time. Each ticket gives you two hours of access, and then the rooms are cleared for the next group. The two hours is not enough, so you might consider doing it twice. The audio guides are good, but there is so much to see that the guides don't cover. The two hour limit has its advantages, however, since it means that the gallery is not over-crowded, unlike the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.No cameras are allowed. Indeed, no handbags or backpacks, for that matter. All such things must be checked. Get to the gallery 30 minutes before your entrance time to pick up your tickets, and to drop off your stuff at the checkroom.Don't tell your taxi driver you want to go to the Villa Borghese, or you'll be dropped off at the wrong spot. There is a small cafe, with sandwiches, which you could buy and eat in the adjacent park. The Galleria is within walking distance of Rome's contemporary art museum, which is housed in a lovely building, but does not have the quality of contemporary art you might expect. Two second-tier Van Goghs are worth seeing, as is a first-rate Jackson Pollack and a stunning Klimpt. For some reason, there are no Picassos, and only one Modigliani. So, if you want an all-art day, walk west through the park to see its collection.Enjoy!

Nice Quiet area in Rome. It was nice to be outside of the busier area of Rome for a while and to enjoy the park for an hour or two. Be sure to get tickets a week or so in advance. Unfortunately, when we were there on a Sunday - visitors were being turned away and told that next available fist was on the following Wednesday. Lots of stuff to see - and only 2 hrs allowed. Very nice visit.

Take your time. Do take your time and make sure to book in advance. When it is your time to enter hang back and let the mad rush go before you. You have two hours to enjoy and there is no reason to be in a rush and you will avoid the crowd.
A Must See. Buy tickets in advance. This is a must see in Rome. The Bernini sculptures are so amazing and memorable.

Got in without a reservation. We had read that reservations were a must to visit the Galleria Borghese, but after a morning of wondering around the gardens stopped to inquire about tickets and only waited one-half hour to get in (fixed 2 hour time slots for entry). The building is beautiful architecturally and contains a number of famous works of art and works by famous artists. This is well worth seeing, but suspect that the advice about advance reservations should be headed if you want to be sure to get in!
Worth reserving. Loved the Bernini sculpture and lovely setting in the big park. They have a very efficient reservation system, but you have to be there at the arranged hour.

Allow time. First of all, do not book your ticket online. It cost us twice as much to book the ticket online (they must be booked in advance) verses going to there and reserving it. We didn't do a tour, and unless you're a big art person, I wouldn't recommend it. There are cards in each room that describe the walls and ceiling, and that was plenty for us. I would allow 2-3 hours to go through and 3-4 if you're serious about looking at absolutely everything. Apparently there is a 2 hour limit, but no one stopped us. The area around the Galleria is beautiful, and I would recommend spending some time there. Think Italian version of Central Park. It's about a 15-20 minute walk (uphill) from the Spanish Steps, so it's easy to make a day out of it. The gardens are at the time of Via Veneto, a famous street in Rome with the U.S. Embassy on it.

Wonderful. Friends had told us about this gem of a museum. A must see. The crowds are not bad. We really had time to get intimate with the art. Make sure you get the audio guides. Makes the pieces come alive. There is a two hour time limit but that was plenty. We enjoyed this museum.

Don't forget to book your visit!. Don't forget to book your visit! It was one of the most rewarding attractions in our visit to Rome. DON'T MISS IT. Even the kids liked it. As the museum doesn't allow to many visitors, it's not crowded. Highly recommended to get a local guide as otherwise very challenging to enjoy the amazing pieces of art.

Better than the Vatican Museum. Have gone twice as the art work is just amazing....especially of you like Bernini and Carvaggio. I enjoy this museum's art collection much more than that found in the Vatican Museum.

Be quick. 2 hour limit per visit. Dont book your bag into the cloakroom before you have hired your audio guide because the need ID as deposit. The staff hiring the audio were rude, kept us waiting whilst they chatted yet did not care to be polite with us. A lovely venue. I would have liked more time to view the amazing artworks and sculpures that are housed here.
A must do!. The sculpture here is incredible. Take the audio guided tour. You must make reservations and are only allowed 2 hours but it is well worth it to find this treasure in Rome.
Borghese Museum and Gallery in Rome. Be sure to buy tickets in advance. Lovely. Would have liked to have spent more time roaming around the grounds.

A taste of the life of the 1%. This is a must see museum, not just for its few masterpieces, but for the ability to walk through a villa and experience how the rich lived and decorated their homes. The frescos really do seem to have depth and the artwork is amazing. Its small enough not to be overwhelming but still impressive. Advance reservations are a must.
Place for art lovers. Galleria full of masterpieces.If I have to highlight just one, it would be "David" by Bernini. If you travel to Rome, you must visit Galleria Borghese!

Wonderful art collection. The Galleria Borghese is a worthwhile visit if you enjoy fine art and have the time to explore this fine collection of Imperial Rome sculptures and renaissance art.We book ahead, if you don,t, then you probably won't get in as they only allow 350 people at a time and you don't always get the time and date you want .Make sure you book well ahead in the busy seasons.It is not the easiest place to find so give yourself lots of time. No pictures are allowed.After two hours you are asked to leave , but we found this time ample. Watch out for the staircaseif you have trouble climbing it could be a problem as it is steep and narrow to the third floor.Well worth the visit though.

My favorite museum!. I've been to a lot of museums around the world and I would have to say that this one is my favorite. The works by Bernini are incomparable...I appreciate that there are rooms dedicated to individual pieces. It is difficult to believe that the flowing fabric and soft skin are truly carved in marble. I recommend this museum as an absolute must see to all my friends visiting Rome. However, if you plan to visit, make sure you get your tickets early. I have friends that stayed a week in Rome and couldn't get tickets. Last time I visited I bought mine on the website Tickitaly.com. You choose the date and time, pay in advance, print your tickets and basically just walk in. We took the subway but still had a bit of a walk to get there. Also, you only have one hour in the museum so save most of your time for Bernini!

Overwhelming Art!. This was a great museum to go to in Rome - the best in the city. It's not crowded - you have to reserve a entrance time before hand. It has a impressive number of sculptures and art. My 13 year old son didn't like it, but it was really impressive collection for adults to see.

As good as people say it is. The sculptures, in particular, are amazing. A museum where the "show-stoppers" live up to their billing. However, be sure to look at all of the ceilings in the building; some of them are quite incredible, as artists decorated them to complement the art work with some extraordinary results. You must reserve your tickets in advance, so plan ahead! The nearest Metro stop is Spagna; the Galleria is a 20 minute walk from there; note there is a tunnel in the Metro station for "Villa Borghese" which eliminates walking along streets, but it leads to a rather forlorn location on the far southwestern part of the Villa grounds. From there, head due east until you find roads and signage which will lead you to the museum.

Beautiful collection!. I honestly just went to see Apollo and Daphne and even though it delivered to my highest expectations, I was much more taken aback by the beauty and excellence of Bernini's Rape of Proserpina. It was surreal, violent and beautifully revolting. There are also so many more that were stunny! The Borghese collection is definitely not to be missed!

YOU MUST MAKE A RESERVATION IN ADVANCE!. You must make a reservation either online or by phone and in advance to obtain a ticket and a time to enter the Museum. Our tickets were 13 Euro each for a specified entrance time, and the tour is limited to two hours. The museum is great as other reviews will tell you but if you are on a schedule or your time is limited, make your reservation well in advance. The park area surrounding the galleria is beautiful to walk through with fountains and statues. We walked from the Metro-Spagna station to the Museum. As you exit the metro station to the Spanish Steps, there is an elevator on the left side that takes you up to the Villa Borghese and a beautiful walk from there.
Don't miss it!. Such an awesome collection! I highly recommend getting the audio guide, its so informative but actually interesting to listen to and easy to follow.

My Favorite Museum in Rome & Florence!. The museum is full of beautiful Roman sculptures and Renaissance art. The walls and ceilings of the museum itself are painted beautifully as well. Bernini's David is just stunning and was by far my favorite piece in both Rome and Florence.
Great art. We had a guide and wished the reservation was for more then two hours. The art was good but the check in and out took a long time. Worth it though!

Tried to make a reservation two days in advance, but failed. Had no idea they restricted attendance so much. Even though we were Rome in April, we could not get a midweek reservation two days in advance. Can't imagine how far in advance you'd need to call during peak season!!!

Best of the museums. Although this museum was not as large as many of the other museums, like the Vatican, we felt is was by far the best and most tastefully displayed. The artwork was lovely and sculpture some of the best in the world. Be sure and make your reservation and don't miss the Borghese. A walk through the park and to the city overlook are also a treat.

One Of The Best Galleries Ever!. We have been fortunate to have traveled to many countries in our lifetime and many galleries but Galleria Borghese was beyond words. They time it so you have two hours and you can study a sculpture closely without a crowd. If you have a desired time book as far as you can in advance. I believe it was two months!We saw many people who didn't realize that you MUST have a booking and were turned away.If you are visiting Rome this should not be missed.There is a nice shop for a cappuccino if you arrive early and a gift shop.

Beautiful art & location, but must book in advance. It is always helpful once in awhile to remind future visitors that you MUST buy your tickets in advance. We purchased online while we were still in the US and it was an easy process. Even so, you still have to wait on line after admission - I believe they let people by groups & timeslots.When you enter, you are greeted with 3 flights of stairs. You navigate the galleries floor by floor. Keep your admission ticket as it is required for use of the bathroom on the ground level.Taking pictures was prohibited which is a shame, as Borghese had some of the loveliest sculptures we have ever seen, very detailed, artistic and emotive. The rooms themselves were beautiful. There are laminated room guides you can read in some of the rooms, but an audio guide or book would probably have significantly enhanced our experience here.Lastly, make sure you allot some extra time to enjoy the park right by the museum. I would suggest booking your museum admission for the early/mid-afternoon and then spending the rest of the afternoon in the park. They rent bicycles and motorized 2 & 4-seaters at a reasonable price for you to bike around the park and see all the sights. At the other end of the park affords one a great elevated view of Rome. There are bus stops in the park with small buses that will take you in the direction of the Spanish Steps and Piazza Navona, in time for a nice dinner.

Real treasure. You need a reservation, the ticket is 13 E, the time for visiting is limited for 2 hours. There were many guided tours, but maybe our reservation time (11-13) was preferred for most tourists. Nevertheless the treasure inside,the statues from Bernini,the frescoes and mosaics are astonishing. Every minute in this gallery is worth and every tourist should visit it.Enjoy it!

not worth the money,but.... who likes the art so much will pay for it 13e. I expected more works of art, bigger museum. You need reservation (because limited number of people they let in)we ask in hotel reception when we arrived. You can go at 11,13,15,17 I think and stay max 2h

Disappointing -Needs some work. I have wanted to come to the Galleria for years, and made it this trip, but sadly was really disappointed by my experience. The 'raw materials' that the museum has to work with are wonderful - opulent marble decor, trompe l'oeil extravaganzas, scores of dark renaissance paintings and a setting within Rome's largest central park. The things that really let it down for us were: 1. Rude staff on the ticket desk - really unpleasant. 2. Interpretation was awful and very old fashioned. We did not get the audio tour and I believe that some basic info should be freely available as part of admission prices. It was over-verbose in places and not available for many pieces. Given the prices and popularity the museum can't be that short of resources, so possibly down to laziness/arrogance. 3. Cant use Roma Pass unless you phone4. Toilets were appalling -even by Italian standards- and the main stairway up was filthy.5. Most of the really famous paintings seemed to be on loan..Its the little things that all added up

Be prepared for crowds. The galleria was great with very interesting period paintings, sculptures, ceilings and furnishings but be prepared to stand in line. Everyone is admitted at the same time so there are lines to enter, to check bags and to pick up audio guides. Make sure you bring your confirmation when you arrive to enter because the ticketing service is not connected to the galleria and without the number even with your credit card and id you will not be able to pick up your entry ticket. Also there is a strict time limit so when 2 hours are up you are escorted out so the next group can enter. They could make the experience a lot more enjoyable but the offerings are still worth the effort. We had a nice little picnic in the park before our tour started which was very pleasant
well worth a visit. We took a Viatour ( Dark Rome) guided tour and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The stories behind the art and sculptures was a real education and most enjoyable
Wonderful sculptures. the Galleria Borghese is a must and needs to be pre-booked most of the times during season. Look at a breathtaking array of sculptures e.g. by Bernini. Lovely park.

Great museum! Beautiful art!. We loved the Galleria Borghese. The thing I did not like was that you cannot take pictures. I would love to have some of these memories to take home. We also, for some reason, had a hard time finding the Galleria. It is quite a walk,so, be ready for that and make sure you take a map. The area surrounding it is huge and it's easy to go the wrong way. They do have lockers for you to put your belongings in. You can't take purses in with you. The locker system is safe and easy though. Book ahead of time, the time slots get sold out. You will have to wait until your alloted time to get in the museum. There is a nice big bookstore and waiting area in side to wait until it's time if you get there early. This was our favorite museum. Lots of famous artists! This museum, since it is timed, only allows a certain number of people in at a time. This was so nice. It was not overly crowded, but, there is also a time limit. I think it was 2 hours. We found that to be just about right. Loved it!

Be prepared to walk up 3 flights of stairs to start the tour. Having heard that a section of this gallery just opened after being closed for 17 years made us eager to get tickets (hard to come by) to visit this gallery on our most recent trip to Rome in early June. We were disappointed especially when the staff was very unfriendly and there was a long wait before we could even enter the gallery. There was not sufficient places to sit and wait and once we were allowed in, we had to climb 3 flights of stairs. By the time we got to the top, we were ready to leave. We were not impressed with the way the art was displayed and even though there was some incredible Bernini sculptures, we did not find the descriptions next to the art pieces to be very complete especially if you had limited knowledge of this period of art. After spending quite a bit on the tickets which must be reserved and allow you to stay only 2 hours in the gallery, we did not realize that we should have also spent more to get the audio tape. We decided to cut our losses and leave. Sorry, we didn't just spend time in the park surrounding the gallery. Unless you have a good background in the art displayed at this gallery, I would suggest not wasting your time.

Favorite museum in Rome, hands down.. Rome is one of the most beautiful cities in the world, and this art gallery is no exception. Housed in a beautiful old villa right outside of downtown Rome, the Galleria Borghese has some of the most beautiful artwork in both canvas and marble that exists in the world. The galleria has some amazing pieces from: Bernini, Caravaggio, and Raphael. In fact I believe the trip is worth it alone to see Bernini's sculpture Apollo and Daphne which is one of my favorite marble sculptures I have ever seen.Reminder - You must get reservations in advance! Don't try and show up to get tickets, you will be disappointed. It is worth scheduling a day and or your entire trip to Rome around the reservation times that you get at Galleria Borghese. There is both a gift shop, and a small deli, but I would consider eating elsewhere the food choices are minimal.

Place 4 stars, staff 1 star. I say do not miss this when you are in Rome, I would see this over any place we saw. It is full of history, the opulence of the Borghese family. But the art and beautiful rooms are worth the visit.The grounds are a disaster, not kept up much and the gardens were nothing to see.The staff were the rudest most unhelpful people we met anywhere in Italy.

Reservation not always necessary!. Having found that we were too late to book for the FOLLWING DAY, we were told that we could always visit on the off-chance of a cancellation. So we walked up from Piazza del Popolo and through the gardens to the Galleria (allow at least an hour, more if you wish to take in the views and arrive less sweaty!). On arrival in the Galleria we enquired for cancellations and were told that as long as we were out in 75 minutes we could go straight in! All visits are booked and timed for a maximum two hours (which is enough) and right now (until mid-September) you get the bonus of seeing the artist Hoeffer's work....intricate paintings of the rooms in THIS Galleria, including the actual paintings on the walls. This Philistine thought that these were almost the highlight!

A warning... Only writing this to remind people you must book in advance. It has some paintings I have wanted to see for years and feel silly for not having ignored the advice which said you must book in advance

Our favorite museum in Rome. It is easy to get "museumed" out in Rome but this musuem should not be missed. It is small enough to be manageable and not overwhelming. The sculptures were particularly impressive and our favorite was Bernini's Apollo & Daphne.Reservations are essential and should be made at least two weeks in advance. We paid extra for an English guide and it was well worth it.
Don't Miss the Galleria Borghese. This museum is a real gem. You must book online in advance and I recommend doing a guided tour or audio guide to get the most out of your visit.
Loved Loved Loved it!. Bernini at his most beautiful best. Walk through the gardens and take your time to enjoy and relax from the hectic sightseeing of rome.

This makes the Highlight reel. This was one of my highlights in Rome. This was also one of the first bookings I made online knowing they require reservations. The collections in the gallery are devine, and the access to the sculptures is great. Get close, see the artists work close up, like Bernini's Apollo and Daphne in Marble. Exquisite. The public park situated next to the gallery makes for a pleasant stroll before or after. The only draw back we found was the ban on photography and mandatory bag check. I have read some of the poor reviews on Trip Advisor, and most are not about the gallery, just the policies of fixed size tours requiring reservations. Just plan ahead if you love art and sculpture.

Great art and a grand setting. This was our second visit to Galleria Borghese (the first was in 2005). As many other reviewers have mentioned, you must book a reservation well in advance and be there about 15 minutes before your entry time. You have two hours to complete your tour. I suggest that you set aside enough time to enjoy the paintings on the second floor and that you take the time to fully contemplate Bernini's Apollo and Daphne sculpture, which is my favorite sculpture (including Michelangelo's David!). Also, set aside time to walk the grounds outside. On our recent visit, a young man from Ukraine was playing his accordion as he sat on a bench--and he was extraordinary. This is great art in a grand setting.

A Rome must see. This requires advanced reservations and I highly recommend booking a tour through Context Travel so that you get an indepth understanding of the art you will see inside. The Berninis are absolutely life altering :)

What a collection. If you are an art lover, this is a must. The villa itself is a piece of art.What is great about this museum, you must make reservation to enter. Your time is limited to two hours and the number of visitors are limited to 300. This makes it a very pleasant visit with nobody pushing you while looking at the numerous pieces of art. After you are fished, take time to walk and relax in the garden (Park)

One of Favorites in Rome. The gallery and collections are just amazing. In many cases, I am bored by audio guides, but here I highly recommend renting audio guide. In many rooms, room decoration and collections are made in theme or related to certain myth, so it will be more meaningful if you have an audio guide. The size of the place and number of visitors allowed in each round are just about right to allow one to enjoy the most. Also the park outside the gallery has nice atmosphere.
