The best of the baroque. A Roman Must Do!. If you visit Rome this is one place you must go. Some of the most famous art in the world. Much of it displayed in the room for which it was created.You have to buy tickets several days ahead of time but it is well worth the effort. The advantage is that the museum is not overcrowded while you are there.

Not to be missed. For me Rome is two things: art and food. The Galleria Borghese is the epitome of art in Rome. Prebooking a ticket for timed admission is essential. I recommend rental of an audio guide, but I do not recommend booking a tour. See what you want to see at your own pace. Do not try to see everything in a single visit. The Bernini sculptures on the ground floor and Carivaggio upstairs may well be enough for a first visit - and likely an experience to remember.
Best Little Collection in Rome. This was a beautiful experience. Small crowd and limited time to see the collection. The park is an added delight.

Favorite museum in Rome. First word of advice: Make a reservation before you get to Rome. Luckily I had read this advice on Trip Advisor "City Guide" before we left the States. The museum is limited to 350 people during each 2 hour segment and we saw many people turned away. Second word of advice: purchase the audio tour and start at the beginning. We started at the entrance and we were very confused until we realized that the audio tour starts elsewhere. Third word of advice: Enjoy! If you love Bernini, this museum is unsurpassed. Unfortunately, no photography is allowed. Oh well, I had to buy a few post cards.Another suggestion: take a cab to be on time.

Wonderful Private Museum. If you want to see one of the best collections in the world and avoid the crowds of public museums and the Vatican, this is the place. You MUST make reservations in advance as they limit the number of guests per day. You will see possibly the best collection of Bernini sculptures and Caravaggio paintings possible. You can get up close to all the pieces and enjoy their beauty. This should be one of the top places for anyone who likes museums.

More than Just an Art Museum.. The sculptures and art work were amazing. Being able to touch the sculptures and unbelievable. Only a specific number of people are allowed in at one time to ensure the best experience. Be sure an buy your tickets in advance and the museum was sold out on the day we were there and many were disappointed.

Very Strict Timings. This place was full of beautiful statues and paintings, but can become boring if one does not know the stories of what the images tell. I suggest having a guide with you to explain everything to enjoy the place the most. The tickets that you purchase are valid for certain timings, and if you are not out by the time they want you to be out, they come and find you inside the museum. Be sure to check the times on the ticket.

Beautiful Gallery!. This is a must do for all art lovers. However, a little planning is required. We made our reservations and paid for our tickets a month before our trip. Arrive to your reservation at least 30 minutes before. It was incredible to see all of the beautiful art. The gallery had an authentic feel to it, as the art was commissioned for this beautiful home. My favorite work was The Rape of Proserpine. I loved how you could see the indention of her skin as he pressed on her leg. My husbands was the Caravaggio paintings. Bernini's work was equally impressive. The are very strict about checking in bags and no cameras. Try to soak in as much as you can in your two hour slot!

Stunning. A must see while in Rome. Best gallery I have been to. Book on line before you leave home. They limit the number of people entering so this means you can actually see the exhibits without the crowds.

World class museum in a beautiful park setting. Don't miss this one folks. Beautiful museum highlighting some key works of Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael and more. Beautifully displayed, feels intimate. You need reservations (at least a few days in advance during busy season). The reservations mean the Galleria is never too crowded. There were guided tours going on, we paid 5 Euro for the self-guided audio tour offered in several languages. I liked it, it allowed us to go at our own pace. Another hint for you, as long as you keep track of where you have been, you don't have to go in order with the self-guided tours. If the room you step into is crowded, try the next one, then come back. It takes only 1.5-2 hours to view the entire collection. Here's another tip: if you are in Rome in busy season (June-August) it can get very hot in the afternoon. Plan an outdoor activity in the morning and reserve your time at Borghese from 2-4 or 3-5pm. Nice book /souvenir shop and cafe too.

Bernini and a wonderful presentation. We missed this on a previous trip due to a sporadic taxi strike, but this time spent 2+ hours slowly walking through this rather small estate loaded with tremendous art and sculpture. It is wise to get a history of the Borghese and its lineage, because many of the original works were taken (home) to France, now in the Louvre. Not to miss is the park however. It is a very used one but retains all the magic of nature and urban uses.
a must visit. So much quieter than the Vatican Museums and with treasures and cravings to rival anything there. Book well in advance and make sure that you visit. Simply stunning.

First floor is a must see. May 24, 2013 we, my 21 year old son, his friend and my sister in law had reservations for 9am at the Borghese Gallery. All of us agreed that the first floor is an an amazing place and we were so glad we went. The boys weren't too enthused about the paintings on the second floor saying they really liked sculptures rather than paintings - but we all were absolutely glad we took the time to take the tour of the Borghese Gallery.

Must-see museum in Rome. One of the highlights of our trip to Italy, particularly the fantastic sculptures by Bernini.Get your hotel to phone the Borghese ahead of time to get you a reservation number.I also recommend buying the Roma Pass if you are staying 3 or more days in Rome, as it allows you to avoid the lines at 2 of the sights you visit.

Getting to Borghese. Decided to walk from tram line, and take in Spanish Steps along the way. Couldn't make it without help. By the time we got to the park we hired a golf cart driver to take us the rest of the way which was a few more KM. Museum was fantastic. Gardens were beautiful but we wanted to make it to the collosseum as it was our last day. We called the golfcart driver for pick up and drove us in his golf cart to the collosseum. It was an adventure.

Worth the visit!. Lovely experience. The sculptures on the first floor will blow you away. Be sure to rent the audio tour or get a guide. It is worth it at this gallery to get the most out of the amazing art work. Also I noticed the museum was sold out for several days so don't forget to make your reservations.The second floor is devoted to painting and you don't have as much time there. I wish I had spent some more time researching what I was going to see at the Gallery to get more out of the visit. Our 13-year-old daughter loved it and gained an appreciation for Bernini. A don't miss in Rome and a nice break because they don't allow the pushy schlock vendors in the park.

MUST SEE!!. No question, this needs to be on your list of MUST SEES in Rome. Do yourself a favour, book your reservation at least a week (or more) in advance and try to book it for 9:00am. Show up at 8:30am to pick up your tickets - you will not be sorry!! You need to make a reservation to see this gallery, do not risk missing out by just showing up at the door and hoping to get in. This unbeliveable collection of art is a far more enjoyable and relaxed setting than others you can visit. If you're a fan of Bernini's work you cannot come to Rome without seeing this FABULOUS gallery!!! Even if you're not familiar with Bernini, you will love it here!! A+++

If it would not be for the Sistine Chappel - this would be THE museum to visit in Rome. Small museum with unbelievable sculptures by Bernini and beautiful paintings by many different painters including Caravaggio. Even my kids, who are not museum lovers at all, have enjoyed it and selected it as the top site in Rome. Make sure to make reservations ahead of time on the internet since space is limited and it is reserved days, if not weeks, ahead.

Absolutely Beautiful. We toured the Villa and Gallery Borghese as part of a pre-arranged package tour. Do this with a guide so you can reap he benefits of the history attached to the various rooms and art. The Gallery was absolutely mind-blowing and beautiful, as were the gardens. The only drawback is that visits to the Gallery itself are limited to two hours because of the crowds...you could spend a whole day in the Gallery alone. Well worth the visit.

Fantastic!. This is a wonderful museum and the marble statues are breathtaking in quality. I really enjoyed the fact that they don't allow cameras so everyone gets to take in the art with no distractions. They also only allow a limited number of people at set times, which again is really pleasant, compared to the Vatican museums! Finally don't bother with the fast track VIP tickets available from some websites, they get you in no quicker but you just pay more. Note - that all belongings including handbags needs to be checked into the cloakroom before hand.

Avoid the pitfalls!. We did not buy tickets online but went indoor and bought them directly. Look online for the ticket office opening hours if you do this. The next available tickets were for three days ahead and there was a 2 Euro reservation charge per person. As we are over 65 and EU citizens we didn't have to pay for the tickets. This is true for many museums in Rome. You need your passport as proof of age. Having got lost getting there the first time we took the advice given at the ticket office and took the bus 910 from Termini. This stops in the road to the side of the villa, a hundred metres from the Galeria. Take nothing with you otherwise you will have to queue to leave the stuff and collect it afterwards....and they charge, take only a wallet or whatever that can fit in your pocket. You get 2 hours in there but I would say that it is as much as the average person can absorb in the time of what is an intense and concentrated experience with some real show stoppers. The quality of the collection is overwhelming. It should be remembered that this place is not like a regular art gallery with a representative and balanced collection but instead the collection of mainly one family at a particular period in time. I had one of the best art experiences ever and for my personal outlay of 2 Euros to go in plus 3 Euros total in bus fares (apart from London where galleries are free) it was cheap as chips as we say at home!

Interesting Gallery !. Borghese Gallery is a must if you only have time for one museum or gallery. Their reservation process is GREAT. Our apartment host made our reservations by phone 2 days before. You are given a set time during the day and your visit is for 2 hours, therefore numbers are limited. NO PUSHING CROWDS ! The sculptures and paintings are magnificent.
Awesome Bernini Sculptures. Some incredible works by Bernini and Caravaggio are included here. You must pre-book your tickets at least a day in advance or you won't get in.

Book plenty in advance. Enjoyed the Borghese very much. The self guided audio tour was plenty of information for me; as someone that has interest in art but haven't read books upon books.
Book plenty in advance as tickets do sell out, and arrive early as the surrounding area, Villa Borghese, it beautiful to spend some time in.

The Statues are from Heaven. This is a MUST see when you are in Rome, you will never experience such a powerful impression of art. Although you can only stay for 2 hours, there are a couple pieces which would warrant standing in awe of just them for 2 hours. Never have we seen such a concentration of art (but a small sample) by this powerfully rich family with an amazing history.

Book Ahead. Well-known to be one of the most impressive museums in Rome--it was even the favorite of two of our local guides. The building itself is amazing as is the collection--primarily statuary on the lower floor (including Bernini masterpieces) and painting on the upper floor. Admission is strictly controlled by time of entry and limited to two hour visits.. Everything, including cameras, is to be checked. Purses are kept under lock and key. Excellent audio guides are available. We purchased our tickets on-line well in advance. This is critical. On the day we were there, entry tickets were sold out for the next eight days!

well worth the trip. Make sure to book your visit to the Galleria Borghese in advance. There is no way to get in there in passing...the collection is beautiful, I discovered the Bernini sculptures and my trip companion loved the Caravaggio paintings. A nice change for the Musei Vaticani.

Galleria Borghese - Outstanding Museum. In our 10 day trip to Rome, Frorence, and Venice, the Borghese Museum was the most outstanding museum we visited. A must in Rome. The Bernini sculptures were the highlight of the trip.

Fabulous Renassaince Art -. I understand some are complaining at restricted viewing - ie must pre-book and 2 hours limit but compared to the queues of other tourist attractions, I think it makes it more enjoyable.. the ground floor sculptures are just out of this world, and then first floor for a huge selection of Italian artwork and some grest introductions to artists I was not previously aware of... and set in fabulous settings, where you can choose to arrive by electric train, segway, mountain bike, dual or quad pedal cars, golf buggies, pedal karts or just old fashioned walking Highly recommended and I have been to Rome several times and the first time here.. will come back

Expensive, yet worth it.. You have to plan in advance and book your ticket in advance. Your allowed up to 2 hours during your visit. Which was plenty of time for me. This place is amazing. Full of beautiful sculptures, paintings, and paintings on the ceilings. Beautiful building. However, the staff is not at all helpful or friendly. It's like they hate there jobs. But ignore there bad attitudes and enjoy the amazing building.
Go for the Bernini sculptures. Loved the Bernini sculptures. Recommend the audio guide despite the fact that it needs to be updated to indicate the correct entrance.

Beautiful collection of baroque sculpture. There are some lovely paintings here but what is special is the collection of sculptures, particularly Bernini. You need to book tickets ahead but the website is very easy to navigate.

Borghese Galleria. I arrived on time to this gallery on my last day in Rome only to find that they had booked a meeting at 1pm and that I had to come back either at 3pm or 5 pm. I opted to stay in the park for the 2 hours and I rented a bike and toured around the park which is pretty. The gallery itself was good but I suppose I felt it was a tad overrated given all the rave reviews. It was worth 2 hours for sure but maybe not the 5 hours that I spent waiting to get in and viewing the gallery. Hopefully, that is an unusual occurrence.

Must see. What makes the Galleria Borghese interesting is not only the fabulous collection of mythical works of art, but also the house itself, with its incredible layout and decorated ceilings. The place is magical. On top of the marble sculptures of all ages, I particularly enjoyed the Caravaggio paintings. Truely unique. Reservations compulsory. Book well in advance!

So glad I went. Thought I had had enough since I spent 6 hours in the Vatican and Museum and Basillica for the umpteenth time the day before. But the Villa Borghese where I had never been in 6 trips to Rome was a highlight. The Bernini sculptures are equal to Michelangelo and his paintings are magnificent. the Gallery is not crowed since you need appoinments and only 350 let in for two hours at a time. The walls and paintings and sculptures are not overwhelming. Excellent experience. A friend said that there would have been so many more magnifiecnt carvings if Michelangelo had not spent 30 or 35 years painting the Sistine Chapel. What magnificent sculptures he would have still produced. .
A must for lovers of Renaissance art. This art collection and setting are unlike any other. Because of their reservation limits, you are able to view the collection up close without crowds.

You'll love it even if you're new to art. This museum is so worth the trip. We went on our first trip to Rome and had no idea how spectacular the sculptures would be. Once we were there, we were blown away. We just went back last month and were just as delighted. The museum is not intimidating and because they control the number of people via reservations, it doesn't get overwhelmingly crowded, so you can actually spend some time looking at everything.You definitely need a reservation, they are almost always sold out. You can make a reservation online (we ordered our tickets through viator and received email vouchers which we exchanged for tickets when we got to the museum), through a travel agent or your hotel. The set up is a little confusing and you have to check knapsacks, umbrellas, etc. but once you're in it's fine. No photos. The audioguide is worth getting, you'll need to give them some ID for the rental which they give back to you when you return the audioguide. We used our driver's license. The museum is situated in the huge Borghese Gardens, and it's a beautiful walk through the park back to the Piazza del Popolo. You'll be rewarded with a great view of the city before heading down to the piazza (perhaps for a gelato!).

Too overrated. Yes, it is nice museum but highly overrated. It did not worse all the trouble for me. There are too many people. They will let you in at exact time, and get you out 2 hours later…. There are very few restrooms for the number of people. There are so many other great museums in Rome without all the hassle.

A manageable art gallery in an authentic setting. We often visit this museum with guests, and rarely you see so many masterpieces in painting and sculpture gathered in such an evocative place. One has to book several days ahead, as small groups are allowed in for two-hour slots, but don't let that put you off. I feel that many works, like Canova's reclining sculpture of Paulina Borghese (Napoleon's sister) and Bernini's Apollo and Daphne, are without rivals anywhere; you can see each unfolding leaf gradually embracing Daphne, transforming her gracefully into a tree. Among the many famous and excellent paintings, I particularly like Antonello da Messina's Portrait of a Man, and Titian's Sacred and Profane Love, as well as Cranach's Venus (wearing only an astounding hat) with a tree trunk and stubby sceptical Cupid making her seem even more elongated. Apart from the exhibits, each room provides a different sort of grandiose architectural appeal. The villa is set in a very large and varied park, so walking back across to the Pincio is indeed pleasant. From there you find yourself above Piazza del Popolo, and by turning right, Villa Medici and the top of the Spanish Steps.

Bernini Bonanza. If you love sculpture, you will love this museum. The numbers allowed in are limited, so make your reservation early. We arranged our tour through our hotel, Boscolo Palace, and had a great guide.

Great stuff, rude staff. Amazing works of art on display, breathtaking sculptures. Too bad the staff is arrogant and rude in maintaining the rigid and bothersome two-hour-timeslot regime. But once you're past them it's (limited) time to enjoy.Be warned: you have to climb a huge staircase to get to the good stuff.

The Best Art in Rome but Make Reservation. So glad I made a reservation in advance, because on the week of our visit, the museum was booked and you couldn't get in without a reservation. You are allowed in for only 2 hours, so don't dally -- there's lots to see! You might want to buy a guidebook ahead of time. Not as overwhelming as some of the other overstuffed museums -- and all the pieces are incredible.

Stunning Colloction of Art. The Borghese Gallery is must see experience. The timed entry system works very well but requires that you make reservations several days in advance.We used the audio tour phones which, if you choose not to use a guide, gives you the rich background of selected pieces. Most interesting were the back stories of out this art was acquired....in some cases by very devious means.Don't miss this exhibit....located in a Park setting which is also fascinating to explore.

Art. We were told this was a must see, personally, I should have done another museum and skipped this one. The rooms were amazing, but I would have enjoyed another place better, and the time restraint is exactly that.

Heaven on earth for the sculpture lover. Two hours is not enough time. If you love sculpture, skip the upper floors and stay on the ground floor. Drink in memories of masterpieces by Bernini and others. Incidentally, the grounds are beautiful as well.

Focusing on the majestic. Mario from Through Eternity Tours took us on a wonderful journey of discovery through the Galleria Borghese. We are so thankful for booking a tour and focus on the major pieces of art. The gallery operates a system of 2-hour slots and so it was great to home in on the most significant pieces. Mario was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic in his delivery, while taking time to answer all questions. It is a magnificent gallery with world renowned pieces, brought alive by our guide.
Breath Taking!. One of the finest art museums in Rome, it features the work of Bernini. Set in the beautiful gardens of the Villa Borghese.

Can't miss while in Rome. I am not an avid art lover....however...you will be floored by the sheer beauty of the art here. I found it more impressive than the Vatican museum....perhaps because of the non crowded environment as well as they only let small groups in every 2 hours. Must book ahead to get tix. Bernini sculptures were immaculate, and each room offered something amazing. A must see while in Rome. You can't bring any bags/cameras etc in, and pics on books don't do this place justice. Go see it!!

Must See!. You need a reservation but this is a must see place to visit. Beautiful works of art - the Bernini sculpture depicting the rape of Persephone is visceral. Make sure you go for a walk in the park afterwards - it's beautiful.

Unlike the Vatican, a beautiful and enriching experience. If you have time only for one or two major art collections, this must be at the top of your list. You must get tickets in advance via the web. The upside is that this museum is really good about honoring the "timed entrance" slots. Unlike the horrible Vatican experience, this fine art museum really honors its own presence by limiting the crowd, so you can stroll through at a leisurely pace and absorb the jaw dropping art and actually feel up close and personal, versus vying with a crowd to see the objects. Don't worry about the "end time" of your 2 hour time selection; it is just to regulate the entrance and no one will be trying to kick you out!
The best for sculptures.. This little place had spectacular Benini sculptures. You only get two hours so be early and purchase tickets in advance! Our favorite part of Rome.

A great collection but a customer service glitch. The art was amazing (Bernini, sculptures, Caravaggio paintings, etc., etc.) and the building is located within a beautiful park. And it's quality over quantity: the museum is not overly large so the visit will not wear you out. Another must-see if you are in Rome and you like art.What made this rating "average" was the problematic customer service. Because the gallery only lets a certain number of visitors in at a time, and for a fixed (2-hour) period, it is strongly advised to make reservations well in advance. We did so, and were given reservations from 3 pm to 5 pm, with instructions to show up at 2:30 pm to pick up our tickets, check our bags, etc. so we could take full advantage of our two hours. We arrived well before 2:30 and found a sign on the door that the building was closed from 1 to 3 pm for a "worker's assembly." Not only did this make it impossible for us get in early, as we had been instructed, but all of the people who had been scheduled for the 1 to 3 pm slot were standing around wondering what to do. At 3 pm the door (there was only one) opened and a mob of people--all of the 3 pm bunch and many of the 1 pm bunch--swarmed in and descended on the ticket desk. Luckily, we had been very close to the door and therefore got our tickets quickly and lost only 15 minutes from our two hours. But as far as I can tell, the 1:00 group was simply out of luck, and the 3:00 people who were at the back of the pack probably spent a significant part of their two hours standing in line. As far as I know, they got kicked out at 5:00 so the next group could come in.The point of all this--and the reason for the middlin' review--is that there was never any explanation, and as far as I could tell, no sympathy or efforts to accommodate, from the staff. I have no idea what a "worker's assembly" is, or how often they take place, so maybe there is something I am missing. What we experienced may be a rare occurrence. But the attitude seemed to be "it happens, and there's nothing we can do to make it right."

Exceptional!. The Bernini sculptures here are breathtaking - easily worth visiting the gallery for these alone and everything else in the collection (which is fabulous) is simply the icing on the cake! The famous Canova sculpture is also wonderful. We found the two hour time slot about right and we didn't find the gallery crowded at all. A real pleasure to visit!

One of Rome's "Must-Do" Attractions. Buy your tickets well before your trip - the Galleria Borghese sells out quickly, and for good reason: it is one of the most beautiful art museums you will ever see. The sculptures and paintings presented are simply stunning. Make sure to reserve your time and show up on time, and be aware that you will have to check your bags.
Gorgeous gallery. If you like villas and Bernini sculptures then should wills enjoy this Galleria. Beautiful park setting and incredible collection of Bernini's.
fabulous!. They limit the amount of people in the place at any given time. Get your tickets before leaving home because the next available ones when we were there weren't available for six days.

Some of the best!. For me, the works of Bernini were worth the price alone. Absolutely amazing! Much more to this museum as well though it didn't feel overwhelming to. It seems to be a place that draws students of art and those with a more intense love for art. I'm learning - and really enjoyed it.You definitely have to make reservations. It was an easy thing to do online at their website. Great place to utilize Romapass but call for reservation instead of website. I went without guide/audio guide and wouldn't have minded a little more info. There are cards in each room that are handy - but not all seemed to match the right room. It's nice that you can get a check-in time - but that means everyone enters at once and it's kind of hectic checking your bags. Get there earlier than your check-in time. You will have to check something because they don't allow bags, cameras, etc.
The words themselves make me smile - Galleria Borghese. If you like art, one of the world's gems. Reservations are essential, and can take a few weeks in high season. Book ahead.

Wow. Book well in advance: we went on Wednesday and the first tickets for sale were for the following Saturday. The internet site works well but only the Paypal option worked for me. Bernini statues blew me away especially Apollo and Persephone, and David. Caravaggios also astonishing. Advice from me would be to start downstairs. Ask because the info and signage is dire. But that is the charm of Rome is it not?

Make sure you book in advance.. This was the highlight of my trip to Rome. The sculpture (particularly the sculpture by Bernini) was haunting. Unfortunately, I did not realise that the visit was time limited so I lingered too long on some items and missed out on many of the paintings. Still, that gives me an excuse to return.

Fantastic Gardens, Art overload!. We booked tickets in advance for this gallery, it was very reasonably priced. We walked there up Via Veneto and grabbed an ice cream on the way. It is set in beautiful grounds and my children loved playing in the park afterwards while we sat and rested in the sun.The gallery itself has some beautiful pieces, there is just so much, it is gluttonous in its collection, and too much of a good thing springs to mind. However, it was a nice visit with some standout pieces. Don't expect friendly staff but you can spend a quiet hour or so before or after your visit in the grounds in this rather well heeled neighbourhood in Rome.

Amazing artwork and beautiful location. Galleria Borghese is one of the best places I visited during my trip to Rome! I am an art student and one of my instructors told me to not leave Rome without seeing this collection of art. I am a huge lover of Bernini and this has the best collection of Bernini works I've seen. It is difficult not to be captivated by the art in this gallery. Even the non art lover can appreciate the collection here. A trip to Rome would not be complete without visiting Galleria Borghese. Make sure to book your ticket in advance and show up early just to walk around Villa Borghese while you wait to enter the gallery. Truly an experience not to be missed and is one of the best parts of Rome!!

Just breathtaking!. My husband and I went to the Galleria after we heard about it in Frommer's guide and we were not disappointed. This was in fact, my husband's favorite place out of all the places we visited. The fresco's were nothing sort of awe-inspiring. Every painting and marble sculpture are more beautiful than words can describe. Even the grounds around the galleria were beautiful. On the walk up the road to the galleria was a man playing Bach Toccata and Fugue in D minor, which just added to the atmosphere. One thing I will advise is to book in advance and be there at least a half hour before. If you arrive later THEY WILL NOT LET YOU IN!! One very angry guest was not happy when he arrived too late and they would not let him in. This is good though in a way; because they only allow so many people in at once, it means you do not have to compete with crowds to see anything. You can stroll for as long as you wish with relative comfort. Definitely worth checking out if you come. Its a bit out of the way, but worth it!!

Fabulous Art But Book Well Ahead. We lucked into two tickets for the last tour of the day on our last day in Rome. Not inexpensive but worth the price. I love statues but the statue of Apollo and Daphne by Bernini took my breath away. His work is marvelous, but this one simply takes the cake. It took us 70 min. to go through at a very quick pace, you only have a two hour time frame and I pity the true art connoisseur who wants to view every piece.....make arrangements to return, you'll need it.

Nice but a little overated. We did this Gallery the last day we were in Rome after reading all of the tripadvisor reviews. Unless you are a die hard art type of person I question how this particular gallery has such a high rating. I enjoyed it but there are other galleries in Italy that I thought were better. The colliseum it certainly higher on my list than this gallery as far as sights are concerned. Nice but not sure its worth the hassle of getting the tickets an standing in line.

NOT WORTH WAITING 4 DAYS. When I went the slots were sold out and they were taking reservations for 4 days later. The line was long just to find that out. The park is wonderful and we spent the better part of the day exploring the park. Skip it and enjoy the (free) park.

Superb collection. Every time I am in Rome, I go to the Borghese. It is an exquisite exhibition and one that my wife and I always enjoy. Just to view the Bernini Apollo and Daphne is alone worth the visit.

I Am Sure It Would Have Been Excellent If We Got In. Please note, that if you want to gain entry to this landmark, you need to book it at least a week or two before. Nobody told us this, so we could not gain entry as we were only in Rome for four nights and they were booked a week ahead.Learn from our mistake.

A long awaited visit. A beautiful gallery set in amazing gardens. In order to preserve the art in the gallery they only allow a certain amount of visitors a day so you must book in advance if you want to go and you only get a 2 hour time slot so don't be late.
Great Gallery. Reserve ahead of time. Great collection, I love air-conditioning but I love the art more. The works by Bernini and Caravaggio are amazing.

Don't Miss It!. What an experience! Do not miss this attraction while in Rome if you love art. Although I am not Christian, the works are magnificent, and there are enough non-religious items to satisfy. Even if you only see the magnicent sculpture "Apollo and Daphne" the entrance fee is well worth it. Make sure you reserve online well in advance. Tickets when we went were selling out 2-3 months in advance. They only allow a certain number of visitors in for 2 hour blocks of time.

Beautiful but reserve ahead. Beautiful works of art in a building with amazing architecture! And a very manageable size so you don't get museum fatigue. Be sure to book tickets ahead online. We did and when we went they were sold out for the next 5 days. Also arrive at least a half hour early to get through the baggage check (mandatory) and audioguide lines so you don't waste any of your 2 hours. I would strongly recommend the audio guide as the signage was poor.
grand. if your an art lover the villa Borghese is a must, Caravaggio paintings, grand sculptures and beautiful ceilings that you can look at for hours

Must see gallery for art lovers. We visited a number of museums on our recent trip to Italy, and the Borghese Gallery is at the top of our "must see" list. For a little more money than an audio tour, we explored the gallery with a guide who obviously loved the artwork and did a wonderful job of teaching us about it. After having toured the Vatican Museums, we especially appreciated the fact that entrance to the Borghese Gallery is limited, so we had room to breathe and enjoy what we were seeing. The gallery is best known for its Bernini sculptures, which are truly amazing. We also enjoyed viewing paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. After the tour, we took a leisurely walk through the adjacent gardens. Be sure to make reservations in advance because you don't want to miss this!
Don't miss this!. We loved the fabulous statues and paintings here! Make reservations ahead of time!! The grounds are gorgeous too and you could spend a full day here if you wanted.

Beautiful Gallery. Arranged tour with Viator - very hot day, stuffy rooms. (don't the europeans get it yet that Americans LOVE air conditioning!?)Beautiful works by Bernini. No horrible hustle like at The Vatican Museums. Guide Redecca was good.
Opulence at its best. If you want a taste of history - this is the place to be. Make sure you reserve well in advance since they restrict the number of people that are allowed per day.

Incredible art. It was raining the day we went, so didn't get to enjoy the beautiful park setting as much as we would have liked. Be sure to bring your own water. Stands in park were outrageously priced at 4 euros for a bottle of water!. Cafe in Galleria was closed.The Galleria offered some of the most amazing art we saw. And that is saying something in Rome. Many paintings and sculpture. You'll need the full two hours to enjoy the beauty. Unfortunately, no photos allowed.

An exceptional collection. The sculptures and artworks were exceptional. We bought the book to take home as a momento. It's a good idea to buy your tickets online beforehand as visits are only on a Saturday and are restricted to two hours. Follow your visit with a stroll through the gardens for great views over Rome.

Make Sure You Reserve Prior To Going. We got our reservations early, so we were happy. We did see people being turned away. They let you in for a 2 hour visit (which is sufficient) and they are very strict about that. You check your bags (mandatory) and walk through this incredible gallery of sculptures and paintings. It is awesome. The building itself is beautiful, as well. My favorite piece was Apollo and Daphne (Bernini) and you can get right up close to really get a good look. Walk around the gardens as, well. Kind of like Central Park! We were there on a dreary, drizzly day so it wasn't so nice to walk around, the it was beautiful just the same!

A really pleasant surprise. I did not expect the fantastic art and sculptures in this gallery. It is a truly special gallery and well worth the effort of pre booking and making this part of your trip to Rome.

Best museum in Rome. Whatever you do, make sure you reserve your tickets before you travel to Rome. Tickets to the museum sell out days in advance. You will not be disappointed. The focal point of the museum are the great sculptures of Bernini.....my personal favorite, Apollo and Daphne. The Pinacoteca has an excellent collection of paintings as well. You will want to visit this museum after any others you visit in the city (with the exception of the Vatican). Other museums pale in comparison to this one. If you enjoy Italian art, this is a must see when you visit Rome. While you are waiting for your appointment, walk the grounds which are beautiful.

Beautiful museum. A gem of a museum in Rome. You need to book it ahead of time as they limit the number of visitors each hour by reservation. The audio guide is a bit confusing at first but once you understand the system it works fine. Incredible selection of sculptures and paintings by Bernini, Canova, Caravaggio, Titan, Raphael and Ruben.

Ready, steady, art. The gallery's policy of limiting both the number of visitors at any one time and the amount of time available to visit makes this one of the most pleasurable museums to visit in the world. Especially with kids.There are no queues to see the most famous of the art-works, you can go against the crowd and start with the upper floor (concentrating largely on paintings before descending to the sculptures), and the little ones can always see around the big people, rather than being lost in a forest of bodies.The set-time for the beginning of the visit does make it seem as though you need to get there well before your time to check in your bags and cameras (the only queue we endured), but in fact we were able to take in as much as we could in well-under the allotted 2 hours.I was very anxious not to miss out, as the building conceived as a gallery holds some of the greatest works by the great masters of Western Art & sculpture including Titian's Sacred and Profane Love, Caravaggio's David and Goliath (and sick Bacchus self-portrait) and some stupendous sculptures by Bernini, including Apollo and Daphne and the abduction of persephone as well as the notorious Canova masterpiece of Pauline Bonaparte. That's without speaking of Lucas Cranach the elder, Parmigianino, Fra'Bartholomeo, Dosso Dossi, Bassano, Raphael, Reubens and many many others whose works would be worthy of a visit for them alone.So with the help of the wonderful Rossana at Caesar House we made securing a booking the highest priority on our arrival. Lucky for us, as the first available slot, on the Saturday afternoon, was for the following Wednesday at 1pm. And sure enough, when we arrived, there was one disappointed tourist hoping against hope for a no-show in order not to miss out as all tickets were already booked up for the next 3 days.Easily the kids' favourite art museum, had it not rained we would have completed a lovely afternoon discovering the Borghese Gardens by 4-person bike. It's also worth noting that children who are european citizens have a discount rate that does not apply to mere residents of Europe (pity the same can't be said of the taxes we pay) so those with children with European citizenships may want to bring your/ your children's passports at the time of booking.
Great Art. This was a wonderful museum, Wasn't too crowded. The art was amazing. Enjoyed this museum way more the over crowded Vatican.

MAKE SURE YOU BOOK IN ADVANCE!. This is one muesum we really wanted to do and we couldnt. They must only allow a certain number each day which is actually a good idea unlike other sites where you spend more time moving around people then actually enjoying and appreciating what you came for and you dont waste half a day lining up. Anyway it is a popular museum with a great park outside to relax in so you need to book tickets in advance, from what i have gathered at least three to four days. And i dont think it is open Mondays, there is one day it is closed.
Beautiful gardens. We went there and the weather was not very nice, but worth a check, specially if you like gardens.It is close to Piazza di Spagna and you can go walking from there.

The most beautiful museum in Rome. Of course, this is my own personal opinion: Galleria Borghese is the most beautiful museum in Rome, maybe in Italy. It is just outstanding with outstanding works of sculpture (AND paintings, but mainly sculpture). Just seeing a few of the works by Canova is worth the visit. But the Galleria has much much more. My friends and relatives who usually frown on passing a day in a museum rather than out visiting the city have all fallen in love with this museum.

A gorgeous afternoon outing. The Borghese museum is situated in the lovely Villa Borghese gardens. Take a picnic lunch and enjoy the gardens before you head into the museum. You must book your tour of the museum well in advance, easy to do online, and pick up your tickets in the lower floor of the museum just before your allotted time. The museum is not large, but houses the incredible sculotures of Gian Lorenzo Bernini, including his captivating statue of David. After seeing Bernini's statues, it is hard to look at any other statues without comparing them to Bernini's, as they will undoubtedly fall short. Because they limit the number of people in the gallery at any one time, you can fully appreciate all of the art and not have to fight the crowds in the process. The garden and museum make for a gorgeous afternoon outing - a must do while in Rome!

Can't wait to go back!. I am no student of art, but on a recent trip to Rome, I took a friend's advice and visited the Galleria Borghese. The grounds are beautiful, with statues, fountains and an overlook that will give you dramatic views of Rome. Inside, the works of art are amazing and I fell in love instantly with the works of Bernini. So much history here.....what a wonderful afternoon and looking forward to my return.

Excellent collection. Come here if you're interested in seeing one of the greatest private collections of Renaissance and Baroque art - the galleria is situated in the beautiful Borghese park easily accessible by subway. Rent the audio guide, it will help guide and enhance your understanding of some of the more prominent works of art housed here, like Bernini's sculpture of Appollo e Dafne, a true masterpiece. Stroll through the park after with a gelato to complete your visit to this gallery.

Just wonderful. Went to the Galleria Borghese and loved it. I wanted to see the statue of David in particular and was not disappointed. I reserved my time slot on line which is highly recommended as when I went they were allowing preserved tickets only. I bought a Roma pass which entitles you to the first two entries to tourist attractions (excluding the Vatican), public transport and discounts on the remaining attractions for €34 This worked out to be good value as the cost of the ticket was €13. You are allowed two hours in the gallery and are not allowed to take your bags/cameras into the gallery (these are left in a secure locker whilst inside the gallery). I found the audio guide really helpful (€5). The Galleria Boghese was one of the highlights of my trip. Worth visiting if you are into art or just like looking at nice things!
One of the best galleries in the world. I think this is one of the best galleries in the world surrounded by a very nice park. The park is also nice location for running.

Book ahead and enjoy!. This gallery is amazing, you MUST book ahead for a 2 hour time slot-when we visited the tickets were sold out for the following 4 days! We arrived early for our 5-7pm slot and visited the bookshop in the gallery basement first. We bought a book called 10 Masterpieces of the Borghese Gallery and had a look through it while we waited to go in. it really added to our visit. We went upstairs to the Picture Gallery first, signs tell you that you will be allowed 30 minutes in here but in fact this is not enforced. However you will definitely want to leave plenty of time for the galleries downstairs where there are the most beautiful sculptures by Bernini which truly have to be seen to be believed. Along with stunning paintings and the gorgeous surroundings of the building itself, this gallery is one of our favourite places in Rome.

Uncomparable. Speaking of the works of Bernini, Canova and Caravaggio, Villa Borghese is the place to go. Plus a number of other icons in art history like Tizian's "Sacred and Profane Love". The strict reservation policy -- advanced booking via internet is mandatory -- helps to canalize the stream of visitor's. We found no room overcrowded, had in fact time and space to look at the colelction undisturbed.

My favorite museum. I love this place. I wish it was still the way it used to be in the 1980s and before (dating myself!) when you could just walk in. But it's still a fabulous museum, beautifully designed for the artwork itself, and the rooms are a treat to see and admire when looking at the art since they go so beautifully together.We had to book 6 weeks ahead for our group, and it was all quite smooth and efficient. They only allow you 90 minutes but most of the group was fine with that. I would have loved a bit more time but I'll just have to come back, no hardship there.Favorites: Bernini sculptures, Canova sculptures, and the paintings - all of them....

Beautiful art, terrible management. I have read everything about this place and reserved my tickets about 3 weeks prior to our arrival. It was our last day in Rome and we had a flight out that evening. We had a reservation for 1 PM and we got there early (at 12:15), when we got to the ticket office we were informed to our amazement, that the museum will be closed between 1 and 3 PM. We were obviously very upset and the guy said we could come back at 3 or 5 PM, which was no good for us since we had a flight to catch. Then the guy said that we could go in from now until 1 PM (it was 12:20 by then). We took him up on that offer since we didn't have any choice. He charged us 2 Euros a person and got upset with us about not having exact change (we didn't bring our purses as we knew we couldn't take them into the museum...).We got in and rushed through the museum. The art is beautiful and there are so many works of art there. We saw the famous statues of Daphne turning into a tree and the rape of Persephone, that were indeed magnificent, but we were rushed to finish our visit at around 12:50, so we only had a decent half hour there.I will not be back there and will not recommend it to my friends. A place that has such strict rules must be the first one to uphold them. We enjoyed the Vatican museums much more (separate review).

A very civilized museum and gallery. It is essential to book tickets well in advance as an unplanned attempt to visit will almost certainly result in disappointment. Visitors are admitted in groups of about 100 and have two hours to view the galleries (which is ample time). These arrangements allow you to tour the rooms without feeling overcrowded. The museum houses the finest collection of Bernini's statues not in a religious setting, Canova's sculpture of Napoleon's sister and paintings by several masters including Titian. The rooms themselves are richly ornate and would be worth a visit on their own merit. Walk to the museum through the lovely gardens of the Villa Borghese and enjoy a distinctly civilized experience (as long as you booked in advance). We found Select Italy's website (based in Chicago) a simple and very efficient way of getting our tickets in advance (tickets sent electronically about one month prior to departure and presented without fuss at the Gallery ticket office upon arrival).

WOW.. Book your tickets online because if you just show up, chances are there are no more tickets for that day. You are allotted a specific time that you can be in the gallery (and you pick your time when you buy your ticket) and WARNING: Do not be late! You do not want to miss out on anything in this gallery. The Bernini statues are the most beautiful things I have ever seen in my entire life. The David statue is jaw-dropping; you want to touch it even though that's not allowed. The paintings are just as inspiring. Afterward, you can stroll through the garden and just take in the amazingness of the experience.

A must-see for art and history buffs. Highly recommended by Rick Steves, and he was dead on. Get there at least 30 minutes ahead to get your ticket and sign up for the English-language tour. Our tour guide introduced us to 17th-century papal politics, Bernini and Caravaggio, all new to us. The Bernini scupture has to be seen to be understood and enjoyed. All-in-all a thrilling experience. Also, the surrounding park is wonderful.

Great Experience. They do a wonderful job in limiting the crowds with timed and ticketed entry. I wish all museums would adopt this method. It allows you to appreciate the art without the ridiculous crowds found at other Italian tourist attractions. I actually enjoyed this musuem more than the Vatican.
Must visit if you love art. The sculptures are amazing , don't expect to spend the day but it is a must visit when in Rome , we visited in the winter so we did not get the chance to tour the gardens.
Must visit if you love art. The sculptures are amazing , don't expect to spend the day but it is a must visit when in Rome , we visited in the winter so we did not get the chance to tour the gardens.

One of my favorites in all of Rome.. This museum is on my "A" list! Perhaps my favorite in all of Europe. Be sure & schedule an appointment as they ore very subscribed. You can make a reservation on line.

Abandon the Nightmare of the Spanish Steps & Relax Here!. Escape the tourist-traps and enjoy this shaded glade of quiet elegance under the watchful (mostly nose-free) gaze of the Classical/Renaissance busts. A perfect place to munch your scalding-hot portable pizza and glug your bottled water - filled for free at the ice-cold public fountains. You can even have a free pee at the public lavatory: a rarity for Rome!

You can miss it!. It is unbelievable!The place of the Villa,everything!
Inside even if you are not fond of art like me,you will be lost with all these great pieces of art!
I was drew away with the Daphne Status..
A Must See. This is a must see in Rome. Amazing art and sculptures in an amazing building. This is often overlooked, but definitely try to find time to visit.

Temple of art. The collection of paintings and statues is absolutely amazing, the decoration of the ceiling and the walls is very ornate.it's a trip through Renaissance and the Baroque era with plenty exhibits.It's definitely worth a visit but it is mandatory to book your ticket online or by telephone.This is because only a particular number of people (around 350 I think) are allowed to enter every two hours, which is very good because it is not crowded like the Vatican museums for example.You present your voucher which you printed when booking and paying the tickets on line and they print the actual tickets for you.These tickets you must present in the second entrance of the gallery in order to enter.You are not allowed to enter the gallery with a purse or camera and you must deliver them to the counter they have for this reason.You can keep your wallet with you.You are also given the possibility to rent audioguide at the price of 5 euros.The gallery is situated inside the villa Borghese wich is a huge park also offering a zoo, a beautiful lake and it is ideal for a long walk after or before visiting the gallery.

Don't Miss This!. The Villa Borghese is a fabulous museum with some of the greatest sculpture ever made! Absolutely amazing! The building is fantastic too. Don't forget to look at the ceilings.The two hour timed limit works really well. It keeps the crowds down and is enough time in the museum. The staff is a little short with you during the last minute crush, but not bad.They say to come 15 minutes before your entry time, but I would recommend 30, as there is a last minute hub-bub of people trying to get their tickets and check their bags.You MUST have advance tickets to get in. The Villa is at the back of the park and somewhat hard to find, so either leave time for a long walk from central Rome, or take a cab. We took a cab there and walked back. The park was pleasant, but not that special.I love this place! It was my second visit, the first was just after it re-opened. My first trip to fabulous Rome the Villa was closed for renovations-I was heart-broken

Galleria Borghese. Took a tour with Mario, guide for Through Eternity. The gardens are beautiful, so much green in one place.Mario our tour guide was extremely well informed and passionate about the wonderful collections at this museum. There was one room dedicated, well almost all of it to Caravaggio. Mario went through one detail after another so we could appreciate the complete paintings. Thanks again Mario, the pleasure was ours.Good luck
Overwhelming. An overwhelming collection of paintings and fabulous sculpture. Unfortunately, you only get 2 hours inside and then are ushered out quite abruptly.

Love it!. Love Galleria Borghese and its gorgeous collection of statues and artwork. The villa itself is a sight to see and you can't get better than the park around it. Apollo and Daphne is beyond imagination!

Impressed me far more than the Musei Vaticani. This collection is truly amazing, especially the Bernini statues. Somehow the hard marble seems more like wax or even flesh than stone, and the characters portrayed strongly show emotion and an illusion of movement or momentum, which older sculptures often lack.
If you have a chance to go here when in Rome, make sure to do so!

One of the best in Rome--Reserve in Advance. This old palace was converted to make it into a museum. The incredible high ceilings covered in fresco's and large windows letting in light combine to provide an amazing backdrop for this art collection. The collection is a combination of sculptures and paintings and it is a WOW. The sculptures are some of the finest in the world and when you look at them they almost seem to come alive.....they are that good! The Best of the best is located downstairs and there is also an upstairs that also has some nice artwork (and a restroom on the way)....You cannot miss this when in Rome, We go everytime we visit the city. You MUST reserve online in advance at least 30 days or you will not get in. Rome is filled with tourists and this museum is strictly capacity controlled. fyi.

Amazing. Four of us traveling through Rome and with out hesitation, this is a must do! It was suggested in Rick Steves to the do the top floor first. We highliy agree. The first floor is so amazing, save it. Pay particular attention to Bernini's sculptures. Breath taking. Be sure to walk around them observing all you can.We reserved these by phone, but be sure to get an email confirmation. When, in Rome, purchase a Roma Pass which gives you free admission to your first two museums. Be sure to use it for the Borghese. Then, you can skip all lines, with your reservation, show your pass, and go right in to the top floor.

What a disappointment. Nice trip on the metro and pleasant walk through the park. Really upset to go all the way to find out when we got there that all the tickets were sold for the next 10 days. Communication is not their strong point.

One word - Amazing!!. For the Bernini sculptures alone I would not miss this museum! I loved the fact that you had to make a reservation and it was limited to a smaller amount of people. We went to the Louvre and the Orsay and while the art was amazing both were a bit of a downer because of the crowds. You could walk around freely in this museum and didn't have to battle your way to the front of any given painting or sculpture to look closely. Because of the controlled size of the group 2 hours was plenty of time. We made our reservation online with our credit card a month in advance. On the day of our reservation we arrived 1 hour before our allotted time. We showed them the printout of our reservation (don't just rely on showing them your phone - actually bring the printed receipt) and we were given our admission tickets. Then we walked through the book store and bought a book on the Borghese masterpieces. It was great to have the book (we also rented the audio guides) for reference as we were walking through the museum and is a wonderful souvenir to take home. We spent 12 days in Europe visiting all kinds of museums, sights etc... and this was one of our very favorite things we did. I could easily go back and marvel at it all over again!

WOW!!. The Bernini works are the highlight of the collection. With one exception his works compare with Michaelangelo's David in Florence. Book/pay for your tickets in advance to insure your admission. Before or afterwards you can take a leisurely stroll through the Gardens/park.

BRAVO!. A museum hidden in the beauty of the biggest park in Rome. Be sure to make advance reservations online or you won't be able to get into this beautiful museum. Paintings and sculpture abound. A must for any lover of the works of Bernini but also for lovers of art in general. You only get 2 hours to explore the treasures so you might want to consider a private tour guide or at the very least rent the audio guide to make the best use of the limited time allowed.
Bernini sculptures.. I fell in love with Bernini's sculptures, what absolute beauty, they took my breath away.Unfortunately we did not have time to wander in the gardens, but they looked beautiful.

Borghese.... One thing to say... Well maybe two...Make arrangements well in advance...If you do, you will be very happy you took the time to make the effort.A bit of a hike but the grounds are well kept and the villa...Well this is what you came for...An amazing private collection...

Pre-book tickets!!. We turned up this May on a Tuesday, but apparently there were no more walk-in places to see the museum until Sunday. Not allowed to use the toilet unless you have a ticket and spent 20 mins walking around the gardens (which are OK) in heavy rain trying to find the public toilets, sign posts didnt lead to the cafe or toilets and we just left. Museum of modern art and Piazza del popolo nearby to have a look at though.

Sold out - but you won't find out until you get there. We took the long walk to the museum only to find it had sold out when we got there, and were only taking bookings for the next week. Considering the villa is quite a hike through extensive (but beautiful) woodland, it would've been nice to have been informed sooner. Just a small kiosk with a sign to say no tickets were available would've been good. If you are intending to visit, check availability online.

Excellent and Worth the Effort. Make the effort to get your tickets. This was a great museum. Worth it to see Apollo and Daphne statue alone! We used the Roma pass and had to call about 2 weeks prior to our visit to make reservations. We did not have to pay with the Roma pass even though it was our third attraction. We paid for the audio guides - worth it. And the 2 hours they recommend is perfect. It's not overcrowded like other museums (except for the gift shop) which makes it very pleasant experience.

It's really something. See it to believe it.. The art collection is really gd and varied from painted masterpieces by Carravaggio, to marble sculptures by master sculptor Loreno Bernini. The audio guide is a must-have in order to best understand the art, artist, and even the history of how the Borghese family went about collecting these works or art. One of the best audio guides we've heard during our time in italy this far - lively voice with appropriate background music. The grounds around the galleria villa is also a sight to behold on weekends with families picnicking, joggerz n walkers abundant with their dogs in tow etc.

Unkept but beautiful. Maybe it is because of the Italian economy being in the dumps, but even though the gallery is beautful, the buildings are slowly crumbling and the gardens are unkept. In its heyday it must have been truly amazing. Today is a great park for the Romans to spend a great Sunday or holiday with their families, having a picinic and enjoying the company of their loved ones.

Go there. The Gardens are a lovely place to spend some down time but the Galleria is one of the most amazing places I have been to. The sculptures and the paintings are just incredible. Make sure you book in advance as it is often booked out for at least a week ahead.

Buy tickets in advance and take the audio guide.. Visitors are let in about 300 at a time for two hour blocks. This means that the you should plan ahead a little. Go online and purchase your tickets about a week before starting your trip. To get your tickets at the gallery, you will need a "pick-up" code that is in the email receipt sent to you after purchasing the tickets. The code is kind of in the middle of the email so look closely for it. Of course, the gallery is really amazing. The walls are stunning. the art is breathtaking. Because the amount of visitors is strictly controlled, you can really see the art works.

Great Sculptures. We went mainly for the great display of sculptures and were not disappointed. Be sure to get a guide book or audio guide before your visit as tours are limited to just two hours. As others mention, reservations are required unless you really luck out and catch the museum on a slow day. The museum is quite a hike but the garden setting is a great escape from the city streets!

Magnificant Estate. I am so glad we included the Villa Gourghese and the Borghese Gardens in our tours of Rome. The paintings, sculptures, and ceiling fescos were some of the best in the city. Our tour guide was a your lady from the Netherlands and spoke multiple languages extremely well. This was a small group tour and we did not have to wait in line. All of our Dark Rome tour groups were small and we enjoyed allof the guides and found only one who could have spoken English a little more clearly.

Second time and even better experience. This gallery is a jewel itself. This gallery is located in a beautiful park near upscale neighborhoods. I would suggest booking your tickets ahead of time and purchasing audio-tour there. The park is very peaceful and we had an enjoyable time there.

Most beautiful sculptures. Wonderful and relatively small museum. The sculptures are fabulous. Make a reservation. Wonderful location in the park too. We went in the morning and it wasn't busy. We had made our reservation online.

Try this if you don't have a reservation. If you don't have a reservation, allow all of the people who have a reservation queue up and get in at their designated time. The lines will get shorter as you get close to the hour. Get in the queue toward the end of the line with the 10-15 people who show up not holding a reservation. If you get to the front of the line and the ticket attendant asks if you have a reservation and you say "no", they will tell you it's sold out and not possible to get in. They might be rude and abrupt. My advice is stick around and be persistent. At the last minute they will open up the line and allow non reservation holders in to purchase tickets. Some people who are turned away leave and and people who stick around get in with a swift nod just past the hour. It worked for us and the 10-15 or so people like us without a reservation. Don't be intimidated by the ticket cashiers.

The elegance of the Borhese collection!. A well kept institute of art on the Borghese grounds is a quite and relaxing experience. The history and evolution of this villa adds to the beauty and totality of the galleria.

Great sculptures. A nice display of sculptures in a nice setting. Buy your tickets before you go or you may be disappointed. They only allow a limited number in at a time, which makes for a great chance to see some fantastic sculptures up close without the crowds of some other museums in Rome. Nice gardens to stroll through on the way in and out. I'd go back in a heartbeat.

Very interesting and beautiful!. Loved this gallery and a must see. The things I disliked the most, was not very organized with getting people in and was very, very noisy. The garden ground is huge and if you have time, please do take a stroll.

Worth a visit but make a reservation and a watch out. It has been a rainy day so out off the Metro we went with a quick walk to the beautifull park to the Villa Borghese.The park is worth a visit to relax, if the weather is beautifull you can have a pinic.There are restaurants ,rent a sort of bikes.When we arrived we were happy that we made a online reservation otherwise no entry at all at Villa Borghese.You have to give your back and so to a special collecting point.Just do it otherwise you can't go in.When you go in there's a wow a big one , mozaik floors ,paintings ,the painted ceiling ,and the art off Bernini.It's really beautifull there are several rooms to walk through.Villa Borghese is one off the treasure in Rome and worth a visit.

Terrific museum. Well worth the trip. Make sure you reserve at least a couple days in advance otherwise you probably will not get in. They only let about 300 in for 2 hours so it is not too crowded. You can take the small electric bus from downtown and it drops you off a short distance from the museum.

long trip to it!!. The Villa is located far away but worth all the efforts. Make sure you book your entry before!! At least a week before you plan to visit ! We had luck but the bookings were done until the 7th day upfront!

If you don't like art don't go. Went on a 3 hour tour so we could skip the line. Way to long. I would rather just have an audio guide and go on my own. It your not an art lover just visit the gardens free of charge. Tour was way too expensive $440 for 5 people

Make sure to book before you go. Six important Caravaggio's can be found in the Borghese. Cardinal Scipio Borghese - a contemporary of Caravaggio - was a huge fan and managed to acquire lots of the painters work - by fair means or foul! Beautiful sculptures and fabulous paintings set in pretty gardens. An essential part of a trip to Rome, but do book before you arrive in Rome as the tickets are timed and sold out many days in advance - so if you are only there for a 4 day stay, you may not be able to get in.

Stunning collection of art. We didn't know exactly what to expect, but were really impressed by the beauty of the art in this museum. There are several sculptures and paintings that are world famous like the ones from Caravaggio. Highly recommended. Only we wished we had booked a guided tour to appreciate it even more
Calm and relaxing. Reserve your space ahead of time.Lovely museum wonderful park.Rent a bike ,pack a picnic enjoy the day

must visit. fantastic, gardens are incredible also. make sure you give yourself time to take it all in. we hired motorised push bike/golf cart which made it even more relaxed and enjoyable (make sure you have photo id for this). great place for picnic also

Great collection -- horrible staff. The collection is a dream. It's a must-see if you have time while in Rome. The gardens surrounding are wonderful and a welcome distraction from the chaos of the city.The staff of the museum, however, are not kind. The staff at the entrance desk are horrible. They yell and are very rude. The staff that are throughout the gallery as guards are too busy on their cell phones to do anything even remotely like work, other than yell "no photos!" at people.Book ahead online and make sure to print out every darn word on your reservation or the rude women at the front desk will pretend that they can't find your reservations any other way (after three tries were were *miraculously* able to find my reservations by my last name. Imagine that!)

Fabulous art- definitely worth a visit. Book on line in advance if at all possible. We had an online reservation made 2 days before which was clearly a good idea because when we got there there they were full for the next week!It was well organized and efficient, and the art is magnificent. Do not miss Bernini's Apollo and Daphne which is sublime. Down side, the cafe was not open at 1pm on a hot day and they do not offer a short guide. Each room however has large plastic covered sheets in several languages which provides a good overview. The rooms are magnificent and some of the walls and ceilings are more wonderful than the paintings. The gardens are really pleasant especially after a hot morning in the streets.

incredible art. Sculpture isn’t my thing and I prefer paintings, but the sculpture here is amazing. Bernini’s three sculptures, Apollo and Daphne, David and the Rape of <can't remember the name now> being the highlights. But the whole rooms are just so impressive on the ground level. I have to admit I was a little disappointed with the first floor art (maybe the bar had been set too high by what I’d already seen - and if the Carravagios on the ground floor had been up there with them it would have made it better). Having said that the two hours you’re given (you only get 2 hours before having to leave) went too quickly and so I didn’t have enough time to do the full first floor. I would have liked at least another hour in there. A highlight of the trip none-the-less (but then I had previously seen the Colosseum and Vatican on a previous trip there, otherwise maybe it wouldn’t have been the highlight). If you love art you should make time for the Borghese in your itinerary (remembering to pre-book of course as you can’t just turn up and get in).
Prebook. Bit chaotic to get in due to crowds and you must prebook time slot. No refresment facilities at time of our visit but Caffe dell'Arte just a short walk away. The museum..memorable.
great sculptures. Although the Galleria is away from the city center it worths a visit but you have to make a reservation first

Small but great. We booked borgese in advance and had to rush through the garden to the place. So I would recommend to come there earlier because finding galleria in the garden turned out to be difficult as we walked from piazza di poppolo.The exhibition is fantastic.once you enter you leave your belongings in the lobby as its obligatory and go to enjoy art. Great art.

Impressive. Well worth the visit. Full of beautiful works of art. Scipione Borghese was a patron of Bernini so many of Bernini's pieces are there. Seeing the Apollo and Daphne alone made the visit for me.

Great collectyion. Easy to book on line which was mandatory. We were late for our timed appointment so we were limited to the remaining one hour.My teen age grandchildren were very impressed by the site as well as the art collection.

A MUST-SEE!. We went to the Museo Borghese during a long trip to Paris, Venice, Florence and Rome. This museum was one of the highlights. Due to the smaller crowds, and smaller venue (as opposed to the large d'Orsay and Huge Lourve) this museum was much more enjoyable. Besides that, the number of Bernini sculptures is impressive and IMO, Bernini is probably histories best sculptor (sorry Michelangelo). Be Advised: you MUST make a reservation. We were there on a Thursday, and they were sold out until late afternoon on the following Saturday! This was in April, which is not nearly as crowded/busy as summer, so make your reservation EARLY or you will miss out on this wonderful museum. Reservations are for 2 hours for set periods: 9-11,11-1,1-3,3-5,or 5-7.Photography is NOT allow, and you will be required to check ALL bags and purses, so if you have something you just don't want to lose hold of, put it in a pocket.

Number one thing to visit in Rome. too many tourists miss out one visiting this absolutely stunning museum. Being Roman, I think you did not experience Rome if you haven't seen Bernini's works of art. You can book ina dvance - you should actually.

Be sure an Book Ahead-or you won't get in. This is well worth seeing, but if you don't make advance reservations, you won't get in. Not crowded because the number of folks admitted is very limited. Be sure and see the Catacombs of Priscilla-north of Borghese-we walked, but maybe a taxi is a good idea.

Art in a splendid villa. Do get tickets online before your trip so you don't miss this wonderful museum. You are only permitted to spend two hours and must check your bags and cameras. We bought an superb book in the museum shop that concentrated on ten of the most outstanding works of art. I would highly recommend doing that. The museum is small enough that if you follow this book, the two hours will suffice

Absolute Must See. Just spent two wonderful hours in this incredible museum. Worth the ticket price alone to see the astonishing Bernini sculptures. Add the Ruben's, Caravaggio's, Botticelli's, Garofalo's, etc. and be amazed at the plethora of great art under one roof. The ceilings will leave you breathless and don't forget to look at the mosaic floors. We walked out a bit dazed from all the beautiful art we saw. Be sure to get your tickets ahead of time. They were sold out for the whole week. You are allowed only two hours in the galleria and must check just about everything but the clothes you're wearing at the free cloak room. Two hours seemed adequate, so don't feel you have to rush. Take your time and enjoy. If you see only one museum in Rome, I urge you to make it this one. Read their website for all pertinent info before you go.

Worth the walk. The Borghese is a ways from the heart of the city, but worth the trip. It was nice to see so many renaissance masters in a way that was easy to take in and understand. Definitely get the audio guide and reservations are mandatory.

Bernini and Caravaggio.... After seeing their work again in this fantastic gallery i am starting to like and perhaps even understand baroque art (Rome IS baroque) - this is a place everyone must visit. Booking the tickets in advance can be troublesome to some , but it guarantees rather peaceful 2 hours visit.

Art overload, but in a good way.. We took the Rick Steve's Rome guide with us, and I would say that you really need to have something (an audio guide, a book, etc.) to help you find the highlights and understand what you're looking at. There's just too much to see without some sort of context.After our 2 hour period was done, we took a leisurely stroll through the gardens to find the Metro entrance at Spagna. We got a little turned around and ended up walking the rest of the way home. I would say that you should certainly give yourself some time to stroll the grounds if you decide to visit the gallery.This was our first RomaPass site. We booked about a week in advance, using the phone. The operator spoke good English, which was good since I didn't trust my Italian to get the job done. She gave us a booking code to present to the desk along with the RomaPass. They state to arrive 30 minutes prior to your scheduled entrance, but we were running pretty late. We arrived at 4:50pm for a 5pm entrance, but they let us in and we checked our bags just in time for 5pm. Lucky, though, since we saw several people lined up who would have taken our spots had we been late. I planned to buy a book in the gift shop, since they don't let you take photos, but I missed the shop closing by about 15 minutes. (It closed at 6:30pm and our time slot ended at 7:00pm.)I didn't come here on my first trip to Rome, but I'm glad I did on my second.
Gorgeous. Gorgeous art and scandalous history! Statues are amazing. We loved it! There are also beautiful gardens.

Two hours was too much. I was overwhelmed by the Galleria Borghese - it is a sensory overload. Every corner and section of the lower rooms are breathtaking. The ceilings, the walls, the sculptures. It was difficult to take it all in. I ended up just trying to concentrate on a couple of the sculptures.The paintings upstairs are nice - but it is the downstairs rooms that are the stars.Book in advance or you will not get in. We loved it. Worth the hassle. Definitely get the audio guide so you can better appreciate what you are seeing.

My fav place in Rome!. Go on a sunny day if you know the forecast. Make sure you hire bikes and a boat on the lake. They were both worth every penny. The gardens are so exotic and a different world to the rest of Rome. We had lunch before we visited the gardens and an afternoon cuppaccino and gelato to refresh! Only one public loo which was out of order which meant I had to pay 50c to use a restaurant WC. Try bring as little baggage to the park as possible! Makes the experience all the more enjoyable!

Not to be missed. Make reservations in advance. Bernini's David, Apollo & Daphne, and the rape of Proserpina are the work of a genius who Cardinal Borghese discovered. Canova's Pauline Bonaparte Venus Victrix is unimagiably real and the first masterpiece you will see.
Worth hassle. You have to make a reservation before you show up. We did a guided tour 8 euros and entry fee 13 euros so it came to about $30 pp. Very nice experience

Borghese Gallery. We booked our tickets about a month ahead of our visit, which is about the earliest you can do it. I used Google Chrome to translate the website for me and had no problems making the arrangements.Got to the Gallery about 30 minutes early to get our tickets. You do not need to get there that early. Sign on the counter said that tickets were sold out for the next 3 days. Each "group" gets 2 hours to visit the museum, which is plenty of time for most people. The one thing I'd say is that unlike other museums, there is not a lot of information on the artwork you are looking at. Most rooms had laminated sheets in Italian/English that explained the artwork in the room, however, these sheets were not current. Some did not match up to the artwork that was actually in the room. The paintings were nice, however, I'd have to say that the artwork on the ceilings are what really make the visit worthwhile. Some of these ceilings are breathtaking!
