The sculptures run a close second.After we left the gallery (after about 90 minutes) we stopped by the bookstore. They had some really good books there that explained the artwork we saw. If I went again, I'd probably buy one of these books before going into the Gallery. It'll help you understand what you're looking at.

Statues, Mosaics, Ceilings in a Villa in the Park. You will need a reservation, you will need to check any big purses or bags downstairs before going up the steps to enter. Our entry time was 5 pm and you have access for 2 hours only. But after touring many sites in Rome our legs and feet were giving out on us. Our plan to be at the front of the entry line so as to be in first, we made it through all the rooms enjoying every detail, (I had studied ahead of time and shared details as we went) We were finished in 30 minutes and everyone was happy. Could we have stayed longer? Yes, but we were trying to do it all (Rome) and it is hard to get everything in but Yes, you should schedule a visit to Galleria Borghese. Don' miss the statues - they are fabulous!

Book your tickets in advance and you will have the chance to enjoy this beautiful place. We booked the tickets in advance, 2 weeks before and it was great since at the day of our arrival at Friday, all tickets were sold out till Tuesday next week, we took the guided tour in English, it started at 11 and took almost 1 1/2 and was great, we could learn many new thinks about art in this beautiful gallery, you need to deposit your bags and cameras next to the bookshop, and 2 hour it's great to enjoy the gallery, later you can rent a bike or just walk in the great villa Borghese park.

Gallerie borghese....a true delight. We visited the gallerie borghese and decided to get a guided tour instead of the audio. Luckily for us, no one else was on our tour so we ended up with a private tour of the gallerie with our wonderful guide. She was knowledgable and spoke well. Our 11 year daughter loved the tour as the guide explained things in a very simple and clear manner. The sculptures there are wonderful. The Apollo sculpture, the Pauline Bonaparte Venus, they were all a must see. There are a few paintings worth seeing there but the gems are the sculptures. IMHO this was more fun than the Vatican museum, where the crowds made it impossible to enjoy the art.

A must, at least once. Paintings, statues, ceilings, mosaics - made by the masters of the 17th century. The villa is located in a park making the walk Villa Borghese an event by itself. Reservation is necessary at least 3-4 days in advance. Not overly crowded when we were there.

Nice Art, bad attitude. Maybe it suffers because of it's location, but I was let down by this lovely little gallery. I had just been to the Vatican Museum, which is overwhelming and incredibly accessible. The Borghese, however, seems rather impressed with itself. Ladies must check their purses before entering (pick them up when leaving), and no matter how few people are in the museum, you may not enter until the time on your ticket. The staff is not friendly. While the sculptures and paintings are beautiful, the attitude spoiled it for me.

bo-ring. Not a huge art fanatic, but I do enjoy art museums. This one was very, very lengthy and hot as hell. They coral tight groups of sweaty people in like cattle. The tour facts and information were delivered in such a boring monotone fashion, it was not even worth trying to smash in closer to hear. Totall waste of half of a day.

Do Not Miss while in Rome!. Secure tickets well in advance and do not show up even a minute late or you will be turned away! Spend the extra and rent a headset - you won't regret it, the information is fascinating. If possible, allow for time to enjoy the beautiful park afterward.

Amazing collection!. We bought tickets online, 3 weeks before. We showed up at 9am as planned and easily entered the Gallery for the alloted 2hrs. The sculptures and paintings are amazing but you must have the audio guide to describe the details.

Great gallery, go on time and buy the audio tour!. This is a really great gallery that you have to go! Don't forget to go on time and book tickets from the internet. They have devided the visiting time into periods. I went at 9.00 and I had to leave at 11.00! You are obliged to leave, so the next "group" can enter. Only certain number of visitors can be at the same time inside the museum. Buy the audio tour, it's very helpful and costs 5.5?. You can share it with one more person if you want to save money, because it's loud enough.Visiting Galleria Borghese is a good starting point for a walk in the Villa Borghese-Park and end up near Piazza Del Popolo!

Premiere Art Collection. The Bernini sculptures are well worth the trip. We made a reservation by phone. Get an audio guide. Beautiful place! By day, walk through the large park surrounding the gallery.

Astonishing museum. Wonderful sculptures and art in a lovely garden /park setting. The experience was just amazing and the park was full of families, couples and on a Saturday afternoon set a lovely atmosphere for our Rome visit.

A treasure trove of sculpture and art. Situated in the lovely Borghese gardens (which is shaped lik a heart), the Galleria is filled with artwork collected by the Borghese family. Closed on Mondays. Reservations required for a 2-hour visit.

The place of the best sculplture of the world. In this gallery, you will see some sculpture. The best is Rape Of Proserpina which s created by Gian Lorenzo Bernini. This sculpture is really a masterpiece and in fact what you see is not enough. Pre-booking is mandatory and you have at least 30 min walking to arrive to gallery via garden. If you visited Rome, never lose the chance to visit this gallery.

Great garden and the art work is wonderful. Grand old home but as a palace . Holds many great works of art and brings life in its presentations. Can be seen in an hour to hour and a half but longer if studying the works. This is a good fill in if you have time but not at the expense of missing the primary must see sites.

Beautiful . Though we are not the knowledgeable types when it comes to art, this place would still would rank as one of the highlights of our Rome trip. The collection of marble statues and paintings is incredible. Do remember to get the audio guide in order to better appreciate the stories behind each art piece.

Interesting. Very good ART collection, located in the park.SInce the enterance is for 2 hours it is suggested to arrive half an hour before the time you booked since you need to stand in the line even if you booked in advance and it yakes time.

Lovely Gallery. The Galleria Borghese was well worth the visit. Bernini sculptures were magnificent. It is crowded with lines even when you have a reservation! You must reserve ahead which is easy enough to do on line. A reservation gives you a two hour time frame for the visit. A walk through the park is also a pleasant and relaxing time.

The most beautiful sculptures of Rome!. There is a lot to see in the galleria Borghese, so we mainly focused on the sculptures by Bernini although we toured the house for 2 hours looking at the painting also. Our guide explained how Bernini sculpted and worked and it was fascinating to see the smallest and finest details of his work on the marble. Quite an experience!

Amazing statues. This is a wonderful museum to visit if you like sculpture and early art. You need reservations, and they are strict about your arriving on the hours stated on the reservation voucher. Very strict about bag checking and you need to show your tickets in order to use the bathrooms. No photography allowed. As there are no elevators, you have to be in great shape to climb up the long flight of stairs to the exhibits.

Great museum with annoying bag check requirement. The museum is beautiful with a great collection of sculptures. The mandatory reservation system limits the number of patrons at one time, improving the experience (although large groups of teenagers still annoy...) but the mandatory checking of ALL bags and no cameras are beyond annoying. If you are going to have a mandatory checking policy at least have the staff to manage it.

Awesome Museum Especially when Done with Onsite Historian. Reservations are a MUST!!! We bought the Roma pass and this was one of our "free" museums. What I did was call the museum from home and made reservations, so you don't need to pre-purchase tickets but you do need to reserve before going, just make sure you write down your reservation number. Cons:1. You must leave all cell phones, cameras & bags at the counter. I was not happy about that but everything was returned safely. 2. Limited time. You only have, I believe, 2 hours for you visit.Pros:1. Stunning museum. Everything was so beautiful.2. Guided Tour with Historian: While waiting for our turn, I noticed 2 signs. One sign was for an audio tour, which was for 5 euros and the other was for a guided tour with a historian, which was 6.50 euros. We decided to go for the guided tour with historian and let me tell you, it was money well spent. We had a very knowledgeable guide and she brought certain paintings and sculptures to life. She was not only knowledgeable, but very expressive and it totally added to our experience. It was definitely a highlight our trip to Rome. This is not a tour of the entire museum but a tour of the "must-sees" in the gallery. Once you're done, check out the park for a leisurely stroll. Also, the Spanish Steps are close by if you want to check that out, though I found it to be overcrowded and overrated.

Small museum Reservation required. This is an absolutely beautiful villa turned into a art museum. It is small,just two floors, but has some stunning works. I especially enjoyed the sculptures on the first floor. The pieces are much more accessible than in the Vatican Museum. Reserved tickets and entry times are required.

Worth the visit. Beautiful collection of art. I did have an issue with the tickets. I made the reservations ahead of time online (as they specify). Printed out the documents that were emailed to me, but when I arrived and presented the docs at the box office, the woman said I didn't have some number she needed so it was a big hassle to get the tickets. I had email receipts and confirmation, so not sure what additional paperwork she wanted.So maybe double check any confirmation paperwork before you go.For the museum itself, incredible collection and worth the ticket hassle. The grounds are also perfect to visit spring-fall if you want to make a picnic. Walking distance from the city center.

One of the great museums of the world.. You MUST make reservations at least a couple of days in advance. You have a two hour time limit to get through the museum, which is just about enough time. Start on the second floor first and avoid the crowd. The cafe on site has been closed for about a year due to a contract dispute, so count on getting lunch there before your tour.

Amazing collection in a quiet setting. 2 hours is not enough to see it all, but I appreciated to timed tickets to limit the usual hordes of tourist. Amazing paintings and sculptures. Definately worth the wait!

Dazzling!. This is one of those small sites that you can't believe until you see it. Went with about 25 people all of whom were stunned with the collections and building. One must reserve a 2-hour slot in advance - definitely worth the extra trouble. Walk thru park afterward to balcony overlooking Piazza del Populo for the best view of the Roman skyline.
Appolo & Daphney yah!. This is a very nice museum... not your typical rats maze. the rooms are all open (none closed off) and the staff is pleasant. One gift shop is all you need with the basics!
Galleria Borghese. You are in awe looking at all the paintings and statues. Quite a remarkable collection in a wonderful setting.

Good. Three points are only for the what's in the museum and place is far and you need to book ahead. and you can't take a photo and you need to put your bag in their locker. Also if you don't have a ticket, then can't use the restroom.

Wonderful experience. I found the smallish gallery so much more interesting and easy to enjoy than large crowded attractions like the Vatican museum. The guide book which can be purchased from the gift shop is wonderful. The audio guides are helpful but not essential. The sculputure collection is amazing for anyone with any interest in art.

not for plebs who dont really appreciate art. having read the previous reviews about it being absolutely wonderful, i made a resevation for my group to go. we were all thoroughly underwhelmed, not to mention half a day lost (which is massive for rome). it is quite a trek from the nearest metro. to be fair, it would be great if one is an art fan. I am not, and am here writing to warn people- your money and time is better spent elsewhere in Rome if you're not an art fan.

This Museum Does It Right. With one of best curated (over the centuries) sculpture and art collections in the world, this museum is a "must see". Thankfully, they strictly limit access by requiring reservations. While the process is tedious, the resulting experience is well worth the effort.Make sure and talk a walk through the lovely gardens when you attend.

Great museum, nasty staff. The museum is great. We thoroughly enjoyed the exhibits. We visited Rome during the Holy week. You have to reserve your tickets at least a week before the day of your visit. You have to bring the confirmed reservation email (on your phone or a print out) and be there at least 30 minutes before your entry time. The process of getting tickets is not complicated. Remember, they do not allow any bags or cameras inside, so you need to check them in at no cost. I recommend getting an audio guide that helps you with the exhibits because you only have 2 hours time. Do not use spend your 2 hour time to visit the gift shop or the cafe. You can do that later. Also, most people will start the tour at the lower gallery and go to the picture gallery (upper) during the last 30 minutes. I suggest you reverse the order so that the galleries are not crowded for you. The only bad experience I had was with the staff who were distributing audio guides. They were plainly rude and refused to answer any questions. I later found out that they only open 20 minutes prior to the entrance to distribute the audio guides. Instead of answering my question about the audio guide, she yelled at me in Italian and pushed us out and sealed the area.The gallery is fantastic. The upper gallery has Raffael's painting (The deposition) and Caravaggios's paintings (David and the Goliath) which are must see. Downstairs, they have several unique statues of Bernini (Pluto and Prosperino and David ) and Canova (Paulina Boanparte), which are all must see. Note: You are only allowed more than 30 minutes at the upper picture gallery. Interesting note: The owner of the gallery, Cardinal Scipione Borghese was the nephew of Pope Paul V. Apparently, Scipione Borghese was not a very religious person. He was appointed as a Cardinal by his uncle the Pope. In Italian nephew is called nepote, which lead to the word nepotism or favoritism!
Best Museum in Rome. Far less crowded than the Vatican museums, and a fantastic collection of paintings and statues. This was a pleasant visit as compared to the crowds at the Vatican...

a MUST see when in Rome. Bernini's sculptures of David and Apollo and Daphne alone are worth the price of admission. I am a big fan of Bernini after seeing those works. You must have a reservation to get in. They only allow 2 hours and NO cameras, in fact you have to check all personal belongings. Know where you are going beforehand as the Boghese grounds are quite large and if you miss your reservation time, they give it to someone else. Fairly large crowd when they let you in, I would advise going to the top floor first and working your way down to allow you better view with less people

Beautiful art, beautiful grounds. We made a reservation a week ahead to get in, and were not disappointed. It isn't as large as some of the major Italy museums, so it's easier to see it all. The rooms aren't numbered well, and the guidebook I bought didn't exactly match with the rooms, so that was a bit confusing. There are paintings upstairs (a very long climb), but in addition to the beautiful sculptures, the grounds make it worth the visit. You have to show your ticket to use the restrooms. There is a magnificent view of Rome from the overlook if you walk (going left) as you exit the gallery. You can actually walk down from there directly to Piazzo del Popolo. There is also a small train that takes you on a short ride (3 euros each.) Nice family atmosphere, a few carnival-type rides for the kids.

Loved it!. A great museum and a must to visit when in Rome! Loved the fact that it was not overly crowded and one really gets the opportunity to appreciate the art work. Do note that you are required to reserve your entrance spot in advance. I called +39 0622582330 and was given a reservation number. I would suggest to make your reservations well in advance as its quite popular. The museum is also part of the Roma pass network, so once you've made your reservations, you could enter the museum with the roma pass for a maximum of 2 hours. Its a relatively small museum (2 storeys) so 2 hours is sufficient to appreciate the superb art. The gardens does not require an entrance fee.

Best museum in Rome!. Yes, I know the Vatican Museums are very famous but when in Rome this is THE museum you have to see.This gallery is a villa with just two floors, therefore you won’t walk much (at least inside the museum since outside there are a beautiful park with a lot to see and it’s a great place to relax from the crowds in Rome). The villa is a piece of art itself, with several rooms decorated with frescos and sculptures in the walls. Beside that you have some paints and sculptures that will make the time fly. I used the audio guide to enhance the experience since it explains some pieces in particular and describes the story of each room.You can’t spend more than 2 hours inside and it is very hard to get a ticket without booking in advance. This museum is always crowed therefore you should go straight to the second floor and start from there. Afterwards you can go downstairs when most of the visitors will start going to the second floor.The Bernini sculptures totally changed my perception of what a sculpture is, since the stone seems totally weightless… Unfortunately we aren’t allowed to take photos but the memories will remain forever.
Great, small museum. They have my favorite version of the statue of David here, by Bernini. It's nice because it's smaller and a more manageable size while you can also visit the park.

Make your reservations now! It's really worth it!. This was our third trip to Rome and we didn't see the Museo Borghese previously because there was always so much to see, and you must make reservations days, maybe weeks, maybe more in peak season, in advance! So I say, plan ahead, it's really worth it. The museum is small and your reservation is for a two hour window. Ours was from 1-3pm. You must check all your bags, even purses, so get there early. Bernini sculptures to die for... The fabulous park-like setting was super enjoyable after.

Wonderful small museum. This museum is small, but it is totally worth the trip. The gardens (park like setting) surrounding the museum are gorgeous and worth the walk through them to get to the museum. Whatever you do, do not miss the sculptures. The are magnificent! Leave plenty of time for the last 3 as you do not want to rush those in particular. Because the museum is so popular you will have only 2 hours to see the entire museum, but it is doable. Make sure to purchase your tickets prior to going as the museum sells out. My 2 adult daughters and I got lucky and were able to go in at the 5 pm time slot. Others were only able to purchase tickets for a later day.

Amazing Gallery, but the staff are SO RUDE!!. Loved the gallery, it was truly breathtaking.However I was disgusted by the staff, I simply asked one of the male staff members directions and he started shouting at me and walking away.I was so shocked by this reactions as are the staff of the Gallery not there to help you?Very odd! Such a shame that the staff let down such a beautiful place.
Beautiful museum. Gorgeous museum, lovely artwork in breathtaking rooms. A little stuffy personnel at the museum, but worth the time to make reservations for your visit.
ticket hassle. It is a famous gallery but ticket hassle is not truly rewarded Ok fabulous if showy sculpture but the paintings are better elsewhere. I just needed to see Daphne again.
So much art. We toured after traveling 24 hours so I did not get out of it what I could have if rested. The sculptures were fantastic....get the audio guide!

Brilliant. WE visited this Gallery on the advice of the owner of our B&B. It's a bit out of town but you can get the bus up the mountain and if you are fit, walk back into the city.Make sure you book your tickets well in advance as they operate a strict headcount for each visiting schedule.
Great Artwork. Very interesting tour of Roman art and sculptures. Lucky enough to have a beautiful day to enjoy both the Gallery and Gardens. Wear your hiking shoes....
Worth a visit. Visited this galleria as an afterthought but much to my surprise, this place is wonderful, loaded with art and sculptures. Definitely worth the visit.
Amazing sculptures. A wonderful gallery in the middle of a wonderful park in a wonderful city. Perfect for a summer's afternoon and then wander home through the sunny Villa Borghese.

Pre book!. Have only given this venue a low score because we walked for ages in pouring rain only to discover that the gallery was booked up for the next 3 days (until after our stay)! We were very dissappointed. So if you want to go make sure you pre book it!

Wonderful museum of sculptures and paintings. Overall a great experience in a museum that is not overly crowded and where you can take your time (within 2 hours!) to enjoy the art. ADMISSION1. Book your tickets online at least 1 week or more in advance: http://www.tosc.it/ (Else there is NO way you are getting in. A man in front of me tried to buy tickets on the spot and was turned away. ) Your ticket allows you a 2 hour visit.2. Plan to arrive at least 15 mins before your admission time as you will need to queue up to show your receipt to the admission desk for your tickets and then queue up AGAIN to check in your camera and bagsCHECK IN 1. Yes, you will need to check in your bags and all cameras. They are strict about that. Try to pack light that day because these are not huge lockers. TOUR1. Bring a guide book with you so you know what you are looking at, or pick up an audio tour guide. I used the Rick Steves tour and it was fine. I had ample time to take in the Bernini statues and the Caravaggios and Raphael paintings.It's great that they limit the visitors and the time. The rooms never felt too crowded or overheated and it just made for a pleasant experience. There's a bathroom there and I took a leisurely time and still completed my tour with 5 minutes to spare!Afterwards, take a stroll down Via Veneto and get a snack in the many cafes there!

A gem. A perfect museum. wonderfull setting, exquisite art, just the right size. a pity though that photography is not allowed and that the entry arrangements are a total mess. long ques and lack of signs make the entry a frustrating affair even after advanced reservation on the internet.

Great Museum. Need reservations. They "kick you out" after two hours, which is the perfect amount of time to view the museum. It was a little strange that they only allow you 30 minutes on the top floor, I didn't quite understand the reasoning behind that, but oh well. Still good. We got the audio tour and it was well worth it. I wouldn't do it without the audio tour. Located in a beautiful park also.

A MUST in Rome. We visited the museum with 2 teenagers and we all enjoyed it. before coming to the museum one has to know a few major points:1. purchase tickets in advance ( at least a few days ) otherweise there are no tickets available. 2. get there at least 30 minutes earlier in order to get the tickets and put the bags away. they let you in right on time anf if you are late, you're told that your tickets have expired and can not be used or exchanged. Once inside it is a real cultural and artistic treat and an audio guide helps a lot.

just buy the ticket from the internet before your visit!!!. probably one of the best art museums in rome/italy, beautiful, a place to return to every time you are in rome. but there is a problem with tickets, you have to buy them in advance on the internet. it's very very simple, i do it all the time. if you dont, there is a very big chance not to be able to enter!!! also be careful from where you will buy your ticket - just go on galleriaborghese.it and there you will have the ticket section, very simple to use with just 2E more on the price for taking it in advance. don't miss the visit to galleria borghese for anything, you will enjoy it!

Borghese Gallery - Maria Candrilli. Did a Private Tour with Maria - she is noted as a Borghese Gallery expert and she certainly lived up to all of that. She was so good and explained so much about each of the iconic pieces of art that we experienced. It was a full and a real learning experience. Highly recommend Maria.

Arrive at least 30 minutes early. After wandering around the park looking for the gallery (the only signs are close to the gallery) and then waiting in line for 30 minutes for our pre-purchased tickets we were over an hour late. We were told that our tickets had expired and could not enter the gallery. I tried to tell them we would only stay a short time and be out by the end of our designated time as there was only one Bernini sculpture that we really wanted to see. The clerk was rude and inflexible. We wasted the money for the non-refundable tickets and more importantly our time. There are plenty of Bernini pieces and countless works of art everywhere in Rome available for free viewing without wasting your vacation time waiting in line.
ART AT IT'S BEST. What a beautiful gallery. The vivid statues are amazing works of art, with such detail. Be sure to make reservations

Our family with kids ages 13 and 10 LOVED IT. A great two hour museuem visit with timed entry and exit tix that must be secured in advance. A true highlight of our trip and a great area to walk around before and after. start on the second floor with paintings for 30 mins and do the remaining 1.5 hours on the first floor with statues. use the audio tour for true enjoyment and learning.

No Bags or Purses Allowed. I'm not a huge art guy but I will say, I was really impressed by this place. It was "do able." What do I mean by that? Well, it's not as overwhelming as say the Louve, but it has really fascintating works of art. My favorite was Bernini's Apollo e Davne Sorry no pictures allowed in gallery; this leads me to some other tips.1.) Tickets are timed stamped in 2 hour intervals beginning at 09:00 and last entry is 17:00. BUY ONLINE ahead of time to avoid your preferred time slot selling out. 2.) No bags (even purses) allowed in the gallery. We found out the hard way after waiting in the long line we had to go all the way back to bag check. 3.) Save euro and just buy one audio guide and share it. I saw a couple doing this, GENIUS!
Favorite place in Roma. I could spend every day at Galleria Borghese. It is beautiful, peaceful, comforting and the perfect place to spend a day soaking up art and culture.

A highlight. We used the Roma Pass for entry, and had called for a reservation time--necessary even during off-peak months, especially on weekends. The gallery is simply the best collection of baroque art anywhere--the Bernini sculptures will overwhelm you. We visited the sculpture floor, then cruised through the painting gallery (I'm sure I didn't appreciate it as I should have--I wanted to get back to the Berninis), then went back to the sculptures for a less-crowded look. Two hours was about right at one sitting, but I could do that museum over and over again. The Villa grounds are wonderful, too--Roman families out for a day in the park, musicians playing, and the umbrella pines--nearly perfect. Don't miss the chance to walk to the Pincio while you're there.

A must see in Rome!. This gallery is incredible! I am not usually a big museum-goer but I thoroughly enjoyed my visit to Galleria Borghese and have no hesitation in recommending it to others. Every room in the gallery is intricately decorated and stunning, full of different masterpieces, and no two rooms are the same. Beautiful! A very worthwhile visit which will take no more than 2 hours out of your day in a visit to Rome. You can even squeeze in a visit to this museum if you have lots to do in Rome and feel as though you don't have enough time to fit it all in: booking the 5-7pm visit is ideal, as that way you can go to the gallery after the main sightseeing of your morning and afternoon, and before dinner.

Excellent gallery, not too crowded. Having battled with the crowds at the Vatican Museums and Sistine Chapel, it was a delight to visit a gallery which restricted access tickets to a sensible number. There were plenty of visitors, but enough space to see everything and to go round at your own pace.We loved the scale of the place and the combination of superb sculptures on one floor and paintings on the others, plus wonderful ceiling paintings throughout. The audio guides were really good - clear and just the right amount of detail. One niggle - the room numbers on the audio guide and the numbers over the entrance doors to each room did not match - this caused some debate initially! Our only irritation was the system for entrance - as tickets were all timed once every two hours, it meant that there were queues to get in. The cloakroom requirement was really frustrating - most people had small bags but we were told we had to check in. So, there was a queue of annoyed people, and then if you needed to take a purse/passport whatever with you, you had to get a plastic bag from them which often had a bigger capacity than the bag you were not allowed to take in!This frustration evaporated once you'd spent a few minutes looking round.The other huge benefit of the Borghese is that it's situated in the Borghese Gardens which are glorious. We were there on a sunny Sunday and it was a delight to wander round, watching people relaxing, cycling, roller blading, chatting.
Beautiful. The paintings are gorgeous and the gardens are amazing. It was a wonderful way to spend a beautiful day.

Must See in Rome. Marvelous sculpture wors of Bernini the master sculpture of Rome and paintings of Caravaggio. Hire a personal Art guide to get the most information about the exhibits. Federica Dal Palu was my guide. She was fantastic at the Borghese and the Vatican. Her web site is fedeart.com.

Excellent Artwork. We really enjoyed seeing the artwork and 2 hours was perfect to see it. There are three statues which awe struck me, Apollo with Derce, The R. of Persephone, and Bonaparte-Borghese. The paintings were pretty good too. It was actually the Egyptian room I enjoyed the most. Pick one room and just sit for 15 minutes and take it in. Well worth it.

Jaw dropping awe!. Make reservations a couple weeks in advance. Get a Roma pass and call ahead. Really. It's worth the international phone call. Never in my life have I been in rooms with such beauty. It truly was a shame to only have 2 hours. Buy the audio guide. Otherwise, you'll waste time staring too much and you won't see everything. We just barely made it. The only souvenir I bought in Rome (besides trinkets) was a book detailing the works I had just beheld.

Amazing place!. This was one of the highlights of our visit. The Bernini statues were absolutely amazing. Make the most of the first floor and go the opposite way to the masses - clockwise - we had some rooms to ourselves!

Going for Baroque. If you are fond of Baroque sculpture and painting, this is the place for you. If you are less enthusiastic you might want to take a pass. We caught the last session of the day (5 PM) and some of the sculptures were not well lit without the additional lighting from the windows. The audio guide was helpful, but the corresponding numbers on the works of art were very small and hard to find. Perhaps a guided tour or a detailed book with descriptions might have made the experience more useful. Given all the hype, the difficulty getting tickets, the timed entry etc, I expected more. If you enter from the outside and try to find the staircase to the second floor at the start of the session, good luck! The guards have this nondescript glass door leading to the stairwell to the second floor closed for the first 15 minutes until the crowds from the basement have made their way directly to the second floor. I had to ask them to open it for me. Better to enter from the basement if you plan on finding the second floor. It wasn't a total loss, we stopped for some great desserts at one of the 5 star hotels on the via Veneto on the walk from the Barberini metro stop. (The 910 bus is also a quick way to get there from the Termini.) If you go to the Borghese, make sure you get to the Vatican Museum as well. Even though the Sistine Chapel was closed due to the conclave while we were there, the newly restored Raphael rooms and the "School of Athens" was worth the price of admissions to all the museums (including the Borghese) and sites during our week in Rome.
rent a bike. You can rent a bike, so you can cycle the park. It will save you some time. 15 euro for one hour, and you will get a electric bycicle, a little car. Perfect and great fun.
call to reserve. it's beautiful! they tell you to be there 1/2 hr before your appt time; i don't think that's necessary because you then have to wait & nowhere to sit.

Galleria Borghese - Rome - DarkRome tour. Another great tour with DarkRome Tours to another fabulous attraction in Rome. [As a note, visits to this gallery are limited to two hours, and large bags (backpacks, handbags) are required to be checked in / left at the secure cloak room.]

Breathtaking!. Don't make the mistake of being late for your time slot. They really do police your exit, and start closing doors. And it is SO WORTH seeing every gallery. Also, go early in the day and spend some time in the park, it is gorgeous. You can even rent a Segway for 15 euros an hour. Put on your walking shoes, this place is huge.

A piece of art, with low service. I went there with my wife. She is crazy about art. We went there wednesday and could buy tickets for friday. That is what we did. It was hard to know where to wait. The entrance of the museum is not at the ticketbox wich is at the exit. The staff is inpacient (like every Italian) and is not well with the English language. The museum wants us to leave the purse in the wardrobe but we had to keep the coats on(?).Once inside it was beautifull. The entrance hall is very beautifull and overwelming. Same as the room of the emperors. The statues the paintings and the mozique of tge egyptian room was beautifull.The route was not logical. But thats probaly cause it was not build as an museum.

Style and substance - plus suggest you share an audio guide. We turned up at 12:30 on 22nd March and were very fortunate to get two tickets on the spot, i believe they were for the last two spaces - and tomorrow sold out completely (presale only). Winging it worked out for us but I suggest you plan ahead.Two hour limit in the gallery meant we chose to purchase an audio guide for 5 Euro each. The guide was excellent but i would suggest sharing with your companion as they have a small speaker, rather than headphones, so can be share by two people with minimum of effort.As for the Sculptures & Paintings - they are a world class collection and a must see for anyone interested in those artforms.

must see in Rome. You will have a beautiful walk through a large park.The gallery & garden are well worth your time.
Make sure to reserve on line.You will be given a reserved 2 hours to visit.Very well organized.Fantastic collection.

not to be missed. A good place to start your visit to Rome. Unwind from the stress of travel with a walk through the park and imerse yourself in spectacular art and sculpture in a manageable scale. 2 hours is sufficient time.

Outstanding but critical to understand the reservation system. First of all, the walk to this Galleria through the Borghese Gardens is just amazing (even in the rain). We didn't know much about Bernini before this tour but left with a huge appreciation (is anyone doing anything like this work today??). It is worth the trip just to see Apollo and Daphne.Now here is the deal....you simply must book online in advance. If you do not do this, you risk being turned away even if you have the Rome card. They book in two hour time slots which is plenty of time to see the entire museum. The building itself is also a treasure.

Best of Baroque. Thiis was my third trip to Rome, and also the third time I've visited this excellent art gallery. The Louvre, the Prado, and the Uffizi are awesome, but for that "just right size" and experience, this is the place to go. The gallery limits entrance to 200 people at any one time block--so you won't feel crowded--and your time block is limited to two hours. It's just the right amount of time to truly enjoy the Berninis and Caravaggios in this elegant space. Be sure to take time either before or after your visit to walk around the grounds of this villa. If you like art, this should be on your must see list when in Rome.

Wonderful collection. Thank you Scipione Borghese for having started this amazing collection! It is true that the organization is really bad, but once you get in, you just forget it! Don't try to book the ticket online, ask in the reception of your hotel, normally they do it for you. Just remember that it is a scheduled visit, and you have only two hours to see the Gallery (I would stay there the whole day). The Collection is not big, but is made of masterpieces. Don't miss the four Bernini's masterpieces, Titian's Sacred and Profane Love and Canova's statue of Pauline Bonaparte. If you get to leave around six, go to the Pincio to see one of Rome's most beautiful views.
A wonderful gallery. Do book! It was sold out on the day we went. It is fairly small but has an amazing collection. worth using the audio guide although this is extra. The Bernini's are wonderful.

Book ahead. Don't expect to turn up and buy tickets on the day. This is a popular and busy museum and I would recommend buying tickets on line before you get to Rome - you can chose your day and time. Fantastic sculpture, paintings and setting and a walk in the park is restful and great for people watching.

Fabulous museum. Initially, I thought the requirement to get tickets in advance was a pain in the neck but after our visit, I believe they know what they are doing. The timed tickets help control the number of people in the museum at one time, ensuring you can see the works of art. (In contrast, you move through the Vatican like cattle through a chute, without being able to linger over anything.) The Galleria Borghese was a highlight of our visit to Rome and I highly recommend a visit.

Stunning art but dreadful organisation. You must pre book , which is a sensible arrangement for what is a smallish and popular museum . The beautiful building is host to a large number Renaissance paintings and an even more impressive collection of sculptures and statues .Unfortunately the initial part of the visitor experience is terrible . Having pre booked for a two hour "slot" ( 9am , 11am , 1pm , or 3pm ) you are advised to turn up a half hour early . This is to give you time to queue for tickets and then to queue again for the compulsory bag drop ( don't try to do the bag drop first as they wont let you ) . You then congregate in a large group to the rear of the entrance floor , waiting to be admitted . If you are elderly or infirm don't bank upon having anywhere to sit as seating is at a minimum . When the doors finally open there is a mass scrum to enter the first gallery on the first floor . Having been warned of this , we hung back and tried to start our viewing on the second floor but were prevented from doing so by a brusk official who was guarding the stairs and insisted that we join the throng . The system of pre booking is presumably to avoid overcrowding , so why on earth do they force the entire population of the museum to enter the same gallery all at the same time ! Bizarre . It is difficult to envisage many visitors spending the full two hours at the museum , so why not start letting the earlier arrivals enter upto half an hour before their allotted slot time .It is a shame that the bureaucrats have managed to spoil what should be a pleasant and relaxing visit .

We got in with no reservations, worth a try!. So this was my second time in Rome, and I did not want to miss the Berninis again. But ... I also didn't know how our day would pan out, so we didn't reserve tickets. We walked the park first, which was HUGE... it took us forever to get to the actual museum. And when we did, they told us we had to wait until 5. So we stood there looking sad, and they took pity on us and acknowledged that the earlier time slot hadn't sold out, so they let us in. Definitely get the audio tour, the written guides are hard to follow, and they audio guides will help you block out the tours in various languages going on around you. The Berninis are AMAZING. Definitely this small museum is worth the trip.

Not worth the hassle. The gallery is in every guide book and website, and I fail to see why. The art collection is heavy on marginal Renaissance artists to be honest. There are a few Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculptures but not worth going through all the hassles to just see those. Quite a few churches in the city, not to mention St Peter's, have much better examples of these artists' works. I went through the whole thing in 45'.
The gallery of the cardinale. This gallery was founded by Scipione Borghese, son of Lucrezia Borgia. It is a wonderfull gallery and there is also a beautifull park aroud it.
Restufl. Clearly one of the best place in Rome. Really cool to rest in the park after visited the musuem.Highly recommended

An afternoon delight. The weather was excellent and the Gardens were being enjoyed by families, young couples (always kissing but quickly) and dogs. There is a dining spot, (The Cinema, I think?), on the Borghese campus that has a buffet lunch. It's pricey but if the weather permits, you can eat outside and enjoy fabulous food and wine before or after your visit to the Museo. The audio tour of the gallery is good-- make sure you buy it-- for commentary on the Bernini statues and Caravaggio paintings. And you must book tickets beforehand. There were angry foreigners (not Americans, thankfully) who were turned away for lack of making a simple reservation beforehand. The website is tricky but figure it out. And once you get to this little piece of paradise, don't rush! Slow down and enjoy.

Out of this World. The paintings and sculptures in this gallery are out of this world. I am a fan of art galleries and have been to several across the world. This is definetly one of the most impressive and the audio tour brings the whole thing to life.I was most impressed with the statues and the story of how the collection was put together and saved by a law that showed great foresight.The queue to enter is unreal - even with pre-booked tickets. Arrive in plenty of time.

The Best Museum in Rome. I just finished my third visit to this amazing museum, which must be booked online ahead of time. I ended up using an general Italy tourism website to book our tickets, as the main GB website is difficult to use. Exchanging your voucher for tickets in the crowded downstairs ticket area is crazy with tourists and not well organized, but once you get through that step, you are on your way to a very special museum experience. The residence was closed for many years, its collections hidden away from the world. Now, you can tour the magnificent house set in the verdant Borghese Gardens and get close to some of Bernini's (and other) great works of art. The entire museum can be viewed in two hours at a leisurely pace. I recommend booking at 11, then going somewhere nearby for lunch. Warning: Our friend was pickpocketed just outside of the museum by an Indian couple that asked for directions. When she opened her purse to look for a map, off they went with her money. She didn't even know it had happened before it was too late. So, be careful here and all over Rome with your money, and don't talk to any strangers.

Reservation System is Awful.. We followed procedure and made a reservation to get into the gallery. They gave us a time to come to pick up tickets. We went and the was a large group of people clustered around the door - maybe 50? Then they let everyone in at once to a small entryway and it was packed with people. It was a mob scene. A woman who was there with her handicapped son couldn't get near the ticket window. Finally we got into the museum and they had us wait on another line to check our bags. We finally got into the gallery and felt like what we saw wasn't worth the ordeal of getting in. It is a terrible and unsafe system and needs to be improved and we were there off season! I think we would be disappointed even further had we paid to get in. We used one of the free museums on our Roma cards to get into the gallery. Think hard before you voluntarily put yourself through this. Outside the gardens are beautiful and they are free.

Absolutely Fabulous. This Gallery is amazing. The Bernini's alone make it worth visiting. I have been to many international galleries and museums and I would go back to this one in a heartbeat. Make sure that you call for reservations and get your time slot for when you can visit. We did that and, in true Italian fashion, the museum workers decided to have a meeting during the earlier time slot and closed the museum. So everyone that should have gone in at 1:00 was now lined up to go in at 4:00 like us. Bit of a crazy entrance, but it was worth every bit.

Excellent. I absolutely loved this place. You are limited with your time. I think you get 2 hours and you do have to book tickets in advance which was good as it stops the place being crowded and you get to admire the work up close and personal. You are not allowed bags or cameras in there so its all down to memory and the gift shop. Guides are available both personal and audio but please note if you are going for personal the minimum is two people, even if there is only one of you and you offer to pay for two, (doesnt work like that). I thought it was well worth the money and very cheap. A personal guide was only 1 euro more and worth it.

Charming Galleria Borghese. We visited Galleria Borghese in March 2013. You must make reservations in advance to visit this site, and are provided a ticket to tour the gallery for a 2 hour block of time with a stated entrance and exit time. March is a perfect time to go because the crowds are slim, and we were able to get reservations the night before we visited -- an impossible feat in the high season. The site is easily accessible via the Spagna metro site with about a 10 minute walk through Borghese Park to the gallery. The park is very beautiful, and there are gardens at the gallery that can be viewed as well. The sculpture and paintings within the gallery are wonderful. We particularly enjoyed the ancient Roman gladiator mosaics that decorate the villa's floors. An audio tour is available, and I would recommend it to get the background on the various works on exhibit.

Ahh, the beauty of winter travel.. February is not always an easy month to travel. But the beauty of it is the lack of crowds. I got a same day appt to see the Borghese and if you enjoy sculpture, it's is amazing. Used that very handy Roma pass here and got in for free! BUY A ROMA PASS!!!!
The Best So Far. The Bernini sculptures are the most amazing works of art I've ever seen. It's true. The rest of the collection is beyond compare as well.

Caravaggio & Canova under one roof. the most important piece of advice i can give about this attraction is make sure to have a reservation or book online. I went on a sunday - the queue was ten deep no one had a ticket (bar me) and the next available tickets were for Tuesday - and this was in March - off peak!! For this - i would also advise the audio guide (5e) there is so much to see - you only get 2 hours (entrance is at 9/11/1/3pm) and so you want to make the most of your time. For many its Room 8 where the Caravaggios hang that has the most appeal - although for me the dimple in the marble skin of one of the sculptures just amazed me. the galleria is in the BOrghese gardens - try and remember your route in and out - you can lose your bearings easily if you take a wrong turn in the gardens. The equitation area brings you back to the metro where it is an underground walk back to the Spanish steps.

My favorite museum in rome. This museum is the best of everything...beautiful, manageable size, gorgeous pieces to see and the most beautiful setting as well. I didn't get to tour this musuem till I had been to Rome many times, but I know recommend it to all my friends. Be sure to make a reservation in advance or you will never get in. The tour is about 2 hours and then everyone is "booted" out and the next group in admitted. It is the perfect amount of time so book it and then enjoy! Here is the link to reserve online, or ask your hotel concierge or desk clerk to do it for you. http://www.galleriaborghese.it/borghese/en/einfo.htm

Time to kill. We went here the first day, really just to stay awake from our jet lag.It was ok, I wouldn't go out of my ay to go back. They were very strict about the time of tickets, and made us check our bags. ( only place that did this) a little on the nasty side.

Fantastic art collection and lovely grounds. I'm not a huge art fan (or so I thought), I took a guided tour through the galleria and was absolutely blown away. How many places in the world can you see three Caravaggio paintings together? After this go the the church of Santa Maria in the Piazza del Popolo, and see two more outstanding paintings, Crucifixion of Saint Peter is amazing.Some of the sculpture work is just exquisite. I would highly recommend visiting here but to make the most of the experience best book a tour guide.

Gem of a museum in Roma. We had booked with a tour that cancelled on us....we had no idea and tey let us in for a special price anyway......you must book in advance...we were so lucky and we loved every peice of art......a lovely museum with scultpures that take your breath away..
Borghese bliss. Arranged a english tour guide. Fantastic. Definately worth booking. We only had three people on our tour, just great.

deep dive into the 16th and 17th century. a number of painters have been "sponsored" by the Borghese family, and you can see them all. Caravage and his "Bacchus" is my favorite.Be informed that the audio guides are focusing on a limited number of pieces. I'd have expected some more overview of the periods, painters or techniques.

Disappointing - doesn't live up to it's hype. Some wonderful paintings and sculptures, and room ceilings are all worth seeing. But it is very badly organised. The entry system is chaos, and staff were rude and couldn't care less. Signposting is awful. Some of the lesser quality paintings were almost falling out of their frames.

House of Bernini. Bernini is my favorite was an Italian artist and leading sculptor. He possessed the ability to capture natural moment with a dramatic realism which was almost shocking. Each room was filled with treasures that were breath taking.

Finest art collection. The gallery houses one of the finest sculpture and painting collections in Italy. It is not grand but almost every piece is precious. Make sure to order tickets well in advance as the admission is limited. And bear in mind that each group is allowed two hours of visit only.

Best art of our first trip to Roma!. The Borghese made up for the frustration of our previous Vatican museum trip and tour. The overwhelming private collection of sculpture juxtaposed perfectly with period paintings had an incredible effect. Moreover, the staggering of the visitors made for a more enjoyable visit than my previous visit to the Sixteenth Chapel (a mild disappoint). Further, I feel compelled to visit Florence to further investigate and indulge my new found interest in Bernini. Please be sure to book online for a reservation as it is well worth your time!
Don't miss it. Admission is limited to two hours, but that is about the right amount of time to see this gallery. There are a couple of Bernini sculptures here that just blew me away.

Amazing art collection. We were really looking forward to visiting the Gallery and gardens, and the Art collection is fabulous. We were both disappointed with the 'gardens'; they appeared to be not very well kept, better described as 'park area', quite tatty in places, as was the walk towards the Gallery, especially when compared to other Galleries/museums. The Ladies toilets were not clean, the staff were not helpful, and the staircase looked like it had not been cleaned in a long time. It was difficult to book online, so our Hotel kindly did this, and then on arrival, queueing to collect tickets is quite confusing. The overall visit was not as enjoyable as we hoped. The paintings in the Beautiful Churches in Rome were a more enjoyable experience, more inviting, with a beautiful atmosphere.

Well worth the visit. This had to be the highlight of our visit to Rome. We got off the Metro and walked through the gardens. I think this set us in the right frame of mind. It was cloudy and threatening rain when we set off on our walk but the sun broke through and it was pleasantly warm for early March. The Museum and its contents are astounding. Caravaggios, Titians, Berninis, and on and on and on. The Cardinal who built the place in the 1600's doesn't sound like a very nice guy, but the collection of paintings and statuary he acquired, and the building he had erected to display it, are truly unique.If you have one place to visit in Rome, this has to be it.

Just worth the hassle. Although we had prebooked on line, actually getting to the ticket desk was a bind. then back to the bag deposit and finally to the gallery itself. A bit of thought about queue management and traffic flow would have been a big help. The exhibition itself was interesting but I did not feel that it warranted the high praise heaped on it by some of the tourist guides unless you were a devotee of the painters/sculptors represented. Pity the cafe was closed - (permanently?).

It will make you an art lover!. Let me preface that I am not an art aficionado. We added Galleria Borghese as an after thought as we figured we would see enough art going through the Vatican Museum. I am so glad we did! I had heard of Raphael, but really had no idea of the beauty of his work. Bernini's statues can not be fully appreciated in a picture. You must be in the room with them!Warning: We took a cab from the taxi stand at the Colosseum. After we were driving a couple of minutes, I notice that the meter was not running. I asked the driver how much the ride would cost. 14 Euro. It seemed a little high, but we were already moving. When we were leaving Borghese (at closing time) we walked to the taxi stand, but there were no taxis to hire! Luckily, the florist there took pity on us and called a taxi. The taxi ride back used his meter and was only 7.50 Euro.
Amazing sculptures and paintings. The audio guide is a must. You must reserve in advance and get there 15 minutes before your reserved time.

Well organized gallery. We made a reservation for this about a week ahead of time. This is required, and they stick to the reservation times very carefully. You have to budget your time, as there is a 2 hour time limit. We loved seeing all the Bernini artwork, and the rooms are well laid out, with informative signage and helpful staff.

Very nice Gallery. very nice collection of statues and painting gathered by the Borghese family.Very nice paintings from Caravaggio but personally, I preferred the statues on the first floor. They are all very beautiful with a special mention for Bernini work (I am always surprised that he managed to get some of his work into roman churches).Book your tickets in advance on the internet otherwise chances are that you will not get inside, the number of visitors is limited to about 200 every 2 hours.

Beautiful Gallery. The Galleria Borghese is situated in a large municipal park just outside the walls of ancient Rome. The Galleria has gorgeous sculptures and paintings, especially by Rafael and Caravaggio. Be sure to book your tickets well in advance.

A Roman Jewel. The Galleria is a wonderful jewel in the middle of parkland. The day we visited it was pouring with rain but we were pleased we went, worth the struggle against the wind and rain as the collection is stunning. A Roman Jewel.
Amazing. Very close to our hotel. You need to book ahead but well worth it. In a beautiful park . Amazing art collection
Well worth the visit. Great sculpture and decorations. It was very crowded. People were turned away who had not reserved. You have to reserve online before you go.

Best collections. This museum is by far the best, nestled in the Villa Borghese complex, the gallery is based in the villa. The highlights are the fantastic works of Bernini, Rape of Prosperina, David and Apollo and Daphne. They mesmerising and the detailing is fantastic. Room after room, work after work, I must say the museum has been delightfully curated. Whatever you do don't miss this for the world.
One of the best museums in Rome!!. In the center of the lovely Villa Borghese ,the Galleria Borghese is a must see in Rome. If you like Roman art this is the place for you. Don't miss!!

If you have any interest in sculpture this is an essential visit. This was my first trip to the Galleria Borghese and I am very glad that I went.Here are the main points I discovered:You must book your visit in advance. As soon as you know when you intend to visit, check the Galleria Borghese website and book your tickets. I think that they allow bookings up to 6 weeks ahead. The sooner you can book the better. If you call them you can use your Roma pass to get a reduction on the ticket price, but I simply booked online and paid the full price of 13 euro per person.Visits are booked for a specific day and 2 hour time slot. Do plan to arrive at the Galleria in plenty of time before your time slot, maybe 30 minutes. You need to deposit any bags at the locker room beforehand. You are also not allowed to take pictures or video anywhere inside the museum.Also, note that the Galleria Borghese is quite a trek from central Rome. Even if you get off at one of the nearer metro stops (eg Spagna) it is still a long walk, maybe 30 minutes or 45 minutes. It is also not that well signposted. So, either allow plenty of time for your journey or consider a bus or taxi. There is also no cover on the walk to the Galleria and if it does rain (as it did on us!) you can get quite wet. Come prepared for the weather!Do always consider a Roma pass when visiting Rome. It costs 30 euro but gets you into your first 2 attractions free and many more at half price. It also gives you free transport for 3 days on the buses and metro and allows you to bypass the ticket queues which can be a real boon at some attractions.There aren't really any other major attractions in the immediate vicinity of the Galleria, so you need to plan what you are going to do with the other half of the day. The Galleria does sit in a large and very pleasant park which in some places has excellent views of Rome. It is often recommended to visit the upper floor of the museum first, which houses the paintings. This is because most people start downstairs with the sculpture. The idea is that by the time you have seen the paintings (which I found only moderately interesting) the people on the lower floor will have finished looking at the sculpture and will start to leave, allowing you more spce to see the sculptures. This is what we did and it worked quite well.The sculptures are truly remarkable and it's hard to imagine that sculpture could ever exceed what is here. In particular the sculpture of Napoleons sister on a couch and the sculpture of Apollo and Daphne are incredible. The couch, despite being of marble, really looks like a comfy couch and how the leaves and branches were done I do not know!I did not notice a cafe at the museum, although there may well be one. There are of course toilet facilities.

Great museum and gallery. Largest collection of Bernini's work I have seen. We opted for the audio guide (5 euro) and it was well organized and well timed. There is so much to see and you are limited to a fixed time of 2 hours from the time of admission, so it is best to go with a guided tour or the audio guide. The gallery of paintings at the end was breathtaking. In addition to the gallery, be sure to leave time to see the Villa and the surrounding land. There are beautiful walking trails and the nicest dog park in Rome.

A must-see in Rome, but advance planning will save hassles. The Bernini sculptures in this collection are reason enough to see this museum, and I'm glad we put it on our list.We used a Roma Pass for entry, so we had to call them directly to reserve our slots. I don't speak any Italian, but I had no trouble reserving our times, and the phone call took all of 4 minutes.Once we got to Rome in the afternoon, we had a lot of trouble finding the 116 bus that takes you right up to the Borghese Gallery, and one passed us by at a bus stop because we weren't on the curb waiving vigorously enough for the driver to stop. We did finally catch a 116 bus and it took us right to the museum. To spare the frustration, I wish we had researched before we got to Rome the exact street coordinates where the 116 picks up, and more importantly, where we wanted to get off when we were finished at the gallery. We rode it very far out of our way when we were done because it was dark and we didn't know when to get off the bus!I am glad we invested the additional 5 to 7 euro (cash only!) in an audio tour so we weren't just gazing at stuff without knowing why it was special. Also FYI, you cannot take ANY bags (purses, etc.) into the gallery. They have a monitored bag check, and though I was a bit nervous about leaving my purse anywhere, its contents came back undisturbed.After seeing the place, I wished we would've headed directly upstairs to see the paintings first, then came down to see the sculpture on the first floor so we could have had the sculptures to ourselves for the remaining two hours. The sculptures are truly breathtaking, but harder to enjoy with lots of people trying to see them at the same time.

Beautiful. This was the highlight of our trip and well worth the effort of having to book ahead (the hotel did this for us). They only allow a two hour visit which is just about enough time to see the whole gallery, but they start to clear the gallery after a hour and fifty minutes. The metro stop is the Spagna and there are signs to the gallery in the metro. You then walk to the house through the park, which is also stunning. The house is so beautiful, that it's worth a visit on it's own without all the amazing art. The gallery contains the most determined looking statue of David that I've ever seen in my life!! This is a must see for Rome (and you get discount with your Roma pass!)

A Bernini Theater.. My wife and I visited the Galleria Borghese when we were in Rome last July. This has to be one of the premier museums in Europe. The paintings and marble sculptures are from the most talented and renowned of Italian artists. It was refreshing to see such a variety of work as many museums in Italy are guilty of "Madonna and child" overload. The art is so excellent that you can easily return several times and enjoy it just as much as your first visit. It's also a very warm and attractive building where the lighting and environment seem to compliment the displays in a seamless fashion. Bernini's marble statues left an especially strong impression on us. That's saying a lot since the competition for greatness is really evident at the Borghese. However, his statues are absolutely stunning. They evoke a sense of motion that is common with the baroque period. Check out Apollo and Daphne, The Rape of Proserpina and David. If your not a fan of great art, you will be after seeing these irresistible masterpieces.
Close to Heaven!. Our eyes popped out at all of the historical art and sculptures at the gallery. Truly, it is a must see when visiting Rome. You will use the maximum time allowed for your tour!

Amazing, Opulent, Inspirational.... ...only problem is that without an audio (or personal) guide you get a bit lost, as there is just so much to see. I literally felt dizzy after quick-gazing at hundreds of masterpieces - this place is a must for lovers of art and/or those who wish to expand their cultural experiences a little further. I wouldn't, however, advise taking children under the age of 8 (unless the child is quite quiet and has a predisposition towards art) because of the nature of the exhibitions.

Small, intimate and ALL remarkable. There are only a handful of museums in the world -- the Frick and Mauritzhuis come to mind -- where a "small" collection which can be encompassed comfortably in a couple of hours is housed in a beautiful and accessible building. The Berninis and Caravaggios are undoubtedly the highlights, but the (mostly unlabeled) Roman statuary is no less impressive both for its amazing condition breadth of scope. DO make a reservation for 9 AM and get there a few minutes early to ensure that you can enjoy the 2 full hours -- and follow Rick Steves' advice of starting upstairs in the Pinocoteca.
AMAZING!. Make the reservation. Reubens, Raphael, Bergnini, are just a few of the treats at this place. It was my humanities textbook coming to life.

Outstanding Art. We highly suggest visiting the Galleria Borghese if you are a big fan of Art and History. You must have a reservation to get into the gallery but it's easy to make reservations online or ask your hotel to make them on your behalf. A free bag check is provided as no bags whatsoever are allowed in the gallery - not even small purses. We suggest taking a stroll through the park before or after your visit as it's beautiful and filled with locals without many tourists.

A great slice of culture. If your looking for a refreshing taste of culture set within a lovely park then this is the place to go.It does require pre booking as it runs on a time slot system but this helps to keep things running smoothly and you still get plenty of time to look around.

It takes your breath away.... I think it is absolutely impossible to dislike Galleria Borghese, the art gallery housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana.First take a stroll through Borghese gardens if the weather is permitted. We were there at the beginning of January, and the weather was absolutely delightful (nice and warm).It is advisable to hire an audio guide if you did not book a guided tour, otherwise you'll miss it. The Galleria contains an amazing collection of paintings, sculpture and antiquities begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese. He was also an early patron of Bernini and collector of works by Caravaggio. That's why, Bernini is so well represented by his famous sculptures like Apollo and Daphne, Rape of Proserpina etc. My daughter absolutely fell in love with his creations - they are so flawless, airy as if they are alive. We were impressed by Bernini's sculptures most of all. Also we really enjoyed paintings by Caravaggio (his Boy with a Basket of Fruit), Titian, Raphael and Rubens. Without doubt, we consider the sculpture of Pauline Bonaparte (sister of Napoleon Bonaparte) to be a pearl of this beautiful collection.There are twenty rooms across two floors, you need to book your visit in advance on-line or by phone, otherwise you will be turned off. No reservation - no entrance, tickets are always sold out. Also you can book the certain time of the day to visit, so plan in advance and enjoy.

Requires pre-booking but worth it!. We went to Rome in a "slow" season (mid-February) and were able to pre-book tickets to this museum online with short notice. We booked the opening time, 9 a.m., and it was well worth it. There is so much history and artwork in this beautiful, smaller museum—it was amazing. Even our teenage daughters enjoyed it (who usually roll their eyes at me when I make them go into yet another museum). The videoguides are worth the investment as well as the signage is pretty much all in Italian. Another perk about going at the opening time is there aren't very many people there; we kept hearing on the audioguide that "this room will be crowded but still look at ..." and we never had that problem. You're allowed two hours in the museum and you'll want to stay every minute.

A new favorite. This is a new favorite museum for me - and whenever I return to Rome I will make the time to go again. You need to make a reservation and purchase your ticket in advance - at least a week in advance. We arrived by bus, and it was quite easy. It's a quick walk from the bus stop to the museum. (note - we did not see anyplace to eat when we got off the bus, so walked to the museum. The cafeteria in the museum was closed, so we picked up our tickets and then had time to walk through the park to find a cart where we bought sandwiches and sat on a bench enjoying the park. The people watching was top-notch!) This museum is one of those perfect-sized museums. It's big enough to keep you fascinated, but small enough that it's not overwhelming. Get the audio tour and take your time. Tours are timed every couple of hours - so you all enter at once and have a couple of hours to enjoy. You may want to ditch the crowd and go counter-clockwise, or find a way to skip ahead and then backtrack. I didn't know much about Italian art, but after this visit I'm just entranced. Don't miss this collection! By the way - there is an elevator and a staircase - depending on your energy and ability. I think you probably have to take a few steps to get into the building. The gift shop is good - pick up a few postcards to remember the art you loved. You will need to check your bags, coat, etc. so make sure to allow time for that.
The church, the man, the collection. This place is a must for all to visit while in Rome. Find out how most of the pieces collected have a connection back to the power of the church.

Must be one of the best museums in the world. This is an incredible collection of art, built up over 400 years by the wealthy Borghese family. The museum is quite small, but every exhibit is worth studying.Highlights include six paintings by Caravaggio (I think this is the largest number in a museum anywhere in the world) and at least five of Bernini's greatest sculptures. His 'David' and 'Apollo and Daphne' are simply amazing. And don't forget the extensive art gallery upstairs, which includes works by Raphael, Rubens and Titian.The only drawback to the place is the staff, who seem to hate tourists and go out of their way to make life difficult for visitors. Just grit your teeth and obey their petty rules, for the sake of the art.

Amazing art!. We were lucky enough to get tickets on the day, thanks to Francesco at Hotel Rimini.Take your time when looking at the amazing pictures and sculptors, you will get a sore neck, the ceilings are just awesome!

Go early. I went in February and I imagine it was relatively quiet. Although you have to reserve a time to visit and numbers are limited, the entry process left a lot to be desired. We were directed to go in through the bookshop and although I already had a ticket via my Roma Pass there was no separate line for pass holders unlike at some other sites. You were required to get your ticket before checking your bag, but the ticket queue was placed after the bag check, so people were milling back and forward and there was very little room in the admissions area BUT...once in it was worth every penny of the admission fee and any amount of waiting. In fact, the Caravaggios and the Apollo and Daphne were sublime and limiting the number of visitors made it possible to really spend your allocated 2 hours enjoying your favourite pieces.
Spectacular. Art that you can only see here. Superb rooms. Superb art both sculpture and paintings. David with the slingshot is very special

Well organized and staffed. We bought tickets in advance and were asked to be 15 minutes before time. At this time we exchanged reservations by tickets (actually this step could be avoided....) and left bags at the front desk. The visit started on time and the organized entrance was OK since it regulates the number of visitants. The sorounding Park is wonderful and added to the visit. The pinacoteque and the sculptures at the exposition are excellent and well maintained (photos are forbidden) - highly recommended.

Don't miss this!. Just seeing the inside of this gorgeous museum is worth the entry fee. I have seen some beautiful places all over Europe, but I can honestly say the ceilings and walls in this galleria are some of the most amazing I have ever laid eyes on. I easily made reservations from the USA before I left and we walked right in. Two hours is plenty, though I have to admit I went back three times to see the Bernini sculpture of Apollo and Daphne - it was simple exquisite. Next time I will do the audio guide, and I WILL go back, even though I don't like doing anything twice! You cannot take any photos inside (don't even bother trying!) so I bought lots of postcards at the gift shop. Also, there is a nice little cafe to get a snack or drink.
Beautiful Museum. We liked very much the bertini's sculptures and many very known paints.You must make a reservation and the access is limited in time.A must see in Rome.

Beautiful. We have visited the gallery 4 times over the last 7 years - need i Say more. Great history and art. Some of the most beautiful sculpture in the world. Book early you will need prereservations on most days. Tours are guided and you have a set time to enter and to exit. Plan to walk the gardens and see the other sights on the gorunds. There is even a zoo. Bring a picnic lunch in a backpack and spend the entire day. On a good day it is as close to heaven as you can get on earth.

Simply stupendous. The six Caravaggios (in one room), the ceilings, and the Bernini sculptures alone make this a Rome must-see. Plus hundreds of others to make an art fan weep with joy. The two hour time slot (not strictly observed, it seems, at least in early February) is plenty of time to take in your favourite pieces and generally absorb to magisterial opulence of the place. Tip: Do you homework on getting there in time and knowing what you can and can't take in with you.Tip 2: The cafe wasn't open during my visit. If you want a drink go to the small bar one hundred meters away, just to the east through the gates to the park.

Not impressed in a city like Rome. Fifth visit to Rome so thought we'd take this in for the first time. The Galleria is located in a large park which is not worth investigating. When we arrived, the signs said you had to order tickets for a future date. When I inquired about it, I was told, no problem we could get in immediately. This was a little concerning since it showed they were not well organized.Nice, not great art. Not pleased with the art presentation, map, orgainization, descriptive information or the time limit imposed on visitors. Entry to the gallery was also confused with everyone queing to leave their bags upon entrance (none allowed in the building), or queing to pick up their bags upon exit. Everyone working their seemed brusk, not just to us, but others as well.Over rated and rather expensive to visit. If you go, you'll be kind of isolated in that part of town with a long walk or cab to anything else of interest. Rather spend time at central museums or galleries and skip this one. You can live without it.

Galleria Borghese. Two floors, one of sculptures, one of paintings. Lots of Bernini and Caravaggio. Beautiful rooms, amazing private collection of the Borghese family. No cameras allowed, your bag is left in a cloakroom to be collected at the end. Didn't realise you could pay for an audio guide until after we'd left in our bags, so had to do without. Great if you're an avid fan of art, impressive collection anyway, worth a look if you're staying in Rome for more than a weekend.

This is a Future Favorite Memory. Galleria Borghese has the right idea by limiting the number of patrons. It affords you the ability to wander and get up close to these paintings and sculptures.  Here's a tip: Once inside you may enter whatever room you wish. When the crowd goes one way, go the opposite. You'll get to spend some alone time with great works of art. Get up close to a Caravaggio canvas and view it from different angles and distances. See how Pluto's fingers into the flesh of Proserpina and you'll scarcely believe this was carved from stone. Book in advance. Nearly everybody says this this but it's not overstated. Book it well before you arrive in Rome. It will be one of your favorite stops you recall your Roman Holiday years from now.

BOOK in advance. By chance we left the wifi-enabled Gardens and entered the Galleria at a quiet time of day and year, otherwise we would have missed this wonderful place.Not enough time to use audio guide or book. Just wandered around admiring everything. Labels only in Italian. Well worth the wait if you arrive in ignorance of the timed ticketing system.
Fantastic. No. 1 site to see in Rome! Beautiful grounds and wonderful museum. Be sure to make your advance reservation to see this amazing place.

Outstanding. Walking up to Borghese Galleria is breathtaking & relaxing.The house & artwork inside is amazing.The gardens are stunning.No bags including handbags or camera's allowed inside.You have to check them in downstairs before heading in.Security in everyroom.The paintings are unbelievable.Booking in advance is highly recommended.

Well worth seeing. You get a lot with a visit here. It is in the Borghese Gardens, so it is a lovely setting, but in addition you see a stunning villa with a brilliant collection of paintings and statues, quite a few of which are very familiar to art lovers.
Very accessible. I had expected something like Versailles. What I found was much more accessible, easier to understand, and better art.
A must see!!. If you love Bernini, you must go to this lovely museum. It is a treasure. There are a number of amazing Bernini statues, and the museum is located in beautiful gardens.
