Bernini overload - but in a good way. With so much to see in Rome, I'm glad we took the time to see this place. There's alot to see but be sure, obviously, to take plenty of time to see all of the Bernini works. Amazing.

Advance Timed Reservation Suggested - Your patience will be rewarded. An advance timed reservation is necessary but unfortunately that process could not be more difficult or inefficient. I had to call Italy multiple times on four different dates before I was able to secure a timed a reservation. The staff answering the phones were not very helpful and I was hung up on before I was done more than once. If you do manage to get a reservation it is a must see and worth the hassle. If you decide to walk up there is a good chance you will be turned away.

one piece alone was worth the entrance fee. the Bernini sculpture of Apollo & Daphne was my favorite in all of Rome. It alone was worth the entrance fee to the Borghese Gallery and there was so much more to see...

The best Museum I have ever been in. Off the top, book your tickets on line ahead of time or you will wait in line for hours. You have your ticket in your hand and have a set time (make sure you are on time or you will not get in and have to stand in line), They only let so many people in at one time and you have to be out by a certain time, so don't dally around so as to see everything in this museum.This site is fantastic, you won't find another like it anywhere. A tip... get the guided voice tour, it's well worth it.This is a must see in Italy, beats the Vatican hands down.Cheers

A lot to see - all high quality. So many people visit that you need to book in advance for a timed slot - though being January we got our hotel to phone through first thing in the morning to reserve us a slot for 11.00am. We were in fact let in early and didn't leave until 1.00pm. Perhaps the outstanding works are the sculptures by Bernini, but there is also ancient sculpture and an art gallery, all in beautiful rooms. Well worth the visit.

Only for devoted masochists. There is no way to get to it except taxi. Public transit was on strike, but nobody would tell us that. I walked 2 hours to get to it, and then gave up. BTW, they insist that you announce visit in advance. NEVER BUY THE TICKET IN ADVANCE!!! You can never be sure if you can get there.
Great art exhibit. Incredible sculptures and lots of really great paintings in a magnificent mansion. Beyond imagination!

Great Gallery. Loved this for the Sculptures. it was great to see a Museum where everything was exhibited in location where the pieces were purpose commissioned. Loved the marble of Pauline however she looked as if she may have had a dislocated # of radius; sure Bernini knew best. Apollo & Daphne exquisite. Remember that a time must be booked for entry, as numbers are restricted. We were annoyed that the attendants did not enforce the queues allowing many people to jump the lines.

Lovely art museum, with amazing history. Fantastic museum full of Bernini and Michelangelo and Raphael works. Hard to believe this was a home.Even if you don't think so, two hours is not enough. You will need the whole two hours they allow you. Tip- get the audio guide, it was very helpful and provide lots of facts about the pieces that even kept my husband interested!

Take a taxi to the door if you are not able to climb the steep steps and hills across the Villa Borghese!. The museum is fabulous, no question, but access to the museum is difficult for older patrons that cannot walk steep inclines or the steps required to get to the second floor up steep spiral stairs. Take a taxi as the bus 53 did not run on Sunday, we waited and missed our time. We still were able to enter with the Roma Pass and enjoy the beautiful works of art! I just wish someone advised to NOT TAKE THE SUBWAY, the walk is very long and steep UPHILL.
Galleria Burghese. Wonderful visit, I recomment the guided tour ( there is a tour in English twice a day). The gardens are also beautiful. Take a few hours to visit.

Crowded site, overrated. I had very high expectations for this museum and went on the advice of others that had visited. I appreciate the important scupture and painintgs in the Galleria Borgese, but there is also beautiful art in the free churches throughout Rome. You would not expect a museum that requires advance reservations and limits the amount of time you can spend on each floor to be so crowded inside, but it most certainly was on the Sunday afternoon we visited the Borgese Gallery. The museum also makes you check all bags and other items, including small purses and umbrellas. The audio guide that you pay 5 euros for (which I'd recommend having, since not all works in the museum are even labeled) does not match the route you must take inside so you waste time trying to figure out what room you are in and why it does not match up with the start of the audio guide. I found this museum, although beautiful, to be expensive (20 euros) and overrated.

A magical gallery located in the Borghese Gardens.... The last time we were here was during the Bacon/Caravaggio exhibition. It is simply tremendous to have a Galleria that feels more like a home/castle than an art institution...Reminder it is a little bit of a walk from the Flaminia/Piazza Popolo metro...
An absolute must. Superb collection of sculpture, make sure you get a guide.Important !!! Reservations are mandatory - so book in advance via the internet.

Note time limit and reservation. We read that the Gallery housed some Raphael and his successors, so we decided to check it out after covering the other highlights. We visited on our last day before treking to the airport. Luckily, we were in Rome during off season and arrived promptly at 9am to the gallery, as a reservation is required. Also, you are given a 2 hour time slot. Others wait until their time slot and the museum is cleared at the end of each. Interesting system; however, it was plenty of time for us as we were leaving anyways. It is not huge in size either, so perhaps they have their system in place with this knowledge. Worth a visit if you have some time to spare and want to fit in a little more art.

Another wonderful visit. The gallery was just magnificent!! make reservations and pay for tickets ahead of time to avoid delays as only so many people are allowed in at any given time frame. Head phones are a must to make the most of your visit!

Better than Vatican!. The vibrant artworks in Borghese Gallery is so much more impressive than the faded ones at Vatican City! Too bad photographing is not allowed... The crowd is huge, take bus 910 from Termini to save the long uphill walk from the Metro!
To book. Always to book galleria borghese, not possible go there if you don't have reservation. But to get this number you only have to phone them, ask to Gigi!!
Best of Rome. I loved this gallery, which is set in a beautiful park in northern rome. Have to see the sculpture of daphne, and David by Bernini.

great museum with great artwork....... great piece of art with its fine gallery and sculptors.....amazing in artwork and its garden and courtyardlots of work from Bernini and his great marble artworkFYI - no photos are allowed

Not Just For Art Lovers. I am an art historian, but I travel with family members who are a little less keen about spending hours in a museum. That said, my husband felt this to be one of the peak artistic experiences he has had. The audio tour is wonderful, so I do not think a personally guided tour is necessary, but do make your reservations ahead of time.

Must see. This museum is absolutely brialliant. It is well laid out and they limit numbers in two hour slots so that you are not fighting mobs of people. The works of art are etraordinary and the digital listening guide is well worth the small cost.

AN INCREDIBLE EXPERIENCE. The Galleria itself is amazing in its opulence and the artwork within is marvelous. The grounds look lovely as well although our visit was in November on a drizzly day and therefore did not get much of a chance to experience the park.

Bernini masterpieces in marble. Amazing sculptures by Bernini. While every guide and the museum's website will insist that you have to precook tickets, on two trips in the off season I have been able to buy tickets at the door for immediate entry. So if you're visiting rome in the winter, chances are you don't have to reserve in advance.

Fabulous house and gardens. We went here as part of an organised trip and were not disappointed. The house and all the art, sculptures and general decor was really good. High praise from one who doesn't really "do" museums and galleries. The audio guide is worth having as it gives you lots of extra information. Very well organised as timed entry, also has a good cafe and toilets.

Took My Breath Away!. Do not miss this fantastic collection! The sculptures alone are worth the visit. I never wanted to leave. You must have reservations and only 350 guests are allowed in at a time with a set amount of time per group. Once you are in the gallery you are free to move about in the different areas. I enjoy this option so that I can linger at pieces that captivate me. No bags of any kind are permitted. The limited number of visitors allows for a relaxed and intimate experience in the gallery. The audio tour is a worthwhile addition to the tour and enhances the experience.Give yourself a full day for this gallery and the surrounding park. It is a beautiful slice of art and nature in the heart of Rome.

Worth the visit. Well worth the visit and make sure to take extra time to visit the surrounding park and gardens and other museums. I think you have to love art and sculpture and history to appreciate this gallery and its not for everyone, but well worth the visit if you do. Note they do set time entry and do not let late comers in. Book well ahead in busy times.

Beautiful!! the best in Rome. Amazing collection of Bernini's sculptures which were so life like that you could almost see them coming to life. Correggio's masterpiece, Danäe was stunning. You need to make advance reservations otherwise they will offer you the 5 to 7 pm slot if you just walk. A must see for people interested in scuptures and paintings.

best museum of my whole trip. 2 hours very short . i bought the book about the 10 most important exhibits and just had a short time left for everything else. no time for the audio guide, will come again for that. i had prepared the caravaggios and the bernini statues, so I spent ages just gazing at those. Even if you are not into art this is an amazing museum.

Caravaggio feast. Timed tickets, strict entry rules - and still a bit crowded. We booked for the 5pm - 7pm slot, hoping it would be less busy, but it wasn't really. The Caravaggios are all together on the ground floor. I had seen some at an exhibition some years ago, and looked forward to seeing them again and others new to me. The gallery does have a lift, which is just as well as the stairs are testing and I could note have managed them. Once upstairs however, wheelchairs were available.
Very nice Sculptures. while sculptures are not my favorite artwork to see this place was very neat to see must make reservations ahead of time
Borghese Gallery. Incredible collection of premier Italian Renaissance Art in a magnificent setting. Advance reservations required, but the museum beautifully manages crowds.

Brilliant!. The building itself and the garden itself are very impressive but the art collection is, of course, spectacular. Personally, I'm not the biggest fan of Bernini, but Caravaggio and Raphael, Botticelli and Antonello da Messina, Fra Angelico and Titian are definitely enough of a reason to visit the gallery.

Reservations required!. Our hotel let us know on check-in that we would need reservations, so that was great. We went on my 52nd birthday, which is a tradition of ours. You can't take photos inside which is understandable but makes me sad. The pieces are historical, beautiful, and amazing! It's hard to see everything since there is so much it's a little overwhelming but in a good way!

Love art......You'll love this!. We came here after family members told us not to miss, it was a rainy afternoon so we walked up to Villa Borghese. Before you enter the museum after paying you are made to leave your handbag in the reception area, no cameras no phones allowed it was very strict. The art work and sculptures are amazing, we saw work from some of the great well known artists Bernini, Rafael, TItan etc etc. Every single room took our breath away. For 2 people it was 21 euro I got a little discount as I am under 27.

Amazing sculpture. Highly recommended, some of the most fabulous sculpture in the world by Bernini and Michelangelo. Audio tour was great with just the right amount of interesting information - it really enhanced our visit.

If it's the Only Museum you Visit....See this one!. Some of the most beautiful art in Rome are here. It was like a sampler plate of the great masters! Bernini, da Vinci, Raphael, Canova, Titian....artists whose works are easily recognizable! I became a fan of Bernini once I saw Apollo and Daphne. The gallery is only two floors, but packed with beautiful art. You are limited in the amount of time you can stay, so you don't get overloaded as you might in many larger museums.
superb. they say it has the the best private art collection in the world. I vehemently concur! its just 2 floors and you need to reserve in advance, but the place was more than worth it.
Bernini masterpieces. The Roman mosaics and especially the Bernini sculptures are well worth a visit.Be aware of the time limit on your entry ticket and all bags have to be checked in.

Book online before your trip. We booked online before we left for the trip because only 360 people are allowed every two hours. We took a cab from the Pantheon and it was about 10 euros. Cardinal Borghese built a villa to showcase his art collection. He was the nephew of a pope and gained considerable influence due to being related. There are two main areas: the picture gallery and the main entry hall which contained sculptures. We did not buy an audio guide but used Rick Steve's guidebook. Some of the main interests were: Napoleon's sister as Venus, Bernini's interpretation of David, my favorite was Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. In the picture gallery there was a Raphael, Titan and some Berninis.It was an interesting gallery to view the impressive marble sculptures but it pales when compared to the Louvre and the Prado.It was raining so we didn't walk through the gardens. I would imagine it would be enjoyable on a warm summer day.

Bernini to die for!. This gallery is full of exquisite artworks and sculptures, many of which were 'acquisitioned' through coercion by Cardinal Scipione. My favourite was Apollo and Daphne, where she is transformed into a laurel tree. Apparently the highest thin leaves of marble will sound a note ... Although of course, I could not test this out! You need to book ahead for a timed ticket.

Amazing Galleria, shame about the staff.. We booked on line and received an email to exchange for tickets on arrival. The Galleria is in a large park,near a zoo where there are sign posts and maps. The Gallerias collection was amazing and is value for money and well worth a visit, it exeeded our expectations.It was such a shame that the staff on the ticket desk were completely not interested in welcoming us, and spoke amongst themselves as if we were invisible. No eye contact or help was given, and when asked where the cafe was we were abruptly told "closed". Luckly we didnt take a bag or any valuables, because none are allowed.There are ques for audio tours and group tours, we wanted a group tour and were told by another member of staff "no tour guide at 1,only audio" she then said" tour guides were at 9am and 11am but not at 1pm," our pre booked tickets were for 1pm!. We feel that this could have been organised and explained better. Luckly the audio tour was good and cost 5 euros each.We spent 2hours in the Galleria Borghese which was amazing.We didnt find the staff at the Galleria helpful at all, they do the bare minimum. Dont expect any customer service,no help or direction was given.If the cafe is closed their is a nice one by the zoo.Galleria was Excellent.Staff were terrible.

The Best of Bernini. We found this collection wonderful, especially the sculptures. The setting was equally impressive and well looked after. The only negative point was that having to get there half an hour prior to visit with pre-paid tickets didn't make much sense.

Amazing!. I couldn't get beyond the first room. The marble sculptures were perfection...almost like someone poured marble over humans. THe detail in the carving was so precise you could almost see the blood pulsing through their veins.THe gardens are absolutely beautiful and lovely to sit and read or write in your journal. Absolutely worth a tour.
Galleria Borghese. For this, my third visit, I had a professional guide, which made for time better spent and more enjoyable. She was also on hand to answer our myriad questions.
Best for last .... Another gem - had earliest time booked online - for my last day of 6 in Rome. I still look back at souvenir book at all that is contained here.

A good place to go for art lovers. In order to not be disappointed, one need to adjust the expectation: this is a collection of a rich family. There is a few top notch pieces in the galleria, but it is not Metropolitan, not Louvre, not Hermitage. The diffidence is between a very rich man and greatest Kings.

Wonderful. It's the second time I visit and will go again whenever I have a chance. Bernini statues are mesmerizing, the palace itself is breathtaking. Must make reservation or buy tickets in advance.

Galleria Borghese+the Park. The immense collection (incl. Caravaggio, Titian, Raphael, Bernini...) is almost too much. If you love this period in art - this is the place to go! But prepare mentally to take it all in, but read ahead so to concentrate on the best pieces - there are 20 rooms to see! The only limitation is that only 2 hrs are allowed inside + you have to reserve a time to go as the group size is limited. But as there are no crowds, it is almost an intimate experience, so it is eve better. Roma pass will get you free inside. DO NOT FORGET TO VISIT THE WHOLE GARDEN AROUND! Unforgettable.

Fantastic! Best Part of 10 Day Trip to Rome!. Galleria Borghese was my favorite place in Rome. The collection is amazing, especially the mesmerizing Bernini statues of David and Apollo e Dafne (which I could have stared at for hours). The Annunciation painting located right inside the main doors brought tears to my eyes because it is so gorgeous.A few things: make a reservation online, show up about 15 minutes before your time slot in order to pick up your tickets (which give you a two-hour limit for visiting the museum). I highly recommend renting the audio tour for 5 euros. Lots of interesting details that put the collection in historical perspective.Lovely!

Lovely Gallery. Wonderful gallery. Amazing works of art so enjoy, but be aware of the entry system. You need a timed booking - available online - but you then line up outside to get your ticket, which can take up to half an hour. You then must hand in any bags, cameras etc so do allow more time - and do make sure you arrive half an hour before your timed entry. Also do be aware that you will not get in early - timed entry does mean that two hour entry. Overall though an amazing collection of works and for me the sculptures were the highlights.

An absolute must see!. This was recommended and I'm so glad as it possibly wasn't on my radar but was my favourite gallery/museum of our Europe trip. The building interior and the sculptures are incredible, especially Apollo e Dafne by Bernini. You must book ahead (online is easy) and get here even if you only have 2-3 days in Rome.

A must see museum - even if you only visit this one. Absolutely gorgeous! A breeze of fresh air in noisy, hectic Rome. This villa is located in a lovely and spacious park, the villa itself is to die for and the art is as exciting as the walss, paintings, and ceilings. A must! Reservations are required, but easily acquired online.

One of the world's most beautiful museums. Wandering around the Borghese is one of life's great pleasures, the Bernini statues are breathtaking and they have more stunning pictures than you can take in, the whole experience is a delight in a beautiful setting
Amazing Museum - Book in Advance. This is an amazing museum to visit. Ensure you book in advance it is very worthwhile. Beautiful sculptures of Bernini and much more.
Must see Apollo and Daphne. Make a reservation and give yourself 20-25 minutes to walk from the nearest metro. See room 3. Part of Roma Pass but you still need to make a reservation.

Galleria Borghese. The only place where you can see Bernini's scuptures up close!! Well worth it, book in advance! The museum is not only beautiful but filled with the most amazing sculptures from the king of modern Roman architecture and art.

Book and prepare in advance. More of two hundreds of richness and taste gave the borghese family the oppurtunity to collect masterpieces that you won't have the time to appreciate, due to the maximum stay of two hours allowed. Online booking is mandatory. My advice is to study in advance the works of art on the e-site, then plan your way. Not to waste time, be there half an hour before your scheduled time and leave luggages and bags at the desk downstairs, then go upstairs and queue there. Follw your interests, classical paintings, Greek-Roman sculpture and Cellini. Obviously, don't miss Canova's Paolina.

Magnificent Bernini Sculptures and More. I was completely blown away by the magnificent Bernini sculptures in this museum, spending half an hour admiring the Apollo and Daphne piece. No photographs or videos can fully capture the beauty of the Bernini sculptures.Reservation is needed as the museum is very busy. Get an audio guide because there was not written descriptions of the art in this museum. We visited during around Christmas, each visiting group was limited to a two-hour session which was tight if one wished to view all the pieces. We had to skip a lot of the paintings to have enough time to admire the sculptures.Despite the chaos and confusion of the museum operations, Galleria Borghese is a must-see.

Fabulous Experience. We visited the Borghese Gallery the day before we left Rome and we were so thankful that we did. This was definitely one of the most spectacular displays of Bernini art located in one place. Although there were quite a few people visiting the gallery, I never had the feeling I was crowded or had to move at a certain pace through the exhibits. I could take as long as I wanted looking at the "Rape of Persephone" and other wonderful sculptures and paintings. The setting is beautiful and the display of art spectacular. A 'not to miss' experience if you're ever in Rome. But you have to reserve a date and time online and cannot just show up at the gallery. Also, each visit is a maximum of 2 hours in length which was more than enough time for us to see everything.

Art&history. Great collection of art mixed with history of the family.
Wish we had more time for thoughtful walk, 2 hours are not enough.
Not to be missed!. Best museum ever! Book tickets early-as they are often sold out! Each piece of artwork is amazing!!!!!

Amazing Galleria Borghese. Joined the English tour - it was amazing and absoutely worth it. Took a taxi to get there - best thing we did!! The art is incredible, incredible, incredible!! The restaurant was advertised but is not operational - take drink, food along. No photos allowed; bookshop is well stocked.

Morning at the Borghese. Spent the morning at the Villa Borghese with my family...wondered through the wonderful rooms enjoying the awesome pieces of art. The ground were also a refreshing break..there is a small museum also on the grounds that we toured featuring a 20th century sculptor. Go there!

Must see!. I am an art lover and was advised by more experienced travelers and my Italian night class teacher that this museum was not to be missed. How right they were. Statues by Bernini, paintings by Caravaggio and others moved me to tears. My family knew nothing about the art here, but we were all thrilled with the Bernini statues. We walked through the gardens a bit after our visit and they were beautiful, too. One big hint: we made our reservations online and got a time from 13:00 to 15:00 to visit. We thought that meant to arrive between those two times. No! That was the time we had in the museum! Get there right at the first time given, though you will wait in a line. We missed an hour in the museum because they clear the visitors out for the next group.

Magnificent. You need to have a reservation. Have your hotel book it for you.Go early, the line begins to form a half hour before your allotted time.The sculpture just blew me away...particularly the one of Apollo and Daphne. Her fingers are beginning to turn into tree branches...in marble.The gardens are lovely, and you can walk straight across to the Modern Art Museum, which was also wonderful.
Magnificent Art - out of the way. The Borghese Gallery contains magnificent paintings and sculpture. It is out of the way.. I would not include it on a one or two day visit

Well managed part of a lovely day. This ornate museum is situated in a large, beautiful green space that was a 10 Euro taxi ride for us from Trastevere (reasonable and worth it). It is carefully managed from a crowd control point of view (I wish more museums took this approach). You must be there 30 minutes before giving the museum staff time to process your entry which includes: checking all bags and cameras (no photos at all), verifying reservation, buying audiotape if desired...it all takes time but leaves you with the full two hours of viewing time that you are tightly restricted to for the two floors. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the price of admission. When your two hours are up, you will be almost escorted out to retrieve your bags if you are slow to respond to the announced admonishments to leave. As bossy as the staff are, I think it made for a much more civilized experience where there is room to actually see the art, at a reasonable pace and with enough time to cover everything. After you leave, you can stroll through the park to other museums, eat outside at the Museum of Contemporary Art and make your way out at either the Spanish Steps or the Piazza del Popolo. Rome's upscale shopping area is nearby on Vittorio Veneto and surrounding streets. It's a lovely day!

Art in motion. We were lucky enought to arrive for the early session and have an English guide all to ourselves - wow - she really made the museum and all its history, sculptures and artworks come alive! We'd recommend the guided tour to get the most out of this wonderful museum.

Galleria borghese. Unexpectedly great place. You have to book a time and was one of the best we saw in Rome also great to balance a trip to the park and the children's craft centre in the park with so everyone has fun.

Tips for maximizing your 2 hour visit. I visited Galleria Borghese in mid- October and like most visitors, was blown away by David, Pluto and Proserpina, Apollo and Daphne, etc. There are not enough superlatives to describe the sculptures and art in this exquisite museum. Just reserve your time and go and see for yourself. Tips:Don't wait for that 1/2 hour time slot to pick up your ticket. I arrived 2 1/2 hours beforehand, walked right up to the desk and was able to get my ticket immediately. That gave me plenty of time to enjoy the gardens and browse the gift shop before my prescheduled time. (I purchased the Galleria Borghese red guide book and found it helpful). Half an hour before my reservation time I checked my bag and again there was no line up as everyone else was in line waiting to pick up their ticket.I followed the advice in Rick Steve's Rome tour book and went directly upstairs to the Pinacoteca and stayed for approximately 25 minutes viewing the works of Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. By the time I got downstairs the crowd was thinning out and I was able to view Bernini's masterpieces and the other amazing sculptures without feeling rushed or having to dodge the crowds. At one point I was the only person in the room admiring David. In fact because of this strategy there was never more than 3 or 4 people at any time when I was looking at Bernini's sculptures and Pauline Borghese. Enjoy!

Gallery Borghese!. You can use your Roma Pass as one of two museums you can visit with the pass! The tours are in two hour time slots and I highly recommend you have your hotel concierge reserve the time slot you want to attend to avoid the long queue for your tickets! All you need is the confirmation number and time slot. After getting your tickets I suggest getting the audio to listen and guide you through the gallery! No cameras are allow in the gallery! As I would say that this gallery and the Vatican Museum are a must see in Rome!

Loved this place! One of the most beautiful I've visited!. You could spend hours here just taking in the amazing artwork and sculptures. The way the museum has been designed and decorated is stunningly beautiful. Cameras are not allowed to be taken in which is a shame but good in a way as it doesn't detract from the experience. Also, it was great that there were so few people allowed in each timed session so it ever became crowded and it felt like you were in a private viewing. The audio guide was 5€ and is worth it as you will learn more than just wandering around. I loved the Bernini sculptures!We booked through tickitaly who took into consideration the timings we could attend the gallery. Would love to visit again in the warmer months as its set in a beautiful park but we were cold and hungry so didn't hang around in the park. This place is a definite must when in Roma.

Take a guided tour. We took the tour with an art historian, who provided an excellent cultural history of the art in the gallery and of the gallery itself. The lines are very long--be sure to reserve tickets in advance, and then come with ample patience for the poorly organized way they get you into and out of the gallery. That said, it's worth it all. The art is beautiful, the sculptures stunning, and the building itself something to see. The grounds are also amazing--the gallery is in a park, with street musicians, food carts, and rolling hills to stroll around.

Must Sees in Roma. This is a must see while visiting Roma if you are interested in Bernini and Caravaggio. The Villa itself is fabulous and the surrounding park is someplace you can spend hours strolling through.
Worth the trip. Make reservation for this gallery. It is worth it. The gardens, the art and the area are all wonderful.
Astounding!. The collections in the Galleria Borghese are nothing less than jaw-dropping. My wife and I could easily spend an entire day in the Galleria, but they only allow you two hours at a time.

A Must see. Even the walk up the this attraction makes it worth it, strolling through the tree lined park, mixing with locals out for walks made the anticipation of this visit even greater. We had the folks at our B&B reserve us a time to visit, although for some this system may be a bind it makes it less busy and allows you space to view the art. The audio guide is very helpful and enhanced my understanding of the art groupings and the history around them.
In awe. The Galleria Borghese has one of the largest collections of Marble statues. It is a beautiful museum surrounded by a lovely park.

Overwhelming. Ticketing must be done ahead of time. Calling from the US was too complicated, but they responded to an e-mail. It is included in the Roma Pass but you still need a reservation. We arrived over an hour early to pick up our tickets and check our bags and avoided the crowds. The sculptures and paintings were impressive. It would have helped to have a guide or detailed guidebook.The circular marble steps to the upper floor were poorly marked and almost dangerous for a person with walking limitations. There is a small elevator which requires a staff member to operate and is only accessible from the lower level.There is almost too much to see, and In spite of timed ticketing it seemed crowded. My favorite sculpture was of John the Baptist. There were no pictures of it in the gift shop and of course photography was prohibited. The difference in atmosphere between the Galleria Borghese and the Pallazo Massimo was like night and day.

Worth a look. You need to reserve your ticket in advance, since they allow a limited number of people in at intervals, which means this is one of the attractions that require formal planning-ahead, but it is a worthwhile visit. An excellent collection of sculpture and paintings awaits you inside.

Great sculptures and paintings. Located in a quiet location in north-west Rome, this museum boats of a nice collection of sculptures and paintings. Do not miss the sculptures by Bernini, in particular the one of Pauline Borghese (and the stories about it). The garden is great for a walk after the visit to the museum. One gets two hours to go around the museum. No photos allowed and bags have to be left at the counter.
Bernini the master. A small but very rich museum. The Bernini sculptures were astounding! To think he was only 20 when he began producing such marvelous works

Must see!. The Bernini sculptures are not to be missed! Make sure to arrive early for your booked tour - you should book online ahead of time. Beautiful gallery. And the park outside is wonderful - we walked to the far end overlooking Piazza de Popolo for amazing views! We stopped at a little restaurant in the park along the way for a light lunch - very nice day....
not enough time to visit. it is a great place, but 2 hours is really not enough. With audio guide you could just see the chef oeuvres, but the others are also worth some time

Great Museum. I am not a museum guy bt this museum was beautiful and amazing. Every room was decorated from floor to ceiling. Be sure that you make a reservation prior to getting to Rome as it is by reservation only and don't be late. We had our hotel set it up.We were able to see the hotel in a little more than an hour.

Definitely must see but watch out for lack of organization!!!. The visit to Borghese gallery was absolutely mind blowing when it comes to the artistic side of it, but you've got to watch out for lack of organization. There is no separate queue for people with reservations so you have to stay in a huge line to pick up the tickets which you already purchased online. There is also a problem with getting upstairs since the stairs are difficult to find (a simple arrow or a sign would be helpful), many people don't even realise that there is an upstairs and they just go out.

For true art aficionados!. Gorgeous, restored museum palazzo in the Borghese Gardens. Bernini finest sculptures, Caravaggio, Titian and so much more. You are only allowed a 2 hour visit so plan accordingly and maximize what you see in this exceptional art museum. It's one of the top 5 things to see in Rome...the Vatican/Sistine Chapel, the Pantheon, the Colleseum, the Forum and the Borghese Gallery are absolute musts!
A must see - even if you're not into art. Even if you don't think you'd enjoy an art museum I'd still recommend visiting this one. The Bernini sculptures are just incredible.

Marble made flesh. Gem of a museum set in formal park land and finely cultivated gardens growing monster lemons. If the opulent ceilings, wall paintings and marble don't impress you then the Bellini sculptures will knock you sideways. The upper gallery contains many paintings of mainly religious content - not to my taste, but the gallery offers fine views of the park and gardens. Well worth the entry fee.

Too much to see and a hassle getting in even when pre booked.. The walk through the park to get there was beautiful, but the galleria itself was draining. Many great works, but it was more exhausting than inspiring. Long line to pick up reserved tickets then another line to enter the museum. Probably a great resource if one is studying the works of a particular artist. I had a better tome at lunch.

Fantastic collection. Likes; it's small, easy to see everything, located in fabulous park w/ tons of trails, roads, cafes, sculptures and benches. Need to reserve your tix the day before-they do NOT sell them at the door and if you walk there thinking to go in, w/ out a reserved ticket yer SOL.

A must-see destination. Art works and sculptures that will bring you to tears. Magnificent surroundings. Enough said!We had a tour guide; audio tours also available.One or the other probably a must to truly appreciate this spectacular place.

Master Bernini. We visit this Galleria whenever we are in Rome. Bernini's sculptures blow me away every time! To gaze on the dimpled flesh of Persephone as she is being kidnapped and to scrutinise the concentration on the face of David as he takes his aim is a privilege. Worth every penny, or cent, of the entrance fee.... An experience you won't forget.
Awe inspiring art. Be advised that tickets must be purchased in advance as the gallery limits the number of people in the gallery at any one time

So much to see!. This museum displays some of our favorite art, but they set a time limit of 2 hours for your visit to keep the crowds down. 2 hours is just not enough! The Bernini scuptures alone take that much time! You need to immerse yourself in these pieces and get to know them (via audio tour or purchased book guide) intimately.

Gorgeous museum. It takes a bit of an effort to get there, but it is so, so worth it. What a beautiful collection in a magnificent setting. Some of the works are just breathtaking. Highly advise doing the audio tour. It adds a lot to the experience. And add in enough to time to wander the ground around the galleria.
Lovely. A lovely park and this building is great to look at. Very busy when we went as it was at the weekend.

How poorly princes lived!. The Borghese family, was one of the most powerfuk and wealthy roman families of the Renaissance. One of theri domain was a big park, were some interesting buildings were erected. This Galleria Borghese was infact built from its very beginning as a museum. Wealthy families invested part of their money in fine arts, and acted as Mecenas for the artists of their time. A very fine collection of sclptures, starting from ancient Greece, through some of the most emotional examples of the Renaissance

The Bernini sculptures memorized me. The powerful physiques captured in amazing detail and grandeur, coupled with the delicate seeming fragile execution is astonishing. Must read about his techniques to be able to sculpt the extended fingers and flowing robes. I know there is much more there to see but for me, that will be another visit. I was captivated by his sublime works.

Cannot stop thinking about it!. There are no words to describe this place. Just go! Bernini will blow your mind away. This is the second time I've been (they changed the layout/entry point, so beware Rick Steves' readers, everything's out of order), and I still wish they would allow us >2 hours just to gawk and be in awe. =D Will definitely go back every time I am in Rome!

Well worth it!. I love this gallery, well worth the ticket price. It has Bernini and Caravaggio everywhere you look which are incredible seen up close. Tip: Pre book tickets online as they have very strict capacity rules and it is very popular. The audio guide is worth the €5 - just to learn about the eccentric Borghese family!
Sculpture heaven. Bernini at his best - how does he make the marble look like flesh? wonderful wonderful place to visit and then go to Villa Guilia for the etruscan finds
excellent. you have to ask your hotel to book in advance because otherwise you can't get in. Noteworthy, the zoo nearby is also a great place to visit.

Outstanding artwork - gorgeous setting :). I liked the fact that it was not a sterile environment like some galleries - the villa is thoroughly decorated in the 'old style' with ceilings to die for and sculptured doorways and architraves that beggar belief. Coming from Australia, we have nothing to compare - it is REAL CULTURE ! Naturally the paintings etc are fantastic too.
Amazing Museum and Place. Wow -- this place rekindled my love of art. The building itself was amazing and the Titian, Raphael, Berini -- breathtaking. the park was also beautiful and romantic.

Splendid building, splendid art treasures. In the middle of beautiful gardens, a splendid palace - they say "villa", full of art treasures. Important paintings of Raphael (Christ deposition, The young lady with the unicorn, Portrait of a man), Caravaggio (Self-portrait as Bacchus, The Madonna with the snake, Saint Jerome, David with Goliath’s head), a lot of other important Italian masters, sculptures of Bernini, antiques etc. It is absolutely necessary to book the ticket before the visit (on Internet or at the telephone +39 06 32810).

Amazing Sculptures. Included in the masterpieces on display are some sculptures by Bernini that are a must-see, whether you are an art buff or not: "Apollo and Daphne" and "Pluto and Persephone" to name a few.

Cardinal Borghese is my new hero.. OK, from what I read, he may not have been the best cardinal, and he may not have even been a particularly nice person, but, wow, did that man have good taste in art (to say nothing of apparently unlimited resources in acquiring it). The Bernini sculptures alone were amazing, and they were but a small fraction of this collection. Go see it.

Well..it just "knocked my socks off". You MUST go...just climb the many stairs...and you will enter a room that will take your breath away...even AFTER the stairs...it is beautiful...the paintings are wonderful....but the ceilings are even better IMO....Pls...don't miss this!!!

Borghese Museo. Wonderful art and sculpture. Worth the visit. Visits are restricted to two hours and reservations are a must. We had some difficulty getting to the site, so be sure to ger clear detailed instructions before you go

Great wander!. We went on the best day for it. Walking through the nice green park as the sun shines through the many trees is amazing. You can certainly get lost in here and not mind at all. There's a couple nice cafes and things tossed in too. Come out the west side of the park and you end up overlooking Piazza del Popolo which was also an amazing view of the city.

One of my favorite art museums. I love the arts but I'm no art history major. After traveling through Italy, starting in Milan to see the last supper and arriving to Rome after having been in Florence, I had my share of the repetitive art themes such as the last supper, the anunciation, the crucifixion, david and goliath etc... Galleria Borghese offered a breath of fresh air. It's a beautiful place and you do have to make reservations. We had the Roma pass which we were able to use. I didn't know what to expect but after having gone, I can't wait to go back. After visiting Italy, I became a fan of Bernini and his statue of Apollo and Daphne is a must see at the Galleria. The fact that your visit is made through reservations is really a benefit and not a disadvantage. It allows you to enjoy it's beautiful are in a quiet setting. You will not be disappointed!

Go later in the year, avoid hassles. My friend and I went to Galleria Borghese today, Dec 11, on a whim, we happened to be in that part of Rome. We had no reservation, and there was no line. The cost was 8 Euros, we spent all the time we wanted and nobody kicked us out, so go in the off season!! That said, it is a fantastic museum. The Bernini sculptures alone make it worth the price of the ticket. Multiply that by two dozen more masters and you have one of the best art museums in Europe.

A Moving Experience. This museum was hands down the best museum I've ever been to. The Bernini sculptures in this museum are a MUST SEE. They are incredible. The frescoes and ornamentation within the museum itself are a glimpse into the wealth of the Borghese family. I would recommend getting an audio guide, which provides many fun facts regarding the various sculptures, paintings and frescoes within the museum--it's a nominal fee of 5 euro. The paintings are worth perusing, but are nowhere near as fantastic as the Bernini sculptures on the first floor. Be sure to make reservations in advance. If possible, get a Roma Pass, which will get you in free, or at least provide a small discount in admission. And bags are not allowed, but there is a free checked bag service. Visits are limited to 2 hour windows, but the entire museum is doable in that time. After your visit, walk the beautiful grounds. There are other museums in close proximity like the museum of contemporary art, as well as the zoo. You can also rent bikes and tool around the grounds, enjoying the lush greenery in the middle of the busy city.
Great!. This is the most interesting museum in Rome, don't miss it if you saty in this beautiful city. a unique art collection

Fabulous Bernini sculptures. This museum is (imho), all about the Bernini sculpture of Pluto and Prosperina, which is a beautiful piece of sculpture, despite it's violent subject. The two figures are almost alive; Prosperina's fingers and toes and tensed and twisted in horror; they are draped in freshly ironed sheets whose edges are so fine the stone is translucent. The rest of the collection... Some interesting Caravaggios. Some paintings by Bernini, including two self portraits. Some great ceiling paintings.Amazingly opulent decoration of the house itself, reminder of the power and wealth concentrated in the hands of the papal Borghese family, and all that hilariously juxtaposed with the modern day pettiness "please show your ticket before using the toilet".Visits are in time slots of two hours, which is plenty of time to see the whole place and linger at the Bernini sculpture.

Two hours went much too fast. We visited off-season in Dec, no crowds, no problem with reservations. Rented the whisper set that explains many of the pieces. I thoroughly enjoyed this museum, except for the stairs. They have a small lift and you are to notify an employee if you need assistance. No employees could be found on the second floor. Then, of course, no one pushed us out when the bells rang. Several of us took it slowly a step at a time down the difficult stairs. Don't carry a purse in Rome.

what an amazing gallery!. this was one of the best gallery i have ever been to. i enjoyed the collection and the explanation from the audio guide! too bad that we have to wait so long to collect the ticket we ordered online and that the rooms of the gallery are not numbered

They don't make it easy to enjoy - but it is lovely. Booking on line in advance was painless but once you're there they dont half make a meal of it - join a queue to get your actual tickets, then join another queue to check in your bags and cameras and mobile phones - but NOT your coats which you get to carry. Then join another queue to purchase the audio tour - for which you have to deposit id (passport!) or the key they've just given you in return for your bags / camera etc,. Then join another queue to actually enter the gallery but there's no checks or screening as far as we could see so people were taking cellphones in. The layout of these different queues is illogical and must be a nightmare in peak season. We visited in December on a Sunday morning and the best advice would be to pick up your tickets and / or arrive on the half hour as I suspect the peak times are on the hourInside the Bernini and other sculptures are superb, the picture galleries less so for me and the building itself with it's ornate decoration are lovely. We got around it in less than the 2 hour slot and spent the rest of the time enjoying the surrounding gardens
Galleria Borclosee!. Public Service strike in Rome meant that prepaid tickets were a waste of time. No opportunity to go another day. No refund either.
Great. .but hated the fact you had to make reservations. Also the fact that I had to leave my purse at check in. It was fine nothing was missing but wish I knew ahead of time
Should have done more research. I wish I knew more about the pieces we were looking at while here. This is one of the few sites I did not research before leaving on this trip and I wish I had

Lots of paintings and statues. The garden has lots of fountains as well, you need to pay to get into the museum/galleria. A lot of people jogs in the park, you can rent electric bicycle to get around and there's lots of birds in the park. Be sure to walk around the park, get a map.

Don't miss this one!. World class museum of master pieces. A must to see. Greatly enhanced with a private tour. Our tour guide took the time to explain and point out many things that you would not see on your own. We couldn't begin to say enough about the Galleria Borghese. It is fabulous!

a jewel. You need a reservation to visit, but it is not hard to get online. There are 2 hour time slots, so it is a bit of a hassle when you are wanting to be free with your timing. The collection of sculpture and paintings is wonderful and the setting is over the top.

Interesting!. The galleria is not so big, but it has interesting works of art and all the rooms have paper guides in English, which are very helpful for tourists. i just didnt like the fact that there is limited time to spend in the museum and the fact you have to leave your purse locked. The galleria is also in a nice park, so it is nice to walk around in a sunny day.
Great Gallery. Fantastic visit and wonderful gardens. You need to make reservations and I recommend that you get the audio guide.

Masterpieces to be treasured. Each painting and sculpture is remarkable in its' own right. Each room is amazing - the walls and ceilings covered with art work and sculptures that make you just want to sit and wonder about the artists who created all this beauty. Thoroughly enjoyed our visit!

discovering Bernini. Galleria Borghese impressed me very much. This is a real jewel, located in a beutiful park of Rome. Bernini sculptures are magnificent, breathtaking. Through this gallery's room you discover Bernini extraordinar talent, but also wonderful paintings of Caravagio Rafael, Titian, Antoanello da Mesina, Rubens. There is a very good part in not allowing photos or camera. The visitors can enjoy better the beauties inside, without spending time to take photoes or being distracted by other tourists making photos. We have made a reservation 10 days before.
A must for Baroque fans. This museum is over the top. The collection is huge with a spotlight on Bernini's works. Well worth the hassle of making reservations and having to arrive early.

A great delight. The sad part about it is no camera,no cellphone, not much of information if you dont take a tour or a audio guide. Also you have only a certain time frame to visit it in. Advise you to buy the Roma Pass and use this as one of your free attractions. But call ahead of time and book your window. We went in the end of October and the visits were booked for two day ahead. Thankfully we had called ahead. Missed two of the Raphael's as they were in renovation. But the Botticellis and the paintings on the ceilings were unforgettable. Not a sight to miss. Lovely gardens and buidlings nearby. Take the train and you can take a tour as well. We used it as a hopon-hopoff. There is a park nearby with some coin rides as well

The abundance of art here is staggering.. This gallery is really a must, not to be missed! You have to advance book online or have in your possession a Roma Pass or similar. After a convoluted entry system which annoyed many of our fellow visitors we deposited our bags and embarked on a walk round the fantastic art on display. There are laminated information sheets stacked at the entrance to each room, these are enlightening, very helpful and make you aware of what incredible art, works of Bernini, Titian, Caravaggio and the gang that lie before you.The optional audio sets are a good addition and enrich the experience. After a visit here we found great pleasure in walking round the perimeter of the gardens.

Just great art even for those who do not like museums.... The museum is a small one that can be enjoyed without getting tired, it is located in a beautiful house situated in a wonderful park.Make sure to make a reservation either my phone or through their internet site

Amazing collection. The Gallery contains some amazing statues. Study what you will see ahead of time as you can only visit for two hours. The signage in English is poor and the guides to what you will see in each room are a good idea but are too lengthy and confusing to be of much use.
Amazing museum. Anyone who goes to Rome should visit. You have to book your tickets beforehand. AMAZING art. This is where some of Bernini's most famous statues are.

The art is suberb, the experience is not. We had booked this as an ending highlight to our time in Rome. You need to reserve on-line and arrive early. The staff are not at all pleasant and act as tourist herds with no charm. You are allowed in only at your time, don't think about checking a coat but you must leave bags outside. No photos, cafe closed, show your ticket for the toilet etc. Not a great experience. Worst, we found the signing and lighting to be very poor which really spoiled the tour. Despite a guide book, the labels and room 'guide' sheets it was unclear. Labels were wrong, paintings missing etc. In hindsight I should have used an audio guide but I personaly don't like them very much.

Fascinating Collection of Paintings and Sculptures. This museum was the first stop in our Rome itinerary and set the scene for our history of art experience. This private collection covers ancient mosaics, greek and roman sculpture as well as Renaissance artwork. I thoroughly recommened getting the audio guide which takes you through the Galleria giving interesting information on key pieces of artwork.
majestic. this is one of the must sights in rome. one of the finest collections of paintings,sculpture and objects d' art in the world

WORDS CAN'T DESCRIBE . YOU MUST VISIT!I. What's not to like in a gallery full of masterpieces? We had plenty of time with no crowds. We went very early in the morning and had purchased tickets online ahead of time.

Mind blowing!. Grab and audio guide and you will appreciate the finer points of the sculptures and paintings, the little nuances that made each work a masterpiece. In the room full of the busts of Roman emperors make sure you lock eyes with Hadrian... in real life you wouldn't have a head left if you did this! And walk to the Galleria, which was a family villa at one time set in luscious natural surroundings.

Favorite museum. This is one of the best museums I have ever been in. Make reservations and show up on time. The gallery used to be a papal residence and now houses some of Bernini's best sculpture. It's guaranteed to make your mouth drop in aw to see what that man could do with marble.

One of my favorite places in Rome. If you like Baroque Art, you must go to Galleria Borghese. But you must realize you are only allowed to be there during the time your ticket states, in 2 hour increments. They really do clear the museum at the end of the time period for the next group to come in.

Favorite, gallery and park beautiful. First suggest taking bus to outside park and walking thru park to gallery, suggest making arrangements for tour guide and going early. The marble statues were most incredible! good gift shop, beautiful relaxing surrounding gardens. We walked from here to the top of the steps/Trivi fountain and had our best meal on little side street next to shop that makes it own pasta daily.

Fantastic Two Hours. This is a MUST DO in Rome and reserve ahead. The Bernini, Caravaggio and Raphael pieces are incredible. Not allowing cameras permits you to truly enjoy the art and to get through in the two hours allotted each group of visitors. Leave plenty of time to find the museum building within the large Villa Borghese park. Most free tourist maps are not big enough to include the detailed building location at the far east end of the park.
Once in a life time statues. Bernini's statues are so unique and beautiful. Never seen anything like them. They look so vivid and moving, despite being from marble. Expressive too. Worth a booking

Nowhere does Bernini’s genius speak to you more.... Each tour last only two hours which is hardly enough time to absorb it all…but the tour is worth every penny.The gallery is astonishing in size depth and breadth. The building itself is a work of art, and you will find yourself on the verge of sensory overload. Bernini’s genius astounds and I had to tear myself away from his exquisite sculptures. They are a symphony in stone. The second floor is full of paintings and some sculptures, but if I had to take the tour all over again, I would go to the second floor first so I could have the sculptures on the first floor all to myself during the second hour. They are lyrical, and nowhere does Bernini’s genius speak to you more.
must see. The Bernini marble sculptures are simply amazing, an absolute must see! The overall collection is really quite fantastic.

Wonderful. The gallery itself is not as interesting as Vatican museum,but there are still some unique pieces to see,such as Lady with Unicorn by Rafael and Caravaggio.The garden around the place is very beautiful,with unique fountains and nature.I strongly recommend to take a bicycle or any other vehicle near the park entrance,because it's quite big, and good luck with a weather!

Book Ahead. Wonderful collection. Self-guided tour needs booking ahead (2-day turnaround in November) and you are ushered out after 2 hours. Lots to see on the grounds as well, including an accordion player rendering a pretty wonderful selection by Vivaldi (at least, during our visit.)

Best in situ museum in Rome. Bernini's marble masterpieces are all here. Apollo & Daphne will take your breath away. Remember to have your hotel call ahead for a reservation - you must have a pre-scheduled entry time in order to get in.

This palace is a must see in Rome. We prebooked our time a week before arrival to Rome. We used Rick Steves Galleria Borguese walking tour as our guide and it was great. After spending hours in Vatican Museum with a great guide, it was nice to just walk through the huge rooms of this palace and experience the paintings and sculptures on our own. We spent about an hour viewing the rooms.

A must see for any Bernini fan, then get lost in the park!. Make reservations! Favorite museum in Roma! This gallery limits the number of person that may enter. I do believe the max is 360 persons at a time with a 2 hour time frame. No bags or cameras, coat check is free. The experience is up close and personal, spend the 5 euros for the audio guide it keeps you on track and you learn so much! The audio guide points out the do not miss pieces and provides history along with fun stories; to bring the art to life. Don't miss any of the Bernini pieces especially the "Appollo e Dafne" by Gian Lorenzo Bernini - I found the piece amazing!!! Hint: Book online directly with the gallery, I booked from the USA, paid by credit card and just picked up my tickets. After visiting the gallery, ride a bike in the park or take a walk, stop have a sandwich from a vendor. I found one of the best views of Roma by getting lost in the park and navigating myself back to the Spanish Stairs. Excellent place for a break from the city. Enjoy!
Worth it just for the Bernini. Hades & Persephone. Apollo & Daphne. Oh, and the Carravagios. And the grounds. The grounds are beautiful. The view from the park is gorgeous.

Beautiful home and gardens. It was good to be a Borghese - This museum housed in the Borghese villa is chock-full of the art collected (and sometimes outright stolen) by the Borghese family. Don't miss the Caravaggio paintings, especially the one of David holding Goliath's head (Goliath was painted with Caravaggio's face as an apology to the Pope and a request to come home).Apollo and Daphne by Bernini is breathtaking, as the figures seem quite alive.Read Rick Steves' review before you go to get some of the inside scoop, especially thae story behind the nude sculpture of Napoleon's sister.Highly worth the money.Start at the TOP and work your way down the two flights of stairs.Ticket times indicate that is the earliest you can enter. I don't know if they clear the museum after the allotted 2 hours before they let a new group in, but it will take you that long to go through the whole villa. And then there are the gardens...which are free and open to the public. If your feet can handle it, take a tour through those, and note the succulent fruit which still grows there.I think I must have been a Borghese in a former life. I wish, anyway.

Worth the cab ride. A little off the beaten path, perhaps, and requires reservations, but, oh, what a collection! Tip: Since you will be limited to two hours within the Galleria, it helps to read about the collection prior to your arrival.

Breathtaking place. This place has an extraordinary collection of art, if you think the sistine chapel has the best you ain't seen nothing until you go to Galleria Borghese, only problem...you can't take your camera in! Well worth making the effort to get there.

gone for nothing. It was raining and it was our last day. We decided to go to galleria borghese. When we arrived, the tickets were Sold out until the next tuesday. It was Sunday. We were really nit expecting this. Too bad
Interesting medieval history. Figures! Paoline and David were beautiful, especially Paoline. Remarkable decorative chambers. All that property and now the Borghese family has not anymore inheritors.

Wonderful experience. Booked to visit here last weekend.It was a fabulous experience.I would recommend getting the tour with a guide .You arrange the tour after you collect your tickets which should be pre booked.
2 hour time limit is just enough. So much quality and interesting content and all exhibits labelled in English. Need to book in advance, can do by telephone with a Roma pass

?!. Well Galleria Borghese is, one of those places, you must see. But buying tickets on line, reservations...I mean, sure I want to see, but if in that time I could see tones of other things, why not. Crowd is big...and even with tickets you buy on line several days prior to your visit.

feast your eyes. So much art and sculpture in such a small building - the rooms are crammed full of paintings and sculptures - including some fantastic prices - it is hard too take so much in in such a small amount of time as visits are strictly limited to 2 hours. It is fairly expensive but we bought a Roma Pass for 30 euros which allowed us to get in here and another site free plus free public transport for 3 days. Guide book says you need to book advance but we didnt - just turned up and they let us in with the next group but we may have been lucky. The groups are only every 2 hours so you could end up waiting a long time if its busy. Also a long walk from the Metro station so recommend getting a bus instead. The park is lovely for a stroll too if you need to kill a couple of hours whilst waiting for the gallery. Or you can hire bikes by the hour. Anyway well worth the money/wait etc as must be one of the best galleries in Europe

One of the most worthwhile experiences in Rome!. Of course you need to see the "famous" outdoor sites of Rome but once you turn to the insides there are few places as wonderful as the Villa Borghese. Yes, Italian museums can be a bit "over the top" in that the works of art extend floor to ceiling (including the flooring and the ceiling!) and this is no exception. The "reservations required" Villa downstairs from the Galleria is a must add to the regular Galleria tour. Easy to spend 2 hrs lost in the place - wonderful collection!!

Worth it for the Bernini's alone. The Galleria Borghese is beautifully situated in its own stunning gardens. The park seemed to stretch for miles,and would be a lovely peaceful place for a picnic. The queueing system could do with refining. We had booked online,but had to queue for our booked ticket,then another queue to have our bags taken,and then another queue to wait for our appointed two-hour slot. Also,we were disappointed that the cafe was closed. However,the exhibits are amazing,and well worth the queueing niggles. The entry hall is breathtaking,with its beautiful ceiling and mosaics on the floor. The Bernini sculptures are truly wonderful,and incredibly moving. Upstairs are the picture galleries,where Caravaggio's and Raphael's are to be seen. If the queueing system could be refined,and if the cafe had been open,this would have rated an 'excellent'. But the Bernini's were worth it.

Incredible. Amazing! Unbelievable works by Bernini! You are able to get up close to the pieces. Not being able to take pictures, they take all cameras and phones, is a plus. Get's you to be close and enjoy the pieces instead of just snapping pictures.

An Art Gallery Like No Other. This is a 'must' see. Walking through the immense garden in itself is quite a pleasant experience. You can walk, rent a bikes or even rent a golf cart. The gardens have hidden musicians and a small merry go round for children. The museum itself is tucked into a back corner. A beautifulbuilding with its' own garden and the art inside absolutely spectacular. Here you will find some of the oldest paintings and the sculptures make you wonder 'How did he do that?'.This is what a museum should be!

Wow!. Do the 9 AM tour and get there at 8 AM. It is a great park to walk around in the early morning, before the crowds arrive. The Borgheses' knew their art. Too bad the French took so much of the good stuff.

Best Museum in Rome. If you can only do one museum in Rome (apart from the Vatican/Sistine) do this one. The ground floor alone is filled with wonderful and famous sculptures and if pushed for time opt for this section. Upstairs there are paintings, also worth seeing, but the sculptures, including Paolina Borghese reclining on a sofa, and the amazing Apollo and Daphne, are the best part.

Spectacular art. Plan ahead. Make sure that you do your research regarding scheduling and also do research on the art itself as the time allowed within the walls can be limited! The art held within these walls is just astounding and well presented.Like most places displaying art, they are not always as entertaining for (all) children, but then the large gardens and views of Rome, and its vicinity to St Peters and the Spanish Steps is just amazing! Not to be missed!
If you can visit only a single museum in Rome, this is it. Just for the Caravaggios and Berninis, the visit would be unmissable. Don't forget to book in advance; you can do it online.
A must!. The Galleria Borghese is in the beautiful Borghese Gardens and has a wonderful small collection. Highly recommend getting the audio tour. Need to book tickets in advance (can do it online).

A must in Rome!!. If you're in Rome don't forget to book your tickets for Galleria Borghese! It is a must! You will see beautiful paintings and sculptures by Bernini, Caravaggio, Canova and more! If you're not going there with a group, don't forget to take audio-guidance!
Wonderful museum. The museum was full of wonderful sculptures and paintings. I'm no artist, but as a human being loved to look at all of the beautiful creations.

Out of this world treasures. This private collection of some of the best art in Rome is a true national treasure. Do not leave Rome without seeing it. A collection of Bernini statues that is unrivalled. They do limit your time in the galleries, so plan wisely. Try booking through an organized tour like Dark Rome to increase your experience and appreciation of the masterpieces.

Great museum, Poor ticket policy. We had tickets for 9-11am. We thought we could show up anytime between those hours. We got there at 10:45 and they cleared the museum at 10:50 for the 11-1 group. Only there for 5 minutes! Ugh. They would not let us stay longer. Only good news: We've been there before and it was a beautiful day so we were able to enjoy the gardens instead. Make sure you get there early!

bernini sculptures. Gardens were lovely, seeing people strolling is a picture of a more relaxed way of life that we do not see in the states . I got very lost and I recommend not being in this area after dark b/c the signage is not helpful and there are not a lot of people to help you get back to the center of Rome.The people in the ticketing office are rather rude and the rules for what can be taken into the museum are ridiculous.However, seeing the Bernini sculptures made it worthwhile but I would not venture there again

Two hours to study Caravaggio and Bernini. Even without the artistic contributions of the abovementioned artists this Gallery contains a sumptuous display of artistic talent. But forget all the rest and concentrate the whole visit (2 hours only allowed) on the offerings of Caravaggio and Bernini.Unparalleled riches !The v small cafe could be dramatically improved if the authorities wished it (amazingly, they seem unaware of this ! perhaps deliberately small ?). The ticket and security arrangements are extremely irritating and could surely be vastly improved. Again the authorities appear unconcerned, which is inexplicable.Never mind - the exhibits are of course more than worth any irritation briefly endured.

You must book ahead. This museum recently reopened after a lengthy restoration. It is jammed with people and you must reserve an entrance time 2 days in advance. I avoid being oppressed by crowds by obtaining an audio tape. This way I can fully appreciate the most important pieces of art and feel that I am not part of the crowd.These is a bus which can drop you off at the entrance, but you need help to find it. Maybe ask at your hotel for advice.

Could spend days there.... Don't forget to reserve a time space ahead of arrival. The museum has dozens of paintings and sculpture that are well known. The Bellini sculptures were my special favorite. The audio guide is worth it. You only get a couple of hours so use it wisely.

No, No and No. Booking days in advance for a 17:00 slot, queuing to get in only to be told that my wife cannot take her handbag in....not a rucksack....not a Beckham special....just a normal size handbag that has our passports money, cards and other essentials in it. NO BAGS at all, none even mothers with children who had small bags with dummies were turned back to the left bag area.....another queue to leave you essentials in the hand of a random employee, no lockers just a wire rack, oh sorry we just gave your essentials to someone else, we imagined and went and got a refund.Rome has the museum thing wrong, booking in advance, being ordered about like prisoners or naughty kids just does not do it. What happened to if it's raining we can do....and if it dry we can do the museum? oh we can't we have to book three days in advance.....

Awesome Place to Visit. this museum is fantastic words can't describe you really have to go to understand i would strongly recommend to anyone visiting Rome pre book as it gets busy , the park is great also for strolls

Galleria Borghese. We were directed to the wrong Metro and do had to walk back a long way, almost missing our booking.Disappointed that directions were not clearer, inside and outside. The art was amazing!Did not see the "erotica", so wondered if it had been moved or blended in.

Bernini!. Go if only to see the sculptures by Bernini (of course there is much more to see, but oh! this art.)Make sure to purchase tickets ahead of time, or risk serious disappointment.Don't wait for the doors to open up on the first floor. Get in line to hand in your tickets/vouchers are in what looks like the basement. Any bags or backpacks will need to be left in the coat check, which can be a long line, so don't bring anything with you if at all possible. The audio tour is worthwhile.

Would be great. We so wanted to go in but we had not booked, it was our last day. The park surrounding it is lovely and full of life, even unable to get into the Gallery we enjoyed the park. We were able to get into the book shop and buy some really good souveniers
Great museum. One of the best museum I have ever visited with few people inside at a time and a wonderful collection.

Can't Miss. It is definitely an eye opener. Cannot miss this place out of your itinerary. There is a limit of 2 hours in the museum but we had sufficient time to finish. Since they only allow a certain amount of people in you actually get to enjoy the works without a huge crowd. I really like the Apollo and Daphne, Pluto and Proserpina and Canova sculptures. So real that I want to touch the bed of the Canova sculpture.

Beauty. First you see the surrounding of the building and can be impressed: spacious, dreamy and clean. Once you enter the villa your heart stops! Bernini, the artist of these astonishing sculptures, truely had magical hands. The details of these human replicas are breathtaking. I won't spoil too much but when I entered the room with Bernini's sculpture of "David" my mouth dropped open and I fell in love. Everyone knows Michelangelo's David, but THIS was incomparable. I could have spent all day in that room. Can't wait to go back.

A "must see" gallery. The Galleria Borghese is a wonderful gallery of artwork and sculpture. The sculpture of Paulina Bonaparte by Cavalli is breathtaking--don't miss it. Be sure you make reservations to go at least a day or two before as they book up quickly and limit the number for each session. The tickets are for 2 hours only which is plenty of time to see it all. Try to get the 9am booking to avoid the crush of the changeover times. There are no bags of any kind or cameras allowed in the gallery so everyone must check bags and it can get quite busy with long lines. And tickets must be picked up before the session so be there at least 30 minutes or more before your session.We really enjoyed this gallery. I suggest you read up a little on it to make it more interesting, although we had no background and still found it all wonderful. We then looked up further information afterward and re-lived it all.

Top Spot to visit while in Roma!. The two hour visit was not enough. There is so much eye candy in this place. The paintings and sculptures were so beautiful it blew me away. You must buy your ticket in advance and it can be sold out for many days so I would purchase my ticket before I visited Roma. You can do it online! I have visited many museums and this collection is at the top of my list. I am not going to list all the artists here. Please visit their website for more information. Do not linger too long in the rooms, as the Galleria is bigger than it seems and they only allow you two hours. If you are a real art lover, you might buy tickets to come back another time.

Overwhelming!. The Galleria Borghese is simply overwhelming! The quality and quantity of the artworks is amazing, as is the villa in which they are displayed! A couple of things to be aware of: 1) you need to book at least 4-5 days ahead to ensure you get in. We rang on Tuesday and the 1st available day was Friday. 2) If you can't book in and are still keen to visit, take a chance and go to the ticket queue anyway. We missed out on a booking but still went late one afternoon to look at the garden, parks etc. Seeing as we were there we took a chance and asked at the ticket office, and were allowed in! I'm not sure why, maybe it was because it was the last entry for the day, but we were very happy. 3) We found it difficult to find the actual Galleria Borghese. We hopped off the Metro at the recommended station (Spagna?) and followed the signs, but then the signs stopped.....
Great works of Art. Don't miss the Bernini's statues and the Caravaggio's paintings. Great gallery! Only problem is that you can only spend 2.5 hours at the gallery.

Neat experience. We liked the sculptures more than the paintings, but to each their own, I guess. If you enjoy art, there should be zero hesitation for a visit. Make sure to call ahead and reserve (you have to, as others have said)....an English-speaking person will be easy to find over the phone. Also the park you walk through to get there is a nice look at a quieter side of Rome.
Agree with everyone else. There is a two hour limit, including 30 minutes for the paintings. There are helpful laminated information pages in each room in English that are helpful.

Beautiful!. Amazing collection of beautiful art and sculptures. Bernini was especially overwhelming. Please make sure to book reservations before showing up.....a lot of people were turned away on the rainy day we visited.

So must see paintings but otherwise dull. The odd Caraggio is nice to see but it is enless unless you like that era of painting - very underwhleming expecially if you have already been to the Vatican Museum

This is a must!!!. Well , this galleria in the center of a huge park , contains some masterpieces that hold your breath at the first sight!Caravaggio, Bernini and Raphael are some names that for sure can have your attention!!! Make sure you make a reservation before you go , since its obligatory.

Take your time!. Villa Borghese is a lovely gallery that you must book a few days in advance. Even in November which is quieter we still had to book three days ahead.My suggestion would be to get the audio guide, as the signage available is pretty minimal and if you dont know alot about the art an audio guide will help. Also there is a bit of a rush at the beginning of the two hour session and I sort of panicked a bit and was worried I wouldnt get through everything. But in hindsight 2 hours is plenty of time to head through the galleries, but one suggestion might be to perhaps skip a few rooms at the beginning to get ahead of the crowd, and then come back a bit later once the groups have thinned. Will make your visit more enjoyable!

WOW!. Napolens sister makes a great nude model. About a 20 minute walk from the Hotel Sonya. Need to book an entry time months in advance. I recommend the 9am slot as there were less than the 200 max allowed in at a time. Words cannot describe the art; if the Villa had a Sistine Chapel it would be better than the Vatican Museum.

Amazing! A must see. Galleria Borghese should be on your must see list when visiting Rome. For $11 Euros it is an incredible bargain. The sculptures, paintings and architecture of the building is beyond breathtaking. You could spend hours and hours wandering throughout the Galleria, though you are only allowed a maximum of two hours. And, the walk through the beautiful park adds to the whole experience. I would definitely go back the next time I'm in Rome.
