Pre book this visit. Lacked adequate information of where to go. Staff on admission desk were not particularly helpful and rude to some people in the queue. Using Roma pass requires advance telephone booking, other booking can be done via internet. The art was well worth the effort.

Could't get in. I couldn't get in the museum since they want an advanced booking, but we take a good walk in the gardens around, which are huge. You can rent a bike, if you are too tired to walk around them.

Beautiful collection. We didn`t plan to visit there, and we visited twice.First day we only bought tickets for the next day. It is important to buy tickets before, online or at the museum. This collection is surely worth visiting. If you dont have time visit every museum, I recommend to visit here.

a gem of a museum. Loved the Bernini statues -- so alive and sensitive! Also loved the Caravaggio and Raphael masterpieces! We took an audio guide, which was extremely helpful and the way to go. The museum is not too big, so it is not overwhelming. Once you reserve in advance, you are allotted approximately two hours inside the museum, which is sufficient time to get a taste of the outstanding art that resides there. A downside is that no photographs are allowed, but that forced you to focus on the works of art that are there instead of focusing on capturing great shots. A must-do if you're in Rome.

Great gallery and park but bad signposting!. I enjoyed my visit here and the grounds are beautiful, however the signposting for the cafes are very misleading and take you on a wildgoose chase! We spent so long looking for a cafe we ended up miles from where we started on the other side of the park and gave up in the end. It ruined our trip and we missed some of the park as my four year olds little legs were too tired to keep walking after this! We never found the cafe...

Best Example of Renaissance Rome Art Collections and One of World's Best Art Museums. Read the reviews, what can I say. I never miss the Borghese when I am in Rome. This private collection of the Borghese family is like none other. Make a reservation ahead of time and avoid the line and disappointment. I you only go to see the Caravaggios or Berninis it still worth the trip. But if you haven't been there yet, here is what I would say. One, to get the most out of your visit, do some homework first and learn about the history of this unique collection and the magnificent building that houses it. Look at the walls, floor and ceilings, they are as amazing as the art works. Pony up for the guide if you must do it that way but don't just walk in and walk through.The floor in the first salon is covered with ancient mosaics from properties the family owned elsewhere that depict the actual gladiators who fought and died, their names, their sport and whether they lived or died. Many of the salons are completely done in trompe l'oeil, which was very popular at the time the villa was built and the work, which I imagine has been redone over the years, is fabulous.Downstairs is mostly sculpture, and the Bernini collection is the reason for their popularity. (if you have a chance to see the archelogical museum in Naples, the Farnese collection has many wonderful pieces that I can imagine Bernini much have studied and that show the definite precursors of his work.) Also, the Caravaggio's are there.The second floor is mostly painting, but don't miss the little boy and goat in the large salon that is one of Bernini's first pieces.WORD OF ADVICE - GO WITHOUT YOUR BAG, YOU MUST CHECK IT IN AND IT IS A HASSLECAMERA'S - THEY SEEM TO HAVE CHANGED THEIR POLICY ON THIS. I HAVE PHOTOGRAPHED IN THE MUSEUM FOR YEARS WITHOUT FLASH, THE CURRENT POLICY IS NO CAMERAS BUT IT IS NOT WELL POSTED. I WAS ACCOSTED BY AN ANGRY PATRON AS I HAPPILY PHOTOGRAPHED MY FAVORITE DETAILS OF APOLLO AND DAPHNE. MY MESSAGE IS IF YOU REALLY REALLY WANT THE PHOTOGRAPHS FOR YOUR PERSONAL REASONS (I AM A PROFESSIONAL AND ALSO AN ARTIST) BE DISCREET AND CERTAINLY DON'T USE FLASH, USE A SMALL CAMERA OR A SMALLER LENS WITH NO HOOD ON YOUR LARGER CAMERA. IF THE MUSEUM PERSONNEL SAY STOP, STOP. AND IF OTHER PATRONS COMPLAIN BE POLITE AND TELL THEM THE POLICY IS GENTLE FOR PEOPLE WHO ARE COURTEOUS AND DISCREET.

Mammoth of Art Museum. No matter whose art you admire most from the old masters you will find it here. You need to plan this visit ahead of time and it is very easy to book online. Once inside this museum you will not know where to stop because piece after piece is just mind boggling. Plan to spend a while as you can't just walk through and out the other side.
Humbling. The museum rivals the Uffizi as to the artists, the viewing venue is grand and the park makes for a quaint 1/2 day stroll.
Be sure not to miss this!. Make sure you have reservations before you go. We arrived in Rome early in the morning and this was the first thing we did, after leaving our bags at our hotel. Wonderful!

must see. Even those who hate museums will enjoy this one. Masterworks of Bernini and Caravaggio in a beautifully decorated palace.You need to reserve upfront. Do this upfront, online. You can only stay 2 hours inside, which is more than enough. Go first to the picture gallery on the first floor (normally you can only stay here for 30 minutes - start with the Rafael room, rest are merely fillers). Then go down to see Bernini and Caravaggio on the ground floor.

the whole park is worth seeing. we loved the galllery and the grounds. You will find a huge park, gardens, great people watching and even a zoo. This is worth spending at least a half a day. Purchase your tickets on line and avoid the wait or purchase and enjoy the grounds...then go back for the art. We had a nice snack at the outdoor cafe, as well!

Yikes!. I thought that I was just going to go to a really good art museum, but OH MY! -- I was simply awestruck! It beats any other art museum that I have ever seen. The story of the collection is incredible and the building is exquisite. To think that some of the "best" or "more valuable" pieces had been sold off makes it almost overwhelming. It is clearly a MUST SEE in Rome. Do get the audio tour, because it will help focus your attention on the more important pieces while at the same time, help you to understand what it took to acquire such a collection. Breathtaking, in a word. We took the 9am tour, and I'm glad we did, because the crowd for the 11am entry seemed to be waiting in a long line. Make reservations beforehand and get there 1/2 hour early to avoid the lines.

Italy....Bellissimo!!. Bellissimo! Walking thru the several gardens on the property and the different museums was delightful and beautiful. Absolutely worth the ticket admission for the exhibits...after all, it is Italy!!
A Must-See. Don't miss this outstanding display of art. Words fail in describing the beauty of this collection. You just have to see it for yourself.

Plan ahead. We approached the gallery on a Sunday to only see signs that it was sold out until Tuesday. We inquired inside and found that they had cancellations and was able to get tickets. You get a specific time to enter and exit. And they dont mess around with that. We tried to go outside half way thru the tour as the audio guide stated and the front access was locked to keep people out... and I guess IN. You then have no more then 30 minutes to visit upstairs. They make announcements and herd you out when your time is up inside the gallery.

This is THE BEST in Rome.. I was in Italy for almost ten days and this was definitely THE highlight of the trip. Tip: get your ticket online. It is fully booked for a few days so plan ahead. You cannot just show up there and get in. I saw a lot of disappointed tourists who showed up. Upon leaving, I felt extremely bad for them because this place was simply amazing. Photos are not allowed, which is totally fine. Nothing can express the beauty of the sculptures other than your naked eyes. I looked at those photos on the Internet and they are not the same. Bernini's sculptures move when you look at them. They tell stories. They are alive. I cannot wait to go back to Rome just to see those sculptures again. I am not an artist, but this is definitely AMAZING. Do not forget to check this out.

Wonderful, but be sure to book in advance and arrive before your entry time. Be sure to pre-book to guarantee entry to this museum. Also be sure to pace yourself to ensure you have time to see everything because they clear the gallery at each two hour interval. Bernini's Appolo and Daphne sculpture is worth the visit on their own, but there are many other wonderful treasures here. A must for any art lovers when visiting Rome. The Borghese Gardens in which the Galleria is located are fun as well. We were there on a Sunday morning and and families, couples--old and young, were out strolling, riding bicycles or bike carts, skating, etc.

Many Paintings by Caravaggio. Rooms with floor to ceiling arts and multi-hued marble as well as many sculptures by Bernini. One room shows many Caravaggio paintings. All bags had to be checked in and no photos allowed. Need to make a phone reservation specifying date and time such as noon, 3 PM, etc., As usual, no discounts for non-EU seniors.
Book online. This is a really beautiful property! A must do when in Rome, but book online to avoid long lines or not being able to enter at all.

Great!. First of all make sure that you have reserved tickets, this is a beautifull building with lots and lots of incredible art belonging to Popes...My favorite is the reclining women by Canovas an incredible masterpiece

Best gallery in Rome. The gallery is small but it is all killer no filler. Bernini's sculptures are breathtaking, particularly David, Apollo and Daphne and the magnificent Rape of Proserpine. Works by Titian, Reubens, Raphael and Caravaggio also feature. Tickets MUST be
pre-purchased and your time in the gallery is limited to two hours.

Wonderful Museum in wonderful surroundings. You have to pre-book to guarantee entry into the museum, and we used our Roma Pass to pay. You only have a two hour slot, which we found just about right. The ceilings alone are worth the entrance money, with some wonderful exhibits and paintings to view as well. The grounds are amazing, and there is a "train" that you can tour the area on for 3 euro's each, or you can hire a variety of bikes etc. I think this is a must do for everyone visiting Rome.

Worth the price of admission!. And the hassle of getting your ticket beforehand. To understand the greatness of Bernini you need go no farther. Start at the Borghese, then see his other sculptural and architectural works. Sadly some of the Caravaggios were out on loan, but the building is stunning.

Unusual museum experience. Make a reservation in advance. We waited in a holding area with a lot of other folks until our reservation time arrived. Most rooms do not have guards! The rooms themselves are amazing in their decoration...we loved the paintings and sculpture...
A must to see. Fantastic collection!!. Increadible collection of art. You can book time to come so no line ups. Located in a beautiful park,
GREAT SHOPPING.... Give the wife the credit card and let her go wild! You'll find stuff here you will not find anywhere else in the world. $$$$ so be prepared for the bill when you get home!

Incredible Art Experience. We bought tickets online ahead of time and did not have to wait in line to visit this museum. I would definitely recommend getting the headset with the guided tour because it gave the history behind the man who purchased all the art and created the villa and it explained about the most important pieces of art in each room. The sculptures were wonderful and the mosaics and murals on the walls were amazing. The gardens surrounding the villa are worth a visit as well

Had a private tour guide who was excellent. The Bernini sculptures were fantastic. Was very worthwhile to book in advance with a tour guide who had a PHD since the information was very valuable to us being art lovers. Amount of people allowed in at one time is controlled. All bags have to be locked away.

One of the top museums in the world. This exquisite museum is the former home of the fabulously wealthy Cardinal Scipione Borghese. With help from his uncle, who was the Pope, he was able to build himself an incredible villa surrounded by acres of gardens and parks.Today, the park is the largest in Rome, and the villa seems as fresh and new as it must have been when the Cardinal lived there. Every inch is covered with paintings, fescoes, mosiacs, real and faux marble, gold leaf trim, painted ceilings, statues--you name it. Room after room after room after room. One of them had no fewer than seven Caravaggio paintings in it, although one was on loan the day we were there.Tip: Get a reservation in advance by calling (or asking your hotel to call for you). Arrive early to get your tickets, but if you have a reservation, you do not have to pay for them in advance.
Brilliant art. Fantastic collection of paintings and sculpture especially Caravaggio and Bernini. Go late in the day and be the last ones to leave for unbeatable atmosphere.
The Bernini sculptures!. This was a true highlight of my time in Italy. I recommend the audio guide, as guests are limited to two hours only. The Bernini sculptures alone are not to be missed.

Do not Miss this. One must have a reservation to get in to this very special museum. Reservations can be arranged online, it is not as user friendly as it might be, but keep at it. This is an exquisite collection, which as been housed in the palace since the 1700's. There are Bernini sculptures that were commissioned when he was very, very young and have been there since they were made. Nothing broken or dirty like so many other sculptures in museums. Amazing pieces or art in pristine condition. Take the guided tour. The garden is like Central Park in New York, huge, lovely to walk through, or take a pedi cab.
lots of stairs, gardens not worth it,. marelous collection of sculpture and paintings - very tiring walking up stairs, not for husbands who bore easily.

Tough ticket to score, but worth it. The museum delightfully laid out and contains some of the most gorgeous works in Rome, but you have to get on the case early with advance reservations. Please, get here and see this place and its Caravaggios and Berninis, and then walk around the Villa Borghese for the total experience.

Wow!. Need to book tickets in advance so booked from home but on Friday 28th September got to gallery to find there was a 24hr strike but tickets honoured on the Saturday. Well worth the wait as this is an absolutely stunning small museum. Only 2 hour time slot to look around but to be honest this was enough as when I left I needed to close my eyes for 10 minutes as my senses had been overstimulated by all the excellent art work.
Go there if you're interessted in art!. Personally, I thought it was too much paintings after two hours, but regardless of this, it is a place well worth visit.

Excellent. The park and museum are worth a visit. Truly exceptional! Please note you have to book in advance for the museum. We did it online in the UK. It was worth the effort. The park has a restaurant and segways for hire - brilliant.
Excellent. The marble sculptures were superb! Even the flowing hair, marvelous, well worth the trip. Should have allocated more time, maybe on our next trip.
Beautiful. One of my favourite museums in the world! Take at least an extra hour or two to walk around the park!
Ancient Art. Awesome paintings and sculpture by old masters preserved in pristine quality with magnificent lighting.

A place to spend a day. This is quite an extraordinary place. One can easily spend a whole day there. We walked around the whole park, took in the relaxing views, had some cappuccino and even rented a golf cart to drive around and have some fun. Highly recommend this place.

interesting building and statues. worth a visit (essential to buy tickets online well in advance as not available there...) the paintings did not inspire me but the building and statues downstairs in partic were worth the trip and a nice location with other museums around. oddly tho no cafe and food. note- you have to leave bags etc checked in...

Magnifico!. This was one of the best museums we had the privilege to visit. A definite "must-see"! The audio-guide is excellent! The only thing that was unfortunate (but understandable) is no photo-taking is allowed. The Bernini statues are absolutely astounding to look at.

One of the best collections in Rome. Unlike the Sistine and the Vatican museums, this little gem of a museum is run on appointment system, you can book an appointment online or by phone a few days ahead. and go to your designated appointment which is with a relatively small number of other visitors. No hustling/claustrophobic crowds in chocking humidity to turn your visit into an annoying thing.The collection boasts some amazing pieces by Bernini (most notable of which is the Apollo and Daphne as well as Pluto and Proserpina). Paintings by Caravaggio, Raphael, Rubens and Titian among many others).The collection exhibits incredible gems from the renaissance and after in the beautiful villa.If you prefer to admire the art than to just check the "seen it" box this is the place that is not to be missed.After your visit the cafe at the basement offers good coffee and pastries that you can either enjoy there or take outside and enjoy in the beautiful Borghesi gardens.Don't miss the beautiful fountain behind the gallery and if you have small children on the visit, who are getting bored of the museum and becoming unruly, you can swap shifts with your family in the museum (they will let you in and out) and take the kids to the play ground just behind the villa to the right (behind the herbal garden) and have them play a while till your partner does the visit then you can do it as well.If you need it, there is an elevator between the two floors (ask the nice museum attendants and they will accompany you).
Wow! So much to see, such quality.. Wonderful treasures to see, was not crowded when we went, easy to linger and absorb. Gift shop expensive but not compulsory to buy.

Loved this museum!. Must say I am not big on art and sculptures but when I left here I was quite amazed at how much I enjoyed it and wanted to see more. We used the earphones which was just as good as any tour guide. Save your money and use the earphone tour from the gallery. GREAT Museum!

Just a museum. Unless you're a huge art freak, skip this and spend more time at St. Peter's Basilica, the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel. It's an 11 euro entrance fee plus a metro ride, and I didn't find it worth the extra time or money. It's small and subpar compared to the Vatican, but it is a lot quieter and less hectic. I'm a 20 year old poor college student and don't fully appreciate art so this was just my opinion. Still beautiful but with all-do respect I'd rather be drinking Italian wine on the Spanish Steps:)

Excellent collection. Be aware visitors are grouped into entrance times every 2 hours, so limited flexibility, and you need to book in advance. Turn up on the day without a ticket and you probably won't get in.

One of the best Museums in the world.. This museum is so special. Be sure to have a reservation and get the guided tour headphones. It takes about two hours during which you stand next to some of the most amazing sculptures, paintings and mosaics in the world. Really.

Amazing Museum. This quite an amazing museum. The history here is unbelievable. It is off the beaten track and taking a tube here was not difficult at all. If you have a Roma pass which costs +/- 40euros it is free. Definitely worth the trip. Earlier better +/- 10-11am after 1pm the crowds come through.

Pleasant Museum Experience. In contrast to the only other museum I visited in Rome, the Vatican Museum, this was a very pleasant, mostly non-frenzied, experience. I am not a huge sculpture person, but this place was pretty stunning.

Wonderful Museum. After our crazy, crowded trip to teh Vatican, this museum was especially wonderful. They only allow in a few hundred people at a time, so you can actually see all the artwork and take some time to enjoy the art...

Beautiful and overwhelming amount of artwork.. Make sure you see the portrait gallery on the seciond floor - absolutely beautiful pieces. The main floor has a combination of paintings and sculpture. Every inch of this Galleria is covered in artwork. Even the picture frames are decorative. Wonderful combination of 17 - 18th century artwork. The gardens are beautiful as well, although it rained and we did not get to fully appreciate them.Highly recommend. Definitely need the 2 hours and as suggested spend a half hour in the portrait gallery on the second floor.

These is what you call ART. The sculptures are so real. You can even see veins, muscles and if you look carefully, you can even see orange peel on the fat lady's buttock. The paintings on the ceiling look 3D. The bed where Paolina Borghese was lying looks so real and comfy but it's actually marble carving. If you want to visit this place, you can ask your hotel to book ahead once you arrive Rome. It's worth visiting the Borghese Gallaria. But when we finished visiting the gallery, we had a hard time getting public transport.

Pleasant Morning at the Borghese. This was my second time at the Borghese Gallery. The first time we just got the audio guide and this time decided to pay one more euro (making it a grand total of 6eu) and do the guided tour. It was fascinating! Our guide had a broad base of knowledge of art in general and an obvious love for the pieces she so eloquently described to us. She taught about the significance of each piece and placed it in an historical setting that helped us sort out and soak in the significance of the contributions of artists such as Caravaggio and Bernini. Note about the Borghese itself. Because they schedule the tours you are never in the midst of a huge crowd. This is refreshing after being in the hustle and bustle of Rome. Also-I suggest taking a taxi ride there but afterwards take time to ramble or picnic in he park. We enjoyed beautiful weather and musicians along with local families taking their kids out for a bike ride. To get back to the city center just exit the park at the end opposite the gallery and look to your left. You will see a portion of the old city wall consisting of one of the entrance gates (which is just an archway) Just through the archway you will come upon the beautiful Via Veneto which you can follow for quite some time or catch a metro to your next destination.

Favorite museum -- hands down. Beautiful museum with stunning art! Get a reservation though so you won't be turned away. Used Roma card, had reservation and only paid for the audio guide...Best collection of art that we saw in Italy!

Beautiful grounds and fantastic art. I loved the museum and the gardens but be sure and make reservations early. We booked a private tour through Avventure Bellismee and wouldn't have made it in if we had not had reservations ahead of time.

Such a rich art collection in one place. Visited this museum since it is located in a park , which seemed nice to us to walk in , since it was on a Sunday. We got to the ticket counter quite fast, but were a little disappointed to hear that the next possible entry moment was only 2 hours later (found out afterwards that we were in fact lucky to get an entry so fast, it seems the museum is sometimes fully booked for the whole day)We really liked the beautifully decorated rooms, the marvelous paintings and the delicately made statues. We even had to hurry to see everything within the limited time allowed to visit).

Finished watching soon. I expected too much, because i needed reservation and I was given two hours to see.I came to the place 30 min before the reservation time and waited to enter.The interior was very good but there were not so much rooms and exhibitions I expected. I finished watching all rooms for first 15 min. and I watch again from the entrance. I watched each room twice but still it took only 30 min. I felt bored and got out.

Fantastic...just don't take your time !. Amazing collection of Art in amazing settings. My only gripe was that your time is limited in the picture gallery for security reasons which can rush you into missing out on certain works.By the way.., we were lucky and gained entry on the day.

not bad. lots of art spanning over 2 floors; you have to book in advance via the website (we went on a sunday and there was a sign saying sold out till tuesday! people that had not booked in advance were being turned away). some very nice (and famous) pieces, but i'm sort of an art dummy so we were done in an hour (half of the allotted 2 hours per appointment). i definitely recommend strolling around the villa (gardens) as well, it's very pretty.

Gorgeous!. If you are a fan of art, you will need to visit Galleria Borghese. Be aware though, that you will need to book in advance, and you are only allowed two hours. Also, you will not be allowed to take in a camera or bag. This Galleria Borghese is home to some of the most beautiful sculptures I've ever seen including the "Rape of Proserpina", and "Apollo and Daphne" by Bernini. You will also be able to view paintings by DaVinci, Raphael and Carvaggio. So many masters in one place, this is a must-see for anyone interested in art!
What a treat!. An absolutely beautiful gallery with as many Caravaggio paintings as one could take in at one sitting. The grounds were breathtaking.
One of the world's top museums. Sculptures by Bernini and Canova are unique in the world. Buy tickets before you visit--the museum is usually sold out.

A necessary existential experience. If only for the Bernini statue of "El Ratto de Proserpine," everyone should pay a visit to this unbelievable museum. Make sure to reserve your tickets ahead of time!

Incredible - all the masters are here. We bought advanced tickets - but still the line up was huge. Do not go without purchasing advance tickets!!! You won't get in!! Go early to be processed through the line that will be there. Remember - be there on time as you only have 2 hours to go through the gallery.
Art lovers' paradise. Make reservation ahead of time. Tour lasts for 2 hours. Arrive early. No photography. Well presented art work by the masters. Remarkable building.

Disappointed not to get in. Warning: if you want to see this YOU MUST BOOK IN ADVANCEWe wanted to visit this gallery. We'd heard so much about it. I'd read about the suggestions to consider booking in advance but we were planning to go midweek in October which we didn't think would be peak.We were wrong. When we arrived we were told at the ticket desk that the gallery was sold out FOR 3 DAYS, the first tickets available were for after we left Rome.What sort of gallery organises itself like this ? Maybe it just block sells its tickets to tour groups for the commissions to stop independent visitors from getting in ?Anyway the gardens are lovely and if you can't get in then you can have an enjoyable experience at the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna or the Museo Nazionale di Villa Giulia which are just down the road and you won't have problems getting in.

Exterior view only.. We pre purchased tickets for four, showed up when asked only to find a strike notice posted on the gate therefore our view was of a walk around outside. We were only availbe that day so no alternated days were available to us. When I requested a refund there was no replay, though I sent a picture of the notice. They seem to relish the "rip-off the tourist" practice nicely.

One of the best. Book ahead, otherwise you might have to wait for a couple of days to get a ticket. The sculptures, especially Bernini, were breathtaking. The ceilings, walls and floors are just amazing. Go! Don't miss this treat.

unbelievable!. one of my best visit in Rome!! too much for words!! all i can say: do NOT miss it!!! to me that i hate crow,(Vatican;Colosseum...),visit the gallery was my score! you can admire masterpierce with no rush and with relax and tiket is not expensive.

Not to be missed!. We used our Roma Pass for this and reserved via telephone about 3 weeks prior to our arrival. Our reservation was for 11:00 am on a Sat. Definitely need to arrive at least half hr. before your reserved time so that you can check in bags, wait in line, etc. We did the guided tour (approx. 1.5 hrs.) which I would strongly recommend. Our group was no larger than 20 people. The only problem with doing a tour is that because of the time constraint, we only saw limited areas of the museum. Guess you could go back and see the rest after the tour.Beautiful and elegant surroundings. Great artwork-really liked the Bernini sculptures.Nice thing about this museum is they restrict the number of people at any one time so that you can actually enjoy the artwork and not fight crowds as we had to do in the Vatican Museum.The park was very pleasant and many people had rented those quad bikes but we chose to walk through the park to the Spanish Steps.

One word- Bernini. The palace itself is gorgeous! Each room can overwhelm your senses! We forgot to get reservations! No worries, we had to return just after the entry time to see if there was space to enter. We lucked out because it was not a busy day. If you don't opt for the audio, each room has information sheets to guide you. The Bernini statues are breath taking works of art that you can get very close to observe. No crowds here, gives you the opportunity to spend some time looking at each.
the most exquisite collection!!unic collection. it is a must!! reserve tickets in advance on internet otherwise you will not get in!!it is an hounor to see such a place!!

Fantastic. If for nothing else than to see the Bernini sculptures, it earns a five. We enjoyed it from start to finish. We also enjoyed the adjancent park afterwards and wish we would have scheduled more time for a picnic after viewing the museum. This was our third time to Rome and we can't believe we didn't see this place on our first trip.

Don't miss this wonderful treasure trove.. We had pre booked a slot for 1 p.m. and spent a leisurely morning strolling through the park having taken a picnic lunch. Our timed visit was one of the most pleasant we had during our stay as numbers were limited and we had lots of time (2 hours) and space to look round in comfort. The Galleria has a wonderful collection including some of Bernini's finest works and some of the finest Caravaggio paintings you will ever see.

Should not be missed by art lovers. The borghese contains a tremendous collection of art and sculptures that will leave you breathless. My wife and I were amazed by the quantity and quantity of the collection. So you are not disappointed I recommend making a reservation ahead of your visit since they limit the number of people in the museum. Also spend some time strolling the gardens.

Marvelous Museum. The only down side of a visit is that you must make a reservation in advance (can do on the internet) and be sure to be there on time. If you take a taxi be specific that you want Galleria otherwise you will wind up in the gardens and have a long walk. While there are several painters and sculptors works on display, there are many sculptures by Bernini and they are all fabulous. Amazing how an artist can make marble look like curly hair or eyes that look frightened. The garden paths surrounding the museum are lovely and worth walking through. With enough stamina you can wind up in Piazza Popolo.

A great gallery. This gallery gives you access for 2 hours only and it is just enough. You can see works of Carravaggio, Bernini, Rafael,...all the big masters. And the halls are so beautifully decorated. And I have to say I don´t like museums in general.

A must see when in Rome. First and foremost make internet reservations well ahead of time to avoid disappointment. I observed visitors turned away on a Wednesday being told the next available date would be Saturday. What strikes me from the beginning is that almost all artifacts are complete with nothing missing (like noses, fingers, penises... as in other museums). They are all beautifully preserved. The immense diverse collection of these super wealthy patrons is simply stunning. Don't forget a stroll through the park which can lead you to trolley stop, bringing you right back to the vatican. A very pleasant and inexpensive way to travel.

Peaceful haven. The walk to the Galleria through the park is beautiful and very peaceful, even with the crowds of tourists, the Galleria itself has amazing art and sculptures, the only problem being they take cameras and video cams off you before you go in. Not sure why? do not think you can harm a sculture by taking a photo!!

Spectacular!. It is a must! if you come to Rome and have time to visit only one museum, do not miss Villa Torlonia. It is tiny, it is not the Vatican Museum or the Musei Capitolini, bur you will not regret it.

not just another museum. Gallery Borghese is located in a beautiful park on the north side of Rome, just outside the city walls. It offers many paintings and sculptures by some of the most celebrated artists of the 16th and 17th century. It is very beautiful. The statue of David by Bernini is one that I remember because of its differences as compared to Michaelangelos David in Florence. In this statue Bernini captures David just as he has released the stone which slew Goliath. The sense of concentration and determination is almost palatable. There is also a wonderful sculpture of Apollo cathing Daphne just as she is turned into a tree. Bernini was also a master working with marble. The first floor are all sculptures,the second floor paintings. Allow yourself at least two to three hours as there is a lot to see. Worth more that the small admision charge. One of the things to see while on Rome.

Highlight of our trip!. Lovely walk through the Villa Borghese Gardens to the galleria. Lovely sized galleria with such delights from the building itself to the breathtaking sculptures of 'Apollo and Daphne' by Bernini and 'Pauline Bonaparte' by Antonio Canova, my two favourites. Be sure to get a ticket before and be early to get in in a timely manner. (no Knapsacks, you will have to go to another line to check them in. Be sure to get the audio guide. Enjoy!
Gorgeous!. Well worth a visit. We went on our last day in Rome. Almost missed it but really glad we didn't. A relaxing way to spend a couple hours.
Ahhhhhh. What a fabulous home and gallery. We almost missed it as we didn't make reservations in time. The Canovas and Berninis are outstanding.

Most accessible museum in Rome. The Galleria Borghese limits the number of visitors at any one time so you can enjoy its incredible collection without being crowded or rushed. The collection is varied and excellent without being as huge as the Vatican museum. The grounds are beautiful as well - situated in a lovely park, its a great way to decompress from all that Rome is.
Weird opening times. Amazing little gallery but often need to book in advance as viewing is in specific time slots. Loads to see and in middle of great park

amazing. i loved the fact it was free with the roma pass overwise its 12euros well spent, the amount of significant sculpturs and paintings are incredible,we were overwhelmed at the beauty of the building and gardens. the only downside is you only have a 2 hour timeslot to get through it all (which we didnt manage) and then your ushered out

Astounding Art. This was the first museum we visited in Italy. It was simply amazing. Floor to ceiling art. The sculptures were exquisite. Beautiful mosaics. Guests are only allowed two hours, but we felt we had seen enough in an hour and a half. It was worth going to.

plan your visit. This is a very popular museum as part of Borghese park. We went there on Sunday morning, with Roma pass, I thought we could just skip the line. But we were told the only availble time slot on the same day is from 5 to 7pm. Or else we have to wait until Wed for the next available slot. I think it is good that they try to control the number of visiors at one time. It was no poblem for us, because we had plenty of free time in Rome. But if you have limit time, make sure to plan your visit well.
beautiful. well organized and not crowded. Booking is essential. We followed the Rick Steves recommended visit approach and it was good

Beautiful. Please make reservations ahead of time! The galleria is often sold out for days. Show up early on the lower level to lineup for your ticket, rent audio guide and check your bag (keep your wallet in your pocket), no cell phone allowed either. No photo inside. After getting your ticket for the reserved entry time, line up on the upper level for entrance. All this trouble is well worth it. Beautiful art work!

fantastic gallery and gardens-not to be missed. we booked in advance (from Canada) with victor, a prepaid walking tour of the gallery, including rome art history and it was well worth while. There is a lot to see and our guide focused on a few artists and their place in Roman history and their accomplishments. We spent a fun and educational 2 hours, not overwhelmed or just "browsing"/not too crowded on a Tues am.
Beautiful gardens. like everywhere else in Rome. But they were closing when we arrived and could only look from the outside.

A Great Museum, but be sure to reserve on-line in advance. All of the many wonderful reviews of this museum in a park by other TripAdvisors are absolutely accurate -- it's one of the glories of Rome, and easy to get to: either walk up the Via Veneto to the top of the hill and cross the street (taking your life in your hands, as always in Rome) or take a taxi to the park entrance. Then it's a 10 minute walk inside the park to the museum itself. Do purchase the audio guide; it's good. Be aware of the two hour time limit that keeps the museum from getting too crowded: consider skipping some rooms -- a hard task -- to avoid feeling rushed. Afterwards, we wandered through the park toward the little lake (where you can rent a boat) and chanced upon a lovely little outdoor trattoria where, under big umbrellas, we had a lovely leisurely lunch, reasonably priced. Don't be discouraged by the need to reserve your date and time in advance; this museum is well worth the trouble.
rich people's houses. look online to pre-order your tickets as the museum has scheduled dates/times and lasst minute tickets are hard to come by. Wonderful collection

unbelievable collection. fantastic collection of statuary in a beautiful setting. the 2 hour time limit for your visit is strictly enforced so make sure and show up well in advance of your reservation (required) so that the lines to collect your tickets and stow your belongings in the cloakroom don't take up any of your viewing time.

Beautiful in a wonderful setting.. The art in this museum is as outstanding as the rooms that the art is in. It's just incredible to walk through these rooms and think of the people living there so long ago. It is necessary to have reservations and I think it's a very good thing, as it really controls the crowds. It makes the experience that much better if you are not elbowing your way through the rooms as we did in the Vatican museums. The lovely park that the museum is in is also worth some time to enjoy.

Classic. The Borghese museum is a small gallery, but contains several masterpieces. It is best to reserve ahead and tours are limited to 2 hours. Plan ahead, as their cafe was closed when we were there.There were some privately booked tours, which from our eavesdropping, were quite informative. It was definitely worth the revisit. The parkland around is quite lovely, and a stroll is definitely in order.

Waited three years to see it. My first trip to Rome in 2010 and imagine my surprise to find that I needed to book month in advance to see this marvel of art and museo. I missed seeing it sadly. This trip I booked 6 months early and visited one of the most wonderful galleries on the planet. Right up there with Uffizi in Florence in my opinion.Too bad the visit to Borghese is limited to two hours!
World Class Museum. Recommend a Dark Rome tour to really appreciate all there is to see in this museum. Tours are limited to 2 hours so you can't dawdle; what you see is quite spectacular.

Wonderful Museum. Reservations must be made in advance for this museum but we made the reservation by phone (English operator available), brought our reservation number with us, and paid using our Rome card. The surrounding parkland and gardens are a lovely and serene break from bustling Rome so make sure to include some time to visit them. The building itself is beautiful and and it is wonderful how they control the number of visitors so it never feels crowded. The way the gallery is set up with a limited number of pieces in each room allows the visitor to view this magnificent collection room by room without feeling overwhelmed. The audio guide for this collection is particularly good and includes interesting stories about some of the prominent artists and pieces. This collection in this museum was one of the best I have ever seen and our visit was one of the highlights of our two week trip to Italy.

Lovely museum/gallery... Was very nice to go and visit in a lovely location in the middle of the park. Was a bit annoying that you cant take and cameras into the building :( but will leave an image on you you wont forget.. Be sure to book early..!!!

one of my favorites. This is definitely one of my favorite museums. The best part is that they limit the number of guests that they let in at any one time. The works of art are fabulous! The headphones are a must if you don't have a private tour.

A must see!. I missed this on my first visit to Rome and am so glad I saw it on my second. This gallery has some of the most beautiful art and it is not as overwhelming as the Vatican or the Uffizzi. It is charming and elegant. The gardens outside are also lovely. Make sure to order tickets online well in advance as this sells out quickly.

When in Rome, this is a must!. First - make reservations - they are always sold out days in advance. Because they only allow so few people in, the rooms are not crowded and you can really enjoy these masterpieces. This is a magnificent collection and you can get very close to the paintings and sculptures. Bernini's pieces just have to been seen to understand his genius. A highlight of our trip to Rome!
Fabulous museum. One of the best museums I've ever seen; unbelievable Bernini sculptures; beautiful palace; interesting history. You must have advance reservations.
Too much for nothing. Too burocratic for less than expected. It is necessary to book in advance, it is far from city center, it does not have a good infrastructure such as a nice cafeteria.

my favorite Rome museum. I recently had the joyful experience of staying in Rome for a month, and visited many beautiful places. The Galleria Borghese is not to be missed. It's a bit more complicated to visit than others, since you must make a reservation days in advance, but it is worth it. So much beauty and incredible works of art, with a number of Bernini sculptures and paintings by Caravaggio. All are arranged in what was essentially a mansion (beautiful, ornate, a work of art in itself), so it is an intimite gallery that allows you to get close enough to really experience the art. Fantastic!
Impressive. A must see museum. Statues from Bernini are so beautiful as is the overall setting. We loved it. Make sure to book in advance via Internet
Too far a walk, no directions. If you've been to the lourve, this will be skip-able..not really worth the walk if you're going in summer or fall when the sun can be very merciless...

A must visist attraction. Take the guided tour, they are well worth the extra cost.
Girl on the desk where you book the guides was so rude, but ll of the others were just great
Superb. You need to book for this but again the Villa and all around is so beatifull. Don`t miss this wonderfull area of Rome.

a must if you're and art lover in Rome. If you've never been there it's an absolute must. We frequent Rome and go there every other time. The 'unfortunate' thing is that you have to reserve tickets some 4-5 days in advance!

Not to be missed. Legendary galleria. Must buy tix ahead and be prepared for the line that forms (with tix) about 20 minutes before your appointed time. Also be aware that you must leave the museum when your time is up, so plan accordingly. We used the audio tour, but it did not include the level of detail we were looking for-- it may actually be worth taking tour with a pre-booked guide.

An afternoon with the rich and famous. After much research, I decided to buy our Borghese Gallery tickets online; this was the correct decision. When we arrived, the gallery was sold out for the next two days. There are strict visiting times, 2 times in the morning and 2 times in the afternoon. We had 3-5 and were not let in one minute earlier, you also have to check your bags, as there is no photography allowed. There are 2 floors- we went right upstairs and had the place to ourselves. The artwork and rooms are incredible- exquisite paintings, statues and room decorations. Each room has tiled/marble floors and a ceiling painting. The rooms have a theme, the Egyptian room downstairs is a marvel. Eat and drink coffee before you go, then just take your time to enjoy the lifestyle and art of the Borghese family.

A Fabulous Art Collection. Friends gave us two tickets to the Borghese and it turned out to be an outstanding tour stop for us. The statuary is magnificent and the audio guide we used from the Museum is fabulous in its explanations of what we were seeing there. The staff was incredibly helpful as we arrived three hours after our slotted time for entry. They walked us up back staircases to avoid the lines ahead of us and made us feel like valued guests. The history of the Galleria Borghese is wonderful and historic. We highly recommend this as a stop when in Rome. The gardens and pathways outside the Galleria are like NYC's Central Park.

Artistic Splendour. Walking through the parks and gardens from the top of the Spanish Steps as an approach to the Galleria was delightful. The depth and quality of the artworks and sculpture on display Most Definitely has to be seen to be believed...could not recommend more highly
Excellent museum. Well laid out. Because of the limited admission policies, it was less crowded than most museums. Be aware that you must reserve in advance.

Galleria Borghese, set in a green oasis.. The Galleria is set in parkland on the northern edge of the city. You can book on line before your visit if that is convenient for you. HOWEVER you must pre-book your visit even if you go there in person and buy a ticket for a visit the following day. Entries are also timed and last two hours.Visitors are held in a queue until the correct time so you will not get in early. The paintings are on the upper floor with many headline artists on display. What wowed us though were the sculptures on the ground floor. There are Bernini sculptures in the display that will call you back over and again. The David sculpted with his slingshot fighting Goliath with incredible concentration on his face will remain with you.We got to Borghese on the electric bus service 116 which goes right into the Villa grounds, although there are other services available.

art lover's haven. The amount and quality of art in this museum is just astounding. The fact that the number of people in the museum at any one time is very tightly controlled makes the visit more enjoyable.

Gorgeous Gallery. As other have written, walking up to the Galley with advanced reservations will keep you outside. We asked our Hotels front desk to call the Gallery when we arrived in Rome and received a reservation two days in advance, I highly recommend doing this. We then were able to schedule the rest of our stay around this reservation time. The Gallery it's self is amazing, smaller then in other major European cities, but with the ticketing reservation system the crowds are very manageable.
Borghese Gallery. This is a must see whether you appreciate art or not. The masterpieces here are astounding and will boggle the mind
Borghese. Beautiful grounds. Nice that they only let a few people in at a time and you had two hours to view paintings etc. without the crowds. Make sure you book ahead. No tickets at the door.

A must for art lovers. This is an amazing collection of sculpture - particularly Bernini - and paintings - particularly Caravaggio. It's best to reserve in advance on line, which is easy to do. It's true that visits are limited to two hours, so get the audio guide or take the guided tour, which is available in English. There were only five of us on our tour (in October) and the guide was quite knowledgeable.

Visit Galleria Borghese. There are so many places, and so much art in Rome, sometimesdepending on the time we have, is not easy to select, but Galleria Borghese is worth a visit, excellent paintings and sculptures, and a nice walk through the park.

Too much to see, too little time. Galleria Borghese contains magnificent sculpture and art -- any art lover will want to spend a day there. And that's the problem -- visitors are given two hour slots (the officials literally clear the entire gallery every two hours) which is not nearly enough time to savour the delights. The authorities should perhaps consider a multiple-entry ticket.

Admin. I couldn't believe that Trip Advisor gave this place an award. The staff were impossibly rude!! It was user unfriendly. Booking was a nightmare. Beware you could end up with a wrong code and unable to visit. Obligatory pre-booking!! All sites are poorly informed. Staff don't know much about what is in the gallery.
Villa Borguese. Very nice and modern even though the preservation of the buildings is still their priority.nice place to walk and admire the history.

One of favorite art museums in the world. Brilliant how art blends with building. Must buy in advance. I've been to countless art museums, and I can now say this is one of my favorites in the world. I thought art was exhibited so perfectly. They blended so well with the building itself. The sculpture floor was outstanding. There isn't a lot of clutter, so everything gets its due attention. The vaulted ceilings are also painted, and they're beautiful as well. It looks like the figures on the ceiling are really supporting the roof like columns.The upper floor of paintings was alright. Not nearly as memorable as the sculptures in my opinion. I even went through the sculptures a second time after seeing the paintings.They really limit the number of people per day, so you must buy tickets in advance. From the looks of it, your chances of getting in without doing so are slim.

A Do not miss in Rome. This is a fantastic Gallery. Make sure you make an appointment and see the art. The works of Bernini are breathtaking and art work and history are outstanding.The self directed tour is well done and very educational. It really gives you a sense of the history of the times.
One of the top 4-5 tings to do in Rome. Great art in a beautiful building, loated in a great park. A little too noisy in the room due to larger tour groups.
Gorgeous!. The most beautiful place I've ever toured!! So much history, so many beautiful pieces of art. A definite stop for anyone touring in Rome.

view. if we are reviwing the same property, this is across from a park and is now a restaurant with a spectaclar view, just going up there and standing at the wall and looking over the city is worth every minute

Galleria Borghese is a must see!. You need a reservation but that makes the visit so much better because there are only a certain number of people allowed in at one time so it is not crowded. This is a must see. There are wonderful statues and great paintings.

Art lovers paradise!. I learned to appreciate two hour limit per reserved appointment as it greatly enhances experience and is indicative of a better than average museum administration and has lower impact on exhibits by way of avoiding overcrowding and associated stale / contaminated air which damage painted surfaces of every type.Advance reservations made by telephone was simple enough and also enhances experience by avoiding throngs awaiting ticket purchase in queue.Tip: call ahead to reserve appointment. If citing purchase and payment with Roma Pass when reserving, museum will book appointment at no charge until day at museum with Roma Pass.

A perfect little gallery. What more can you ask for? This location is a beautiful palace in Rome's centrally located Villa Borghese. It's not too big, so you can see everything in it with your eyes glazing over in an aesthetic coma. It's never too crowded by design, so you won't have anyone else standing between you and the Baroque masterpieces that fill the palace. Some of the works were commissioned for the very spots in which they now stand, which means that the lighting, space and provinance are pretty much ideal. Bernini's "Rape of Proserpina" alone is easily worth the price of admission.
Well worth it.. Make sure to book early - It was booked up a week in advance. I would recommend doing this museum while in Rome. To see Bernini's work in person is something you don't want to miss.
great collection. Great collection of sculptures and paintings. The building itself is worth the visit. A pity you have to book 2 days in advance

Breathtaking.. Based on TA advice, we reserved tickets for the Galleria Borghese. Good thing we did because when we visited on a Sunday, reservations were booked until the following Thursday. When you arrive be sure to take your on line reservation and exchange it for actual tix. Also, the audio tour is a must so pick one up as soon as you arrive. (The audio tour takes almost the entire 2 hours so you don't want to be late getting it). Finally, large handbags must be checked. Be sure to do all of the foregoing as soon as you arrive. As for the collection, it is breathtaking. Along with the Vatican Museum, probably our favorite sites. Unfortunately, no pictures are allowed once inside so be sure that the sculptures and pictures are firmly etched in your memory(either that or buy a book at their store). Apollo and Daphne-magnificant. Words can't adequately describe Bernini's works. Raphael and Caravaggio paintings- beautiful. And on and on. The Galleria Borghese has to be on your list of must sees while in Rome.
Incredible art with a manageable crowd.. Once inside you have all the time to want to look at these magnificant statues and paintings. One of my favorites places.

Wonderful Sculptures. Not even a huge fan of sculpture, but these were breathtaking. Don't forget to reserve a time in advance and leave yourself some time to just wonder around the great villa park near the museum.

Venue & art fabulous. We loved the setting of this art gallery in a sumptious villa, rooms were as wonderful to look at as the art treasures. We rented the audioguide and there was a place for an extra set of earphones so my husband and I could both listen and learn. Get there early because the bag check line is lengthy and not very efficient (also the pick up). You must have reservations in advance--we were there on a Tuesday and they were sold out until Saturday. Afterwards we enjoyed walking in the park, which is huge and beautiful. Nice overlook over the Piazza Picolo (sp.?)

worth the trip for the gardens alone. Loved this gallery !!! Unique and appreciated all the work. To enjoy Bernini's Rape of Persephone alone was worth admission... he made the marble appear like flesh...soft and vunerable... you felt her fear and his rapture... and forgot it was carved in such a cold , hard, medium.Brilliant!Great area to walk & enjoy after as well:)
Great Walk. Spend a day just walking around the Borghese Gardens. Beautiful area just to walk around and spend some time relaxing.

Art fest!!. Loved the paintings and the ceilings were amazing . Took a bike for 4 round the grounds. They rent them for 1 hour. 30 mins was more than enough we must have been down every road at least twice in just over 30 mins and got fed up so returned it.

best kept secret...best museum in italy. loved the tour we took, through Dark Rome. You have to reserve your time and you only have 2 hours...so wefelt a tour was the best way to go. Also lovely gardens towalk and refresh

Great Gallery, Strange Visiting Rules. Galleria Borghese is considered to be one of the best private art collections in the world. It houses works by Raphael, Canova, Bernini, Rubens, Titian, Cranach and Carravagio, and that is why it's a must-see for art-lovers.However, the gallery has, perhaps, the most complicated (not to say stupid) visiting rules among Italian art museums, and I have been to many. These rules look like rules for visiting a prison, not a gallery:1) It's impossible to buy a ticket right there - you need to book it by phone or online at least 1 day ahead. Ordering tickets by phone is convenient, 'cause English-speaking assistance is available.2) Your visit is limited to 2 hours, and that's it. It is also stated, that visitors are allowed to stay at the picture gallery for not more than 30 minutes, which is too little, but I have not seen this to be controlled (doesn't mean it's not, anyway).3) Pre-ordered tickets are to be collected at the museum at least 30 minutes in advance.4) Bags of any size are not allowed inside, so you need to leave them at the locker, that accepts them 20 minutes prior to your visiting time.5) Photography is prohibited.Tickets: 12 EUR, so I'd recommend to include this visit into your Roma Pass (30 EUR, includes visits to any 2 museums + discount to the 3rd museum + unlimited use of public transport in Rome for 3 days; very economical). You'll need to say you're going to pay with a Roma Pass right away, before the cashier would state you're paying with cash, 'cause otherwise the pass would not be accepted.There is a cafe in the ground floor, but it was closed for a while when I was visiting.

A little rushed but worth it.. They only give you 2 hours to see all the mind boggling art work in the Galleria but its better than nothing. We booked in advance and they were booked for several days straight when we arrived. The sculptures are amazing, it is worth it to get an audio guide to help navigate and understand the history. It is disappointing that you can't take photos, in fact you have to check most of your belongings at the front desk. The line-ups were tedious. Still it is interesting to see how much bounty a ruthless pope could beg, extort or steal. He had impeccable taste. Well worth the trip.
extraordinary. If you go to ome you need to visit Vila Borghese. Exceptional sculptures, paintings and statues. Audio guide is a must.
An art lover's paradise. The amount of art the Borgheses collected was amazing. Certain artists were a favorite of our tour guide.

Lovely Art Gallery. This gallery houses an extensive art collection. A large part of it consists of lovely sculptures. One has to reserve a time in advance. It is a good idea to arrive about 30 minutes ahead of the assigned time in order queue for the tickets and then rent an audio tour. We found the audio tour quite useful. The Galleria is situated in the "Villa Borghese" (really a huge park with other museums/galleries as well). Maps and signage in the park are not very precise. We got lost trying to find another galleria. Lots of opportunity to have a snack (gelato, etc.) in the park.

Overrated. Too much light, and incompetently applied, completely destroys the old masterpiece paintings. Too stuffed with too many pieces of art. The sculptures should not be mixed with the paintings. They require different light.

Fabulous museum in the "Central Park" of Rome. My wife was an art major so visiting the Galleria Borghese was a must. Our tour guide recommended getting there by 11:00 am in order to take a guided tour. It certainly enhances to tour and you get a perspective not included in the audio tours. The grounds are as impressive as the museum. Highly recommend it to anyone who loves art. One can only imagine the power of the Borghese family to accumulate such a massive collection of art and the grounds that surround it.

Amazing sculpture. I am not an "art lover" but the marble sculptures inside this museum were nothing short of amazing. I had no idea you could make marble that detailed and defined where it looks lifelike. I would recommend making this a half-day destination on any trip to Rome.
Awesome Gallery. The most beautiful galleria in Rome! Picture taking allowed, not crowded. Book tickets. And entry time Early to have the most interesting art experience everyone!

You had to book your visit in advance. Impossible to enter. We should have booked a visit before !!! So we did not see the Galleria (but there is a bookshop under it, so we purchased some books about what we did not see)

Buy tickets in advance and go early. This gallery is on everyone's list so don't expect to be able to rock up on a whim and get in. Buy your tickets online well-ahead of when you want to go and either take the printed receipt with you (with your booking number) or write it down on paper and take it with you. We went in the shoulder season. We booked 4 days in advance and when we arrived it was sold out for the next 5 days. You will need to put all your bags in a locker (free) and you cannot take photos. Spaces are booked in two hour slots starting from 9am and you get a max of 30 min in the picture gallery (although I saw no-one get thrown out!). You have to climb a fairly high spiral staircase to get into the picture gallery, but there is a tiny lift if you need it - not obvious, so ask if you need it.We were on a mission to see every Caravaggio in Rome in 4 days and there are at least 5 here. But they are not in the picture gallery - they are on the ground floor in a room of the museum. One of his finest paintings (personal opinion) "The crucifixion of St Peter" is just down the hill in the church of Santa Maria del Popolo in Piazza del Popolo, as is his "Conversion of Saint Paul" so add that to your day's itinerary. Entry to Santa Maria is free but take some coins for the light boxes. Once again, no photos.

Fantastic Marble work by Bernini. I really enjoyed my visit to this gallery in comparison to all of the other galleries that I have been to in Italy. I highly recommend the audio guide. Please make reservations ahead of time! It is well worth the time and effort.

Great experience. If visiting Rome this is one place that has to be on your list.
Top notch art and beautiful gardens in this old world wonderland.
Be sure you don't miss this piece of history
A must see.. Amazing Gallery. A little difficult to find. It was not well marked. You could not take photos, and I would love to have had some pictures. The statues were fantastic.

This is an amazing museum and well worth the advanced purchase and waiting to enter the museum at the designated time.. The museum is a perfect gem. We waited over an hour at the small entrance to get in at designated time. The cafe was closed and so seating was very limited.

Not to be Missed if you enjoy Fine Art and Sculpture. I could not disagree more with Anika M. My husband and I have visited this Gallery twice, and were equally awed by the collection the second time as the first. Bernini's sculpture of Apollo and Daphne is stunning, and is very widely admired in the art world. Likewise, his statue of David hurling his slingshot to slay Goliath, Bernini's his "Rape of Proserpina," and Canova's statue of Pauline Bonaparte (Napoleon's sister). I consider the Galleria Borghese to be one of the "must see's" in Rome, along with the Forum, the Pantheon, and Piazza Navona. I think that only someone totally disinterested in fine art and sculpture would not be thrilled and awed by this collection.

Stunning. A MUST visit for any first-timer's trip to Rome! This is a beautiful private home and collection of some of the most awe-inspiring masterpieces you'll ever find under one roof. Easiest way to get in is to make a reservation online at LEAST 1 week BEFORE - I saw hundreds of frustrated tourists standing around outside, waiting to get in because the Villa was at full occupancy. I bought my ticket online, showed up a 1/2 hour early (make sure you get there at least 30 mins in advance of your scheduled tour time because you still have to wait in line to check in - took me about 20 mins) and I had no issues. Make sure to rent the digital audio guide - it's imperative and you'll be lost without it. And don't "lolly-gag" in the rooms (move from room to room at the same pace with the audio guide) as you have a TIMED LIMIT and they enforce it strictly - I was literally ushered out of the building! Also know that you will NOT be allowed entrance with even the tiniest of purses or "fanny packs" - so wear a money belt and tuck your credit cards and cash inside because you won't want to leave them at the bag check - plus this was another two annoying lines to wait in to check your bag then retrieve it. You can put your mobile phones in your pocket but you'll NOT be permitted to bring your cameras, so leave your big / good cameras in the hotel along with your purses and backpacks, take a taxi and make a beeline from your hotel to the Villa, and then back to your hotel to retrieve your gear.
Well worth a visit. Need to book in advance but fantastic place with amazing range of art. The Bernini sculptures are awesome.

Beauatiful collection and Felix was a great tour guide.. Recenetly went tothe Borghese and had a great tour wih Felix in English who gaveus all of the back stories on the amazing woks of art in the museum and about the Cardinal who collected the works and the building housing the collection. It was one of the best tours we've ever had and would definfitly do it again.Pat

Amazing. This was the most amazing gallery we saw in Italy. The collection itself is amazing, and it helps that it's in such a wonderful setting. Personal highlights were the statue of Paulina Borghese, and my favourite painting, Titian's Sacred and Profane Love. Utterly incredible. You do need to book in advance, but I liked the 2-hour visit system as it really pretend crowds building up.

Fantastic. This Galeria was a delightful surprise. We went early in the morning and walked around the serene park before it opened among the locals walking their dogs, running, biking, etc. Then we were among the first in line to enter the Galleria and loved everything about the museum. Such a beautiful building and amazing art. You must make reservations ahead of time. We took a taxi from our hotel for an inexpensive ride. Well worth a visit!

Lovely little museum with great works of art. Great art and sculpture, and a lovely home! I recommend the audio guide. Orientation is a bit weird as you enter through the back, but once we figured that out, saw several great pieces of artwork. Worth the visit.

One of the most fantastic private collections in the world. Visiting the Galleria was one of the high spots of our visit to Rome. The beauty of the rooms, the fabulous works by Bernini, the paintings, the ceilings and the setting made the Galleria Borghese just breathtaking.We went at 5 pm which was a very good time with less crowds. You do have to book at least 2 or 3 days ahead and may have to hang on to the phone for 10 or 15 minutes as a recorded message tells you where you are in the queue. Going later in the day means that the bookshop may be closed when you finish your visit, so do buy any wanted books or postcards before you start.The Galleria Borgese is a must for any visit to Rome and you could enhance your visit by hiring a cycle for 4 to go round the huge gardens outside.

SO OVERRATED. If you're well travelled like myself, then this is a total let down. You have to book tickets in advance as they sell out completely!! But this has no comparison to palaces in Venice/Paris etc! I don't understand what the hype really is - but just go there to tick the box!
Unbeleivable beautiful. A great collection of art and the area around the museum was nice to stroll in. You were not allowed to take pictures inside.

A dream came true. I love Bernini's sculptures and fulfilled a life long dream seeing them in person. I really wish they would have allowed flashless photography. I don't see how it would have hurt anything.

We loved everything about the Borghese Gardens and Gallery. We were disappointed that the cafeteria was closed during a very busy tourist season. We booked our time on line the day before and picked up the audio tour - an absolute must to appreciate the gallery.

Check what section is open before you go. The Galleria Borghese opens up in sections (floors) so if you know what you want to see you should call and see if your floor is open. Why so complicated? Personnel cuts have reduced staffing to a minimum - bummer :(

a must see. Do this gallery and the gardens that go with it, it is mind blowing all the scuplture and paintings, was my lifelong dream to see the Carrivaggio's. The gardens are very nice!! a terrific spot to walk and take a breath from the hustle and bustle that is Rome.

Worth the visit. Normally you have to book in advance, but we showed up without a reservation because the online booking system was closed. We showed up and was able to get in. Lots to see inside. There is a large park next to the Galleria. Great for walking and running.
So big it can't be crowded. Because only so many people are allowed in every two hours and it is so big it never seems crowded. Always look up as the ceilings are three dimensional. Exquisite.

Galleria Borghese, Baroque splendor. Stunning Baroque rooms and sculpture. Staff is less than accomodating...My husband loves the Josephine Bonaparte scupture by Canova. I prefer the Bernini Apollo and Daphne. Typically Baroque, full of drama and movement. A friend favors Bernini's David, but I am loyal to Michelangelo's monumental sculpture that I think exhibits more emotion and power even though the figure remains still.

????. The guide books say that booking is recommended, it's not it's MANDATORY, so if possible book before you go, or as soon as you get there. The appointments are timed slots, 2 hourly, 11am, 1pm etc. This is the one place I wanted to go and didn't.

A must see if you are in Rome. Whether you want to relax in the afternoon, have a romantic walk with you partner, or do some sports, this heart shaped park is the place to be. I went there while on my honeymoon in Rome in September. The greenary is not that great as you would imagine it to be in parks, but the old houses and museums inside are worth make the visit all worthwhile. You can reserve tickets to access museums online before heading there.I adivse you take the Segway (which is a 2-wheeled transport) to save time and see as much as possible of the villa Borghese. I dont recommed you spend more than 1.5 hrs if you are on a tight schedule.The park is located on a hill and on one side there is an open Terrace overlooking Vatican city and a good portion of Rome. A splendid view!. Make sure to visit while there.

Excellent Canova Statues. Wonderful small museum in a palace. Needlessly confusing entry--stand in line to turn in your reservation voucher, then another line to turn in your purse. Nice gift shop and toilettes.
Loveliest palace in Rome!. Too much to absorb in a single afternoon, which I'd had another day there! The audio tour is well worth it. You must check every bag you have with you, even your purse!
wonderful collection. get your tickets online early as they sell out weeks in advance.The statues and paintings are glorious

Don't miss this!. This is an incredible gallery not to be missed! The fact that there is a limit to the number of visitors admitted every two hours truly enriches the experience for viewing the magnificent works of art on display here. Visiting this museum was absolutely a highlight of our 12 visit to Italy!

go, make reservation and enjoy. this museum isn't that big, but the works in the Galleria are among the greatest ever made, you get a room piled up with Caravaggio masterpieces, you get Bellini, Raffaello, Cranach, Tiziano, Correggio. Since it gets very crowded, get a reservation and be free of stress or long waiting lines, just be there on time (you make a reservation for a specific hour) or your ticket becomes worthless.enjoy the works in this spectacular setting, surrounded by the park this museum gives deep insights of nobility and art. It’s airy, and a walk through the art history.I heard from friends that the guides are very good, so you might consider one (I assume that can be arranged when you reserve tickets)in short: perfect in every way, afterwards you can rent a bike and chew on what you saw in the big park surrounding the galleria)

Nice but not a must go if you're not a art lover. We used our Roma Pass to go in here as many suggested. THEY'RE VERY STRICT so make sure you make your reservations in advance. They won't even let you get the audioguide until closer to your reservation time. As the entrance requires reservations and they're timed, you don't really get to skip the line. You still have to wait online to present your roma pass at the box office and you still have to wait online as the rest of your group who's going to the museum at the time your reservation is for.The museum is relatively small and in a big park, near a zoo. We got there an hour early and didn't have much to do around. Some were riding bikes, etc but nothing super amusing. There was no guided tour so we did the audiotour. The statues and paintings are impressive and the audiotour gave us very interesting facts.However, if you're not much into arts, there will be a lot of names that you've maybe heard of, but don't really know much about. My husband totally lost interest after the first 30 mins or so.I'd say go only if you love arts, if not, skip....

A lovely gallery in a lovely place. This is a worthwhile experience. You make reservations for a block of time and go in and out based on that reservation. The gallery is not large, but is excellent. The grounds - a park - are a great place to wait to go in and a great place to get away from the bussle of Rome.

Our favourite art gallery in Rome. This is by far our favourite art gallery in Rome, and one we have visited three times. It hosts an impressive collection of sculptures, especially Bernini's masterpieces, and a host of paintings, among them Caravaggio's breathtaking masterpieces. We recommend booking a visit in advance (bookings may even be mandatory), as sometimes the place is fully booked for days. Also arrive promptly at the appointed time, since the museum only lets in a set number of visitors at a time, and for a limited period of time. If you are late, it eats away your time in the museum.Our first visit was in 2003 during our honeymoon as part of a prearranged tour with a Finnish guide who happened to be well-versed in art history, and this original experience really helped us to appreciate the place also on later visits. So perhaps some kind of guided tour is recommended, although we can't vouch for the quality of the local tours, as we have never been on one.For us the highlights were, usurprisingly, Bernini's "David" (the soon to be exploding tension in his pose and grimace), "Apollo and Daphne" (the moment of transformation frozen in time) and "the Rape of Proserpina" (desperation and the fleshlikeness of marble); and Caravaggio's "Bacchus" and "David with Goliath's Head". But the place is brimming with interesting and historically important art, so people with more knowledge in those things will be able to enjoy this place even more deeply. However, this is a moving experience even for us laymen, so don't let lack of education to stop you. And of course, reflect on the experience by taking a long walk in the Borghese park. If you need a place where to have lunch before or after the tour, we recommend "Pomodorino" very close just inside the City Walls.

Buy tickets on the internet. Print out your tickets and when you arrive at the Galleria Borghese, you will see a queue waiting to enter through the basement doors. With your print out in hand, bypass the line, enter the building, walk down the stairs and to to the left of the ticket window in an alcove you will see a bar code reading machine that will print out your admission tickets. Then check you bags (and leave enough time, because the attendants move at their own pace) and get in the entrance queue. Don't miss the Bernini sculptures, especially Daphne and Apollo.

Just because of Belini. Location is kind of out of place but worth the trip. Please take taxi to get there and be prepared to walk up a long stairs at the bginning of tour. I love the control of crowd. The building and garden itself is beautiful. After the tour, take a 30 min walk and have a break at Cafe de Paris.

Fantastic Collection. Amazing collection of art. Bernini's statues are amazing. A must do. I've noticed that most of the negative comments are about administrative issues, like booking tickets. Yes, you must book in advance; the gallery sells out frequently, as they allow a limited number of people every two hours.TIP: Get an Audio Guide - it is excellent.

The best museum/gallery in Rome. After spending the previous day enduring the Vatican Museum this really was a very welcome pleasure!An excellent museum with some fine quality pieces & a lot of interest. Good value for money, plenty of time to see everything due to restricted numbers.Don't miss the view from the edge of the park over Piazza del Popolo & beyond.

My favorite muesum of Rome and Florence. Not a huge museum person but this place is fantastic. The first floor is definitely the most impressive. There are several outstanding sculptures and if you are a lover of painting you will not be disappointed. The fact that it used to be a home with painted ceilings and walls just adds to the splendor. We used the audio guide there and it was very helpful. NOTE- There is an elevator, though I never saw it used, there are a lot of stairs to get to the second floor. Also you have to check any bags including purses.

Most amazing sculptures.. This was a real highlight, not to be missed on a trip to Rome. Prebooking is the only way to go. I just wish that there was more time allotted as I could have stood there for hours marveling at the sheer beauty of the sculptures.

Gallery visit. Once you are organised and get into the galleria it is amazing. You need to allow plenty of time for queuing to check in your bag as strict rules apply as to what can be taken into the galleria.

Gallery and Museum. Book ahead (hotel did this) for allotted time. Leave at least an hour beforehand - not an easy place to reach by transport. There are buses from termini. No elevator - probably need audio - extraordinary place. Can use Roma pass.

Book in advance. Great gllery, very good value at 11 euros. Make sure you phone or go on line to book your viewing. Not open Mondays. Worth a visit to see the sculptures.
