Bellini's David absolutely stunning! First floor picture gallery a bit disappointing and little commentary available. The grounds are lovely.

We loved it!. We took the audioguide and it was very well put-together. The collection in the gallery was spectacular with a number of famous works from a lot of the masters. During our trip to the Uffizi we got a tad bored and dazed with the amount of art and no sense of progression. We thought this this was a perfectly sized gallery and we really enjoyed our time here. I'd definitely recommend making sure you get in by 3pm so you have atleast 3 hours to follow the audioguide to the end. If you go in at 5pm, you could be cut short at 7pm when the gallery closes.

A Gem of a Museum. The museum was a bit out of the way from other sites, but still readily accessible. Absolutely worth going, though. The Bernini sculptures alone are nothing short of breathtaking in their baroque beauty. This is inanimate stone with life breathed into it. Our children were as completely amazed as we were. the paintings were great too. Meanwhile, the park is a nice walk, there is a nice cafe in it where my wife and I had a good cap while our kids (accidentally) attempted to kill themselves riding the pedal carriages.

You won't believe. The Borghese is fantastic. The opulance is amazing and you can virtually get right next to a Raphel or Ruben without some alarm going off. Outside of the Louve or National Gallery in London this is the place to see art.

Beautiful Art. Getting in this gallery is the hardest part of your journey. First you must make an appointment to buy your ticket. Arrive before your appointed time to avoid standing in line, but after you buy your ticket you'll have to sit and wait until you may enter. The best strategy for seeing everything with the least amount of crowd is to go immediately to the top floor and work backwards. If you rent an audio guide, going to the end first is a bit confusing, but there are numbers on the works of art and those numbers can be entered into the device. Without the audio device you'll simply walk around and look at art, so the small fee to rent the device is well worth it. There are so many pieces to see you will just want to hit the high spots anyway, that is if you are not really into the art. You must check your packs before entering.

Best museum I saw in Rome! I loved it!. I had previously visited Rome several years ago, but missed the Borghese Gallery then due to neglecting to book tickets in advance. I was almost dreading going to another museum during this trip, but I wanted to go during this visit to Rome due to reading such excellent reviews of this site. Every guidebook I read highly recommended it. Most of the reviews on TripAdvisor were great too.Now, I understand why. The musuem contained some of the most gorgous paintings, sculptures, and artworks which are housed in a very lush and gorgeous villa. The floors were exquisite marble. The rooms were so finely decorated that they took my breath away. I was amazed by the art and also by the way it was displayed. It felt much different to me than a normal museum. It was much better and I enjoyed my 2 hours immensely. Also, the audioguide was excellent and I would highly recommend it.There are large lines to get in and also to check your bags. Making advanced reservations for your 2 hour time slot is imperative. But, once inside.... it will all be worth it. Also, make sure to focus on the ground level. We, unfortately, started on the 2nd floor and ran out of time to fully explore the ground level - which is much more impressive.

Fantastic!!!. One of the best museums ever been.Very useful audio guide.Many masterpieces from renaissance.Just remember to book in advance because there is a limit of 300 visitors per 2 hours.You also can use the Roma card as we did.

Even my husband the CPA loved it!. This gallery was recommended by so many people and it lived up to it's reputation. The building itself it a museum since every single surface is decorated by painting of some kind - faux marbles, trim, wood all look real until you get up close. The art is perfect against this back drop and the audio guide is a good one, focusing on the important pieces with just a little general commentary. The whole tour will just 2 hours and if you go first thing in the morning, there are only about 120+ people there, which is a far cry from the hot and bothered masses at The Vatican. You actually have the space to appreciate everything and can get extremely close to the Bernini sculptures - they are incredible. Give yourself about 35-45 minutes for the paintings and the rest of your time for the sculpture floor. The gift shop is nice with high-quality post cards, which makes up for the fact that there are no cameras allowed in the museum - no bags of any kind are allowed in either - it all has to be checked. Your tickets have to be booked in advance and it does sell out on certain days...be sure to book early. One Warning: for those who may have trouble climbing stairs - the only way up or down is on a very old marble spiral staircase. I counted over 70 steps to the top and I saw several older visitors struggling with the hike. If you think this might be an issue, you might want to check as you first come in RE: any kind of elevator options because there did not seem to be any staff available anywhere to help - this my only negative impression of the museum.

Fantastic Art!. I loved this villa/museum. The art, and particularly the sculpture, is incomparable. I would visit here every time I come to Rome, but the tickets are frequently sold out. Don't miss this, but plan ahead at least a few days!
Galleria Borghese - wonderful. Take your time to stroll in the park, and visit the gallery that's worth the time. Though you should be well organized, visit is limited to 2 hrs.

Excellent beyond expectations. This was one of the best sites to visit while in Rome. The sculpture was spectacular, and the English speaking guide was one of the best guides we ever had on any tour. Limiting the tour to 2 hours and limiting the admisssions made this the most enjoyable tour while in Rome. Don't miss it!
Must see!. Be blown away with the beautiful works of art in this world class museum. You are given 2 hours to see all these. Be sure to reserve way ahead online - tickets are sold out days before.

The best museum we visited. Make sure you put this museum on your list .Because you have to book numbers are limited and you actually get the chance to enjoy and appreciate the exhibits Hire a bike and cycle round the park after you finish

peacefull walk. a great place to wonder wround , suprising amount of things to look at , hire bikes or have a trip around in the train,plenty of space to chill out and enjoy the various buskers who are very talented.

no middle class. You must reserve in advance and you will only be allowed to stay for two hours. The audio guides are essential as there is so much to see it helps to get you through the whole museum seeing everything important. The gardens are wonderful too.
Well presented, Fabulous art. The art is fabulous and very well organized. The location is beautful. The staff could be a bit friendlier. I appreciated the crowd control.
Beautiful grounds and art. Liked the Art and the grounds leading to the museum. Was glad I bought my ticket ahead of time. Felt a little too rushed to get through. Would've liked a little more time.

Reservation system. Probably my error but I made a reservation on line several weeks in advance and at the end of the process said thank you for your reservation, gave the date, time and number of people plus the total. It said Not Captured on a line that I translated as notes. I did not know what this meant but since it also said thank you for your reservation figured the credit card would be charged on the date of the visit. Not so - maybe I used a Discover but apparently the card did not go through. We waited in line (got there 1/2 hour early to a large line) only to have a rude ticket person say that not captured meant that we did not have a reservation. She was quite demeaning really. Big disappointment. Have a travel agent or service book this for you unless your are fluent in Italian.

Get Tickets in Advance. This is a coveted attraction and you should buy tickets in advance. Even if you have tickets, be sure to arrive 45 minutes early to wait in line for your tickets and make sure to get an audioguide. You only have two hours in the gallery and the guide helps you navigate the facility while telling you what your seeing. It was our first attraction and after four days remained at the top of our list.

Go with a tour. We purchased our tickets with Viatour several weeks before our arrival in Rome. In fact, many of our excursions were pre-purchased with a tour group. It was a great move because there were so many tourists everywhere! The guide provided us with a trouble-free visit and the information was rich and interesting. She pointed out things that we would have missed otherwise.
museum lover's paradise.. lovely museum in a lovlier park. needs a few hours and a few panini to get round with, well worth the sore feet.

Artworks are amazing but the experience is not very well organized. They have masterful works of art here and the villa is situated in a beautiful and very large park. Factor in extra time to get here and find the place. If you have online reservations (which is the only way to get a ticket), you must show up 30 minutes before to pick up your ticket or they cancel your reservation and you lose your money. That's a bit stressful considering there is ample opportunity to get lost upon arrival and there are long lines even with reservations.You are only allowed 2 hours to see the entire museum and then they push you out. Get the audio guides. It definitely makes the experience.Staff also requires you to check your bags, including purses. No cameras allowed. You have to go to the bag pickup afterwards and there is usually a mob of people there.Important tip: try to schedule your visit first thing in the morning. There are less crowds and this ensures you get to see everything in time.
One of the Best. Buy tickets days in advance! Museum only allows scheduled two hour visits and 360 people per visit. Wonderful collection and not so crowded you can't enjoy it.

Wonderful collection of arts and sculptures. We've been here last week and have enjoyed every single second of our visit. We had booked our ticket two days in advance via the reservation hotline after reading about the compulsory booking three days before our visit to the galleria.So make sure you book the ticket in advance, else you will be returning home after still having to book a ticket.

In this Musee you can be "so close" to the Art. This was our third visit here. An absolute must see for us when in Rome. This time we took the bus and found it easier than the metro.My advice is to book this as soon as you book your hotel. The entry is limited to two hour slots. Be at least a half hour early. If you are late your reservation is resold to walk ins. Again, we did the audio. This may be my last trip in Rome, so we were very deliberate in this tour. Two hours is enough, but I could do three easy. We choose the first opening of the day, that gave us time to stroll and eat a little in the cafe in the park. You can actually get within inches of this superb art collection. I like to study the small details, and here I can do that. I think it is the best museum I have ever had the privilege to visit.
Breathtaking sculptures. Speechless at Bernini's sculptures. Appreciated the laminated cards with more information for each room.

Great Gallery. I really enjoyed my visit to Borghese Gallery. My husband even enjoyed it and he did not want to go at all. It is very impressive. We got the headsets for the tour and it really answered all the questions and more. I would highly recommend reserving tickets and going to this exhibit. It was very impressive and a must wee.

Perfect Sized Museum. With an admission ticket--which you need to reserve online or through your hotel and should do so at least a day in advance of your desired visit--you are allotted a 2 hour time to visit. For us, this is the perfect amount of time to spend in an art museum before our feet start to rebel and our brains start to wander and this Galleria needs to be seen. Get the Audioguide for the additional Euros, it is well worth it and lends a much deeper understanding than what you will achieve on your own. The building itself is beautiful, the artwork of great interest, and the back story the Audioguide provides on how the art was acquired really get you thinking about the complexities of appreciating what is in front of you, i.e. the nefarious means of art acquisition justifying (or not) the end product. You can bundle this visit with a stroll through the beautiful park and a walk down the stylish Via Veneto.

Amazing Art Experience. The Borghese Galleria is one of those places not to be missed. When visiting you are limited to two hours, and the art there mostly 16th and 17th century is so impressive. Every room there was enthralling. Wish we could have spent more than the allotted time. I might do this place with a guide as there is so much to see and I felt that I missed a lot even with the audio tour.

Great Museum in lovely park. You must book beforehand and it can be done online, very quick and easy and you just turn up at the appropriate time to collect tickets. You have to leave all bags, cameras etc in a cloakroom, they are put in lockers and you are given a key from the attendant. there's no charge for this and you just pick your bag up when you have finished.You are not supposed to take phones in either or take photos but a few people were doing so.There are a lot of sculptures and paintings by famous artists adn one of the great things about this museum was that in each room there is a stand with A3 laminated information sheets so that you can read all about the room and the different works in them.It's not big but there are a lot of things to see so worth visiting and then afterwards the park is lovely to stroll round

Great collection of sculpture, terribly disorganised! Book ahead. We first came to the Borghese Gallery without having looked it up on Tripadvisor, when we arrived we were told that all the tickets had sold out. Apparently you can't get into the museum without booking in advance. We left and decided to book tickets to return the following week. Upon our arrival at the museum there was a mass of tourists outside, they let people in through two entrances which cause a lot of confusion when there was really only one queue. There is also a time limit of 2 hours in the museum which I feel is too short.Upon entering the museum we found out that we were only permitted 30 minutes in the picture gallery and everyone was lined up to get in to see it. They did not filter people through in small groups but let everyone in at once which causes a small amount of chaos. There are no signs outside saying that you cannot enter the museum without booking in advance. I feel that they should let people know as many people queued a long time only to find out that they couldn't even get tickets at the desk. Also, despite booking in advance, there is a lot of chaos and disorganisation. People at the back of the queue who would have booked in advance but ended up queuing for nearly an hour would have their two hour time quote within the museum cut short.The museum houses Bernini's great sculptures and an impressive collection of marble sculpture. This is what makes the visit worthwhile. The picture gallery is good, but not evocative. However Bernini's statues come alive and are awe inspiring. Bernini is the artist of many sculptural works around Rome including the statues at the Piazza Navone fountains and the Ecstasy of St Theresa. To see his famous Rape of Persephone and Apollo and Daphne and his statue of David is a must when in Rome. Book ahead and be prepared for lots of queuing but this museum is well worth a visit.

For Bernini sculpture, this is THE place to go.. This was my favorite museum in Rome. Its a smaller scale musuem showcasing Baroque painting and sculputure, located on the side of a very large park. They "dedicated" four rooms more or less to a single Bernini sculpture, each one a masterpiece. The rest of the museum contains some very nice work, but the Bernini's are by far the strength of the musuem.Be sure to make a reservation, by phone or online. Otherwise you won't get in.

Great gallery, reserve in advance. The Borghese Gallery is a fantastic collection of sculpture and paintings, housed in a beautiful palace. The collection is relatively small but of very high quality, and personally I much preferred it to the Uffizi in Florence. Highlights of the collection are breathtaking sculptures by Canova and Bernini, and a handful of Carravagio, Raphael and Titian.The audioguide was one of the best gallery audioguides I've used - interesting, in depth and very informative. I felt that having an audioguide added a lot to my experience. The Borghese requires reservations and I strongly recommend you do so at least a couple of days in advance - we visited on a Tuesday (with a reservation) and the signs said it was booked out until Friday.

Bernini Heaven. The Bernini David, The Rape of Proserpina and Apollo and Daphne are amazing. The detail and the life carved out of marble is awe inspiring. The gallery i loaded with great art but the Bernini sculptures are special.

Beautiful Gallery. Lovely art gallery inside a peaceful park. We entered at 5 pm and enjoyed the exhibits at a leisurely pace. I printed out the pictures of the famous pieces from the Galleria Borghese website and had fun viewing the originals one by one. I was disappointed that no photography was allowed inside. I took off a star for that fact.

Peaceful stop in Rome -Borghese Gallery. The gardens were a delight and I did set for a bit and rested since I was sightseeing so much. Very lovely. Be sure to order your tickets a few days in advance. You can order on-line, or have your hotel help you. You will only have a specific time for your tour. The tours are monitored well and controlled, so please follow the rules. You can lock up your backpack or purse also. A good pause in the gardens after touring the Colosseum and resting for dinner later on in the day. A huge collection of paintings, antique sculptures and it represents the "golden age" of the Borghese Family.

Breathtaking collection of sculptures and paintings.. I was in awe of the sculpture in this collection. The Bernini works were hauntingly beautiful,especially considering his youth when many were done. His David has a look of concentration that is extremely realistic, you can feel his determination. I can't begin to describe Apollo and Daphne, just go see for yourself! The building is a jewel as well, opulent beyond description. I really did love this museum! Now here is why I did not give it a five...Having made my reservations in advance on line, (reservations are a must). I thought my voucher would be my ticket and we could go right in. We still had to wait in line to exchange the voucher for a ticket, then wait in another, much slower, line to check our backpack. Since you are only allotted two hours for the tour, it was annoying to waste so much of it in line. My second issue is that it is over 80 steps to the second floor and you must get a pass from a guide to use the small elevator. I know that it is not easy to retrofit a lift in these old, historic buildings, but since one is ther, why make it difficult to use? Many people have heart conditions or other hidden health issues and should not have to disclose it to use a lift! My last negative has to do with the setting of the museum. Frankly, the park was rather scruffy! Lots of litter, ill kept plantings, and few flowers. The cafe in the park was dirty and the one ladies room that was functional had a long line! In conclusion - definitely go to the museum, but don't waste much time in the park.

Beautiful art. I liked that you have to make a reservation to enter so that it doesn't feel crowded. You can take the audio tour which I highly recommend. There is a lot to see here, even though the museum is quite small. I would say a couple of hours is enough time to get through it. There are also some nice gardens here to escape the city for a while. A very enjoyable visit.

One of the most important collection in Rome. The Bernini's, by themselves, are worth making the trip to Rome. Add in the many Caravaggio's, and it is a collection that cannot be matched. I went back to the Bernini's over and over, and the beauty and power is hard to grasp. That a 24 year old could do this is hard to fathom. Do not miss this collection.

Very relaxing day. The Gallera had so many great pices of art. One place not to miss. Take your time and enjoy. The vast gardens were a pleasure to walk around. Be sure to have comfortable walking shoes. The gardens are very large
Make sure you book your tickets before you get to Rome. We did not book our tickets in advvance and were unable to go!! It is suppossed to have amazing art so we were disappointed.

Simply Elegant. A collection of sculptures and art work that certainly rivals the best museums of the world in a smaller space. Set in a lovely park in which to stroll. Once you've seen the Colosseum and the Roman Forum, the Vatican and the Trevi Fountain. and you need to slow down, this is a must-see.Make sure you make reservations in advance, and use the audio guide service if they're not doing a tour when you visit. They allow a 2-hour window for your stay.
Great Gallery. Wonderful gallery full of masterpieces from Bernini and Carravagio. Must make reservations to ensure entry. Takes about two hours to explore.

Fantastic Collection. The setting is beautiful, the building is charming and the collection amazing. Absolutely worth visiting and next time we will spend more time on the grounds of the Villa Borghese. If you have taken the metro to the Spanish Steps and plan on walking the rest of the way, from the metro station, take the Via Veneto exit and not the Villa Borghese exit. I think the Villa and Galleria are closer easier to find from Via Veneto.
Don"t miss the Galleria Borghese. You need to make a reservation for a 2 hour visit. We liked the sculpture better than the painting gallery. It is a pretty amazing collection.

Art History Essential. A small but high quality collection of art that is a 50:50 mix of classic and neoclassic scruptures/tiles and renaissance artwork. Some paintings are easily worth >10M. It isn't the Louvre in terms of volume but it is also less crowded because of their reservations system. I also enjoyed the audioguide (5 euro), which is short, like the museum, but high quality as well. Be ready to spend at least 1 hour here but probably no more than 3 hours. Tips: In order to realistically get in, you must make reservations ahead of time online (what I did) or phone. Bus (or rather mini-bus) 117 takes you there. You can metro it to the Barberini Fountain di Trevi station and then switch to 117 there (1.5 euros for a metro/bus ticket or free if you got the roma pass). Or walk in from the Flaminio Piazza del Popolo (Plaza of the People) metro station and enjoy the park as well (will need at 30 min to walk leisurely there)

Stunning Bernini sculptures. A fantastic building. Stunning Bernini and a Canova sculptures. The paintings are less impressive. Plan to hire a 4 wheeled bike for 2 with motor and 'cycle' round the park when you are there. Definitely a Top 10 site.

A beautiful experience in a beautiful setting. The Borghese gallery is an artwork in itself - the floors, ceilings and walls are just breathtaking, and you get quite a sore neck staring at the ceiling. Sublime works of art... a few Bernini sculptures, Caravaggio paintings, Rubens.... The setting in the park is lovely, and a welcome relief from the crazy hustle and bustle of the city! A very efficient booking system ensures that there are not too many people in the museum at one time.

Amazing Gallery - Don't Miss This. It is easy to miss this gallery with everything else to see in Rome, but this was perhaps my favorite part of my visit - the Bernini Sculptures still haunt my dreams and the opulence of the palazzo with stay with you for a long time - it's only two hours and easily accessible - don't miss out
Book early!. Worth the hassle to see this fantastic collection of some of the best art from100AD through the 17th century,

Best Small Museum in Europe!. This small museum is incredibly rich in artwork. Bernini's Apollo & Daphne, David, and Pluto & Proserpina could easily be the main attractions at three separate museums, and here they are in one building! And Canova's Venus (starring Pauline Bonaparte) sits upon a marble cushion that must be cloth; what genius!This along with classical sculpture (Artemus is one of the only extant Helenistic scultpures), Roman mosaics lifted from an ancient villa, and paintings by Corregio, Titian, Raphael, Rubens and Caravaggio (one of the largest collections anywhere) make the Galleria Borghese a mandatory destination in Rome.Now the mechanics: you must get a reservation first. The Gallery only allows in a limited number every 2 hours so your schedule must adapt to theirs. It is a long walk through the Villa Borghese Gardens so plan ahead--if you're taking a taxi ask for the Borghese Gallery, not the Borghese Villa. Show up early to stand in line to pay for and get your tickets, then stand in another line to check your bags, purses, cameras (NO PHOTOS!), and backpacks. We found two hours to be plenty of time to see all the sights.Time saving tip: when you first enter go up to the top floor and see the paintings. Give yourself 30 minutes, then come down and start at the first sculpture room--by now most of the crowds will have moved on and you'll be able to follow behind the crowds and enjoy your own private viewing of the scultpures. One and a half hours is plenty of time for the sculptures.

Elegant. We were impressed with the sculptures and elegance of the location. It makes you almost feel like royalty! I recommend travelers make reservations a couple of weeks in advance to make sure they get in since they only allow a certain number of visitors in in schedule blocks.

Don't miss this. Incredible palace. It's been restored recently (after being closed) and the place is beautiful. You only have 2 hours to see everything (with a 30 minute limit in one area). One poster mentioned running up to the second floor to start the tour to avoid the crowd. They would not let us do this so I think the cat is out of the bag on that one. One hint that may save you some time and avoid confusion if you rent the audio guide (recommended). The audio guide assumes the tour starts by entering the main entrance at the top of the stairs. This was closed and entrance is actually through the door under it. The audio guide hasn't caught up with this change and you'll start out in room #3 instead of #1.

All that in such a small place. Got to see this . Recommend guide - dark Rome was excellent. Only 2 hrs inside , could have spent days ! Key pieces of Benini & carrevagio , but so much more. Wouldn't have missedi it book it now !!

Beautiful museum and gardens. Galleria Borghese. Bernini's sculptures are amazing masterpieces and should not be missed. There are also Caravaggio and Raphael, such an excellent collection. Admissions are timed so you know that there is enough space for everyone and that it won't be overcrowded like most attractions/museums in Rome. The gardens are also quite beautiful, it's quite peaceful even at peak season.

The MUST see museum. located in beautiful park (that is an adventure by itself) the Villa Borghese is a MUST see museum.order your ticket by phone and arrive a little early to enjoy the park.be prepared to see some of the most amazing sculptures and painting.if you're in town for more than a day or two, don't add any other major sightseeing because this experience will surely take your breath away.After all the fine art end the day with great coffee and pastries at the cinema café
Lovely villa with fabulous treasures. The scultures and paintings. The audioguide was an essential. The grounds surrounding the villa is beautiful too.
Great contents but watch the queues. Queue to collect online tickets, queue to collect audio guide, queue to leave bags at cloakroom. Good job the museum contents are exceptional
well worth the admission. make sure to get the audio tour, especially if you don't know alot about renassance artthe line ups can be long, so get there well ahead of your reserved time

A homage to Bennini. The visitor numbers are well managed and you have time a space to enjoy some very important works by Bennini, the Rape of Daphne is breathtaking, as well as Carravaggio.The park is wonderful to walk in afterwards
Well worth the trip. Beautiful museum with paintings and incredible sculptures. Appointments are for 2 hour periods, so the number of people is manageable.

This rating is for the gallery, but not for the terrible experience there.. The first thing I want to say is: Be aware that you have to check in your purse or any bag you are carrying. They don't just check the contents. They take the bag and give you a claim check. So, be ready: Take your wallet and eyeglasses out before you get to the counter!! They will give you a little plastic bag to carry them in, but you have to give up your purse or bag. I have seen some comments about purchasing tickets. This was a terrible experience! My sister got in line to purchase tickets for that day, and was told--in a very unfriendly fashion-- that tickets for that entire day were sold out. We were very disappointed, because we were leaving the next day. Just on a whim, my sister suggested that I get on the ticket line myself and try to purchase tickets from the other ticket seller.So, I did. I waited to get the other guy (also having to deal with crazy people pushing, shoving, and cutting in the line) and --lo and behold--I got tickets not only for that day but for the very time that we were there!!! Why? How did this happen? Who knows? I didn't ask the guy; I just paid for the tickets, grateful to be able to get in.So, we then had to get on the bag-check line, which I expected to be security people checking the contents, and I did not expect someone to take my bag .  So I had to quickly get my bag back and pull out my wallet . But in all the confusion, I forgot to pull out my eyeglasses. And, truly, it was unnerving to leave my bag there with my new camera in it. If I had been prepared, it would have been different.The gallery itself and the grounds there are lovely and worth the trip and the aggravation, especially to see the Bernini sculptures. All I can say is--just be prepared for the negative stuff before you can enjoy the amazing art.Another comment: if you take the Metro to the Spagna stop, the signs are NOT CLEAR as to how to get to the actual gallery once you get out of the Metro. You will be near the statue of Goethe, and, if you have a good map, you might be able to figure out where you are. You will eventually find the gallery, of course, but there are no signs until you get to the other side of the park.All in all, it was a lovely park and a lovely gallery, but, as I said, a very negative experience otherwise.
Place to relax. Quite nice place. Art, sculpture and the biggest open park in Rome. For cheldren - zoo. A lot of tourist and far away from metro. Must visit
Beautiful art, sculptures and gardens. The Galleria Borghese and surrounding gardens are beautiful and a must see and provide a few relaxing moments from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Lovely Gallery. A fantastic sight. can sit in the grounds which are beautiful and enjoy an ice cream or beer and watch the world go by. Not the normal sort of place I would go in but I must say it is a must on a visit to Rome. Wonderful rooms just filled with paintings and artifacts that take your breath away

Incredible Art. The Galleria Borghese is worth the visit for a collection of art that is truly beautiful and eclectic for the time period when it was collected. I am so glad that we made the time (and reservation) to see this spectacular gallery.

Must see! Again: must see! (mind the logistics...). The art in this museum needs no endorsement from me. It is simply something you must see.Instead of referring to the art, capable of only understatements, I will refer to the logistics of visiting the place.Book tickets:You must register in advance and order tickets for a certain visit time window. Other wise you probably will not get tickets.Note:1. You will not be allowed to bring camera into the building and you will have to give it to a safe keeping there.2. Arrive before time since your visit is limited to the 2 hours of your reservation and the visitors process before they can go in is about 30 minutes.At the location:When you arrive at the museum, you need to enter a small unmarked entrance for your tickets (see arrow #1 in the attached pictures). Behind this little door a considerable underground activity takes place.Pre visit:You will need to go through 3 lines (impressively inefficient but who cares…).1. Getting your pre-reserved tickets.2. Getting Audio Guides (5 Euro each but worth every cent)3. Deposit your bag in a safe keepingIf you do it line-after-line successively it might take you 30-40 minutes (on September at 11:00am). Therefore it is recommended that your group splits, ideally to 3 teams, to do the 3 lineups in parallel and save a lot of time and frustration.Entering the museum:After standing in the 3 lines proving you are determined to pass al obstacles to get in, a 4th line comes up down there in the basement. The line to get into the museum.Well, the good news is that you can skip this line.Just go out from door #1 (see picture) and climb the steps to the entrance marked with arrow #2. There is no line there.Enter and enjoy!

A bit overwhelming. My husband and I had been in Europe for a month by the time we got to Rome. So, sadly, our senses were a bit overstimulated by the time we got to go through this museum. But still amazing and gorgeous works to behold. When we go again, we'll definitely start in Rome first, and then head south. It's a lot to digest for sure! Still highly recommended.
It was not worth the aggravation. Go to the Vatican and other churches around rome to be overwhelmed. Look at statues around the city such as benini's in Piazzo Navona and save your time and money.
Oldest museum so far. A beutifully located museum, in the garden, collection gathered in mid 1700-th century, excellent pieces giving a picture what was chiq at that time.

Lovely park. We went to go the Galleria but it was not opened, it did not matter the park and grounds are beautiful, lovely lake with terrapins, ducks, geese etc, fabulous park to enjoy a lovely summer days walk in then to have tea in the cafe, a lovely surprise and enjoyable day was had.
Great museum and beautiful gardens. well priced with beautiful gardens. The art collection had a variety of artist and if you visit Rome it ia a must see.

Plenty to see. Great art, and not as busy as the day before when visiting the Vatican and Sistine Chapel which was v crowded and spoilt the enjoyment of the great works of art somewhat. Well out of the cluster of the main historic sites so plan your journey well and allow plenty of time to get there before your allocated time slot if you've pre-bought tickets as we did.

Intimate and enchanting experience. Me and my husband booked tickets for Galleria Borghese a couple of days in advance, which was no problem (note that we were in Rome somewhat after high season). On the day for the visit my husband did not feel so well so I went to Borghese on my own. When I arrived I saw that tickets were sold out for my two-hour slot, i.e. between 17.00-19.00, yet when they opened the doors, the group quickly spread out and it felt like you were on a private show in an abandoned mansion. Some objects are absolutely breathtaking and all are very interesting. I went back to a couple of them again. I really enjoyed the whole excperience as such, which was amongst my top 5 in Rome.

Great art, sculptures that defy the mind. Incredible sculptures, a must see. Was told "if you see one museum in Rome, this is it". Agreed. The ticket line process is a mess and chaotic. Definitely reserve tickets online ahead. they sell out often.

Best museum in rome. This museum has an amazing collection of 6 Caravaggios and 6 or more Berninis. The presentation of the art is in the Borghese's home which is decorated in ornate style with alabaster and marble panel walls, bas reliefs on the walls and stunning ceiling paintings in each room. It houses Bernini's "David" and Carvaggio's "The Taking of Christ," among others. Best of all the museum strictly limits the number of visitors during each 2 hour window. Tours are at 9 am, 1 pm, 3 pm and 5 pm during he week. Check website for schedule. House surrounded by beautiful forest type park and grounds. A true oasis in the city. You must have a confirmed reservation to buy a ticket. It's a hassle, but it is worth every minute and every penny. There is even an antique elevator for use by handicapped people. Staff is very helpful- lovely place all round. Also a very nice museum shop.

Amazing history. You have to make a reservation in advance but well worth the 11euros we paid. we bought the audio guide which you really do need. It was just amazing to think of the work that has gone in to these sculptures

Best small museum in the world!. Home of many masterworks, especially of Baroque period; only downside is that you need reservations and are limited to 2 hours in the museum so you can't really see everything in one visit. You can see everything on audioguided tour, though.

Slightly Disappointing. We had looked forward to visiting this Gallery but with just one or two exceptions found most of the exhibits to be mundane with many lesser known artists represented. Maybe we are less interested in the sculpture and thought the paintings would be more outstanding. We also expected to learn and see more about the Borgias. We Thought the visit to the Villa Farnesina to be better

Such a fine taste of art. The only Museum on Rome required advance reservation. You have 2 hour from the reservation time to walk around and immense yourself in the excellent collection of sculptures and paintings, and wall murals. Take time to read the description and explanation or just enjoy the view. Roma pass worked here (part of the first 2 free tickets). Bernini everywhere.

Good Collection. Make a reservation the day before, maybe you can arrange through your hotel, my friend who lives in Italy helped me get in with my husband. Nice because this museum is not crowded because they go by reservation only, located by Via Veneto inside the Villa Borghese park. I personally like seeing statutes, they have a good amount inside on the first floor and outside the museum as well.
GEM!. Outstanding museum, filled with treasures in an intimate and glorious setting. The Villa Borghese Park is a lovely place to relax before or after your museum tour. Be sure to book reservations!

Beautiful. We had an amazing personal tour guide in the city of Rome! This is one of our favorite locations. The sculptures by Bernini are truly amazing. They are something to see. We like this museum because they have a limit of 200 people that can tour it at a time and for 2 hours. We felt like we could move and didn't feel rushed while admiring the works of art!

Good to visit, but not my favorite. This gallery does have a lot of interesting pieces, and you will find a LOT of Bernini sculptures, however compared to the rest of the sites in Italy (some of which are free), I wasn't as much of a fan. I would recommend other sites above the Borghese.

An Oasis of Art and Calm. The Galleria Borghese collection is superb and the setting couldn't be better in magnificent frescoed or marble-encrusted rooms overlooking the surrounding parklands of the Villa Borghese. Don't miss the Caravaggios, Titian's Sacred and Profane Love and the Bernini sculptures - but that is only a hint of the treasures to be found there. The Bernini sculptures are especially worthwhile since they are best appreciated in the round and Bernini's skill with textures is amazing. Count on a visit of at least two hours. The system of advanced reservations ensures that you don't spend hours in line. One slight critique: the museum could use with a good cafe to rest and refresh yourself.

Must See for Baroque lovers. A mini shrine to Bernini, this personal collection walks you through ancient sculpture, to neo-classicism and then to the majestic baroque; moving, fluttering and eye-dizzying sculptures from the man himself, Bernini. Upstairs is a fine collection of paintings not to be missed either. I started the tour upstairs and saved the downstairs for last (it was less crowded that way) and I saved the best of the collection for last (the Bernini sculptures and the Caravaggio room). Time limit is 2 hours - so use the 90min. audio guide and then spend the last 1/2 hour revisiting your favorite pieces.Have your hotel concierge call and make your reservations the day before. You cannot show up - reservations are required.

Accessible, Uncrowded, No Guilt viewing. As entries to this gallery are timed, it doesn't get overly crowded. It's not obvious what to do when you arrive. Go down stairs, under the steps to exchange your reservation (required) for a ticket and turn in your bags. Then wait for your entry. I would then go straight to the Pinocteca (Painting Gallery) while the crowd dissipates in the main gallery. Spend 30 minutes there, when you come back downstairs, the main marble sculptures are all yours!

Definitely don't miss this one!. This gallery is the home of several of the most famous Bernini sculptures that truly demonstrate how phenomenal this sculptor was. This was my introduction to his work which sent me on an all Rome quest to see more. The art in this museum shows the best of art in the history of Italy. All of this was made even more enjoyable by our guide, Felix, who with his art history background brought out all the details that we may mave overlooked in the works that we saw. It's a 2 hour visit that is far too short. This is a gallery that needs to be visited again and again.

Wonderful. It is incredible that the art here was owned by one family. You are allowed within inches of each piece, not keep several feet away. Get your tickets early, online as it sells out weeks in advance.

Best Museum in Italy!. This museum was memorable! Well worth the hassle of booking ahead, and still waiting in the massive lines to get in and another to get the headset. The headset here was also far superior to any others we encountered, and worth the extra cost. Again, if you can only do one museum, this should be it. Several weeks later I'm still thinking about it!

Heaven!!. What can I say. For an art lover and even friends that visit that aren't into art so much this collection leaves you amazed. It is a superlative in collections. Any visitor to Rome should visit this museum.

We went for Bernini and were blown away!!. We visited Borghese for the Bernini sculptures and were absolutely stunned and blown away by the beauty. You must purchase your tickets in advance, we did so online the day before we visited (this was in slow season). We also arrived a little early, around 10:15am for an 11am showing, and were so glad we did because by 10:30am there was a huge line out the door. This gallery was by far, our favorite in Rome. There are many artists' work featured here but I think Bernini was the highlight for our trip.
A Must see. Great place must see if you like to see a great collection of art.If you do not like to walk the gardens there are golf carts available to tour the area.

Beautiful, but perhaps overrated. The Galleria Borghese is full of beautiful pieces, and is situated in a lovely park..a nice place to spend a day relaxing in the sun. However both my partner and I were left slightly underwhelmed by the whole collection, esp. considering the price of admittance.

One of the loveliest small galleries in the world. This was my second visit to the fabulous Gallery Borghese. The Bernini sculptures are breathtakingly lovely and there are some wonderful Caravaggios too. The layout of the museum and the fact that they limit the number of people allowed in at any one time all enhance the experience. Remember to book online before you go as otherwise you may be turned away.

I'll Never Be The Same. I still can't get over Bernini's talent. His statues are amazing. I don't know how it is humanly possible to do what he did. Photos are not allowed, so you photograph with your eyes. David's pursed lips, folds of fabric, etc. are life-like details that affect how you will view art forever.

Lovely surroundings. The park is lovely and we had a nice day. This is a little out of the way and we did wish we'd spent the day covering other things in Rome, the museum was hard to locate. it was worth a visit.

a must see in rome. if you are faced with a choice of doing just one cultural arty thing in rome (well that's hard) this should be high on your list. it requires planning as you need to book a visit. they let in a fixed amount of people every two hours. this also means no nightmarish cues Uffizi style, and crowd control. still, two hours are such a short time, this risks being an intense, stendhal syndrome inducing experience. you might want to plan two visits :). two hours could be easily spent just ogling at the frescoes. the owner of the place had himself, his family and friends depicted in mythological scenes. so the gallery itself is in fact a mesmerising, megalomaniac work of art. and then there's the collection, the bernini sculptures especially, and a lot more, including some favorite caravaggios. about Bernini, you get to marvel at his sculptures, then fall in love with his self portrait up on the second floor. intense, as i was saying. outside, you have the villa borghese gardens to recover and regroup.

Lovely gallery - highlight of my art sight-seeing. Bernini sculptures were the highlight of my trip to Rome. I went early (9am admission) and used the audioguide in English. Staff was friendly and the art was gorgeous! I enjoyed this more than the Sistine Chapel.

Interesting gallery. Interesting gallery with some beautiful paintings and sculptures. Make sure to order your tickets online before, as there are only a limited number of visitors allowed per hour. If you choose to buy your ticket at the gallery, there's a chance you'll have to wait for several hours or come back another day. The big advantage of this is that inside the museum you can walk around and study the objects in relative quiet surroundings.

A must see in Rome. If you like art, that is! Not too crowded, with timed two hour entries. Beautifully laid out, with a masterpiece in each gallery, it is well worth a visit. If you show up a little past the entrance time, you can miss the initial crowd, say arrive at 1:15 for a 1:00 entrance. You must have reservations, but if it is not high season you can arrive in the gardens, get tickets, and wander about or have lunch until your entrance time.
Great gallery. Tis needs advance reservations and is time constricted, but it is a great smaller gallery. The surrounding park is a ice walk and has other museums and attractions.

Overwhelming!. You have to see this before The Vatican State!, but don't miss it!
A wonderful walk amongst the most spectacular furniture of the old days and beautiful paintings :)
Exellent art. Very impressive. Great Bernini's. Definetly worth the trip! Also, situated in a very quite, secluded area of Rome.

Lovely park, Bernini sculptures were worth the trip. The headset issue is poor since after you have checked everything you then need to leave some ID to get the head sets - not free. The head sets are wrong and send you into the incorrect room. After that it is still confusing and needs more signage. Look at the ceilings.
You'll never forget it!. Oh, just to see the detail and quality of this palace... we also had a picnic lunch in the gardens under a tree by the fountain. I will surely never forget it!

In the middle of Rome?. It's amazing to find this museum tucked away in a park int he middle of such a city as Rome. Even if you don't visit the museum (which is fantastic) just to walk passed the building in this oasis is worth it

Must See. This museum is unique and a must see in Rome. The history of it and the art represented is amazing. Additional the method of entrance, through reservations, allows visitors the ability to view the art without throngs of people which is very rewarding.

Excellent collection in a beautiful location. You must prebook which our hotel did for us. They limit the amount of people in the gallery. This is where they have one of the great sculptures: Apollo and Daphne by Bernini. A marvel not to be missed.

expencive. a ticket costs 11 euro and you only get 2 hours to be inside. although the place is amazing and of great cultural value, i don't think its worth that much. you cannot take pics inside and you cant go in with your bags, and for me it was upsetting.

Book ahead of time!. My husband and I loved the Borghese museo! However, please note that you must book a ticket ahead of time and choose a viewing appointment. This can be done online. Then you should arrive early because your ticket is only good for two hours, and the line will be quite long, so we spent almost an hour in line during our viewing time. The line is so long because so many people try to get in without appointments and then stand there arranging a booking for a future time, and of course arguing their plight. But notwithstanding that hassle, what is inside is unique and worth the inconvenience.

The best.. The best gallery in Rome. Some very special exhibits and a very beautiful building. Do however remember to book online and be preapred to leave all bags in a special depository.The park is glorious with a wonderful atmosphere and plenty of shade on the inevitable hot summer days.
spend the whole day here. you could easily spend the entire day in the park and galleries.it was a fasinating and I wouldn't mind a return visit to see all the bits I missed

Art Lovers Behold!. Beautiful location - a villa housing so many important works of art edged on a wonderful park. Everything is stunning! I respect the Gallery's protocol of having to make a phone call to reserve an entrance. They will give you a time and you have just two hours to waft and stroll two floors. Not to be missed. The Gallery qualifies under the Roma Pass as one of two museums with free entrance. Photos not/not allowed.

See all of the great artists that made Rome. A must for all tourists, a collection of art not found anywhere else in Rome, plus the surrounding gardens and fountains are well kept and beautiful. You can rent a bicycle type car that you can peddle 3 or 4 people to the museum and the other areas of the Borghese grounds. You need to buy tickets ahead of time here as they have special hours. This is an advantage because you a assured a good museum visit.

Bernini at his finest. This is a hidden gem of a gallery with bookings the day before required meant we nearly had the place to ourself and were richly rewarded with incredible Bernini works of art.This was worth the trip to Rome!

Chaotic Admission practice. Beautiful Gallery with superb pieces and stunning rooms but having booked online we had to join a large queue of people some who had booked and others who hadn't. Then there was another queue for bag check. The cafe wasn't operational. Altogether pretty chaotic. People were asking each other if they were in the right queue as the signeage was not at all clear. It could have been a much better experience if the organisation had been better.

maybe the finest museum I ever visited. I know, you can't compare to the Louvre, the Uffizi, Prado, Guggenheim just to name a few. To a great extent: luckily they don't compare. The Borghese houses a relatively small collection. But one holding only the best of the best. So you don't have to find your way across countless rooms with 'very nice stuff' (wearing out your feet, your eyes and your patience) to find those two or three masterpieces. You just walk through the entire two floors and get struck over and over again. Now, you could dislike the entry policy forcing you to book in advance, be there well in advance and stick stricktly to your two-hour slot. But it does have an enormous upside: the rooms are not crowded. You can actually stand in awe for minutes, not being disturbed by a constant stream of other tourists bumping into you.

Wonderful. A beautiful collection of art well worth a visit, blew us away!!We booked our visit on line through the Gallery before our trip & printed off the ticket . There was no waiting around as they only allow a certain number into the Gallery at one time.

Beautiful collection, including statues of Bernini. Galleria Borghese is situated in the park of Villa Borghese. It is a beautiful building and the collection they show is magnificent. Works of Caravaggio, Michelangelo, Bernini.... Apart from that the villa is piece of art itself. Beautiful ceilings, walls, floors...Please note that you have to make a reservation a couple of days before visiting! You have to choose a date and a time! This is obligatory!!
Great. You need to book, and the entrance procedure is tedious, but the collection is wonderful. The Caravaggios are worth the visit alone

Visit visit!. This is a stunning collection in a beautiful setting.Remember to book ahead. There is a limited number of entries for each 2 hour slot. This may seem a pain but means that the people there have made an effort and aren't just ticking off the 'I've visited' box and it isn't uncomfortably over crowded.Loed it.
Better than the Uffizi. In the midst of the Villa Borghese is this wonderful gallery housing some of the best sculptures in the world. Book ahead of time and use the Roma Pass.

Museum is fantastic...the staff were a disgrace. Three different sets of staff members (front desk, bathroom attendant and the ticket collector) were all rude and unhelpful, which spoiled the otherwise very good and interesting museum, set in gorgeous grounds.Think 'Gestapo'...

Sculpture worth tolerating the bizarre experience the gallery was. The gallery is packed full of art and sculpture. You need to reserve a ticket in advance due to the small size of the gallery. The 2nd floor (art) is bizarre - didn't like the atmosphere at all, unhelpful staff, little information, not good. The 1st floor (sculpture) is heavenly. The Bernini marble sculptures are something very special and the Emperors Room a delight. Somehow the gallery is a curious place that lies in an awkward location, but it is worth going to visit.
Beautiful. This Galleria had a stunning range of art and was absolutely beautiful to walk around. Make sure you book your slot in advance. Our hotel booked ours for us. It's so worth visiting!

Galleria Borghese. this attraction was under renovation for 15 years , during peak season you need a reservation but since i travel off season i got right in , easy to ascess by subway , that's how i got there , there are many structures on the vast grounds , the original owner was a nephew of one of the Popes and he had an enending quest for art and it was vast , there are several Bernini sculpters in there featuring Pagan myhths , i loved it
Amazing Art. The art here is amazing, but you need a reservation to see this place. The building that houses the art is breathtaking. This is a must see in Rome!
Do not miss this. Even if you've overloaded on art galleries this is a must-see. Just stick to the first floor and see the magical statues (Berrnini, Cavona) plus the Carravegios.
Don't miss this!. The statues and frescos are breathtaking! And the Borghese Gardens is a beautiful park where you can rent a bike or just walk and enjoy the beautiful landscape.

Breath-taking. Absolutely gorgeous! Hard to believe so much incredible art is in one place! Started with the studios upstairs to ensure enough time for the sculptures. Simply didn't have enough time to see it all. Full of art from ceiling to floors.
We loved the Borghese Villa museum. Make sure to take a guided tour. For an extra 6.5 Euro you will appreciate the visit that much more. Peter was our guide and he was delightful!

Amazing Collection of Art. This museum is a must see in Rome. The Cardinal might not have been the nicest guy at the time, but he sure put together a great collection. Advice: make sure you have a time slot reserved, go early before the crowds arrive and use the audio guides.

A fantastic 2 hours. This museum is the perfect size for a couple of hours. There are three time periods you can gain entrance and the number of visitors is limited so check the website in advance. We arrived at 1115 and purchased tickets for the 11 to 13 visiting period. It was perfect. Spend the $ on the audio tour - it is one of the best we have ever used. With the audio tour this is one of the most interesting attractions in Rome!!

Get an audioguide. An amazing building in itself, one of the worlds first public displays of art, and what art!The audioguide not only educates you on the art but also the logic to the art and how and why it was acquired making the visit all that more enjoyable .

best deal in Rome. This is the best deal in Rome. Unbelievable access to sculpture and paintings in an intimate environment for not a large amount of money.They limit access, however, and only let a certain amount of people in every 2 hours (and consequently, you will only get 2 hours in the Galleria). Therefore, you need to get your tickets on the internet 2-3 weeks before yout trip so you can be sure to get in at the time that is convenient for your travels.Also, definitely get the guided tour they offer, as opposed to the audioguide. It is only 5 more Euros than the audioguide, but you get tons more info. The guide will leave you with about 30 minutes to explore on your own before your time runs out.  If you were really interested in the artwork, you could get an audioguide too; then go back to the pieces you were really interested in and see what the audioguide had to say.
Bernini is wonderful thanks to our guide.. If you go to the Borghese, make sure you get a guide. Ours made us see how much she loved her job. She was great.

Great art but beware of queues and booking requirement. Galleria Borghese in beautiful Borghese park ticks all the Italian art boxes Bernini, early and late Caravaggio. and Titian etc sumptuous ceilings, floors, and Greek and Roman statues. However they only admit people every other hour on the hour. At nine am the day I went earliest admittance was three so book in advance if you are on a time restriction. Because of their admittance policies you get long queues at bag check are and headphone collection and entering. This could be an ordeal for children and those with only a passing interest in art Note restaurant closed in the gallery in august. Staff uniformly sullen. If you can only do one palazzo Galleria do the Doria Pagilli which is a much more relaxed visit and on my visit a lot less crowded

a bit out of the way, but a must-see.. It sits in a very large park area, great for a picnic or long walk. The museum itself is very beautiful. Much the same as most of the other art museums in Italy, but the Bernini statue of Apollo and Daphne alone is enough reason to see it. It is absolutely incredible. You will need reservations at least a few days in advance, because there are very limited numbers that are allowed through each day. Just call them and set it up in advance. Don't bother with all the third-party websites that will book it for you and take more of your money.

Re-book or don't bother!. After walking across most of Rome and getting to Museo Borghese on a Thursady, we were told it was booked out until Friday. Its a gallery for crying out loud. People come and go! Well thats how its done everywhere else. Dont ever assume in Rome. Unfortunate for us as we leave the Friday morning and all I wanted to do is see Caravaggio's work. Just like the rest of Rome, very poor communication. Very very disappointed and make sure you pre-book or, like us you will miss out.

Villa Compliments the artwork perfectly. Not a place for the kids, but really is anywhere in Italy. The Villa compliments all the artwork perfectly. Do not miss this museum on your visit. Dont miss Room 2 for Gian Lorenzo Bernini´s, take on David. The curved stair case up was pure class.

Good for art lovers. It is hard not to be impressed by the creativity and skill of both the building and art. I give the Borghese 4 stars, just to draw attention to the fact that children, even older, world-conscious children, will lose patience and stare at the ceiling after about 15 minutes. There are only so many old portraits youngsters can tolerate, so you have been warned. The museum is in a large park which can get hot in the summer. The Bernini sculpture Apollo and Daphne, in a back corner of the first floor, is a highlight.

Smart museum that could be yours for free. Go for a guided tour (two people min participation) - it costs not much more than an audioguide and is more interactive. If you are disabled according to your countries laws take proof with you and enjoy a great museum for free (as the good old cardinal collected mostly "rejects", find yourself in a room with six Carravagios). Get there as early as possible to avoid the crowds.
Hard not to be awestruck,. while it was a bit too heavy for the kids in our group, the Caravaggios alone made this truly memorable.

What a treat; such a beautiful building, art collection and park.. We reserved tickets several weeks in advance (be certain to do this) and actually entered before our scheduled time.This collection may be one of the under rated treasures of Rome.

A Villa built for the purpose of displaying the art within--simply gorgeous. This may have been my favorite place to view art in all of Rome. The pieces within were commissioned for the villa, and so the art is viewed in its proper place and in perspective. The Bernini sculptures are not to be missed. Best of all, the Galleria is open by reservation only as a means for crowd control. While very busy, one is not overwhelmed by a throng. It is a great place to see great works.
Bellissima. SO many amazing things to see in here, and I don't always love art museums. I would definitely recommend the headsets, and walking through the park afterwards.

DO NOT MISS THIS MUSEUM!. You do not have to be an artist to appreciate fine art. This museum, which is a former residence, is decorated with priceless works of art. The Borghese Family commissioned works for their home from all over the world. These works are all in situ--exactly where and as they have always been. Bernini, Raphael, Caravaggio and Canova are just a few of the more famous artists represented. Be sure to see Bernini's David, Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Prosperpina. Cardinal Borghese certainly succeeded in creating a "theater of the universe."You must buy tickets ahead for a specific entry time into the Borghese. You are limited to two hours, but I have to say I did not see anyone trying to herd out the previous group before letting the next one in, so, although we left at our appointed time, you may be able to meander a bit longer without being noticed! The tickets were about $13 each and were easy to obtain on the Galleria's website. You bring the printouts with you and exchange them for actual tickets at least 30 minutes before your entry time (because they start to give away unclaimed tickets). This ticket exchange area is below the building and was not marked with any type of signt. We walked right past the stairs going down. As you face the Galleria with your back to the park, you should see a staircase going down directly in front of you. This is where you need to go. There is also a bag check, gift shop and restrooms here. After getting your actual tickets, you can rent an audio guide or sign up for an English speaking tour. We decided to take the tour. It was informative, but I have to say that I had the Rick Steves guidebook with me and the comments the guide made were almost verbatim. So if you have the book, you can simply use that. The ground floor rooms basically connect via a circular shape and are also numbered so it is easy to follow and also easy to locate any of the famous pieces if you know the room number it is in. The guided tour is approximately 90 minutes long, leaving you 30 minutes to stroll on your own and revisit some of your favorites.We could have walked here from our hotel (probably about 25 minutes) but decided to take a cab. We were told to make sure we say "Galleria Borghese" and not "Villa Borghese" as they are two different things. We did get dropped in the proper location. Afterwards, we got a bite to eat from one of the food carts in the park and enjoyed just sitting in this little piece of heaven in the center of intense Rome. Then, after a bit of searching, we found that there are signs for the Metro/Spanish Steps. This is really an underground tunnel (with shops, etc--it seemed safe to me) allowing you to walk from the edge of the park and then exit at the Spanish Steps. We used this route to get back to our hotel.This is a "must see" when in Rome!

Fantastic Place. One of my favorite museums. It is fairly small, several rooms, each with a different theme. It is home to many Bernini, including the Rape of Daphne, amongst other masterpieces. You need to reserve your visit ahead of time.

The most well maintained. Have been there many years ago, it was my favorite then and now it still is. It was not only the artifacts that attracted you but also the upkeep of the museum as a whole. Every room was clearly stated in ordered number which made the audioguide particularly useful. Most of all, there was air condition in every room! It did matter when you visited the museum at 38 degree in August! Most of the museum didn't have air condition which made museum visit very difficult even for an art lover like me!

Wonderful for art lovers. My husband and I are not art lovers, but art appreciators. The Borghese gallery is in an amazing building and there is SO much to see. You are only allowed 2 hours in the museum and you must have reservations, so plan ahead. We are glad we saw it, but probably wouldn't go back because we are kind of ' you've seen one statue you've seen them all' people. Some truly amazing works of art and statuary.
Blown Away. This is a superb gallery the Bernini sculptures are unbelievable. We were just blown away by the fluidity of movement sculpted in marble.

Nice Change of Pace in Rome. When my sister suggested visiting the Borghese Gallery during our stay in Rome, I was initially a little skeptical. Tickets have to be purchased well in advance?You are limited to a 2 hour stay?You cannot bring your purse into the museum? I had my doubts, but the visit was well worth dealing with the complications. After spending the day before feeling mobbed at the Vatican Museum, the Borghese Gallery was a breath of fresh air. The art was fabulous and the number of visitors being limited does make for a better experience.We bought tickets for the earliest time of the day because we were looking for a time that had an English speaking guide available. Our guide was very enthusiastic about the art and clearly conveyed her passion to the visitors. It turns out that we did not need to go that early in the morning as there are handheld self-tour devices in all languages that we could have used later in the day.There was a little gift shop / cafe downstairs where we bought some books, cards and water on our way out. There were nice bathrooms, too (something I came to appeciate more during our time in Italy).We took a taxi from our hotel to the gallery (20 minutes) but ended up walking back much of the way before finding a taxi to take us back.

Definitely visit this gallery!!!. Rome as a city is rich with art and architecture and Borghese gallery is the best gem among all of it. You can for sure tell by big crowds of people and long lines. Definitely buy the tickets in advance and don’t bring purse/bag to avoid second line to check it. Start the tour on the second level, to avoid the traffic of the crowd. And definitely rent the audio tour guide. You will love it!
Interesting galleria. I liked this gallery because they don't allow more 360 visitors at a time. Reservations are must. Don't miss seeing Napolean's sister Pauline, a life size sculpture.

Not an Ideal Experience--but Worthwhile Nonetheless. Most of the popular galleries and museums in Rome cope with a major dilemma: how to accommodate huge numbers of guests and offer a worthwhile experience. Officials at the wonderful Galleria Borghese attempt to deal with the problem by limiting the number of people allowed in at any given time. Therefore, it is necessary to book ahead and reserve a two-hour time slot: (9:00-11:00, 11:00-13:00, etc). It is relatively easy to do online at the official website which has a passably good English translation. The entrance fee is 11 Euros. There is an additional 1.50 Euro online fee added to the price of the ticket. Arrive at least 30 minutes before the time you have selected and be prepared for a large number of people in a small space. Leave bags, cameras etc at the hotel. The officials are very strict about making guests check virtually all bags. It's free--but a hassle to drop off and retrieve your belongings. It's a good idea to rent an audio guide. The carefully prepared commentary is helpful. Put simply: there is way too much to see in two hours, so an intelligent guide helps maximize the experience.Like so many other art collectors, both before and after, Cardinal Scipione Borghese, who built the villa, had close connections with the pope and used family wealth and influence to begin to amass a spectacular collection. All the big names are represented--Raphael, Bruegel, Titian, Botticelli, Caravaggio, Rubens--the list is endless. Some magnificent sculpture is to be found, including Bernini's "Apollo and Daphne." With fewer people per square foot than other galleries--the Uffizi in Florence, for example--it is possible to study paintings at leisure. Guests must budget their time, however, since there is a two-hour limit before they must leave! There are guided tour groups to contend with, of course, but they don't seem as irritating as at some other places. Needless-to-say, photos are strictly forbidden. Galleria Borghese is just north of central Rome, so a taxi is the best bet. There is an electric bus (#116) that apparently goes there, but the useless directions from the Tourist Information Office just off Piazza Navona resulted in our taking a taxi out of frustration. About 12 Euros. If you can live with the imposition of a two-hour time limit to see some of the World's great art, the Galleria Borghese is a good way to spend half a day in Rome. The extensive gardens around the gallery are a bonus.

Bernini. Period.. The Borghese is worth a visit just to see the sculptures of Bernini, particularly the Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Persephone, to name just two exquisite Bernini sculptures. It is difficult to describe how delicate and beautiful the leaves of the tree Daphne becomes are. When viewing The Rape of Persephone, make sure you look at how the force of Pluto's hand presses into Persephone's thigh. It is hard to conceive how such a thing can be depicted in marble.Make sure you make a reservation. If you are heading there from the Termini station, take the 910 bus to the Pinciana stop.

Galleria Borghese. This is a must for lovers of art and sculpture, especially the works of Bernini. We were sorry there was no art historian available to take us on a tour but the audio guide was adequate.

Bernini at his staggering best. You don't need to be an art-lover to appreciate the collection of Bernini's staggering sculptures on display at the Borghese. For these alone, and for the odd Carravaggio, the Borghese is a must. And better yet: the Borghese manages the crowds perfectly. You wont feel crowded, rushed or intimidated. A surprisingly intimate experience.

Great trip out. Took the metro out here. Took about 20 mins to walk from station. Lovely walk though through a park. Villa itself was amazing. Art and sculptures were fascinating!! would suggest a trip here.

A true education. I would recommend getting the audioguides. Don't waste time in bringing bags into the museum. I was carrying a small shoulder bag that the security person made me checkin because it was "grosso". I wasted time doing that.Favorite sculptures: Daphne and Apollo by Bernini --- the transformation of Daphne is amazing; Pauline Borghese as Venus --- the overwhelming personality of this lady comes through the sculpture. There were such great paintings that communicated so much.The time is limited so be aware to see both floors. We had the Roma Pass so it covered our entrance fee as well as the bus and metro.

Unforgettable visit to the art. .We were lucky to chose this Galleria. It was late (2 hours before closing time) and we entered easily. Although my first aim was to see some Caravaggios, Bernini sculptures resulted unforgettable! It is not like other European museums: you need to leave bags and cameras outside and visitors are limited to 360 every two hours (so rooms are not very crowdy). In some moments we found ourselves alone in a room surrounded only by amazing masterpieces. Another main topic is the building itself: each room has another huge masterpiece painted in the ceilings

Wonderful art!. You needed to book for a certain time as there are only limited spaces during each tour. There is a choice of either laminated cards for each of the rooms or an audio guide if you are not in a group. Walking to the Villa was also worthwhile!

Really a wonderful museum but BOOK IN ADVANCE. I really loved this gem in the park. For me it is a must see in Rome. Caravaggio was a surprise and you must see a movie about this artist (check Blockbuster) to truly appreciate his creativity. It takes about two hours but you could linger longer if you really explore each and every piece on display. The museum was once a home so it is fun to imagine which room you would have used for your own bedroom. I have visited Rome many times and always had this on my list and finally visited. It is only 7 euro and worth the investment. Then take a stroll in the park and have an espresso to take you on your jouney for the remainder of the day. If you just show up without a reservation chances are it will be sold out for the day or week depending on when you visit so book in advance. Buon viaggio!!!

My favorite museum in Rome. As earlier reviews state, you must book and reserve your tickets and only 2 hours are allotted but it is well worth it. I advise using the audio guides to hear a little bit more about the collection and it's collector. There are laminated cards describing the art in various languages in each room but your language may be in use. Somewhat crowded and hot at times in the smaller rooms but the Apollo and Daphne Bernini sculpture alone will make you forget your surroundings. Do take the extra time to walk the grounds and even stop in at the zoo which is a quick stroll. Although there was a taxi stop, we had to call to get a taxi.

Beautiful Gallery. I thought that I would be most impressed by the Caravaggios, but the Bernini sculptures are surreal. This is a large and outstanding collection. Since the admissions are limited, it never felt crowded or rushed and I was able to go back and admire certain pieces over and over. After leaving the gallery we enjoyed the serene setting of the Villa Borghese, which is a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Great tour. I booked this tour out of blue and just to keep myself busy and I was pleasantly surprised with it. Actually, I think it was the second best tour (after Coliseum/Pantheon tour) I took in Rome and I would recommend it to everyone. Our tour guide was great. After the tour of galleria (that was very nice, by the way), we've took the tour/a walk in the park.
It's beauty will make you cry.. Truly one of our favorite moments was walking through this Galleria. The art is so moving I think my husband almost cried, I did!

Something very special indeed. Organising this visit well in advance is well worth all the effort - Bernini's sculptures simply have to be seen to be believed.If you're not intending to spend the full two hours allotted in the museum you'll probably find the rooms are less crowded, if you com half an hour later. If you pick up the tickets an hour in advance you have 90 minutes to have a stroll round the wonderful park beforehand.If you come by public bus it's worth finding out the name of the nearest bus stop in advance as the villa was not indicated on the route we took. Our stop was in the Via Po and we still had to go round a couple of corners to find the entrance to the park.The route back to the town centre is nearly all downhill.

Best Museum in Rome. Book ticket in advanced! Museum is visited by time slots, each slot allowed for about 250 people only and it is air conditioned! A little off from city centre but we walk from Spanish Steps to here within 20 minutes. No pictures/Videos allowed and all bags must check-in. If you can only visit 1 museum in Rome, this is the one.

Amazing Art Collection. Beautiful building with an amazing art collection - and limited access, so uncrowded (in Rome? In the summer? Yes!). You need to buy tickets online ahead of your visit - the sooner the better - but well worth it.

Fabulous Museum - Galleria Borghese. We only went to this museum because it was a Fodors Choice museum -- none of our friends had mentioned it -- I cannot tell you how much we enjoyed this museum. The collection is in a spectacular villa built for Cardinal Borghese in 1615 - so part of the visit is getting a chance to enjoy this beautiful building. The many Bernini works are breathtaking - especially the statue of Apollo and Daphne -- our family favorite. There are also many fabulous works by Titian, Caravaggio and Raphael. The nice thing is the size -- it is a perfect size -- especially if you have kids. You need to make advance reservations for a two hour time slot so it is not too crowded. We used our Romapass to get in. All four of our children enjoyed this museum --it is not as overwhelming as many, not as crowded and you an get quite close to the art which is nice. It is also located in the Borghese Gardens which is a nice relaxing area apart from the craziness of the rest of Rome.
Wow!. This museum houses some of the most amazing sculptures that I've ever seen. Some of them are so realistic, it seems they'll come to life at any moment. Make sure and make a reservation.

Amazing. An amazing collection of treasures.
