Well worth a visit.
You will need to book your tickets online in advance as they only let in a certain number of people at a time, and during peak times you could miss out.

Try for reservations when English tour is given. This museum was wonderful and deserves to be seen with an equally good guide. Check the museum's website as English tours are only provided several times a day. When we went 2 years ago, our 9:00 tour had the most fabulous guide. She was working on her art-history PhD and as a museum-sponsored guide, the other groups moved out of her way whenever she (and we) approached a piece of art. There were only 4 of us in her group and if I recall correctly, it cost an additional 5 euros each.

Highly Recommend!. This gallery is wonderful... and set in a very expansive garden... so you can spend the afternoon. A wonderful respite in the heat of summer. Be sure to get tickets online ahead of time.
OVERWHELMED. I can not suggest a better selection in the world.almost missed it, this is the top of experiences for me. even if i was left in the Borghese for weeks I wouls still stand in aw.

Great museum. The walk through the Borghese gardens is a great respite from the hustle and bustle of Rome, and visiting the Galleria Borghese at the conclusion of the walk is very much the cherry on top. The Galleria limits the number of people admitted every two hours, so reservations are very much encouraged. We had the Roma Pass, but no reservations, and we were very lucky we were able to get in. The collection is impressive, and everything down to the details on the floors and ceilings is just beautiful. Well worth a visit, and any art lover should definitely visit the Galleria Borghese.

go with one of the art historians. I and my two teenagers visited the Borghese a few days ago and decided to opt for the live tour (6.50 a person) rather than the audio tour (5.00) per person, and were we ever glad we did. Our tour guide was a young woman (sorry, I didn't get her name) who was so excited about the art she was showing us and the stories she was telling us even my 15 year old son was excited. Don't miss this gallery.

A must see gem of Rome!!! Don't miss this spot!. I had a terrific time at the Galleria Borghese and the gorgeous Borghese Gardens! It is a small museum of some of the finest art and it felt so intimate because of how small it was. I believe all museums should have the great crowd limit Borghese has. It was not overly crowded which can diminish the experience of other museums. It is such a beautiful place and a wonderful experience you will not soon forget! Be sure to book tickets in advance because you do not want to miss out on visiting this wonderful gem! Also, be sure to stroll the gardens, they are so peaceful and well maintained!

The final word on beauty. One could in fact spend the entire time one has in Rome at the Borghese, and never feel sated!! Wow, this is rather a smallish museum, but what a museum. Some of the greatest museums in the world--Metropolitan in NYC, British Museum, Louvre....etc, have a very hard time comparing to he Borghese... Wow wow

You Must Go!!. Rome=museums and art. This is a must see destination. We had tickets before (you must order them before coming). They also take bags, cameras and umbrellas. Don't worry, it's safe. The Bernini's in this museum leave you speechless. It is not a crowded museum as they limit the amount allowed in. Do some on line research as to the must see art and don't get "fried" by looking at everything. You'll be exhausted, but see the top 25 and enjoy. The Rape of Persephone is breathtaking. In any case, you won't be disappointed.

unique museum. you have to book the tikets a couple of days in advance , you can book the tikets even on the web. the Galleria Borghese is not far away from Via Veneto, I suggest to have a nice walk also to via Veneto.

For all art lovers:-). I've always liked paintings, but Villa Borghese teached me how to appreciate also the sculptures, it's collections are impressive and the surroundings too. Before or after your visit take a stroll through Pincio- the gardens around Villa Borghese. My preferred path starts at Spanish steps and leads through the different terasses with magical panoramas of all Rome till Villa Borghese. To do preferably during the sunset. PS: Don't forget to book your ticket in advance! I'd recommend late hours when the museum is slightely less crowded.

Beautiful small museum. It is easy to get overwhelmed when visiting the sites in Rome. The Galleria Borghese is packed with beautiful art, however, you feel as if you can appreciate the art without being overwhelmed. I took my husband and four teenagers and they all enjoyed it.

Some of the Greatest Sculpture in the World. Gian Lorenzo Bernini's two great masterpieces, Apollo and Daphne and the Rape of Persephone, are worth the price of admission alone. To see delicate laurel leaves carved from solid marble, to see the way that Hades's hand presses into Persephone's thigh, is to see towering achievements of one of the world's great sculptors.The rest of the museum, from ancient Roman frescoes to Italian Renaissance paintings (including a beautiful Raphael), will fill the two hours your ticket will allow you to stay at the museum.Leave plenty of time to explore the gardens of Villa Borghese. They are beautiful, peaceful and (on a hot day like the day of our visit) much cooler than the streets and sidewalks of central Rome.
Marvellous sculptures. What I like best is the possibility of seen so many magnificent sculptors and their masterpieces all together

The BEST museum in Rome. Villa Borghese is simply the best museum in Rome. Small, but every item is a greatest hit. If you are a Bernini fan, don't miss it. We used Rick Steve's mp3 download and felt like we had our own personal guide. A little out of the way, but that's not bad after the crush of tourists at other sites. Make sure you make reservations.

Great museum in a beautiful park.. Loved it- a beautiful villa with a wonderful collection of sculpturesand paintings- heavy on Bernini and Caravaggio. The best part is that they limit entrance, so it's never overcrowded. Make sure to plan ahead and reserve in advance- you can never just walk in.
Must see while in Rome. Book your reservation a day or two in advance. Incredible museum. Make sure you leave time to walk around the gardens.

My favorite gallery!. This fabulous private collection of Cardinal Scipio Borghese is a short course in art history. The best feature is that it showcases the major body of work of Gianlorenzo Bernini. His sculpture comes to life. For a bargain 6 euro, you can go through the Gallery with a guide in your language. The down side is that you are only allowed to be there for 2 hours at a time - understandable since the Gallery is fairly small and very popular. Many masterpieces packed into a comparatively small building.

Wonderful gallery. They recommend you reserve your tickets in advance. However, if like us you don't, you can go to the museum at the tour times (9, 11, 1, 3, 5) and buy the tickets that people reserved but did not actually use. No photos allowed, and must check ALL bags and purses. After you visit the gallery, take time to tour the extensive park that the gallery is located in.

Finest Sculptures. I have seen too many amazing sculptures in Italy, but what I saw there in Galleria Borghese is really extremely amazing. If you plan to visit it, you have to book ahead by calling them and you can do that from your country. I called them from my country a month before my visit and I told them I would use "Roma Pass Card", simply they made a reservation for me and gave me a number. Make sure to book early because when I arrived there I saw a paper beside the entrance and it was written that "reservation is not possible for 1 week or 2 because it is full". before I visited this place, I had read too many reviews here about the long queues and impolite people working there,but actually when I went there I did not find that, they were polite and there were no long queues. The best thing in Galleria Borghese is that a limited number of people are allowed at a time which makes no crowds inside.

Worth the trip, but book ahead. If you have a few days in Rome it is worth the trek out to the Galleria Borghese. Amazing sculptures and statues, beautiful frescoes, and not jam-packed with tourists like some other galleries. Very unique setting too. Book ahead or you might not get in on the day - we had pre-booked and we wouldn't have got in otherwise.

Apollo and Daphne --> I had no idea. Of all the art that I saw in Italy, of all the paintings, the statues, and the grand churches - none touched me like Apollo and Daphne in the Borghese Gallery. We made reservations online several weeks before our visit to Rome and I was most interested to see Bernini's David - I mean the arrogance of this man - to have seen Michelangelo's David and then to make a David of your own. The confidence to do this , I thought, shows a strong belief in yourself - was it warranted?Well - his David is good. Styled after himself and more Baroque than not, it captures the imagination but did not take my breath away. No, that happened when I entered the room where Apollo was reaching for Daphne. This statue - it cant be made of marble - it is time, it is space, it is movement -- Anyway I kept wandering back to stare again. I left the Galleria Borghese a Bernini fan - not for his David - for his artistry and skill. I guess his ego was justified.
Book a ticket. Must book a ticket ahead as they are often booked far ahead as you only get a two hour slot. An amazing museum - so much to see.

Beautiful. It's fantastic !!!!! But be carefull you have to reserve in advance . The collection its incredile a take the audioguide its very interesting also I suggest after the visit to take a cappuccino at the cafe , bring a lunch and past so time in the park and rent a little bike it's very funny for sure with the galleria and the park you will past a wonderfull day

Beautiful Setting. Being from Canada, it's amazing to view so much beauty in such a lovely "home". This gallery was one of the highlights of our trip. Written sheets assisted with explanations however a guide would have been nice. Cavagio paintings, Belini sculptures that look so "soft" although of course they aren't. So much beauty!

More Bernini!. You'll find Bernini's best most famous works here. You'd be a fool not to go. He is such an amazing artist, a masterpiece worth understanding. He puts such detail in his sculptures, such as where the fingers on the body indented.
Bernini sculptures. The collection of paintings is outstanding BUT... even if you have just 15 minutes... you have to see the two sculptures by Bernini! They are incredible!

Worth the hassle of getting tickets. You need reservations to go to this galleria, but it is worth it! They only let in 360 people in 2 hours blocks then clear it for the next group. Even if not an art afficionado, you can appreciate the greatness of this private collection. Excellent variety of sculpture and paintings. My personal favorite part was looking at the amazing paintings on the ceilings in every room! One more nice touch - being a 2 hour max visit, even the little kids could handle this art museum. Booking tip from out of the country: If you want to get tickets for your upcoming trip to Rome, contact the hotel where you will be staying and ask them to reserve the number you want for the day and time you want. Saves the international phone charges.
Rent the two person bike!. Very pretty park. We rented the two seat bicycle and had a blast. Great way to see all of the gardens. Bike was 10 euro for 1 hr.
statues. personal taste that we didn't like it that much, the art was just not our style. the organization is perfect though.
No tickets to get in by mid-morning. Tried to get in on a Friday morning, but they had already run out of spaces. Was not impressed with the managing of the site.
Amazing collection!. Best collection of sculpture and art we saw in Italy! Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is breathtaking!

Good, even for a non art-loving visitor. Impressive collection of painting and sculptures. I'm not a art aficionado and i don't know much about paintings or sculptures but it was really interesting, a lot more than the Vatican Museum.

Great Art Made Easy. This is one of the best museum experiences I have everr had. You MUST book in advance--and you will be given a precise day and time. The tour takes two hours (following an excellent audio guide that comes with the ticket)--after which your group MUST leave. The Galleria is air conditioned (unlike a lot of other museums); the number in your timed group dmitted is limited (no mobs to negotiate) and the collection of sculpture, paintings, etc. is outstanding. All of this takes place in a beautiful former palazzo. What more could one want?

Summer 2012. We used the audio tour and found it very helpful. We fully enjoyed the sculptures - I wasn't aware that my husband would be so impressed but he couldn't stop talking about it! You do have to make reservations but if you purchase a RomaPass, you don't have to pay in advance (just let them know you have the pass or will be getting the pass) and use the pass for the Borghese Gallery and then the Colosseum, Forum and Palentine Hill as well as take the electric bus 117 from Piazza Popolla to San Giovanni in Laterano (through narrow streets) and 116 electric bus - gives you an overview of the city (RomaPass includes public transportation for 3 days).
Bernini, Bernini, Bernini. The Caravaggios, Rafaels and Bernini sculptures were spectacular. Get the headphones, the tour guides were not the greatest.

Interesting Art work. This is a really nice galleria, it's hard to visit in just two hours. You have to do it with a guide because otherwise you'll send too much time in one room and miss some of the amazing attractions in other rooms.

A gift for the soul!. Only second most visited after the Vatican&Colosseum, here things are easy to see and appreciate, due to the place accessibility, very well set in the Borghese Park next to the hotels quarter, and because paintings and sculptures are so beautiful and easy to understand as well. Just a smart tip: if you have a reservation, just go there 1 hour before, because just half an hour before it's already packed with people and your only two hours allowance might be shortened, so better lose half hour before than being rushed off afterwards.

Don't miss this - prebook your ticket. The Galleria Borghese within the Borghese Villa. Don't expect to walk in during peak tourist times. They STRICTLY limit your visit within a two hour window and they limit the tickets sold. We have always prebooked which requires choosing a time and date but it has been worth it. They completely clear out the Gallary when your two hour time slot is up before letting the next group in. If you don't have a guide the audio guide (which we used on two separate visits) is well worth the 5 euros. This collection is amazing - The Apollo and Daphne marble statue by Bernini is our favortie but there are other Berini works as well as Raphael, Caravaggio and on and on. It is just two levels so it is possible to do the tour in the two hours they give you but you will want to come back like we did.

Come back tommorrow!. A pleasant walk through the Villa Borghese brought us to our intended destination of the Galleria. Very disappointed to find that we could only buy tickets for the following day - despite the fact that there did not seem to be a huge crowd. Then to find that tickets were for a visit for a very short fixed period after which you must leave.

Bernini Rules!!. Not everybody will have ultimate appreciation for this museum and small children most likely won't have a good time here. What I enjoyed the most were a number of sculptures, especially those by Bernini. I developed an appreciation for this artist thanks to the entries of his in this location.

Simple. It took 4 visits to Rome before I was able to enjoy the art at the Borghese. I loved everything about it. The have so many wonderful artists. The Bernini sculptures and Carvaggio paintings make this 2 hour visit worth it.

Full of Art Stuffs. Even for me who are not familiar with art, this place is still amazing. The painting and statues are amazing. One suggestion to go there is to book 1 month before to avoid any queue. If you are an art guys, i can guarantee, 3 hrs will not be enough to see one by one the painting and statue.

Great collection without the crowds. This gallery has a fantastic collection. One major plus is that they limit entry to a certain number of visitors so it's not packed to the brim with tourists. Be sure to get tickets in advance– online seems easiest. One downside is that items aren't labeled clearly if you are a non-Italian speaker and the audio guide is a bit confusing. Read up on the pieces on the website before you go if you can to avoid confusion.

The Best!!. We managed to get an extra day in Rome and managed to get a reservations spot for the Borghese Gallery. What an amazing collection of art and sculptures. This place is a must see!! The Museum is a work of art in itself along with the fantastic collection of Bernini, Caravaggio , Vasari and so many others. we got the audio guide and it definitely enhanced the experience putting everything in context and giving some history on specific pieces. DO NOT MISS!!

Not to be missed, but be sure to make a reservation!. The Borghese Gallery was definitely the highlight of our trip to Rome! But, be sure to make a reservation ahead of time. I made a reservation, but my husband and I got lost...we looked at a map and thought that it was in the Borghese Plaza, but this was not the case. It was actually off the map as it is further away from the city center than we realized. We got to the place 30 minutes late and the guy at the desk was very rude. He said that we were late and he cannot let us in. After I explained the story that we got lost, he told us to come a couple hours later at 5pm and that "maybe" we could be admitted into the museum. We came back to the museum and there was a long line, but made it to the desk by 4:50pm as we did not want to be late again! He told us that it was not 5:00pm yet and that we had to come back in 10 minutes. At this point we were so frustrated and almost left, but we are so glad we didn't! The museum is amazing and I defnitely suggest getting the audio guide!All in all, DO NOT be late for your reservation. Staff was so rude, but it was worth dealing with it just to get into the museum!
Paintings. Awesome artwork and sculptures. Truly a collection to see. Very interesting.

Stepping into another world. Although a bit out of the way, the Galleria Borghese is well worth the visit. As anyone who has visited Rome well knows, there's fantastic art everywhere. What sets the Galleria apart is the setting. Each room is breathtaking in and of itself and you really get to see the art in the setting for which it was made. Truly a trip into the past. Two tips: first, you have to reserve ahead (which although a bit of a bother is well worth the smaller crowds). Reservations are easily done online or by phone. Second, get the audio guide. It's well worth the 5 euro charge

Art lovers' half-paradise. Both the building (and the huge park) and the art it houses are remarkable. But we shouldn't exaggerate with the ratings: it's neither the Louvre, nor the Guggenheim. My verdict: does it deserve the 8th place on the Tripadvisor list? - No it doesn't. Is it still worth a visit? - You bet!

CAREFUL: they are strict about time slots!. i visited galleria borghese a couple of weeks ago with two friends after a week filled with art museums. against our better judgment, we decided to walk to the gallery from trastevere in the 100 degree heat. needless to say, it took us longer to get to the museum than we expected, so we were a little late for our 1pm appointment. because the works in the museum are so exposed, they require that you check all your bags at the door. i was carrying a brand new nikon 1, and i was hesitant to hand it to a staffer to place in a room with everyone else's stuff (no personal lockers with keys). i insisted that i wouldn't take any photos, but that i did not feel comfortable giving up my camera, and they gave me a plastic bag to carry it around in... i'd recommend leaving anything valuable at home, and visiting this museum REALLY light in terms of what you bring with you.we knew that the appointment slots were for 2 hours, but one of my friends had visited the museum before, and she said that they let her group stay in the museum for longer than their time frame. following her advice, we started on the top level and took our time enjoying the magnificent work in galleria borghese. we were truly in awe of the works in front of us, and we completely lost track of time. at 2:50, a bell rang to notify everyone that we needed to start filtering out of the museum. we hadn't even seen the first floor! we quickly ran down the stairs to see if we could take a peek really fast, but the doors to the first floor were closed and we weren't able to go through. basically, the museum is amazing, and i highly recommend it, but GET THERE ON TIME and expect to leave when your time slot is over. there was a long line of people waiting to get in for their 3pm appointment as we walked out. i'll have to go back and visit again to see what i missed.

Not to be missed if you love art.. Make your ticket reservations well in advance. If you don't have reservations, then show up 10 minutes before an admission time (every two hours another admission, limited to 200). At that time unclaimed reservations are released. After two hours the gallery is cleared of visitors, so make good use of your time. Here is where you go for sculpture by Bernini, as well as the Canova Pauline Bonaparte. Tip: As people go in, they tend to linger around the sculpture, which one comes to first. Thus the sculpture galleries are crowded early in the 2-hour visiting period. Instead of doing this, go directly to the paintings one floor above. These galleries will be nearly empty while everyone is crowded around the Canova and Bernini, then after seeing the paintings, go down to the sculpture rooms which will be rather empty of visitors. Don't linger much in front of anything, though you will want to. Two hours is not enough, in my opinion, for this place. You will want to go back.

Excellent!. Absolutely adored this museum visit! Although booking in advance may put people off it's as simple as a 2 min phone call that we made just 2days before. We opted for the 5pm visit as I'd heard it was less busy and it was. We paid â¬5 for the audio guide and felt it was worth it(altho we prob could have shared as we moved through the museum together) with our Roma pass the admission was â¬7 each- well worth it's price! An experience not to be missed!
Bernini marbles are fabulous. The marble statues by Bernini are amazing. It is a bit annoying to have to reserve your visit ahead of time, though.

Priceless. We've all seen the commercials where they put a value on something or another only to find some experience as priceless. This museum warrants that kind of recognition. The sculptures by Bernini and Canova are breathtaking and need to be seen in person to truly appreciate the genius of these artists. The museum is in the middle of the most wonderful park in Rome. We rented this fun electric assisted bicycle for two to see the park and it was a great way to get around for not a lot of money. Please be sure to make reservations for this amazing museum as they are very strict about their admittance policy of only 360 visitors at a time in the downstairs rooms. You are also limited to a total of 2 hours to spend in the museum. Get the audio guide!

Unbelievable. Almost overwhelming the art is so incredible. You can take the bus from Popolo but it seemed a little complicated to us so we just took a taxi from the plaza and he dropped us right outside the entrance to the Galleria Borghese grounds.

A must-see but book ahead of time. Make sure to book your tickets ahead. The Galleria is located in the beautiful Villa Borghese Garden. Well worth it to just walk around the park and see the outside, but to go in- make sure you book ahead of time (at least in the height of tourist season). Spectacular works of art are located within and you must see it.

Magnificent!. Crammed full of stunning sculptures and painting by Italian renaissance masters, there's just too much to take in during the 2 hours permitted. You need to book a timed 2 hour slot and as the gallery is very busy in the tourist season you might have to do so in advance. The audio guides (€5 each) are very good and well worth the price. For citizens of the EC who are over 65 entrance is free, though pre-booking a timed slot might incur a €3 administration fee.

Bernini's David is a Masterpiece. We recently visited Rome and when we checked into our accommodation hour hostess stressed the importance of visiting the Galleria Borghese and said that if we wanted to see it during our 6 day stay in Rome we must, and she stressed the 'must', ring and book today. You don't really need to pay for skip the line tickets for this museum as they only admit 360 people in at each 2hour time slot, yes you only get 2 hours in the museum, but this is plenty of time. Just make sure you book on your first day in Rome as the there are only 5 session times. The quietest session if the 5pm one. We booked on line and it was very simple and only cost 12Euro. We also hired the audio guide which was invaluable. This museum houses a variety of Bernini statues, one of which is his David. This is the most remarkable statue and very different to the Michaelangelo David. The museum also has some wonderful Caravaggios and many other beautifulworks of art. The building itself is also worth visit. Definitely a must see when in Rome. After your tour of the museum make sure you stroll through the beaufiful Borghese Gardens, very peaceful and relaxing.

best part was the donut from the cafe.... Borghese is located in a huge park or "garden" as they call it. My family arrived a while before our reservation time (reservations are required for visiting this museum) so we took a fun bike ride through the gardens. The museum itself made me feel gypped. It was only two relatively small floors of art and the reservations for 5 people cost upwards of 60 euros. Borghese had a few famous sculptures and paintings and the rest of it was pretty lame. It took about 45 minutes to cover the whole museum. The highlight of Borghese was the cafe. I bought a donut there and it was HEAVENLY, so I bought a second one. Honestly, THE BEST DONUT EVER!!! I would actually recommend you to visit Borghese just to eat a donut. The donut was fairly priced too. I LOVE BORGHESE...donuts!!!!!

Converted me!. I'm not one for a galleria but wow, it actually made me appreciate art and how can a painting 505 years old be as colourful as a rainbow. Some of mosaics were unbelievable and there were ao very odd paints like a dogs head on a human body with wings. It really gets you thinking. No cameras allowed. Book online same price on official website. It was fully booked when i went yesturday. Enjoy it!!
A must see. Definitely a must see for anyone who loves art. the statues and gardens in particular, are incredible. The lines can get a little long, but worth waiting.

Nice Collection, Too Many Rules. This was probably our least favorite museum experience in Rome. They have endless rules, including leaving ALL of your belongings in a coat check area. I still can't believe I gave them my bag containing my wallet, all my money, and about $4K worth of camera & lenses. The staff is crabby and unfriendly. The collection, however, is stunning, especially some of the Bernini sculptures.

Not as impressed as I hoped.. There are a couple of pieces to be seen, but overall the walk up the unending spiral staircase to the third floor was probably not worth it.There are two statues that make you glad you made the investment, but the rest is static. Our ticket was good for a two hour admittance and initially I was worried we wouldn't have enough time. Two hours was plenty.
wonderful art in beautiful setting. Despite prebooked time to visit, we had to wait in a long line to pick up the actual tickets -- this is true throughout Italy. But the experience was worth it.

A stunning museum with exquisite masterpieces. I had read that this is one of the most beautiful museums in the world, housed in the former Villa Borghese Pinciana that was built in the early 1600’s, so decided that I had to go on this 2nd trip to Rome to do something different this time around. Warning, you must really plan ahead and reserve in advance online in order not to miss out. Reservations are by two-hour blocks so choose wisely and give yourself plenty of time to get there especially if you take the metro. The Villa Borghese Park is huge and it is a good hike to get to the Galleria through the park, about 20-30 minutes, plus you need to arrive 30 minutes ahead of the time block you have reserved. If you are in a hurry, or do not want to walk up from the metro, then it is advisable to take a taxi. However, the park is lovely and does deserve some time spent there. Once inside the Galleria you must turn over everything to the obligatory baggage check, including phones, cameras and small purses. Just don’t forget to pull out your ID and some cash first, so that you can rent the audio guide (highly recommended to get the most out of the visit) or buy a snack at the snack bar while you wait for your time block to start. It seems that most people start on the lower level, so I advise starting at the first floor where all of the paintings are. It will be quiet and you’ll feel like you almost have the place to yourself. Then once everyone starts coming upstairs you’ll go down and do the lower level and feel like you have the place almost to yourself. I actually found myself alone a few times in some of the rooms, which was a great experience. I appreciate all art and while I enjoyed the paintings upstairs I absolutely loved the marble sculptures and the rooms downstairs more. The whole place is absolutely breathtaking, so ornate and with so many details to admire. I couldn’t take my eyes off of Bernini’s Apollo and Daphne sculpture, which is truly exquisite. Canova’s Pauline Bonaparte as Venus Victrix marble sculpture was another stunning piece that I couldn’t keep my eyes off of. I was a bit worried that 2 hours would not be enough time here but I had time to go back and see favorite sculptures a few times and didn’t feel rushed. If there is one frustrating thing, it is that no photos are allowed inside to immortalize your visit. A small consolation is to buy a book or some postcards at the small bookshop on your way out.
Wonderful Sight to Stumble Upon. I was looking for this, but I stumbled upon it & glad that I did. It's beautiful, and a wonderful place to watch the sun go down.

a different sort of museum. we loved how each room on the ground floor was organized around particular roman deities. the two-hour time limit was exactly right for us. some of the sculptures were really incredible -- our favorite was a bernini's "apollo and daphne". magnificent.
for art lovers. I was so exited that I had tears in my eyes. Lovely collection! take guided tour from the galleria it make the tour even better!!! buy tickts in advance from internet!!!
Small Museum with Amazing sculptures. Probably my favourite museum in Rome. Amazing Bernini sculptures. Be sure to book ahead as walk ins are seldom allowed. The cafeteria is overcrowded

lots of art. wonderful place. wish there had been more information on the artworks.
we paid for the audioguides. but there was only info on main
pieces. would have liked information on more pieces.
would be wonderful for art geeks or if you paid for a private guide.

Wonderfull museum. Must be see: Apolon and Dafne - Bernini, Abduction of Persephone - Bernini, David - Bernini, Grains with a snake- Caravaggio, Entombment - Rafael, and so many others beautiful works of art.
Very good collection of classical antiquities. Used Roma pass and booked the slots in advance. Take an audio guide. Need to arrive 10 mins early to collect the tickets.
Great Museum. A beautiful museum with so lots of exhibitions and a great park.

Galleria Borhese. Good selection of art in grand Italian Villa. Not sure how this was compatible with being a man of the church in th way the collection came together, but the legacy is a fine collection of art. Get the audio-guide to wear to get the most out of it.

Don't miss it.. You only get two hours here and it's worth it. We actually only spent about an hour wandering through - might have been more if we'd had an audio tour. The sculptures are magical, and all of the art is not to be missed.

Amazing Must See. The artwork and sculpture are outstanding. The sculpture of Pluto and Proserpine will take your breath away. This site is an absolute must see and a walk around the grounds is worth the time. Allow plenty of time.
Best Private Collection of Art Anywhere. We spent 5 days in Rome 10 years ago. The first thing I wanted to see on this trip was the Galleria Borghese. I especially like Bernini's sculptures.

An Amazing Collection!. As others have mentioned you must make a reservation for this museum but can do so via the internet or have your hotel do it for you. It does book up quickly so don't wait till the last minute. They do not allow anything inside - no purses, jackets, cameras, etc. While not an art expert I found the audio tour and the art work marvelous! It was well worth the 5 Euro for the audio handset - the stories about the art were wonderful and added to the experience. You get 2 hours inside and for us. I would say of all the museums we visited in Italy (and we saw MANY) this was by far the best.
Great walk in the park. Very peaceful park!lots of trees right in the city,great little food stands and not far from the westin

Excellent sculptors & paintings. It is a gem in Rome. Do not forget to include it in your trip. The sculptors and the paintings are too good. This was our second best place we liked after the Vatican. Do the early morning trip which will have less crowds.

Museumed out? Go to the Borghese!. I do a lot of traveling - and wind up going to a lot of museums (because they are "must see"). That said, I wasn't too eager to go to the Borghese, but everyone I spoke with told me NOT to miss it. I am so glad I listened - this is a gorgeous "museum" unlike any other. Bellini's work fills the mansion and drops your jaw. Amazing. Beautiful. And best of all - thanks to the reservation system its not crowded!!

Captivating marble sculptures by Lorenzo Bernini. This is one of the few places in Rome that can be visited only by appointment. It has Cardinal Borghese's art collection. I was captivated by the famous Italian artist Bernini's master pieces David, Apollo and Daphne, etc, as well as the sumptuous decor of the villa. All 18th century's art decor techniques were used in this villa. Yellow marble was also used in the decor. Many other famous Italian artists' artifacts are among the collection.Tips: buy Roma pass, and call the Gallery's reservation line to set up your visiting appointment.

Excellent Gallery. The Upper floor has the picture gallery with paintings by Rubens, Caravaggio, Bernini and many more painters. The art work on the ceilings in the rooms are magnificent.Lower floor full of marble sculptures which are quite incredible, well worth a visit.Entrance is by pre booking only.
Hard to find but well worth it.. I adored this museum, mainly for the first floor of sculptures, especially Bernini's depiction of Apollo and Dafne. My favorite museum in Rome.

Ok but not sure worth the money. It was ok but at 11 Euros each I am not sure would go around it again. If you do I would definately recommend the audio so you have more idea about the artwork as there is not much information otherwise

A great treasure of Rome. The Galleria is an excellent place to visit, the art work and ceilings are superb. Be careful to read the ticket times when you purchase, our ticket ran from 11.00am to 1.00pm but we entered at 11.25am so only had 1.5hrs for the tour, so check times when you buy tickets.

Make sure you book your tickets!. Cool gallery with amazing sculptures. It is worth the 5euros for an audio tour which tells the story of the sculptures and rooms as well as some painting highlights. Really enjoyed the sculptures, the paintings were good too. The gardens outside are quite quiet and peaceful to walk around in.

Amazing! Best statues in Rome. Loved all of Bernini's works in the museum. You need to make a reservation ahead of time to visit (especially during the summer). Apart from the Sistine Chapel, I enjoyed this museum MUCH more than the Vatican Museum.

Most incredible museum experience. Because the Galleria Borghese requires a reservation and limits each visitor to two hours, one can enjoy the museum in a way one can't most others. To be able to take the time to really enjoy each piece of art without large crowds is a treat indeed. Not only is the Galleria the home to some of the most amazing Bernini sculptures and paintings by Titian, it is set in a beautiful park. Be aware that you are required to check all of your belongings, including purses, cameras and phones, before entering the Galleria. Although we had no problems, it did make me a little nervous, and I might have brought less with me that day had I known that in advance.

F-a-n-t-a-s-t-i-c!. Galleria Borghese is a must-go place! Make the booking days after to avoid lines and overbooking and enoy not only the amazing arts of the genius, but the ride to the gallery: it´s inside Villa Borghese, an amazing garden inside the busy Rome!
Rent a bicycle. We rented bikes in the park. Explored a bunch. got some exercise. Perfect!

Not to be missed!. If you have to skip something in Rome, don't let it be the Borghese. Great website for ticketing, astonishing Bernini's you won't see anywhere else, and beautiful grounds to wander when you've finished with the art........oh, and a great gift shop too!
An art lover's delight-The Borghese Gallery. Absolutely loved this gallery! A must see for any art lover. Be sure to book your tickets in advance.

excellent. would recommend pre booking on line before travelling as only so many people are allowed in at one time. Used audio guides there which were well worth the money. Beautiful sculptures and pictures. Well worth a visit.

A hidden gem. A visit to Galleria Borghese is a must. Make sure you pebook online and have some time to wanter through the gardens. The audio tour is worht it but make sure you know which floor you are on It can be very confusing.

Borghese Gallery always a winner!. Be sure you plan ahead and reserve your date and time...reservations only at this museum keep the number of visitors strictly limited. Use the Romapass for this visit. You can take public bus #910 from the bus station next to the train station directly to the entrance of the Villa grounds. They require all bags, cameras, etc. to be checked...nice to know this ahead of time. The museum itself is two floors of paintings and sculptures, which you have 2 hours to explore. There is a nice gift shop and snack bar as well. The little tourist train around the grounds is a fun way to see how huge this public park is, and what else is there to visit if you have time. Go for the art, stay for a relaxing time away from the clamor of the city below.

Don't miss it and reserve your entrance time!. This coming from a family with teens who are not art lovers, we truly enjoyed this gallery! Give yourself time to get here, as it is further away than you think. Book a reservation time a few weeks ahead on line and arrive 30 minutes ahead of time. We had the 9 am time and even in the busy crowds of summer, it was not crowded in the morning. The audio tour was inexpensive and well worth the money. They limit the amount of people allowed in for the two hour time slot. The Bernini sculptures were amazing and we wish we would have had more than the two hours which says something . They promptly shuffle you out when the two hours are up, so don't arrive late.
Do not miss it!. Another wonderful "must see" places in Rome. Be sure to take your time ...... the paintings are simply amazing!

Beautiful grounds. The best part of the galleria Borghese is the grounds surrounding it. There are some great pieces of sculpture here, but if you are already museumed out, then it is hard to appreciate it. There are a lot of religious works in the building. It is worth it to go walk around among the trees and see the garden at the Villa. **NOTE: you need to make your reservation online ahead of time so that you can be sure to get in at the right time. Everyone explores downstairs first, so you might want to go upstairs first, and then go down so that you miss the crowds. I wouldn't say that you need to rent the audio guide.

Priceless art. We had a guide, Margerite (sp?) from Viator who did an excellent job presenting the most important works. I saw everything I expected to. You must book way in advance (we booked in March for a June visit and only 1 time remained of the 5 days we were in Rome) and you only get 2 hours in the museum then they kick everyone out and let the next 250 or so people enter.
Special. This place is special. I'm not a serious art lover but I really enjoyed walking through the picture gallery of this beautiful and historic house.

Best gallery in the city-What you need to know.... The Borghese is the best art gallery in the city!OK - what do you need to know. First of all, you MUST call and reserve your appointment time. I would do this a least a week in advance - probably two.Give yourself sufficient time to reach the gallery. It is a little out of the way, and if you are walking and rushing, you will show up a hot sweaty mess. You also should aim to arrive 30 minutes before your appointment time. If you have any bags, it must be checked - again give yourself time to do this. How important is making your appointment time? You only have 2 hours in the gallery. After that everyone is thrown out to make room for the next appointment time. So do not be late. Get the audioguide. It will focus on many of the best pieces in the gallery - usually 1-3 per room. You just punch in the number and listen. At first you may be not sure what room you are in, but just be patient, you will figure it out. As the guide it talking about the room and/or artwork, you can also check out the other pieces in the room.Two hours is the right amount of time. When you are finished, use the bathrooms and check out the gift shop. The gallery is in the park, and if you prepared a lunch you can go find a nice spot on the grass and relax and eat (weather depending of course). Overall - wonderful gallery of paintings and sculpture.Check out this site for a sample of what you can see, but of course seeing the pictures online is nothing like seeing them in person:http://www.galleriaborghese.it/borghese/en/edefault.htmI hope this helps

Bernini, Bernini, Bernini!. Firstly, enjoy the building. The large ground floor reception rooms in particular are just magnificent. Secondly, some of the pictures are great to see. (As any art student will know there are some genuine and iconic old friends here including examples by Caravaggio, Cranach, Titian and Fra Bartolomeo). To my taste though too many are over-cleaned. But save yourself for the sculpture. Yes, there's Canova's beautiful and daring portrait of Paolina Borghese, but the absolute stars of the show are the group of Berninis which are utterly breathtaking. I could have spent hours - unfortunately you only have two hours to see the whole museum - with the stunning depiction of Apollo and Daphne: for the chance of seeing that sculpture alone you have justified the price of your admission.

A lovely gallery. It was worth the walk - a great gallery with some particularly fine sculptures. Book in advance if you can -it will save a long wait as they only let a small number of people in at any one time.

Truly Wonderful Small Museum. This is a treasure of a museum. If you like Bernini and Caravaggio you won't be disappointed. The layout is superb, and the air conditioning and limiting of crowds thru an on-line reservation system make the experience truly wonderful.

Must!. Rome has so much art to offer, but if you have to choose, or just packing in as much as possible you HAVE to see the Borghese! It has a variety of 2D & 3D art work! Out of all the places I went in Italy Borghese had the best audio guide, and it is inexpensive! Please do yourself the favor and get the audio guide! Try to go when it opens so you don't have to fight as much of a crowd!

Amazing. This was truly an amazing experience. Reserve early through the website and get there half an hour before to pick up the tickets. Must do the audio tour, which explains the collection beautifully and provides the truly fascinating story and history.

Astounding Beauty. This gallery set in the lovely Borghese Gardens (Rome's answer to Central Park) was a highlight of our trip. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the price of admission. The best thing is that, because you must have a reservation to enter, only about 300 people are allowed in the gallery at a time. This leaves plenty of room to ponder the genius of the artists represented here. You could walk around the various Berninis to see these magnificent pieces as theyt should be seen - in the round. We hired an English speaking guide for 6 Euros each and it was well worth it.

Breathtaking. Many gorgeous things to see here,but the stand out is the breathtaking sculptures by Bernini. Hard to believe he was working in stone.Book your tickets in advance (before you go) because you cannot get in otherwise. Visits are for 2 hours. This minimizes the crowds and makes for a wonderful visit. Plan to walk around the gardens surrounding the Galleria.Don't miss this spot!!!!

Nice Place. Nice place if you like 15th/16th century art.
Very nice garden area.

Amazing palace, history, and art!. Our family loved this museum! Advanced reservations required, so plan ahead. Lines for getting tickets from voucher and then bag check were a little long. If possible, have one person check bags while other checks in. Highly recommend audio guide-interesting facts and wide variety of topics. Palace is a gem in itself, but the art is beyond belief! The Bernini pieces are incomparable! You are limited to two hours, which was adequate. Cafe-if you wish to stand or take out, pay at cashier first, then bring receipt for items. If you wish to sit down, go in special reserved section. Price is a bit higher, but a nice break. Bit of a walk through the park, so plan accordingly.

Often sold out. Galleria Borghese limits the tickets sold giving each group a couple hours to view the magnificent paintings and sculptures so plan ahead. Cameras and bags are not allowed and must be checked. Ask your hotel concierge to make reservations for you.

Amazing place, but surly staff. It is an amazing space, spoilt in part by a very surly receptionist who acted like he was a Borghese and a cloakroom attendant who was clearly too cool for school. Worth a visit nevertheless.
Great Small Museum!. Don't let the small size fool you, this is probably the best small museum ever, but be certain to book ahead of time because it does sell out.
paintings. worth it just to see the Caravaggio paintings and the walk through the gardens on a warm Spring day is delightful
You need plenty of time. The gardens are beautiful and the views of Rome are fantastic. Make sure you have your camera

Worth it just for the Bernini's. By reservation only, which we made online a few days before and just showed them the confirmation email on my phone. You have a two hour limit to look around, which is just about enough time. The audio tour was 1.5 hours and covers the highlights. This is worth the visit just for the Bernini statues!

Read your tickets. Note, you have a specified amount of time in the museum. If you book 10-1, if you arrive at 11:30 you still have to LEAVE the museum at 1pm. Reservations mandatory but museum is worth it.

A Little Boring. This was probably more of a bad choice on my part versus the quality of the museum. Although I enjoyed the Bernini sculptures, our party of 3 (mid-20s-mid-30s) breezed through here in about 45 minutes and were a bit bored. We probably just don't appreciate art enough.
It's worth the money. The surrounding of Villa Borguese and the Galleria it's absolutely amazing and worth the visit

A must!. I visited this museum while in Rome and didn't even know it existed but thanks to the tour company that organized my travel I was able to experience this amazing Museum. Michelangelo, Borromini sculptures are out of this world. Note that you need a reservation in order to enter so make sure you book in advance!

The best 2nd Best Gallery in rome. You have to book in advance but do it! Because of this there are only 320 peopel in the gallery at a time. You can see and experience the art, unlike the Vatican. A must that I would dearly love to go back to
One of the most beautiful galleries in Rome. Absolutely beautiful, worth every euro. Stunning sculpture and art set in the gorgeous palatial home of Cardinal Borghese.
Bernini, Bernini, Bernini. While the artwork was quite magnificent, it was the statues made by Bernini that blew my mind away. Must see.
What a collection. You really must book well in advance (even before your holiday) as only set times & 350 people per day allowed but oh so worth it
Magnificent. It's difficult choosing which things to see in a city like Rome, but this Museum is a definite must.
My favorite museum so far. Bernini's sculptures are incredible to see in person. I'm not a fan of paintings, but the sculptures alone are worth coming for.

You should make a reservation. You can make a reservation by phone or Internet.
Is filled with visitors from all over the world. I was overwhelmed by the power.
Bernini's sculpture is amazing.I love it.

A must see museum. This museum is in the Borghese Park which in itself is a reason to go - an oasis of calm and green in frenetic Rome. A very doable size - not overwhelming and if you are seeing the Vatican, which you probably are, it is a good complement without adding a second huge museum to your list. Reservations are a must.

One of my favorite museums in the World!. Just visited for my 3rd time and is just as magnificant viewing the Berninis as the very first time. You must go online and purchase tickets in advance. We booked a few days before for the 5:00 and didn't have a problem. This museum is so amazing and the sculptures are like no other in the world!
Tour Cancelled. We had scheduled a night tour....it was cancelled. Very disappointed because we left the next morning at 4:30 am.
The only problem is they limit your time!. You are really on a guided tour of this museum, with very limited time on the top floor. However, the collection is superb and not to be missed.

Bernini Extravaganza. My boyfriend and I went to the Galleria Borghese on the first day our of visit to Rome. Be sure to pre-purchase your tickets! We purchased tickets for the last showing from 5-7 pm. I forgot to read the confirmation that says you must pick your tickets up 30 minutes prior to 5pm or that our reservation would be deleted. Thankfully, they still honored our reservation when we arrived about 5 minutes before 5 pm. We opted to do the audio tour which was great so we actually knew what we were looking at since we were not with a tour. I definitely recommend the audio tour (unless you are already highly versed in art history). This was one of the highlights of our trip.

Gallery gave me special memories. Advance tickets are required and the time limits are real. We had a little trouble finding the gallery by public transportation. Once we walked through the main doors we were in awe of all that we saw. A more quiet place to visit so save it for a day when you need a break. I loved it so much when I got back to the states I bought a book about it since the store was closed when we finished our tour. If I ever get back to Rome I would go here once again.

Terrific. The statues by Bernini such as Apollo and Daphne, Rape of Persephone and David. Great paintings by Caravaggio, Titian and Raphael and a superb setting in the gardens.Note: Entrance to the gallery is strictly by reservation only so you need to book your ticket well ahead of time over the Internet.

Must see the Bernini sculptures here!. The Bernini sculptures are all absolutely amazing. Make sure to get tickets at least one day in advance, they sell out quick. You can do this online. Minus is that you must pick up tickets 1/2 hour before your time slot so the start times are crowded. Worth it though.
Do not miss. One of the most beautiful gallery of Rome do not forget visiting at least 2 times becasue one time is not enough to see all its magnificent stucco roofs, statuary and paints.

Be careful in the gardens!. Our tickets were for a 3:00 admittance and so we decided to have a picnic in the garden. I think of myself as very careful and aware of my surroundings, but we were taken by a gypsy that came up to us waving pamphlets in our faces. In a very brief momentary encounter he stole my daughter's iPhone. Thankfully no one was hurt and a phone can be replaced, but just beware!The Gallery is beautiful and well worth the visit!!!
Advanced tickets and audio guide essential. Beautiful art and because they limit the numbers of people, it is not overcrowded.

Small and Interesting. I like small museums where you can really see well and get close to the art; this is one of those gems. Kudos for the staff to limit visitors in quantity and length of stay; you must be out in 2 hours, which is just right. Good art. Good variety. Very interesting all around. Afterwards, grab a sandwich and eat in the adjacent park.

BOOK AHEAD. WOW - really not to be missed. I would book for a first visit in the morning - and get there a little ahead of time, as you still need to pick up a ticket to get in - and the line can get Very long!

Worth the reservation. Really cool private collection. Lots of amazing Bernini sculptures. Make sure and make reservations early (your hotel should be able to make them for you several weeks in advance). You are limited to 2 hours and we finished our last room at the 2 hour mark so make sure and pace your time correctly. Also, we didn't buy the audio tour, but that is probably worth it. They do have information sheets (in English) in all the rooms with descriptions of the works of art.
Amazing Collection of Art.. We really enjoyed our vist. What a collection. Bernini, Carravaggio and Canova are all worth viewing. Worth the trouble.

Astounding sculpture. The jaw-dropping centerpiece of this great collection is the Bernini sculptures - great and important paintings too, but it is the sculpture that steals the show. Bernini showed the world sculpture it had never seen before - or has seen since!

Classical and renaissance wonders. The Galleria Borghese is to my mind one of the most fantastic museum galleries in existence. It is even on a par with the Uffizi gallery in Florence.Be prepared for a fair bit of nudity in sculpture and painting.The sculptures are on a different floor to the paintings.You have to book a timed slot, and you can only just get around everything with the audio guide in the 2 hours that you get before they throw everybody out for the next slot.If you turn up in person to book a slot (in the downstairs entry), you have the possibility of getting in on a cancellation, as we did.If you get a Roma pass, it is worth visiting as one of your first two free entries, as it is fairly expensive, but worth every Euro.The 116 bus stops near its entry, as does the park train, otherwise be prepared for a long uphill walk.

Beautiful Gallery and Gardens. The Borghese Gallery is within the Villa Borghese gardens and contains the Borghese collection of paintings, sculpture and antiquities, begun by Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the nephew of Pope Paul V (1605–1621). The Villa was built by the architect Flaminio Ponzio from sketches by Scipione Borghese, who used it as a party villa at the edge of Rome. Scipione Borghese was an early patron of Bernini and collector of works by Caravaggio, who is well represented in the collection. Other paintings include Titian's Sacred and Profane Love, Raphael's Entombment of Christ and works by Peter Paul Rubens and Federico Barocci. The Gallery contains many works by Bernini including the famous Apollo and Daphne. I ran 8 to 12 miles per day in the Borghese gardens surrounding the Gallery and met many local Italian runners there.

great classics of Italy. this was my second time to Rome, and i picked to go there again, even though i was there on my first trip..it is simply fabulous!although, the signs to get there are bad or non-existing at all.. we ended up walking in the sun for quite a while, until we took a cab there.. missed 45 minutes of our time slot..

The sculptures of Bernini. One of the most impressive collections of art, we spent 2 hours but it was not enough, Bernini is a genius, he makes marble seem like flesh, the paintings and their stories made it a truly memorable experience, it was definitely the best of all the visits in Rome despite the fact that we loved the Sistine Chapel and the Vatican Museum in general.

The remarkable result of Borghese meeting Bernini. You must book in advance, but the numbers of visitors are thus kept sensible. Time to go round twice. Recap Ovid and the Aeneid first--or buy the postcards and do the reading later. Listen to the guides, but form your own opinions. While in the Borghese Gardens have a look at other items, e.g. Villa Giulia.

A-Mazing ~ Must see!. The sculptures are just incredible. Apollo and Daphne is unbelievable and I could stand there and appreciate it the whole day. Unfortunately you're only allowed inside for 2 hours by appointment only. I will return for sure.
No cameras/photos allowed.

A wonderful museum that's just the right size. If you can leave your backpack, purse and packages at your hotel you can skip the long lines at the 'bag check'. Then you can get right to the pleasure of this museum. It's great to be able to enjoy the beauty of the villa, the paintings, sculptures and furnishings without being overwhelmed. Only the best of the best is here and you can take it all in in just under two hours. With a stop for a restorative espresso or gelato you're ready for more sight-seeing!

Don't miss the Carravaggio collection. 1. You MUST MUST MUST prebook online. We were there quite early in the day and they were turning people away saying they were full.2. It's a bit of a pain to find. If you want to use the sightseeing bus to get you there you're best going on a day when the route takes you nearby. Otherwise, allow plenty of time and bring lots of water because it's a walk uphill and then across a park.

A highlight of our 16 days in Europe. The sculptures are among the most amazing things I have ever seen created by man. They are beautiful and inspiring. It is mind boggling to contemplate the artistic genius and the technical ability of Bernini. This is a place I would visit every time I go to Rome. It is a small museum and therefore not overwhelming at all. The audio tour was excellent and very helpful. We also really enjoyed renting bikes and riding around the park after our tour. It is beautiful and there is a great scenic overlook of the city.
Borghese WOW !!!. Book your tickets on-line before you go. Breathtaking gallery, Well worth a visit beatiful.

A Must!. My husband and I are not real "artsy" types but loved this museum! We made an online reservation before we left home and were so glad that we did. the art and sculpture are AMAZING...make certain to rent the audio tour so that you can appreciate all that you are seeing. The marble artistry on the busts is just incredible!

I'm in heaven. Pre-book is best and go clockwise around as the tours go anti-clockwise. See the BEST of Bernini and Caravaggio. Those sculptures are just so life-like. Also keep looking up! Never seen so many trompe l'oeil on the ceilings.

Must visit in Rome. This gallery is a must visit for any tourist visiting Rome. It was part of my visitor pass package. There are a lot of magnificent artworks and statues to see in many different rooms. Some may be familiar to you, and others not, but they will all amaze you the same. Bernini's David was one of my favorites in the collection. Photography was prohibited but I still took many shots from my camera to preserve the memories. :) Ciao!
A must see Museum. on your next to Rome, because I'm sure the 1st trip you had no more time left, you must skip the Vatican and see this museum. I have been here twice now, and would go again.

Bernini and more Bernini. Don't hesitate to make the reservation and put this museum on your itinerary. You cannot imagination being so close to glorious works of art and if you love Bernini it s a MUST see!

Buy tickets in advance and do not miss your appointment!. We missed our appointment due to a fire at our hotel - and they almost didn't let us in. I had to beg several people for entrance. They are very strict about tickets. It was well worth it though. Many beautiful things to see and make sure you spend some time outdoors.
Villa Borghese Gardens. Excellent cafe in the park - delightful. Lovely lake and walks

excellent gallery!. We visited this place September 2006 and it was one of the highlight of our trip. Don't be sway by the mandatory reservation. It was worth it! We arrived an hour early just to stroll around the garden in the back. The collections were amazing!

Bernini was a genius. The sculptures by Bernini are not to be missed. The attention to detail is amazing. For example, in Pluto and Proserpina, you can see how lifelike it looks where Pluto has his hand on her thigh as she tries to escape his grasp.

must see for art lovers. This is a fabulous private museum. The cost is minimal (compared to what most private collections charge). Make your reservations before you go, just pay on-line. You'll be glad they handle it this way because it assures that the groups going through are small and you can actually see the art. We found the paintings as fascinating as the sculptures (which are fab), and toured the upstairs paintings for the 1st hour, and the downstairs sculptures for the 2nd hour.If you have any physical difficulties, ask about the tiny elevator. It's hard to find, but does exist for people who honestly have conditions that interfere with walking. Also, follow the instructions on your ticket - arrive early as you will have to get checked in, then turn ALL your belongings that don't fit in a pocket into the lockers. You can't even carry a small purse into the galleries.Be prepared to be amazed - what a collection!
Beautiful display of Berninni sculptures. Enjoyed the beautful works of Berninni. This lead to us visiting Piazza Navona to view more of his work and also his burial site in Santa Maria Maggiore.

Wonderful Museum-recommend a visit!. The Galleria Borghese is a wonderful museum. The building itself and all its rooms are worth seeing on their own. Then add the amazing sculptures and paintings and it makes it my favorite museum in Rome! I absolutely recommend adding this to your visit to Rome. I've been twice -once in 2005 on my own and last week with a private guide. I recommend going with a guide if you can as you really learn more about what you are looking at! As others have said there are timed tickets and they really do kick you out after the 2 hours.

Staff was wonderful-loved the art. We had tickets for the 2PM visit. The staff noticed my husband walked with the assistance of a cane and took him to the 2nd floor via a private elevator 10 minutes early. We were alone in the museum for 20 minutes until we saw another visitor! It was great. Hint: start on the second as the crowd typically starts on the 1st floor.

The must-see museum in Rome.. I could have missed the Vatican Museum and just seen Borghese and been quite happy. Reserve well ahead and take your time, there are some spectacular pieces here. Highly recommended.

Well worth a visit. Book tickets in advance because 360 people allowed into the Gallery in 2 hour slots. There is no queque so don't pay extra to beat the queque. Its cheap to enter, hire an audio guide for 5 euro and deposit your bags at reception. They don't allow photos so, you will have to buy the guide but it is an incredibly beautiful collection of sculptures and pictures. Well worth the view
always elegant. Loved the air-conditioning this year. Some of the audioguide needs to be updated.
Breathtaking. Be sure to book in advance - easy on the Internet - and spend two glorious hours in this amazing museum. It should be on the top of everyones list when visiting Rome.
Hands Down the Best in Rome. If you have the time and can get a reservation to go it is a must.

Best of the best.. The building itself is a masterpiece of art in itself. The ceiling frescoes worthy of much time and contemplation.
The gallery containing art work from 1400 to about 1750. Just the Bernini sculptures make it worthwhile. The Carravagio room is worthy of the best museum.
If you are not art savy a guide would be helpful.
Fabulous gardens and Museum. Walk the gardens and have a reservation for museum. You normally can NOT just walk in.

Fantastic sculptures and pictures. This is one of the repeat locations for our second visit to Rome and I would go every time to see the Bernini sculptures and the limit on visitor numbers means no crowding, just book in advance as the tickets sell at least a day ahead at the museum.

A must see museum in Rome. This museum is my favourite in the whole world. Simply stunning and a private collection on show.
You MUST book online first as you have 2 hours only. Visit the park surrounding the museum also as it it lovely too.

Off the tourist track. This gem of a villa is filled with wonderful art from the owners collection. We wish we would have had more time to see all of the grounds. It was just steps away from the old city wall beyond the top of the spanish steps. There is never enough time to take it all in!

AWESOME!! Totally worth it!. We did not make reservations before we left for Italy, but on our first day there we went straight to the museum and were told we could make reservations for the next day. (This was the first week of June, July travelers may have to be more cautious as it may fill up more easily). We went on recommendation from our friends and really had our doubts before we got in, especially since it's about 12 euros a ticket. It was one of our favorite places in Rome, we are really glad we went! It was neat because the rooms are organized very well and each room is an artwork, really. The ceilings, sculptures, and paintings in every room are pretty much themed. There are some laminated guide papers in each room to give you a little history of the artwork--we were fine without an official guide, all of it was fascinating. My husband usually isn't into artwork and was very enthusiastic about Bernini! We are SO glad we went. If you go, you'll probably be glad you did too and will not regret it. Word of caution: you have a 2 hour time limit (they let you in at your reservation time, and kick you out promptly 2 hours later). It came fast for my husband and me, we really ahd to pace ourselves in the rooms and be strategic to avoid large tour groups and crowds. But it was amazing!

Great private sculpture museum in Rome. a great optional museum when you visit Roma. This famous museum or gallery is a well worth visit, though, a bit hassle to get ticket. You must book/buy in advance, otherwise, chances are you won't be able to get in or must wait a long queue.most sculptures are very beautiful, pretty old and antique. many works of famous artists that you would not want to miss.expect 1.5-2 hours for a trip to this gallery, a bit walk from train station.

Great musuem for your first day in Roma!. We were new to Bernini and so we were fortunate to have a great tour guide (Lauren from Context Travel) who was able to tell us the stories behind both the Borgheses and the wonderful sculptures of Gian Lorenzo Bernini, one of our new favorites. The museum is relatively small and so I would recommended this to other jet lagged travelers for their first day. Our tour lasted two hours and while that wasn't enough time to cover everything in the museum we covered all of the essentials and spent plenty of time looking at the masterpieces of Bernini and Carpaccio

Didn't Fail to impress. I particularly wanted to see Bernini's David plus his Apollo and Daphne sculptures. They didn't fail...even hubby was impressed !! However, there is so much to see so there will be something for everyone. Plus it's in a lovely park setting and we had a lovely afternoon in the park and Galleria Borghese
Advance planning needed. Be aware that you need to book in advance for this museum, you can't just turn up on the day. We couldn't get in because of this.
MAGNIFICENT SCULPTURES. A must to see even if this art is not to your liking .So life like ,so expressive one can really understand what was behind each "creation" .
Incredible Gallery. Loved the artwork, artifacts and sculptures throughout the gallery and area are simply magnificant. Well worth the visit and admission into the gallery

Only must-see museum of Rome. THis was the home of cardinal Scipione Borghese, the greatest art collector of his time and the collection was greatly enlarged by his acquisitions and has been added to down the years. THis jewel of a museum is the only must -see museum of Rome and can be done even if you've only got one day in the city, but you must book online at least three days ahead, much earlier than that for peak season between April and October. Takes 2 hrs to see, (they push you after that, to bring in more people), arrive at least a half hour before your ticket time in order to pay your reservations and leave your bags and packs and coats , cameras, too, at the wardrobe. Two floors of marbles, bronzes , paintings and mosaics, the best representative of Italian art there is, followed by the Capitoline Museum collection, which also has many, many Roman statues and 2.000 yrs of Italic art. Stop afterwards in the Villa Borghese city park, the best city park of Rome, you can cross the park over to Via Veneto or to the PIazzale delle Belle Arti, where the Modern Art Museum is.

Amazing collection. We did this tour with "Dark Rome" and the guide, Rebecca, was truly outstanding. I don't know how someone can know so much, and be able to impart it to the tour group. The paintings and sculptures are really awesome, and the whole experience breathtaking, highly recommended
Great Collection. If you like sculpture the Galleria has to be included during your trip to Rome...just go and enjoy.

Beautiful Borghese. This was absolutely gorgeous! You must be sure to make reservations as you are only allowed two hours. The grounds and the park are worth spending a day enjoying... simply beautiful!!!

Fantastic!!!. We found the gallery by accident whilst taking a Sunday morning stroll in the Villa Borghese park.We saw more world class painting and sculpture in the two hours we were there than in any other two hours spent in a gallery or museum ever.Entrance is by ticket only, available in the basement, ladies no handbags, everything is checked into secure storage.Must be done whenvisiting Rome.

WOW. To think I was debating whether to go or not.....thank god I made the right choice!Booked tickets online about one month in advance, took bus 910 from Termini which stops close by, everything works fine. And the actual meseum is awesome, also nice and quiet as only 200 ppl are allowed in for every 2 hours.Apollo and Daphne is def my favourite here, if you like Bernini, this is a must go. There are also a number of paintings by Caravaggio.

It was a bit of a trek to get to.. The grounds were lovely and calming, but a trek to get to. You have to book in advance and there are set times which they are strict with. Yo must get here half an hour before your booking, which for me was 9am, so I got there at 8:30am. It was quite a way uphill too, and I walked. The staff were not that friendly or helpful and were unwilling to speak to you if you spoke English. I found it rather unfriendly and an awkward atmosphere. I wouldn't go again.
Incredible sculpture and art.. A definite must for the serious art lover. You need reservations in advance. Takes about an hour to see. A top ten destination.

Bernini is a genius!. The Galleria Borghese's mandatory reservation policy made our visit so much more worthwhile than our visit to the Vatican Museum. Where the Borghese was quiet and peaceful, the Vatican was crowded and noisy. There were no pushy tourists and the garden was a pleasant area to wait. Bernini's statues of Apollo and Daphne are amazing to view. Bernini's David is also perpetually in motion. The expression on his face in undeniable.

Magnificent works of art!. This is a wonderful villa located in the Borghese park. The artwork and sculptures were magnificent to see in this stately mansion. Be sure to book reservations in advance of your visit so that you're not disappointed. It is unlikely that you'll get tickets if you just walk up. Save time for a walk through the park after/before your visit to the gallery.

Borghese. The must do stopin Rome for the art collection completeness and significance, Restoration of building is also very well done. All in all, Borghese is worth at least ten visits as well as extensive preparation for any scholar of its art collection. Fascinating.

Statute of Pauline Bonaparte is stunning. We visited last year whilst on a family holiday in Rome with our 3 children. You need to book in advance and you have a 2 hour time slot. The park is much bigger than it looks on the map and it’s quite a walk to the Gallery. We arrived just in time for our 1pm slot. We hired audio guides , which are very clear and made our way through the various rooms. The highlight for me, as for many others is undoubtedly Canova’s statute of Pauline Bonaparte as Venus, this is absolutely stunning. The museum is packed full of statues and pictures, it is all very well displayed and it is amazing that so much art is in one relatively small place.The fact that you have to book in advance means that it does not get too crowded. It is also very easy to navigate round.We had a quick bite to eat in the café and then headed into the park. We hired a 5 seater bike and we had fun riding through the park for an hour or so. It was a welcome break from all the culture of the last few days and we had great views over the City.

Small gallery, but every cm of it looks wonderful :-). It is a small gallery, but every cm of it looks wonderful :-). Everything is great there: the walls, the furniture, the painting, the scultures. Famous scultures of Barberini is there. The take of photos is forbidden and impossible there, so that you will enjoy the beauty with all your senses :-). See the website: http://www.galleriaborghese.it/default-en.htm

Must go - but remember to book ahead. This is a relatively small gallery, housing numerous treasures of art in a palace. If you are in Rome, you simply must go - but remember to book ahead - as you cannot buy tickets at the door, and numbers of people in the gallery at any time are limited.
Not to be missed. Skip the vatican and visit Galleria Borghese. Buy tickets in advance and enjoy. Probably the only place in the world to see 6 Caravaggios hanging in 1 room!

Buy your ticket online before your trip to avoid being closed out.. This was my second favorite museum in Rome (my favorite was the Museo Nacionale degli Strumenti Musicali). When we got there they were taking reservations for two days later. Luckily, I had purchased my tickets online at tickitaly.com before leaving the U.S., so we went right in at the appointed hour. Fantastic collection of art! By the way, don't buy too many tickets online, they really aren't needed for things like bus tours. I only bought them for the Borghese and the Colosseum. You can't get them for the Vatican, unfortunately, so count on two or three hours in line if it's not busy.
can't get enough of it. I could go back every week and never get enough of the wonderful Bernini statues

Breathtaking!!. Simply amazing experience...A must do in Rome....Book your tickets in advance because it's usually fully booked for days. The only minus is that you are allowed to spend only 2 hours in this one of Europe's best galleries...
Enjoyable museum. After visiting many museums across Italy, this was one of our favorites.
Must See!. Do not leave Rome without seeing the Galleria Borghese. Reservations are required.

A must for the art lover. this was certainly one of the highlights of my trip. The collection is pretty extensive containing numerous paintings and sculpture from the greats including Bernini and Caravaggio.Bernini's David is a masterpiece. In a lot of was it was more awe inspiring than michealngelo's.Another favorite of mine was Caravaggio's painting of david with the decapitated goliath being a portrait of himself.The audioguide was helpful and enhanced the experience.Overall this was indeed a wonderful experience and I highly recommended a visit here.
Lonely Planet was right. We stayed in the Hilton Garden Inn Rome Clarige so this was a walk away. Get the audio tour and enjoy.

Breathtaking Elegance. if you do nothing else (and like art) do not miss the chance to visit the superb gallery in a classical villa. Many works you will know are here but seeing them arranged is separate rooms, all wonderfully decorated, is absolutely remarkable.
Interesting. Was interesting and if this is the sort of thing you are in to, then no doubt you will enjoy it. Was a bit samey for me.

Book well in advance!. This place was absolsutely spectacular. Make sure you book in advance days before you go. Get an audio guide for 5 Euro as its well worth it. The art collection is magnificent, and although I feel the 2 hours is barely enough time to see everything, I think it is just enough time to ensure that there is no feelings of being unable to see things due to too many people being in there. The stafff were all really helpful, only down side is that no photos are allowed :-(Outside the grounds are beautiful and there is a little train that takes you on a tour of the grounds for 3 euro. We had difficulty finding this place though.....when asked we were given the wrong directions, and even policemen did not seem to understand what or where the Galleria Borghese was!!!!!!! I would definately recommend you go see it, the collection is awesome.

You must get your tickets weeks in advance !!!!. This museum sells out there will be no tickets to buy if you wait utill you are in Rome !
