And this museum is the very best art museum in Rome for paintings,sculptur and furnature.as well as achetecture. No need to buy books or art in the gift shop amazon.com has it all for great prices and art.com has large posters of the art too. Get the book Bernini by Howard Hibbard it is a $14 book I got it used for $5 Every room of this palace was built to display the art you see the ceilings ,floors,tables ,are works of art that hold the paintings and sculpture. I wish I could visit this museum often

Come for the museum. Stay for the grounds.. This multi-story warehouse of late Renaissance and Baroque art and sculpture overloaded our senses after three rooms. We saw enough angels, saints, gods, madonnas and flesh to last a lifetime. Monumental in scope, but overwhelmingly forgetful in content, except for two or three items. However, a walk around the extensive grounds, including a delightful cafe located deep in the garden, made the trip memorable.
Wonderful place. Perfect collection of sculpture and painting. Book your ticket at advance at the site of museum.
a villa filled with TOP art. we had the chance to visit the villa with an expert in the rome art and we got for each peace of art the full history.

Beautiful. You really only get to be within the Museum for 2 hours - it is plenty of time to view the collection. The pieces are beautiful and be sure to walk around and check out the gardens as they are wonderful.

Loved it!. This is a must see. We did not take a tour but used their audio tour (5 euro) It was very good and the way they have the entrance for tours at 2 hour slots made it feel less packed with people (unlike the Vatican tour) I could have gone back 3 or 4 times and not taken in everything.If you are not in a tour, you need to go online to get tickets early. When we were there on the 20th, they were sold out to walk ups until May 23rd.

If you want a time travell, go there.. All your estetic sensors will enjoy in the most beautiful time travell throught Caravaggio's and Bernini's world, and a lot of other great artist.Rape of the Proserpine is the great.

A Museum Not to be Missed. Be sure to purchase tickets separately. I did ours before we left by a phone call to Rome (expensive but worth it), They give you a reference nunber that you use to pick up your tickets. You are only allowed in the Gallery for two hours. I recommend the audio tour because I always am fascinated by the history of each piece. Take time to enoy the Gardens either before or after your visit, they are beautiful.
My favorie museum in rome. The sculpture in this museum is amazing and the museum is a good size for easy viewing. They only let so many people in at a time so it is not too busy. Unbelievable!

Borghese Gallery is a gem. We have been to many museums, but the Borghese Gallery is one of our favorites. It is a relatively small museum and one must make a reservation for a time frame for your visit. The sculptures were phenomenal, espcially Canova's Pauline Bonaparte and Bernini's Appollo and Daphne. You swear you could see these statues breathe!
wonderful. amazing and breathless all the time. not too much people around and in a wonderful lication
beautiful and worth seeing. take a tour to get the most from your experience well worth it...gardens afterwards rather boring not as expected could skip

Can't get tickets online!. Hi, I have tried numerous times through the Gallery'ws website to make reservations. The site states tickets are available and takes my reservation, but when I try to click through to pay, it does not go through. Frustrating!
We will probably have to book through our hotel and pay a hefty surcharge. Hope it is worth it.

A Very Lovely Visit. You must obtain tickets ahead of time, but it is well worth planning a trip to the Galleria Borghese while in Rome.Your ticket is for a set time and you then have 2 hours (and you must leave when the 2 hours are up). The first floor is primarily the beauty of the building and sculptors and was the part that we enjoyed the most. The second floor is more about the art. We enjoyed the first floor the most.To get the most out of your visit rent one of the audio guides. They are easy to use and are an excellent guide to all of the beautiful things that you will see.The Galleria is in the Borghese Gardens and is a lovely setting for a stroll after visiting the Galleria.

fabulous- a MUST. Small for a museum of this stature and easy to navigate. Intricate, whimsical collection which in the same time does not overwhelm, especially in comparison with the Vatican museums. Remeber: reservations are required!

Bernini!. This is one of the great small museums of Europe with mostly amazing sculpture on the first floor and paitings on the second. It is noted for several of the best Bernini sculptures in existence. The museum was the brainchild of a 16th Century nephew to the Pope, who loved art and acquired it by any means possible (even unscrupulously). You MUST reserve your ticket in advance online and your tour is limited to 2 hours. Spend 1 1/2 hours downstairs and 30 minutes upstairs. The villa itself is a work of art and reminded me of the Getty Villa in Malibu, CA. No expense was spared in making this a showcase for art even back in the day it was founded.
Wonderful. Just not enough time to appreciate the Carravagios and the Berninis. The ceilings are so lovely. The grounds are a real family place so many things to do. This is unmissable!

breathtaking, but reserve in advance!. The Borghese houses the most amazing collection of sculpture that you will ever see, but if you plan to visit it, make a reservation well in advance and do not be late. The number of visitors is strictly limited by time, and on the day we we there (5/9/12) we noticed that they were fully booked for at least the next 10 days. Make a reservation for the latest time available and you'll be more likely to have priviate indivduals touring with you rather than packs of tour groups. As others have mentioned, it is quite a hike to the museum so give yourself plenty of time if you are walking and you will be rewarded with the absolute best of sculpture in the world. Canova's beautiful Paolina is amazing. Bernini's talent can not be overstated, and his work, done in his 20's is breathtaking (what were YOU doing in your 20's??). The museum's limitation on numbers of visitors provides everyone with an opportunity to truely enjoy the works. There are also fabulous rooms painted on literally every surface and oil paintings by masters, but the sculpture is the star here.

Do not be late!. We had a reservation which was not honored because we were 10 min late. Like everything in Rome, it is farther than it appears on a map. The museum is at the top of a steep, long walk from the Spanish Steps. I would strongly suggest taking a cab and arriving early. The park outside of the museum is great.
Amazing!. The Borghese is not to be missed! Make your reservations well in advance. They don't admit you if you don't have a reservation.

Art and sculpture in a Villa situate in a garden. The Galleria Borghese gathers art and sculpture in what was once a private villa situate in lovely gardens. YOu need a timed entry reservation - easy to make on website - and have to check in ALL bags including your purse and camera. I did and had no problems. The number of visitors is limited and there are set entry times (e.g. your reservation may be for 2:30 p.m. and you must get there on time to claim your ticket, but you will not have access until the next "entry" time, which may be 3:00p.m or 4:00p.m. We waited about 30 minutes after getting our ticket. The benefit is that the galleries are not unbearably crowded. Both the paintings and sculptures are interesting but the setting is what makes it a truly wonderful experience.

Galleria Borghese. Had a private tour guide, Francesca from Rome City Tours (romecitytours.com) who was fantastic. She was passionate, informative, attentive, engaging and spoke of topics of interest to us rather than following some type of strict format. She was educated enough about the artwork to be able to discuss it from any perspective (historical and artistic). We thoroughly enjoyed her tour

Just amazing!. Words cannot do justice to describe this museum. If you are an art lover, this is an absolute must-see! This is a treasure trove - sculptures (Bernini, Canova,...) and paintings (Carvaggio, Titian, Raphael, Rubens,...). 2 hours is not enough time to see these masterpieces. Fortunately for us, we had a tour guide and he was able to whisk us through so that we could spend more time on the specific art of our liking. We also reserved our tickets online before our departure from the US to get the specific time slot and day. Cameras are not allowed and we had to leave ours at the cloakroom - it was safe. Highly recommend this museum!

get a private guide to assist your experience at the Borghese. What a vast historical perspective, especially on the Renaissance artists including Michaelangelo, with this visit to the home of the once high powered Cardinal whose only goal was to obtain the best European art pieces at that time! We obtained a private guide who made the art come to life. What was so nice is that we could listen to her while gazing at the various pieces - this made it all so much more enjoyable. Make sure to pay for a discount to most museums/galleries by pre-purchasing online and picking the pass up at Leonardo Da Vinci Airpot.
set in lovely garden. all the paintings from old masters and Canova sculpture

Make reservations early to see this stunning collection. We loved that they limit the number of people for the 2-hour block you reserve. It keeps congestion down (a bit). The optional audio tour was very helpful. Visit the nearby neighborhood of art deco buildings afterward and enjoy the peaceful park.

Amazing art!. The only problem was that I didn't understand clearly that the duration of the visit was 2 hours including the gallery, so I never saw that. (It's difficult with the roman accent, I only study italian for 3 years, after all...) We only saw the statues. But they are truly, truly fantastic! The David of Bernini frankly changed my life. Ah, and it's forbidden, strictly forbidden to take pictures, so you have to go and see it yourself...!

Gorgeous museum. This is a must see. Make your reservation in advance as they sell out quickly. We rented the audios and it was well worth the money. The dialog while rather dry was very informative. And the museum was just over the top beautiful... The paintings and sculpture are great but the rooms themselves in this musuem are a sight to behold...it is artistic overload!!

Fantastic art in a beautiful location. The amount of art and sculptures is overwhelming. I suggest using Rick Steve's guide to navigate this gallery. He has useful tips for seeing the highlights and beating the crowds. Be sure to reserve early, show up early to check your bags, and then wander around the lovely gardens after.

Best Gallery we went to. It you love art- call and make your reservation. It is absolutely beautiful. The collection was breathtaking. We used the info cards in the room to understand what we were viewing. This is the only place that I wish we had gotten the audioguide. We booked at 9am and after days of early mornings I wish we went a bit later but couldn't change as they would booked for about a week out.

Amazing museum. Do not miss this museum. Tickets need to be purchased in advance so be sure to visit their website to reserve your spot. The collection is amazing and very well preserved. The grounds of the park are wonderful as well.

G. Likes: Great sculptures and paintings. Amazing interiors. Glad we made the effort to go. Set in a lovely park.Dislikes: You must book your visit at least 2 weeks in advance or you won't get in and you have to turn up three quaters of an hour before your alloted time or they'll give you place away. A waste of time when you have so little time in Rome.
Worshipping at the feet of Bernini. The title says it all. The perfection and beauty of Bernini 's work alone brought tear to my eyes. Well worth the advance reservation and less than friendly staff.
Must see!. Make reservation. Don't worry. They speak perfect English. Pronto!

Amazing museum in a quiet park in a busy city. This was the first museum we visited on our visit to Rome. We reserved tickets ahead of time online (this is a must as you will be turned away at the door if there are no time slots available for the day). We started our day walking from central Rome through the south entrance of the gardens. The gardens themselves are lovely. A nice quiet oasis in the middle of a bustling city. Since it was a weekend, there were plenty of families strolling through the park. The museum itself is a must. The Bernini sculptures are AMAZING! Although maybe not as massive in size compared to David or other sculptures, the details in these pieces really tell a story. Look for the laminated "placemats" in each of the rooms (available in multiple languages) to give you a brief summary of the pieces in the room. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Rome.
A wonderful experience. Bernini's sculptures are simply breathtaking and every room is exquisite,
Wonderful gallery-. You will thoroughly enjoy this gallery/museum. So many magnificent works of art in a beautiful setting.

Favorite Museum in 2 Weeks in Italy. The sculpture in the museum is the finest we saw anywhere in Italy. A ticket gives you two hours, and that's just about the right amount of time to be overwhelmed by the beauty and craftsmanship. Make sure to reserve tickets ahead of time - in February, they were totally sold out for the day as of 11:00 a.m.
beautiful park. this is a great park for families and art lovers too. the museum has wonderful art pieces, and the gardens and statues are worth the visit.

Do not miss.... If you enjoy art and sculpture you MUST go here. Bernini was a master and his sculptures are simply something to marvel at. I am so glad we had enough time in Rome to visit this villa. The park grounds are lovely too and we spent an afternoon renting one of the double bike carts and riding around the park.

Houses the Most Breathtaking Sculptures in the World. The sculptures of Appollo Chasing Daphne and the Rape of Persephone are world treasures and overwhelming to see in person. The Galleria Borghese is a not to be missed sight when visiting Rome. The interior is overwhelming and worth every penny. It houses some of the finest art in the world.

Magnificent. This is another must-see attraction in Rome. Booking ahead is essential, so some planning is required. For this, you will get a timed ticket, and you won't get in a moment before. You can, however, use the cafe and toilets.The highlight for me was the collection of Bernini sculptures. Fantastic what that sculptor could do with some marble.Photography is not allowed in the gallery, but plenty of postcards and books are available.

The must-do place in Rome.. To be honest, I wasn't able to visit this museum this time in Rome because the place is getting so busy you really have to book about a week in advance these days.My review score is based on a previous visit.BOOK A TIME SLOT IN ADVANCE!!!!

Just Phenomenal!. A little hard to get to, but well worth it. You should buy tickets in advance for a specific time slot, as it sells out and they limit the number of people who can attend. Your time slot is good for exactly 2 hours, so make sure you see everything because they ring a bell and shoo everyone out the door when your time is up. The ceilings in each room as you go from room to room are the most spectacular, and the sculptures by Bernini make you understand why many feel he is greater than Michaelangelo. The powerful and wealthy Borghese family has left a stunning public legacy.
a true inspiration. I keep coming back here every time I am in Rome, this place is a true inspiration and treasury of masterpieces - book&buy your ticket online in advance and enjoy!

Bernini sculptures. Bernini's sculptures are amazing. After seeing them it is difficult to concentrate in the paintings upstares which are as amazing. Caravaggio, Raphael, Lippi etc. Go here - Borghese is a must!
The best of the best art museum of Rome (perhaps of the world). From all word, no place in terms of masterpieces can compare to Cardinal Scipio Borguese palace

Be sure and make prior reservations. You need to make reservations to enter the gallery weeks to months ahead of your visit. They do not have tickets available to see the gallery on a walk up basis. There is some very beautiful sculptures and paintings throughout the gallery. The gallery is housed in what was a summer home. I was expecting more than what I experienced at the gallery. Perhaps I had overdosed on sculptures and artwork at the Vatican the previous day! If you are an art history type, this place is a must see.
Visited Gallery & Gardens. Excellent gallery. We booked a tour of the garden for an hour and discovered it is a big park. Would not have booked it I had known. Nothing special in the park.

Beautiful building, fantastic sculptures, great paintingsj. What a place. The decor of the building was gorgeous, however, you don't get much chance to appreciate it because every room is crammed with stunning works of art. We were totally blown away by Bernini's statues. Per-booking is absolutely essential. In a city of superlatives, the Galleria Borghese stood head and shoulders above the rest.
Good, but busy. Very busy, we went during Cultural Week, & had tried to book tickets in advance, hadn't been able to do so. When we arrived, the tickets were sold out for the entire week.

Excellent sculptures and mosaics- book in advance and arrive early. We thought the sculptures and mosaics were amazing - the paintings less so. Well worth all the planning in advance. Get there early to avoid the scrum of the cloakroom and renting the audio guides. Once inside it didn't seem crowded at all , unlike the dire experience at the Vatican museums.

Marvelous place!. If you like at art at all you like this place. Last time I don´t booked on the good time and we don´t reach the Gallery. Booked in the internet befor the trip. Two hours is the time that each person can spend a gallery.
Bernini: "David" and " Apollo and Dafne" WOW!

Some signs would have helped. Easy enough to find the location, but no sign as to which door to enter - and staff snapped at us for going in the wrong door (shocking). Once inside it was nice enough, although we couldn't find the exit (the entrance is locked and no signs to exit - we wandered around for 20 minutes unable to find a security person to show us where to go) before deciding to try going down an unmarked staircase and finding ourselves in the basement by the bathrooms.Other than that, it was a very lovely museum, marred by typical european vagueness and lack of signage.

Must see! Two hours are not enough. The two hours you are allowed in the gallery are not enough! I could spent the whole day looking at the Bernini sculptures alone. Heed the advise on the reservation and show up min 30 minutes before to get your ticket, check in your camera and bag and line up for the audio guide which is (a) worth it! and (b) scarce.
disappointing. We went here and walked about 2 miles to it. On arrival were told that we should have pre-booked to get in. Very disappointing to be told this.

Oh the Berninis. My favorite museum in Rome. The Bernini scultures are amazing. Walk around and observe them from all angles. Don't forget to book an entrance time BEFORE you fly to Rome. You don't want to miss this one if you love art.

Lots of hoops, jumping not allowed.. For all the hoops one must jump through to get into the Galleria you would think there would be more to the tour than one and a half floors of art. The security to get inside harkened to Fort Knox but the guards inside were more like Barney Fife..
Bernini must be seen to be believed.... It's indescribable. Just go. Be sure to make reservations, wear comfortable shoes, and take your time. Enjoy!

Make your reservations now!. Our visit was one of, if not the, highlight of our week in Rome. When the museum itself was sold out for the week, we purchased our tickets (and a tour) through tickitaly.com, which contracted the tour to a local guide service. The museum sells out way in advance, so make your reservations as soon as you have your travel plans firmed up. The tour guide, Tiberio, was terrific.

A jewel. I visited several times Galleria Borghese and I fully recommend it ! It features a lot of remarkable works of art (to mention only the statue of Paolina Borghese by Canova, the Roman mosaic, and 3 pictures -if I remember well- by Caravaggio !!!) and the villa itself is a magnificent renaissance architectural work. The park around is worth visiting, but have good shoes (not sandals). This year in January we had the rare chance to see it under snow it was a real spectacle, although a bit dangerous as a lot of pine branches fell due to heavy snow.

One of the best ever. This was one of the best museums I've ever been to in my life, and it's just the right size! Two stories of great art. I think there's a limit to how much you can absorb in a visit.The sculptures Bernini are not to be missed.
Hidden Gem. This is a wonderful museum located in a beautiful park. The statuary and the paintings are amazing!
One of the best museums in Rome. The sculptures will leave you awestruck. The museum is small, reservations needed which keeps the crowd to a minimum and you are really able to enjoy it.

Wonderful way to spend and afternoon. From the moment you see it from a distance, the building sets the tone of the adventure. Structured, though incredibly beautiful, the museum of artwork, the setting, the statuary, not to be missed. Enjoy a drink on the Via Veneto, steps away after a hard day at the museum.

So beautiful - and awe inspiring!. We went through the upstair galleries first. By the time we went downstairs, the galleries were amost empty an we had the Bernini's to ourselves. We did get there early to check our bags and avoided the lines at the check room. We had more than enough time at the Galleria.

Arrive early. Try and arrive 20 minutes before your allotted time so you can exchange your prebooked voucher for a real ticket. You can also hand in all your belongings, bags, cameras etc- not hats! That way you are ready to start your tour whenever your two hour slot begins. The galleria is in Villa Borghese so look out for signposts as it's quite a large park and there are other buildings in the park. Sculptures ansd Caravaggio on ground floor, paintings one floor up.
Non-visitable. With no previous information, the tickets are sold-out in advance. Forget about showing up there and gettin in! When we visited, no tickets were available until four (4!) days later.
My Favorite !. limited number of people at certain time slotsBernini's Appolo and Daphne
Hub of Masterpieces. Beautiful park, magnificent collection of sculptures and paintings. A must.

This is a must, life-changing, beautiful!. Here, you will fall in love with Bernini and see some of his most amazing work. Make an advance appointment, and pick an early time, get there on time, because they limit the time of your visit. You will love it!

Worst museum I have NOT visited. Paid 22 euros to get there. At arrival we were informed that the museum was booked for the next two weeks. That is the worst policy I have ever seen for a museum, which is not something special by the way. What happens with the occasional visitor does not concern the. Not that there have been hordes of tourist also. The ticket was rather expensive also for such a small museum. Avoid and show them that they can't ignore all visitors but groups.

Paradise in your own backyard , Villa Borghese. The gallery is in the park with the same name. The pre-bookings worked well and you were let in at the time listed on ticket.I went back twice to see the Bernini sculptures and the wonderful After your 2 hrs. of living like a Baroque princess, the guards escorted you out ...and the next group was lined up and ready to go. I believe only 360 people were allowed in at a time so you were close and uncrowded as you viewed the great art.

Don't miss it!. Very impressive even though we were restricted to 2 hours. The gallery is set in wonderful gardens close to the centre and we spent an afternoon walking from there to places like the spanish steps and piazza del popolo. Wonderful views and scenery in every direction!

Tough to get in but what an amazing place. Beautiful artwork, beautiful building...great collection. You will need to buy a reserved ticket in advance of going out there. It's small and so they limit patrons. The park there is incredible as well.

Once inside the galleries, great!. As visits are timed with a two hour maximum, you need to secure your reservations in advance. What you don't expect is the long lines to pay for the ticket; another line to check everything you are carrying; and if desired, another line to rent the taped handheld guide. This all takes time, and you are stressed to complete in the 30 minutes allowed before your timed entry. Whew! Once inside the sculpture is on the first floor and most paintings on the second. Be sure to time your visit so you aren't rushed through the sculptures! Also, note the historic building architectural features - magnificent! A fabulous two hour experience ... could improve on the 30 minutes beforehand.
must visit. Perfect place to have a rest during siteseeing. To gallery you need to make reservation ahead. Easy to find, the rest in tourist guides

Beautiful gallery. Beautiful gallery but tour seemed rushed. One cannot take ANYTHING in, even a camera, and as I was travelling with a group, it was time consuming to have to check literally everything. However, overall, well worth seeing, particularly the sculptures. Very well-informed guides.
Inspiring Masterpieces. By far the most awesome collection of art and sculpture I have ever seen. You are limited to just 2 hours viewing and must make reservations 3 to 5 days in advance
The park. Gallery good, but the park is a lovely green area. Seeing the turtles in the 'lake' was a surprise.

Awesome!!!. You must visit this place, sculpture is some of the best in the world. Take time to go through the park. Make sure to buy tickets ahead...they will sell out. Small groups taken through every couple of hours. Take your time and enjoy the are here, one of the best collections.

Buy tickets well in advance. The attendance to the museum is very closely regulated and that makes it all the more wonderful an experience because you are not crambed in like sardines trying to see the fabulous sculptures and art. If you are 'last minute' try GoItaly as I think they might buy blocks of tickets and there is an off chance you can get a spot.This is one of the most wonderful museums I have ever seen. It was built to be a museum and it is made up of several 'salons' many of which have a Bernini sculpture in the center of the room that sets the stage for the 'decor' of the entire room.Only thing I don't understand is why the Italians are so bad at lighting art! There are some pieces that are very difficult to view becaause there is a big spot light on it.

Elegant marble statues in a beautiful villa. This former residence of a cardinal has a magnificent collection of Bernini and Canova marble statues. "Apollo and Daphne" by Bernini and "Venus" by Canova are timeless and speak for themselves.

Amazing collection. The Bernini and Caravaggio collections at the Borghese are worth the trip to the Galleria. It can get kind of tight in the lobby areas when there are school trips, so try to get there at least 20 minutes before your reservation time. It'll make it easier to get through the baggage check area. Apollo and Daphne, The Rape of Proserpina, and David are well worth the trip, as well as the statue of Josephine. Amazing sculptures and paintings.

Awesome gallery. A wonderful museum in a beautiful location. You must reserve a time for entry, which makes for a more enjoyable visit. This gallery has a variety of art, one room after anther keeps you awestruck!
Easily the best museum in Italy. Unbelievable collection of statues by the genius Bernini and other greats. The Apollo and Daphne statue is the most amazing sculpture I've ever seen.

Fabulous Art! Seriously Worthwhile!. Don't miss the opportunity to visit this museum. Get a reservation ahead of time. Use the audio guide and enjoy some of the world's best artwork! Bernini is a brilliant. Loved my time here!!!

Lovely. Fantastic collection of beautiful paintings, sculptures, etc. NOThandicapped or elderly friendly, however, with many stairs and a non functioning elevator. They do hold your purse or backpack until tour is finished.

feel a bit bad, but..... i was a little disappointed in the borghese. i went for the bernini and the rooms are a little small and cramped for proper viewing. bernini feels squished. and the carravaggios, if you can have this many in one place, you have the obligation to make them all truly visible and not hang them so high that the glare makes it nearly impossible to see them properly. interesting experience, the house and the gardens...but not the best museum experience.
worth the time. The gardens themselves was nice to stroll in too. We recommend getting the audio guide - made it much nicer to know what you are looking at. Great day

A Must See. This is an amazing museum. Make sure to order your tickets well in advance. Admission is limited. If you can't get a ticket for the day you want, you can try to get in after everyone with a pre-purchased ticket has already entered, but I wouldn't want to take the chance.
No photos allowed, unfortunately.
Wonderful Gallery. if you like sculpture this is the museum for you. Of course my favorites were Apollo and Daphne, as well as David by Bernini. Make sure you make reservations before your trip.
book ahead. its a trap for weary travellers, you cannot just turn up at this gallery and expect to get in. it has to be pre-booked and expect to wait for days. Even in January there was a 3 day wait!
Best Art. Cardinal Borghese property with massive collection of fine art. If you like art...this is a must visit. Beautiful park also.
unpolite and snob. It was impossible to have a reservation to get in (in addition to unpolite and snob personell of ticket office).

Too much to take in during one visit.. Glad we made reservations before the trip. Doubt we would have made it in without them. Give plenty of time to get there if you're a walking. The park is very large, and we walked across from the Piazze del Popolo. The guided tour was a bit confusing as to which room you were in.

Forward planning needed. We visited the galleria on the recommendation of friends and booked tickets for an early start. What we hadn't appreciated was the need to be at the Galleria at least half an hour before your allotted time slot in order to check in handbags and obtain an audio guide. We missed the opportunity for the audio guide and think our visit suffered as a result. It was a lovely building, but having visited the Vatican the day before, it felt a bit of a let down.
Marvelous art collection. Not overwhelming in size, but a wonderful collection of paintings and sculpture.
Outstanding Baroque art. If you haven't been, put this at the top of your list of museums to see in Rome.
Rome. All the history of Rome. The whole older part of the city of Rome was something to see
Wonderful. Intimate and easy to walk around, the Bernini statues are wonderful, as is the artwork and the ceilings - all of it is delightful. Remember to book in advance.
wonderful place. it's difficult to enter inside because of lack of tickets. But you can get it if ask and wait for tickets released from reserve. The park around is unbelievable!
So much Boroque. The title says it all. The Galleria Borghese is a well stocked exhibit of lots of styles of art, mostly baroque. Beautiful exhibit.

My favourite part of Rome. Everyone will talk about Vatican City, the Sistine Chapel and the amazing frescoes everywhere, but as a sculpture lover my fav place in Rome was the Borghese. Its way smaller than the Vatican and most other museums in Rome, but every inch of it is breathtaking and the Apollo & Diana statue was stunning in its concept and detail. I'd recommend booking early to see it, and if not I was advised (and was successful) to hang about at the entry times (every two hours from 9am) and if you're not a large group, they might sell you a ticket. Shhh though :)

We couldn't get in. We tried to get tickets on the day but it was impossible as they were fully booked 9 days in advance. You can go and queue on the off chance that someone with a pre booked ticket doesn't turn up or buy your ticket online before you go.
beautiful. Get the audio tour...totally worth it. The Bernini statues were amazing.

wonderful guide made the difference. The galleriea is only open for two hours, morning and afternoon. So it is a challenge to get through it all with a feeling of intelligence. The tour guide Rebecca who came supplied through the agency Dark Rome was marvellous. She cleverly took us with excellent description and story through all the rooms showing the highlights and the Bernini. I could not imagine seeing it without her. Although it was easter week the Galleria was not a zoo. There is a small cafeteria where a much needed coffee was drunk and nice bathrooms. The walk through the park was not so spectacular.

Great art in a beautiful setting. My husband and I definitely enjoyed visiting this museum. The building is a work of art unto itself and contains some beautiful sculptures and paintings that are not to be missed. You must book your tickets online and pick them up about a half hour before. Be aware you do have to check all bags/purses. I would have left mine in the hotel had I known.

Great Collection. For my money the sculpture of Apollo and Daphne was worth the price of admission. This Bernini is absolutely amazing. It is one of the most magnificent I have ever seen. I thought it even better than the David in Florence or other Michelangelo works.Best to make a reservation by phone without any financial obligation till you show up to buy your tickets.

Nice Museum. The Roma Pass gives you 2 free passes to any 2 museums and the tourist information center said this is one of the good ones. There are sheets of paper in every room where you can read about the art pieces inside the room. Very informative. The art pieces inside are beautiful. Come here if you have the time.
Great expierence!. So many gems together. Don't forget that you need to book your visit on-line.
Must visit the villa. Just make sure u book the tickets online, as lot of ppl wanna visit it so they may not let u in. I would go there on a sunny day as the gardens are nice, relaxing as well

Bernini and some of the Most Beautiful Art in the world. If you are an Art lover this place is for you,the most important thing I can say for this is to get your hotel to make you a reservation,this is not to be missed
Sublime Berlinis. Listen to those people who tell you that you must visit the Gallerie Borghese. And if you are in a hurry, seek out the Berlinis and the Caravaggios and stare and stare

very crowded. In my first trip we visited galleria borghese and in the second time We want our familt to visit this place. But it was very crowded. We went there on Friday but they were selling tickets for Wednesday.

NIce art Gallery. we booked this art gallery befor we left Englad online. This was necessery because were were allocated a two hour slot to spend out time browsing the scuptures and paintings in this wonderful building. Because it's prebooked the don't let too many people in at any time so you've plenty of space to spend at your favourite piece of art. Our only gripe was that you couldn't take your camera in (understandable) but when we went to the shop on our way out we was disappointed that we couldn't buy a postcard with our best pictures or sculptures on!

So much amazing art in such a small space!. With prior reservations recommended by our hotel, we entered the Galleria Borghese and were uniformly impressed the art pieces it contains. For a lover of classical art, there is arguably no better way to spend two hours. The audio guide was very helpful and is highly recommended.
Beautiful!. Beautiful and interesting! However, the gardens were bare and disappointing.

A true delight of masterpieces. We took a stroll in the park and ended up at Villa Burghese. We knew that you had to make a reservation days in advance but decided to try anyway and see if anybody canceled and sure enough we were able to get in. The building itself is very beautiful and magnificent frescoes. Many statues that resided at the Louvre until recently were returned at the villa and arranged according to period paintings and sketches. The result is the most impressive private collection I’ve seen.

Not our favorite... Our background: We are both well education Americans from the DC area. We love to travel and take 2-3 trips per year out of the US. We like to learn about the culture and history of the countries that we visit.Review: I was excited to visit this Gallery, but for some reason it wasn't for us. We aren't huge art lovers, but we do have an appreciation for the amount of work and effort that goes into making a painting or sculpture. Perhaps since we spent the morning with a private guide in the Vatican Museum, we were tired of Art for the day. Or perhaps it was the price and hype for the place and then we were let down with the dry audio guide, amount of people and small space.Things to know: You do have to make reservations. Bag check is mandatory and yes, that means your purse too. It is extra for an audio guide and you need to leave an ID with them.Otherwise, the park and surroundings are beautiful. There is also a WONDERFUL restaurant nearby called Il Pomodorino. Their gelato is spectacular!
Never ever miss this one.. This happens to be my favorite galleries ever. Beautiful place and great stories about the former owner, Borghese. Just know that it will be packed.

Wonderful!. This museum was the highlight of our trip. Bernini sculptures were amazing. Amazing. Amazing. Tickets sell out sometimes weeks in advance! We had a private tour guide that showed us exactly what we needed to see in this huge museum they only allow you 2 hours to see.

A small museum of GREAT works. This museum isn't huge which plays to its advantage. It is laid out in an old villa and in each room there is usually one or two large statues and the walls covered with famous art. The Borgheses were great patrons of the sculptor Bernini and the painter Carvaggio- two of Italy's finest artists. As you walk through each room you would think that Apollo and Daphne are in reality running ahead of you, but really its just a statue in the middle of the dining room. Might be my favorite museum in all of Rome, has an extensive and beautiful collection, yet small and intimate enough to have your time with each piece. Highly recommended.

Breathtaking. This is easily my favorite museum in Rome, due not only to the superb collection of art works but also the controlled number of patrons allowed in at a time. Unlike the Vatican Museum, here one is able to admire the art and reflect without being pushed on. If you like the statues (and paintings) of Bernini or the works of Caravaggio this is the place for you. Just make sure you have reservations ahead of your visit or you risk being unable to enter.

Best Museum. This place is amazing, the sculpture is so beautiful, I wish they let you spend more than two hours here, I could spend all day. Make sure you get your reserved time before you travel to Rome!

Interesting, albeit very small, museum. I am glad I went to see this museum, but I would urge that if you only have 1-2 days to explore, this is one museum I would probably put further down the list.The museum is also very complicated to locate, especially if, like me, you like to walk as much as possible, as opposed to taking the metro everywhere! Carefully plan out your visit, making note of all aspects to your arrival at this museum, and you will have a much more enjoyable experience.That said, the walk path I used to get to this museum took me up the Spanish Steps, which you could become easily distracted with as it is not only a well functioning water feature, the people watching is very rich! So, you might well get distracted on your way to the Borghese.

One of the world's great small museums.. Tucked into a corner of Rome, in a beautiful park not far from the Spagna and Via Veneto areas, this gem of a gallery houses several of Bernini's greatest sculptures, amid excellent Roman copies of Greek sculptures and paintings by titian and others of equal stature. You must reserve ahead, and visits are for specific times and limited to two hours.

expected much more!. I was very much looking forward to seeing this museum and made sure I booked the ticket online in advance and arrived well in advance to pick up the ticket. Considering all the security there is (ex. mobiles are not allowed in the museum and you have to give your handbag to the staff so they place it in a locker), I was not that impressed with the museum and artifacts. Yes, there are caravaggio paintings and other beautiful artistic statues dating back to ancient rome. however, I have seen other museums around europe and was more impressed. The gardens around the Villa are beautiful though.
Pretty. Nice park area. Make sure you have a map so you know where you are!
Seeing is beleving. Worth every penny they charge as entrance and they mind you they charge big

Two hours of jaw-dropping art. I am not a big art enthusiast, but we heard that Galleria Borghese was a must-see in Rome. We are so glad that we went. There are so many amazing things to see. You can get really close to the art to get inside of the spirit of the artist and truly appreciate the fine work. The place is packed with amazing objects. I was thrilled and saturated by the sights. Our 2-hour time slot flew by. I would go back in an instant.

Stunning Statues and wonderful interior. An absolute must if you go to Rome but you must book in advance. Once you enter to collect your ticket there is typical Italian chaos and it takes nearly 30 minutes to deposit handbags, cameras etc. Second only to the Vatican Museums. Beautifully displayed statues with numerous paintings and detailed ceilings to admire. The audioguide was helpful.
Great art gallery, prebook though. Book tickets online in advance as they have a prebook system and you won't get tickets at the door.

Must see!. My favorite sculptures of all time! The surrounding park is beautiful with lots of fun activities for the family or for romance. Rent a peddled cart and enjoy an awesome picnic in Spring and Summer.

Small museum but beautiful artwork. For an average tourist that knows little about the artwork in this museum, this may be a stop to skip in Rome. However there are some good guide books to purchase in the bookshop before your tour that help in uneducated to appreciate the paintings and statues. You must have a prebooked appointment to tour.
Beautiful collection. If you love baroque era sculpture, Bernini is king ! They don't allow cameras though

I found the best sculpture in Rome here.. First off, you must make a reservation to tour these galleries. Arrive on time, and be prepared to check your bags and camera. (Photos are not allowed inside. Boo. Hiss.) First off, we toured the Pinoteca. (Go straight to the upper floors to avoid all the crowds on the first floor). Cardinal Borghese, though not an overly religious man, was the nephew of the pope. He was wealthy enough to amass quite an art collection, and much of it is religious in nature. After exploring the beautiful works in the Pinoteca, we headed for the amazing sculpture and Caravaggios on the first floor. I LOVED Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. I thought it was the best sculpture we saw on our entire trip to Rome. (And we went to ALOT of museums.) The stone of Apollo's cloak and Daphne's leaves was translucent; I can't believe stone can be carved like that. Also flabbergasting is the fact that the statue has remained so perfectly intact all of these years. Clearly, it's always been someone's treasured possession. Bernini's Rape of Proserpine was also gorgeous, and my husband loved Bernini's David, also a standout of this collection.

Very Efficient- Excellent Art Collection. I was worried about giving up purse and the restrictive time period but the process was painless and the time was adequate. We followed others advice and visited the 2nd floor first, thus the crowds were sparse when we arrived at the main attractions. Don't forget to call and reserve a time or you will miss this attraction. Coop

One of the finest galleries in the world.. We were lucky to see (for the umpteenth time) the gallery while the sculptures from The Louvre were on loan. These sculptures were originally part of the gallery but were sold to Napoleon in the early 19th century. To see them all together was a marvel. One can't consider a trip to Rome complete without a visit here. The Bernini sculptures are worth the price of admission alone. The 6 Caravaggio paintings and all the other incredible art that are housed here make the Galleria Borghese a must see. Don't forget to reserve tickets in advance since you will be turned away without one (a week in advance is recommended).

Who lived here?. Besides the wonderous artwork, the building itself is a work of art. Looking at the structure, the gardens and the statues it's hard to imagine the lives of the people who lived here. Should not ber missed on any visit to Rome!
Staggering. The contents of this fantastic palace/museum are staggeringly beautiful. Prepare to be blown away by the most amazing statues and paintings from Rome's incredible past.

Worth a visit but.... There are so many wonderful pieces in the collection of this Gallery that a visit is really worthy all the troubles you have to go to get in, starting from the booking system (tried to do it online but ended up calling straight to Italy from Australia), the no-photo policy, the huge amount of people in (you wonder, why the bookings then!) and the numerous school groups that just get in the way of any other visitors. But hey, if you love art, this place is a must.
Stunning Experience. Great display. Enjoyable layout. Folks nice. Excellent.

The Queen of private collections, Galleria Borghese is one of the very top attractions in Rome.. Simply put, this is one of the finest private collections in the world. The Galleria Borghese (8.50 Euro per person) is often called the Queen of private collections and for good reason. Here you find approximately twenty rooms, of various size, spread out over two floors, each featuring very special and impressive works of art and/or sculpture from the likes of Bernini, Caravaggio, Ruebens, Titan and Raphael. There are so many pieces of sublime excellence here, its difficult to process all that you are seeing. When you visit, just take your time! Also, compared to other world class museums, which are often quite monstrous in size, the Galleria Borghese is much more manageable since it housed in a smaller building and spread across just twenty or so rooms. This means you can have a quality experience here but not have to invest a full day of your time. For those pressed for time in Rome, you can see most of the collection in perhaps as little as just 45-60 minutes, or you can stick around and spent hours appreciating and enjoying what you can see here. The Galleria Borghese is located in the impressive Villa Borghese grounds, which are also worthy of an hour or two of your time. Collectively, they make an outstanding way to spend an afternoon in Rome. We suggest visiting the Galleria first thing after lunch and then spending the rest of the evening strolling through the Villa in the direction of Piazza del Popolo where you can find nice hillside views of the city of Rome. Overall, the Galleria Borghese is a magnificent attraction, well deserving of raving reviews which it so regularly receives. It is a place we have visited numerous times and will happily return to with anticipation for the numerous masterpieces which are to be found here. This is just one of those very special places and a very top attraction in the city of Rome, particularly for art and sculpture lovers.

Really Wonderful. This is a wonderful gallery. It is in the Borghese home, so while seeing all the wonderful art you also get a sense of what living in this home must have been like. If you are interested in the history of the art and home but don’t want to pay extra for the tour guide or audio tour I recommend either the Eye Witness Rome Top Ten book or download the Rick Steve’s podcast. Both are excellent. This museum is part of the ROMA pass system so if you are seeing all the sites in Rome, I recommend the pass; it will save you time and money. For the Borghese Gallery you will need a reservation as the entries are timed. The gallery has a small gift shop and café.
must see. No russian audio-guide, but the collection is really impressive.

Breathtaking Bernini. The works by Bernini are indescribable. Rick Steves suggests starting upstairs with the paintings for half an hour. We thought that was good advice, but spend more than the half hour because no one is timing the exit. Be sure to book tickets on line! The sign said the museum was sold out for a week from the day we visited.
Buy tickets in advance. Unbelievable sculptures with a great audio guide. You're only allowed 2 hours and it takes all of that. One of the highlights of our trip

If you like Bernini you have to go. An absolute barrage of Renaissance art. A feast for the eyes that is hard to match. Always busy, so it's hard to linger. All the super good stuff is on the ground floor, but there are beautiful pieces upstairs. If you are an art lover, go to their web site and make a reservation a couple of weeks before you go. It's a must-see!

Must see. Very impressed. Must receive a reservation code to view this beautiful museum. Ask/email your hotel in Rome to book for you as it's free of cost to receive a code for those traveling to Rome.

2 hours captivated by beauty and genius. They only allow visits in 2 hours slots (you need to think about this and plan) but in those 2 hours you are totally engrossed in the skills and beautiful works of masters such as Raffael or Carravaggio or Bernini. You do need to have at least an audio guide and I strongly recommend going AFTER you have settled into the rhythm of viewing Roman art. You see how Raffael brought structure and expression, Carravaggio brought light to the colours of black, red and white and Bernini seemed to soften marble so that the flesh appears to be pressed in.And save for last the Bernini statue (only his genius could have done it) of the condemned girl transforming into an oak tree whilst being held by her unbelieving young lover.The Borghese family & Popes may have been amongst the most corrupt but their Villa, their museums, their gardens, their pilfered art collections are truly beautiful.
Make time for this. A wonderful collection of sculptures and paintings.

Cardinal's choice. Impressive collection of art showing the wealth and power of its founder cardinal Scipion Borghese. Full of masterpieces made by Bernini, Caravagio and may others. You must make a reservation well in advance for a dedicated 2 hour time slot. This can best be done by internet.
A lot of art. We prefer to outdoors. The artwork was amazing, but it took a lot of time, if you are really into art I would recommend, otherwise skip or go through quickly

Unbelievable art worth the reservation. The fact that the number of tickets are limited make visiting this beautiful museum a very pleasant experience. The two hour time limit is a little short - an extra 30 minutes would have been just right. There is art on the ceiling, on the walls and with some of the painting and sculptures you wish you had a longer time to look at them. I will admit I was skeptical about the rave reviews but decided to reserve ahead because it was so highly recommended. I am very glad we visited Galleria Borghese, it was awesome. Be sure to get the audio guide - it is well worth the 5E!

Simply magnificent.. This is a fascinating and beautiful art collection, with a superb audio guide. The park itself is just lovely, and the museum, with its policy of pre-sale tickets and no bags inside, provides manageable crowds that preserve the serenity and atmosphere of your visit (unlike the Vatican museums where crowds can become overwhelming and unruly, snapping flash photos at every turn). The collection itself is amazing, and the audio guide gives a vivid sense of Borghese the collector and his influence on the art world. Highlights are of course Bernini's sculptures, but the depth of the Caravaggio collection and the occasional Rubens or Titan round out a magnificent collection. The audio tour makes the museum manageable and accessible in under 2 hours.
Best place to see great sculpture art in Rome. A great selection of sculptures by the very best artist like Bernini ++
awesome. you can get up close and personal with the art. Check out the Bellini's and other masters in the setting created for them

Lovely and well worth a visit. This gallery is stunning. It is an easy walk from the metro through the park and well worth the visit. The art pieces cover a vast timeframe and are set in a lovely place. There are great descriptions in English in each room - reservations are essential.

the best Gallery. Excellent, not big but very nice Gallery with fantastic collection of the best paintings, squelchers and great interiers. For 2 hours we can spend in this museum. We were there from 4.00 and most of the tourists at 5.00 leaved Gallery se we had enough time to see all we wanted. I like this place!
Bernini, Caravaggio and more..... Beautifull and impressive art collection. One of the most, if not the most, beautifull sculptures by Bernini.... Apollo and Daphne. Shows the genius of the artist
Amazing Galleria. You have to remenber to buy your tickets way in avance, it's worth a trip to Rome if you love art. Magnificent!
great art! not to miss. paintings and sculptures! don't forget to go to the first floor!

Please make your reservation well in advance. Unfortunately I did not get to visit this magnificent museum during this last trip in March. Trying to take advantage of the Roma Pass discount, I missed the boat by about 4 days. If you plan to visit Galleria Borghese, (which I highly recommend having visited in the past), plan to pay the full price and not use your "free entry" with the Roma Pass. You must make reservations for this exhibit and if you want to book using the Roma Pass, you are required to give them the number on the pass. Since the pass is only good for 3 days, by the time you pick up the pass and try to make your reservation with that number, it is too late. They book out at least 4 days in advance and this was in March!. Don't miss out like I did this time around. Book early, pay the full price and make sure you get in.
Great Galleria!. Off the beaten path and a little expensive but very neat - and on some beautiful land.

What a great museum!. The museum is a bit hard to find since it is in a big park and there aren't many signs. Once I found it though, I fell in love. The building is beautiful and hints at the treasures you will find inside.I was on a very small tour; because I am not an art expert, I find it helpful to have a guide who is. The Bernini sculptures were worth the trip alone, but then I "discovered" my favorite painter: Caravaggio. I love his art, and this museum has several of his paintings.A great experience, even if you don't consider yourself an art lover. And use the restroom before you leave...it's one of the nicer ones I saw in Rome.

eh. I dont understand why this is such a high rated sight. I have been to Rome before and been blown away by the art and museums, but this one was not very good in my opinion. Too hard to get into for such an uninspiring collection. Ridiculously crowded even in off season. I did enjoy seeing the caravaggios but I dont think its a must see sight. Go to the Vatican museums instead if you are going to wait in line for art.
The Art is Amazing.. Start with Bernini statues and add rooms and rooms of priceless and fascinating art. You need to make your reservations early as access is limited.

Best small museum in the world.. We loved the size of the museum and the beauty of the displays. The audio guide that you buy separately for 6 euro is the best one I've ever heard and I am a museum junkie. There are Bernini sculptures like Apollo and Bernin's David (so much more enthralling than Micheal Angelo's) and Caravagios galore, just to name two heavy hitters that are represented. You have to make a reservation to buy a ticket. The museum only allows in about 50 people every 2 hours and you are made to leave after 2 hours which can be a wrench, but you could always go again. I certainly plan to.

Worth the advanced booking. A vistor must make an advanced reservation to get into the Galleria Borghese as only 380 people are allowed in for each two-hour period throughout the day. The gallery is worth the effort only if a visitor does some research ahead of time as most of the art, although wonderful, is not for people who are not familiar with Baroque art history. Most people who go should know something about Bernini or Caravaggio before going. The gallery has a nice gift shop and a "stand and eat" sandwich shop. The only negatives are that no photos are allowed inside the museum--in fact, visitors must check their cameras, backpacks, and here is the big thing for women--your handbags. I don't see the need for these restrictions.If you love Bernini don't miss the statue of Apollo and Daphne--I didn't know marble could look like that.

Stunning. One of the most beautiful villas I have ever seen. This museum of Roman art is unique and would be even more impressive nowadays if Napoleon did not take (buy?) away everything for the Louvre. It is virtually impossible to get in if you don't pre-order tickets online at least a week before your visit.
Don't miss this site!. Some of the greatest sculptures are found in this newley restored site. It is out of the way a little but well worth the effort to get there.
Great Gallery not to be missed. Get tickets in advance or you may not be able to get in.
Small museum, big artists. One of the best museums I've ever been to. Have some great pieces by some very famous artists. The marble statues are incredibly realistic - - how did they do that?!

Must see!. My favorite of all the museums I had visited. There are two floors. The first floor held mostly statues, and the second floor contained mostly paintings. I could have stayed on the first floor forever! Their website says that you have to make reservations in order to enter. The tickets are in two hours time slots, and you have to be there half an hour prior to pick up your tickets. Let me say that I did call Italy and made my reservations for 9AM. I got lost and actually showed up at 9:15AM, instead of the 8:30AM that I wanted. Lucky for me, I went during low season so it was not that crowded. The staff was really nice and even sold me my tickets. I was given the 9AM-11AM time slot tickets. Two hours is enough to see the museum. I was done in 1 and a half, and even had time to grab a coffee at the bar. By the way, the museum has a lovely bar/cafe that sold delicious coffee, pastries and sandwiches. The prices are very reasonable.When you are done, please make time to explore the park/garden. The Gallery is siutated in the middle of a beautiful giant park. I saw people joging, and walking their dogs. Very serene, and far away from the hustle and bustle of city center! I walked in but they have buses that can get you in so you don't have to walk so far. In some places, it was a pretty steep hike as well. If you're in good shape, I recommend doing it all by foot =)Please note, it was required that I check in my backpack and photos are not allowed.

Bernini sculptues up close. The presentation of the Bernini sculptures was fantastic. The works are placed in the center of the room so viewing from all sides is possible. One of the best galleries we visited.
Antiquities in a beautiful setting. Visit soon as the current exhibit includes treasures that were sent to France during Napoleon's reign - Pauline Bonaparte was married to a Borghese.

One of my favorites. This is a total gem. The tour is only 2 hours and you have to make reservations several days in advance (even during the off-season), but it is totally worth it. I would not recommend a guided tour, just because there is not a lot of time to move through all the galleries. I would recommend renting an audioguide though (5 euro apiece) as it will tell you about the highlights. Please make sure you get the one with a full battery - we had to waste our precious time on the exchange.

The best museum to us in Rome.. Probably the best museum to go to! Out of the way but well worth to see all its collections from paintings to sculptures. Only setback is also that they give limited viewing times and duration. Could hardly cover the place thoroughly and seemed to have to rush through the audio guide and various levels of the museum.
Awesome. Bernini is just my favorite!!!!!! the kidnapping of Proserpina is breathtaking and also the villa is amazing, located in very beautiful park

Do not miss it. First of all be aware to pre-book the ticket on line really in advance.In my second time in Rome I've booked 2 months before my arrival,since 2 years ago I wasn't able to go to the Galleria because was sold out.Keep in mind that yoou could not see everything..too many things and less time.But it worth it anyway!Fantastic!!!

simply amazing. When in Rome, a visit to the Borghese is a must!! The sculptures by Bernini, especially the "Apollo and Daphne", are inspiring. Titian's painting "Sacred and Profane Love" and Raphael's "The Deposition" are also in this collection. Make sure you book tickets in advance as each two hour viewing period has a limited number of tickets which sell out quickly.
Worth the trip. Fantastic collection. Call early, you must have a reservation to see the collection.
Wow. Such a beautiful gallery, showing some of the marvelous treasures of ancient Rome. Loved it.
A must see when in Rome.. One of the top Galleries in the world. It doesn't disappoint. Get a free audio guide from Rick Steve's website and enjoy it more.

The gallery and gardens really worth the visit. Admission is based on a 2 hour slot, which you need to book. It was really worth taking the English Tour round the gallery, you learn so much more and it is booked at the desk. The gardens are really worth exploring even in winter and glorious views over Rome

Disappointing. Although housing plenty of works of art & sculpture they are exhibited in a crowded manner which makes viewing problematic. A number of the paintings had been glazed to protect them but this made it almost impossible to appreciate properly.
lose yourself in artistic luxury. Highlight of museums -- a bit of a crush at the entrance shouldn't deter you. Bellini sculptures worth a loooong look. Worth the effort to get tickets....
Awesome sculptures. Most beautiful pieces of art and most impressive of all. Go.
The Perfect Art Museum. An amazing villa with a mind boggling art collection. Perfect for those who might be overwhelmed by museums. Must have a reservation.

Galleria Borghese - A must see. We went to Rome in October 2011 and wanted to visit the Galleria Borghese on Saturday 8th October. We had tried to book online for the Galleria Borghese from South Africa, as we had heard that it was essential to have a booking as they only allow a certain amount of people in for a certain amount of time, but we had been unsuccessful. Our hotel manager tried to book for us but was told they only had bookings available for Tuesday (too late for us), however he told us to take a chance and just go there as sometimes people did not arrive for their tour. We decided to do this the next morning.We walked maybe a kilometre from our hotel to the Villa Borghese. It is the most stunning building from the outside, and yes, we asked if there were cancellations and they said yes, so again we used our Roma card and saved ourselves the entrance fee of €8.50 and didn’t have to pay the booking fee of €6.They are absolutely right when the say it is the most splendiferous palace in Italy. The art and statues are unbelievable. The statue that impressed us the most was of Pauline Bonaparte reclining on a couch. It is carved out of marble of course, but it looks so real and so soft that we felt if we touched it, it would dent under the pressure of our fingers. We had a giggle at the description in the book we had purchases at the gift shop that read, that when she was asked by her peers how she could have posed in the nude, she answered “it wasn’t too bad, they had heating”. Another incredible statue is of Marcus Curtius on his horse flinging himself in a chasm (who knows why?), how this statue seems to emerge from the wall and remain suspended almost in midair is a marvel to behold.There are masterpieces by Caravaggio, Rubens, Titian and paintings and statues by Bernini and of course then there are those by Raphael especially (one of my favourites) Lady with a unicorn.Do not miss this gallery, even if you are not well versed in the arts, the sheer beauty of the paintings and statues will take your breath away.When we had had our fill of art we strolled through the beautiful gardens admiring the fountains and yet more statues and then went on our way to explore yet more wonders of Rome.

The best David?. Apart from Paolina, who is just an amazingtly gorgeous sculpture, Bernini's David is, for me, one of the best representations of this subject. The contortion of his body, the facial expression of complete concentration... it is all amazing! And then there is still a whole Gallery to walk through, filled with all kinds of paintings and statues.Absolutely worth the visit, just make sure you book your tickets well in advance. Nothing sucks more than showing up clueless and not being able to get in!

Beautiful and elegant--a must stop for Rome. Book online to avoid hassle!. Galleria Borghese is a must for Rome--beautiful paintings, sculptures and frescoes in an intimate environment nestled in a beautiful park. Its an easy walk from Piazza di Spagna and the park provides a great opportunity to have a picnic or to relax. No pictures are allowed in the gallery--so you will have to check your purse and belongings at the door. The tickets are only good for two hours--and you are only allowed in during that time--they are quite strict about the timing. I recommend starting upstairs to avoid the larger tour groups and going during the weekday if possible. There is a gift shop, cafe and clean restrooms on the ground floor.

purchase tix ahead. if you are into art, then you should go here. so much, it's hard to take it all in, but definitely worth it. highly recommend pre purchasing tickets. we were there in off season so it was a bit easier, however, it was still packed so I can just imagine how busy it is in prime tourist season.

Nice, but a little unusual. The villa is very nice and the collection of art is interesting, although most of the statues are a little odd in that they are mostly pieced together from ancient Roman pieces made whole in the 17th? century. Worthwhile seeing and the grounds are beautiful, but it's no Vatican Museum.

Don't miss. A little controlled (no cell phones or purses even allowed in - there's a no-cost check service), and you need a time-specific reservation for a 2-hour visit (can do on-line). Fabulous art paintings and sculpture. Save time to visit the gardens just outside (no charge or reservation required for the gardens).

AMAZING.. This is the best small gallery I have EVER been to. The Bernini sculptures, Caravaggio paintings, and so many other impressive pieces earn this gallery my firm stamp of approval. I will admit getting there requires a bit of a hike if you try to walk there from the closest Metro station, and you do have to make reservations to get in at least a few days in advance even during off-season, but it's all worth it.

Most magnificent sculptures, beautiful gallery. Also loved the surrounding park on a Sunday afternoon which was amazingly not crowded. It was a wonderful respite after visiting places like the Vatican and Trevi Fountain. The park was the least crowded site and gave us a wonderful sense of what Rome must be like for those who live there with children year round.
Amazing. The sculptures here are fabulous! You must pre-book to enter and it's well worth it.
nice place with great pieces of art. nice setting i this beautiful park, great masterpieces inside, entrance staff upstairs kind of rude
Bernini, Bernini, Bernini. A beautiful gallery in the park on a sunny, mild day, chock full of Bernini treasures, as well as paintings by Raphael, Caravaggio and other masters.

Just right. We felt the size and scale of this museum was just right, some really excellent exhibits and a wonderful building to display them in. The day we went the weather was really good and we enjoyed walking around the park and sat outside for a while. Definitely book in advance, the day we went no tickets were available for another three days.

More than expected. without a guide we spent 2 hrs here, using a guide book. Its easy to book and the walk from Central Rome is very nice, download an app for a map of Rome and you will find here without a problem.

Wow. Please try to book in advance. I was lucky and was able to go in without a reservation but don’t take the chance. This is a gallery that you don’t want to miss. There are plenty of gorgeous and impressive works of art. My favorite was Bernini’s Apollo and Daphne he really was a master sculpture and is amazing how he was able to portrait his art.
incredible mansion and collection. you cannot miss it!it's amazing! the gardens, the mansion, the whole collection is outstanding!
Book in advance. Wonderful Caravaggios in a sumptious setting. You can get discounted entry with the Rome Pass. The last daily visiting period was less crowded
Galleria Borghese. Just renovated (again) amazing Bernini and Canova statues,plus frescoes, paintings, furniture...each room could be a museum in its own right anywhere but Rome!

Best gallery - perfect size, fantastic collection. I love the way the Borghese gallery operates. You have to make a reservation - for a two hour time slot - they limit the number of people who enter. We took exactly two hours to see the collection. We rented the audio guide and I would highly recommend doing so. It really added to the tour. The variety was great. Better than the Vatican!
GO RIGHT NOW. We enjoyed the "regular" display PLUS a temporary display of some pieces of the Borghese collection, coming from museum of all over the world.

Yes, they are open on Mondays.. A wonderful museum which is open on Mondays, despite what the guidebooks and the signs on the museum say. Make reservations before you go. The highlight for our two young children was renting the rickshaw bikes after we toured the museum. The Rick Steves guidebook says that there are kiosks for printing out your ticket. I saw one inside the museum, but it wasn't working, so it's best to stand near the lowest door of the museum and get inside first as the line is very slow-going. The doors open 30 minutes before your reservation time. Getting to the gardens and the museum is a bit of a trek- about 15 minutes on foot from the Spanish Steps. We brought a picnic and got to the park an hour early. Allow for plenty of time so you don't feel rushed.

Amazing property!. The galleria itself holds so many impressive and historical works of art, but my favorite part was wandering the grounds of the villa on a quiet Sunday morning. What a welcome respite from the noise and congestion that is Rome! You could easily spend an entire day here

Well worth the visit, but book beforehand!. A fantastic collection of art in a beautiful park. So glad I made the effort as its a bit out of the way. Also, be sure to book, either online or over the phone as the gallery gets very busy and are sometimes sold out for a few days in advance.

must see. Inside of the very nice park that is Villa Borghese you can find this museum that deserves all the attention. It is the home of great works by Caravaggio and Bernini and overall an overwhelming collection of art pieces. It takes about 2 hours to go through it and you need to make a reservation (by phone, also in English, or in the museum website )

Well worth the effort of booking in advance. We came mainly for the 6 Caravaggios, but were just as bowled over by the amazing Bernini scuptures, especially the expression on the face of David as he is about to fight Goliath. The 2 hour slot you book for is perfect, and if you wander round at a different pace from others you can end up having some of the exhibits to yourself

Inspiring - don't miss. I'd read that 'if you see one art gallery in Rome, make it this one' and we weren't disappointed. The collection of Renaissance art is amazing and although the Bernini sculptures, Caravaggio masterpieces and the building itself are obviously jaw-dropping, some of the smaller pieces are the ones I'll really remember. My only regret was not going earlier in the day so that we could take a stroll around the beautiful gardens as well. You need to book in advance, and you'll have to check bags in, which is a bit of a chaotic process, but aside from that it's great and you shouldn't miss it.
A "Must" for art like Forum Romanum for history !!!. Rome has many gallerys and exhibitions but this is maybe the best of them all. Lots of stunning art

If I had choices of museums to see in Rome, I'd see Coloseum, then Borghese. Get reservation on line. no cost. Art is great and you should enjoy walking the gardens.my second favorite after coliseum for must see places in rome. Use Metro. Metro is easy to use and buses are great.
Carravagio. the largest collection of Carravagio paintings in the world. The gardens are wonderful too. Not a top priority for a 1st visit to Rome but must be seen

Great for art lovers. Pulled into this one by my wife but found it very interesting and worthwhile. Reservations are necessary and the tour time is limited to two hours which is just enough to take it in without an art overload. Don't overlook the lesser pieces which tend to be some of the better items.

Don't miss this museum. A wonderful way to spend a couple of hours. The art and sculptures are breathtaking and the building itself is kept in perfect condition. Unfortunately you are taken through too quickly when the museum is busy. I would have liked to spend longer in each room.The park surrounding the gallery can occupy a whole afternoon if you like walking.
don't miss this. The Borghese Gallery is one of the finest museums in the world, in a beautiful and charming setting. You need an advance reservation.

Wonderful art that should not be missed. Several sculptures that I fell in love with; visit the Borghese when in Rome. Purchase tickets before your visit to Rome, go at 9am and after walk through Borghese park to Via Veneto. Walk up Via Veneto and visit Harry's Bar. Wonderful morning adventure - leaving the afternoon open for more sites!
Beautiful art BUT BOOK AHEAD. Beautiful villa, art, gardens - but BOOK in advance - or try your luck early. You get a session then you HAVE to leave. It was a bit busy.

Fantastic sculptures and paintings in a brilliant setting. An interesting museum in a fantastic setting. some fantastic sculptures and paintings, all bags including cameras need to be checked. Bookings are required, the numbers of visitors is limited which allows good viewing, with no crowds. The statue of
Apollo pursuing Daphne by Bernini alone is worth the trip.

Amazing Collection of Sculptures. The quality of the sculptures in here are the best works you can find in Rome. I don't think the vatican museum has such a great collection as did the Borghese gallery. Bernini's works are breathtaking and Canova's work is also so realistic looking that it does not even seem to be cut out of stone. The only negative is that you have a timed entrance and exit and must structure your time efficiently if you want to see all the works.
Amazing Art. Beautiful area, wonderful art. Not so close to Flaminio metro stop as we thought.

Absolutely stunning art collection. Not to be missed.. We visited the Galleria Borghese at the end of a month-long trip around Italy. When I was in Rome at the beginning of my trip I made reservations for when I was returning which was too far in advance, but reservations here are a must. I really wasn't sure I was going to be wowed by another gallery. I was wrong! The marble statues alone are unbelievable and absolutely worth the trip alone. You could spend hours gawking at all of the paintings or zip through if you only want to see key pieces of art. What you make of this experience is really up to you! The art here is incredibly accessible which really what makes the gallery that much more amazing than anything else I recall in Italy. You can ALMOST touch some of the major works of art. I am so glad I went and would absolutely recommend this experience to anyone. After exploring the Galleria, make time to wander around the park. It is absolutely beautiful. We were there early November and everything was so green and luscious.

HAD A PLEASANT AFTERNOON. Had a wonderful day on these grounds with nice gardens and a great dog park with lots of darling dogs and families.Of course the galleria was great.You need to get a reservation to take a tour to see the great art.We spent an in tire afternoon here.

Beats the Vatican.... It's difficult to say it beats the Vatican and the Sistine chapel, but the small size of the museum allows one to appreciate it more. And don't miss the paintings and sculptures upstairs - they do have some of the best well-known works. We take all our visitors to Rome there, amd every one has rated it hghly. The Bernini's are exquisite and look out for the Roman hermaphrodite and compare the drapings with the Canova. Don't forget that Scipione who built it took all the best mosaics and statues left from Roman times, employed the best artisans of the time and put all the best works here as his showpiece, so it is quite stunning. Check the Gallery's website and ring for a ticket in advance - you have to arrive half an hour before the appointment time to pick up the ticket, giving you time to have a coffee or drink in their very pleasant cafe befoe going in.

Lifestyles of the rich and famous in the 17th century. Beautiful galleria located within a huge garden. Worth seeing. My favorite was the sculpture of the Rape of Proserpina by Bernini.
