Be warned though that you must make ticket reservations by phone or internet prior to going there. They limit the number of people entering and you can only view for 2 hours.

Sculptures are not to be missed!. Amazing sculptures!!! The paintings on the second floor you can do without. Spend most of your time on the first floor. Simply amazing. Thinking about it makes me miss Rome!

Unfair Practices, duplicate ticket charges by the Borghese Gallery. Consumers, watch out for the SCAM via UNFAIR practices by the Borghese Gallery when purchasing tickets online. We attempted to buy the tickets (family of 4) online at their website from the USA but got no confirmation or email. So, we tried again and still the same - no confirmation or email confirmation reply. We tried one last time and still the same results. When we got to Rome, we purchased ROMA Passes which included entry to the Borghese Gallery. Upon arriving at the Borghese Gallery, we advised the ticket clerk that we attempted to buy the tickets online 3 times with no luck. She (Christina) stated that we do in fact have a reservation, 3 of them and thus 3 charges. We asked for an adjustment refund for the extra 2 charges explaining what happened. She began to argue with us rudely saying that they do not give refunds, that all purchases are final, regardless of whether we got confirmations. I summarized to Christina that her position on behalf of the Borghese Gallery is that they are knowingly charging us 2 extra times ($75.82 and $75.82) even though we are only here once - she did not disagree and offered no other response. We also took it up with their website contact and were given the same response. We disputed the extra charges with our bank (Bank of America) explaining the entire situation and are awaiting final disposition, but their initial response was that the "charges are considered valid". Gosh, what an UNFAIR situation to the consumer!!!!

Amazing experience. We paid for the guided tour, which was onlty 1.5 euros more than the audio tour. We ended up being the only people on the tour! The guide was wonderful and caused us to notice details we never would have otherwise.

Dreadful to locate. Loved the sculptures and paintings. However, only 2 hours to look at it all, plus nowhere near enough detail about individual pieces given. We were late for our tour despite allowing over an hour to get there. We arrived near the site but the signs were poor or non existent. It is such a shame that the negatives outweigh the positives, I would not go back.
Great collections!. If you are art lovers you shouldn't miss all the treasures in this gallery probably one of the most famous in the world . Too difficult to describe Appreciate by yourselves
dont miss. do not miss the galleria Borghese it is beautiful

Wonderful collection of the works of Bernini. Even a cultural desert is struck by the life in the cold marble created by the master, Bernini - definitely my highlight of any trip to Rome - all set in a magnificent park - if on a brief trip make sure you get to this.....surpasses the Sistine for me!

Intimate museum. This intimate museum is full of Bernini's and other incredible works. The story of how Cardinal Borghese came upon these treasures, and the coruption that was involved. My favorites were Apollo and Daphne by Bernini and Pauline Bonaparte by Canova. Pauline Bonaparte was Napoleon's little sister.

Loved it. Liked how they limited the # of people so that you can appreciate the art. Disliked the tour groups. Something that cannot be controlled. No camera's allowed, I liked it allowed for you to appreciate the art, They have a nice cafe center and gift shop. recommend making morning reservation so that less people are at the Galleria.,

Art lover's delight. The palace itself is a Renaissance jewel. The collection is stunning. For me, it is worth visiting just for the Caravaggio and Bernini masterpieces alone. But there is so much more. Book your tickets online well in advance!

Incredible museum!. This is the best museum in Rome! The sculptures by Bernini are mind-blowing. The talent that man had was incredible! The second floor has many wonderful paintings and the villa itself is beautiful.
You must make reservations in advance and you are allowed only two hours inside. That was enough time for me.

The Gold Standard for Art Museums. Skip the Vatican Museum and visit the Galleria Borghese. Unlike the Vatican Museum, which packs visitors like sardines in a hot and humid can and then herds them through quickly like cattle in a stockyard, the Borghese Gallery has a reservation system that enhances the experience for visitors. You purchase your reservation in advance and simply show up at the appointed time. You can't take photos and you must check your camera and bags before entering. If you don't read Italian, you may wish to purchase an audio guide in your primary language. The art is amazing. The museum is not crowded and you can take your time and enjoy the art at your pleasure. The Borghese Gallery was the highlight of our last trip to Rome.

Beautiful art, a little disorganized. The masterpieces in this gallery are definitely worth seeing. However, it seemed like they had recently made some changes to the arrangement of the gallery and didn't get around to updating the info pages and audio guides. Maybe they'll fix it later. Either way, get your ticket in advance and definitely go - just be aware that you don't have much time to get lost between the statues as you can only stay for 2 hours.

Don't miss this galleria. This is a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours. The sculptures and art are breathtaking and the building itself is kept in immaculate condition. My only complaint is that you are taken through too quickly when the museum is busy, I would have liked to spend longer in each room. The park surrounding the gallery can occupy a whole afternoon if you like walking.
Fantastic!. What a magnificent gallery. Must see these Berninis in person -- really special to see them up that close. First floor is stunning all around -- better than second floor.

So much art in one place!. This place is amazing. The art that is there would take days to look at it all. 2 hours for just the highlights. Besides the art, the history of how it all got to this one collection could be a Hollywood movie.

This is a must - How often do you see art like this?. The art, rooms and general ambience of the Galleria Borghese sets is far above any gallery I have to in Europe. It is small, and intimate. As a result entry is strictly limited, so book tickets in advance or you may not get in. However the true spectacle of the villa is that it was designed by the leading artists and architects of the day, and the rooms are left (mostly) as they were intended to be. The interpretation perfectly corresponds with the masterpieces of sculpture and painting, simply because the art was made to grace the rooms, and the rooms to complement the art. Submerse yourself here for 2 hours - then you have to leave to make room for the next entry. But those 2 hours will be well remembered.
A Must See. This is a must see to first time Rome visitors. The Gallery and the gardens make it very rewarding.

Bernini's Big Hits. The collection is magnificent, with huge Bernini sculptures & many a Caravaggio filling the first floor.Too bad they only allow you in for 2 hrs, before their bouncers bounce you outta there.All it would take to make this a prime experience are people-counters due to the fire safety of those in the paintings gallery. So, get there early, dump your belongings, get the audioguide, and get on your way - so as not to eat in your 120 min mandatory experience.

If you go in no other gallery in Rome, go here. One of the great virtues is that you book ahead for a limited crowd to be admitted for two hours. I leave to you to read the huge amount of information available on the art works.Take a picnic to the gardens (Villa Borghese) if weather permits!

Hidden Treasure. Walked here from the Colisseum area and were pleasantly surprised. Located in a large park area, the gallery was a delight. It was a very pleasant walk through Rome to get here and we were able to see several neighborhoods. The gallery had several exhibits that are worth checking out. Tip: make you reservation online ahead of time. You are able to pick up your tickets at the window. They also have a room to keep your coats and bags that is attended.

Hidden Gem. Gardens would be wonderful in spring or summer, the sculptures & paintings were fabulous & jaw dropping even though Napoleon nicked most of them & they're still in the Louvre.Remember to book a visit.
Because of the History. If you have time, it will be a good experience to visit the Villa. Just make sure to plan ahead and make sure you are aware of the closing times.
Amazing collection of art in a beautiful setting. Seeing the palace was a highlight of our visit to Rome. The park is a nice place to wander around.

Be sure to buy the audio tour. Galleria Borghese is a must-see museum, especially if you enjoy sculpture. If you have not studied art or reviewed a museum guidebook prior to your visit, be sure to buy the audio tour. Allow at least 2.5 hours for the museum. Visitors are required to pick up date/time-specific tickets 30 minutes prior to entrance, so give yourself *plenty* of time to find GALLERIA Borghese, as the VILLA Borghese (property/garden/park) is immense. We're pretty good navigators and walked from our hotel near Piazza del Popolo but made a number of wrong turns along the way.Tips: Be prepared to check your camera and bag/backpack/purse prior to entrance to the galleria. Food and beverages are available on site, but they are expensive. Pack a picnic instead.

Excellent Collection but not everyone’s cup of tea. - NO CAMERAS. Art collection is really excellent if you know what you are looking at but if you are going just to find out what all the fuss is all about then you maybe disappointed. You can spend that time and money somewhere else if art is not your cup of tea.You need to buy a ticket and on top of that you have to book a time slot to view the artwork. It wasn’t as busy as other attractions in Rome like Colosseum and Pantheon. It is a little out of the way as well.Most importantly, you are not allowed to take cameras so you hardly have any memories to take away.There is no facility for buggies and if your child is asleep then you have had it.

Must See in Rome. This was a highlight for my trip - the artwork and sculpture is simply not to be missed. Sculpture includes Apollo and Daphine as well as some of the great paintings by Caravaggio. The Villa is magnificant. Buy the guidebook before going on the tour - it will provide details on each room for you.
wonderful collection of art. wonderful collection of paintings and sculptures in a beautiful setting
Feast your eyes on Caravaggio. Wonderful Caravaggio paintings and beautiful Italian sculpture! Make sure you book a ticket for timed entry.
Nice and quiet area in winter. Very nice area/parc with an excellent view over Rome when you're at the top of the parc!

In the top 3 for art museums. My visit didn't start auspiciously. At the coat check the attendant demanded my handbag in exchange for a plastic bag for my wallet. I fussed but he was relentless. Are visitors really walking off with marble busts in their handbags?! This was also after a high-speed walk to get to the museum 30 minutes ahead of time to pick up the ticket-prebooked online. A lot of drama before you even get through the front door. STILL. Despite the purse/linewait and internet booking hoops, it was worth it. So many exquisite, beautiful pieces. I could have spent the entire 2 hours (yes, you also have a time limit on your visit) on the Bernini sculpture where some goddess turns into a laurel tree. *Do get the audio tour, I didn't and wished I had.
Amazing Bernini sculptures. The Bernini sculptures in this gallery are among the most beautiful things I have ever seen. Excellent audio guide - comprehensive but not overwhelming.

Hard to absorb it all. Full of amazing historic paintings and sculptures, most with a religious theme. No cameras allowed and a 2 hour limit on your stay, forward booking is essential, even in low season.
Must see. The quantity and quality of the exhibits are breathtaking. Do book ahead .
Beautiful art. Only go if you're really into art. Otherwise, skip and spend your time seeing other sites.
Lovely not to be missed. Make sure to check this out. The ceilings are amazing, and the collection is great. Make sure to visit it.

Ooh! Paolina.. Thank god that in 1614 Cardinal Scipione Borghese decided to have his own personal museum and built (by Jan Van Santen, AKA Giovanni Vasanzio) this superb villa in the mist of the Borghese park (at the time an olive grove). Every room is dedicated to an artist or an art period. Unfortunately, you have to make a reservation to visit this jewel. Do rent the audio guide and use it when needed. The visit - with no rush - will take approximately 90 minutes. Everything is beautiful and Canova's Paolina Borghese is just....superb. A must.
Must See. This is by far my favorite museum in the world, its small enough to see in a couple hours but each piece is amazing, if I could I would spend a couple hours in front of each work.
Don't miss it!. Most impressive gallery of the trip. Make reservations as that's the only way to get in. Surrounded by a beautiful park.

Incredible collection of magnificent art. This magnificent museum in the centrally located Vills Borghese gardens is a "must" for art lovers. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth a pilgrimage. Reservations are essential, since fixed numbers of people are admitted only three times a day. Reservations may be conveniently made by phone to English-speaking operators.
Inspired. beautiful museum, fun but boring VERY expensive cafe.
gorgeous!. Beautiful villa, grounds, artwork and helpful staff

Amazing place, rude staff, book before you go.. Amazing. Think it was as amazing ( a building) as the interior of Versailles! Incredible ceilings and marble walls. However. 1) You HAVE to book tickets before you go. The website didn't work on 7-8 repeated attempts ( had to call). 2) You have to turn up 30 min before to pick up tickets and you get there and there is a long line (inside) in 2 places ( other one is to check in bags). If you don't speak Italian and you're wondering if you're going to miss getting you're ticket - don't worry - just ask someone which line to get in. They don't allow photo's and they boot you out in 2 hours ( actually 1 hour and 45 minutes) so if you want to sketch, you have to have an action plan. Only allowed to use toilets with your ticket so don't throw it out at the end. Have fun
Bernini's David. We learned to appreciate Bernini in this museum. We then found that his work is all over Rome, and he should be as famous as Michaelangelo.
villa borgheses. very dissapointed to find limited tour times, with no option to view unnacompanied, would of had to wait three hours for tour so gave it a miss.
Just a park. It's a park, you know. People running, dogs walking. Park it is.

Just be aware. My well traveled sister-in-law said, after her 6th trip to Rome, that the Borghese was Not To Be Missed!!I never got inside so this review is actually an advisory.  The Gallery is closed on Mondays. We had tickets for Tuesday. However, Monday of that week was a public holiday and therefore the Gallery then closed on the Tuesday. We had only just bought the tickets on the Saturday before, so no one was aware that it was closed on a day following a holiday. There were about 50 of us wandering around outside of the place so at least we weren't alone! Any where but Italy it would be surprising that they would sell tickets for a day that a tourist site isnt open, but its not the most organized place. You must book tickets to go there, do make sure you don't book on a day that follows a public holiday.someday I'll get back there!

Stunning. Borghese Gallery is stunning. All the art is exceptionally well presented and Bernini's statues are breathtaking. The gallery limits the time and number of visitors so the crowds aren't overwhelming and you have plenty to time to enjoy the masterpieces. I was particularly struck by Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. The audio tour is very well done and well worth taking.
Incredible!. The art collection is extensive and beautiful, We were drawn to the sculpture of Bernini over and over again. Located on beautiful grounds.
Treasure trove. A treasure trove of art but don't forget to book your tickets on line. Make a day of it and picknic in the Borghese park, Great for families
Definitely worth the reservation. This gallery has amazing pieces of art, it is definitely a must when you go to Rome, if you are interested in art and archeology.
must see. go here first as vatican was crowded and really appreciated the collection and way they keep group small enough so you have time to enjoy each piece- enjoy the park setting too
My love of Bernini. If you like Baroque and Bernini, there is no place like the Borghese.

lovely walk. if the weather is average and you fancy a long stroll in the park this is the place to go, plenty of statues and open space, and the water clock is unusual. it might not be as friendly when it gets dark but during the day it is fine for families
The best!. The Galleria Borghese houses the most wonderful and exciting sculptures and paintings. Berninis Apollo and Daphne touches everyone who sees it!
Excellent museum. This museum has an amazing collection of artwork. Even the building itself is an amazing piece of arwork!

Like in Heaven!. We were astonished by the beauty of this place and we couldn't imagine that in the heart of Rome someone would be able to find a place like Borghese park! There are trees and flowers everywhere, and you can find a huge lake with all kinds of animals splashing in the crystal waters! I strongly urge you to rent a bike (you can do it at the entrance of the park)! If you have spare time, you can also visit the Zoo and the aquarium inside(splendid)!!

Galleria Borghese. Beautiful building. Incredible art collection from the Cortona ceiling fresco to the Caravaggios. That's right, Caravaggios. The Bernini Daphne and Apollo is worth the price of admission alone. Take a stroll through the magnificent park afterwards.
It is A must in Rome sightseen. The Collection is magnificent !! and also the Expositions are always very very interesting
Worth the trip. Most beautiful collection. Be sure to make a reservation in advance
Prosecco in the gardens. There's a cute and comfortable little cafe tucked away in the gardens. Great place to rest your feet,grabe a snack, have a Prosecco and relax. But watch out for the pigeons!

Visit this!. Booked tickets in advance of my trip, and am very glad that I did. There were strict requirements for entry, so be sure to do your research before you try to get in (ditch or check your bags, etc). Many people were delayed entry because they didn't take the time to check their belongings and get their audio guides ahead of time. The collection contains a variety of items, and is well worth the time and admission to see it. Do yourself a favor, and get there early - spend some time in the Villa Borghese prior to the gallery for some relaxation.
Beautiful. This is a wonderful museum that is not to be missed by all art enthusiasts.

Great luck for us. Got in without reservations!. We got Roma Passes that included the Galleria Borghese, but learned too late on a Sunday that reservations were all but a must. Well it was January and early on a Sunday (11AM-1PM showing) so we got in anyway. It seemed to be booked for the 1-3PM showing. We loved the intimate feel of the small setting. The Caravaggio paintings and Bernini statues were amazing and are a must see for any art lover while in Rome. They seem like they are there just for you to see.
Worth the wait to get in. Many wonderful works of art. I like the limited number of people allowed in at a time. The park is also a beautiful walk!

Art at its Best. THis gallery has the most fascinating collection of sculpture. I was absolutely inthralled with the details of the sculpture found in this collection. Make sure you reserve in advance and plan to be there 30 minutes before entry time designated on the ticket. YOu cant take anything into the museum except a book on the museum. Well worth the time and effort.

The most beautiful attraction in Rome. Without a doubt - Galleria Borghese is the most beatiful site available to visit in rome, above all other museums and cathedrals.The Museum is Small and a bit out of the center but most definitley worth a visit with some of the most amazing sculptures and rooms i've seen in my life.When visiting make sure to dedicate as much time as you can to the first floor as the second floor as more about paintings and less impressive.Tip 1 - each room has a plaque explaining in general and a stack of laminated pamphlets explaining every drawing, frascoe and statue that's in that room so no book/guide/previous knowledge is required.Tip 2 - you have to reserve tickets but you can do so easily by phone or by asking your hotel to reserve for you. no reason to buy online as everybody stand in line for their tickets anyway.Tip 3 - visit is restricted to 2 hours - seems like a lot but it's almost not enough so plan your time.tip 4 - pictures are not allowed so consider buying something in the book shop before the start of your tour.

Worth the Wait. On the day I was supposed to visit the gallery (had purchased a pre-booked ticket online - absolutely necessary), it was closed until 3 pm. I was told to return then, which I duly did, then was told that I wouldn't be able to get in until the following morning. I'm really glad I didn't give up on the gallery, because it was entirely worth the wait. The Berninis and Caravaggios alone made the visit worth it, not to mention all the other wonderful art. In addition, there was a special exhibit with the classical pieces that had been sold to the Louvre by Camilo Borghese, Pauline Bonaparte's husband, making their first return in more than 200 years, and in their original locations in the gallery! A few wonderful things about the gallery: 1. access is through a timed ticket, with a limited number of people available in the gallery, which makes it much easier to enjoy the art as there aren't mobs of people in there. 2. even though you only are allowed two hours in the gallery, it's enough time to see everything and do it justice. 3. No photography is allowed, so everyone simply had to look at the pictures/sculptures and enjoy them, instead of just snapping a photo and moving on. 4. It's situated in the beautiful and peaceful Borghese Gardens, a large park which, when you're in the heart of it, hardly seems like it's in the middle of a busy city. It's especially wonderful in the early morning when the only other people there are joggers.
Just perfect. The Gallery in so nice and well organized. The way of getting tickets is a bit difficult.

Take the time to go see this incredible gallery.. The Berninis are worth the trip alone - Apollo and Daphne was absolutely breathtaking. Definitely try to get a tour of the place with an expert as the history of the building is as interesting as the artwork it holds. Our tour guide was booked through my study abroad program, but I am sure there are other options.This may not be the first thing that comes to mind for must-see attractions in Rome, but it was a top five favorite place I visited while in Rome!

Appointment required but well worth it!. My husband and I are novice art lovers but thoroughly enjoyed the visit to this unique gallery. Spend the 5 euro and get a recorded tour guide. Very informative on the key pieces of art in each room. Take comfy shoes as you will slowly wander this house for a while without much seating. Appointments were essential, our hotel manager arranged ours. Extremely glad we went.

Better even than the Vatican Museum. Loved it loved it loved it. So beautiful - the trompe l'oeil murals on the ground floor, the Bernini statues... hard to find in the park though, the signposts vanished! You need to book online first and keep to a specific time. Oh and they take your bags away at reception which is a bit frightening - you get them back.
Unparalleled Beauty. The Villa and Galleria Borghese located in the park is a beautiful classic example of the spendor that is Rome.

Wow. Seeing all the works in their "natural setting" was incredible. I really like this museum but I think a guide would be a valuable addition to your visit if you can afford it. My sister and two teenage sons wandered about for the two hours and while there is some information provided on cards throughout the museum I would have really loved to have more information.
beautiful exhibits. I liked the gardens and the sculpture the best. The rooms were well designed for the display.
Do not miss. Need reservations for two- hour visit. Get there early and buy the guided tour
not so easy to get in. It worths to got there but they do not answer the phone to book a date. Finally we got there, and there were free places (in March!), paintings ar excellent!

Our Favourite Rome Gallery. We are a family with 3 teenagers. We know virtually nothing about art. We loved the Borghese Gallery. The statutes are stunning, including the famous Apollo chasing Daphne by Bernini. For me, every bit the equal of David in Florence. But again, I'm no art historian. I just know what I like. You will appreciate the fact that the admit only limited numbers of people at one time. It allows for a much more enjoyable viewing experience than, say, the Vatican Museum. Unlike the Vatican, a guided tour isn't necessary, but the audio tour was very good (just don't let your 13 yr old son swing the handset by its strap in the bust gallery - the strap comes off - but don't worry...nothing broke). And the Borghese Gardens around the gallery make for a nice walk afterwards. In my opinion, this is an absolute must see while in Rome.
Great Art. If you can only see one museum while in Rome, go here. Incredible collection.
A good walk. Other than being a decent walk away from the traffic noise, the gardens were disappointing and slightly scruffy, maybe it was the time of year but not one of romes finest sides.

Well worth the effort. You have to book ahead these days and are only allowed two hours to visit, however this is all well worthwhile as the gallery contains the most fantastic collection of sculpture, both roman and barroque with Berninis and the famous Canova statue of Paulina to the fore. The villa itself is stunning, particularly the ceilings, which illustrate the art of tromp d'oie and its evolution.TIP....go early and buy from the shop the Guide by K H Fiore, read the introduction whist waiting to get in and use the guide to understand the ceilings.
A worthwile visit. Great place to visit. Interesting exhibition and great enviroment
Incredible. possibly best thing about Rome, worth going to the city just for this alone, Bernini's sculptures are simply outstanding.
Very good museum.. The villa is amuseum for roman art mostly scuptures and very good paintings of the 1500 and 1600.
Just renovated, go for the frescoes if not for the art. I loved the Raphael frescoes adorning the exhibition rooms

Top 5 MUST SEE in Rome". I am not an art guru nor were my friends...but this place is amazing. Of all the museums we visited in our 3 weeks in Italy this was the best and our favorite. The Bernini statues will take your breathe away. We took the private tour with a guide, I highly recommend it - we learned about the art but also stories of the artists that were informative and also were hysterical. I became a Bernini lover, and wanted to see everything he did for the rest of the trip...even hauled a HUGE Bernini art book all the way home. I almost skipped the Borghese but it was one of my favorites and when I am back in Rome I will visit again. We walked around Villa Borghese afterwards...beautiful place also, even has a zoo. Of, you have to check your bags, no cameras allowed...they have it down to a science in efficiency.

Definitely worth the visit!. My family and I visited here back in August. Being an art lover, this was one of the places I had really wanted to visit, and I wasn't disappointed at all! Even my parents who aren't huge art fans really enjoyed the gallery. Bernini's statues were definitely the highlight. It absolutely mind boggling how much detail he carved from marble using a chisel!!! I felt as if I could stare at them all day. The only downside was that you weren't allowed to bring your camera and take pictures.
Top art!. Nice museum (not perfectly organised - in an Italian way) but worth a visit; especially the top floor (paintings) - but don't forget that in busy periods you have to pre-book entry

"Definitely worth the visit". Visiting the Galleria Borghese was one of the things that my husband really wanted to do. Originally, I half heartedly agreed but I am so glad that we did. The works of art were wonderful and the entire park area was quite relaxing and away from the bustle of Rome. Our tour was booked through Rome in the Dark and our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the masterpieces. I would highly recommend it.

Much of the art was under cover. This hard-to-get-to-by-walking museum was a bit of a disappointment. After making a reservation in advance, the staff was indifferent to our questions. Much of the statuary was covered and the main hall was under renovation and could not be viewed. Although we used the Roma Pass, the cost of admission and audio tours would add up.

Amazing. It's amazing as almost everything in Italy. It's another great place to dive into history. There you'll enjoy fantastic building, gardens and, of course, art. In order to get to it you'll have to enjoy Villa Borghese park. And thus you'll get 2 amazing sites in one place.

Bernini Paradice!. This is a gem of an art museum. Appreciated that you had to book to visit it and only small groups allowed at any given time. The location in the park also is a treat afterwards and it is only a 20 minute to Piazza del Popolo.

High Italian Sculpture Art - Not to be missed. Spectacular Italian art with lots of Bellini and othersIt is located in a garden on the north part of Rome. It's a bit of a bother to get there but if you are visiting the Spanish steps, you can probably walk over (20-30 minutes walk north) You need to reserve your place online and get there just a bit earlier. You are limited to only 2 hours at a time. The museum actually makes you wait and line up in the lobby until your appointed time to let you in. You need to check your bags in. I wished it was a bit longer but it was enough to at least get a brief primer of the major pieces of art there. Because of the popularity of this museum, the crowds is still quite sizable. I would recommend going upstairs first when you enter before coming downstairs to finish up the rest of the exhibits. Most of the crowd floods into the first floor when you first get in and you won't get much of a view. I wouldn't spend more than 45 minutes upstairs as the most important art work are downstairs.
Beautiful. Stunning works and the park is absolutely beautiful.

Well Worth the Trip!. The statues in the Borghese are not to be missed! The Apollo and Daphne by Bernini was the best work of marble I have ever seen, and my daughter's favorite piece of art in Rome and Florence. The palazzo itself is stunning and full of wonder.
Un esempio.. Un esempio di Museo italiano ben gestito e mantenuto. Meraviglioso il primo piano con le sculture del Bernini, altrettanto bella la pinacoteca al secondo piano. Da vedere assolutamente.
Advance booking. You have to book 2 week in advance. Don't risk it as we fail to get it because no booking.........:(

beautiful palazzo in elegant park. wonderful statues and paintings collection in a beautiful setting. made me feel happy, honoured, horny and hungry. Luckily we brought some excellent pizza to eat in the park afterwards.

CARAVAGGIO E BERNINI, cosa vuoi di piu'?. Effettivamente viene da chiedersi: ma cosa vuoi di piu' da un piccolo museo?Galleria Borghese è un piccolo incredibile contenitore di capolavori. Non troverai la folla del Vaticano, devi prenotare perchè è a numero chiuso ed hai 2 ore per visitarlo. Ti sarà poi chiesto di accomodarti fuori perchè un altro gruppo di visitatori deve entrare: questo è grandioso! Ottima organizzazione. Puoi godere l'arte che stai ammirando senza essere disturbato da voci, chiasso persone che ti spingono....Pensate che in una stanza ci sono ben 6 dipinti del grande Caravaggio...è incredibile! I dipinti di Caravaggio sono sparsi in tutto il mondo e noi ne abbiamo 6 in una stanza...Figo!Scultura: BERNINI (figlio)- Il ratto di Proserpina potrebbe rubarvi anche 20/25 minuti....è cosi' reale che ti viene da toccarlo ( ma non farlo!) ed è quello che la gente del suo tempo era solita fare, incredula dinanzi a cotanta verità!Non posso elencare tutte le straordinarie bellezze presenti nel museo....Insomma chiamate e prenotate una visita...vale la pena....è straordinario ragazzi!
Beautiful. A must see when you're in Rome.. Very interesting and ancient.. You step into history when you're in Rome but avoid in Summertime du to excessive heat
Amazing. The statuary is wonderful and the walk through the park is nice. Take the metro and look for the tiny signs.

For lovers of art. Go to view some of the best Bernini statutes and other famous statues and paintings. Go not just for the art, but for the fantastic building itself that houses the works of art. Even views out the windows to the gardens appeal to the senses.

Sculptures, Gardens, and a Surprise Treat. What I didn't like: after getting your ticket, you MUST take your bags to the cloakroom, however, you can take everything out of yours bags and put them into one. It's rather strange. Once inside though...What I did like: the detailed summaries of each room on only one placard. Learning something new....that Bonaparte had ties to the Borghese family and that interesting history that goes along with that. And lastly, the Barberini sculptures...well, you'll just have to see for yourself...it kind of blows your mind the detail he was able to create.On a side note: at the bottom of the gardens there is a Cafe. It's part of the cinema. We stumbled across it and had the most delicious buffet for only 25 euros each (including dessert and drinks...bottled water and wine)

Over the top art collection, gaudy and extraordinary. Worth the pre-arrival reservation hassle/expense. Some of the best pieces found anywhere. But one must overlook how the artwork was acquired..........

A must see!!!. This beautiful gallery is an absolute must see while you are in Rome. It is surrounded by lovely gardens where you can grab a snack from a street vendor before or after your tour of the gallery. It houses amazing sculptures including a scandalous one of Napoleon's sister and Bernini's famous Apollo Chasing Daphne.

The Best small museum in the world.. Stay in the room with the Bernini's, Daphne and Apollo, and The Rape of Persephone, for as long as you can. You will never see anything like them in marble anywhere ever again.

Fabulous Art in a Gorgeous Palazzo. Be sure and make reservations ahead of time on the website or by telephone! You won't forget visiting a beautiful home filled with art by Bernini, Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. You'll need every minute of your allotted two hours.
Beautiful Paintings and wonderful Gardens. I personally enjoyed the exhibit and the elegant gardens. Its a definite "must see" if you are in Rome.

Wonderfull collection. I love this collection, I come in Rome quit often, and every now and then I go here. You have to make a reservation in advance. Especially in busy times. The staf is quit rude, as often in Rome. Don't get offended by it. You come here for high quality art.

too many covered statues. The villa was exquisite; thoroughly enjoyed walking its grounds. We were disappointed with the Galleria....very cold staff who refused to help us call a cab. Most of the statues were wrapped in shrouds but no one would explain to us why. Some of the paintings were very beautiful. Website indicated that a timed reservation would be required so we booked the time we thought we could do. Meant that we had to wait over an hour for our entry even though the museum was very lightly attended that day and could've easily accommodated us a little earlier.

Well worth the time to visit!. This was our third trip to Rome and we wanted to see something different. I am so glad that we purchased tickets (they must be purchased in advance--we used the internet at home) to see the Galleria. I was amazed at the amount of art housed here. My favorite is the Bellini statues. They are breathtaking. Give yourself an extra hour to find the galleria inside the Villa Borghese. You can visit the Galleria for two hours.
Fantastic---don't miss it!. WOW---one of the most fantastic museums I have visited anywhere in the world (and I have visited 123 countries).
Great Caravaggios. Wonderful collection but especially good for its collection of paintings by Caravaggio

Incredible museum, Bernini sculptures were the highlight. This museum is very strict on the number of people who are in the museum at any one time and how much time they can spend in the museum. We ended up taking a tour which I think would be the best way to visit the museum, as you hit the major pieces and get the stories around them as well. We used Dark Rome tours and paid around $60 a person that also included a walk around the gardens too (FYI I think tickets are 9 euro a person and 5 euro for an augioguide if you want to try it on your own). One important thing to notwe is that tickets do sell out, so if you want to do it on your own be sure to reserve them in advance. My favorite were the four Bernini sculptures in the Borghese, and after visiting Florence and seeing many Michalangelo sculptures, Bernini is still the best. It is just amazing what he did with pieces of marble, my favorite sculpture was Pluto and Proserpina. There are also several Caravaggio paintings along with some Rubens and a Raphael. Overall a great collection and we really enjoyed the time we spent there. Important to note it is forbidden to take pictures in the museum which is a shame. In our whole trip we learned that many museums "forbid pictures" but in pretty much all cases it is bc of merchandizing, and in almost all of them you can still take picutres, you just need to be sly about it and do no flash. This museum has people in every room and I wouldn't reccamend trying to take any pictures here.

Amazing!. I really enjoyed my tour of the gallery. I loved that I had to sign up in advance, to limit admittance, which ensured there weren't hordes of tourists obscuring my access to all the amazing works of art. 2 hours is plenty of time to see everything and to go back to revisit your favorites, which I did for Bernini's 'Rape of Proserpina', which was breathtaking. I wish that there were tours offered through the museum, or if there were, they weren't publicized. But there were helpful card plaques in each room to identify paintings a bit more.Overall, awesome visit!

Wonderful museum.. Be sure to reserve your tickets ahead of time. You can arrive 15-20 minutes after your ticket time and avoid the crush of people at the start of the assigned time. Most people would still have enough time to see all the sights.

Wonderful. Our host Luca suggested to visit this Gallery as it is considered one of the best private collection of the entire world . He booked for us the tickets, they gave him a reservation code and you have to be there 30 minutes in advance of the scheduled visit.Only Bernini sculptures worth the ticket ! Highly recommended !

Great gallery and grounds some treasures. Being a disabled traveller its always refreshing to find somewhere that helps. If like me you are on crutches but get tired easily they helpfully provide a wheel chair on each floor but there is not access if you are wheelchair bound. You have to negotiate down steps to the entrance and then take the very old lift to the floors escorted by staff, the lift doors are very narrow. Otherwise well worth a visit and good value especially as disabled people and their carers get in free!
Book ahead to avoid disappointment. Unfortunately we didn't know to book ahead and it was sold out for several days. Book a week ahead during peak season. Grounds were lovely.
Sculpture. Exquisite pieces of sculpture by Benini and in excellent condition. The marble is chiselled so fine that it is almost transparent.

Wonderful sculptures, booking required. I especially liked the collection of sculptures that the gallery - and they have a lot! Booking is required (up to two days ahead in peak season - we booked day before in December though).

Magnificent park with my favourite museum. You can walk for hours in this tranquil place in the middle of room. And then enjoy the most wonderful pieces of art, paintings and sculptures of many Italian masters like Michelangelo, Raffaelo, Bernini, Botticelli and so many more.

Buy ticket online at least 2 days beforehand. The most stunning historical artwork that gave me goosebumps!!! I did not have a tour guide though, which I totally regret. I did not get to hear the significance of the pieces that I somewhat recognised and felt the experience would have been enhanced a TON if I had done that.
Great sculpture collection. In the middle of a beautiful park. A little hard to find but worth the hunt.

The best art, but terrible organization.. No maps in English that day. Rooms were not easily understood, and the plastic cards available in some rooms were disorganized. Audio guide of only limited use.

Amazing. The gallery is amazing, it's small bit filled with wonderfull pieces. The Bernini statues were worth every penny.You have to book the ticket in advance and come half an hour before your schedueled time, the gallery is a bit away from city center so it must be taken into account.The entrance to the gallery is on top of the flight of stairs, but the ticket office is douwnstairs so first you have to go down take the ticket leave all your bags and then go up.The gallery is located in a beutiful park so it is nice to strall around and enjoy it.
Loved Bernini. We read somewhere that if you have time for only one museum in Rome, this is the one to see. Could not agree more. Wonderful collection of Bernini's work.

Nice art gallery but people were a little unfriendly. The Villa Borghese is worth seeing with much beautiful art work. However it was probably the only place in Rome where the help was not friendly. Everyone seemed to have a bit of an attitude problem and did not go out of their way to answer questions or help you

Interesting. The building itself and the works of art were spectacular, but the audio guide and map need fine-tuning. We were limited to a 2-hour visit. The numbers on the map and on the various works of art did not match up easily. We had to look carefully for the numbers ,and when you don't have much time, it can get stressful.

Very nice scupltures and art. Having the self guided tour with the earphones was great. Beautiful pieces inn the museum. Have to check in all bags and cameras. The museum is in the middle of this gorgeous park that you can walk, have a picnic, rent bikes and segways. My favorite is renting the paddle boat on the pond in the middle of the park. Very romantic!
definitely a must. if you are in rome this museum should be visited. all the pieces of bernini are breathtaking. if you have time, go there with the bus number 910 from termini station.
Watch your time... Love the Galleria just not enough time to see and admire it all.

Beautiful museum. I spent 3 months travelling Italy to visit museums. Galleria Borghese is one of the most beautiful I have seen. I appreciated the fact you need a reservation (free) to enter. It limits to number of visitors and you can take your time to enjoy the art. The gardens aroung the Galleria are also worth visiting.

An absolute must in Rome. controlled access means that you are not fighting huge crowds and a very pleasant experience- electronic guides are a must and very good - the room full of Carravagios is just the best thing ever, as well the Bernini's, Raphaels the list goes on.. It was the highlight of Rome for me and it's set in a great park.book a few days in advance online as tickets sell out.

Must See Bernini Sculptures. Be sure to book reservations in advance. Walk around the Bernini sculptures and be humbled by the sculptor's genius to create such dynamic, 360 degree movement from a piece of rock.

don't miss it. we love rome,we love vatican , sixtine chapelle and san peter's church but galleria borghese is in our soul memory more than anything else.don't forget to book your tickets in advance ,otherwise you have to go to rome once more,

Impressive museum...endless lines. Borghese should be high on list of museums to see in Rome but they need better system. Even with the required advance reservations the lines were ridiculous. The surrounding park was less stressful.

Very interesting. I liked that you need to make an appointment to visit the museum. I also appreciated that they stuck to the 2 hour limit. Two hours to see everything was just enough and I didn't feel rushed. It's a little confusing about which door to go into to get your entrance ticket and audio guide. It the door on the ground floor. Once you get all that, go back outside and up the steps. Definitely get the audio guides. It's worth it. A very nice, large park to enjoy is right next door.

Spectacular. I've never seen anything like the art work and scuptures in this museum. A walk around the grounds is a must when visiting Rome as well. But book this ahead of time. There was a 4 day wait otherwise.

Close and worth the visit. Paintings and pieces were excellent! I wish we could have taken pictures. Our favorites were the marble sculptures by Bernini... such detail! Make sure to buy tickets in advance to skip the lines. We got ours through www.selectitaly.com.

Stunning museum - but be sure to arrive well before your reservation!. Leave plenty of extra time to both get here and then figure things out once you do. Especially if you have a reservation later than 9 AM. It took us till almost 9 to walk all the way up to the gallery, and then we were quite confused as to where to go once we had our tickets. The tickets advise that entry is on the second floor, which makes you think to go back outside and up the stairs to what appears to be the second-floor (as multiple people were doing at 9 when we were there). This is not correct. The guided tours start downstairs where you get your tickets, next to where you pick up the audio guides (which is in the adjoining room to where you pick up tickets with reservations). Also, once you have figured this all out, you need to proceed to the checking counter and have them lock-up all bags, cameras, phones, etc before you can go on the tour. This gets VERY backed up, especially after 9AM, so allow extra time for this. At any rate, we were quite confused and had little time to figure this all out, so we missed the start of the guided tour and were on our own to explore the museum. Tip 2 = bring a watch. You are allowed two hours inside the museum with no clocks to be found anywhere, and they have you check your phones and cameras when you arrive. A watch is a smart choice here! We were left guessing, though somehow managed to finish up around 4 minutes before we needed to leave. Even without the guided tour or the audio guide, it was a very enjoyable visit. They have sheets of information in every room to tell you about the art within that room, so pick one of those up when you enter each room if you don’t have a tour. All that being said, I cannot describe how stellar this museum is. Simply breathtaking. Not to be missed! Just leave yourself plenty of time beforehand!

Best museum we visited. Absolutely loved it, especially that they limit the crowd so you can actually see the artwork. Get the audio tour, even if it's a little tricky to figure out what artwork they're talking about.

bernini at his peak. carvaggio is there also, but the high point are the 3 great bernini sculptures: david, apolo and daphne and my favorite the rape of persefone by Hades. incredible realism and capo lavoro of barroco.

An art lovers PARADISE! Not to be missed. Reservations are required.. If you love art, don't miss this venue!The Borghese gallery (lying just outside the Porta Pinciana, lwithin the beautiful Villa Borghese Park) , was built in the early 1600's to house the art collection of Cardinal Scipione Borghese. This is a stunning collection of classic and antique art (both paintings and sculpture). The sculptures by Bernini and Canova are simpy stunning.Reservations are a must! You can reserve online and print-out your vouchers. Since your entrance to the gallery is a timed admittance, the gallery is not crowded. At first we balked at a timed entry, thinking we would not have adequate time to spend admiring the art. However, the limited entry turned out to be a very good concept as the gallery was not crowded allowing close inspection of all the works.

Very nice museum if you love Rennaisance era. Galleria is located in the best place of Rome, inside Villa Borghese. It is a very nice museum with many alternative and not-so-famous renaissance painters. It worths to visit it, but keep in mind that you have to go at least 1 hour before to buy the tickets.
Quaint museum. Nice, quaint museum in the Villa Borghese park, not far from the original Roman fortified wall. Nice park as well.
Amazing pieces.. I'd say it is better than museo Vaticano. Some really amazing pieces. Yes, you have to book in advance but it's totally worth it.

Blew me away. I was reluctant to deal with booking a ticket to this gallery/palace. We had been in Italy for two weeks and had seen so many incredible sites, that I was numb to the idea of having to book a specific time for a site that limited you to a two hour visit. Fortunately, my wife wanted to go, and I requested our hotel to book us for 3:00 p.m. on Sunday afternoon. We took the subway to the piazza on the west end of the Borghese Park, and decided to stroll our way across the entire park to arrive at the gallery. It was such a lovely day, and we enjoyed seeing all the local people enjoying their park with families. Lots of kids playing, picnics, and bicycle carriages that you could share with 4 to 6 people, rolling throughout the park. Then when we got to the gallery, it was an easy check-in. We then realized we were at one of the most incredible art collections in the world. The facility is very doable in 2 hours, but if you are an art buff, you'll want to go back for more. If you are going in high tourist season, you best book weeks ahead. It is an art pilgrimage worth trekking to, and the Carravagio paintings and Bellini sculptures will blow you away!
Easy to visit. Easy to get to beautiful grounds to relax in and the gallery is like all of Rome full of history

Amazing but they don't care about the visitors' experience.. We had been told that if there were one museum to visit, this was it. It is beautiful but the experience as a whole was disapointing. They are undergoing important refurbishments that reduced our enjoyment of this beautiful place. We understand that repair work has to be done but there is a way to do them so the visitors can still enjoy themselves. There were wooden crates all over the place, many sculptures were covered with blankets and several areas were simply closed off. They should warn us and possiby reduce the price of the admission. We felt we were visiting a home when people have just moved in the same day and are not ready to receive visitors! The sculptures were amazing but most of the time you couldn't see them properly because of all the barriers and crates. They had closed off a main part of an exceptional room because a large crew was filming some sort of restauration on a scultpure. Why didn't they do this after hours? Please reduce the cost of the admision or advise your visitors as this had an impact on our visit.

lovely museum!. They have a couple of Bernini sculptures, my favorite is the Pluto e Proserpina. The only bad thing was that they make you check in any type of purse and no photos are allowed, also you only have 2 hours to see everything! But i think if they didn't do that the museum would get very crowded. Overall, I highly recommend a visit to this museum!

Graceful. The galleria hosts some of the most magnificant scultures. The villa is so beautiful that you can stay on the grounds and just enjoy the landscape after visiting the museaum. One of my favorite places.
Wonderful setting. Enjoyed the total experience. Had reservations and found the procedures very well organized. Lovely museum and grounds with a well displayed collection.

Full of history. Check out this museum. You can't take photos and must check your bags to enter. Also you need to reserve your tickets online before you go there or else good luck. If you're from the USA go during Thanksgiving Weekend if you can swing it. Much less crowds and not hot. Just need a light jacket.

Book first but also get there early. Book first but also get there early. We had booked for 10.30 but our entry time was 11. Not too bad but we hung around. Lovely walk through the gardens and a bus to jump on if you're tired!
A must see. This is a wonderful museum in a beautiful part of town.

Outstanding. Wow this place was great, so much history, make sure you get there 1/2 hour before your time slot.i thought that with our reservation that you can arrive within that 2 hour window. But that is not how it was. You only have 2 hours to view the museum. As the group you are with all goes in and comes out at the same time. This is just a FYI. Make sure you get the audio, it makes is so much more interesting as things are explained. Some really beautiful pieces here. Afterwards you have the whole grounds to explore, including the zoo. My wife and I rented a bike and we were able to explore the whole area. I feel my review doesn't give this place the great review it deserves. But this place was #1 of our Rome trip

Glad I finally went!. A fabulous collection of art, and although I had been in Rome three times before, missed it, but got to see it this time. Not disappointed! the star of the collection is Canova's "Venus reclining", a life size statue said to be Paulina Borghese, who was one of the sisters of Napoleon.
Most Excellent. Incredible art for an reasonable price, one of the places in Rome I visit each time

Loved it. The galleria is housed in a beautiful building inside the park of villa Borghese. A pre booking is required . It contains paintings and sculptures. I Loved Bernini’s sculptures. They are brilliant. My favorite is Apollo and Daphne. I could stay there all day looking at them.

Brilliant!. This is really one of the major sites of Rome, it was the family manse of the Borghese, and it's filled with absolutely terrific and comprehensive art, covering all sorts of time periods. The Bernini sculptures are absolutely breathtaking, and the Caravaggios are amazing. The grounds are marvelous, too-a really lovely place, quite magical. The secret gardens are fabulous, with the citrus trees and the aviary..We had a wonderful time, but it was quite exhausting, the whole Palace took us about three hours to see-sneak upstairs, as we did, and enjoy! You won't regret it. I miss it already.
Don't miss this!. Best art museum we've ever been to, among beautiful park as well.

One of the greatest little known museums of the world. What's not to like about the Galleria Borghese? Its great location in a wonderful building, just the right size for a visit that will not tire you, and its wonderful collection of art masterpieces, make it impossible not to love it. The Bernini marbles alone are worth the visit -- only a great master could render flesh in marble in such realistic way. Do go at once!
exquisite art. If only to see Bernini's "Apollo and Diana" I would have come. This will take your breath away. Did not like having only 2 hours to view everything, needed another hour.

Great gallery-worth to be seen!!!!Don't forget to make reservation!!. It is quite tricky to go there, we used metro-underground but because there is a big park we get a bit confused. You must make a reservation one or two days before(maybe you could do it earlier,I don't know) to see it. Prices: full ticket 8.50euro, reduced 5.25, free 2euro(!!then why they call it ''free'??')-check at the museum's site for more information about the tickets.It is very interesting with a lot of exhibits to see!I would suggest to take the headset with the information- is very useful to understand what you see!The annoying part is that you can't take any photo:(If you have time you can have a walk to the beautiful garden in the garden of Galleria.

a must-see!!. Probably the best Museum we did in Rome, (and we did a lot), especially the sculptures of Bernini are incredible. Make sure you book in advance (we just asked our receptionist the day we checked in), then the visit is 2 hours only. Our advice is to go directly to the second floor, to spend 45 minutes there, and then spend the rest of the time at the ground level.
Great Bernini showcase. Bernini statues were excellent. A little out of the way but definitely worth visiting. Surrounded by a nice garden area.

Bernini's 'Apollo and Daphne' , David' and 'Pluto and Persephone' are unmissable.. The main attractions for us were the work of Bernini who was a genius and whose work perhaps more than anyone's defines the Rome that we see today.

Overhyped, but quite good. After visiting the Vatican and the Uffizi in Florence, this wasn't too exciting for us. The art pieces are without a dobut impressive, and the galleria is designed in a very unique way - Every little piece or free space is highly decorated and fantastic to watch.The Galleria is quite small, you won't need more than 2 hours to thoroughly explore it, however, the Villa Borghese gardens outside the Galleria are splendid; be sure you don't miss a stroll in the gardens (Which could consume some time as well). The Galleria is quite impressive and is probably a must for the art lovers. However, I can't say it would fit even my top 10 must see spots for the casual tourist trying to get a taste of Rome.

So So...... If I visited this again, I would take a tour. We took the audio tour and found it frustrating. It was difficult to match up the audio portion with the rooms/artwork we were looking at. The Borghese is not that easy to get to, and unless you are very much into art (which we aren't), I think there are other sites that would have been a better use of our time.

Art Lovers Only. This is an expensive museum at the far end of the city. If you are into art, by all means go. However, if you are just going b/c you think you should (like we did) you'll end up wasting money. There are some beautiful paintings and sculptures, but for the price tag and limitations (you have to make reservations) I'm not sure I would return. The gardens surrounding it were beautiful (and free)
Not enough time. They herd your through too fast to see everything.

really nice place. Its located in big park 10 minutes walk after Spanish Steps. Souranded by this lovely park and fancy garden. You need to book entrence online on their webside, as they are letting only limmited amouth of people in at the time and you are allowed 2hours in. I think it costed 12euros. The only thing that i disliked was the way paintings were exposed It was a bit over the tip. Every single cm of that place is well decorated. At some point your eyes are too tired :) Originaly this place was home of of of well situated prists, nethew of the pope He was collecting all types of art, and had plenty of money to do so. Definitely not a modest place.
Great Museum! The Bernini's are Fabulous!. Don't worry about the 2 hour limit. It is sufficient. Make the reservations ahead of time for sure.

Amazing even for the uncultured amongst us. Amazing, would never have gone if we didn't see that it was the number one thing to do on Trip advisor. Really interesting and the audio guide was great. Not normally an arty person, but really told you the stories of the sculptures. Make sure you arrive at the start of your time though as after 2 hours they do throw everyone out finished or not. We went for the 9am on Sunday slot, which was a bit brutal, but was nice and empty for our walk around, the 11am bunch coming in looked absolutely mobbed. If you have the Roma Pass this will get you in as one of your two free items, but you do still have to phone ahead to reserve (they do speak English, option 2 when you call!) Oh they are doing some moving around of the artwork, so the entrance hall is a bit under covers, but still brilliant, so much to see!

Do Not Miss!. The most beautiful sculpture in the world set in a spectacular former country palace surrounded by gardens and miles of a beautiful park, filled with sculpture, fountains, restaurants, bikes and families. Lovely small snack bar and gift shop. You have to check your purse and backpak here, so be forewarned.
Bernini!. Bernini and Caravaggio in the same building, what is there not to like!
Borghese museum. Astounding art treasures, but cameras are not allowed.
Art in a great setting. It is set in a very large park, a nice break from the hustle of Rome. Tickets must be purchased on-line in advance.
Our trip to Rome. not impressive, too little description, perhaps for art lovers would appreciate it more

If you have time for only one museum, choose this. Beautiful small museum with an incredible collection of Bernini sculptures and wonderful paintings. Buy your tickets on line and get there 1/2 hour early to pick them up.

The Gallery Is #1 of Things to Do in Rome For A Reason. The gallery is number one because of the outstanding sculptures and paintings. We had no problem getting online tickets (reservations are required) and for an extra five euro per person we got an hour and a half English speaking tour (my grandson and I were the only people on the tour). They still had tickets available for 0900-1100 the day of our visit (late November).
Top art. Fabulous art collection with top Bernini statues and great paintings, very worth while visiting due to compact overall size. Mind the necessity for reserving a visitor "slot"!

What's not to like?. Beautiful artwork, beautiful setting. If the weather is nice, the park the museum is located in makes for a beautiful walk before or after. Must reserve, and show up at the time you are told to be there. Caravaggio, Bernini and so much more. Go!

Mindblowing statues. You do have to book the hotel reception staff reserved tickets for us.You are not allowed to take any bags cameras etc in with you.The statues are fantastic and there are guide notes in each room

Exclusive place!. We succeeded to visit galleria Borghese only in our second visit to Rome (reserve tickets before!) and it was amazing expirience. A lot of breathtaking Bernini masterpieces and other great art works. The place itself also very lovely and there is a big park to walk and enjoy the nature and the silence.
Tremendous art that you can practically touch. No waiting and limited crowds.. Great access and very easy to enter. Can be done in less than 2 hours
Electric bus 116. Take the electric bus 116 practically to the museum - then walk down to Spanish Steps . . . but it is not clearly marked!
Currently partly under construction. Part of the statues covered in plastic, but still worth a visit!
Boring Borghese. We thought this was less interesting than many other places in Rome. Depends whether or not you like that sort of picture.

Call ahead but worth the trip. This is a bit off of the beaten path but easily within metro range. The weeks of art are exceptional especially the sculptures by Bernini. If you are looking for a few hours away from the crowds but want to stay engaged in the arts, this is the place.

A paradise for sculpture lovers. Appolo & Daphane was one of the sculptures I have been dreaming for seeing, as I was amazed when I first saw a picture of it in a magazine when I was a kid. I am shocked again at Borghese when I really saw it. It was just perfect. A lot of other amazing scultures and paintings as well. Not that easy to find the gallery, even after you are in the Villa Borghese.

Worth a visit. They only let a set amount of people in so you need to call to book ahead. Go early at 9am and you will not have to queue (in Novemeber at least). Get a guided tour for 6 Euro (audioguide was 5 Euro), it was worth the extra euro.
Lovely museum.. Great museum, had an excellent guide from Walks of Italy.

The Borgese Art Collection. For me this was the highlight of the art galleries we visited. The Bernini statues were amazing and the Cavaggio paintings were overpowering. We went on a guided tour with Dark Rome tours which made it special. Afterwards you can wander through the park and reflect on your experience.
Great art collection. Nice audio guides. Book in advance by phone. A bit far from other tourist sights.

very civilised. You must book as the gallery limits the numbers per time slot which means you have a very nice time when you get in as there are never too many people. YOu can be alone in a room with all this fantastic art - it is amazing
A wonderful Villa full of exceptional art!. The villa is a gem located in Rome. The art collection is exceptional and the grounds are beautiful

Unmissable. This is as good an experience as you can get in a museum - sensational surroundings, extraordinary contents and very good information - provided you use the audio guides for €5. A number of items out on the road when we visited; similarly some serious restoration under way in a couple of rooms. I recognise we made a good call by going for the first two hour slot on a November Sunday morning - while busy it wasn't unpleasant. As we left after two hours, the atmosphere was distinctly more frenetic for a second session which they said had sold out. So be prepared for a different kind of experience when it's hot and/or very crowded.

Great gallery tucked away in a beautiful park. Finally managed to visit the Borghese Gardens - a delightful place for a quiet stroll. Gardens are vast & the Galleria Borghese tucked away in one corner. We pre-booked through the hotel concierge - you cannot just arrive & hope to get in. November is hardly high season & our 'group' at one in the afternoon was quite substantial. I assume in July, August, September you would want to book as early as you could. One other point to note: you basically cannot take anything but yourself inside the building - everything must be left at the cloak room. On the day we visited many people were barred entrance (after waiting in the queue) because they hadn't checked their belongings in. As far as we could see there was no noticeable sign on the exterior of the building, and as the entrance to the gallery is at ground level & the cloakroom at basement there is no great connection between the two. So. The gallery. I think it would be well worth the admittance just to see the two major Bernini sculptures. Both works: Proserpina being abducted by Pluto, and Daphne escaping Apollo are really tour-de-forces. My partner does not claim any deep artistic taste & was blown away by the Berninis. I have seen them previously only as images in books - this was definitely a case of the real thing being miles better than any image could hope to convey.Canova's saucy statue of Napoleon's sister is not too shabby either...One of the major Caravaggio's was on loan to Moscow, but there was plenty else to catch your attention - not forgetting the building itself: it is almost impossibly decorated - like a mini-Versailles.Plenty of 'biggies' to be seen: Raphael, Titian, Rubens, Coreggio. My favourite though was probably the beautiful Cranach work of Venus & Cupid.The pluses I saw were that allowing people in at specific times & in specific sized groups meant that you did not feel that awful crush of bodies that ruins so many galleries. I also thought the relatively small size of the gallery meant a less frenetic attitude to 'getting everything in'. My only minor complaint would be with the displaying of some of the works. Even given the limitations regarding space I thought some works, which were hung well above eye level were difficult to appreciate. Similarly, a number of works were poorly lit. Caravaggio's 'David with the head of Goliath' was a prime example: the lighting meant that it was very difficult to view the painting without reflections from the varnishing being problematic.These are minor quibbles however. Galleria Borghese is a great gallery & well-worthy of being a 'must see' on any visit to Rome.
Excellent sightseeing. The only inconvenient was that we were not allowed to take photos inside.
The colors. The Artwork was UNSURPASSED!!! Just Beautiful!!! I LIked it all except for (I Understand why) NO CAMERAS allowed!

Special. Remember to book several days in advance.
The guide "Lucca" was perfect.
The gallery is located in a beautiful park.
Do not forget to include it in your Rome trip
Bellini is worth seeing. Amazing collection of Bellini sculptures. It is especially interesting to compare Bellini's David with the Michaelangelo in Florence.
Sculptures almost real life.. The Museum was not crowded so we had the opportunity to study the paintings and sculptures.

Don't Miss This. With everything to see in Rome, you may think that you don't have time for this Art Gallery. It is magnificent. Purchase a ticket online before you go. The sculptures are amazing and in the intimate setting, you can really get close and admire the art
Must see. It's lovely and the Bernini sculptures are rapturous.

Some of the best scupltures in Rome. Many beautiful pieces of art, but the sculptures are simply the best. And they allow photography so my husband could enjoy making his own form of art. They do limit how much time you can spend so make sure to pace yourself so you don't miss anything.

Small Jewel Museum. One of my favorite museums in Rome - Bernini sculpture of Apollo & Daphne, and Madame Pauline, Napolean's sister, reclining are amazing. Proserpina can't possibly be made of marble, but she is! Amazing! It's small and comfortable. Easy to do in 2 hours, then walk to the Via Veneto for a wonderful alfresco lunch. Make a reservation in advance, then pick up your Roma Pass and walk in at your reservation time.

Amazing experience. We bought our tickets online before we arrived in Europe. We queued up to pick them up on the morning of the day. We got one audioguide between us. The audioguide goes for 1.5 hours and you're only allowed to be there for 2 hours. So if you're sharing an audioguide, listen to it together. Also, I overheard the personal guide taking a group around and they basically said the same thing as the audioguide. I guess the difference is that you can ask them questions if you want. The audioguide map was quite confusing though. The paintings/sculptures had been rearranged. We managed by just walking from room to room and just pushing the relevant choices in.Personally, I really enjoyed this because the crowd voulme was controlled and I actually had a chance to stop and admire the artwork, unlike many of the other attractions. The paintings were beautiful and the history of how the entered this collection was also fascinating.:)

Two hours with an art historian. Two hours flew by with a doctoral docent, whom we booked with Context tours. Dr. Golden was wonderful and made the experience come alive with her enthusiasm. We only did Caravaggio and Bernini, but it was like being part of the filming of a documentary.
Lovel full day of wondering in the park. Special day with my wife just taking it easy and relaxing in a beautiful well maintained park.
Nice Place. Beautiful work of art. I could stay there for days.
Must visit. Beautiful park and museum - offers a green oasis in the heart of a busy city. The Galleria and collections are absolutly beautiful - it is a must see!

enjoyable. We took the wrong fork in the Spagno metro and ended up hiking through the park for over a half hour trying the find the gallery! The signage in the park isn't great and most of the maps in the tour books are very general (ie they dont list the street names within the park). Once in the gallery, it was very enjoyable. It is small, beautiful, and houses some very great works of art. You will probably need an audio guide or a book with detailed info on each room to get the most out of your visit.Info to families with young children: non-EU kids pay the full rate . :-(

Galleria Borghese in a beautiful park. We liked the Gallery however we were tired and found that by the third floor we had seen enough. Perhaps the walk to the Gallery in 30+ heat was not such a good idea!

Amazing Sculpture in a beautiful park. It had a set time to go in along with a large number of people which made it crowded at first. You had to check your pocketbook before visiting which was a bit unnerving. The pictures and sculptures were wonderful and the park beautiful. Take small bus 116 from the Daphne Trevi into and back from the park.

To be safe, get it for free. I love and collect art. And I love (most) museums. But I really wasn't into this museum at all. Perhaps if I was more into art history. I find art personal and intuitive for me, and most of this collection just didn't strike me deeply. Given most of the reviews, if one uses a Roma Pass and gets in for free (I didn't) -- well, no, that couldn't have anything to do with it! With such long lines and difficulty making reservations, I hoped this would be a memorable experience. For me, it wasn't at all.

Bernini’s Apollo and Daphne sculpture - simply inspiring.. We booked a 09:00 reservation that we made via our hotel front-desk, I’m sure we could have called but as we had the Rome pass we wanted to make sure it was free. 09:00 is a good time to go as you get to go straight in so got the whole two hours inside. You may want to leave your camera at home otherwise you'll need to check it, there's not photos allowed inside. You can use the Metro to get to the park, we used the Spagna stop on Line A and it’s a short walk in to the park to find the museum, about 15 mins. The gallery is impressive it’s worth the visit just for Gian Lorenzo Bernini’s Apollo and Daphne sculpture - simply inspiring.

Be Warned!!!. We turned up early to get in to this gallery which was near us., only to be told all the tickets for that day had been sold! They had only been open about 40 minutes and there was no queue, so obviously they had sold all their tickets to coach parties! A lousy trick, but very Roman, so if you really want to go there you should buy your tickets in advance.
Gorgeous parks. Beautiful gardens around the gallery Worth spending an entire day.

'...this is Italy...'. The gallery itself is perfect, but the staff is terrible. At the ticket corner we were told that can leave our clothes at the garderobe, but there they said NO. Our visit was reserver fo 11a.m., but we were allowed to enter at 11:10. It was said that the visit has to be 2h, but at 12:50 we were throun away - when I complained, the guy nearly beat me saying '...this is Italy...'
Don't pass this by. The grounds were amazing, but the gallery even more so.

Borghese is well worth planning ahead. This was our third visit and we enjoyed it even more than the first two. Reservations are essential. Entry is only by timed ticket, and is strictly limited to 2 hours. This was the palace of an extremely wealthy family who collected the very finest art. It is displayed in the rooms that were designed around the collection. The sculpture is especially fine. Walking into a room with Canova's "Pauline Bonaparte as Venus" is unforgettable. The next room has Bernini's "David," which according to Rick Steves was a self-portrait of the artist as a vigorous, confident young man of 25. In the next room, Bernini's "Apollo and Daphne" is worth the price of admission all by itself. It depicts the moment Daphne transformed herself into a tree to escape the attentions of Apollo. The piece is so delicate and airy that it is hard to believe you are looking at a huge piece of marble.The paintings are also very fine. The entire palace is a work of art, with something beautiful on every single surface. The lighting is warm and bright, so the palace still feels like a home.We had the last 2-hour time slot of the day. As we left, caterers rushed onto the front loggia to set up a fancy private dinner . There were huge floral arrangements, small tables set with sparkling silver and china, and a spectacular buffet. We lingered a little on the stairs to watch the first guests arrive in formal wear. Alas, our invitations must have been lost in the mail. We walked back through the park, content with our glimpse of aristocratic life past and present.
A must see. Perfect size. Small museum with the most amazing sculptures.
3D paintings!!. Paintings like they were talking to you!!like they were shaking your hand!!unbelievable!!
Top quality. Small, expensive, but with the best quality artworks

Incredible Berninni Marble Statues. The Borghese is a treasure trove of incredible sculpture. Be sure to book ahead and make a copy of your online booking page from the computer. You will need the number to claim your tickets. We never received a confirmation e-mail so I am very glad that I printed the page listing my booking number etc
Great museum with great artist like Caravaggio.. I liked the museum with great works of arts from the Bernini, Caravaggio, and Titian and a lot more.

Very nice if you have extra time.. We sat on a bench surrounded by trees and people strolling by. A man with a guitar came by and sang to us for 1/2 hour, it was wonderful. We bought a CD. Some people rented little buggies/scooters and drove around I would have done that if I had known about it.

Breathtaking Genius and inspiration await.. Well organised, a perfect sized collection and some of the greatest masterpieces you may ever see. Originally a private collection that belonged to the famous/infamous Borghese family, this gem of a museum, hidden away in the beautiful, lush Borghese park is a must see in Rome. With the right guide, this museum will come to life and unveil some incredible mysteries and stories. The main focus truly is Gian-lorenzo Bernini, without out doubt the greatest sculptor of the Baroque. However remember to book, as they limit places specifically to make it more enjoyable and manageable (the Vatican could learn a thing or two). If you need help or assistance visiting feel free to contact. Enjoy.
The central parc of Rome. A must visit when in Rome. If the weather god is without undoubtly given you a nice afternoon
What a great collection of must see items. Loved getting close to Bernini sculptures and seeing his talent so much clearer than photos alone give.
