Another great museum. The private collection of a cardinal.... some of the greatest works of artists like Bernini, Caraveggio and Titian. Must see if you visit Rome. If you have some time to laze afterwards, enjoy a walk in the park where the gallery is located... it is called the Villa of Borghese. The audioguided tour was worth it. Make advance reservations during peak season and plan you visit carefully as you are not allowed to stay inside for over 2 hours. Spend most of the time at the ground level and leave about 40 minutes for the upper level that hold great frescoes of Caraveggio and others.I would definitely recommend this!

Get a reservation by phone and save time/money!. We had a 1pm reservation that we made via phone. It saved us a few Euro. And we used the Roma Pass once we arrived, so our ticket was free. Make SURE you look at a map of this location before getting there. Getting to Villa Borghese means you are a 30+ minute walk to the gallery! And the signage in the Villa is not very helpful. The map provided with the Roma Pass may be better than a tourist map from your hotel! But the gallery itself was one of our favorites!

Magnificent. Difficult to say which art work we liked the best as there are many spectactular works. It is truly remarkalble that Cardinal Borghese was able to amass such a collection. Recommend renting an audio tour guide, partiucularly if you are a "beginner" art lover.

Galleria Borghese. Fantastic, located in a park, the gallery is a gem. You must call or book online for a ticket. The museum has showings at scheduled times during the day and has limited tickets. I called in early Nov. 2011 for a ticket that day but during the summer the museum may be booked.

Most beautiful museum I've been in. I wasn't expecting much when I toured this museum but I was blown away by the beautiful artwork on the walls, ceilings, and floor. I could have spend all day in here if I wasn't meeting up with other's in my party who did not go with me. The Bernini statues were breathtaking, especially Apollo and Daphne. I did not go with a tour, but that might have been better if just to get more background on the art. You must pre-purchase your tickets (it is crowded but with a limited number of entrances, it isn't that bad. You have to check all belongings and enter the museum in the basement.

Disappointing and Frustrating Display of Masterpieces. Bad presentation of some excellent art work. Perhaps because it was night and the exterior light could not contribute to the poor lighting on more than half of the wall hanging art. Or perhaps it was because so many bulbs were burnt out or aimed poorly or not at all many of the paintings. This display would have been twice as nice if it had half as much all well displayed. None were labeled in English. That would make a good 5th grade English project for an Italian elementary school. The major room was closed for repair, which is certainly excusable but much else is just bad presentation. Better spending the extra time at the Vatican Museum. The pieces were too close together imposing on each other and reducing the impact of each.
Beautiful villa museum. It is a medium-sized museum villa, nice and lovely, easy access but mandatory booking in advance.

Gallery is amazing, the staff is not.. The gallery is well worth a visit, however, I had my visit almost ruined by the staff at the gallery. After arriving, I signed up for the English tour of the gallery. You are limited to two hours in the gallery per visit, and the tour is set to start ten minutes after you can enter. I was the only one to sign up for the tour, and therefore, the gallery does not do the tour (apparently, there must be at least 2 people for them to give a tour). However, instead of telling me this at 11am (when I could have entered the gallery on my own), the staff elected to dither around, and finally told me that the tour would not go at 11:20am. Then, they had to give me a refund, and give me the audio recording (which took another 5 minutes). Finally, they told me the wrong starting point on the audioguide, so that I had to come back down to the desk to ask for clarification (another 10 minutes). It was a nightmare, the staff was hostile and actively obstructionist, and as a result I did not get to complete the entire tour of the gallery. When I pointed this out, the staff blamed me. This soured me on the gallery for the unprofessional behavior. So... the art is amazing, and should not be missed. However, avoid the staff at all costs as they will hinder your enjoyment of this wonderful exhibit.

Galleria Borghese A MUST. Galleria Borghese a beautiful villa in a wonderful park setting....in the fall the park and gardens were pretty but must be stunning in the spring and summer. The main draw for me were the sculptures. Bernini's Apollo chasing Daphne as she turns into a tree - you can get close enough to see her toes & fingers changing so delicate and beautiful you forget it is cold hard marble. Canova's Venus reclines on cushions you would believe to be soft to the touch...I could go on and on - you must go to experience them for yourselves. Because you are allowed to get so close to the art they require you check ALL baggage even my small cross shoulder purse wasn't allowed and absolutely no cameras. We had no problems with cking our belongings unlike another reviewer...reservations are required ( you must make them days in advance) then you get 2hrs to enjoy...a wonderful break from the very crowded Vatican Museum of the day before. Oh and make sure you ask directions to Gallergia Borghese and not Villa Borghese or you will have a long walk thru the park.....

Incredible Collection. So many pieces of artwork to absorb in such a limited amount of time. The collection is extremely varied. We had an excellent guide who knew the stories behind the most fascinating pieces.

Dont forget to reserve a ticket. Wonderful collection of art. You can't arrive and purchase tickets. You must call to get a reservation code. You get two hours which was plenty for me. My favorites were Il Ratto di Proserpina and PaolinaThe food at the sit down part of the cafeteria was pretty bad and overpriced. Suggest eating elsewhere.
Villa Borghese. By needing to book a visit, numbers are limited and the experience is much more civilized

Beautiful gardens and museum. Beautiful sculptures and paintings in an equally beautiful park. Must make reservations a couple of days ahead of time. I reserved online before I left home. Exchange your receipt for a ticket downstairs, must check all coats and bags, then upstairs to enter the gallery.
Worth a visit. Amazing property, beauty at every turn. We should have taken a cab from the Pantheon, it's quite a hike, uphill.
Amazingly beautiful. We were speechless at the beauty of the painted ceilings!

Worth the visit. The gardens are beautiful and the artwork is inspiring. When dropping off/picking up your bags there are two lines. We waited in a really long line (the incorrect one) not realizing the were two until closer to the drop off area.

Some artwork very inspiring but all in all, not all it's advertised to be!. Loved the sculptures and certain paintings. Adored the inside of the building. The location is not ideal though and the fact that you have to prebook your tickets for a sight that, let's face it, is not the Vatican Museum, that was a bit over the top. Plus, once you get in, you can easily get confused because the rooms are scattered.

superb. we had a very good guide who explained the exhibits so clearly and well
getting into the gallery seemed long winded and it was unclear what you needed to do.

Art... Bellissimo.... You should book ticket in advance. Downside if you first think of it. But it's easy to do via phone, we booked tickets over the phone in the morning for the same day in the evening. Worked excellent.
perfect. tips: book at least one week in advance! it is always fully booked
Relaxing afternoon. The gallery is wonderful and the park is a great place to relax and unwind for a few hours.

Galleries Borghese - worth it but be prepared. A few things to know before you go: you MUST have a reservation (ask your Hotel for help), you should allow a least an hour to get to the Galleries, it is nestled (hidden) in Rome's "Central Park" and while everything in Rome is "just 5 minutes up on your right" allow time to get to this Gallery, not to be confused with the 4 or 5 other Museos in the park. It is worth the trip, effort and their rules (yes you do have to check your bag, right down to your small hand held purse) in an open cubby hole "storage" system. Only 360 people are allowed in at a time, your ticket reservation grants you 2 hours and when time is up, TIME IS UP! Only 90 people on the top floor. Enter, head straight to the top and work your way down; you will be able to see it all thoroughly in the two hours.It is NOT free, it was 8,50 Euros Nov 5, 2011 - well worth it! This was a private home in the past (NY'ers think the Frick) and if you take the hop on hop off bus please note that the Villa Borghese (which is the park) stop is about a 10 minute stroll to the Park, add another 10 or 15 in the park to get to the galleries, without getting lost. I cannot stress enough that you need to allow time to find this place, I cannot stress enough that if you go to one museum only in Rome, it should be this one but honestly don't limit yourself like that :-) ENJOY!
great attraction. Nice park.. The park is very beautiful and convenient. A picnic there is recommended. The gallery is also great.
Beautiful experience. Wonderful paintings and sculptures and very well organized.

must do museum. Great collection. Well presented. This is a don't miss museum in Rome.Take the 116 bus from near the Ponte Vittorio. The small bus (10-12 passengers)is an experience in itself. Goes places so narrow no bus should go there.

Definitely worth seeing. I am not an art lover and have never studied art history, but I was blown away by this place. We had three days in Rome and followed the Rick Steves' guidebook to a T and we are glad we did. You need reservations and have to show up early to get your tickets, but it wasn't too much trouble.

Unexpected Treat. While not the most known tourist destination, it is a must-see. Delightfully restored or pristine sculptures of great importance adorn an immaculate palace, visited by manageable crowds. The park and surrounding areas are a nice visit too.
Brilliant Borghese!. An incredible collection of historic and beautiful art work and sculptures surrounded by a peaceful and serene park.
Art at its Best. Beautifully displayed masterpieces in an incredible mansion!
Don't Go Without a Guide!. A wonderful experience, thanks to a guided tour. There is much-to-much to see here on your own. You would miss the great stories behind the art.
Dynamic Bernini. Dynamic Bernini sculptures, including one of David in competition with Michelangelo. Close run thing. Great, and less showy, earlier Roman sculptures.

Plan ahead!. This venue requires timed tickets that can be purchased online, but they sell out fast! They were very serious about the timing, and they wouldn't allow any types of bags into the building, including purses. The art was phenomenal as was the gift shop.
Deffinitely!. Definitely get a reservation! Definitely get the audio tour! Definitely worth the effort!

Must see. This is a small museum with outstanding statues and paintings. It is in a beautiful setting of a huge park. Make reservations at least days ahead, when it is full you can not get in. It was a bit tricky to get to by bus because we did not know where to get off, but got there eventually. We took the metro back and that was a bit tricky too, we could see the Metro but the way the road was it was hard to get too.

A Zoo. Had a 5 pm reservation, arrived after a 40 minute walk from hotel at 4:50 pm. There was a Line to pick up ticket & the foyer seemed very crowded. We paid & then found they allowed no bags at all in. I carry my iPad in my pac safe bag (small compact & secure - NOT backpack size). This was the ONLY site on my whole 3 week trip to Italy that required this. No other sight did - not Vatican/Sistine, St Peter's, San Marco's Basilica in Venice, The Last Supper in Milan. Seriously the "cloak room" check line was huge, I stood & watched the attendant pile bags on open shelves willy nilly as he handed out claim checks. No lockers that I saw. It looked neither organized nor secure. About that time, we over heard a woman come to the desk to report the theft of her belongings. They had spilled out of her purse when she tripped on the curb & fell on her face. Her purse along with her cell phone & wallet that had spilled out were stolen quickly as she gathered herself off the ground. At this, we decided to leave without checking my bag. Just wanted to make people aware, this is not a peaceful or secure place to visit. Glad I skipped it.
Do not miss this.. Not easy to get tickets but you should persist. An amazing museum!

My favorite museum. We happened upon the Galleria Borghese one afternoon and, despite not having made reservations, were able to get in since we had the Roma Pass. The collection of Bernini and other sculptures was excellent. This museum is well worth a visit!

Art ,Beauty, Architecture, Astounding, Knowledge, A must see in Rome!. First off, you must book this early as there is limited availability (360 persons every 2 hours). So if you are looking at this or other reviews, book now! Go to the website that is attached and click on ticket reservations. Be sure and check the times that they are open. If you are in Rome call the number on the website or have your hotel call to see if you can get in. Don't miss it. I would highly recommend that you take the guided tour. It costs more but you may be rewarded with the Curator and an unexpected lesson in art that you will never forget! I learned more about art in my visit to this museum (because of the guided tour) than I have anywhere. It was a treat for someone with limited knowledge but enjoys the beauty of art and the stories of the artists. The Guide for the tour was EXCELLENT for both the art buff and tourist! The history of the galleria and it's works were explained as well as artists, their styles and their differences! And of course, she had the pictures and sculptures right there to show us! I have since seen other works of art that she spoke about in Madrid at the Prado and to my amazement in Montserrat outside Barcelona. So, do yourself a favor and take the guided tour!!!!!! You won't regret spending the extra few Euros! Take your time and enjoy the Borghese Gardens and the astounding views. Stroll through the garden after your visit to the Galleria Borghese and breath in the fresh air! Contemplate on how lucky you have been to have seen and learned what you just have!! That's what I did! What a wonderful day indeed.
Plan Ahead, but Worth a Visit. Our guide was very knowledgeable and made this a very insightful visit.

A must for art lovers. Mi è piaciuto di più e di meno: Art masterpieces set in a stunning villa. The Bernini sculptures are astounding! Get that reservation in advance by internet or telephone! The villa is set in a very large and beautiful park, so be sure to have a map to find it. Many bus lines go there but the villa is a little difficult to find.

Pay E5 and get the audio guide. You must buy a ticket in advance. Admittance is limited and you have a 2 hour time limit. Entry starts at 9.00am. Next entry is at 11.00am.When I went in at 9 am , they were not checking tickets so if you do not have the opportunity to return later, buy an advance ticket and just walk in with everyone else.This was my second visit and it really is an amazing place.Andrew

Beautiful building filled with amazing art.. The Galleria Borghese is a beautiful building filled with amazing art. The sculptures alone are worth visiting. The ceilings are breathtaking. Be sure to make a reservation. We went the afternoon of our first day in Rome and it was an excellent way to start our visit.

Fabulous. Really good collection of paintings. Quite difficult to reach as signs inside the park and metro station are not very clear. I literally wandered around inside the park with many other confused tourists for long time before reaching the Galleria, but it's really worth it!Ticket reservation is mandatory!!
Not to be missed. The restoration of the villa and the quality of the Bernini's are superb

Wonderful Galleria Borghese - a must to visit in Rome. Galleria Borghese is a marvel of sumptious beauty. We visited the gallery on our first day in Rome, on our own without a guide or ear plugs. We had of course read about it beforehand, but still we were not mentally prepared for this absolutely stunning experience. It was overwhelming, it was so extremely beautiful, so impressive. Berninis incredible sculptures, the splendid paintings on the walls and ceilings, the mosaic floors in the entry hall - an abundance of cultural treasures. This is a must!
Wonderful gallery!. amazing sculptures and a great way to get out of the touristy center of the city. Be sure to buy the audio guide, well worth it!
Beautiful works of art in an amazing building. Truly beautiful sculptures, paintings and ceilings. Our second visit to the Galleria Borghese and would return for a third!
Wonderful art collection. Master piece of art. Limitation on visitor per visiting period so that it will not be crowded.

Not quite what I expected but nice. I expected to see a lot more in the painting gallery but didn't know in advance that half the collection had been sold to Napoleon. it was still worth the time and effort to see the museum but it didn't take me the full two hours permitted to see it all comfortably - and I'm an art lover. I was very surprised that after 90 minutes, I was one of the few visitors left in the museum during my time frame. So if you have the time, make the effort to go and also enjoy the surrounding park.

An absolute must see.. Hiring Sylvie, a private guide form Eyes of Rome made this one of our most memorable experiences. We viewed it all through her expert eyes and it was just wonderful! More museums should be like this - only so many people, preorderd tickets, no cameras.

A truly special museum. I had been to Rome before, but it wasn't until I asked frequent traveler to Rome about her favorite places to visit, that I became aware of the Borghese villa. Make sure you make reservations in advance as it can sell out days in advance, but its worth it. There are some spectacular sculptures and paintings in a wonderful setting.
The only gallery you need. If you only had time to go to one gallery in Rome then this would be the one to go to. You need to book in advance, but it's quite easy to do online
art at the very best. Excellent art sight. Fool of history and art. If you go in the morning and in the working days no need to preautorization.

Not for everyone. Frankly, this review is for people who, like us, are NOT hardcore art lovers. This was our first attraction in Rome because of the rave reviews on TripAdvisor. We booked the tickets and everything, but I wish we had spent all that time walking through the park that surrounds the Gallery. The park is fantastic - spacious, quiet and a great romantic hangout. The gallery will impress you if you have not been to similar museums or galleries anywhere else in the world. Don't even bother going there without and audio guide - you will not take anything out at all. This was definitely not #1 attraction for us, but again this only applies to those who like art but are not too hardcore.
Fantastic. Amazing statues an pictures in a beautiful setting. Must prebook as sold out days ahead

The higlight of our stay in Rome. The Borghese admits only a few visitors at a time and allows them only two hours. Having only a few people in the museum makes getting close to the artwork easy, but having to leave after two hours was not good. We missed seeing the last rooms! Do rent the audio tour. It will deepen your experience and appreciation of the artworks immensely. As my husband said when we left, "Bernini rocks!"
Best thing we did in Rome. The artwork, and sculpture is world class. And the crowds are kept to a minimum by the Gallery's policy of only allowing 300 or so people to visit at a time.

well organised. The sculptures are mind-blowing in their intricacy and the museum's policy of letting in a limited number at a time means there is just enough space to see everything properly. Another plus is the setting, simply strolling in the park was one of the highlights of our trip.

Great panorama over the city. The garden itself is not so much extraordinary, rather a big park with some nice flora. However it is located on the top of the hill, and you can have a great view over the city.
Interesting. We need to leave all bags and camera at the counter. Glad that we made tickets reservation in advance. They had to reject quite a number of people wanting to buy tickets for that day.
An Oasis of calm. How lovely to escape the city noises for a while and find this quiet and green place for some tranquility

Don't miss. The Galleria Borghese is just full of amazing paintings and sculptures. The best part though is the lovely setting in the park. We so enjoyed walking around and just exploring this area. The park would also be a great spot for families.
Rome 2011. Open air, lots of walking. Gets you above the noise of Rome and see some great vistas,
Feast for the eyes!. Loved the Borghese Gallery. The sculptures & paintings were just breath taking.

good but expensive. amazing place for everybody who likes art
no discounts for non eu-citizens
Fabulous Museum. Very beautiful - would highly recommend making reservations in advance. This is very popular and gets sold out fast.

Galleria Borghese. Outstanding sculptures by Bernini, takes your breath away.
Don't eat at the cafeteria, horrible food and service.
Amazing. Highly recommend visiting. Allow sometime to walk through the park where the gallery/museum is located. Bus 116 goes from center of Rome to Borghese.
The treasures of Rome. Wonderful building and sumptuous paintings by Caravaggio and scultures by Bernini. The high renaissance in all its glory.

Awesome Museum - Buy Tix well In Advance. Stunning building and museum. We arrived looking to buy a ticket for the next day to find they were sold out 3-4 days. Asking about returns and cancellations we were told to come back at 3:05 and lo and behold we had two tickets and were in the museum in minutes. Once in you can see why they limit the number of addmissions and sell tix in advance and the ticket admits you for a max 2 hour period.

Incredibly beautiful place with fabulous works of art.. Disappoints in gardens. Just large greens ace but the gallerie was breathtaking. The old masterpieces were amazing. Don't bother getting audio guide. Just makes visit too long

Hard to find coming out of Metro Spanga. Beautiful sculptures in a very nice villa setting. It was incredibally hard to find this place coming out of the SPANGA metro stop. The Villa is inside the vast park but the there is no signage pointing tourist in the direction for the Villa Borghese. We had to ask several people for directions and some of them didn't know.... other tourists were also lost.

Absolutely Magnificant!. The art work here was outstanding, but the building itself, and the wonderful frescoed ceilings were just magnificant. The grounds are so beautiful and huge. And no crowds! This was one of the most outstanding places we saw.

A Must See. A must see! You must arrange for tickets ahead of time, sometimes up to week in advance. Pick them up on arrival, check all bags, get audio guide and you're off. Could easily spend the whole day in the gardens etc
This is one of the best in the world. Bernini Statues Pluto and Proserpina, Apollo and daphnie will set you soul on fire, and the 7 Caravaggio paintings in one spot is something to experience.
Very Good. Lots very good pictures,But if not for Hotel booking us in would not have seen it as booked for week
Amazing opulence. Truly amazing that a rape statue would be the centerpiece of a pope's collection

Great art in a great setting. Loved that it wasn't crowded like many other European museums. It was a beautiful collection in a beautiful villa in a beautiful park. Make sure you get a reservation before you go!
Beautiful. Don't miss this! It's a wonderful art museum; but beyond that, it's a lovely afternoon up in the huge (and quiet) park. It's a great rest in nature from the mania of Rome!

Worth it! Get tickets early. We prebooked this tour - and you should be warned, to prepurchase tickets to museums, you pay quite a mark up from the regular entrance fee. That said, unlike many of the museums that are over crowded (I studied art in Paris and the museums there were NOTHING like the crowdedness of Italy museums) this was a bit better (please note, it's still crowded, but the flow of the museum allows the guides to move around each other). You only get 2 hours in the museum, but to give you an idea of how easily the place sells out, it was booked through tuesday when we were there on a sunday. After the museum, we had a walking tour of the gardens ending at sunset at a great vista of St. Peter's. Well worth it and the fun stories that surrounded each amazing artwork.

Beautiful rooms, magnificent collection. Galleria Borghese, in the large and beautiful Villa Borghese park, houses a magnificent art collection with some of Bernini's best sculptures as one of the highlights. The beautiful decorated rooms is an art exhibition in their own right.Remember to book your tickets in advance as the access is usually sold out. A booking will grant you a specific two hour visit.

Awe inspiring. On beautiful grounds, a gem sitting amidst the trees, this galleria is breathtaking. From the master sculpter Bernini's works, to the frescoes on the ceiling, this is truly a must visit place. I liked that you needed a reservation and they let only so many people in at one time. This made it a more comfortable experience as you did not have to fight any crowds whatsoever to view the masterpieces in this galleria. I will visit this galleria again. My only dislike is that you cannot take photos.

Well worth seeing. Make sure you give yourself plenty of time to arrive and get your ticket (we used a skip the line which worked well). Well worth visiting- amazing artworks and sculpture. Two hour visit is timed and not too rushed.

Reserve your tickets in advance. You need to reserve tickets for this wonderful Gallery in advance. We were booked for a Thursday and the noted a sign when we arrived saying it was sold out until Sunday. The gallery had a wonderful collection of Bernini sculpture. A couple hours is all you really need. The gardens around Villa Borghese are also worth visiting. Great for a stroll and some people watching. If you lived in Rome, you'd want to take a walk here every day.

Opulent. The Galleria Borghese can be entered only by reservation and only for 2 hours. The rooms are incredible and feature some truly outstanding works of art (like Bernini's statue of Daphne and Apollo). The garden was open since the day was warm and sunny and was a pleasant place to stroll after taking in so much art. We visited during October and it was nearly sold out when we reserved 2 days before our visit so make sure to book early, especially during peak times. The scheduling system seems designed to create queues so arrive early to ensure that you have full use of your allotted time.
Too many cooks!. Too many turisti has led to necessarily tighter control of admission and this has led to a less enjoyable experience. Staff and not all as friendly as they could be.
beautiful place. It is a beautiful place to see and worth the effort and not hard to get to:)
Galleria Borghese. I liked the collection but the staff I dealt with was rude.
Beauty!. Book ahead online! You can't take pictures and need to check larger bags at the front desk.
great. Beauty and culture combined - wonderful to walk through and relax

Amazing!. The collection is stunning and because of a very strict timed entrance policy it was easy to view the exhibits. It is essential to book during busy times. All bags have to be left in the cloakroom.

Outstanding Museum. The Galleria Borghese was one of my favorite places in Rome. The paintings, statues and grounds were definitely worthwhile seeing. I highly recommend adding this stop and purchasing the audio tour as it explains the artwork. The best was that with the Roma pass we got free admission. And, although we didn't pre-reserve tickets, and the sign said that they were sold-out, we were still able to get in.
Lovely park with art museum. It was a lovely place. The art was wonderful. The flowers and trees in the park were so pretty.

Good Museum, Too Little Time. Make sure you book tickets in advance (you're more likely to get tickets if you call). They only allow 2 hours inside the museum. To avoid the crowd and see more, I would recommend touring the museum reverse order--do the top level first, and end with the Bernini's and Caravaggio's on the bottom level.
Worth a visit. It was a beautiful mansion that had some really unique paces of art. It was worth a visit but if you're cramped for time, I wouldn't deem this one essential.
Beautiful musuem - great collection. Loved the Bernini scuptures - especially his DAVID and the PLUTO AND PROSERPINA.

bad taste. no leaflets in english,when you walked in main entrance we were sent out and down two flights of steps to get tickets when we returned we were told we would have to go down to leave in a handbag so we did when we returned we noticed some peoplewith audio phones so we asked for them so they were also downstaires we had had enough at this stage so we just walkedaround in ignorence through the gallery disgusted but thats notall on our way out i turned around to see if any leaflets in english had arrived when an old man with a stick who was talking to a girl working there started shouting at me i can only suppose he thaught i was going back in if he is in the employ of the gallery its time to move him on and as for the rest of the staff there not much better.It was a horrible experience. joe
Great collection of statues!. We liked how the reservations made for smaller crowds in the Gallery. The art collect is amazing; I could have stayed all day

small, but totally worth it!. Incredible museum in the middle of romantic park (Villa Borghese).
The only inconvenience about this museum is that you have to book it in advance, but it is totally worth it. Apart from permanent exhibition (including chef-d'oevres of Canova, Caravaggio) there are interesting temporary exhibitions quite often, so the time allowed for a visit might not be enough.
Stunning. Amazing art and limited numbers allowed in so much more enjoyable to look around. Book in advance.
DO NOT MISS. This is an incredible home and collection of many, many great pieces. It does not get crowded as they limit the number of people every two hours.

A wonderful gallery, worth every ounce of your time!. This is a wonderful gallery that lets you take in Italian art without all the crowds of the colleseum and Vatican (they limit the amount of tours and travelers per day, so make a reservation!). This was probably my favorite part of Rome, especially because it is nestled in a large park area that is breathtaking!

Amazing sculpture. I am not much of an art person. I typically don't go to museums when I travel, but the Borghese came highly recommended. It didn't disappoint. I didn't spend too much time on the upper floor, but the sculptures on the first floor were nothing short of amazing. I've never seen stone look so lifelike. I would highly recommend Galleria Borghese to anyone visiting Rome. Make sure you make a reservation in advance.

Great Art Gallery. Wonderful Bernini sculptures, and paintings, mosaics, etc. Really fascinating. Don't forget to reserve your time slot though. We saw many people turned away because they did not reserve a time to go in the Gallery. Easy enough to reserve online though.Recommended Rome attraction. Also the Borghese park is beautiful. Wish we had more time while in Rome to enjoy it!

Include it in your schedule!. It seems a little rude that they require a phone reservation and limits your visit to 2 hours, but definitely it's worth a visit! The villa itself is beautiful, and it has paintings from Caravaggio and splendid sculptures of Bernini.
Wonderful Museum, MUST SEE.. Mostly beautiful scupture and fantastic art. They give you a device that you listen to all around the museum. A self guide. Very good.

Fabulous Gallery. Villa Borghese is one of the best museums in Europe. If you buy a Rome Pass (25 Euro) first 2 museums you visit are free, and you can go without lining up to buy tickets! we visited Collosseum and Villa Borghese without any reservations / lines. In addition, you have unlimited travel on bus / metro for 3 days.
A must in Rome. great dont miss it and use the audio guided tour. it only takes 90 minutes. The surrounding gardens are great for a picnic lunch

A lovely, quiet museum where the art is alive.. Galleria Borghese limits the number of visitors per hour by requiring reservations. This is effective crowd control and allows visitors to see the art, especially the Bernini sculputres, with some space to breath. The reservations are easy to obtain by calling first and they guarantee a lovely experience. Many Rome attractions are so thick with tourists that there is hardly air to breath.
Accessible. This smaller museum was a breath of fresh air after the overwhelming huge museums (Vatican and Uffizi in Florence.)

Walk the grounds and make a Reservation. A glimpse of life from the past. The grounds are a nice change from the hustle of the city. If you are lucky to get the Roma pass, it can be difficult to get a reservation or a ticket on the Roma Pass. Make a reservation once it opens up. The Gallery took us about 2 hours.

Fantastic!. You need to book for this as there are limited numbers that go through each day. We booked through Viatour online. We had a late afternoon group time booked and had an American guide who was simply fantastic! He added so much to this tour with his knowledge and obvious passion and understanding of the exhibits. Lots of Bernini work here - really good. We had a two hour informative tour through the Villa and it concluded with a walk through the gardens with some discussion and commentary from the guide down to the Piazza Del Popolo. You do need to check your backpack in so it is wise to have something very small to keep your wallet and passport in if you feel more comfortable with this. Very enjoyable and very well done.

Not to be missed. The Villa Borghese is a delight to the visitor. The Bernini statues and Carravagio paintings alone are worth the visit. So much art and splendor in one location- almost overwhelming. Unless you enjoy walking, you might consider taking a taxi to the museum. Getting there can be a little confusing. Be sure to book your visit ahead of time as the museum limits the number fo visitors to tour the rooms at one time.

One of our very favorite sights.. We truly enjoyed visiting the Borghese Gallery. Amazing artwork! We particularly enjoyed Bernini's sculpture of Apollo and Daphne. Be aware that you must check your purse and camera. No photos are allowed inside. Also be aware that reservations are a must. Your hotel can reserve a time for you, but arrive a little early so that you have time to trade the reserved time for actual tickets. You have 2 hours to view the inside. The gardens are very nice, too. Renting a two person bicycle is a great option to see all of the gardens.

It was good. We went here in the evening, and it was not very crowded. We called a week in advance to reserve our tickets then paid and picked up the tickets there. You do have to check your purse and bags. I'm not an art lover, but the expereince was still pretty cool. I'm not sure I would do it again though. It is amazing to think that these statues were carved out of a block of marble and that the statues tell a story. In my opinion, the best part was the garden that you can walk out to. It has lime trees and flowers and is beautiful. Upstairs there are paintings.

Wonderful art museum in beautiful setting. This residence filled with art is located in the beautiful Borghese Gardens. I would recommend buying your tickets online in advance as they often sell out. Your ticket is good for a 2-hour time slot. The previous group leaves and then a new one is let in. I would suggest heading up the stairs at the back for the 2nd floor first before the crowds make it up there and then returning through the downstairs. You are not allowed to bring any bags into the gallery but must check everything downstairs before you enter. The ticket booth and gift shop are also in the lower level.

As nice as Central Park . . .. . . . . but without the homeless sleeping in the bushes.This is the place to be on a Sunday afternoon in Rome. The park has Italian dogs free from their leashes and police are on horseback. Very safe, great Zoo and history here. Beautifully kept, a must see.

When in Rome you must see this place!. I don't know how we missed the Galleria Borghese the last time we visited Rome, but I thank the Lord we had the chance to see it this trip. You will be overwhelmed by the beauty that surrounds you on each floor and words will not be enough to relate this experience to others. See it!

Bernini to Nourish Your Soul. This elegant museum contains masterpieces of the highest quality. The Bernini statues are beautiful beyond words, and the Carravagios are part of our common consiousness.
Generally, you need to book in advance (you can do it on line). Don't miss this if you are in Rome - or go to Rome specifically for this gallery!!

If you pick one gallery, pick this one. If you pick one gallery to visit in Rome, pick this one. Wow. I knew gig in that this was going to be cool but it surpassed all expectations. You have to make a reservation in advance. They only let in a set number of people every few hours, which I actually liked. They give you enough time to see everything and by staggering the people you are not crammed in there like at the Uffizi in Florence. They have a great collection of Bernin sculptures and Caravaggio paintings. I'm not a big art person, so for me to say that this ended up being one of my favorite things in Rome is saying something.We chose to do it in the afternoon. Afterwards we enjoyed a wonderful walk south through the beautiful park to an plaza that overlooked the Piazza del Popolo.

Heavenly!! a MUST SEE!!. OMG!! that pretty much sums up this wonderful place. i had read about Bernini's beautiful work but seeing them in person was.... words can't even describe the feeling. of course, his pieces are the highlight but the entire Borghese experience was just great. as previous reviewers said, you have to book a specific 2-hour time frame in which to enjoy the gallery. and of that, only 30 minutes in the paintings gallery upstairs.it was so worth it to rent the audioguide as it will give you more insight into significant pieces. and the price is not bad at EUR5. but even with the audioguide, it would be best to do some research before you go in order to much better appreciate the art.

A must see!. I wasn't sure that I wanted to go, but I'm glad I did. Make sure you get the audio tour,it helps. They give you 2 hours to go through the museum but if they would give more time I'd take it. They sculptures are incredible and the paintings, words can't describe it. If you are in Rome, make sure you book yourself a reservation!

Worth the reservation. Like walking through a person's home.. Be sure to make your reservation for the Borghese Museum because they were booked 2 days out on the day we went. Getting into the museum was a little confusing. There is a single line heading into the place, with the line splitting off to the right those who need to pick up there tickets, and to the left with people who need to check bags (EVERYONE, btw, has to check their bags). If there are 2 of you I'd suggest you split up and one person check the bags, and one person pick up the tickets. If you're picking up the tickets be sure to bring small bills of cash; our girl would not let us change a 50 euro. Be sure to hang on to your bag ticket or your id because you need it as collateral to pick up the audio tour.As someone who is not a huge art person - this collection was both impressive and moving for me to see. The park surrounding the museum is also beautiful. I highly recommend this as a stop while you are in Rome.

THE absolute gem for a visit to Rome.. We visited here while vacationing in Rome for several days. It is located in the Villa Borghese, which reminded me of Central Park in NY. This museum was once owned by the Borghese family and the art collection therein was begun and largely curated by a former Cardinal (if I recall, whose uncle was a Pope). This was easily one of my most favorite attractions in all of Rome. If you are an art buff, it's a must. There are works by a number of great masters, but it was obvious Bernini was a favorite of the Cardinal. Your ticket allots you a specific 2-hour window in which to enjoy the museum. The size of the museum is manageable and the two hours provides ample time to enjoy the collection. This is a wonderful value from a time and money perspective and I would highly recommend it to anyone.TIP: Buying tickets ahead of time online is nearly a must. If you have some time to kill before or after your visit, the Zoo is about a 5-10 minute walk away, also in the Villa Borghese.

Not to be missed!. You must get tickets in advance and they limit the amount of tickets sold. That is the beauty of this site. Because it limits the amount of people you can really enjoy the art with out feeling crowded. The only bummer is that you are only able to be there for 2 hours. The collection of Bernni's statutes etc.. are woth the price of admission. You are not allowed to bring any kind of bag (including purses) and or camreas.They strickly enforece those policies.

Breath-taking art!. This museum has a great collection of arts. All the sculptures, paintings, fresco etc are top notch, and created by some of the most famous artists in the history. I am not an art connoisseur, but thoroughly enjoyed the museum.They allow only upto 300 people at a time in the museum so you need reservations in advance. Reserving 3-4 days in advance should be fine. However if you plan to visit on a weekend, you may want to reserve a bit earlier.Limiting number of people to 300 at a time means it is not at all crowded and you can enjoy the art at your own pace.To reserve, you can visit their website, or call them. If you want to avail Roma Pass at this museum, you have to call them.Most important tip: Definitely take the audio tour! It's excellent, very interesting and a bit interactive too. You won't regret it!While you are in that area, you may also want to roam around in the Villa Borghese!

Not your ordinary museum. You MUST reserve a date and time in advance to going since they will not allow you in without a reservation. Although this seems strict, it provided for a wonderful viewing experience. If you've been to the Lourve to see Mona Lisa, you know what I mean. It is not one of the biggest museums nor one that has the most to see but with the 2 hour "reservation", it is the perfect amount of time. I suggest going for the audio guide (5 euros) since it does give you interesting information. Not a must see but more of a "glad I went to see it" kind of attraction.

The "Just RIght" Museum--Not Too Big, Not Too Small, Not Too Hot, Not Too Crowded. The Galleria Borghese ingeniously admits only 360 lucky people every two hours, and this time limit is strictly enforced. While initially this may seem overly harsh, it's an idea that other museums (yes, this means you, Vatican Museum and Uffizi!) would do well to adopt. The result is an uncrowded, leisurely experience. In two hours, I had more than enough time to stroll through all the rooms at an unhurried pace and to revisit rooms with my favorite pieces. Because there are no crowds, your view of the paintings and statues are not blocked by others, and you have ample room to step back and see the paintings or statuary in perspective, as well as from different angles. There are backless couches so that you may lie flat on your back to view the magnificent painted ceilings, as several people were doing during my visit (ok, I confess, I did it too!). Even though I was initially unfamiliar with the artists who were on display there, I was bowled over by the collection and its presentation. Or perhaps charmed is a better word. While out of the way, the museum is a stately building in the Villa Borghese park, surrounded by gardens and more statuary. Despite its relatively isolated location, mandatory reservation requirements and time limits, it's a must see. The two hours that I spent in the Galleria Borghese were the best, coolest, most relaxing, and most enjoyable two hours I spent in Rome.
worth a visit but out of the way. i wanted to see the obvious - bernini, apart from this there isn't a great deal, I enjoyed some of the painitings but this is all a matter of taste

Wonderful Treat. The galleria houses two different art collections in magnificiently decorated rooms. The first floor is mainly Greek and Roman sculptures while the second floor is 15th to 18th century paintings. As your visit is limited to two hours you need to be very selective in what you want to see as there isn't quite enough time to appreciate all the art that is displayed. The art work, in my opinion, equals the found in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.

A Must See when in Rome. You must get your tickets in advance because it sells out quickly. We bought the headsets and that is my best advise. You have only 2 hours before you have to leave. With the headsets as opposed to a guided tour, you have the ability to see what you want for as long as you want within the 2 hour limit. When you leave, be sure to walk back through the park to the Spanish Steps. We were there on a Sunday and the park was filled with people just enjoying the day.

Galleria Borghese - Not as good as it thinks it is. My friend and I visited Galleria Borghese a few days ago. We booked prior to leaving for our holiday and could only get a ticket for 3pm on the day we had chosen, which meant that we had to cut short a visit to Ostia Antica to fit it in. Tickets were €12.50 each. We arrived early so had time for a drink prior to commencing our visit. Staff in the cafeteria were rude and surly, similarly those in the bag-check area. I understand that their jobs are probably boring but they didn't help to make the visit a positive experience. The internet voucher had to be exchanged for "proper" tickets and this could not be done at the door so some visitors were having to fight their way back through the queue to get to the ticket desk in the basement. Everyone for the 3pm visit is allowed entry at the same time so this can make the earlier rooms very busy with tour groups - if visiting independently I would make for a room further from the door and enjoy some solitude then work backwards. The rooms and the sculptures are breathtaking, particularly the Bernini sculptures, but we found that the collection of paintings was not so interesting and although I am a regular visitor to galleries we found that after an hour we had finished our tour and did not need the two hours allotted to us. I could not really see why it was necessary to make an appointment for individual visitors although can see that this made sense for groups as some of the rooms are relatively small. Overall, a not entirely positive experience due to the hassle of booking and the attitude of the staff.

Beautiful. There are some lovely sculptures and paintings in this gallery; well worth a visit. The surrounding gardens are also a treat. You must make a booking to visit the gallery, which gives you two hours to browse around, and you can pick up your tickets beforehand. Once your allotted time arrives, a staff member will let you through and you can purchase a headset guided tour if you wish. The tour makes it much more interesting because you learn about the works and why/when they were created etc. All bags are confiscated at the door and no photos can be taken inside.

A lovely and memorable museum. I had to take two busses across the city to get to the Mueseo Borghese, but I can tell you it was well worth it.I was lucky and called the day before I wanted to go, my last day in Rome, and was able to get a ticket. When I arrived at the Museum, I noticed a sign in the ticket office that no tickets were available til four days later, so I was lucky. You should call ahead to reserve a ticket early. You can reserve for a specific entrance time, and then pay when you get there, so do show up a half hour early as they advise. Groups can go in at 9am, 11 am, 1 pm, 3 pm or 5 pm. You will also have to check any bags, parcels, etc. and leave your camera at home, no cameras are allowed.Each entry time allows two hours to tour the museum, and what I liked about it was that it is not vast, and you can take your time going through both floors well within the two hours allotted.If you have a hard time with the stairs between floors, ask, because I noticed there was an elevator, though I had seen a few people staggering up the beautiful staircase who probably would have been better off on the elevator. Bathrooms and cafe on the bottom floor are handy.OK, those are the functional things I think of. The museum collection itself is wonderful beyond words. First floor mostly statues, second floor mostly paintings. The Bernini sculptures were the most lovely things I saw in all of Rome, and the paintings were terrific too. I am so glad that I took the trouble to go tour this highlight of Rome. You will find some of the greatest art in the world in a serene and relaxing setting that makes the most of the collection.

Borghese Gallery - Do not miss !!. Do not miss the Borghese Gallery showing masterpieces of the Baroque period, especially Bernini's stunning sculptures - "Pluto and Persephone," "Apollo and Daphne", "David" and others. Canova's statue, too awesome. Do not miss the artists Korg'io ("Danae") and Caravaggio ("Boy with a basket of flowers," David with Goliath's head ").You should buy tickets in advance, for the date and time specific.Buying tickets through the museum Web site.Amazing!

smorgasbord for art lovers. The Galleria Borghese is a must see for anyone who enjoys art. The sculptures are breathtaking and make you want to gaze indefinately to enjoy the beauty. We went from 3-5 pm and that was a great time to visit....not too busy. We had arranged our visit on line so it was an easy entry with our voucher. Don't take bags or parcels with you as everything must be checked including cameras. If walking to this building, it is on the far north/east side of the park and we had great difficulty finding it. Nobody in the park seemed to know exactly where it was. I believe there is a city bus that goes right there so check before you go.

Smaller than I expected. We did not need the 2 hrs alloted in this museum. We were done in about 60 mins. There were only a couple of interesting pieces (Pauline Bonaparte/Apollo and Daphne). I guess having just visited the Vatican Museum before coming here, it felt a bit mediocre with all the other art pieces in the Vatican.

Look at the walls!. If they took out all the paintings and sculpture you are paying to see, oh the Bellini's, If they took out all the medallions and bit and pieces and incredible furniture, you could spend a week staring at the absolutely incredibly beautifully painted walls. And look up at the ceilings .. stunning. If you're dizzy looking up be careful looking down as the floors are sublime in their intricate marble. This is a house where the art of renaissance Italy permeates the atmosphere.

A must visit for Bernini's lovers. This is the best art museum in Rome; it is the home of several masterpieces of Gian Lorenzo Bernini including:Bernini's DavidApollo and DaphneRape of ProserpineTruth Unveiled by Time Other artistes:Antonio Canova (sculpture of Paoline Borghese)Raphael (The deposition of christ)Titian (Sacred and Profane Love)Caravaggio (Boy with a fruit basket) and (Madonna dei Palafrenieri)Correggio (Danae)One observation to mention regarding the staff (not the museum itself): The workers are arrogant, rude, and disrespectful and reflect really bad image of the Italian people. Please, make no mistake; real Italian people are friendly and helpful. The workers there are only reflecting their own bad image not a generalization of the people of Italy. Enjoy the awesome museum and do not let them bother you.

A Must See. Not always on everyone's itinerary, this is an absolutely amazing collection of some of the world's finest art. Strange hours and entrance requirements, but once you get in, you are not rushed, and the experience is fantastic.

Art lovers - A MUST. As an arts student i have studied about some of the Art here a long time ago. This was the highlight of our visit to Rome.Know that you have to buy tickets in advance, and that you only have 2 hours to be there. we were lucky to find tickets for a free Sunday, but were late, and didn't know about the time restriction, so we only visited the 1st floor. Perhaps better this way, since i wouldn't like to miss the opportunity to hover around Bernini's David, and Apollo and Daphne for more than an hour. Rent a bike in the park and spend the day there. Heaven.

A MUST for Lovers of Sculpture. My wife and I visited Borghese on our recent stay in Rome. I made reservations from home (a must if you are on a short visit). We rented an audio set (highly recommended).We particularly enjoyed the Bernini sculptures. A must for art lovers. The setting in the park makes for an enjoyable day in good weather.

The best place we visited in all of Europe! Better than the Louvre!. You need to book in advance and show up a little early to get the audio guide. No problem with that, though, as the gallery is located in a beautiful park where you can watch people go on with their daily activities.As soon as we entered the first room, our breath was taken away. I will not ruin the experience by describing everything I saw there, but let's say that the sculptures there are among the most beautiful I've ever seen, and that breath-taking ceiling painting in the first room is something I'll never forget.If I ever go back to Rome, this is the first place I'd go back to.Oh, and cameras are not allowed.

Museum fantastic! Getting in-a nightmare!". As others have said, reservations to enter this wonderful museum must be made in advance. That was not a problem. But once we found it, it was total disorganization. It is unclear where the line started or where to check in. There is a computer to enter your reservation info and collect a ticket, but once we finally got in the building, we saw that getting in the line for the receptionist was faster. (and the AC was not working). The other big time consumer-my husband waited in line to rent the audio guide while I waited in line to check our pack (nothing at all is allowed to be carried into the museum). After 15 minutes and finally reaching the head of the line, there is a little sign that says you must present your entrance ticket in order to leave valuables and I was sent to the rear of the line. Had to find my husband first to get my ticket. THEN, once we were ready to enter the museum, there was no signage to direct us, no one around to ask. By the the time we did enter, there was only 1 1/2 of our alloted time remaining. It's very strange that such a famous and wonderful museum is so disorganized. Put a damper on the visit.

Breathtakingly fabulous. The Galleria Borghese is really worth the visit, organise your visit by phone as only certain numbers are let in for 2 hour periods. No bags, cameras, mobile phones allowed in, they have to be checked. The audio guide is excellent as it allows you the best way to use your allotted 2 hours. When you are overwhelmed by what power could buy in the 16th century you can have a good coffee downstairs and rstart your tour. Beautiful, well organised and run by charming staff.

Worth visiting Rome alone for.. Make sure you book in advance. Timed booking. Bernini's best sculptures are here - David and Apollo and Daphne cannot be missed, whilst the cafe can! Titian's Sacred Love and Correggio's Danae should be compulsory study for all aspiring artists and in a turbulent world remind us of the wonder of man' creativity - when he's not selfishly creating banking mayhem or killing the innocent. Walk in the charming gardens - you'll need to to reflect on the multitude of wonders housed in this relatively small gallery. Then go back in and enjoy the rest of the 2 hrs allotted taking in the beautiful frescoes and the amazing wonders in this gem of gems. (Whilst the staff and their idea of directions are far from perfect. We love Italy and Italians in the main - but we felt the staff here were bored, tired and would rather be somewhere else! - It was very hot that day though.)

Poor website - unable to buy tickets because dates don't change. I have been trying for days to buy tickets on the Borghese Gallery website. However, the option for dates for purchase has not changed for a couple of weeks. And the telephone line is always busy, so I am being forced to purchase tickets from private agents.

Tour guide was great!. We took a guided tour of Galleria Borghese and loved it! Our guide was adorable and a joy to listen to. She gave us some great background on the art and history of the Galleria. Just be warned, there are lots of rules for visitors. Tickets sell out sometimes weeks in advance, so make reservations early. Also, you must be there half an hour before your reservation. You must check your bags and you are not allowed to take cameras into the museum.

Everything about it is wonderful. There was too much to see and take in within the two hour slot you are allowed: the marble floors, wall decorations and ceilings and, of course, the paintings. The best of these need very little explanation to understand. We did not use a guide of any kind and could find out all we wanted in rthe notes in the room and explanations on the internet afterwards.To book your time, you can telephone direct up to a day before, but slots get booked early. We booked a week in advance, but couldn't get in on the day we first wanted. Finding it was more difficult than I thought as it is just off the tourist map I was given at my hotel, so only just made it in time as there are two other museums in the grounds that we went to first!

A must.. Don't miss this museum. Stunning in collection, architecture, location, uniqueness, history, and authenticity. Plan way ahead - it requires reservations. Our favorite museum in all of Rome. Do not miss it.

Breathtaking!!!. One of the most important museums in the world for it's collection of sculptures and paintings, featuring many spectacular Bernini and Caravaggio works, this is a must see. In a wonderful park north of the city center, you need a reservation to obtain a two hour slot to enter. We chose the 9:00 AM slot, which proved the right move. Be aware of your time as they will begin ushering you out as your two hours finishes.

Beautiful!. Galleria Borghese is said to have the best private collection of artwork in the world. The experience is truly memorable. This collection is situated inside a large mansion on the grounds of Villa Borghese, which is the largest public park in Rome. The impressive collection of paintings and sculptures include works by Raphael, Caravaggio, Titian and Correggio. But it's the many works by Gian Lorenzo Bernini that dominate this collection and truly stand-out. Each room of this sprawling mansion has a theme. The paintings and sculptures are nicely spaced without being overwhelming or cluttered. The ceiling paintings are breathtaking. You can rent audio guides in the visitor center. There are also laminated information sheets available in each room with text in multiple languages. The visitor center in the basement of the gallery includes the ticket office, bag check, a book store, cafe and restrooms. All bags must be checked before entering the museum. No cameras are allowed either. The Galleria Borghese is closed on Mondays and all holidays. Reservations are generally required and time the in gallery itself is limited to two hours. Groups are admitted every thirty minutes. Guided tours are also available. If you have a Roma Pass, you can visit the Galleria Borghese for free. Don't forget to explore the Villa Borghese during your visit to this area as well.

DO NOT Miss this Art Museum!. I have been here at least 4 times and it is one of my favorites after the MET in NYC. The Bernini's are breathless and the Palace itself is sumptous. It's location is next to the Zoo and the Architecture of both is some of the best in details, typical of Rome. Buy the book tour and/or video online before, so you know exactly what you want to see the most.

Exquisite art. My husband and I enjoyed the Galleria Borghese and we are glad we went. It is easy to get to by bus from Termini. The Bernini sculptures are exquisite. We also enjoyed all the other art on the first floor. The second floor was not as interesting to us. The setting is very beautiful in the park. The only down side is that staff is unfriendly and a little full of themselves. It is easy to get tickets, even the same day, so I would not worry in advance if tickets will be available.
Unbelievable Art in a Sumptuous Setting. The Borgheses make the Bourbon kings who built Versailles look like amateurs. Just incredible that private families had the wealth to build this collection.

A must see -- but order your tickets before leaving home. The sculptures by Bernini were absolutely amazing. Your entry is timed and at the end of your two hours, the museum is cleared. You must check all bags (including purses) so allow extra time before your entry.

Not to be missed!. We were slightly apprehensive about online reservations, but all went smoothly for our 9 am tickets. We decided to purchase the English language tour. We were the only ones on the tour for most of the 1.75 hours! The guide, Laura, was wonderful. She made the whole experience memorable.

Ring beforehand. After much walking etc. we got to the Galleria Borghese only to discover they had sold out of tickets and no others would be available until the following day.
Advice: Phone beforehand to check otherwise a wasted journey. We never got to visit !!!
Small but excellent museum. The paintings are fine but the sculpture and the building itself are what makes this worthwhile. A great excuse to visit the Borghese Gardens park.

Persevere to get a ticket; it's worth it.. This is very popular and you have to ring a number to reserve a ticket, then arrive 30 mi before your entry time and queue in a long line to pay. Then you have to queue again to put your bag in the cloakroom as you are not allowed to take it in the gallery, then you have to queue and pay again to get the audio guide! However it is worth it, if nothing else for the Bernini sculptures. The audio guide definitely adds interest and you can start halfway along the tour to see everything without the crowds. Then see the beginning last. Stunning ceilings. Afterwards my tip would be to stroll through the park, past the lake, and exit above the piazza del popolo for a lovely view from a raised terrace across the city. You can walk along and enjoy the view before descending via the Spanish steps. Best time to enjoy the park stroll is early evening when the local families come out.

Book ahead for access to this impressive art collection. Its a small gallery, on the edge of a large park North of the Spanish Steps - with an astonishing interior design, sculpture, mosaic and fine art collection. Much of the quality is on par with the Vatican Museums - but much more manageable in scale.Access is by timed ticket - which needed booking two or three days in advance. The ticket gave a couple of hours access, which was about as much as my brain could process in a visit.Some of the rooms are small, so move past the first few rooms on entry, and the other visitors soon spread themselves out to allow a pleasurable viewing of the magnificent pieces - light levels are surprisingly high.Small cafe and bookshop in the basement - or benches in the public park nearby. Free storage for bags.

If sold out, don't hesitate to ask. You need a reservation to visit the Galleria as there are timed admittances. We were just meandering around the city. When we reached the Galleria, there was a sign it was sold out until Tuesday. This was a Saturday afternoon. They are closed on Mondays. But my partner went to the ticket office and inquired about entry that day. The clerk asked "how many?" Two. We were sold immediate entry tickets although told we had to be out in "x" period of time. Not sure of exact time but believe it was about 90 to 105 minutes; not sure how they would monitor it.As my mother always said, it doesn't hurt to ask . All they can say is no.The Galleria is beautiful and well worth the visit.

Stunning!. Even my kids were impressed. The Berninis were great. Probably a great sized gallery to take kids to as there are only the two floors but everything is of amazing quality. Make sure you book a few days ahead, though, or you aren't getting in!
A must see when in Italy!. Garden looks to be in very sad shape but Museum is worth it.

An unexpected highlight of Rome. We found the Museo rather hard to find as it is located within a very large garden complex but the searching was well rewarded. We spent several hours covering the gallery and admiring its displays but it was all well worth it, and were able to relax with a cuppa in the cafe before our walk back to the hotel. You have to purchase tickets well in advance as visitors are strictly limited within the gallery.

See it!. Great organization- you won't be squashed by hundreds of visitors at once. Plan your trip carefully as two hours are not enough...Bernini's Apollo and Daphne is breathtaking.The park is spendid, we visited there few times to hide away from the scorching heat.

A tiny jewel-box of a museum! Favorite museum in Rome!. My husband and I enjoyed the Borghese Gallery more than the Louvre! The small size of the museum wasn't overwhelming like bigger museums. We enjoyed the art so much more since there were fewer pieces but they were all unique, special and just beautiful! We had a fabulous tour and learned a lot. Any museum that limits the number of visitors per day (reservations are required) and prevents any cameras takes art seriously. If you're only going to visit one art museum in Rome, this is it!

One of the best Museums I have ever visited, anywhere. Galleria Borghese is small, but has one of the highest concentrations of high quality art, particularly sculptures, of any museum I have ever visited. The Bernini sculptures, especially Apollo and Daphne, is worth the trip to Rome even if you see nothing else. You have to make reservations, but this is to limit the number of people in the museum at any one time. Because of this, there was absolutely no problem moving around and getting to really enjoy the artwork without feeling crowded. We arrived early and enjoyed a nice morning walk through the surrounding park before entering the museum.

Definitely worth a visit. Villa Borghese is a little off the beaten track in Rome but nevertheless very busy. Make sure you book in advance because if you land up there expecting to get a ticket, the chances are you'll be disappointed. The disadvantage is that you get a two-hour time slot to get through the museum and after that you get shooed out. So, you have to stick to the program. The audio guide is good and certainly worth getting. The art, sculpture and general ambiance are not to be missed. Well worth the visit.

Make a Reservation!. An exquisite home/art gallery in a beautiful park. A very impressive collection, and don't forget to look down at the floor or up at the ceilings! Aside from the magnificent Caravaggio paintings and Bernini sculpture (which would make the visit reason enough) the traveler should go when the trees provide shade and rent a motorized bicycle-surry to see the whole garden's fountains, lakes and horse race areas. The Gallery and park were highlights of our trip.

An exquisite jewel that ranks with all the “e-ticket” attractions in Rome. Please do not miss this gallery; the first level is mostly statues by Bernini and Canova – so lifelike and animated that you wonder how the artist could transform marble into such incredible works of art. Take a close look at the face of Bernini’s David and study the tension and determination. Then check out the finger impressions in Proserpina’s legs as Pluto takes her to the underworld. Or, for an all time “how did he do that?” moment, study the statue of Apollo and Daphne as she is turning into a tree. The second level consists of a number of paintings by Rubens, Titan, Raphael and Caravaggio. The Caravaggio’s are really great; look at “David with the head of Goliath” – Goliath is a self-portrait of the artist. Do you think he resembled Pavarotti? We enjoy the limited admittance policy, the self guided tour using whispers and the overall intimacy of the gallery. Also, after you finish you tour, take a walk through the Borghese grounds to the overlook of the Piazza del Popolo and Rome.Please do not miss this tiny but exquisite jewel in Rome’s wealth of tourist attractions.

One of the great museums of Rome. This is a wonderful museum full of some of Bernini's finest work. It is smaller than many other museums in the capital, which makes it even more appealing in a way. You don't feel exhausted and overwhelmed by the time you go through it (as sometimes happens with larger museums like the Vatican Museum or the Louvre). It is really a fantastic place in the middle of one of the huge beautiful parks in Rome. Be sure to make reservations before you plan your trip. During the summer, you may have to do this many weeks in advance.

Something fab to do on a Sunday. I booked my ticket online so just had to collect it there on the day. I would recommend doing this if you can to save on queuing time. In fact the museum website states that you must reserve your ticket online at www.ticketeria.ie although I think you might be able to buy it on the day but you may have a long wait as groups of certain numbers are allowed entereance at timed intervals. Booking online would guarentee entry for your preferred timeslot. Allow yourself plenty of time as the gallery is set in a fabulous park. On a Sunday expect to see a lot of the locals out enjoying their sunday too. That was a real treat. There was even a Carbinieri horse band playing in the park. You can hire four wheeled bikes that two can pedal with room for extra adults or kids too you could also hire those things that you stand on whith wheels. Don't know what they're called but it's fun to see people on them :)At the Gallery itself you have to check your bag in and camera's are strictly forbidden. The ticket sales and bag check are downstairs. There are doors either side of the main entrance stairs. It takes around 2-3 hours to go round. Allow longer if you want to explore the huge park though. Once in the front door if you turn left the first actual room you go in is the Caravaggio room. The paintings are awe inspiring. One of my favourites in this room isn't a Caravaggio it's The Judgement of Solomon by Jose de Ribera. Look out for it , it's so moving. The scupltures too are outstanding. Especially the Rape of Proserpina.Before you leave via the gift shop, be sure to grab a coffee and a pastry at the cofee shop. You'll need some refreshment by then :). I was grateful for it myself.
Highlight of our week in Rome!. We are glad we went here near the end our our trip. It is outstanding!!!

Amazing Italian Collection. You must book in advance to go to this gallery. Timings are 9, 11, 1, 3 and 5.Definitely get the ROMA PASS. With the discount I think it was around 7 Euros. Dont use the free entry on this one as the Colosseum and Capitoline Museums are more expensive (13 Euros or so). I think full price here is 8.50?One of the nice things about this stunning collection is that it is very manageable. In Rome you are constantly walking everywhere for ever through massive collections like in the Vatican Museums. This is short (2 hrs tops) and sweet. The gallery is set in a beautiful park (like Italy's Central Park) which you can enjoy before or after you head out to pound the streets and sights again.

Just amazing. If you like the art of Bernini or Caravaggio then this is pretty much a must. There are a host of Bernini masterpieces (Rape of Proserpine, Apollo and Daphne, David, Bust of Scipione Borghese), and a room given over largely to Caravaggios (including David With the Head of Goliath). I'd wanted to see these works for years and wasn't disappointed. And all in a beautiful Baroque decorated house in a fantastic park away from the bustle and noise of the city centre. It' not cheap (€11.50 per person) and you have to pre-book tickets as 300 people are admitted every two hours, but it's a brilliant way to pass a couple of hours if you love Renaissance or 17th Century art. Check out the Roman mosaic floors too - very dramatic and bloodthirsty.

Incredible Collection. The collection is not particularily large but it has the very best of some of the very best artists such as Bernini and Carravaggio. Thickets have to be purchased in advance and only two hours are allowed to view the entire collection. In reality alot longer is required to do it justice. Only 30 minutes are allowed for the paintings. The audio is good and starts with the sculpture on the ground floor. This means you have to go outside to enter after getting your ticket and audio guide. Groups start onin the picture gallery on the second floor to avoid interfering with the individual tourists.

Don't miss this!. You need to book in advance to visit this museum. Visits to the museum are timed. They let you in at a certain time and then clear the whole museum before letting the next group in. I highly recommend the Walks of Italy Borghese tour to get the most out of the time you have in the museum. We were fortunate to be the only ones booked on the day we visited and had a private guide just for our family. Amanda was wonderful. Before the tour our kids (ages 12 & 15) weren't thrilled about the day's activity. Having been through days of visiting art & historic sites. Her explanations and stories about the art and artists engaged them and really made our visit special. We've been back from Rome for a few weeks now & they're still talking about the art in the Galleria Borghese.There are many extraordinary works here, but Bernini's Apollo & Daphne sculpture is truly one of the most beautiful pieces of art I have ever seen!

Dreamlike. do not miss for anything in the world.Online reservation must be made prior to visit.Bernini's sculptures wonderful, almost too beautiful for a human hand.From Domus Livia (Via Nazionale) I took bus number 52 up in front of Borghese gallery.attention to the 2 hour visit.photographing is not allowed

Stunning collection! Must-see.. The price of admission is worth it for the Bernini sculptures alone - and I am not a sculpture connoisseur. The ceilings are also incredible, so don't forget to look up! Don't forget that you must book your tickets in advance. Afterwards, budget some time to take a stroll through the Villa Borghese.

Amazing museum - every inch of the museum is gorgeous. The sculptures and paintings leave you stunned. Used the roma pass so entry was free. We did make reservations through our hotel so had no issues getting in. Once u r inside it is like stepping in a beautiful villa where every inch is an artwork. There is beautiful art on the ceilings, walls and ofcourse their masterpieces are excellent. The Bernini sculptures are awesome and so are the paintings on the second floorMake sure you DO take the audio guide (5 Euros) as that gives such good context that you almost feel like jumping in joy when you hear something and can actually see it in front of your eyes. The audio guide is brief and onlybfor select piece so you can indeed do all of the main pieces in your slot. Lastly, be on time. We were 15 mins late but still had to leave at the end of our slot which was sad. But still spent a good 1 HR and 45 mins in the museum. One of the main highlights of our Rome visit.

Not to be missed.. Beautiful location and artwork especially Bernini sculptures which help you appreciate the artwork all over Rome. You have to book a two hour period online and check your bags in before the visit but it is not a problem, If you want to carry a few items they will give you a bag. Arrive 30 mins before the time slot and if you purchase A Roma Pass once you are in Rome, you can use that to pay for your ticket. Take a cab to get there because it is easier to find that way but you can walk through the gardens to the Spanish steps afterwards. It's a bit of a hike downhill, but not too far.

Galleria Borghese - a Don't miss!. A must see while in Rome!! Did the audio guide tour and hit the highlights. There is more to see in the allotted time so a return visit might be necessary. Don't miss this while in Rome.
Amazing!!!. Great Galleria!!! Great Service. Buy tickets online and you can get in very quickly

Breathe in the most delightful art in Rome. Galleria Borghese contains art that is simply extraordinary. However, just a few suggestions I would like to share..1. You don't have to pre-book. I didn't book but arrived early and got tickets for the 11am slot - but for peace of mind, it is recommended to avoid disappontment. 2. Make sure you don't miss the exquisite Caravaggio, Raphael etc art which is located on the second floor. There is a stairway in one of the rooms to take you up there but it isn't well sign posted. If in doubt ask someone to point you in the right direction. 3. I would recommend getting an audioguide which really provides a little more historical/cultural context to the pieces. They are in numerous languages- To get one you have to leave one form of ID as a deposit, for example a driving license, credit card etc.4. You will be asked to leave your bags in a locker for which you will receive a key so when travelling to the Galleria it may be a good idea to take just what you need so you don't feel anxious leaving any valuables in a locker while you tour. It seemed totally safe and you get everything returned.5. Do try and book/go early if you can. You only have 2 hours and they are strict with this time slot so use the time well to enjoy the pieces! - Finally, when you first walk in look up at the ceiling, many people miss the beautiful fresco, make sure you don't!

fantastic.
