Went with 13 year old twins, who moaned until they got inside the Galleria, only had to pay EUR 4 each as I showed copies of their British passports, I had Roma Pass so it was free, would suggest getting a booking for early as possible as when we left the queue was very long, you still have to get in line even witth the Roma Pass to exchange for tickets, Galleriea was amazing, the statues left the twins speechless which was amazing in it's self!! Would love to go back again

If you see one museum in Rome.... Rome is packed full of amazing museums. But if your schedule doesn't allow you to visit more than one, please make it this one! It's an absolute jewel box full of treasures, small enough to get through in 1-2 hours yet packed with masterpieces.The collection of major Bernini sculptures inside alone makes the trip worth it -- they look like they're alive. There are also stunning works by Caravaggio, Boticelli, Raphael, Titian, Veronese, and more, as well as ancient Roman statuary and even some mosaics. You'll get a little bit of everything in one spot! The Palazzo housing the collection is also eye-popping, and getting there involves a lovely stroll through the lush Villa Borghese park.The only wrinkle? You must reserve tickets online in advance for a specific entry time. But this is easily done, even at the last minute, and prevents you from wasting your trip standing in the kinds of nightmare lines that pop up at the massive Vatican museum.
Bernini. Galleria and Villa Borghese was the best part of our trip. Bernini's statues at the gallery were wonderful and the villa has a large park to rest. The tickets are valid for 2 hours

Some stunning art but........ This is a good venue to view some classical art but it gets busy, the ticketing system is - well let's say 'italian'! Also the air con wasn't working went we went so the heat made it very oppresive. Gardens are nice as well. Overall there are plenty of free places to visit in Rome but if you run out of these then the villa is worth a few hours.

Nice place - leave ANY bags/purses at hotel!!!. It is a beautiful gallery with nice collections; however, even tiny purses must be checked. It may be on their website, but I did not see this warning. The staff could tell I was not comfortable with this and gave me a key, saying it was locked up- this did little to reassure me that it was actually in a locked bin. With the timed entry, you can't even take it back to the hotel. They also need your passport if you want to rent a headset - so if you only carry a copy, or don't like parting with your passport, you are out of luck. With general concerns of fraud & having read reports on various forums of credit card theft when renting equipment within the park, I questioned my visit. I am a seasoned traveler & generally a trusting person, but have rarely encountered such rigid requirements at a site. Needless to say, I had an extremely short visit and have no plans to go back to Gallery Borghese during my next trip to Rome in a few months. The staff wasn't all that nice either - and this was when I was still looking forward to my visit (before I learned of the bag check requirement). If you go, plan on doubling back to your hotel to get your stuff after your visit, or plan on checking it. When you go to pick up your online ticket, arrive early and go to the entrance at ground level (under the stairs). You cannot use the reduced museum discount from the Rome Pass online - you have to pay full price online or call the gallery to make your reservation with your pass.

Villa Borghese. I went to the Villa Borghese with my daughter, we had bought the tickets prior to our trip whilst still in the UK.You have to be at the villa 30 mins before time and you are only allowed 2 hrs in the villa due to numbers.Cameras and videos are not allowed and all your bags are removed from you on entry and placed into lockers. The first floor room is full of Art works and I hadn't purchased an audio guide so a lot passed me by as the signage was all in Italian. The next floor was statues and this for me was more enjoyable. The grounds at the villa are lovely with fountains all over. You could easily spend a few hours wandering around. There are fountains right at the entrance whereby you can refill your water bottles. Apparently the best spring water is on the route to the boating lake just sticking out of a rock but we missed it!Tip - either plan to visit early or late as the heat is unbearable once the sun is up.
Ecellent to get away from the hustle of Rome. Excellent place to spend time out of the heat and crowds of central Rome, great place to take the family

Make sure you reserve in advance!. Not to be missed!!! but make sure you reserve and buy your ticket online! (One cannot enter without reservation!!!!!!!!!!!and you are given a time slot and 2 hours to visit.)Before or after your visit, make sure you tour the large and wonderful gardens by bike and go boating on the lake!!!If you have a car, you can easily park (that is in August) near the piazza del popolo.ENJOYPS. impossible to take any picture in the galleries, you have to check your belongings at the entrance

One of the best places in Rome!!!. we LOVED it!!! if you love art you should and have to see it!!!we made a reservation from abroad so that we could enter and it was a smart thing to do since there were tourists there that didn't booked and had no reservation code and they didn\t enter because the place was full.

Fabulous Art. The museum is breath taking. The Bernini's are so amazing it is impossible to think how this delicate work could be carved in marble. The breadth of the collection is stunning. A must see for art lovers. This visit was a highlight of our Rome trip.The tickets are timed so you must proceed at a good pace to take it all in but worth every minute. Nice garden surrounding the gallery.You must book in advance to assure you don't miss this gem.In order to get an electronic tour guide you must surrender your passport to assure return of the guides.

The magnificent Bernini!. The Bernini's are the most beautiful things I have ever seen in my life. I strongly recommend going here.Be warned. If you don't make a reservation you will be rejected. But if you persist, you might just get lucky and be let in so don't leave!!!!
Wow!...don't miss this Gallery, a must see. This is the best of the best. Really. Better than the Vatican museums. I mean it. do not miss the Galleria Borghese.

Reserve your tickets online. Galleria Borghese has one of the greatest collection of Bernini sculptures as well as Caravaggio paintings and many others. Really nice gallery, however, at least in high season you are limited to only 2 hour visit and must have reservation for certain time in order to buy tickets. We didn't know that and had to wait 2 hours for the next entrance time (luckily the gardens and park have enough attractions to spend time (quadruple bikes, auto carts, little boats on the pond that you can rent) so, we were able to get in afterall. There is even a little zoo in the park, that we didn't go to, but you can easily spend a whole day in the Borghese park and museum.
A breathtaking must see. The beauty of the building and its integration with artwork inside make it an unforgettable experience.The great thing is that is is located very close to Rome city center
Spectacular!. Our family liked it better than the Uffizi. Beautiful artwork, beautiful building located in a very nice park. The Botticelli sculptures were amazing.

Worth every minute of it. we called for reservation before we left Canada and they gave us a reservation number which they retreived very easily the day of our visit. We booked for 111h . You are allowed only 2h and we chose to start by the Pinacoteca at the second level. You are allowed in this area for 30 min so by doing it first, you avoid the crowd entering the Galleria on the main floor , you vist, then you go downstrairs to the Galleria itself. The showpeices are the Bernini sculptures. Take your time, circle around them, see the story unfold. The time allocated was more than enough. I cicled around at least 2 additional times, trying to imagine life back then.there was an forgettable sculpture in the aviary (in the garden)we went there by taxi from P della Minerva (near Pantheon) (6.10E)we brought lunch that we ate in the park after the tour.we took the bus back towrds the centro.

Best in Italy.. Galleria Borghese is well worth working into your travel plans. Access is limited and tickets were required but the experience was quite possibly the artistic highlight of our nine days in Italy.

Small gallery with remarkable sculpture. Remarkable sculpture is a smaller gallery. There is a time limit on you visit so be prepared to be amazed repeatedly as you hurry from one room to the next. Wish I could have just sat & admired some piece longer.

An art lover's must see. If you love renaissance art and sculpture, you must see the Galleria Borghese. The Bernini works alone are work the 8 euro entry fee. You must, however, prepurchase your tickets, or you won't go in. They are generally sold out everyday, at least in summer.

Probably the most enjoyable museum in Italy. Visiting Galleria Borghese was a wonderful experience. Many other museums in Italy feature incredible art collections, but this museum stands out in the way it is presented. Located in a beautiful pallazzo surrounded by a huge park, the art is exceptionally well displayed and is not overwhelming. Very importantly, visits are limited to 2 hours and the number of visitors is also strictly limited, so that the overall experience, particularly during the busy summer months when other museums are packed and uncomfortable, was really wonderful. It is important to book in advance; very easy to do online.

Make a reservation and GO!. The reservation was key because it can sell-out a few days in advance (we went on a Sat afternoon and the next day available was Tuesday). You only get 2hrs inside and it's timed for crowd control, which is great. They're serious about "no bags" - my smallish purse got me sent back to bag check, but that's free so it wasn't an issue. Definitely use Rick Steves to make sure you get everything you want out of a visit here. Also make sure to make time to walk through the park nearby - the umbrella pines are beautiful.

Very very hot with poor air conditioning - how do the priceless works of art survive?. The title says it all - a must-see for the beautiful Bernini collection, however the rooms are extremely hot. There were visible airconditioners in many rooms, however they offered insufficient cooling in the gallery. Was quite unpleasant. Would be better to visit in cooler months, or very early in the day.

a must see while in Rome. A fabulous art gallery. You will not be disappointed and unlike the Colosseum and the Vatican, it is not over crowded and therefore you can see everything properly. Tip. Make sure you book online or you will not be able to get in.

Fantastic - glad we booked so much to see. Just amazing took my Mother and 17 yr old daughter and exceeded our expectations, the art that is here is amazing and the sculptures out of this world. Bernini's Daphne and Apollo is beautiful. We to booked in advance as they only let a certain number in each day. What I didn't expect was the entrance procedure, you enter downstairs in an airless crypt type area, and you need to leave all bags in a secure cloakroom, then you join another queue to collect your guide earphones, and they take id as a deposit. There is a lift but its a barrell shaped basket. Villa is in parkland

Excellent. Guide books make it seem this excellent gallery is some way out of Rome; it isn't. The bus from Rome central station stops directly at the gallery entrance. It is at most a 10 minute ride. The sculptures just take the breath away. You only get 2 hours in the gallery.
Small but very special. Not the biggest museam of all, but Bernini's Daphne alone is worth the trip.

Absolutely Stunning. This gallery is absolutely breathtaking. The amount of art is mind blowing. As someone who appreciates good art, this was a dream come true!You need to get your tickets ahead of time, so plan accordingly.
Do not miss this - must buy tickets in advance. Fabulous sculptures and Architecture. Bernini is a genius!

Amazing - the best museum I've ever been to. We showed up at the Borghese Galley without a ticket or reservation, and were able to snag the last 2 of 3 remaining tickets. What luck! You get a two-hour ticket with the entry date stamped on it, and most people trickle out of the place by the end of the two hours, but my husband and I stayed there the entire time, and had the opportunity to have the best museum experience of our European trip.The Borghese is not the biggest museum in Rome, but it packs a punch - no filler here, only some of the finest sculptures in the world set in beautiful themed rooms with ceiling and wall art. Bernini's Rape of Proserpina, Apollo and Daphne, and David were the highlights of the museum - they are breathtaking, and I feel fortunate to have seen them. I have to say that after seeing the British National Galley, the Louvre, the Uffizi, the Accademia, the Vatican Museum, and others, the Borghese Gallery really is my favorite.
Loved the art. If you like art, visit this museum. I was truly impressed with the collection. One of my favorite sites in Rome.
Well worth a visit!. We went and had english tour guide. The tour was excellent and we learnt alot and we would definately return

Bernini Sculptures Are a Must See. Photographs of Bernini's sculptures truly do not do them justice. The details are exquisite --- the leaves stemming from Daphne's fingertips as she is transformed into a tree, the tear falling along Proserpina's cheek as Pluto abducts her, David's expression as he confronts Goliath. The audio tour provided wonderful insight into the creation of these pieces. Do make your reservations early. Another couple that we spoke with were unable to visit the gallery, as they had not made a reservation before arriving in Rome and no times remained during the rest of their stay. Also, be sure to arrive early enough to pick up your tickets and check your bags (we actually picked up our tickets the day before which saved us time the morning of our visit). If you have time, stroll the beautiful park before or after your visit to the gallery.

Magnificent Sculptures in an Intimate Setting. Galleria Borghese is right up there with must-see attractions like the Colosseum and Roman Forum. A bus takes you directly to and from Villa Borghese, the setting of the museum, from the Roma Termini train station. Don't be turned off by the requirement of advance reservations. Since we were getting the Roma Pass for our 3-day visit, I had to call the ticket office (closed on the weekends) instead of making reservations online. We received a confirmation number to submit upon entry and it was very easy. Galleria Borghese has many restrictions – reservations, check backpacks, no cameras, two-hour time slot – but all of this adds up to a relaxing, uncrowded museum experience. It was so much nicer than the hot, stuffy, extremely crowded and claustrophobic experience at the Vatican Museum. The smaller scale of the building (basically a mansion) makes it easy on the kids, too. The museum houses some amazing artwork but the sculptures are the real draw. Bernini's "David" is much more interesting than Michelangelo's, no offense. The teardrop on the girl's face in the sculpture "Pluto and Proserpina" is absolutely surreal. After enjoying the art, go out to the park and explore beautiful Villa Borghese. Highly, highly recommended!

Totally worth every Euro!:)). I booked my ticket via Select Italy cost me 33.99 USD, a little bit expensive than direct booking but totally worth it. Ah! I could stay and stare at Apollo and Daphne for eternity! Two hours is definitely not enough. I suggest you first look for the most famous sculptures and paintings for they are really worth seeing then you can marvel on the less famous ones with your extra time. It would be a pity not to see all of them.Be sure to come ahead of time for you still need to deposit your things at their counter and if you want to have an audio guide which for me, the best thing ever , you need to deposit some money for that as well. I forgot how much exactly ( maybe 10 euros, not sure) but you can get it back as soon as you return the headset. BTW, if you have an overactive bladder, better visit the restrooms before the tour..enjoy!

please fit this into your itinerary when in Rome. This is a Must-do when in Rome. Advance reservations need to be made, which is very easy to do before your visit, or through your hotel when you arrive in Italy, or in Rome. The advance reservations are great, since it makes wandering the museum leisurely, without pushing, shoving. No overcrowding here! Arrive early for some lovely wine,and/or a snack while awaiting entrance into this jewel. The artwork is breathtaking, the grounds, beautiful. We were a group of four adults, and we all had a wonderful evening here. I hope you all reading this have a delightful time.

The most beautiful museum I have been to.. I have been blessed with the opportunity of visiting some of the best museums in Europe: Louvre, Vatican Museum, D'Orsay... the Borgese Gallery is without a doubt the most beautiful. The best feature is that several of the sculptures are in their original setting, the sculptures were designed for the rooms in which you find them. Tickets must be purchased in advance, my hotel concierge took care of the arrangements for me. All belongings must be checked upon entry, purses, jackets, backpacks, cameras, I rented the audio guide and it is well worth it. Entry times are every two hours, and you are able to visit the gallery as you please. The gallery features Bernini at his best, you can see the sculptures up close, take in every detail, my favorite sculpture is "Apollo and Daphne", exquisite. Bernini's "David" is amazingly expressive and "Rape of Proserpine" is the most powerful of them all... it is mind-blowing to see what Bernini could do with marble. Take your time, the gallery will not disappoint. Once you are done, be sure to roam about the Borghese Gardens. The walk is calming before heading back into the awesome insanity that is Rome.

Overall the Borghese is a monumental work of art.. Frustrating to many a traveller are the critics, who when you get home tell you about the wonderful places you did not visit, the one they never mention is the Galleria Borghese. Rome is a complex city and I doubt that any tourist could visit everything of interest in a short period. However there were a couple of places that are a must to visit. One of these is the Galleria Borghese. It is at one end of the Borghese Gardens which are immediately behind the Church at the top of the Spanish Steps (Piazza Spagna) A short walk through the gardens will bring you to the Borghese. Check that it is open before you go and note that there are two entrance times per day. This gallery holds a candle to other great galleries such as the Louvre, The Prado and the Vatican Museum. Prominent among the various works of art, sculptures and frescoes is a remarkable and large collection of the work of Bernini. It is said that Rome belongs to Bernini. The Borghese collection bears tis out.

Not Worth the Price or the Hassle. This is a nice museum, but it is not worth the effort to get there and back. We took the subway, which is pretty convenient, but there's nothing around it. There are virtually no options for dining nearby. in the heat, I would spend the day elsewhere!

A Must to See. I made an on-line booking about a month prior the visit because admission is strictly allowed for only 360 persons every 2 hours. We arrived about 30 minutes before our scheduled time slot. We showed the printout to the counter where we did not need to wait in queue. After getting the tickets, we rented audio, pick up the pamphlet, deposited bags and cameras at the cloak room and walked upstairs to wait at the entrance. The doors opened right on time. We started from the top floor (second floor) first to avoid the crowd at Bernini's Apollo and Daphne which was displayed on the ground floor. Sculptures and paintings are amazing. If not using guide service, audio is a must to help you appreciate and know more about the collections in this fantastic gallery. After the museum, we strolled in the huge Borghese park. It was quite a long walk to to the Spanish Steps though. Well worth a visit.

Fantastic museum, a must see. Shame about the staff.. We arrived at the museum on a Saturday afternoon to be informed on a board outside that we'd have to return on Tuesday as they'd sold out till then. We went downstairs to book for the Tuesday only to be informed we could go in 'now'.The ticket guy seemed to be very stressed about something & was talking poor English very fast. When he slowed down some, we understood that bags & camera/phones had to be handed in at the cloak room before admittance - fair enough.The cloakroom staff were equally as miserable & surly as was one of the 'caretakers' in the museum which was a shame.This was my second visit to the Galleria Borghese but my partners first & part of the shine was taken off our visit due to the attitude of some of the staff, especially as I found the general tone around the rest of the city, hotel,shops & bars had been so welcoming & friendly.The Galleria Borghese for me is right up there with The Vatican & Colosseum as 'must sees'. I'm not a massive art fan 'but I know what I like' & I love the Villa Borghese, the collection there (David & Apollo and Daphne are my favourites), the ceilings, mosaic floors & the sprawling grounds (which is a lovely days stroll & explore in itself)I would have given an excellent but for the sour pusses.Enjoy but wear a tin hat

Excellent Sculpture Museum. We toured the Galleria Borghese with a guide from Through Eternity and had a great time on our tour. The gallery is in a wonderful park setting that itself is worth spending time in. You will see sculptures done with such craft that the mable looks soft and the fingers of one figure press into the marble 'flesh' of another. Many famous works of art can be found here. Bernini and Canova dominate. I suggest that you spend a bit of time with Bernini's "David" and witness the resolve on his face. Apollo and Daphne and Th eRape of Proserpine are testiments to Bernini's virtuosity. Canova's rendering of Pauline Bonapart as Venus is quite striking as well.There are some worthy painting here as well by Caravaggio, Raphael and Titian. This is one of those annoying museums that won't let you take photos even without a flash.

One of our favorite museums!. The sculptures are AMAZING! You must make a reservation in advance. If you are going to use a Roma pass you can call for a reservation code and not have to pre-pay. Then you just give them the reservation code when you arrive and show them the Roma pass. They apply the discount and you pay the difference. This is an absolute MUST VISIT. Because they control the entry numbers for each time slot it is very pleasant and you can wander without a mob. Our 2 hour time slot gave us plenty of time to see it all and even go back and revisit the sculptures downstairs!

Call center closed on Saturday and Sunday. To visit Galeria Borghese, you have to book prior to your visit. We arrived Rome on Saturday and called the call center to book for a visit on Sunday. But the answering machine said the call center is working from Monday to Friday. We were lucky to get in because we went there early as possible on Sunday morning. We got in for the 9 - 11 am visit hours and when we went out it was very crowded. If we were late, it would be impossible. And there it said the tickets were sold until Tuesday. So, if you want to go there, book your ticket early.

Favorite museum in Rome. This small museum is worth the hassle of getting a reservation. The villa itself is beautiful and a perfect setting for the artwork. Spring for the audio guide, it really adds to your appreciation of the art, especially the sculptures. Bernini's Apollo and Daphne alone is worth the admission. It is my favorite museum in three trips to Rome.

Stunning, Absolutely Stunning.. One of, if not the most, stunning museum I have ever been to. I wasn't too sure when I first arrived there, but as soon as I laid eyes on the first Bernini statue I was captivated. The work is breathtaking, particularly the main statues displayed in each room. Who knew such gorgeous and life-like carvings could be created!? I now thoroughly understand what people mean when they say a piece of artwork strikes them to their core. I highly recommend this museum to any art-lover out there. However, if you really just hate artwork, then this place is not for you. Reminder: you need to place an order for your tickets online before arriving. They only let a limited number of people in at once and it's only for a certain amount of time as the museum is quite small and they want everyone to easily observe the work. You are also not allowed to brings bags into the museum itself, but they have storage lockers available where you pick up the tickets. It's very safe. The museum is basically situated inside of a mansion inside of the park. If you take the metro to, I believe, the Spagna stop, one of the exits takes you toward the park. It might not seem like the right place as you start walking through, but trust me, it is! People are very helpful, especially since they know it's hard to find, so don't hesitate to ask. There's vendors, etc. throughout the park and signs as you get farther in, so it shouldn't be too much of a problem.

Wonderful collection, well worth the visit. This is one of the top 3 attractions we visited in our recent trip to the Mediterranean. They allow only a limited number of visitors every 2 hours, and when we got there tickets were sold out till the next few days. We're glad we booked our tickets in advance, otherwise we would have missed this wonderful art collection ! Unlike the other sites that can get very crowded, in here you can browse to your hearts' content because of the limited number o fvisitors.This is one site you ABSOLUTELY have to visit when in Rome ! Tips: Get the audioguides for an extra 5E, you'll get much more from your visit. Also give enough time to get there, the building is a far walk from the entrance plus if you book through the internet, tickets have to be picked up 30 minutes before your scheduled visit. Too bad no picture taking is allowed inside , cameras have to be checked in..

Great place to visit, because it's not crowded, but not that good either. I liked the reservation/time slot system and you must be a dummie if you are experiencing troubles with the reservation process. With the code (actually with your last name only) you get your tickets, and you enter the gallery at your time slot. Simple, easy and not crowded as all other attractions in Rome. Still, is it worth it? Yes and no. If you're a Bernini fanatic, then yes. If you've seen world's best art galleries, then you will not be that impressed. I found the statue floor interesting, especially couple of Bernini's masterpieces were really amazing. The second floor is just OK, and for the whole gallery one hour is more than enough (without the audio guide).

Overrated compared to others. Perhaps we would have been more impressed seeing the Borghese Gallery prior to visiting the Vatican Museum. Sadly, this was one of the few things we actually regretted seeing in Rome. The grounds that the gallery sit on are beautiful; however, the gallery itself is nothing special compared to all the artwork in Rome. The hassle of reserving the tickets and waiting for our reservation time was certainly not worth what was inside. Even then, there were no postcards of the particular paintings I did enjoy, so I will have nothing to remember them by.

Don't Miss It. No reservation for the Galleria? Thanks to the Concierge of the Hilton Cavalieri we showed up @8:45 am and asked about cancellations. We were permitted to pay the entrance fee and tour. This was indeed to most enthralling experience of our visit i Rome. Get the audio guide and enjoy. You are limited to 2 hours but you'll have time to see everything really notable.

Fabulous Villa/Gallery - A must see!. We had pre-booked our tickets and enjoyed a wonderful tour of this Villa/Gallery. The works of art are amazing and the sculptures are absolutely fantastic. The Villa is a visually amazing, very inch decorated with frescos, art, sculptures in a very well preserved museum. This is a must see - do book ahead otherwise you will be disappointed! The gardens and surrounding park is an oasis in the centre of Rome!

awesome experience. We arrived at 8:30, grabbed a cup of coffee and pastry, picked up our audio-guide (excellent), and were amazed at the building and all of it's contents. I've been to every art museum in Paris, Amsterdam, London, Florence, Rome (including Vatican) and it was my favorite museum. I am an oil-painter and an art enthusiast...my husband is not.....we both LOVED this place. Bernini's sculptures were amazing and the background narration given by the audio-guide was fascinating. Not TMI like so many are. (vatican, Pompeii, etc....I usually shut them off the first 10 min.)  Afterwards, we rented bikes and enjoyed the gardens (really more of a park...not a lot of flowers). Lots of good food vendors and cafes to grab a picnic or sit at a table and enjoy getting away from the crowds. We went on a Fri. morning then spent the rest of the day relaxing before our Vatican entry at 7:00 pm (highly recommend - no crowds)

A must for art lovers. Outstanding smaller gallery with an incredible collection of art and sculpture (led by a few Bernini masterpieces) in a stunning building. Your ticket is for a timed admission and that does cause a bit of a crowd to form once you get inside. This tends to thin as you get further into the building and you can double back at the end and have some rooms to yourself. Would recommend getting the audio guide to the get the most out of your visit.I've read some reviews or Forum comments that say you don't need to book tickets in advance - well, a couple walked in ahead of us and were told the next available tickets were 7 days from then. This was only the third week of May.While waiting outside we even got to see Rick Steves filming a piece at the Gallery - it took about 10 takes to get him walking up a set of stairs and speaking for maybe 15 seconds. On that basis I would guess a 30 minute program on Rome must take about 6 months to film!

Overrated. After going to the Vatican Museum, Louvre, etc. Gallery Borghese is just okay. They did not have any of the highlights, therefore the crowds were somewhat manageable. You need to reserve your tickets prior to going and you have only 2 hours to see all the rooms. While we were there the lights went out for almost 15-20 minutes. We ended up leaving shortly afterward. Unless you are truly passionate for art, I would not recommend this museum. I Just a note that you will need to check-in all your bags, purses, cameras. Also, I highly recommend coming early, the signs within the park are a bit odd, and a few of us had trouble finding the museum.

If you only have time for one museum in Rome, go here.. Magnificent museum in the Villa Borghese just north of the main tourist areas of Rome. Former home of Cardinal Borghese who had unlimited appetite and unlimited funds to collect fine art. The Bernini sculptures alone are worth the trip. Like many museums in Rome, the building housing the art is a work of art in itself. Be sure and buy tickets online prior to arriving in Rome to ensure you can get inside, and purchase the audio guide in the museum for your tour. The number 52 bus gets you there from the Via Veneto. After your visit to the museum, spend the next few hours walking around the park.

Great Museum. I enjoyed seeing the sculptures of Bernini and all the artwork in the museum. I think this is one of the best museums in the world. I feel lucky that I was able to make a reservation to the museum on my first try on the phone.My favorite was Gian Lorenzo Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. Bernini also sculpted The Rape of Proserpine, Aeneas and Anchises, and David with the Sling. There was also the Venus Victrix, a life-size statue of Pauline Borghese created by Canova. She was the sister of Napoleon and the wife of Prince Camilo Borghese. In the Great Hall, there were 12 busts of the Emperors, created by Giovanni Battista Della Porta. Our visit to this museum was very satisfying.

Unpleasant Staff completely ruin a possibly good experience.. After traveling all over Europe and visiting plenty of museums, I must say that I have never felt more unwelcome and insulted as when attempting to visit the museum at Villa Borghese. The very unpleasant man at the ticket office ( obviously hates his job, his life,...whatever...not only treated us as we were stupid, but also yelled at us as we were exiting the ticket office. By all means...avoid the ticket office here until this angry Queen is fired or finds a new life elsewhere (perhaps the planet Jupiter is more suitable for this creature).

Now that's what I call art!. I'm now a huge fan of Bernini's. The sculptures and paintings in this museum are astonishing. I read that you should go immediately to the paintings and work your way back to the beginning which we did. When we got back to the sculptures we were all alone with them. Just 2 of us and perhaps the most incredible art in the world. While you are there wander the gardens and rent one of those two or four seat guadro bicycles. We spent a good 8 hours at the gallery and park and didn't see everything. Allow a full day!

Worth every penny and every minute!. I didn't quite understand all the fuss in reserving tickets in advance in order to visit this museum... well... because it is the key to a great experience! By restricting number of visitors, we didn't have to deal with the crowds we ran into such as Uffizi (avoid it at all cost) and the Vatican. Another big plus of Borghese is its limited collection and small but beautiful facility. They don't have a large collection but MOST Of them are true master pieces (most than other large museums). You don't need to walk miles to see all of them. Their audio guide is very organized and has wonderful content. It not only explains the significance of the art but also includes very interesting anecdotal related stories. Out of our entire trip to Italy (Rome, Florence, Venice), this is our favorite museum. A MUST SEE!

Wow! What a beautiful museum.. I am very glad that I learned about this museum before my trip to Rome and booked a time to see it. I fell in love with the incredible Bernini sculptures and my husband loved the paintings. It was worth every penny and I'm glad we paid extra for the audio guides, they were very helpful.Things to keep in mind: You can only use the Roma Pass if you book by phone. Booking online is easy - just make sure you remember to print out your confirmation and bring it with you so you can get your tickets. I highly recommend following Rick Steves' Rome guidebook (which has a good self-guided tour in it) and start with the upper floor (paintings) first as most people start with the sculptures on the lower floor. By following this advice (thanks Steve - you are awesome!), we had an opportunity to be alone in rooms with some of the world's most gorgeous artwork - what a thrill! If you decide to book a tour with a tour company, make sure they keep their numbers small (i.e. no more than 15 people) as some of the rooms aren't very large and being part of a large group would take away from the experience. You must check ALL of your baggage (cameras, phones, purses, etc) but you can't check your jacket. So, stuff your jacket in your bag if you don't want to carry it around. We found the park surrounding the museum to be perfect for a picnic and enjoyed walking through the park afterwards towards the Piazza del Popolo (great views from above). If you're planning a picnic, buy your sandwiches before you get there, the sandwiches sold from the trucks at the park are overpriced and gross. Or, arrive early or stay late and eat at the cafe on site.

Although small, this has to be one of the best, if not the best, museum I have been to. I decided to visit this museum based on the AA guide recommending it as one of the best museums in Rome. Be warned, this is very popular and, in order to ensure you get to see it, you need to book your tickets in advance. This can be down in a couple of ways, using their online booking service which incurs a 1€ fee on top, or you can reserve a ticket by telephone if you want to use the Roma Pass. However, they sell out quickly...I, however, did not pre book and turned up early on a Wednesday morning, I waited outside from about 8 a.m. to ask about returns or any spares. The sign outside said they were already sold out until the following Tuesday. When the doors opened for the pre booking collection at half past I asked and they were unable to tell me until just after 9 a.m., once they knew the exact numbers for that session. From what I know, they only allow 300 in the museum in each 2 hour session. I was lucky enough to have a return and was able to enter at 9.10. However, I would recommend that you do not get your hopes up, and pre book.The museum is fantastic with some of the best sculptures I have ever seen by Bernini. They are trult breathtaking and in wonderful condition. The two best, in my opinion, are David and Apollo & Daphne. This is an absolute must for any art lover, and even for those who are not into art as the museum has a wonderful, but relatively small, collection, if you compare it to the Louvre etc.You only have a limited time in the museum but the two hours allocated was adequate.

Very good collection of artwork. You can only reserve your tickets online. You can't buy them when you get there. Once you reserve your tickets, you have to be there a half hour before the entrance time to validate your voucher. I highly recommend to rent audio guides because there's so much in depth information that is provided. If not go with a tour guide. This place has one of the most beauitul art collections, I especially love the statues based off the ancient stories/myths that holds much attention as the centerpiece of the rooms. There are many rooms to see with much artwork. It's very well worth visiting. Purses are not allowed nor are photos allowed. You need to check in your purse but for no charge!

Favorite museum in Rome, incredible sculptures. This is my favorite museum in Rome. I studied in Rome for months and this museum really stood out to me. It's small, but the sculptures by Bernini are like nothing I have ever seen. It would be a shame to visit Rome and skip this museum. Make sure to make reservations early.
Not to be missed. sculptures by Bernini are stunning. see the works of a true genius up close & personal. make sure to book ahead.

Do not miss this intimate museum!. First of all, reservation are essential (if you don't want to chance not getting in since there's limited amount of people who get 2 hours to explore the museum). We made a reservation by calling from the US so we could use our Roma Pass and not pay ahead of time. This went smoothly. We walked from our hotel near the Spanish Steps and it's a lovely, albeit longer walk than anticipated! The walk within the park reminded me a bit of Central Park in New York City.Rick Steve tour book recommended that we start on the second floor where there would be less of a crowd, which we did. We were able to admire every piece with a slow walk and some stoppage time with extra time to visit some of the more beautiful marble sculptures 2 or 3 times before we were kicked out. Don't rush, 2 hours doesn't seem like enough time, but it worked well for us. The marble statues were the highlights of the visit there - read up on what you are going to see, the statues will be even more inspiring. No pictures allowed, so leave time to soak up what you can. We didn't get a chance to really explore the grounds due to cold rain (we were there in November), but if you have the time, I would recommend it - a great way to step away from the crowds.

Simply the Best. The Borghese gallery is a small museum with masterpieces in each room. It limits the amount of people allowed to enter which makes for an enjoyable viewing experience. If you are going to Rome, than this place should not be missed.

Best museum in Italy, snotty guards. Ok, so the experience is a little unnecessarily intense (I have to check my cell phone and my purse??) but this museum is worth the hassle. The Bernini sculptures are an amazing break from all the Renaissance-era art. Get the audio guide...super helpful!

Absolutely superb. Very, very worthwhile. When you visit Rome for the first time you feel overwhelmed by the beautiful piazzas and the Vatican and Ancient Rome routes. And it's quite likely that you decide to skip this gallery or not hear of it at all. But if you have more that one day in Rome, DO visit it. Bernini's sculptures inside are pure aesthetic pleasure, both to the eyes of an ever-grumbling teenager and to the eyes of an experienced traveller who's seen the Louvre and Uffizi. After visisting many cities and many museums and many galleries, memories and places get mixed up. But there are always a couple of places which you will never forget, Galleria Borghese is one of those few!

A not-to-be-missed attraction in Rome.... Although you must have a reservation to tour the Galleria Borghese, it is truly the most fascinating site to see in Rome. The audio tour is a must, as is getting a bite to eat & taking it outside to eat on their lovely grounds while people watching. This is an attraction you won't regret going to. It is so much more breathtaking than you can imagine from pictures

Make the Effort, Make a Day of It. Don't be put off by the advance booking procedure because it is well worth the effort to see the incredible Bernini marble sculptures alone. I am not an avid art fan however was in awe of these beautiful sculptures and even more so knowing that he completed some at age 15. Our Hotel Concierge booked on our behalf with less than 24 hours notice, so this may be the easiest way to arrange a viewing. Note that the 9am tour is the least busiest (and most relaxing).Because of the Galleria's strict booking procedures you are able to see the artworks without jostling through the crowd (they limit the number of visitors daily, allocating 2 hour timeslots to each group) and without feeling pressured to move onto the next item. It is a truly amazing collection of art - Caravaggio, Bernini, Raphael, ancient Roman mosaics from the 1st century AD, ancient Greek sculptures, ceilings painted by Renaissance Masters, Egyptian art etc. I would highly recommend paying the extra 6 euro to join a Guided Tour with a qualified Art Curator (4 euro for audio guide). The information we received about various pieces in each room really enhanced our visit. Otherwise would have been wondering about looking at the pieces without realising their significance in the Borghese collection. And the stories of how some pieces were "acquired" were truly fascinating. The curator who conducted our Tour had a particular love for Bernini and her enthusiasm rubbed off onto all of us. She even told us the where the best position to stand to see various aspects of the sculptures and artworks. I would also recommend purchasing a Roma Pass before making your booking to receive either free entry or a discounted entry. We found the Roma Pass to be incredible value as it also included all transportation in Rome (25euro).The Galleria is situated in a stunning house which used to be the Borghese Family's country estate; so the grounds and gardens are amazing too. Make a day of it by attending the 9am viewing, then hiring a bike to ride around the lakes and sculptures of Villa Borghese. There is plenty to see and kiosks for food/refreshments. It is actually a relaxing day when considering how frantic Rome is.You can catch a bus to the Galleria, or catch the Metro to Spagna. Follow the escalators to the top and take the exit to Via Veneto. It is a bit of a walk (about 10 mins) but not difficult to find the Galleria. Once inside Villa Borghese, there are signposts to the Galleria.Enjoy!

Awe-inspiring art, book ahead even with a Roma ticket ,and prepare yourself for the bad tempered staff. I cant add any more than has been said by many others about the impact this amazing place and it's artifacts has. The system of booking ahead has many advantages of not queueing for ages to get in, and because the numbers moving around the exhibits is limited you have a wonderful opportunity to get up close to some incredible sculptures. The trip was a little tinged not so much by own experiences, but by witnessing the way in which we saw the staff here talking to some visitors with a lack of patience or courtesy and bad temperedness. Still, I guess if you have all that priceless artwork to show your viewers are a bit of captive audience!

Must See Gallery for Art Lovers. One of my favorite things to do in foreign cities is to see their art, and so when I read about the Galleria Borghese collection, I decided we had to go, even though I usually avoid attractions that require any extra effort - and you are required to book ahead to visit the Borghese, as they only allow about 350 people in at a time, and each group is in for two hours. The building is in a lovely spot, and the collection is breath-taking - especially the rooms in which it is housed, but don't miss the Bernini sculptures, which look like they were once real and might come to life at any moment, or the paintings, which include everything from Rubens to Caravaggio. Note that photography is not permitted.I had occasion to need help from the staff, as my mother was feeling very unwell but didn't want to miss the gallery, so I had to arrange for her to have a wheel chair. The ticket desk staff was fairly rude to me, but the two women who were working the information desk were exceptionally helpful, ran around trying to figure out how to make it work, let my mother sit in one of their comfy chairs when she came in, and made sure that everything was set up so that we could enjoy our experience - they even let us in almost ten minutes early! We did end up having a hitch - due to the small size of the elevator, it was necessary for us to change wheel chairs on each floor, and the elevator could only be accessed by the staff - in that on the first floor, we could find no one who could help us get back down to the ground floor, so we managed the stairs. (the only staff member I found told me it was "impossible" even when I pointed at my mother in the wheel chair - but there was a definite language barrier making it harder).We also went to the cafe, which was tasty, and I've been happily reading the very thorough "The Borghese Gallery" book, and wishing all small museums had books that recorded their collections with such care.

Fantastic - an amazing collection. An amazing collection of portraits and sculptures - far too much to see in the 2 hour timeslot allocated. The museum is VERY strict on the timeslots and bgin asking visitors to leave 10 minutes before the allocated time expires. No cameras or bags are allowed so I suggest that you arrive at least 20 minutes before your allocated timeslot to allow to collect tickets, check in bags/cameras, pick up earphones and join the entry queue (to maximise the time in the museum).This is a popular attraction with restricted numbers so book tickets in advance. Well worthwhile - highly recommended.

A must see!. My fourth trip to Rome finally allowed me time to visit this wonderful gallery. I can't believe it took me this long! The art is simply magnificent, and the grounds peaceful and expansive. Be sure to take the bus, not the subway. The walk from the subway was substantial...much easier from the bus stop. Do take time to visit the gardens and just relax...Ah, dolce far niente!

Beautiful. The Galleria Borghese is a must see while in Rome. We were advised to take a bus to get to the gallery and the bus dropped us off at the entrance. One needs to make reservations to go to the gallery as it was fully booked on the day we went and glad that we had made reservations. We needed to phone in advance to get a timeslot and a reference number was supplied. We used the Roma pass so got free entry. Time is limited to 2 hours. No photography is allowed inside the gallery and you need to leave your cameras and bags in the bag deposit section. This is a bit chaotic and there are long queues to drop off and collect the bags. We did not experience any problems with our bags, nothing was taken. The sculptures and paintings are truly spectacular and is definitely a must do while in Rome.

My favorite experience in Rome. We had not planned to visit Galleria Borghese, but my tour guide in Florence (which was our stop prior to Rome) highly recommended this and gushed about the magnificent art and statues here, and so my Rome tour guide very kindly called and booked tickets for us just the day before. The mandatory reservations and quota on visitors meant that the museum was not as crowded as the Vatican or Uffizi, which allowed time to stand close and observe the pieces with minimal jostling. We used the audioguide, which was informative and had the right pace. I'm not an art lover but I really enjoyed and learnt a lot from this museum. The art pieces, especially the statues, were absolutely gorgeous. The size is just right and not overwhelming, and after 2 hrs I left feeling energised and wanting to learn more, whereas some other museums have just too much to see and, while enjoyable, took a lot of energy out of me.Note that there are 3 queues before entering the museum - one to collect the reserved tickets, one for baggage check (everything carried has to be checked in, not just bagpacks) and one for the audio guide. If you are visiting in a group, do divide up the queuing to minimise queuing time. I had a Roma Pass and this was one of the 2 free entrances that I used the pass for.

Great art, unfriendly staff. Some important things to note:1. Pre booking is essential - book tickets and pay online2. Like nearly every other museum in Rome, it is closed on Mondays, so if you are on a long weekend break plan your trip accordingly3. Be prepared to be herded at the start of your visit.Despite pre booking tickets, there is a long queue to exchange your e-ticket for the entrance ticket. The long list of rules (no bags, no cameras etc) stiulate that you must arrive 30 minutes before your scheduled visit time. (You are given an entrance time and an exit time). The time slots limit the number of visitors.We found the staff unfriendly and unsmiling. Three staff sitting at the "information desk" were more intent on having a discussion with one another than aiding visitors. We witnessed two staff actually having an argument in front of museum visitors. The gallery guide was difficult to read - the English version was written entirely in italics with no paragraphing or eye friendly typesetting. Beware school parties and guided parties who crowd the rooms despite the limit on the volume of visitors. It is best to try and circulate in the opposite direction to these large groups and bypass them, returning to the room where they were after they have moved on. Despite everything the art is amazing. Several important pieces were on loan, but the opportunity to "get close and personal" with some great Bernini sculptures and some Carravagio paintings was worth the considerable hassle and unpleasantness.

Borghese Gallery - Pauline Bonaparte as Venus. To get here you must take the metro and the bus but it is worth it. Also you cannot get in without a reservation because they only let so many people in at a time. There is no photography. I am not an art person but when I laid my eyes on Napoleon's sister, I was speechless. I could not believe that Antonio Canova created Pauline Bonaparte as Venus by hand. Don't forget about the gardens either.

Maybe the best in Rome. Reservations only, for a 2 hour visit, so book ahead. 2 hours is plenty of time. We visited during the Caravaggio/Bacon exhibition, which was an added treat for us because the chance to gaze at Caravaggio's work was one of our reasons to visit Rome. Each room is magical and full of guidebook attractions and hidden surprises. Take time to look at the ceilings and floors for unbelievable artwork and design. The walls are thick, so the spaces in the archways of doors are filled with small vignettes that most people never notice. Sumptuous is too short a word to describe what you see.You are allowed up close and personal for all the statuary, and at any space it is stunning. I was especially knocked out by Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. Does marble have motion? Is it pliable and soft to the touch? You will believe it when you see this masterwork. We visited on a sunny day, and the light shining on the statue passed right through the leaves above Daphne, glimmering with a translucent glow. Stunning.We visited 5 museums during our visit, including the Vatican. This one had the most surprises, and because you are allowed time to stand and gaze and absorb the surroundings and each individual work without overcrowding, the appreciation for what you experience stays with you.

Wonderful museum in Rome- Galleria Borghese. Beautiful museum in a park location, lemon and orange trees everywhere. Sculptures by Bernini are exquisite. Must have reservations to visit. Highly recommend the Roma Pass to receive free admission to first two museums visited (and discounts to all others) and unlimited bus and subway transportation.

Oh, holy Bernini!!!. This is an absolute must-do for and art lover's visit to Rome, I ain't foolin'! Set in the beautiful former palace grounds of the uber-swanky Borghese Clan and easily reached via Rome's extensive bus system, the Galleria Borghese holds masterworks by many of Europe's best artists from the baroque period. Most notably Gian Lorenzo Bernini and Michelangelo Merisi/Caravaggio, who happned to compete at the highest levels of art making for fame and fortune in their time. Bernini seemingly conquering all challenges in sculpture and architecture up to a point... and Caravaggio unquestionably mastering painting, if not his personal life... but I digress!Make time for this visit! I would not bother with any less than 2.5 hours here (spent that on the first floor alone, where the major sculptures are) 4 hours would be perfect. Three main sculptures by Bernini housed here: his revolutionary David-ready to launch his stone at Goliath, Pluto and Proserpina-in all its muscle and flesh glory, and as a counterpoint Apollo & Daphne-exquisite sensuality, movement and metamorphosis! (You may want to pre-brief any 14-18 yr olds before the visit to supress nervous giggles ;) Here too you will see Caravaggio's curious Madonna of the Palafrenieri-with young Jesus samping out the serpent, and the somewhat less than celabratory David with the Head of Goliath-supposedly painted his own head as Goliath, hmmm... My only complaint.. NO Photographs!?! further info at http://www.galleriaborghese.itEnjoy!

[--] to Do Before You Die: Galleria Borghese. My first “To do” takes us to the Galleria Borghese in Rome. The art gallery is inside the former Villa Borghese Pinciana, which is located in a lovely park on the outskirts of Rome. The villa was primarily used by Cardinal Scipione Borghese to house his art collection. Galleria Borghese’s collection started from Scipione Borghese’s own private collection, which is why it is fairly small and why the pieces are in such good condition.Read the rest of this blog at http://travelverse.wordpress.com/

Very RUDE staff, avoid bag check. Summary: very rude staff with poor attitude. very unsafe bag check area, zero security. no mention of no bag and camera before you buy your ticket. no refund or exchange after you are not agreed to leave your bag behind.I am sure most people agree there are some great scultures and paintings in the Gallery and it is a must see. No doubt about it but I got a really bad experience with their staff. We got the ticket, the lady was just doing a routine job, no eye contact, no smile, just print us the ticket, that's fine. We were told to head to the bag check counter because no bag is allowed inside. We headed there and I felt unsafe to leave my bag with my $3000 camera and lens with them because it looks like they are just putting all the bags behind a room or something behind the counter and no locks, they just give you a number like coat check. I expressed my concern in a normal tone and the staff just said it's safe, it's safe. I asked who is going to be responsible for any lost or damage, they said it's them (pointing at himself). I asked who is going to insure them (the staff), they said the whole gallery. Then they started to raise the voice and this is exactly the guy said twice "it's safe, it's safe. I don't care if you want to leave your bag here or not, I don't care." Then he walked away from the counter towards the cafe or something while yelling and not looking at me either. So now the counter which they claim is safe has no staff standing. I can easily walk in there and take whatever I want and leave, there is absolutely zero security and this is exactly I was worried. I ended up letting my friends going to the gallery first and waited them to come back and watch for my bag when they are done so I can go up an quickly see what's interesting.While waiting, I realized the ticket says it's only valid for 2 hours. So kindly asked the ticket staff if I could have a time slot change. Without looking at me at all and she said "I cannot change it, there is no change or refund on your ticket" and then point at a piece of paper. "You should leave your bag there and go". Again no eye contact, no smile but at least she was not yelling. I said that is fine.I don't want to waste my time to tell them there is no mention of no bag or camera before I commit to buy the ticket as I notice it seems no one can do anything. There is only one simple rule for them in their mind, no bag in the gallery. If I have known this ahead of time, I would not buy my ticket.I went to several other galleries, and churches and in general, the other staff or security were fine and sometimes nice.

A Must!. The gallery and the park are a must when visiting Rome. The park is beautiful and you can spend hours walking and taking in a beautiful setting. The Borghese Gallery is exciting and full of history. They only allow you to visit 2 hours and then they empty the museum. When we were there the museum was sold out so do as we did and get advanced tickets. I guarantee you that you will not see everything there is to see in 2 hours and you will want to return to get it all.

The Best Rome Has to Offer. I agree with every word the previous reviewer writes; the Borghese is gorgeous, a feast for the eyes and for the senses. The Berninis are awe inspiring and the general lushness of the museum is intoxicating. It's worth every euro - more so than anything else we spent money on in Rome. Don't miss it and don't forget to make your reservation in advance.

single greatest museum on face of earth.. yes, i am not kidding. i admit it might be more fair to ammend this to 'the single greatest small museum on face of earth', but i would rather not. indeed, i refuse to amend in any way at all. rome is a miraculous and glorious city, but go to all your vaticans and forums only after you make sure this is in your plans first. bernini is every bit the sculptor michelangelo is and half of his masterpieces are here! there are quite a few caravaggios here as well. caravaggio was a very good painter, slightly more gifted than (insert name of any painter in the history of humankind here). the interior decorating is quite as good as any of the glorious roman churches, but a touch more fun and homey. really, i'm beside myself, i turn to myself and say "self, are you okay?" "yes." i reply." i just really really like this museum." sometimes on all these review sites we forget that taste and evaluation is subjective. i may love one thing and someone may find it horrible and ugly. i can live with this. but not when it applies to the galleria borghese because those who differ with me will be wrong. if you go here and do not like it you will need to look into your heart, listen to your soul, because an awakening is due. you will enjoy this awakening. thank you. good night.
worth a visit. even if art and sculpture are not high on your interest list this museum is worth seeing. great to walk around for 90-100 minutes and then go to the park or zoo which are right there

Great place. Beautiful works of art. Very nice, quiet setting. Even though we'd just finished a week touring Venice, Florence and Rome and seeing historical pieces of art until we didn't think we could stand any more, we thoroughly enjoyed this gallery. The volume of pieces wasn't as overwhelming of some sites. The quality of the works was excellent. We found the audio guide to be well worth the value here. If you bring your own headphones and a y-splitter, you can both listen to one audio guide.The Bernini works here are worth the price of admission. I particularly love the Apollo and Daphne piece. Wow.Our hotel was able to make the reservation for us and the admission price was included in our Roma Pass. We had a nice long walk in the gardens/park afterward. I might suggest a good map though, as it's a large park and somewhat challenging to find your way through.

Good art, horrible attitude. The art was nice, specifically a couple of sculptures that really are masterpieces. However, to see the art you have to deal with the attitude of those that work there. From issues to paying for the tickets, to a bag that we checked (all bags must be checked, which I don't have a problem with as it makes alot of sense) that we weren't given a claim ticket for as they just weren't handing them out and then were told it was impossible to not have a claim ticket for, to the guy taking tickets being very rude when asking us to please wait outside instead of inside the vestibule with the shade for our time (which wasn't obvious as the door was wide open), the attitude of those that work at this gallery was unmatched by any of the 15+ museums and galleries that we've been to in Italy in the past 2 weeks.Definitely would not go back and wish we hadn't been in the first place. Honestly, there are plenty of other places to see art (especially if your trip includes Florence or Venice, or possibly other cities in Italy which we didn't make it to on this trip) that you don't need to put up with the attitude of this gallery.

A must for art lovers.. We booked the Galleria Borghese in advance as we realised that they only let people in at timed intervals. We opted for the 3-5 slot and getting there at 3 it was busy but bearable. Two hours was about right as by 5pm we had seen all we wanted to see. There are some amazing works on display here in particular the Caravaggios were a must see for me. The spaces were very light and a perfect setting for the artwork. A very worthwhile experience! Also don't forgot to use your Roma Pass if you have one as we got money off here too.

A must visit while in Rome. If you're in Rome doing any sightseeing, this should be your second stop after the Colosseum. The paintings and sculptures here were amazing. Just know that you need to reserve ahead of time because they only allow a certain number of people in at a time. They have audio tours but we got a guided tour in English (I think only available during the first entrance time at 9am). Do yourself a favor and go there.

You have to know what you are looking at. I was a bit disappointed by the Borghese Gallery, probably due to my own lack of knowlegde. I'm sure I was looking at some very famous scultures and paintings, but to my untrained eye it was mainly ordinary-looking scultpures and a load of old paintings. Nothing jumped out at me with a 'wow' factor, which I thought would have happened despite not knowing the details.Downgraded from a neutral score because of the ritual to get in. Booked in advance, then you have to collect your tickets on the day more than 30 minutes before your 2 hour time slot, which means 2 visits here in one day (better ways to spend limited holiday time than collecting tickets).On the 2 hour timeslots: 3 till 5 means you can arrive after 3pm (I thought you had to be there for 3), people are let inside in 30 minute intervals, and all out by 5pm. Once inside, I needed about 45 minutes to see everything. 360 people are admitted in each 2 hours slot, it would comfortably hold more than that so the cynic in me thinks they are creating a shortage to make it more well-known.

Number one in Rome for us. The Borghese Gallery is simply amazing. You have space (especially if you go round backwards - as everyone is let in together try turning away from the crowds) and the most stunning sculpture in Italy. The Bernini done when he was a child is incredible. The Vatican Museum is my next best museum but oh, the crowds. This is really special.We actually would have liked longer and used the audio guide and guide book avidly. Even the 6 year old was riveted. I felt that we rushed the paintings and next time am going to book two separate visits so that we can start with the paintings the second time.It is a bit of a trek off the main routes. Bus or taxi a good idea and be early. They let your booking go otherwise. Just do not miss it. Pony ride in the gardens went down well afterwards too.

Worth every penny. The Bernini's are magnificent.. Tickets: The advanced ticket buying process is a pain in the rear, but I understand why they do it. When I was in the Galleria, I appreciated the fact that the museum limits how many people can enter and how long each person can stay. It was so much better than most of the other places we went, because we didn't have to deal with huge, noisy crowds.Museum: The entire building seems to be decorated. It is as though each surface is covered in detailed ornamentation. I had seen many photos before visiting, but I could not fully fathom just how ornately decorated each wall, ceiling and floor truly is. You only visit two floors. There are a few key artworks on the second floor, but not that many. I suggest quickly passing through the second floor and saving most of your time for the Bernini sculptures, celing frescos, and Caravaggio paintings. Art: Amazing! Amazing! Amazing! I just cannot stress this enough. The Bernini's are incredible and so much more magnificent in person. The Caravaggio paintings are more colorful in person. The ceiling frescos-well, let's just say that it is easy to understand why a couple of them are so important in the grand scheme of the art world. One of them directly quotes Michelangelo's color usage in a really obvious way. Just amazing.Food/Drink/A Place to Sit: There is a moderately priced cafe. However, expect to pay extra and to wait a long time if you want a seat. You can stand and drink at the bar, like most places in Europe, but know that there really is no where to sit in the entire museum, except for the cafe and a bench or two in the hallway.Gift Shop: Limited selection of items, many of which are lame or just not entirely relevant to the collection you just saw.Tip: There is a Metro station closer to the Galleria Borghese, just outside the grounds, across the street. It is within maybe three or four blocks or 3/4 of a mile from the Galleria.

One of the Most Amazing places in the City. Hidden in one of the largest parks in the City, the Galleria Borghese is a must for anyone who is passionate about art. They have all the big names of the Baroque housed in the collection, Bernini, Carravaggio, and more.Bernini's name is all over the city, from St. Peter's Church and Square, to Piazza Navona to many other churches, squares, and fountains. The statues he created for Card. Borghese are hard to put in words---amazing to say the least. During low season it is easier to get in without reservations, but in the summer reservations are a must. There are 3 2-hour slots to get in, and you are only allowed 2 hours to see the collections.In my opinion, this is th #2 museum that you should see in the city, after the Vatican Museums. (Other museums cannot stand up to the vast collection of the Vatican).

A very good museum to see gorgeous sculpture. You have to go downstairs through the center door and there was an absolutely chaotic line. We then had to go to check our bags at the desk on the other side of the room. After that, you have to exit and then go upstairs to the museum entrance. We have a 2 hour allotment. It was 2 stores filled with fabulous sculpture and paintings. This is where Pluto & Prosperina, Apollo & Daphne and the Venus statue (with Paolina Borghese) are. Bernini's works are visually stunning and can see the emotions and muscles of the pieces. They also have somewhat of a secret and very clean bathroom in between the first and second floors. We stroll through both floors, sit on the wide salon couches in the upstairs rooms and soak in all the paintings around us. We also head down to the gift shop, buy some postcards as photos are not allowed. The employees are fine but not friendly. We only used up an hour and a half of our 2 hour allotment. After, we stroll through the gardens and walk through Villa Borghese (the bigger park outside of the Galleria) to Via Veneto. The Galleria is located is a very vast park, so be sure to give yourself enough time to get there.

Fantastic roof!!!. We visited here on our first day in Rome. It was a bit of a walk to it from the Metro but we finally found it. Had to wait over an hour to get in as I had not realised there was a time difference between our last country and Rome. Yes I know. Stupid of me.But the wait was worth it. I had booked our time slot over the internet and when we paid for our tickets there I brought the Roma Pass. Our first view walking through the curtains was the roof. Oh so amazing. Then on to all the rest of the Gallery. Fantastic.Recommend a visit. The long walk around the lovely grounds was very nice as well. Funny thing is that there is only a little sign actually telling you where the Gallery is.But we found it and glad we did.Jacquie

Breathtaking!. Based on TripAdvisor reviews, my husband and I booked a guided tour in advance of our trip to Rome, and were so glad that we did. Yes, it's somewhat of a hassle booking ahead, arriving in plenty of time, checking your bags, 2 hour time limit, etc. -- but we still felt it was well worth all the hassle. We're not aficionados of sculpture and weren't familiar with Bernini, but we thought his work was breathtaking and we could've stayed there all day admiring it. (Not that it's a contest, but we preferred Bernini's David to Michaelangelo's.) Plus the Titian and Carravagio paintings were also amazing. Our guide was very knowledgeable and interesting and the 1 1/2 hour tour just flew buy. This truly is a gem and if we ever return to Rome, we'll definitely make a return visit. Not to be missed!

Best art gallery ever!. Having read the revving reviews on Trip Advisor, our group of five decided to go check out the Galleria on our last day in Rome. As the rest have said it so well, Galleria Borghese is an absolute gem, and I would agree with the rest that it is a must-go in Rome! Bernini is truly a master - the sculptures are amazing. You can even see emotion on the faces, accurate anatomy of muscular tension, flowing strokes on dress, all on stone marble.I shall not belabour the necessity of making a reservation before going. I saw people being turned away while I was waiting in line to collect tickets. And check out the map of Villa Borghese before going. The distance is much much more than it seems. The compound is HUGE. I recommend taking buses there. There is a bus stop just outside the nearest gate to the Galleria and there is at least 1 bus that goes there from Termini.

Do not miss! Sculpture at its best.. Mrs. Geek and I visited this gallery earlier this week and it was the highlight of our trip to Rome and Florence. We are interested in sculpture and eager to see the Bernini pieces -- we were not disappointed. There are also some great paintings on the upper floor.As others have mentioned, reservations are strictly required, absolutely no bags can be taken in, and visits are for 2 hours only.The gallery is also hard to find in the Villa Borghese park, and a fair walk from the nearest metro station, so plan accordingly.I usually avoid gift shops, but this one is worth a look if you want mementos of your visit. We saw some interesting books and trinkets, but they appeared expensive so we thought we would shop around. We ended up missing out because we could not find some of the things, particularly Bernini-related trinkets (e.g., fridge magnets, figurines), at other locations

Love This Museum!. This museum is just a treasure. I saw it in 1978 and was dazzled by it then. I had the pleasure of revisiting it in 2006 and it was just as wonderful. It has my all time favorite sculpture in the world - Bernini's Apollo and Daphne. It is simply dazzling. I was traveling with my husband and a friend and had been gushing about this sculpture for months. I am pleased to say that they were both equally blown away by it when they saw it in person.You must make reservations in advance to visit this museum or else you will not get in. As much of a pain as that is, it pays off with manageable crowds so that you can actually enjoy the stunning artwork. The grounds are also wonderful and it makes for a wonderful day in Rome to visit the museum and stroll the park. We actually walked from the museum to the top of the Spanish Steps on a really lovely day in May.Highly recommended.

Underrated and worth your time. After 68 days through almost all of Europe, with many, many churches, museums, buildings - this by far was my favorite museum/gallery. The stone work looks like the people were frozen in time. Make a reservation and go.

Home of Bernini's "Apollo and Daphne", among other masterpieces. To avoid an unpleasant experience you must know:* Viewing times are in 2-hour slots, strict policy * Bring a map so you can find it in the Borghese Park * All cameras and bags are checked * NO PHOTOGRAPHY ALLOWED *Let me say that I enjoyed this jewel of a museum more than the Vatican (yes!!! actually!!!). It is small so you will not lose your bearings. Not only is the artwork, paintings, and sculptures breathtaking, the architecture of the building is astounding. There are beautiful murals and frescos that adorn the ceilings, so don't forget to look up! There are ancient mosaics of Roman soldiers on the floor. The Bernini sculptures will take your breath away, especially "Apollo and Daphne." Do yourself a favor and do some research on Roman mythology before you go. Or just go on a tour if you're lazy.

Galleria Borghese. Certainly one of the must sees in Rome. In January 2008 we were extremely fortunate to see an extended Canova exhibitiion with works from Firenze, Met in NY, Leeds etc. The Berninis are breathtaking. Ensure you book, understand that there is a 2 hour time slot and that bags, coats must be checked. No photography. Walk through the Metro underground from the Spanish Steps underground if the weather is inclement. If time, or if waiting, the other museums are also worth visiting. The restaurant (different building),does a nice buffet lunch or something more simple. Easy to spend half a day or more here including your visit to the Galleria.

Not to be missed. As many of the other posts have indicated this is a piece of Rome not to be missed, the building is wonderful and the art is outstanding. For periods during the next eight years they are featuring specific artists. This year (through early February 2008) it is the sculptor Canova with the centerpiece being his daring portrait of Paolina Borghese. The admission fee is 12.50Euros including the mandatory fee for the Canova exhibit.We went this week and signed up for a guided tour (5Euro) which lasts about one hour and twenty minutes and offers a different perspective than the regular audio guides (also 5Euro). I plan on going back and using the audio guides to take advantage of both perspectives.Caveats: (1) The gallery is not handicapped or even mildly disabled friendly. Apart from the steps down into the basement for the tickets, in order to get to the second floor of the gallery one has to climb many stairs (I didn't count them but I would guess there are around 50 or 70 steps). Apparently the lift is not strictly a visitor lift, not being insured for such use, and is currently broken.(2) There is a cafe in the basement which serves pretty decent coffee but think before sitting down. A cafe latte' is 1.80Euro standing at the bar and 3.50Euro at a table.(3) All bags (including purses), cameras, strollers, etc must be checked and its pretty chaotic for both checking and retrieving one's bags, expect a 15 to 20 minute wait immediately after a 2 hour viewing block. One person complained about the lack of signs from Spagna. If you're in that neighborhood consider taking the 116 Electric Bus to Porta Pinciana and then walking. Alternatively, go into the Spagna Metro station (don't go down to the trains) and follow the signs for Via Veneto. There is an underground walkway/gallery/shops that takes one to the top of Via Veneto exiting next to Harry's Bar at Porta Pinciana, turn left on Via Veneto, go through the Porta in the city wall, cross Coros d'Italia (busy Road) and its a 10 minute walk along the traffic free avenue to the Galleria. If one is coming from Termini, take the number 910 bus, it drops you off right at the park entrance by the Galleria. Ask the driver for the stop (they are usually accommodating but don't expect a conversation).

A must see for all Caravaggio and Bernini lovers. This is without a doubt one of the top art galleries in Rome. While it is not a big place like the Uffizi in Florence, the quality of the collection more than makes up for it. Apart from the stunning sculptures by Bernini, including "Apollo and Daphne", "David", "Aeneas, Anchises & Ascanius" and "Rape of Proserpine", each room are decorated with magnificant paintings. Don't miss the Gladiator Mosaic. If you have seen a TV documentary on Gladiators then you will recognise many of the scenes depicted.There are also many of the most famous works by Caravaggio. Not to mention Titian's "Sacred and Profane Love".They are as some reviewer said, very strict with visiting hours. The upside of that is the quality of the experience is guaranteed to be unspoilt by large tour groups and crowds.

Great sculptures by Bernini. I am not an art lover althought really enjoyed my brief visit at the Borghese Museum and I liked Bernini's work and the sculpture of Napolean's sister.
