We had a 2 hour slot but it was more than adequate and we got bored after a while as it all began to look the same. I prefer the sculptures to the painting upstairs but it's a personal preference. The only downside was not being able to take photographs. I made the mistake of not reading up about the sculptures before I went and since I have got back i've done some reading and it far more interesting once know what you are looking at. It may seem like common sense but I would advise checking out their website properly before you go. [-]

A must-see for the art lover. The Borghese Museum is small but definitely world-class and a must-see attraction when you're in Rome. The only downside is that you have to make reservations and you only have a 2 hour timeslot. Photographs are not allowed which is also a disappointment since the scultrures are truly outstanding. There is a small giftshop in the comparatively modern basement and the surrounding park is a nice place to stroll and relax.

Awesome Sculpture Collection. We absolutely loved our visit to Borghese Gallery. Yes, they restrict you to 2 hours. But for savvy travelers who do their research and make reservations well in advance (at least one month) this is not a problem. We simply showed up at our time, collected our tickets, dropped our bags at the mandatory bag check and had 2 full hours to soak up the incredible Bernini detail.The sculptures are amazing. My personal favorites: "Apollo and Daphne" and "The Rape of Persephone". They are just exquisite. I would definitely rate Borghese Gallery as a "Do NOT Miss!!" for Rome.I do agree with the previous reviewer that Rome in general can be hard to navigate because signage is terrible! The best advice I have: arm yourself with a good map and just ask locals where sites are. They're used to tourists and will usually help (even if it is grudgingly.)

Not visitor friendly. I was very excited to visit this attraction, as I had heard lots of good things about it. Sadly on the day, my visit was spoiled by the unfriendly vistor restrictions. Let me explain: You are only allowed to visit in two hour time slots 9 - 11; 11 - 1; 1 - 3 etc. We happened to arrive just before noon, unaware of the time factor. When we purchased tickets we were given the option to return at 1pm, or enter immediately but only get one hour in there. We were advised that a 30 minute video guide (on an Ipod) was available, and that would lead us to all the highlights. It's a small buliding anyway, so we decided to go ahead and do this. Inside there are some stunning rooms that contain some equally stunning art. The Bernini sculptures are gorgeous, and the video guide did a great job of enlightening us on them. I was keeping one eye on my watch as I knew we only had until 1pm, or so I thought! At 12:50, an announcement was made that the session was over, and to please leave. I took that to be a nudge that you had only ten minutes left, but it was not a nudge - it was an order! A very gruff man came over and basically told us that our time was up, and motioned us to leave. I said it was only 12:50, but he didn't care, and said we had to exit. I was very very annoyed at this. Not only do they have these ridiculous restrictions, but then you are cut short aswell! That extra ten minutes was probably all we needed to see the final couple of rooms, but we were denied the chance. The irony is that it's a small gallery, and two hours would be more than enough for all but the most hardened art fan. The two hour timeslots are simply not necesessary. They should allow people to come and go at will, as 99% of other galleries and museums worldwide do!!!! I had the impression that they view the visitors as an annoyance. There was no welcoming atnmosphere in this place, which is a shame, as the art was gorgeous. One other thing to mention that spolied it too was the walk from the station. When you exit Spagna station there are one or two signs to direct you, but not enough to stop you getting lost. Rome as a whole could do with a better attitude to tourists. I didn't find the cities sites all that easy to navigate, which was a shame.

Did not live up to expectations!. Having read all the reviews on this particular attraction, my expectations were very high, and made this prime spot on my list of things to do in Rome. After dodging the beggars in the park, then enduring the requirement to pre-book and wait for a time slot, plus queuing to deposit all the forbidden items (compulsory to deposit every kind of bag, purse, camera, video camera, umbrella etc), finally gained entrance to the museum. I like art and sculpture as much as anybody, but I must confess I did not get the wow factor that all the other reveiwers felt, and wonder if I missed something on the way round. Yes there were some very good sculptures by Bernini and grand master paintings; the ceilings were very ornate with decoration more vignette than verrio. There were very good room information cards in many languages in all the rooms, and an audio tour available too. But I found the rooms and the exhibits to be too constructed and repetitve after a while, and this is perhaps where my enthusiasm wandered, and was not returned by visiting the upstairs gallery. This was again (although I hate to say it) was a bit too "studio" and "from the school of.." for my liking. I must admit (again in contradiction of the earlier reviewers), I found the Vatican museum art and sculptures a better option. But as anything in life, you have to go and see for yourself to make your mind up, give an opinion, so do not let my review deter you to visit - either you will be pleasantly surprised and disagree with me, or nod sagely and say - I see what he meant. As Lord Bryon said - "A drop of ink may make a million think."

A Gem. This was the highlight of my trip to Rome. Our hotel was just across the road from the Borghese Gardens but I was aware of the Gallery and had prebooked our space prior to arriving.As with the previous reviewer I would HIGHLY recommend the guided tour rather than the audio tour - it literally cost's Euro 5 for an hour and half tour. Our guide was a lovely, lovely lady and SO knowledgable but in a very friendly and informal manner but she really knew her stuff. She went into the history of the Borghese family and the beautiful building as well as the actual works of art and sculpture. Without doubt the Bernini sculptures were the highlight of the tour - our guide explained the thought and process behind each piece and brought us all around each piece and let us touch them and really brought them to life for us. But there are amazing Titian and Carravaggio paintings also. We had been to the Vatican the previous day and had also gotten a guided tour, but the Vatican museum and Sistine Palace are so big and there is SO much art there its rather overwhelming. This is like visiting someone's house with great art and would recommend it as a must-see / do on anyone's trip to Rome and not just for art - buff's so to speak.

Most underrated attraction in Rome. The Borghese Gallery is the most underrated attraction in Rome. It does not get enough accolades, this museum was marvelous!! MUCH smaller then the Vatican Museum, the viewing much more personal, the artwork much more accessible. The crowd here was pleasant compared to the madhouse that is the Vatican Museum. And Bernini's work, just unbelievable to see.We almost skipped the Borghese Gallery but I'm glad we visited. The entire Borghese Village is an excellent change of pace from the rest of Rome. Like stepping into a garden after being cooped up in Times Square. Very nice, very relaxing, perfect for the last day of your vacation in Rome.

Bernini Bonanza. Highly recommended, if only for the spectacular Bernini sculptures.Suggestions:Make internet reservations a month or so in advance. Plus, book for the first flight, at 9 am. (Have to show at 8.30 for tickets.) Advantage was that was the least crowded time, a real plus for Rome, which was distressingly crowded with tourists.Take the guided, rather than the audio tour, which is the same price. We had a delightful older docent who taught us a lot.After your two-hour session (they do chase you out), stroll across the Villa Borghese to the Etruscan Museum. That was an unexpected treat for us. Highlight was a stunning jewelry collection, plus the "Sposa" sarcophagus. (Have to look for the latter--it's a bit hidden because of renovations).

What museaum were those guys looking at??. My wife and i just spent our 2 hours at the Borghese Gallery in late May. The exhibition of Raphael was there with more than 50 of the masters works on display---the was a Bernini staue at every turn. Caravagio's line the walls like studio prints. I have toured the greatest art houses in europe and never have I been so overwhelmed by a collection. The depth and variety of the gallery is without equal. I rank this as one of the best I've ever seen, second only to the Vatican and the Louvre. GO!! Enjoy!! My only disappointment was the short time allowed for the visit. I could have spent the day easiy.

Ummm....I didn't get it.. Hello,I visited the Borghese Gallery during my stay in Rome on April 28th. Don't get me wrong I am a big fan of Bernini's work as well, but I didn't find this museum all that great or amazing. I did however enjoy being away from the hustle and bustle of the Colosseum and Roman Forum. I found the paint gallery on the 2nd floor to be very quaint and interesting, but the sculpture section on the 1st floor is waaaaay overated. It didn't wow me like the capitoline museum did. Base on the previous reviews (not meaning to disrepect their opinions) I was a little disappointed. My only input is if you can't make it to this museum make sure you make it to the capitoline museam which to me is much better and closer to all of the other main attractions. On a positive note, I think I was expecting a little too much from the Borghese!

You will be glad you saw this!. We took our college aged children to the museum and all of us loved it for it's amazing collection and for the beautiful site. This is definitely a highlight to any visit to Rome. The audio guide was excellent- one of the best audio guides I've used in any museum.! This gallery is not to be missed! Look at their website if you have any doubts and then go see it for yourself! You won't be sorry.

Transfers /Tour to Civitaveccha Ships: Rome Tour in Bestlimosinrome.com. Borghese Gallery was selected thanks to our limousine service that met us early in the morning at Fiumicino air-port. He drove us with a Mercedes van Viano model 2005 to museum for 09:15am for a private Tour. It lasted less than 90 minutes which we enjoyed every 'second'.I want to thank JJ of Bestlimosinrome for driving us to such a splendid museum with great art by Bernini(1598-1680). Even if you do not appreciate museums too much this one will change your view...........

Our favorite sight. Don't miss this museum. It was our favorite site in all of Rome. The artwork was amazing, but we appreciated it so much more because we opted for the human tourguide (I've heard its much better than the audioguide.) Our guide did an incredible job of helping us to understand what we were looking at, why it was important in history, told us little rarely known secrets about the art, and gave us a much better appreciation for it all, which made it all much more interesting. We fell in love with Bernini's marble statues, and recognized them afterwards all over Rome. My only regret is we couldn't take pictures inside. Reservations required, plan to spend the full 2 hours there.

Amazing Place!. What a beautiful place! We had a private guide who did an amazing job of bringing the artwork to life..and what artwork! I have a new found appreciation for Bernini and his rendering of marble. Just keep in mind that you must make an appointment just to get into the gallery (which can be made online) and then you have two hours to be indoors. Afterwards they will announce and shoo you out so that the next "group" can enter. The gardens you can wander through for as long as you please. It's a worthwhile visit.

Fascinating Inside the Museum. Very cool place. We spent about an hour here, but if your really into art, thn I'd plan for about 8 hours. They say you have to make reservations, which I did, but when we got there we did not need them and people were just walking right in. Once you buy tickets, there is an area where you can rent an audio-guide or a regular tour guide. I would opt for the tour-guide. The audio was informative, but very very dry. And if you plan on walking there from the hotel, it's a very enjoyable workout, but it will take about an hour from the Spanish Steps to get there being the park it's in is huge.

A little bit of heaven. Villa Borghese was an absolutely pleasant surprise. It was small but it is certainly the one gallery we are recommending not to miss. If you only have a short time in Rome and don't want to spend hours in a museum, this is the place to go. The sculptures are magnificent and made us fall in love with Bernini. Spectacular!

Great Gallery - terrible little cafe. The Galleria Borghese is so outstanding. You just want to cry when they make you leave.If you can, have food before or after you arrive. The panini, as with almost all Italy food shops, are dry and boring.

Wonderful collection-and a tip that paid off on our visit.. We visited the Gallery two weeks ago. It's an incredible collection housed in a beautiful place. Following the advice of one of our guidebooks (I think Rick Steves) we went to the Pinoteca (painting gallery) upstairs first, while most of the crowds went through the sculpture gallery. When we went downstairs to view the sculpture, we found we had most of the galleries to ourselves! A real treat to be able to examine the Berninis and others from all angles.

Spectacular. Make reservations days ahead. (We made them on the internet before we left the US.) You will need reservations. It is worth the trip. You are only allowed to enter within your 2-hour time slot. Paying for the guided tour is worth it, as the history makes the art, sculptures, and building even more interesting. Even non-art lovers will like this.

Spectacular collection of paintings and sculpture. A must for art fans. Make a reservation over the internet (you don't pay until you show up). They limit you to 2 hours, really not enough. There are only titles, so take the tour (I did) or get the audioguide. Even with the limited reservations it was crowded, they also had school groups. I went 11-1, it looked like the 1:00 group was smaller. But the sculpture collection in particular is unparalled.

Better than remembered!. We have just returned from a two week trip to Sicily and Umbria finishing up in Rome for 2 days. It had been 30 years since we last visited, and it was better than remembered, particularly the Borghese Gallery where the Bernini sculptures are. It is hard to believe the textures and emotions that Bernine got from marble. I had a hard time stopping myself from wanting to touch them.We made our reservations on the internet - walked to the ticket office and were smilingly given out tickets which are issued for two hour slots to control the crowds. I would strongly advise taking the 9:00 A.M. slot for best viewing of the amazing frescos as well as the sculptures. Bon Voyage.
